en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary (Shorthand)
tr: Jonathan Harker's diary
es: I.– FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: (Kept in shorthand.)
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary (Shorthand)
tr: (written in stenography)
es: Bistritz, May 3.

en: 3 May. Bistritz.—Left Munich at 8:35 P. M., on 1st May, arriving at Vienna early next morning; should have arrived at 6:46, but train was an hour late. Buda-Pesth seems a wonderful place, from the glimpse which I got of it from the train and the little I could walk through the streets. I feared to go very far from the station, as we had arrived late and would start as near the correct time as possible. The impression I had was that we were leaving the West and entering the East; the most western of splendid bridges over the Danube, which is here of noble width and depth, took us among the traditions of Turkish rule.
vi: • Bistritz, May 3 Left Munich at 8 PM on May 1st; arrived in Vienna early the next morning. We were supposed to arrive at 6:50, but the train was delayed by an hour. And during the continued journey to Budapest, as imagined from what was witnessed while sitting on the train, and from what was admired in a few streets during a walk when the train temporarily stopped, I found this to be a beautiful city. But because I was very afraid of going too far from the station, as even if we were late, we still had to continue our departure as planned... I had a very clear impression of the journey leaving the West to reach the world of the East. After the train glided over the beautiful bridges with exemplary Western architecture spanning the wide and deep Danube river here, we immediately wandered into a region rich in Turkish customs.
tr: May 3rd. Bistriţa2 - 8 PM on the evening of May 1st. We left Munich at 8:35 and arrived in Vienna early the next morning; we should have arrived at 6:46, but the train was an hour late. From what I could see from the train and the short walk I took in the streets, Budapest looks like a wonderful place. Since we arrived late in Budapest and would be departing as close to the scheduled time as possible, I was afraid to stray too far from the station. I got the impression that we were leaving the West and entering the East; the most Western of the magnificent bridges over the Danube River, with its noble breadth and depth, carried us into the traditions of Turkish rule.
es: I left Munich at 8:35 PM on May 1st, arriving in Vienna early the next morning; I should have arrived at 6:46, but the train was an hour late. Budapest seems like a wonderful place, judging by the little I could see of it from the train and the short walk I took through its streets. I feared straying too far from the station, as we had arrived late and would depart as close to the scheduled time as possible. The impression I had was that we were leaving the West and entering the East. By the most western of the splendid bridges over the Danube, which here is of great width and depth, we reached places once under Turkish rule.

en: We left in pretty good time, and came after nightfall to Klausenburgh. Here I stopped for the night at the Hotel Royale. I had for dinner, or rather supper, a chicken done up some way with red pepper, which was very good but thirsty. (Mem., get recipe for Mina.) I asked the waiter, and he said it was called “paprika hendl,” and that, as it was a national dish, I should be able to get it anywhere along the Carpathians. I found my smattering of German very useful here; indeed, I don’t know how I should be able to get on without it.
vi: Leaving Budapest not too late, we arrived in Klausenburgh by early evening. Here, I had to stay overnight at the Royal Hotel. They served me dinner, or rather a soup, a young chicken cooked with red pepper, quite tasty, but it would definitely make you very thirsty! (I thought about this dish from Mina's perspective). The waiter told me it was paprika hendi, a traditional dish that I could find everywhere in the Carpathian region. My basic knowledge of German proved to be quite useful, because honestly, if I didn't know any, I wouldn't have known how to manage.
tr: We departed with quite good timing and arrived in Klausenburg after nightfall. I spent the night here at the Royale Hotel. For dinner, or rather a late-night dinner, I had chicken cooked with red pepper; it tasted very good but was quite thirst-inducing. (Note: Get the recipe for Mina.) I asked the waiter and he said it was called paprika hendl and that I could find it everywhere in the Carpathian Mountains as it is a local dish. My broken German was very useful here; I really don't know how I would have managed without it.
es: We left with quite good weather, and it was pitch dark when we arrived in Klausenburg, where I spent the night at the Royale hotel. At the meal, or rather, at dinner, I ate chicken prepared with red paprika, which was very tasty but made me very thirsty. (Remember to get the recipe for Mina). I asked the waiter and he told me it was called "paprika hendl," and that, as it was a national dish, it would be very easy for me to get it anywhere in the Carpathians. I found that my limited knowledge of German was very useful there; in fact, I don't know how I would have managed without it.

en: Having had some time at my disposal when in London, I had visited the British Museum, and made search among the books and maps in the library regarding Transylvania; it had struck me that some foreknowledge of the country could hardly fail to have some importance in dealing with a nobleman of that country. I find that the district he named is in the extreme east of the country, just on the borders of three states, Transylvania, Moldavia and Bukovina, in the midst of the Carpathian mountains; one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe. I was not able to light on any map or work giving the exact locality of the Castle Dracula, as there are no maps of this country as yet to compare with our own Ordnance Survey maps; but I found that Bistritz, the post town named by Count Dracula, is a fairly well-known place. I shall enter here some of my notes, as they may refresh my memory when I talk over my travels with Mina.
vi: In London, during my free time, I often went to the British Museum or the National Library to look up geographical maps and books about Transylvania. I found it quite interesting to know a little about this place because I was about to have a business deal with a gentleman there. The land that this gentleman mentioned in his letter to me is located in the eastern part of the country, at the border of three regions: Transylvania, Moldavia, and Bukovina, in the Carpathian Mountains. This is one of the least known and most wild regions of Europe. But no book or map could show me the exact location of the castle named Count Dracula, as there is still no detailed map of this place. However, my research did inform me that Bistritz - the place Count Dracula mentioned to me and where I would have to travel by carriage - is a small, ancient city known to many people. I will recount my unforgettable impressions. That will revive a memory when recalling the excursions with Mina.
tr: When I had some time to myself in London, I visited the British Museum and did some research in the library among books and maps related to Transylvania; I thought that having some preliminary knowledge about the country wouldn't be insignificant when negotiating with a nobleman from that country. I saw that the region it is named after is at the easternmost edge of the country, at the border of Transylvania, Moldavia, and Bukovina, in the middle of the Carpathian Mountains; one of the wildest and least known parts of Europe. I couldn't find a map or study that gave the exact location of Dracula's Castle, as this country didn't have maps comparable to our detailed Ordnance Survey maps; but I saw that the town of Bistriţa, which Count Dracula named, was a fairly well-known place. While talking to Mina about my journey, I will record some of my notes here as they might refresh my memory.
es: Since I had some free time when I was in London, I visited the British Museum and studied the books and maps in the library that referred to Transylvania; it had occurred to me that prior knowledge of the country would always be useful and important when dealing with a nobleman from the region. I discovered that the district he had mentioned was located in the easternmost part of the country, right on the border of three states: Transylvania, Moldavia, and Bukovina, in the center of the Carpathian Mountains; one of the wildest and least known parts of Europe. I could not find any map or work that shed light on the exact location of Dracula's castle, as there are no maps in this country that can compare in accuracy with ours; but I discovered that Bistritz, the post town mentioned by Count Dracula, was a fairly well-known place. I am going to include some of my notes here, as they may refresh my memory when I recount my travels to Mina.

en: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)
vi: There are four races living in Transylvania: in the south are the Saxons living mixed with the Wallachians, who originate from the Dacian ethnicity; in the west are the Magyars; and in the east and north are the Szekelys. I will stay with the Szekelys. It is said that they descend from Attila and are the descendants of the Huns. This might be true because in the twelfth century, when the Magyars conquered the land they now inhabit, the Huns had already settled there. It seems that all the superstitions in the world exist in the Carpathians, and they always stir the imagination of the local people. If this is indeed the case, then my stay in this land will surely be very interesting. (I will certainly always bother the count with questions about these superstitious beliefs).
tr: There are four different nationalities in the population of Transylvania: in the south, the Saxons and the Wallachians, who are mixed with them and descended from the Dacians; in the west, the Hungarians; in the east and north, the Székelys. I am going among the last group, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This claim might be true because when the Hungarians conquered the country in the eleventh century, they found that the Huns had already settled there. I read that all known superstitions in the world seem to gather in the horseshoe formed by the Carpathian Mountains as if it were the center of a fanciful vortex; if so, my visit could be very interesting. (Note: I must ask the Count about all this.)
es: In the population of Transylvania, there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the south, and mixed with them the Vlachs, who are descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the west, and Szeklers in the east and north. I am among the latter, who claim to be descendants of Attila and the Huns. This may be true, since when the Magyars conquered the country in the 11th century, they found the Huns, who had already settled there. I read that all the superstitions known in the world are gathered in the Carpathian horseshoe, as if it were the center of some kind of imaginative vortex; if so, my stay may be very interesting. (Remember to ask the Count about these superstitions).

en: I did not sleep well, though my bed was comfortable enough, for I had all sorts of queer dreams. There was a dog howling all night under my window, which may have had something to do with it; or it may have been the paprika, for I had to drink up all the water in my carafe, and was still thirsty. Towards morning I slept and was wakened by the continuous knocking at my door, so I guess I must have been sleeping soundly then. I had for breakfast more paprika, and a sort of porridge of maize flour which they said was “mamaliga,” and egg-plant stuffed with forcemeat, a very excellent dish, which they call “impletata.” (Mem., get recipe for this also.) I had to hurry breakfast, for the train started a little before eight, or rather it ought to have done so, for after rushing to the station at 7:30 I had to sit in the carriage for more than an hour before we began to move. It seems to me that the further east you go the more unpunctual are the trains. What ought they to be in China?
vi: The first night I couldn't sleep soundly, not because of the unfamiliar house and surroundings, but because I had strange dreams. Throughout the night, I always felt like there was a wolf howling loudly right below my window: was it due to my insomnia or the paprika dish? Because I had drained the water bottle in the room and still had a burning thirst. But eventually, I fell into a deep sleep when it was nearing dawn, as I was awakened by the sound of knocking, and it seemed the person knocking had to do so for a very long time. At breakfast, they served me paprika again, a bit of oatmeal made from cornmeal which they called mamaliga, and a few bowls of stuffed pastries - a delicious dish named impletata. (I noted down the recipe for Mina). I ate hastily, as the train was supposed to depart a few minutes before eight; to be precise, it was supposed to leave at a few minutes to eight, yet after a breathless sprint to the station at seven-thirty, I still had to wait over an hour in the carriage before the train started moving. I have a feeling that the farther east we go, the later the trains run. I wonder how things are in China?
tr: Although my bed was comfortable enough, I couldn't sleep well because I had all sorts of strange dreams. A dog barked under my window all night; maybe my sleeplessness had something to do with that; or maybe it was because of the red pepper since I had to drink all the water in my pitcher but still couldn't quench my thirst. I fell asleep towards morning and woke up to the persistent knocking on my door; at that moment, I think I was in a deep sleep. For breakfast, I ate some more red pepper, a type of porridge made from cornmeal which they said was called mamaliga, and a dish called impletata, which is eggplant stuffed with minced meat and is an excellent meal. (Note: Get the recipe for this as well.) Since the train was supposed to leave a little before eight - or rather it was supposed to leave at 7. 30, I had to rush my breakfast because after running to the station, I had to sit in the carriage for more than an hour before we started moving. It seems to me that as we move further east, the trains get more delayed. Who knows what they are like in China?
es: I did not sleep well, although my bed was sufficiently comfortable, because I had all kinds of strange dreams. Throughout the night a dog howled under my window, which may have had something to do with it; or it may have also been the paprika, since I had to drink all the water from my jug, and I was still thirsty. In the early morning, I fell asleep, but I was awakened by some insistent knocks on my door, so I suppose that at that moment I was sleeping deeply. I ate more bell pepper for breakfast, a kind of porridge made from cornmeal that they say was "mamaliga", and eggplant stuffed with minced meat, an excellent dish they call "impletata" (remember to also get the recipe for this). I hurried to have breakfast, as the train was leaving a little after eight, or rather, it should have left, because after running to the station at seven-thirty, I had to wait sitting in the carriage for more than an hour before we started moving. It seems to me that the further east you go, the less punctual the trains are. What will they be like in China?

en: All day long we seemed to dawdle through a country which was full of beauty of every kind. Sometimes we saw little towns or castles on the top of steep hills such as we see in old missals; sometimes we ran by rivers and streams which seemed from the wide stony margin on each side of them to be subject to great floods. It takes a lot of water, and running strong, to sweep the outside edge of a river clear. At every station there were groups of people, sometimes crowds, and in all sorts of attire. Some of them were just like the peasants at home or those I saw coming through France and Germany, with short jackets and round hats and home-made trousers; but others were very picturesque. The women looked pretty, except when you got near them, but they were very clumsy about the waist. They had all full white sleeves of some kind or other, and most of them had big belts with a lot of strips of something fluttering from them like the dresses in a ballet, but of course there were petticoats under them. The strangest figures we saw were the Slovaks, who were more barbarian than the rest, with their big cow-boy hats, great baggy dirty-white trousers, white linen shirts, and enormous heavy leather belts, nearly a foot wide, all studded over with brass nails. They wore high boots, with their trousers tucked into them, and had long black hair and heavy black moustaches. They are very picturesque, but do not look prepossessing. On the stage they would be set down at once as some old Oriental band of brigands. They are, however, I am told, very harmless and rather wanting in natural self-assertion.
vi: All day long, our train traveled through a beautiful and diverse land. At times, we admired small cities with castles perched precariously on steep hills, reminiscent of scenes described in ancient Biblical texts; at other times, the train ran alongside large and small streams with rocky, winding banks resembling nature's own railings. At the stations where we stopped, every platform was bustling with crowds dressed in vibrant, colorful attire of various kinds. Some people looked very similar to the farmers in our country or in France and Germany: they wore simple mesh shirts with rather wide-cut trousers and round-brimmed hats; but others were dressed in more colorful outfits. The women here seem very healthy and quite beautiful if you don't look at them too closely. They all wear oversized white-sleeved shirts, with leather belts that are always fluttering over their splendid skirts. However, I find the Slovakians to be the most peculiar; they wear wide-brimmed cowboy-style hats, baggy pants in a dull color, white linen shirts, and wide leather belts studded with brass rivets. Particularly, every man likes to tuck his pants into a pair of long boots. Their long black hair and thick beards make them look more distinctive but not at all charming. Honestly, if I were traveling by horse-drawn carriage, I might have mistaken them for a band of highway robbers, although I have been told that they have never done anything bad to anyone; on the contrary, they are always quite cowardly.
tr: Throughout the day, we slowly progressed through a terrain filled with all kinds of beauty. Sometimes, at the tops of steep hills, we saw small villages and castles similar to those we had seen in old prayer books; sometimes, we passed by rivers and streams with wide, stony banks that suggested they had been subjected to great floods. It takes a large amount of strong flowing water to sweep and clean the outer edges of a river. At every train station, there were crowds of people dressed in various kinds of attire, sometimes large gatherings. Some wore short jackets, round hats, and homemade trousers, just like those in our region or those I saw while passing through France and Germany; but others were very interesting. The women looked beautiful unless you got close to them, but their waistlines were quite thick. All of their clothes had white sleeves in one way or another; many wore wide belts with lots of ribbons hanging from them, resembling ballet dresses; but of course, they had underskirts underneath. The strangest people we saw were the Slovaks, who looked more barbaric than the rest with their large cowboy hats, wide, sack-like dirty white trousers, white linen shirts, and enormous, heavy belts almost a foot wide, studded all over with brass nails. They wore high boots into which they tucked their trousers, and they had long black hair and thick black mustaches. They were very impressive but not attractive. They could be placed on stage right now as an old Eastern bandit gang. But as I was told, they were quite harmless and moreover, people who lacked self-defense skills.
es: It seemed that throughout the day we wandered through a country that was full of all kinds of beauties. Sometimes we saw small villages or castles on the tops of steep hills, such as those seen in old missals; sometimes we ran alongside rivers and streams, which, by the wide and stony margins on either side of them, seemed to be subject to great floods. It takes a great amount of water, with a very strong current, to be able to clean the outer bank of a river. At all the stations there were groups of people, sometimes crowds, and in all kinds of attire. Some of them were exactly like the peasants of my country, or those I had seen when crossing France and Germany, with short jackets and round hats and pants made by themselves; but others were very picturesque. The women were pretty, except when one got close to them, for they were quite thick around the waist. They all wore long white sleeves, and most of them had wide belts with a bunch of fringes of something hanging like in ballet dresses, but of course they wore petticoats underneath them. The strangest figures we saw were the Slovaks, who were more barbaric than the rest, with their wide cowboy hats, large baggy and dirty pants, white linen shirts, and huge and heavy leather belts, almost a foot wide, completely studded with tin nails. They wore high boots, with their pants tucked inside them, and had long black hair and heavy black mustaches. They were very picturesque, but they did not seem friendly. In any setting, they would be immediately recognized as some old gang of bandits. However, I am told that they are quite harmless and, moreover, quite shy.

en: It was on the dark side of twilight when we got to Bistritz, which is a very interesting old place. Being practically on the frontier—for the Borgo Pass leads from it into Bukovina—it has had a very stormy existence, and it certainly shows marks of it. Fifty years ago a series of great fires took place, which made terrible havoc on five separate occasions. At the very beginning of the seventeenth century it underwent a siege of three weeks and lost 13,000 people, the casualties of war proper being assisted by famine and disease.
vi: We arrived in Bistritz at midnight. As I mentioned, Bistritz is an ancient city with a unique past. Located near the border - indeed, when leaving Bistritz, just crossing the Borgo Pass leads to Bukovina - this city has experienced numerous ups and downs, many of which are still evident today. Fifty years ago, terrifying fires continuously occurred, flattening everything. At the beginning of the seventeenth century, this city also had to withstand a siege for three weeks, resulting in thirteen thousand deaths, not to mention the victims of famine and disease.
tr: When we arrived in Bistriţa, a very interesting old settlement, it was the dark side of twilight. Since it is almost on the border - as the Borgo Pass starts there and extends to Bukovina - it has quite a stormy nature and definitely bears the traces of it. Fifty years ago, there was a series of major fires that caused terrible damage at five different times. At the very beginning of the seventeenth century, the city was subjected to a siege that lasted three weeks and lost 13,000 people from its population; war-related losses increased due to famine and disease.
es: It was already getting dark when we arrived in Bistritz, which is a very interesting old town. Since it is practically on the border, as the Borgo Pass leads from there to Bucovina, it has had a rather turbulent existence, and you can certainly see the signs of it. Fifty years ago, there were major fires that caused terrible devastation on five different occasions. At the beginning of the 17th century, it endured a three-week siege and lost thirteen thousand people, with casualties from war compounded by those from hunger and disease.

en: Count Dracula had directed me to go to the Golden Krone Hotel, which I found, to my great delight, to be thoroughly old-fashioned, for of course I wanted to see all I could of the ways of the country. I was evidently expected, for when I got near the door I faced a cheery-looking elderly woman in the usual peasant dress—white undergarment with long double apron, front, and back, of coloured stuff fitting almost too tight for modesty. When I came close she bowed and said, “The Herr Englishman?” “Yes,” I said, “Jonathan Harker.” She smiled, and gave some message to an elderly man in white shirt-sleeves, who had followed her to the door. He went, but immediately returned with a letter:—
vi: Count Dracula arranged for me to stay at the Golden Crown Hotel. I was very pleased to see that it was a very ancient house, because after all, I wanted to understand as much as possible about the customs and traditions of this land. Someone was waiting for me at the door: it was a middle-aged woman with a radiant face, dressed in the typical local peasant style. She bowed deeply to greet me and asked: — Are you an Englishman? — Yes, - I replied - I am Jonathan Harker. The woman smiled and said something to a shirtless man standing behind her. The man immediately disappeared but then quickly returned with a letter for me. The letter read as follows:
tr: Count Dracula directed me with great pleasure to the Golden Krone Hotel, which I saw was old-fashioned in every way; because, of course, I wanted to see all the traditions unique to the country. Clearly, I was expected, for as I approached the door, I was met by a cheerful elderly woman in traditional peasant attire - a long white undergarment, with a colorful apron made of fabrics at the front and back that seemed too tight for modesty. As I approached, she greeted me with a nod and said, "English Herr?" "Yes," I said, "Jonathan Harker." She smiled and spoke to an elderly man in a white-sleeved shirt who had followed her to the door. The man left but quickly returned with a letter in hand:
es: Count Dracula had instructed me to go to the Golden Krone Hotel, which, to my great satisfaction, was quite old-fashioned, for of course, I wanted to learn as much as possible about the customs of the country. They were evidently expecting me, for as I approached the door, I found myself facing a woman already advanced in years, with a cheerful face, dressed in peasant fashion: white underwear with a double apron, front and back, of colorful fabric, so tight to the body that it could not be described as modest. When I approached, she bowed and said: –The English gentleman? –Yes -I replied-: Jonathan Harker. She smiled and gave some instructions to an elderly man in a white-sleeved shirt, who had followed her to the door. The man left, but immediately returned with a letter:

en: “My Friend.—Welcome to the Carpathians. I am anxiously expecting you. Sleep well to-night. At three to-morrow the diligence will start for Bukovina; a place on it is kept for you. At the Borgo Pass my carriage will await you and will bring you to me. I trust that your journey from London has been a happy one, and that you will enjoy your stay in my beautiful land.
vi: “Dear friend, Welcome to the Carpathians. I have been eagerly awaiting you. Wish you a good night's sleep tonight. The carriage trip to Bukovina tomorrow afternoon will start at three o'clock, your seat has been reserved. My carriage will be waiting to pick you up at the Borgo Pass. Hope that from London, your journey will be smooth, and you will feel truly comfortable during your days in our beautiful country.
tr: My friend, Welcome to the Carpathian Mountains. I am eagerly awaiting you. Sleep well tonight. Tomorrow at three o'clock, the stagecoach will depart for Bukovina; a seat has been reserved for you. My carriage will wait for you at the Borgo Pass and will bring you to me. I hope your journey from London has been pleasant and that you will enjoy the time you spend in my beautiful lands.
es: "My dear friend: welcome to the Carpathians. I am eagerly awaiting you. Sleep well tonight. Tomorrow at three, the coach for Bucovina will depart; you already have a reserved seat. At the Borgo Pass, my carriage will be waiting for you and will bring you to my house. I hope your journey from London has been smooth, and that you enjoy your stay in my beautiful country.

en: “Your friend,
vi: Warm regards!
tr: Your friend
es: Your friend,

en: “Dracula.”
vi: "Dracula."
tr: DRACULA
es: DRACULA"

en: 4 May.—I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count, directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened sort of way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting.
vi: • May 4 The hotel owner himself also received a letter from the count with a request to reserve the best seat on the carriage for me, but when I asked a few questions, the owner seemed hesitant and used the excuse that he couldn't fully understand the German I spoke; clearly a lie because when I first arrived at the hotel, he understood everything I said. The hotel owner and his wife looked at each other worriedly, then turned to me and stammered that the carriage fare had been sent in advance along with a letter, and they knew nothing more. When I asked about Count Dracula and his castle, both the husband and wife made the sign of the cross and replied that they knew absolutely nothing, then signaled to me that they did not want to talk about it anymore. Since the departure time had arrived, I had no more time to inquire with others. I found the situation very mysterious and unconvincing.
tr: May 4th. - I learned that the hotel owner had received a letter from the Count instructing him to arrange the best seat in the carriage for me; however, when I asked questions about the details, he somehow seemed tight-lipped and acted as if he didn't understand my German. Yet this couldn't be true because until that moment he had perfectly understood my German; at the very least, he was definitely answering my questions as if he understood me. He and his wife, the elderly lady who greeted me, looked at each other with an expression full of fear. The man mumbled that the money was sent within the letter and that this was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula and if he could tell me anything about his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves and refused to speak further, saying they knew nothing. The departure time was so close that I had no time to ask anyone else, for everything was very mysterious and, in any case, not at all reassuring.
es: May 4th. I found out that my innkeeper had received a letter from the count, instructing him to secure the best seat in the coach for me; but when inquiring about the details, he became somewhat reticent and pretended not to understand my German. This could not be true, because until that moment he had understood me perfectly; at least he answered my questions exactly as if he understood them. He and his wife, the elderly woman who had received me, looked at each other with fear. He murmured that the money had been sent to him in a letter, and that was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula and if he could tell me anything about his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves, and saying that they knew nothing at all, they simply refused to say anything more. It was already so close to the time of departure that I didn't have time to ask anyone else, but everything seemed very mysterious to me and in no way reassuring.

en: Just before I was leaving, the old lady came up to my room and said in a very hysterical way:
vi: Just as I was about to set off, the landlady suddenly rushed into the room and asked me in a panicked voice:
tr: Just before leaving, the elderly woman came to my room and, in an extremely distraught manner, said:
es: A few moments before I left, the old woman came up to my room and said, with a nervous voice:

en: “Must you go? Oh! young Herr, must you go?” She was in such an excited state that she seemed to have lost her grip of what German she knew, and mixed it all up with some other language which I did not know at all. I was just able to follow her by asking many questions. When I told her that I must go at once, and that I was engaged on important business, she asked again:
vi: — Are you really planning to go there? Oh! Young man, are you really planning to go there? The woman was so panic-stricken that she stammered for a long time before she could say a few words in German that she knew, mixed with some sounds completely unfamiliar to me. When I replied that I had to leave immediately to attend to an important matter, she asked me again:
tr: “Is it necessary for you to leave? Ah! Young Herr, is it necessary for you to leave?” He was so excited that he seemed to have lost his command of German and mixed it with another language I did not know. I could only understand him by asking a lot of questions. When I told him that I needed to leave as soon as possible and that I was busy with an important task, he asked once more:
es: –Do you have to go? Oh! Young sir, do you have to go? He was in such a state of excitement that he seemed to have lost the little German he knew, and mixed it all with another language from which I did not understand a single word. I barely understood anything by asking him numerous questions. When I told him that I had to leave immediately, and that I was engaged in important business, he asked again:

en: “Do you know what day it is?” I answered that it was the fourth of May. She shook her head as she said again:
vi: — Do you know what day it is today? I replied on May 4th.
tr: "Do you know what today is?" I replied that it was the fourth of May. She shook her head from side to side and spoke again:
es: –Do you know what day it is today? I replied that it was the fourth of May. She shook her head and spoke again:

en: “Oh, yes! I know that! I know that, but do you know what day it is?” On my saying that I did not understand, she went on:
vi: — Yes, of course, it's May 4th. But what day is it? When I said I didn't fully understand the question, she then explained:
tr: “Ah, yes! I know him, I know him! But do you know what today is?” When I said I didn't understand, he continued:
es: –Oh, yes! I already know that. I already know that, but do you know what day it is today? When I responded that I didn't understand her, she continued:

en: “It is the eve of St. George’s Day. Do you not know that to-night, when the clock strikes midnight, all the evil things in the world will have full sway? Do you know where you are going, and what you are going to?” She was in such evident distress that I tried to comfort her, but without effect. Finally she went down on her knees and implored me not to go; at least to wait a day or two before starting. It was all very ridiculous but I did not feel comfortable. However, there was business to be done, and I could allow nothing to interfere with it. I therefore tried to raise her up, and said, as gravely as I could, that I thanked her, but my duty was imperative, and that I must go. She then rose and dried her eyes, and taking a crucifix from her neck offered it to me. I did not know what to do, for, as an English Churchman, I have been taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet it seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a state of mind. She saw, I suppose, the doubt in my face, for she put the rosary round my neck, and said, “For your mother’s sake,” and went out of the room. I am writing up this part of the diary whilst I am waiting for the coach, which is, of course, late; and the crucifix is still round my neck. Whether it is the old lady’s fear, or the many ghostly traditions of this place, or the crucifix itself, I do not know, but I am not feeling nearly as easy in my mind as usual. If this book should ever reach Mina before I do, let it bring my good-bye. Here comes the coach!
vi: — Is it the day before Saint George's Day? Could you have forgotten that tonight, exactly at the stroke of midnight, all the charms will rule the earth as absolute lords? Do you not know where you are going and what you are about to face? The woman was so terrified that I tried every way to comfort her, but it was in vain. Finally, she suddenly knelt down and begged me not to go, or if I had to go, to stay for another day or two. This strange behavior made me feel a bit uneasy. But in any case, people were waiting for me at the castle, and nothing could stop me from going there. I helped the hostess up, but no matter what, I still had to set off. The woman stood up, wiped her tears, then took off the cross she wore around her neck and handed it to me. It would be disrespectful to refuse the gift from an elderly woman who wished me well and was genuinely worried for me. The hostess gently placed the cross around my neck and said simply, "For the love of your mother," then left the room. I am writing these diary lines while waiting for the horse-drawn carriage - of course, it is late again - and the cross is still dangling around my neck. Is it fear, dreadful beliefs, or this small cross itself that has tormented that elderly woman? Honestly, I don't know, but surely my feelings about what just happened will be less pleasant than usual. • May 5. At the castle
tr: “Today is the eve of St. George's Day. Don't you know that when the clock strikes midnight tonight, all the evil forces in the world will be free to roam around? Do you know where you are going, what you are going towards?” He was in such a state of obvious anxiety that I tried to comfort him, but it had no effect. Finally, he fell to his knees and begged me not to go, or at least to wait a day or two before setting out. All this was very silly, but I did not feel comfortable. However, there was a job to be done, and I could not allow anything to hinder it. So, I tried to get him to his feet and thanked him as seriously as I could, saying that my duty was inevitable and that I had to go. Upon this, he stood up, wiped his eyes, and took a cross from around his neck and gave it to me. I didn't know what to do because, as someone affiliated with the Anglican Church, I had been taught to see such things as a form of idolatry; but still, it seemed very rude to reject such a well-meaning and kind-hearted old lady. I suppose he saw the indecision on my face because he put the rosary around my neck and said, “For your mother's sake,” and left the room. I am writing this part of the journal, of course, while waiting for the delayed carriage, and the cross is still around my neck. I don't know if it's because of the old woman's fear, but I don't feel as peaceful as I usually do. If this notebook reaches Mina before I do, let it convey my farewell words to her. Here comes the carriage!
es: –It is the eve of St. George's Day. Don't you know that tonight, when the clock strikes midnight, all the demonic things in the world will have full power? Do you know where you are going and what you are going for? She was in such a state of desperation that I tried to calm her, but to no avail. Finally, she fell to her knees and begged me not to go; to at least wait one or two days before leaving. All of this was quite ridiculous, but I did not feel at ease. However, I had a business to attend to and could not allow anything to interfere. Therefore, I tried to lift her up, and told her, as seriously as I could, that I appreciated it, but that my duty was imperative and I had to leave. Then she stood up and dried her eyes, and taking a crucifix from her neck, she offered it to me. I did not know what to do, for as a faithful member of the Anglican Church, I have been accustomed to seeing such things as symbols of idolatry, and yet, it seemed discourteous to refuse it from an old woman with such good intentions and in such a mental state. I suppose she could read the doubt on my face, for she placed the rosary around my neck, and said: "For the love of your mother," and then left the room. I am writing this part of my diary while I wait for the coach, which of course, is delayed; and the crucifix still hangs around my neck. I do not know if it is the old woman's fear or the many ghostly traditions of this place, or the crucifix itself, but the truth is that I do not feel as calm as usual. If this book ever reaches Mina's hands before I do, let it carry my farewell. Here comes my coach!

en: 5 May. The Castle.—The grey of the morning has passed, and the sun is high over the distant horizon, which seems jagged, whether with trees or hills I know not, for it is so far off that big things and little are mixed. I am not sleepy, and, as I am not to be called till I awake, naturally I write till sleep comes. There are many odd things to put down, and, lest who reads them may fancy that I dined too well before I left Bistritz, let me put down my dinner exactly. I dined on what they called “robber steak”—bits of bacon, onion, and beef, seasoned with red pepper, and strung on sticks and roasted over the fire, in the simple style of the London cat’s meat! The wine was Golden Mediasch, which produces a queer sting on the tongue, which is, however, not disagreeable. I had only a couple of glasses of this, and nothing else.
vi: The grayish-blue color of the early morning is gradually fading, giving way to the fresh pink of the sun. The horizon seems to be cut into pieces by clusters of trees or hills or something that I can't quite make out, because all the scenery, big and small, is far away and blends into each other. At this moment, I no longer feel sleepy; tomorrow I will have plenty of free time, I can wake up whenever I want, and I will write until I get sleepy, because I have many strange things to write about. Before leaving Bistritz, I had a satisfying and delicious meal. The hotel served me a dish they called "robber steak" - which is a few pieces of leaf lard mixed with onions, beef, and paprika, all rolled around small sticks and grilled over a fire. I drank a type of golden Mediasch, a kind of wine that can burn your tongue, but to me, it was not unpleasant. However, I could only drink two glasses.
tr: May 5. - The Castle - The grayness of the morning passed and the sun rose on the distant horizon; the horizon presented a jagged appearance with things I couldn't tell if they were trees or hills, because the horizon was so far away that big and small things had merged together. I am not sleepy, and since I won't be called until I wake up, naturally I will write until I get sleepy. There are many strange things to write about, and so that the person reading this doesn't think I had a very nice meal before leaving Bistriţa, let me write exactly what I had for dinner. I ate something called "bandit steak" - bacon, onions, and beef seasoned with red pepper, skewered and roasted over a fire in the simple London cat meat4 style! The wine was Golden Mediasch, which, though not bad on the tongue, left a strange bitterness. I only had a few glasses of it, that's all.
es: May 5th. The castle. The darkness of the morning has passed and the sun is very high above the distant horizon, which seems pursued, I don't know if by trees or by hills, for it is so far away that large and small things blend together. I am not sleepy and, as I will not be called until I wake up on my own, I naturally write until sleep comes. There are many strange things I would like to note, and so that no one reading them can imagine that I dined too well before leaving Bistritz, I will also note exactly my dinner. I had what they call "robbed steak," with slices of bacon, onion, and beef, all seasoned with red pepper skewered on sticks and roasted. In the simple style of London's "cat meat!" The wine was Golden Mediasch, which produces a rare tingling on the tongue, which, however, is not unpleasant. I only drank a couple of glasses of this wine, and nothing more.

en: When I got on the coach the driver had not taken his seat, and I saw him talking with the landlady. They were evidently talking of me, for every now and then they looked at me, and some of the people who were sitting on the bench outside the door—which they call by a name meaning “word-bearer”—came and listened, and then looked at me, most of them pityingly. I could hear a lot of words often repeated, queer words, for there were many nationalities in the crowd; so I quietly got my polyglot dictionary from my bag and looked them out. I must say they were not cheering to me, for amongst them were “Ordog”—Satan, “pokol”—hell, “stregoica”—witch, “vrolok” and “vlkoslak”—both of which mean the same thing, one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is either were-wolf or vampire. (Mem., I must ask the Count about these superstitions)
vi: When I got into the carriage, I saw that the coachman had not yet taken his seat; he was still busy talking to the hotel owner. There was no doubt that they were talking about me, because every now and then they would turn to look at me. The people sitting in the rows near the hotel door also began to stand up and come closer to listen to the two men talking; occasionally, they would turn back to look at me with eyes that held something akin to pity. As for myself, sometimes I could catch a few words from the crowd, but they were all words I didn't understand. Moreover, they spoke in many different languages. Therefore, I had to take out the multilingual dictionary from my travel bag to look up the meanings of all the strange words I had overheard. But to be honest, none of the meanings I found in the dictionary gave me any courage, because I only found words like: Ordog - Satan; Pokol - hell; stregocia - witch; vrolok and vlkoslak - something like "vampire" or "werewolf" according to the meanings in two dialects.
tr: When I got into the carriage, the coachman had not yet taken his place, and I saw him talking with the hotel owner. It was clear that they were talking about me because they occasionally glanced at me, and some of those sitting on the bench outside the door—who were referred to by a word meaning "gossip-mongers"—went over to the two of them, eavesdropped, and then looked at me; many of them looked at me with pity. I frequently heard many strange words being repeated, as there were people of many nationalities in the crowd; so I quietly took out my multilingual dictionary from my bag and looked up those words. I must say that these words did not cheer me up at all, as they included ordog - devil, pokol - Hell, stregoica - witch, vrolok and vlkoslak - words in Slovak and Serbian respectively, meaning something like werewolf or vampire. (Note: I must ask the Count about these superstitions.)
es: When I arrived at the car, the driver had not yet taken his seat, and I saw him talking with the owner of the inn. They were evidently talking about me, as they occasionally turned to look at me, and some of the people who were sitting on the bench outside the door (whom they call by a name that means "Word Bearers") approached and listened, and then looked at me, most of them pitying me. I could hear many words that were often repeated: strange words, as there were many nationalities in the group; so I quietly took out my polyglot dictionary from my pocket, and looked them up. I must admit they brought me no joy, as among them were "Ordog" (Satan), "pokol" (hell), "stregoica" (witch), "vrolok" and "vlkoslak" (which mean the same thing, one in Slovak and the other in Serbian, referring to something that is a werewolf or a vampire). (Note: I must ask the count about these superstitions.)

en: When we started, the crowd round the inn door, which had by this time swelled to a considerable size, all made the sign of the cross and pointed two fingers towards me. With some difficulty I got a fellow-passenger to tell me what they meant; he would not answer at first, but on learning that I was English, he explained that it was a charm or guard against the evil eye. This was not very pleasant for me, just starting for an unknown place to meet an unknown man; but every one seemed so kind-hearted, and so sorrowful, and so sympathetic that I could not but be touched. I shall never forget the last glimpse which I had of the inn-yard and its crowd of picturesque figures, all crossing themselves, as they stood round the wide archway, with its background of rich foliage of oleander and orange trees in green tubs clustered in the centre of the yard. Then our driver, whose wide linen drawers covered the whole front of the box-seat—“gotza” they call them—cracked his big whip over his four small horses, which ran abreast, and we set off on our journey.
vi: When the carriage was about to start moving, the crowd in front of the hotel grew larger and larger, all making the sign of the cross and pointing their index and middle fingers towards me. It was not easy when I asked a fellow traveler about the meaning of those strange gestures: "They want to protect you," he explained, "against evil eyes. " Honestly, once again, I did not feel comfortable before arriving at an unfamiliar place. But on the other hand, I also had to admit a fact that all those people, both men and women, showed a kindness towards me, wanting to share with me the misfortune they believed would happen. And no matter what, I will never forget these touching images. The coachman, wearing wide-legged pants that almost covered the seat he was sitting on, swung his whip above the heads of the four horses already harnessed. We began our journey.
tr: When we set out, the entire crowd gathered at the inn's door, which had grown considerably by that time, made the sign of the cross and raised two fingers towards me. With some difficulty, I managed to get one of the other travelers to explain what they meant; at first, he didn't want to answer my question, but when he learned that I was English, he explained that it was a charm or protection against the evil eye. Just as I was setting out to meet an unknown man in an unknown place, this situation did not please me at all; however, everyone was so kind-hearted, so sorrowful, and so friendly that it was impossible not to be affected. I will never forget the last glimpse of the courtyard of the inn and the crowd of interesting people making the sign of the cross around the wide arched passage, with the lush leaves of oleander and orange trees planted in green barrels behind it. Then, our coachman, whose wide linen trousers - they called them gotza - covered the entire front seat, cracked his huge whip over the four small horses harnessed abreast, and we began our journey.
es: When we departed, the crowd around the inn's door, which by then had grown to a considerable number, all made the sign of the cross and pointed two fingers at me. With some difficulty, I managed to get a fellow passenger to tell me what all this meant; at first, he did not want to answer me, but when he learned that I was English, he explained that it was the charm or spell against the evil eye. This did not please me much either as I was heading to an unknown place with an unknown man; but everyone seemed so kind, so compassionate, and so sympathetic that I couldn't help but feel moved. I will never forget the last glimpse I took of the inn's courtyard and its multitude of picturesque characters, all crossing themselves, as they stood around the wide porch, with its backdrop of rich foliage of oleanders and orange trees in green tubs grouped in the center of the courtyard. Then our driver, whose wide linen trousers covered the entire front seat (they call it "gotza"), cracked his large whip over the four small horses running two by two, and we began our journey...

en: I soon lost sight and recollection of ghostly fears in the beauty of the scene as we drove along, although had I known the language, or rather languages, which my fellow-passengers were speaking, I might not have been able to throw them off so easily. Before us lay a green sloping land full of forests and woods, with here and there steep hills, crowned with clumps of trees or with farmhouses, the blank gable end to the road. There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom—apple, plum, pear, cherry; and as we drove by I could see the green grass under the trees spangled with the fallen petals. In and out amongst these green hills of what they call here the “Mittel Land” ran the road, losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the hillsides like tongues of flame. The road was rugged, but still we seemed to fly over it with a feverish haste. I could not understand then what the haste meant, but the driver was evidently bent on losing no time in reaching Borgo Prund. I was told that this road is in summertime excellent, but that it had not yet been put in order after the winter snows. In this respect it is different from the general run of roads in the Carpathians, for it is an old tradition that they are not to be kept in too good order. Of old the Hospadars would not repair them, lest the Turk should think that they were preparing to bring in foreign troops, and so hasten the war which was always really at loading point.
vi: The beauty of the scenery along the way quickly made me forget my worries and anxieties, but I don't think I could have easily shed all my obsessions if I had understood the whole story of my fellow travelers. In front of us were vast forests, with steep hills occasionally rising on either side of the road, topped with a solitary clump of trees or a sparse farm casting shadows onto the path. Everywhere, trees were in full bloom - apple blossoms, plum blossoms, pear blossoms, and cherry blossoms, all creating a truly magnificent picture; and even the grassy carpets in the orchards we passed through, under the sunlight, were sparkling with fallen petals. Whether winding around or stretching up the hills, the road always seemed like a soft silk fabric lying exposed on the lush green velvet grass, or peeking out from under a forest of pines extending as far as the eye could see, making me feel as if I were lost in a fairyland. However, the farther we went, the worse the road became, but the coachman still urged the horses to run at full speed. This surprised me greatly. It seemed he wanted to reach Borgo Prund as quickly as possible. Before setting off, I was told that the road was excellent, but it clearly hasn't returned to that state after the recent winter snowfalls. This road is unlike the other roads in the Carpathian Mountains: indeed, no one dares to repair it, fearing that doing so would make the Turks mistakenly believe that preparations for an invasion of their country are underway, which would immediately serve as a pretext for them to declare war.
tr: If I had known the language -or rather, the languages- spoken by the other passengers, although I would not have been able to get rid of them so easily, shortly after setting off, my spiritual fears and memories related to them faded away in the beauty of the scenery. In front of us stretched a green sloping terrain filled with forests, adorned here and there with steep hills, crowned with clusters of farmhouses with trees or side walls facing the road. Everywhere, fruit blossoms were blooming with surprising density - apple, plum, pear, cherry; as we moved along the road, I could see that the green grass under the trees was speckled with fallen petals. The road stretched out among the green hills they called "Mittelland" here, disappearing as it extended over grass-covered curves or being blocked by the edges of pine forests as it descended the slopes like tongues of flame spilling out here and there. The road was rough, but still, it felt as if we were flying over it with an excited rush. At that time, I did not understand what this rush meant, but it was clear that the coachman was determined not to waste any time reaching Prundu Bârgăului. They said that this road was in perfect condition during the summer, but had not yet been restored after the winter snows. In this respect, it is different from most of the roads passing through the Carpathian Mountains, because it is an old tradition that those roads are not kept in very good condition. In the past, the hospodars did not repair the roads so that the Turks would not think they were preparing to bring in foreign troops, thus accelerating a war ready to break out at any moment.
es: Soon I lost sight and memory of the ghostly fears in the beauty of the scene we were passing through, although if I had known the language, or rather, the languages spoken by my travel companions, it is very possible that I would not have been able to get rid of them so easily. Before us stretched the green sloping field full of forests with steep hills here and there, crowned with clusters of clovers or with peasant houses, with their empty walls facing the road. Everywhere there was a maddening amount of flowering fruits: apples, plums, pears, and strawberries. And as we advanced, I could see how the green grass under the trees was covered with fallen petals. The road wound in and out of these green hills of what is called "Middle Earth" here, freeing itself as it swept around the curves, or closed in by the strangling arms of the pine forests, which here and there ran down the hills like tongues of fire. The road was rough, but despite that, it felt like we were flying with an exciting haste. At that time, I couldn't understand the reason for that haste, but evidently the driver didn't want to waste time before reaching the Borgo Pass. I was told that the road was excellent in summer, but that it hadn't yet been repaired after the winter snows. In this regard, it was different from most of the roads in the Carpathians, as it is an ancient tradition that they should not be kept in such good condition. Since ancient times, the hospodars could not repair them, for then the Turks would think they were preparing to bring in foreign troops, and thus stoke the war that was always truly on the verge of breaking out.

en: Beyond the green swelling hills of the Mittel Land rose mighty slopes of forest up to the lofty steeps of the Carpathians themselves. Right and left of us they towered, with the afternoon sun falling full upon them and bringing out all the glorious colours of this beautiful range, deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks, green and brown where grass and rock mingled, and an endless perspective of jagged rock and pointed crags, till these were themselves lost in the distance, where the snowy peaks rose grandly. Here and there seemed mighty rifts in the mountains, through which, as the sun began to sink, we saw now and again the white gleam of falling water. One of my companions touched my arm as we swept round the base of a hill and opened up the lofty, snow-covered peak of a mountain, which seemed, as we wound on our serpentine way, to be right before us:—
vi: In fact, in this mountainous region, war is always on the brink of breaking out. On the other side of the hills, there are still forests and the towering peaks of the Carpathian range. In front of us, everywhere we look, there are forests and mountains. The shimmering, radiant evening sunlight turns the crevices between the towering cliffs into a deep blue or purple, transforms the grass patches covering the rock edges into a brownish green, and the endless panoramic view of jagged, sharp peaks fading into the horizon, where the snow-capped mountains undulate. As the sun began to set, we suddenly noticed here and there, scattered among the large and small rock crevices, waterfalls cascading down in countless silver streams.
tr: Rising from the green hills of the Mittelland to the steep peaks of the Carpathian Mountains, large forest-covered slopes ascended. These rose on our right and left, with the evening sun fully casting its light on them, revealing the magnificent colors of these beautiful mountain ranges. Thus, in the shadows of the peaks, dark blue, purple, green where grass and rocks mingled, and brown appeared, extending into an endless depth of steep and jagged cliffs that continued until they disappeared where the snow-capped summits rose majestically in the distance. In the mountains, here and there, we saw ravines where the glint of water falling from high places was visible as the sun set. As we wound our way around the base of a hill on our serpentine path, one of my travel companions touched my arm when a great snow-covered peak appeared directly in front of us:
es: Beyond the green and swollen hills of Middle-earth rose imposing hills of forests that reached the lofty peaks of the Carpathians. They rose to the left and right of us, with the afternoon sun fully shining upon them and making the glorious colors of this beautiful mountain range gleam, deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks, green and brown where the grass and stones mixed, and an infinite perspective of jagged rocks and pointed crags, until they themselves were lost in the distance, where the snow-capped summits rose grandly. Here and there, imposing crevices seemed to be discovered in the mountains, through which, when the sun began to descend, we occasionally saw the white flash of falling water. One of my companions touched my hand as we slid around the base of a hill and pointed to the high peak of a snow-covered mountain, which seemed, as we advanced on our winding road, to be right in front of us.

en: “Look! Isten szek!”—“God’s seat!”—and he crossed himself reverently.
vi: The horse-drawn carriage diligently continued its seemingly endless journey.
tr: "Look! Isten szek!" -"The seat of God!"- and he crossed himself with a reverent expression.
es: –"Look! Ilsten szek! 'The throne of God!'" he told me, and crossed himself again.

en: As we wound on our endless way, and the sun sank lower and lower behind us, the shadows of the evening began to creep round us. This was emphasised by the fact that the snowy mountain-top still held the sunset, and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink. Here and there we passed Cszeks and Slovaks, all in picturesque attire, but I noticed that goitre was painfully prevalent. By the roadside were many crosses, and as we swept by, my companions all crossed themselves. Here and there was a peasant man or woman kneeling before a shrine, who did not even turn round as we approached, but seemed in the self-surrender of devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world. There were many things new to me: for instance, hay-ricks in the trees, and here and there very beautiful masses of weeping birch, their white stems shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves. Now and again we passed a leiter-wagon—the ordinary peasant’s cart—with its long, snake-like vertebra, calculated to suit the inequalities of the road. On this were sure to be seated quite a group of home-coming peasants, the Cszeks with their white, and the Slovaks with their coloured, sheepskins, the latter carrying lance-fashion their long staves, with axe at end. As the evening fell it began to get very cold, and the growing twilight seemed to merge into one dark mistiness the gloom of the trees, oak, beech, and pine, though in the valleys which ran deep between the spurs of the hills, as we ascended through the Pass, the dark firs stood out here and there against the background of late-lying snow. Sometimes, as the road was cut through the pine woods that seemed in the darkness to be closing down upon us, great masses of greyness, which here and there bestrewed the trees, produced a peculiarly weird and solemn effect, which carried on the thoughts and grim fancies engendered earlier in the evening, when the falling sunset threw into strange relief the ghost-like clouds which amongst the Carpathians seem to wind ceaselessly through the valleys. Sometimes the hills were so steep that, despite our driver’s haste, the horses could only go slowly. I wished to get down and walk up them, as we do at home, but the driver would not hear of it. “No, no,” he said; “you must not walk here; the dogs are too fierce”; and then he added, with what he evidently meant for grim pleasantry—for he looked round to catch the approving smile of the rest—“and you may have enough of such matters before you go to sleep.” The only stop he would make was a moment’s pause to light his lamps.
vi: Behind us, the sun gradually sank below the horizon, and the shadows of dusk descended ever more quickly. The sense of sunset became even more vivid when we were at a higher altitude. The snow-capped mountain peaks still sparkled with the scattered pink rays of the sun. Occasionally along the way, we encountered groups of Czechs and Slovaks in their famous traditional costumes. However, there was one thing that made me unhappy: most of them suffered from goiters. Every now and then, a solitary cross would stand by the roadside, and each time the carriage passed by, the passengers would hurriedly make the sign of the cross. We also saw farmers kneeling in prayer in front of graveyard chapels. They were so absorbed in their prayers that they didn't bother to look up when they heard the carriage approaching. All of them were devout, and while praying, they never paid attention to the world around them. Almost everything was new to me: the haystacks piled high up to the tree canopies, the weeping willows revealing through their leaves slender branches glistening with silver light...Occasionally, I encountered an ox cart carrying farmers returning home, the Czech men wearing pure white sheepskin coats; while the Slovaks wore dyed sheepskin coats, and they carried long axes like spears by their sides. Nightfall heralded a scene of icy coldness, the darkness deepening among the dense fir and oak leaves. We were on our way to the Borgo Pass. In the valley beneath us, the black fir trees seemed to be torn apart against a backdrop of freshly fallen white snow. Sometimes, as the road delved into a fir forest - which seemed to be swallowing us whole - thick, white fog banks would suddenly appear, completely obscuring the bushes, making them look like ghostly apparitions. Once again, I felt a shiver similar to the tingling sensation I had experienced at dusk. In the Carpathians, the setting sun had left behind bizarrely shaped clouds drifting among the rocky crags. The hillsides were now so steep that, despite being in a hurry to reach our destination, the coachman had to slow the horses down. I expressed my desire to get off and walk for a bit, as I would do back home in a similar situation, but the coachman immediately objected: — No, no! - He replied. - You can't walk there... Are the dogs here fierce? The coachman added another sentence, which I guessed was his attempt to prove that he too had a sense of humor, as I could clearly see him glancing at each passenger, hoping for a responsive smile: — Just trust me, and you will have everything, including the walk, when you are comfortably lying in bed tonight. He only kept quiet when it was time to light the lamps on the carriage.
tr: As we wound our way on our seemingly endless journey and the sun sank lower behind us, the shadows of evening began to silently envelop us. This was further accentuated by the snowy peak of the mountain, which still held the sunset upon it, appearing to glow with a light and cool pinkness. From time to time, we passed by Czechs and Slovaks in remarkable attire, and unfortunately, I noticed that goiter was a common condition. There were numerous crosses by the roadside, and as we passed them, all my companions crossed themselves. Here and there, there were peasant women and men kneeling before a shrine, who did not turn to look as we approached, wholly absorbed in their devotions, their eyes and ears shut off from the outside world. Many things were new to me: for instance, the haystacks in the trees, the beautiful clusters of birch trees with white trunks shimmering like silver among the delicate green of their leaves. From time to time, we overtook a leiter-wagon, an ordinary peasant cart with a long, sinuous spine adjusted to the roughness of the road. On this vehicle, there was always a group of farmers returning home, with white sheepskins for the Czechs and colored ones for the Slovaks; the second group carried long sticks with axes at the end, giving them the air of spears. As evening fell, the air grew very cold, and the increasingly dense twilight seemed to blend into a thick mist with the dimness of trees like oak, beech, and pine; yet, as we descended from the pass into the valleys deep between the arms of the mountains, we occasionally came across dark fir trees backed by patches of snow that had not yet melted. At times, the road was intersected by pine forests that seemed to close in on us in the darkness, while the early evening sunset, sinking ever lower, cast strange shapes with the ghostly clouds drifting incessantly through the valleys of the Carpathians, creating an unusually eerie and majestic effect with the large patches of gray covering the trees here and there. Sometimes the hills were so steep that, despite our driver's haste, the horses could only proceed slowly. I wanted to get out of the carriage and approach the horses, but the driver would not allow it. "No, no!" he said; "You must not walk here; the dogs are too savage," then, making it clear he was making a cruel joke by looking around to catch the approving smiles of the others, he added, "You will have enough of such matters to deal with before you sleep." The only stop he made was for a moment to light the lamps.
es: As we continued on our endless journey and the sun sank lower and lower behind us, the shadows of the evening began to surround us. This fact was highlighted because the peaks of the snow-capped mountains still received the sun's rays and seemed to glow with a delicate and cold pink color. Here and there we passed by Czechs and Slovaks, all in their picturesque attire, but I noticed that goiter was painfully prevalent. Along the road, there were many crosses, and as we passed, all my companions crossed themselves before them. Here and there, there was a peasant woman kneeling before an altar, not even turning to see us as we approached, but rather, in the rapture of devotion, she seemed to have neither eyes nor ears for the outside world. Many things were completely new to me; for example, haystacks in the trees, and here and there, very beautiful groups of weeping willows, with their white branches shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves. Time and again we passed a wagon (the ordinary cart of the peasants) with its long, sinuous spine, designed to adjust to the unevenness of the road. In each of them sat a group of peasants returning to their homes, the Czechs with their white sheepskins and the Slovaks with their colored ones. The latter carried their long staves like spears, with an axe at the end. As night began to fall, it became very cold, and the growing twilight seemed to blend the gloom of the trees—oaks, beeches, and pines—into a single mist, although in the valleys that ran deeply through the furrows of the hills, as we ascended towards the gorge, the dark fir trees stood out against the backdrop of the late snow. Sometimes, as the road was cut through the pine forests that seemed to close in on us in the darkness, large gray masses scattered here and there among the trees produced a gloomy and solemn effect, which revived the thoughts and sinister fantasies engendered by the evening, while the setting sun seemed to cast a strange comfort on the ghostly clouds that, among the Carpathians, seem to wander incessantly through the valleys. On certain occasions, the hills were so steep that, despite our driver's haste, the horses could only advance very slowly. I wanted to get out of the carriage and walk beside them, as we do in my country, but the coachman would have none of it. –No; no -he told me-, you must not walk here. The dogs are very fierce -he said, and then added, with what evidently seemed to be a macabre joke, as he looked around to catch the affirmative smiles of the others-: You will have enough to do before going to sleep. Thus, the only stop he made for a moment served to light the lamps.

en: When it grew dark there seemed to be some excitement amongst the passengers, and they kept speaking to him, one after the other, as though urging him to further speed. He lashed the horses unmercifully with his long whip, and with wild cries of encouragement urged them on to further exertions. Then through the darkness I could see a sort of patch of grey light ahead of us, as though there were a cleft in the hills. The excitement of the passengers grew greater; the crazy coach rocked on its great leather springs, and swayed like a boat tossed on a stormy sea. I had to hold on. The road grew more level, and we appeared to fly along. Then the mountains seemed to come nearer to us on each side and to frown down upon us; we were entering on the Borgo Pass. One by one several of the passengers offered me gifts, which they pressed upon me with an earnestness which would take no denial; these were certainly of an odd and varied kind, but each was given in simple good faith, with a kindly word, and a blessing, and that strange mixture of fear-meaning movements which I had seen outside the hotel at Bistritz—the sign of the cross and the guard against the evil eye. Then, as we flew along, the driver leaned forward, and on each side the passengers, craning over the edge of the coach, peered eagerly into the darkness. It was evident that something very exciting was either happening or expected, but though I asked each passenger, no one would give me the slightest explanation. This state of excitement kept on for some little time; and at last we saw before us the Pass opening out on the eastern side. There were dark, rolling clouds overhead, and in the air the heavy, oppressive sense of thunder. It seemed as though the mountain range had separated two atmospheres, and that now we had got into the thunderous one. I was now myself looking out for the conveyance which was to take me to the Count. Each moment I expected to see the glare of lamps through the blackness; but all was dark. The only light was the flickering rays of our own lamps, in which the steam from our hard-driven horses rose in a white cloud. We could see now the sandy road lying white before us, but there was on it no sign of a vehicle. The passengers drew back with a sigh of gladness, which seemed to mock my own disappointment. I was already thinking what I had best do, when the driver, looking at his watch, said to the others something which I could hardly hear, it was spoken so quietly and in so low a tone; I thought it was “An hour less than the time.” Then turning to me, he said in German worse than my own:—
vi: As soon as the lamps were lit, the passengers suddenly became lively, urging the coachman to drive the horses faster. The coachman immediately swung his whip, urging the horses to gallop up the mountainside. After the carriage had been running for a while, I believed I saw a pale blue light in the darkness ahead - but it was probably nothing more than a crack between the rocks. My fellow travelers became increasingly agitated. The carriage began to roll wildly, causing the springs to creak, making us feel as if we were on a boat in a stormy sea. I had to hold tightly to the side of the carriage to avoid being thrown off. After a while, the road seemed smoother, and I felt as if the carriage was flying through the night. The path also became narrower, the mountains closed in more tightly, and to be honest, it seemed as if they were spreading out to threaten us: we were passing through the Borgo Pass. For some reason, my fellow travelers began handing me various items as gifts, such as a sprig of garlic, a dried wild rose... and I realized I couldn't refuse them. Indeed, each gift had a certain amusing quality, yet those who gave them to me expressed sincere and simple intentions along with mysterious gestures, similar to those made by the people standing in front of the Bistritz hotel: making the sign of the cross and raising two fingers to protect me against the evil eyes lurking around. The coachman leaned forward, and the passengers on the benches strained their necks to look outside. Clearly, they were expecting something to appear in the night. I asked questions, but no one wanted to answer, not even a single sentence. The curiosity kept smoldering within me. Finally, we reached the eastern slope of Borgo Pass. Dark clouds piled up, the air stifling as if a storm was imminent. It must be said that the atmosphere between the two mountain slopes was distinctly different. Now we were entering a dangerous area. I quietly observed the carriage tasked with leading me to the Count's house, anxiously waiting for the moment to catch a glimpse of the faint light from the castle, but everything around was still pitch black. The only light at that moment was the flickering light from the carriage, mingling with the heavy, steamy breaths of the horses. That light allowed us to see the pale road ahead, but there was absolutely no sign of any other vehicle besides ours. My fellow travelers let out a sigh and then turned to find a more comfortable sitting position. I felt their gestures were like a mockery: they were ridiculing my disappointment. I was thinking of how to handle this awkward situation when the coachman suddenly checked his watch and said something to the passengers that I didn't understand; however, I could guess his meaning: "An hour late..." Then he turned to advise me in German that was even worse than mine:
tr: It seemed as if an excitement had arisen among the passengers when it got dark, and the passengers kept talking to the coachman one after another, as if insisting that he go faster.
