But when I saw the man slowly emerging from the window, descending down the castle wall into the terrifying void, his cloak spread around him like wide wings, crawling face down, my feelings turned to disgust and horror. At first, I couldn't believe my eyes. I thought it was some kind of trick played by the moonlight, a strange effect of the shadow; but I kept looking; it couldn't be an optical illusion. I saw his fingers and toes grasping the edges of the stones, whose mortar had worn away over the years, and thus, like a lizard moving on the wall, he used every protrusion and roughness to make his way down.
es: What I saw was the count's head emerging from the window. I didn't see his face, but I knew it was him by the neck and the movement of his back and arms. In any case, I couldn't mistake those hands, which I had studied on so many occasions. At first, I showed interest and was even somewhat entertained, for it is wonderful how a small thing can interest and entertain a man who finds himself imprisoned. But my own sensations turned to repulsion and terror when I saw the entire man slowly emerge from the window and begin to crawl down the castle wall, over the deep abyss, head downwards with his cloak spread out over him like great wings. At first, I couldn't believe my eyes. I thought it was a trick of the moonlight, some malevolent effect of shadows. But I kept looking and it couldn't be any illusion. I saw how the fingers of his hands and feet gripped the corners of the stones, clearly worn from the mortar by the passage of years, and thus using every projection and irregularity, they moved downward at a considerable speed, in the same way a lizard walks on walls.

en: What manner of man is this, or what manner of creature is it in the semblance of man? I feel the dread of this horrible place overpowering me; I am in fear—in awful fear—and there is no escape for me; I am encompassed about with terrors that I dare not think of....
vi: Is he a superhuman being, or a monster in human disguise? The scene unfolding right before my eyes made me feel more horrified than ever, I was scared... I was terrified to the point of panic... and I couldn't help but flee...
tr: What kind of person is this, or what kind of creature in the guise of a human? I feel that the horror of this dreadful place has deeply affected me; I am in fear -great fear- and there is no escape for me; I am surrounded by fears that I dare not even think about...
es: What kind of man is this, or what kind of being with the appearance of a man? I feel that the terror of this horrible place is overcoming me; I am afraid, very afraid, that there may be no possible escape for me. I am surrounded by such terrors that I do not dare to think about them...

en: 15 May.—Once more have I seen the Count go out in his lizard fashion. He moved downwards in a sidelong way, some hundred feet down, and a good deal to the left. He vanished into some hole or window. When his head had disappeared, I leaned out to try and see more, but without avail—the distance was too great to allow a proper angle of sight. I knew he had left the castle now, and thought to use the opportunity to explore more than I had dared to do as yet. I went back to the room, and taking a lamp, tried all the doors. They were all locked, as I had expected, and the locks were comparatively new; but I went down the stone stairs to the hall where I had entered originally. I found I could pull back the bolts easily enough and unhook the great chains; but the door was locked, and the key was gone! That key must be in the Count’s room; I must watch should his door be unlocked, so that I may get it and escape. I went on to make a thorough examination of the various stairs and passages, and to try the doors that opened from them. One or two small rooms near the hall were open, but there was nothing to see in them except old furniture, dusty with age and moth-eaten. At last, however, I found one door at the top of the stairway which, though it seemed to be locked, gave a little under pressure. I tried it harder, and found that it was not really locked, but that the resistance came from the fact that the hinges had fallen somewhat, and the heavy door rested on the floor. Here was an opportunity which I might not have again, so I exerted myself, and with many efforts forced it back so that I could enter. I was now in a wing of the castle further to the right than the rooms I knew and a storey lower down. From the windows I could see that the suite of rooms lay along to the south of the castle, the windows of the end room looking out both west and south. On the latter side, as well as to the former, there was a great precipice. The castle was built on the corner of a great rock, so that on three sides it was quite impregnable, and great windows were placed here where sling, or bow, or culverin could not reach, and consequently light and comfort, impossible to a position which had to be guarded, were secured. To the west was a great valley, and then, rising far away, great jagged mountain fastnesses, rising peak on peak, the sheer rock studded with mountain ash and thorn, whose roots clung in cracks and crevices and crannies of the stone. This was evidently the portion of the castle occupied by the ladies in bygone days, for the furniture had more air of comfort than any I had seen. The windows were curtainless, and the yellow moonlight, flooding in through the diamond panes, enabled one to see even colours, whilst it softened the wealth of dust which lay over all and disguised in some measure the ravages of time and the moth. My lamp seemed to be of little effect in the brilliant moonlight, but I was glad to have it with me, for there was a dread loneliness in the place which chilled my heart and made my nerves tremble. Still, it was better than living alone in the rooms which I had come to hate from the presence of the Count, and after trying a little to school my nerves, I found a soft quietude come over me. Here I am, sitting at a little oak table where in old times possibly some fair lady sat to pen, with much thought and many blushes, her ill-spelt love-letter, and writing in my diary in shorthand all that has happened since I closed it last. It is nineteenth century up-to-date with a vengeance. And yet, unless my senses deceive me, the old centuries had, and have, powers of their own which mere “modernity” cannot kill.
vi: • May 15 I was stunned to see the old count continue to crawl like a lizard. He crawled along the wall in a slightly diagonal line to the left. Then he suddenly slipped into a hole or some kind of window. When I could no longer see his head, I dared to lean out further to get a clearer view of his path, but I didn't discover anything new, as the hole or window was too far from where I stood. However, I was certain of one thing: the count had left the castle, and now I could do something I hadn't dared to do before: take the opportunity to explore the castle. I went to the middle of the room, grabbed the lamp, and tried to open all the doors. As I suspected, every door was tightly locked, and from what I could see, the locks were relatively new. I went down the stairs, walked along the hallway through the door I had entered on my first night at the castle. I found that I could easily open the door latches and remove the chain, but the door was tightly locked, and of course, the key was no longer in the lock. Surely the key was kept in the count's room, and so I needed to seize the opportunity, when his room door was unlocked, to sneak in, steal the key, and escape. I continued to meticulously inspect each corridor, each staircase, and tried opening all the doors I encountered along the way. The doors of one or two small rooms facing the central corridor were unlocked, but inside there was nothing noteworthy except for some old dusty wooden furniture and a few fabric-covered armchairs that had been badly gnawed by termites. Finally, upon reaching the top of a staircase, I came across a door that at first glance seemed tightly locked, but when I gave it a gentle push, it budged slightly. Continuing to push harder, I realized that the door was indeed not locked; it just resisted my push a bit because the hinges were somewhat loose, causing the door to sag close to the floor. This might be a unique opportunity that I must seize. After a few attempts of mustering my strength, I managed to open the door. I was standing in an annex of the castle, which was slightly to the right and below the rooms I had previously explored. Looking through the window, I saw the rooms stretching along the southern side of the castle, with the windows of the last room facing both south and west. Both sides overlooked a deep abyss. The castle was built right at the corner of a large mountain peak, so much so that all three sides were inaccessible; similarly, the windows were positioned very high on the walls, making them invulnerable to weapons like bows, catapults, and conventional firearms, which couldn't reach them. The high position of the windows gave part of the castle a more airy and pleasant atmosphere. To the east lay a valley deep at the foot of towering and steep mountains. Surely, in the old days, these rooms were the quarters of the ladies, because all the furniture here seems to be more comfortable compared to what I have seen in other rooms. The windows had no curtains, so the clear moonlight filtered through the glass, allowing me to easily distinguish the colors of the objects in the room, even though everything was blurred by the dust of time. The lamp in my hand suddenly became useless under the moonlight, but it still somewhat made me feel at ease, as it was clear that I was alone, a loneliness that made my heart tighten with a vague fear. However, it was better to be alone like this than to have the old count in the room. A bit of rational effort along with the comfort of the lamp in my hand helped me calm down. I sat down by a small oak table, where once a beautiful woman must have sat, dreamily and bashfully writing flowing but clumsy love letters. I sat thinking back on the diary pages that recorded everything that had happened to me. Shorthand is indeed a nineteenth-century advancement! Indeed, each century has its own distinct powers that modernism cannot extinguish...
tr: 15 May. - I saw the Count slipping out like a lizard once again. He was moving sideways, descending about thirty meters down and quite a bit to the left. He disappeared into a hole or a window. When his head vanished from sight, I leaned out to see more, but it was no use - the distance was too great to allow a proper viewing angle. I knew he had left the castle, and I thought of using this opportunity to explore more than I had dared so far. I returned to the room, took the lamp, and tried all the doors. As I had guessed, they were all locked, and the locks were relatively new; but I went down the stone stairs to the hall where I had first entered. I found that I could easily pull the bolts and remove the huge chains, but the door was locked and there was no key! That key must be in the Count's room; I must watch for a time when the door to his room is not locked so I can take the key and escape. I continued to carefully examine various stairs and corridors, trying the doors that opened onto them. A few small rooms near the hall had open doors, but inside there was nothing to see except old, moth-eaten furniture covered in years of dust. But finally, at the top of a staircase, I found a door that, although it appeared to be locked, opened with a bit of force. I pushed harder and saw that it was not truly locked, the resistance came from the hinges somehow dropping, and the heavy door was resting on the ground. This was an opportunity that might not come again, so after using all my strength and many attempts, I pushed it back enough to get inside. Now, I was in the right wing of the castle, one floor below the rooms I knew. From the window, I could see that the connected rooms extended along the south wing of the castle, with the room at the end facing both west and south. As on the first side, there was a deep chasm on the second side as well. The castle was built on the corner of a large rock, making it quite impregnable from three sides, and the large windows were placed where no slingshot, arrow, or rifle could reach, thus providing light and comfort impossible for a place that needed to be defended. To the west, there was a wide valley and behind it, in the distance, rows of sharp-peaked mountains rising summit upon summit, with rowan trees and thorny bushes clinging to the cracks, crevices, and fissures in the rock. This part of the castle was evidently inhabited in the past because the furniture had a more comfortable air than what I had seen before. There were no curtains on the windows, and the yellow moonlight streaming through the diamond-shaped window panes weakened the layer of dust covering everything, somewhat concealing the damage caused by time and moths, making it possible to see colors. Under the bright moonlight, my lamp seemed almost useless, but I was glad to have it with me because there was a dreadful loneliness in this place that chilled my blood and unnerved me. Still, it was better than being alone in the rooms I had come to hate due to the Count's presence, and after trying to steady my nerves a bit, I felt a soft peace settle over me. Here I am, sitting at a small oak table where, in old times, a lovely lady might have penned a love letter full of spelling mistakes, blushing as she thought long and hard, writing in shorthand in my journal about what has happened since I last closed it. This is the nineteenth century, as updated as it can be. Yet, if my senses do not deceive me, the old times had their own unique powers that "modernity" could not kill, and still do.
es: May 15th. Once again, I saw the Count slither like a lizard. He walked downward, slightly sideways, for about a hundred feet and veered to the left. There he disappeared into a hole or window. When his head had vanished, I leaned out trying to see more, but to no avail, as the distance was too great to provide me with a favorable viewing angle. But by then I already knew he had left the castle, and I thought I should take the opportunity to explore more than I had dared to see until then. I returned to the room, and taking a lamp, I tried all the doors. All were locked, just as I had expected, and the locks were comparatively new. Then, I descended the stone steps to the corridor where I had originally entered. I found that I could easily enough remove the bolts and unlock the large chains; but the door was firmly locked and there was no key! The key must be in the count's room. I have to watch in case his door is unlocked, so that I can get it and escape. I continued to make a thorough examination of various staircases and passages and pressed all the doors that were before them. One or two rooms near the corridor were open, but there was nothing in them, nothing to see except old furniture, dusty from the wind and moth-eaten. Finally, however, I found a door at the end of the staircase, which, although it seemed to be locked, gave way a little under pressure. I pushed it harder and discovered that it was not actually locked, but the resistance came from the hinges having sagged a bit and the heavy door resting on the floor. There was an opportunity that might well be unique, so I made a supreme effort, and after many attempts, I forced it back so that I could enter. I found myself at that moment in a wing of the castle much further to the right than the rooms I knew and a floor lower. From the windows, I could see that the series of rooms were situated along the south side of the castle, with the windows of the last room facing both east and south. On that last side, as well as the previous one, there was a great precipice. The castle was built on the corner of a large rock, making it almost impregnable on three of its sides, and large windows were placed here where neither wave, nor bow, nor culverin could reach, thus ensuring light and comfort to a position that had to be guarded. To the west, there was a great valley, and then, rising far away, a large chain of jagged mountains, rising peak to peak, where the bare stone was dotted with rowan trees and brambles, whose roots clung to the crevices, cracks, and fissures of the rocks. This was evidently the portion of the castle occupied in days past by the ladies, as the furniture had a more comfortable air than I had seen until then. The windows had no curtains, and the yellow moonlight reflecting in the diamond-shaped hollows allowed even the colors to be distinguished, while it softened the amount of dust that lay over everything and somewhat disguised the effects of time and moths. My lamp had little effect in the bright moonlight, but I was glad to have it with me, for there was a gloomy solitude in the place that made my heart and nerves tremble. Despite everything, it was better than living alone in the rooms I had come to hate due to the presence of the count, and after trying a bit to calm my nerves, I felt overwhelmed by a gentle tranquility. And here I am, sitting at a small oak table where in ancient times some beautiful lady used to take up the pen, with many thoughts and more blushes, to poorly write her love letter, writing in my diary in shorthand everything that has happened since I last closed it. It is the 19th century, very modern, with all its soul. And yet, unless my senses deceive me, past centuries had and have peculiar powers of their own, which mere "modernity" cannot kill.

en: Later: the Morning of 16 May.—God preserve my sanity, for to this I am reduced. Safety and the assurance of safety are things of the past. Whilst I live on here there is but one thing to hope for, that I may not go mad, if, indeed, I be not mad already. If I be sane, then surely it is maddening to think that of all the foul things that lurk in this hateful place the Count is the least dreadful to me; that to him alone I can look for safety, even though this be only whilst I can serve his purpose. Great God! merciful God! Let me be calm, for out of that way lies madness indeed. I begin to get new lights on certain things which have puzzled me. Up to now I never quite knew what Shakespeare meant when he made Hamlet say:—
vi: • May 16, morning God wants me to maintain my mental balance at this moment, because that is all I have left. For me, safety, or ensuring safety, is a thing of the past. In the remaining weeks of living here, I can only hope that I do not become a madman. And if I can keep a sound mind, I will surely panic at the thought that among all the threats surrounding me here, the presence of the count is the least of them! Oh God! Oh merciful God! Help me to stay calm, for if calmness leaves me, it will surely give way to madness! At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: Later: the morning of May 16. - My God, keep my mind safe, because in the end, I have fallen to this state. Security and the assurance of security are things of the past. During my time here, there is only one thing to wish for: Not to go mad, that is, if I am not already mad. If I am in my right mind, it is truly maddening to think that among the horrible things lurking in this hateful place, the least terrifying for me is the Count, and that as long as I work for his purpose, the only person I can go to for safety is the Count. Oh, Almighty God! Merciful God! Help me stay calm, because straying from this path truly means going mad. I am beginning to gain clarity on certain matters that previously confused me. Until now, I had never fully understood what Shakespeare meant when he had Hamlet say these words:
es: Later: morning of May 16. God keep me sane, for this is what I am reduced to. Safety, and confidence in safety, are things of the past. As long as I live here, there is only one thing to wish for, and that is that I do not go mad, if I am not mad already. If I am sane, then it is certainly maddening to think that of all the rotten things that crawl in this hateful place, the count is the least dreadful to me; that only in him can I seek safety, even if it is only as long as I can serve his purposes. Great God, merciful God! Give me calm, for in that direction madness surely awaits me. I am beginning to see new lights on certain things that previously perplexed me. Until now I did not truly understand what Shakespeare meant when he made Hamlet say:

en: “My tablets! quick, my tablets!
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: My tablets! Quickly! My tablets!
es: "My notebooks, quickly, my notebooks!

en: ’Tis meet that I put it down,” etc.,
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide.
tr: I must write these down... 11
es: it is essential that you write it", etc.,

en: for now, feeling as though my own brain were unhinged or as if the shock had come which must end in its undoing, I turn to my diary for repose. The habit of entering accurately must help to soothe me.
vi: At this moment, when I feel like my mind is about to go insane or at least has just gone through a harmful shock, I can only entrust myself to the diary: the diary will be my guide. Detailing everything I discover will be a way for me to console myself.
tr: Now I feel as if my mind has lost its balance or as if the shock that should end its ruin has come, and I turn to my journal for peace. The habit of writing everything down completely will comfort me.
es: Well now, feeling as if my brain were deranged or as if the blow that will end in its disorder had arrived, I turn to my diary seeking rest. The habit of noting everything meticulously should help me to calm down.

en: The Count’s mysterious warning frightened me at the time; it frightens me more now when I think of it, for in future he has a fearful hold upon me. I shall fear to doubt what he may say!
vi: The mysterious warning of the old count made me fearful from the moment he spoke, and now, thinking back, I feel even more terrified because I know this strange man will have a terrible influence on me. What I need to do now is not to take his words too seriously!
tr: Kont's mysterious warning had frightened me at the time; now, thinking about it, it scares me even more because he will have great authority over me in the future. I will be afraid to doubt what he might say in the future!
es: The mysterious warning from the count scared me; but it scares me more now when I think about it, for in the future it has a terrifying power over me. I will doubt everything he tells me!

en: When I had written in my diary and had fortunately replaced the book and pen in my pocket I felt sleepy. The Count’s warning came into my mind, but I took a pleasure in disobeying it. The sense of sleep was upon me, and with it the obstinacy which sleep brings as outrider. The soft moonlight soothed, and the wide expanse without gave a sense of freedom which refreshed me. I determined not to return to-night to the gloom-haunted rooms, but to sleep here, where, of old, ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives whilst their gentle breasts were sad for their menfolk away in the midst of remorseless wars. I drew a great couch out of its place near the corner, so that as I lay, I could look at the lovely view to east and south, and unthinking of and uncaring for the dust, composed myself for sleep. I suppose I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear, for all that followed was startlingly real—so real that now sitting here in the broad, full sunlight of the morning, I cannot in the least believe that it was all sleep.
vi: Having finished writing the recent diary entries and putting the paper and pen into my pocket, I suddenly felt my eyes grow heavy with sleep. Of course, I did not forget the count's warning, but for some reason, I still liked not following his words. The bright moonlight seemed so gentle and kind to me, and the vast, expansive scenery outside also seemed to want to comfort and soothe me, giving me a sense of the free sky. I decided not to return to my room but to sleep right here, where people still speculate about the presence of noble ladies of the past and where they used to gather to sing and alleviate the sadness of a luxurious but dull life, as their husbands were always away in distant lands due to endless and deadly wars. I chose a long reclining chair placed near the window so that I could still enjoy the view while lying down. Ignoring the thin layer of dust, I wearily leaned back, hoping to soon fall asleep. Indeed, I did fall asleep, or at least I hoped I did, because honestly, I was just afraid I hadn't fallen asleep yet, as everything that happened next seemed so real to me that even now, in broad daylight, in a room filled with the bright morning light, I still can't believe I could have been dreaming.
tr: After writing in my journal and fortunately putting the notebook and pen in my pocket, I felt sleepy. I remembered the Count's warning, but I enjoyed defying him. The feeling of sleep had settled over me, and stubbornness had come along as sleep's servant. The soft moonlight was soothing me, and the vastness outside was giving me a sense of freedom that delighted me. Tonight, I decided not to return to those gloomy rooms and to sleep in this room where, in old times, ladies with sensitive hearts would sit and sing in sorrow because their men were far away in merciless wars, and they lived sweet lives. I pulled a large sofa close to the corner so that I could watch the beautiful view of the east and south while lying down and prepare myself for sleep without worrying about the dust. I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear what happened afterward was terrifyingly real - so real that now, as I sit here in the bright daylight of the morning, I can't believe even a little that it was all a dream.
es: Once I had written in my diary and put the pen and the book back in my pocket, I felt drowsy. I immediately remembered the count's warning, but it was a pleasure to disobey it. The feeling of sleep had numbed me, and with it the obstinacy that sleep brings like a stranger. The soft moonlight calmed me, and the vast expanse outside gave me a sense of freedom that refreshed me. I made the decision not to return that night to the rooms filled with horrors, but to sleep here where, in the past, ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives while their gentle breasts saddened for the men away in bloody wars. I pulled a wide bed from its place near a corner, so that when I lay down, I could look at the beautiful landscape to the east and south, and without thinking and without minding the dust, I prepared to sleep. I suppose I must have fallen asleep; I hope so, but I fear it, for everything that followed was so extraordinarily real, so real, that now sitting here in the full light of the morning sun, I cannot think in any way that I was asleep.

en: I was not alone. The room was the same, unchanged in any way since I came into it; I could see along the floor, in the brilliant moonlight, my own footsteps marked where I had disturbed the long accumulation of dust. In the moonlight opposite me were three young women, ladies by their dress and manner. I thought at the time that I must be dreaming when I saw them, for, though the moonlight was behind them, they threw no shadow on the floor. They came close to me, and looked at me for some time, and then whispered together. Two were dark, and had high aquiline noses, like the Count, and great dark, piercing eyes that seemed to be almost red when contrasted with the pale yellow moon. The other was fair, as fair as can be, with great wavy masses of golden hair and eyes like pale sapphires. I seemed somehow to know her face, and to know it in connection with some dreamy fear, but I could not recollect at the moment how or where. All three had brilliant white teeth that shone like pearls against the ruby of their voluptuous lips. There was something about them that made me uneasy, some longing and at the same time some deadly fear. I felt in my heart a wicked, burning desire that they would kiss me with those red lips. It is not good to note this down, lest some day it should meet Mina’s eyes and cause her pain; but it is the truth. They whispered together, and then they all three laughed—such a silvery, musical laugh, but as hard as though the sound never could have come through the softness of human lips. It was like the intolerable, tingling sweetness of water-glasses when played on by a cunning hand. The fair girl shook her head coquettishly, and the other two urged her on. One said:—
vi: I'm not alone in the room. Clearly, nothing has changed since I stepped in here. I noticed on the floor, the moonlight illuminated my footprints clearly imprinted on the layer of dust. But standing before me now are three women, three noblewomen as shown by their makeup and demeanor. At first glance, I thought I was dreaming, because even though the moonlight shone through the window, I still couldn't see any shadow of theirs cast on the floor. They approached me, stared at my face for a moment, then turned to each other and whispered something. Two of them had brown hair, hooked noses like the old count's, sharp eyes like knives, wide open and gleaming as if on fire. The third was an incredibly beautiful woman with long, shiny blonde hair and eyes as blue as sapphires. I found her face somewhat familiar; and my memory took me back to a face I had seen in a nightmare, although at this moment I couldn't recall the exact time and circumstances. All three had sparkling white teeth, shining like pearls, peeking out from behind their bright red, sensual lips. There was something about them that made me feel uneasy, both desirous and fearful. Yes, indeed I very much longed to place a burning kiss on those red lips. But perhaps it's best that I don't write such words, for it would make my Mina sad if she read these diary entries, yet I must also say that it is the truth. The three women continued whispering to each other, then burst into a melodious, clear laugh, but I find it hard to fully describe, for that laugh contained something that seemed impossible to come from a human throat. It was both shrill and gentle, to the point of being unbearable, like the sound of clinking glasses in the hands of a clumsy artist. The blonde woman shook her head, seemingly provocatively, leaving the other two to push forward from behind. — Go ahead! - One of them said.
tr: I was not alone. The room was the same, it hadn't changed at all since I entered; in the bright moonlight, I could see the long dust trails disturbed by my own footprints all across the floor. In the moonlight, directly in front of me were three young women; judging by their clothes and demeanor, they were noble ladies. At that moment, when I saw them, I thought I was dreaming, because despite the moonlight being behind them, their shadows did not fall on the ground. They approached me and looked at me for a while, then whispered together. Two of them were brunettes and had high noses resembling an eagle's beak like the Count's, and large, dark, piercing eyes that seemed almost red compared to the pale, yellow moon. The other was as blonde as could be, with wavy golden hair and pale, sapphire-like eyes. It was as if I knew her face from somewhere, in connection with an imaginary fear, but at that moment, I couldn't figure out how and where I knew her from. All three had dazzling white teeth that shone like pearls against the redness of their voluptuous lips. There was something about them that made me uneasy, a bit of longing and at the same time, a deadly fear. In my heart, I felt a wicked, burning desire for them to kiss me with those red lips. It's not good for me to write these here, as one day Mina might see them and it could cause her pain, but this is the truth. They whispered and then all three laughed - such silvery and harmonious, yet harsh laughs that seemed like they could never come from the softness of human lips. It was like the unbearable, chilling delight that comes from a glass of water when played by a skillful hand. The blonde girl coquettishly nodded her head and the other two encouraged her. One of them said:
es: He was not alone. The room was the same, without any change of any kind since I had entered it; in the light of the bright moonlight, I could see my own footprints marked where I had disturbed the long accumulation of dust. In the moonlight on the opposite side from where I was standing were three young women, or rather three ladies, due to their dress and demeanor. The moment I saw them I thought I was dreaming, for, although the moonlight was behind them, they cast no shadow on the floor. They approached me and looked at me for a time, and then began to murmur among themselves. Two were dark-haired and had high aquiline noses, like the count, and large, piercing black eyes, which almost seemed to be red in contrast to the pale yellow moon. The other was blonde; incredibly blonde, with large locks of golden wavy hair and eyes like pale sapphires. It seemed to me that somehow I knew her face, and that I knew it in connection with some dark dream, but at the moment I could not remember where or how. The three had bright white teeth that gleamed like pearls against the ruby of their voluptuous lips. There was something about them that made me feel uneasy; a fear both nostalgic and deadly. I felt in my heart a malevolent, burning desire for them to kiss me with those red lips. It is not right for me to write this down, in case one day it meets Mina's eyes and causes her pain; but it is the truth. They murmured among themselves, and then the three laughed, with a silvery, musical laugh, but as harsh as if its sound had never passed through the softness of human lips. It was like the intolerable, tinkling sweetness of water glasses when touched by a skilled hand. The blonde woman coquettishly shook her head, and the other two insisted on her. One said:

en: “Go on! You are first, and we shall follow; yours is the right to begin.” The other added:—
vi: - I'll let you go first, we'll do it after. — He still looks young and strong. - The second woman spoke up. -
tr: "Come on! You are first and we will follow you; the right to start is yours."" The other added:
es: –Go ahead! You go first and we will follow you; it is your right to start. The other added:

en: “He is young and strong; there are kisses for us all.” I lay quiet, looking out under my eyelashes in an agony of delightful anticipation. The fair girl advanced and bent over me till I could feel the movement of her breath upon me. Sweet it was in one sense, honey-sweet, and sent the same tingling through the nerves as her voice, but with a bitter underlying the sweet, a bitter offensiveness, as one smells in blood.
vi: All three of us will give him a kiss. I lay still, observing the drama through half-closed eyes, feeling as if I were being tormented by an anxious excitement and an indescribable carnal pleasure. The blonde woman approached me, bending close to me, so close that I could even feel her passionate breath: her breath was as gentle and soothing as her voice, but there was something slightly fishy, fishy like the smell of blood.
tr: “A young and strong man; there are kisses for all of us.” I lay silently, looking from under my eyelashes with the pain of a sweet anticipation. The blonde girl walked over and continued to lean over me until I could feel the movement of her breath. In one sense, it was sweet - sweet as honey, I felt the shiver caused by her voice in my nerves, but like the smell of blood, there was a painful, painful ugliness lying beneath the sweetness.
es: –He is young and strong. There are kisses for everyone. I remained still, looking under my eyelashes at the agony of a delightful expectation. The blonde girl advanced and leaned over me until I could feel the movement of her breath on my face. In one sense it was sweet, sweet as honey, and sent, like her voice, the same tingle through the nerves, but with a bitterness beneath the sweetness, an offensive bitterness like that which is smelled in blood.

en: I was afraid to raise my eyelids, but looked out and saw perfectly under the lashes. The girl went on her knees, and bent over me, simply gloating. There was a deliberate voluptuousness which was both thrilling and repulsive, and as she arched her neck she actually licked her lips like an animal, till I could see in the moonlight the moisture shining on the scarlet lips and on the red tongue as it lapped the white sharp teeth. Lower and lower went her head as the lips went below the range of my mouth and chin and seemed about to fasten on my throat. Then she paused, and I could hear the churning sound of her tongue as it licked her teeth and lips, and could feel the hot breath on my neck. Then the skin of my throat began to tingle as one’s flesh does when the hand that is to tickle it approaches nearer—nearer. I could feel the soft, shivering touch of the lips on the super-sensitive skin of my throat, and the hard dents of two sharp teeth, just touching and pausing there. I closed my eyes in a languorous ecstasy and waited—waited with beating heart.
vi: I didn't dare open my eyes wide, but I continued to look through my eyelashes. Even with that, I could completely see the woman now kneeling, bending closer to me, her face joyful and satisfied. That face revealed a pleasure full of emotion but also truly disgusting; she licked her lips like a hungry animal, so much so that under the clear moonlight, I could even see the slimy saliva on her ruby-colored lips and on the tip of her red tongue sweeping back and forth over her sharp white teeth. She bent lower and lower. I had the feeling she was about to press her chili-red lips against my neck. But no, she stopped, and I suddenly heard a sound, a sound almost like stirring water. It turned out to be the sound of her tongue hitting her teeth and her saliva-filled lips. I felt a hot breath blowing on my neck. The skin on my neck began to get goosebumps as if being caressed by a smooth hand, and what I was feeling was the trembling caress of her lips along with the very light gnashing of her sharp teeth. Pleasure gently passed by, I closed my eyes tightly in a state of ecstasy. Thus, I waited, waited, letting my heart throb and stir.
tr: I was afraid to lift my eyelids, but I looked from under my eyelashes and saw perfectly. The blonde girl knelt down and leaned over me with considerable pleasure. There was a conscious lust in her actions that was both exciting and disgusting, and she licked her lips like an animal as she bent her neck backward; until I saw the wetness shining on her red tongue moving over her crimson lips and sharp white teeth in the moonlight. Her head descended lower and lower, as if her lips were about to slip under my mouth and chin and sink into my throat. Then she stopped, and I could hear the slurping sound her tongue made as she licked her teeth and lips, feeling her hot breath on my neck. Then, the skin of my throat began to shiver as it does when a hand approaches to tickle it. On the overly sensitive skin of my throat, I could feel the soft, chilling touch of her lips and the touch and wait of her sharp teeth. In a state of dizzying ecstasy, I closed my eyes and waited - waited with a pounding heart.
es: I was afraid to lift my eyelids, but I looked and saw perfectly beneath my lashes. The girl knelt and leaned over me, simply rejoicing. There was a deliberate voluptuousness that was both wonderful and repulsive, and at the moment she bent her neck, she licked her lips like an animal, so that I could see the moisture shining on her scarlet lips in the moonlight and the red tongue as it struck her white, sharp teeth. Her head descended and descended as her lips passed along my mouth and chin, and seemed to settle on my throat. Then she paused and I could hear the agitated sound of her tongue licking her teeth and lips, and I could feel the hot breath on my neck. Then the skin of my throat began to tingle as happens to one's flesh when the hand that is going to tickle it comes closer and closer. I could feel the soft, trembling touch of the lips on the supersensitive skin of my throat, and the strong pressure of two sharp teeth, just touching me and stopping there; I closed my eyes in languid ecstasy and waited; I waited with my heart beating strongly.

en: But at that instant, another sensation swept through me as quick as lightning. I was conscious of the presence of the Count, and of his being as if lapped in a storm of fury. As my eyes opened involuntarily I saw his strong hand grasp the slender neck of the fair woman and with giant’s power draw it back, the blue eyes transformed with fury, the white teeth champing with rage, and the fair cheeks blazing red with passion. But the Count! Never did I imagine such wrath and fury, even to the demons of the pit. His eyes were positively blazing. The red light in them was lurid, as if the flames of hell-fire blazed behind them. His face was deathly pale, and the lines of it were hard like drawn wires; the thick eyebrows that met over the nose now seemed like a heaving bar of white-hot metal. With a fierce sweep of his arm, he hurled the woman from him, and then motioned to the others, as though he were beating them back; it was the same imperious gesture that I had seen used to the wolves. In a voice which, though low and almost in a whisper seemed to cut through the air and then ring round the room he said:—
vi: But right at that moment, I had to go through another feeling, a feeling that suddenly flashed like lightning. The old count was standing there as if he had just fallen from the sky. Indeed, when I reluctantly opened my eyes, I saw his iron hand gripping the slender neck of the woman and pulling her back with the tremendous strength of a brutish laborer. The woman's blue eyes flashed with anger, her teeth grinding together like a mad beast. And the old count? Never had I imagined someone swept away by fury like that. His eyes blazed with real flames, I even felt those flames had just erupted from the depths of hell. His face looked ashen like a corpse, his cheeks twitching continuously, his thick eyebrows furrowing together over his nose like a warped rusty iron bar heated to a white glow. He waved his hand, forcefully pushing the woman to the end of the room, then coldly signaled the other two women to immediately leave the room. That was the very same wave of the hand I had seen him use before the pack of wolves that day. In a deep, almost whispering voice, but enough to tear apart the atmosphere in the room, he spoke to the women:
tr: But at that very moment, another feeling spread through me with the speed of lightning. I felt the presence of the Count and that he was caught in a storm of rage. When my eyes involuntarily opened, I saw the Count's strong hand grasping the slender neck of the blonde woman and pulling her back with the strength of a giant, his blue eyes changing with anger, his white teeth clashing with fury, and his pale cheeks burning with passion. But the Count! I had never imagined that even the demons in the pits of Hell could have such wrath and anger. His eyes were absolutely blazing. The red light in his eyes was terrifying; it was as if the fires of Hell were burning behind his eyes. His face was as pale as a corpse and the lines on his face were as taut as tight strings; his thick eyebrows, meeting above his nose, now looked like a rod swollen with molten metal. With a single harsh movement of his arm, he flung the woman away from him and then made a gesture as if to repel them; it was the same commanding hand gesture he used against the wolves. In a voice that was low and almost like a whisper, yet piercing the air and echoing in the room, he said:
es: But at that moment, another sensation ran through me as quickly as lightning. I became aware of the count's presence, and of his existence as if wrapped in a storm of fury. As my eyes involuntarily opened, I saw his strong hand gripping the delicate neck of the blonde woman, and with the power of a giant dragging her backward, with his blue eyes transformed by rage, his white teeth clenched in anger, and his pale cheeks flushed with passion. But the count! I never imagined such an outburst and fury even in the demons of hell. His eyes positively emitted flames. The red light in them was terrifying, as if behind them were the flames of hell itself. His face was deathly pale and its lines were as hard as twisted wires; the thick eyebrows, which met over the nose, now seemed like a lever of white-hot metal. With a fierce movement of his hand, he threw the woman away from him, and then gestured towards the others as if he were repelling them; it was the same imperious gesture I had seen used with the wolves. In a voice that, though low and almost a whisper, seemed to cut through the air and then resonate throughout the room, he said to them:

en: “How dare you touch him, any of you? How dare you cast eyes on him when I had forbidden it? Back, I tell you all! This man belongs to me! Beware how you meddle with him, or you’ll have to deal with me.” The fair girl, with a laugh of ribald coquetry, turned to answer him:—
vi: — How dare you do that to him? Who gave you permission to gawk at him? Get out, I said get out, all of you! This man is under my authority. Don't touch him, or else don't blame me. — But have you ever dared to love?
tr: “With what audacity do any of you dare touch him? How dare you look at him when I have forbidden it? Step back, I tell you! This man belongs to me! Do not mess with him or you will have to deal with me.” The blonde girl, laughing with a suggestive coquetry, replied to the Count:
es: –How dare any of you touch him? How dare you lay your eyes on him when I have forbidden it? Back off, I tell you all! This man belongs to me! Beware of messing with him, or you'll have to deal with me. The blonde girl, with a flirtatious rival laugh, turned to respond to him:

en: “You yourself never loved; you never love!” On this the other women joined, and such a mirthless, hard, soulless laughter rang through the room that it almost made me faint to hear; it seemed like the pleasure of fiends. Then the Count turned, after looking at my face attentively, and said in a soft whisper:—
vi: You don't dare to love, do you? The remaining two laughed gleefully with each other, their laughter was truly joyous, yet also truly harsh and cruel, making me almost faint. Indeed, their laughter was no different from the laughter of demons. Carefully observing me for a moment, the old count then turned and replied, his voice still cold and whispering:
tr: “You never loved yourself; you never love at all!” The other women joined in, and such joyless, harsh, soulless laughter echoed in the room that hearing it almost made me faint; it was like the joy of demons. After carefully looking at my face, the Count turned and said in a soft whisper:
es: –You yourself have never loved; you never love! Upon hearing this, the other women echoed her, and a laughter so gloomy, harsh, and merciless resonated through the room that I almost fainted upon hearing it. It seemed like the pleasure of enemies. Then the count turned after looking intently at my face, and said in a soft whisper:

en: “Yes, I too can love; you yourselves can tell it from the past. Is it not so? Well, now I promise you that when I am done with him you shall kiss him at your will. Now go! go! I must awaken him, for there is work to be done.”
vi: — Yes, I can love too. Then you all will see that. Remember that? I promise you all that after finishing the work with him, I will let you do whatever you want with him! But for now, leave us alone. I have to wake him up, there's still a lot of work waiting for me.
tr: “Yes, I can love too; you yourself can say this by looking at the past. Isn't that so? Yes, now I promise you, when I'm done with him, you will kiss him as you wish. Now go! Go! I must wake him up because there are things to be done.”
es: –Yes, I can also love; you yourselves know it from the past. Isn't that so? Well, now I promise you that when I am done with him, I will let you kiss him as much as you want. Now go, go! I must wake him because there is work to be done.

en: “Are we to have nothing to-night?” said one of them, with a low laugh, as she pointed to the bag which he had thrown upon the floor, and which moved as though there were some living thing within it. For answer he nodded his head. One of the women jumped forward and opened it. If my ears did not deceive me there was a gasp and a low wail, as of a half-smothered child. The women closed round, whilst I was aghast with horror; but as I looked they disappeared, and with them the dreadful bag. There was no door near them, and they could not have passed me without my noticing. They simply seemed to fade into the rays of the moonlight and pass out through the window, for I could see outside the dim, shadowy forms for a moment before they entirely faded away.
vi: — So, we have nothing tonight? - One of the women asked with a laugh, while pointing to the bag the old count had just thrown carelessly on the floor: the bag was moving as if there was a living entity inside. The old count nodded in place of a reply. One of the women immediately jumped forward to open the bag. I believe I heard a faint moan, like the sound of a child about to suffocate. The women gathered around the bag, while I stood frozen in horror. But what terrified me even more was that, somehow, the women had suddenly disappeared with the bag, even though my eyes had not left the floor for a second. Clearly, there were no doors near them, and if they had left in front of me, I would have seen it. They must have vanished with the moonlight through the window, because a moment later, I noticed the familiar shadows just barely outside. A moment later, the three shadows disappeared completely.
tr: One of them pointed to the bag that the Count had thrown to the ground, which moved as if something alive was inside, and said with a low laugh, "Aren't we going to drink anything tonight?" The Count nodded in response, as if to say yes. One of the women sprang forward and opened the bag. If my ears did not deceive me, I heard sounds of labored breathing and moaning, as if from a half-drowned child. While I was frozen with fear, the women gathered around the bag; but when I looked, they had vanished, and the dreadful bag had disappeared with them. There was no door nearby, and they could not have passed by me without my noticing. They seemed to have flown out through the window among the moonbeams, for outside, I could see faint shapes for a moment before they completely vanished.
es: –Aren't we going to have anything tonight? – asked one of them, with a suppressed laugh, while pointing to a bag that he had thrown on the ground and that was moving as if there were something alive inside. In response, he made a nodding gesture. One of the women jumped forward and opened the bag. If my ears did not deceive me, a sigh and a whimper like that of a nursing baby were heard. The women surrounded the bag, while I remained petrified with fear. But when I looked again, they had already disappeared, and with them the horrifying bag. There was no door near them, and it is not possible that they passed over me without me noticing. It seemed that they simply vanished into the moonlight rays and exited through the window, as I could see outside the faint shapes of their shadows, a moment before they disappeared completely.

en: Then the horror overcame me, and I sank down unconscious.
vi: Terror had rendered me lifeless in the realm of unconsciousness.
tr: Then terror overcame me and I lost consciousness.
es: Then horror overwhelmed me, and I sank into unconsciousness.

en: CHAPTER IV
vi: CHAPTER 4
tr: IV
es: IV.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL—continued
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary (continued)
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF JONATHAN HARKER (continued)

en: I AWOKE in my own bed. If it be that I had not dreamt, the Count must have carried me here. I tried to satisfy myself on the subject, but could not arrive at any unquestionable result. To be sure, there were certain small evidences, such as that my clothes were folded and laid by in a manner which was not my habit. My watch was still unwound, and I am rigorously accustomed to wind it the last thing before going to bed, and many such details. But these things are no proof, for they may have been evidences that my mind was not as usual, and, from some cause or another, I had certainly been much upset. I must watch for proof. Of one thing I am glad: if it was that the Count carried me here and undressed me, he must have been hurried in his task, for my pockets are intact. I am sure this diary would have been a mystery to him which he would not have brooked. He would have taken or destroyed it. As I look round this room, although it has been to me so full of fear, it is now a sort of sanctuary, for nothing can be more dreadful than those awful women, who were—who are—waiting to suck my blood.
vi: I woke up in bed. If it is true that I wasn't dreaming last night, then surely the count must have brought me back here. I tried to calm myself, but I couldn't come to any definite conclusion. Obviously, I saw things around me that could serve as evidence: for example, my clothes were carefully folded and placed on a chair, which is not my usual habit. On the other hand, my watch had stopped, even though I always wind it before going to bed. And there were many other details...But no, none of this would mean anything if I had been absent-minded last night, or if some reason had caused my mind to be in a whirl. I need to find concrete evidence. However, there was still one thing that made me happy: if the count was the one who brought me back here, he must have been in a great hurry, because everything in my pockets was still intact. Surely, if he found these diary entries, he wouldn't understand anything, because I write in shorthand. That would annoy him and he would immediately destroy what I had written. Looking around the room, where despite all the anxiety and fear I had experienced, I still felt that this was the only place I could be safe, because nothing was more terrifying than those dreadful women waiting, waiting to suck my blood.
tr: I woke up in my own bed. If I didn't dream, the Count must have carried me here. I tried to find a convincing explanation, but I couldn't reach a definite conclusion. Undoubtedly, there were some small pieces of evidence, like my clothes being folded and placed in a manner that is not my habit. My watch was not wound, and the last thing I would do before going to bed would certainly be to wind it; many other details like this. But these cannot be evidence, as they could be proof that my mind is not as usual and for one reason or another, there is no doubt that I was all mixed up. I must be careful to find evidence. I am pleased about one thing: If the Count carried me here and undressed me, he must have done it in a hurry because my pockets were untouched. I am sure this journal would be an irresistible mystery for him. He would have taken and destroyed it. Although it is filled with fear for me, as I look at my room now, it seems like a kind of refuge because nothing can be more terrifying than those dreadful women waiting to suck my blood -continuing to wait.
es: I woke up in my own bed. If it hasn't all been a dream, the count must have carried me here in his arms. I tried to explain the event to myself, but I couldn't reach any clear conclusion. To be sure, there were certain small pieces of evidence, such as my clothes being folded and arranged in a strange manner. My watch was unwound, and I am strictly accustomed to winding it as the last thing before going to bed, and other similar details. But all these things are not definitive proof, as they could be evidence that my mind was not in its normal state, and, for one reason or another, the truth is that I had been very excited. I have to observe to prove. One thing I am glad about: if it was the count who brought me here and undressed me, he must have done it all quickly, for my pockets were intact. I am sure this diary would have been a mystery he could not have endured. He would have taken it or destroyed it. Looking around this room, although it has been so intimidating to me, I see that it is now a kind of sanctuary, for nothing can be more terrible than those monstrous women who were there - they are waiting to suck my blood.

en: 18 May.—I have been down to look at that room again in daylight, for I must know the truth. When I got to the doorway at the top of the stairs I found it closed. It had been so forcibly driven against the jamb that part of the woodwork was splintered. I could see that the bolt of the lock had not been shot, but the door is fastened from the inside. I fear it was no dream, and must act on this surmise.
vi: • May 18 I want to return to that room in the middle of the day, because I must know the truth at all costs. Upon reaching the top of the stairs, I saw the door to the room was still ajar. Someone had tried to push the door back to its original position against the standing latch, even though the wooden latch was broken. I noticed the door latch was not fastened, and it seemed the door had been closed from the inside. Therefore, I fear that I was not dreaming, and from now on, I am compelled to act, starting from this almost certain fact.
tr: May 18. - I went down to look at that room again in daylight, because I must learn the truth. When I reached the door at the top of the stairs, I saw that it was closed. The frame had been pushed with such great force that the wooden joinery in that part was shattered. I could see the latch tongue inside, but the door was bolted from the inside. I'm afraid what I experienced was not a dream, and I had to act according to this belief.
es: May 18. I've been down there again to take another look at the room, taking advantage of the daylight, for I must know the truth. When I reached the door at the end of the stairs, I found it closed. It had been pushed with such force against the frame that part of the wood had splintered. I could see that the bolt on the door hadn't been slid, but the door is barred from the inside. I'm afraid it wasn't a dream, and I must act according to this assumption.

en: 19 May.—I am surely in the toils. Last night the Count asked me in the suavest tones to write three letters, one saying that my work here was nearly done, and that I should start for home within a few days, another that I was starting on the next morning from the time of the letter, and the third that I had left the castle and arrived at Bistritz. I would fain have rebelled, but felt that in the present state of things it would be madness to quarrel openly with the Count whilst I am so absolutely in his power; and to refuse would be to excite his suspicion and to arouse his anger. He knows that I know too much, and that I must not live, lest I be dangerous to him; my only chance is to prolong my opportunities. Something may occur which will give me a chance to escape. I saw in his eyes something of that gathering wrath which was manifest when he hurled that fair woman from him. He explained to me that posts were few and uncertain, and that my writing now would ensure ease of mind to my friends; and he assured me with so much impressiveness that he would countermand the later letters, which would be held over at Bistritz until due time in case chance would admit of my prolonging my stay, that to oppose him would have been to create new suspicion. I therefore pretended to fall in with his views, and asked him what dates I should put on the letters. He calculated a minute, and then said:—
vi: • May 19 Surely, I have fallen into the count's trap; any hope of escape is just a vain dream. Last night, with a voice like a spell, he made me write three more letters, informing that I am about to finish my work here and will return in a few days, the second letter stating that I will leave here the very next day. The last letter indicates that I have left the castle and am on my way to Bistritz. Honestly, I very much wanted to rebel against this coercion, but upon reflection, I realized it would be madness to discuss the count's goodwill, for at this moment I am entirely in his hands; if I do not comply with his demands, I will make him suspicious and provoke his wrath. He understands that I know too much about him and could become a danger to him. My only chance, if it can still be called that, is to try to prolong the current situation. Who knows, an opportunity might arise that allows me to escape... I have seen the violence in his eyes when he roughly pushed that beautiful woman. He explained to me that the postal service here is very erratic, and the letters would reassure my friends. He also told me that with the last letter I have to write, he would have it held in Bistritz until the exact day I am supposed to return, fearing that my stay here might be prolonged. He spoke with such conviction that merely opening my mouth to protest would be enough to arouse new suspicions in him. So I had to restrain myself. I asked him how I should date the letters, and he replied:
tr: May 19. - It is certain that I have fallen into a trap like an animal. Last night, the Count, with a pleasant but deceptive demeanor, asked me to write three letters: one stating that my work here is almost finished and that I will be heading home in a few days, another saying that I will leave the day after writing the letter, and the third indicating that I have left the castle and arrived in Bistriţa. I wanted to oppose this, but given that I am entirely under his control at the moment, I felt that openly arguing with the Count would be madness, and refusing his request would arouse suspicion and anger him. He knows that I know too much and that I must die so that I won't be a danger to him; my only chance is to bide my time. Something might come up that will give me a chance to escape. A kind of rage, similar to the fury that appeared in his eyes when he threw that blonde woman away from himself, is gathering in his eyes. He said that the postal service is sparse and unreliable, and that writing now would put my friends at ease, and he so insistently assured me that if I had the chance to extend my stay here, he would cancel the forward-dated letters to be held in Bistriţa until the time came, that opposing him would have aroused new suspicions. So I pretended to agree with him and asked what dates I should put on the letters. He calculated for a minute and then said:
es: May 19. It is certain that I am ensnared. Last night the Count asked me, in the gentlest of tones, to write three letters: one saying that my work here was almost finished, and that I would be leaving for home in a few days; another saying that I would be leaving the next morning after writing the letter, and a third stating that I had left the castle and had arrived in Bistritz. I would have gladly protested, but I felt that in the current state of affairs it would be madness to have an altercation with the Count, as I am absolutely in his power; and to refuse would have been to arouse his suspicions and excite his anger. He knows that I know too much, and that I must not live, for it would be dangerous for him; my only chance lies in prolonging my opportunities. Something might happen that gives me a chance to escape. I saw in his eyes some of that anger that manifested when he threw the blonde woman away from him. He explained to me that jobs were few and insecure, and that by writing now I would surely give peace of mind to my friends; and he assured me so insistently that he would send the last letters (which would be held in Bistritz until the opportune time in case chance allowed me to prolong my stay) that opposing him would have created new suspicions. Therefore, I pretended to agree with his points of view and asked him what date I should put on the letters. He calculated for a minute. Then, he said:

en: “The first should be June 12, the second June 19, and the third June 29.”
vi: — The first letter is dated June 12, the second letter is dated June 19, and the third letter is dated June 29.
tr: "The first should be June 12, the second June 19, and the third June 29."
es: –The first one should be on June 12th, the second on June 19th, and the third on June 29th.

en: I know now the span of my life. God help me!
vi: Now I understand how much longer I have to stay here. May God protect me!
tr: Now I know the rest of my life. My God, help me!
es: Now I know how long I will live. God help me!

en: 28 May.—There is a chance of escape, or at any rate of being able to send word home. A band of Szgany have come to the castle, and are encamped in the courtyard. These Szgany are gipsies; I have notes of them in my book. They are peculiar to this part of the world, though allied to the ordinary gipsies all the world over. There are thousands of them in Hungary and Transylvania, who are almost outside all law. They attach themselves as a rule to some great noble or boyar, and call themselves by his name. They are fearless and without religion, save superstition, and they talk only their own varieties of the Romany tongue.
vi: • May 28 Maybe I will find a way to escape, or at least send some news back home. The Gypsies have returned to the castle and camped in the courtyard. I will write a few letters and try to ask them to send them to the post office for me.
tr: May 28. - There is a chance for an escape or at least to send news home. A group of Gypsies came to the castle and set up camp in the courtyard. I have notes about these Gypsies in my notebook. Although they are related to the ordinary Gypsies around the world, they are unique to this part of the world. In Hungary and Transylvania, there are thousands of them, almost all of whom are lawless. As a rule, they attach themselves to a great noble or boyar and take his name. They are fearless, godless except for superstitions, and speak a unique type of the Romanian language.
es: May 28. I am offered an opportunity to escape, or at least to send a few words home. A band of gypsies has come to the castle and camped in the inner courtyard. These are nothing but gypsies; I have certain data about them in my book. They are peculiar to this part of the world, although they are allied with ordinary gypsies in all countries. There are thousands of them in Hungary and Transylvania, almost always living on the fringes of the law. They usually attach themselves to some noble or boyar, and call themselves by his name. They are indomitable and without religion, except for superstition, and only speak their own dialects.

en: I shall write some letters home, and shall try to get them to have them posted. I have already spoken them through my window to begin acquaintanceship. They took their hats off and made obeisance and many signs, which, however, I could not understand any more than I could their spoken language....
vi: I will write a few letters and try to ask them to send them to the post office for me. I have started talking to them from my room window, and we have gotten to know each other. They express their feelings by bowing very low and trying to communicate with me through gestures, which, to be honest, I don't understand at all.
tr: I will try to write a few letters and have these Gypsies mail them. I even spoke to them from my window to establish some sort of acquaintance. They took off their hats, bowed before me, and made many signs that I couldn't understand, just as I couldn't understand their spoken language...
es: I will write some letters to my home and try to convince them to put them in the mail. I have already spoken to them through the window to start getting to know them. They took off their hats and made many bows and gestures, which, however, I could not understand any more than I understand the language they speak...

en: I have written the letters. Mina’s is in shorthand, and I simply ask Mr. Hawkins to communicate with her. To her I have explained my situation, but without the horrors which I may only surmise. It would shock and frighten her to death were I to expose my heart to her. Should the letters not carry, then the Count shall not yet know my secret or the extent of my knowledge....
vi: All the letters have been written. The letter to Mina I still wrote in shorthand, while the letter to Mr. Hawkins, I only asked him to try to contact Mina. I clearly informed my girlfriend of my situation, but did not mention any of the horrors I had experienced. She would be terrified if I even hinted at my circumstances. Therefore, even if these letters do not reach their destination, the Count cannot suspect the extent to which I have grasped his plans.
tr: I wrote the letters. I wrote Mina’s in shorthand and asked Mr. Hawkins to speak only with Mina. I explained my situation to Mina without mentioning the horrors I could only speculate about. If I open my heart to her, it would shake her greatly and she would die of fear. If the letters do not go, the Count will still learn my secret and the extent of what I know.
es: I have written the letters. Mina's in shorthand, and I simply ask Mr. Hawkins to get in touch with her. To her, I have explained my situation, but without the horrors that I can only suppose. If I showed her my heart, it would give her a fright that could even kill her. In case the letters could not be dispatched, the count will not be able to know my secret nor the extent of my knowledge…

en: I have given the letters; I threw them through the bars of my window with a gold piece, and made what signs I could to have them posted. The man who took them pressed them to his heart and bowed, and then put them in his cap. I could do no more. I stole back to the study, and began to read. As the Count did not come in, I have written here....
vi: I threw two letters along with a gold coin out the window to the Gypsies and signaled to them that I wanted them to take the letters to the post office. One of them ran to pick up the letters, pressed them to his chest, then bowed to me as per Gypsy custom, and then he put the letters into his hat. Now, what else can I do but wait? A little later, I wandered into the library to read some books. I am writing these lines before the count arrives...
tr: I gave the letters; I threw them along with a gold coin through the bars of my window and made all the signs I could to ensure they would be mailed. The man who received the letters pressed them to his chest, bowed, and placed them under his hat. There was nothing more I could do. I returned to the study and began to read a book. Since the Count did not come, I started to write here...
es: I have delivered the letters; I threw them through the bars of my window, with a gold coin, and made the signs I could, wanting to indicate that they should be put in the mail. The man who picked them up pressed them against his heart and bowed, and then put them in his cap. I could do no more. I stealthily returned to the library and began to read. Since the count did not come, I have written here…

en: The Count has come. He sat down beside me, and said in his smoothest voice as he opened two letters:—
vi: I am writing these lines before the count arrives... However, I was not allowed to sit alone for long; the old count unexpectedly came to sit beside me and spoke to me in his familiar gentle voice while opening two letters to show me:
tr: The count arrived. He sat next to me and, while opening the two letters, said in the softest voice: “The Gypsies, although I do not know where they came from, gave me these letters which I will of course take an interest in.
es: The count has come. He sat next to me and told me with the softest of voices while opening two letters:

en: “The Szgany has given me these, of which, though I know not whence they come, I shall, of course, take care. See!”—he must have looked at it—“one is from you, and to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other”—here he caught sight of the strange symbols as he opened the envelope, and the dark look came into his face, and his eyes blazed wickedly—“the other is a vile thing, an outrage upon friendship and hospitality! It is not signed. Well! so it cannot matter to us.” And he calmly held letter and envelope in the flame of the lamp till they were consumed. Then he went on:—
vi: — The Gypsies just handed me these papers. Although I don't understand their origin, I have kept them very carefully! Look here... (so he has already seen the letters). This one is yours, addressed to my friend Peter Hawkins; and this one... (upon opening the second letter and seeing the scribbled shorthand, his face darkened, his eyes gleaming with anger and malice)... this one before me is an abomination, it betrays a hospitable friendship! Moreover, it doesn't even have a signature! Therefore, it cannot be related to us. Then he calmly put both the envelope and the letter into the desk lamp's flame. After waiting for the papers to burn completely, he turned to me and said:
tr: He sat next to me and, while opening the two letters, said in the softest voice: “The Gypsies, although I do not know where they came from, gave me these letters which I will of course take an interest in. Look!” - He must have looked inside. “One is from you to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other,” - here, as soon as he opened the letter and saw the strange symbols, a dark expression settled on his face and his eyes flared sinfully - “the other is something vile, a great insult to friendship and hospitality! Unsigned. Yes! So it cannot concern us.” He calmly held the letter and the envelope to the flame of the lamp until they burned. Then he continued his words:
es: –The gypsies have given me these, of which, although I do not know where they come from, I will certainly take care of. Look! (he must have looked at it before), one is for you, and addressed to my friend Peter Hawkins; the other -and here he saw for the first time the strange symbols upon opening the envelope, and a murky look appeared on his face and his eyes gleamed malevolently-, the other is a vile thing, an insult to friendship and hospitality! It is not signed, so it cannot concern us. And then, with great calm, he held the letter and the envelope in the lamp's flame until they were consumed. After that, he continued:

en: “The letter to Hawkins—that I shall, of course, send on, since it is yours. Your letters are sacred to me. Your pardon, my friend, that unknowingly I did break the seal. Will you not cover it again?” He held out the letter to me, and with a courteous bow handed me a clean envelope. I could only redirect it and hand it to him in silence. When he went out of the room I could hear the key turn softly. A minute later I went over and tried it, and the door was locked.
vi: — As for the letter to Mr. Hawkins, which is this remaining letter, I will personally take it to be sent because it is a letter written by you. To me, your letters are something truly sacred. Surely you will forgive me for opening your letter without permission, won't you, my friend? I really didn't know whose letter it was. Will you put the letter back into the envelope for me? The old man bowed his head, looking very polite, and handed me a new envelope. I could only rewrite the address and reluctantly handed it back to him. He bid me farewell and left the library. As soon as the door closed, I suddenly heard the faint sound of a key turning in the lock. It was a while before I dared to go and try to open it, and indeed the door was tightly locked.
tr: “The letter to Hawkins, since it is yours, I will of course send it. Your letters are sacred to me. Forgive me, my friend, for breaking the seal unknowingly. Aren’t you going to seal it again?” He handed me the letter and, bowing politely, gave me a clean envelope. All I could do was rewrite the address and quietly hand the envelope to the Count. When he left the room, I heard the key turn slowly. A minute later, I looked at the door and tried it; it was locked.
es: –The letter for Hawkins, that one, of course, since it is his, I will send it. Your letters are sacred to me. Forgive me, my friend, for unknowingly breaking the seal. Would you like to put it in another envelope? He handed me the letter, and with a courteous bow, he gave me a clean envelope. I could only write the address again and silently returned it to him. When he left the room, I heard the key turn softly. A minute later, I went to it and tried to open it. The door was locked.

en: When, an hour or two after, the Count came quietly into the room, his coming awakened me, for I had gone to sleep on the sofa. He was very courteous and very cheery in his manner, and seeing that I had been sleeping, he said:—
vi: It wasn't until one or two hours later that the old count returned to the library, his face still as calm as ever. I was startled awake, as I had been lying asleep on the couch. He spoke to me in a very cheerful and kind voice.
tr: The Count woke me up by quietly entering the room one or two hours later, because I had fallen asleep on the couch. He was in a very kind and cheerful manner, and upon seeing that I was asleep, he said:
es: When, one or two hours later, the count entered the room silently, his arrival woke me up, as I had fallen asleep on the sofa. He was very courteous and very cheerful in his own way, and seeing that I had slept, he said:

en: “So, my friend, you are tired? Get to bed. There is the surest rest. I may not have the pleasure to talk to-night, since there are many labours to me; but you will sleep, I pray.” I passed to my room and went to bed, and, strange to say, slept without dreaming. Despair has its own calms.
vi: — Tired, aren't you, my friend? Then go to bed and lie down. That's the place where you can sleep the best. Besides, tonight I don't feel like chatting with you, because I have a lot of work to do. Go to sleep, I suggest it to you. I went back to my room to lie down, and strangely enough, I had a very peaceful sleep without any dreams at all. Disappointment had brought with it a soothing remedy.
tr: "So, you are exhausted, my friend. Go to bed. The best rest is there. Since I have a lot of work to do, I might miss the pleasure of talking with you tonight; but please, you sleep." I went to my room and lay down, and strangely enough, I slept without dreaming at all. Despair has its own ways of soothing.
es: –So, my friend, you are tired? Go to your bed. That is where you can rest most safely. I may not have the pleasure of speaking with you tonight, as I have many tasks pending; but I wish you a peaceful sleep.
