I went to my room and lay down on the bed; strange to say, I slept without dreaming. Despair has its own calms.

en: 31 May.—This morning when I woke I thought I would provide myself with some paper and envelopes from my bag and keep them in my pocket, so that I might write in case I should get an opportunity, but again a surprise, again a shock!
vi: • May 31 My first thought when I woke up this morning was to take a few sheets of paper and some envelopes stored in my travel bag and put them in my jacket pocket, so I could take advantage of any opportunity to write during the day. But then another surprise, another shock came to me!
tr: May 31. - This morning, when I woke up, I thought of taking some paper and envelopes from my bag and keeping them in my pocket so that I could write if I got the chance; but again, a surprise, again a shock!
es: May 31. This morning, when I woke up, I thought I would take some papers and envelopes out of my briefcase and put them in my pocket, so that I could write in case I found an opportunity; but once again a surprise awaited me. A big surprise!

en: Every scrap of paper was gone, and with it all my notes, my memoranda, relating to railways and travel, my letter of credit, in fact all that might be useful to me were I once outside the castle. I sat and pondered awhile, and then some thought occurred to me, and I made search of my portmanteau and in the wardrobe where I had placed my clothes.
vi: All my papers had disappeared, from the meaningless ones to the necessary and unnecessary ones for me if I had the chance to leave the castle. Sitting idly for a while, I suddenly remembered to check the remaining suitcase and the wardrobe where I kept my clothes.
tr: All the pieces of paper and along with them all my notes, my notes on railways and travel, my letter of credit, in fact, everything that could be useful to me if I left the castle, was gone. I sat and thought for a while, and then an idea came to my mind; I searched my wardrobe and the coat rack where I had put my clothes.
es: I couldn't find even a piece of paper. Everything had disappeared, along with my notes, my railway and travel-related notes, my credentials. In fact, everything that could be useful to me once I left the castle. I sat down and reflected for a few moments; then an idea occurred to me and I went to look for my light suitcase, and to the wardrobe where I had placed my suits.

en: The suit in which I had travelled was gone, and also my overcoat and rug; I could find no trace of them anywhere. This looked like some new scheme of villainy....
vi: The set of clothes I intended to take with me for the trip was no longer in the wardrobe, and the cloak, travel blanket... had all disappeared as well. I rummaged around aimlessly, but it was all in vain. What kind of scheme is the old man planning with this cat trick?
tr: The suit and coat I wore on my journey, along with my blanket, were gone; I couldn't find any trace of them anywhere. This seemed like a new kind of devilry plan...
es: The suit with which I had made the journey had disappeared, as well as my coat and my blanket; I could not find any trace of them anywhere. This seemed to me a new villainy...

en: 17 June.—This morning, as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains, I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses’ feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard. With joy I hurried to the window, and saw drive into the yard two great leiter-wagons, each drawn by eight sturdy horses, and at the head of each pair a Slovak, with his wide hat, great nail-studded belt, dirty sheepskin, and high boots. They had also their long staves in hand. I ran to the door, intending to descend and try and join them through the main hall, as I thought that way might be opened for them. Again a shock: my door was fastened on the outside.
vi: • June 17 This morning, while sitting absentmindedly on the edge of the bed, I suddenly heard the sound of a whip cracking outside, followed by the clatter of horse hooves on the gravel path leading to the castle courtyard. Feeling a surge of excitement, I rushed to the window and looked down to see two rather large carriages entering, each drawn by eight strong horses, driven by a Slovakian dressed in traditional ethnic attire. I quickly turned towards the door with the intention of running down to the main entrance to get to the courtyard, thinking that surely someone would open the door from that side. But then another shock: the door was locked tight!
tr: June 17. - This morning, while I was sitting on the edge of my bed, straining my mind, I heard the cracking of whips and the pounding of horses' hooves on the stony road beyond the courtyard. In high spirits, I ran to the window and saw two large wagons, each pulled by eight sturdy horses, entering the courtyard, with a Slovak at the head of each pair of horses, wearing a wide hat, a studded belt, dirty sheepskin, and high boots. They also had long sticks in their hands. I ran to the door to join them in the main hall, which I thought might have been opened for them. Another shock: My door was locked from the outside.
es: June 17. This morning, while I was sitting on the edge of my bed racking my brains, I heard outside the cracking of whips and the clattering of horses' hooves along the stone path beyond the courtyard. With joy, I quickly went to the window and saw two large carriages entering the courtyard, each drawn by eight spirited steeds, and at the head of each, a pair of Slovaks wearing wide-brimmed hats, belts studded with large nails, dirty sheepskins, and tall boots. They also carried their long whips in their hands. I ran to the door, trying to go down to catch them in the main corridor, which I thought must be open waiting for them. A new surprise awaited me: my door was bolted from the outside.

en: Then I ran to the window and cried to them. They looked up at me stupidly and pointed, but just then the “hetman” of the Szgany came out, and seeing them pointing to my window, said something, at which they laughed. Henceforth no effort of mine, no piteous cry or agonised entreaty, would make them even look at me. They resolutely turned away. The leiter-wagons contained great, square boxes, with handles of thick rope; these were evidently empty by the ease with which the Slovaks handled them, and by their resonance as they were roughly moved. When they were all unloaded and packed in a great heap in one corner of the yard, the Slovaks were given some money by the Szgany, and spitting on it for luck, lazily went each to his horse’s head. Shortly afterwards, I heard the cracking of their whips die away in the distance.
vi: I had to return to the window and call down to the yard. Everyone looked up at me, pointing and gesturing, looking very surprised. At that moment, the leader of the Gypsy group appeared. Seeing the group intently looking up at the window, he said something that made everyone burst out laughing. So all my efforts were in vain, and now no one even bothered to look up at the window anymore. Two horse-drawn carriages arrived carrying large square chests with handles made of very thick rope. Judging by the way the Slovakians were handling them and the sound of the chests hitting the ground, I guessed they were empty. When everything was piled up in a corner of the yard, the Gypsies paid the Slovakians a few silver coins. After receiving the money, the Slovakians turned their horses around and left. I stood dazed by the window, listening to the sound of the horse hooves fading away until they were completely gone.
tr: Then I ran to the window and called out to them. They looked up at me stupidly and pointed, but just then the hetman of the Gypsies came out and said something to them that made them laugh when he saw them pointing at my window. From then on, no effort, no pitiful cry or painful plea would even make them look at me. They turned and left resolutely. There were large square crates with thick rope handles on the wagons; judging by how easily the Slovaks carried them and the sounds they made when moved roughly, the crates were obviously empty. When all were unloaded from the wagons and piled in a corner of the courtyard, the Gypsy gave the Slovaks some money, and spitting on it for good luck, they lazily went to their horses. Soon after, I heard the crack of their whips fade into the distance.
es: Then, I ran to the window and shouted at them. They looked at me stupidly and pointed towards me, but at that moment the "ataman" of the gypsies came out, and seeing that they were pointing towards my window, he said something, which made them burst into laughter. After that, none of my efforts, no pitiful or agonizing scream moved them to look at me again. Resolutely, they turned their backs on me and walked away. The carts contained large square boxes with thick rope handles; they were evidently empty due to the ease with which the Slovaks unloaded them, and the resonance as they dragged them across the ground. When all were unloaded and piled up in a corner of the courtyard, the Slovaks received some money from the gypsy, and after spitting on it for luck, each went to their respective carriage, walking lazily. Shortly after, I heard the crack of their whips dying away in the distance.

en: 24 June, before morning.—Last night the Count left me early, and locked himself into his own room. As soon as I dared I ran up the winding stair, and looked out of the window, which opened south. I thought I would watch for the Count, for there is something going on. The Szgany are quartered somewhere in the castle and are doing work of some kind. I know it, for now and then I hear a far-away muffled sound as of mattock and spade, and, whatever it is, it must be the end of some ruthless villainy.
vi: • June 24, before dawn Last night, the old count left me quite early to return to his room. After he left, I stealthily hurried up the spiral staircase, intending to spy on him from the south window. I was certain that something was about to happen. The Gypsies had gone off to do something in the castle that I didn't know about, I only knew they were working because occasionally I heard clattering sounds like shovels and picks coming from afar. I had a feeling that this must be a sinful act.
tr: June 24, before sunrise. - The Count left my side early last night and locked himself in his room. As soon as I gathered my courage, I ran to the spiral staircase and looked out the window facing south. I thought of following the Count, because something was going on. The Gypsies were settled somewhere in the castle and were doing some kind of work. I know this because I occasionally hear the muffled sounds of digging and shoveling from afar, and whatever this is, it must be nearing the end of some cruel evil.
es: June 24, before dawn. Last night the Count left me very early and locked himself in his own room. As soon as I dared, I ran up the spiral staircase and looked out the window facing south. I thought I should keep an eye on the Count, for something was happening. The gypsies are camped somewhere in the castle and are doing some work for him. I know this because from time to time I hear in the distance the muffled sound of picks and shovels, and whatever it is, it must be the completion of some horrendous villainy.

en: I had been at the window somewhat less than half an hour, when I saw something coming out of the Count’s window. I drew back and watched carefully, and saw the whole man emerge. It was a new shock to me to find that he had on the suit of clothes which I had worn whilst travelling here, and slung over his shoulder the terrible bag which I had seen the women take away. There could be no doubt as to his quest, and in my garb, too! This, then, is his new scheme of evil: that he will allow others to see me, as they think, so that he may both leave evidence that I have been seen in the towns or villages posting my own letters, and that any wickedness which he may do shall by the local people be attributed to me.
vi: I stood by the window for nearly half an hour when I saw a shadow lurking at the count's window. That dark figure first stuck its head out and then quickly extended its whole body outside. It was none other than the count himself. But this time, he surprised me even more: he was wearing the clothes I had worn during my journey to the castle, and on his shoulder was the terrifying bag that I had seen disappear with the three women. There was no doubt about it, his intention was to use my appearance for some new shady action that I was unaware of. It was indeed an extremely cunning trick of his: he intended to make others think it was me. By doing so, he could prove to everyone that I was also allowed to go to the city post office or the post offices in neighboring villages to send my letters, and from now on, all his vile actions would have my involvement.
tr: When I saw something coming out of the Count's window, I had been at the window for less than half an hour. I pulled back and watched carefully and saw the man's entire body come out. It was a new shock for me to see that the Count was wearing the clothes I wore while traveling here and had slung that dreadful bag, which the women had taken away, over his shoulder. There was no doubt about what he was looking for and that he was doing it in my clothes! So this was the new evil plan: He would make others think they saw me, and thus he could leave traces in the villages and towns of me being seen while posting my own letters, and any mischief he could do would be blamed on me by the local people.
es: I had been looking out the window for a little less than half an hour when I saw something coming out of the count's window. I stepped back and watched carefully, and I saw the man come out. It was a surprise to me to discover that he had put on the suit I had worn during my journey to this place, and that the terrible bag I had seen the women take away was hanging from his shoulder. There could be no doubt about his intentions, and moreover, with my attire! This is, then, his new diabolical trick: he will allow others to see me, so that on one hand there will be evidence that I have been seen in the towns or villages posting my own letters, and on the other hand, any evil he might do will be attributed by the local people to me.

en: It makes me rage to think that this can go on, and whilst I am shut up here, a veritable prisoner, but without that protection of the law which is even a criminal’s right and consolation.
vi: I started to feel furious when I thought about all the tricks of that old man, yet they still continued while I was locked up here, imprisoned like a real prisoner without any protection or shelter.
tr: It angers me to think that this could continue while I am confined here like a real prisoner and deprived of the protection of the law, which is a right and solace even for criminals.
es: It infuriates me to think that this could continue like this, and meanwhile I remain locked up here, like a true prisoner, but without that protection of the law that is even the right and consolation of criminals.

en: I thought I would watch for the Count’s return, and for a long time sat doggedly at the window. Then I began to notice that there were some quaint little specks floating in the rays of the moonlight. They were like the tiniest grains of dust, and they whirled round and gathered in clusters in a nebulous sort of way. I watched them with a sense of soothing, and a sort of calm stole over me. I leaned back in the embrasure in a more comfortable position, so that I could enjoy more fully the aërial gambolling.
vi: I decided to just stand by the window waiting for him to return, as there was nothing that made me want to leave where I was standing. After a while, I was startled when I saw strange little dots dancing with the moonlight. They looked like tiny dust particles swirling around and occasionally gathering together like a small cloud. Looking at those dust particles, I suddenly felt a sense of relief in my heart. I leaned against the window frame to find a more comfortable position to better observe this strange scene.
tr: I thought, let me wait for Kont's return, and I stubbornly sat by the window for a long time. Then, I started to see small strange dots floating in the moonlight. They were like tiny dust particles, and I noticed that they were swirling and coming together like a cloud. I watched them in peace, and a kind of tranquility settled over me. To better enjoy this aerial display, I took a more comfortable position in the window frame and leaned back.
es: I thought I could observe the count's return, and for a long time I sat tenaciously by the window. Then I began to notice that there were small spots of pristine beauty floating in the moonlight. They were like the tiniest particles of dust, swirling in whirlwinds and clustering together in shapes similar to nebulae. I watched them with a feeling of tranquility, and a kind of calm invaded my entire being. I reclined in search of a more comfortable position, so that I could more fully enjoy that ethereal spectacle.

en: Something made me start up, a low, piteous howling of dogs somewhere far below in the valley, which was hidden from my sight. Louder it seemed to ring in my ears, and the floating motes of dust to take new shapes to the sound as they danced in the moonlight. I felt myself struggling to awake to some call of my instincts; nay, my very soul was struggling, and my half-remembered sensibilities were striving to answer the call. I was becoming hypnotised! Quicker and quicker danced the dust; the moonbeams seemed to quiver as they went by me into the mass of gloom beyond. More and more they gathered till they seemed to take dim phantom shapes. And then I started, broad awake and in full possession of my senses, and ran screaming from the place. The phantom shapes, which were becoming gradually materialised from the moonbeams, were those of the three ghostly women to whom I was doomed. I fled, and felt somewhat safer in my own room, where there was no moonlight and where the lamp was burning brightly.
vi: Suddenly, something startled me—the heavy and groaning cries of the pack of dogs echoed from the valley below. Those cries became clearer with each passing moment, and I felt as if the dust particles were transforming into new shapes in response to the distant clamor, though now they were dancing under a weaker moonlight. It seemed as though I was straining to awaken the instincts that always slumbered deep within my subconscious, my living soul struggling to respond to those wild calls. I was being hypnotized by the bizarre scene unfolding right before my eyes! The dust particles danced faster and faster, and the moonbeams also seemed to start dancing near me, then suddenly vanished into the darkness. At this moment, even the moonbeams converged to form eerie shapes. I jolted once more, the sudden shock brought me back to my senses and restored my self-control; I screamed and ran for my life. The eerie shapes gradually separated from the moonlight, and now I could recognize them: they were women, with whom my fate would be intertwined from now on. Only when I reached my room did I feel somewhat relieved: here, the moonlight could not penetrate, and only the lamp illuminated every tiny corner.
tr: Something; distant from my sight, the low, heart-wrenching dog barks coming from down the valley caused me to startle. The barks were ringing louder in my ears, and as the dust particles floating in the air seemed to take on new shapes while dancing in the moonlight, I felt like I was trying to wake up, obeying the call of my instincts; no! My soul was striving for this, and my half-remembered sensitivities wanted to respond to the call. I was being hypnotized! The dust was dancing faster and faster, and as the moonbeams passed by me and moved toward the mass of gloom beyond, they seemed to be vibrating. They gathered even more until they appeared to turn into vague silhouettes. And then, I jolted, fully awakened, and ran away from there, screaming with all my senses in control. The silhouettes, increasingly materializing from the moon's rays, belonged to my ill fate, those three ghost-like women. I fled and somehow felt safer in my room, where the moonlight did not enter, and the lamp was shining brightly.
es: Something startled me; a faint, melancholic howl of dogs somewhere far away in the valley down below that was hidden from my eyes. It sounded louder in my ears, and the floating dust particles took on new shapes, as if they were dancing to the rhythm of a moonlit dance. I felt desperate efforts to awaken to some call of my instincts; no, rather it was my own soul that was struggling and my half-asleep sensitivity trying to respond to the call. They were hypnotizing me! The dust danced more rapidly. The moonbeams seemed to tremble as they passed near me towards the darkness behind me. They joined together until they seemed to take on the faint forms of ghosts. And then I woke up completely and in full possession of my senses, and I started running, screaming and fleeing from the place. The ghostly forms that were gradually materializing from the moonbeams were those of the three ghostly women to whom I was condemned. I fled, and felt somewhat safer in my own room, where there was no moonlight and where the lamp burned brightly.

en: When a couple of hours had passed I heard something stirring in the Count’s room, something like a sharp wail quickly suppressed; and then there was silence, deep, awful silence, which chilled me. With a beating heart, I tried the door; but I was locked in my prison, and could do nothing. I sat down and simply cried.
vi: About two hours later, I suddenly heard a sound that resembled the crying of a baby coming from the old count's room. But then the shrill and muffled cry quickly faded away, returning the atmosphere to a deep, eerie silence that made my skin crawl. I rushed out to open the door, but once again, the door was tightly locked, leaving me completely helpless. I could only collapse onto the bed and cry for my fate.
tr: After a few hours had passed, I heard something stir in the Count's room, something like a sharp cry that was quickly stifled; then silence - a deep and terrible silence that made my hair stand on end. My heart pounding, I tried the door; but I was locked in my cell and there was nothing I could do. I sat down and cried.
es: After a few hours had passed, I heard something moving in the count's room; something like a sharp moan quickly stifled. And then everything fell silent, into a deep and horrible silence that made me shudder. With my heart pounding wildly, I pressed the door; but I found myself locked in my prison, and I could do nothing. I sat down and simply started to cry.

en: As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard without—the agonised cry of a woman. I rushed to the window, and throwing it up, peered out between the bars. There, indeed, was a woman with dishevelled hair, holding her hands over her heart as one distressed with running. She was leaning against a corner of the gateway. When she saw my face at the window she threw herself forward, and shouted in a voice laden with menace:—
vi: That was when I heard a scream in the yard, the painful scream of a woman. I went to the window and looked down; indeed, there was a woman with disheveled hair, clutching her chest and crying out in anguish. Suddenly seeing me at the window, she screamed loudly, her voice full of threats:
tr: While sitting in the courtyard outside, I heard a sound - it was a woman's cry of pain. I ran to the window, opened it, and looked through the bars. Indeed, there was a woman with disheveled hair, looking exhausted from running, holding her hands over her heart. When she saw my face at the window, she lunged forward and shouted in a threatening voice:
es: While I was sitting, I heard a noise outside, in the yard: the agonizing scream of a woman. I ran to the window and, throwing it open, I peered through the bars. Indeed, out there was a woman with disheveled hair, clutching her hands over her heart as if she were the victim of great misfortune. She was leaning against the corner of the hallway. When she saw my face in the window, she lunged forward and shouted in a voice laden with threat:

en: “Monster, give me my child!”
vi: — You devil, give me back my child!
tr: “Monster! Give me my child!””
es: –Monster, give me back my son!

en: She threw herself on her knees, and raising up her hands, cried the same words in tones which wrung my heart. Then she tore her hair and beat her breast, and abandoned herself to all the violences of extravagant emotion. Finally, she threw herself forward, and, though I could not see her, I could hear the beating of her naked hands against the door.
vi: Then she fell to her knees, raising her hands to the sky, mumbling, her shrill voice repeatedly demanding her child. Seeing no one respond, she began tearing her hair, pounding her chest, and performing all sorts of outrageous acts that only those in the utmost agony could do. Finally, she rushed towards the front of the castle. Even though I could no longer see her, I could still hear the mad pounding on the entrance door.
tr: He threw himself on his knees and raised his hands, shouting the same words in tones that wrenched my heart. Then he tore at his hair and beat his chest, surrendering himself to the intensity of exaggerated emotions. Finally, he lunged forward; although I couldn't see him, I could hear him pounding on the door with his bare hands.
es: He fell to his knees, and raising his arms, he shouted some words in tones that tormented my heart. Then he tore his hair and beat his chest, giving in to all the violences of extravagant emotion. Finally, he ran, and although I could not see him, I could hear him pounding on the door with his bare hands.

en: Somewhere high overhead, probably on the tower, I heard the voice of the Count calling in his harsh, metallic whisper. His call seemed to be answered from far and wide by the howling of wolves. Before many minutes had passed a pack of them poured, like a pent-up dam when liberated, through the wide entrance into the courtyard.
vi: At the same time, I heard the voice of the old count, perhaps echoing down from the castle tower. His voice was murmuring, hoarse, and had something like a metallic sound to it. And suddenly from afar, the howling of the wolves rose up as if in response to his call. Indeed, a few minutes later, a pack of wolves suddenly came rushing into the castle courtyard with a force like floodwaters breaching a dam.
tr: Somewhere up high, probably in the tower, I heard the Count calling out with his harsh, metallic whisper. It seemed as though the howling of wolves from afar was answering his call. Before long, a pack of wolves, like a dam releasing its waters, poured into the courtyard through the wide gate.
es: Somewhere quite high above me, probably in the tower, I heard the Count's voice calling in his hard and metallic whisper. His call seemed to be answered from afar and all around by the howling of wolves. Before many minutes had passed, a pack of them entered, like an overflowing dam, through the wide entrance of the courtyard.

en: There was no cry from the woman, and the howling of the wolves was but short. Before long they streamed away singly, licking their lips.
vi: The woman barely had time to scream another sound, and the pack of wolves almost immediately fell silent. In a flash, I saw them retreating in single file, their tongues hanging out, licking their lips.
tr: No scream rose from the woman and the howling of the wolves was short-lived. Before long, they returned one by one, licking their lips.
es: No screams were heard from the woman, and the howls of the wolves lasted only a short time. After a little while, they withdrew one by one, still licking their snouts.

en: I could not pity her, for I knew now what had become of her child, and she was better dead.
vi: Honestly speaking, I have no complaints about that woman, because a misfortunate fate has befallen her child, so it is better to let her go to the afterlife with her unfortunate child.
tr: Since I now knew what had happened to her child, I couldn't pity the woman; it was better for her to die.
es: I did not feel pity for the woman, for I knew what had happened to her son, and it was better that she was dead.

en: What shall I do? what can I do? How can I escape from this dreadful thing of night and gloom and fear?
vi: What should I do now? What can I do now? How can I escape this long, terrifying night?
tr: What will I do? What can I do? How can I escape and get rid of this terrifying captivity of night, gloom, and fear?
es: What will I do? What can I do? How can I escape from this horrifying night of terror and fear?

en: 25 June, morning.—No man knows till he has suffered from the night how sweet and how dear to his heart and eye the morning can be. When the sun grew so high this morning that it struck the top of the great gateway opposite my window, the high spot which it touched seemed to me as if the dove from the ark had lighted there. My fear fell from me as if it had been a vaporous garment which dissolved in the warmth. I must take action of some sort whilst the courage of the day is upon me. Last night one of my post-dated letters went to post, the first of that fatal series which is to blot out the very traces of my existence from the earth.
vi: • June 25, morning Those who have never experienced terrifying dark nights will not be able to appreciate the gentleness and purity of the early morning. This morning, when the early sunlight gently perched on the iron fence right outside my window, I thought a peace dove had just landed there! All my fears disappeared like a mist under the sun. The sunlight restored my courage, so I must act immediately! Last night, one of those dreadful letters, the letters that could erase my existence from this world, the fateful letters the old count forced me to write, was sent.
tr: June 25, morning. - No one knows how sweet and precious the morning can seem to the heart and eyes without bearing the pain of the night. This morning, when the sun rose high enough to strike the top of the large door opposite my window, it seemed to me as if the pigeon on the arch was illuminated at the high point it touched. My fear flowed off me as if it were a garment made of steam, melting away in the heat. I must somehow take action while I have the courage of the day. Last night, one of my future-dated letters was mailed; the first in a deadly series that will erase all traces of my existence from the earth.
es: June 25, in the morning. No one knows until they have suffered the horrors of the night, how sweet and pleasant the arrival of the morning can be for their heart and eyes. When the sun rose this morning high enough to light up the top of the gate opposite my window, the dark place it illuminated seemed to me as if the dove from the ark had been there. My fear evaporated like a vaporous garment dissolving with the heat. I must take action in some way while the courage of the day lasts. Last night one of my already dated letters was put in the mail, the first of that fatal series that is to erase all trace of my existence on earth.

en: Let me not think of it. Action!
vi: It is best not to think too much about them, but to find a way to act?
tr: I shouldn't think about this. It's time for action!
es: I must not think about it. I must act!

en: It has always been at night-time that I have been molested or threatened, or in some way in danger or in fear. I have not yet seen the Count in the daylight. Can it be that he sleeps when others wake, that he may be awake whilst they sleep? If I could only get into his room! But there is no possible way. The door is always locked, no way for me.
vi: During my entire stay at the castle, every night I felt threats, in one way or another, weighing heavily on me, forcing me to believe that I was always facing a danger. One very strange thing is that since I arrived here, I have not seen the Count even once during the day. Could it be that he sleeps while others are awake, and only wakes when others have slept? How strange! How wonderful it would be if I could sneak into his room! But that is impossible. His room is always locked, there is no way...
tr: The times I was harassed or threatened or somehow fell into danger or fear were always at night. I have not yet seen the Count in daylight. Could he be sleeping while others are awake and awake while they are sleeping? Ah, if only I could enter the room! But this is not possible. The door is always locked, there is no way I can go.
es: It has always been during the night when I have been disturbed or threatened; where I have found myself in some way or another in danger or afraid. I still have not seen the count in the daylight. Is it possible that he sleeps when others are awake, and that he is awake when everyone sleeps? If only I could get to his room! But there is no possible way. The door is always locked; there is no way for me to reach him. I lie.

en: Yes, there is a way, if one dares to take it. Where his body has gone why may not another body go? I have seen him myself crawl from his window. Why should not I imitate him, and go in by his window? The chances are desperate, but my need is more desperate still. I shall risk it. At the worst it can only be death; and a man’s death is not a calf’s, and the dreaded Hereafter may still be open to me. God help me in my task! Good-bye, Mina, if I fail; good-bye, my faithful friend and second father; good-bye, all, and last of all Mina!
vi: No, there is still a way, but the question is whether I dare to do it or not. The way the Count uses to sneak outside, why can't I do the same? I have seen him crawl through the window several times. Why can't I sneak into his room through that window? This is indeed a very difficult task, but my current situation is much more desperate. I will take a risk. The worst that could happen to me is death. But the death of a human is not the death of an animal, and perhaps God will grant me eternal life. God will bless me! Mina, farewell if I do not return. Farewell to my faithful friend, who always regarded me as a second father. Finally, farewell to all. Mina, once again, farewell!
tr: Yes, if one dares, there is a way. Why shouldn't another body go the way his body went? I saw with my own eyes that he crawled out of his window; why shouldn't I emulate him and crawl in through the window? The chances are slim, but my situation is more hopeless than my chances. I will take the risk. The worst that could happen is death. Human death is not like the death of a calf, and the terror of the "Other World" may still be open to me. God, help me in my duty! If I fail, goodbye Mina; goodbye my loyal friend and second father; farewell to you all and lastly, Mina!
es: There is a way, if one dares to take it. Where his body has passed, why can't another body pass? I myself have seen him crawl from his window. Why can't I imitate him, and crawl to enter through his window? The odds are very slim, but necessity forces me to take all risks. I will take the risk. The worst that can happen to me is death; but the death of a man is not the death of a calf, and the dark "beyond" might still offer me opportunities. May God help me in my endeavor! Goodbye, Mina, if I fail; goodbye, my faithful friend and second father; goodbye, everything, and as the last thing, goodbye Mina!

en: Same day, later.—I have made the effort, and God, helping me, have come safely back to this room. I must put down every detail in order. I went whilst my courage was fresh straight to the window on the south side, and at once got outside on the narrow ledge of stone which runs around the building on this side. The stones are big and roughly cut, and the mortar has by process of time been washed away between them. I took off my boots, and ventured out on the desperate way. I looked down once, so as to make sure that a sudden glimpse of the awful depth would not overcome me, but after that kept my eyes away from it. I knew pretty well the direction and distance of the Count’s window, and made for it as well as I could, having regard to the opportunities available. I did not feel dizzy—I suppose I was too excited—and the time seemed ridiculously short till I found myself standing on the window-sill and trying to raise up the sash. I was filled with agitation, however, when I bent down and slid feet foremost in through the window. Then I looked around for the Count, but, with surprise and gladness, made a discovery. The room was empty! It was barely furnished with odd things, which seemed to have never been used; the furniture was something the same style as that in the south rooms, and was covered with dust. I looked for the key, but it was not in the lock, and I could not find it anywhere. The only thing I found was a great heap of gold in one corner—gold of all kinds, Roman, and British, and Austrian, and Hungarian, and Greek and Turkish money, covered with a film of dust, as though it had lain long in the ground. None of it that I noticed was less than three hundred years old. There were also chains and ornaments, some jewelled, but all of them old and stained.
vi: • That same morning, a little while later So I managed to get down there, and by the grace of God, I returned to my room without a scratch. I will explain everything in detail right now. At that moment, I don't know why I was so brave! I walked towards the southern window of the castle and immediately climbed onto the narrow stone ledge running along the outer wall. The stones on the outer edge of the wall were very large and only roughly hewn; as I mentioned, the mortar joints were weathered and crumbling with age. Setting foot on these precarious stone ledges meant embarking on a deadly adventure. After climbing a few steps, I tried to look down at the deep abyss below the castle to see if I would get dizzy, but clearly, I didn't dare do so for more than a second. I had completely determined the position of the count's window and tried to climb there as quickly as possible. The precariousness of the wall's edge didn't make me dizzy, as I always tried to look straight ahead. And in what seemed to me to be a very short time, I had climbed to the ledge of the count's window shutter. After pushing the door open, I bent my body, stuck my legs in first, and then slid into the room. I furtively looked around, and luckily the old count was not in the room. There wasn't much furniture down here, just a few rickety wooden items that seemed like they were never used; each one was covered in dust, some looking very similar to the ones I had seen in the rooms in the southern wing of the castle. I immediately thought of the key, but it was not in the lock, and I couldn't find it anywhere. My attention was drawn to a heap of gold coins piled high in the corner of the room - they were coins of various kinds from Romania, England, Austria, Hungary, Greece. These coins seemed to have been there for a long time as they were covered with a thick layer of dust. All of them were ancient coins dating back at least three hundred years. I also noticed a few necklaces and some art pieces inlaid with more or less gemstones, but these items were all very old and damaged.
tr: The same day, later. - I did my best and, with God's help, I returned safely to this room. I must write down all the details in order. While my courage was still fresh, I went straight to the window on the south side of the castle and immediately stepped out onto the narrow stone ledge that surrounds this side of the building. The stones were large and roughly cut, and the mortar between them had worn away over time. I took off my boots and embarked on this desperate path. So that I wouldn't suddenly see the terrifying depth and succumb to it, I looked down once, but then kept my eyes away from it. I knew the direction and the distance to the Count's window quite well, and I aimed there as best as I could to seize the opportunity. I didn't get dizzy - I think I was too excited - the time it took until I found myself standing at the window ledge trying to open the sash seemed ridiculously short. But I tensed up when I leaned in and my feet first slipped inside the window. Then I looked around for the Count but discovered something with surprise and delight. The room was empty! It was furnished with a few odd items that looked as if they had never been used; the furniture in the room was in the same style as the rooms in the south wing and was covered in dust. I searched for the key but it wasn't in the lock and I couldn't find it anywhere. The only thing I found instead was a large pile of gold in one of the corners - all sorts of gold coins, covered with a layer of dust as if they had been lying there for a long time, from Rome, England, Austria, Hungary, Greece, and Turkey. Among those that caught my attention, none were less than three hundred years old. There were also chains and ornaments adorned with precious stones, but they were all old and tarnished.
es: Same day, later. I made the effort, and with God's help I returned safely to this room. I must write down every detail in order. I went, while my courage was still fresh, directly to the window on the south side, and went out from there. The stones are large and roughly cut, and over time the mortar has worn away. I took off my boots and ventured like a desperate man. I looked down once, as if to make sure that a sudden glance at the horrifying depth would not overwhelm me, but after that I kept my eyes looking forward. I know the count's window quite well, and I headed towards it as best as I could, taking advantage of the opportunities that presented themselves. I did not feel dizzy, I suppose I was too nervous, and the time it took me to reach the windowsill seemed ridiculously short. In a flash, I found myself trying to lift the sash window. However, when I slid feet first through the window, I was seized by a terrible agitation. Then I looked everywhere for the count, but, with surprise and joy, I made a discovery: the room was empty! It was barely furnished with strange things that seemed never to have been used; the furniture was somewhat similar in style to those in the rooms situated to the south, and they were covered in dust. I looked for the key, but it was not in the lock, and I couldn't find it anywhere. The only thing I found was a large pile of gold in a corner, gold of all kinds, in Roman and British coins, Austrian and Hungarian, Greek and Turkish. The coins were covered with a film of dust, as if they had lain on the ground for a long time. None of the ones I noticed were less than three hundred years old. There were also chains and ornaments, some jeweled, but all old and faded.

en: At one corner of the room was a heavy door. I tried it, for, since I could not find the key of the room or the key of the outer door, which was the main object of my search, I must make further examination, or all my efforts would be in vain. It was open, and led through a stone passage to a circular stairway, which went steeply down. I descended, minding carefully where I went, for the stairs were dark, being only lit by loopholes in the heavy masonry. At the bottom there was a dark, tunnel-like passage, through which came a deathly, sickly odour, the odour of old earth newly turned. As I went through the passage the smell grew closer and heavier. At last I pulled open a heavy door which stood ajar, and found myself in an old, ruined chapel, which had evidently been used as a graveyard. The roof was broken, and in two places were steps leading to vaults, but the ground had recently been dug over, and the earth placed in great wooden boxes, manifestly those which had been brought by the Slovaks. There was nobody about, and I made search for any further outlet, but there was none. Then I went over every inch of the ground, so as not to lose a chance. I went down even into the vaults, where the dim light struggled, although to do so was a dread to my very soul. Into two of these I went, but saw nothing except fragments of old coffins and piles of dust; in the third, however, I made a discovery.
vi: I walked towards a heavy door that had just been discovered in a corner of the room, because I couldn't find the room key or the castle key. This is something I must not forget and is my main search objective, so I had to rummage around and explore randomly; otherwise, my recent adventurous journey would be of no use at all. This door opened to a corridor with walls entirely built of stone, leading to a spiral staircase. I cautiously stepped down, as this steep staircase was only illuminated by two arrow slits on a very thick wall. At the bottom of the stairs, I found myself in another dark corridor, a real tunnel, filled with a sour, pungent smell that reminded me of the scent of corpses—a smell rising from freshly dug earth. The deeper I went, the stronger that smell became, making it almost unbearable. Finally, I flung open another very thick door in the corridor. I was standing in front of an ancient, dilapidated church, where bodies must have been buried. The church roof was full of holes, and there were many steps on both sides of the walls leading to the crypts. I noticed the freshly dug earth and shovels of dirt filling large scattered crates around: these were surely the wooden crates that the Slovak men had just transported. There was no one in the church. I continued to grope around: who knows, maybe there was an exit inside? No, there was no exit at all. I continued to inspect more thoroughly. And despite my great disgust, I still barged into the crypts, where faint light was emanating. In the first two crypts, I found nothing but fragments of old coffins and dust. Entering the third crypt, I suddenly jumped when I discovered something.
tr: There was a heavy door in one corner of the room. I tried this door because I needed to investigate further, having not found the key to the room or the key to the outer door, which were the main subjects of my research, or all my efforts would be in vain. The door was open and led to a stone corridor that descended steeply to a spiral staircase. Since the steps were dark, illuminated only by the loopholes in the heavy stone walls, I descended carefully, watching my step. At the bottom, there was a dark, tunnel-like corridor from which emanated a deadly, nauseating smell, like the scent of old, overturned earth. As I progressed down the corridor, the smell grew closer and heavier. Finally, I opened the heavy door that was ajar and found myself in an old, abandoned chapel that was evidently used as a cemetery. The roof had collapsed, and there were steps leading down to underground tombs in two places, but the ground had been recently dug up, and the soil had clearly been filled into large wooden crates brought by the Slovaks. There was no one around, so I searched for another exit but found none. Then, to leave no stone unturned, I scanned every square inch of the floor. Despite my terror, I even descended into the dimly lit burial chambers where the light flickered. I entered two of them but saw nothing except old coffin fragments and piles of dust; however, in the third one, I discovered something.
es: In one corner of the room, there was a heavy door. I pushed it, for since I could not find the key to the room or the key to the outer door, which was the main objective of my search, I had to make other investigations, or all my efforts would be in vain. The door I pushed was open, and it led me through a stone passageway to a very steep spiral staircase. I descended, taking great care where I stepped, for the steps were dark, being lit only by the loopholes in the heavy masonry. At the bottom, there was a dark passageway, similar to a tunnel, through which a deadly and sickly smell could be perceived: the smell of freshly turned earth. As I advanced through the passageway, the smell became more intense and closer. Finally, I opened a heavy door that was ajar and found myself in an old and ruined chapel, which had evidently been used as a cemetery. The ceiling was cracked, and in places, there were steps leading to vaults, but the ground had been recently dug up, and the earth had been placed in large wooden boxes, evidently the ones the Slovaks had transported. There was no one around, and I made a thorough search of every inch of the ground. I even went down into the vaults, where the dim light struggled with the shadows, though in doing so, my soul was filled with the most terrible horror. I went to two of them, but saw nothing but fragments of old coffins and piles of dust; however, in the third, I made a discovery.

en: There, in one of the great boxes, of which there were fifty in all, on a pile of newly dug earth, lay the Count! He was either dead or asleep, I could not say which—for the eyes were open and stony, but without the glassiness of death—and the cheeks had the warmth of life through all their pallor; the lips were as red as ever. But there was no sign of movement, no pulse, no breath, no beating of the heart. I bent over him, and tried to find any sign of life, but in vain. He could not have lain there long, for the earthy smell would have passed away in a few hours. By the side of the box was its cover, pierced with holes here and there. I thought he might have the keys on him, but when I went to search I saw the dead eyes, and in them, dead though they were, such a look of hate, though unconscious of me or my presence, that I fled from the place, and leaving the Count’s room by the window, crawled again up the castle wall. Regaining my room, I threw myself panting upon the bed and tried to think....
vi: The old count was lying heavily on a chest placed on a pile of freshly dug earth? I couldn't tell if he was dead or sleeping, as his eyes were still wide open, lifeless like stone eyes, but not dull like those of a dead person. His cheeks, though ashen, seemed to still retain the warmth of life, and his lips were still as red as they usually were. However, his body was completely motionless, showing no signs of breathing, and his heart seemed to have stopped beating in his chest. Despite this, I still bent down with the hope that he had just lain there, as the smell of the earth was still very fresh. The lid of the chest, full of holes, was propped up against the pile of earth. I thought the keys might be kept in the pockets of the clothes he was wearing, but when I intended to approach him to search, I lost my nerve. Clearly, in my presence, his eyes remained lifeless and showed no sign of awareness, yet the lingering hatred in those wide-open eyes made me immediately flee, return to his room, climb out the window, and crawl back up the wall. When I got back to my room, I collapsed on the bed, breathing heavily. I tried to piece together all my thoughts.
tr: Count was lying on top of a freshly dug mound of earth inside one of the large chests, which were about fifty in total! He was either dead or sleeping, I couldn't tell which, because his eyes were open and rigid - but there was no glassy look that comes with death - despite his pallor, there was a warmth of life in his cheeks and his lips were as red as ever. However, there was no sign of movement, pulse, breath, or heartbeat. I leaned over him and tried to find a sign of life, but it was in vain. He couldn't have been lying here for long because the smell of the earth would have dissipated within a few hours. Next to the chest, the lid, which had holes drilled here and there, was lying. I thought the keys might be on him, but when I started to search, I saw such a look of hatred in his dead eyes - even though they were dead, they were not aware of me or my presence - that I fled from there and left the Count's room through the window, crawling along the castle walls again. I returned to my room, threw myself onto the bed, breathless, and tried to think...
es: There, in one of the large boxes, of which there were fifty in total, on a pile of freshly dug earth, lay the count! He was either dead or asleep; I couldn't tell for sure, for his eyes were open and fixed, but with the glassiness of death, and his cheeks had the warmth of life despite their paleness; moreover, his lips were redder than ever. But there was no sign of movement, no pulse, no breath, no heartbeat. I leaned over him and tried to find some sign of life, but in vain. He could not have been lying there for long, for the smell of earth would have dissipated in a few hours. Next to the box was its lid, pierced with holes here and there. I thought he might have the keys with him, but as I was about to search him, I saw his dead eyes, and in them, despite being dead, a look of such hatred, though unconscious of me or my presence, that I fled the place, and leaving the count's room through the window, I slid down the castle wall again. Upon reaching my room again, I threw myself panting onto the bed and tried to think…

en: 29 June.—To-day is the date of my last letter, and the Count has taken steps to prove that it was genuine, for again I saw him leave the castle by the same window, and in my clothes. As he went down the wall, lizard fashion, I wished I had a gun or some lethal weapon, that I might destroy him; but I fear that no weapon wrought alone by man’s hand would have any effect on him. I dared not wait to see him return, for I feared to see those weird sisters. I came back to the library, and read there till I fell asleep.
vi: • June 29 Today is the day I send my last letter. The old count surely hasn't forgotten about this, for once again I saw him leave the castle through the window, while still wearing my clothes. Watching him crawl down the wall like a lizard, I had only one desire: to grab a gun or any deadly weapon and give him a shot! Although I don't know if such a weapon would have any effect on him. I didn't dare to wait for his return, because at this moment I was truly afraid of seeing the deadly trio once again. I went back to the library to find a book to read for distraction; but after a short while, I fell asleep.
tr: June 29. - Today is the day of my last letter, and the Count has taken the necessary steps to prove it is real because I saw him leaving the castle again through the same window and in my clothes. I wished I had a gun or a deadly weapon to destroy him as he descended the wall like a lizard; but I fear that no weapon made by human hands can have any effect on him. I did not dare to wait for the Count's return because I was afraid of seeing those strange sisters. I returned to the library and read books there until I fell asleep.
es: June 29. Today is the date of my last letter, and the count has taken the necessary steps to prove it is authentic, for I have again seen him leave the castle through the same window and wearing my clothes. Seeing him slide through the window, like a lizard, I felt the urge to have a rifle or some lethal weapon to destroy him; but I fear that no weapon wielded solely by the hand of a man can have any effect on him. I did not dare to wait for his return, as I feared seeing his wicked sisters. I returned to the library and read until I fell asleep.

en: I was awakened by the Count, who looked at me as grimly as a man can look as he said:—
vi: The appearance of the count woke me up. He spoke to me, his voice full of menace:
tr: I was awakened by the Count, who was looking at me with the wildest expression a person could have; he said:
es: I was awakened by the count, who looked at me as grimly as a man can look, while he said to me:

en: “To-morrow, my friend, we must part. You return to your beautiful England, I to some work which may have such an end that we may never meet. Your letter home has been despatched; to-morrow I shall not be here, but all shall be ready for your journey. In the morning come the Szgany, who have some labours of their own here, and also come some Slovaks. When they have gone, my carriage shall come for you, and shall bear you to the Borgo Pass to meet the diligence from Bukovina to Bistritz. But I am in hopes that I shall see more of you at Castle Dracula.” I suspected him, and determined to test his sincerity. Sincerity! It seems like a profanation of the word to write it in connection with such a monster, so asked him point-blank:—
vi: — My friend, tomorrow we will bid each other farewell. You will return to your beautiful England. In the future, we may not meet again. The letter you wrote to your loved ones has been sent to the post office. Tomorrow I will not be here, but everything necessary for your journey has been meticulously prepared. The Gypsies will come here in the morning, as they have work to do, and so will the Slovak people. When they leave, my carriage will come to find you and take you to the Borgo Pass, where you will catch the coach to Bistritz. But in any case, I still hope to have the pleasure of welcoming you again at Dracula's castle! Hearing that, I decided to test how honest the old count really was. I felt as if I was desecrating this thought by imagining a demon. I suddenly asked him:
tr: “Tomorrow, my friend, we must part. You return to your beautiful England, and I will return to some of my affairs which may result in us never meeting again. The letter you wrote home has been sent; I will not be here tomorrow, but everything will be ready for your journey. In the morning, Gypsies and Slovaks who have some business here will arrive. When they leave, my carriage will come to pick you up and take you to the Borgo Pass to meet the coach going from Bistriţa to Bukovina. But I hope to see you more at Dracula’s Castle.” I was suspicious of him and decided to test his sincerity. Sincerity! It would be disrespectful to write this word in association with such a monster; so I asked him directly: “Why can’t I leave this evening?”
es: –Tomorrow, my friend, we must depart. You will return to your beautiful England, I to a job that may have such an end that we may never meet again. Your letter home has been dispatched; tomorrow I will not be here, but everything will be ready for your journey. In the morning the gypsies come, who have some tasks of their own, and the Slovaks also come. When they have left, my carriage will come to take you and will bring you to the Borgo Pass, to meet there with the coach that goes from Bukovina to Bistritz. But I hope that we will meet again in Dracula's castle. I suspected his words, and decided to test his sincerity. Sincerity! It seems like a desecration of the word in connection with a monster like this, so I spoke to him bluntly:

en: “Why may I not go to-night?”
vi: — Why can't I leave tonight?
tr: It would be disrespectful to write this word in association with such a monster; so I asked him directly: “Why can’t I leave this evening?”
es: –Why can't I leave tonight?

en: “Because, dear sir, my coachman and horses are away on a mission.”
vi: — My dear friend, because my coachman and the horses are all currently occupied.
tr: “Because, dear sir, my coachman and my horses are not here as they have work to do.”
es: –Because, dear sir, my coachman and the horses have gone on a mission.

en: “But I would walk with pleasure. I want to get away at once.” He smiled, such a soft, smooth, diabolical smile that I knew there was some trick behind his smoothness. He said:—
vi: — But I would be very pleased if that were the case. To be honest with you, I want to leave here immediately. The old man smiled, a smile that was both gentle and mischievous, a smile in which I could easily discern the dark intentions hidden behind that chilling gentleness. — What about your luggage, sir? -
tr: "But I will walk gladly. I want to get away as soon as possible." He smiled; it was such a soft, calm, and devilish smile that I knew there was a kind of trick beneath its softness. He said:
es: –But I would gladly walk. What I want is to get out of here as soon as possible. He smiled, with a smile so soft, delicate, and devilish, that I immediately knew there was some trick behind his kindness; he said:

en: “And your baggage?”
vi: He asked.
tr: “What about your suitcases?”
es: –And your luggage?

en: “I do not care about it. I can send for it some other time.”
vi: — It doesn't matter. - I replied. - I can get it later.
tr: "I don't care. I can have them picked up later."
es: –I don't care. I can send someone to pick it up later.

en: The Count stood up, and said, with a sweet courtesy which made me rub my eyes, it seemed so real:—
vi: The old man stood up and bowed to me, his gesture was so polite that I almost had to rub my eyes because I couldn't believe he could be so sincere.
tr: The count stood up and, with a sweetness that caused me to rub my eyes and seemed quite real, said:
es: The count stood up and said, with a sweet courtesy that made me rub my eyes, as it seemed real:

en: “You English have a saying which is close to my heart, for its spirit is that which rules our boyars: ‘Welcome the coming; speed the parting guest.’ Come with me, my dear young friend. Not an hour shall you wait in my house against your will, though sad am I at your going, and that you so suddenly desire it. Come!” With a stately gravity, he, with the lamp, preceded me down the stairs and along the hall. Suddenly he stopped.
vi: — Your English people have a proverb that I really like, because it clearly reflects the spirit in the behavior of those of us from noble lineage: "Please the guest who comes, satisfy the guest who leaves!" Follow me, my dear young friend, you will not have to stay here another hour reluctantly, although I am truly sad to part with you and when you are so eager to leave early. Here again? The old man solemnly held the lamp and led me down the stairs, then continued towards the main door of the castle. But when we reached the middle of the hallway, he suddenly stopped.
tr: “You English have a saying that greatly appeals to me because it governs our boyars: ‘Welcome the arrival of the guest, hasten their departure.’ Come with me, my dear young friend. Although I am saddened by your departure and your sudden desire for it, do not stay in my home for even an hour against your will. Come!” With a lamp in hand, he descended the stairs with majestic dignity and proceeded ahead of me down the corridor. Suddenly, he stopped.
es: –You English have a saying that is dear to my heart, for its spirit is the same that governs our boyars: "Welcome the coming, speed the parting guest." Come with me, my dear young friend. Not one more hour will you stay in my house against your wishes, though it saddens me that you are leaving, and that you wish it so suddenly. Come. With majestic seriousness, he, with the lamp, preceded me up the stairs and along the corridor. Suddenly, he stopped.

en: “Hark!”
vi: — Listen! -
tr: “Listen!”
es: –Listen!

en: Close at hand came the howling of many wolves. It was almost as if the sound sprang up at the rising of his hand, just as the music of a great orchestra seems to leap under the bâton of the conductor. After a pause of a moment, he proceeded, in his stately way, to the door, drew back the ponderous bolts, unhooked the heavy chains, and began to draw it open.
vi: He told me. There was the howl of a pack of wolves not far from the castle. He raised his hand, and it seemed that the howls rose in unison with his gesture, like an orchestra obeying the conductor's baton. A moment later, still with that majestic demeanor, he continued walking. Upon reaching the castle gate, he pulled out the latch, dragged down the heavy chains, and slowly opened the door.
tr: The howling of many wolves was heard up close. The sound had almost begun with the raising of the Count's hand, just like the music of a large orchestra under the direction of a conductor. After a momentary hesitation, he advanced to the door with his majestic demeanor, pulled the heavy bolts, removed the heavy chains from their hooks, and began to open the door.
es: The howling of the wolves reached us from nearby. It was almost as if the howls arose when he raised his hand, similar to how music emerges from a great orchestra when the conductor's baton is lifted. After a moment of pause, he continued, in his majestic manner, towards the door. He slid the enormous bolts, unlocked the heavy chains, and began to open it.

en: To my intense astonishment I saw that it was unlocked. Suspiciously, I looked all round, but could see no key of any kind.
vi: I was surprised: the door was not locked. Not believing it to be true, I looked around in bewilderment, but still saw no sign of a key.
tr: I saw with great astonishment that the door was not locked. I looked around with suspicion, but I couldn't see anything resembling a key.
es: To my incredible astonishment, I saw that it was unlocked. Suspiciously, I looked all around me, but I couldn't find any kind of key.

en: As the door began to open, the howling of the wolves without grew louder and angrier; their red jaws, with champing teeth, and their blunt-clawed feet as they leaped, came in through the opening door. I knew then that to struggle at the moment against the Count was useless. With such allies as these at his command, I could do nothing. But still the door continued slowly to open, and only the Count’s body stood in the gap. Suddenly it struck me that this might be the moment and means of my doom; I was to be given to the wolves, and at my own instigation. There was a diabolical wickedness in the idea great enough for the Count, and as a last chance I cried out:—
vi: The wider the door opened, the more ferocious the wolves' howls became. The beasts, each one baring its teeth and sticking out its blood-red tongue, looked very menacing, with some even grinding their teeth. I had no idea when they appeared outside the door. I suddenly realized I couldn't resist the count's will. What could I do to oppose him, when he had such terrifying allies? However, the door continued to open slowly, and the count calmly stood right at the threshold. A thought suddenly flashed through my mind: perhaps my destined hour had come; I would be thrown out as prey for the wolves, because I wished it so. This insidious move must have greatly pleased the count. And as if there were no other choice, I was forced to cry out in search of one last stroke of luck:
tr: As the door began to open, the howling of the wolves outside grew louder and filled with rage; with their red jaws and blunt-clawed feet, they entered through the opening door. At that moment, I realized that it was useless to oppose the Count. With such allies at his command, I could do nothing. Yet still, the door continued to open slowly, and in the gap stood only the body of the Count. Suddenly, it dawned on me that this could be the moment and method of my demise; I would be given to the wolves, and it would be as a result of my own suggestion. There was a diabolical evil in this, worthy of the Count, and I cried out for one last chance:
es: As the door began to open, the howls of the wolves increased in intensity and fury: through the opening of the door, their red jaws with sharp teeth and the claws of their heavy paws could be seen as they leaped. I realized that it was useless to fight against the count at that moment. Nothing could be done with him having such allies under his command. However, the door continued to open slowly, and now it was only the count's body that was blocking the way. Suddenly, the idea came to me that perhaps this was the moment and the means of my condemnation; I was going to be handed over to the wolves, and at my own instigation. There was a diabolical wickedness in the idea, sufficiently grand for the count, and as a last chance, I shouted:

en: “Shut the door; I shall wait till morning!” and covered my face with my hands to hide my tears of bitter disappointment. With one sweep of his powerful arm, the Count threw the door shut, and the great bolts clanged and echoed through the hall as they shot back into their places.
vi: — Close the door! I will wait! So, I will go in the morning? Having said only that, I covered my face with my hands to hide the bitter, despairing tears. The iron hand of the old count pulled the heavy door shut and latched the bolts, the clanking of metal echoing dully in the hallway.
tr: “Close the door; I will wait until morning!” And then, to hide the tears caused by bitter disappointment, I covered my face with my hands. The Count closed the door with a single movement of his strong arm, the large bolts clanged and settled into place, the sound echoing down the corridor.
es: –Close the door! I'll wait until tomorrow! I covered my face with my hands to hide the tears of bitter disappointment. With a movement of his powerful arm, the count slammed the door shut, and the large bolts clanged and echoed through the corridor as they fell back into place.

en: In silence we returned to the library, and after a minute or two I went to my own room. The last I saw of Count Dracula was his kissing his hand to me; with a red light of triumph in his eyes, and with a smile that Judas in hell might be proud of.
vi: No one said a word to each other, we returned to the library, but seeing no reason to stay there, I went straight back to my room. The last time I looked back at Count Dracula, I saw him just raise his hand to blow me a kiss, his eyes gleaming with a triumphant look along with a sinister smile that even the devil Judas would be proud of.
tr: We returned to the library in silence; a minute or two later, I went to my own room. The last time I saw Count Dracula, he was looking at me with a red glint of triumph in his eyes and a smile that could have made Judas in Hell proud, kissing his own hand.
es: We returned to the library in silence, and after one or two minutes I went to my room. The last thing I saw of Count Dracula was his terrible gaze, with a red light of triumph in his eyes and a smile that Judas, in hell, might be proud of.

en: When I was in my room and about to lie down, I thought I heard a whispering at my door. I went to it softly and listened. Unless my ears deceived me, I heard the voice of the Count:—
vi: I was about to lie down in bed when I suddenly heard what seemed like someone whispering outside the door. I tiptoed closer to listen. I believed I recognized the voice of the old count: — No, no. - The voice still rose.
tr: As I was about to lie down in my room, I thought I heard a whisper at my door. I quietly went to the door and listened. If my ears did not deceive me, I heard the Count's voice: "Go back, go back, return to your place!
es: When I was in my room and about to go to bed, I thought I heard murmurs on the other side of my door. I approached it silently and listened. Unless my ears deceived me, I heard the count's voice:

en: “Back, back, to your own place! Your time is not yet come. Wait! Have patience! To-night is mine. To-morrow night is yours!” There was a low, sweet ripple of laughter, and in a rage I threw open the door, and saw without the three terrible women licking their lips. As I appeared they all joined in a horrible laugh, and ran away.
vi: - Turn back, all of you! Now is not the time for you. Just wait! You must be patient! Tonight will be mine, the next night will be yours! In response to the count's words were mocking giggles. Infuriated, I flung the door open, and in front of me stood three women licking their lips. Recognizing me, they burst into more lewd and malicious laughter before leaving.
tr: If my ears did not deceive me, I heard the Count's voice: "Go back, go back, return to your place! Your time has not yet come. Wait. Be patient. Tomorrow night, tomorrow night is yours!" There was a low, sweet wave of laughter, and I angrily opened the door and saw three terrifying women licking their lips outside. When I appeared, they let out a horrifying laugh and fled.
es: –Back, back, to your place! Your time has not yet come. Wait! Be patient! This night is mine. Tomorrow night is yours. There was a slight and sweet murmur of laughter, and in a fit of rage, I flung the door open and saw those three terrible women outside, licking their lips. When I appeared, they all joined in a horrible laugh and ran away.

en: I came back to my room and threw myself on my knees. It is then so near the end? To-morrow! to-morrow! Lord, help me, and those to whom I am dear!
vi: I staggered back in and collapsed onto the floor. Could it be that my end is coming so soon? Tomorrow! Tomorrow! Dear God! Please save me, save all my loved ones!
tr: I turned around and threw myself onto my knees. So, this is how close my end is, huh? Tomorrow! Tomorrow! God, help me and those who love me.
es: I returned to my room and fell to my knees. Is the end then so near? Tomorrow! Tomorrow! Lord, help me, and those who love me!

en: 30 June, morning.—These may be the last words I ever write in this diary. I slept till just before the dawn, and when I woke threw myself on my knees, for I determined that if Death came he should find me ready.
vi: • June 30, morning Perhaps these will be the last lines I can write in this diary. Immediately after waking up before dawn, I hurriedly knelt down on the floor, because if my final hour had come, I wanted the Grim Reaper to see that I was ready.
tr: June 30, morning. - These might be the last words I write in this journal. I slept until just before dawn and when I woke up, I threw myself onto my knees because I had decided that if Death were to come, it should find me ready.
es: June 30th, in the morning. These may be the last words I ever write in this journal. I slept until shortly before dawn, and upon waking, I fell to my knees, for I am determined that if death comes, it will find me prepared.

en: At last I felt that subtle change in the air, and knew that the morning had come. Then came the welcome cock-crow, and I felt that I was safe. With a glad heart, I opened my door and ran down to the hall. I had seen that the door was unlocked, and now escape was before me. With hands that trembled with eagerness, I unhooked the chains and drew back the massive bolts.
vi: Kneeling for a while, I began to sense that the early morning atmosphere was undergoing a subtle, indescribable change... and the morning was still coming... as the first rooster crowed. I felt as if I was narrowly escaping death. I opened the door, walked down the stairs with a lighter heart. The castle gate was clearly unlocked, which meant I had another chance to escape! Impatiently, I unchained and unlatched it, my hands trembling.
tr: Finally, I felt the slight change in the air and realized that morning had come. Then, the crowing of the rooster welcoming the morning came, and I felt safe. With a content heart, I opened my door and ran downstairs to the hall. I had seen that the door was not locked, and now escape was before me. With hands trembling with eagerness, I unhooked the chains and pulled the mighty bolts.
es: Finally, I felt that subtle change in the air and knew that the morning had arrived. Then I heard the welcoming crow of the rooster and felt that I was safe. With a joyful heart, I opened the door and ran down the stairs, towards the corridor. I had seen that the door was unlocked, and now freedom was before me. With hands trembling with anxiety, I unlatched the chains and slid back the bolts.

en: But the door would not move. Despair seized me. I pulled, and pulled, at the door, and shook it till, massive as it was, it rattled in its casement. I could see the bolt shot. It had been locked after I left the Count.
vi: But the door did not budge at all. The discouragement and despair within me gradually reached their peak. I threw myself against the door in the hope of finding an escape, but it was all in vain. It was only then that I realized the door had been locked right after I parted ways with the old count.
tr: But the door did not budge. I fell into despair. I pulled, pulled, and though it was mighty, I shook it until it creaked in its frame. I could see that the latch was inside. The door had been locked after I left the Count's side.
es: But the door did not move. Desperation took hold of me. I repeatedly pulled and pushed the door until, despite being very heavy, it shook on its hinges. I could see that the latch was fastened. They had locked it after I left the count.

en: Then a wild desire took me to obtain that key at any risk, and I determined then and there to scale the wall again and gain the Count’s room. He might kill me, but death now seemed the happier choice of evils. Without a pause I rushed up to the east window, and scrambled down the wall, as before, into the Count’s room. It was empty, but that was as I expected. I could not see a key anywhere, but the heap of gold remained. I went through the door in the corner and down the winding stair and along the dark passage to the old chapel. I knew now well enough where to find the monster I sought.
vi: However, I kept telling myself that by any means necessary, I had to find and get that wretched key; I would climb the wall again and sneak into the count's room. Surely, I would face death if he caught me in his room, but among the worst things that could happen to me, death seemed to be the least of them. Without wasting a minute, I immediately climbed through the window and descended into the count's room. The room was empty. I couldn't find the key anywhere. The pile of gold coins was still there. I followed the stairs and the dark corridors I had taken before to reach the church. I knew very well where the demon I was looking for was lying.
tr: Then, taking every risk, a wild desire to get hold of that key seized me; right there and then, I decided to climb the wall once more and reach the Count's room. He could kill me, but death was the best option among the evils. Without wasting any time, I ran to the east window and, as I had done before, crawled along the wall and descended into the Count's room. It was empty, but I was expecting that. I couldn't see the key anywhere, but the pile of gold was there. I passed through the door in the corner, went down the spiral staircase, and walked through the dark corridor leading to the old chapel. Now I knew well enough where to find the monster I was looking for.
es: Then a wild desire to obtain the key at any cost seized me, and right there I resolved to climb the wall and reach the count's room once again. He could kill me, but death now seemed the least of all evils. Without wasting time, I ran to the east window and slid down the wall, as before, to the count's room. It was empty, but that was what I expected. I couldn't see the key anywhere, but the pile of gold remained in its place. I went through the door in the corner and descended the spiral staircase and along the dark passageway to the old chapel. I already knew very well where to find the monster I was looking for.

en: The great box was in the same place, close against the wall, but the lid was laid on it, not fastened down, but with the nails ready in their places to be hammered home. I knew I must reach the body for the key, so I raised the lid, and laid it back against the wall; and then I saw something which filled my very soul with horror.
