There lay the Count, but looking as if his youth had been half renewed, for the white hair and moustache were changed to dark iron-grey; the cheeks were fuller, and the white skin seemed ruby-red underneath; the mouth was redder than ever, for on the lips were gouts of fresh blood, which trickled from the corners of the mouth and ran over the chin and neck. Even the deep, burning eyes seemed set amongst swollen flesh, for the lids and pouches underneath were bloated. It seemed as if the whole awful creature were simply gorged with blood. He lay like a filthy leech, exhausted with his repletion. I shuddered as I bent over to touch him, and every sense in me revolted at the contact; but I had to search, or I was lost. The coming night might see my own body a banquet in a similar way to those horrid three. I felt all over the body, but no sign could I find of the key. Then I stopped and looked at the Count. There was a mocking smile on the bloated face which seemed to drive me mad. This was the being I was helping to transfer to London, where, perhaps, for centuries to come he might, amongst its teeming millions, satiate his lust for blood, and create a new and ever-widening circle of semi-demons to batten on the helpless. The very thought drove me mad. A terrible desire came upon me to rid the world of such a monster. There was no lethal weapon at hand, but I seized a shovel which the workmen had been using to fill the cases, and lifting it high, struck, with the edge downward, at the hateful face. But as I did so the head turned, and the eyes fell full upon me, with all their blaze of basilisk horror. The sight seemed to paralyse me, and the shovel turned in my hand and glanced from the face, merely making a deep gash above the forehead. The shovel fell from my hand across the box, and as I pulled it away the flange of the blade caught the edge of the lid which fell over again, and hid the horrid thing from my sight. The last glimpse I had was of the bloated face, blood-stained and fixed with a grin of malice which would have held its own in the nethermost hell.
vi: The large chest still lay in its old place, close to the wall, but this time it was carefully covered, the lid of the chest was pre-nailed as if waiting for hammer blows. I knew that I had to search the corpse inside to possibly find the key. Therefore, I had to lift the lid of the chest and lean it against the wall, the corpse inside the chest terrified me? Yes, it was still the old count lying there, but now he looked half his age, as his white hair and beard had turned a grayish ash color; his cheeks appeared fuller and even seemed to have a fresh pink hue beneath the pale skin. Especially his lips, which now looked plumper than ever, with fresh blood dripping from the corners, streaming down his chin and neck. His deep-set, glaring eyes were lost in a swollen face. I had the impression that this terrifying monster lived solely on fresh blood. The mere thought of bending down to touch him made me shudder; the contact filled me with a sense of revulsion, but no matter what, I had to find what I was looking for, or I would fail! And thus, my body could become a plaything for the three dreadful women the next night. I gritted my teeth and searched all the pockets on his person, but still couldn't find the key. The count's bloated face seemed to mock me, driving me to the brink of madness. Yet, I had spent countless efforts to help him move closer to London, where he could continue to satiate his insatiable bloodlust for centuries to come, turning the weak into half-human, half-monster creatures. The mere thought of it was unbearable. Thinking this, I furiously grabbed the shovel lying on the ground and aimed to strike the count's hideous face. But at that moment, the count's head slightly turned to one side, and his gleaming, malevolent eyes met mine. I froze as if paralyzed, my hand dropped, causing the shovel to make a deep cut on his forehead. The shovel slipped from my hand, fell into the coffin, and got caught in the wooden lid. I was about to bend down to grab the shovel handle when the coffin lid suddenly slammed shut, sparing me from the ghastly sight below. The last detail I saw was the bloated, blood-stained face with a sinister, mocking grin that could only belong in hell.
tr: The large chest was in the same place, close to the wall, but its lid, though not reinforced, was placed on top; the nails were also ready in their places to be hammered into their slots. I knew I had to search its surface to find the key, so I lifted the lid and leaned it against the wall; then I saw something that filled my soul with fear. The Count was lying there, but he looked as if he had half-rejuvenated, for his white hair and mustache had turned to a dark iron gray; his cheeks were fuller, and beneath his pale skin, a ruby red was visible; his mouth was redder than ever, as there were fresh blood droplets on his lips, trickling from the corners of his mouth and running down his chin and neck. Even his sunken, gleaming eyes seemed lost among the swollen flesh, for his eyelids and under-eye bags were swollen. The horrific creature seemed to be bloated with blood; he lay there like a repulsive parasite, exhausted from overindulgence. When I leaned over to touch him, my skin crawled, and all my senses revolted at the contact; but I had to search, or I was doomed. The approaching night could similarly present my body as a feast to that terrifying trio. I searched his entire body, but I found not a single trace of the key. Then I stopped and looked at the Count. There was a mocking smile on his swollen face, which seemed to be driving me mad. Perhaps this was the creature I had helped move to London to satisfy his thirst for blood among the city's fertile millions for centuries to come, creating a new and ever-expanding circle of half-demons clogged with the desperate. This thought drove me insane. I was seized with a terrible desire to rid the world of such a monster. There was no deadly weapon nearby, but I raised the shovel the workers had used to fill the chests, with its point downward, to strike the hateful face. But just as I did so, his eyes turned to me, burning with a terror reminiscent of mythological serpents. This sight seemed to paralyze me, and the shovel twisted in my hand, missing his face and opening a deep wound above the forehead. The shovel slipped from my hand and fell onto the chest, its edge catching the corner of the lid; the lid closed again, hiding the horrific thing from my eyes. The last thing I saw was a swollen face, smeared with blood, fixed in a grin full of evil that held its place in the deepest hell.
es: The large box was in the same place, leaning against the wall, but the lid had been put on, with the nails ready in place to be driven in, although this had not yet been done. I knew I had to get to the body to look for the key, so I lifted the lid and leaned it against the wall; and then I saw something that filled my soul with terror. There lay the count, but looking as young as if he had been rejuvenated for his white hair and mustache had changed to a dark gray; the cheeks were fuller, and the white skin seemed a ruby red beneath them; the mouth was redder than ever; on his lips were drops of fresh blood that fell in trickles from the corners of his mouth and ran down his chin and neck. Even his eyes, deep and sparkling, seemed to be sunken in the midst of the swollen flesh, for the eyelids and the bags beneath them were bloated. It seemed as if the horrid creature was simply sated with blood. It lay like a horrid leech, exhausted from gluttony. I trembled as I bent down to touch it, and every sense in me rebelled at the contact; but I had to rummage through its pockets, or I was lost. The next night I could see my own body serving as a feast in a similar manner for those horrid three. I fell upon the body, but I could not find any signs of the key. Then I stopped and looked at the count. There was a mocking smile on his swollen face that seemed to drive me mad. That was the being I was helping to move to London, where, perhaps, in the centuries to come, he could quench his thirst for blood among its prolific millions, and create a new and ever-widening circle of semi-demons to prey upon the defenseless. The mere thought of it drove me mad. I felt a terrible desire to save the world from such a monster. I had no lethal weapon at hand, but I took the shovel the men had been using to fill the boxes and, raising it high, struck the hateful face with the edge. But as I did so, the head turned and the eyes fell upon me with all their horrid basilisk brilliance. His gaze seemed to paralyze me and the shovel twisted in my hand, missing the face, making only a deep cut on the forehead. The shovel fell from my hands onto the box, and as I pulled it, the edge of the blade caught on the edge of the lid, which fell back over the crate, hiding the horrid image from my sight. The last glimpse I had was of the swollen face, stained with blood and fixed, with a grimace of malice that would have been very fitting in the deepest of hells.

en: I thought and thought what should be my next move, but my brain seemed on fire, and I waited with a despairing feeling growing over me. As I waited I heard in the distance a gipsy song sung by merry voices coming closer, and through their song the rolling of heavy wheels and the cracking of whips; the Szgany and the Slovaks of whom the Count had spoken were coming. With a last look around and at the box which contained the vile body, I ran from the place and gained the Count’s room, determined to rush out at the moment the door should be opened. With strained ears, I listened, and heard downstairs the grinding of the key in the great lock and the falling back of the heavy door. There must have been some other means of entry, or some one had a key for one of the locked doors. Then there came the sound of many feet tramping and dying away in some passage which sent up a clanging echo. I turned to run down again towards the vault, where I might find the new entrance; but at the moment there seemed to come a violent puff of wind, and the door to the winding stair blew to with a shock that set the dust from the lintels flying. When I ran to push it open, I found that it was hopelessly fast. I was again a prisoner, and the net of doom was closing round me more closely.
vi: I stood there, dazed, thinking about what I would have to do, but clearly, I couldn't think of anything. My body felt heavy, despondent, powerless...I kept standing, standing, until suddenly the singing of the Gypsies echoed from afar. The singing grew closer and closer, accompanied by the rhythmic sound of horse hooves. As the old count had told me last night, the Gypsies and even the Slovaks were coming to the castle. After glancing around and taking one last look at the chest containing the cursed corpse, I hurried back to the old man's room, intending to escape right when the gate opened. I strained my ears to listen: there was the sound of a key turning in a large lock, followed by the heavy creaking of a door on the ground floor. So, either there were other entrances to the castle, or someone with a key had opened one of the doors I knew about. Then, I heard the varying sounds of many footsteps in some hallway. I turned back and ran towards the church, thinking there might be an exit I hadn't seen yet. But just then, a sudden strong gust of wind slammed the door leading to the spiral staircase shut, causing dust to fly everywhere. I hurriedly ran back, but it was too late, the door was locked. So, I became a prisoner again. The net of fate was tightening around me.
tr: I kept thinking about what my next move should be, but my mind was like a burning field, and I waited with a growing sense of hopelessness inside me. While waiting, I heard a Gypsy song sung by cheerful voices coming closer and closer, and amidst the songs, the turning of heavy wheels and the cracking of whips; the Gypsies and Slovaks the Count had mentioned were coming. After taking one last look around and at the coffin hiding the disgusting body, I decided to dash out as soon as the door opened and escaped to the Count's room. I listened to the sounds with great care and heard the key turning and the heavy door being pulled back downstairs. There must have been other entrances, or one of the locked doors had a key. Then, footsteps making noise and echoing in the corridor were heard, moving away. I turned to run to the crypt where I could find the new entrance; but at that moment, a violent and sudden wind blew, slamming the door opening to the spiral staircase and scattering the dust on the upper lintel. When I ran to open the door, I found it desperately jammed. I was a prisoner again, and fate was weaving its webs around me more tightly.
es: I thought and thought about what my next move would be, but it seemed like my brain was on fire, and I waited with a desperation that I felt growing by the moment. While I was waiting, I heard in the distance a gypsy song sung by cheerful voices that were approaching, and through the song, the sound of heavy wheels and cracking whips; the gypsies and Slovaks whom the count had spoken of were arriving. Taking one last look at the box containing the vile body, I ran out of that place and reached the count's room, determined to leave suddenly the moment the door opened. With attentive ears, I listened, and heard below the creak of the key in the great lock and the sound of the heavy door opening. There must have been other means of entry, or someone had a key to one of the locked doors. Then the sound of many feet walking reached me, dying away in some passage that sent back a resounding echo. I wanted to run back to the vault, where I might find the new entrance; but at that moment a violent gust of wind seemed to penetrate the room, and the door leading to the spiral staircase slammed shut with such force that it raised the dust from the lintels. When I ran to open the door, I found it was tightly shut. Once again, I was a prisoner, and the web of my fate seemed to be closing in ever tighter.

en: As I write there is in the passage below a sound of many tramping feet and the crash of weights being set down heavily, doubtless the boxes, with their freight of earth. There is a sound of hammering; it is the box being nailed down. Now I can hear the heavy feet tramping again along the hall, with many other idle feet coming behind them.
vi: As I write these lines, I hear heavy footsteps and the sound of something being thrown... yes... it must be the boxes filled with earth in the hallway below. Then there is the sound of hammering. The people from earlier are nailing shut the lid of the box that I had just knocked over. A moment later, I hear the sound of heavy footsteps in the hallway again, followed by lighter footsteps.
tr: As I write these, there are numerous footsteps and the noise of weights being placed heavily on the floor in the corridor below; those being placed are undoubtedly crates filled with soil. The sound of hammering is heard; this is the crate being nailed shut. Now, I can hear the sound of heavy footsteps, followed by many other footsteps, echoing along the corridor.
es: While I write this, in the passageway below me, the sound of many feet stepping and the noise of weights being abruptly deposited can be heard, undoubtedly the boxes with their cargo of earth. The sound of a hammer can also be heard; it is the count's box being sealed. Now I can hear again the heavy feet advancing along the corridor, with many other useless feet following behind them.

en: The door is shut, and the chains rattle; there is a grinding of the key in the lock; I can hear the key withdraw: then another door opens and shuts; I hear the creaking of lock and bolt.
vi: The last sounds that reach my ears are the slamming of a door, the clinking of a chain, the turning of a lock, the removal of a key from the lock, and then the opening and closing of another door. I can still hear the sound of a key turning and a latch being fastened once more.
tr: The door closed, chains rattled; the key is turning in the lock; I can hear the key being removed; then another door opens and closes; I hear the creak of the lock and the latch.
es: The door closes, the chains clash against each other as they are placed; the squeak of the key in the lock is heard; I can even hear when the key is removed; then another door opens and closes; I hear the creaks of the lock and the bolts.

en: Hark! in the courtyard and down the rocky way the roll of heavy wheels, the crack of whips, and the chorus of the Szgany as they pass into the distance.
vi: Outside in the yard, at the far end, on the gravel path, the sound of a horse-drawn carriage slowly receded along with the clattering of horse hooves. The sad song of the Gypsy once again soared faintly and then faded away in my ears.
tr: Listen! In the courtyard and on the stony road, listen to the turning of heavy wheels, the cracking of whips, and the Gypsy chorus singing as they move away.
es: Listen! In the courtyard and along the rocky path go the heavy wheels, the crack of the whips, and the choruses of the gypsies as they disappear into the distance.

en: I am alone in the castle with those awful women. Faugh! Mina is a woman, and there is nought in common. They are devils of the Pit!
vi: So, I was left alone in the castle, alone with those three women! Women! Mina is also a woman, but she has nothing in common with them. Are they just female demons?
tr: I am alone in the castle with those dreadful women. Ah! Mina is also a woman and has nothing in common with them. These are the demons of the pit of hell!
es: I am alone in the castle with those horrible women. Phew! Mina is a woman, and she has nothing in common with them. These are she-devils from hell.

en: I shall not remain alone with them; I shall try to scale the castle wall farther than I have yet attempted. I shall take some of the gold with me, lest I want it later. I may find a way from this dreadful place.
vi: But I will not stay alone with them. Then I will climb the wall again, farther than I have ever done before, and I will take the gold coins from the count's room because I might need that money later.
tr: I must not be alone with them; I will try to descend lower from the castle wall than I have attempted so far; I will take some of the gold with me in case I need it later. I might find a way to escape from this dreadful place.
es: I will not stay here alone with them; I will try to climb the castle wall farther than I have attempted so far. I will take some gold with me, as I might need it later. Perhaps I will find some way to escape this horrendous place.

en: And then away for home! away to the quickest and nearest train! away from this cursed spot, from this cursed land, where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!
vi: I absolutely must leave this cursed castle to return to my loved ones! The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies!
tr: And then home! To the fastest and nearest train! Away from this cursed place, this cursed land where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!
es: And then, quickly home! Quickly to the fastest and nearest of the trains! Away from this cursed place, from this cursed land where the devil and his children still walk with earthly feet!

en: At least God’s mercy is better than that of these monsters, and the precipice is steep and high. At its foot a man may sleep—as a man. Good-bye, all! Mina!
vi: The first train, and the fastest one, will take me away from this hellish place, away from this damned land where demons and monstrous creations live as they have always lived in this world full of ironies! CHAPTER 5
tr: At least God's mercy is better than that of these monsters; the abyss is steep and high. A man can sleep at its feet - like a man. Farewell to everyone! Farewell, Mina!
es: At least the goodness of God is better than that of these monsters, and the precipice is steep and high. At its feet, a man can sleep like a man. Goodbye, everything! Goodbye, Mina!

en: CHAPTER V
vi: CHAPTER 5
tr: V
es: V.– LETTER FROM MISS MINA MURRAY TO MISS

en: Letter from Miss Mina Murray to Miss Lucy Westenra.
vi: Letter from Mina Murray to Lucy Westenra
tr: From Miss Mina Murray to Miss Letter to Lucy Westenra
es: LUCY WESTENRA

en: “9 May.
vi: "May 9"
tr: May 9
es: May 9

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Dear Lucy.
tr: Dearest Lucy,
es: “My very dear Lucy”

en: “Forgive my long delay in writing, but I have been simply overwhelmed with work. The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying. I am longing to be with you, and by the sea, where we can talk together freely and build our castles in the air. I have been working very hard lately, because I want to keep up with Jonathan’s studies, and I have been practising shorthand very assiduously. When we are married I shall be able to be useful to Jonathan, and if I can stenograph well enough I can take down what he wants to say in this way and write it out for him on the typewriter, at which also I am practising very hard. He and I sometimes write letters in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic journal of his travels abroad. When I am with you I shall keep a diary in the same way. I don’t mean one of those two-pages-to-the-week-with-Sunday-squeezed-in-a-corner diaries, but a sort of journal which I can write in whenever I feel inclined. I do not suppose there will be much of interest to other people; but it is not intended for them. I may show it to Jonathan some day if there is in it anything worth sharing, but it is really an exercise book. I shall try to do what I see lady journalists do: interviewing and writing descriptions and trying to remember conversations. I am told that, with a little practice, one can remember all that goes on or that one hears said during a day. However, we shall see. I will tell you of my little plans when we meet. I have just had a few hurried lines from Jonathan from Transylvania. He is well, and will be returning in about a week. I am longing to hear all his news. It must be so nice to see strange countries. I wonder if we—I mean Jonathan and I—shall ever see them together. There is the ten o’clock bell ringing. Good-bye.
vi: Sorry for my prolonged silence, but actually, I haven't encountered any troubles; it's simply because I'm always swamped with work, that's all. The life of a female trainer is not always easy. How I long to walk with you along the beach and chat about everything under the sun. Yes, these days I've been burying myself in work because I want to be capable enough to collaborate with Jonathan. I've been diligently practicing shorthand, so that when we get married, I can help him record everything he deems necessary and then type it out. I'm also learning to type now. Moreover, we both often receive letters written in shorthand, and I know that during his travels, he also keeps a diary in that way. When I return to you, I will do the same. I will keep a diary and whenever I feel like it, I will jot down everything that comes to mind. Maybe one day, I will show that diary to Jonathan if needed. But first, I will treat it as an exercise book. I want to do what female journalists often do: conduct interviews, describe what I see, try to recall stories I've heard, and then recount everything as truthfully as possible. Someone told me that with just a bit of practice, one can easily remember everything that happened, or everything heard during the day. In the end, we will see... I'm very happy to share with you my little plans. I just received a few words from Jonathan sent from Transylvania. He is still healthy and will return here in about a week. I'm very excited to hear Jonathan talk about his trip. The trip must have been wonderful because it spanned so many lands. I'm wondering if the day when we, I mean Jonathan and I, will travel together will ever come. Alright, it's already ten o'clock now. Goodbye!
tr: Forgive me for being so late in writing, but I was overwhelmed with work. The life of an assistant teacher can sometimes be challenging. I am longing to be with you, to talk freely by the seaside and dream together. I've been working a lot lately because I want to keep up with Jonathan's studies and I am persistently practicing shorthand. When we get married, I should be able to help Jonathan; if I know shorthand well enough, I can transcribe what he wants to say and also type it out on the typewriter, which I have also practiced a lot. He and I sometimes correspond in shorthand and he keeps a journal in shorthand during his travels abroad. I will keep a journal in the same way when I am with you. I don't mean those journals where a whole week is squeezed into two pages with Sunday tucked into a corner. I don't think there will be much to interest other people; but these journals are not written for others. If there is something worth sharing, I might show it to Jonathan one day, but it will essentially be a practice notebook. I will try to do what I have seen women journalists do: conduct interviews, write descriptions, and try to remember conversations. I had heard that with a little practice, one can remember everything that happens or is said during the day. Still, we will see. When we get together, I will tell you all my little plans. Just now, I received a few hurried lines from Jonathan from Transylvania. He is well and will be back here in about a week. I am eager to hear all his news. It must be wonderful to see foreign countries. I wonder if we - that is, Jonathan and I - will be able to see these countries together. The ten o'clock bell is ringing. Goodbye.
es: “Forgive my delay in writing to you, but I have been truly overwhelmed with work. The life of an assistant school principal is distressing. I am dying to be with you, and by the seaside, where we can talk freely and build our castles in the air. Lately, I have been working a lot, because I want to maintain Jonathan's level of studies, and I have been practicing shorthand very actively. When we get married, I will be very useful to Jonathan, and if I can write well in shorthand, I will be able to transcribe everything he says and then type it up neatly for him, which I am also practicing very hard. He and I sometimes write to each other in shorthand, and he is keeping a stenographic diary of his travels abroad. When I am with you, I will also keep a diary in the same way. I don't mean one of those diaries that are written hastily on the corner of a couple of pages when there's time on Sundays, but a diary in which I can write whenever I feel inclined to do so. I suppose it won't be of much interest to other people, but it isn't intended for them. Someday I will show it to Jonathan, in case there is something in it that deserves to be shared, but truly it is an exercise book. I will try to do what I have seen women journalists do: interviews, descriptions, trying to remember conversations as best as possible. I have been told that, with a little practice, one can remember everything that has happened or everything one has heard during the day. However, we shall see. I will tell you about my little plans when we see each other. I have just received a few lines from Jonathan from Transylvania. He is well and will return in about a week. I am very anxious to hear all your news. It must be so nice to visit foreign countries! Sometimes I wonder if we, I mean Jonathan and I, will ever see them together. The ten o'clock bell just rang. Goodbye.

en: “My dearest Mina,—
vi: Dear Mina,
tr: Dearest Mina,
es: "My dearest Mina:

en: “I must say you tax me very unfairly with being a bad correspondent. I wrote to you twice since we parted, and your last letter was only your second. Besides, I have nothing to tell you. There is really nothing to interest you. Town is very pleasant just now, and we go a good deal to picture-galleries and for walks and rides in the park. As to the tall, curly-haired man, I suppose it was the one who was with me at the last Pop. Some one has evidently been telling tales. That was Mr. Holmwood. He often comes to see us, and he and mamma get on very well together; they have so many things to talk about in common. We met some time ago a man that would just do for you, if you were not already engaged to Jonathan. He is an excellent parti, being handsome, well off, and of good birth. He is a doctor and really clever. Just fancy! He is only nine-and-twenty, and he has an immense lunatic asylum all under his own care. Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me, and he called here to see us, and often comes now. I think he is one of the most resolute men I ever saw, and yet the most calm. He seems absolutely imperturbable. I can fancy what a wonderful power he must have over his patients. He has a curious habit of looking one straight in the face, as if trying to read one’s thoughts. He tries this on very much with me, but I flatter myself he has got a tough nut to crack. I know that from my glass. Do you ever try to read your own face? I do, and I can tell you it is not a bad study, and gives you more trouble than you can well fancy if you have never tried it. He says that I afford him a curious psychological study, and I humbly think I do. I do not, as you know, take sufficient interest in dress to be able to describe the new fashions. Dress is a bore. That is slang again, but never mind; Arthur says that every day. There, it is all out. Mina, we have told all our secrets to each other since we were children; we have slept together and eaten together, and laughed and cried together; and now, though I have spoken, I would like to speak more. Oh, Mina, couldn’t you guess? I love him. I am blushing as I write, for although I think he loves me, he has not told me so in words. But oh, Mina, I love him; I love him; I love him! There, that does me good. I wish I were with you, dear, sitting by the fire undressing, as we used to sit; and I would try to tell you what I feel. I do not know how I am writing this even to you. I am afraid to stop, or I should tear up the letter, and I don’t want to stop, for I do so want to tell you all. Let me hear from you at once, and tell me all that you think about it. Mina, I must stop. Good-night. Bless me in your prayers; and, Mina, pray for my happiness.
vi: To be honest, you were a bit too harsh in criticizing me: I have written to you twice since we parted ways, and your latest letter is only the second one I have received? Moreover, I don't have anything new to tell you; honestly, there's nothing worth your attention. These days, we go out quite often, sometimes to art exhibitions, sometimes for walks or horseback riding in the park. As for the tall, handsome guy with blond hair you mentioned, I think you were referring to the guy who accompanied me to a recent concert. Clearly, you've heard some rumors... That was Holmwood. He often visits my house; my mother and he seem to get along very well. They usually care about the same things. At least that's what I think. Recently, we met someone like you mentioned, and I was planning to set you up with him if you weren't Jonathan's fiancée. Isn't that a wonderful match? A handsome, elegant, wealthy, and very knowledgeable young man. He is a very intelligent doctor. Can you imagine, at just twenty-nine years old, he is already able to run a very large sanatorium. It was Holmwood who introduced him to me. These days, he often comes to my house. I believe he is the most resilient, determined, and at the same time, the calmest man I have ever met in my life. I sense in him an unshakeable resoluteness. He also always lingers in the eyes of others, as if he wants to read all their thoughts. He often acts according to my interests, but I am very glad to tell you that he is far from achieving his goal! For me right now, just being able to look at myself in the mirror is enough. Have you ever tried reading your own expression in the mirror? That psychiatrist said that to him, I am quite a peculiar mental case, and although it's uncomfortable, I still think he's right. Mental illness! How amusing? You know, I'm not the kind of person who pays much attention to fashion to be able to describe to you what's trending. Fashion is just a frivolous thing, as Arthur often says... All that is called new to me is just that. Mina, do you remember, from our youthful days, we used to share with each other our deepest secrets; we used to sleep together, share every piece of cake, every smile, and even tears? You know, now I really want to talk, to chat endlessly with you! Mina! Can you guess? I love him! I'm blushing as I write these words, because even if I have enough reason to believe that he loves me too, he hasn't said it to me yet. Mina, I love him! I love him? I love him! That's it! Only by writing this do I feel at ease. If only I could be with you now, sitting close to you by the fire in casual clothes to confide like the old days; we would whisper to each other, and I would try to share with you all the emotions I've been through. I don't know how to express my innermost feelings, even to you. ..I'm afraid I have to stop writing here, because if I don't, I might tear this letter apart. Honestly, I still don't want to stop writing, because I still crave to tell you something more. Reply to me right away, tell me frankly what you think. Mina, I'm stopping here. Goodbye. Pray to God to bless me and my happiness, Mina.
tr: I must say that you have very unfairly accused me of being a bad pen pal. Since we parted, I have written to you twice, and the last one you sent was only your second letter. Besides, I have nothing to tell you. Seriously, there is nothing that would interest you. The town is very nice these days, and we often visit art galleries, take walks in the park, and go horseback riding. As for the tall, curly-haired man, I think he was the one with me at the last concert. Someone is clearly telling tales. That man was Mr. Holmwood. He often comes to see us; he gets along very well with my mother, and they have a lot to talk about. A while ago, if you weren't already engaged to Jonathan, we met a man who would be perfect for you. A perfect husband candidate; handsome, wealthy, and from a good family. A doctor and really smart. Just think! At only twenty-nine years old, he has a huge mental hospital entirely under his supervision. Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me, he came to visit us, and now he comes often. I think he is one of the bravest and at the same time the most cool-headed men I have ever seen. He definitely looks dignified. I can imagine how he could have perfect control over his patients. He has a strange habit of looking directly into a person's face as if trying to read their mind. He often tries this on me, but I pride myself on thinking he has met his match. I know this from my mirror. Do you ever try to read your own face? I do, and I can tell you, it's not a bad examination, and if you haven't tried it before, it causes you more trouble than you might think. He says I am an interesting psychological case for him to study, and I humbly think so too. As you know, I don't care enough about clothing to describe the latest fashions. Clothing is a nuisance. That's slang, but never mind; Arthur says it every day. That's all. Mina, we've shared all our secrets since childhood; we've slept together, eaten together, cried and laughed together; now, even though I've spoken, I want to talk more. Oh Mina! Can't you guess? I'm in love with him. My face blushes as I write because although I think he loves me too, he hasn't told me in words. But oh! Mina! I'm in love with him; I'm in love with him; I'm in love with him! There, that makes me feel better. I wish I were with you, dear; sitting by the fire with our clothes off as we used to; I would try to tell you how I feel. I don't even know how I'm writing this to you. I'm afraid to stop, or I'll have to tear up the letter, but I don't want to stop because I so much want to tell you everything. I'm eagerly waiting to hear from you; tell me everything you think about this. Mina, I must stop. Good night. Bless me in your prayers and Mina, pray for my happiness.
es: "I must say that you value me very unfairly by saying that I am bad at correspondence. I have written to you twice since we parted, and your last letter was only the second. Besides, I have nothing to tell you. There is really nothing that might interest you. The city is very beautiful these days, and we often go to the art galleries and to walk or ride horses in the park. As for the tall man with curly hair, I suppose he was the one who was with me at the last popular concert. Evidently, someone has been telling tall tales. It was Mr. Holmwood. He often comes to see us, and he gets along very well with mom; they have many things in common to talk about. Some time ago we met a man who would be suitable for you if you were not already engaged to Jonathan. He is an excellent match; handsome, rich, and from a good family. He is a doctor and very smart. Imagine that! He is twenty-nine years old and owns a huge lunatic asylum, all under his direction. Mr. Holmwood introduced him to me and he came here to see us, and now he visits us often. I think he is one of the most resolute men I have ever seen, and yet, the calmest. He seems absolutely unperturbable. I can imagine the magnificent power he has over his patients. He has the curious habit of looking one directly in the face as if trying to read one's thoughts. He tries to do this many times with me, but I pride myself that this time he has met a nut too hard to crack. I know that from my mirror. Have you never tried to read your own face? I have, and I can tell you it is not a bad study, and it gives you more work than you can imagine if you have never tried it yet. He says that I provide him with a curious psychological case, and I humbly believe that is so. As you know, I do not take enough interest in dresses to be able to describe the new fashions. The subject of dresses is boring. That is slang again, but don't mind it; Arthur says that every day. Well, that is all. Mina, we have told each other all our secrets since we were girls; we have slept together and eaten together, we have laughed and cried together; and now, although I have already spoken, I would like to speak more. Oh, Mina! Could you not guess? I love him; I love him! Well, that makes me feel good. I wish I were with you, dear, sitting in confidence by the fire, just as we used to; then I would try to tell you how I feel; I don't even know how I am writing this to you. I am afraid to stop, because I might tear up the letter, and I don't want to stop, because I want to tell you everything. Send me news of you immediately, and tell me everything you think about this. Mina, I must finish. Good night. Bless me in your prayers, and, Mina, pray for my happiness.
