My gog, but it’ll be a quare scowderment at the Day of Judgment when they come tumblin’ up in their death-sarks, all jouped together an’ tryin’ to drag their tombsteans with them to prove how good they was; some of them trimmlin’ and ditherin’, with their hands that dozzened an’ slippy from lyin’ in the sea that they can’t even keep their grup o’ them.”
vi: — Girl, I told you, it's all just nonsense: those are silly stories, nothing more, nothing less! All those fascinating, alluring, enchanting stories are only suitable for senile old women. All of that is concocted by a few priests and those who lure customers in hotels to manipulate others into doing things they don't want to do. Every time I think about it, I get infuriated. Printing it on a pile of scrap paper wasn't enough, they even told each other to engrave all sorts of things on tombstones... Just look around: all those stones standing proudly there are actually weighed down by the lies that people have inscribed all over them! And under those graves, most are empty, there's no one lying there. Better to find a way to get a pinch of tobacco than to worry about those silly stories! That's it, it's all just lies, lies in one way or another, nothing but lies? Oh God? How interesting it would be to see the unfortunate souls staggering, clutching each other's shoulders, dragging those tombstones to prove that they are living peacefully down there?
tr: “It's all nonsense, from top to bottom; that's it, nothing else. All these curses, ghosts, bogeymen, and everything related to them are things suitable for children and foolish women to believe in. Nothing but soap bubbles! All these horrors, signs, and warnings are concocted by priests, malicious educated people, and railway barkers to scare half-wits and to make people do things they wouldn't otherwise be inclined to do. Thinking about them makes me angry. The lies they print in newspapers, the lies they preach from the pulpit aren't enough; they also want to carve them onto gravestones. Look around you, all the stones seem to be proudly lifting their heads, but in reality, they are toppling under the weight of the lies written on them; on all of them, it says, ‘Here lies the body of so-and-so’ or, ‘In sacred memory of so-and-so,’ but half of them don't contain any bodies; and they are neither sacred, nor does anyone care about their memory. It's all lies, all lies in one way or another! My God, on Judgment Day, what a mess it will be when they try to drag their gravestones, struggling to hold onto them with their slippery hands from being in the sea for so long, to prove how good they were.”
es: –All of that is nonsense, from beginning to end; that's what it is, and nothing more. Those sayings and signs and ghosts and stone guests and foolishness and all that, only serve to scare children and women. They are nothing but words, that and all those frights, signs, and warnings that were invented by priests and malicious people and by railroad recruiters, to scare a poor guy and to make people do something they otherwise wouldn't do. It enrages me to think about it. Why is it that they, not content with printing lies on paper and preaching them from pulpits, want to engrave them even on tombstones? Look around as much as you want and you'll see that all those tombstones that raise their heads as much as their pride allows, are tilted..., simply falling under the weight of the lies written on them. The "Here lie the remains" or "To the sacred memory" are written on them and yet, not even in half of them is there any body; no one has given a damn about their memories and much less have they sanctified them. It's all lies, just lies of one kind or another! Good God! But the great repudiation will come on Judgment Day, when everyone comes out with their shrouds, all united trying to drag their tombstones with them to prove how good they were; some of them trembling, falling with their numb and slippery hands from having lain in the sea, to the point that they won't even be able to stay together.

en: I could see from the old fellow’s self-satisfied air and the way in which he looked round for the approval of his cronies that he was “showing off,” so I put in a word to keep him going:—
vi: Seeing the satisfied look on the old man's face and the way he glanced around seeking approval from his two old friends, I understood that he wanted to appear as someone outstanding, but that was enough for me to ask him another question:
tr: I could see from the old man's confident demeanor and the way he looked around for approval from his friends that he was "showing off," so I interrupted him to keep him talking:
es: By the satisfied air of the old man and the way he looked around seeking support for his words, I could tell he was boasting, so I said something to make him continue.

en: “Oh, Mr. Swales, you can’t be serious. Surely these tombstones are not all wrong?”
vi: — Oh! Old Swales, you're not being serious again! Almost none of the graves in this cemetery are empty, right?
tr: "Oh! Mr. Swales, you can't be serious. Surely, not all these tombstones are fake, are they?"
es: –Oh, Mr. Swales, you can't be serious! Surely all the tombstones can't be wrong.

en: “Yabblins! There may be a poorish few not wrong, savin’ where they make out the people too good; for there be folk that do think a balm-bowl be like the sea, if only it be their own. The whole thing be only lies. Now look you here; you come here a stranger, an’ you see this kirk-garth.” I nodded, for I thought it better to assent, though I did not quite understand his dialect. I knew it had something to do with the church. He went on: “And you consate that all these steans be aboon folk that be happed here, snod an’ snog?” I assented again. “Then that be just where the lie comes in. Why, there be scores of these lay-beds that be toom as old Dun’s ’bacca-box on Friday night.” He nudged one of his companions, and they all laughed. “And my gog! how could they be otherwise? Look at that one, the aftest abaft the bier-bank: read it!” I went over and read:—
vi: The old man seemed to be more pretentious: — Young lady, I have said so much already, yet you stubbornly keep bringing up all these foolish matters! There are very few graves there that aren't completely empty... that's it... good people are very prone to believing in the blabbering of others. Lies, it's all lies! Listen carefully, young lady: I don't believe that you came here without knowing anything, even if you are a stranger, and you should look at... I couldn't grasp the words the old man just said. To be honest, I didn't understand even half of the dialects he used, and I knew it would be hard for me to reproduce that subtle dialect, but I still nodded, though I was still doubtful that the old man might have been referring to the monastery. The old man continued: — So, do you believe that all those stone graves over there are sheltering someone who is resting in peace? I replied with a nod. — That is also just a lie! There are up to twenty, twenty, and twenty of those beds that are empty, empty like the minds of those who are accustomed to lying! The old man turned to seek the approval of his two peers, and then all three burst into laughter. — There, dear Lord! How could it be otherwise? Girl, just try looking at that grave over there, the one I'm pointing at... then try reading it! There... just give it a try...
tr: “It is possible! There may be very few who are not fake, except for those who make people look better than they are; because there are people who will believe that a bowl of liquid is the ocean as long as it belongs to them. All of this is a lie. Look over there; you came here as a stranger, you see this churchyard.” I nodded because, although I didn't understand his dialect very well, I thought it would be better to agree. I knew it had something to do with the church. He continued: “And you think all these stones are about the people buried here, don't you?” I nodded again. “Here's the lie, this is where it comes into play. Here, there are as many beds as there are people filling old Dun’s place on Friday nights.” He nudged one of his companions with his elbow and they all laughed together. “And my God! How could it be otherwise? Look at that, read that one over there!” I went over and read:
es: –Nonsense! There may scarcely be a few that are not bad, except for those where people are praised too much; because there are people who think that a container of balm could be like the sea, if only it were theirs. All that is nothing but lies. Listen, you came here as a stranger and saw this church atrium. I nodded because I thought the best thing to do would be that. I knew it had something to do with the temple. The man continued: –And you are certain that all those tombstones belong to people who have been buried here, aren't you? I nodded again. –So, that is precisely where the lie appears. Listen, there are dozens of such resting places that are as old as the old Dun's coffin from Friday night -he nudged one of his friends and they all laughed-. Good heavens! And how could they be anything else? Look at that one, the one at the far end of the cemetery, read it! I went up to her, and I read:

en: “Edward Spencelagh, master mariner, murdered by pirates off the coast of Andres, April, 1854, æt. 30.” When I came back Mr. Swales went on:—
vi: I walked closer to the grave the old man was pointing at and read: "Edward Spenceland, captain, murdered by pirates off the coast of Cordillere at the age of 30. April. 1854." When I returned, old Mr. Swales continued:
tr: “Edward Spencelagh, a former sailor, was killed by pirates on the shores of Andres in April 1854, at the age of 30.” When I returned, Mr. Swales continued his words:
es: –Edward Spencelagh, boatswain, murdered by pirates off the coast of Andres, April 1845, at the age of 30. When I returned, Mr. Swales continued:

en: “Who brought him home, I wonder, to hap him here? Murdered off the coast of Andres! an’ you consated his body lay under! Why, I could name ye a dozen whose bones lie in the Greenland seas above”—he pointed northwards—“or where the currents may have drifted them. There be the steans around ye. Ye can, with your young eyes, read the small-print of the lies from here. This Braithwaite Lowrey—I knew his father, lost in the Lively off Greenland in ’20; or Andrew Woodhouse, drowned in the same seas in 1777; or John Paxton, drowned off Cape Farewell a year later; or old John Rawlings, whose grandfather sailed with me, drowned in the Gulf of Finland in ’50. Do ye think that all these men will have to make a rush to Whitby when the trumpet sounds? I have me antherums aboot it! I tell ye that when they got here they’d be jommlin’ an’ jostlin’ one another that way that it ’ud be like a fight up on the ice in the old days, when we’d be at one another from daylight to dark, an’ tryin’ to tie up our cuts by the light of the aurora borealis.” This was evidently local pleasantry, for the old man cackled over it, and his cronies joined in with gusto.
vi: — So who was the one who brought him back to this land to bury him there? He was murdered all the way in the Cordillera! How could his body possibly be there? I can tell you about dozens of people who have lain at the bottom of the sea, in Greenland or over there, said the old man while pointing north, if at least they weren't carried away further by the currents. Yet their graves are still here, all around you. From where you sit, with your beautiful eyes, you can read all the deceitful inscriptions carved on each tombstone. Look, there's Braithwaite Lowrey over there. I knew his father; he drowned in the shipwreck of the “Life is Beautiful” off the coast of Greenland when he was just twenty... and Andrew Woodhouse too, he also drowned near there in 1777..., and John Paxton, he died a year later off Cape Farewell..., then old John Rawlings, whose grandfather sailed with me, died in the Gulf of Finland at the age of fifty. Many, many... Do you believe that when they hear the trumpets of the Last Judgment blaring, all these men will rush to Whitby? I think so! I assure you that they will push and shove each other so much that it will seem like a battle on the ice, lasting from dawn until dark, where the warriors have to bandage their wounds under the dim light of the Arctic. Surely, that is a common joke in this place, because when he said it, the old man laughed heartily along with his two friends sitting beside him.
tr: “I wonder who brought him home for burial. He was killed off the coast of Andres! You also thought his body was buried here! I can count a dozen people for you whose bones lie in the Greenland Sea above,” he pointed north, “or wherever the currents have carried them. Their tombstones stand around you. You can read the lies written in small letters with your own eyes from here. This is Braithwaite Lowrey - I knew his father - lost off Lively in Greenland in '20; or Andrew Woodhouse, drowned in the same seas in 1777; or John Paxton, drowned off Cape Farewell a year later; or old John Rawlings, who sailed with me, drowned in the Gulf of Finland in '50. Do you think all these men will have to rush to Whitby when the trumpet of Israfil sounds? I doubt it! Let me tell you, when they come here, they will jostle and shove, just like the fights we had on the ice in the old days; from morning till night, we would get into it and try to tend to our wounds under the polar lights.” Clearly, this was a local joke because the old man laughed, and his companions joined him with pleasure.
es: –I wonder, who brought him to be buried here? Murdered on the outskirts of the coast of Andres! And you all know that his body rests there!. I could list a dozen whose bones lie in the seas of Greenland, to the north -and he pointed in that direction-, or wherever they have been carried by the currents. Their tombstones are around you, and with your young eyes you can read from here the lies that lie between the lines. Regarding this Braithwaite Lowrey…, I knew his father, he was lost on the Lively off the coast of Greenland in the year twenty; and Andrew Woodhouse, drowned in the same sea in 1777; and John Paxton, who drowned near Cape Farewell a year later, and old John Rawlings, whose grandfather sailed with me and who drowned in the Gulf of Finland in the year fifty. Do you think all these men have to hurry to Whitby when the trumpet sounds? I highly doubt it! I assure you that by the time they got here they would be bumping and shaking each other in a way that would look like a fight on the ice, like in the old days when we faced each other from dawn to dusk and tried to heal our wounds by the light of the aurora borealis. Evidently, this was a local joke, because the old man laughed as he spoke and his friends celebrated it very gladly.

en: “But,” I said, “surely you are not quite correct, for you start on the assumption that all the poor people, or their spirits, will have to take their tombstones with them on the Day of Judgment. Do you think that will be really necessary?”
vi: — But, - I asked - surely you were mistaken in thinking that all those poor people, or rather their pitiable souls, necessarily have to present themselves at their graves at the moment of the Last Judgment. Do you really still think that is something that must happen?
tr: "But," I said, "I think you are not quite right because you are acting on the assumption that all poor people or their souls will have to carry their tombstones on 'Judgment Day.' Do you really think this will be necessary?"
es: –But -I said-, surely this is not entirely correct because you assume that all the poor people, or their spirits, will have to carry their tombstones with them on Judgment Day. Do you really think that will be necessary?

en: “Well, what else be they tombstones for? Answer me that, miss!”
vi: — That's right, if not, then what are the stone tombs used for, I'm asking you, girl? — To please the members of their family, right, old man?
tr: “Eh, what other purpose could gravestones have? Answer me, young lady!”
es: –Well, what else could those tombstones be for? Answer me that, dear!

en: “To please their relatives, I suppose.”
vi: — To please the families, right old man? -
tr: “To make their relatives happy, I think.”
es: –I suppose to please their relatives.

en: “To please their relatives, you suppose!” This he said with intense scorn. “How will it pleasure their relatives to know that lies is wrote over them, and that everybody in the place knows that they be lies?” He pointed to a stone at our feet which had been laid down as a slab, on which the seat was rested, close to the edge of the cliff. “Read the lies on that thruff-stean,” he said. The letters were upside down to me from where I sat, but Lucy was more opposite to them, so she leant over and read:—
vi: The old man mocked, mimicking my question. - Try telling me, what pleasure is there for the families when they know that the inscriptions on those graves are just lies, and that everyone knows it? Then he pointed to a stone lying at our feet, like a slab keeping the bench balanced on the edge of the cliff: — Read these lines of lies below. From where I was sitting, I could only read the words on the back, but from Lucy's spot, everything was readable. Seeing me mention it, Lucy bent down to read:
tr: “To make your relatives happy, you think!” He said this with great disdain. “How will knowing that lies are written about them and that everyone here knows these are lies make your relatives happy?” He pointed to a stone lying on its side near the edge of the yard, forming the base of the bench above it. “Read what is written on that horizontal tombstone.” From where I was sitting, the letters appeared upside down, but Lucy saw them more upright from her position, so she leaned in and began to read:
es: –I suppose to please their relatives. –"He supposes that to please his relatives!" – his words were imbued with intense sarcasm-. "How can it please his relatives to know that everything written there is a lie, and that everyone, in this place, knows it is?" He pointed to a stone at our feet that had been placed as a tombstone, upon which the chair rested, near the edge of the cliff. –Read the lies that are on that tombstone -he said. The letters were upside down from where I was; but Lucy was facing them, so she leaned over and read:

en: “Sacred to the memory of George Canon, who died, in the hope of a glorious resurrection, on July, 29, 1873, falling from the rocks at Kettleness. This tomb was erected by his sorrowing mother to her dearly beloved son. ‘He was the only son of his mother, and she was a widow.’ Really, Mr. Swales, I don’t see anything very funny in that!” She spoke her comment very gravely and somewhat severely.
vi: "In loving memory of George Canon, who died on July 29, 1873, falling from the mountain peak into the sea, in the hope of a glorious resurrection of the flesh." "This grave was erected by his mother, who suffered an unending sorrow throughout her life for the loss of a beloved son." "He was the only son, and his mother was a widow." — There's really nothing strange here at all, - Lucy said - old Swales. My friend commented in a truly serious tone.
tr: “In sacred memory of George Canon, who fell from the cliffs at Kettleness on July 29, 1873, in the hope of a glorious resurrection.” This grave was erected by his grieving mother for her beloved son. He was his mother's only son, and the poor woman was a widow. “Really, Mr. Swales? I don't see anything to laugh about in this!” She expressed her comment with great seriousness and a bit of sternness.
es: –To the sacred memory of George Canon, who died in the hope of a glorious resurrection, on July 29, 1873, after falling from the rocks at Kettleness. This tomb was erected by his grieving mother for her dearly beloved son. "He was the only son of his mother who was a widow." To tell the truth, Mr. Swales, I don't see anything funny about that -her words were spoken with utmost seriousness and a certain severity.

en: “Ye don’t see aught funny! Ha! ha! But that’s because ye don’t gawm the sorrowin’ mother was a hell-cat that hated him because he was acrewk’d—a regular lamiter he was—an’ he hated her so that he committed suicide in order that she mightn’t get an insurance she put on his life. He blew nigh the top of his head off with an old musket that they had for scarin’ the crows with. ’Twarn’t for crows then, for it brought the clegs and the dowps to him. That’s the way he fell off the rocks. And, as to hopes of a glorious resurrection, I’ve often heard him say masel’ that he hoped he’d go to hell, for his mother was so pious that she’d be sure to go to heaven, an’ he didn’t want to addle where she was. Now isn’t that stean at any rate”—he hammered it with his stick as he spoke—“a pack of lies? and won’t it make Gabriel keckle when Geordie comes pantin’ up the grees with the tombstean balanced on his hump, and asks it to be took as evidence!”
vi: — Don't you find anything strange... Ha! Ha! Of course not, because you don't know that poor mother, a wicked witch who hated her son bitterly just because he was weak, and the son also hated his mother because she couldn't provide for his life. He shot himself in the head with an old gun that he used to scare off the young crows. That day, he didn't use the gun to scare the crows anymore... And what people said was a fall from the cliffs... Of course he fell, and the so-called hope of a glorious resurrection of the dead, I often heard that he wanted to go to hell, because his mother, a very devout person, would surely go to heaven, and he didn't want to die in heaven with his mother... Now you can say that this stone doesn't bear lies!
tr: "So you see nothing to laugh about! Ha! Ha! Because you don't know that the grieving mother was a witch who hated her son because he was crippled -lame- and that he hated her so much that he committed suicide to prevent her from getting the money from the life insurance she had taken out for him. He blew his head off with the gun they used to scare away the crows. So it wasn't for the crows, because it gathered flies and carrion crows around him. This is how he fell from the cliffs. And as for his hopes of a glorious resurrection, personally, I had often heard him say that he hoped to go to Hell frequently because his mother was very religious and would surely go to Heaven, and he didn't want to be where she was. Now this stone," -he was hitting the stone with his cane as he spoke- "isn't it a pile of lies no matter what? And when Geordie comes out of breath through the trees with the tombstone on his back and asks for the stone to be taken as evidence, won't it make Gabriel chuckle?"
es: –He doesn't find it funny! Ha! Ha! But that's because he doesn't know that the grieving mother was a witch who hated him because he was a rascal... a real rascal...; and he hated her so much that he committed suicide so she wouldn't collect an insurance policy she had taken out on his life. He almost blew his brains out with an old shotgun they used to scare away the crows; he didn't aim it at the crows that time, but it made other objects fall on him. That's how he fell from the rocks. And as for the hopes of a glorious resurrection, I often heard him say, miss, that he hoped to go to hell because his mother was so pious that she would surely go to heaven and he didn't want to be in the same place as her. Now, in any case, isn't that a pack of lies? – and he emphasized the words with his cane-. And won't it make Gabriel laugh when Geordie comes panting up the rocks with his tombstone balanced on his hump, and asks that it be taken as evidence!

en: I did not know what to say, but Lucy turned the conversation as she said, rising up:—
vi: I was about to respond when Lucy suddenly stood up and steered the conversation in a different direction:
tr: I didn't know what to say, but Lucy changed the subject as she stood up:
es: I didn't know what to say; but Lucy changed the conversation by saying, as she stood up:

en: “Oh, why did you tell us of this? It is my favourite seat, and I cannot leave it; and now I find I must go on sitting over the grave of a suicide.”
vi: — Oh! Why do you keep telling us all these pointless stories? This is the chair I usually sit on, and I will never give up that habit, but now I will always tell myself that I am sitting on the grave of a suicide!
tr: “Ah! Why did you tell us this? This is my favorite bench and I can't leave it; but now I learn that I will continue to sit on the grave of someone who committed suicide.”
es: –Why did you tell us about this? It's my favorite seat and I can't leave it, and now I find out that I have to keep sitting on a suicide's grave.

en: “That won’t harm ye, my pretty; an’ it may make poor Geordie gladsome to have so trim a lass sittin’ on his lap. That won’t hurt ye. Why, I’ve sat here off an’ on for nigh twenty years past, an’ it hasn’t done me no harm. Don’t ye fash about them as lies under ye, or that doesn’ lie there either! It’ll be time for ye to be getting scart when ye see the tombsteans all run away with, and the place as bare as a stubble-field. There’s the clock, an’ I must gang. My service to ye, ladies!” And off he hobbled.
vi: — That won't bother you, beautiful girl! And that poor George would surely be very happy to see such a charming girl sitting on his pillow... No, that won't bother you at all... Since I was not even twenty years old, I have been sitting here, and since then, I have never felt uncomfortable? Don't think too much about those lying at your feet, or those who aren't lying there at all. You will have plenty of time to be scared when you see all the graves being taken away one by one and the cemetery left bare like a field with only stubble... But anyway, it's time, I have to go back now. Goodbye, ladies? The old man trudged away into the distance.
tr: “This won't harm you, my dear; knowing that someone so elegant is sitting on his lap would make poor Geordie happy. It won't harm you. I've been sitting here from time to time for almost twenty years, and it hasn't harmed me. Don't worry about the lies lying beneath you or not! It will take quite a while until you see all the tombstones fleeing and this whole place left as empty as a stubble field. There, the clock is striking, I must go. Always at your service, ladies!” And he limped away.
es: –That won't do you any harm, darling, and Geordie might be glad to have such a slender girl on his lap. It won't hurt you, I've sat there countless times over the past twenty years and nothing has happened to me. Don't worry about guys like the one lying there or those who aren't there either. The time to run will come when you see everyone carrying the tombstones and the place is as bare as a mown field. The hour is already sounding and I must go, at your feet, ladies! And he walked away limping.

en: Lucy and I sat awhile, and it was all so beautiful before us that we took hands as we sat; and she told me all over again about Arthur and their coming marriage. That made me just a little heart-sick, for I haven’t heard from Jonathan for a whole month.
vi: We sat for a while longer. The scenery was so beautiful! Lucy told me again about Arthur and their upcoming wedding. I suddenly felt a pang of sadness; it has been over a month since I last heard from Jonathan.
tr: We sat with Lucy for a while; the view in front of us was so beautiful that we held hands while sitting; she told me again and again about Arthur and their upcoming marriage. This saddened me a bit, because I haven't heard from Jonathan for a whole month.
es: Lucy and I remained seated for a few moments, and everything before us was so beautiful that we held hands. She told me again about Arthur and his upcoming marriage; that made me feel a bit sad, because I haven't heard anything from Jonathan for a whole month.

en: The same day. I came up here alone, for I am very sad. There was no letter for me. I hope there cannot be anything the matter with Jonathan. The clock has just struck nine. I see the lights scattered all over the town, sometimes in rows where the streets are, and sometimes singly; they run right up the Esk and die away in the curve of the valley. To my left the view is cut off by a black line of roof of the old house next the abbey. The sheep and lambs are bleating in the fields away behind me, and there is a clatter of a donkey’s hoofs up the paved road below. The band on the pier is playing a harsh waltz in good time, and further along the quay there is a Salvation Army meeting in a back street. Neither of the bands hears the other, but up here I hear and see them both. I wonder where Jonathan is and if he is thinking of me! I wish he were here.
vi: • On the same day I returned here with a heavy heart. Still, the mailman hasn't appeared this evening. I hope nothing troublesome has happened to Jonathan. The clock has struck nine. The city lights have been on for a long time, twinkling like falling stars, sometimes solitary, sometimes lighting up in a continuous row along the streets. To my left, the scenery is completely obscured by the old rooftops rising near the monastery. The young lambs are still bleating in the fields behind. And down below, I can clearly hear the slow clopping of a donkey's hooves. The harbor band is playing a sad waltz. A little further away, below the harbor, on a slightly hidden small road, a Salvation Army band is gathering. Suddenly, both bands start playing loud, jarring tunes, neither listening to the other. However, standing here, I can hear both clearly, but in my heart right now is still the image of Jonathan. Where are you? Are you still thinking of me? How I wish to leave this place.
tr: The same day. - I came here alone because I am very sad. There was no letter for me. I hope Jonathan has no problems. The clock has just struck nine. I see lights scattered over the whole town; sometimes in rows along the roads and sometimes individually; to the right, they stretch along the Esk and disappear in the curve of the valley. The view to my left is cut off by a black line belonging to the roof of the house next to the Monastery. Sheep and lambs are bleating in the distant fields behind me, and the clatter of a donkey's hooves can be heard from the asphalt road. The band on the pier is playing a fast, ear-piercing waltz, and in one of the back streets beyond the pier, a Salvation Army meeting is being held. Neither band can hear the other, but here, up above, I can hear and see both. I wonder where Jonathan is and if he is thinking of me! I wish he were here.
es: The same day. I came here alone because I feel very sad. There was no letter for me: I hope nothing has happened to Jonathan. The clock has just struck nine, I can see the lights scattered all over the town, forming rows where the streets are and in other solitary places; they rise up to the Esk and then disappear in the curve of the valley. To my left, the view is cut off by the black line of the roof of the old house next to the abbey. The sheep and lambs are bleating in the distant fields behind me, and from the cobblestone road below comes the sound of donkey hooves. The band on the pier is playing a solemn waltz in good time, and further along the pier, there is a Salvation Army session in some alley. Neither band listens to the other; but from here I can see and hear both. I wonder where Jonathan is and if he is thinking of me! How I wish he were here.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the Diary of Dr. Seward

en: 5 June.—The case of Renfield grows more interesting the more I get to understand the man. He has certain qualities very largely developed; selfishness, secrecy, and purpose. I wish I could get at what is the object of the latter. He seems to have some settled scheme of his own, but what it is I do not yet know. His redeeming quality is a love of animals, though, indeed, he has such curious turns in it that I sometimes imagine he is only abnormally cruel. His pets are of odd sorts. Just now his hobby is catching flies. He has at present such a quantity that I have had myself to expostulate. To my astonishment, he did not break out into a fury, as I expected, but took the matter in simple seriousness. He thought for a moment, and then said: “May I have three days? I shall clear them away.” Of course, I said that would do. I must watch him.
vi: • June 5 The case of Renfield is becoming increasingly interesting, making me understand more and more about human nature. In his personality, the most prominent traits are selfishness, cunning pretense, and stubbornness. I hope I will understand why he is so obstinate. It seems to me that he is harboring a very specific intention, but what is that intention? However, he loves animals very much, though in that affection, expressed in various foolish ways, there is something strangely cruel. Up to now, his eccentricity has been manifested in the hobby of catching flies. I find it unnecessary to keep observing this peculiar behavior, as his absurd actions are not few. One thing that surprises me greatly is that he never gets angry, as I had feared, but after thinking for a moment, he just asked me in a rather serious tone: “Would you agree to give me three days? Within three days, I will make them disappear.” Of course, I replied: “Agreed,” then stared at him as if I had never seen him before.
tr: June 5. - The Renfield case is becoming more interesting as I understand the man better. He has some highly developed qualities: Selfishness, reticence, and determination. I wish I could understand what his determination is directed towards. He seems to have a specific plan of his own, but I don't know what it is yet. His love for animals is one of his good qualities, but he has such unprecedented tendencies in this regard that sometimes I think the man possesses a mere perverse cruelty. He has peculiar kinds of pets. His current hobby is catching flies. At present, he has so many flies that I felt compelled to personally warn him. I was surprised to see that, as I expected, he did not have a fit of rage and took the matter seriously. He thought for a moment and said, “Will you give me three days? I will get rid of them.” Of course, I said I could give him that time. I must keep an eye on him.
es: June 5. Renfield's case becomes more interesting the more I manage to understand the man. He certainly has some very broadly developed characteristics: selfishness, stealth, and intentionality. I wish I could find out what the purpose of the latter is. He seems to have a finished scheme of his own, but I don't know what it is. His redeeming virtue is his love for animals, although, in fact, he has such curious changes that sometimes I imagine he is just abnormally cruel. He plays with all kinds of animals. Right now his hobby is catching flies. Currently, he has so many that I had an altercation with him. To my astonishment, he did not have any outburst of fury, as I had expected, but took the matter with a very dignified seriousness. He reflected for a moment, and then said: –Can you give me three days? At the end of them, I will set them free. I told him that, of course, I would give him that time. I must watch him.

en: 18 June.—He has turned his mind now to spiders, and has got several very big fellows in a box. He keeps feeding them with his flies, and the number of the latter is becoming sensibly diminished, although he has used half his food in attracting more flies from outside to his room.
vi: • June 18 Now he only thought about the spiders, the very large spiders he had put into a box. He fed the spiders with the flies he caught. The number of flies had decreased significantly after being caught by him several times. He caught the flies by using half of his food ration as bait on the window ledge.
tr: June 18. - Now he is obsessed with spiders and has a box full of large spiders. He feeds them with flies, and although he uses half of his food to attract flies outside his room, the number of flies has reasonably decreased.
es: June 18. Now he has turned his attention to spiders, and he has a few very large specimens in a box. He spends the whole day feeding them with his flies, and the number of the latter has decreased significantly, although he has used half of his food to attract more flies from outside.

en: 1 July.—His spiders are now becoming as great a nuisance as his flies, and to-day I told him that he must get rid of them. He looked very sad at this, so I said that he must clear out some of them, at all events. He cheerfully acquiesced in this, and I gave him the same time as before for reduction. He disgusted me much while with him, for when a horrid blow-fly, bloated with some carrion food, buzzed into the room, he caught it, held it exultantly for a few moments between his finger and thumb, and, before I knew what he was going to do, put it in his mouth and ate it. I scolded him for it, but he argued quietly that it was very good and very wholesome; that it was life, strong life, and gave life to him. This gave me an idea, or the rudiment of one. I must watch how he gets rid of his spiders. He has evidently some deep problem in his mind, for he keeps a little note-book in which he is always jotting down something. Whole pages of it are filled with masses of figures, generally single numbers added up in batches, and then the totals added in batches again, as though he were “focussing” some account, as the auditors put it.
vi: • July 1 The number of spiders is increasing along with the number of flies being caught. I angrily made him throw them all away. But seeing his sorrowful face, I felt a pang of sympathy. I told him at least to throw away a portion. He promised to do so. While sitting with him, I suddenly felt a shiver when a huge fly quickly flew into the room; he swiftly caught the creature, then held it between his thumb and index finger, examining it with a very delighted expression. And before I could guess what would happen next, he suddenly popped the fly into his mouth and chewed it voraciously. I did not hesitate to express my disgust, but he nonchalantly replied that flies are delicious, and that the vibrant life of the fly would invigorate him. A thought, or rather a suspicion, flashed through my mind: I needed to know how he intended to deal with the spiders. There must be something quite serious occupying his mind, as he was scribbling furiously into a pocket notebook. The pages were filled with numbers, as if he was doing calculations.
tr: July 1st. - Now the spiders have also become as big a problem as the flies, and today I told him that he needed to get rid of the spiders. He was very upset to hear this, so I told him that he still needed to clean up some of them. He accepted this cheerfully, and I gave him the same amount of time I had given him before to reduce their number. When I was with him, he made me feel terribly nauseous, because when a disgusting, bloated horsefly that had been feeding on rotting meat buzzed into the room, he caught it, held it joyfully between his fingers for a few seconds, and before I could understand what he was going to do, he put it in his mouth and ate it. I scolded him for this, but he calmly argued that the fly was very tasty and nutritious; that it meant life - strong life - and it gave him life. This gave me an idea or at least a fragment of an idea. I should watch how he gets rid of his spiders. Clearly, he has a serious problem in his mind, because he keeps a notebook in which he constantly scribbles something. As if, in the words of the auditors, he is "focusing" on an account, all the pages of the notebook are filled with heaps of numbers, mostly gathered in clusters, consisting of odd numbers; then he adds these totals together in clusters as well.
es: July 1st. His spiders are now becoming as much of a nuisance as his flies, and today I told him he must get rid of them. He became very sad upon hearing this, so I told him he should at least get rid of some. He cheerfully accepted this proposal, and I gave him the same amount of time again to carry out the reduction. While I was with him, he caused me much distress, for when a horrible blowfly, swollen with food waste, buzzed into the room, he caught it and held it for a moment between his index finger and thumb, and before I could warn him of what he was about to do, he popped it into his mouth and ate it. I scolded him for what he had done, but he argued that it tasted very good and was very healthy; that it was life, strong life, and that it gave life to him. This gave me an idea, or the rudiment of one. I must watch how he gets rid of his spiders. He evidently has a difficult problem on his mind, for he is always carrying a small notebook in which he writes something down every moment. Whole pages of that notebook are filled with heaps of numbers, usually simple numbers added in batches, and then the sums added again in batches, as if "focusing" on some account, as auditors say.

en: 8 July.—There is a method in his madness, and the rudimentary idea in my mind is growing. It will be a whole idea soon, and then, oh, unconscious cerebration! you will have to give the wall to your conscious brother. I kept away from my friend for a few days, so that I might notice if there were any change. Things remain as they were except that he has parted with some of his pets and got a new one. He has managed to get a sparrow, and has already partially tamed it. His means of taming is simple, for already the spiders have diminished. Those that do remain, however, are well fed, for he still brings in the flies by tempting them with his food.
vi: • July 8 In a fit of madness, he followed a real method, and that observation gradually became clearer in my mind. That method was completely clear. Oh, the workings of the unconscious mind? Then one must give way to a conscious intellect. I deliberately avoided meeting my patient for a few days, convinced that he was undergoing a notable change in state. He could catch a sparrow and tame it in a very simple way that I suddenly guessed: the spiders in the box had significantly decreased. However, the remaining spiders were very plump, as he diligently caught flies every day with a portion of food placed on the windowsill.
tr: 8 July. - There is a method in his madness, and the thought in my mind is maturing. Soon it will be a complete idea, and then, oh, unconscious thought! You must bow to your conscious brother. I stayed away from my friend for a few days so that I might notice if there was any difference. Everything was the same except that he had parted with some of his pets and acquired a new one. He had managed to obtain a sparrow and had even partially tamed it. The method of taming was simple, for the number of spiders had already decreased. The remaining ones were well-fed, for he was still offering them the flies he lured with his food.
es: July 8. There is a method in his madness, and the rudiments of the idea in my mind are growing; soon it will be a complete idea, and then, oh, unconscious cerebration!, you will have to give way to your conscious sister. I stayed away from my friend for a few days, so that I could see if any changes occurred. Things remain as before, except that he has abandoned some of his little animals and acquired a new one. He got himself a sparrow, and has partially tamed it. His way of taming is very simple, as the spiders have considerably decreased. However, those that still remain are well-fed, as he still attracts flies by tempting them with his food.

en: 19 July.—We are progressing. My friend has now a whole colony of sparrows, and his flies and spiders are almost obliterated. When I came in he ran to me and said he wanted to ask me a great favour—a very, very great favour; and as he spoke he fawned on me like a dog. I asked him what it was, and he said, with a sort of rapture in his voice and bearing:—
vi: • July 19 We have made progress in studying the case. Now Renfield has a whole flock of sparrows, while the swarms of flies and spiders have almost completely disappeared. Seeing me enter the room, he hurriedly came up and said that he wanted to ask me for a big favor, a very big one; as he spoke, he stroked me like a dog licking its owner. I asked what exactly he needed, and he ecstatically replied: "I want a cat, a cute little kitten to be my friend.
tr: July 19. - We are making progress. My friend now has a complete sparrow colony, and with it, the flies and spiders are almost entirely gone. When I entered, he ran to me and said he wanted a big favor - a very, very big favor; he was fawning like a dog as he spoke. I asked him what he wanted; with a kind of ecstasy in his voice and manner, he said:
es: July 19. We are making progress. My friend now has almost a complete colony of sparrows, and his flies and spiders have almost disappeared. When I entered, he ran towards me and told me he wanted to ask me a great favor; a very, very big favor; and as he spoke to me, he fawned over me like a dog. I asked him what he wanted, and he told me, with an emotional voice that almost broke into sobs:

en: “A kitten, a nice little, sleek playful kitten, that I can play with, and teach, and feed—and feed—and feed!” I was not unprepared for this request, for I had noticed how his pets went on increasing in size and vivacity, but I did not care that his pretty family of tame sparrows should be wiped out in the same manner as the flies and the spiders; so I said I would see about it, and asked him if he would not rather have a cat than a kitten. His eagerness betrayed him as he answered:—
vi: I will train it and feed it... Oh! Yes... I will feed it." Indeed, I was a bit surprised by this, as I noticed that he seemed to like bigger animals more and more. I really cannot accept the fact that the lovely tamed sparrow family has disappeared in the same way that the flies and spiders have; therefore, I replied that I still needed to think about it. However, before leaving the room, I asked him in a very indifferent tone why he preferred a kitten over a grown cat. — Oh! Yes, - He replied cheerfully - a big cat.
tr: “A kitten, a small, cute, shiny-furred, playful kitten that I can play with, train, and feed -and feed- and feed.” I was not caught unprepared by this request, as I had noticed that the size and liveliness of her pets were increasing, but I did not care about the fact that the lovely pet sparrow family would be gone in the same way as flies and spiders; therefore, I said I would take care of it and asked if she wanted an adult cat instead of a kitten. Her greed betrayed her as she replied:
es: –A kitten; a little kitten, silky and playful, so that I can play with it, and I can tame it, and I can feed it, and feed it, and feed it! I was not unprepared for such a request, as I had noticed how his little animals were growing in size and liveliness. But it did not seem pleasant to me that his lovely family of tamed sparrows would be swept away in the same manner as the flies and spiders had been; so I told him I would think about it, and asked if he would not prefer to have a big cat instead of a kitten. Anxiety betrayed him as he answered:

en: “Oh, yes, I would like a cat! I only asked for a kitten lest you should refuse me a cat. No one would refuse me a kitten, would they?” I shook my head, and said that at present I feared it would not be possible, but that I would see about it. His face fell, and I could see a warning of danger in it, for there was a sudden fierce, sidelong look which meant killing. The man is an undeveloped homicidal maniac. I shall test him with his present craving and see how it will work out; then I shall know more.
vi: I would really like to have a big cat! If I asked you for a kitten, it was because I was afraid you would refuse me a big cat? No one would refuse me a small cat, right? I shook my head and replied that I thought it was impossible, at least for now, but eventually we would... His face darkened, and I immediately read a dangerous warning on that face, as his eyes suddenly flashed with cruel glints like those of a murderer. There is no doubt anymore, this patient is indeed a violent murderer. Then I will see where the obsession of the devil will lead him.
tr: “Ah! Yes! I want a cat! The only reason I asked for a kitten was to see if you would refuse to give me one. No one refuses to give me a kitten, right?” I shook my head and said that I was afraid it was impossible at the moment but that I would look into it. His face fell; I could see an expression of danger warning on his face because suddenly, a merciless, sideways glance that meant killing settled on his face. This man is an undeveloped, homicidal maniac. I must test him with his current request and see how it turns out; then I will learn more.
es: –Oh, yes! Of course, I would like a big cat! I only asked for a kitten fearing that you would refuse to give me a big cat. No one can deny me a little kitten, right? I shook my head and told him that at the moment I feared it wouldn't be possible, but that I would see what I could do. His face darkened and I could see a warning of danger in it, as he gave me a grim look, which signified a desire to kill. The man is a potential homicidal maniac. I will test him with his current desires and see what comes of it: then I will know more.

en: 10 p. m.—I have visited him again and found him sitting in a corner brooding. When I came in he threw himself on his knees before me and implored me to let him have a cat; that his salvation depended upon it. I was firm, however, and told him that he could not have it, whereupon he went without a word, and sat down, gnawing his fingers, in the corner where I had found him. I shall see him in the morning early.
vi: • 10 PM When I returned, I saw him sitting dejectedly in a corner of the room. As soon as he saw me, he hurriedly knelt down and begged me to bring the cat. I immediately replied that it was impossible. Hearing me say that, he angrily returned to his place, clenching his fists as he walked. I would see him again early the next morning.
tr: It's 10 PM. - I visited him once more and found him sitting in a corner, lost in deep thoughts. When I entered, he knelt before me and begged for permission to feed a cat; he said his salvation depended on it. However, I was determined and told him he couldn't feed the cat, upon which he walked away without a word and went to the corner where I had found him, sitting and gnawing at his fingers. I will see him early tomorrow morning.
es: 10 p. m. I visited him again and found him sitting in a corner, head down. When I entered, he fell to his knees before me and begged me to please let him have a cat; that his salvation depended on it. However, I was firm and told him that I couldn't tell him, so he got up without saying a word, sat down again in the corner where I had found him, and began to nibble on his fingers. I will come to see him early in the morning.

en: 20 July.—Visited Renfield very early, before the attendant went his rounds. Found him up and humming a tune. He was spreading out his sugar, which he had saved, in the window, and was manifestly beginning his fly-catching again; and beginning it cheerfully and with a good grace. I looked around for his birds, and not seeing them, asked him where they were. He replied, without turning round, that they had all flown away. There were a few feathers about the room and on his pillow a drop of blood. I said nothing, but went and told the keeper to report to me if there were anything odd about him during the day.
vi: • July 20 I met Renfield very early, even earlier than when the warden went to wake the patients in the rooms. He was standing, humming some tune, while his hands were sprinkling sugar grains on the window sill to bait flies. The task made him visibly happy. I glanced around for the sparrows, but didn't see any. Seeing me ask, he didn't bother to turn around and replied that they had all flown away. I noticed a few tufts of feathers on the ground, and there was a bloodstain on the pillow he slept on. When leaving, I tried to act as if nothing had happened, but still instructed the gardener to inform me if anything unusual occurred during the day.
tr: July 20. - Before the nurse made her morning rounds, I visited Renfield very early in the morning. I found him standing, humming a tune. He was spreading the sugar he had collected on the window and was clearly starting to catch flies again; he began this task with joy and a certain dignity. I looked around for his birds and, not seeing them, asked where they were. Without turning around, he said they had all flown away. There were a few scattered feathers in the room and a drop of blood on his pillow. I didn't say anything, but I went to the nurse and told her to inform me if there was anything unusual about Renfield during the day.
es: July 20. I visited Renfield very early, before my assistant made his rounds. I found him already up, humming a tune. He was spreading the sugar he had stored on the window, and he was starting again to catch flies; and he was starting again with joy. I looked around for his birds, and not seeing them, I asked him where they were. He answered, without turning to look at me, that they had all escaped. There were a few feathers in the room and on his pillow there were some drops of blood. I said nothing, but went and ordered the guard to report to me if anything strange happened to Renfield during the day.

en: 11 a. m.—The attendant has just been to me to say that Renfield has been very sick and has disgorged a whole lot of feathers. “My belief is, doctor,” he said, “that he has eaten his birds, and that he just took and ate them raw!”
vi: • 11 AM It didn't take long before the warden hurriedly ran to inform me that Renfield was very sick, that he had vomited a whole pile of bird feathers, just bird feathers. "Doctor," the warden told me, "I believe he has eaten his entire flock of birds alive?"
tr: It's 11 in the morning. - The nurse came to me to say that Renfield was very sick and had vomited a ton of bird feathers. “I think, doctor,” he said, “he ate his birds, took his birds and ate them raw!”
es: 11 a. m. My assistant just came to see me to tell me that Renfield is very sick and that he has vomited many feathers. "My belief is, doctor -he told me-, that he has eaten all his birds, and that he has eaten them raw, just like that!".

en: 11 p. m.—I gave Renfield a strong opiate to-night, enough to make even him sleep, and took away his pocket-book to look at it. The thought that has been buzzing about my brain lately is complete, and the theory proved. My homicidal maniac is of a peculiar kind. I shall have to invent a new classification for him, and call him a zoöphagous (life-eating) maniac; what he desires is to absorb as many lives as he can, and he has laid himself out to achieve it in a cumulative way. He gave many flies to one spider and many spiders to one bird, and then wanted a cat to eat the many birds. What would have been his later steps? It would almost be worth while to complete the experiment. It might be done if there were only a sufficient cause. Men sneered at vivisection, and yet look at its results to-day! Why not advance science in its most difficult and vital aspect—the knowledge of the brain? Had I even the secret of one such mind—did I hold the key to the fancy of even one lunatic—I might advance my own branch of science to a pitch compared with which Burdon-Sanderson’s physiology or Ferrier’s brain-knowledge would be as nothing. If only there were a sufficient cause! I must not think too much of this, or I may be tempted; a good cause might turn the scale with me, for may not I too be of an exceptional brain, congenitally?
vi: • 11 PM Tonight, I gave Renfield a sleeping pill and then stole his pocket notebook to read. Indeed, I was not wrong with my assumptions: this murderous patient is truly a very special kind of person. I have to categorize him as unprecedented and call him an animalistic madman, a lunatic who only wants to survive by consuming living creatures. His mind is constantly obsessed with the need to eat as many living bodies as he craves. He has fed countless flies to a spider, raised a bird with many spiders, and then he even wanted a cat to kill the entire flock of birds. What does he intend to do next? I really want to see my experiment through to the end. But to do so, there must be a sufficient reason. People will spit in my face if I talk about dissecting this issue, but in any case, I cannot avoid the current reality. Why not advance science in a more difficult yet vital issue like understanding the brain, the mechanism of human reasoning? If I could understand the mystery of the brain, if I could find the key to unlock the imagination of this unique mental patient, I would surely make a significant leap in my field, and this would allow me to compare myself with the physiologist Burdon Sanderson or the anatomist Ferrier. Just one valid reason is enough! But I don't need to think too much about it, because the temptation is also very simple, a sufficient reason can make me think of a state of balance from my side, because by nature, am I not someone with that special kind of mind?
tr: It's 11 PM. - This evening, I gave Renfield a sedative strong enough to make him sleep and took his small notebook to examine. The thought that was ringing in my head has recently been completed, and my theory has been proven. My homicidal lunatic is of a special kind. I need to discover a new classification for him and define him as a zoophagous (life-eating) lunatic; what he desires is to absorb as much life as possible and to work tirelessly to do so in an accumulative manner. He gave many flies to a spider, many spiders to a bird, and then asked for a cat to eat many birds. What could his next steps be? It was almost worth completing the experiment. If there were sufficient justification, it could be done. People ridicule experiments on living beings, but look at their results today! Why not advance science in the most difficult and crucial aspect - the knowledge of the brain? If I could unlock the secret of such a brain - if I had the key to the imagination of a single lunatic - I could elevate my field of science to a pinnacle where Burdon-Sanderson's physiology and Ferrier's brain knowledge would pale in comparison. If only there were sufficient justification! I must not think about this too much, or I will be tempted; a good justification could point the needle toward me, for am I not, by nature, an extraordinary brain?
es: 11 p.m. Tonight I gave Renfield a strong sedative, enough to make even him sleep, and took his notebook to have a look at it. The thought that has been hovering in my brain lately is complete, and the theory proven. My homicidal maniac is of a peculiar kind. I will have to invent a new classification for him and call him a zoophagous maniac (one who feeds on living things); what he desires is to absorb as many lives as he can, and he has set himself the task of achieving this in a cumulative manner. He gave many flies to each spider, and many spiders to each bird, and then wanted a cat to eat many birds. What would his next step have been? It would almost have been worth completing the experiment. It could be done if there were sufficient cause. Men were scandalized by vivisection, and yet, look at the current results! Why should I not advance science in its most difficult and vital aspect, the knowledge of the human brain? If only I had the secret of such a mind, if I had the key to the fantasy of even one lunatic, I could advance my own branch of science to such a place that, compared to it, Burdon Sanderson's physiology or Ferrier's knowledge of the brain would be little less than nothing. If there were sufficient cause! I must not think too much about this, lest I fall into temptation; a good cause could tip the scale with me, for is it not true that I too may be an exceptional brain, congenitally?

en: How well the man reasoned; lunatics always do within their own scope. I wonder at how many lives he values a man, or if at only one. He has closed the account most accurately, and to-day begun a new record. How many of us begin a new record with each day of our lives?
vi: Indeed, the patient had his own correct way of reasoning! Yes, madmen always have correct reasoning when they pursue their own ideas. I wonder how he evaluated a human being in terms of how many living creatures, or did he evaluate a human life as equivalent to just one living creature? He had concluded his calculations very precisely, and today, he started on new calculations again. Who among us does not start a day with new calculations?
tr: How beautifully humans reason! Madmen always do this within themselves. I wonder how many lives a person values, if such a thing exists. He closed the account very accurately and started a new page today. How many of us start a new page in our lives every day?
es: How well the man reasoned; lunatics always reason well within their own realm. I wonder in how many lives he will value a man, or even just one. He has closed the account with complete accuracy, and today he will start a new record. How many of us start a new record with each day of our lives?

en: To me it seems only yesterday that my whole life ended with my new hope, and that truly I began a new record. So it will be until the Great Recorder sums me up and closes my ledger account with a balance to profit or loss. Oh, Lucy, Lucy, I cannot be angry with you, nor can I be angry with my friend whose happiness is yours; but I must only wait on hopeless and work. Work! work!
vi: As for myself, it seems as if just yesterday, my life had truly sunk along with my youthful aspirations, and I also feel that my life began from zero. It seems as though God is about to call me up there and close the big ledger that clearly records the balance of my gains and losses. Oh! Lucy, Lucy! I cannot blame you for that, nor can I blame the friend who was fortunate enough to share happiness with you. But I should not expect much from an existence without hope, an existence where only work remains the sole important thing to me. Yes, work, only work!
tr: Just yesterday, it felt as if my entire life had ended along with my new hope, and indeed, I started a new chapter. This will continue until the Great Judge tallies my total and closes my main ledger with a balance of profit or loss. Ah! Lucy! Lucy! I cannot be angry with you or with my friend whose happiness is your happiness; but all I can do is wait and work in despair. Work! Work!
es: It seems to me that it was only yesterday when my entire life ended with my new hope, and that a new record truly began. So it will be until the Great Recorder sums me up and closes my account book with a balance of gains or losses. Oh, Lucy, Lucy!, I cannot be angry with you, nor can I be angry with my friend whose happiness is yours; but I must only wait in misfortune and work. Work, work!.

en: If I only could have as strong a cause as my poor mad friend there—a good, unselfish cause to make me work—that would be indeed happiness.
vi: As long as I can find a compelling reason like the argument of that patient and then, if that reason is strong enough to drive me into work, I will surely find some form of happiness.
tr: I wish I had as strong a reason as my poor mad friend there; a good and selfless reason to make me work; that would truly be my happiness.
es: If I could have a cause as strong as the one my poor crazy friend has, a good, selfless cause that would make me work, that would undoubtedly be happiness.

en: Mina Murray’s Journal.
vi: Mina Murray's Diary
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: From the journal of Mina Murray

en: 26 July.—I am anxious, and it soothes me to express myself here; it is like whispering to one’s self and listening at the same time. And there is also something about the shorthand symbols that makes it different from writing. I am unhappy about Lucy and about Jonathan. I had not heard from Jonathan for some time, and was very concerned; but yesterday dear Mr. Hawkins, who is always so kind, sent me a letter from him. I had written asking him if he had heard, and he said the enclosed had just been received. It is only a line dated from Castle Dracula, and says that he is just starting for home. That is not like Jonathan; I do not understand it, and it makes me uneasy. Then, too, Lucy, although she is so well, has lately taken to her old habit of walking in her sleep. Her mother has spoken to me about it, and we have decided that I am to lock the door of our room every night. Mrs. Westenra has got an idea that sleep-walkers always go out on roofs of houses and along the edges of cliffs and then get suddenly wakened and fall over with a despairing cry that echoes all over the place. Poor dear, she is naturally anxious about Lucy, and she tells me that her husband, Lucy’s father, had the same habit; that he would get up in the night and dress himself and go out, if he were not stopped. Lucy is to be married in the autumn, and she is already planning out her dresses and how her house is to be arranged. I sympathise with her, for I do the same, only Jonathan and I will start in life in a very simple way, and shall have to try to make both ends meet. Mr. Holmwood—he is the Hon. Arthur Holmwood, only son of Lord Godalming—is coming up here very shortly—as soon as he can leave town, for his father is not very well, and I think dear Lucy is counting the moments till he comes. She wants to take him up to the seat on the churchyard cliff and show him the beauty of Whitby. I daresay it is the waiting which disturbs her; she will be all right when he arrives.
vi: • July 26 The more time passes, the more anxious I feel, and writing in my diary somewhat eases my mind; it's like confiding in myself. Moreover, writing in shorthand gives me a different feeling compared to regular writing. I feel worried for Lucy as well as for Jonathan. It's been a long time since I last heard from him, but yesterday, Mr. Hawkins, who is always very kind, sent me a letter he received from Jonathan. The letter contained only a few short lines informing about his return from Dracula's castle. This is not like Jonathan at all? I don't understand what could have happened... why do I long for peace of mind so much! As for Lucy, although she seems much healthier, lately, she has been experiencing sleepwalking, also known as somnambulism as the doctors call it. Her mother told me about it, and we decided that from now on, I will lock the door tightly every night. Mrs. Westenra always imagines that sleepwalkers often climb onto the roof, walk to the edge of the most precarious walls, and then wake up and fall to the ground with a desperate, tragic scream that can be heard everywhere. The poor mother has trembled many times at the thought of such a tragedy happening to her Lucy. She told me that in the past, her husband, Lucy's father, also suffered from similar conditions: he would often wake up in the middle of the night, get dressed, and wander out of the house if no one stopped him. Lucy is supposed to get married this fall; she has already prepared her wedding dress, house, and a bunch of clothes to take along. Sir Holmwood - the honorable Arthur Holmwood, son of Lord Godalming and Lucy's fiancé, will surely come here soon; he will come as soon as he can leave the city, as his father is ill. Lucy quietly counts each day, each hour...She says she really wants to sit with him on the stone bench in the cemetery and show him the magnificent scenery of Whitby. I think her anxious waiting will negatively affect her health. I hope she will be satisfied when she meets her fiancé here.
tr: July 26. - I am anxious and expressing myself here calms me; it's like whispering to oneself and listening at the same time. Also, there is something in the shorthand symbols that sets it apart from regular writing. I am unhappy about Lucy and Jonathan. I hadn't heard from Jonathan for a while and was worried; but yesterday, dear Mr. Hawkins, who has always been very kind, sent me a letter from him. I had asked him if he had heard from Jonathan, and he said that the enclosed letter had just arrived. The letter was a single line written from Castle Dracula, saying that he was about to set off for home. This is not at all like Jonathan; I don't understand anything and this situation makes me very uneasy. Then, Lucy, although she is actually very well, has recently reverted to her old sleepwalking habit. Her mother told me about this and we decided to lock our room door every night. Mrs. Westenra thinks that sleepwalkers always go up to the roofs of houses, walk along the edges of cliffs, and then suddenly wake up and fall down with a desperate scream that echoes everywhere. Poor thing, she is naturally worried about Lucy; and she tells me that her husband, that is, Lucy's father, had the same habit and would get up, dress, and go out at night if not stopped. Lucy will get married in the fall; she is already planning her clothes and how her house should be arranged. I understand her because I am doing the same, only Jonathan and I will start life from a much simpler place and try to make ends meet. Mr. Holmwood - that is, the Honorable Arthur Holmwood, the only son of Lord Godalming - is coming here very soon, as soon as he manages to leave town, because his father is not very well; I think dear Lucy is counting the seconds until he arrives. She wants to take him to the bench on the hill in the churchyard and show him the beauty of Whitby. I can tell that what bothers her is the waiting; she will be fine when Mr. Holmwood arrives.
es: July 26. I am anxious and it calms me to express myself in writing; it is like whispering to oneself and listening at the same time. And there is something also about the shorthand symbols that makes it different from simple writing. I am sad for Lucy and for Jonathan. I had not heard from Jonathan for some time, and I was very worried; but yesterday dear Mr. Hawkins, who is always so kind, sent me a letter from him. I had written to him asking if he had heard from Jonathan and he replied that the letter he was sending me he had just received. It is just a line dated from Dracula's castle, in which he says that at that moment he is starting the journey back home. It is not like Jonathan; I do not quite understand, and I feel very uneasy. And then, also Lucy, although she is so well, has lately fallen back into her old habit of sleepwalking. Her mother has spoken to me about it, and we have decided that I should lock our room door every night. Mrs. Westenra has the idea that sleepwalkers always go walking on the roofs of houses and along the edges of cliffs, and then wake up suddenly and fall off with a desperate cry that echoes all over the place. Poor thing, naturally she is anxious about Lucy, and she has told me that her husband, Lucy's father, had the same habit; that he would get up at night and dress and go out for a walk, if he was not stopped. Lucy is going to get married in the autumn, and she is already planning her dresses and how her house is going to be arranged. I understand her well, for I will do the same, with the difference that Jonathan and I will start life in a simple way, and we will have to try to make both ends meet. Mr. Holmwood (he is the honorable Arthur Holmwood, only son of Lord Godalming) is going to come here for a brief visit, as soon as he can leave the town, for his father is not so well, and I believe dear Lucy is counting the minutes until he arrives. She wants to take him to the bench in the churchyard on the cliff and show him the beauty of Whitby. I dare say it is the waiting that makes her impatient: she will feel better when he arrives.

en: 27 July.—No news from Jonathan. I am getting quite uneasy about him, though why I should I do not know; but I do wish that he would write, if it were only a single line. Lucy walks more than ever, and each night I am awakened by her moving about the room. Fortunately, the weather is so hot that she cannot get cold; but still the anxiety and the perpetually being wakened is beginning to tell on me, and I am getting nervous and wakeful myself. Thank God, Lucy’s health keeps up. Mr. Holmwood has been suddenly called to Ring to see his father, who has been taken seriously ill. Lucy frets at the postponement of seeing him, but it does not touch her looks; she is a trifle stouter, and her cheeks are a lovely rose-pink. She has lost that anæmic look which she had. I pray it will all last.
vi: • July 27 There is still no further news about Jonathan. Why doesn't he write to me, even just a word? Lately, Lucy has been getting up more often at night, and every time I wake up, I see her pacing back and forth in the room. Fortunately, the weather is still warm, otherwise she would surely catch a cold. As for me, my anxiety keeps growing, and the restless, almost sleepless nights have made me very tense. On the contrary, thank God, Lucy is still healthy. Holmwood just received a telegram and had to return to Ring immediately; Lord Godalming's health is becoming very serious. Of course, Lucy is very upset because she cannot meet her fiancé as she thought she would, sometimes she even shows irritation and frustration, but her health is not affected at all, and her cheeks are sometimes even rosier than usual. May this last forever.
tr: July 27. - No news from Jonathan. Although I don't know why I should be, I am getting increasingly worried about him; I keep thinking that I wish he would write something, even if it's just a single line. Lucy is walking more than ever and I wake up every night to her movements in the room. Fortunately, the weather is so hot that it's impossible for her to catch a cold; but still, the anxiety I feel and the constant waking up are affecting me badly; I am nervous and sleepless. Thank God, Lucy's health is good. Mr. Holmwood was suddenly called to Ring to see his father, who has become seriously ill. Lucy is sad about the postponement of seeing him, but this situation does not affect her appearance; she has gained a little weight and her cheeks have turned a beautiful rosy pink. There is no trace left of the previous pale appearance. I pray that it continues this way.
es: July 27. No news from Jonathan. I'm getting anxious about him, although I don't know exactly why; but I would really like him to write, even if it's just a line. Lucy walks more than ever, and every night I wake up because she is pacing up and down the room. Fortunately, the weather is so hot that she can't catch a cold; but in any case, the anxiety and being perpetually awake are starting to affect me, and I myself am getting nervous and suffering a bit of insomnia. Thank God, Lucy's health is holding up. Mr. Holmwood has been suddenly called to Ring to see his father, who has become seriously ill. Lucy is impatient about the postponement of seeing him, but it doesn't affect her appearance; she is a little bit plumper and her cheeks have a lovely rosy color. She has lost the anemic look she had. I pray that everything continues to go well.

en: 3 August.—Another week gone, and no news from Jonathan, not even to Mr. Hawkins, from whom I have heard. Oh, I do hope he is not ill. He surely would have written. I look at that last letter of his, but somehow it does not satisfy me. It does not read like him, and yet it is his writing. There is no mistake of that. Lucy has not walked much in her sleep the last week, but there is an odd concentration about her which I do not understand; even in her sleep she seems to be watching me. She tries the door, and finding it locked, goes about the room searching for the key.
vi: • August 3 Another week has passed, and I still haven't received any news from Jonathan! This time, he didn't even write to Mr. Hawkins. Oh! I hope he's not sick. But if that were the case, he would surely have sent a letter. Reading his last letter, I felt something was off. I no longer recognize him in the things he says in the letter. This time, Lucy is no longer sleepwalking as much as before, but now there is something really strange about her that makes me somewhat worried: even when she is sleeping, I still have the feeling that she is watching me. She tried to open the door several times, but when she realized that it was locked, she started looking for the key all over the room.
tr: August 3rd. - Another week has passed and still no news from Jonathan, even mr Hawkins, who writes to me, hasn't heard anything. Oh! I hope he is not ill. I am looking at his last letter, but somehow it doesn't satisfy me. It's not his style at all, but it's his handwriting. There is no doubt about that. In the past week, Lucy hasn't walked much in her sleep, but lately, there is a strange intensity about her; she seems to be watching me even in her sleep. She tries the door and when she sees it's locked, she wanders around the room looking for the key.
es: August 3rd. Another week has passed, and I have had no news from Jonathan. Not even Mr. Hawkins has heard from him, from whom I have received communication. Oh, I truly hope he is not ill. He would almost certainly have written. I have read his last letter, and there is something in it that does not satisfy me. It does not seem to be from him, and yet, it is written in his handwriting. There is no possible mistake about this last point. In the past week, Lucy has not walked in her sleep as much, but there is a strange concentration about her that I do not understand; even when she sleeps, she seems to be watching me. She turns the door handle, and finding it locked, she goes from one side of the room to the other looking for the key.

en: 6 August.—Another three days, and no news. This suspense is getting dreadful. If I only knew where to write to or where to go to, I should feel easier; but no one has heard a word of Jonathan since that last letter. I must only pray to God for patience. Lucy is more excitable than ever, but is otherwise well. Last night was very threatening, and the fishermen say that we are in for a storm. I must try to watch it and learn the weather signs. To-day is a grey day, and the sun as I write is hidden in thick clouds, high over Kettleness. Everything is grey—except the green grass, which seems like emerald amongst it; grey earthy rock; grey clouds, tinged with the sunburst at the far edge, hang over the grey sea, into which the sand-points stretch like grey fingers. The sea is tumbling in over the shallows and the sandy flats with a roar, muffled in the sea-mists drifting inland. The horizon is lost in a grey mist. All is vastness; the clouds are piled up like giant rocks, and there is a “brool” over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom. Dark figures are on the beach here and there, sometimes half shrouded in the mist, and seem “men like trees walking.” The fishing-boats are racing for home, and rise and dip in the ground swell as they sweep into the harbour, bending to the scuppers. Here comes old Mr. Swales. He is making straight for me, and I can see, by the way he lifts his hat, that he wants to talk....
vi: • August 6 Another three days passed, and Jonathan was still nowhere to be found. The waiting for me now has become a truly terrible anxiety.
