vi: On July 13th, we arrived at Cape Natapan. The crew seemed unhappy, as if they were afraid of something but no one dared to speak up.
tr: We passed Cape Matapan on July 13th. The crew is discontent about something. They seem scared, but they are not saying it outright.
es: On July 13, we passed Cape Matapan. The crew is dissatisfied with something. They seem scared, but they don't say why.

en: On 14 July was somewhat anxious about crew. Men all steady fellows, who sailed with me before. Mate could not make out what was wrong; they only told him there was something, and crossed themselves. Mate lost temper with one of them that day and struck him. Expected fierce quarrel, but all was quiet.
vi: On July 14, I began to feel quite anxious about their issue. I knew I could rely on these people, as I often went to sea with them. Like me, my deputy did not understand what was happening. The men were just talking and gesturing that something was happening on the ship. He suddenly got furious and started hitting a sailor repeatedly. Except for this incident, there were no other issues.
tr: On July 14, I had concerns regarding the crew. They are all sturdy men who have sailed with me before. The deck officer couldn't understand what the issue was; they just told him there was something on the ship and made the sign of the cross. That day, the deck officer got very angry and hit someone. I expected a heated fight, but everything was calm.
es: On July 14, I was somewhat anxious about the crew. All the men are trustworthy and have sailed with me before. The pilot couldn't figure out what was happening either; they only told him that there was something, and they crossed themselves. The pilot lost his temper with one of them that day and punched him. I expected a fierce fight, but everything is calm.

en: On 16 July mate reported in the morning that one of crew, Petrofsky, was missing. Could not account for it. Took larboard watch eight bells last night; was relieved by Abramoff, but did not go to bunk. Men more downcast than ever. All said they expected something of the kind, but would not say more than there was something aboard. Mate getting very impatient with them; feared some trouble ahead.
vi: On the morning of the 16th, the deputy came to inform me that one of them, named Petrofsky, had disappeared. The matter is inexplicable. At 8 PM last night, he was still on duty, then handed over the shift to Abrámoff, but after that, no one saw him go to sleep. The remaining people began to show more anxiety than ever, it seemed they had suspected such a disappearance for a few days already, but when asked, they still consistently responded with the familiar phrase that something was happening on the ship. Finally, my deputy got furious again: he suspected that they were planning a mutiny.
tr: On the morning of July 16, the deck officer reported that one of the crew members, Petrovski, was missing. He couldn't provide an explanation. The night before, he had taken the port watch at eight; he handed over the watch to Abramov, but did not return to his bunk. The men are more cheerless than ever. They all said they expected something like this, but they weren't saying more than that there was something on the ship. The deck officer is getting increasingly nervous; I fear there might be trouble ahead.
es: On July 16, the pilot reported in the morning that one of the crew, Petrovsky, has disappeared. He could not provide more details. He took the port watch at eight bells last night; he was relieved by Abramov, but he did not go to his bunk. The men, very depressed, all said that they already expected something like this, but they did not say more except that there was something on board. The pilot is becoming very impatient with them; I fear more troublesome incidents later.

en: On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin, and in an awestruck way confided to me that he thought there was a strange man aboard the ship. He said that in his watch he had been sheltering behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall, thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way, and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously, but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed. He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may spread. To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from stem to stern.
vi: On July 17th, yesterday, sailor Olgaren came to me and fearfully confided that he was thinking about a strange man on the ship. He said that during his watch, he had stood hiding behind the ship's bow to avoid the rising storm, and had accidentally seen a tall but gaunt man, unlike anyone among us, appear on the deck, walk quickly towards the bow, and suddenly disappear. He followed, but when he reached the bow, he saw no one there; all the deck doors were still locked. Standing in front of me, the sailor's fear had not lessened at all; I feared that his panic would spread to the entire crew. To reassure them, today I had to search every nook and cranny of the ship.
tr: One day before July 17, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin and explained in fear that he believed there was a stranger on the ship. During his watch, when he took shelter behind the wheelhouse because of a rainstorm, he saw a tall, thin man who did not resemble any of the crew members come out from the deck doorway and disappear as he walked along the deck. He had carefully watched the man and found no one when he reached the bow of the ship; all the hatchways were closed. He was seized by a fear based on superstition, and I am afraid this panic might spread. To quell it, I will carefully search the entire ship from top to bottom today.
es: On July 17, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin and in a confidential and fearful manner told me that he thought there was a strange man on board the ship. He narrated that during his watch he had been hiding behind the deckhouse, as there was a stormy rain, when he saw a tall, thin man, who did not resemble any of the crew, climbing the deckhouse ladder and walking forward on the deck, only to disappear. He followed him cautiously, but when he reached near the bow he found no one, and all the hatches were closed. A superstitious panic seized him, and I fear that this panic may spread to the others. Anticipating this, today I will have the entire ship carefully searched, from bow to stern.

en: Later in the day I got together the whole crew, and told them, as they evidently thought there was some one in the ship, we would search from stem to stern. First mate angry; said it was folly, and to yield to such foolish ideas would demoralise the men; said he would engage to keep them out of trouble with a handspike. I let him take the helm, while the rest began thorough search, all keeping abreast, with lanterns: we left no corner unsearched. As there were only the big wooden boxes, there were no odd corners where a man could hide. Men much relieved when search over, and went back to work cheerfully. First mate scowled, but said nothing.
vi: I gathered everyone together and told them that since they believed there was a stranger on board, we would search every place from the bow to the stern of the ship. The first mate showed displeasure with my idea, he said that conceding to such foolish suggestions was laughable and that it would only encourage the sailors to cause more trouble. Leaving him in the cockpit, I, along with the others, took lamps and searched the entire ship. We searched very thoroughly in the corners where the man could be hiding. Our search ended, everyone breathed a sigh of relief and could happily return to their duties. The first mate tilted his head and looked at me but said nothing.
tr: Later in the day, I gathered the entire crew and told them that since they thought someone was on board, we would search every inch of the ship. The first deck officer was angry; he said it was nonsense and that giving in to such foolish thoughts would lower the men's morale, and he promised to keep them out of trouble with a stick. When the others started searching carefully side by side with lanterns in hand, I left the helm to the deck officer; we did not leave a single corner unsearched. There were no odd corners where a man could hide, just large wooden crates. When the search ended, the men were greatly relieved and returned to work cheerfully. The first deck officer frowned but said nothing.
es: Later that same day, I gathered the entire crew and told them that, since they evidently thought there was someone on the ship, we would search it from bow to stern. The first officer got angry; he said it was nonsense, and that giving in to such foolish ideas would demoralize the men even more; he said he committed to keeping them in order with a club. I left him in charge of the helm, while the rest began to search, all of us staying side by side, with lanterns; we didn't leave a corner unchecked. Since all there were were some large wooden boxes, there were no possible crevices where a man could hide. The men were much more relieved when we finished the search, and they went about their tasks with joy. The first officer grumbled, but said nothing more.

en: 22 July.—Rough weather last three days, and all hands busy with sails—no time to be frightened. Men seem to have forgotten their dread. Mate cheerful again, and all on good terms. Praised men for work in bad weather. Passed Gibralter and out through Straits. All well.
vi: July 22 The storm has been raging for the past three days, and all of us have been struggling with the sails. There is no time left to be afraid; sometimes they don't even think about it. However, the first mate still hasn't shaken off his irritation. Commendable are those who are dedicated to their work amidst the waves. The ship has passed Gibraltar and is entering the Strait of Gibraltar. Everything is fine.
tr: July 22. - The weather has been stormy for the last three days and the entire crew is busy with the sails - no time to be afraid. The men seem to have forgotten their fears. The deck officer has regained his cheerfulness and everyone is getting along well with each other. I praised the men for their work in the bad weather. We passed through the Strait of Gibraltar. Everything is fine.
es: July 22. The last three days, bad weather, and all hands busy with the sails: no time to be scared. The men seem to have forgotten their fears. The helmsman, cheerful again, and everything is going very well. I praised the men for their magnificent work during the bad weather. We passed Gibraltar and exited the straits. All good.

en: 24 July.—There seems some doom over this ship. Already a hand short, and entering on the Bay of Biscay with wild weather ahead, and yet last night another man lost—disappeared. Like the first, he came off his watch and was not seen again. Men all in a panic of fear; sent a round robin, asking to have double watch, as they fear to be alone. Mate angry. Fear there will be some trouble, as either he or the men will do some violence.
vi: July 24 Clearly, the curse still haunts us. A person on the ship has disappeared, and last night, while the storm was still raging, on the way into the Bay of Biscay, we found another person missing. Just like before, he had just finished his shift, but no one saw him return to sleep. Panic once again enveloped the entire ship; the sailors had to agree to stand watch in pairs, simply because they were afraid to be alone. Of course, my first mate was furious again. I feared an outburst, either from him or from the crew.
tr: July 24. - It's as if there's a bad fate over the ship. We are already one crew member short, and with the bad weather, as we entered the Bay of Biscay, another man went missing - disappeared. Like the first one, he finished his watch and was never seen again. All the men are in a panic from fear; they wanted to keep watch in pairs because they are afraid to be alone. The deck officer got angry. I'm afraid there will be some trouble, because either he or the crew will resort to violence.
es: July 24. It seems that a curse weighs upon this ship. We were already one hand short, and upon entering the Bay of Biscay in devilish weather, another man disappeared last night without a trace. Like the first, he left his watch and was never seen again. All the men are in a panic; I sent an order accepting their request to have double watches, as they are afraid to be alone. The pilot, furious. I fear we may have some trouble, as either he or the men might resort to violence.

en: 28 July.—Four days in hell, knocking about in a sort of maelstrom, and the wind a tempest. No sleep for any one. Men all worn out. Hardly know how to set a watch, since no one fit to go on. Second mate volunteered to steer and watch, and let men snatch a few hours’ sleep. Wind abating; seas still terrific, but feel them less, as ship is steadier.
vi: July 28 For the past four days, the ship has been like entering a real hell, still stormy winds, no one can sleep anymore, everyone is exhausted. There is no longer a single person who can stand watch. The first mate was asked to take over the watch so that the remaining people could rest and catch a bit of sleep. The wind had weakened somewhat, but the waves were still very fierce. However, we felt less tossed about, and the ship gradually regained its balance.
tr: July 28. - Four days in a kind of vortex where we were battered and the wind turned into a storm in hell. No sleep for anyone. All the men are exhausted. I don't quite know how to organize the watches as no one has the strength to continue. The second deck officer volunteered to take the helm, keep watch, and allow the men to sleep for a few hours. The wind is dying down; the sea is still terrible, but we feel it less as the ship is more stable.
es: July 28. Four days of hell, tossing about in some kind of typhoon, with stormy winds. No one has been able to sleep. All the men are exhausted. I hardly know how to set up a watch, as no one is in any condition to carry on. The second officer volunteered to steer and keep watch, allowing the men to sleep for a couple of hours. The wind is dying down; the sea is still terrifying, but it feels less so, as the ship has gained stability.

en: 29 July.—Another tragedy. Had single watch to-night, as crew too tired to double. When morning watch came on deck could find no one except steersman. Raised outcry, and all came on deck. Thorough search, but no one found. Are now without second mate, and crew in a panic. Mate and I agreed to go armed henceforth and wait for any sign of cause.
vi: July 29 Another tragedy. Tonight, there was only one person on watch. In the morning, another sailor came to replace him, but when he got on deck, he saw no one except a man by the helm. Hearing the terrified cry of the sailor, we all rushed up to the deck, but all our searches were in vain. The ship had lost another sailor. Everyone was in panic again. The first mate and I decided to arm ourselves and wait.
tr: July 29. - Another disaster. Since the crew was too tired to keep watch in pairs, single watches were held tonight. When the morning watchman came to the deck, he saw no one around except the helmsman. He shouted, and everyone came to the deck. Everywhere was searched thoroughly, but no one was found. We no longer have our second deck officer, and the crew is in a panic. The deck officer and I have agreed to walk around armed from now on and wait for a signal.
es: July 29. Another tragedy. Tonight we had a single watch, as the crew is too tired to make it double. When the morning watch came on deck, they couldn't find anyone except the helmsman. He started shouting and everyone came on deck. Thorough search, but no one was found. Now we are without a second officer, and the crew is in great panic. The helmsman and I agreed to always go armed from now on, and to watch for any sign of the cause.

en: 30 July.—Last night. Rejoiced we are nearing England. Weather fine, all sails set. Retired worn out; slept soundly; awaked by mate telling me that both man of watch and steersman missing. Only self and mate and two hands left to work ship.
vi: July 30 It is certainly the last night. Luckily, we are nearing England. The weather is beautiful, and all the sails on the ship are hoisted. I had to go to sleep, a deep sleep, but the first mate unexpectedly woke me up and informed me that two sailors on duty had disappeared, including the helmsman. So there are only four of us left on the ship - me, the first mate, and two others.
tr: July 30. - Last night. I was happy because we were approaching England. The weather is nice, all sails are open. I retreated to the cabin exhausted; I slept soundly; I was awakened by the deck officer who said that both the watchman and the helmsman were missing. Only the deck officer, two crew members, and I were left to navigate the ship.
es: July 30. Night. Everyone is rejoicing as we approach England. Magnificent weather, all sails unfurled. I retired due to exhaustion; slept deeply; was awakened by the officer telling me that both men, the one on watch and the pilot, had disappeared. Only two crew members remain, the first officer and I, to steer the ship.

en: 1 August.—Two days of fog, and not a sail sighted. Had hoped when in the English Channel to be able to signal for help or get in somewhere. Not having power to work sails, have to run before wind. Dare not lower, as could not raise them again. We seem to be drifting to some terrible doom. Mate now more demoralised than either of men. His stronger nature seems to have worked inwardly against himself. Men are beyond fear, working stolidly and patiently, with minds made up to worst. They are Russian, he Roumanian.
vi: August 1, 1924 Two days of dense fog and not a single sail in sight. I hope that when we reach the English Channel, we can call for help. When there was no way to control the sails (I didn't dare lower them for fear of not being able to raise them again), we began to be threatened by the winds blowing from behind. Indeed, we were being driven towards a terrible fate. The first mate at this moment was even more discouraged than the other two sailors. These two men didn't even dare to think to be afraid anymore; they continued to patiently work and await the worst. They were Russian, while the first mate was Romanian.
tr: August 1st. - There has been fog for two days and no ship has been seen. I had hoped to send a distress signal or to enter somewhere when we entered the English Channel. Since we do not have the strength to use the sails, we must take the wind at our back. We do not dare to lower the sails because we would not be able to raise them again. It felt like we were drifting towards a terrible end, caught in the current. The deck officer's morale was worse than that of the other two men. His strong nature seemed to be working against him internally. The men are worse than scared; they have prepared their minds for the worst, working insensibly and patiently. The men are Russian, the deck officer is Romanian.
es: August 1st. Two days of fog and without sighting a sail. I had hoped that in the English Channel we could signal for help or reach somewhere. Not having the strength to work the sails, we have to sail with the wind. We do not dare to lower them, because we would not be able to raise them again. It seems we are being dragged towards a terrible end. The first officer is now more demoralized than any of the men. His stronger nature seems to have worked internally against him. The men are beyond fear, working hard and patiently, with their minds prepared for the worst. They are Russians; he is Romanian.

en: 2 August, midnight.—Woke up from few minutes’ sleep by hearing a cry, seemingly outside my port. Could see nothing in fog. Rushed on deck, and ran against mate. Tells me heard cry and ran, but no sign of man on watch. One more gone. Lord, help us! Mate says we must be past Straits of Dover, as in a moment of fog lifting he saw North Foreland, just as he heard the man cry out. If so we are now off in the North Sea, and only God can guide us in the fog, which seems to move with us; and God seems to have deserted us.
vi: August 2, midnight Just a few minutes after falling asleep, I was suddenly startled awake by a heartrending cry that came through the window. I rushed up to the deck and met the first mate there. He said he also heard the cry, but before running here immediately, he had not seen the sailor on duty anywhere. Another life lost. God, please protect us! According to the first mate, we are in the North Sea, and only God can guide us through the layers of fog, but it seems God has abandoned us?
tr: 2 August, midnight. - I woke up from a few minutes of sleep, apparently due to a scream coming from outside my door. I couldn't see anything in the fog. I ran to the deck and encountered the deck officer. He said he heard the scream and ran, but there was no sign of the man on watch. Another one is gone. God help us! The deck officer says we must have passed the Dover Strait because the fog lifted for a moment just as he heard the man scream, and he saw the North Foreland. If so, it means we have now entered the North Sea, and only God can guide us in this fog that seems to move with us; yet it seems God has forsaken us.
es: August 2, midnight. I woke up after a few minutes of sleep hearing a scream, which seemed to come from right outside my door. I couldn't see anything because of the fog. I ran to the deck and bumped into the first officer. He tells me he heard the scream and ran, but there were no signs of the man who was on watch. Another one gone. Lord, help us! The first officer says we must have already passed the Strait of Dover, because at a moment when the fog cleared, he managed to see North Foreland, at the same instant he heard the man's scream. If so, we are now in the North Sea, and only God can guide us in this fog, which seems to move with us; and God seems to have abandoned us.

en: 3 August.—At midnight I went to relieve the man at the wheel, and when I got to it found no one there. The wind was steady, and as we ran before it there was no yawing. I dared not leave it, so shouted for the mate. After a few seconds he rushed up on deck in his flannels. He looked wild-eyed and haggard, and I greatly fear his reason has given way. He came close to me and whispered hoarsely, with his mouth to my ear, as though fearing the very air might hear: “It is here; I know it, now. On the watch last night I saw It, like a man, tall and thin, and ghastly pale. It was in the bows, and looking out. I crept behind It, and gave It my knife; but the knife went through It, empty as the air.” And as he spoke he took his knife and drove it savagely into space. Then he went on: “But It is here, and I’ll find It. It is in the hold, perhaps in one of those boxes. I’ll unscrew them one by one and see. You work the helm.” And, with a warning look and his finger on his lip, he went below. There was springing up a choppy wind, and I could not leave the helm. I saw him come out on deck again with a tool-chest and a lantern, and go down the forward hatchway. He is mad, stark, raving mad, and it’s no use my trying to stop him. He can’t hurt those big boxes: they are invoiced as “clay,” and to pull them about is as harmless a thing as he can do. So here I stay, and mind the helm, and write these notes. I can only trust in God and wait till the fog clears. Then, if I can’t steer to any harbour with the wind that is, I shall cut down sails and lie by, and signal for help....
vi: August 3, 1938 At midnight, I intended to sneak over to the sailor who was steering, but to my astonishment, I couldn't see anyone there! I shouted for the first mate, and he appeared immediately. His wide, frantic eyes clearly showed real panic, and I feared he might lose his mind. He came close to me and whispered in my ear as if afraid the wind might hear: "I know for sure what's happening here. Last night I saw it: a tall, skinny figure with a pale face. It was standing at the bow, facing out to sea. I sneaked up behind it and aimed a slash at its neck, but the blade didn't hit anything; I felt as if I had just slashed through air."- As he spoke, he pulled a knife from his pocket and slashed violently as if trying to cut through the air. - "But if I stay here, I'll definitely catch it. In the ship's hold, or in some barrel. I'll open each barrel one by one; it can't escape. " And you, please take the helm. "After saying that, he winked, raised a finger to his lips to signal me to be quiet, and then went below deck. The sea wind was blowing stronger and stronger, and of course, I couldn't leave the helm. A moment later, I saw the first mate returning to the deck with a toolbox and a lantern, then disappearing into the forward hatch. He's gone mad; reasoning with him now would be useless. So I had to sit here alone to watch the helm and take the opportunity to write these lines. All I can do now is trust in God and wait for the fog to gradually lift. If I can reach a port, I'll lower all the sails and signal for help.
tr: August 3rd. - At midnight, I went to relieve the man at the helm, but when I arrived, I found no one there. The wind had calmed, and since we were sailing before the wind, we were not off course. I didn't dare leave the helm, so I called out to the deck officer. Within seconds, he rushed to the deck in his undershirt. He looked at me with wild eyes and appeared exhausted; I feared he had completely lost his mind. He came close to me and, as if afraid the air might hear us, he whispered hoarsely into my ear: "He's here; now I know. Last night, while on watch, I saw that Thing; it looked human, tall, thin, and deathly pale. It was standing at the bow, looking out. I sneaked up behind it and stabbed that Thing with my knife; but the knife passed through it as if it were air." And as he spoke, he drew out his knife and stabbed it fiercely into the air. Then he continued: "But that Thing is here, and I will find it. Maybe it's hiding inside one of those crates. I will pry the nails off each one and see. You hold the helm." He went below with a warning look and his finger to his lips. The wind was shifting, and I couldn't leave the helm. I saw him come back on deck with a tool chest and a lantern, then descend through the forward hatch. He's gone mad, completely deranged; there's no point in trying to stop him. He can't harm those big crates: they were billed as "Mud," the most harmless thing he could do is push them around. So, I stay here at the helm, writing this. I can only trust in God and wait for the fog to lift. Then, if I can't steer to a port with the wind, I'll cut the sails and signal for help...
es: August 3rd. At midnight, I went to relieve the man at the helm, and when I arrived, I found no one there. The wind was steady, and as we sail wherever it takes us, there was no movement. I did not dare to leave the helm alone, so I shouted for the officer. After a few seconds, he came running up to the deck in his flannels. His eyes were wide and his face was gaunt, so I greatly fear he has lost his mind. He came close to me and whispered hoarsely, placing his mouth near my ear, as if he feared even the air would hear: "It is here; now I know. While on watch last night, I saw it, a tall, thin man, deathly pale. He was near the prow, looking out. I crawled towards him and plunged my knife into him; but it went through him, empty as the air." As he spoke, he drew his knife and began to wave it wildly in the air. Then, he continued: "But since it is here, I will find it. It is in the hold, perhaps in one of those boxes. I will unscrew them one by one and see. You, hold the helm." And, with a warning look, placing his finger on his lips, he headed below. A dangerous wind was rising, and I could not leave the helm. I saw him come out again on deck with a toolbox and a lantern and descend through the forward hatch. He is mad; completely delirious with madness, and there is no point in trying to stop him. He cannot harm those large boxes: they are marked as "clay," and moving them around does not matter. So here I stay, tending the helm and writing these notes. I can only trust in God and wait for the fog to clear. Then, if I can steer the ship towards any port with the wind available, I will lower the sails and stay resting, signaling, asking for help...

en: It is nearly all over now. Just as I was beginning to hope that the mate would come out calmer—for I heard him knocking away at something in the hold, and work is good for him—there came up the hatchway a sudden, startled scream, which made my blood run cold, and up on the deck he came as if shot from a gun—a raging madman, with his eyes rolling and his face convulsed with fear. “Save me! save me!” he cried, and then looked round on the blanket of fog. His horror turned to despair, and in a steady voice he said: “You had better come too, captain, before it is too late. He is there. I know the secret now. The sea will save me from Him, and it is all that is left!” Before I could say a word, or move forward to seize him, he sprang on the bulwark and deliberately threw himself into the sea. I suppose I know the secret too, now. It was this madman who had got rid of the men one by one, and now he has followed them himself. God help me! How am I to account for all these horrors when I get to port? When I get to port! Will that ever be?
vi: Oh Lord! I am very afraid that everything will end right now. Just when I started to hope that the first mate would calm down (because I had heard the sounds of his knife slashing in the hold), there was a sudden horrifying scream that echoed through the deck door, followed by the sight of the first mate being thrown up onto the deck like a banana tree. At this moment, he looked no different from a truly insane person: his eyes were bewildered, his face clearly showing fear. "Help me! Help me!" He screamed while fearfully looking around the wall of fog. Then his fear was replaced by a feeling of despair, and he spoke to me in a rather determined voice: "You should also find a way to manage before it's too late, captain. It's down there. Now I know everything very clearly. Only the sea can help me escape the claws of this monster!" Before I could say a word or make any reflexive movement, I saw him jump into the sea. I believe that now I also understand the secret clearly. Surely that unfortunate person had gone mad, driving everyone off the ship one by one, and now he himself wanted to follow them into the sea. May God help me! How will I explain these terrible nightmares when the ship docks? When the ship docks! Or will I never be able to reach the port again?
tr: Almost everything is now over. Just as I was beginning to hope that the deck officer would appear more composed - because I had heard him hitting something in the hold, and working would do him good - a blood-curdling, unexpected, and fear-filled scream came from the hatch; the deck officer shot up to the deck like a bullet - a furious madman with eyes wild and face contorted with fear. "Save me! Save me!" he shouted; he looked around at his surroundings shrouded in mist. His fear turned to despair, and in a calm voice, he said, "You'd better come too, captain, before it's too late. He's here." Now I know the secret. The sea will protect me from Him, and that's all that's left. Before I could say a single word or move to stop him, he dashed to the rail and deliberately threw himself into the sea. I think now I know the secret too. This madman who had gotten rid of the men one by one, and now he followed them. God, help me! How will I account for all these horrifying events when I reach the port? When I reach the port! Will such a thing even happen?
es: Almost everything is over now. Just when I was beginning to think that the first officer might return more calmly, as I heard him hammering something in the hold, and work does him good, a sudden scream that froze my blood came up through the hatch; and he appeared on deck as if shot from a gun, completely mad, with eyes rolling and face convulsed with fear. "Save me, save me!" he shouted, and then looked around at the blanket of fog. His horror turned to despair, and in a calm voice he said, "It would be better if you came too, captain, before it's too late. It's here. Now I know the secret. The sea will save me from it, and that's all that's left!" Before I could say a word, or move to stop him, he jumped to the bow, and deliberately threw himself into the sea. I suppose now I know the secret too. It was this madman who dispatched the men one by one and now he himself has followed them. God help me! How am I going to report all these horrors when I reach port? When I reach port! And when will that be?

en: 4 August.—Still fog, which the sunrise cannot pierce. I know there is sunrise because I am a sailor, why else I know not. I dared not go below, I dared not leave the helm; so here all night I stayed, and in the dimness of the night I saw It—Him! God forgive me, but the mate was right to jump overboard. It was better to die like a man; to die like a sailor in blue water no man can object. But I am captain, and I must not leave my ship. But I shall baffle this fiend or monster, for I shall tie my hands to the wheel when my strength begins to fail, and along with them I shall tie that which He—It!—dare not touch; and then, come good wind or foul, I shall save my soul, and my honour as a captain. I am growing weaker, and the night is coming on. If He can look me in the face again, I may not have time to act.... If we are wrecked, mayhap this bottle may be found, and those who find it may understand; if not, ... well, then all men shall know that I have been true to my trust. God and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying to do his duty....
vi: August 4 The sunlight could not dispel the thick fog. If I were not a sailor, I might not have known that the sun had risen. I did not dare go below deck, nor did I dare leave the helm to go elsewhere, so I had to sit there anxiously all night. And in the pitch darkness, I realized the situation - or rather, I realized it! It was it! So that's how it was. Lord, please forgive me? My mate did the right thing by jumping into the sea. I want to die like a man, no one can criticize such a death for a sailor. But as for me, I cannot abandon the ship, because I am the captain. However, I will find a way to thwart all the schemes of this demon: when I feel exhausted, I will tie my hands to the wheel and also tie to it that which... that which it dares not touch, and regardless of whether the weather is favorable or not, I will still find every way to escape and preserve the honor of a captain! I feel myself growing weaker, soon the night will fall again. If I delay, I might not have time to act... If not, at least people will know that I was not an irresponsible person. Lord, Holy Virgin Mary, and all the merciful saints, please come to save an innocent, pitiable, and well-intentioned soul!...»
tr: August 4. - The fog that even the sunrise cannot pierce still persists. I know the sun has risen because I am a sailor, for no other reason do I know. I did not dare to go below, I did not dare to leave the helm; so I stayed here all night and in the dimness of the night I saw that Thing - that Man! God forgive me, but the deck officer was right to jump off the ship. It is better to die like a human; no one can object to dying like a sailor in the blue waters. But I am the captain and I must not abandon my ship. But I will outwit this enemy or monster, because when my strength begins to wane, I will tie my hands to the helm and with them I will tie something that this Man - this Thing! - dares not touch; then, whether the wind be good or bad, I will preserve my soul and honor like a captain. I am weakening and night is falling. If he can fix his gaze on me once more, I may not have time to act. If we have an accident, perhaps this bottle may be found and those who find it may understand what happened; otherwise, well, let everyone know that I remained faithful to what was entrusted to me. God, the Holy Virgin, and the saints help the poor, ignorant soul trying to fulfill his duty...
es: August 4th. Still fog, which the sun cannot penetrate. I know the sun has risen because I am a sailor, but I don't know for what other reasons. I don't dare go below; I don't dare leave the helm; so I spent the whole night here, and in the dark of the night I saw him, him! God forgive me, but the officer was right to jump overboard. It was better to die like a man; the death of a sailor in the blue waters of the sea cannot be objected to by anyone. But I am the captain, and I cannot abandon my ship. But I will thwart this enemy or monster, for when my strength begins to fail, I will tie my hands to the helm, and along with them, I will tie that which this - him! - does not dare to touch; and then, come good wind or bad wind, I will save my soul and my captain's honor. I am weakening, and night is approaching. If he can see my face again, it might be that I won't have time to act... If we shipwreck, perhaps this bottle will be found, and those who find me will understand; if not... Well, then all men will know that I have been faithful to my oath. God and the Blessed Virgin and the saints help a poor ignorant soul trying to do his duty...

en: Of course the verdict was an open one. There is no evidence to adduce; and whether or not the man himself committed the murders there is now none to say. The folk here hold almost universally that the captain is simply a hero, and he is to be given a public funeral. Already it is arranged that his body is to be taken with a train of boats up the Esk for a piece and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and up the abbey steps; for he is to be buried in the churchyard on the cliff. The owners of more than a hundred boats have already given in their names as wishing to follow him to the grave.
vi: After I finished listening to all the diary entries, the inspector concluded that this was a serious case with an unknown perpetrator. Indeed, there was no reliable evidence on the ship, and no one could say whether the culprit behind the deaths was human or not. The fishermen in Whitby all agreed to honor the captain as a hero and organized a funeral for him with the most solemn ceremonies in the area. His body will be buried at a place on the cliff overlooking the harbor. People still have not found any trace of that big dog; public opinion in the area as well as the small town of Whitby has expressed regret about this.
tr: Of course, the outcome of the matter was open to interpretation. There is no evidence at all; and there is no one to say whether this man committed the murders. Almost the entire public argues that the captain is a hero, and therefore a public funeral will be held for him. It has already been decided that his body will be taken to Esk with a boat convoy and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and carried up the monastery steps; because he will be buried in the churchyard on the hillside. More than a hundred boat owners have already given their names, stating that they want to follow the captain to his grave.
es: Of course, the verdict was acquittal. There is no evidence to present; and whether it was the man himself who committed the murders, or it was not him, is something that no one can attest to. The people here almost universally hold that the captain is simply a hero, and he is going to be buried with all honors. It is already arranged that his body is to be taken with a train of boats for a stretch along the Esk, and then brought back to Tate Hill Pier and carried up the steps to the abbey; for it has been arranged that he be buried in the church cemetery, on the cliff. The owners of more than a hundred barges have already given their names, indicating that they wish to follow the captain's funeral procession.

en: No trace has ever been found of the great dog; at which there is much mourning, for, with public opinion in its present state, he would, I believe, be adopted by the town. To-morrow will see the funeral; and so will end this one more “mystery of the sea.”
vi: People still have not found any trace of that big dog; public opinion in the area as well as the small town of Whitby has expressed regret about this. So, tomorrow we will attend the captain's funeral. And this will be the conclusion of the story "The Mystery of the Sea," which has been embellished with countless details.
tr: There is no trace of the big dog; this is causing much sorrow because, considering the current state of public opinion, I believe the dog would have been adopted by the town. The funeral will be held tomorrow; thus, another "sea mystery" will come to an end.
es: No traces of the immense dog have been found; because of this, there is much sadness, as, with public opinion in its present state, the animal would have been, I believe, adopted by the people. Tomorrow will be the funeral, and thus will end this new "mystery of the sea".

en: Mina Murray’s Journal.
vi: Mina Murray's Journal
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: From the journal of Mina Murray

en: 8 August.—Lucy was very restless all night, and I, too, could not sleep. The storm was fearful, and as it boomed loudly among the chimney-pots, it made me shudder. When a sharp puff came it seemed to be like a distant gun. Strangely enough, Lucy did not wake; but she got up twice and dressed herself. Fortunately, each time I awoke in time and managed to undress her without waking her, and got her back to bed. It is a very strange thing, this sleep-walking, for as soon as her will is thwarted in any physical way, her intention, if there be any, disappears, and she yields herself almost exactly to the routine of her life.
vi: • August 6 Lucy rummaged around all night, and so did I, tossing and turning without being able to fall asleep. The storm was terrifying; hearing the wind whistling through the chimney, I thought it was the sound of cannons. Strangely enough, even though she wasn't awake, Lucy got up twice to put on her clothes. Fortunately, each time I heard the noise and quickly ran over to intervene, guiding her back to bed. I really can't understand people who sleepwalk, because when I ran over to stop Lucy's movements, I saw her immediately abandon the intention she had formed just moments before—if it can even be called an intention in this case—and return to her normal routine.
tr: August 8. - Lucy was very restless all night, so I couldn't sleep either. The storm was frightening, and the wind made a loud clattering noise in the chimney caps, causing me to startle. When a strong and sudden gust blew, the sound was like a gunshot in the distance. It's strange that Lucy didn't wake up; but she got up and dressed twice. Fortunately, each time I woke up in time and managed to undress her and put her back to bed without waking her. This sleepwalking issue is very peculiar, because as soon as her will is obstructed by any physical means, her purpose - if there is one - disappears, and she completely surrenders to the ordinary course of her life.
es: August 8. Lucy spent the whole night very restless, and I couldn't sleep either. The storm was terrible, and as it thundered loudly among the chimney pots, it made me tremble. When a strong gust of wind came, it sounded like the distant shot of a cannon. Quite strangely, Lucy did not wake up; but she got up twice and dressed herself. Fortunately, on each occasion I woke up in time and managed to undress her without waking her, putting her back to bed. This sleepwalking of hers is very strange, for as soon as her will is thwarted in any physical way, her intention, if she has one, disappears, and she almost exactly follows the routine of her life.

en: Early in the morning we both got up and went down to the harbour to see if anything had happened in the night. There were very few people about, and though the sun was bright, and the air clear and fresh, the big, grim-looking waves, that seemed dark themselves because the foam that topped them was like snow, forced themselves in through the narrow mouth of the harbour—like a bullying man going through a crowd. Somehow I felt glad that Jonathan was not on the sea last night, but on land. But, oh, is he on land or sea? Where is he, and how? I am getting fearfully anxious about him. If I only knew what to do, and could do anything!
vi: The two of us woke up very early and curiously invited each other to the port to see what had happened last night. There was almost no one there, even though the sun had risen and the weather had somewhat cooled down again. The sky was still filled with heavy black clouds. I was delighted with the thought that Jonathan had not gone to sea last night. But did he really not go to sea? Was he still on land? Where was he, and how were things going? Why was I so worried about him? If only I knew what I should do, if only I could do something, my mind would be so much more at ease.
tr: In the morning, we both got up early and went to the harbor to see if anything had happened during the night. There were very few people around; despite the sun being bright and the air clear and clean, the waves, which looked dark because of the foam on their crests like snow, were forcing their way through the narrow mouth of the harbor like a bully pushing through a crowd. For some reason, I was glad that Jonathan was on land rather than at sea last night. But, oh, on land or at sea? Where and how? I am worried for him in fear. I wish I knew what to do and could do something!
es: Early this morning, the two of us got up and went down to the port to see if anything had happened during the night. There were very few people around, and although the sun was shining and the air was clear and fresh, the great threatening waves, which seemed darker than they were because the foam crowned them with plumes of snow, made their way through the narrow mouth of the port, like a man elbowing his way through a crowd. For no apparent reason, I felt glad that Jonathan had not been at sea, but on land. But, oh! Is he on land or at sea? Where is he, and how is he? I am becoming truly anxious about his whereabouts. If only I knew what I should do, and if I could do something!

en: 10 August.—The funeral of the poor sea-captain to-day was most touching. Every boat in the harbour seemed to be there, and the coffin was carried by captains all the way from Tate Hill Pier up to the churchyard. Lucy came with me, and we went early to our old seat, whilst the cortège of boats went up the river to the Viaduct and came down again. We had a lovely view, and saw the procession nearly all the way. The poor fellow was laid to rest quite near our seat so that we stood on it when the time came and saw everything. Poor Lucy seemed much upset. She was restless and uneasy all the time, and I cannot but think that her dreaming at night is telling on her. She is quite odd in one thing: she will not admit to me that there is any cause for restlessness; or if there be, she does not understand it herself. There is an additional cause in that poor old Mr. Swales was found dead this morning on our seat, his neck being broken. He had evidently, as the doctor said, fallen back in the seat in some sort of fright, for there was a look of fear and horror on his face that the men said made them shudder. Poor dear old man! Perhaps he had seen Death with his dying eyes! Lucy is so sweet and sensitive that she feels influences more acutely than other people do. Just now she was quite upset by a little thing which I did not much heed, though I am myself very fond of animals. One of the men who came up here often to look for the boats was followed by his dog. The dog is always with him. They are both quiet persons, and I never saw the man angry, nor heard the dog bark. During the service the dog would not come to its master, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few yards off, barking and howling. Its master spoke to it gently, and then harshly, and then angrily; but it would neither come nor cease to make a noise. It was in a sort of fury, with its eyes savage, and all its hairs bristling out like a cat’s tail when puss is on the war-path. Finally the man, too, got angry, and jumped down and kicked the dog, and then took it by the scruff of the neck and half dragged and half threw it on the tombstone on which the seat is fixed. The moment it touched the stone the poor thing became quiet and fell all into a tremble. It did not try to get away, but crouched down, quivering and cowering, and was in such a pitiable state of terror that I tried, though without effect, to comfort it. Lucy was full of pity, too, but she did not attempt to touch the dog, but looked at it in an agonised sort of way. I greatly fear that she is of too super-sensitive a nature to go through the world without trouble. She will be dreaming of this to-night, I am sure. The whole agglomeration of things—the ship steered into port by a dead man; his attitude, tied to the wheel with a crucifix and beads; the touching funeral; the dog, now furious and now in terror—will all afford material for her dreams.
vi: • August 10 The funeral of the poor captain today was truly moving. I believe that all the ships in the port gathered at his funeral. The naval officers directly carried his coffin from Tate Hill to the cemetery. Lucy went with me. The two of us sat on the familiar stone bench watching the funeral procession of ships go upstream the small river to the viaduct and then return to Tate Hill. Sitting at the top of the cliff, we could see everything within our view. We observed every detail of the burial ceremony. Lucy was very emotional, deeply sorrowful, when she saw the captain's remains being lowered into a grave right within our sight. Perhaps the restless nights and continuous dreams had a very negative impact on her health. But strangely, when I mentioned this, Lucy absolutely refused to admit the cause of her nervous tension, even denying that she felt that way at all. Perhaps today, her distress increased greatly after learning that this morning, old Mr. Swales was found dead right on the bench we were sitting on, with a cut on his neck. According to the doctor, it was certain that before he fell, the old man must have experienced an inexplicable, tremendous terror, as that terror was still clearly etched on his face when they found his body. What an unfortunate old man? Did he see the Grim Reaper?... Lucy is such a sensitive girl that everything can affect her more deeply than anyone else going through the same ordeal. While people were burying the unfortunate captain, she was haunted by something that didn't catch my attention at all, even though I am someone who always loves animals. One of the men who often came here to watch the boats and the sea appeared with a dog that he always brought along. For some reason, the dog didn't want to approach its owner, who was sitting on the same bench as us. The dog stood some distance away, barking and growling loudly. At first, the man gently reminded it, but the dog still wouldn't be quiet. He then raised his voice, and angrily shouted at it. It was useless. The animal barked even more fiercely than before. It was also furious, its eyes wild, fur standing on end like a porcupine's quills. The man truly lost his temper, jumped off the bench, and kicked the dog in the stomach, then furiously grabbed it by the neck and dragged it to the stone grave where the bench was placed. Strangely, as soon as it touched the stone, the animal fell silent, but instead, its body began to tremble violently. Not only did it fail to calm down, but the animal also collapsed to the ground, seemingly terrified of something. I tried to soothe it, but it was no use. Lucy also felt sorry for the animal, but she did nothing to comfort it, only looked at it with a very worried expression. I feared she had an incredibly sensitive and delicate instinct, adding to all that life had already given her. I wondered how she would get through the night! All the events that had just occurred: a ship arriving at the port with a dead body right before the helm, a prolonged funeral, then the dog alternating between fury and terror - yes, all of it happened at once, causing my friend to fall into new nightmares.
tr: August 10.- The poor captain's funeral today was very sad. It seemed like all the boats in the harbor were there, and the coffin was carried by the captains from Tate Hill Pier all the way to the churchyard. Lucy came with me, and we went early to our old bench and sat down as the boat procession went up the viaduct and then back down. We had a very good view and watched the procession almost from start to finish. The poor man was buried very close to our bench; thus, when the time came, we stood on the bench and saw everything. Poor Lucy looked very sad. She was constantly restless and tense; I couldn't help but think that the dreams she had at night were having a bad effect on her. She is acting quite strangely about one thing: She doesn't admit that there is any reason for her restlessness, or if there is such a reason, she doesn't understand it herself. There is another reason for her restlessness: Poor old Mr. Swales was found dead on our bench this morning with his neck broken. According to the doctor, he clearly fell onto the bench out of some kind of terror, because his face had an expression of fear and horror that, according to the men, made their hair stand on end. Poor dear old man! Perhaps his dying eyes saw Death! Lucy is so sweet and sensitive that she feels such effects much more strongly than other people. Now she is very upset over a small matter that I, personally, don't care much about despite liking animals a lot. One of the men who often comes here to look at the boats always has his dog with him. The dog is always with him. Both are very quiet beings; I have never seen the man get angry or the dog bark. During the ceremony, the dog did not come to its owner, who was sitting on the bench next to us, but stood a few meters away, barking and howling. The owner spoke to it first gently, then sternly, and finally angrily; but the dog neither came to him nor stopped making noise. It was in some kind of rage; its eyes wild, its fur standing on end like the tail of a cat going into battle. Eventually, the man also got angry, walked towards the dog, kicked it, and half-dragged, half-threw it onto the gravestone to which the bench was fixed. As soon as it fell onto the stone, the poor thing went quiet and started trembling. It didn't try to escape, it cowered and trembled in such a pitiable terror that I tried to soothe it, though it had little effect. Lucy also felt very sorry for it, but she did not try to touch the dog, only looked at it with pained eyes. I fear that Lucy's nature is too sensitive to go through life without trouble. I am sure she will see this in her dreams tonight. The combination of all these things - the ship being brought into the harbor by a dead man; the man being tied to the helm with a cross and rosary; the touching funeral ceremony; the dog in a state of furious terror - will provide material for her dreams.
es: August 10. The funeral of the poor captain today was most moving. All the boats in the harbor seemed to be there, and the coffin was carried on the shoulders of captains all the way from Tate Hill Pier to the churchyard. Lucy came with me, and we went very early to our old seat, while the procession of boats went up the river to the viaduct and then came down again. We had a magnificent view, and we saw the procession almost the entire way. The poor man was laid to rest near our seat, so we stood up and, when the time came, we could see everything. Poor Lucy seemed very nervous. She was restless and agitated the whole time, and I can't help but think that her dreams at night are affecting her. There is something very strange: she doesn't want to admit to me that there is any cause for her unease; or if there is a cause, she herself does not understand it. There is an additional reason in the fact that the poor old man, Mr. Swales, was found dead this morning in our seat, with his neck broken. Evidently, as the doctor said, he fell backward onto the seat, stricken with fear, for there was a look of dread and horror on his face that the men said made them tremble. Poor dear old man! Perhaps he saw death with his dying eyes! Lucy is so sweet and feels influences more keenly than other people. Right now she is very excited about a small detail to which I did not pay much attention, even though I myself love animals very much. One of the men who always came up here to look at the boats was followed by his dog. The dog was always with him. Both are very calm, and I never saw the man angry, nor did I hear the dog bark. During the service, the dog did not want to approach his owner, who was on the seat with us, but kept a few meters away, barking and howling. His owner spoke to him first softly, then in a harsher tone, and finally very angrily; but the animal did not want to come closer nor did it stop making noise. It was possessed as if by some kind of rage, with its eyes shining wildly, and all its hairs standing on end like a cat's tail when preparing for a fight. Finally, the man also got angry, and jumping off the seat, he kicked the dog, and then, grabbing it by the neck, dragged it and threw it onto the tombstone on which the seat is mounted. At the moment it touched the tombstone, the poor creature regained its peaceful demeanor but began to tremble desperately. It did not try to leave, but curled up, trembling and crouching, and was in such a state of terror that I tried to calm it, though without effect. Lucy also felt compassion, but did not try to touch the dog, only looking at it with pity. I fear very much that she has too sensitive a nature to be able to go through the world without problems. I am sure that tonight she will dream of everything that has happened. All the accumulation of strange events (the ship piloted into the harbor by a dead man; his posture, tied to the helm with a crucifix and rosaries; the emotional funeral; the dog, sometimes furious and other times terrified) will give her plenty of material for her dreams.

en: I think it will be best for her to go to bed tired out physically, so I shall take her for a long walk by the cliffs to Robin Hood’s Bay and back. She ought not to have much inclination for sleep-walking then.
vi: Of course, I want Lucy to have a deep sleep tonight because of exhaustion: I mean physical exhaustion, not mental. Therefore, I invited her to take a long walk along the cliffs to Robin Hood's Bay, and then walk back. I think that tonight she won't leave her bed and wander outside while still asleep.
tr: I think the best thing will be for him to get physically tired and go to bed, so I will take him for a long walk on the slopes leading to Robin Hood's Bay and bring him back. Then, he won't have much desire for sleepwalking.
es: I think the best thing for her would be to retire to her bed, physically tired, so I will take her for a long walk along the cliffs of Robin Hood's Bay, and then back. I don't think she will have much inclination to sleepwalk afterwards.

en: CHAPTER VIII
vi: CHAPTER 8
tr: VIII
es: VIII.–

en: MINA MURRAY’S JOURNAL
vi: Mina Murray's Journal
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: FROM MINAMURRAY'S DIARY

en: Same day, 11 o’clock p. m.—Oh, but I am tired! If it were not that I had made my diary a duty I should not open it to-night. We had a lovely walk. Lucy, after a while, was in gay spirits, owing, I think, to some dear cows who came nosing towards us in a field close to the lighthouse, and frightened the wits out of us. I believe we forgot everything except, of course, personal fear, and it seemed to wipe the slate clean and give us a fresh start. We had a capital “severe tea” at Robin Hood’s Bay in a sweet little old-fashioned inn, with a bow-window right over the seaweed-covered rocks of the strand. I believe we should have shocked the “New Woman” with our appetites. Men are more tolerant, bless them! Then we walked home with some, or rather many, stoppages to rest, and with our hearts full of a constant dread of wild bulls. Lucy was really tired, and we intended to creep off to bed as soon as we could. The young curate came in, however, and Mrs. Westenra asked him to stay for supper. Lucy and I had both a fight for it with the dusty miller; I know it was a hard fight on my part, and I am quite heroic. I think that some day the bishops must get together and see about breeding up a new class of curates, who don’t take supper, no matter how they may be pressed to, and who will know when girls are tired. Lucy is asleep and breathing softly. She has more colour in her cheeks than usual, and looks, oh, so sweet. If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her seeing her only in the drawing-room, I wonder what he would say if he saw her now. Some of the “New Women” writers will some day start an idea that men and women should be allowed to see each other asleep before proposing or accepting. But I suppose the New Woman won’t condescend in future to accept; she will do the proposing herself. And a nice job she will make of it, too! There’s some consolation in that. I am so happy to-night, because dear Lucy seems better. I really believe she has turned the corner, and that we are over her troubles with dreaming. I should be quite happy if I only knew if Jonathan.... God bless and keep him.
vi: • 11 PM the same day It's quite funny, the one exhausted after the walk is actually me! If I didn't have the habit of writing a diary, I probably wouldn't write anything tonight. We had a rather interesting walk. Lucy seemed more serene, she laughed heartily at the curiosity of the cows as they ambled near the fence, naively watching us pass by - this seemed to make both of us forget all our most troubling thoughts. Down at Robin Hood's Bay, in a small teahouse where guests could sit and look out at the seaweed-covered rocks, the owner served us an excellent tea. Surely, the mothers and sisters who call themselves "fashionable women" would be shocked to see us enjoying it so much. As for the gentlemen, thank God, they always seem more generous! After that, we continued back, but occasionally stopped to rest a bit. Back at the hotel, Lucy said she was very tired, so we decided to go straight to our room to lie down. But a young vicar had just come to visit, and Mrs. Westenra invited him to stay for dinner with us: I wasn't pleased, but Lucy was still fine. Her face looked so lovely with her rosy cheeks. If Holmwood felt love for her at first sight in the drawing room, I can't imagine how he would feel seeing her asleep like tonight! Perhaps some "fashionable women" writers would immediately think of a new trend: they would suggest that young men and women, before getting married, should watch each other sleep! But I think from now on, the "fashionable woman" will no longer be content with just accepting a man's proposal; she might even be the one to do it, and perfectly at that. That is just a consolation. I would be so happy to see Lucy healthier. I truly believe she has passed the most critical moment, and tonight she will have a peaceful sleep. As for me, I will have complete joy if I know that Jonathan...May God bless and protect him!
tr: The same day, 11 PM.- Ah! How tired I am! If I hadn't made it a duty to keep a journal, I wouldn't open it tonight. We had a very nice walk. After a while, Lucy cheered up; I think we owe this to a few cute cows that slowly approached us in the field near the lighthouse and scared us. I think we forgot everything except our personal fears, and in this way, we wiped the slate clean and made a fresh start. At Robin Hood's Bay, we had a perfect "bitter tea" in a lovely, tiny, old-fashioned inn with a curved window right above the seaweed-covered rocks on the shore. I'm sure our appetite would astonish the "New Woman". Men are more tolerant, God bless them! Then we walked home, taking a few, or rather many, rest breaks, with an unending fear of wild bulls in our hearts. Lucy was really very tired, and we aimed to crawl into our beds as quickly as possible. But the young preacher came to visit us, and Ms. Westenra asked him to stay for dinner. Both Lucy and I fought the sleep fairy for him; I know it was a tough battle for me, but I acted quite heroically. I think one day bishops should come together and find a way to produce a new class of preachers who, no matter how much they are insisted upon, do not stay for dinner and understand that the girls are tired. Lucy fell asleep and is breathing lightly. Her cheeks are more colorful than ever and oh, she looks so sweet. If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her just by seeing her in the living room, I wonder what he would say if he saw her now. Someday, some "New Woman" writers will support the idea that men and women should be allowed to see each other while sleeping before proposing or accepting a marriage proposal. But I think in the future, the "New Woman" will not show the humility to accept a marriage proposal; she will make the proposal herself. And she will do a very good job at it! We can find some consolation in this. I am very happy tonight because Lucy looks better. Really, I believe she has overcome the danger and the problems related to dreaming. My happiness would be complete if I knew Jonathan was well, God bless and protect him.
es: Same day, 11 p.m. Oh, how tired I am! If it weren't for the fact that I have taken it as a duty to write in my diary every night, I wouldn't open it today. We had a lovely walk. After a while, Lucy was in a better mood, due, I think, to some peaceful cows that came to sniff us in the field near the lighthouse, and they completely drove us crazy. I think we forgot everything, except, of course, personal fear, and this seemed to erase everything and give us the chance to start anew. We had a magnificent "English tea" at a small and charming old-fashioned inn in Robin Hood's Bay, with an arched window overlooking the seaweed-covered rocks on the beach. I think we would have scared the "New Woman" with our appetites. Men are more tolerant, bless them! Then, we set off on the walk back home, making some or rather many stops to rest, and with our hearts in constant fear of the wild bulls. Lucy was truly tired, and we intended to sneak off to bed as soon as we could. However, the young priest arrived, and Mrs. Westenra asked him to stay for dinner. Lucy and I both had a quarrel about it with the miller; I know that on my part it was a very tough fight, and I am quite heroic. I believe that someday the bishops should meet and see how to raise a new class of priests, who do not accept staying for dinner, no matter how much they are insisted upon, and who know when the young women are tired. Lucy is asleep and breathing softly. She has more color in her cheeks than other times, and she looks so sweet! If Mr. Holmwood fell in love with her just by seeing her in the living room, I wonder what he would say if he could see her now. Some of the "New Woman" writers might someday put into practice the idea that men and women should be able to see each other sleeping first before proposing or accepting. But I suppose that the "New Woman" will not condescend to accept in the future; she will make the proposal herself. And what a job she will have! There is some consolation in this. Tonight I am very happy because my dear Lucy seems to be quite better. I really believe that he has turned the corner, and that the problems caused by his sleepwalking have been overcome. I would be completely happy just to hear news from Jonathan... God bless him and keep him.

en: 11 August, 3 a. m.—Diary again. No sleep now, so I may as well write. I am too agitated to sleep. We have had such an adventure, such an agonising experience. I fell asleep as soon as I had closed my diary.... Suddenly I became broad awake, and sat up, with a horrible sense of fear upon me, and of some feeling of emptiness around me. The room was dark, so I could not see Lucy’s bed; I stole across and felt for her. The bed was empty. I lit a match and found that she was not in the room. The door was shut, but not locked, as I had left it. I feared to wake her mother, who has been more than usually ill lately, so threw on some clothes and got ready to look for her. As I was leaving the room it struck me that the clothes she wore might give me some clue to her dreaming intention. Dressing-gown would mean house; dress, outside. Dressing-gown and dress were both in their places. “Thank God,” I said to myself, “she cannot be far, as she is only in her nightdress.” I ran downstairs and looked in the sitting-room. Not there! Then I looked in all the other open rooms of the house, with an ever-growing fear chilling my heart. Finally I came to the hall door and found it open. It was not wide open, but the catch of the lock had not caught. The people of the house are careful to lock the door every night, so I feared that Lucy must have gone out as she was. There was no time to think of what might happen; a vague, overmastering fear obscured all details. I took a big, heavy shawl and ran out. The clock was striking one as I was in the Crescent, and there was not a soul in sight. I ran along the North Terrace, but could see no sign of the white figure which I expected. At the edge of the West Cliff above the pier I looked across the harbour to the East Cliff, in the hope or fear—I don’t know which—of seeing Lucy in our favourite seat. There was a bright full moon, with heavy black, driving clouds, which threw the whole scene into a fleeting diorama of light and shade as they sailed across. For a moment or two I could see nothing, as the shadow of a cloud obscured St. Mary’s Church and all around it. Then as the cloud passed I could see the ruins of the abbey coming into view; and as the edge of a narrow band of light as sharp as a sword-cut moved along, the church and the churchyard became gradually visible. Whatever my expectation was, it was not disappointed, for there, on our favourite seat, the silver light of the moon struck a half-reclining figure, snowy white. The coming of the cloud was too quick for me to see much, for shadow shut down on light almost immediately; but it seemed to me as though something dark stood behind the seat where the white figure shone, and bent over it. What it was, whether man or beast, I could not tell; I did not wait to catch another glance, but flew down the steep steps to the pier and along by the fish-market to the bridge, which was the only way to reach the East Cliff. The town seemed as dead, for not a soul did I see; I rejoiced that it was so, for I wanted no witness of poor Lucy’s condition. The time and distance seemed endless, and my knees trembled and my breath came laboured as I toiled up the endless steps to the abbey. I must have gone fast, and yet it seemed to me as if my feet were weighted with lead, and as though every joint in my body were rusty. When I got almost to the top I could see the seat and the white figure, for I was now close enough to distinguish it even through the spells of shadow. There was undoubtedly something, long and black, bending over the half-reclining white figure. I called in fright, “Lucy! Lucy!” and something raised a head, and from where I was I could see a white face and red, gleaming eyes. Lucy did not answer, and I ran on to the entrance of the churchyard. As I entered, the church was between me and the seat, and for a minute or so I lost sight of her. When I came in view again the cloud had passed, and the moonlight struck so brilliantly that I could see Lucy half reclining with her head lying over the back of the seat. She was quite alone, and there was not a sign of any living thing about.
vi: • August 11, 3 AM I continue writing in my diary after being unable to sleep any longer. How could I sleep after that terrifying adventure? To be honest, I did manage to sleep for a while right after closing the notebook. However, I woke up with a start, drenched in sweat, without understanding why. I had the feeling that I was alone in the room; it was so dark that I couldn't see Lucy's bed. Only when I tiptoed closer did I realize that the bed was empty - Lucy was no longer there! I struck a match to see: she wasn't in the room! The door was still closed but not locked; I clearly remembered turning the lock before going to sleep. So Lucy had gone out. Not wanting to disturb Mrs. Westenra's hard-earned sleep, I quickly threw on a coat and rushed out to find her daughter. As I left the room, I thought that the clothes Lucy wore when she went out might give me a clue about her intentions while sleepwalking. If she was wearing her nightgown, she might still be somewhere in the house, but if she was wearing a dress, it meant she had gone outside. But her nightgown, along with all her other clothes, were still in the room. "Thank God!" I thought to myself, "she couldn't have gone far in the middle of the night wearing only a nightgown!" I rushed downstairs into the living room. Lucy wasn't there. I burst into all the remaining rooms, growing more anxious by the minute. Finally, I ran to the front door and was startled to see it wide open. Remembering that this door was usually locked every night, I began to fear that Lucy had gone outside with only her nightgown on. But I couldn't waste time thinking about what might have happened: a vague sense of dread was rising within me, making me incapable of focusing on details. I hurriedly ran out the door. When I reached Crescent Street, the clock somewhere struck a long chime, the street was deserted with not a soul in sight. I kept running without noticing a white shadow. Reaching the western cliff edge that jutted out over the bridge, I stopped to look around the eastern side, feeling both hopeful and fearful. I truly don't know how to describe my emotions when I saw Lucy's silhouette sitting on the familiar stone bench. The clear moonlight in the sky was being obscured by gathering dark clouds, leaving the world below alternately bright and dim. At times, I couldn't distinguish anything, as a massive dark cloud had enveloped the silhouette of St. Mary's Church and the surrounding areas. However, the clouds soon dispersed due to the strong winds, allowing the moonlight to once again illuminate the ruins of the abbey, then the church, and the cemetery. My waiting, whether hopeful or fearful, would not be in vain, for on that bench, the pale moonlight clearly revealed a white figure, half lying, half sitting. Another cloud quickly swept in, plunging everything back into darkness, but I still had the feeling that something very dark was standing behind the bench, bending over the white figure. I couldn't tell if it was a human shadow or that of an animal. Not wasting time waiting for the cloud to pass, I quickly slipped down to the harbor, walked along the fish market, and climbed up the bridge, as this was the only way to reach the eastern cliff. The deserted city made me feel more comfortable, because after all, I didn't want the world to know the true state of my poor friend Lucy. Time, and even distance, seemed to stretch endlessly for me; my knees began to tremble, and I felt increasingly breathless as I climbed the stone steps leading to the monastery. I mustered all my strength to climb to the top as quickly as possible, yet my legs felt as heavy as lead. Groping near the place, I immediately recognized the stone bench and the white figure there; now I was close enough to distinguish everything in the darkness. There was no doubt about it, there was clearly a long, dark shadow bending over my friend. I blurted out, "Lucy, Lucy?" and immediately saw a head lift up along with a pale face and bright eyes. Not hearing Lucy respond, I dashed into the cemetery. The towering shadow of the church obscured my view. I ran around the church. Finally, the moonlight, free of clouds, allowed me to clearly see Lucy in a half-lying, half-sitting position, her head resting against the back of the stone bench. She was alone there; behind the bench, there was no trace, not even the smallest, of any living creature.
tr: August 11, 3 AM.- Diary again. Now there's no sleep, so I might as well write. I'm too excited to sleep. We experienced such an adventure, such a surprising experience. As soon as I closed my diary, I fell asleep. I suddenly woke up, sitting up with a terrifying fear pressing down on me and a sense of emptiness around me. The room was dark, so I couldn't see Lucy's bed; I quietly went over and searched for Lucy by touch. The bed was empty. I lit a match and saw that she wasn't in the room. The door was closed, but it wasn't locked as I had left it. I was afraid of waking her mother, who had been sicker than ever lately; so I put on some clothes and prepared to look for Lucy. As I was leaving the room, it occurred to me that what she was wearing might give some clues about her purpose in sleepwalking. A robe meant home; a dress meant outside. Both the robe and the dress were in their places. "Thank God!" I said to myself; "She can't have gone far, because she's only in her nightgown. "I ran downstairs and looked in the sitting room. She wasn't there! Then, with a growing fear that chilled my heart, I looked in all the other rooms with open doors in the house. Finally, I reached the entrance door and saw that it was open. It wasn't wide open, but the latch wasn't in place. The household is quite diligent about locking the door every night, so I feared that Lucy had gone outside just as she was. There was no time to think about what might have happened; an overwhelming, all-encompassing fear blurred all the details. I grabbed a large, heavy shawl and ran outside. When I reached the Crescent, the clock struck one, and there wasn't a single person in sight. I ran along North Terrace, but there was no sign of the white figure I was expecting. With hope or fear - I don't know which - of seeing Lucy on our favorite bench, I looked from the edge of North Cliff over the harbor to East Cliff on the other side. There was a bright full moon and heavy, dark, moving clouds that turned the entire landscape into a visual feast of light and shadow as they drifted. For a second or two, I couldn't see anything because a cloud's shadow darkened Saint Mary's Church and its surroundings. Then, as the cloud passed, I saw the ruins of the Abbey reappear; a narrow line of light, as sharp as a sword cut, moved forward, and the church and churchyard began to come into view. Whatever my expectation was, it wasn't in vain, because there, on our favorite bench, the moon's silver light was shining on a snow-white figure leaning back slightly. The cloud quickly returned before I could see much more; the shadow almost immediately cut off the light, but it seemed to me that there was something dark standing behind the bench where the white figure had shone.
