I couldn't tell what it was, whether human or animal; I didn't wait to look again; I ran down the steep steps leading to the pier and ran across the bridge, the only way to reach East Cliff from the fish market. The town was dead, as I didn't see a single person; I was glad of this because I didn't want anyone to witness Lucy's condition. Time and distance seemed infinite; my knees trembled, and I began to breathe heavily as I struggled up the endless stairs leading to the Abbey. I must have gone quickly, but I felt as if lead weights were tied to my feet and all the joints in my body were rusted. As I approached the top, I began to see the bench and the white figure, for I was now close enough to distinguish it despite the shadow's effect. Undoubtedly, there was a long, black thing bending over the half-reclining white figure. In horror, I shouted, "Lucy! Lucy!" and something lifted its head; from where I stood, I could see a white face with red, gleaming eyes. Lucy didn't respond, and I ran to the entrance of the churchyard. When I entered, the church was between me and the bench, and I lost sight of Lucy for about a minute. When I began to see her again, the cloud had passed, and the moonlight was so bright that I could see Lucy lying slightly reclined with her head on the back of the bench. She was completely alone, and there was no sign of any living thing around her.
es: August 11, 3 a.m. I am not sleepy, so it would be better if I write. I am too agitated to be able to sleep. We have had an extraordinary adventure; a very painful experience. I fell asleep as soon as I closed my diary… Suddenly I woke up completely and sat up, with a terrible sensation of fear all over my body; with a feeling of emptiness around me. The room was dark, so I couldn't see Lucy's bed; I approached it and searched for her by touch. The bed was empty. I lit a match and discovered that she was not in the room. The door was closed, but not locked as I had left it. I feared waking her mother, who has been quite ill lately, so I put on some clothes and prepared to look for her. As I was leaving the room, it occurred to me that the clothes she was wearing might give me some clue about her sleepwalking intentions. A robe would mean the house; a dress, the street. But both the robe and her dresses were in their place. " My God," I said to myself, "she can't be far, as she is only wearing her nightgown. "I ran downstairs and looked in the living room. She wasn't there! Then I searched the other open rooms in the house, with a cold, ever-growing fear in my heart. Finally, I reached the hallway door and found it open. It wasn't fully open, but the latch was not fastened. The people in the house are always very careful to close the door every night, so I feared that Lucy had gone out just as she was. There was no time to think about what might happen; a vague, invincible fear overshadowed all the details. I took a large, heavy shawl and ran outside. The clock was striking one when I was on the Crescent, and there wasn't a soul in sight. I ran along North Terrace but could not see any sign of the white figure I expected to find. At the edge of West Cliff, over the pier, I looked across the harbor towards East Cliff, with hope or fear, I don't know which, of seeing Lucy in our favorite seat. There was a full, bright moon, with fast-moving black and heavy clouds, giving the whole scene a diorama of light and shadow as they sailed across; for a few moments, I couldn't see anything, as the shadow of a cloud darkened St. Mary's Church and all around it. Then, as the cloud passed, I could see the ruins of the abbey becoming visible; and when a narrow strip of light as sharp as a sword's edge passed along, I could see the church and the churchyard appear within the field of light. Whatever my expectation was, it was not disappointed, for there, in our seat, the silvery moonlight illuminated a half-reclined figure, white as snow. The arrival of the cloud was too quick for me, and it didn't allow me to see much, as the shadows fell over the light almost immediately; but it seemed to me as if something dark was behind the seat where the white figure shone, and was leaning over it. Whether it was man or beast, I cannot say. I didn't wait to take another look, but ran down the steps to the pier and hurried through the fish market to the bridge, which was the only way to get to East Cliff. The town seemed dead, as there wasn't a soul around. I was glad it was so, as I didn't want any witnesses to the poor condition Lucy was in. Time and distance seemed infinite, and my knees trembled and my breath became labored as I climbed the endless steps to the abbey. I must have run fast, and yet, it seemed to me that my feet were weighed down with lead, and as if every joint in my body was rusted. When I had almost reached the top, I could see the seat and the white figure, for now I was close enough to distinguish it even through the cloak of shadows. Undoubtedly, there was something long and black leaning over the half-reclined white figure. Filled with fear, I shouted, "Lucy! Lucy!", and something lifted a head, and from where I was, I could see a white face with red, gleaming eyes. Lucy did not respond to me, and I ran towards the entrance of the churchyard. As I entered, the church stood between me and the seat, and for a minute I lost sight of it. When I saw her again, the cloud had already passed, and the moonlight illuminated the place so brightly that I could see Lucy half-reclined with her head resting on the back of the seat. She was completely alone, and there were no signs of living beings anywhere.

en: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted, and she was breathing—not softly as usual with her, but in long, heavy gasps, as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath. As I came close, she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat. Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her, as though she felt the cold. I flung the warm shawl over her, and drew the edges tight round her neck, for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air, unclad as she was. I feared to wake her all at once, so, in order to have my hands free that I might help her, I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safety-pin; but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it, for by-and-by, when her breathing became quieter, she put her hand to her throat again and moaned. When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her. At first she did not respond; but gradually she became more and more uneasy in her sleep, moaning and sighing occasionally. At last, as time was passing fast, and, for many other reasons, I wished to get her home at once, I shook her more forcibly, till finally she opened her eyes and awoke. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not realise all at once where she was. Lucy always wakes prettily, and even at such a time, when her body must have been chilled with cold, and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night, she did not lose her grace. She trembled a little, and clung to me; when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word, with the obedience of a child. As we passed along, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed me wince. She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes; but I would not. However, when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle of water, remaining from the storm, I daubed my feet with mud, using each foot in turn on the other, so that as we went home, no one, in case we should meet any one, should notice my bare feet.
vi: Lucy was sleeping very soundly, her lips slightly parted, her breathing not as smooth as usual. It seemed she was struggling with labored breaths to draw air into her chest. She stirred slightly and unconsciously pulled her nightgown up to cover her neck. I suddenly noticed she was shivering from head to toe. I gently wrapped my woolen scarf around her neck. However, it seemed my clumsy, frightened hand had jabbed her neck, as I saw her raise her hand to rub her neck and let out a soft moan. My long fingernail had hurt her, but she did not wake up because of it. After putting my shoes on her feet, I dared to gently wake her up. She let out another soft moan and exhaled deeply, but did not move any further. Realizing that a new day was approaching, which would make it inconvenient to take Lucy back to the hotel, I had to shake her a bit more firmly. Finally, she opened her eyes, but did not show any surprise upon seeing me, clearly still unaware of where she was. Even in her drowsy state, Lucy looked as beautiful as ever. Even though she had spent a cold, shivering night in a desolate graveyard, wearing only a nightgown, she had not lost her graceful charm. Even after waking up, she was still trembling. When I said, "Let's go home right away," she silently stood up and obediently followed like a child. On the way back, the gravel had bloodied my feet. Seeing this, she stopped and insisted that I put on the shoes I had given her. Of course, I refused. Upon leaving the cemetery, I had to dip both feet in mud so that if anyone saw us, they wouldn't notice I was barefoot.
tr: When I leaned over, I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were parted and she was breathing - not softly as usual, but with long, deep breaths as if she wanted to fill her lungs completely with each inhale. When I approached her, she raised her hand in her sleep and wrapped the collar of her nightgown around her neck. As she did this, she shivered slightly as if she felt the cold. I threw a warm shawl over her and fastened the edges tightly around her neck because I was afraid she might catch a bad chill in the night air while she was so exposed. I was afraid of waking her suddenly, so I secured the shawl around her neck with a large safety pin to free my hands and help her; but in my anxious clumsiness, I must have pricked or stuck her with the pin because soon after, as her breathing calmed, she brought her hand to her neck and groaned once more. Once I had carefully wrapped her up, I put my shoes on her feet and then began to wake her gently. At first, she did not respond, but she became increasingly restless, occasionally groaning and sighing in her sleep. Time was passing quickly, and for many other reasons, I wanted to get her home as soon as possible; finally, I shook her with great effort until she opened her eyes and woke up. Of course, she did not seem surprised to see me because she did not immediately understand where she was. Lucy always wakes up beautifully, and even at such a time, when her body was chilled from the cold and her mind was somewhat horrified by waking up in the churchyard at night without her clothes, she did not lose her grace. She shivered a little and hugged me; when I told her to come home with me immediately, she stood up without saying a word, like an obedient child. As we walked, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed the pained expression on my face. She stopped and wanted to insist that I take my shoes back, but I refused. But when we reached the goat path outside the churchyard, where there was a puddle left from the storm, I stepped into the mud with one foot after the other, so that if we encountered anyone on the way home, no one would notice my bare feet.
es: When I leaned over her, I could see that she was still asleep. Her lips were open, and she was breathing, but not with the usual softness; rather, in large and heavy gasps, as if she were trying to fully fill her lungs with each breath. As I approached, she raised her hand and pulled at the neck of her nightgown, as if she felt cold. However, she remained asleep. I placed the warm shawl over her shoulders, tying the ends tightly around her neck, as I was very afraid she might catch a deadly cold from the night air, being almost naked as she was. I feared waking her abruptly, so to have my hands free to help her, I fastened the shawl near her throat with a large safety pin; but in my anxiety, I must have acted clumsily and pricked her with it, because shortly after, when her breathing became more regular, she brought her hand to her throat again and moaned. Once I had carefully wrapped her, I put my shoes on her feet and began to wake her very gently. At first, she did not respond: but gradually she became more and more restless in her sleep, occasionally moaning and sighing. Finally, as time was passing quickly and for many other reasons, I wanted to take her home immediately, I shook her more forcefully until she finally opened her eyes and woke up. She did not seem surprised to see me, as, of course, she did not immediately realize where we were. Lucy always wakes up with a beautiful expression, and even at that moment, when her body must have been pierced by the cold and her mind terrified upon knowing she had walked semi-naked through the cemetery at night, she did not seem to lose her grace. She shivered a little and hugged me tightly; when I told her to come back home with me immediately, she got up without a word and obeyed me like a child. As we began to walk, the gravel hurt my feet, and Lucy noticed my jump. She stopped and wanted to insist that I put on my shoes, but I refused. However, when we reached the path outside the cemetery, where there was a puddle of water, a remnant of the storm, I smeared my feet with mud using one foot over the other, so that when we went home, no one, in case we met anyone, could notice my bare feet.

en: Fortune favoured us, and we got home without meeting a soul. Once we saw a man, who seemed not quite sober, passing along a street in front of us; but we hid in a door till he had disappeared up an opening such as there are here, steep little closes, or “wynds,” as they call them in Scotland. My heart beat so loud all the time that sometimes I thought I should faint. I was filled with anxiety about Lucy, not only for her health, lest she should suffer from the exposure, but for her reputation in case the story should get wind. When we got in, and had washed our feet, and had said a prayer of thankfulness together, I tucked her into bed. Before falling asleep she asked—even implored—me not to say a word to any one, even her mother, about her sleep-walking adventure. I hesitated at first to promise; but on thinking of the state of her mother’s health, and how the knowledge of such a thing would fret her, and thinking, too, of how such a story might become distorted—nay, infallibly would—in case it should leak out, I thought it wiser to do so. I hope I did right. I have locked the door, and the key is tied to my wrist, so perhaps I shall not be again disturbed. Lucy is sleeping soundly; the reflex of the dawn is high and far over the sea....
vi: But luck smiled on Lucy and me: we made it home without encountering anyone. Actually, there was a man on his way to get fish, but we managed to hide by the church gate until he passed. It’s hardly worth mentioning that I was not only worried about Lucy catching a cold, but also deeply afraid of her reputation being tarnished if this incident came to light. Once home, after washing her feet, I immediately took her to her room. Before sleeping, she pleaded with me not to tell anyone, not even her mother. At first, I hesitated about whether to promise her, but after thinking it over, I decided to agree, as I was also concerned about her mother's health, knowing she would be shocked by the news. I hope I did the right thing. I locked the door and kept the key in my hand as I lay down. Perhaps I won't find myself in such a difficult situation again. Lucy quickly fell back into a deep sleep. Outside, the dawn light was glimmering on the sea...
tr: Luck was on our side and we reached home without encountering anyone. Once, as we were moving along the road ahead, we saw a man who was not very sober; but we hid in the recess of a doorway until the man disappeared down one of the steep paths called wynds in Scotland. My heart was beating so fast that I thought I would faint at times. I was very worried about Lucy; not only for her health, fearing she might be harmed by being exposed, but also for her reputation if the story were to spread from ear to ear. After we went inside, washed our feet, and said a prayer of thanks together, I put her to bed. Before falling asleep, she asked me not to tell anyone, not even her mother, about this sleepwalking adventure, she even begged for it. At first, I hesitated to promise this; but when I thought about her mother's health and how learning about this would worry her, and how such a story could be distorted if it leaked out -no, it would definitely be distorted- I decided it was wiser to do as she asked. I hope I did the right thing. I locked the door; the key is tied to my hand so that perhaps I won't be disturbed again. Lucy is sleeping soundly; the reflection of dawn can be seen over the sea...
es: Fortune favored us and we arrived home without encountering a soul. On one occasion, we saw a man, who did not seem to be entirely sober, crossing a street in front of us; but we hid behind a door until he disappeared into an open field like the ones that abound here, small sloping courtyards, or winds, as they are called in Scotland. During all this time, my heart pounded so strongly that at times I thought I would faint. I was filled with anxiety for Lucy, not so much for her health, even though the cold air could affect her, but for her reputation in case the story of what happened became public. When we entered, and once we had washed our feet and prayed together a prayer of thanks, I put her to bed. Before falling asleep, she asked me, implored me, not to say a word to anyone, not even to her mother, about what had happened that night. At first, I hesitated to make the promise; but when I thought about her mother's state of health, and how the news of such an event would excite her, and also considering how that story could be twisted (no, it would infallibly be falsified) if it became known, I thought it was wiser to promise what was asked of me. I hope I have acted rightly. I have closed the door and tied the key to my wrist, so I may not be disturbed again. Lucy is sleeping deeply; the reflection of the dawn appears high and far over the sea…

en: Same day, noon.—All goes well. Lucy slept till I woke her and seemed not to have even changed her side. The adventure of the night does not seem to have harmed her; on the contrary, it has benefited her, for she looks better this morning than she has done for weeks. I was sorry to notice that my clumsiness with the safety-pin hurt her. Indeed, it might have been serious, for the skin of her throat was pierced. I must have pinched up a piece of loose skin and have transfixed it, for there are two little red points like pin-pricks, and on the band of her nightdress was a drop of blood. When I apologised and was concerned about it, she laughed and petted me, and said she did not even feel it. Fortunately it cannot leave a scar, as it is so tiny.
vi: • On the same day, at noon Everything is fine. Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Same day, noon. - Everything is fine. Lucy slept until I woke her up and she doesn't seem to have turned in her bed. The night's adventure doesn't seem to have harmed her; on the contrary, it seems to have benefited her, because this morning she looks better than she has in weeks. I'm sorry that my clumsiness with the safety pin hurt her. Indeed, the situation could have been serious because the skin on her neck is slightly pierced. I must have pierced a loose piece of skin because there are two small red dots on her neck like pinholes and a drop of blood on the collar band of her nightgown. When I apologized and said I was worried about it, she laughed, patted me, and said she didn't feel anything. Fortunately, since it is very tiny, it won't leave a mark.
es: Same day, in the afternoon. Everything is going well. Lucy slept until I woke her up and it seemed she hadn't even changed sides. The night's adventure doesn't seem to have caused her any harm; on the contrary, it has benefited her, as she is much better this morning than in the past few weeks. I felt sad to notice that my clumsiness with the safety pin had hurt her. In fact, it could have been something serious, as the skin on her throat was punctured. I must have caught a piece of skin with the safety pin, piercing it, as there are two small red dots like pinholes, and there was a drop of blood on the neck of her nightgown. When I apologized and showed my concern about it, Lucy laughed and comforted me, saying she hadn't even felt it. Fortunately, there will be no scar, as they are tiny holes.

en: Same day, night.—We passed a happy day. The air was clear, and the sun bright, and there was a cool breeze. We took our lunch to Mulgrave Woods, Mrs. Westenra driving by the road and Lucy and I walking by the cliff-path and joining her at the gate. I felt a little sad myself, for I could not but feel how absolutely happy it would have been had Jonathan been with me. But there! I must only be patient. In the evening we strolled in the Casino Terrace, and heard some good music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed early. Lucy seems more restful than she has been for some time, and fell asleep at once. I shall lock the door and secure the key the same as before, though I do not expect any trouble to-night.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: Same day, night. - We had a happy day. The weather was clear, the sun was shining, and there was a cool breeze. We took our lunch to Mulgrave Woods, Ms. Westenra went by road in the carriage, and Lucy and I walked along the cliff path and met her at the gate. I was a bit sad because I couldn't help but feel how completely happy I would be if Jonathan were with me. But there it is! I must be patient. In the evening, we strolled on the Casino Terrace, listened to beautiful music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed early. Lucy seems more peaceful than she has been for some time, she fell asleep immediately. Even though I don't expect any trouble tonight, I will lock the door and secure the key as before.
es: Same day, at night. We have spent the day very happily. The air was clear, the sun bright, and there was a fresh breeze. We took our lunch to the Mulgrave woods; Mrs. Westenra driving along the road, Lucy and I walking along the gorge path and meeting her at the entrance. I felt a little sad, as I could realize how absolutely happy I would have been if I had Jonathan by my side. But, oh well! I just need to be patient. In the evening, we took a walk to the Terrace Casino, and listened to some good music by Spohr and Mackenzie, and went to bed very early. Lucy seems to be calmer than she has been lately, and I fell asleep immediately. I will secure the door and keep the key in the same way as before, as I do not think there will be any problem tonight.

en: 12 August.—My expectations were wrong, for twice during the night I was wakened by Lucy trying to get out. She seemed, even in her sleep, to be a little impatient at finding the door shut, and went back to bed under a sort of protest. I woke with the dawn, and heard the birds chirping outside of the window. Lucy woke, too, and, I was glad to see, was even better than on the previous morning. All her old gaiety of manner seemed to have come back, and she came and snuggled in beside me and told me all about Arthur. I told her how anxious I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to comfort me. Well, she succeeded somewhat, for, though sympathy can’t alter facts, it can help to make them more bearable.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: August 12. - My expectations were wrong because I woke up twice during the night with Lucy trying to go outside. Even in her sleep, she seemed a bit impatient to find the door closed and returned to bed with a protesting attitude. I woke up at dawn and heard the chirping of birds in front of the window. Lucy also woke up, and I was glad to see that she was even better than the previous morning. Her old cheerful demeanor seemed to have completely returned; she came and curled up next to me and told me everything about Arthur; I told her how worried I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to comfort me. Well, she somehow managed to do so, because although empathy cannot change the facts, it can help make them more bearable.
es: August 12. My predictions were wrong, as twice during the night I was awakened by Lucy, who was trying to get out. She seemed, even while asleep, to be a little impatient at finding the door locked, and lay back down uttering groans of protest. I woke at dawn and heard the birds chirping outside the window. Lucy woke up too, and I was glad to see that she was even better than yesterday morning. All her old cheerfulness seems to have returned, and she moved over to my bed, snuggling up to me to tell me all about Arthur. I told her how anxious I was about Jonathan, and then she tried to console me. Well, to some extent she succeeded, as although sympathy cannot alter facts, it can help make them more bearable.

en: 13 August.—Another quiet day, and to bed with the key on my wrist as before. Again I awoke in the night, and found Lucy sitting up in bed, still asleep, pointing to the window. I got up quietly, and pulling aside the blind, looked out. It was brilliant moonlight, and the soft effect of the light over the sea and sky—merged together in one great, silent mystery—was beautiful beyond words. Between me and the moonlight flitted a great bat, coming and going in great whirling circles. Once or twice it came quite close, but was, I suppose, frightened at seeing me, and flitted away across the harbour towards the abbey. When I came back from the window Lucy had lain down again, and was sleeping peacefully. She did not stir again all night.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: August 13th. - Another calm day and, as on previous nights, I went to bed with the key tied to my hand. Once again, I woke up during the night and found Lucy sitting on the bed still asleep, pointing towards the window. I quietly got up and drew the curtain to look outside. There was a bright moonlight, and the soft effect of the light on the sea and sky - the two blending into each other in a great, silent mystery - was indescribably beautiful. A large bat was flying in wide circles between the moonlight and me. Once or twice it came quite close, but I think it got scared when it saw me, and flew away towards the Monastery, passing over the harbor. When I turned back from the window, Lucy had lain down again and was sleeping peacefully. She did not move at all for the rest of the night.
es: August 13. Another quiet day, and I went to bed with the key on my wrist as before. Again I woke up during the night and found Lucy sitting on her bed, still asleep, pointing towards the window. I got up stealthily, and parting the blind, looked outside. The moon shone splendidly, and the soft effect of the light on the sea and sky, merged into one great and silent mystery, was of indescribable beauty. Between me and the moonlight fluttered a large bat, coming and going in wide circles. A couple of times it came quite close, but I suppose, frightened by seeing me, it flew back, heading towards the port and the abbey. When I returned from the window, Lucy had lain down again and was sleeping peacefully. She did not move again all night.

en: 14 August.—On the East Cliff, reading and writing all day. Lucy seems to have become as much in love with the spot as I am, and it is hard to get her away from it when it is time to come home for lunch or tea or dinner. This afternoon she made a funny remark. We were coming home for dinner, and had come to the top of the steps up from the West Pier and stopped to look at the view, as we generally do. The setting sun, low down in the sky, was just dropping behind Kettleness; the red light was thrown over on the East Cliff and the old abbey, and seemed to bathe everything in a beautiful rosy glow. We were silent for a while, and suddenly Lucy murmured as if to herself:—
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed.
tr: August 14. - I spent the whole day reading and writing at East Cliff. Lucy seems to love this place as much as I do, and it's hard to get her to leave and go home for lunch, tea, or dinner. She said something strange this afternoon. We were heading home for dinner and had reached the top of the stairs that start at the West Pier, and as usual, we stopped to look at the view. The sun, which had sunk quite low in the sky, was almost setting behind Kettleness; its red light was spread over East Cliff and the Abbey, making everything seem bathed in a beautiful pink glow. We stood in silence for a while, and suddenly Lucy murmured, as if talking to herself:
es: August 14th. I have been at East Cliff, reading and writing all day. Lucy seems to have fallen in love with this place as much as I have, and it is very difficult to tear her away from here when it is time to go home for lunch, tea, or dinner. This afternoon she made a very strange comment. We were on our way home for dinner, and we had reached the upper steps of the West Pier, stopping to look at the scenery as we always do. The setting sun, very low on the horizon, was hiding behind Kettleness; the red light fell on East Cliff and the old abbey, and it seemed to bathe everything in a beautiful rosy glow. We were silent for a few moments, and suddenly Lucy murmured as if to herself:

en: “His red eyes again! They are just the same.” It was such an odd expression, coming apropos of nothing, that it quite startled me. I slewed round a little, so as to see Lucy well without seeming to stare at her, and saw that she was in a half-dreamy state, with an odd look on her face that I could not quite make out; so I said nothing, but followed her eyes. She appeared to be looking over at our own seat, whereon was a dark figure seated alone. I was a little startled myself, for it seemed for an instant as if the stranger had great eyes like burning flames; but a second look dispelled the illusion. The red sunlight was shining on the windows of St. Mary’s Church behind our seat, and as the sun dipped there was just sufficient change in the refraction and reflection to make it appear as if the light moved. I called Lucy’s attention to the peculiar effect, and she became herself with a start, but she looked sad all the same; it may have been that she was thinking of that terrible night up there. We never refer to it; so I said nothing, and we went home to dinner. Lucy had a headache and went early to bed. I saw her asleep, and went out for a little stroll myself; I walked along the cliffs to the westward, and was full of sweet sadness, for I was thinking of Jonathan. When coming home—it was then bright moonlight, so bright that, though the front of our part of the Crescent was in shadow, everything could be well seen—I threw a glance up at our window, and saw Lucy’s head leaning out. I thought that perhaps she was looking out for me, so I opened my handkerchief and waved it. She did not notice or make any movement whatever. Just then, the moonlight crept round an angle of the building, and the light fell on the window. There distinctly was Lucy with her head lying up against the side of the window-sill and her eyes shut. She was fast asleep, and by her, seated on the window-sill, was something that looked like a good-sized bird. I was afraid she might get a chill, so I ran upstairs, but as I came into the room she was moving back to her bed, fast asleep, and breathing heavily; she was holding her hand to her throat, as though to protect it from cold.
vi: Lucy slept soundly until I woke up, and it seemed she only turned over once in bed. It appears that last night's adventure did not tire her out; on the contrary, I have the feeling she looks even more refreshed this morning, more so than she has in weeks. However, she still looks sad, very sad indeed. She must be recalling the terrible scene she went through on the cliff last night. We do not want to bring up that matter again. After dinner, Lucy complained of a headache and went back to bed. Once she was asleep, I dared to go out; I wanted to take a walk alone on the cliffs. To be honest, I also felt very sad because I always think of Jonathan. When I returned, the moonlight was so bright that although the hotel was almost entirely in darkness, I could still distinguish every small object. Looking up at the window of my room, I glimpsed Lucy's slanted shadow. I took out my handkerchief and waved, thinking she was looking for me. However, she did not move at all; it seemed she did not notice me. At that moment, the clear moonlight illuminated the corner of the house, so my window was as bright as day. I saw my friend with her eyes closed, leaning her head on the window sill. She was sleeping, and I had the feeling there was a large bird perched beside her. Afraid she might catch a cold, I rushed upstairs, but when I entered the room, I found her back in bed, still sleeping soundly with labored breaths, one hand clutching her neck as if to ward off the chill.
tr: “Those red eyes again!” “Just like those eyes.” It was such a strange, unrelated remark that it quite frightened me. I turned a bit to get a better look at Lucy without seeming to stare at her and saw that she was in a semi-dazed state with a strange, incomprehensible expression on her face; so I said nothing, but watched her eyes. She seemed to be looking at the bench where a shadow sat alone. I was a bit frightened, because for a moment it seemed as if the stranger had large, blazing eyes; but when I looked again, the optical illusion was gone. The red sunlight was shining on the windows of Saint Mary’s Church behind our bench, and as the sun set, the light refracted and reflected in such a way that it seemed as if the light had moved. I drew Lucy’s attention to this unusual effect; she started and came to herself, but she looked unhappy; she might have been thinking about the terrible night here. We never mention that night; so I said nothing and we returned home for dinner. Lucy had a headache and went to bed early. Seeing that she was asleep, I went out for a short walk; I walked along the slopes to the west; a sweet melancholy filled me because I was thinking of Jonathan. On my way back home -the moonlight was bright; so bright that although the part of the Crescent on our side was in shadow, everything could be seen very clearly- I glanced at our window and saw Lucy’s head leaning out. I thought she might be looking for me, so I opened my handkerchief and waved it. She didn’t notice or make any movement. At that moment, the moonlight slid from the corner of the building and fell on the window. There was Lucy, clearly, with her head resting on the window sill and her eyes closed. She was in a deep sleep, and beside her, on the window ledge, sat something that looked like a large bird. Fearing she might catch cold, I ran upstairs, but when I entered the room, she was still asleep and breathing deeply as she returned to her bed; she had brought her hand to her throat as if to protect it from the cold.
es: –Again with his red eyes! They are exactly the same. That was such a strange expression, out of context, that it left me perplexed. I moved away a little, just enough to see Lucy well without seeming to be looking at her, and I saw that she was in a state of drowsiness, with such a strange expression on her face that I couldn't decipher it; so I didn't say anything, but I followed her eyes. She seemed to be looking at our own seat, where at that moment a dark and solitary figure was sitting. I myself felt a bit uneasy, for a few moments it seemed that the stranger had large eyes like blazing flames; but a second look dispelled the illusion. The red light of the sun was shining on the windows of St. Mary's Church, situated behind our seat, and as the sun set, there was just enough change in the refraction and reflection of the light to give the appearance that the light was moving. I drew Lucy's attention to this peculiar effect, and she seemed to come to herself with a start, though at the same time she seemed very sad. It is possible that she was thinking about the terrible night she had spent up there. We never talked about it; so I said nothing, and we went home to have dinner. Lucy had a headache and went to bed early. When I saw her asleep, I went out for a little walk by myself; I walked along the cliffs to the west, and I was filled with a sweet sadness, for I was thinking about Jonathan. Upon returning home (the moonlight was shining intensely; so intensely that, although the front of our part of the Crescent was in shadow, everything could be seen distinctly) I glanced at our window and saw Lucy's head leaning out. I thought she might be waiting for my return, so I opened my handkerchief and waved it. However, she did not notice it, she made no movement. At that moment, the moonlight crept around a corner of the building, and its rays fell upon the window. There was Lucy, with her head leaning against the side of the window sill, and her eyes closed. She was deeply asleep, and next to her, perched on the windowsill, there was something that seemed to be a bird of regular size. I felt afraid that she might catch a cold, so I ran upstairs, but when I got to the room she was already back in bed, deeply asleep and breathing heavily; she was holding her hand to her neck, as if protecting it from the cold.

en: I did not wake her, but tucked her up warmly; I have taken care that the door is locked and the window securely fastened.
vi: I gently pulled the blanket over her. Now, the door is securely locked, and I have carefully latched the window as well.
tr: I didn’t wake her, but I covered her well; I made sure the door was locked and the window was tightly closed.
es: I did not wake her, but rather I covered her as best as I could; I checked that the door was well closed, and the window too.

en: She looks so sweet as she sleeps; but she is paler than is her wont, and there is a drawn, haggard look under her eyes which I do not like. I fear she is fretting about something. I wish I could find out what it is.
vi: Although she still looked very beautiful and gentle, Lucy's face now clearly showed signs of fatigue with a pale complexion. It seemed she was worried about something that I didn't know. If only I knew, my heart would be much lighter.
tr: He looks so sweet while sleeping; but he looks paler than usual and there is a tired and weary shadow under his eyes that I don't quite like. I'm afraid there is something troubling him. I wish I could find out what it is.
es: She is so sweet when she sleeps! But she is paler than usual, and in her eyes there is a tired, wan look that I do not like. I fear that she is troubled by something. I wish I could find out what it is.

en: 15 August.—Rose later than usual. Lucy was languid and tired, and slept on after we had been called. We had a happy surprise at breakfast. Arthur’s father is better, and wants the marriage to come off soon. Lucy is full of quiet joy, and her mother is glad and sorry at once. Later on in the day she told me the cause. She is grieved to lose Lucy as her very own, but she is rejoiced that she is soon to have some one to protect her. Poor dear, sweet lady! She confided to me that she has got her death-warrant. She has not told Lucy, and made me promise secrecy; her doctor told her that within a few months, at most, she must die, for her heart is weakening. At any time, even now, a sudden shock would be almost sure to kill her. Ah, we were wise to keep from her the affair of the dreadful night of Lucy’s sleep-walking.
vi: • August 15 We woke up later than usual. Lucy, perhaps because of fatigue, fell back asleep right after being awakened. There was a piece of unexpected good news during our breakfast: Arthur's father's health had improved significantly, and he wanted his son's wedding to be held as soon as possible. Lucy was overjoyed, while her mother had mixed feelings. She confided her emotions to me. She was very sad at the thought of parting with Lucy, but she was also very happy that her daughter would have a husband to take care of her day and night. Poor woman! While confiding in me, she said that she wouldn't live much longer. However, she didn't mention this to her daughter and made me promise to keep it a secret. She might die as if it were her fate. Fortunately, we didn't tell her anything about Lucy's adventure the other night!
tr: August 15. - I woke up later than usual. Lucy was sluggish and tired, and she continued to sleep even after we were called downstairs. There was a happy surprise waiting for us at breakfast. Arthur's father is better and wants the wedding to take place as soon as possible. Lucy was filled with quiet joy; her mother looked both pleased and sad at the same time. She told me the reason later in the day. She is sad because she will lose her dear Lucy, but happy that she will soon have someone to protect her. Poor sweet woman! She told me she had received her death warrant. She hasn't told Lucy and made me promise to keep it a secret; her doctor said that due to her weak heart, she would die within a few months at most. At any moment, even now, a sudden shock would certainly kill the mother. Oh, we were wise to keep that terrible night of Lucy's sleepwalking from her.
es: August 15. I got up later than usual. Lucy is languid and tired, and she slept until after we had been called. At breakfast, we had a pleasant surprise. Arthur's father is improved, and he wants the wedding to take place as soon as possible. Lucy is full of quiet joy, and her mother is both happy and sad. She told me the reason later. She is melancholy about having to lose Lucy, but she is glad that soon she will have someone to protect her. Poor lady, so dear and sweet! She confided in me that she will soon die. She hasn't told Lucy anything, and she made me promise to keep the secret; her doctor has told her that within a few months, at most, she will die, as her heart is weakening. At any moment, even now, a sudden shock would almost certainly cause her death. Ah! We did well not to tell her about that terrible night of Lucy's sleepwalking.

en: 17 August.—No diary for two whole days. I have not had the heart to write. Some sort of shadowy pall seems to be coming over our happiness. No news from Jonathan, and Lucy seems to be growing weaker, whilst her mother’s hours are numbering to a close. I do not understand Lucy’s fading away as she is doing. She eats well and sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air; but all the time the roses in her cheeks are fading, and she gets weaker and more languid day by day; at night I hear her gasping as if for air. I keep the key of our door always fastened to my wrist at night, but she gets up and walks about the room, and sits at the open window. Last night I found her leaning out when I woke up, and when I tried to wake her I could not; she was in a faint. When I managed to restore her she was as weak as water, and cried silently between long, painful struggles for breath. When I asked her how she came to be at the window she shook her head and turned away. I trust her feeling ill may not be from that unlucky prick of the safety-pin. I looked at her throat just now as she lay asleep, and the tiny wounds seem not to have healed. They are still open, and, if anything, larger than before, and the edges of them are faintly white. They are like little white dots with red centres. Unless they heal within a day or two, I shall insist on the doctor seeing about them.
vi: • August 17 I haven't written a single line for the past two days; I really don't have the heart for it. Yes, it seems like everything is trying to discourage me at this moment. I haven't received any news from Jonathan, and Lucy looks more and more haggard. I don't understand why, as she clearly still eats well, sleeps soundly, and regularly takes walks in the fresh air. Yet her skin looks pale, and her breathing remains heavy and labored. It's been a long time since I could sleep without tying the room key to my wrist. Lucy often gets up to walk around the room or sits leaning against the window. The night before, I even saw her sticking her head out the window, and no matter how much I called, she didn't respond: she had fainted. Finally, when I managed to wake her, she cried silently with labored breaths. When I asked why she was at the window, she just shook her head and turned away. I hope her discomfort is not caused by the scratches on her neck. While she was sound asleep, I secretly checked her neck. The two small wounds there still haven't healed, in fact, they have widened, and the edges of the wounds are a pale pink. If the scratches on my friend's neck don't improve in a day or two, I might have to call a doctor.
tr: August 17. - I haven't written in my journal for exactly two days. I didn't have the heart to write. It's as if a dark veil has been cast over our happiness. No news from Jonathan, and as her mother's final hours draw near, Lucy is growing weaker. I can't understand why Lucy is fading away like this. She eats well, sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air, but the roses in her cheeks keep fading and she grows weaker and more lethargic each day; at night, I can almost hear her struggling to breathe. I always keep the key to our door tied to my wrist at night, but she gets up and walks around the room and sits by the open window. Last night, when I woke up, I found her hanging out of the window, and when I tried to wake her, I couldn't; she was in a trance. When I finally managed to bring her around, she was as weak as water and silently cried between her long, painful struggles to breathe. When I asked her how she got to the window, she shook her head and turned away. I hope her feeling ill isn't because of that unfortunate pin prick. Now, while she was sleeping, I looked at her throat and the tiny wounds still don't seem to be healing. They are still open and, on the contrary, they appear to be wider and the edges slightly whitened. The centers are red with small white spots. If they don't heal in a day or two, I will insist that the doctor looks at them.
es: August 17. I have not written anything for two consecutive days. I have not felt like doing it. A kind of dark fate seems to be looming over our happiness. No news from Jonathan, and Lucy seems to be getting weaker and weaker, while her mother's hours are drawing to a final close. I do not understand how Lucy is fading away as she is. She eats well and sleeps well, and enjoys the fresh air; but all the time the roses in her cheeks are withering and day by day she becomes weaker and more languid; at night I hear her gasping as if she were short of breath. I always have the key to the door tied to my wrist during the night, but she gets up and walks back and forth across the room, and sits by the open window. Last night I found her leaning out, and when I tried to wake her I could not; she was unconscious. When I managed to bring her to, she was extremely weak and was quietly crying between long and painful efforts to breathe. When I asked her how she had been able to go to the window, she shook her head and turned it to the other side of the pillow. I hope her illness is not due to that ill-fated pinprick. I observed her throat once she had fallen asleep, and the punctures did not seem to have healed. The scars are still open, and even wider than before; their edges appear whitish, like small white spots with red centers. Unless they heal in a day or two, I will insist that the doctor sees them.

en: Letter, Samuel F. Billington & Son, Solicitors, Whitby, to Messrs. Carter, Paterson & Co., London.
vi: Letter from the consulting group Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby to Carter Paterson & Co. in London
tr: Samuel F. in Whitby Billington & Son, From the legal advisors, Carter in London, Letter to Paterson Partners Company
es: Letter from Samuel F. Billington and Son, solicitors, in Whitby, to Mr. Carter, Paterson, and Co., in London

en: “17 August.
vi: "August 1st"
tr: August 17
es: August 17

en: “Dear Sirs,—
vi: Dear sirs,
tr: Dear Gentlemen,
es: "Dear Sirs:

en: “Herewith please receive invoice of goods sent by Great Northern Railway. Same are to be delivered at Carfax, near Purfleet, immediately on receipt at goods station King’s Cross. The house is at present empty, but enclosed please find keys, all of which are labelled.
vi: We are very pleased to inform you about the shipment sent by rail from the Dai Bac group. The packages will be delivered at Carfax as soon as they arrive at Kings Cross market station. The house is currently unoccupied, but you will find that all the keys are labeled with the room numbers.
tr: You can find the invoice for the goods sent by Great Northern Railways attached. They should be delivered to Carfax near Purfleet as soon as they arrive at King’s Cross freight station. The house is currently vacant, but you can find all the labeled keys attached.
es: "Attached to this letter, we are sending you the goods shipped by the Great Northern Railway. These are to be delivered to Carfax, near Purfleet, immediately after the goods are received at King's Cross station. The house is currently vacant, but we are also sending you the keys, all of them labeled.

en: “You will please deposit the boxes, fifty in number, which form the consignment, in the partially ruined building forming part of the house and marked ‘A’ on rough diagram enclosed. Your agent will easily recognise the locality, as it is the ancient chapel of the mansion. The goods leave by the train at 9:30 to-night, and will be due at King’s Cross at 4:30 to-morrow afternoon. As our client wishes the delivery made as soon as possible, we shall be obliged by your having teams ready at King’s Cross at the time named and forthwith conveying the goods to destination. In order to obviate any delays possible through any routine requirements as to payment in your departments, we enclose cheque herewith for ten pounds (£10), receipt of which please acknowledge. Should the charge be less than this amount, you can return balance; if greater, we shall at once send cheque for difference on hearing from you. You are to leave the keys on coming away in the main hall of the house, where the proprietor may get them on his entering the house by means of his duplicate key.
vi: You will place all fifty crates in the ruins and the section marked "A" according to the attached drawing of the house. Your staff will easily recognize the location when they know exactly that it is an old church located within the manor. The freight train will leave Whitby at nine-thirty tonight and will arrive at Kings Cross at four-thirty tomorrow afternoon. Our client wants the crates to be delivered as soon as possible, so we suggest that you pick up the goods at Kings Cross promptly and then immediately transfer them to Carfax. Moreover, to avoid any delay in payment, you will also receive a check for ten pounds as proposed with this letter. If the expenses do not reach this amount, please kindly return the surplus to us. Conversely, if the above amount is still insufficient, we will send another check as per your request. The bunch of keys will be left in the hallway of the house so that the owner can easily see them right after he opens the gate with his own key.
tr: Please leave the fifty crates that make up the shipment in the partially ruined building marked with the letter "A" on the attached rough sketch, which is part of the house. Since it is the old chapel of the mansion, your representative will find the place immediately. The goods are departing on the 9:30 train tonight and will arrive at King’s Cross by 4:30 tomorrow afternoon. As our client requested the delivery to be made as quickly as possible, your teams need to be ready at King’s Cross at the specified time and transport the goods to the destination without delay. To prevent any potential delays that may arise from usual requirements such as payments for your services, we are sending a check for ten pounds (£10) attached; please confirm receipt. If the account is less than this amount, you may send the remainder; if it is more, we will send a check for the difference immediately upon hearing from you. When leaving, you need to leave the keys in the main hall of the house; thus, the property owner can take them when they enter the house with their own keys.
es: "Please deposit the boxes, fifty in total, which constitute the shipment, in the partially demolished building that is part of the house and is marked with 'A' on the schematic plan we sent you. Your agent will easily recognize the place, as it is the old chapel of the mansion. The goods leave by train at 9:30 PM; they will arrive at King's Cross tomorrow afternoon at 4:30. As our client wishes the delivery to be made as quickly as possible, we would greatly appreciate it if you could have some people ready at King's Cross at the indicated time to transfer the goods to their destination. To avoid any possible delay due to routine procedures, such as payments in your departments, we are sending you a check for ten pounds (£10) enclosed, for which we would appreciate receiving a receipt. If the expenses are less than this amount, you can return the balance; if they are more, we will immediately send you a check for the difference upon hearing from you. Upon completing the delivery, please leave the keys in the main corridor of the house, where the owner can collect them upon entering the house with the key he possesses.

en: “Pray do not take us as exceeding the bounds of business courtesy in pressing you in all ways to use the utmost expedition.
vi: We hope that we will not be considered too demanding when we request that you carefully execute this contract.
tr: Please do not think that we are overstepping the bounds of work delicacy by pressuring you to work as quickly as possible.
es: "Please do not think that we are exceeding the bounds of commercial courtesy by insisting in every way that you complete this work as quickly as possible."

en: “We are, dear Sirs,
vi: We hope that we will not be considered too demanding when we request that you carefully execute this contract.
tr: Please do not think that we are overstepping the bounds of work delicacy by pressuring you to work as quickly as possible.
es: "We remain yours, dear sirs, your Attos.

en: “Faithfully yours,
vi: Awaiting your response.
tr: Respectfully...
es: "We remain yours, dear sirs, your Attos.

en: “Samuel F. Billington & Son.”
vi: Sincerely thank Samuel F. Billington & Sons.
tr: Samuel F. Billington & Son
es: and Ss. Ss. SAMUEL F. BILLINGTON AND SON

en: Letter, Messrs. Carter, Paterson & Co., London, to Messrs. Billington & Son, Whitby.
vi: Letter from Carter Paterson & Co., London to Samuel F. Billington & Sons in Whitby
tr: Samuel F. Billington & Son Carter, Paterson & Co. in London From his partners, Billington & in Whitby His son's letter to the Legal Advisors
es: Letter from Mr. Carter, Paterson and Co., in London, to the gentlemen Billington and Son, in Whitby

en: “21 August.
vi: “August 21st”
tr: August 21
es: August 21

en: “Dear Sirs,—
vi: Dear Sirs,
tr: Dear Gentlemen,
es: "Dear Sirs,"

en: “We beg to acknowledge £10 received and to return cheque £1 17s. 9d, amount of overplus, as shown in receipted account herewith. Goods are delivered in exact accordance with instructions, and keys left in parcel in main hall, as directed.
vi: We have received the check worth ten pounds. The crates have been delivered according to your instructions and the bunch of keys has been placed in the correct spot in the hallway.
tr: We inform you that the 10 pounds have reached us and that the surplus of 1 pound, 17 shillings, and 9 pence shown in the attached receipt has been returned by check. The goods have been delivered exactly according to your instructions, and the keys have been left in a package in the main hall as requested.
es: "We acknowledge receipt of £10 and send you £1 17s. 9d, surplus, as shown by the included receipts. The goods have been delivered according to your instructions, and the keys were left in a package in the main corridor, as requested.

en: Mina Murray’s Journal.
vi: Mina Murray's Journal
tr: Mina Murray's journal
es: From the journal of Mina Murray

en: 18 August.—I am happy to-day, and write sitting on the seat in the churchyard. Lucy is ever so much better. Last night she slept well all night, and did not disturb me once. The roses seem coming back already to her cheeks, though she is still sadly pale and wan-looking. If she were in any way anæmic I could understand it, but she is not. She is in gay spirits and full of life and cheerfulness. All the morbid reticence seems to have passed from her, and she has just reminded me, as if I needed any reminding, of that night, and that it was here, on this very seat, I found her asleep. As she told me she tapped playfully with the heel of her boot on the stone slab and said:—
vi: • August 18 I am writing these lines while sitting on a cemetery bench. Today, Lucy seems to be better. Last night, she did not wake up even once. Although she is still pale and weak, her cheeks have a slight blush. She also seems happier, very happy indeed. She has shed her long-standing inexplicable gloom and even reminded me of the incident that happened the other night! As she spoke, she delightedly tapped her heel on the stone grave.
tr: August 18. - Today I am happy and writing while sitting on a bench in the church garden. Lucy is much better. Last night, she slept well all night and did not disturb me even once. Although she still looks distressingly pale and exhausted, it is as if the roses have returned to her cheeks. If she had anemia, I could understand it, but she does not. Her spirits are high, full of life and joy. She seems to have moved away from all that frightening silence and, as if I needed reminding, she reminded me of that night and how I found her here, sleeping on this very bench. As she was telling me these things, she was joyfully tapping the stone slab on the ground with the heel of her boot:
es: August 18th. Today I am very happy, and I am writing while sitting on the seat in the church cemetery. Lucy is much better. Last night she slept well all night, and did not bother me even once. It seems that the roses are returning to her cheeks, although she is still sadly pale and discolored. I would understand her situation if she were anemic, but that is not the case. She is in very good spirits, and full of life and joy. All that morbid reticence seems to have left her, and just a moment ago she reminded me, as if I needed reminding, of that night, and what happened here, on this very seat, where I found her asleep. As she spoke to me, she playfully tapped her boot heel on the tombstone, and said:

en: “My poor little feet didn’t make much noise then! I daresay poor old Mr. Swales would have told me that it was because I didn’t want to wake up Geordie.” As she was in such a communicative humour, I asked her if she had dreamed at all that night. Before she answered, that sweet, puckered look came into her forehead, which Arthur—I call him Arthur from her habit—says he loves; and, indeed, I don’t wonder that he does. Then she went on in a half-dreaming kind of way, as if trying to recall it to herself:—
vi: — That night, I don't know why my poor feet walked so quietly! I kept imagining old man Swales telling me that the reason I did so was because I didn't want to wake up Georgie down there! Seeing her in a cheerful state, I finally dared to ask if she had any nightmares that night. Before answering me, she flirted in the exact manner that Arthur always liked. A moment later, she began to recount the story in a dreamy voice:
tr: “Then my poor little feet didn't make much noise! I think if poor old Mr. Swales were here, he would tell me it was because I didn't want to wake Geordie.” Since he was so talkative, I asked him if he had any dreams that night. Before answering, that sweet, wrinkled expression that Arthur - I call him Arthur too, as is Lucy's habit - said he loved came over his face; indeed, I am not surprised that Arthur says so. Then, as if trying to remind himself, he continued his words in a half-dazed manner:
es: –My poor feet didn't make much noise back then! I dare say that poor Mr. Swales would have told me it was because I didn't want to wake Geordie. Since she was so communicative, I asked her if she had had any dreams that night. Before answering me, that sweet and mischievous look appeared on her face, which Arthur (I call him Arthur out of her habit) says he loves; and, in fact, it doesn't surprise me that he does. Then, she continued in a dreamy manner, as if she were trying to remember what had happened.

en: “I didn’t quite dream; but it all seemed to be real. I only wanted to be here in this spot—I don’t know why, for I was afraid of something—I don’t know what. I remember, though I suppose I was asleep, passing through the streets and over the bridge. A fish leaped as I went by, and I leaned over to look at it, and I heard a lot of dogs howling—the whole town seemed as if it must be full of dogs all howling at once—as I went up the steps. Then I had a vague memory of something long and dark with red eyes, just as we saw in the sunset, and something very sweet and very bitter all around me at once; and then I seemed sinking into deep green water, and there was a singing in my ears, as I have heard there is to drowning men; and then everything seemed passing away from me; my soul seemed to go out from my body and float about the air. I seem to remember that once the West Lighthouse was right under me, and then there was a sort of agonising feeling, as if I were in an earthquake, and I came back and found you shaking my body. I saw you do it before I felt you.”
vi: — No, I wasn't dreaming... Everything seemed real to me. I just wanted to come here, to this place, without understanding why... I was afraid of something very vague... I was sleeping, I wandered through the streets, then across the bridge. At that moment, a fish jumped out of the water, making me look down, and when I started climbing the stone steps, the dogs suddenly started barking loudly - I felt like all the dogs in the city were barking at once. I vaguely remember that afterwards, something long and black, with bright eyes, hovered near me. At the same time, a feeling both sweet and bitter surged within me. Then... I saw myself plunging into a deep, blue abyss, my ears ringing, my body dazed like someone about to drown. I felt like I no longer existed... My soul began to leave my body and float, wandering in the air... I believe I won't forget the flickering light below from the western searchlight sweeping across. Then I felt pain, an indescribable pain, like the feeling of falling into an earthquake. And finally, I returned to myself when you shook me awake. I saw all your gestures before I could feel them.
tr: “I didn't dream much; but everything felt real. I just wanted to be here, at this point - I don't know why, but I was afraid of something - I don't know what it was. I think I was sleeping, but I remember passing through the streets and over the bridge. As I was passing, a fish jumped, I bent down to look at it, and as I was climbing the stairs, I heard a lot of dogs barking - it was as if the whole town was full of dogs barking in unison. Then, vaguely, I remember something both very sweet and very bitter surrounding me, along with a long and dark figure with red eyes, just like we saw at sunset; then it felt like I was diving into deep green waters and a song was playing in my ears, just like the ones I heard in the ears of drowning people; then everything seemed to move away from me; it was as if my soul had left my body and was flying in the air. At one point, I remember the West Lighthouse being right below me, then a painful feeling came over me as if I was caught in an earthquake, and I came back, I saw you shaking my body. I saw you doing it before I felt you.”
es: –I didn't exactly dream, but everything seemed very real. I just wanted to be here in this place, without knowing why, because I was afraid of something, I don't know what. Although I suppose I was asleep, I remember passing through the streets and over the bridge. As I was passing, a fish jumped, I leaned down to see it and heard many dogs howling; so many that the whole town seemed to be filled with dogs howling at the same time, while I was climbing the steps. Then I had a vague sensation of something long and dark with red eyes, similar to what we saw at that sunset, and suddenly I was surrounded by something very sweet and very bitter at the same time; then it seemed to me that I was sinking into green and deep water, and I heard a buzzing sound like I've heard people say they feel when they are drowning; and then everything seemed to evaporate and move away from me; my soul seemed to leave my body and float in the air. I seem to remember that at one point the western lighthouse was right below me, and then there was a kind of pain, as if I were in an earthquake, and I came back to myself, and I discovered that you were shaking me. I saw you doing it before I could feel you.

en: Then she began to laugh. It seemed a little uncanny to me, and I listened to her breathlessly. I did not quite like it, and thought it better not to keep her mind on the subject, so we drifted on to other subjects, and Lucy was like her old self again. When we got home the fresh breeze had braced her up, and her pale cheeks were really more rosy. Her mother rejoiced when she saw her, and we all spent a very happy evening together.
vi: Speaking of this, my friend suddenly burst into laughter, to be honest, I started to feel worried about her unusual smile. I had to hold my breath listening to her laugh. Her laughter really made me uncomfortable. It's better not to let her think about that wandering adventure anymore. Thinking so, I immediately tried to steer the conversation to another topic to bring her back to herself. When we returned to the hotel, the gentle sea breezes made her cheeks blush pink. Her mother was very happy to see her looking so rosy. All three of us had a really good evening.
tr: Then she started laughing. What she told me seemed a bit eerie and I listened to her without taking a breath. I didn't quite like what she was saying and thought it would be better to steer her mind away from this topic; thus, we shifted to other subjects and Lucy returned to her old self. When we got home, the fresh breeze invigorated her, and her once pale cheeks were now truly pinker. Her mother was very happy to see her and we had a very pleasant evening together.
es: Then she began to laugh. To me, all of that seemed dreadful, and I listened breathlessly. It was suspicious, and I thought it would be better if her mind did not dwell on the subject any longer, so we started talking about other things, and Lucy was like her old self. When we returned home, the fresh breeze had invigorated her, and her pale cheeks were truly rosier. Her mother rejoiced to see her like that, and we all spent a very happy evening together.

en: 19 August.—Joy, joy, joy! although not all joy. At last, news of Jonathan. The dear fellow has been ill; that is why he did not write. I am not afraid to think it or say it, now that I know. Mr. Hawkins sent me on the letter, and wrote himself, oh, so kindly. I am to leave in the morning and go over to Jonathan, and to help to nurse him if necessary, and to bring him home. Mr. Hawkins says it would not be a bad thing if we were to be married out there. I have cried over the good Sister’s letter till I can feel it wet against my bosom, where it lies. It is of Jonathan, and must be next my heart, for he is in my heart. My journey is all mapped out, and my luggage ready. I am only taking one change of dress; Lucy will bring my trunk to London and keep it till I send for it, for it may be that ... I must write no more; I must keep it to say to Jonathan, my husband. The letter that he has seen and touched must comfort me till we meet.
vi: • August 19 I feel so happy! But is that already a true happiness? No, not quite yet. But finally, I have received news from Jonathan. Poor thing, he has been ill all this time, so he didn't want to write anything. Now I feel somewhat at ease. Mr. Hawkins just forwarded me the letter that the nun taking care of Jonathan sent to him. Tomorrow, I will set out to find him, and if necessary, I will help take care of him, and then we will return to England together. Mr. Hawkins advised me to have the wedding there. I couldn't hold back my tears when reading the letter from that kind-hearted nun. After reading the letter, I immediately put it in my chest pocket, closest to my heart! This letter will be my source of comfort until I meet Jonathan. All my luggage is ready, I am prepared to set out to find my fiancé.
tr: August 19. - Joy! Joy! Joy! Even if not everything is joyful. Finally, there is news from Jonathan. My poor darling was sick; that's why he didn't write. Now that I know what happened, I'm not afraid to think or say it. Mr. Hawkins sent me the letter, and he also wrote himself, oh, how thoughtful. I will leave here in the morning to go to Jonathan, and if necessary, help with his treatment and bring him home. Mr. Hawkins says it wouldn't be a bad thing to get married there. When I read the kind-hearted Sister's letter, I cried so much that I am now holding it to my chest and feeling its wetness. The letter is from Jonathan and it should stay close to my heart because Jonathan is in my heart. The details of my journey have been planned and my suitcase is packed. I am only taking one dress besides what I am wearing; Lucy will bring my luggage to London and keep it there until I ask for it, because... I should not write more; I should save these for Jonathan, my husband. The letter he saw and touched should comfort me until I meet him.
es: August 19. Joy, joy, joy! Although not everything is joy. Finally news from Jonathan. The poor thing has been sick, and that's why he hadn't written. I'm no longer afraid to think it or say it, now that I know. Mr. Hawkins handed me the letter, and he wrote to me himself. Oh! How kind! I'm going to leave tomorrow morning and go to Jonathan, to take care of him if necessary and bring him home. Mr. Hawkins says it wouldn't be bad if we could get married there. I have cried over the letter from the good sister, to the point that I can feel it wet against my chest, where I keep it. It is about Jonathan, and it must be close to my heart, since he is in my heart. I have planned and foreseen my trip, and my luggage is ready. I'll only take a change of clothes; Lucy will take my trunk to London and keep it until I send for it, because it may be that... I must not write anymore. I must save it all to tell Jonathan, my husband. The letter he has seen and touched must comfort me until we meet.

en: “12 August.
vi: “August 12th
tr: August 12
es: August 12

en: “Dear Madam,—
vi: Dear Madam,
tr: Dear Madam,
es: "Dear Miss:"

en: “I write by desire of Mr. Jonathan Harker, who is himself not strong enough to write, though progressing well, thanks to God and St. Joseph and Ste. Mary. He has been under our care for nearly six weeks, suffering from a violent brain fever. He wishes me to convey his love, and to say that by this post I write for him to Mr. Peter Hawkins, Exeter, to say, with his dutiful respects, that he is sorry for his delay, and that all of his work is completed. He will require some few weeks’ rest in our sanatorium in the hills, but will then return. He wishes me to say that he has not sufficient money with him, and that he would like to pay for his staying here, so that others who need shall not be wanting for help.
vi: By the grace of God, Saint Joseph, and Saint Mary, Mr. Jonathan's health condition has been improving day by day. However, he is still too weak to write a letter himself, so he has asked me to write these lines to you. He has been bedridden with us for nearly six weeks due to a rather severe brain illness. He asked me to write to you that he always remembers you, and that along with this letter to you, I am also writing another letter to Mr. Peter Hawkins, in which I must express his regrets for not being able to inform him of his condition sooner. Mr. Jonathan needs to rest a few more weeks at our sanatorium before he can return to England. He also asked me to tell you that he needs a certain amount of money to reciprocate the kindness of the sanatorium during his stay here, as the sanatorium is also in great need of assistance to be able to care for other patients.
tr: Thanks be to God, Saint Joseph, and Mother Mary, I am writing on behalf of Mr. Jonathan Harker, whose condition is improving but who does not yet have the strength to write himself. He has been under our care for about six weeks, suffering from severe brain fever. He wishes me to convey his love and, while writing to Mr. Peter Hawkins in Exeter on his behalf, to extend his deepest respects, apologize for the delay, and inform that all his tasks are completed. He needs to rest for a few weeks in our sanatorium in the mountains, but he will return afterward. He desires me to say that he does not have enough money with him and wishes to pay for the days he has spent here so that others in need of help are not deprived.
es: "I am writing to you at the request of Mr. Jonathan Harker, as he himself is not strong enough to write, although he is improving thanks to God, Saint Joseph, and the Virgin Mary. He has been under our care for almost six weeks, as he suffers from a violent brain fever. He sends you his love, and asks me to tell you that I am writing to Mr. Peter Hawkins in Exeter by this same mail, to inform him, with the deepest respect, that he is very distressed by his delay, and that all his work has been completely finished. Mr. Harker will have to remain resting in our hospital in the mountains for a few more weeks, but then he will return. He wishes me to say that he does not have enough money with him, and that he would like to pay for his stay here, so that others in need do not go without receiving help.

en: “Believe me,
vi: I deeply sympathize with you, and I hope you will accept my deepest condolences.
tr: With my love and blessings...
es: "Consider me always at your service, with my affection and blessings,"

en: “Yours, with sympathy and all blessings,
vi: I deeply sympathize with you, and I hope you will accept my deepest condolences.
