es: "Consider me always at your service, with my affection and blessings,"

en: “Sister Agatha.
vi: Sister Agatha.
tr: NUN AGATHA
es: SISTER AGATHA.

en: “P. S.—My patient being asleep, I open this to let you know something more. He has told me all about you, and that you are shortly to be his wife. All blessings to you both! He has had some fearful shock—so says our doctor—and in his delirium his ravings have been dreadful; of wolves and poison and blood; of ghosts and demons; and I fear to say of what. Be careful with him always that there may be nothing to excite him of this kind for a long time to come; the traces of such an illness as his do not lightly die away. We should have written long ago, but we knew nothing of his friends, and there was on him nothing that any one could understand. He came in the train from Klausenburg, and the guard was told by the station-master there that he rushed into the station shouting for a ticket for home. Seeing from his violent demeanour that he was English, they gave him a ticket for the furthest station on the way thither that the train reached.
vi: T. B. My patient has fallen asleep, so I am opening the letter again to write you a few more lines. He told me a lot about you and informed me that the two of you will soon be getting married. Heartfelt congratulations to you and your husband! According to the doctor, your husband went through a terrible shock, and during his delirium, he only spoke of very frightening things. I personally heard him rambling about wolves, poison, blood; about ghosts and demons; and many other things that I dare not mention. I would advise you that for a long time, you should not bring up these frightening stories with your husband; what is deeply ingrained in his thoughts surely cannot be easily erased. We should have informed you of this long ago, but the unfortunate thing is we did not know whom to write to, as we did not have any address of friends, relatives, or the patient's parents, and he did not have any documents on him that could help us find a contact address. He came to us after a train trip from Klausenburg, and the station master recounted that before boarding the train, your husband had rushed madly into the station and shouted that he needed a ticket back to England. Knowing he was English, the station master gave him a ticket to the nearest station.
tr: Note: I am opening the letter while I am still asleep to let you know one more thing. He told me everything about you and said that you would soon be his wife. I extend my best wishes to both of you! He experienced a horrifying shock - our doctor says so -; the things he raved about while he was not himself were hair-raising; wolves, poison, and blood; ghouls and evil spirits and many other terrifying things that I fear to name. Always be careful to prevent such things from exciting him in the future; the traces of illnesses like his do not easily disappear. We should have written to you long ago, but we had no knowledge of his friends and found nothing on him that anyone could understand. He arrived here by train from Klausenberg, and according to what the station master told the conductor, he had run into the station and shouted that he wanted a ticket home. Realizing from his harsh behavior that he was English, they gave him a ticket to the farthest station reached by the train on this route.
es: "P. D. While my patient is asleep, I open this to inform you of the events. Mr. Harker has told me everything about you, and that soon you will be his wife. All blessings to you both! He has suffered a terrible shock, so says our doctor, and in his delirium his ravings have been terrible; of wolves, poison and blood, of ghosts and demons, and I fear to say what else. Always be very careful with him so that in the future there is nothing similar to these things that can excite him; the traces of an illness like the one he has had do not disappear so easily. We would have written a long time ago, but we knew nothing about his friends, and he did not say anything that we could understand. He arrived on the train from Klausenburg and the guard was notified by the station master of that place, who came running into the station shouting for a ticket to return home. Seeing from his violent gestures that he was an Englishman, they gave him a ticket to the furthest station in this direction, to which the train goes.

en: “Be assured that he is well cared for. He has won all hearts by his sweetness and gentleness. He is truly getting on well, and I have no doubt will in a few weeks be all himself. But be careful of him for safety’s sake. There are, I pray God and St. Joseph and Ste. Mary, many, many, happy years for you both.”
vi: Please rest assured, your husband has been taken care of very thoroughly. His kindness and pain have truly moved everyone here. As I mentioned at the beginning of the letter, your husband's health is progressing very well, but I must reiterate that in the future, you should be very careful in taking care of him, especially regarding his mental stability. I have prayed to God, Saint Joseph, and Saint Mary to bless both of you until your hair turns gray and your teeth fall out.
tr: Make sure she is well taken care of. She won all hearts with her sweetness and kindness. She is genuinely getting better, and I have no doubt that she will fully recover in a few weeks. But for your safety, keep an eye on her. I pray to God, Saint Joseph, and Mother Mary that you have many long and happy years ahead.
es: "Be assured that we are taking good care of him. He has won all our hearts with his sweetness and gentleness. He is truly improving, and I have no doubt that in a few weeks he will be completely recovered. But for the sake of safety, take good care of him. Surely there are, as I ask God and Saint Joseph and Saint Mary, many, many happy years ahead for both of you."

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 19 August.—Strange and sudden change in Renfield last night. About eight o’clock he began to get excited and sniff about as a dog does when setting. The attendant was struck by his manner, and knowing my interest in him, encouraged him to talk. He is usually respectful to the attendant and at times servile; but to-night, the man tells me, he was quite haughty. Would not condescend to talk with him at all. All he would say was:—
vi: • August 19 Last night, there were unexpected and strange changes in Renfield. Around 8 o'clock, he suddenly became very agitated, crawling on the floor with his hands, sniffing the ground like a dog scenting something. Seeing this bizarre scene and knowing that I was very interested in him, the warden asked him the reason why. Normally, Renfield showed great respect for this warden, and sometimes he even obeyed him like a slave. But according to what the warden told me, this time it wasn't like that: Renfield was disdainful and didn't bother to answer his question. He only said one sentence to him:
tr: August 19. - Last night, there was a strange and sudden change in Renfield. Around eight o'clock, he began to get excited and sniff around like a dog. The attendant, who was affected by his behavior and knew of my interest in him, encouraged Renfield to talk. Renfield is generally respectful to the attendant and sometimes even fawns over him, but the man said he was very arrogant tonight. He did not deign to speak in any manner. The only thing he said was:
es: August 19. Strange and sudden changes in Renfield last night. Around eight o'clock, he began to get restless and sniff around everywhere, like a dog when hunting. My assistant was amazed by his behavior, and knowing my interest in him, encouraged him to talk. He is usually very respectful to my assistant, and sometimes even servile; but last night, the man told me, he behaved quite arrogantly. He wouldn't deign to speak to him for anything in the world. All he said was:

en: “I don’t want to talk to you: you don’t count now; the Master is at hand.”
vi: — I don't want to talk to you. To me, you no longer exist in this world; my master is nearby.
tr: “I don't want to talk to you: You are not important right now; My master is about to arrive.”
es: –I don't want to talk to you: you don't matter anymore; the boss is near.

en: The attendant thinks it is some sudden form of religious mania which has seized him. If so, we must look out for squalls, for a strong man with homicidal and religious mania at once might be dangerous. The combination is a dreadful one. At nine o’clock I visited him myself. His attitude to me was the same as that to the attendant; in his sublime self-feeling the difference between myself and attendant seemed to him as nothing. It looks like religious mania, and he will soon think that he himself is God. These infinitesimal distinctions between man and man are too paltry for an Omnipotent Being. How these madmen give themselves away! The real God taketh heed lest a sparrow fall; but the God created from human vanity sees no difference between an eagle and a sparrow. Oh, if men only knew!
vi: The warden believed that he had begun to suffer from a mysterious madness. If this were indeed the case, then surely there would come a time when we would witness unforeseeable scenes, for a strong man like him, if afflicted by a mysterious and homicidal mental illness, could become dangerous, very dangerous indeed. I visited him at 9 o'clock. He behaved towards me exactly as he had behaved towards the warden earlier. It seemed that in his current mental state, he could no longer distinguish the difference between me and the warden. Perhaps at some point, he would consider himself to be God? But his poor ability to distinguish between two people hardly qualifies him to become a Supreme Being!
tr: The nurse thinks that the patient has been influenced by a sudden onset of some kind of religious frenzy. If so, we should be cautious of the uproar that will ensue, because a strong person who is inclined to kill and has fallen into religious madness can suddenly become dangerous. I visited him personally at nine o'clock. His attitude towards me was the same as the one he had towards the nurse; in his exalted state of mind, the difference between me and the nurse was nothing. The situation appears to be a religious-themed madness, soon he will think that he is God. This small difference between two people is extremely insignificant for an Omnipotent being. How these madmen reveal themselves! The true God cares about the fall of a sparrow; but the God created from human pride cannot see the difference between an eagle and a sparrow.
es: My assistant believes that some sudden form of religious mania has taken hold of him. If so, we must be on alert for storms, as a strong man with homicidal and religious manias at the same time can be dangerous. At nine in the evening, I visited him myself. His attitude towards me was the same as with my assistant; in his extreme withdrawal into himself, the difference between me and my assistant seems null to him. It seems to me that it is a religious mania; very soon he will think he is God himself. The infinitesimal distinctions between one man and another are too petty for an omnipotent being. How exalted these madmen can become! The true God pays attention even when a sparrow falls; but the God created by human vanity sees no difference between an eagle and a sparrow. Oh, if only men knew!

en: For half an hour or more Renfield kept getting excited in greater and greater degree. I did not pretend to be watching him, but I kept strict observation all the same. All at once that shifty look came into his eyes which we always see when a madman has seized an idea, and with it the shifty movement of the head and back which asylum attendants come to know so well. He became quite quiet, and went and sat on the edge of his bed resignedly, and looked into space with lack-lustre eyes. I thought I would find out if his apathy were real or only assumed, and tried to lead him to talk of his pets, a theme which had never failed to excite his attention. At first he made no reply, but at length said testily:—
vi: For half an hour or more, Renfield became increasingly agitated. Although outwardly I always appeared indifferent to him, in reality, I quietly observed his every move. I suddenly noticed a certain cunning in his eyes, the kind of cunning that madmen always have when they are plotting something - an aspect that asylum wardens are very familiar with. Then, he suddenly became completely silent and sat down heavily on the edge of the bed, his face showing a clear expression of resignation. He began to stare into the distance with a vague, inscrutable look in his eyes. I didn't know whether his emotions were real or fake, so I decided to test him by bringing up his little animals - a topic he was always very attentive to. At first, he didn't say anything, but eventually, he got annoyed and spoke up:
tr: For half an hour or more, Renfield's excitement gradually increased. I pretended not to be watching him, but I still observed him closely. Suddenly, that cunning look we see in the eyes of madmen when an idea strikes them, and the sly movement of the head and back well known to the attendants in the asylum, appeared. The patient became very quiet, went and sat meekly at the edge of his bed, staring blankly into space. I thought I could discern whether his indifference was genuine or feigned, so I tried to steer the conversation towards his pets, a topic that never failed to capture his interest. At first, he did not respond, but finally, he said in a contrary manner:
es: For half an hour or more, Renfield was becoming increasingly excited. I pretended not to be observing him, but I kept a strict watch on everything he did. Suddenly, that cloudy look appeared in his eyes that we always see when a madman has grasped an idea, and with it that sideways movement of the head and back that doctors come to know so well. He became quite calm, and went and sat on the edge of his bed resignedly, staring into empty space with dull eyes. I thought I would find out if his apathy was real or just feigned, and I tried to engage him in a conversation about his animals, a topic that had always captured his interest. At first, he did not respond, but finally, he said, with visible ill humor:

en: “Bother them all! I don’t care a pin about them.”
vi: — Throw it all away! They mean nothing to me now...
tr: “What do I care about them! They don't matter to me at all!”
es: –Who cares about them? I don't give a damn!

en: “What?” I said. “You don’t mean to tell me you don’t care about spiders?” (Spiders at present are his hobby and the note-book is filling up with columns of small figures.) To this he answered enigmatically:—
vi: — What? - I interrupted him. - You’re not going to tell me that you no longer care about the spiders, are you? (Because his hobby these past few days has been the spiders, and his notebook is filled with numbers). When I asked that, he responded in a really incomprehensible voice:
tr: “No!” I said. “You don't mean to say you're not interested in spiders.” (His current hobby is spiders, and his notebook is filled with columns of small numbers.) He gave a mysterious answer to this:
es: –What? – I said-. Are you no longer interested in spiders? (Spiders are currently their biggest entertainment, and their notebook is filling up with columns of small numbers.) To this, he responded enigmatically:

en: “The bride-maidens rejoice the eyes that wait the coming of the bride; but when the bride draweth nigh, then the maidens shine not to the eyes that are filled.”
vi: — Distinguished ladies always please those who are waiting for the bride to appear, but once the bride appears, the distinguished ladies no longer matter to those guests.
tr: “Bridesmaids please the eyes that await the bride's arrival; but when the bride approaches, the bridesmaids do not shine in those eyes.”
es: The wedding godmothers rejoice their eyes, which await the arrival of the bride; but when the bride goes to bed, then the godmothers do not shine to the eyes that are full.

en: He would not explain himself, but remained obstinately seated on his bed all the time I remained with him.
vi: He didn't explain anything further and just sat at the edge of the bed the entire time I remained in his room.
tr: He did not explain what he meant, but throughout the time I stayed with him, he sat tirelessly on his bed.
es: He did not want to give any explanation for what was said but remained obstinately seated on the bed the entire time I was with him.

en: I am weary to-night and low in spirits. I cannot but think of Lucy, and how different things might have been. If I don’t sleep at once, chloral, the modern Morpheus—C2HCl3O. H2O! I must be careful not to let it grow into a habit. No, I shall take none to-night! I have thought of Lucy, and I shall not dishonour her by mixing the two. If need be, to-night shall be sleepless....
vi: Tonight I feel so exhausted, my body wilting like a withered leaf. The thought of Lucy continuously haunts me, and every time I think of her, I can't help but wonder if the situation might change? Tonight, if I can't quickly fall asleep after lying down, I might have to reluctantly take a newly developed sleeping pill - the type C2HCl3O. H2O. Of course, I must try not to let this become a habit. No, tonight I will definitely not use any sedatives. To be honest, I have thought a lot about Lucy, and I don't intend to erase the sweet memory of her at any cost. Tonight, I will once again not sleep.
tr: Tonight I am weary and unhappy. I could do nothing but think of Lucy and how different everything could be. If I don't sleep immediately, then chloral, the modern Morpheos25 - C2Cl3CH(OH)2! I must be careful not to let this become a habit. No, I will not take it tonight! I thought of Lucy and I should not mix this with thoughts of her, it would be disrespectful to Lucy. If necessary, I will spend this night sleepless...
es: Tonight I am quite tired and discouraged. I can't stop thinking about Lucy, and how things would have been different. If I don't sleep immediately, chloral, the modern Morpheus: CHCl3CHO. I must be very careful not to get used to it. No, I won't take anything tonight! I've thought about Lucy, and I won't dishonor her by mixing her with the other. If it has to be this way, I'll spend the night awake...

en: Later.—Glad I made the resolution; gladder that I kept to it. I had lain tossing about, and had heard the clock strike only twice, when the night-watchman came to me, sent up from the ward, to say that Renfield had escaped. I threw on my clothes and ran down at once; my patient is too dangerous a person to be roaming about. Those ideas of his might work out dangerously with strangers. The attendant was waiting for me. He said he had seen him not ten minutes before, seemingly asleep in his bed, when he had looked through the observation-trap in the door. His attention was called by the sound of the window being wrenched out. He ran back and saw his feet disappear through the window, and had at once sent up for me. He was only in his night-gear, and cannot be far off. The attendant thought it would be more useful to watch where he should go than to follow him, as he might lose sight of him whilst getting out of the building by the door. He is a bulky man, and couldn’t get through the window. I am thin, so, with his aid, I got out, but feet foremost, and, as we were only a few feet above ground, landed unhurt. The attendant told me the patient had gone to the left, and had taken a straight line, so I ran as quickly as I could. As I got through the belt of trees I saw a white figure scale the high wall which separates our grounds from those of the deserted house.
vi: I had just been lying awake for a while when the clock chimed twice - so it was only 2 AM! I had just turned over wearily when I suddenly heard a knock on the door; the night attendant came to inform me that patient Renfield had escaped! I hurriedly dressed and rushed down the stairs. It would indeed be very dangerous if my patient were to wander freely around the surrounding areas. His stubborn thoughts could pose a real threat to anyone he encountered on the road. The warden was waiting for me. About ten minutes earlier, through a small hole in the door, he had still seen Renfield lying on the bed, seemingly asleep. But then, he was startled when he heard a noise outside the window. He ran to Renfield's room door but didn't see him there anymore: had he jumped out the window to escape? He immediately sent someone to call me. According to the warden, Renfield, wearing only a nightgown, couldn't have gone far. He asserted that Renfield had run to the left and then straight ahead. I also quickly jumped out the window into the yard, of course with the warden's assistance, and hurriedly ran in that direction. As I neared the bushes, I suddenly noticed a faint white figure climbing the wall that separated our garden from the garden of an abandoned house.
tr: I am pleased that I made this decision, and even more pleased that I adhered to it. I lay tossing and turning; when the guard sent from the ward came to tell me that Renfield had escaped, I had only heard the clock strike twice. I quickly put on my clothes and ran downstairs; my patient is a man too dangerous to be wandering around. His thoughts can lead to dangerous outcomes for others. When I arrived, the nurse was waiting for me. He said it had not even been ten minutes since he looked through the observation hole in the door and saw him seemingly asleep in his bed. The sound of the window being opened outward caught his attention. He turned back and ran to the door, and upon seeing the patient's foot disappear out the window, he immediately called for me. The patient is only in his nightclothes and cannot have gone far. The nurse thought it would be more useful to watch where he was going rather than chase after him and risk losing his trail as he exited the building through the door. The nurse is a burly man and couldn't get out the window. I am slender, and with the nurse's help, I went out the window feet first and landed on the ground without injury, as we were only a few meters up. The nurse said the patient turned left and went straight ahead, so I ran as fast as I could. As I passed through the trees, I saw a white figure climbing the high wall that separates our grounds from the abandoned house's property.
es: Later. I am glad to have made that resolution; even more glad to have carried it out. I had been tossing and turning in bed for some time; and I had only heard the clock chime twice when the guard on duty came to see me, sent by my assistant, to tell me that Renfield had escaped. I dressed and ran down immediately; my patient is too dangerous a person to be at large. Those ideas he has can work dangerously in front of strangers. The assistant was waiting for me. He told me that he had seen him less than ten minutes ago, apparently asleep on his bed, when he looked through the observation slit in the door. Then his attention was drawn by the noise of a window being forced open. He ran back and saw his feet disappearing through the window, and then quickly sent the guard to call me. Renfield was only in his nightclothes, so he couldn't have gone far. The assistant thought it would be more useful to see where he was going than to chase him, as he might lose sight of him while turning to exit through the building's door. He was a stout man, and he couldn't get out through the window. I am slender, so with his help, I got out, but feet first, and since we were only a few feet above the ground, I fell without hurting myself. The assistant told me that the patient had run to the left and had disappeared in a straight line. So I hurried in the same direction as fast as I could; as I was crossing the belt of trees, I saw a white figure climbing the high wall that separates our grounds from those of the deserted house.

en: I ran back at once, told the watchman to get three or four men immediately and follow me into the grounds of Carfax, in case our friend might be dangerous. I got a ladder myself, and crossing the wall, dropped down on the other side. I could see Renfield’s figure just disappearing behind the angle of the house, so I ran after him. On the far side of the house I found him pressed close against the old ironbound oak door of the chapel. He was talking, apparently to some one, but I was afraid to go near enough to hear what he was saying, lest I might frighten him, and he should run off. Chasing an errant swarm of bees is nothing to following a naked lunatic, when the fit of escaping is upon him! After a few minutes, however, I could see that he did not take note of anything around him, and so ventured to draw nearer to him—the more so as my men had now crossed the wall and were closing him in. I heard him say:—
vi: I ran back to tell the night watchman to call three or four more people to come with me to Carfax, in case Renfield turned aggressive if we had to bring him back. I took a ladder, climbed over the wall, and jumped to the other side. As soon as my feet touched the ground, I immediately recognized Renfield's shadow disappearing behind the house. I hurriedly chased after him. When I reached the corner of the house, I saw him furiously pushing against the oak door of the chapel. It seemed like he was talking to someone, but I didn't dare get closer for fear he would recognize me and run away. Teasing a bee is not as difficult as catching a madman plotting to escape! However, after a few minutes of observation, I realized he wasn't paying any attention to what was happening around him, so I boldly moved closer, feeling reassured that the people I had just called for help had probably also climbed over the wall and were preparing to surround him. At this point, I could clearly hear what he was saying:
tr: I ran back immediately and told the guard to quickly gather three or four men and follow me to the Carfax estate in case our friend was dangerous. I took a ladder and climbed over the wall to the other side. I could see Renfield's silhouette disappearing around the corner of the house, so I ran after him. I found him leaning against the iron-framed oak door of the chapel at the far end of the house. He was clearly talking to someone, but I was afraid to get close enough to hear what he was saying for fear of scaring him away. Chasing a swarm of stray bees is nothing compared to watching a naked madman in the throes of an escape fit! But after a few minutes, I realized he wasn't paying attention to anything around him, so I dared to approach him - my courage bolstered by the fact that my men had climbed over the wall and were approaching him as well. I heard him say: "I am here to carry out your orders, Master.
es: I immediately ran back and told the guard to bring three or four men and follow me to the Carfax grounds, in case our friend was going to behave dangerously. I myself got a ladder, and climbing over the wall, jumped to the other side. I could see Renfield's figure disappearing behind the corner of the house, so I ran after him. At the other end of the house, I found him leaning heavily against the old oak door, framed in iron, of the chapel. He was talking, apparently to someone, but I was afraid to get too close to hear what he was saying, as I might scare him and he would run off again. Chasing after a wandering swarm of bees is nothing compared to following a naked lunatic when he has got it into his head that he must escape! However, after a few minutes, I could see that he was unaware of anything happening around him, and I dared to get closer, especially since my men had jumped over the wall and were approaching him. I heard him say:

en: “I am here to do Your bidding, Master. I am Your slave, and You will reward me, for I shall be faithful. I have worshipped You long and afar off. Now that You are near, I await Your commands, and You will not pass me by, will You, dear Master, in Your distribution of good things?”
vi: — I submit to you, master. I am your slave and I know that you will reward me, for I am always loyal to you. I have admired you for a long, long time! Now that you are here, I will await your orders, and you won't forget to share the wealth with me, will you, master?
tr: I heard him say: "I am here to carry out your orders, Master. I am your slave and you will reward me, for I will be faithful to you. I have worshipped you for a long time, even when you were far away. Now that you are near, I await your commands; you won't overlook me when distributing the good things, will you, dear Master?"
es: –I am here to fulfill your orders, master. I am your slave, and you will reward me, for I will be faithful. I have adored you for a long time and from afar. Now that you are near, I await your orders, and you will not forget me, will you, my dear master?, in your distribution of good things.

en: He is a selfish old beggar anyhow. He thinks of the loaves and fishes even when he believes he is in a Real Presence. His manias make a startling combination. When we closed in on him he fought like a tiger. He is immensely strong, for he was more like a wild beast than a man. I never saw a lunatic in such a paroxysm of rage before; and I hope I shall not again. It is a mercy that we have found out his strength and his danger in good time. With strength and determination like his, he might have done wild work before he was caged. He is safe now at any rate. Jack Sheppard himself couldn’t get free from the strait-waistcoat that keeps him restrained, and he’s chained to the wall in the padded room. His cries are at times awful, but the silences that follow are more deadly still, for he means murder in every turn and movement.
vi: It truly was the voice of a beggar! His eccentricity was beyond words. When we grabbed him by the arms, he struggled wildly like a tiger, because he resembled a wild beast more than a human being. Never had I encountered a mental patient so strong and aggressive, and I hope this will be the last time! Fortunately, I anticipated the situation and managed to call for additional help in time. I dare not think about what he might have done if we hadn't managed to bring him back! On the way back, he occasionally let out terrifying roars, but the silence that followed each of his cries worried us just as much, for we had already guessed his deadly intentions.
tr: Still, he was an old, selfish beggar. Even when he believed he was in the presence of Absolute Power, he was thinking about bread and fish. The coming together of their madness creates a surprising mixture. He fought like a tiger when we surrounded him. He was very strong and resembled a wild animal more than a human. I had never seen a madman having such a fit of rage before; I hope I never see one again. It is a great blessing that we understood the extent of his power and the danger he posed. With the strength and determination he showed, he could have done wild things before being caged. Anyway, he is safe now. Even Jack Sheppard26 couldn't escape from the straitjacket that restrained him; he was chained to the wall in a padded room. His screams are sometimes terrifying, but the silences that follow are even more frightening, because with every turn and every movement, he is plotting death.
es: Anyway, he is an old and selfish beggar. He thinks about bread and fish even when he believes he is in a real presence. His obsessions make an astonishing combination. When we fell upon him, he fought like a tiger; he is very strong, and he behaved more like a wild beast than a man. I had never seen a lunatic in such a paroxysm of fury; and I hope never to see it again. It is a good thing that we found out his intentions and his strength in time. With a strength and determination like his, he could have done many barbarities before being caged. In any case, he is in a safe place. Not even Jack Sheppard himself could have escaped from the straitjacket that holds him, and he is also chained to the wall in the security cell. His screams are sometimes horrible, but the silences that follow are even more deadly, for in every turn and movement he manifests his desire to kill.

en: Just now he spoke coherent words for the first time:—
vi: The first time I heard him speak in broken sentences:
tr: He just spoke sensibly for the first time:
es: A few moments ago, he said these first coherent words:

en: “I shall be patient, Master. It is coming—coming—coming!”
vi: — I will be patient, master! I will wait... wait... wait...
tr: “I will be patient, Sir. It's coming - it's coming - it's coming!”
es: –I will have patience, master. It's coming..., coming..., coming!

en: So I took the hint, and came too. I was too excited to sleep, but this diary has quieted me, and I feel I shall get some sleep to-night.
vi: Me too, I will wait!
tr: I deciphered the implied meaning of this indirect statement and came here. I was too excited to sleep, but this journal calmed me down and I feel like I will get some sleep tonight.
es: So I took his hint, and I also arrived. I was too excited to sleep, but this journal has calmed me down and I feel that tonight I will sleep a bit.

en: CHAPTER IX
vi: CHAPTER 9
tr: IX
es: IX.–

en: Letter, Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra.
vi: Mina Harker's letter to Lucy Westenra
tr: From Mina Harker Letter to Lucy Westenra
es: MINA HARKER'S LETTER TO LUCY WESTENRA

en: “Buda-Pesth, 24 August.
vi: “Budapest, August 24”
tr: Budapest, August 24
es: Budapest, August 24

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Dear Lucy, I know you are very anxious to know everything that has happened since we parted ways at Whitby station.
tr: Dearest Lucy,
es: "My dearest Lucy:

en: “I know you will be anxious to hear all that has happened since we parted at the railway station at Whitby. Well, my dear, I got to Hull all right, and caught the boat to Hamburg, and then the train on here. I feel that I can hardly recall anything of the journey, except that I knew I was coming to Jonathan, and, that as I should have to do some nursing, I had better get all the sleep I could.... I found my dear one, oh, so thin and pale and weak-looking. All the resolution has gone out of his dear eyes, and that quiet dignity which I told you was in his face has vanished. He is only a wreck of himself, and he does not remember anything that has happened to him for a long time past. At least, he wants me to believe so, and I shall never ask. He has had some terrible shock, and I fear it might tax his poor brain if he were to try to recall it. Sister Agatha, who is a good creature and a born nurse, tells me that he raved of dreadful things whilst he was off his head. I wanted her to tell me what they were; but she would only cross herself, and say she would never tell; that the ravings of the sick were the secrets of God, and that if a nurse through her vocation should hear them, she should respect her trust. She is a sweet, good soul, and the next day, when she saw I was troubled, she opened up the subject again, and after saying that she could never mention what my poor dear raved about, added: ‘I can tell you this much, my dear: that it was not about anything which he has done wrong himself; and you, as his wife to be, have no cause to be concerned. He has not forgotten you or what he owes to you. His fear was of great and terrible things, which no mortal can treat of.’ I do believe the dear soul thought I might be jealous lest my poor dear should have fallen in love with any other girl. The idea of my being jealous about Jonathan! And yet, my dear, let me whisper, I felt a thrill of joy through me when I knew that no other woman was a cause of trouble. I am now sitting by his bedside, where I can see his face while he sleeps. He is waking!...
vi: Dear Lucy, I know you are very anxious to know everything that has happened since we parted ways at Whitby station. I'll tell you! To Hull, I took a ship to Hamburg and from there, I took a train back here. It would be a bit tiring if I had to recall all the details of my journey. When I realized I had to find Jonathan and take care of him, I only thought of one thing: to sleep as much as possible. I met Jonathan, he looked emaciated, pale, and in a very poor state of health. In his eyes, there was no longer the resolute, calm look that I often described to you, instead, there was a dark gaze that did not recall anything that had happened to him recently, at least that was my impression when I first met him. Jonathan had gone through a real shock, and I fear that even if his memory is restored, he still won't be able to bear the recollection of what happened to him. Sister Agatha, a wonderful believer and a kind nurse, recounted that Jonathan only spoke of terrible things while delirious. I wanted to know more details, but Sister Agatha said that it was impossible, because everything a patient utters in delirium is considered God's secret, and if overheard, all doctors are obliged to keep this secret. However, the next day, knowing I was very worried, the sister met me and said: “All I can tell you is that your husband often spoke of a mistake he made. And you, who will soon become his wife, had nothing to do with this mistake. Your husband has not forgotten you, nor has he forgotten everything you have done for him. His worries stem from the terrible things that anyone, being human, would find hard to forget.” Perhaps the kind sister feared I was jealous, thinking that my fiancé had fallen in love with another girl! Jealous of a girl my beloved had fallen for! Jealousy? I have always trusted in Jonathan's love! My dear friend, now I can tell you that there is no woman who is the cause of his poor mental state. As I write to you, I am watching him sleep... He has woken up!
tr: I know you'll be curious to learn everything that has happened since we parted at the train station in Whitby. Well, my dear, I arrived safely in Hull, caught the ship to Hamburg, and from there, the train that brought me here. I can't remember much about the journey except that I knew I needed to sleep as much as possible since I would need to take care of Jonathan when I arrived. I found my beloved looking so weak, pale, and frail! My dear, all the determination in his eyes, that quiet dignity I told you about on his face, had vanished. He has become a shadow of himself and does not remember what happened to him during that long period. At least, he wants me to believe that, and I will never ask. He has suffered a terrible shock, and I fear that trying to remember it might strain his poor brain too much. Sister Agatha, who is a very good soul and a natural nurse, says that he raved about horrible things when he was acting mad. I asked her to tell me what they were, but she just crossed herself and said she would never tell; because a patient's ravings are considered God's secrets, and if a nun hears them as part of her duty, she must respect the trust placed in her. She is sweet and kind; the next day, when she saw I was distressed, she brought up the subject again and said she could never speak of what my beloved raved about, but added: "I can tell you this much, dear: What he raved about was not something bad he had done, and there is no reason for you to worry as his future wife. He has not forgotten you or what he owes you. His fear is related to things so great and terrifying that no mortal could speak of them. "I think this sweet person thought I might be jealous if my poor beloved had fallen in love with another girl. Imagine thinking I could be jealous of Jonathan! But still, my dear, let me whisper that I felt a joyful relief when I learned that another woman was not the cause of his distress. Now, I am sitting by his bed, where I can see his face while he sleeps. He is waking up!..
es: "I know you must be very anxious to know everything that has happened since we parted at the railway station in Whitby. Well, dear, I arrived in Hull without any trouble, took the boat to Hamburg, and then the train from there. I feel like I can barely remember what happened during the journey, except that I knew I was on my way to Jonathan, and that, as I would surely have to act as a nurse, it was best to sleep as much as I could… I found my beloved very thin, pale, and weak. All the strength has escaped from his dear eyes, and that quiet dignity that I have always told you he showed on his face has disappeared. He is only a shadow of what he was, and he remembers nothing of what has happened to him in recent times. At least, that is what he wants me to believe, and therefore I will never ask him. He has had a terrible experience, and I fear his poor brain will pay the consequences if he tries to remember. Sister Agatha, who is a wonderful nun and a born nurse, tells me that he raved about horrible things while his head was disturbed. I wanted her to tell me what it was about, but she only crossed herself and told me she would never say anything; that the ravings of the sick were secrets of God, and that if a nurse through her vocation came to hear them, she must respect her vows. She is a sweet, good soul; and the next day, when she saw that I was very distressed, she herself brought up the subject again, and after saying that she would never mention what my poor patient raved about, she added: 'I can tell you this, dear: it was not about anything bad that he himself had done; and you, who will be his wife, have nothing to worry about. He has not forgotten you nor what he owes you. His fears were about great and terrible things, which no mortal should speak of. I believe the sweet sister thought I might be jealous, fearing that my beloved had fallen in love with another woman. The idea that I could be jealous of Jonathan!. And yet, my dear Lucy, let me whisper to you that when I found out that it was not another woman causing all the trouble, I felt a rush of joy throughout my body. I am now sitting beside his bed, from where I can see his face as he sleeps. He is waking up…!

en: “When he woke he asked me for his coat, as he wanted to get something from the pocket; I asked Sister Agatha, and she brought all his things. I saw that amongst them was his note-book, and was going to ask him to let me look at it—for I knew then that I might find some clue to his trouble—but I suppose he must have seen my wish in my eyes, for he sent me over to the window, saying he wanted to be quite alone for a moment. Then he called me back, and when I came he had his hand over the note-book, and he said to me very solemnly:—
vi: As soon as he woke up, he asked me about the notebook kept in his jacket pocket. I intended to beg him to let me read the notes in it - because I knew I would find clues to guess the cause of his breakdown, but it seemed he had guessed that intention from the look in my eyes, as he suggested I move near the window, he wanted to be alone. A moment later, he called me back, still holding the notebook, and spoke to me in a very serious tone:
tr: When he woke up, he wanted his coat to get something from his pocket; I told Sister Agatha, and she brought all of Jonathan's belongings. Among his things, I saw his notebook, and knowing that I might find a clue to his trouble inside, I was about to ask for permission to look at it when I think he saw my desire in my eyes; because he asked me to go to the window for a moment, saying he wanted to be alone. Then he called me back, and when I returned, his hand was on the notebook, and with a very serious expression, he said: "Wilhelmina," - that was when I knew he was very serious because he hadn't called me by that name since he proposed - "My dear, you know my thoughts on trust between husband and wife:
es: "Upon waking, he asked me for his coat, as he wanted to take something out of his pocket; I asked Sister Agatha if he could do it, and she brought all his things. I saw that among them was his notebook, and I was going to ask him to let me see it (for I knew that in it I might find some clue to his ailment), but I suppose he must have seen my desire in my eyes, for he told me to go to the window for a moment, as he wished to be alone for a while. Then he called me and said very solemnly:

en: “‘Wilhelmina’—I knew then that he was in deadly earnest, for he has never called me by that name since he asked me to marry him—‘you know, dear, my ideas of the trust between husband and wife: there should be no secret, no concealment. I have had a great shock, and when I try to think of what it is I feel my head spin round, and I do not know if it was all real or the dreaming of a madman. You know I have had brain fever, and that is to be mad. The secret is here, and I do not want to know it. I want to take up my life here, with our marriage.’ For, my dear, we had decided to be married as soon as the formalities are complete. ‘Are you willing, Wilhelmina, to share my ignorance? Here is the book. Take it and keep it, read it if you will, but never let me know; unless, indeed, some solemn duty should come upon me to go back to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, sane or mad, recorded here.’ He fell back exhausted, and I put the book under his pillow, and kissed him. I have asked Sister Agatha to beg the Superior to let our wedding be this afternoon, and am waiting her reply....
vi: — Wilhelmina, - Yes, what he intends to confide in me must be very serious, my dear friend, because since we fell in love, this is the first time he has mentioned my given name - surely you know what he is thinking about the trust that must exist between a wife and a husband. They should not hide anything from each other, and there should be no secrets kept by either. Therefore, I can confess to you that I have gone through a terrible shock; and now, as I try to recall what happened to me, I no longer know if it was real or just a nightmare. People have told you that I have a brain disease, like a kind of mental illness, isn't it frightening? The secret of what happened to me lies in these pages, but I don't want to mention it anymore. I want my life, and our wedding as well, to start from scratch. (Because, my dear friend, we will get married here, right after all the procedures are completed) Wilhelmina, do you want to share this innocence with me? Here is the notebook, take it and keep it, and if you want, you can read everything I have written, but remember never to mention any of it to me, I don't want to recall that terrible chapter... unless some duty compels me to do so. After saying that much, Jonathan fell asleep again due to exhaustion. I hugged him while slipping the notebook under his pillow. Sister Agatha had gone to the Cathedral of Our Lady on my behalf to pray for our wedding, which is to take place this afternoon. I am eagerly awaiting her response.
tr: There should never be any secrets or mysteries between them. I have experienced a great shock, and when I try to think about what it was, I feel as if my head is spinning; I don't know if these things are entirely real or just the dreams of a madman. You know I had brain fever, and that means madness. The secret is here, and I don't want to know what it is. I want to continue my life here, by marrying you. " Because, my dear, we had decided to marry as soon as the formalities were completed. " Wilhelmina, are you willing to share my ignorance? Here is the notebook. Take it and keep it, read it if you want, but never let me know; unless a serious duty compels me to revisit those painful hours recorded here, whether asleep or awake, sane or mad. " He leaned back in exhaustion, placed the notebook under his pillow, and I kissed him. I asked Sister Agatha to plead with the higher authorities to allow our marriage to take place today, and now I am waiting for the answer...
es: "Willhelmina (I knew she wanted to speak to me with all seriousness, as she had never called me by my name since she asked me to marry her), you know, dear, my ideas about the trust that must exist between husband and wife: there should be no secrets, no hiding places between them. I have suffered a great shock, and when I try to think about what it was, I feel my head spinning, and I don't know if it was all real or the dreams of a madman. You know that I have had a brain fever, and that means being mad. The secret is here, and I do not wish to know it. I want to start my life anew at this moment, with our marriage. (For, my dear Lucy, we have decided to marry as soon as the formalities are arranged.) Do you wish, Willhelmina, to share my ignorance? Here is the book. Take it and keep it, read it if you want, but never mention to me what it contains; unless, of course, some solemn duty falls upon me and forces me to return to the bitter hours recorded here, asleep or awake, sane or mad. "And upon saying that, he reclined exhausted, and I placed the book under his pillow and kissed him. I have asked Sister Agatha to plead with the superior that our wedding can take place this afternoon, and I am waiting for her response…

en: “She has come and told me that the chaplain of the English mission church has been sent for. We are to be married in an hour, or as soon after as Jonathan awakes....
vi: The nun came back and told me that she had asked someone to find the chaplain of the Church of England. Within an hour, or perhaps sooner, maybe right after Jonathan wakes up, we will get married.
tr: The nun came back and said that the English missionary church pastor had been called. We will get married within an hour or as soon as Jonathan wakes up...
es: "He has returned and told me that they have already gone to fetch the chaplain of the English Mission church. We will get married within an hour, or as soon as Jonathan wakes up…

en: “Lucy, the time has come and gone. I feel very solemn, but very, very happy. Jonathan woke a little after the hour, and all was ready, and he sat up in bed, propped up with pillows. He answered his ‘I will’ firmly and strongly. I could hardly speak; my heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me. The dear sisters were so kind. Please God, I shall never, never forget them, nor the grave and sweet responsibilities I have taken upon me. I must tell you of my wedding present. When the chaplain and the sisters had left me alone with my husband—oh, Lucy, it is the first time I have written the words ‘my husband’—left me alone with my husband, I took the book from under his pillow, and wrapped it up in white paper, and tied it with a little bit of pale blue ribbon which was round my neck, and sealed it over the knot with sealing-wax, and for my seal I used my wedding ring. Then I kissed it and showed it to my husband, and told him that I would keep it so, and then it would be an outward and visible sign for us all our lives that we trusted each other; that I would never open it unless it were for his own dear sake or for the sake of some stern duty. Then he took my hand in his, and oh, Lucy, it was the first time he took his wife’s hand, and said that it was the dearest thing in all the wide world, and that he would go through all the past again to win it, if need be. The poor dear meant to have said a part of the past, but he cannot think of time yet, and I shall not wonder if at first he mixes up not only the month, but the year.
vi: Lucy, do you know, many hours have passed since I put pen to paper...Time passes so slowly for me! But anyhow, now I feel overflowing with happiness! When Jonathan woke up, everything was ready. He struggled to sit up against the pillows on the bed and answered with a determined voice, "yes". As for me, I could only say very softly, overwhelming happiness made me sob with emotion. The devotees here are so dedicated to us! God wants me to never forget them, to never forget the heavy but gentle responsibilities I have to bear! Perhaps now I should tell you about my wedding gift. When the chaplain and the nuns left me alone with my husband. Oh! Lucy, this is the first time I get to write these words: my husband, I took the notebook from under his pillow, wrapped it in silver paper, and tied it with a bow like a real gift. I placed a kiss on it and told my husband that I would keep this memento for life as a testament to my faith in him and that I would never open the notebook unless it was for his benefit or in a truly urgent situation. He took my hand...Oh! Lucy, this is the first time he held his wife's hand...He replied to me that he would engrave my heart's sentiment in his and to be worthy of my affection, he would revive the past if necessary. Clearly, my poor man was ready to reveal a part of his past, but he couldn't determine the time that had passed, and I wouldn't be surprised if at some point, he not only forgets the days but also the years.
tr: Lucy, the moment came and went. I feel very honored and very, very happy. Jonathan woke up about an hour after our last conversation; everything was ready, and Jonathan was sitting up in bed, propped up by pillows. "I accept," he said clearly and strongly. I could barely speak; my heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me. The dear nuns were very considerate. Please, God, never ever let me forget them or the heavy and sweet responsibilities I have taken on. I must tell you about my wedding gift. When the priest and the nuns left my husband and me -Oh, Lucy, this is the first time I write the word "husband"- when they left my husband and me alone, I took the notebook out from under his pillow, wrapped it in white paper, tied it with a light blue ribbon that I wore around my neck, sealed it with wax, and used my wedding ring as the seal. Then I kissed the package and showed it to my husband, telling him that I would keep the notebook this way, so it would be a visible and clear sign that we trust each other throughout our lives, and that I would never open it unless it was for his own good or an unrelenting duty. Then he took my hand, and oh, Lucy, it was the first time he held his wife's hand, and he said it was the most beautiful thing in the world and that he would relive the entire past to earn it, if necessary. My poor darling meant a part of the past, but he can't think about time yet, and I wouldn't be surprised if he mixes up not only months but also years.
es: "Lucy, the time came and she left." I feel very solemn, but very, very happy. Jonathan woke up shortly after the hour, and everything was prepared; he sat on the bed, surrounded by pillows. He responded 'yes, I accept' with firmness and strength. I could barely speak; my heart was so full that even those words seemed to choke me. The sisters were all very refined. Never, never will I forget them, nor the serious and sweet responsibilities that have fallen upon me. I must tell you about my wedding gift... When the chaplain and the sisters had left me alone with my husband, oh, Lucy! It's the first time I have written the words 'my husband'! When they had left me alone with my husband, I took the book from under his pillow, wrapped it in white paper, tied it with a small pale blue ribbon that I wore around my neck, and sealed it over the knot with wax, using my wedding ring as a seal. Then I kissed it and showed it to my husband; I told him that I would keep it that way, and that it would be an outward and visible sign for us throughout our lives that we trusted each other; that I would never open it, unless it was for his own good or to fulfill an unavoidable duty. Then he took my hand in his, and, oh, Lucy, it was the first time he took his wife's hands!, and he said they were the most beautiful things in the whole wide world, and that if necessary he would go through everything again to deserve them. The poor thing must have meant part of the past, but he still can't think about time, and it wouldn't surprise me if at first he mixed not only the months but also the years.

en: “Well, my dear, what could I say? I could only tell him that I was the happiest woman in all the wide world, and that I had nothing to give him except myself, my life, and my trust, and that with these went my love and duty for all the days of my life. And, my dear, when he kissed me, and drew me to him with his poor weak hands, it was like a very solemn pledge between us....
vi: What else could I possibly criticize him for? Just being able to whisper to him that I am the happiest woman in the world, that I have nothing else to offer him but my own life, my heart, my love, and my duty to him, is already more than enough for me. And when he holds me in his arms and tightly grasps my hand with his frail, thin hands, I feel as though we are once again making a serious promise to each other.
tr: Yes, my love, what could I have said? I told him only that I was the happiest woman in the world and that I had nothing to give but myself, my life, and my trust, and that these would be accompanied by the love and respect I would feel for him every day of my life. And my love, when he kissed me and pulled me towards him with his poor, weak hands, it felt as if there was a sacred vow between us.
es: "Well, dear, what more can I say? I can only tell you that I am the happiest woman in this wide world, and that I had nothing to give him except myself, my life, and my trust, and with these things went my love and my duty for all the days of my life. And, dear, when he kissed me, and drew me to him with his poor weak hands, it was like a very solemn prayer between the two of us…

en: “Lucy dear, do you know why I tell you all this? It is not only because it is all sweet to me, but because you have been, and are, very dear to me. It was my privilege to be your friend and guide when you came from the schoolroom to prepare for the world of life. I want you to see now, and with the eyes of a very happy wife, whither duty has led me; so that in your own married life you too may be all happy as I am. My dear, please Almighty God, your life may be all it promises: a long day of sunshine, with no harsh wind, no forgetting duty, no distrust. I must not wish you no pain, for that can never be; but I do hope you will be always as happy as I am now. Good-bye, my dear. I shall post this at once, and, perhaps, write you very soon again. I must stop, for Jonathan is waking—I must attend to my husband!
vi: Dear Lucy, do you know why I tell you everything? It's not just a sweet love story as you might guess, but also because you have always been a great friend to me, and always will be. I still consider myself fortunate to have you as a friend, and now I am eagerly hoping that you too will experience the happiness I have just grasped. Oh Lucy, may God bless you, may He grant you the promises for your earthly struggles: a long day filled with sunshine, a peaceful day without storms, without forgetfulness, without doubt. I won't wish for you to never face hardships, for that is unrealistic, but once again I wish for you to enjoy a complete and sweet happiness like I am feeling now: Goodbye, dear friend. I will drop this letter in the mail right away, and will write again soon to keep you from feeling lonely. I have to say goodbye for now, as Jonathan has just woken up... I need to check if my husband needs anything.
tr: Lucy, my dear, do you know why I am telling you all this? Not only because I enjoyed these things, but also because you are very important to me. It was a privilege for me to be your friend and guide when you left the classroom to prepare for life. Now, I want you to see with the eyes of a very happy spouse where this duty has brought me; so that you can be as happy in your married life as I am. My dear, I pray to the Almighty God that your life will be as promised: a long, sunny day where harsh winds do not blow, duties are not forgotten, and there is no insecurity. I should not wish for it to be painless, because that can never be; but I hope you will always be as happy as I am now. Goodbye, my dear. I will send this to the post immediately and perhaps write to you again very soon. I must finish my letter because Jonathan is waking up - I need to take care of my husband!
es: "Lucy, dear, do you know why I am telling you all this? Not only because it is so sweet for me, but also because you have been, and are, my dearest friend. It was my privilege to be your friend and guide when you left the classroom to prepare yourself in the world of life. I want to see you now, and with the eyes of a very happy wife, to what duty has led me, so that in your own married life you too can be as happy as I am. My dear, may Almighty God make your life all that it promises to be: a long day of bright sunshine, without adverse winds, without forgetting duty, without distrust. I must not wish you to have no sorrows, for that can never be; but I do wish you to always be as happy as I am now. Goodbye, dear. I will put this letter in the mail immediately, and perhaps I will write to you again very soon. I must finish now, for Jonathan is waking up. I must attend to my husband!

en: “Your ever-loving
vi: Your eternal friend, Mina Harker
tr: Will always love you
es: "Who always loves you,

en: “Mina Harker.”
vi: Your eternal friend, Mina Harker
tr: MINA HARKER
es: MINA HARKER

vi: Letter from Lucy Westenra to Mina Harker

en: “Whitby, 30 August.
vi: "Whitby, August 30"
tr: Whitby, August 30
es: Whitby, August 30

en: “My dearest Mina,—
vi: Dear Mina,
tr: Dearest Mina,
es: "My dearest Mina:

en: “Oceans of love and millions of kisses, and may you soon be in your own home with your husband. I wish you could be coming home soon enough to stay with us here. The strong air would soon restore Jonathan; it has quite restored me. I have an appetite like a cormorant, am full of life, and sleep well. You will be glad to know that I have quite given up walking in my sleep. I think I have not stirred out of my bed for a week, that is when I once got into it at night. Arthur says I am getting fat. By the way, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here. We have such walks and drives, and rides, and rowing, and tennis, and fishing together; and I love him more than ever. He tells me that he loves me more, but I doubt that, for at first he told me that he couldn’t love me more than he did then. But this is nonsense. There he is, calling to me. So no more just at present from your loving
vi: I wish to give you an ocean of friendship, millions of kisses, and hope that you will soon return home with your newlywed husband! If you return to England soon, remember to visit Whitby with me for a few days. The fresh sea air will help Jonathan recover best - it was the air here that helped me fully recover; now I can sleep very well, and I feel full of life. I believe you will be very happy to know that I no longer wander in my sleep. It's been a week since I last got out of bed - I mean at night! Arthur says I've noticeably gained weight. Oh, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here. Every day we go for walks, play tennis or fish, and ride horses together. I love him more than ever. He also says he feels he loves me more and more each day. I don't quite believe it, because at first, he told me that he couldn't love me more than he already does... There, he's calling me again... Perhaps I should say goodbye to you here.
tr: Oceans of love and millions of kisses; I hope you will soon be in your own home with your husband. I also hope you return early enough to stay with us here for a while. This harsh weather will quickly restore Jonathan's health; it has brought me back to myself quite a bit. My appetite is like that of a wild animal, I am full of life and sleeping well. You will be glad to know that I have quite stopped sleepwalking. I don't think I've moved from my bed for a week, I mean after getting into bed at night. Arthur says I am starting to gain weight. By the way, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here. We are having such wonderful walks, carriage rides, horse riding, boat trips, playing tennis, and fishing together! I love him more than ever. He tells me that he loves me more, but I doubt it because he had said from the very beginning that it was impossible for him to love me more than he did at that moment. But that's nonsense. Look, he is calling me. So that's all for now. The one who loves you
es: "Oceans of love and millions of kisses, and may you soon be in your own home with your husband. I would like you to return soon so that you could spend some time here with us. The strong air would soon restore Jonathan; it has done so with me. I have a voracious appetite, I am full of life, and I sleep well. You will be pleased to know that I no longer sleepwalk. I believe I haven't moved from the bed for a week, that is, once I lie down at night. Arthur says I am getting fat. By the way, I forgot to tell you that Arthur is here. We take long walks, ride horses, row, play tennis, and fish together; I love him more than ever. She tells me that she loves me more: but I doubt it, because at the beginning she told me that she couldn't love me more than she already did. But these are silly things. There she is, calling me, so that's all for today.
