en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 20 August.—The case of Renfield grows even more interesting. He has now so far quieted that there are spells of cessation from his passion. For the first week after his attack he was perpetually violent. Then one night, just as the moon rose, he grew quiet, and kept murmuring to himself: “Now I can wait; now I can wait.” The attendant came to tell me, so I ran down at once to have a look at him. He was still in the strait-waistcoat and in the padded room, but the suffused look had gone from his face, and his eyes had something of their old pleading—I might almost say, “cringing”—softness. I was satisfied with his present condition, and directed him to be relieved. The attendants hesitated, but finally carried out my wishes without protest. It was a strange thing that the patient had humour enough to see their distrust, for, coming close to me, he said in a whisper, all the while looking furtively at them:—
vi: • August 22 Renfield's case is becoming increasingly complex and also more interesting: suddenly he has become very calm. But after the recent escape attempt, he continuously exhibited violent behavior for several days. Then one evening, when the moonlight awakened, he suddenly calmed down and muttered to himself countless times: "Now I can wait... I can wait..." Hearing the warden report this, I immediately ran down and understood what was happening. Renfield, still confined in his room and wearing a straitjacket specifically for the insane, no longer had the ferocious look he had in the past few days; his eyes now had a certain gentle, pleading quality. I ordered him to be loosened. The attendant hesitated, but eventually complied with my instructions. Strangely enough, the patient somehow immediately recognized the suspicion of those watching him, as he tiptoed over and whispered in my ear, while still sneaking glances at them:
tr: August 20. - The Renfield case is becoming more and more interesting. He has now become so quiet that there are moments of calm between his bouts of madness. During the first week after his seizure, he constantly exhibited violent tendencies. Then one night, just as the moon was rising, he calmed down and began to mutter to himself: "I can wait now; I can wait now." The nurse came to tell me this, and I immediately rushed downstairs to check on Renfield. He was still in the padded room with his straitjacket on, but the expression we had seen on his face for so long was gone, and the old pleading - almost "fawning" - soft look had returned to his eyes. I was pleased with his current state and ordered the straitjacket to be removed. The nurses hesitated, but eventually complied with my wishes without objection. It was strange that the patient had enough sense of humor to notice their distrust; because he came up to me and, looking at them slyly, whispered:
es: August 20. Renfield's case is becoming more and more interesting. For now, we have been able to establish that there are periods of decline in his passion. For a week after his first attack, he remained in perpetual violence. Then, one night, just as the moon rose, he calmed down and was murmuring to himself: "Now I can wait; now I can wait." The assistant came to call me, so I quickly ran downstairs to take a look at him. He was still in the straitjacket and in the security room; but the congested expression had disappeared from his face, and his eyes had something of their former pleading; I might almost say their "cringing" softness. I was satisfied with his current condition and gave orders for him to be released. My assistants hesitated, but finally carried out my wishes without protest. A strange thing was that the patient had enough good sense to notice their distrust, for, approaching me, he said in a whisper, while looking at them furtively:

en: “They think I could hurt you! Fancy me hurting you! The fools!”
vi: — They must be thinking that I'm about to give you a good beating? How could I ever do such a thing! What a bunch of fools!
tr: “They think I can harm you! Imagine if I thought I could harm you! Fools!”
es: –They think I can hurt you! Imagine that, me hurting you! Idiots!

en: It was soothing, somehow, to the feelings to find myself dissociated even in the mind of this poor madman from the others; but all the same I do not follow his thought. Am I to take it that I have anything in common with him, so that we are, as it were, to stand together; or has he to gain from me some good so stupendous that my well-being is needful to him? I must find out later on. To-night he will not speak. Even the offer of a kitten or even a full-grown cat will not tempt him. He will only say: “I don’t take any stock in cats. I have more to think of now, and I can wait; I can wait.”
vi: In short, no matter what is said, it is truly not alarming to make an observation that even in the mind of this unfortunate person, I have many differences compared to my subordinates. However, I still cannot grasp his thoughts. Moreover, is it necessary to understand that I have something in common with him, leading others to say that he and I will stand on the same shore? Or is he patiently waiting for some goodwill from me, so that at some point he will call me his ally? I will try to understand the issue. Tonight, he was determined not to open his mouth to say anything. Even when someone brought him a cat, a large cat at that, he only said a few words: "I no longer care about those filthy cats. Now there are many other things that concern me, and I can wait... I can wait...”
tr: Even in the mind of this poor madman, being kept separate from the others was somehow a soothing feeling; but still, I did not understand his thinking. Should I think that we have something in common and that we should stick together because of it, or is my well-being necessary for him because he will gain a great benefit from me? I must understand this later. He will not speak tonight. Even the suggestion of a kitten or an adult cat will not tempt him. The only thing he said was: "I am not interested in cats. I have other things to think about now and I can wait; I can wait."
es: It was somewhat consoling, for my feelings, to find myself dissociated even in the mind of this poor madman from the others; but in any case, I do not understand his thoughts. Should I accept that I have something in common with him, so that being as we are, as we were, we must unite? Or does he have to obtain such a great benefit from me that my health is necessary to him? I will have to find out later. Tonight he will not speak. Not even the offer of a kitten, or even a big cat, is capable of tempting him. He only says: "I don't care about cats at all. Now I have more to think about, and I can wait; I can wait."

en: After a while I left him. The attendant tells me that he was quiet until just before dawn, and that then he began to get uneasy, and at length violent, until at last he fell into a paroxysm which exhausted him so that he swooned into a sort of coma.
vi: The warden told me that when I left his room, he sat in silence until morning. After that, he started acting up again, and this time, his madness made him so aggressive that he fainted and fell into a coma.
tr: After a while, I left his side. The nurse says that Renfield remained quiet until dawn, then started to become restless, and eventually had a violent seizure that exhausted him to the point of fainting.
es: After a while, I left him. The assistant tells me that he was calm until a little before dawn and then began to show signs of nervousness. Finally, he became violent, until, at last, he fell into a kind of paroxysm that exhausted him so much that, finally, he fainted into a kind of coma.

en: ... Three nights has the same thing happened—violent all day then quiet from moonrise to sunrise. I wish I could get some clue to the cause. It would almost seem as if there was some influence which came and went. Happy thought! We shall to-night play sane wits against mad ones. He escaped before without our help; to-night he shall escape with it. We shall give him a chance, and have the men ready to follow in case they are required....
vi: The event has been happening like this for three days already. First, there were violent fits of madness, followed by hours of sitting still throughout the night. I must find the cause of these cyclical bouts of madness. It is possible that my patient has been subjected to some influence. If that is the case, then tonight we will pit sound minds against the sick ones! The other day, Renfield escaped despite our precautions. Tonight, we will help him escape. We will give him a chance, and the guards will be ready to follow him...
tr: ... For three nights the same thing happened - violent during the day and then, from moonrise to sunrise, silent. I wish I could find a clue as to why. It was as if he was under the influence of something that came and went intermittently. What a good thought! Tonight we will play the sane against the mad. He escaped without our help before; tonight he will escape with our help. We will give him a chance and keep men ready to follow him if necessary...
es: … Three nights in a row the same thing has happened: violent all day and calm from moonrise to sunrise. I really wish I could discover some clue to the cause. It almost seems as if there were some influence that comes and goes. What an idea! Tonight we are going to pit healthy brains against sick brains in a game. Once he escaped without our help. Tonight he will escape with it. We will give him the opportunity, and the men will be ready to follow him if necessary…

en: 23 August.—“The unexpected always happens.” How well Disraeli knew life. Our bird when he found the cage open would not fly, so all our subtle arrangements were for nought. At any rate, we have proved one thing; that the spells of quietness last a reasonable time. We shall in future be able to ease his bonds for a few hours each day. I have given orders to the night attendant merely to shut him in the padded room, when once he is quiet, until an hour before sunrise. The poor soul’s body will enjoy the relief even if his mind cannot appreciate it. Hark! The unexpected again! I am called; the patient has once more escaped.
vi: • August 23 The incident did not go as we expected! Even though the cage door was open, our bird still refused to fly away. So all our arrangements and preparations were in vain! However, there is one thing that has been confirmed: the stubborn phases of the patient have been shortened. From now on, we will let him be free for a few hours each day. I told the night shift warden not to lock him in the insane cell when he is in a normal state, and only to put him in there about an hour before sunrise. He seems very pleased with this half-freedom regime even when his mind is not yet capable of evaluating and perceiving things. However, someone came running to call me in a panic!... The thing I did not expect happened once again: the patient has escaped.
tr: August 23. - "The unexpected always happens." Disraeli knew life so well. Our bird did not fly when it found the cage open, thus all our clever arrangements went to waste. Still, we proved one thing: Periods of silence last quite long. In the future, we can loosen its bonds for a few hours each day. I instructed the night attendant to confine it to the padded room only when it quiets down until an hour before dawn. Although the poor thing's mind may not appreciate the value of this, its body will enjoy the relaxation. Wait! The unexpected happened again! They are calling me; the patient has escaped once more.
es: August 23. "The unexpected always happens." How well Disraeli knew life. When our bird found the cage open, it did not want to fly, so all our subtle preparations were for nothing. In any case, we have proven one thing: that periods of tranquility last a reasonable amount of time. In the future, we will be able to loosen the restrictions a bit for a few hours each day. I have given instructions to my night assistant to only lock him in the secure room once he has calmed down, until an hour before sunrise. The poor patient's body will enjoy this benefit, even if his mind cannot appreciate it. Stop! The unexpected! They are calling me: the patient has escaped again.

en: Later.—Another night adventure. Renfield artfully waited until the attendant was entering the room to inspect. Then he dashed out past him and flew down the passage. I sent word for the attendants to follow. Again he went into the grounds of the deserted house, and we found him in the same place, pressed against the old chapel door. When he saw me he became furious, and had not the attendants seized him in time, he would have tried to kill me. As we were holding him a strange thing happened. He suddenly redoubled his efforts, and then as suddenly grew calm. I looked round instinctively, but could see nothing. Then I caught the patient’s eye and followed it, but could trace nothing as it looked into the moonlit sky except a big bat, which was flapping its silent and ghostly way to the west. Bats usually wheel and flit about, but this one seemed to go straight on, as if it knew where it was bound for or had some intention of its own. The patient grew calmer every instant, and presently said:—
vi: • On the same day, a little while later Another adventure tonight. Renfield waited for the warden to enter the room and took advantage of the moment he was busy with something to run quickly into the hallway. I hurriedly ordered the night guards to chase after him. Just like the last time, he headed towards the abandoned house, and we still saw him pushing his whole body against the oak door of the old church. Seeing me arrive with a guard, he went into a frenzy, and if my men hadn't grabbed his hands in time, he might have torn me apart. Surrounded and subdued by us, he became even more ferocious, but shortly after, he suddenly calmed down, which surprised me greatly. I looked around: there was nothing unusual. Following his gaze, I also didn't notice anything unusual in the moonlit sky, except for a large bat fluttering westward like a ghost. I've heard that bats usually fly back and forth in one place, but that bat was different; it seemed to be flying towards a specific destination. Renfield said to us, in a very gentle voice:
tr: Later. - Another night adventure! Renfield skillfully waited for the nurse to enter the room for inspection. Then he quickly passed him and dashed out, flying down the corridor. I told the nurses to go after him. He went to the grounds of the abandoned house again, and we found him pressed against the door of the old chapel in the same place. He got very angry when he saw me; if the nurses hadn't caught him in time, he might have tried to kill me. Something strange happened while the men were holding him. Suddenly, he made twice the effort to escape from our grasp and then immediately calmed down. Instinctively, I looked around, but I saw nothing. Then I caught the patient's gaze and focused on where he was looking; in the great silence, I found nothing but the sky illuminated by the moonlight, with a large bat flapping its wings like a ghost towards the west. Bats usually fly in circles, but this one seemed to be going straight as if it knew where it was going and had a specific purpose. The patient calmed down more with each passing second and finally said:
es: Later. Another night of adventures. Renfield cunningly waited until the attendant was entering the room to inspect. Then, he ran out beside him and flew down the corridor. I sent orders to the attendants to follow him. Again, he went directly to the grounds of the deserted house, and we found him in the same place, leaning against the old chapel door. When he saw me, he became furious, and if the attendants hadn't restrained him in time, he would have tried to kill me. While we were holding him, a strange thing happened. Suddenly, he redoubled his efforts, and then, just as suddenly, he regained his calm. I instinctively looked around, but I couldn't see anything. Then I caught the patient's eye and followed it, but I couldn't discover anything while looking at the moonlit sky, except for a large bat, flapping in its silent and ghostly journey towards the west. Bats usually circle indecisively, but this one seemed to go straight, as if it knew where it was heading or as if it had its own intentions. The patient calmed down more, and after a while, he said:

en: “You needn’t tie me; I shall go quietly!” Without trouble we came back to the house. I feel there is something ominous in his calm, and shall not forget this night....
vi: — You don't need to hold me so tightly, I can go back on my own, just calm down! It is true that we returned without encountering any trouble, but the sudden and inexplicable silence of the patient did not convey anything that could reassure me, and I should not forget what just happened.
tr: "You don't need to tie me up; I'll go quietly!" We returned home without any trouble. I feel that there is something unsettling in his calmness, and I will never forget this night.
es: –You don't need to tie me up; I'll follow you calmly. Without any other mishap, we returned to the house. I feel that there is something threatening in its calm, and I will not forget this night...

en: Lucy Westenra’s Diary
vi: Lucy Westenra's diary
tr: Lucy Westenra's diary
es: From the diary of Lucy Westenra

en: Hillingham, 24 August.—I must imitate Mina, and keep writing things down. Then we can have long talks when we do meet. I wonder when it will be. I wish she were with me again, for I feel so unhappy. Last night I seemed to be dreaming again just as I was at Whitby. Perhaps it is the change of air, or getting home again. It is all dark and horrid to me, for I can remember nothing; but I am full of vague fear, and I feel so weak and worn out. When Arthur came to lunch he looked quite grieved when he saw me, and I hadn’t the spirit to try to be cheerful. I wonder if I could sleep in mother’s room to-night. I shall make an excuse and try.
vi: • Hillingham, August 24 I also intended to sit down and write a diary like Mina, so that when we meet again, we can sit and talk at length about everything I have recorded here. But when will we meet again? I wish Mina were here right now, because I am feeling very sad! Last night, I had the feeling that I was about to repeat the dreams I had in Whitby, maybe because of the weather change, or maybe because of my return home... The most terrible thing is that I don't remember anything at all. Moreover, I always feel scared, a vague fear that I don't understand why. I am becoming weaker and thinner every day. When he came to have lunch with us, Arthur seemed very sad when he looked at me. I am so tired that I can't even try to be cheerful. I wondered if I would have to sleep in the same room with my mother tonight. I hope I will have a good night's sleep there. I will find a reason to ask my mother's permission.
tr: Hillingham, 24 August. - I should emulate Mina and write down what has happened. That way, we can talk at length when we meet. I wonder when we will meet. I wish she were by my side again, because I feel very unhappy. I think I had a dream again last night, just like in Whitby. Maybe it's because of the change in weather or because we have returned home again. Everything is very dark and frightening for me, because I can't remember anything, but I am gripped by an inexplicable fear; I feel very weak and exhausted. Arthur was quite upset when he saw me at lunch, but I had no strength to try to cheer up. I wonder if I can sleep in my mother's room tonight? I must come up with an excuse and try to sleep in my mother's room.
es: Hillingham, August 24th. I must imitate Mina and write things down in a book. That way, when we see each other we can have long talks. I wonder when that will be. I wish she were here with me again, for I feel so unhappy. Last night it seemed I was dreaming again like in Whitby. Perhaps it is the change of climate, or the fact that I am home again. Everything is dark and dreadful to me, for I cannot remember anything; but I am filled with a vague fear, and I feel weak and exhausted. When Arthur came to dinner he looked quite worried upon seeing me, and I did not have the spirit to try to appear cheerful. I wonder if I might sleep in mother's room tonight. I will invent an excuse and try...

en: 25 August.—Another bad night. Mother did not seem to take to my proposal. She seems not too well herself, and doubtless she fears to worry me. I tried to keep awake, and succeeded for a while; but when the clock struck twelve it waked me from a doze, so I must have been falling asleep. There was a sort of scratching or flapping at the window, but I did not mind it, and as I remember no more, I suppose I must then have fallen asleep. More bad dreams. I wish I could remember them. This morning I am horribly weak. My face is ghastly pale, and my throat pains me. It must be something wrong with my lungs, for I don’t seem ever to get air enough. I shall try to cheer up when Arthur comes, or else I know he will be miserable to see me so.
vi: • August 25 Another terrible night. My suggestion seemed to have not pleased my mother. She herself was not feeling very well. Moreover, she was probably afraid of disturbing my sleep if we shared a room. So I still had to sleep in my own room, and in fact, I did get some sleep, but the long chime at midnight woke me up. I suddenly heard strange sounds like someone scratching at the door, or rather the flapping of wings. But I didn't wonder about it for long, and honestly, I don't remember anything else. I went back to sleep right after that. Again, nightmares. If only I could remember everything... In the morning, I felt terribly weak. My face was as pale as someone about to enter the grave, and I also felt pain in my neck... it seemed like there was a problem with my chest too, occasionally I found it very hard to breathe. But no matter what, I still tried to appear a bit cheerful in front of Arthur, otherwise, he would be very sad again.
tr: August 25. - Another bad night. My mother seemed unwilling to accept my offer. She doesn't look very well herself and undoubtedly fears worrying me. I tried to stay awake and managed to do so for a while; when the clock struck twelve, it woke me from my sleep, so I must have fallen asleep. There was a kind of scratching or flapping sound at the window, but I didn't pay any attention to it; I don't remember anything else, I think I must have fallen asleep at that moment. Nightmares again. I wish I could remember them. This morning, I am terribly weak. My face is deathly pale and my throat hurts. There must be something wrong with my lungs because it feels like I'm not getting enough air. I'll try to cheer up when Arthur arrives, otherwise, I know he'll be devastated to see me like this.
es: August 25. Another bad night. My mother didn't seem to fall for my proposal. She herself doesn't seem to be doing so well, and there's no doubt that she worries a lot about me. I tried to stay awake, and for a while I managed; but when the clock struck twelve, it woke me from a stupor, so I must have been dozing off. There were some kind of flapping and scratching at the window, but I didn't pay them any mind, and since I don't remember what happened next, I suppose I must have fallen asleep. More nightmares. How I wish I could remember them! This morning I felt terribly weak. My face is extremely pale, and my throat hurts. Something must be wrong with my lungs, as it seems I never inhale enough air. I will try to appear cheerful when Arthur arrives, because otherwise I know he will suffer greatly seeing me like this.

en: Letter, Arthur Holmwood to Dr. Seward.
vi: Letter from Arthur Holmwood to Dr. Seward
tr: From Arthur Holmwood Dr. Seward's letter
es: Letter from Arthur Holmwood to Doctor Seward

en: “Albemarle Hotel, 31 August.
vi: "Albemarle Hotel, August 31"
tr: Albemarle Hotel, August 31
es: Hotel Albemarle, August 31

en: “My dear Jack,—
vi: "Albemarle Hotel, August 31"
tr: Dear Jack,
es: "My dear Jack:

en: “I want you to do me a favour. Lucy is ill; that is, she has no special disease, but she looks awful, and is getting worse every day. I have asked her if there is any cause; I do not dare to ask her mother, for to disturb the poor lady’s mind about her daughter in her present state of health would be fatal. Mrs. Westenra has confided to me that her doom is spoken—disease of the heart—though poor Lucy does not know it yet. I am sure that there is something preying on my dear girl’s mind. I am almost distracted when I think of her; to look at her gives me a pang. I told her I should ask you to see her, and though she demurred at first—I know why, old fellow—she finally consented. It will be a painful task for you, I know, old friend, but it is for her sake, and I must not hesitate to ask, or you to act. You are to come to lunch at Hillingham to-morrow, two o’clock, so as not to arouse any suspicion in Mrs. Westenra, and after lunch Lucy will take an opportunity of being alone with you. I shall come in for tea, and we can go away together; I am filled with anxiety, and want to consult with you alone as soon as I can after you have seen her. Do not fail!
vi: I want to ask you a favor. Lucy is falling ill, not with a specific disease, but with some kind of illness that is really hard to identify. Her health is deteriorating day by day, making me unable to stop worrying. Mrs. Westenra confided in me that she doesn't have much longer to live, but Lucy is still unaware of this. I don't know how Lucy will endure in her current health condition. I am certain that my poor fiancée, despite always telling me otherwise, is still secretly hiding something that I cannot know. I must reiterate that I am very worried. Everything is so vague. Seeing her at this moment is truly a pain for me. I suggested that you come to check on her, and finally, she has agreed. It might be really hard for you, but Lucy's health is a very important issue. We must act quickly, for her health cannot be delayed another day, am I right, my friend? Can you come? This way, we won't arouse any suspicion from Mrs. Westenra: after lunch, as previously arranged, Lucy will spend some time alone with you. For the last time, I must reiterate that I am worried to the point of madness, and I am very anxious to know what your conclusion will be regarding her condition. Please come immediately!
tr: I want you to do me a favor. Lucy is ill; that is, she doesn't have a specific illness, but she looks terrible and is getting worse every day. I asked her if there was a reason for this; I don't dare ask her mother because worrying the poor lady about her daughter could be fatal given her current condition. Ms. Westenra told me that poor Lucy doesn't know yet, but her end is near due to heart disease. I'm sure there's something eating away at my beloved. I go crazy thinking about her; it pains me to look at her. I told her I would ask you to see her; although she initially resisted - I know why, my old friend - she eventually agreed. I know it will be a bothersome task for you, my old friend, but it's for her own good, and neither of us should hesitate to do this. Tomorrow, to avoid arousing Ms. Westenra's suspicion, you will have lunch at Hillingham at two o'clock, and after lunch, Lucy will have the opportunity to be alone with you. I will come for tea, and we can leave together; I am very worried and want to talk to you alone as soon as possible after you see her. Please don't neglect this!
es: "I want you to do me a favor. Lucy is sick; that is, she doesn't have any specific illness, but she looks sickly and is getting worse every day. I have asked her if there is any cause; I don't dare to ask her mother, as disturbing the poor lady's mind about her daughter would be fatal, since her own health is very poor. Mrs. Westenra has confided in me that her fate is already sealed (heart disease), although poor Lucy still doesn't know. I am sure that something is influencing the mind of my beloved fiancée. When I think of her, I almost get distracted; looking at her always gives me a start. I told her that I would ask you to see her, and although at first she had some reservations, I know why, old friend, she finally gave her consent. It will be a painful task for you, I know, old friend, but it is for her good, and I must not hesitate to ask you, nor you to act. You can come to lunch at Hillingham tomorrow at two, so that Mrs. Westenra doesn't suspect anything, and after lunch, Lucy will find an opportunity to be alone with you. I will come at tea time, and we can leave together; I am full of anxiety, and I would like to talk to you alone as soon as you have seen her. Don't miss it!

tr: ARTHUR
es: ARTHUR

en: “Am summoned to see my father, who is worse. Am writing. Write me fully by to-night’s post to Ring. Wire me if necessary.”

es: They call me to see my father, who has worsened. I write. Write to me in detail by night mail to Ring. Call if necessary.

es: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood

en: “2 September.
vi: "September 2"
tr: 2 September
es: September 2

en: “My dear old fellow,—
vi: Hello dear friend.
tr: Dear old friend,
es: "My dear old friend:

en: “With regard to Miss Westenra’s health I hasten to let you know at once that in my opinion there is not any functional disturbance or any malady that I know of. At the same time, I am not by any means satisfied with her appearance; she is woefully different from what she was when I saw her last. Of course you must bear in mind that I did not have full opportunity of examination such as I should wish; our very friendship makes a little difficulty which not even medical science or custom can bridge over. I had better tell you exactly what happened, leaving you to draw, in a measure, your own conclusions. I shall then say what I have done and propose doing.
vi: I must tell you right away that, in my opinion, Lucy Westenra is not suffering from any illness or functional disorder. However, I was truly shocked when I saw her. Good Lord! Lucy now is not the same Lucy I met the last time. Of course, I do not forget that I was unable to examine her as I had hoped: our friendship made the examination more difficult and delicate. I will tell you in detail about this visit, and from my explanations, you can draw your own conclusions. Therefore, I will only recount to you what I have done and what I am planning to do at this moment.
tr: I can quickly tell you about Miss Westenra's health that, in my opinion, there is no functional disorder or any disease that I know of. However, I was not at all pleased with her appearance; she looks distressingly changed compared to the last time I saw her. Of course, you must take into account that I did not have the opportunity for a thorough examination as I would have liked; our friendship creates a difficulty that neither medical science nor traditions can overcome. The best thing is for me to tell you exactly what happened so that you can come to your own conclusions to some extent. Then I will tell you what I did and what I suggest should be done.
es: "Regarding Miss Westenra's health, I hasten to tell you immediately that in my opinion there is no functional disorder or disease that I am aware of. At the same time, I cannot in any way consider myself satisfied with her appearance; it is totally different from what it was the last time I saw her. Of course, you must keep in mind that I did not have the opportunity to conduct a thorough examination as I would have liked; our very friendship poses a small difficulty here that neither medical science nor custom can overcome. The best thing will be for me to tell you exactly what happened, leaving you free to draw your own conclusions to a certain extent. Then I will tell you what I have done and what I intend to do.

en: “I found Miss Westenra in seemingly gay spirits. Her mother was present, and in a few seconds I made up my mind that she was trying all she knew to mislead her mother and prevent her from being anxious. I have no doubt she guesses, if she does not know, what need of caution there is. We lunched alone, and as we all exerted ourselves to be cheerful, we got, as some kind of reward for our labours, some real cheerfulness amongst us. Then Mrs. Westenra went to lie down, and Lucy was left with me. We went into her boudoir, and till we got there her gaiety remained, for the servants were coming and going. As soon as the door was closed, however, the mask fell from her face, and she sank down into a chair with a great sigh, and hid her eyes with her hand. When I saw that her high spirits had failed, I at once took advantage of her reaction to make a diagnosis. She said to me very sweetly:—
vi: Seeing me arrive at Hillingham, Lucy appeared very cheerful and innocent. Her mother also stood close to her, and it didn't take me long to realize that she couldn't hide her condition forever with the hope of not causing her daughter anxiety and distress. Mrs. Westenra's caution was indeed necessary, but I still believed that at some point, her daughter would figure out her health condition, even if no one told her. I had lunch with the family, and without saying a word, all three of us silently tried to appear cheerful and carefree. These efforts were well rewarded: we genuinely had fun for at least an hour. Afterward, Mrs. Westenra said she wanted to rest, leaving me alone with Lucy. Until we moved to the living room to talk, Lucy kept up a cheerful demeanor, as the servants were constantly coming and going. But as soon as the door closed, she collapsed into a chair, covering her face with her hands and sighing. She could no longer keep up the act. I had to ask why she was sighing.
tr: I found Miss Westenra seemingly cheerful. Her mother was there, and after a few seconds, I concluded that she was doing everything to deceive her mother and prevent her from worrying. Although she wasn't sure what it was, I have no doubt that she sensed precautions needed to be taken. We had lunch alone, and while we all strove to cheer up, our efforts were somewhat rewarded, and a bit of genuine joy emerged among us. Then Miss Westenra went to lie down, and Lucy stayed with me. We went to Lucy's room; her cheerfulness lasted until we entered the room because the servants were coming and going. But as soon as the door closed, the mask on her face fell, and with a deep sigh, she collapsed into a chair and covered her eyes with her hands. Seeing her mood change, I immediately took the opportunity to diagnose her reaction. With great kindness, she said:
es: "I found Miss Westenra in quite good spirits. Her mother was present, and within a few seconds, I realized that she was trying by all means to deceive her mother, and thus spare her any anxieties. I have no doubt that she guesses, if she does not know, that there is a need for caution. We dined alone, and as we endeavored to appear cheerful, we achieved, as a sort of reward for our efforts, some real cheerfulness between us. Then, Mrs. Westenra retired to rest, and Lucy stayed with me. We went to her boudoir, and until we got there, her reserve did not change, as the servants were coming and going. However, as soon as the door closed, the mask fell from his face, and he sank into an armchair with a great sigh, hiding his eyes with his hand. When I saw that his animosity had failed, I immediately took advantage of his reaction to make a diagnosis. He told me very sweetly:

en: “‘I cannot tell you how I loathe talking about myself.’ I reminded her that a doctor’s confidence was sacred, but that you were grievously anxious about her. She caught on to my meaning at once, and settled that matter in a word. ‘Tell Arthur everything you choose. I do not care for myself, but all for him!’ So I am quite free.
vi: — If only I had known you didn't like talking about yourself, I wouldn't have asked that - She exclaimed. I have to tell her that there is nothing to worry about when confiding all her concerns to a doctor; however, I also admit that he is very worried about her. She immediately grasped the situation, and with just a few words, I was able to freely start a conversation: — You can tell Arthur everything you want to say. If I have any worries, it's not for myself, but for him! That is why I have to tell you my thoughts.
tr: “I can't tell you how much I hate talking about myself." I reminded her that doctor-patient confidentiality is sacred, but that you were becoming increasingly worried about her with each passing day. She immediately understood what I meant and summarized the matter in a single word: “Tell Arthur whatever you want. I'm not thinking about myself, only him!” That's why I'm quite free.
es: "I cannot tell you how much I detest having to talk to you about myself." "I reminded her that a doctor's confidences were sacred, but that you were truly very anxious about her. She immediately grasped the meaning of my words and settled the whole matter with a couple of words. "Tell Arthur anything you think is appropriate. I don't worry about myself, but about him! "Therefore, I have the freedom to speak."

en: “I could easily see that she is somewhat bloodless, but I could not see the usual anæmic signs, and by a chance I was actually able to test the quality of her blood, for in opening a window which was stiff a cord gave way, and she cut her hand slightly with broken glass. It was a slight matter in itself, but it gave me an evident chance, and I secured a few drops of the blood and have analysed them. The qualitative analysis gives a quite normal condition, and shows, I should infer, in itself a vigorous state of health. In other physical matters I was quite satisfied that there is no need for anxiety; but as there must be a cause somewhere, I have come to the conclusion that it must be something mental. She complains of difficulty in breathing satisfactorily at times, and of heavy, lethargic sleep, with dreams that frighten her, but regarding which she can remember nothing. She says that as a child she used to walk in her sleep, and that when in Whitby the habit came back, and that once she walked out in the night and went to East Cliff, where Miss Murray found her; but she assures me that of late the habit has not returned. I am in doubt, and so have done the best thing I know of; I have written to my old friend and master, Professor Van Helsing, of Amsterdam, who knows as much about obscure diseases as any one in the world. I have asked him to come over, and as you told me that all things were to be at your charge, I have mentioned to him who you are and your relations to Miss Westenra. This, my dear fellow, is in obedience to your wishes, for I am only too proud and happy to do anything I can for her. Van Helsing would, I know, do anything for me for a personal reason, so, no matter on what ground he comes, we must accept his wishes. He is a seemingly arbitrary man, but this is because he knows what he is talking about better than any one else. He is a philosopher and a metaphysician, and one of the most advanced scientists of his day; and he has, I believe, an absolutely open mind. This, with an iron nerve, a temper of the ice-brook, an indomitable resolution, self-command, and toleration exalted from virtues to blessings, and the kindliest and truest heart that beats—these form his equipment for the noble work that he is doing for mankind—work both in theory and practice, for his views are as wide as his all-embracing sympathy. I tell you these facts that you may know why I have such confidence in him. I have asked him to come at once. I shall see Miss Westenra to-morrow again. She is to meet me at the Stores, so that I may not alarm her mother by too early a repetition of my call.
vi: I immediately noticed that Lucy was suffering from anemia, although she showed no specific signs of the disease. Moreover, by chance, I was able to check her blood levels because she had a slight injury when opening the window. Of course, it was nothing serious, but it was enough for me to take a few drops of blood for analysis. The test results were very good. On the other hand, I did not see any worrying symptoms. However, when this anemia clearly stems from a specific cause, it must be due to some mental instability. Lucy also complained of shortness of breath and heavy, laborious sleep, similar to a stupor, often accompanied by terrible nightmares that her memory did not record any specific details of. Lucy told me that as a child, she suffered from sleepwalking, and this summer in Whitby, the condition clung to her again. One night, still in a sleepwalking state, she left the hotel and climbed a steep cliff where Mina Murray found her. However, she reassured me that she has had peaceful nights recently. Not being very knowledgeable about this type of pathology, I did what I thought was best: I wrote to my old friend and mentor, Professor Van Helsing, a master expert on similar diseases in Amsterdam. I asked Van Helsing to visit Lucy, and as he mentioned in his letter to me, he would cover all the costs of the trip, as I had told him that you are Lucy's fiancé. Anyway, I want to help Lucy to the best of my ability. As for Van Helsing, I am sure he will do his utmost for me. Therefore, when the professor arrives, we should follow his decisions. In some situations, the professor may appear authoritarian, but he truly knows what he is talking about, so please do not be obstinate. Van Helsing is both a philosopher and a metaphysician - he deserves to be one of the greatest scholars of our time. Therefore, I believe he will have an open mind to all possibilities. Moreover, the professor has nerves of steel, a resolute character, an iron will that always sees things through, a commendable self-discipline, and finally, an infinite kindness. These are the admirable qualities of the professor, a man who dedicates himself wholeheartedly to his humanitarian mission. I say this so that you can understand why I trust this professor so much. I have asked him to temporarily stop all work at home. Tomorrow, I will visit Lucy Westenra again, but not at her home, because I do not want my frequent visits to worry her mother.
tr: I could easily see that she was somewhat anemic, but there were no usual signs of anemia; by chance, I was able to measure the quality of her blood because a wire snapped while opening a stuck window and she slightly cut her hand with the broken glass. In itself, it was a trivial thing, but it gave me a clear opportunity, and I took a few drops of blood and examined them. The qualitative examination yielded quite normal results, and according to this conclusion, her health seems quite good. I was convinced that there was no need to worry about other physical matters; but since there must be a cause for this problem somewhere, I concluded that it must be mental. She complained that from time to time she had difficulty getting enough breath and that she had heavy, deep sleeps filled with dreams that frightened her, but she remembered nothing afterward. She says she had a habit of sleepwalking as a child, that this habit reappeared while she was in Whitby, and one night she went out in her sleep to East Cliff and Miss Murray found her there; but she emphasizes that this old habit has not recurred recently. I am skeptical of this and did the best thing that came to my mind; I wrote to my old friend and mentor, Professor Van Helsing of Amsterdam, who knows more about obscure diseases than anyone else in the world. I asked him to come here, and since you said you would cover everything, I told him who you are and what your connection is with Miss Westenra. I did this in accordance with your wishes, my dear friend, because I would take great pride and happiness in doing anything for Miss Westenra. For a personal reason, I know that Van Helsing would do anything for me. Therefore, whatever reason he comes here for, we must accept his wishes. He may seem like someone who does whatever he pleases, but this is because he knows what he is talking about better than anyone else. He is a philosopher, a metaphysician, one of the best scientists of his time, and I believe he is entirely open-minded. Besides these, his iron nerves, nature resembling a river of ice, unyielding determination, self-control, and tolerance, his extremely fine and honest heart - these are the tools of his noble work for humanity - all these work both in theory and practice, because his views are as broad as his all-encompassing love. I am telling you these facts so that you can understand why I trust him so much. I wanted him to come here immediately. I will see Miss Westenra again tomorrow. She will meet me at Harrod's so as not to alarm her mother by repeating my visit so early.
es: "I could easily tell that she is a bit low on blood, but I couldn't see the typical symptoms of anemia, and by chance, I actually had the opportunity to test the quality of her blood, because when opening a window that was nailed shut, a cord broke and she slightly cut her hand on the broken glass. In itself, it was an insignificant event, but it gave me an obvious opportunity, so I took a few drops of blood and analyzed them. The qualitative analysis shows that there are normal conditions, and moreover, I can infer, they indicate the existence of a vigorous state of health. In other physical matters, I was fully convinced that there is no need to fear; but since there must be a cause somewhere, I have come to the conclusion that it must be something mental. She complains of sometimes having difficulty breathing, and of having heavy, lethargic dreams with nightmares that frighten her, but which she cannot remember. She says that as a child she used to sleepwalk, and that while in Whitby the habit returned, and that once she walked out at night and went to East Cliff, where Miss Murray found her; but she assures me that lately this habit has disappeared again. I have been left with doubts, so I have done the best I know: I have written to my old friend and teacher, Professor Van Helsing, from Amsterdam, who is one of the most knowledgeable people about rare diseases in the world. I have asked him to come, and as you told me that all these things would be under your charge, I have mentioned you and your relationship with Miss Westenra. This, my old friend, is in deference to your wishes, for I feel too proud and too happy to be able to do whatever I can for her. I know that Van Helsing will do anything for me for a personal reason, so it doesn't matter why he comes, we must accept his wishes. He is an apparently very arbitrary man, but this is because he knows what he is talking about more than anyone else. He is a philosopher and a metaphysician, and one of the most advanced scientists of our time; and he has, I suppose, an absolutely open mind. This, with nerves of steel, a cool temperament, an indomitable resolution, self-control, and an exalted tolerance of virtues and blessings, and the kindest of the most sincere hearts that beat, form his equipment for the noble task he is performing for humanity, working both in theory and practice, for his vision is as broad as his sympathy. I tell you this so that you can know why I have so much confidence in him. I have asked him to come immediately. Tomorrow I will see Miss Westenra again. We will meet in the city, so that I do not alarm her mother with my visit.

en: “Yours always,
vi: Wishing you all the best.
tr: With my love
es: "Your friend,

en: “John Seward.”
vi: John Seward.
tr: JOHN SEWARD
es: JOHN SEWARD

vi: Professor Abraham Van Helsing's letter to Dr. Seward
