en: “2 September.
vi: “September 2nd”
tr: 2 September
es: September 3

en: “My good Friend,—
vi: Dear friend,
tr: Dear Friend,
es: "My good friend:

en: “When I have received your letter I am already coming to you. By good fortune I can leave just at once, without wrong to any of those who have trusted me. Were fortune other, then it were bad for those who have trusted, for I come to my friend when he call me to aid those he holds dear. Tell your friend that when that time you suck from my wound so swiftly the poison of the gangrene from that knife that our other friend, too nervous, let slip, you did more for him when he wants my aids and you call for them than all his great fortune could do. But it is pleasure added to do for him, your friend; it is to you that I come. Have then rooms for me at the Great Eastern Hotel, so that I may be near to hand, and please it so arrange that we may see the young lady not too late on to-morrow, for it is likely that I may have to return here that night. But if need be I shall come again in three days, and stay longer if it must. Till then good-bye, my friend John.
vi: I have received your letter and of course I will come! I can come immediately without encountering any obstacles, none of my patients need me for the next day or two. I would feel very sorry for them if something unexpected happened, but truly nothing can prevent me from helping those considered the closest. Helping a close friend of yours is indeed a great honor for me. Don't worry about the money. Please book me a room at the Grand Phuong Dong Hotel near the patient's residence, and inform that young lady that we will visit her tomorrow morning, as I might have to return here tomorrow evening. But if that happens, I will return to London in three days and then, I can stay longer. Goodbye, my friend!
tr: When I received your letter, I was already preparing to come to you. By chance, I can set off immediately without wronging any of the people who trust me. If luck had been otherwise, it would have been bad for the people who trust me because, my friend, I go when someone who values certain people asks for my help. Tell your friend that when you quickly sucked the gangrene poison from my wound, which was transferred from that scalpel slipped by our other overly nervous friend, you did more for me than you need my help now, and if luck favors them, you did more than I could ever do for them. But for him, for your friend, doing something is an added happiness for me; I am coming for you. Then arrange rooms for me at the Great Eastern Hotel, so I will be nearby, and please arrange for me to see the young lady before it gets too late tomorrow, because I may need to return here that night. But if necessary, I will come again within three days and stay longer if required. Until that day, farewell, my dear friend John.
es: "When I received your letter, I was already on my way to you." "Fortunately, I can leave immediately, without harm to any of those who have trusted me." If the circumstances were different, it would be detrimental to those who have trusted me, for I go to my friend when he calls me to help those he cares about. Tell your friend that when you quickly sucked the venom of gangrene from my wound caused by that knife that our other friend, so nervous, let slip, you did more for him when he wants my help and you request it, than all that his great fortune can do. But it is a double pleasure to do it for him, your friend; and towards you I go. Have it ready, and please arrange it so, that we can see the young lady not so late tomorrow, for it is likely that I will have to return here that night. But if there is a need, I will return again three days later, and I will stay longer if necessary. Until then, my good friend John, goodbye.

en: “Van Helsing.”
vi: Van Helsing.
tr: VAN HELSING
es: VAN HELSING "

en: Letter, Dr. Seward to Hon. Arthur Holmwood.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: Respectfully from Dr. Seward Arthur Holmwood's letter
es: Letter from Dr. Seward to the Honorable Arthur Holmwood

en: “3 September.
vi: "September 3rd"
tr: September 3
es: September 3

en: “My dear Art,—
vi: Dear Arthur,
tr: Dear Art,
es: "Dear Art:

en: “Van Helsing has come and gone. He came on with me to Hillingham, and found that, by Lucy’s discretion, her mother was lunching out, so that we were alone with her. Van Helsing made a very careful examination of the patient. He is to report to me, and I shall advise you, for of course I was not present all the time. He is, I fear, much concerned, but says he must think. When I told him of our friendship and how you trust to me in the matter, he said: ‘You must tell him all you think. Tell him what I think, if you can guess it, if you will. Nay, I am not jesting. This is no jest, but life and death, perhaps more.’ I asked what he meant by that, for he was very serious. This was when we had come back to town, and he was having a cup of tea before starting on his return to Amsterdam. He would not give me any further clue. You must not be angry with me, Art, because his very reticence means that all his brains are working for her good. He will speak plainly enough when the time comes, be sure. So I told him I would simply write an account of our visit, just as if I were doing a descriptive special article for The Daily Telegraph. He seemed not to notice, but remarked that the smuts in London were not quite so bad as they used to be when he was a student here. I am to get his report to-morrow if he can possibly make it. In any case I am to have a letter.
vi: Van Helsing has come and gone again. He accompanied me to Hillingham. Mrs. Westenra went out for lunch, so it was just us with Lucy. Van Helsing examined her very seriously and thoroughly. He recounted to me the results of his diagnosis, as I was not present for the entire examination. He seemed very worried because he had not yet accurately diagnosed Lucy's illness; he told me that he needed to think and further investigate her condition. When I spoke about our friendship and the trust he had placed in me regarding Lucy's examination and treatment, Van Helsing replied to me: “You must absolutely keep secret what you are thinking, and everything I am thinking if you can guess my thoughts. I am not joking; this is a matter of life and death, and it could involve other serious issues as well... Hearing Van Helsing's serious tone on the way back to the city, I was compelled to ask more questions, but he still refused to explain further. Arthur, please don't blame me! Professor Van Helsing's silence indicates that he is thinking a lot about the patient and is meticulously studying this case with all his scientific knowledge. Please believe that the professor will explain more clearly when you know everything you need to know. That's why I had to tell the professor that I would limit what I say about this medical visit to you, Arthur. Maybe tomorrow I will receive the professor's conclusion. Anyway, I am anxiously waiting for a letter.
tr: Van Helsing came and went. He came with me to Hillingham, and thanks to Lucy’s cleverness, we saw that her mother was out for lunch so that we could be alone with her. Van Helsing examined the patient very carefully. He will inform me, and I will tell you, because of course, I was not always with them. I fear Van Helsing is very worried, but he believes he needs to think. When I told him about our friendship and how you trust me on this matter, he said: “You should tell her everything you think. If you can guess, you can also tell her what I think, if you wish. No, I am not joking. This is not a joke; it is a matter of life and death, perhaps even more.” I asked him what he meant by that because he was very serious. This conversation happened when we returned to town, while Van Helsing was having a cup of tea before setting off for Amsterdam. He gave me no other clues. You must not be angry with him, Art, because his silence means his mind is working for Miss Westenra’s well-being. Undoubtedly, he will speak clearly enough when the time comes. So I told him I would write an account of our visit as if I were writing a special descriptive article for the Daily Telegraph. He seemed not to notice, but he remarked that the fog in London was not as bad as it was during his student years here. If he can prepare it, I will get his report tomorrow. In any case, I will get a letter from him.
es: "Van Helsing came and went. He went with me to Hillingham, and I found that, by Lucy's discretion, her mother had been invited out to dinner, so we were left alone with her. Van Helsing conducted a very thorough examination of the patient. He agreed to communicate it to me, and I will advise you, since of course I was not present. He is, I fear, very worried, but he told me he needed to reflect. When I told him about our friendship and how you had confided the matter to me, he said: 'You must tell him everything you think. Tell him what I think, if you can guess, and you will guess. No; I am not joking. This is no joke, but life and death; perhaps more.' I asked him what he meant by that, as he was very serious. This happened when we had already returned to the city, and he was having a cup of tea before starting his return to Amsterdam. He did not give me any more clues. You must not be angry with me, Art, because his very reticence means that his entire brain is working for her good. You can be sure that, in due time, he will speak with complete clarity. So I told him I would simply write a record of our visit, just as if I were doing a special descriptive article for the Daily Telegraph. He seemed not to take note of it, and only commented that the soot of London was not as bad as it used to be when he was a student here. I will receive his report tomorrow, if he has time to do it. In any case, I will receive a letter.

en: “Well, as to the visit. Lucy was more cheerful than on the day I first saw her, and certainly looked better. She had lost something of the ghastly look that so upset you, and her breathing was normal. She was very sweet to the professor (as she always is), and tried to make him feel at ease; though I could see that the poor girl was making a hard struggle for it. I believe Van Helsing saw it, too, for I saw the quick look under his bushy brows that I knew of old. Then he began to chat of all things except ourselves and diseases and with such an infinite geniality that I could see poor Lucy’s pretense of animation merge into reality. Then, without any seeming change, he brought the conversation gently round to his visit, and suavely said:—
vi: And now it is the visit of our teacher and us. Lucy seems happier than the previous day, and her complexion also looks better. She no longer looks with the eyes that used to make him fearful, and her breathing has returned to normal. To the professor (as well as to everyone else), she appeared very lovely, and she tried to behave as naturally as possible. However, in my opinion, to be so cheerful, the poor girl must have struggled tremendously with herself. I believe Van Helsing thought the same as I did, because I saw the professor quickly furrow his brow when he looked at her. The professor chatted about various topics, except about ourselves and the patients, because he really wanted to bring true joy to Lucy. And while pretending to continue the flow of conversation, the professor slowly revealed the purpose of his visit:
tr: Yes, regarding the visit: Lucy was more cheerful compared to the first day I saw her and definitely looked better. The pallor that had unsettled you had somewhat faded, and her breathing had returned to normal. She behaved very sweetly towards the Professor (as always) and tried to make him feel comfortable; though, I could see that the poor girl was making a great effort for it. I think Van Helsing saw it too, because I noticed that sharp look I knew from the past under his bushy eyebrows. Then, she started talking about all sorts of topics other than ourselves and illnesses, and she did it with such great cheerfulness that Lucy's feigned liveliness disappeared and turned into reality. Then, without changing her demeanor at all, she gently brought up the topic of his visit and sweetly said:
es: "Well, now, to the visit. Lucy was more cheerful than the day I first saw her, and she certainly seemed much better. She had lost some of that ghostly look that unsettles you so much, and her breathing was normal. She was very sweet with the professor (she always is), and tried to make him feel at ease; however, I could see that the poor girl was making a great effort. I think Van Helsing noticed it too, for under his thick eyebrows I saw that quick look that I know so well. Then, he began to chat about all sorts of things except for us and illnesses, and he did it so cleverly that I could see how Lucy's feigned liveliness turned into reality. Then, without the change being noticeable, my teacher smoothly steered the conversation to the reason for his visit, and said calmly:

en: “‘My dear young miss, I have the so great pleasure because you are so much beloved. That is much, my dear, ever were there that which I do not see. They told me you were down in the spirit, and that you were of a ghastly pale. To them I say: “Pouf!”’ And he snapped his fingers at me and went on: ‘But you and I shall show them how wrong they are. How can he’—and he pointed at me with the same look and gesture as that with which once he pointed me out to his class, on, or rather after, a particular occasion which he never fails to remind me of—‘know anything of a young ladies? He has his madmans to play with, and to bring them back to happiness, and to those that love them. It is much to do, and, oh, but there are rewards, in that we can bestow such happiness. But the young ladies! He has no wife nor daughter, and the young do not tell themselves to the young, but to the old, like me, who have known so many sorrows and the causes of them. So, my dear, we will send him away to smoke the cigarette in the garden, whiles you and I have little talk all to ourselves.’ I took the hint, and strolled about, and presently the professor came to the window and called me in. He looked grave, but said: ‘I have made careful examination, but there is no functional cause. With you I agree that there has been much blood lost; it has been, but is not. But the conditions of her are in no way anæmic. I have asked her to send me her maid, that I may ask just one or two question, that so I may not chance to miss nothing. I know well what she will say. And yet there is cause; there is always cause for everything. I must go back home and think. You must send to me the telegram every day; and if there be cause I shall come again. The disease—for not to be all well is a disease—interest me, and the sweet young dear, she interest me too. She charm me, and for her, if not for you or disease, I come.’
vi: — My dear friend, - the professor began to explain - indeed, I am very honored to visit you, because my friend here wants us to act for a great love. And that is a truly precious sentiment, please believe me! Before coming here, my friend said that you looked very pale and weak. I replied: "Oh dear..." I did not believe what he said. Now you and I will prove to him that he was wrong. How could he - the professor said while looking at and pointing to me exactly the same way he did to me once, when I caused an accident while studying under him, which I still haven't forgotten - how could he possibly understand anything thoroughly about young girls? He should be busy caring for his patients, helping them find happiness, and returning them to their loved ones. The reward for a doctor's efforts like his is seeing the happiness of each patient. As for young girls! He doesn't have a wife, and of course, no daughters either, and young girls never trust young men, they only trust old men, those who have gone through many hardships and bitterness throughout their lives, which even they sometimes haven't fully realized. So, my dear, let him go out to the garden to smoke, and we will sit here and chat about some trivial matters. Knowing the professor's intention, I quietly went outside to walk around the house. But not long after, I heard the professor calling through the window. When we met again, he informed me: — I have examined very thoroughly but still do not see any signs of functional decline. Like you, I think perhaps she lost a lot of blood, I say lost, do you hear me clearly? I say that because she is no longer losing blood now. However, there is something very strange that she does not have any symptoms of anemia. I suggested she call her maid to ask a few questions, and then we will find the most accurate information possible. But in fact, I already know what this maid will answer. Anyway, there must be a cause leading to the pathological state, and there is always only one cause. I will return to Amsterdam to think further. Send me a telegram every day, and if necessary, I will come back here. I call it a disease because no matter what, it is still a disease that I cannot ignore, and even I cannot be indifferent to the charming girl. Yes, she is indeed very charming, lovely, and I would willingly come back just for her, even if you are not here and she is not ill.
tr: “Dear young lady, I am very pleased that you are so loved. Even if there are things I haven't seen, my dear, this is an important matter. They told me that you were feeling unwell and looking pale as a ghost. I say to them, ‘Pshaw!’" Then she snapped her fingers at me and continued: “But you and I will show them how wrong they are. He," and she pointed at me with the look and gesture she used after a particular incident she never failed to remind me of, “what could he know about young ladies? They have fools to play with and bring them back to happiness and love them again. There is much work to do and oh, great rewards of happiness to be found. But young ladies! He has neither wife nor daughter, and young people confide in the elderly like me, who know many sorrows and their causes, not in the young. So, my dear, we will send him to the garden to smoke, and meanwhile, you and I will have a little chat alone.” I took the hint and wandered around; soon the Professor came to the window and called me inside. He looked serious and said: “I have examined very carefully, but there is no functional cause. I agree with you that there has been a great loss of blood; the blood loss happened a long time ago, it is not recent. However, her condition has nothing to do with anemia under any circumstances. To make sure I haven't missed anything, I asked her to send her servant to me to answer a few questions. I know well what the servant will say. Yet there is a reason; there is always a reason for everything. I must go home and think. You must send me a telegram every day; if necessary, I will come again. The illness -for not being well is an illness- interests me, and the dear sweet young lady interests me too. She has fascinated me, and I would come for her sake, if not for yours or the illness.”
es: "My dear young lady, I have this great pleasure because you are charming. That is a lot, dear, even if he whom I do not see were here. They told me you were discouraged, and that you had a ghostly pallor. To them I say: bah! (and he snapped his fingers, adding afterwards): But you and I are going to show them how wrong they are. How can he (he said, and pointed at me with the same look and gesture with which he had once dismissed me from his class, or rather, after that occasion), how can he know anything about young people? He has his madmen with whom he plays, and to whom he returns happiness, along with the happiness of those who love him. It is quite a lot he does, and, oh!, but there are rewards, in the very act of being able to restore that happiness. More so with young ladies! He has no wife or daughter, and young people do not trust the young, but the old like me, who have already known so many pains and their causes. So, dear, we will send him to smoke a cigar in the garden, while you and I have a little confidential chat. "I accepted the suggestion and left the room, until after a while the professor came out the window and asked me to come in. He seemed worried, but said: "I have conducted a thorough examination, but there is no functional cause. I agree with you that there has been a lot of blood loss; there has been, but there is none now. Moreover, the young woman's general condition does not show any symptoms of anemia. I have asked him to send me his maid so that I can ask her a couple of questions, in such a way that there is no chance of missing anything. I know very well what she will say. And yet, there is a cause; there is always a cause for everything. I must return home and think. You must send me the telegram every day; and if there is a reason, I will come again. The illness, for not being completely well is an illness, interests me and she interests me too, the sweet young lady. I adore her, and for her, if not for you, or for the illness, I will come.

en: “As I tell you, he would not say a word more, even when we were alone. And so now, Art, you know all I know. I shall keep stern watch. I trust your poor father is rallying. It must be a terrible thing to you, my dear old fellow, to be placed in such a position between two people who are both so dear to you. I know your idea of duty to your father, and you are right to stick to it; but, if need be, I shall send you word to come at once to Lucy; so do not be over-anxious unless you hear from me.”
vi: Arthur, let me remind you that the professor did not want to talk more to me about that matter, even when it was just the two of us. Up until now, I only know as much as you do, because whatever I know, I have already told you. Please believe that I will always keep an eye on our dear patient. I hope your father's condition will improve. In your position, I would probably find it hard to stand firm: it is truly terrible to know that the two people closest to you are both in critical condition! I fully understand the feelings and duties of a son with a sick father, but if Lucy's condition worsens, I will still write to call you immediately. Therefore, if you do not hear from me, you should not worry too much."
tr: As I told you, he didn't say another single word even when we were alone. So, Art, now you know everything I know. I will observe the situation carefully. I believe your poor father has pulled himself together. It must be a terrible thing for you, my dear old friend, to be caught between two people who are so valuable to you. I know your sense of duty to your father, and you are right to stick to it; but if necessary, I will send word for you to come to Lucy as soon as possible; so, don't worry too much unless you hear from me.
es: "And as I tell you, he didn't want to say more, not even when we were alone. So it is, Art, that now you know everything I know. I will keep a strict watch. I hope your poor father continues to improve. It must be a terrible thing for you, my dear old friend, to be in such a position between two people who are so dear to you. I know your sense of duty towards your father, and you do well to be faithful to it; but if there is a need, I will send you a message to come immediately to where Lucy is; so do not distress yourself too much, unless you hear from me."

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 4 September.—Zoöphagous patient still keeps up our interest in him. He had only one outburst and that was yesterday at an unusual time. Just before the stroke of noon he began to grow restless. The attendant knew the symptoms, and at once summoned aid. Fortunately the men came at a run, and were just in time, for at the stroke of noon he became so violent that it took all their strength to hold him. In about five minutes, however, he began to get more and more quiet, and finally sank into a sort of melancholy, in which state he has remained up to now. The attendant tells me that his screams whilst in the paroxysm were really appalling; I found my hands full when I got in, attending to some of the other patients who were frightened by him. Indeed, I can quite understand the effect, for the sounds disturbed even me, though I was some distance away. It is now after the dinner-hour of the asylum, and as yet my patient sits in a corner brooding, with a dull, sullen, woe-begone look in his face, which seems rather to indicate than to show something directly. I cannot quite understand it.
vi: • September 4 The more I observe my psychiatric patients, the more interesting I find it. Yesterday, he only had one episode. Near noon, he started to go berserk. Recognizing his familiar symptoms, the warden immediately called for assistance. Fortunately, everyone arrived in time; otherwise, we would have had a hard time restraining someone in such a terrible fit of madness like his. But only about five minutes later, he calmed down and, of course, fell into a prolonged state of melancholy again. The warden informed me that just before his episode, he had uttered some terrifying screams. This did not surprise me, as I had grown accustomed to the long, mournful cries in the wild states of some other patients. As I write these lines, it is dinner time for the inpatients, yet Renfield is still sitting with his knees hugged in a corner of the room, his face sorrowful with his own thoughts. I do not think much about his state of mind.
tr: September 4th. - The zoophagous patient still holds our interest. He only had one outburst, and that was at an unusual hour yesterday. He started getting restless just before noon. The nurse recognized the symptoms and immediately called for help. Fortunately, the men came running and arrived just in time, because as the clock struck noon, the patient became so aggressive that they had to use all their strength to restrain him. But within about five minutes, he quieted down and eventually sank into a sort of melancholy that is still ongoing. The nurse says the screams he let out during the seizure were truly horrifying; when I went in, I found I had a lot of work to do, attending to some of the other patients he had frightened. Honestly, I can very well understand the impact it created, because the sounds, even though I was far away, were bothering me too. Dinner time at the mental hospital had passed, and my patient was now sitting in a corner with a dull, sullen, troubled expression that only pointed out things instead of saying anything directly. I can't quite make sense of it.
es: September 4th. My zoophagous patient always keeps me interested. He has only had one attack, and that was yesterday at an unusual hour. Shortly before noon, he began to show signs of restlessness. The attendant recognized the symptoms and immediately called for help. Fortunately, the men arrived running, and just in time, because at noon he became so furious that they had to use all their strength to hold him down. However, after about five minutes he began to calm down gradually, until he finally sank into a kind of melancholy, a state in which he has remained until now. The assistant tells me that his screams, during the paroxysm, were truly chilling; when I entered, I found myself with my hands full, attending to some of the other patients who were frightened by his behavior. In fact, I can quite understand the effect, because the noise of his screams disturbed even me, although I was far away, at a certain distance. We have just finished dinner at the asylum, and yet, my patient is still sitting in a corner muttering, with a gloomy, threatening, and distressing look. His face rather seems to indicate, instead of showing something directly. I cannot quite understand it.

en: Later.—Another change in my patient. At five o’clock I looked in on him, and found him seemingly as happy and contented as he used to be. He was catching flies and eating them, and was keeping note of his capture by making nail-marks on the edge of the door between the ridges of padding. When he saw me, he came over and apologised for his bad conduct, and asked me in a very humble, cringing way to be led back to his own room and to have his note-book again. I thought it well to humour him: so he is back in his room with the window open. He has the sugar of his tea spread out on the window-sill, and is reaping quite a harvest of flies. He is not now eating them, but putting them into a box, as of old, and is already examining the corners of his room to find a spider. I tried to get him to talk about the past few days, for any clue to his thoughts would be of immense help to me; but he would not rise. For a moment or two he looked very sad, and said in a sort of far-away voice, as though saying it rather to himself than to me:—
vi: • A moment later There was a change in the person of my patient. I went back to visit him at 5 o'clock, and it seemed he was very content with his fate. He caught flies and put them in his mouth, chewing voraciously, and each time he caught one, he would mark a line on the door with his fingernail. As soon as he saw me, he hurriedly apologized for his improper behavior and then requested, or rather begged, me to allow him to return to his room, where he could continue his work of recording in his notebook. I thought I had to make him abandon this erratic temperament, so I agreed to his request. He returned to his room and immediately opened the window, then he took a pinch of sugar and sprinkled it on the outer window ledge to catch flies. But this time he caught flies not to put them in his mouth, but to put them in a box as he had done before, and then he went to check all the corners of the room to look for a spider. I tried to probe him to see what he thought about the past days, because even a minimal thread in his thoughts would help me a lot in my work. But indeed, there was no way to draw him out of his silence at this moment. After a while, his sullen face suddenly showed a hint of sadness, and only then did he whisper in a barely audible voice, making me feel as if he was talking to himself rather than to me:
tr: Later. - There has been a new change in my patient. I went to see him at five o'clock and found him happy and content as before. He was catching flies and eating them, and he was keeping a record of his captures by making notches with his fingernail on the protrusions of the door frame. When he saw me, he came up to me and apologized for his bad behavior, and with great respect and obsequiousness, he asked to be taken back to his room and to be allowed to have his notebook back. I thought it would be good to humor him; so, he returned to his room and his window is open. He spread the sugar from his tea on the window sill and is having a good harvest of flies. He is no longer eating them, but is putting them in a box as before, and has already started looking in the corners of his room for spiders. I tried to get him to talk about the last few days, because any clue about his thoughts would be of great help to me; but he did not join me in this conversation. For a second or two, he looked very sad and, in a tone as if he were talking to himself rather than to me, he said:
es: Later. Another change in my patient. At five in the afternoon I went to see him and found him almost as cheerful as he used to be before. He was catching flies and eating them, and keeping track of his catches by making marks with his nails on the edge of the door between the channels of the filling. When he saw me, he approached me and apologized for his bad behavior, and begged me in a very humble and attentive manner to allow him to return to his room again and to give him his notebook. I thought it best to please him; so he is back in his room with the window open. He has spread the sugar from his tea on the window sill, and is once again devoted to his collection of flies. At the moment he is not eating them, but putting them in a box, just like before, and he is already examining the corners of his room to find spiders. I tried to get him to talk about what happened in the last few days, as any clue about his thoughts would be very useful to me, but he did not want to engage in conversation. For a few moments he put on a rather sad expression, and said in a muted voice, as if he were talking to himself rather than to me:

en: “All over! all over! He has deserted me. No hope for me now unless I do it for myself!” Then suddenly turning to me in a resolute way, he said: “Doctor, won’t you be very good to me and let me have a little more sugar? I think it would be good for me.”
vi: — So that's it? Is it really over? He has abandoned me! Now I have nothing left to hope for. So I have to act on my own again. Then he suddenly turned to look at me, his voice becoming more resolute: — Doctor, would you like to show some kindness towards me? Please have someone bring me a little more sugar. I believe that will make me feel much better.
tr: “Everything is over! Everything is over! She left me. If I don't do it myself, there is no hope left for me!” Then suddenly, turning to me decisively, she said: “Doctor, would you do me a great favor and allow me to have a bit more sugar? I think it will do me good.”
es: –Everything is over! Everything is over! He has abandoned me. I have no hope, unless I do it myself! Then, suddenly, turning to me resolutely, he said: –Doctor, would you be so kind as to give me a little more sugar? I think it would do me a lot of good.

en: “And the flies?” I said.
vi: — What about the flies?
tr: “Even for the flies?” I said.
es: –And the flies? – I asked him.

en: “Yes! The flies like it, too, and I like the flies; therefore I like it.” And there are people who know so little as to think that madmen do not argue. I procured him a double supply, and left him as happy a man as, I suppose, any in the world. I wish I could fathom his mind.
vi: — What about the flies? — Of course, flies also love sugar, and I, on the other hand, love flies very much: that's the reason why I like the sweetness of sugar. Yet, there are quite a few foolish people who believe that madmen cannot connect many ideas together in a truly satisfying way! Indeed, he became noticeably happier when I had someone bring him a little more sugar.
tr: “Yes! Flies love it, and I love flies; therefore, I love sugar.” There are people ignorant enough to think that madmen cannot reason. I had him bring twice as much sugar as now, and I think I left him as the happiest man in the world. I wish I could delve into the depths of his mind.
es: –Yes! Flies like it too, and I like flies; therefore, I like it. And to think that there are people so ignorant that they believe a madman has no arguments! I gave him a double portion of sugar and left him happy, as I suppose a man can be happy in this world. I wish I could penetrate his mind.

en: Midnight.—Another change in him. I had been to see Miss Westenra, whom I found much better, and had just returned, and was standing at our own gate looking at the sunset, when once more I heard him yelling. As his room is on this side of the house, I could hear it better than in the morning. It was a shock to me to turn from the wonderful smoky beauty of a sunset over London, with its lurid lights and inky shadows and all the marvellous tints that come on foul clouds even as on foul water, and to realise all the grim sternness of my own cold stone building, with its wealth of breathing misery, and my own desolate heart to endure it all. I reached him just as the sun was going down, and from his window saw the red disc sink. As it sank he became less and less frenzied; and just as it dipped he slid from the hands that held him, an inert mass, on the floor. It is wonderful, however, what intellectual recuperative power lunatics have, for within a few minutes he stood up quite calmly and looked around him. I signalled to the attendants not to hold him, for I was anxious to see what he would do. He went straight over to the window and brushed out the crumbs of sugar; then he took his fly-box, and emptied it outside, and threw away the box; then he shut the window, and crossing over, sat down on his bed. All this surprised me, so I asked him: “Are you not going to keep flies any more?”
vi: • Midnight Another change in Renfield's behavior. I had just returned from Lucy's house (her condition has improved) and stopped at the threshold of the asylum, intending to sit for a while to watch the sunset, when I was startled by a scream. It was him again. I felt a bit uneasy and saddened that I could no longer leisurely admire the wondrous sky at sunset casting its golden haze over London, but had to turn back to face the dismal stone walls of the asylum, which cast a hopeless shadow over a wretched soul. I stepped into Renfield's room as the sun was gradually setting outside the window. The patient's madness had subsided for a few minutes, but just as the sun disappeared, he suddenly slipped from the grasp of the person holding him and collapsed to the floor like a felled tree. It was truly surprising to see patients suddenly regain their sanity, even if only fleetingly, for after a few minutes, he stood up again and looked around with a very calm demeanor. I signaled to the attendants to let him act as he wished, because I was very curious to see what would happen. He quickly walked towards the window and swept all the sugar grains off the ledge onto the ground, then he opened the lid of the fly box to let them all fly out before tossing the lid away. Finally, he slammed the window shut and plopped down on the bed. — So you don't need those flies anymore?
tr: Midnight. - Another change in the patient. I had just returned to the hospital after visiting Miss Westenra, whom I found much better, and was standing at our door looking at the sunset when I heard Renfield shouting once again. Since his room is on this side of the building, I could hear him better than in the morning. Turning from the perfect, misty sunset over London, with its red lights, dark shadows, and all those extraordinary hues coming over the ugly clouds and even uglier waters, to the cold, stony rigidity of my building, breathing in the richness of suffering and my lonely heart that would endure it all, shook me. As the sun set, I reached the patient and saw the red orb setting from his window. At the moment the sun set, the patient's madness gradually decreased, and as it completely set, the patient slid to the ground like a heavy lump from the hands holding him. But the mental healing power that mental patients possess is extraordinary, for within a few minutes, he stood up with great calmness and looked around. I signaled the attendants not to hold him, as I was curious to see what he would do. He went directly to the window and swept the sugar crumbs outside; then he took the fly box in his hand, emptied it outside, and threw the box away; then he closed the window, crossed to the other side of the room, and sat on his bed. All this surprised me, so I asked him, "Won't you keep flies anymore?"
es: Midnight. Another change in him. I had gone to visit Miss Westenra, whom I found much better, and had just returned; I was standing at our own gate looking at the sunset when I heard the madman scream. Since his room is on this side of the house, I could hear him better than in the morning. It was a very strong surprise for me, and with displeasure, I turned my gaze away from the wonderful smoky beauty of the sunset over London, with its fantastic lights and purplish shadows, and all the wonderful hues seen in the dirty clouds as well as in the dirty water, to realize the sad austerity of my own cold stone building, with its wealth of breathing miseries, and my own desolate heart that endures it. I reached the patient at the moment the sun was sinking, and from his window, I saw the red disk disappear. As it sank, the patient began to calm down, and as it completely disappeared, he slipped from the hands holding him, like an inert mass, falling to the ground. However, the intellectual recuperative power that lunatics have is wonderful, for after a few minutes he stood up quite calmly and looked around. I signaled to the attendants not to restrain him, as I was anxious to see what he would do. He went directly to the window and cleaned off the remains of the sugar; then he took his box of flies and emptied it outside, subsequently throwing the box away; then he closed the window and, crossing the room, sat on his own bed. All this surprised me, so I asked him: –Aren't you going to keep catching more flies?

en: “No,” said he; “I am sick of all that rubbish!” He certainly is a wonderfully interesting study. I wish I could get some glimpse of his mind or of the cause of his sudden passion. Stop; there may be a clue after all, if we can find why to-day his paroxysms came on at high noon and at sunset. Can it be that there is a malign influence of the sun at periods which affects certain natures—as at times the moon does others? We shall see.
vi: - I asked. — No need, - He replied - I am fed up with those useless bugs! To be honest, I can't understand the reason behind his changes! Please pay attention, everyone! We might find the real cause if we know why his madness reached its peak exactly at noon and then again at sunset today. Should we consider that at certain times, the sun has a malign influence on some living creatures, just as the moon sometimes has a negative impact on other entities? Then we will see...
tr: “No,” he said; “I’m tired of this nonsense!” Definitely an extraordinarily interesting case. I wish I could take a look at his mind or the reason for his sudden madness. Wait; still, if we can find out why his fits occur exactly at noon and sunset today, we might get a clue. Could it be that the sun has a harmful effect on some dispositions - just as the moon affects others from time to time? We shall see.
es: –No -he replied to me-, I am tired of so much garbage! Of course, it is a formidable and interesting case study. I wish I could have a slight insight into his mind, or the causes of his sudden passion. Wait: there may be, after all, a clue, if we can find out why today his paroxysms occurred at noon and not at sunset. Could it be possible that there are malignant influences of the sun at certain periods that affect certain natures, just as the moon affects others? We shall see.

en: “4 September.—Patient still better to-day.”
vi: Telegram from Dr. Seward, London to Professor Van Helsing, Amsterdam
tr: September 4. - The patient is better again today.
es: September 4th. Patient still better today.

en: Telegram, Seward, London, to Van Helsing, Amsterdam.
vi: Telegram from Dr. Seward, London to Professor Van Helsing, Amsterdam
tr: From Seward in London to Amsterdam Telegram to Van Helsing
es: Telegram from Seward, in London, to Van Helsing, in Amsterdam

en: “5 September.—Patient greatly improved. Good appetite; sleeps naturally; good spirits; colour coming back.”
vi: September 4 “Today the patient is much better.” September 5 "The patient is getting better every day. Eating well, sleeping soundly, stable temperament, and their complexion is becoming rosy again."
tr: September 5. - The patient's condition is improving significantly. His appetite has increased; he is sleeping normally; his spirits are high; his color is returning.
es: September 5. Patient much improved. Good appetite; sleeps well; good mood; color returning.

en: Telegram, Seward, London, to Van Helsing, Amsterdam.
vi: Eating well, sleeping soundly, stable temperament, and their complexion is becoming rosy again."
tr: From Seward in London to Amsterdam Telegram to Van Helsing
es: Seward's telegram, in London, to Van Helsing, in Amsterdam

en: “6 September.—Terrible change for the worse. Come at once; do not lose an hour. I hold over telegram to Holmwood till have seen you.”
vi: September 6 "The situation suddenly became very serious." "Professor, please come immediately, do not delay even for an hour."
tr: September 6. - A terrible turn for the worse. Come immediately; do not lose even an hour. I am holding off sending the telegram to Holmwood until I see you.
es: September 6. Terrible change for the worse. Come immediately; do not lose an hour. I will not send a telegram to Holmwood until I see you.

en: CHAPTER X
vi: CHAPTER 10
tr: X
es: X.– LETTER FROM DOCTOR SEWARD TO THE HONORABLE ARTHUR HOLMWOOD

en: Letter, Dr. Seward to Hon. Arthur Holmwood.
vi: Letter from Dr. Seward to Arthur Holmwood
tr: Letter from Dr. Seward to the Honorable Arthur Holmwood
es: X.– LETTER FROM DOCTOR SEWARD TO THE HONORABLE ARTHUR HOLMWOOD

en: “6 September.
vi: “September 6
tr: September 6
es: September 6.

en: “My dear Art,—
vi: Dear friend Arthur,
tr: Dear Art,
es: "My dear Art:

en: “My news to-day is not so good. Lucy this morning had gone back a bit. There is, however, one good thing which has arisen from it; Mrs. Westenra was naturally anxious concerning Lucy, and has consulted me professionally about her. I took advantage of the opportunity, and told her that my old master, Van Helsing, the great specialist, was coming to stay with me, and that I would put her in his charge conjointly with myself; so now we can come and go without alarming her unduly, for a shock to her would mean sudden death, and this, in Lucy’s weak condition, might be disastrous to her. We are hedged in with difficulties, all of us, my poor old fellow; but, please God, we shall come through them all right. If any need I shall write, so that, if you do not hear from me, take it for granted that I am simply waiting for news. In haste
vi: The news I am sending you today is no longer good; Lucy's health condition has worsened. This deterioration is an outcome I dared not hope for. Mrs. Westenra asked me what I thought about Lucy's current state, and I took the opportunity to tell her that my old friend, Professor Van Helsing, had just come to visit me for a few days, and I could ask the professor to examine and treat her daughter. The issue now is that if necessary, we must frequently visit this kind-hearted woman without making her too worried or causing her too much emotion, which could make her collapse. We must also avoid making her aware of Lucy's situation at all costs, as it would be a painful shock that nothing could compensate for. My dear friend, we are facing seemingly insurmountable difficulties. However, with the grace of God, we hope to remain steadfast. Whenever necessary, I will update you further. Therefore, if you do not hear anything more from me, do not be anxious; it simply means that there are no new developments to report. I am in a hurry.
tr: My news today is not very good. This morning, Lucy's condition deteriorated a bit. But this situation had a good outcome: naturally, Ms. Westenra was worried about Lucy and consulted me about her in a professional context. Taking advantage of this opportunity, I told her that my old master, the great master Van Helsing, would be coming to stay with me and that we would take joint responsibility for Lucy; thus, we can come and go without unnecessarily alarming her because a sudden shock could mean her death, and in Lucy's weak condition, such a development could be disastrous for her. We are all surrounded by difficulties, my poor old friend; but with God's permission, we will overcome them. I will write if necessary, that is, if you don't hear from me, just understand that I am waiting for news. With my love
es: "My news today is not very good. This morning Lucy had relapsed a little. However, one good thing has come of it: Mrs. Westenra was naturally anxious about Lucy, and she consulted me professionally about her. I took the opportunity to tell her that my old master, Van Helsing, the great specialist, was going to spend a few days with me, and that I would put Lucy under his care; so now we can come and go without causing her alarm, for a shock to her would mean sudden death, and this, combined with Lucy's weakness, could be disastrous for her. We are all full of tribulations, but, my old friend, God willing, we will be able to endure and overcome them. If there is any need, I will write to you, so if you don't hear from me, you can be sure that I am simply waiting. I am in a hurry.

en: Yours ever,
vi: Wishing good health to Mr. John Seward
tr: With my love
es: Goodbye. Your friend forever,

en: “John Seward.”
vi: Wishing good health to Mr. John Seward
tr: JOHN SEWARD
es: JOHN SEWARD

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 7 September.—The first thing Van Helsing said to me when we met at Liverpool Street was:—
vi: • September 7 When we met on Liverpool Street, the first thing Helsing asked me was:
tr: September 7 - The first thing Van Helsing said to me when we met on Liverpool Street was this:
es: September 7.

en: “Have you said anything to our young friend the lover of her?”
vi: — Have you informed our young friend, that fiancé of hers, yet?
tr: “Did you say anything to our young friend, that is, the lady's lover?”
es: The first thing Van Helsing said to me when we met on Liverpool Street was: "Have you told your friend, her fiancé?"

en: “No,” I said. “I waited till I had seen you, as I said in my telegram. I wrote him a letter simply telling him that you were coming, as Miss Westenra was not so well, and that I should let him know if need be.”
vi: — Not yet, Professor, - I replied - as I mentioned in the telegram, I must meet with you first. I sent him a letter, but it only briefly stated that the professor was planning to return to examine Lucy once more, and that I would inform him as soon as there was any news.
tr: “No,” I said. “As I mentioned in my telegram, I waited until I saw you. I wrote him a letter saying that you would come because Miss Westenra is not very well and that I would inform him if necessary.”
es: –No –I said–. I wanted to wait until I saw you first, as I mentioned in my telegram. I wrote a letter simply stating that you were coming, since Miss Westenra was not in good health, and that I would send more news later.

en: “Right, my friend,” he said, “quite right! Better he not know as yet; perhaps he shall never know. I pray so; but if it be needed, then he shall know all. And, my good friend John, let me caution you. You deal with the madmen. All men are mad in some way or the other; and inasmuch as you deal discreetly with your madmen, so deal with God’s madmen, too—the rest of the world. You tell not your madmen what you do nor why you do it; you tell them not what you think. So you shall keep knowledge in its place, where it may rest—where it may gather its kind around it and breed. You and I shall keep as yet what we know here, and here.” He touched me on the heart and on the forehead, and then touched himself the same way. “I have for myself thoughts at the present. Later I shall unfold to you.”
vi: — Good, my friend, very good! It's best not to let him know, because at this moment he might never find out the truth, I hope so! But if it is really necessary, I will tell him everything. My friend, please understand me. More than anyone else, as a specialist in caring for mental patients, you should be someone who understands me very well. In one way or another, we are all madmen, and in the case where you show a lack of caution when caring for your mental patients, you would be acting no differently than the mad sheep of God. Do not tell your patients why you have to care for them, nor should you tell them what you are thinking. In situations that make us hesitate, he should keep what he knows to himself until his belief is more firmly established. Yes, let us keep what we know to ourselves, like this and like that... for now... (Saying this, he placed his hand on his chest, then on my forehead, then moved his finger back to his chest, and then to his forehead). As for myself, I have understood a few issues and will gradually reveal them to you later.
tr: “True, my friend,” he said, “very true! It is better that he does not know yet; perhaps he should never know. I hope it will be so; but if necessary, he must learn everything. And my good friend John, let me warn you. You are dealing with madmen. Everyone is mad in one way or another; be as sensible when dealing with God's madmen - the rest of the world - as you are with your own madmen. You do not tell your madmen what you are doing to them or why you are doing it; you do not tell them what you are thinking. So, leave knowledge where it can rest comfortably, gather its kind around it, and propagate. You and I will keep what we know here and here for now.” He touched first my chest and forehead and then his own in the same manner. “I have thoughts that I am keeping to myself right now. I will explain to you later.”
es: "Very well, very well, my friend," he told me. "It is better that he does not know yet; perhaps he will never come to know." "I hope so; but if it is necessary, then he will know everything." "And, my old friend John, let me warn you: you are dealing with madmen." "All men are more or less mad; and just as you deal discreetly with your madmen, so deal discreetly with God's madmen: the rest of the world." "You do not tell your madmen what you do or why you do it; you do not tell them what you think." "So you must keep knowledge in its place, where it can rest; where it can gather with its kind and procreate." "You and I will keep to ourselves what we know, as we have done so far..." And upon saying this, he touched my heart and my forehead, and then he touched himself in a similar manner. –For my part, I have some ideas for the moment. Later, I will present them to you.

en: “Why not now?” I asked. “It may do some good; we may arrive at some decision.” He stopped and looked at me, and said:—
vi: — Why not say it now? - I asked. - Who knows, it might be useful for us, it could help us make a decision. The professor waved his hand and looked straight into my eyes as if he wanted me to be silent:
tr: “Why not now?” I asked. “It might work; we could come to a decision.” He paused and looked at me, then said:
es: –Why not now? – I asked him-. They might yield good results; we could reach some conclusion. He looked at me intently, and said:

en: “My friend John, when the corn is grown, even before it has ripened—while the milk of its mother-earth is in him, and the sunshine has not yet begun to paint him with his gold, the husbandman he pull the ear and rub him between his rough hands, and blow away the green chaff, and say to you: ‘Look! he’s good corn; he will make good crop when the time comes.’” I did not see the application, and told him so. For reply he reached over and took my ear in his hand and pulled it playfully, as he used long ago to do at lectures, and said: “The good husbandman tell you so then because he knows, but not till then. But you do not find the good husbandman dig up his planted corn to see if he grow; that is for the children who play at husbandry, and not for those who take it as of the work of their life. See you now, friend John? I have sown my corn, and Nature has her work to do in making it sprout; if he sprout at all, there’s some promise; and I wait till the ear begins to swell.” He broke off, for he evidently saw that I understood. Then he went on, and very gravely:—
vi: — My friend, when the wheat plant emerges from the ground but has not yet reached maturity, the milk of the mother earth still flows within its body. However, before the sun has yet to spread its radiant golden rays, the plowman hastily picks a stalk, crushes it in his rough hand, and blows away the still-green grain, saying to you: "Just look at this! The grain is truly plump." It is promising a bountiful harvest!” To be honest, I still haven't grasped the connection between the professor's metaphorical story and what we are discussing. Van Helsing did not reply but pinched my ear hard and pulled it to one side just as he used to do when I was his student. Finally, he explained: — The kind-hearted farmer said this because at that moment he was certain of a good harvest, but before seeing the wheat ears, he did not dare to boast. There would never be a case where a farmer would uproot the wheat he had spent so much effort sowing and tending to just to see how it had grown. Only carefree children would act like that, but those who sow seeds to make a living would never do so. Now, do you understand my point, my friend? I sow the wheat seeds, and nature must make them sprout. And if the seeds sprout, then what I await will be plump, full grains. Van Helsing's expression suddenly became pensive and hard to understand. After a moment of silence, he continued the story, his tone serious, quite different from before:
tr: “My friend John, when corn is growing, even before it matures - while Mother Nature's milk is still inside and the sun has not yet begun to paint it golden, the farmer pulls the cob and takes it in his rough hands, blows off the green husk, and says to you: ‘Look! This is good corn; it will yield a good harvest when the time comes.’” I didn't understand what he was trying to say and told him so. In response, just as he did in lessons long ago, he reached out and grabbed my ear, tugging it playfully as he said: “A good farmer tells you this because he knows, but until then he does not know. But you don't see a good farmer pulling the corn out of the ground to see if it is growing; that is for children playing at farming, not for those who see it as their life's work. Do you understand now, my friend John? I have planted my corn and there are things Nature must do for it to sprout; if it sprouts, there is hope; I will wait until the cob grows.” He suddenly stopped because he saw that I understood. Then he continued his words and said with great seriousness:
es: –My friend John, when the corn has grown, even before it has matured, while the sap of its mother earth is still in it, and the sun has not yet begun to paint it with its gold, the husband pulls his ear and rubs it between his rough hands, and cleans the green foliage, and tells you: "Look!: it is good corn; when the time comes, it will be a good grain." I didn't see the application, and I told him. In response, he extended his arm and took my ear between his hands, pulling it playfully, as he used to do during his classes in the past, and said: –The good husband says so because he knows, but not until then. But you don't find the good husband by digging up the planted corn to see if it grows; that's for children who play at being sowers. But not for those who have that trade as a means of subsistence. Do you understand now, friend John? I have sown my corn, and now nature has the job of making it grow; if it grows, then there is some hope; and I will wait until the grain begins to show. Upon saying this, he stopped, as he evidently saw that I had understood him. Then, he continued with all seriousness:

en: “You were always a careful student, and your case-book was ever more full than the rest. You were only student then; now you are master, and I trust that good habit have not fail. Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory, and we should not trust the weaker. Even if you have not kept the good practise, let me tell you that this case of our dear miss is one that may be—mind, I say may be—of such interest to us and others that all the rest may not make him kick the beam, as your peoples say. Take then good note of it. Nothing is too small. I counsel you, put down in record even your doubts and surmises. Hereafter it may be of interest to you to see how true you guess. We learn from failure, not from success!”
vi: — You were once one of the most outstanding students that I cherished. At that time, you were just a student, but now, you are a teacher, and I believe that you still maintain the passionate research habits of the past. My friend, remember that knowledge is always more important than memories, that we should not blindly pride ourselves on the basic concepts we have achieved. If you have abandoned those valuable habitual practices, now is the time to restore them. Let me tell you that the case of that young friend could - pay attention, I said could - become a practical benefit for us and for others as well. Do not be negligent in any way. Here is a piece of advice for you: remember all your doubts, your hypotheses about phenomena, even the smallest detail. It will certainly be very useful for verifying the accuracy of your later judgments. It is not success, but failure that brings us lessons!
tr: “You were always a very diligent student, and your casebook was always fuller than the others. Back then, you were just a student; now you are a master, and I believe your good habit has not diminished. Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory, and we should not rely on the weaker one. Even if you have not maintained this good practice, let me tell you, this case concerning our dear young lady might interest us and others so much - mind you, I say might. So, take good notes. Nothing is too small. I advise you; record even your doubts and conjectures. Later, you might be interested to see how accurate your conjectures were. We learn from our failures, not our successes!”
es: –You were always a careful student, and your case was always fuller than the others. Back then you were just a student; now you are a teacher, and I hope your good habits have not disappeared. Remember, my friend, that knowledge is stronger than memory, and we should not rely on the weaker. Even if you have not maintained the good practice, let me tell you that this case of our dear miss is one that may be, mind you, I say may be, of such interest to us and to others that all other cases are nothing compared to it. Take, then, good note of it. Nothing is too small. I give you a piece of advice: write down in the record even your doubts and conjectures. Later it might be interesting for you to see how much truth you can guess. We learn from failures; not from successes.

en: When I described Lucy’s symptoms—the same as before, but infinitely more marked—he looked very grave, but said nothing. He took with him a bag in which were many instruments and drugs, “the ghastly paraphernalia of our beneficial trade,” as he once called, in one of his lectures, the equipment of a professor of the healing craft. When we were shown in, Mrs. Westenra met us. She was alarmed, but not nearly so much as I expected to find her. Nature in one of her beneficent moods has ordained that even death has some antidote to its own terrors. Here, in a case where any shock may prove fatal, matters are so ordered that, from some cause or other, the things not personal—even the terrible change in her daughter to whom she is so attached—do not seem to reach her. It is something like the way Dame Nature gathers round a foreign body an envelope of some insensitive tissue which can protect from evil that which it would otherwise harm by contact. If this be an ordered selfishness, then we should pause before we condemn any one for the vice of egoism, for there may be deeper root for its causes than we have knowledge of.
vi: Listening to me describe the symptoms I had observed in Lucy, although he listened attentively, the professor still did not make any comments. He quietly picked up the medical and medicine kit. "A whole bunch of cumbersome tools necessary for our delightful professional work." - he had once said to us, his students, in a lecture about all the most basic tools a doctor needs to practice. Mrs. Westenra came out to greet us. She did not have the worried look that I had feared. The nature of nature has the good quality of always providing a remedy for the most terrible obsessions, even if death is lurking somewhere. Mrs. Westenra had donned an emotional armor against all harm, even when she sensed the changes in her daughter that I found frightening. If this can be called a self-liberating selfishness, then we should not be quick to condemn those whom we see as selfish, because the reasons leading to that character trait are sometimes much more mysterious than what people usually think.
tr: When I described the symptoms in Lucy -the same as before but much more pronounced- he looked very serious, but said nothing. He took a bag with him, containing many tools and medicines, which he referred to in one of his lectures as "the dreadful paraphernalia of our beneficial profession," the equipment of a professor in the field of treatment. When we were admitted inside, we were greeted by Mrs. Westenra. She was frightened, but not as much as I had expected to find her. Nature, in one of its good moods, had decreed that even the horrors caused by death should have their remedy. Here, in a case where a sudden shock could be fatal, things were arranged in such a way that impersonal matters -even the terrifying change in the daughter she was so attached to- seemed not to affect her. It was like Mother Nature covering the surroundings of a foreign mass with a kind of insensitive tissue to protect from harm upon touch. If this was a form of situationally arranged selfishness, then we must pause before accusing anyone of the immorality of egoism, for its reasons may have deeper roots than we know.
es: When I described Lucy's symptoms to him (the same as before, but infinitely more pronounced), he became very serious, but said nothing. He took a briefcase containing many instruments and medicines, "the horrible attire of our benevolent trade," as he had called it in one of his classes, the equipment of a professor of medical science. When we were shown in, Mrs. Westenra came out to meet us. She was alarmed, but not as much as I had expected to find her. Nature, in one of its moments of good disposition, has decreed that even death has some antidote for its own errors. Here, in a case where any impression could be fatal, matters are arranged in such a way that, for one reason or another, non-personal things (not even the terrible change in her daughter, whom she loved so much) seem to reach her. It is something akin to how Mother Nature gathers around a foreign body and envelops it with some insensitive tissue, which can protect it from the harm it would otherwise be subjected to by contact. If this is an ordered selfishness, then we should refrain for a moment before condemning anyone for the defect of selfishness, for its causes may have deeper roots than we know so far.

en: I used my knowledge of this phase of spiritual pathology, and laid down a rule that she should not be present with Lucy or think of her illness more than was absolutely required. She assented readily, so readily that I saw again the hand of Nature fighting for life. Van Helsing and I were shown up to Lucy’s room. If I was shocked when I saw her yesterday, I was horrified when I saw her to-day. She was ghastly, chalkily pale; the red seemed to have gone even from her lips and gums, and the bones of her face stood out prominently; her breathing was painful to see or hear. Van Helsing’s face grew set as marble, and his eyebrows converged till they almost touched over his nose. Lucy lay motionless, and did not seem to have strength to speak, so for a while we were all silent. Then Van Helsing beckoned to me, and we went gently out of the room. The instant we had closed the door he stepped quickly along the passage to the next door, which was open. Then he pulled me quickly in with him and closed the door. “My God!” he said; “this is dreadful. There is no time to be lost. She will die for sheer want of blood to keep the heart’s action as it should be. There must be transfusion of blood at once. Is it you or me?”
vi: However, my understanding of the core of psychiatric pathology compelled me to adhere to a very clear course of action: I decided never to allow Mrs. Westenra to be present when we examined Lucy, and she should not be concerned about her daughter's health unless it was absolutely necessary. Lucy's mother tried to appear cheerful when accepting my suggestion. A maid led us, that is Van Helsing and me, into Lucy's room. If yesterday, looking at her, I only felt a slight concern, then today I was truly shocked by the change that had taken place in her: before me was a gaunt, sallow Lucy; her face was pale, her lips were colorless, and her gums seemed to have no blood circulating inside. Listening to her breathing at this moment was truly a torment: she was struggling to breathe to the point that it seemed she could not endure it much longer. Van Helsing's complexion seemed unchanged; he was deep in thought about something. Lucy lay still, she didn't even have the strength to greet us anymore. The three of us quietly looked at each other for a long time. Then Van Helsing slightly nodded to signal me, and we quietly left the room. The door hadn't fully closed yet when he pulled me, dragging me to the next room, and said: — My God! It's really terrible? We can't afford to waste another minute. Lucy will die from blood loss. She doesn't even have enough blood left for her heart to function. We need to perform a blood transfusion immediately. Which one of us two?
tr: I used my knowledge regarding this stage of the mental illness and established the rule that, except in absolutely necessary situations, Lucy should not be around or think about the illness. She accepted this wholeheartedly, so wholeheartedly that once again I saw the hand of Nature fighting for life before me. Van Helsing and I were taken to Lucy's room. If I was surprised when I saw her yesterday, I can say that I was horrified when I saw her today. She was as pale as death, white as chalk; the red had drained even from her lips and gums, and her facial bones were prominently protruding; it was painful to see or hear her breathing. Van Helsing's face hardened like marble and his eyebrows drew so close together they almost touched above his nose. Lucy lay motionless and seemed to lack the strength to speak, so we all remained silent for a while. Then Van Helsing beckoned me over with a nod, and we slowly left the room together. As soon as we closed the door, we quickly moved down the corridor and passed through the open door next to it. Then he quickly pulled me inside and closed the door. "My God!" he said; "This is terrible. There is no time to lose. She will die from the lack of blood her heart needs to keep beating. A blood transfusion must be done immediately. You or me?"
es: I put my knowledge of this phase of spiritual pathology into practice and established the rule that she should not be present with Lucy, or think about her illness, except when absolutely necessary. She agreed readily; so readily that once again I saw the hand of nature protecting life. Van Helsing and I were led to Lucy's room. If I had been impressed seeing her yesterday, when I saw her today I was horrified. She was terribly pale; white as chalk. The red seemed to have gone even from her lips and gums, and the bones of her face stood out prominently; it pained one to see or hear her breathing. Van Helsing's face became rigid as marble, and his eyebrows converged until they almost met over his nose. Lucy lay motionless and did not seem to have the strength to speak, so for a moment we all remained silent. Then, Van Helsing signaled to me and we quietly left the room. As soon as we closed the door, he walked quickly down the corridor to the next door, which was open. Then he quickly pushed me inside and closed it. –My God! – he said-. This is terrible! There is no time to lose. He will die from lack of blood to keep the heart functioning. We must perform a blood transfusion immediately. You, or me?

en: “I am younger and stronger, Professor. It must be me.”
vi: — I am younger and healthier, professor. So let me donate blood.
tr: "I am younger and stronger, Professor. It should be me."
es: –Master, I am younger and stronger; it should be me.

en: “Then get ready at once. I will bring up my bag. I am prepared.”
vi: — Then we must proceed immediately! You get ready! I need to go get the tool bag.
tr: “Then get ready immediately. I will bring my bag. I am prepared.”
es: –Then, get ready immediately. I will bring my briefcase. I am already prepared.

en: I went downstairs with him, and as we were going there was a knock at the hall-door. When we reached the hall the maid had just opened the door, and Arthur was stepping quickly in. He rushed up to me, saying in an eager whisper:—
vi: We were both going down the stairs when we heard a knock on the door. The housekeeper ran to open the door, and it turned out to be Arthur. He hurried towards me, his voice trembling with worry:
tr: I went down with him and as we were leaving, the entrance door was knocked. When we reached the hall, the servant had just opened the door and Arthur was hurriedly coming in. He ran towards me and said in an impatient whisper:
es: I accompanied him downstairs, and as we descended, someone knocked on the hallway door. When we reached it, the maid had just opened the door and Arthur was swiftly entering. He ran towards me, speaking in an anguished whisper.

en: “Jack, I was so anxious. I read between the lines of your letter, and have been in an agony. The dad was better, so I ran down here to see for myself. Is not that gentleman Dr. Van Helsing? I am so thankful to you, sir, for coming.” When first the Professor’s eye had lit upon him he had been angry at his interruption at such a time; but now, as he took in his stalwart proportions and recognised the strong young manhood which seemed to emanate from him, his eyes gleamed. Without a pause he said to him gravely as he held out his hand:—
vi: — Jack, I'm so worried. I have read your letter over and over, you can't know how much I've had to endure since then. Seeing that my old man's health has stabilized, I decided I had to come here immediately to see what's going on. That's Dr. Van Helsing, right? Very grateful for your presence! Seeing the newcomer, the professor seemed displeased; he was annoyed because his work was interrupted at a critical moment. But after a while, when he understood Arthur's courageous approach to the situation, his eyes lit up, he extended his hand and said:
tr: “Jack, I was very worried. I read between the lines of your letter and have been in great pain ever since. My father was better, so I rushed here to see with my own eyes. This gentleman, is he Dr. Van Helsing? I am grateful to you for coming, sir.” The professor looked at Arthur, annoyed at being disturbed at such a time; but now, as he examined the large build of the man before him and recognized the powerful young masculinity that seemed to emanate from him, his eyes sparkled. As he extended his hand, he said solemnly without hesitation:
es: –Jack, I was very distressed. I read between the lines of your letter, and I have been in constant torment. My father is better, so I rushed here to see things for myself. Isn't this gentleman Dr. van Helsing? Doctor, I am very grateful that you have come. When the professor's eyes first fell upon him, there was a glint of anger in them due to the interruption at such a moment: but upon seeing his sturdy proportions and recognizing the strong youthful manliness that seemed to emanate from him, his eyes brightened. Without any delay, he said to him while extending his hand:

en: “Sir, you have come in time. You are the lover of our dear miss. She is bad, very, very bad. Nay, my child, do not go like that.” For he suddenly grew pale and sat down in a chair almost fainting. “You are to help her. You can do more than any that live, and your courage is your best help.”
vi: — You arrived just in time. You must be the fiancé of that young lady? She is very ill, gravely ill. But stay calm, young man, don't let yourself collapse at this moment. (Because, Arthur now looks very haggard, his face pale, he slumped into the chair as if about to faint) On the contrary, you must be even more courageous. You will have to help her. You can help her more than anyone else in this world, and to be precise, you can help her best with your own courage.
tr: “Sir, you have arrived just in time. You are the beloved of our dear young lady. Her condition is bad, very very bad. No, my child, do not let yourself go like this.” Because suddenly Arthur turned pale and sat down on a chair as if he were about to faint. “You will help her. For her, you can do more than anyone alive, and your courage is your greatest ally.”
es: –Young man, you have arrived just in time. You are the fiancé of our patient, correct? She is in bad shape; very, very bad. No, son, don't react like that -he said, seeing that my friend suddenly turned pale and sat in a chair almost fainting-. You are going to help her. You can do more than anyone else to keep her alive, and your courage is your best help.

en: “What can I do?” asked Arthur hoarsely. “Tell me, and I shall do it. My life is hers, and I would give the last drop of blood in my body for her.” The Professor has a strongly humorous side, and I could from old knowledge detect a trace of its origin in his answer:—
vi: — So what can I possibly do? - Arthur asked again in a very weak voice. - Please, professor, just say it, I will not hesitate. My life belongs to her, I must save her until the last drop of blood. — Young man.
tr: Arthur asked in a low voice, "What can I do?" "Tell me, I'll do it. My life belongs to him, and I would give the last drop of blood in my body for him." The Professor had a strong sense of humor, and in his response, I could sense traces of his origins from my past experiences:
es: –What can I do? – asked Arthur, with a hoarse voice-. Tell me and I will do it. My life is hers, and I would give up to the last drop of my blood to help her. The professor had a strong sense of humor, and because I knew him so well, I could detect a trait of his in his response:

en: “My young sir, I do not ask so much as that—not the last!”
vi: - Van Helsing replied, humorously - I don't demand that much from you: you don't need to sacrifice your last drop of blood?
tr: “Young gentleman, I don't want that much - not the last drop!”
es: –My young friend, I do not ask so much of you; at least not the last one.

en: “What shall I do?” There was fire in his eyes, and his open nostril quivered with intent. Van Helsing slapped him on the shoulder. “Come!” he said. “You are a man, and it is a man we want. You are better than me, better than my friend John.” Arthur looked bewildered, and the Professor went on by explaining in a kindly way:—
vi: — So what should I do? In Arthur's eyes, there seemed to be fire, and both his nostrils flared with impatience. Van Helsing gently patted his shoulder: — Come here. We really need a man like you. You will be more suitable than me, much more than our friend John in this matter. It is clear that Arthur still did not understand what the professor meant, so he had to gently explain further:
tr: “What should I do?” His eyes were blazing and his flared nostrils quivered with determination. Van Helsing patted him on the shoulder. “Come!” he said. “You are a man, and what we need is a man. You are better than me, better than my friend John.” Arthur was stunned, and the Professor continued his words with a gentle explanation:
