es: –What should I do? There was fire in his eyes, and his nose quivered with emotion. Van Helsing patted him on the shoulder. "Come on," he said to him. "You are a man, and a man is what we need." "You are better than me, and better than my friend John." Arthur looked perplexed, and then my teacher began to explain to him kindly:

en: “Young miss is bad, very bad. She wants blood, and blood she must have or die. My friend John and I have consulted; and we are about to perform what we call transfusion of blood—to transfer from full veins of one to the empty veins which pine for him. John was to give his blood, as he is the more young and strong than me”—here Arthur took my hand and wrung it hard in silence—“but, now you are here, you are more good than us, old or young, who toil much in the world of thought. Our nerves are not so calm and our blood not so bright than yours!” Arthur turned to him and said:—
vi: — It is true that the young girl is very seriously ill. One could say that there is hardly any blood left in her body; if we do not transfuse blood, she will certainly not survive. John and I have agreed to perform what we call a blood transfusion, which means taking blood from full veins and letting it flow into nearly empty veins in an emergency situation! And John will be the blood donor, as he is younger and healthier than I am. But now, since you are here, you are the healthiest among the three of us; age is no longer an important factor because both of us have been working too hard, and thus our blood is no longer as rich as the blood flowing in your veins! Arthur turned to Van Helsing and said:
tr: “The young lady's condition is bad, very bad. She needs blood and must receive it, otherwise she will die. My friend John and I have consulted, and we are about to perform a blood transfusion, which means transferring blood from full veins to her empty veins that crave it. Since John is younger and stronger than me, he was going to give his blood,” -Arthur held my hand here and squeezed it tightly in silence- “but now that you are here, whether young or old, you are much better than us who are tired from working in the world of thought. Our nerves are not as calm as yours and our blood is not as bright as yours!” Arthur turned to him and said: “If you knew how happily I would die for her, you would understand that...”
es: –The young lady is in a bad way, very bad. She needs blood, and blood must be given to her, or she will die. My friend John and I have consulted; and we are about to perform what we call a blood transfusion: transferring blood from the full veins of one to the empty veins of another who is in need of it. John was going to give his blood, as he is younger and stronger than I am (and here Arthur took my hand and squeezed it tightly in silence), but now you are here; you are stronger than any of us, old or young, who spend much of our energy in the world of thought. Our nerves are not as steady nor is our blood as rich as yours! Then Arthur turned to the eminent doctor and said to him:

en: “If you only knew how gladly I would die for her you would understand——”
vi: — If only you could know how much I am yearning to sacrifice my life for hers, then perhaps you would understand...
tr: Arthur turned to him and said: “If you knew how happily I would die for her, you would understand that...”
es: –If you knew how happily I would die for her, then you would understand...

en: He stopped, with a sort of choke in his voice.
vi: He suddenly choked up and couldn't speak anymore.
tr: Her voice halted with a kind of obstruction.
es: He stopped, with a kind of choking in his voice.

en: “Good boy!” said Van Helsing. “In the not-so-far-off you will be happy that you have done all for her you love. Come now and be silent. You shall kiss her once before it is done, but then you must go; and you must leave at my sign. Say no word to Madame; you know how it is with her! There must be no shock; any knowledge of this would be one. Come!”
vi: — Bravo, my friend! - Van Helsing exclaimed. - Now, come with us, but remember to stay quiet. You can kiss your beloved once before the blood transfusion, but once the work begins, leave it to us. When I signal, you must leave the room immediately. And don't say anything to Mrs. Westenra! We need to preserve her strength. Come here!
tr: Van Helsing said, "Well done, my boy!" "In the not too distant future, you will be happy for having done everything for the woman you love. Now come and be silent. Before the procedure is carried out, kiss her, but then you must leave; you must depart at my signal. Do not tell the great lady anything; you know how she is! She must not experience shock; any information on this matter would be a shock. Come!"
es: –Well done, young man! – said Van Helsing. In the not too distant future, you will be glad you did everything possible to help the one you love. Now come and remain silent. Before we proceed, you will kiss her once, but then you must leave: and you must leave at my signal. Do not say a word of this to the lady; you already know her condition! She must not have any impression; any upset would kill her. Come!

en: We all went up to Lucy’s room. Arthur by direction remained outside. Lucy turned her head and looked at us, but said nothing. She was not asleep, but she was simply too weak to make the effort. Her eyes spoke to us; that was all. Van Helsing took some things from his bag and laid them on a little table out of sight. Then he mixed a narcotic, and coming over to the bed, said cheerily:—
vi: All three of us walked up the stairs together. But Professor Van Helsing did not want Arthur to enter the room at the same time as us. He had to wait on the landing. Seeing us, Lucy turned her face but said nothing. She wasn't sleeping but just lying still because she was too weak. Trying to speak was impossible for her at that moment. Speaking with her eyes was all she could do in front of us. Van Helsing opened his bag, took out some items, and placed them on the table, out of the patient's sight. He prepared a dose of anesthetic and then returned to Lucy's bed:
tr: We all went up to Lucy's room together. Upon receiving his orders, Arthur stayed outside. Lucy turned her head and looked at us, but she didn't say anything. She wasn't sleeping, but she was too weak to make an effort to speak. Her eyes spoke to us; that was all. Van Helsing took some things out of his bag and arranged them on a small table out of sight. Then he prepared a sedative and, coming to the head of the bed, cheerfully said:
es: We all entered Lucy's room. At the teacher's suggestion, Arthur stayed outside. Lucy turned her head towards us and looked at us, but said nothing. She was not asleep, but she was simply so weak that she could not make any effort. Her eyes spoke to us; that was all. Van Helsing took some things out of his bag and placed them on a small table out of her sight. Then, he mixed a narcotic and, approaching the bed, said to her cheerfully:

en: “Now, little miss, here is your medicine. Drink it off, like a good child. See, I lift you so that to swallow is easy. Yes.” She had made the effort with success.
vi: — Come on, little girl, take this medicine! Try to drink this whole cup like a good child. Pay attention, I'll hold the cup for you, that way it will be easier. There... Good!
tr: "Now, little lady, here is your medicine. Be a good child and take it. Look, I'm lifting it up so you can swallow it easily. Yes." Lucy made an effort and succeeded.
es: –Well, miss, here is your medicine. Take it all like a good girl. See; I will lift you up so you can swallow easily. Like this. He made the effort with good results.

en: It astonished me how long the drug took to act. This, in fact, marked the extent of her weakness. The time seemed endless until sleep began to flicker in her eyelids. At last, however, the narcotic began to manifest its potency; and she fell into a deep sleep. When the Professor was satisfied he called Arthur into the room, and bade him strip off his coat. Then he added: “You may take that one little kiss whiles I bring over the table. Friend John, help to me!” So neither of us looked whilst he bent over her.
vi: I was very surprised to see how quickly the sleeping pill took effect, which showed how weak the girl was. It seemed that in her eyes, as she began to close her eyelids, there was an eternal, endless world. Immediately after the sleeping pill took effect, Van Heising called Arthur into the room and told him to take off his vest. — Now, - He said - you can hold her as I instructed. In the meantime, I will set up a table near the patient's bed. John, my friend, give me a hand! Due to being busy preparing the equipment, we didn't notice Arthur fussing over Lucy.
tr: It surprised me greatly to see how long it took for the medicine to take effect. This actually showed the extent of its weakness. The time until sleep began to flutter in his eyelids felt infinite. But finally, the narcotic began to take effect, and he fell into a deep sleep. Once the professor was satisfied, he called Arthur into the room and told him to take off his jacket. Then he added: "You can take that little kiss while I bring the table." "John, my friend, help me!" Thus, while Arthur leaned over Lucy, neither of us looked.
es: I was surprised at how long it took for the drug to take effect. This, in fact, was a clear symptom of its weakness. The time seemed endless until sleep began to flutter on their eyelids. However, in the end, the narcotic began to manifest its potency, and they fell into a deep sleep. When the professor was satisfied, he called Arthur into the room and asked him to take off his jacket. Then he added: –You can give that short kiss while I bring the table. Friend John, help me! Thus, neither of us saw while he leaned over her.

en: Van Helsing turning to me, said:
vi: Van Helsing whispered into my ear:
tr: Van Helsing turned to me and said:
es: Then, turning to me, Van Helsing said:

en: “He is so young and strong and of blood so pure that we need not defibrinate it.”
vi: — He is still young and very healthy, I believe we won't need to remove the blood clot.
tr: “He is so young and strong, and his blood is so pure that we do not need to dilute it.”
es: –She is so young and so strong, and of such pure blood, that we do not need to defibrinate her.

en: Then with swiftness, but with absolute method, Van Helsing performed the operation. As the transfusion went on something like life seemed to come back to poor Lucy’s cheeks, and through Arthur’s growing pallor the joy of his face seemed absolutely to shine. After a bit I began to grow anxious, for the loss of blood was telling on Arthur, strong man as he was. It gave me an idea of what a terrible strain Lucy’s system must have undergone that what weakened Arthur only partially restored her. But the Professor’s face was set, and he stood watch in hand and with his eyes fixed now on the patient and now on Arthur. I could hear my own heart beat. Presently he said in a soft voice: “Do not stir an instant. It is enough. You attend him; I will look to her.” When all was over I could see how much Arthur was weakened. I dressed the wound and took his arm to bring him away, when Van Helsing spoke without turning round—the man seems to have eyes in the back of his head:—
vi: And then, with a few quick, precise, and methodical movements, he began the blood transfusion. Life seemed to be gradually bringing a rosy hue back to Lucy's cheeks, while Arthur's face quickly turned pale, yet his eyes still shone with indescribable joy. Looking at my friend, I couldn't help but feel a pang of sadness. I feared that someone like him would find it difficult to recover after losing so much blood. The professor's face was very serious and tense. Holding the watch in his hand, he kept looking at the patient and then at Arthur. I was so nervous that I could hear every beat of my heart. Van Helsing suddenly told me: — That's enough. Now you have to keep an eye on him, and I'll take care of the patient. Arthur visibly weakened. I only dared to acknowledge this reality after the work was done. I was preparing to take Arthur outside after bandaging his wound when I heard Van Helsing's voice. He spoke without turning around, giving me the impression that he had eyes in the back of his head.
tr: Then Van Helsing quickly, but with absolute order, performed the procedure. As the blood transfusion continued, something resembling life seemed to return to poor Lucy's cheeks, and despite his increasing pallor, Arthur's face definitely appeared to glow with joy. After a while, I began to worry, because even though he was a strong man, the blood loss was badly affecting Arthur. This gave me an idea of the terrible strain Lucy's body was under; so much so that what weakened Arthur had partially healed Lucy. But the Professor's expression was stern, and with a watch in his hand, his eyes kept locking alternately on the patient and on Arthur. I could hear my own heartbeat. A little later, Van Helsing said in a soft tone: "Don't move for a second. Enough. You accompany him, I will look after my little lady. " When everything was over, I could see how weak Arthur had become. I bandaged the wound, and as I took his arm to lead him away, Van Helsing spoke without turning around - as if the man had eyes in the back of his head:
es: Then, quickly but methodically, Van Helsing carried out the operation. As it was being done, something like life seemed to return to the cheeks of poor Lucy, and through Arthur's growing paleness, the joy on his face seemed to shine. After a short time, I began to feel anguish, for despite Arthur being a strong man, the loss of blood was already affecting him. This gave me an idea of the terrible strain Lucy's body must have been under, since what weakened Arthur only partially improved her. But my master's face was rigid, and he stood with the watch in his hand and his gaze fixed sometimes on the patient, sometimes on Arthur. I could hear the beating of my heart. Finally, he said in a low voice: –Don't move for a moment. That's enough. You take care of him; I'll take care of her. When everything was over, I could see how Arthur was weakened. I bandaged his wound and took him by the arm to help him out, when Van Helsing spoke without turning; the man seemed to have eyes in the back of his head.

en: “The brave lover, I think, deserve another kiss, which he shall have presently.” And as he had now finished his operation, he adjusted the pillow to the patient’s head. As he did so the narrow black velvet band which she seems always to wear round her throat, buckled with an old diamond buckle which her lover had given her, was dragged a little up, and showed a red mark on her throat. Arthur did not notice it, but I could hear the deep hiss of indrawn breath which is one of Van Helsing’s ways of betraying emotion. He said nothing at the moment, but turned to me, saying: “Now take down our brave young lover, give him of the port wine, and let him lie down a while. He must then go home and rest, sleep much and eat much, that he may be recruited of what he has so given to his love. He must not stay here. Hold! a moment. I may take it, sir, that you are anxious of result. Then bring it with you that in all ways the operation is successful. You have saved her life this time, and you can go home and rest easy in mind that all that can be is. I shall tell her all when she is well; she shall love you none the less for what you have done. Good-bye.”
vi: — I think this brave fiancé deserves a kiss. You can do it right now. As he spoke, he slipped a pillow under the patient's head. But when Lucy made the first slight movement after receiving the blood transfusion, the black velvet band she always wore around her neck suddenly moved up, revealing a red mark. It seemed that Arthur didn't notice, but Van Helsing did, because I clearly heard his sharp and sudden intake of breath. Whenever he is emotional and surprised by something, I always see him react like that. He still pretended not to notice anything and turned to tell me: — Okay, go down with this brave friend of yours, give him a glass of Porto wine and let him rest for a while. After that, he will go home to rest, sleep well, and eat as much as possible to make up for what he just did for his fiancée. Don't stay here too long! Wait, there's one more thing! My friend, I believe you would want to know the result of what we just did. Rest assured! The operation was a complete success. You have saved the young lady, and now you can go home without any worries. You have done everything you could for her. I will talk to her when she has recovered. Surely she will love you more. Goodbye.
tr: “I think a brave lover deserves another kiss that he should receive immediately.” And now, having completed the procedure, he adjusted the pillow under the patient's head. As he did this, the narrow, black velvet band that Lucy always seemed to wear around her neck, fastened with a diamond brooch given by her lover, slid up a bit and revealed the red mark on her neck. Arthur did not notice this, but I could hear Van Helsing's deep sigh, one of his ways of revealing his emotions. He did not say anything for now, but turned to me and spoke: “Now take our brave, young lover downstairs, give him some port wine, and let him rest a bit. Then he should go home and rest, sleep a lot, and eat well so that he can recover what he has given to his love and heal. He should not stay here. Wait! One minute. I can see you have concerns about the outcome, sir. So, leave here knowing that the procedure was successful. This time you have saved her life, and you can go home and rest with a peaceful mind, knowing that everything that could be done has been done. When she recovers, I will tell her everything; she will love you even more for what you have done. Goodbye.”
es: –The brave groom, I think, deserves another kiss, which he shall have immediately. And since he had now finished his operation, he adjusted the pillow under the patient's head. In doing so, the narrow velvet ribbon that she always seemed to wear around her throat, fastened with an old diamond brooch her boyfriend had given her, slid up a bit and revealed a red mark on her throat. Arthur didn't notice it, but I could hear the deep hiss of inhaled air, which is one of the ways van Helsing betrays his emotion. He said nothing at the moment, but turned to me and said: –Now, go down with our brave groom, give him some wine, and let him rest for a while. Then you must go home and rest; sleep a lot and eat a lot, so you can recover what you have given to your love. You must not stay here. Wait a moment! I presume, sir, that you are anxious about the result; then take him with you, since the operation has been successful anyway. You have saved his life this time, and you can go home and rest peacefully, as everything that needed to be done has been done. I will tell her what happened when she is well; I don't think she will stop loving you for what you have done. Goodbye.

en: When Arthur had gone I went back to the room. Lucy was sleeping gently, but her breathing was stronger; I could see the counterpane move as her breast heaved. By the bedside sat Van Helsing, looking at her intently. The velvet band again covered the red mark. I asked the Professor in a whisper:—
vi: When Arthur had left the house, I returned to meet Van Helsing. Lucy was still asleep, but her breathing seemed much more gentle. The professor was attentively watching her. The black velvet ribbon had been adjusted back to its position, covering the red mark on her neck. I softly asked the professor:
tr: When Arthur left, I returned to the room. Lucy was sleeping peacefully, but her breathing was stronger; I could see the bed cover moving as her chest rose and fell. Van Helsing sat at the head of the bed, carefully looking at Lucy. The velvet band once again covered the red mark. I whispered this to the professor:
es: When Arthur had gone, I returned to the room. Lucy was sleeping peacefully, but her breathing was stronger; I could see the quilt rise as she breathed. Next to her bed sat Van Helsing, watching her intently. The velvet choker covered the red mark. I asked the professor:

en: “What do you make of that mark on her throat?”
vi: — How does the professor explain that wound?
tr: “What do you say about the mark on your neck?”
es: –What do you think about that mark on your throat?

en: “What do you make of it?”
vi: — So what about you, how do you explain it?
tr: “What are you saying?”
es: –And you, what do you think?

en: “I have not examined it yet,” I answered, and then and there proceeded to loose the band. Just over the external jugular vein there were two punctures, not large, but not wholesome-looking. There was no sign of disease, but the edges were white and worn-looking, as if by some trituration. It at once occurred to me that this wound, or whatever it was, might be the means of that manifest loss of blood; but I abandoned the idea as soon as formed, for such a thing could not be. The whole bed would have been drenched to a scarlet with the blood which the girl must have lost to leave such a pallor as she had before the transfusion.
vi: — I still haven't examined that wound carefully, let me remove the bandage and take a look. Indeed, on the outside of the jugular vein on the girl's neck, there were still two small marks like two unhealed punctures. It was certainly not a symptom of any pathology, but the edges of the wounds were pale white with frayed edges as if they had been there for a long time. I immediately thought that this wound, if it could be called a wound, might suggest a cause of severe blood loss for the girl, but I had to quickly dismiss this nascent thought because I found it utterly absurd. If one saw Lucy's pallor, as if she were about to die before the blood transfusion, her bed would surely be soaked with the blood she had lost.
tr: “I haven't seen it yet,” I replied and immediately went to loosen the bandage right there. There were two holes right over her jugular vein; they weren't big but looked somewhat bruised, they didn't look healthy. It occurred to me that this wound, or whatever it was, could be the source of this apparent blood loss; but as soon as this thought formed in my mind, I dismissed it, because such a thing couldn't be possible. With the amount of blood she lost that left the poor girl this pale before the blood transfusion, the entire bed should have been stained red.
es: –I still haven't examined it -I replied, and at that very moment, I proceeded to unfasten the necklace. Precisely over the external jugular vein, there were two punctures, not large, but neither did they bode well. There was no sign of infection, but the edges were white and seemed worn, as if they had been mistreated. At the moment, it occurred to me that this wound, or whatever it was, could be the means of the evident blood loss; but I abandoned the idea as soon as I had formulated it, for such a thing could not be. The entire bed would have been soaked red with the blood the girl must have lost to have a pallor like the one she showed before the transfusion.

en: “Well?” said Van Helsing.
vi: — So? - Van Helsing asked me. — Strange?
tr: “Yes?” said Van Helsing.
es: –Well? – said van Helsing.

en: “Well,” said I, “I can make nothing of it.” The Professor stood up. “I must go back to Amsterdam to-night,” he said. “There are books and things there which I want. You must remain here all the night, and you must not let your sight pass from her.”
vi: I don't understand anything. — Tonight I must return to Amsterdam at all costs. - The professor said as he stood up. - I need to look up some more books and documents. You stay here all night with the patient, okay!
tr: “Yes,” I said, “I can't make any sense of it.” The professor stood up. “I must return to Amsterdam tonight,” he said. “There are books and other things I need there. You must stay here throughout the night and keep an eye on him.”
es: –Well -I said-, I can't explain what it could be. My teacher stood up. –I must return to Amsterdam tonight -he said-. There are books and documents there that I wish to consult. You must stay here all night, and you must not take your eyes off him.

en: “Shall I have a nurse?” I asked.
vi: — Do I need to call another nurse?
tr: "Shall I take a nurse with me?" I asked.
es: –Should I hire a nurse? – I asked him.

en: “We are the best nurses, you and I. You keep watch all night; see that she is well fed, and that nothing disturbs her. You must not sleep all the night. Later on we can sleep, you and I. I shall be back as soon as possible. And then we may begin.”
vi: — You and I, we will be the best nurses. You will have to pay attention to her diet, and especially make sure she is not disturbed. Remember not to fall asleep, okay? Both you and I will catch up on sleep later. I will try to come back here as soon as possible, and then we can start. — Can we start?
tr: “We are the best nurses - you and I. Keep watch all night; make sure he is well-fed and nothing disturbs him. Then we can sleep, you and I. I will return as soon as possible. And then we can start.”
es: –We are the best nurses, you and I. You watch over her all night; make sure she eats well and that nothing bothers her. You must not sleep all night. Later we can sleep, you and I. I will return as soon as possible, and then we can start.

en: “May begin?” I said. “What on earth do you mean?”
vi: What was the professor going to say? — Then you will see?
tr: “Can we start?” I said. “What do you mean?”
es: –Can we start? – I said-. What do you mean by that?

en: “We shall see!” he answered, as he hurried out. He came back a moment later and put his head inside the door and said with warning finger held up:—
vi: - Van Helsing said as he hurriedly walked away. But after a moment, I saw him open the door, stick his head in, and raise his index finger to tell me:
tr: As he hurried out, he said, "We will see!" A second later, he came back, stuck his head in through the door, and raised his index finger as if to warn, saying:
es: –We'll see about that! – replied my teacher, as he hurriedly left. He returned a moment later, poked his head through the door, and said, raising a finger in warning: "Remember: she is your responsibility."

en: “Remember, she is your charge. If you leave her, and harm befall, you shall not sleep easy hereafter!”
vi: — Don't forget: I have great trust in you. If you carelessly leave this room and something unfortunate happens, you will surely have to spend many more sleepless nights!
tr: "Remember, it's your responsibility. If you leave it and it gets harmed, you won't be able to sleep peacefully anymore!"
es: He returned a moment later, poked his head through the door, and said, raising a finger in warning: "Remember: she is your responsibility." "If you leave her and something happens, you will not be able to sleep peacefully in the future!"

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary—continued.
vi: • September 18
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward (continued)

en: 8 September.—I sat up all night with Lucy. The opiate worked itself off towards dusk, and she waked naturally; she looked a different being from what she had been before the operation. Her spirits even were good, and she was full of a happy vivacity, but I could see evidences of the absolute prostration which she had undergone. When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had directed that I should sit up with her she almost pooh-poohed the idea, pointing out her daughter’s renewed strength and excellent spirits. I was firm, however, and made preparations for my long vigil. When her maid had prepared her for the night I came in, having in the meantime had supper, and took a seat by the bedside. She did not in any way make objection, but looked at me gratefully whenever I caught her eye. After a long spell she seemed sinking off to sleep, but with an effort seemed to pull herself together and shook it off. This was repeated several times, with greater effort and with shorter pauses as the time moved on. It was apparent that she did not want to sleep, so I tackled the subject at once:—
vi: I stayed up all night and, of course, didn't dare leave the patient's room for a minute. As night fell, the effect of the sleeping pills wore off, and Lucy woke up completely naturally. She was a completely different young girl from the one we had met before the blood transfusion. There was even a sparkle of joy and liveliness in her eyes, although the signs of deep fatigue were still there. When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had instructed me to stay up all night to watch over her daughter, she expressed reluctance to accept this suggestion, reasoning that her daughter had fully recovered. However, I did not relent and continued to prepare myself to stay awake all night by Lucy's bedside. After the maid finished her personal hygiene and I hurriedly ate dinner, I returned to sit by her bed. There was no one else in the room. Every time we looked at each other, I could read gratitude in her eyes. I had the feeling that she was gradually falling asleep, but at the same time, I sensed that she was resisting that sleep. She kept trying like that, and each attempt was more strenuous than the last. It was clear that she didn't want to sleep, so I had to ask her why.
tr: September 8 - I sat by Lucy's side all night. The effect of the narcotic wore off towards twilight and she woke up on her own; she seemed like a different person compared to before the procedure. Her spirits were even good and she was filled with a happy liveliness, but I could see the traces of the absolute exhaustion she had been subjected to. When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had ordered me to watch over Lucy, she almost scoffed at the idea, pointing out her daughter's renewed strength and perfect morale. But I was determined and made preparations for my long night watch. When her maid prepared her for the night, I went in; meanwhile, I had had my dinner and sat by her bedside. She did not object and looked at me with gratitude when our eyes met. After a long time, she seemed to fall asleep, but she struggled to gather herself and shook off sleep. This situation repeated itself several times with increasing efforts and shorter intervals as time went on. It was clear that she did not want to sleep, so I immediately addressed the issue:
es: September 8. I spent the whole night sitting beside Lucy. The sedative lost its effect at dusk, and she woke up naturally; she seemed like a different person from who she had been before the operation. Her mood was excellent, and she was full of cheerful vivacity, but I could see the traces of the extreme exhaustion she had gone through. When I told Mrs. Westenra that Dr. Van Helsing had ordered that I sit beside her, she almost scoffed at the idea, pointing out her daughter's renewed strength and excellent mood. However, I stood firm and made preparations for my long vigil. When her maid had prepared her for the night, I entered, having dined in the meantime, and took a seat beside her bed. She made no objection, but simply looked at me with gratitude whenever I could catch her eyes. After a long while, she seemed about to fall asleep, but with an effort, she seemed to recover and shake off the sleep. This happened several times, with more effort and shorter pauses as time went by. It was apparent that she did not want to sleep, so I addressed the matter immediately:

en: “You do not want to go to sleep?”
vi: — I'm really scared of sleeping.
tr: “Don't you want to sleep?”
es: –Don't you want to fall asleep?

en: “No; I am afraid.”
tr: “No; I am afraid.”
es: –No. I'm scared.

en: “Afraid to go to sleep! Why so? It is the boon we all crave for.”
vi: She confessed. — Afraid of sleeping! Yet, all of us consider sleep as one of the most valuable treasures! — Oh! Surely you wouldn't say that if you were in my position... if in your sleep you only encountered terrifying nightmares.
tr: “Afraid of sleeping! Why? Sleep is a blessing that we all seek desperately.”
es: –Fear of falling asleep! Why? It is a blessing that we all long for.

en: “Ah, not if you were like me—if sleep was to you a presage of horror!”
vi: Surely you wouldn't say that if you were in my position... if in your sleep you only encountered terrifying nightmares.
tr: “Ah, if you are like me - if sleep is a sign of fear for you, it won't be like that!”
es: –Ah! Not if you were like me. If sleep were a harbinger of horror for you...!

en: “A presage of horror! What on earth do you mean?”
vi: — Nightmares? Good heavens, what are you trying to say?
tr: “A sign of fear! What do you mean?”
es: –A premonition of horror! What do you mean by that?

en: “I don’t know; oh, I don’t know. And that is what is so terrible. All this weakness comes to me in sleep; until I dread the very thought.”
vi: — I don't know, I don't know... And it's precisely that not knowing that makes me even more scared! Just thinking about sleep makes me shudder?
tr: “I don't know; oh, I don't know. And that's what makes it so terrifying. All this helplessness overwhelms me while I'm asleep; until even thinking about it horrifies me.”
es: –I don't know, alas, I don't know. And that is what makes it so terrible. All this weakness comes to me while I sleep; in such a way that now even the very idea of sleeping frightens me.

en: “But, my dear girl, you may sleep to-night. I am here watching you, and I can promise that nothing will happen.”
vi: — But little girl, tonight you can sleep peacefully without any fear. I promise that I will be near you, everything will be fine.
tr: “But my dear daughter, you can sleep tonight. I will be watching over you here and I can promise that nothing will happen.”
es: –But, my dear girl, you can sleep tonight. I will be here watching over your sleep, and I can promise you that nothing will happen.

en: “Ah, I can trust you!” I seized the opportunity, and said: “I promise you that if I see any evidence of bad dreams I will wake you at once.”
vi: — Oh! I trust you, I always trust you! — Yes, I promise that if I notice any sign that you are having a nightmare, I will wake you up immediately.
tr: "Ah, I can trust you!" I took advantage of the opportunity and said: "I promise you; if I see any sign that you are having a bad dream, I will wake you up immediately.""
es: –Ah! I can trust you! I seized the opportunity and said: –I promise that if I see any evidence of nightmares, I will wake you up immediately.

en: “You will? Oh, will you really? How good you are to me. Then I will sleep!” And almost at the word she gave a deep sigh of relief, and sank back, asleep.
vi: — Waking me up? Are you serious? Oh! You are so kind to me. If that's the case, then I will sleep... Speaking up to this point, Lucy let out a long, relieved sigh and then immediately fell asleep.
tr: "Really?" "Oh, will you really wake me up?" "Then I will sleep." And almost as soon as he said this, he leaned back and fell asleep with a deep sigh of relief.
es: –Will you do it? Really? You are so good to me! Then, I will sleep. And almost at the same time, she let out a deep sigh of relief and sank into the pillow, asleep.

en: All night long I watched by her. She never stirred, but slept on and on in a deep, tranquil, life-giving, health-giving sleep. Her lips were slightly parted, and her breast rose and fell with the regularity of a pendulum. There was a smile on her face, and it was evident that no bad dreams had come to disturb her peace of mind.
vi: I stayed up watching her all night. She just lay there in a deep, peaceful sleep without stirring even once. Her lips slightly parted with a happy smile lingering on her face, her chest rising and falling with steady breaths like the pendulum of a clock. Clearly, no terrible dreams disturbed the tranquility of her mind.
tr: I watched him all night. He didn't move at all and kept sleeping a deep, peaceful, invigorating, and healing sleep. His lips were slightly parted and his chest rose and fell with the regularity of a pendulum. There was a smile on his face, and it was clear that he didn't have a single bad dream to disturb his peace of mind.
es: All night I stayed by her side. She did not move even once, but slept with a calm, restorative sleep. Her lips were slightly parted, and her chest rose and fell with the regularity of a pendulum. A smile was drawn on her face, and it was evident that no nightmares had come to disturb the peace of her mind.

en: In the early morning her maid came, and I left her in her care and took myself back home, for I was anxious about many things. I sent a short wire to Van Helsing and to Arthur, telling them of the excellent result of the operation. My own work, with its manifold arrears, took me all day to clear off; it was dark when I was able to inquire about my zoöphagous patient. The report was good; he had been quite quiet for the past day and night. A telegram came from Van Helsing at Amsterdam whilst I was at dinner, suggesting that I should be at Hillingham to-night, as it might be well to be at hand, and stating that he was leaving by the night mail and would join me early in the morning.
vi: The maid came to knock on the door very early; I entrusted her with the task of continuing to take care of the girl, then hurried back to the clinic to handle some matters. I sent a telegram to Van Helsing and Arthur to inform them of the wonderful results of the blood transfusion. By the time I finished dealing with personal matters, the day was almost over. I suddenly remembered Renfield and wanted to know news about him. All good news. He has been calm since last night. I received a telegram from Van Helsing while I was having dinner; he suggested I return to Hillingham tonight, as he thought it might be a useful thing to do. He informed me that he would return to Hillingham tomorrow morning.
tr: Early in the morning, the servant came and I handed Lucy over to her and returned home, because there were many things that worried me. I sent short telegrams to Van Helsing and Arthur, informing them of the flawless outcome of the procedure. It took me all day to finish my own tasks - which were many; by the time I managed to get information about my zoophagous patient, it was already dark. The report was good: He had been quite quiet throughout the past day and night. While I was having dinner, a telegram arrived from Van Helsing, who was in Amsterdam at the time, saying that it would be good for me to be at Hillingham tonight and that he would join me early in the morning after traveling by the night mail coach.
es: Early in the morning, his maid arrived; I left her in charge of him and returned home, as I was worried about many things. I sent a short telegram to van Helsing and Arthur, informing them of the excellent result of the transfusion. My own work, with all its setbacks, kept me busy throughout the day; it was already dark when I had the opportunity to inquire about my zoophagous patient. The report was good; he had been calm during the last day and the last night. While I was having dinner, I received a telegram from Van Helsing, from Amsterdam, suggesting that I go to Hillingham at night, as it might be convenient to be nearby, and letting me know that he would leave with the night mail and would reach me early in the morning.

en: 9 September.—I was pretty tired and worn out when I got to Hillingham. For two nights I had hardly had a wink of sleep, and my brain was beginning to feel that numbness which marks cerebral exhaustion. Lucy was up and in cheerful spirits. When she shook hands with me she looked sharply in my face and said:—
vi: • September 9 I felt very tired when I arrived at Hillingham. After two sleepless nights, my strength had significantly diminished. On the contrary, Lucy was able to stand up, and her temperament was more stable. Holding my hands tightly, looking straight into my eyes, she spoke in an emotional voice:
tr: September 9. - When I arrived at Hillingham, I was quite tired and exhausted. I had barely slept for two nights and my brain was beginning to feel the numbness indicative of fatigue. Lucy was awake and in good spirits. As she shook hands with me, she looked sharply at my face and said:
es: September 9. I was quite tired when I arrived at Hillingham. For two nights I had barely been able to sleep, and my brain was beginning to feel that numbness that indicates cerebral exhaustion. Lucy was up and cheerful. As he shook my hand, he looked me straight in the face and said:

en: “No sitting up to-night for you. You are worn out. I am quite well again; indeed, I am; and if there is to be any sitting up, it is I who will sit up with you.” I would not argue the point, but went and had my supper. Lucy came with me, and, enlivened by her charming presence, I made an excellent meal, and had a couple of glasses of the more than excellent port. Then Lucy took me upstairs, and showed me a room next her own, where a cozy fire was burning. “Now,” she said, “you must stay here. I shall leave this door open and my door too. You can lie on the sofa for I know that nothing would induce any of you doctors to go to bed whilst there is a patient above the horizon. If I want anything I shall call out, and you can come to me at once.” I could not but acquiesce, for I was “dog-tired,” and could not have sat up had I tried. So, on her renewing her promise to call me if she should want anything, I lay on the sofa, and forgot all about everything.
vi: — You don't need to stay up tonight. I assure you that I have completely recovered! If anyone needs to stay up, it should be me; I should stay up so you can sleep, right? I don't want to go against your words. We sat down to have dinner together, and being able to dine with you was truly a pleasant experience for me. I drank two glasses of fine Portuguese wine before going upstairs with Lucy. She showed me a room with a flickering fire next to her room. — There, you will rest there. I will leave both doors of the two rooms open. You will lie on the couch. I know that according to ethics, no doctor would want to lie on a bed when there is a patient. Rest assured, if anything is needed, I will call you immediately. I could only follow Lucy's advice, as honestly, I felt I no longer had the strength to stay awake. Anyway, she had promised me once again that she would call me if needed! Thinking so, I lay down on the couch with peace of mind and fell into a deep sleep just a few minutes later.
tr: “Tonight, you won't be sitting up. You are exhausted. I'm as good as I used to be, really good; if someone needs to stay up all night, I'll be the one staying up with you.” I didn't argue about it, I went and had my dinner. Lucy came with me and I had a perfect meal cheered by her pleasant presence and drank a few glasses of Porto wine that was beyond perfect. Then Lucy took me upstairs and showed me the room next to hers, where a warm fireplace was burning. “Now,” she said, “you must stay here. I will leave this door and my own door open. You can lie on the couch, because I know that when there is a patient nearby, nothing can convince you doctors to lie in bed. If I need anything, I will call out and you can come to me immediately.” I couldn't do anything but accept because I was “dog-tired” and even if I tried to stay up all night, I wouldn't be able to manage it. So, after making her promise once more that she would call out if she needed anything, I lay down on the couch and forgot everything.
es: –You will not sit up all night. You are exhausted. I am quite well again; in fact, I feel perfectly fine, and if anyone is going to take care of someone, then I will be the one to take care of you. I didn't have the energy to argue, so I went to have dinner. Lucy went up with me, and invigorated by her charming presence, I ate with quite an appetite and had a couple of glasses of the finest port. Then Lucy led me upstairs and showed me a room adjacent to hers, where a cozy fireplace was lit. "Now," she said, "you must stay here." "I will leave this door open, and also my door." "You can lie on the sofa, for I know that nothing could induce a doctor to rest properly in a bed while there is a patient nearby." "If I need anything, I will shout, and you can be by my side in a moment." I could do nothing but nod, as I was dead tired, and I wouldn't have been able to stay seated even if I had tried. So, making him renew his promise to call me if he needed anything, I lay down on the sofa and completely forgot about everything.

en: Lucy Westenra’s Diary.
vi: Lucy Westenra's Diary
tr: Lucy Westenra's diary
es: From the diary of Lucy Westenra

en: 9 September.—I feel so happy to-night. I have been so miserably weak, that to be able to think and move about is like feeling sunshine after a long spell of east wind out of a steel sky. Somehow Arthur feels very, very close to me. I seem to feel his presence warm about me. I suppose it is that sickness and weakness are selfish things and turn our inner eyes and sympathy on ourselves, whilst health and strength give Love rein, and in thought and feeling he can wander where he wills. I know where my thoughts are. If Arthur only knew! My dear, my dear, your ears must tingle as you sleep, as mine do waking. Oh, the blissful rest of last night! How I slept, with that dear, good Dr. Seward watching me. And to-night I shall not fear to sleep, since he is close at hand and within call. Thank everybody for being so good to me! Thank God! Good-night, Arthur.
vi: • September 9 It was indeed a pleasant night! The confident footsteps wandering around the house gave me a feeling as if I were strolling under the bright sunshine after a windy winter season beneath a gloomy gray sky. I suddenly felt that Arthur seemed to be very close to me, closer than usual, without understanding why. Even I could feel the warm, passionate heat emanating from him. There is no doubt anymore, it is my illness and weakness that have brought him closer to me. If only Arthur knew what I am thinking about him at this moment? Thank God for giving me a peaceful sleep last night? The presence of Dr. Seward ensured my good sleep! And tonight I will not fear sleeping either, because the doctor is still here, if needed, I just need to call out once. Everyone is so good to me! Thank God! Arthur, good night!
tr: September 9. - Tonight I feel very happy. I had become so weak that being able to think and walk again feels like sensing the daylight after a long-lasting east wind in a steel-like sky. Somehow, I feel Arthur very, very close to me. I feel as if his warm presence is warming me inside. I think illness and weakness are selfish things; they turn our inner eye and love towards ourselves, whereas health and strength leave the reins to Love, allowing thoughts and feelings to go wherever they please. I wish Arthur knew this! My dear, my dear, your ears must be ringing while you sleep, mine ring while I'm awake. Oh, the delightful sleep of last night! How well I slept while that dear, good Dr. Seward watched over me. And tonight I should not be afraid to sleep because he is so close, within calling distance. Thank you so much to everyone for treating me so well! Thank God! Good night, Arthur.
es: September 9. I feel happy tonight. I have been so tremendously weak that being able to think and move is like feeling the sun's rays after a long period of east wind and cloudy, gray skies. Arthur feels very close to me. I seem to feel his warm presence around me. I suppose it is because illness and weakness make one selfish, turning our inner eyes and sympathy upon ourselves, while health and strength give free rein to love, and in thought and feeling one can go wherever one wishes. I know where my thoughts are. If only Arthur knew! My dear, your ears must be buzzing while you sleep, just as mine buzz when I walk. Oh, the wonderful rest of last night! How I slept, with dear, good Dr. Seward watching over me. And tonight I will not be afraid to sleep, as he is very close and I can call him. Thanks to everyone for being so good to me! Thank God! Good night, Arthur.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 10 September.—I was conscious of the Professor’s hand on my head, and started awake all in a second. That is one of the things that we learn in an asylum, at any rate.
vi: • September 10 I felt someone just put their hand on my head, and I immediately thought it was the professor's hand and opened my eyes at once. In the hospital, we were used to this kind of startling awakening.
tr: September 10 - I realized the Professor's hand was on top of my head and woke up instantly. This is one of the things we learned in the mental hospital, no matter the cost.
es: September 10th. I became aware of the professor's hand on my head, and I woke up suddenly in an instant. That is one of the things we at least learn in an asylum.

en: “And how is our patient?”
vi: — So, how is our patient doing?
tr: “So, how is our patient?”
es: –And how is our patient?

en: “Well, when I left her, or rather when she left me,” I answered.
vi: — It's very good that I left her place. — Good.
tr: "Well, when I left her side, or rather, when she left my side," I began to respond.
es: –Well, when I left her, or rather, when she left me -I replied to him.

en: “Come, let us see,” he said. And together we went into the room.
vi: Go visit her! We both turned towards Lucy's room.
tr: “Come on, let's see,” he said. And we entered the room together.
es: –Come on, let's see -he said, and together we entered the adjoining room.

en: The blind was down, and I went over to raise it gently, whilst Van Helsing stepped, with his soft, cat-like tread, over to the bed.
vi: The curtain of her room's window had been lowered for some time; and to raise it, I had to tiptoe towards the window to find the pull cord. Meanwhile, the professor also very gently stepped towards Lucy's bed.
tr: The curtain was drawn, and as Van Helsing quietly moved towards the bed like a cat, I also went to slowly open the curtain.
es: The lattice was lowered, and I raised it very carefully while Van Helsing advanced, with his soft, feline step, towards the bed.

en: As I raised the blind, and the morning sunlight flooded the room, I heard the Professor’s low hiss of inspiration, and knowing its rarity, a deadly fear shot through my heart. As I passed over he moved back, and his exclamation of horror, “Gott in Himmel!” needed no enforcement from his agonised face. He raised his hand and pointed to the bed, and his iron face was drawn and ashen white. I felt my knees begin to tremble.
vi: When the curtain was drawn up, the morning light immediately flooded into the small room. I was suddenly startled when I heard the professor's astonished hiss, my heart instantly tightened. I was paralyzed when I heard the professor's muffled cry as he turned back. His terrified cry, "Heavens, Earth!" was enough for me to immediately understand the actual situation, even though I hadn't yet seen the evident pain and suffering on his face. He shakily pointed to the bed. I felt my knees about to give way.
tr: As I opened the curtain and the morning sun filled the room, I heard the Professor's sigh, and knowing how rare it was, a deadly fear pierced my heart. When I approached him, he recoiled, and there was no need for the anguished expression on his face to emphasize his exclamation of "Gott in Himmel!"27, a sign of his horror. He raised his hand and pointed to the bed; his stern face had fallen and turned ashen. I felt my knees begin to tremble.
es: When I raised the lattice and the morning light flooded the room, I heard the professor's faint hiss of intake, and knowing his peculiarity, a mortal fear froze my blood. As I approached, he stepped back, and his exclamation of horror, "Gott in Himmel!" did not need the reinforcement of his pained face. He raised his hand and pointed towards the bed, and his iron face was furrowed and white as ash. I felt my knees begin to tremble.

en: There on the bed, seemingly in a swoon, lay poor Lucy, more horribly white and wan-looking than ever. Even the lips were white, and the gums seemed to have shrunken back from the teeth, as we sometimes see in a corpse after a prolonged illness. Van Helsing raised his foot to stamp in anger, but the instinct of his life and all the long years of habit stood to him, and he put it down again softly. “Quick!” he said. “Bring the brandy.” I flew to the dining-room, and returned with the decanter. He wetted the poor white lips with it, and together we rubbed palm and wrist and heart. He felt her heart, and after a few moments of agonising suspense said:—
vi: On the bed, Lucy was lying as if unconscious, her skin pale gray like a corpse, looking weaker than ever. Her lips had turned back to a pale white, her teeth bared as if her gums were gone - a sight we often see in someone who has died after a long illness. Van Helsing seemed very angry, he was about to stomp his foot on the floor but then slowly lowered it. After a moment of anxious bewilderment, he gently told me, his voice resolute:
tr: With her terrifyingly pale color, looking more exhausted than ever, Lucy was lying on the bed as if she had fainted. Even her lips were completely white, and her gums appeared receded, as we sometimes see in corpses after a long illness. Van Helsing raised his foot to stomp the ground in anger, but the instinct for life and the habit of his many years prevented him from doing so, and he slowly lowered his foot. "Quick!" he said. "Bring the brandy." I rushed to the dining room and returned with the decanter of liquor. He moistened her poor white lips with it, and together we rubbed her palms, wrists, and heart. Van Helsing checked Lucy's heart, and after a few seconds of painful uncertainty, he said:
es: There on the bed, in an apparent faint, lay poor Lucy, more terribly white and pale than ever. Even her lips were white, and her gums seemed to have shrunk back behind her teeth, as we sometimes see in bodies after a prolonged illness. Van Helsing lifted his foot to kick in anger, but the instinct of his life and all the long years of habits restrained him, and he placed it back down gently. –Quick! – he told me-. Bring the brandy, I flew to the dining room and came back with the bottle. He moistened the poor white lips with it, and together we rubbed the palms, wrists, and heart. He listened to the heart, and after a few moments of agonizing wait, he said: "It is not too late."

en: “It is not too late. It beats, though but feebly. All our work is undone; we must begin again. There is no young Arthur here now; I have to call on you yourself this time, friend John.” As he spoke, he was dipping into his bag and producing the instruments for transfusion; I had taken off my coat and rolled up my shirt-sleeve. There was no possibility of an opiate just at present, and no need of one; and so, without a moment’s delay, we began the operation. After a time—it did not seem a short time either, for the draining away of one’s blood, no matter how willingly it be given, is a terrible feeling—Van Helsing held up a warning finger. “Do not stir,” he said, “but I fear that with growing strength she may wake; and that would make danger, oh, so much danger. But I shall precaution take. I shall give hypodermic injection of morphia.” He proceeded then, swiftly and deftly, to carry out his intent. The effect on Lucy was not bad, for the faint seemed to merge subtly into the narcotic sleep. It was with a feeling of personal pride that I could see a faint tinge of colour steal back into the pallid cheeks and lips. No man knows, till he experiences it, what it is to feel his own life-blood drawn away into the veins of the woman he loves.
vi: — It's not too late yet. Her heart is still beating, though very weak. But we must get to work immediately. Now that Arthur is no longer here, I need to rely on your generosity, my friend John! The professor spoke while pulling out some tools needed for the blood transfusion from his bag; I hurriedly took off my jacket and rolled up my shirt sleeve as high as possible. We quickly got to work. After a few minutes that seemed to stretch into eternity - it was truly grueling to feel the blood flowing out of your veins, even when you are a volunteer. Van Helsing raised his finger to warn me: — Don't move anymore, you must be patient... But I'm afraid that when her strength returns, she will wake up, and that would be very dangerous. We need to be cautious. Perhaps I should give her another dose of morphine. The dose of morphine quickly took effect, as we saw our patient seemingly transition gradually from a state of coma to a natural sleep. Honestly, I felt a surge of pride when I saw her cheeks and then her lips begin to regain their rosy color.
tr: “It is not too late yet. Her heart is beating, weak as it may be, it is beating. Everything we did was in vain; we must start over. Young Arthur is no longer here; this time I must ask you, my friend John.” As he spoke, he plunged his hand into his bag and took out the equipment needed for the blood transfusion; I had taken off my jacket and rolled up the sleeve of my shirt. At this moment, there was neither the possibility nor the necessity for a narcotic; thus, without losing a moment, we began the procedure. After a while -that while had not felt short because, although it was given willingly, the draining of one's blood is a terrifying feeling- Van Helsing raised his finger to warn me. “Do not move,” he said, “but I fear, due to her increasing strength, she may wake up and this could be dangerous, oh, it could create great danger. I must take precautions. I will inject morphine under the skin.” Swiftly and skillfully, he set to work to achieve his purpose. The effect of this procedure on Lucy was not bad because her unconsciousness gracefully blended into a drug-induced sleep. With a personal pride, I could see a faint color returning to her pale cheeks and lips. No man can know what it feels like to have his own blood drawn into the veins of the woman he loves without experiencing it.
es: He listened to the heart, and after a few moments of agonizing wait, he said: "It is not too late." It still beats, although very weakly. All our work has been lost; we must start again. There is no young Arthur here now; this time I have to ask you yourself to donate your blood, friend John. And as he spoke, he reached into the briefcase and took out the instruments for the transfusion; I took off my jacket and rolled up the sleeve of my shirt. In such a situation, there was no possibility of using a soporific, but there was also no need for one; and so, without losing a moment, we began the transfusion. After a certain amount of time (it didn't seem so short either, as the flow of one's own blood, no matter how joyfully it is viewed, is a terrible sensation), Van Helsing raised a finger in warning: –Don't move -he told me-, because I fear that when she regains her strength, she will wake up; and that would be very, very dangerous. But I will be cautious. I will give her a hypodermic injection of morphine. Then he proceeded, swiftly and surely, to carry out his plan. The effect on Lucy was not bad, as the fainting seemed to subtly transform into a narcotic sleep. It was with a feeling of personal pride that I could see a faint tint of color slowly return to her pale cheeks and lips. No man knows, until he experiences it, what it is to feel his own blood being transferred to the veins of the woman he loves.

en: The Professor watched me critically. “That will do,” he said. “Already?” I remonstrated. “You took a great deal more from Art.” To which he smiled a sad sort of smile as he replied:—
vi: Professor Van Helsing is still observing me. — Perhaps that's enough. - He said. — Enough? - I asked in surprise. - The other day, when Arthur donated blood, you left it for so long? He suddenly burst into laughter, a laugh that had something somewhat sad about it, then replied to me:
tr: The professor was watching me with critical eyes. "That's enough," he said. "So soon?" I protested. "You had taken much more from Art." He responded to what I said with a sad smile:
es: The professor was looking at me critically. –That is enough, he said. –Already? – I protested. You took quite a bit more from Art. To which he smiled with a kind of sad smile, and replied to me:

en: “He is her lover, her fiancé. You have work, much work, to do for her and for others; and the present will suffice.”
vi: — Arthur is the fiancé of the girl. As for you, you still have a lot of work to do; your duty is not only to take care of her alone, but also many other patients. That's enough for now.
tr: "Oh, the young lady's lover, her fiancé. You have a lot of work to do for her and for others, and for now, this much will suffice."
es: –He is her boyfriend, her fiancé. You have work, a lot of work to do for her and for others; and with what we have provided, it is enough.

en: When we stopped the operation, he attended to Lucy, whilst I applied digital pressure to my own incision. I laid down, whilst I waited his leisure to attend to me, for I felt faint and a little sick. By-and-by he bound up my wound, and sent me downstairs to get a glass of wine for myself. As I was leaving the room, he came after me, and half whispered:—
vi: After speaking, he turned to take care of Lucy, while I had to take care of my own necessary first steps after the blood transfusion. I stayed lying down for a bit longer, because to be honest, I felt a bit dizzy and quite weak. The professor bandaged my puncture wound and advised me to go downstairs and drink a glass of wine to regain my strength. As I opened the door to leave the room, he followed and whispered in my ear:
tr: When we stopped the procedure, while I was applying pressure to the cut with my finger, he attended to Lucy. While waiting for him to finish his work to attend to me, I lay down because I felt very exhausted and a bit sick. Soon, he bandaged my wound and sent me downstairs to get myself a glass of wine. As I was leaving the room, he followed me and almost whispered:
es: When we stopped the operation, he attended to Lucy while I applied digital pressure to my own wound. I lay down, waiting for him to have time to attend to me, as I felt weak and a bit dizzy. After a while, he bandaged my wound and sent me downstairs to drink a glass of wine. As I was leaving the room, he came behind me and whispered:

en: “Mind, nothing must be said of this. If our young lover should turn up unexpected, as before, no word to him. It would at once frighten him and enjealous him, too. There must be none. So!”
vi: — Don't say anything to anyone, okay! If your friend Arthur happens to come here, just act as if nothing happened. Because it could both make him worried and make him jealous, we should avoid it at all costs! Now, shall we go down? A moment later, when we met again, he looked at me very attentively.
tr: “Be careful, nothing should be said about this. If our young lover shows up unexpectedly as he did before, don't say a word to him. This will immediately scare and make him jealous. None of this should happen. That's why!”
es: –Remember: you must not say anything about this. If our young lover appears unexpectedly, like last time, not a word to him. On one hand, it would scare him, and on top of that, it would make him jealous. There must be none of that, right?

en: When I came back he looked at me carefully, and then said:—
vi: — Now, - he told me - you should lie down and rest for a while, maybe one or two hours, on the couch in the other room!
tr: When I turned back, he looked at me carefully and said:
es: When I returned, he examined me carefully and said:

en: “You are not much the worse. Go into the room, and lie on your sofa, and rest awhile; then have much breakfast, and come here to me.”
vi: Then after having a full lunch... Yes, you need to eat a lot and then come back here to find me!
tr: "You weren't too bad. Go to your room and lie down on your couch for a while; then have a hearty breakfast and come here to me."
es: –You are not much worse. Go to your room and rest on the sofa for a while; then have a good breakfast, and come back here again.

en: I followed out his orders, for I knew how right and wise they were. I had done my part, and now my next duty was to keep up my strength. I felt very weak, and in the weakness lost something of the amazement at what had occurred. I fell asleep on the sofa, however, wondering over and over again how Lucy had made such a retrograde movement, and how she could have been drained of so much blood with no sign anywhere to show for it. I think I must have continued my wonder in my dreams, for, sleeping and waking, my thoughts always came back to the little punctures in her throat and the ragged, exhausted appearance of their edges—tiny though they were.
vi: I obeyed him because I knew that he was right, that his advice was always sound. I did what I needed to do, and now recovering my strength is also a task I cannot shirk. Exhaustion did not prevent me from being surprised by what had happened. Lying on the couch, I kept wondering what could have caused Lucy to become so emaciated and exhausted. Why did she lose blood? Why was there no trace of anything in her room or anywhere else? Surely, whether asleep or awake, these questions kept lingering in my mind, as I knew my thoughts were always haunted by the two small wounds on Lucy's neck, two wounds with torn edges and nothing tangible within them. Our patient woke up a bit late, she looked much better, but still incomparable to her appearance last night.
tr: I followed their instructions because I knew they were correct and wise. I had done my part and my next duty was to conserve my strength. I felt very weak, and in this weakness, some of the astonishment I had felt due to what was happening had faded. But I fell asleep on the couch, wondering how Lucy had deteriorated so much and how she had lost such a large amount of blood without leaving the slightest trace. I suppose I must have continued my curiosity in my dream, because as I slept and woke, my thoughts kept revolving around the small holes in her neck and the rough, dough-like appearance of their edges, even though they were tiny.
es: I followed his orders, for I knew how correct and wise they were. I had done my part and now my next duty was to regain my strength. I felt very weak, and in the weakness, I lost some of the pleasure of what had happened. I fell asleep on the sofa; however, I kept wondering over and over again how it was that Lucy had made such a retrograde move, and how she had been able to lose so much blood without leaving any trace of it anywhere. I think I must have continued wondering this in my sleep, for, sleeping and walking, my thoughts always returned to the tiny punctures in her throat and the withered and battered appearance of their edges despite how small they were.

en: Lucy slept well into the day, and when she woke she was fairly well and strong, though not nearly so much so as the day before. When Van Helsing had seen her, he went out for a walk, leaving me in charge, with strict injunctions that I was not to leave her for a moment. I could hear his voice in the hall, asking the way to the nearest telegraph office.
vi: However, just seeing her like that was enough to comfort us. After examining her, Van Helsing went out to get some fresh air. Before leaving the room, he reminded me not to leave her alone, even for a minute. I also heard him asking someone downstairs about the nearest telegraph office.
tr: Lucy continued to sleep soundly until the later hours of the day; when she woke up, she was quite well and strong, though not as much as the previous day. After seeing her, Van Helsing gave strict orders not to leave her side for a moment and left me in charge before going out for a walk. In the hall, I heard his voice asking for the way to the nearest telegraph office.
es: Lucy slept well into the day, and when she woke up she was quite well and strong, though not as much as the day before. When Van Helsing had seen her, he went out for a walk, leaving me in charge of her, with strict instructions not to leave her for a moment. I could hear his voice in the corridor, asking which way to the nearest telegraph office.

en: Lucy chatted with me freely, and seemed quite unconscious that anything had happened. I tried to keep her amused and interested. When her mother came up to see her, she did not seem to notice any change whatever, but said to me gratefully:—
vi: Lucy innocently continued to chat with me at length, as if she was completely unaware of what had just happened. I tried to make her happy, engaging her in one story after another. And when her mother came to visit, I believed that she also did not notice any change in her. — We really don't know what to do to thank you for all that you and your student have done for us? - She said to me with a voice full of deep gratitude. -
tr: Lucy chatted with me comfortably, as if she was unaware that something was wrong. I tried to keep her occupied and interested. When her mother came upstairs to see her, she didn't seem to notice any change, but she gratefully said to me:
es: Lucy chatted with me cheerfully, and seemed completely unaware of what had happened. I tried to keep her entertained and interested. When her mother came up to see her, she didn't seem to notice any change in her, and only said to me gratefully:

en: “We owe you so much, Dr. Seward, for all you have done, but you really must now take care not to overwork yourself. You are looking pale yourself. You want a wife to nurse and look after you a bit; that you do!” As she spoke, Lucy turned crimson, though it was only momentarily, for her poor wasted veins could not stand for long such an unwonted drain to the head. The reaction came in excessive pallor as she turned imploring eyes on me. I smiled and nodded, and laid my finger on my lips; with a sigh, she sank back amid her pillows.
vi: But now, you should also take care of yourself a bit, don't let yourself become so exhausted. You look so pale today! Maybe you should get married, your wife will take care of you, will be devoted to you, in my opinion, that's what you should do at this moment! Lucy suddenly blushed, the poor blood vessels in her body no longer had enough blood to supply her brain. After a while, her face gradually turned a pale gray, and she looked at me pleadingly. I smiled, nodded, and put my finger to my lips to signal her. She sighed and let herself fall back onto the pillow.
tr: "Dr. Seward, we owe you a great deal for all you have done, but seriously, you must take care not to overwork yourself. You look pale as well. You need a wife to look after you and take care of you; yes, indeed!" As he said this, Lucy blushed, if only for a moment, because her veins, wasted by illness, could not endure such an unusual amount of blood rushing to her head for long. Her reaction was an excessive pallor when she turned to me with pleading eyes. I smiled and nodded, putting my finger to my lips; she sighed and sank back into her pillows.
es: We owe you so much, Dr. Seward, for everything you have done! But really now you must be careful not to overwork yourself. You look a bit pale yourself. You need a woman to serve as a nurse and take care of you a bit; that's what you need! As she spoke, Lucy blushed, although it was only momentarily, for her poor worn-out veins could not withstand the sudden rush of blood to her head. The reaction came as an excessive paleness when she turned her imploring eyes towards me. I smiled and shook my head, and brought my finger to my lips; exhaling a sigh, the young woman sank back into her pillows.

en: Van Helsing returned in a couple of hours, and presently said to me: “Now you go home, and eat much and drink enough. Make yourself strong. I stay here to-night, and I shall sit up with little miss myself. You and I must watch the case, and we must have none other to know. I have grave reasons. No, do not ask them; think what you will. Do not fear to think even the most not-probable. Good-night.”
vi: Two hours later, Van Helsing returned. As soon as he saw me, he immediately said: — Go home, and remember to eat a lot to regain your strength. Tonight, I will stay here with the little girl. You and I will have to study this case together, but don't let anyone know what we're doing. I have thought of some very serious reasons, but I won't tell you about them at this moment. Just keep thinking what you are thinking, and don't be afraid to think about things you believe are unthinkable. Good night?
tr: Within a few hours, Van Helsing returned and immediately said: "Now you go home and eat and drink plenty. Strengthen yourself. Tonight, I will stay here and keep watch over the young lady. We must monitor the situation and not let anyone else learn about it. I have very important reasons for this. No, don't ask what they are; think whatever you want. Don't hesitate to consider even the most unlikely possibilities. Good night."
es: Van Helsing returned after a few hours and said to me: –Now you go home, and eat a lot and drink plenty. Recover. I will stay here tonight, and I will sit myself next to the young lady. You and I must observe the case, and we cannot allow anyone else to know. I have strong reasons. No, do not ask me about them; think what you want. Do not be afraid to think even the most improbable. Good night.

en: In the hall two of the maids came to me, and asked if they or either of them might not sit up with Miss Lucy. They implored me to let them; and when I said it was Dr. Van Helsing’s wish that either he or I should sit up, they asked me quite piteously to intercede with the “foreign gentleman.” I was much touched by their kindness. Perhaps it is because I am weak at present, and perhaps because it was on Lucy’s account, that their devotion was manifested; for over and over again have I seen similar instances of woman’s kindness. I got back here in time for a late dinner; went my rounds—all well; and set this down whilst waiting for sleep. It is coming.
vi: Down the hallway, two servants came running to ask me if they - or at least one of them - could stay the night with Lucy. They pleaded with me to allow them to go to her room. And when I replied that Professor Van Helsing only wanted one of us to stay up and watch over the patient, they burst into tears and asked me to speak to that "foreign gentleman" on their behalf. Their gestures moved me so deeply that I couldn't express this: they might have done so because they saw I was too exhausted, or because they wanted to show their kindness and dedication to Lucy. I returned to the psychiatric hospital just in time to have dinner before visiting my patients; everything is fine. And now, I am writing these diary lines while waiting for sleep. A quick and deep sleep is what I hope will happen.
tr: Two maids came to me and asked if both of them or one of them could stay up all night with Miss Lucy. They begged me to allow it; when I told them that Dr. Van Helsing's wish was that only he or I should stay up with Lucy, they quite heartbreakingly asked me to plead with the foreign gentleman. Their kindness touched me deeply. Perhaps I was so affected because I am weak at the moment, or perhaps their devotion was entirely due to Lucy, because I have seen similar acts of kindness from women many times before. I returned here in time for a late dinner; I checked on my patients - they were all well; and I am recording this while waiting for sleep. And now, sleep is coming.”
es: In the hallway, two of the maids came to me and asked if they or any of them could stay the night with Miss Lucy. They implored me to let them, and when I told them it was an order from Dr. Van Helsing that either he or I should watch over her, they asked me to intercede with the "foreign gentleman." I was very moved by that kindness. Perhaps because I am weak at the moment, and perhaps because it was for Lucy that their devotion was manifested; for time and again I have seen similar displays of women's kindness. I returned here in time for lunch; I made all my visits and all my patients were well; and then I sat down while I waited for sleep to come. It is coming now.

en: 11 September.—This afternoon I went over to Hillingham. Found Van Helsing in excellent spirits, and Lucy much better. Shortly after I had arrived, a big parcel from abroad came for the Professor. He opened it with much impressment—assumed, of course—and showed a great bundle of white flowers.
vi: • September 11 This afternoon, I returned to Hillingham. Lucy seemed much better, which made Van Helsing very pleased. Shortly after I arrived, someone brought a rather large package to the professor from abroad. He hurriedly but very gently opened the package and then turned to give Lucy a large bouquet of white flowers:
tr: September 11. - This afternoon I went to Hillingham. I found Van Helsing in an excellent mood and Lucy much better. Shortly after my arrival, a large package arrived for the Professor from abroad. He opened it, looking very impressed - supposedly, of course - and showed a huge bunch of white flowers.
es: September 11th. This afternoon I went to Hillingham. I found van Helsing in excellent spirits and Lucy much better. Shortly after my arrival, the mail brought a very large package for the professor. He opened it quite hastily, or so it seemed to me, and showed me a large bouquet of white flowers.

en: “These are for you, Miss Lucy,” he said.
vi: — For you, Lucy!
tr: "These are for you, Miss Lucy," he said.
es: –These are for you, Miss Lucy -he said.

en: “For me? Oh, Dr. Van Helsing!”
vi: — For me? Oh! Doctor Van Helsing?
tr: "For me?" "Oh, Dr. Van Helsing!""
es: –For me? Oh, Doctor Van Helsing!

en: “Yes, my dear, but not for you to play with. These are medicines.” Here Lucy made a wry face. “Nay, but they are not to take in a decoction or in nauseous form, so you need not snub that so charming nose, or I shall point out to my friend Arthur what woes he may have to endure in seeing so much beauty that he so loves so much distort. Aha, my pretty miss, that bring the so nice nose all straight again. This is medicinal, but you do not know how. I put him in your window, I make pretty wreath, and hang him round your neck, so that you sleep well. Oh yes! they, like the lotus flower, make your trouble forgotten. It smell so like the waters of Lethe, and of that fountain of youth that the Conquistadores sought for in the Floridas, and find him all too late.”
vi: — That's right, dear girl, but it's not to decorate the room. It's all medicine. - Hearing that, Lucy wrinkled her nose. - But it's not for making tea or brewing with that awful taste that you have to fear. Don't make that face or Arthur will laugh at you, it looks bad… Oh! There, your pretty nose is back to normal! That's better! This is indeed medicine, but you don't need to ingest it. I will place some flowers on the window, and the rest will be made into a garland to hang around your neck so you can sleep peacefully.
