This one ain’t been used to fightin’ or even to providin’ for hisself, and more like he’s somewhere round the Park a-’idin’ an’ a-shiverin’ of, and, if he thinks at all, wonderin’ where he is to get his breakfast from; or maybe he’s got down some area and is in a coal-cellar. My eye, won’t some cook get a rum start when she sees his green eyes a-shining at her out of the dark! If he can’t get food he’s bound to look for it, and mayhap he may chance to light on a butcher’s shop in time. If he doesn’t, and some nursemaid goes a-walkin’ orf with a soldier, leavin’ of the hinfant in the perambulator—well, then I shouldn’t be surprised if the census is one babby the less. That’s all.”
vi: — To be honest, I believe that wolf is hiding somewhere. That soldier said the animal ran madly towards the north, it ran even faster than a horse. I don't believe it, because you see, wolves sometimes run even slower than domestic dogs. That kid is just talking nonsense. Wolves can be terrifying creatures in mythical stories, when they gather together to hunt down some weak animal. But fortunately, God has mercy? In real life, wolves are even less capable than a domestic dog: they are more foolish and much less daring. That Bersicker, not trained in fighting or hunting, is probably just wandering around somewhere in this zoo waiting to starve to death. It could also be hiding in some coal cellar further away. Or perhaps, unable to find anything to eat, it has gone to lurk around a butcher's shop... and that's that! If not, it might have been thrown into some soldier's cart. If that happened, I wouldn't be surprised, because there are plenty of people around here. So, I think the story could end like that.
tr: “I think this way: The wolf is hiding somewhere. The gardener said it galloped northward faster than a horse could go; but I don't believe him, because you know sir, wolves don't gallop, nor do dogs, they weren't made that way. Wolves are good in storybooks and, in my opinion, when they are in packs and chasing something more scared of them, they can make a lot of noise and tear apart whatever they are chasing. But God bless you, in real life, the wolf is a weak creature, not half as smart or brave as a good dog, and it doesn't have even a quarter of the fight in it. This wolf isn't even used to fighting or taking care of itself and is most likely hiding somewhere in the zoo, trembling, and if it can think at all, it's wondering where it will find its breakfast; or it has gone a bit lower and is in a coal cellar. Come on! Won't the cook who goes down to get a bottle of rum be surprised to see its green eyes staring at him! If it can't find food, it will have to search, and maybe after a while, it will spot a butcher's shop by chance. If not, if a soldier goes for a walk and leaves the baby in the pram - well, I won't be surprised if there's one baby less in the census. That's all.”
es: –My opinion is this: that wolf is hiding somewhere, the gardener says he saw it galloping north faster than a horse would; but I don't believe him, because, you know, sir, wolves don't gallop any more than dogs do, as they are not built that way. Wolves are very nice in storybooks, and I would say when they gather in packs and start harassing something that is more scared than they are, they can make a devil of a racket and tear it to pieces, whatever it is. But, God bless him, in real life a wolf is just an inferior creature, not half as intelligent as a good dog; and they don't have a quarter of their fighting ability. This one that escaped is not used to fighting, not even to procuring its own food, and most likely it is somewhere in the park hiding and trembling, if it is capable of thinking about anything, wondering where it will be able to get its breakfast; or maybe it has retreated and is holed up in a coal cave. Ugh! The fright some cook is going to get when they go down and see its green eyes shining in the dark. If it can't get food, it is very likely that it will go out looking for it, and it might just happen to end up at a butcher's shop in time. "If that doesn't happen and some governess goes for a walk with her soldier, leaving the infant in their baby carriage, well, then I wouldn't be surprised if the census shows one less child. That's all.

en: I was handing him the half-sovereign, when something came bobbing up against the window, and Mr. Bilder’s face doubled its natural length with surprise.
vi: I was handing the old man half a pound as we had bargained when something suddenly appeared outside the window and thumped against the glass pane. The old man Bilder's face, which was already long, grew even longer in astonishment.
tr: As something appeared at the window, I was handing him half a gold coin, and Mr. Bilder's face doubled its normal length in astonishment.
es: He was handing over the half-sovereign when something appeared at the window, and Mr. Bilder's face lengthened to twice its natural dimensions due to the surprise.

en: “God bless me!” he said. “If there ain’t old Bersicker come back by ’isself!”
vi: — Oh Lord! - He exclaimed - If that isn't the old wolf Bersicker returning, then what else could it be?
tr: “God bless me!” he said. “If old Bersicker hasn't come back on his own!”
es: God bless me! – he exclaimed -. There is old Bersicker back, without anyone bringing him!

en: He went to the door and opened it; a most unnecessary proceeding it seemed to me. I have always thought that a wild animal never looks so well as when some obstacle of pronounced durability is between us; a personal experience has intensified rather than diminished that idea.
vi: The old man stood up abruptly to open the door - an action which I thought was pointless. I always believed that a wild animal would never stay in one place once it recognized an obstacle between it and us. Experience has helped me affirm the correctness of this thought.
tr: He went and opened the door; in my opinion, a rather unnecessary action. I have always thought that a wild animal never looks as beautiful as when there is a solid barrier between us; personal experience has strengthened this thought rather than weakened it.
es: He got up and went to the door to open it; a procedure that seemed unnecessary to me. I have always thought that a wild animal is never as attractive as when some obstacle of known durability is between it and me; personal experience has intensified, rather than diminished, this idea.

en: After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither Bilder nor his wife thought any more of the wolf than I should of a dog. The animal itself was as peaceful and well-behaved as that father of all picture-wolves—Red Riding Hood’s quondam friend, whilst moving her confidence in masquerade.
vi: Indeed, old man Bilder and his wife were not afraid of wolves as I was afraid of domestic dogs. Contrary to my expectations, the animal remained calmly outside the door with a surprisingly gentle demeanor. It was so obedient that it made me recall its ancestor in the fairy tale of Little Red Riding Hood before revealing its true nature.
tr: But ultimately, there's nothing like habit because neither Bilder's nor his wife's thoughts about the wolf were different from what I thought about dogs. The animal itself, the ancestor of all known wolves, Little Red Riding Hood's old friend, was as peaceful and well-mannered as when he gained the girl's trust in disguise.
es: After all, however, there is nothing like custom, for neither Bilder nor his wife thought any more of the wolf than I would think of a dog. The animal itself was as peaceful as the father of all those wolf tales, the old-time friend of Little Red Riding Hood, while disguised trying to earn her trust.

en: The whole scene was an unutterable mixture of comedy and pathos. The wicked wolf that for half a day had paralysed London and set all the children in the town shivering in their shoes, was there in a sort of penitent mood, and was received and petted like a sort of vulpine prodigal son. Old Bilder examined him all over with most tender solicitude, and when he had finished with his penitent said:—
vi: The scene of it returning to its nest had something both humorous and touching that I couldn't possibly describe. The vicious wolf that had made the entire city of London fearful for nearly a whole day suddenly appeared right in front of us with a completely different demeanor. Old man Bilder eagerly checked the animal from head to toe and then shouted:
tr: The entire scene was an indescribable tragicomedy. The bad wolf, who had paralyzed all of London for half a day and caused the children in the city to tremble in their shoes, stood at the door in remorse and was welcomed and caressed like a cunning, prodigal son. Old Bilder examined him from head to toe with a gentle concern and, when he was done with this penitent, said:
es: The whole scene was a complicated mix of comedy and tragedy. The wicked wolf that for a day and a half had paralyzed London and made all the children in the village tremble in their shoes, was there with a penitent look, and was being received and petted like some sort of vulpine prodigal son. Old Bilder examined him all over with the most tender attention, and when he had finished examining the penitent, he said:

en: “There, I knew the poor old chap would get into some kind of trouble; didn’t I say it all along? Here’s his head all cut and full of broken glass. ’E’s been a-gettin’ over some bloomin’ wall or other. It’s a shyme that people are allowed to top their walls with broken bottles. This ’ere’s what comes of it. Come along, Bersicker.”
vi: — I knew it, I knew this animal would get into trouble; didn't I say so since yesterday? Look at its snout, it's all torn up, and it's still covered in glass shards! It must have tried to break through a wall. It's really shameful for any household that likes to put broken glass on their walls. See, it's terrible... Come here, Bersicker...
tr: “See, I knew that poor old man would get into trouble; didn't I say so from the beginning? His head is full of cuts and broken glass pieces. He must have jumped over a damn wall or something. It's a shame that people are allowed to put broken bottles on top of their walls. Look, this is what happens in the end. Come on now. Bersicker.”
es: –Wow, I already knew that the poor animal was going to get into some kind of trouble! Didn't I always say so? Here is its head all cut and full of broken glass. Surely it tried to jump over some wall or something else. It's a shame that people are allowed to put pieces of bottles on top of their walls. These are the results. Come with me, Bersicker.

en: He took the wolf and locked him up in a cage, with a piece of meat that satisfied, in quantity at any rate, the elementary conditions of the fatted calf, and went off to report.
vi: The old man gently pulled the animal into a stall and then locked the door.
tr: He took the wolf and locked it in a cage along with a piece of meat that probably matched the amount of a well-fed calf, and went to report the situation.
es: He took the wolf and locked it in a cage with a piece of meat that satisfied, at least in terms of quantity, the basic conditions of a fat calf, and then went to write the report.

en: I came off, too, to report the only exclusive information that is given to-day regarding the strange escapade at the Zoo.
vi: He did not forget to toss it a piece of meat before heading to the house of the team leader to report the animal's return.
tr: I also set out to report the only specific information given today about the strange escape at the zoo.
es: I also went to make the report on the unique and exclusive information given today regarding the strange escape from the zoo.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 17 September.—I was engaged after dinner in my study posting up my books, which, through press of other work and the many visits to Lucy, had fallen sadly into arrear. Suddenly the door was burst open, and in rushed my patient, with his face distorted with passion. I was thunderstruck, for such a thing as a patient getting of his own accord into the Superintendent’s study is almost unknown. Without an instant’s pause he made straight at me. He had a dinner-knife in his hand, and, as I saw he was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. He was too quick and too strong for me, however; for before I could get my balance he had struck at me and cut my left wrist rather severely. Before he could strike again, however, I got in my right and he was sprawling on his back on the floor. My wrist bled freely, and quite a little pool trickled on to the carpet. I saw that my friend was not intent on further effort, and occupied myself binding up my wrist, keeping a wary eye on the prostrate figure all the time. When the attendants rushed in, and we turned our attention to him, his employment positively sickened me. He was lying on his belly on the floor licking up, like a dog, the blood which had fallen from my wounded wrist. He was easily secured, and, to my surprise, went with the attendants quite placidly, simply repeating over and over again: “The blood is the life! The blood is the life!”
vi: • September 17 After finishing dinner, I returned to my room, planning to schedule the next few working days. Suddenly, my door burst open, followed by the abrupt appearance of Renfield: he charged straight at me with a very fierce expression. I stood there stunned, as it was very rare for a patient to unexpectedly seek out the head doctor without anyone's permission. He was brandishing a gleaming knife. I immediately realized that in his madness, he could become very dangerous, so I cautiously stepped back, intending to use the wooden table as a barrier between him and me. But he was quicker than I was; before I could regain my balance, he had already slashed my left wrist quite deeply. However, not allowing him to swing the knife a second time, I immediately lunged at him, pushing him flat onto the floor. Blood from the wound on my hand pooled into a small puddle on the carpet. Renfield remained lying still, seemingly not intending to attack again. It was only then that I had time to bandage my wound while keeping my eyes fixed on the patient. When the attendants arrived, we gathered around to lift him up and push him back to his room, but he started thrashing and suddenly turned around to do something that astonished me once again: he crawled on the floor like a dog and licked up the blood that had just dripped from my wound. As he licked, he kept muttering the same phrase over and over: “Blood is life? Blood is life!”
tr: September 17 - After dinner, due to the pressure of other tasks and the numerous visits to Lucy, I unfortunately worked in my room to complete my remaining tasks. Suddenly, the door opened and my patient, whose face was contorted with anger, burst in. I was stunned, because it was almost unheard of for a patient to enter the Administrator's room of their own accord. Without hesitating for even a moment, he came directly at me. He had a dinner knife in his hand, and seeing that it was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. But he was far too fast and far too strong for me; thus, before I could regain my balance, he struck me with the knife and cut my left wrist quite seriously. However, before he could attack again, I lunged at him with my right hand and knocked him flat on his back. My wrist was bleeding heavily, forming a small pool on the carpet. Seeing that my friend had no intention of further struggle, I busied myself with bandaging my wrist without taking my eyes off the person lying on the ground. When the nurses rushed in and we turned our attention to him, what he was doing absolutely sickened me. Lying face down on the floor, like a dog, he was licking the blood that had dripped from my wounded wrist. He was easily caught and, to my surprise, went quite docilely with the nurses; as he left, he kept repeating these words: "The blood is the life! The blood is the life!"
es: September 17th. I was busy, after dinner, in my study dating my books, which, due to the urgency of other work and the many visits to Lucy, were sadly behind. Suddenly, the door burst open and my patient entered like a whirlwind, his face distorted with anxiety. I was startled, as it is almost unheard of for a patient to enter in such a manner and on their own into the superintendent's office. Without any pause, he headed directly towards me. In his hand was a kitchen knife, and seeing that it was dangerous, I tried to keep the table between us. However, he was too quick and too strong for me; before I could regain my balance, he had struck the first blow, cutting my left wrist quite deeply. But before he could strike me again, I punched him with my right hand and he fell to the floor with his arms and legs spread out. My wrist was bleeding profusely, and a small pool formed on the carpet. I saw that my friend did not seem to be making another effort, so I focused on bandaging my wrist, all the while keeping a cautious watch on the prostrate figure. When my assistants came running in and we turned our attention to him, his appearance positively sickened me. He was lying on his stomach on the floor, licking like a dog the blood that had fallen from my wounded wrist. We restrained him easily, and to my surprise, he allowed himself to be taken away quite docilely by the assistants, repeating over and over: –"Blood is life!" "Blood is life!"

en: I cannot afford to lose blood just at present; I have lost too much of late for my physical good, and then the prolonged strain of Lucy’s illness and its horrible phases is telling on me. I am over-excited and weary, and I need rest, rest, rest. Happily Van Helsing has not summoned me, so I need not forego my sleep; to-night I could not well do without it.
vi: Actually, I shouldn't have been careless enough to lose these drops of blood, even if it was just one drop. In the past few days, I have given enough blood already; what if Lucy loses blood again? I can't do any more, it seems like I am about to fall into exhaustion if I don't get a night's rest. Oh! Sleep? How I wish to sleep! Fortunately, Van Helsing didn't call for me, so I can sleep for a long time now.
tr: Right now, I cannot afford to lose any more blood: I have already lost too much blood for my physical well-being, and besides, the prolonged tension caused by Lucy's illness and its horrifying stages has badly affected me. I am overly excited and exhausted; I need to rest, rest, rest. Fortunately, Van Helsing did not call me, so I don't have to give up my sleep; I couldn't manage without it tonight.
es: I cannot afford to lose blood at present; I have already lost too much lately to be healthy, in addition to the prolonged strain of Lucy's illness and its horrible phases which are wearing me down. I am very irritated and tired, and I need rest, rest, rest. Fortunately, Van Helsing has not called me, so I do not need to deprive myself of sleep this time; I don't think I could go without a good rest tonight.

en: Telegram, Van Helsing, Antwerp, to Seward, Carfax.
vi: Telegram from Van Helsing, Antwerp to Seward, Carfax
tr: From Van Helsing in Antwerp to Carfax Telegram to Seward
es: Telegram from van Helsing to Seward, in Carfax

en: (Sent to Carfax, Sussex, as no county given; delivered late by twenty-two hours.)
vi: Telegram from Van Helsing, Antwerp to Seward, Carfax
tr: (Since the district is not specified, Carfax, Sussex sent; arrived twenty-two hours late.)
es: (Sent to Carfax, Sussex, as it did not mention any county; delivered with a delay of twenty-two hours.)

en: “17 September.—Do not fail to be at Hillingham to-night. If not watching all the time frequently, visit and see that flowers are as placed; very important; do not fail. Shall be with you as soon as possible after arrival.”
vi: September 17 Tonight, remember to return to Hillingham. If you can't stay up all night, you should at least frequently check her room to see if the flowers are still in their proper place. It's very important. When I get to London, I will try to meet you as soon as possible within reason."
tr: September 17. - Do not neglect to be at Hillingham tonight. If you cannot stay by her side constantly, go to her room frequently and make sure the flowers are in place; it is very important; do not neglect it. I will be with you as early as possible when I arrive.
es: September 17. Do not fail to be at Hillingham tonight. If not observing all the time, visit frequently and ensure that the flowers are placed; very important; do not fail. I will be with you as soon as possible after arrival.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 18 September.—Just off for train to London. The arrival of Van Helsing’s telegram filled me with dismay. A whole night lost, and I know by bitter experience what may happen in a night. Of course it is possible that all may be well, but what may have happened? Surely there is some horrible doom hanging over us that every possible accident should thwart us in all we try to do. I shall take this cylinder with me, and then I can complete my entry on Lucy’s phonograph.
vi: • September 18 I will take the train to London again. Van Helsing's telegram made me feel like my legs were about to give way. Good Lord! The experiences from the last few times have shown me what can happen in a single night. Things might go smoothly, but could the worst also happen? There must be some kind of curse haunting us, as every effort we make is met with the opposite of what we desire. The memorandum left by Lucy Westenra
tr: September 18. - I have just set out for the London train. The arrival of Van Helsing’s telegram upset me greatly. A whole night was lost, and through a bitter experience, I know what can happen in a single night. Of course, there is a possibility that everything is fine, but what could have happened? Clearly, there is a dreadful fate hovering over us, as every possible accident is hindering everything we try to do. I will take this cylinder with me, and thus I can complete my record on Lucy’s phonograph.
es: September 18. I have just taken the train to London. The arrival of van Helsing's telegram filled me with anxiety. An entire night lost, and from bitter experience, I know what can happen in a night. Of course, it is possible that everything is fine, but what could have happened? Surely there is a horrible fate hanging over us, which causes every possible accident to thwart what we are trying to do. I will take this cylinder with me, and then I will be able to complete my notes on Lucy's phonograph.

en: Memorandum left by Lucy Westenra.
vi: The memorandum left by Lucy Westenra
tr: The note left by Lucy Westenra
es: Memorandum left by Lucy Westenra

en: 17 September. Night.—I write this and leave it to be seen, so that no one may by any chance get into trouble through me. This is an exact record of what took place to-night. I feel I am dying of weakness, and have barely strength to write, but it must be done if I die in the doing.
vi: • September 17 I am writing these lines on loose sheets of paper so that someone can find and read them, because I want them to know exactly what happened tonight. I feel that I will die from weakness. Holding the pen to write is extremely difficult for me now, but I must write, even if the Grim Reaper intends to hold my pen tightly.
tr: September 17. Night. - I am writing this and leaving it to be seen so that no one gets into trouble because of me. This is a complete record of what happened tonight. I think I am dying of weakness and can barely find the strength to write, but I must write even if I die doing so.
es: September 17. Night. I write this and leave it so that it can be seen, in order that no one may find themselves in trouble because of me. This is an exact record of what happened tonight. I feel that I am dying of weakness and I barely have the strength to write, but I must do it, even if I die in the attempt.

en: I went to bed as usual, taking care that the flowers were placed as Dr. Van Helsing directed, and soon fell asleep.
vi: As usual, I lay down on the bed after putting a garland around my neck as ordered by Professor Van Helsing, and I fell asleep almost immediately.
tr: As usual, I lay down paying attention to whether the flowers were placed in the spots indicated by Dr. Van Helsing, and soon fell asleep.
es: I went to bed as usual, making sure that the flowers were placed as Dr. Van Helsing had ordered, and soon I fell asleep.

en: I was waked by the flapping at the window, which had begun after that sleep-walking on the cliff at Whitby when Mina saved me, and which now I know so well. I was not afraid, but I did wish that Dr. Seward was in the next room—as Dr. Van Helsing said he would be—so that I might have called him. I tried to go to sleep, but could not. Then there came to me the old fear of sleep, and I determined to keep awake. Perversely sleep would try to come then when I did not want it; so, as I feared to be alone, I opened my door and called out: “Is there anybody there?” There was no answer. I was afraid to wake mother, and so closed my door again. Then outside in the shrubbery I heard a sort of howl like a dog’s, but more fierce and deeper. I went to the window and looked out, but could see nothing, except a big bat, which had evidently been buffeting its wings against the window. So I went back to bed again, but determined not to go to sleep. Presently the door opened, and mother looked in; seeing by my moving that I was not asleep, came in, and sat by me. She said to me even more sweetly and softly than her wont:—
vi: But I was awakened by the sound of wings flapping against the window, the same sounds I first heard when I was in Whitby, precisely when I was sleepwalking and wandered up the cliff, causing Mina to come looking for me, and since then, I have often heard those eerie wing flaps. Though not afraid, I still wanted Dr. Seward in the next room so I could call him if needed. I tried to fall back asleep but couldn't. And then the fear of falling asleep again overwhelmed me, forcing me to decide not to sleep anymore. But strangely, the more I tried to stay awake, the heavier the drowsiness weighed on me. The feeling of loneliness scared me. I jumped up, opened the door, and called out, "Is anyone there?" There was no response. I didn't dare call again for fear of waking my mother. Just as I closed the door, a howl, more mournful and terrifying than a dog's, echoed from somewhere beneath the bushes. I went to the window and leaned out to see what was in the darkness, but I couldn't make out anything except a large bat - perhaps the same creature that often flapped its wings against my window. I returned to bed but didn't feel sleepy again. A moment later, my mother slightly opened the door and peeked in. Seeing that I was awake, she stepped in and sat near my bed. She gently took my hand and spoke to me in a voice much softer and gentler than usual:
tr: I woke up to the sound of wings outside the window, which I now know very well, starting from my sleepwalking episode on the slope in Whitby where Mina had saved me. I wasn't afraid, but I wished Dr. Seward—or as Dr. Van Helsing suggested—was in the next room so I could call out to him. I tried to sleep, but I couldn't. Then, as before, I became afraid to sleep and decided to stay awake. Ironically, whenever I don't want to sleep, sleep tries to come; so, fearing to be alone, I opened my door and called out, "Is anyone there?" No response came. I hesitated to wake my mother, so I closed my door again. Then, from the bushes outside, I heard a howl that resembled a dog's but was harsher and deeper. I went to the window and looked out but saw nothing except a large bat clearly hitting the window with its wings. So I returned to bed but decided not to sleep. A little later, the door opened, and my mother looked in; she realized I was awake from my movement and came in to sit beside me. In a voice even sweeter and softer than usual, she said, "I was worried about you, my dear, and came to see if you were alright."
es: I was awakened by the flapping at the window, which had begun since that night when I sleepwalked to the Whitby gorge, where Mina saved me, and which I now know so well. I wasn't afraid, but I did wish that Dr. Seward was in the adjoining room (as Dr. Van Helsing had said he would be), so that I could speak to him at any moment. I tried to fall asleep again, but I couldn't. Then the old anguish from before falling asleep returned, and I decided to stay awake. Perversely, sleep tried to return when I no longer wanted to sleep; so, fearing to be alone, I opened my door and shouted: "Is anyone there?" I received no response. I was afraid of waking up my mother, so I closed the door again. Then, outside, in the bushes, I heard a kind of dog howl, but fiercer and deeper. I went to the window and looked outside, but I couldn't make out anything except a large bat, which had evidently been flapping its wings against the window. So I returned to bed again, but with the firm determination not to fall asleep. At that moment, the door opened and my mother looked through it; seeing from my movement that I wasn't asleep, she came in and sat by my side. She spoke to me, more sweetly and gently than usual:

en: “I was uneasy about you, darling, and came in to see that you were all right.”
vi: — Mom kept wondering if you needed anything, my dear daughter, so she had to come up here to be sure.
tr: In a voice even sweeter and softer than usual, she said, "I was worried about you, my dear, and came to see if you were alright."
es: –I was worried about you, dear, and I came in to see if you were alright.

en: I feared she might catch cold sitting there, and asked her to come in and sleep with me, so she came into bed, and lay down beside me; she did not take off her dressing gown, for she said she would only stay a while and then go back to her own bed. As she lay there in my arms, and I in hers, the flapping and buffeting came to the window again. She was startled and a little frightened, and cried out: “What is that?” I tried to pacify her, and at last succeeded, and she lay quiet; but I could hear her poor dear heart still beating terribly. After a while there was the low howl again out in the shrubbery, and shortly after there was a crash at the window, and a lot of broken glass was hurled on the floor. The window blind blew back with the wind that rushed in, and in the aperture of the broken panes there was the head of a great, gaunt grey wolf. Mother cried out in a fright, and struggled up into a sitting posture, and clutched wildly at anything that would help her. Amongst other things, she clutched the wreath of flowers that Dr. Van Helsing insisted on my wearing round my neck, and tore it away from me. For a second or two she sat up, pointing at the wolf, and there was a strange and horrible gurgling in her throat; then she fell over—as if struck with lightning, and her head hit my forehead and made me dizzy for a moment or two. The room and all round seemed to spin round. I kept my eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf drew his head back, and a whole myriad of little specks seemed to come blowing in through the broken window, and wheeling and circling round like the pillar of dust that travellers describe when there is a simoon in the desert. I tried to stir, but there was some spell upon me, and dear mother’s poor body, which seemed to grow cold already—for her dear heart had ceased to beat—weighed me down; and I remembered no more for a while.
vi: Afraid that she might catch a cold, I told her to lie down next to me, but she said she only intended to stay for a while before returning to her room. Even while snug in her arms, I was startled because that bizarre noise suddenly echoed again. My mother also jumped and exclaimed, "What was that? "I had to find words to reassure her. Finally, she lay down beside me, although her heart was still pounding. But then I was startled once more because something suddenly struck the windowpane, shattering it. Shards of glass scattered all over the yard. The curtain fluttered in the wind like a ghost. My body began to tremble like a leaf when I saw the head of a large, emaciated wolf poking through the broken window. My mother let out a terrified scream. She sat up on the bed, her hands flailing wildly as if trying to grab something for protection. In her panic, she tore off the garland around my neck and threw it across the room. After that desperate act, she sat there dazed as if she had lost her soul, while her hand still pointed towards the wolf like a statue. After a moment, she suddenly collapsed as if struck by lightning, her head hitting my forehead. I was stunned for a moment. The room, and everything around it, seemed to be spinning before my eyes, but I kept my gaze fixed on the window; the wolf had disappeared. Tiny specks swirled into the room through the broken window - this scene reminded me of sand columns swept up by the wind in the desert. I tried to sit up but to no avail, some mysterious force prevented me from doing so. My mother's body now seemed slightly cold...Suddenly, I lost consciousness of everything. Everything that happened afterward did not linger in my memory.
tr: I was afraid she might catch a chill sitting there, so I asked her to come and sleep with me. She got into bed and lay down beside me; she didn't take off her dressing gown because she said she would only stay for a little while and then return to her own bed. There, as she lay in my arms and I in hers, we again heard the sound of wings at the window. My mother was startled, a little frightened, and cried out, "What was that?" I tried to calm her, and eventually succeeded, and she lay quietly; but I could hear her poor heart beating wildly. A while later, the deep howling sound came again from the bushes, and shortly after, there was a great crash at the window, and a large amount of broken glass scattered on the floor. The curtain blew open with the wind that rushed in; in the opening of the broken window stood the head of a giant, gaunt, gray wolf. My mother screamed in fear and struggled to sit up in bed, reaching for something that might help her. Among other things, she grabbed the garland that Dr. Van Helsing had insisted I wear around my neck and tore it off. She sat pointing at the wolf for a second or two, a strange and terrifying gurgling sound coming from her throat; then she collapsed as if struck by lightning, and when her head hit my forehead, it caused me to be dazed for a moment. The room and everything around seemed to be spinning. I fixed my eyes on the window, but the wolf had withdrawn its head, and through the broken window, thousands of tiny particles were entering, swirling around like a column of dust that travelers say they see in the desert during a sandstorm. I tried to pull myself together, but it felt as if I were under a spell, and the body of my poor mother, already beginning to cool - for her dear heart had stopped beating - weighed heavily upon me; for a while, I remembered nothing.
es: I feared she might catch a cold sitting there, and I asked her to come and sleep with me, so she got into bed and lay down next to me; she did not take off her robe, as she said she was only going to stay for a moment and then return to her own bed. As she lay there in my arms, and I in hers, the fluttering and rubbing returned to the window. She was startled, and a little scared, and asked, "What is that?" I tried to calm her; finally, I was able to do so, and she lay still; but I could hear how her poor dear heart was still beating terribly. After a while, there was a crash at the window and a lot of pieces of glass fell to the floor. The window shutter flew inward with the wind coming in, and in the opening of the broken panes appeared the head of a large, thin wolf. My mother let out a scream of fear and quickly sat up in bed, nervously clutching at anything that could help her. Among other things, she grabbed the garland of flowers that Dr. Van Helsing insisted I wear around my neck, and she tore it off with a yank. For a second or two she remained sitting, pointing at the wolf, and suddenly there was a strange and horrible gurgling in her throat; then she collapsed, as if struck by lightning, and her head hit me on the forehead, leaving me somewhat dazed for a few moments. The room and everything around seemed to spin. I kept my eyes fixed on the window, but the wolf withdrew its head and a whole myriad of small spots seemed to fly in through the broken window, spiraling and circling like the dust column travelers describe when there is a simoom in the desert. I tried to move, but there was a kind of spell over me, and poor mama's body, which seemed to be cooling already, as her dear heart had stopped beating, weighed on me; and for a while, I remember nothing more.

en: The time did not seem long, but very, very awful, till I recovered consciousness again. Somewhere near, a passing bell was tolling; the dogs all round the neighbourhood were howling; and in our shrubbery, seemingly just outside, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and stupid with pain and terror and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother come back to comfort me. The sounds seemed to have awakened the maids, too, for I could hear their bare feet pattering outside my door. I called to them, and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what it was that lay over me on the bed, they screamed out. The wind rushed in through the broken window, and the door slammed to. They lifted off the body of my dear mother, and laid her, covered up with a sheet, on the bed after I had got up. They were all so frightened and nervous that I directed them to go to the dining-room and have each a glass of wine. The door flew open for an instant and closed again. The maids shrieked, and then went in a body to the dining-room; and I laid what flowers I had on my dear mother’s breast. When they were there I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn’t like to remove them, and, besides, I would have some of the servants to sit up with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not come back. I called them, but got no answer, so I went to the dining-room to look for them.
vi: Although I had only fainted for a short time, I was still very vague about the terrifying moments that had passed. When I regained consciousness, the first sound that reached my ears was the distant ringing of a death knell, followed by the barking of dogs around the house, and from the bushes in the garden, not far from my window, came the melodious singing of a nightingale. Sorrow, fear, and severe health deterioration all seemed to come at once, leaving me as lifeless as a dead person. However, hearing the nightingale's song, I felt as if I were hearing my mother's beloved voice, gently speaking in the dark to comfort me. Surely the strange noise had awakened the servants in the house, because I could clearly hear their bare footsteps softly stepping on the stair landing. Hearing my faint call, they quickly stepped into the room. They all screamed in fear; it goes without saying how terrified they were when they realized the misfortune that had befallen us and saw my mother lying on top of me. The wind blowing through the broken window occasionally made the door creak. The brave girls gathered around to move my mother aside so I could sit up. Knowing they were very emotional, I told them to go down to the dining room and have a sip of wine to calm down. They opened the door and then slammed it shut immediately after stepping out of the room. I could still hear them exclaim once more, followed by the sound of hurried footsteps rushing down the stairs. At that moment, I didn't know what to do except painfully pick up the flowers to place on my mother's chest and recall Professor Van Helsing's instructions, but remembering was just for the sake of remembering, as I no longer needed these flowers for anything. I anxiously waited for the servants to return: we would keep vigil together. But they did not return. I called out: no one answered. Finding it strange, I decided to grope my way down to the dining room.
tr: The time it took for me to regain consciousness wasn't long, but it felt very, very terrifying. A bell was ringing somewhere nearby; all the dogs in the vicinity were howling, and a nightingale was singing in the thicket just outside. I was stunned and bewildered with pain, horror, and weakness, but the nightingale's voice was like the voice of my dead mother who had come back to comfort me. The voice seemed to have awakened the servants too, because I could hear the sound of their bare feet outside my door. I called out to them, they came in, and when they realized what was lying in my bed, they screamed in terror. The wind blew in through the window and the door slammed shut. They lifted my dear mother's corpse and, after I got up, they laid her on the bed and covered her. They were so frightened and tense that I ordered them to go to the dining room and have a glass of wine each. The door opened for a moment and then closed again. The servants screamed and all went to the dining room together; I laid all my flowers on my mother's chest. While they were there, I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I didn't want to move them, and besides, I was going to ask some of the servants to stay with me through the night. I was surprised that the servants did not return. I called out to them, but received no answer, so I went to the dining room to look for them.
es: It did not seem to take long, but rather it was very, very terrible, until I could regain consciousness again. Somewhere nearby, a bell was tolling; all the neighborhood dogs were howling, and in our bushes, seemingly very close, a nightingale was singing. I was dazed and dulled by pain, terror, and weakness, but the sound of the nightingale seemed like the voice of my dead mother returning to comfort me. The noises also seemed to wake the maids, as I could hear their bare footsteps running outside my door. I called them and they came in, and when they saw what had happened, and what was lying on me in the bed, they screamed. The wind burst through the broken window and the door slammed shut. They lifted the body of my beloved mother and laid her, covering her with a sheet, on the bed after I had gotten up. They were so scared and nervous that I ordered them to go to the dining room and each have a glass of wine. The door burst open for a few moments and then closed again. The maids screamed in horror, and then they went in a tight group to the dining room, and I placed the flowers I had had around my neck on my dear mother's chest. When they were already there, I remembered what Dr. Van Helsing had told me, but I did not want to remove them, and besides, one of the maids could sit with me now. I was surprised that the maids did not return. I called them, but received no response, so I went down to the dining room to look for them.

en: My heart sank when I saw what had happened. They all four lay helpless on the floor, breathing heavily. The decanter of sherry was on the table half full, but there was a queer, acrid smell about. I was suspicious, and examined the decanter. It smelt of laudanum, and looking on the sideboard, I found that the bottle which mother’s doctor uses for her—oh! did use—was empty. What am I to do? what am I to do? I am back in the room with mother. I cannot leave her, and I am alone, save for the sleeping servants, whom some one has drugged. Alone with the dead! I dare not go out, for I can hear the low howl of the wolf through the broken window.
vi: I nearly collapsed when I unexpectedly witnessed the scene before my eyes: four maidservants were sprawled on the floor, breathing laboriously. A half-empty wine bottle still sat neatly on the table, but the room was filled with a strange pungent odor. I picked up the wine bottle and sniffed: it was all the smell of cannabis alcohol. Opening the buffet cabinet, I realized the medicine bottle that the doctor used to care for my mother was completely empty. What should I do now? What should I do?...I staggered back to my room, to the bedside with my mother. I couldn't leave her. Now I was in the room alone, if not counting the poor maidservants lying unconscious downstairs due to the opium alcohol someone had poured into the wine bottle. Alone with death? And I didn't dare go outside, as the savage howling of the wolf somewhere still echoed in my ears through the broken window.
tr: I was devastated when I saw what had happened. All four of them were lying on the ground, breathing heavily and helplessly. The sherry decanter was half full on the table, but there was a strange, bitter smell in the air. I became suspicious and examined the decanter. It smelled like laudanum, and when I looked at the sideboard, I saw that the bottle my mother's doctor used to -oh, once used to- use for her was empty. What am I going to do? What am I going to do? I returned to the room to be with my mother. I can't leave her, and except for the servants who were drugged and put to sleep, I'm all alone. Alone with the dead! I don't dare go outside, because I can hear the deep howling of the wolf through the broken window.
es: My heart sank when I saw what had happened. The four lay helpless on the ground, breathing heavily. The sherry jug was on the table half full, but there was a strange acrid smell around. I had my suspicions and examined the jug. It smelled of laudanum, and looking in the cupboard I found that the bottle my mother's doctor uses for her (oh, used!) was empty. What should I do? What should I do? I am back in the room, with mom. I cannot leave her, and I am alone, except for the sleeping maids, whom someone has drugged. Alone with death! I do not dare to go out, for I hear the faint howl of the wolf through the broken window.

en: The air seems full of specks, floating and circling in the draught from the window, and the lights burn blue and dim. What am I to do? God shield me from harm this night! I shall hide this paper in my breast, where they shall find it when they come to lay me out. My dear mother gone! It is time that I go too. Good-bye, dear Arthur, if I should not survive this night. God keep you, dear, and God help me!
vi: Those tiny specks wouldn't stop dancing, spinning madly in the room with each gust of wind through the window. Even the candlelight now seemed dim, as if signaling an imminent demise...What should I do now? Perhaps the time has come for me to depart with her! Farewell, everyone! Arthur, if I must die tonight, then I bid you farewell as well!
tr: The room seems to be filled with particles swirling in the draft coming through the window, and the lights are emitting a blue and dim glow. What am I going to do? God, protect me from the disaster that may befall me tonight! I will keep this paper on my chest so that they find it when they prepare to bury me. My dear mother is gone! Now it is my time to go as well. If I do not survive this night, farewell, my dear Arthur. God bless you, my dear, and may God help me!
es: The air seems full of spots, floating and swirling in the window's draft, and the lights flicker blue and dim. What should I do? God protect me from any harm tonight! I will hide this paper in my bosom, where they will find it when they come to shroud me. My dear mother is gone! It is time for me to go too. Goodbye, dear Arthur, if I do not survive this night. May God protect you, dear, and may God help me!

en: CHAPTER XII
vi: CHAPTER 12
tr: XII
es: XII.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD

en: 18 September.—I drove at once to Hillingham and arrived early. Keeping my cab at the gate, I went up the avenue alone. I knocked gently and rang as quietly as possible, for I feared to disturb Lucy or her mother, and hoped to only bring a servant to the door. After a while, finding no response, I knocked and rang again; still no answer. I cursed the laziness of the servants that they should lie abed at such an hour—for it was now ten o’clock—and so rang and knocked again, but more impatiently, but still without response. Hitherto I had blamed only the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me. Was this desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing tight around us? Was it indeed a house of death to which I had come, too late? I knew that minutes, even seconds of delay, might mean hours of danger to Lucy, if she had had again one of those frightful relapses; and I went round the house to try if I could find by chance an entry anywhere.
vi: • September 18 I arrived at Hillingham very early. Leaving the car parked outside the gate, I walked all the way to the house. I knocked on the door very gently so as not to wake Lucy and Mrs. Westenra if they were still sleeping. I hoped that only the servants would hear the knock. After waiting a while and seeing no one come out, I knocked again, then banged harder. There was still no response. I began to get annoyed with the servants, as it was almost ten in the morning and they were still sound asleep. Thinking about it made me furious and impatient, so I banged on the door repeatedly, but it was all in vain. Granted, the servants were mainly responsible for this silence, but for some reason, an indescribable fear surged within me. Could this silence be yet another sign of the curse that has been haunting us for so long? Do I really have the courage to step into a house where death has arrived before me? I knew that every minute, every second that passed could lead to extremely dire consequences for Lucy if her health deteriorated once again, so I decided to circle around the house in the hope of finding an entrance I had not known before.
tr: September 18. - I immediately drove to Hillingham and arrived there early in the morning. Leaving my car at the garden gate, I walked alone down the tree-lined path to the house. I knocked on the door slowly and rang the bell as quietly as possible because I was afraid of disturbing Lucy or her mother and hoped to bring only one of the servants to the door. After a while, when I received no response, I knocked and rang the bell again; still no answer. At this hour - for it was ten o'clock - I cursed the laziness of the servants who might be in bed and thus knocked and rang the bell more impatiently once again, but still, there was no response. Until now, I had only blamed the servants, but now a great fear began to fill me. Was this abandonment a new link in the chain of bad news that was tightening around us? Was this house, to which I had indeed arrived too late, a house of death? I knew that being late by even a few minutes, or even seconds, could mean long hours of danger for Lucy if her condition had relapsed; I circled the house hoping to find any possible entrance by chance.
es: September 18. I went immediately to Hillingham and arrived early. Leaving my carriage at the gate, I ran down the avenue alone. I rang the bell softly, as delicately as possible, for I feared disturbing Lucy or her mother, and hoped that only a servant would answer the door. After a while, finding no response, I rang again; still, no one answered. I cursed the laziness of the servants who might still be in bed at that hour, as it was ten in the morning, so I rang again, but more impatiently, still without obtaining a response. Up to this point, I had only blamed the servants, but now a terrible fear began to assail me. Was this desolation another link in the chain of misfortunes that seemed to be surrounding us? Could it be that I had arrived at a mansion of death, too late? I know that minutes, or even seconds of delay can mean hours of danger for Lucy if she had another one of those terrible relapses; and I went around the house to see if I could find by chance another entrance.

en: I could find no means of ingress. Every window and door was fastened and locked, and I returned baffled to the porch. As I did so, I heard the rapid pit-pat of a swiftly driven horse’s feet. They stopped at the gate, and a few seconds later I met Van Helsing running up the avenue. When he saw me, he gasped out:—
vi: I knew that every minute, every second that passed could lead to extremely dire consequences for Lucy if her health deteriorated once again, so I decided to circle around the house in the hope of finding an entrance I had not known before. All the doors were tightly locked, and the windows were firmly shut, which made me extremely disappointed. I could only return to the original place. Just as I reached the main door, I suddenly felt a sense of suspicion when I heard the sound of horse hooves pounding on the road, then abruptly stopping right in front of the gate; a few seconds later, I recognized Van Helsing's figure stepping down from the carriage, he hurriedly ran into the house. Seeing me, he immediately asked, panting: — Ah!
tr: I couldn't find a way to get inside. All the doors and windows were closed and locked, and I turned back to the porch in bewilderment. As I went there, I heard the rapid sound of a horse's hooves being driven like a bullet. The sounds ended at the door, and a few seconds later, I encountered Van Helsing running towards the tree-lined road. When he saw me, he started speaking breathlessly:
es: I couldn't find any way to get in. Every window and door was bolted and locked, so I returned puzzled to the porch. As I did so, I heard the rapid clatter of a horse's hooves approaching swiftly, and then stopping at the gate. A few seconds later, I found van Helsing running down the avenue. When he saw me, he managed to murmur:

en: “Then it was you, and just arrived. How is she? Are we too late? Did you not get my telegram?”
vi: So it's you? So you just arrived as well? How is she? Is there still time? Didn't you receive my message?
tr: “So it was you and you just arrived. How is that? Are we too late? Didn't you get my telegram?”
es: –So it was you who just arrived. How is she? Did we arrive too late? Did you not receive my telegram?

en: I answered as quickly and coherently as I could that I had only got his telegram early in the morning, and had not lost a minute in coming here, and that I could not make any one in the house hear me. He paused and raised his hat as he said solemnly:—
vi: I tried to answer clearly and concisely that I had just received his call early in the morning, that I had arranged all my work to come here immediately. I knocked and knocked repeatedly but still didn't get any response. Van Helsing took off his hat and stood silently for a moment. Finally, he spoke to me in a very serious tone:
tr: I explained as quickly and clearly as I could that I had only received his telegram early this morning and had not wasted a single minute in coming here, but I couldn't make anyone at home hear me. He paused and, while taking off his hat, said seriously:
es: I replied as quickly and coherently as I could, warning him that I had not received his telegram until early in the morning, that I had not wasted a minute in getting there, and that I had not been able to make anyone in the house hear me. He paused and lifted his hat, saying solemnly:

en: “Then I fear we are too late. God’s will be done!” With his usual recuperative energy, he went on: “Come. If there be no way open to get in, we must make one. Time is all in all to us now.”
vi: — I suppose we have arrived too late. The will of God has come true! He paused as if to gather more courage, then resolutely said: — Go! If all the doors are closed, we must find some way to get into the house.
tr: “Then, I fear we are too late. God's will be done!” He continued with his usual healing energy: “Come. If there is no open way for us to enter, then we must make one. Time is now everything for us.”
es: –Then I fear that we have arrived too late. Let God's will be done! – but then he continued, regaining his usual energy-: Come. If there is no door open to enter, we must make one. I believe we now have plenty of time.

en: We went round to the back of the house, where there was a kitchen window. The Professor took a small surgical saw from his case, and handing it to me, pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window. I attacked them at once and had very soon cut through three of them. Then with a long, thin knife we pushed back the fastening of the sashes and opened the window. I helped the Professor in, and followed him. There was no one in the kitchen or in the servants’ rooms, which were close at hand. We tried all the rooms as we went along, and in the dining-room, dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters, found four servant-women lying on the floor. There was no need to think them dead, for their stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt as to their condition. Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we moved away he said: “We can attend to them later.” Then we ascended to Lucy’s room. For an instant or two we paused at the door to listen, but there was no sound that we could hear. With white faces and trembling hands, we opened the door gently, and entered the room.
vi: We both went around to the back of the house. Van Helsing held a scalpel and pointed towards a kitchen window. I slid a thin knife through the gap in the door, flipped the latch, and opened the two window panes wide. I helped the professor climb into the kitchen first, then I followed. There was no one in the kitchen, nor in the pantry. We peeked into the rooms on the ground floor, but they were all empty. Only when we reached the dining room, thanks to a faint light filtering through the fanlights, did we notice four servants lying on the floor. We didn't think they were dead, as their heavy opium-laced breaths in the room indicated their condition. Van Helsing calmly told me, "We will come back to them later," then immediately pulled me up to Lucy's room. However, when we got there, we didn't enter right away but stopped at the door to listen: everything was eerily silent. We nervously opened the door, filled with suspense and anxiety.
tr: We circled around to the back of the house where the kitchen window was located. The professor took a small surgical saw from his bag and handed it to me, pointing at the iron bars guarding the window. I immediately set to work and soon cut through three of them. Then, with a long, thin knife, we pushed back the latches of the window sashes and opened the window. I helped the professor inside and followed him. There was no one in the kitchen or the nearby servant rooms. As we advanced, we checked all the rooms and found four maidservants lying on the floor in the dining room, dimly lit by the light filtering through the shutters. There was no reason to think they were dead, as their wheezing breaths and the bitter opium smell in the room left no doubt about their condition. Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we walked, he said, “We can deal with them later.” Then, we went up to Lucy’s room. We paused at the door for a second or two to listen inside, but there was no sound to be heard. With pale faces and trembling hands, we slowly opened the door and entered the room.
es: We took a detour and went to the back of the house, where a kitchen window was open. The professor took a small surgical saw from his briefcase, and handing it to me, pointed towards the iron bars guarding the window. I attacked them immediately and very soon cut three of them. Then, with a long, thin knife, we pushed back the bolt of the guillotines and opened the window. I helped the professor to climb in, and then I followed him. There was no one in the kitchen or in the nearby service rooms. We pressed the knob of every room as we walked, and in the dining room, dimly lit by the rays of light passing through the blinds, we found the four maids lying on the floor. There was no need to think they were dead, as their labored breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt about their condition. Van Helsing and I looked at each other, and as we moved away, he said: "We can attend to them later." Then we went up to Lucy's room. For a few brief seconds, we paused at the door and listened, but we couldn't hear any sound. With pale faces and trembling hands, we gently opened the door and entered the room.

en: How shall I describe what we saw? On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her mother. The latter lay farthest in, and she was covered with a white sheet, the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the broken window, showing the drawn, white face, with a look of terror fixed upon it. By her side lay Lucy, with face white and still more drawn. The flowers which had been round her neck we found upon her mother’s bosom, and her throat was bare, showing the two little wounds which we had noticed before, but looking horribly white and mangled. Without a word the Professor bent over the bed, his head almost touching poor Lucy’s breast; then he gave a quick turn of his head, as of one who listens, and leaping to his feet, he cried out to me:—
vi: I don't know how to describe the scene before my eyes. Both Lucy and her mother were lying on the bed. On the mother's body was a white sheet, the edge of which was blown back by the wind from the broken window, revealing a pale face, deeply etched with lines of terror. Lucy’s face looked even more miserable. The garland around her neck was now placed on Mrs. Westenra's chest. I could easily see that the two small wounds on her had now become much deeper and wider compared to a few days ago, and I didn't understand why. Without a word, Professor Van Helsing bent low over the bed, his head almost touching Lucy's chest; after listening for about a second, he suddenly stood up and told me:
tr: How can I describe what we saw? Two women, Lucy and her mother, were lying in the bed. Her mother was lying further away, covered with a white sheet that had been blown open by the wind coming through the broken window, revealing her pale, terrified face. Next to her lay Lucy, with an even paler face and a more forlorn appearance. We found the flowers that had previously been on her neck on her mother's chest, and her throat was bare, revealing the two small wounds we had noticed earlier, but it looked terrifyingly white and crushed. The professor, without saying a word, bent over the bed with his head almost touching Lucy's chest; then, like someone who had been listening, he quickly turned his head and sprang to his feet, shouting at me:
es: How can I describe what we saw? On the bed lay two women, Lucy and her mother. The latter lay further in, covered with a white sheet whose end had been turned by the draft coming through the broken window, revealing her hollow-eyed white face, with a look of terror fixed upon it. Beside her lay Lucy, with a white and even more hollow-eyed face. The flowers that had been around her neck were on her mother's chest, and her own throat was bare, showing the two small wounds we had seen earlier, but this time terribly white and bruised. Without saying a word, the professor leaned over the bed with his head almost touching poor Lucy's chest; then he quickly turned his head, like someone listening, and standing up, he shouted at me:

en: “It is not yet too late! Quick! quick! Bring the brandy!”
vi: — It's not too late yet! Hurry up, hurry up? Strong liquor!
tr: “It’s not too late yet! Quick! Quick! Bring the brandy!”
es: –It's not too late yet! Quick, quick! Bring the brandy!

en: I flew downstairs and returned with it, taking care to smell and taste it, lest it, too, were drugged like the decanter of sherry which I found on the table. The maids were still breathing, but more restlessly, and I fancied that the narcotic was wearing off. I did not stay to make sure, but returned to Van Helsing. He rubbed the brandy, as on another occasion, on her lips and gums and on her wrists and the palms of her hands. He said to me:—
vi: I rushed down to the dining room, grabbed a bottle of wine, brought it to my nose to smell, and then tasted it to ensure that no one had poured opium into the bottle. The servants were still lying down, breathing; their breaths now seemed lighter and more regular; perhaps the effects of the opium tincture were gradually wearing off. I hurried back to Lucy's room. Van Helsing grabbed the bottle of wine, poured some into his hand, and rubbed it vigorously on Lucy's lips, wrists, and forearms. After completing this emergency task, he softly said to me:
tr: I ran downstairs and returned with the brandy; I did not neglect to smell and taste it to understand whether it was drugged like the sherry decanter I found on the table. The servants were still breathing, but their breathing had become more troubled, and I thought the effect of the narcotic was beginning to wear off. Instead of staying there to be sure, I returned to Van Helsing. As he had done on another occasion, he applied brandy to Lucy's lips, gums, wrists, and palms. He said to me:
es: I flew down the stairs and returned with it, being careful to smell and taste it, just in case it was also drugged like the sherry I found on the table. The maids were still breathing, but more calmly, and I supposed that the effects of the narcotic were already wearing off. I did not stay to make sure, but went back to where Van Helsing was. As on the previous occasion, he rubbed brandy on his lips and gums, wrists, and palms. He said to me:

en: “I can do this, all that can be at the present. You go wake those maids. Flick them in the face with a wet towel, and flick them hard. Make them get heat and fire and a warm bath. This poor soul is nearly as cold as that beside her. She will need be heated before we can do anything more.”
vi: — That's enough for now. There's nothing else to do at the moment. Go downstairs and wake those girls up. Just use a wet towel to slap their faces, don't worry about being cruel! I need them awake to light a fire and boil some hot water. This girl is almost freezing to death, her body is like a block of ice. She needs to be warmed up first, then we can do anything else.
tr: “I can do this, for now, this is the only thing we can do. You go and wake up those servants. Hit their faces with a wet towel; hit hard. Make sure they light a fire and prepare a hot bath. This poor thing is almost as cold as the woman beside her. She needs to be warmed up first before we can do anything else.”
es: –I can do this; it is all that can be done for now. You go and wake up those maids. Gently slap their faces with a damp towel, and slap them hard. Make them gather heat and fire and warm up some water. This poor soul is almost as cold as the other one. We will need to warm her up before we can do anything else.

en: I went at once, and found little difficulty in waking three of the women. The fourth was only a young girl, and the drug had evidently affected her more strongly, so I lifted her on the sofa and let her sleep. The others were dazed at first, but as remembrance came back to them they cried and sobbed in a hysterical manner. I was stern with them, however, and would not let them talk. I told them that one life was bad enough to lose, and that if they delayed they would sacrifice Miss Lucy. So, sobbing and crying, they went about their way, half clad as they were, and prepared fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and boiler fires were still alive, and there was no lack of hot water. We got a bath and carried Lucy out as she was and placed her in it. Whilst we were busy chafing her limbs there was a knock at the hall door. One of the maids ran off, hurried on some more clothes, and opened it. Then she returned and whispered to us that there was a gentleman who had come with a message from Mr. Holmwood. I bade her simply tell him that he must wait, for we could see no one now. She went away with the message, and, engrossed with our work, I clean forgot all about him.
vi: I had no difficulty waking up the first three servants; but the fourth one lay there like a child, seemingly the most affected by the opium. I had to carry her to the couch so she could continue sleeping. The three girls who had just woken up were dazed like simpletons. However, when they suddenly remembered what had happened, they burst into tears and sobbingly recounted the events to me. But I remained resolute and stern, not allowing them to go on for long. I told them that one death in the house was enough, and that if they kept lamenting, Lucy might be next. Hearing this, they had no choice but to sob their way into the kitchen. Fortunately, the stove was still on, so the water in the pot was still hot. After preparing the bath, we placed Lucy in to soak. While we were focused on massaging her limbs, there was a sudden knock at the gate. A servant hurried out to open the door. A moment later, she ran back in to inform us that a man was waiting outside, saying he had a letter from Holmwood. Knowing we couldn't receive guests at that moment, I sent someone to ask him to kindly wait. To be honest, I immediately forgot about his presence; all I could do now was focus on saving the patient.
tr: I went immediately and had no difficulty waking up three of the women. The fourth was a young girl, and it was clear that the drug had affected her more strongly, so I carried her to the couch and let her sleep. The others were a bit dazed at first, but once their memories returned, they screamed and cried hysterically. But I was firm with them and did not allow them to speak. I told them that losing one life was bad enough, and if they delayed, they would sacrifice Miss Lucy. Thus, sobbing and half-dressed, they set to work and prepared the fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and the boiler fire were still burning, and there was no shortage of hot water. We prepared the bath and carried Lucy as she was, placing her in the tub. While we were busy warming her arms and legs, the hall door was knocked. One of the servants ran, hurriedly put on some more clothes, and opened the door. She came back and whispered that a young gentleman had arrived with a message from Mr. Holmwood. I asked her to tell the man he had to wait, as we could not see anyone at the moment. She left with this message, and I focused on our work, completely forgetting about the man.
es: I went immediately and found little difficulty in waking up three of the women. The fourth was just a young girl and the narcotic had evidently affected her more strongly, so I lifted her onto the sofa and let her sleep. The others were initially dazed, but as they began to remember what had happened, they sobbed hysterically. However, I was strict with them and did not allow them to speak. I told them that losing one life was painful enough, and that if they took too long, they would also sacrifice Miss Lucy. So, sobbing, they began to make arrangements, half-dressed as they were, and prepared the fire and water. Fortunately, the kitchen and heater fire were still working, so there was no need for hot water. We fixed the bathroom and took Lucy as she was to the bathtub. While we were busy scrubbing her limbs, someone knocked on the hallway door. One of the maids ran, hastily threw on some more clothes, and opened the door. Then she returned and whispered to us that it was a gentleman who had arrived with a message from Mr. Holmwood. I simply begged her to tell him that he had to wait, as we couldn't see anyone at the moment. She went out with the message, and absorbed in our work, I completely forgot about the presence of that man.

en: I never saw in all my experience the Professor work in such deadly earnest. I knew—as he knew—that it was a stand-up fight with death, and in a pause told him so. He answered me in a way that I did not understand, but with the sternest look that his face could wear:—
vi: Since working with Van Helsing, I have never seen him fight against death in this manner. Because both of us knew that this was the only way, the ultimate battle against a death. When I whispered that, he stood still for a moment. I did not understand his response, but just by looking at his serious expression, I knew.
tr: I had never seen the professor working so tirelessly in my life. Like him, I knew we were fighting against death, and I told him this when we took a break. He responded in a way I didn't understand, with the most serious expression his face could take on:
es: In all my experience, I had never seen my teacher work with such solemn seriousness. I knew, as he did, that it was a desperate struggle against death, and in a pause, I told him so. He responded in a way I couldn't understand, but with the most serious look his face could reflect:

en: “If that were all, I would stop here where we are now, and let her fade away into peace, for I see no light in life over her horizon.” He went on with his work with, if possible, renewed and more frenzied vigour.
vi: — If that's all, - he said - I will try to leave this place, and I will let the little girl rest peacefully, because I am not sure if life will come to her anymore. However, he continued his efforts to massage his young patient tirelessly.
tr: “If it were just like that, I would stay where we are now and let it fade away in peace, because I see no light of life on the horizon.” He continued his work - if such a thing is possible - with renewed and more enthusiastic strength.
es: –If that were all, I would stop right here where we are now and let her fade away in peace, for I see no light on the horizon of her life. He continued his work with a vigor, if possible, renewed and more frenetic.

en: Presently we both began to be conscious that the heat was beginning to be of some effect. Lucy’s heart beat a trifle more audibly to the stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement. Van Helsing’s face almost beamed, and as we lifted her from the bath and rolled her in a hot sheet to dry her he said to me:—
vi: There was no need to wait long; we began to notice that the hot water tub had taken effect. Through the stethoscope, I felt Lucy's heartbeat and breathing gradually stabilizing. When lifting her out of the tub and wrapping her in several layers of warm towels, Van Helsing told me, his face looking somewhat less heavy:
tr: A little later, we both noticed that the heat was starting to work a bit. Lucy’s heart was beating a little more audibly in the stethoscope, and there was tangible movement in her lungs. Van Helsing’s face was almost glowing, and as he wrapped Lucy in a warm blanket to dry her off after taking her out of the bath, he said to me:
es: After a while, we both began to become aware that the heat was starting to have some effect. Lucy's heart beat a little more audibly through the stethoscope, and her lungs had a perceptible movement. Van Helsing's face almost beamed when we lifted her out of the bath and wrapped her in a warm sheet to dry her. He said to me:

en: “The first gain is ours! Check to the King!”
vi: — In the first step, we have achieved victory? The Grim Reaper is retreating!
tr: "The first round is ours! Check!"
es: –The first victory is ours! Check to the king!

en: We took Lucy into another room, which had by now been prepared, and laid her in bed and forced a few drops of brandy down her throat. I noticed that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief round her throat. She was still unconscious, and was quite as bad as, if not worse than, we had ever seen her.
vi: We placed Lucy in another room. I laid her on the bed and dropped a few drops of strong liquor into her mouth. Van Helsing wrapped a very soft silk scarf around her neck. She still hadn't woken up. Looking at her face, I knew she was going through a pain I had never seen before.
tr: We took Lucy to the other room that had been prepared until then and laid her on the bed, forcing a few drops of brandy down her throat. I noticed that Van Helsing had wrapped a soft, silk handkerchief around Lucy's neck. Lucy was still not conscious and, if not worse, she was as bad as she had been when we saw her a little while ago.
es: We took Lucy to another room, which by then had already been prepared, and put her to bed and made her drink a few drops of brandy. I noticed that Van Helsing tied a soft silk handkerchief around her neck. She was still unconscious, and she was as bad, if not worse, than we had ever seen her.

en: Van Helsing called in one of the women, and told her to stay with her and not to take her eyes off her till we returned, and then beckoned me out of the room.
vi: Professor Van Helsing called a servant up and ordered her to stand at the head of the bed to watch the patient, instructing her not to take her eyes off until we returned. Then, he waved his hand to signal me to step out of the room with him.
tr: Van Helsing called one of the women and told her to stay by Lucy's side and not to take her eyes off her until we returned, and then with a gesture, he led me outside.
es: Van Helsing called one of the women and told her to stay with her and not to take her eyes off her until we returned. Then he signaled me to leave the room.

en: “We must consult as to what is to be done,” he said as we descended the stairs. In the hall he opened the dining-room door, and we passed in, he closing the door carefully behind him. The shutters had been opened, but the blinds were already down, with that obedience to the etiquette of death which the British woman of the lower classes always rigidly observes. The room was, therefore, dimly dark. It was, however, light enough for our purposes. Van Helsing’s sternness was somewhat relieved by a look of perplexity. He was evidently torturing his mind about something, so I waited for an instant, and he spoke:—
vi: — Now we have to think about what we need to do next. - The professor told me while going down the stairs. The two of us stepped into the dining room to talk more conveniently. The windows in the room were all open but covered with thick curtains. The professor turned around and carefully closed the door, the room darkened, but the light filtering through the windows was still enough for us to recognize everything around us. The serious expression on the professor's face earlier was gone, replaced by a look of confusion. Clearly, he was trying to find a way to solve some new difficulty.
tr: While descending the stairs, "We should exchange ideas about what needs to be done." In the hallway, he opened the dining room door and as he carefully closed the door behind him, we entered. The shutters were open, but the curtains had already been drawn in accordance with the mourning etiquette that lower-class English women always strictly adhered to. Therefore, the room was dim. Nevertheless, it was bright enough for our purposes. Van Helsing's sternness had diminished due to a kind of bewilderment. It was clear that something was tormenting his mind, so I waited a bit; then he began to speak:
es: –We need to consult about what we are going to do -he told me, as we descended the stairs. In the hallway, he opened the dining room door, and we entered, carefully closing the door behind us.
