The blinds had been left open, but the shutters were already lowered, with that adherence to the etiquette of death that British women of the lower classes always observe rigidly. Therefore, the room was quite dark. However, there was enough light for our purposes. Van Helsing's seriousness was somewhat mitigated by a look of perplexity. He was evidently torturing his brain about something, so I waited a few moments, after which he said:

en: “What are we to do now? Where are we to turn for help? We must have another transfusion of blood, and that soon, or that poor girl’s life won’t be worth an hour’s purchase. You are exhausted already; I am exhausted too. I fear to trust those women, even if they would have courage to submit. What are we to do for some one who will open his veins for her?”
vi: — That's it! What should we do now? - He pondered. - Who will help us? Anyway, we have to perform another blood transfusion. Yes, another one, as soon as possible, otherwise that poor girl won't survive another hour. Young man, like me, you look exhausted. As for me, I don't want to force those helpers to donate blood even if they have the courage to do so. Where can we find a blood donor now?
tr: “What should we do now? Where should we look for help? We need to perform another blood transfusion, and it must be soon, or that poor girl won't last an hour. You are already exhausted; I am exhausted too. Even if they had the courage to accept, I am afraid to trust those women. What should we do to find someone to open their veins for her?”
es: –What are we going to do now? Who can we turn to? We must perform another blood transfusion, and that promptly, or the life of that poor girl will not last an hour. You are already exhausted; I am exhausted too. I fear trusting those women, even if they had the courage to submit. What should we do for someone who wishes to open their veins for her?

en: “What’s the matter with me, anyhow?”
vi: — Am I not here?
tr: "What's wrong with me?""
es: –Well, then, what's going on with me?

en: The voice came from the sofa across the room, and its tones brought relief and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris. Van Helsing started angrily at the first sound, but his face softened and a glad look came into his eyes as I cried out: “Quincey Morris!” and rushed towards him with outstretched hands.
vi: A sudden voice echoed from the settee on the other side of the room; I immediately breathed a sigh of relief, for I could not be mistaken, it was the voice of Quincey Morris. At first, Van Helsing seemed very angry, he turned sharply to look at the young guest, but then his face gradually softened, his eyes brightened considerably. I spread my arms and quickly walked towards my friend, exclaiming: — Quincey Morris!
tr: The sound had come from the couch across the room, and the tone of the voice brought relief and joy to my heart because the voice belonged to Quincey Morris. When Van Helsing first heard the voice, he jumped up angrily, but then his face softened, and as I shouted "Quincey Morris!" and ran towards him with outstretched hands, a pleased expression came to his eyes.
es: The voice came from the sofa on the other side of the room, and its tones brought breath and joy to my heart, for they were those of Quincey Morris. Van Helsing looked angry at the first sound, but his face softened and a joyful look appeared in his eyes when I shouted, "Quincey Morris!" and ran towards him with outstretched arms.

en: “What brought you here?” I cried as our hands met.
vi: What wind has brought you here?
tr: "What wind blew you here?" I asked as our hands joined.
es: –What brought you here? – I asked him as we shook hands.

en: “I guess Art is the cause.”
vi: It must be Arthur who....
tr: “I think so, Art.”
es: –I suppose the cause is Art.

en: He handed me a telegram:—
vi: Instead of an answer, he handed me a telegram.
tr: He handed me a telegram:
es: He handed me a telegram:

en: “Have not heard from Seward for three days, and am terribly anxious. Cannot leave. Father still in same condition. Send me word how Lucy is. Do not delay.—Holmwood.”
vi: I anxiously read it immediately: “No news from Seward for three days. Terribly worried. Cannot leave father, he is still sick. Let me know Lucy's condition immediately. Holmwood.”
tr: I haven't heard from Seward for three days and I am very worried. I cannot leave here. My father is still in the same condition. Tell me how Lucy is. Don't delay. - HOLMWOOD.
es: "I haven't heard from Seward for three days, and I am terribly anxious. I cannot go. My father in the same state. Send me news of Lucy's condition. Don't delay. HOLMWOOD."

en: “I think I came just in the nick of time. You know you have only to tell me what to do.”
vi: — I think I have arrived just in time. - Quincey said. - Now you just need to tell me what I have to do, don't say any more.
tr: “I guess I arrived just in time. Just tell me what I need to do, you know.”
es: I think I have arrived just in time. You know that you only have to tell me what I should do.

en: Van Helsing strode forward, and took his hand, looking him straight in the eyes as he said:—
vi: Van Helsing stepped forward and firmly grasped the hand of the newly arrived guest:
tr: Van Helsing strode forward and took her hand, looking directly into her eyes, and said:
es: Van Helsing took a few steps forward and took his hand, looking him straight in the eyes as he said:

en: “A brave man’s blood is the best thing on this earth when a woman is in trouble. You’re a man and no mistake. Well, the devil may work against us for all he’s worth, but God sends us men when we want them.”
vi: — When a woman is exhausted and in need of a blood transfusion, the blood of a brave man will be the only salvation that can save her. The devil may take all power to oppose us, but God will always bring us truly courageous men.
tr: “When a woman is in trouble, the blood of a brave man is the best thing in this world. You are a man, there is no doubt about it. Yes, the devil may be working against us with all his might, but God sends us a man whenever we need one.”
es: –The best thing in this world when a woman is in danger is the blood of a brave man. You are a man, and there is no doubt about it. Well, the devil may work against us with all his efforts, but God sends us men when we need them.

en: Once again we went through that ghastly operation. I have not the heart to go through with the details. Lucy had got a terrible shock and it told on her more than before, for though plenty of blood went into her veins, her body did not respond to the treatment as well as on the other occasions. Her struggle back into life was something frightful to see and hear. However, the action of both heart and lungs improved, and Van Helsing made a subcutaneous injection of morphia, as before, and with good effect. Her faint became a profound slumber. The Professor watched whilst I went downstairs with Quincey Morris, and sent one of the maids to pay off one of the cabmen who were waiting. I left Quincey lying down after having a glass of wine, and told the cook to get ready a good breakfast. Then a thought struck me, and I went back to the room where Lucy now was. When I came softly in, I found Van Helsing with a sheet or two of note-paper in his hand. He had evidently read it, and was thinking it over as he sat with his hand to his brow. There was a look of grim satisfaction in his face, as of one who has had a doubt solved. He handed me the paper saying only: “It dropped from Lucy’s breast when we carried her to the bath.”
vi: Without much ado, we hurriedly began a new blood transfusion. The work was so exhausting that I can't recount every detail here. Lucy must have gone through a terrible shock, because this time she didn't react as she had before. If you saw her, heard her sobbing and fighting against death to return to life, you wouldn't be able to hold back your emotions. But then her heartbeat became more regular, and the labored breaths from her chest visibly improved. After the transfusion, Van Helsing carefully injected her with a dose of morphine, wanting to turn her pathological unconsciousness into a normal deep sleep. The professor stayed to watch over Lucy, while I had to take Quincey downstairs and instruct a servant to pay the coachman waiting outside the gate. After giving Quincey a glass of wine, I helped him lie down on the couch and told the cook to prepare him a nutritious lunch. As if suddenly remembering something, I immediately returned to the patient's room. Van Helsing was still standing there, holding some papers in his hand. At a glance, I knew he was suspecting something. He handed me the papers and tersely said something out of the blue: — Lucy's blouse fell off when we lifted her out of the bathtub.
tr: We performed that dreadful procedure again. I don't have the heart to go into the details. Lucy had suffered a tremendous shock, and its effect on her was greater than ever because, despite the large amount of blood going into her veins, her body was not responding to the treatment as well as it had before. The struggle she put up to return to life was a terrifying thing to see and hear. But both her heart and lungs began to function better, and Van Helsing, as before, injected morphine subcutaneously; this again proved very effective. The state of unconsciousness gave way to a light sleep. While I went downstairs with Quincey Morris to send one of the servants to pay the waiting coachmen and send them away, Van Helsing kept vigil at Lucy's side. After having a glass of wine, I left Quincey, who had lain down, and told the cook to prepare a good breakfast. Then an idea came to me, and I went to the room where Lucy was now. When I entered quietly, I found Van Helsing with a couple of sheets of paper in his hand. It was clear that he had read them and was contemplating them, with his hand on his forehead. There was an expression of unpleasant satisfaction on his face, typical of someone who has resolved a doubt. As he handed me the paper, he simply said: "It fell from Lucy's chest as we were carrying her to the bath."
es: Once again we had to perform the horrendous operation. I do not have the courage to describe it again in detail. Lucy was terribly weak, and the weakness had affected her more than the other times, for although quite a bit of blood entered her veins, her body did not respond to the treatment as quickly as on other occasions. His struggle to stay alive was something terrible to see and hear. However, the functioning of both his heart and lungs improved, and Van Helsing administered a subcutaneous injection of morphine, as before, with good results. His fainting turned into a deep sleep. The professor watched her while I went downstairs with Quincey Morris, and I sent one of the maids to pay the coachman who was waiting. I left Quincey lying down after serving him a glass of wine, and I told the cook to prepare a good breakfast. Then I had an idea and went back to the room where Lucy was. When I entered, quietly, I found Van Helsing with one or two sheets of paper in his hands. It was evident that he had read them, and that he was now reflecting on their content, sitting with one hand on his forehead. There was a look of grim satisfaction on his face, like that of someone who has resolved a doubt. He handed me the papers, saying only: –It fell from Lucy's chest when we were carrying her to the bathroom.

en: When I had read it, I stood looking at the Professor, and after a pause asked him: “In God’s name, what does it all mean? Was she, or is she, mad; or what sort of horrible danger is it?” I was so bewildered that I did not know what to say more. Van Helsing put out his hand and took the paper, saying:—
vi: After reading the few sheets of paper, I secretly glanced at the professor for a moment before daring to ask: — My God, what is going on? Is she, or rather, is she going crazy? Or is there some terrible danger lurking somewhere around us? Van Helsing took back the papers from my hand.
tr: After reading it, I stopped and looked at the Professor, and after waiting a bit, I asked: "For God's sake, what does all this mean?" Was he mad or is he mad? Or what kind of terrible danger is this?" I was so bewildered that I didn't know what to say. Van Helsing reached out his hand and said as he took the paper:
es: When I had read them, I stared at the professor, and after a pause, I asked him: –In the name of God, what does all this mean? Was she, or is she crazy? Or what kind of horrible danger is this? I was so perplexed that I couldn't find anything else to say. Van Helsing extended his hand and took the paper, saying:

en: “Do not trouble about it now. Forget it for the present. You shall know and understand it all in good time; but it will be later. And now what is it that you came to me to say?” This brought me back to fact, and I was all myself again.
vi: — Now is not the time for you to be overthinking, - He said - try to forget about it. Time will answer everything for you, will help you understand everything. But not now. Later on... Why did you come back here? Is there something you want to say? The professor's question helped me return to myself.
tr: “Now, don't worry about this. Forget about it for now. When the time comes, you will learn and understand everything; but later. So, what did you come to tell me now?” This brought me back to reality and I regained my composure.
es: –Don't worry about it now. For the moment, forget it. You will know and understand everything in due time; but that will be later. And now, what did you come to tell me? This brought me back to reality, and once again, I was myself.

en: “I came to speak about the certificate of death. If we do not act properly and wisely, there may be an inquest, and that paper would have to be produced. I am in hopes that we need have no inquest, for if we had it would surely kill poor Lucy, if nothing else did. I know, and you know, and the other doctor who attended her knows, that Mrs. Westenra had disease of the heart, and we can certify that she died of it. Let us fill up the certificate at once, and I shall take it myself to the registrar and go on to the undertaker.”
vi: — Yes, it's about the death certificate. If we don't complete all the necessary procedures, someone will definitely come to investigate. I believe it's unnecessary for that to happen, as it could very well break poor little Lucy's heart. The professor, myself, and Mrs. Westenra's doctor all know why she died, and we just need to fill out the death certificate according to what actually happened. Perhaps we should do it right away. I will personally take the document to the authorities, and then I will find someone to handle the funeral arrangements.
tr: “I came to talk about the death certificate. If we do not act properly and wisely, an investigation may be opened and this document may need to be presented. I hope there will be no need for an investigation, because if there is, if nothing else, it will certainly cause poor Lucy’s death. I know, you know, and the doctor who is taking care of her knows that Ms. Westenra has a heart condition; we can confirm that she died from this illness. Come, let’s fill out this document immediately; I will take it to the registrar and then proceed to the person who will handle the funeral.”
es: –I came to talk to you about the death certificate. If we do not act properly and wisely, there could be inquiries, and we would have to show that paper. I hope there will be no need for inquiries, because if there were, that would surely kill poor Lucy, if something else doesn't kill her first. I know, and you know, and the other doctor who attended to her also knows, that Mrs. Westenra suffered from a heart condition; we can certify that she died from it. Let's fill out the certificate immediately and I will take it to the registry myself, and then proceed to the funeral service.

en: “Good, oh my friend John! Well thought of! Truly Miss Lucy, if she be sad in the foes that beset her, is at least happy in the friends that love her. One, two, three, all open their veins for her, besides one old man. Ah yes, I know, friend John; I am not blind! I love you all the more for it! Now go.”
vi: — That's good, my friend John! You think very deeply? Indeed, if Lucy is being haunted by dark shadows, at least she can find some comfort in always having loved ones by her side. There have been one, two, and three men ready to open their veins to give her blood, of course, I am not counting my old body. Truly, I am very grateful to you, my friend John! And I very much want you to continue to promote that precious quality. Now, perhaps we should go downstairs!
tr: “Good, oh my friend John! You have thought well! Even though Miss Lucy is saddened by the enemies surrounding her, at least she is happy with the friends who love her. One, two, three, all of them, and also the old man are opening their veins for her. Oh yes, I know, my friend John; I am not blind! I love you even more for this! Now go.”
es: –Well done, friend John! Very well thought out! Truly, if Miss Lucy has to be sad because of the enemies that besiege her, at least she can be happy for the friends who love her. One, two, three, all open their veins for her, besides an old man like me. Ah yes! I know it, friend John; I am not blind; I love you more for it! Now, go away.

en: In the hall I met Quincey Morris, with a telegram for Arthur telling him that Mrs. Westenra was dead; that Lucy also had been ill, but was now going on better; and that Van Helsing and I were with her. I told him where I was going, and he hurried me out, but as I was going said:—
vi: Down the corridor, we met Quincey Morris again as he was preparing to send a telegram to Arthur to inform him about Mrs. Westenra's death and Lucy's health condition. When I said I had to leave for a while, Quincey didn't hold me back but just asked one question:
tr: As I was holding the telegram that informed Arthur that Ms. Westenra had died, Lucy was ill but was getting better, and that Van Helsing and I were by her side, I encountered Quincey Morris. I told him where I was going, and he hurriedly saw me off, but just as I was leaving, he said:
es: In the corridor, I found Quincey Morris with a telegram for Arthur telling him that Mrs. Westenra had died; that Lucy had also been ill, but was now improving; and that Van Helsing and I were with her. I told him where I was going, and he urged me to hurry. But when I was about to do so, he said to me:

en: “When you come back, Jack, may I have two words with you all to ourselves?” I nodded in reply and went out. I found no difficulty about the registration, and arranged with the local undertaker to come up in the evening to measure for the coffin and to make arrangements.
vi: — Jack, when you come back, could you spare a moment to talk with me? I gently nodded in agreement. When it came to Mrs. Westenra's death, the civil servant did not cause me any trouble. And the local funeral director eagerly promised me that he would come in the late afternoon to handle all related matters.
tr: "Jack, when you get back, can I have a word with you in private?" I nodded and said yes, then left. I didn't encounter any difficulties with the registration, and I arranged for the person responsible for the funeral to come in the evening to take measurements for the coffin and make the necessary arrangements.
es: –When you return, Jack, can I speak to you alone? I nodded affirmatively and left. I found no difficulty in making the arrangements, and I agreed with the local funeral home that they would come at night to take the measurements of the coffin and make the other preparations.

en: When I got back Quincey was waiting for me. I told him I would see him as soon as I knew about Lucy, and went up to her room. She was still sleeping, and the Professor seemingly had not moved from his seat at her side. From his putting his finger to his lips, I gathered that he expected her to wake before long and was afraid of forestalling nature. So I went down to Quincey and took him into the breakfast-room, where the blinds were not drawn down, and which was a little more cheerful, or rather less cheerless, than the other rooms. When we were alone, he said to me:—
vi: When I returned, Quincey was still waiting. I told him that after visiting Lucy, I would come down to talk to him. Lucy was still sleeping, and it seemed Van Helsing had been sitting by her bed the entire time I was away. Seeing me enter, the professor quickly put his finger to his lips, signaling for me to keep quiet. He must have thought that Lucy was about to wake up, but he wanted her sleep to be natural, and her awakening to be something natural as well, not forced by any noise. Therefore, I had to go down to meet Quincey. I invited him to a brighter living room, as this room did not have the curtains drawn. As soon as we sat down, Quincey spoke:
tr: When I returned, Quincey was waiting for me. I told him that I would see him as soon as I got information about Lucy and went up to Lucy's room. She was still sleeping, and the Professor, apparently, had not moved from the chair beside her bed. From his gesture of putting his finger to his lips, I concluded that he expected Lucy to wake up soon and was afraid of interfering with the natural course of events. Therefore, I went down to Quincey and took him to the breakfast room, which was a bit more cheerful—or less cheerless—compared to the other rooms, as the curtains were not closed. When we were alone, he said:
es: When I returned, Quincey was waiting for me. I told him that I would see him as soon as I knew something about Lucy, and I went up to her room. She was still sleeping, and apparently my master had not moved from his seat beside her. From the way he put his finger to his lips, I guessed that he expected her to wake up at any moment, and was afraid of getting ahead of nature. So I went down to where Quincey was and took him to the breakfast room, where the shutters were not drawn and therefore it was a bit more cheerful, or rather, less sad than the other rooms. When we were alone, he said to me:

en: “Jack Seward, I don’t want to shove myself in anywhere where I’ve no right to be; but this is no ordinary case. You know I loved that girl and wanted to marry her; but, although that’s all past and gone, I can’t help feeling anxious about her all the same. What is it that’s wrong with her? The Dutchman—and a fine old fellow he is; I can see that—said, that time you two came into the room, that you must have another transfusion of blood, and that both you and he were exhausted. Now I know well that you medical men speak in camera, and that a man must not expect to know what they consult about in private. But this is no common matter, and, whatever it is, I have done my part. Is not that so?”
vi: — Jack Seward, I don't want to speak carelessly about things I don't fully understand, but it seems the situation is very particularly serious. You know that I also love this girl very much and that I once proposed to her. Although that is a thing of the past, I still care and worry a lot. In fact, I still don't know exactly what is wrong with Lucy and what pain she is enduring. Earlier, when we were in the dining room over there, I heard the Dutch professor tell you that another blood transfusion is needed, but he also mentioned that both you and he are exhausted. So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: “Jack Seward, I don't want to intrude where I have no right to be; but this is not an ordinary situation. You know that I once loved that girl and wanted to marry her; but even though all that is in the past, I can't help but worry about her. What is her problem? The Dutchman -and I can see he is a good man- said when you entered the room that you needed to perform another blood transfusion and that both you and he were exhausted. I know that you medical men have private conversations among yourselves and that an ordinary person should not expect to learn about the matters you discuss among yourselves. But this is not an ordinary situation and whatever it is, I have done my part. Isn't that so?”
es: –Jack Seward, I don't want to intrude anywhere I have no right to be, but this is no ordinary case. You know that I loved this girl and wanted to marry her; but, although all that is past and buried, I can't help feeling anxious about her. What is happening to her? What is she suffering from? The Dutchman, and I well realize he is a formidable old man, said, the moment you two entered the room, that another blood transfusion was needed and that you two were already exhausted. Now, I know very well that you doctors speak in camera, and that one should not expect to know what you discuss in private. But this is not a common matter, and, whatever it is, I have done my part. Isn't that so?

en: “That’s so,” I said, and he went on:—
vi: So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: “Yes, that's right,” I said; and he continued his words:
es: –That's right, I told him, and he continued:

en: “I take it that both you and Van Helsing had done already what I did to-day. Is not that so?”
vi: So, Van Helsing and you have each given blood to Lucy at least once, is that correct?
tr: “I believe that both you and Van Helsing have already done what I did today. Isn't that so?”
es: –I suppose that you two, you and Van Helsing, already did what I did today. Isn't that so?

en: “That’s so.”
vi: — Exactly like that.
tr: “Yes, that's right.”
es: –That's right.

en: “And I guess Art was in it too. When I saw him four days ago down at his own place he looked queer. I have not seen anything pulled down so quick since I was on the Pampas and had a mare that I was fond of go to grass all in a night. One of those big bats that they call vampires had got at her in the night, and what with his gorge and the vein left open, there wasn’t enough blood in her to let her stand up, and I had to put a bullet through her as she lay. Jack, if you may tell me without betraying confidence, Arthur was the first, is not that so?” As he spoke the poor fellow looked terribly anxious. He was in a torture of suspense regarding the woman he loved, and his utter ignorance of the terrible mystery which seemed to surround her intensified his pain. His very heart was bleeding, and it took all the manhood of him—and there was a royal lot of it, too—to keep him from breaking down. I paused before answering, for I felt that I must not betray anything which the Professor wished kept secret; but already he knew so much, and guessed so much, that there could be no reason for not answering, so I answered in the same phrase: “That’s so.”
vi: — I even think that Arthur did the same. Four days ago, when we met, I saw that he also looked very pale. I have never seen anyone change so quickly, except for once when I witnessed my beloved horse being attacked by a bat that people call a "vampire," which tore its neck artery and drained all its blood. That night, the horse was too weak to stand up, and I had to put a bullet in its head to spare it a painful death. Jack, if it weren't for professional secrecy, please tell me. Was Arthur the first person to donate blood? The more he spoke, the more the young man revealed his lack of composure in hiding his worries about the health condition of the unfortunate girl he still loved. I noticed that he was just one step away from bursting into tears. I remained silent, contemplating before answering Quincey, because I was hesitating whether to tell the whole truth or not, as I was unsure of Professor Van Helsing's reaction. But clearly, he already knew a little, and it was also possible that he was guessing that I couldn't avoid answering his question. — That's right, - I replied - Arthur was the first.
tr: “And I think Art is involved too. When I saw him at his own house four days ago, he looked strange. I hadn't seen anything deteriorate so quickly since a mare I loved in the South American plains died overnight. One of those big bats they call vampires had latched onto her at night and after gorging itself, left her vein open, and because she didn't have enough blood left to keep her standing, I had to shoot her while she lay down. Jack, I don't want you to betray any trust, but Arthur was the first, wasn't he?” As he spoke, my poor friend was extremely anxious. He was tormented by suspicion about the woman he loved, and his pain was intensified by knowing nothing about the terrible mystery surrounding her. His heart was bleeding, and it took all his manliness—and he had a kingly amount of it—to keep from completely losing himself. I paused before answering, because I felt I shouldn't reveal anything the Professor wanted kept secret; but he already knew and guessed so much that there was no reason not to answer, so I replied in the same way: “Yes, he was.”
es: –And I imagine that Art is also involved in the matter. When I saw him four days ago at his house, he seemed quite strange. I had never seen anyone lose weight so quickly, since I was in the Pampas and had a mare that liked to graze at night. One of those big bats they call vampires got her at night and left her with her throat and vein open, without enough blood inside her to allow her to stand, so I had to put a bullet in her while she lay there. Jack, if you can talk to me without betraying the trust they have placed in you, tell me, Arthur was the first, wasn't he? As he spoke, my poor friend showed signs of being terribly anxious. He was in a torture of restlessness for the woman he loved, and his total ignorance of the terrible mystery that seemed to surround her intensified his pain. His own heart was bleeding, and it took all the manliness in him (of which there was plenty, I can assure you) to keep from collapsing. I paused before responding, as I felt I should not say anything that would betray the secrets the doctor wished to keep; but in any case, he already knew so much, and guessed so much, that there was no reason not to respond, so I answered him with the same phrase:

en: “And how long has this been going on?”
vi: — So when did it happen?
tr: “And how long has this been going on?”
es: –That's right. –And how long has this been happening?

en: “About ten days.”
vi: — About ten days ago.
tr: “About ten days.”
es: –For about ten days,

en: “Ten days! Then I guess, Jack Seward, that that poor pretty creature that we all love has had put into her veins within that time the blood of four strong men. Man alive, her whole body wouldn’t hold it.” Then, coming close to me, he spoke in a fierce half-whisper: “What took it out?”
vi: — Ten days? So the poor girl whom we all love has received blood from four people within just ten days? Under normal circumstances, that amount of blood would be too much for a delicate body like hers. Quincey suddenly sat close to me: — So why is she still so anemic?
tr: “Ten days! Then, Jack, I believe that within this period, that poor beautiful creature we all love has taken the blood of four strong men into her veins. Her entire body couldn't carry that much blood.” Then, approaching me and half-whispering harshly, he said: “What draws the blood?”
es: –Ten days! Then I suppose, Jack Seward, that the poor creature we all love has had the blood of four strong men put into her veins during that time. A single man himself couldn't endure it for long -he added, and then, approaching me, he spoke in a kind of angry whisper-: Who took it from her?

en: I shook my head. “That,” I said, “is the crux. Van Helsing is simply frantic about it, and I am at my wits’ end. I can’t even hazard a guess. There has been a series of little circumstances which have thrown out all our calculations as to Lucy being properly watched. But these shall not occur again. Here we stay until all be well—or ill.” Quincey held out his hand. “Count me in,” he said. “You and the Dutchman will tell me what to do, and I’ll do it.”
vi: — That is still a question mark. - I shook my head. - Both Van Helsing and I are still unclear as to why. It is true that some force has been opposing the professor's efforts. But that no longer seems to be happening. Now we have decided to stay here until everything turns out well, or until everything is over. Quincey tightly grasped my hand. — I will give you a hand. - He said - Just tell me what the Dutch professor and you want me to do, and I will do it immediately.
tr: I shook my head to indicate I didn't know. "That's it," I said, "that's the problem. Van Helsing is very excited about this and I don't know what to do. I don't even dare to make a guess. A series of small events have occurred that have thrown all our plans for properly monitoring Lucy out the window. But these won't happen again. We will stay here until everything is fixed - or broken. Quincey extended his hand. "Count me in," he said. "You and the Dutchman will tell me what to do, and I will do it."
es: I shook my head no. –Therein lies the problem. Van Helsing is simply frantic about it, and I am about to rack my brains. I can no longer even venture a guess. There has been a series of small circumstances that have thwarted all our calculations for Lucy to be properly watched. But this will not happen again. We will stay here until everything is either right... or wrong. Quincey extended his hand. "Count on me," he said. "You and the Dutchman just have to tell me what to do, and I will do it."

en: When she woke late in the afternoon, Lucy’s first movement was to feel in her breast, and, to my surprise, produced the paper which Van Helsing had given me to read. The careful Professor had replaced it where it had come from, lest on waking she should be alarmed. Her eye then lit on Van Helsing and on me too, and gladdened. Then she looked around the room, and seeing where she was, shuddered; she gave a loud cry, and put her poor thin hands before her pale face. We both understood what that meant—that she had realised to the full her mother’s death; so we tried what we could to comfort her. Doubtless sympathy eased her somewhat, but she was very low in thought and spirit, and wept silently and weakly for a long time. We told her that either or both of us would now remain with her all the time, and that seemed to comfort her. Towards dusk she fell into a doze. Here a very odd thing occurred. Whilst still asleep she took the paper from her breast and tore it in two. Van Helsing stepped over and took the pieces from her. All the same, however, she went on with the action of tearing, as though the material were still in her hands; finally she lifted her hands and opened them as though scattering the fragments. Van Helsing seemed surprised, and his brows gathered as if in thought, but he said nothing.
vi: In the afternoon, when she woke up, to my astonishment, the first thing Lucy did was to slip her hand under her nightgown to take out the pieces of paper that Van Helsing had given me to read. The professor had carefully put them back in their original place, fearing that if she woke up and didn't see those pieces of paper, she would be frightened. Holding the pieces of paper in her hand, she looked at Van Helsing for a moment and then turned to look at me, appearing genuinely satisfied. Then she looked around the room like a child getting acquainted with a new world, but when she suddenly realized this wasn't her room, she burst into tears and covered her face with her hands, which were still pale as if she had drowned. It was only at this moment that she remembered the reality that she had lost her mother. We gathered around to comfort and console her. If we could ease her heart even a little, she would be less tormented by the pain. But Lucy continued to sob in front of us. It was only when I said that from now on, either Van Helsing and I would be together, or we would take turns being with her, that she felt a little more at ease. The night fell, she began to drift into sleep again. One more thing surprised me: while sleeping, she held the pieces of paper she had torn earlier and ripped them in half. Van Helsing tried to remove those pieces of paper, but she held on very tightly and even tore them into smaller pieces. Finally, she raised her hand and spread her fingers as if she wanted to throw the tiny pieces of paper high into the air. Van Helsing was very puzzled, but he didn't say anything.
tr: When she woke up late that afternoon, the first thing Lucy did was to feel her chest and, to my surprise, take out the paper that Van Helsing had given me to read from her chest. The careful Professor had put it back where it came from so she wouldn't worry when she woke up. Then, her eyes shifted to Van Helsing and me, and she felt relieved. Then, she looked around the room and shuddered when she realized where she was; she screamed loudly and covered her pale face with her poor, thin hands. We both understood what this meant - that she fully comprehended her mother's death; so we did our best to comfort her. Undoubtedly, the empathy comforted her a bit, but she was very weak mentally and spiritually; she cried silently and feebly for a long time. We told her that one or both of us would always stay with her; this seemed to comfort her a little. She fell into a light sleep towards twilight. During this time, a very strange thing happened. In her sleep, she took the paper out of her chest and tore it up. Van Helsing went to her and took the pieces of paper from her hand. However, despite this, Lucy continued the tearing motion as if the paper was still in her hand; finally, she raised her hands and opened them as if scattering the pieces. Van Helsing seemed surprised, and his eyebrows furrowed as if deep in thought, but he said nothing.
es: When Lucy woke up in the afternoon, her first movement was to feel her chest, and, to my surprise, she pulled out from it the paper that Van Helsing had given me to read. The careful professor had placed it back in its spot again, to prevent her from feeling alarmed when she woke up. Her eyes turned to Van Helsing and me and brightened. Then she looked around the room and, seeing where she was, trembled; she let out a sharp cry and put her poor, thin hands over her pale face. We both understood what it meant (she had fully realized her mother's death), so we tried to console her. There is no doubt that our compassion calmed her a bit, but she still remained very disheartened and continued to sob silently and weakly for a long time. We told her that either one of us, or both, would stay with her all the time, and that seemed to comfort her a little. Towards the evening, she fell into a sort of stupor. Then something very strange happened. While she was still asleep, she took the paper from her chest and tore it into two pieces. Van Helsing stepped forward and took the pieces from her hands. In any case, she continued with the intention of breaking, as if she still had the material in her fingers; finally, she raised her hands and opened them, as if scattering the fragments. Van Helsing seemed surprised and his eyebrows came together as if he were thinking, but he said nothing.

en: 19 September.—All last night she slept fitfully, being always afraid to sleep, and something weaker when she woke from it. The Professor and I took it in turns to watch, and we never left her for a moment unattended. Quincey Morris said nothing about his intention, but I knew that all night long he patrolled round and round the house.
vi: • September 19 Throughout that night, Lucy slept uneasily. I noticed several times that she showed signs of a fear of sleeping, but eventually, she still fell into a deep sleep. It was precisely this deep sleep that revealed all the frail features on her sorrowful face, even more clearly than when she was awake. Van Helsing and I took turns watching over her; we did not dare leave her alone for even a minute. I don't know what Quincey Morris was thinking, but throughout the night, I kept seeing him pacing around the house.
tr: September 19. - Throughout last night, he slept fitfully, always fearing sleep and growing somehow weaker with each awakening. The Professor and I took turns watching over him, never leaving him alone for a moment. Quincey Morris said nothing about his plan, but I knew he patrolled around the house all night long.
es: September 19. All last night she slept fitfully, always feeling afraid to fall asleep and appearing a bit weaker each time she woke up. The professor and I took turns keeping watch, and we did not leave her unattended for a single moment. Quincey Morris said nothing about his intention, but I know that he spent the whole night walking around the house.

en: When the day came, its searching light showed the ravages in poor Lucy’s strength. She was hardly able to turn her head, and the little nourishment which she could take seemed to do her no good. At times she slept, and both Van Helsing and I noticed the difference in her, between sleeping and waking. Whilst asleep she looked stronger, although more haggard, and her breathing was softer; her open mouth showed the pale gums drawn back from the teeth, which thus looked positively longer and sharper than usual; when she woke the softness of her eyes evidently changed the expression, for she looked her own self, although a dying one. In the afternoon she asked for Arthur, and we telegraphed for him. Quincey went off to meet him at the station.
vi: In the morning, looking at Lucy, we knew that she had no strength left. I didn't dare to exaggerate because there were times when she couldn't even turn or move her head from one side to the other. It seemed that the scant nutrition we gave her yesterday had not been digested and converted into energy. Occasionally, Van Helsing and I anxiously observed the changes on her face while she was deeply asleep in the morning. There were also times when her breathing was slower and more regular. She slept with her mouth wide open, exposing her purplish gums receding deep below the gum line, making her teeth appear much longer and sharper than usual. When she woke up, the gentleness in her eyes, though still drowsy, restored the familiar emotions of her usual self. In the afternoon, she suddenly demanded to see Arthur; we had to telegraph him to come, and Quincey would be the one to go to the station to pick him up.
tr: When it was daytime, the sunlight revealed how badly his poor strength had been damaged. He could barely turn his head, and the small amount of food he could consume didn't seem to benefit him. He slept from time to time, and Van Helsing and I could see the difference between when he was asleep and awake. While he appeared weaker and his breathing was lighter when sleeping, he seemed stronger; his open mouth revealed his drawn, pale gums, making his teeth look definitely longer and sharper; when he woke up, the softness in his eyes clearly changed his expression, because even though he was dying, he looked like himself. In the afternoon, he asked for Arthur and sent him a telegram. Quincey went to the station to meet him.
es: When the day arrived, its enlightening light revealed the ravages in poor Lucy's fortitude. She was barely able to turn her head, and the few foods she could take seemed to do no good. At times she slept, and both Van Helsing and I noted the difference in her, while she slept and while she was awake. While she slept, she looked stronger, though more haggard, and her breathing was softer; her open mouth showed the pale gums receding from her teeth, which thus appeared positively longer and sharper than usual; upon waking, the softness of her eyes evidently changed her expression, as she looked more like herself, though still agonizing. In the afternoon, she asked about Arthur, and we telegraphed him. Quincey went to the station to meet him.

en: When he arrived it was nearly six o’clock, and the sun was setting full and warm, and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks. When he saw her, Arthur was simply choking with emotion, and none of us could speak. In the hours that had passed, the fits of sleep, or the comatose condition that passed for it, had grown more frequent, so that the pauses when conversation was possible were shortened. Arthur’s presence, however, seemed to act as a stimulant; she rallied a little, and spoke to him more brightly than she had done since we arrived. He too pulled himself together, and spoke as cheerily as he could, so that the best was made of everything.
vi: Arthur arrived at around 6 o'clock. The afternoon weather was still hot, and the patient's cheeks seemed to blush under the lingering rays of sunlight in the room. Seeing Lucy, Arthur had to try very hard to hide his emotions. None of us had the courage to tell him the truth. Arthur's appearance seemed to gradually restore Lucy's strength. Since she arrived at her house, I had never seen her speak so animatedly.
tr: When Arthur arrived, it was almost six o'clock; the sun was setting, red light was streaming in through the window, giving a bit more color to his pale cheeks. When he saw him, Arthur was almost choked with excitement, none of us could speak. In the hours that passed, healthy sleeps or what were considered coma-like states became more frequent, and thus the intervals where conversation was possible shortened. But Arthur's presence acted as a stimulant; Lucy had somewhat come to herself and was more lively while talking to him than she had been since we arrived here. Arthur had also pulled himself together, speaking as cheerfully as possible, so everything was going as well as it could.
es: When he arrived, it was already around six in the evening, and the sun was setting with all its splendor and color, and the red light flowed through the window, giving more color to her pale cheeks. Upon seeing her, Arthur was simply overwhelmed with emotion, and none of us could speak. In the hours that had passed, the periods of sleep, or the comatose condition that seemed to mimic it, had become more frequent, so much so that the pauses during which conversation was possible had been reduced. However, Arthur's presence seemed to act as a stimulant; she revived a bit and spoke with him more lucidly than she had since our arrival. He also composed himself and spoke as cheerfully as he could, so that the best was made of it.

en: It was now nearly one o’clock, and he and Van Helsing are sitting with her. I am to relieve them in a quarter of an hour, and I am entering this on Lucy’s phonograph. Until six o’clock they are to try to rest. I fear that to-morrow will end our watching, for the shock has been too great; the poor child cannot rally. God help us all.
vi: It is now almost one o'clock; Van Helsing and Arthur are still watching over the patient. In about fifteen minutes, I will take over their shift. While waiting, I have recorded these details into Lucy's phonograph. After I take over, the two of them will take the opportunity to sleep until 6 AM. Hopefully, tomorrow, we won't need to stay up to watch over her anymore. Then the poor girl will have to recover. God help us!
tr: It was almost one o'clock and Arthur and Van Helsing were sitting beside Lucy. In fifteen minutes, I will take over their watch, and I am making this record on Lucy's phonograph. They will try to rest until six o'clock. I fear tomorrow will end our watch, for this shock was too great; the poor child will not recover. God help us all.
es: It's about to be one in the morning, and he and Van Helsing are sitting with her. I will relieve them in a quarter of an hour, and I am recording this in Lucy's phonograph. They will try to rest until six. I fear that our watch will end tomorrow, for the shock has been too great; the poor girl cannot be revived. God help us all.
