tr: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (Unopened by the recipient.)
es: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (unopened)

en: (Unopened by her.)
vi: (The recipient has not opened the letter)
tr: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (Unopened by the recipient.)
es: Letter from Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra (unopened)

en: “17 September.
vi: "September 17"
tr: September 17
es: September 17

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Dear Lucy,
tr: Dearest Lucy
es: "My dear Lucy:

en: “It seems an age since I heard from you, or indeed since I wrote. You will pardon me, I know, for all my faults when you have read all my budget of news. Well, I got my husband back all right; when we arrived at Exeter there was a carriage waiting for us, and in it, though he had an attack of gout, Mr. Hawkins. He took us to his house, where there were rooms for us all nice and comfortable, and we dined together. After dinner Mr. Hawkins said:—
vi: I feel like a whole century has passed without hearing any news from you, or more precisely, I haven't written to you for a century. I hope you will forgive me after reading these lines. First, I must inform you that my spouse and I have moved back here. When we got off the train in Exeter, I saw Mr. Hawkins, despite being tormented by gout, already sitting in the car waiting to pick us up. Hawkins himself drove us to his house. The three of us had dinner together. He provided us with very comfortable rooms. After dinner, he said to us:
tr: It feels like a century has passed since I last heard from you or actually wrote to you. I know you will forgive me for my mistakes once you read all my news. Well, I safely received my husband; when we arrived in Exeter, a car was waiting for us, and despite suffering from gout, Mr. Hawkins was in the car. He took us to his home, where all the rooms allocated to us were very nice and comfortable, and we had dinner together. After dinner, Mr. Hawkins said:
es: "It seems to me that centuries have passed since I last heard from you, or rather since I last wrote to you. I know you will forgive all my faults when you have read the news I am going to give you. Well, I brought my husband back in good condition; when we arrived in Exeter, a carriage was waiting for us, and in it, despite having a gout attack, Mr. Hawkins took us to his house, where there were rooms for us, all arranged and comfortable, and we had dinner together. After dinner, Mr. Hawkins said:

en: “‘My dears, I want to drink your health and prosperity; and may every blessing attend you both. I know you both from children, and have, with love and pride, seen you grow up. Now I want you to make your home here with me. I have left to me neither chick nor child; all are gone, and in my will I have left you everything.’ I cried, Lucy dear, as Jonathan and the old man clasped hands. Our evening was a very, very happy one.
vi: — My friends, I have drunk to your health and happiness for a hundred years! May you always have complete joys? I have known you since you were young, so I am very proud to witness your growth. Today, I want you to consider this place as your own home. I live alone, without any children, so I will write a will to leave all my assets to you. Lucy, hearing Mr. Hawkins speak, seeing the scene of him and my husband shaking hands for a long time, I couldn't hold back my tears. That evening was so incredibly happy.
tr: “My dears, I want to drink to your health and happiness; I wish all the best for you. I have known both of you since your childhood and watched you grow with love and pride. Now I want you to build your home here beside me. I have neither wife nor child left; they are all gone and I have left everything to you in my will." As Jonathan and the old man shook hands, I cried, my dear Lucy. Our evening was very, very, very happy.
es: "My dear ones, I want to toast to your health and prosperity, and may all blessings fall upon you both. I have known you since you were children, and I have watched with love and pride as you grew up. Now I wish for you to make your home here with me. I leave behind neither descendants nor children; all are gone, and in my will, I appoint you as universal heirs. "I cried, dear Lucy, while Jonathan and old Mr. Hawkins shook hands. We had a very, very happy evening.

en: “So here we are, installed in this beautiful old house, and from both my bedroom and the drawing-room I can see the great elms of the cathedral close, with their great black stems standing out against the old yellow stone of the cathedral and I can hear the rooks overhead cawing and cawing and chattering and gossiping all day, after the manner of rooks—and humans. I am busy, I need not tell you, arranging things and housekeeping. Jonathan and Mr. Hawkins are busy all day; for, now that Jonathan is a partner, Mr. Hawkins wants to tell him all about the clients.
vi: So, we were lucky enough to move into a beautiful, ancient house. All the rooms we have access to, from the bedroom to the dining room and the living room, overlook the old elm trees surrounding the chapel, but the only thing is, at night, I often have to listen to the crows flying back and forth over the roof. These crows are really noisy, they keep cawing incessantly, giving me a headache. What can I tell you now? Currently, I am very busy arranging the house and furniture. As for Jonathan, he is buried in work all day long because he is now Mr. Hawkins' assistant - who is urgently handing over all the work related to each client to him.
tr: So here we are, settled in this beautiful old house, and from both my bedroom and the living room, I can see the nearby cathedral, with the great black bodies of the elm trees standing against the old yellow stones of the cathedral; I can hear the crows making noise all day, cawing and gossiping about the behaviors of crows and people. Needless to say, I am busy making arrangements concerning work and household management. Jonathan and Mr. Hawkins work all day long; because Jonathan is now a partner. Mr. Hawkins wants to tell him everything about the clients.
es: "So here we are, settled in this beautiful and ancient house, and from both my bedroom and the living room I can see very close the great elms of the cathedral, with their strong trunks erect against the old yellow stones of the cathedral, and I can hear the crows above cawing and chattering, gossiping in the manner of crows... and humans. I am very busy, and I don't need to tell you, arranging things and doing household chores. Jonathan and Mr. Hawkins are busy all day; for now that Jonathan is his partner, Mr. Hawkins wants him to know everything concerning his clients.

en: “How is your dear mother getting on? I wish I could run up to town for a day or two to see you, dear, but I dare not go yet, with so much on my shoulders; and Jonathan wants looking after still. He is beginning to put some flesh on his bones again, but he was terribly weakened by the long illness; even now he sometimes starts out of his sleep in a sudden way and awakes all trembling until I can coax him back to his usual placidity. However, thank God, these occasions grow less frequent as the days go on, and they will in time pass away altogether, I trust. And now I have told you my news, let me ask yours. When are you to be married, and where, and who is to perform the ceremony, and what are you to wear, and is it to be a public or a private wedding? Tell me all about it, dear; tell me all about everything, for there is nothing which interests you which will not be dear to me. Jonathan asks me to send his ‘respectful duty,’ but I do not think that is good enough from the junior partner of the important firm Hawkins & Harker; and so, as you love me, and he loves me, and I love you with all the moods and tenses of the verb, I send you simply his ‘love’ instead. Good-bye, my dearest Lucy, and all blessings on you.
vi: How is your mother doing? I really want to visit her and you for a few days, but right now it's too difficult, I still have a lot of work to do. Moreover, even if Jonathan gets better, his illness still hasn't fully recovered. Honestly, he still looks very weak. Occasionally, I see him startle in his sleep and then wake up in a panic, his face bewildered like a lost soul, his body trembling. Every time that happens, I have to comfort and soothe him. Thank God, his condition is improving every day, and I dare to hope that gradually he will fully recover. Now, allow me to ask a few questions about your situation. When do you plan to get married, and where? Who will officiate? What dress do you plan to wear? Will you invite many friends or just have a simple ceremony? Remember to answer, my dear friend, because you know well that I always think of you and care about what you are holding in your heart. Jonathan also asked me to send you his sincere regards and best wishes, but I swear that is still not enough for a young assistant of a big company like Hawkins and Harker. Just as you love me and he loves me, I send you their heartfelt feelings. Goodbye, dear Lucy.
tr: How is your dear mother doing? I wish I could come to town for a day or two to see you, dear, but with so much burden on my shoulders, I still don't have the courage; Jonathan still needs care as well. A bit of flesh has started to cover his bones, but he was terribly weakened by the long illness; even now, sometimes he suddenly jumps up in his sleep and wakes up trembling until I can soothe him back to his usual docility with sweet words. Still, thank God, these episodes are becoming less frequent as days go by, and I believe they will completely disappear in time. So, I've given you my news, let me ask about yours. When and where will you get married, who will conduct the wedding, and what will you wear, will it be an open wedding for the guests or will it be just among yourselves? Tell me everything, dear; tell me everything about it because there is nothing that concerns you that is not important to me. Jonathan asked me to convey his "deepest respects" to you, but I don't think that's enough for a greeting from the junior partner of Hawkins & Harker; so, since you love me, and he loves me, and I love you in all tenses and meanings of the word, I am sending you his "love" instead. Goodbye dear Lucy, and may all goodness be upon you.
es: "How is your dear mother doing?" I wish I could go to the city for one or two days to see you, dear, but I don't dare to go yet, with so much work on my shoulders; and Jonathan still needs to be taken care of. He is beginning to put flesh on his bones again, but he was terribly weakened by the long illness; even now sometimes he wakes up startled from his sleep in a sudden way, and he starts trembling until I manage, with cuddles, to restore his usual calmness. However, thank God these occasions are becoming less frequent as the days go by, and I trust that in time they will disappear completely. And now that I have given you my news, let me ask about yours. When are you going to get married, and where, and who is going to perform the ceremony, and what are you going to wear? Is it going to be a public ceremony, or private? Tell me everything you can about it, dear; tell me everything about everything, for there is nothing that interests you that is not dear to me. Jonathan asks me to send you his 'respectful regards', but I don't think that is fitting for the young partner of the important firm Hawkins and just as you love me, and he loves me, and I love you with all the modes and tenses of the verb, I simply send you his 'affection'. Goodbye, my dearest Lucy, and all blessings to you.

en: “Yours,
vi: Wishing you a thousand times happiness.
tr: With my love,
es: "Your friend,

en: “Mina Harker.”
vi: Your Mina.
tr: MINA HARKER
es: MINA HARKER

en: Report from Patrick Hennessey, M. D., M. R. C. S. L. K. Q. C. P. I., etc., etc., to John Seward, M. D.
vi: Report from psychiatrist Patrick Hennessey to Dr. John Seward
tr: Patrick Hennessey; M. D., M. R. C. S., L. K. P. C. P. I. 32 vs. vs. against John Seward; M. D. and the report
es: Report by Patrick Hennessey, M. D.: Member of the Royal College of Surgeons, Licentiate of the King’s and Queen’s College of Physicians. P. I., etc., for John Seward.

en: “20 September.
vi: "September 20"
tr: September 20
es: M. D.

en: “My dear Sir,—
vi: Dear colleague.
tr: Dear Sir,
es: "Dear Sir:

en: “In accordance with your wishes, I enclose report of the conditions of everything left in my charge.... With regard to patient, Renfield, there is more to say. He has had another outbreak, which might have had a dreadful ending, but which, as it fortunately happened, was unattended with any unhappy results. This afternoon a carrier’s cart with two men made a call at the empty house whose grounds abut on ours—the house to which, you will remember, the patient twice ran away. The men stopped at our gate to ask the porter their way, as they were strangers. I was myself looking out of the study window, having a smoke after dinner, and saw one of them come up to the house. As he passed the window of Renfield’s room, the patient began to rate him from within, and called him all the foul names he could lay his tongue to. The man, who seemed a decent fellow enough, contented himself by telling him to “shut up for a foul-mouthed beggar,” whereon our man accused him of robbing him and wanting to murder him and said that he would hinder him if he were to swing for it. I opened the window and signed to the man not to notice, so he contented himself after looking the place over and making up his mind as to what kind of a place he had got to by saying: ‘Lor’ bless yer, sir, I wouldn’t mind what was said to me in a bloomin’ madhouse. I pity ye and the guv’nor for havin’ to live in the house with a wild beast like that.’ Then he asked his way civilly enough, and I told him where the gate of the empty house was; he went away, followed by threats and curses and revilings from our man. I went down to see if I could make out any cause for his anger, since he is usually such a well-behaved man, and except his violent fits nothing of the kind had ever occurred. I found him, to my astonishment, quite composed and most genial in his manner. I tried to get him to talk of the incident, but he blandly asked me questions as to what I meant, and led me to believe that he was completely oblivious of the affair. It was, I am sorry to say, however, only another instance of his cunning, for within half an hour I heard of him again. This time he had broken out through the window of his room, and was running down the avenue. I called to the attendants to follow me, and ran after him, for I feared he was intent on some mischief. My fear was justified when I saw the same cart which had passed before coming down the road, having on it some great wooden boxes. The men were wiping their foreheads, and were flushed in the face, as if with violent exercise. Before I could get up to him the patient rushed at them, and pulling one of them off the cart, began to knock his head against the ground. If I had not seized him just at the moment I believe he would have killed the man there and then. The other fellow jumped down and struck him over the head with the butt-end of his heavy whip. It was a terrible blow; but he did not seem to mind it, but seized him also, and struggled with the three of us, pulling us to and fro as if we were kittens. You know I am no light weight, and the others were both burly men. At first he was silent in his fighting; but as we began to master him, and the attendants were putting a strait-waistcoat on him, he began to shout: ‘I’ll frustrate them! They shan’t rob me! they shan’t murder me by inches! I’ll fight for my Lord and Master!’ and all sorts of similar incoherent ravings. It was with very considerable difficulty that they got him back to the house and put him in the padded room. One of the attendants, Hardy, had a finger broken. However, I set it all right; and he is going on well.
vi: I would like to report that the condition of several patients under my care is nothing noteworthy. As for Renfield's case, I find there is much to be said. He had another episode, but this time it ended without any unfortunate consequences. By the way, I should also mention that this afternoon, a truck with two men appeared at the abandoned house near our hospital—the house where Renfield twice escaped and crossed over to, you remember? These two men stopped in front of the hospital to ask the gatekeeper for directions, as far as I know, they are not locals. At that time, I had just finished lunch and was standing outside my office smoking, so I noticed one of the men heading towards the hospital's outer corridor. When he passed by Renfield's window, the patient immediately sprang up and started cursing wildly. He cursed that the man was not only there to steal but also intended to kill him, and he swore that next time, he wouldn't let the man harm him. I opened the window and told the truck driver not to take it to heart. After glancing back at the front of the hospital building, the man realized where he was standing. Only then did he say to me: — May God bless you. Indeed, I still cannot fully imagine the scene of having to stand before a group of madmen. I truly sympathize with you and your master for having to live among such fierce individuals! Then the man politely asked me for directions to the abandoned house next door. I courteously gave him the directions. He left, but Renfield continued to madly spew out a torrent of curses and threats. When I went down to visit him, I kept wondering if this time I could find out the reason for his anger. When I went down to his room, I was very surprised because I didn't understand why he was so quiet and gentle. I tried to ask him what he had to say about what had happened, but he asked me back what I meant. I felt as if he truly didn't remember anything anymore. It was really unpleasant if that was just another example of his cunning mind, because less than half an hour later, he made me talk about him again. This time, he jumped out of the window and ran away at full speed. Afraid he might do something wrong, I had to call some guards and told them to catch him at all costs. And I wasn't wrong. A while later, I saw the truck turning back towards the hospital, now carrying large crates. The two guys on the truck were wiping sweat off their foreheads, their faces red as if they had just gone through a fierce struggle. Before I could catch the patient, he had already jumped onto the truck, grabbed one of the drivers by the neck, and pulled him to the ground, then he grabbed the victim's hair and repeatedly smashed his head against the road. If I hadn't run after him in time, he probably would have beaten the man to death. The other driver also hurriedly jumped to the ground, holding a rubber hose and whipping it continuously at the patient. These blows should have made him scream in pain, but no, he didn't seem to feel anything, because after that he calmly stood up and fought back against the man attacking him, then he attacked all three of us, pushing us around easily as if we were just a bunch of scrawny cats. You know that I'm just a skinny guy, but I can't say the same for the two truck drivers: they were as strong as bulls. At first, he didn't say a word, only when we tried to subdue him and when the guards put the straitjacket on him did he scream: "I am ruining their plans! They can't steal from me, they can't kill me anymore! I must fight for God and for my master!” He kept spewing out crazy words that no one could understand. It was very difficult for us to get him back to the hospital and lock him in a room. As for the two truck drivers, at first, they kept threatening to take this assault to court; but later, I noticed mixed in with those threats were words of regret and remorse for letting a madman beat them up like that.
tr: In line with your requests, I am sending the report regarding the items left under my responsibility as an attachment. There are more things to be said about the patient, Renfield. He had another fit that could have had a terrible ending, but fortunately, it did not. This afternoon, a transport cart with two men on it arrived at the empty house adjacent to our property - you remember, the house the patient escaped to twice. Since the men were strangers to the area, they stopped at our door to ask the porter for directions. I was looking out the window of my study while smoking my cigarette after dinner and saw one of the men approaching the house. As he passed in front of Renfield's room window, the patient began to scold him from inside and shouted all kinds of obscenities at him. The man, who seemed quite gentlemanly, simply replied, "Shut up, you foul-mouthed beggar," upon which our man accused him of robbing and killing him and said he would stop him even if he were to be hanged for it. I opened the window and signaled to the man not to mind, so he, after taking a look around and deciding what kind of place he had come to, simply said, "God bless you, sir, I don't care what is said to me in a damn madhouse. I pity you and the director for having to live in this house with such a wild animal," and then politely asked for directions; I told him where the door of the empty house was; he walked away with our man's threats, curses, and swearing trailing behind him. Wondering if I could understand why he got so angry, I went downstairs, because he is usually very well-mannered and nothing like this had ever happened outside of his wild fits. To my great surprise, I found him quite calm and moderate in his demeanor. I tried to get him to talk about the incident, but he kept sweetly asking what I meant and made me think he was completely unaware of the matter. Regrettably, I must report that this was just another display of his devilishness, because half an hour later, I received another report about him. This time, he had climbed out of his room window and was running down the tree-lined path. I told the attendants to follow me and ran after the patient because I was afraid he might harm someone. My fear was justified when I saw the cart that had passed by earlier moving down the road with several large wooden crates on it. The men were wiping their foreheads as if they had been exercising vigorously, and their faces were flushed. Before I could reach him, the patient lunged at the men, pulled one of them off the cart, and started banging his head on the ground. If I hadn't caught him in time, I think he would have killed the man right there. The other man jumped down and hit the patient on the head with the blunt end of his whip. It was a terrible blow, but he didn't seem to care and fought with all three of us, pulling us back and forth as if we were kittens. You know, I am not light, and the other two were hefty men as well. At first, he was silent while fighting; but when we started to subdue him and the attendants put a straitjacket on him, he began to shout: "I will stop them! They will not rob me! They will not slowly kill me! I will fight for my master!" He said this and other such nonsensical things. With considerable difficulty, they took him back to the house and put him in the padded room. One of the attendants, Hardy, had a broken finger. But I have sorted everything out, and he is now in good condition.
es: "In compliance with your wishes, I am sending attached a report on the conditions of everything that has been left in my charge... Regarding the patient, there is something more to say. He had another escape attempt, which could have had a terrible end, but fortunately, as it happened, did not reach the tragic outcome that was expected. This afternoon, a carriage with two men arrived at the empty house whose grounds border ours, the house to which, you will recall, the patient escaped on two occasions. The men stopped at the gate to ask the porter for directions, as they were strangers. I myself was looking out the study window, smoking after dinner, and saw one of the men approach the house. As he passed by Renfield's room window, the patient began to taunt him from inside and call him every rotten name he could put on his tongue. The man, who seemed a decent type, merely told him to "shut his rotten beggar's mouth," to which our inmate accused him of stealing from him and wanting to kill him, adding that he would thwart his plans even if they hanged him for it. I opened the window and signaled to the man not to take things seriously, so he contented himself with taking a look around the place, perhaps to get an idea of the kind of site he had ended up at. And then he said: 'God bless you, sir; I don't get upset by what they say to me in a madhouse like this. You and the director rather have my pity for having to live in a house with a wild beast like that. Then he asked for directions quite courteously, and I showed him where the gate of the empty house was; he walked away, followed by threats and insults from our man. I went down to see if I could discover the cause of his anger, as usually he is a proper man, and except for violent periods nothing like this ever happens to him. To my astonishment, I found him quite calm and behaving in the most cordial manner. I tried to get him to talk about the incident, but he gently asked me what I was talking about, leading me to believe he had completely forgotten the matter. It was, however, I regret to say, just another instance of his cunning, for half an hour later I had news of him again. This time he had escaped again from his room window and was running down the avenue. I called the attendants to follow me and ran after him, fearing he was attempting some trick. My fear was justified when I saw the same carriage that had passed by us earlier coming down the road, loaded with some wooden boxes. The men were wiping their foreheads and had flushed faces, as if they had just done some violent exercise. Before I could reach him, the patient ran towards them and, pulling one of them off the carriage, began to bash his head against the ground. If I hadn't restrained him at that moment, I believe he would have beaten the man to death right there. The other fellow jumped off the carriage and struck him with the handle of his heavy whip. It was a terrible blow, but he didn't seem to feel it; instead, he grabbed the man too and fought us three, tossing us around like kittens. You know very well that I am not light, and the other two men were burly. At first, he fought silently, but as we began to overpower him, and when the attendants were putting the straitjacket on him, he started to shout: 'I will stop it. You won't rob me! You won't murder me by inches! I will fight for my master and lord!’, and all that kind of incoherent nonsense. With considerable difficulty, they managed to bring him back to the house and we locked him in the secure room. One of the attendants, Hardy, has a bruised finger. However, he splinted it well, and it is improving.

en: “The two carriers were at first loud in their threats of actions for damages, and promised to rain all the penalties of the law on us. Their threats were, however, mingled with some sort of indirect apology for the defeat of the two of them by a feeble madman. They said that if it had not been for the way their strength had been spent in carrying and raising the heavy boxes to the cart they would have made short work of him. They gave as another reason for their defeat the extraordinary state of drouth to which they had been reduced by the dusty nature of their occupation and the reprehensible distance from the scene of their labours of any place of public entertainment. I quite understood their drift, and after a stiff glass of grog, or rather more of the same, and with each a sovereign in hand, they made light of the attack, and swore that they would encounter a worse madman any day for the pleasure of meeting so ‘bloomin’ good a bloke’ as your correspondent. I took their names and addresses, in case they might be needed. They are as follows:—Jack Smollet, of Dudding’s Rents, King George’s Road, Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling, Peter Farley’s Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green. They are both in the employment of Harris & Sons, Moving and Shipment Company, Orange Master’s Yard, Soho.
vi: As for the two truck drivers, at first, they kept threatening to take this assault to court; but later, I noticed mixed in with those threats were words of regret and remorse for letting a madman beat them up like that. They both tried to explain that if they hadn't been humiliated into delivering the goods smoothly, they would have surely overpowered that madman! But they also gave another reason to justify their defeat: the burning thirst after loading the goods onto the truck had drained their strength, and there wasn't a single refreshment stand around here. I understood what they really wanted. So, after giving each of them two glasses of white wine mixed with lemon, sugar, and hot water, and slipping a gold coin into each of their hands, I didn't hear them mention anything about suing anymore. They even joked that one day they would be ready to fight another madman, even one much fiercer. I carefully noted down their names and addresses, because who knows, we might need them someday. All I wrote was this: Jack Smoliet, Dudding House, King George Street, Great Walworth; and Thomas Snelling, Peter Farley Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green. These two guys are working at the Orange Masters Yard shipping company of Harris.
tr: The two carriers initially shouted their threats regarding the legal measures to be taken for the damage caused, saying they would rain down all the punishments the law could give upon us. But their threats were intertwined with an indirect defense relating to both of them being defeated by a feeble madman. They said they could have dealt with the man quickly if their strength hadn't been spent carrying the heavy chests and lifting them onto the cart. As another reason for their defeat, they cited the unusual thirst they had fallen into due to the dusty nature of their profession and the deplorable distance of their work from any place of amusement. I understood their purpose very well; after one or more glasses of rum and a gold coin placed in each of their hands, they began to disregard the attack and swore they would encounter a worse madman to have the pleasure of meeting such a "damn good fellow" who writes these lines to you. I took their names and addresses in case it might be necessary in the future. The information is as follows: Jack Smollet from Dudding Houses, King George Road, Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling from Peter Parley Houses, Guide Square, Bethnal Green. Both work at Harris & Sons Transport and Haulage Company located at Orange Master's Yard, Soho.
es: At first, the two coachmen shouted loud threats of suing us for damages and promised that all the penalties of the law would rain down on us. However, their threats were mixed with a sort of indirect lamentation over the defeat they had suffered at the hands of a weak madman. They said that if it hadn't been for the way they had exhausted their strength lifting the heavy boxes onto the carriage, they would have finished him off quickly. They gave another reason for their defeat: the extraordinary state of dryness to which they had been reduced by the very nature of their occupation, and the reprehensible distance of any public entertainment establishment from the scene of their labors. I understood their insinuation well, and after a good glass of grog, or rather, several glasses of the same thing, and each of them having a sovereign in hand, they began to joke about the attack and swore they would find any day a madman worse than that just for the pleasure of meeting 'such a charming fool' as the one who writes this. I noted down their names and addresses, in case we need them. They are as follows: Jack Smollet, from Dudding's Rents, King George's Road. Great Walworth, and Thomas Snelling, Peter Farley's Row, Guide Court, Bethnal Green. Both are employees of Harris & Sons, Moving and Shipping Company, Orange Master's Yard, Soho.

en: “I shall report to you any matter of interest occurring here, and shall wire you at once if there is anything of importance.
vi: I will inform you thoroughly about all the important events happening here and will telegraph you as soon as there is any news.
tr: I will write to you about every topic that occurs here and might attract interest, and if something important happens, I will send a telegram as soon as possible.
es: "I will inform you of any matter of interest that occurs here, and I will call you immediately in case something important happens."

en: “18 September.
vi: "September 18"
tr: September 18
es: September 18

en: “My dearest Lucy,—
vi: Lucy, I miss you.
tr: Dearest Lucy
es: “My dearest Lucy:

en: “Such a sad blow has befallen us. Mr. Hawkins has died very suddenly. Some may not think it so sad for us, but we had both come to so love him that it really seems as though we had lost a father. I never knew either father or mother, so that the dear old man’s death is a real blow to me. Jonathan is greatly distressed. It is not only that he feels sorrow, deep sorrow, for the dear, good man who has befriended him all his life, and now at the end has treated him like his own son and left him a fortune which to people of our modest bringing up is wealth beyond the dream of avarice, but Jonathan feels it on another account. He says the amount of responsibility which it puts upon him makes him nervous. He begins to doubt himself. I try to cheer him up, and my belief in him helps him to have a belief in himself. But it is here that the grave shock that he experienced tells upon him the most. Oh, it is too hard that a sweet, simple, noble, strong nature such as his—a nature which enabled him by our dear, good friend’s aid to rise from clerk to master in a few years—should be so injured that the very essence of its strength is gone. Forgive me, dear, if I worry you with my troubles in the midst of your own happiness; but, Lucy dear, I must tell some one, for the strain of keeping up a brave and cheerful appearance to Jonathan tries me, and I have no one here that I can confide in. I dread coming up to London, as we must do the day after to-morrow; for poor Mr. Hawkins left in his will that he was to be buried in the grave with his father. As there are no relations at all, Jonathan will have to be chief mourner. I shall try to run over to see you, dearest, if only for a few minutes. Forgive me for troubling you. With all blessings,
vi: We are going through a great misfortune. Sir Hawkins just suddenly passed away, making us feel like we have lost a real father. I feel this very clearly because I have never known my biological parents. As for Jonathan, the departure of a generous man who always considered him as a biological son has left him with an unending sorrow. So now the responsibility for all the work begins to fall on him, making him feel increasingly stressed and even, at times, he has shown self-doubt. However, I have tried my best to encourage him, and the faith I have placed in him has made him more confident. After all, this is the result of a terrible shock of which he is the victim. I still remember that Jonathan used to be a courageous and determined man - it was this very quality that convinced Hawkins when he decided to entrust him with the role of an assistant. It's hard to imagine that now he is so devastated! My dear friend, if what I have just said worries you and affects your happiness, please forgive me! But I have to confide in someone at this moment, because the more courageous and steadfast I appear in front of Jonathan, the more silently enduring this anxiety alone makes me fall apart. I'm afraid that the day after tomorrow - the day we have to bring Hawkins back to London to be buried beside his ancestors according to his last wish, I will not be able to stand firm if I cannot confide in you. Jonathan will be the one leading the funeral because he no longer has parents either. But no matter what, I will try to visit you, dear Lucy. Once again, please don't blame me for this bad news! Wishing you a thousand times good luck?
tr: We experienced such a great disaster! Mr. Hawkins died suddenly. Some might think that this is not very sad for us, but we both loved him so much that it truly feels like we have lost our father. Since I never knew my mother or father, the death of this dear old man was a great shock to me. Jonathan is quite distressed. Not only does he feel great sorrow for this good man who had been his companion throughout his life and finally treated him like his own son, leaving him a fortune beyond our humble means, but Jonathan is also troubled by something else. He says that the amount of responsibility placed upon him with this situation makes him uneasy. He is starting to doubt himself. I try to cheer him up, and my faith in him helps him believe in himself. But this heavy shock he has experienced affects him the most in this matter. Oh, it is so hard that such a sweet, simple, noble, strong nature - a nature that, with the help of our dear, good friend, elevated him from a legal consultant to mastery within a few years - has been wounded in a way that destroys the essence of its strength. If I am troubling you with my worries in the midst of your own happiness, forgive me, dear; but dear Lucy, I must tell someone because trying to appear brave and cheerful in front of Jonathan is exhausting me, and there is no one here with whom I can share my secret. We have to go to London tomorrow, but I am hesitant about it; Mr. Hawkins stated in his will that he wanted to be buried in the same grave as his father. Since he has no other relatives, Jonathan has to take on the role of the funeral owner. Even if just for a minute or two, I will come to see you, dear. Forgive me for troubling you. With all my best wishes.
es: We have suffered a terrible blow. Mr. Hawkins died suddenly. Some may think this is not sad for us, but we had both come to care for him so much that it truly feels as if we have lost a father. I never knew either my father or my mother, so the death of this dear old man has been a real blow to me. Jonathan is also very downcast. He not only feels sad, very sad, for the dear old man who has helped him so much in his life, and who now at the end has treated him as if he were his own son and has left him a fortune that for people of our modest origin is a wealth beyond the dreams of avarice. Jonathan also feels something else: he says that the great responsibility that falls on him makes him nervous. He begins to doubt himself. I try to encourage him, and my faith in him helps him to have faith in himself. But it is precisely in this way that the great impression he has experienced affects him more. Oh! It is too hard that a nature as sweet, simple, noble, and strong as his (a nature that enabled him, with the help of our friend, to rise from a simple employee to the position he holds today) is so damaged that the very essence of his strength has disappeared. Forgive me, dear, if I trouble you with my problems in the midst of your own happiness; but, dear Lucy, I must talk to someone, for the effort I make to maintain a cheerful appearance before Jonathan tires me, and here I have no one to confide in. I fear going to London, as we must do the day after tomorrow, for the poor Mr. Hawkins left in his will that he wished to be buried in the tomb with his father. As there are no relatives, Jonathan will have to preside over the funeral. I will try to stop by to see you, dear, even if only for a few minutes. Forgive me again for causing you distress. With all blessings, lovingly,

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 20 September.—Only resolution and habit can let me make an entry to-night. I am too miserable, too low-spirited, too sick of the world and all in it, including life itself, that I would not care if I heard this moment the flapping of the wings of the angel of death. And he has been flapping those grim wings to some purpose of late—Lucy’s mother and Arthur’s father, and now.... Let me get on with my work.
vi: • September 20 Tonight, I volunteered to stay alone, and as usual, I took out my journal to write. I feel unhappy, tired, and weak - as if I am weary of life and everyone - to the point that if I hear the sound of bats flapping their wings right now, I would think that Death is inviting me. Indeed, in the past few days, we have seen... First it was Lucy's mother, then Arthur's father, and now... But let me tell you...
tr: September 20 - Only determination and habit can allow me to make a note here tonight. I am in such a pitiable state, so sad, so tired of the world and everything in it, including life itself, that if I were to hear the flutter of the angel of death's wings right now, I wouldn't care. And recently, those merciless wings have been flapping for a certain purpose - Lucy's mother, Arthur's father, and now... Let me get back to my work.
es: September 20. Only a great effort of will and habit allow me to make these notes tonight. I feel too miserable, too dejected, too weary of the world and everything in it, including life itself, in such a way that I wouldn't mind hearing at this very moment the fluttering of the wings of the angel of death. And those dark wings have been fluttering lately for some reason: Lucy's mother and Arthur's father, and now… Let's continue my work.

en: I duly relieved Van Helsing in his watch over Lucy. We wanted Arthur to go to rest also, but he refused at first. It was only when I told him that we should want him to help us during the day, and that we must not all break down for want of rest, lest Lucy should suffer, that he agreed to go. Van Helsing was very kind to him. “Come, my child,” he said; “come with me. You are sick and weak, and have had much sorrow and much mental pain, as well as that tax on your strength that we know of. You must not be alone; for to be alone is to be full of fears and alarms. Come to the drawing-room, where there is a big fire, and there are two sofas. You shall lie on one, and I on the other, and our sympathy will be comfort to each other, even though we do not speak, and even if we sleep.” Arthur went off with him, casting back a longing look on Lucy’s face, which lay in her pillow, almost whiter than the lawn. She lay quite still, and I looked round the room to see that all was as it should be. I could see that the Professor had carried out in this room, as in the other, his purpose of using the garlic; the whole of the window-sashes reeked with it, and round Lucy’s neck, over the silk handkerchief which Van Helsing made her keep on, was a rough chaplet of the same odorous flowers. Lucy was breathing somewhat stertorously, and her face was at its worst, for the open mouth showed the pale gums. Her teeth, in the dim, uncertain light, seemed longer and sharper than they had been in the morning. In particular, by some trick of the light, the canine teeth looked longer and sharper than the rest. I sat down by her, and presently she moved uneasily. At the same moment there came a sort of dull flapping or buffeting at the window. I went over to it softly, and peeped out by the corner of the blind. There was a full moonlight, and I could see that the noise was made by a great bat, which wheeled round—doubtless attracted by the light, although so dim—and every now and again struck the window with its wings. When I came back to my seat, I found that Lucy had moved slightly, and had torn away the garlic flowers from her throat. I replaced them as well as I could, and sat watching her.
vi: At the appointed time, I watched over Lucy so that Van Helsing could rest for a while. Both the professor and I tried to persuade Arthur to take a break, but he stubbornly refused. However, when I explained to him that the next day we might very much need his help and that we shouldn't let ourselves get more tired just because of lack of sleep, he complied. Van Helsing also encouraged him: — Come down and rest, young friend? The pain and sorrow might have already exhausted you, don't let it get worse. You shouldn't stay alone, because loneliness might make you suffer even more. Come down to the living room with me, there's already a fireplace and two couches down there. The two of us will each take a couch instead of a bed. I'll pull my couch closer to yours, we need to be near each other to comfort one another during this time, even if we both fall asleep and don't say anything, that's fine too. Arthur painfully stood watching Lucy for a long time, then quietly followed Van Helsing down the stairs. Lucy remained motionless on the bed. Glancing around the room, I noticed the professor continued to use garlic flowers: he had rubbed garlic flowers on all the windows of the rooms, filling the place with the pungent smell of this unpleasant plant. He also quickly wove the garlic flowers into Lucy's handkerchief and wrapped it around her neck. Lucy had never shown such signs of pain. Occasionally, she would gasp with irregular breaths. She still slept with the same symptoms as before: mouth agape, gums purplish and receding, her teeth appearing longer and even sharper than in the morning, especially the canines, which seemed much longer and sharper than the others. As I sat down at the edge of the bed, she weakly stirred as if experiencing pain. That was also when something suddenly struck the windowpane hard. I cautiously approached the window, lifted a corner of the curtain, and looked outside. In the pale moonlight, I saw a large bat tirelessly flying back and forth as if mad, perhaps attracted by the faint light emanating from the bedroom. Occasionally, I saw it flap its wings and brush against the window glass. When I turned back to the bed, Lucy had slightly changed her lying position and had somehow pushed the garlic wreath off her neck without me noticing. I tried to arrange it back as it was.
tr: I took over the duty of keeping watch over Lucy from Van Helsing just in time. We also wanted Arthur to go and rest, but he initially refused. However, when I told him that we would need his help during the day and that we shouldn't be exhausted from lack of rest if Lucy's condition worsened, he agreed to go. Van Helsing was very kind to him. "Come, my child," he said; "come with me. You are sick and weak, and in addition to the burden we know of, you have also experienced great sorrow and mental anguish. You should not be alone; for to be alone is to be filled with fear and dread. Come to the sitting room where there is a large fire burning and two couches. You lie on one, I on the other, and even if we do not talk or even sleep, our companionship will comfort each other." Arthur, looking longingly at Lucy's face, which was almost whiter than the linen on her pillow, left the room with the Professor. Lucy was lying quite still, and I looked around the room to see that everything was as it should be. I could see that the Professor maintained his determination to use garlic in this room as well as in the other; all the window frames smelled of garlic, and around Lucy's neck, over the silk handkerchief that Van Helsing wanted her to wear, there was a rough garland made of the same scented flowers. Lucy's breathing was a bit raspy, and her face was in a terrible state because her pale gums were exposed through her open mouth. In the dim and uncertain light, her teeth seemed longer and sharper than they had in the morning. Especially, by some trick of the light, her canine teeth appeared longer and sharper than the others. I sat down beside her, and she immediately moved restlessly. At that very moment, monotonous wing sounds were heard at the window. I slowly went to the window and looked outside from the corner of the curtain. There was a full moon, and I could see that the noise was being made by a large bat, which, though very dim, was undoubtedly attracted by the light and occasionally struck the window with its wings. When I returned to my seat, I noticed that Lucy had slightly moved and had torn off the garlic flowers from her throat. I placed them back as best as I could and sat down to watch her.
es: I promptly relieved Van Helsing in his watch over Lucy. We wanted Arthur to go rest as well, but at first, he refused. He only agreed when I told him that we would need him during the day to help us, and that we should not all exhaust ourselves at the same time because Lucy might suffer the consequences. Van Helsing was very kind to him. –Come, son -he said to him-; come with me. You are sick and weak and have had many sorrows and much pain, as well as a depletion of your strength that we know well. You should not be alone, for to be alone is to be full of fears and alarms. Come to the living room, where there is a good fire and two sofas. You will lie on one and I on the other, and our company will give us some relief, even if we do not speak, and even if we sleep. Arthur went with him, casting a nostalgic glance at Lucy's face, which lay on her pillow almost whiter than the sheet. She lay quite still, and I looked around the room to see that everything was in order. I could see that the professor had carried out in this room, as in the other, his intention to use garlic; all the window sashes smelled strongly of it. And around Lucy's neck, over the silk scarf that Van Helsing had made her wear, was a rough necklace made of the same fragrant flowers. Lucy was breathing somewhat stertorously and her face was contorted, for her open mouth revealed pale gums. In the dim and uncertain light, her teeth seemed longer and sharper than they had been in the morning. In particular, perhaps due to some play of light, the canines seemed longer and sharper than the rest. I sat by her side, and after a short time she moved restlessly. At that very moment, a kind of dull flapping or scratching came from the window. I went silently towards it and peered through a corner of the lattice. There was a full moon, and I could see that the noise was caused by a large bat fluttering about, undoubtedly attracted by the light, although it was so faint, and occasionally hitting the window with its wings. When I returned to my seat, I saw that Lucy had moved slightly and the garlic flowers had fallen from her neck. I placed them back in their spot as best as I could, and sat down, watching her.

en: Presently she woke, and I gave her food, as Van Helsing had prescribed. She took but a little, and that languidly. There did not seem to be with her now the unconscious struggle for life and strength that had hitherto so marked her illness. It struck me as curious that the moment she became conscious she pressed the garlic flowers close to her. It was certainly odd that whenever she got into that lethargic state, with the stertorous breathing, she put the flowers from her; but that when she waked she clutched them close. There was no possibility of making any mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many spells of sleeping and waking and repeated both actions many times.
vi: After lying for a while longer, she woke up. I tried to feed her a little as per Van Helsing's instructions, but she ate as if enduring a torture! Despite the fact that even her unconscious instinctive strength had now abandoned her, it seemed there was still something urging her to fight to the end against the illness and to conquer it at all costs. I was truly surprised to see that as soon as she woke up, she hurriedly clutched the garlic wreath. I found this very strange: every time she fell into a deep sleep, making her breathing very labored, she would push the wreath away. Conversely, every time she woke up or was about to wake up, I saw her clutch the wreath tightly to herself. There was one more thing I couldn't mistake: in the hours that followed, I saw her wake up and then fall back into a deep sleep many times, and this kept happening with the same actions from her.
tr: She woke up a little later and I gave her the meal prescribed by Van Helsing. She ate very little and was reluctant. There seemed to be no sign of the struggle for life and strength that had been indicative of her illness until now. It struck me as odd that as soon as she regained consciousness, she pressed the garlic flowers to her chest. It was certainly strange that whenever she fell into that state of sleep with labored breathing, she pushed the flowers away, but when she woke up, she clung to them tightly. There was no possibility of making a mistake in this matter, because she went through many periods of sleep and wakefulness over the long hours that followed, and she repeated these two actions many times.
es: Shortly after, she woke up, and I gave her food just as van Helsing had prescribed. She only took a little, and reluctantly. It seemed that her former unconscious struggle for life, and the strength that had marked her illness until then, were no longer with her. I was surprised by the curious fact that at the moment she became conscious, she pressed the garlic flowers against her chest. It was certainly very strange that whenever she entered that lethargic state, with stertorous breathing, she tried to remove the flowers, but upon waking, she held onto them. There was no possibility of making a mistake about this, for in the long hours that followed, she had many periods of sleep and wakefulness, and repeated both actions many times.

en: At six o’clock Van Helsing came to relieve me. Arthur had then fallen into a doze, and he mercifully let him sleep on. When he saw Lucy’s face I could hear the sissing indraw of his breath, and he said to me in a sharp whisper: “Draw up the blind; I want light!” Then he bent down, and, with his face almost touching Lucy’s, examined her carefully. He removed the flowers and lifted the silk handkerchief from her throat. As he did so he started back, and I could hear his ejaculation, “Mein Gott!” as it was smothered in his throat. I bent over and looked, too, and as I noticed some queer chill came over me.
vi: At six o'clock in the evening, Van Helsing came to take over my shift. Arthur had fallen asleep, so he didn't have the heart to wake him up. He looked at Lucy and couldn't help but sigh. After a while, he turned to me and said, in a very soft yet very clear voice: — Pull up the curtain for me! I want some light! He bent down to remove the garlic wreath from Lucy's neck to check on the patient's condition.
tr: At six o'clock, Van Helsing came to take over the watch from me. During this time, Arthur had fallen asleep, and the Professor, out of compassion, had allowed him to continue sleeping. When he saw Lucy's face, I could hear the hiss in his breathing, and he said harshly in a whisper: "Open the curtain; I want light!" Then he leaned in and examined her carefully, his face almost touching Lucy's. He removed the flowers and the silk handkerchief from her neck. As he did so, he flinched, and I heard him say, as if choking, "Mein Gott!" I also leaned in and felt a strange shiver when I saw what had startled Van Helsing.
es: At six in the morning, Van Helsing arrived to relieve me. Arthur had fallen into a stupor, and kindly he allowed him to continue sleeping. When he saw Lucy's face, I could hear the hissing intake of his breath, and he said to me in a sharp whisper: –Raise the lattice; I want light! Then he leaned over and, with his face almost touching Lucy's, examined her carefully. He removed the flowers and then took off the silk handkerchief from her throat. As he did so, he stepped back, and I could hear his exclamation: "Mein Gott!…" which got stuck in his throat. I leaned over and looked as well, and when I did, a strange chill ran through my body.

en: The wounds on the throat had absolutely disappeared.
vi: The choking sound in his throat startled me: "Oh God!" I silently bent down with him, and what met my eyes made me shudder and tremble: the wounds on her neck had completely disappeared.
tr: The wounds on Lucy's neck had completely disappeared.
es: The wounds on the throat had completely disappeared.

en: For fully five minutes Van Helsing stood looking at her, with his face at its sternest. Then he turned to me and said calmly:—
vi: Van Helsing was stunned for a moment, his face showing more resignation and seriousness than ever before. About five minutes later, he turned to me and said:
tr: For a full five minutes, Van Helsing stood there, looking at Lucy with the sternest expression on his face. Then he turned to me and said calmly:
es: For almost five minutes, Van Helsing was looking at her, with a face more serious and tense than ever. Then he turned to me and said calmly:

en: “She is dying. It will not be long now. It will be much difference, mark me, whether she dies conscious or in her sleep. Wake that poor boy, and let him come and see the last; he trusts us, and we have promised him.”
vi: — The girl is dying, everything will probably end soon. But listen to me, whether she dies in her sleep or not, it makes no difference. Go wake Arthur up so he can see his beloved one last time. He is waiting for us to wake him because I promised him that.
tr: “He is dying. It won't take long now. Be careful; whether he dies while conscious or in his sleep will change many things. Wake that poor child up, let him come and see him one last time; he trusts us and we promised him.”
es: –He is dying. He won't have much time left. There will be a big difference, believe me, if he dies conscious or if he dies while sleeping. Wake up the poor boy and let him come and see the end; he trusts us, and we had promised him.

en: I went to the dining-room and waked him. He was dazed for a moment, but when he saw the sunlight streaming in through the edges of the shutters he thought he was late, and expressed his fear. I assured him that Lucy was still asleep, but told him as gently as I could that both Van Helsing and I feared that the end was near. He covered his face with his hands, and slid down on his knees by the sofa, where he remained, perhaps a minute, with his head buried, praying, whilst his shoulders shook with grief. I took him by the hand and raised him up. “Come,” I said, “my dear old fellow, summon all your fortitude: it will be best and easiest for her.”
vi: I was shocked and ran down to call Arthur. It took him a while to regain his composure after a deep sleep. At first, I had to lie to him that Lucy was still sleeping, but gradually I had to confess that both Professor Van Helsing and I were very afraid of a tragic end approaching. Arthur felt as if the sky was about to collapse; he knelt down on the chair, his hands covering his face, his shoulders shaking violently with sobs. He remained kneeling like that, praying for many minutes. I had to take his hand and pull him up. — Come on, my friend, - I said - be brave, you must be brave for her.
tr: I went to the dining room and woke Arthur up. For a moment he was dazed, but when he saw the daylight streaming through the edges of the shutters, he thought he was late and expressed his fear. I convinced him that Lucy was still asleep, but as gently as I could, I told him that both Van Helsing and I feared the end was near. He covered his face with his hands and fell to his knees at the foot of the couch; there he remained for perhaps a minute, praying with his head bowed and his shoulders shaking with sorrow. I took his hand and lifted him up. "Come," I said, "my dear old friend, gather all your courage; this will be the best and easiest for her."
es: I went down to the dining room and woke him up. He was dazed for a moment, but when he saw the sunlight coming through the slats of the blinds, he thought it was already late, and expressed his fear to me. I assured him that Lucy was still asleep, but I told him as gently as I could that both van Helsing and I feared the end was near. He covered his face with his hands and slid to his knees beside the sofa, where he remained, perhaps a minute, with his head bowed, praying, while his shoulders shook with sorrow. I took him by the hand and lifted him up. –Come -I said, my dear old friend; gather all your strength: it will be the best and the easiest for her.

en: When we came into Lucy’s room I could see that Van Helsing had, with his usual forethought, been putting matters straight and making everything look as pleasing as possible. He had even brushed Lucy’s hair, so that it lay on the pillow in its usual sunny ripples. When we came into the room she opened her eyes, and seeing him, whispered softly:—
vi: Returning to Lucy's room, I saw Van Helsing still trying to appear normal, if not even more cheerful than usual. He even took a comb to brush the silky hair that lay scattered on the girl's pillow. As we just stepped in, she opened her eyes. Seeing her fiancé, she softly whispered:
tr: When we came to Lucy's room, I could see that Van Helsing, with his usual prudence, had fixed everything and made it as pleasant as possible. He had even brushed Lucy's hair, so that it lay on her pillow in its usual sunny waves. When we entered the room, she opened her eyes and, upon seeing him, slowly whispered:
es: When we arrived at Lucy's room, I could see that Van Helsing, with his usual foresight, had been putting everything in its place and making everything as pleasant as possible. He had even brushed Lucy's hair, so that it spread out over the pillow in its usual golden curls. When we entered the room, she opened her eyes, and upon seeing him, she weakly whispered:

en: “Arthur! Oh, my love, I am so glad you have come!” He was stooping to kiss her, when Van Helsing motioned him back. “No,” he whispered, “not yet! Hold her hand; it will comfort her more.”
vi: — Arthur! My love! It is so wonderful to see you here! Arthur bent down, intending to embrace the girl, but Van Helsing managed to stop him in time: — Don't, don't do that, it's not the right time yet. Just hold her hand, that might comfort her even more!
tr: “Arthur! Ah, my love. I am so happy you came!” He was just about to lean in to kiss Lucy when Van Helsing pulled him back. “No,” he whispered, “not yet! Hold her hand; this will comfort her more.”
es: –Arthur! Oh, my love, I am so happy that you have come! He stopped to kiss her, but Van Helsing ordered him to step back. –No -he whispered-, not yet! Hold her hand; it will give her more comfort.

en: So Arthur took her hand and knelt beside her, and she looked her best, with all the soft lines matching the angelic beauty of her eyes. Then gradually her eyes closed, and she sank to sleep. For a little bit her breast heaved softly, and her breath came and went like a tired child’s.
vi: Arthur reluctantly held his fiancée's hand and knelt beside her bed. No matter what, she still looked very beautiful; the gentle features on her delicate face harmonized perfectly with the angelic beauty of her eyes. Her eyelashes slowly closed, leading her into a new sleep. At times, I saw her chest rise and then slowly fall again; watching her breathe, I felt like I was looking at a sick child.
tr: Thus, Arthur held her hand and knelt beside her; Lucy looked more beautiful than ever with the soft lines that matched the angelic beauty of her eyes. Then her eyes slowly closed and she fell asleep. For a short while, her chest rose and fell gently, her breathing like that of a tired child.
es: So Arthur took her hand and knelt beside her, and she glowed, with all the soft lines matching the angelic beauty of her eyes. Then, gradually, her eyes closed and she sank into sleep. For a short time her chest rose gently; and it rose and fell like that of a tired child.

en: And then insensibly there came the strange change which I had noticed in the night. Her breathing grew stertorous, the mouth opened, and the pale gums, drawn back, made the teeth look longer and sharper than ever. In a sort of sleep-waking, vague, unconscious way she opened her eyes, which were now dull and hard at once, and said in a soft, voluptuous voice, such as I had never heard from her lips:—
vi: The abnormal change that I had noticed in her during the previous hours began to reappear: labored breathing with interrupted breaths, mouth agape revealing two rows of pale gums along with long and sharp teeth. She opened her eyes in a near-unconscious state, within those eyes was an endless sorrow mixed with hopeless pain, only her voice remained the same, gentle and filled with love:
tr: And then, in a vague manner, the strange change I noticed at night occurred. His breathing began to take on a wheezing quality, his mouth opened, and his receded pale gums made his teeth appear longer and sharper than ever. As if waking from sleep, vaguely, unconsciously, he opened his eyes that suddenly became dull and rigid, and in a soft, sensual voice I had never heard from his lips before, he said:
es: Then, imperceptibly, came the strange change that I had noticed during the night. His breathing became stertorous, he opened his mouth, and the pale gums stretched back made the teeth appear longer and sharper than ever. He opened his eyes in a vague, somnambulistic manner, as if unconscious, now reflecting both vagueness and hardness, and spoke in a soft and voluptuous voice, such as I had never heard from his lips before:

en: “Arthur! Oh, my love, I am so glad you have come! Kiss me!” Arthur bent eagerly over to kiss her; but at that instant Van Helsing, who, like me, had been startled by her voice, swooped upon him, and catching him by the neck with both hands, dragged him back with a fury of strength which I never thought he could have possessed, and actually hurled him almost across the room.
vi: — Arthur! - She repeated the previous words - Oh! My love! I am so happy to see you by my side again? Kiss me? Just waiting for that, Arthur immediately rushed forward to embrace his fiancée, but once again, Van Helsing and I had to stop him. Van Helsing grabbed Arthur's shoulders firmly and pushed him back almost to the end of the room; indeed, I had never thought he was that strong.
tr: “Arthur! Ah, my darling. I am so happy that you came! Kiss me!” Arthur eagerly leaned in to kiss her, but at that very moment, Van Helsing, who was startled by Lucy’s voice just like I was, pounced on Arthur and grabbed him by the neck with a strength I never thought he possessed, pulling him back - or rather, almost throwing him to the other side of the room.
es: –Arthur! Oh, my love, I am so happy you came! Kiss me! Arthur leaned forward anxiously to kiss her, but at that very moment van Helsing, who, like me, had been astonished by the young woman's voice, rushed at the groom and, grabbing him by the neck with both hands, dragged him back with a strength I never thought he could possess, and indeed threw him almost to the other side of the room.

en: “Not for your life!” he said; “not for your living soul and hers!” And he stood between them like a lion at bay.
vi: — Poor fellow, don't do that! -
tr: "Not in a million years!" he said, "not for your living soul or his!" And he stood between them like a tiger.
es: –Never in your life! – he told him –; don't do it, for the love of your soul and hers! And then, he positioned himself between the two like a cornered lion.

en: Arthur was so taken aback that he did not for a moment know what to do or say; and before any impulse of violence could seize him he realised the place and the occasion, and stood silent, waiting.
vi: He softly exclaimed - Never do that, you must care for her and care for yourself! Arthur could only stand frozen in place, his face showing a dazed and pained expression as if he were awaiting the worst to come.
tr: Arthur was so stunned that for a moment he didn't know what to do or say; before any impulse of violence could take hold of him, he perceived the place and situation, and remained silent, waiting.
es: Arthur was so surprised that for a moment he didn't know what to do or say; and before any impulse of violence could take hold of him, he realized the place and the circumstances and remained silent, waiting.

en: I kept my eyes fixed on Lucy, as did Van Helsing, and we saw a spasm as of rage flit like a shadow over her face; the sharp teeth champed together. Then her eyes closed, and she breathed heavily.
vi: Van Helsing and I did not dare take our eyes off Lucy for even a minute. We noticed that her face seemed to start showing the initial signs of convulsions. Then, her sharp teeth suddenly gaped open and then snapped shut with a dry and horrifying sound. I had the feeling that she had just bitten something. Then her eyes slowly closed, and as before, her breathing began to grow more labored.
tr: My eyes, just like Van Helsing's, were fixed on Lucy; like a shadow, we saw an angry spasm pass over her face; her sharp teeth clashed together. Then, her eyes closed and she took a deep breath.
es: I kept my eyes fixed on Lucy, just like Van Helsing, and we saw a spasm of anger quickly pass like a shadow across her face; her sharp teeth snapped shut. Then her eyes closed and she breathed heavily.

en: Very shortly after she opened her eyes in all their softness, and putting out her poor, pale, thin hand, took Van Helsing’s great brown one; drawing it to her, she kissed it. “My true friend,” she said, in a faint voice, but with untellable pathos, “My true friend, and his! Oh, guard him, and give me peace!”
vi: But just a few minutes later, she opened her eyes again, still with a gentle look on her sorrowful face. She laboriously raised her pale but thin hand to grasp Van Helsing's hand and gently kissed it. — My dear old friend. - She sobbed, speaking in a weak and trembling voice as if she could no longer contain the indescribable emotions within her. - My kind old friend, who is also his kind old friend! Oh! Please take care of him for me, and just leave me be!
tr: Shortly after, with all her tenderness, she opened her eyes and reached out her own poor, pale, thin hand to take Van Helsing's large, brown hand; pulling it towards her and kissed it. “My true friend,” she said, with a voice so weak and a tenderness beyond words, “the true friend of me and Arthur! Oh, protect him and bring me peace!”
es: Soon after, her eyes opened with all their softness, and extending her poor, pale, and thin hand, she took van Helsing's heavy and dark hand; bringing it closer, she kissed it. –My true friend -she said, in a weak voice but with an indescribable painful accent-. My true friend, and his friend! Oh, protect him, and give me peace!

en: “I swear it!” he said solemnly, kneeling beside her and holding up his hand, as one who registers an oath. Then he turned to Arthur, and said to him: “Come, my child, take her hand in yours, and kiss her on the forehead, and only once.”
vi: — Please rest assured, I promise you that. - The professor said as he knelt down beside the sickbed. Then he turned to Arthur and said: — Come here, my friend, take her hand and kiss her forehead, but remember, only once!
tr: Van Helsing said solemnly, "I promise!" while raising his hand like someone taking an oath, kneeling beside Lucy. Then he turned to Arthur and said to him, "Come, my son, take her hand in yours and kiss her on the forehead, just once."
es: –I swear! – he said solemnly, kneeling beside her and holding her hand, like someone taking an oath. Then he turned to Arthur and said: Come, son, take her hand in yours, and kiss her on the forehead, and only once.

en: Their eyes met instead of their lips; and so they parted.
vi: The engaged couple quietly exchanged glances instead of a kiss.
tr: Their eyes met instead of their lips, and thus they parted.
es: Their eyes met instead of their lips; and thus they parted.

en: Lucy’s eyes closed; and Van Helsing, who had been watching closely, took Arthur’s arm, and drew him away.
vi: Arthur did just that and then stepped back. The girl's eyes slowly closed once more. Van Helsing held Arthur's hand, while his eyes remained fixed on the girl.
tr: Lucy’s eyes closed; Van Helsing, who was watching them closely, took Arthur’s arm and moved him away.
es: Lucy’s eyes closed; and Van Helsing, who had been watching closely, took Arthur by the arm and led him away from the bed.

en: And then Lucy’s breathing became stertorous again, and all at once it ceased.
vi: We suddenly heard groans escaping from the heaving chest of the girl, and then nothing more, not even a faint breath!
tr: And then, Lucy's breathing became raspy again and suddenly stopped.
es: Then Lucy's breathing became labored once more, and suddenly it stopped altogether.

en: “It is all over,” said Van Helsing. “She is dead!”
vi: — It's over, - he muttered - everything is finished.
tr: “Everything is over,” said Van Helsing. “She is dead!”
es: "It's all over," said Van Helsing. "She is dead!"

en: I took Arthur by the arm, and led him away to the drawing-room, where he sat down, and covered his face with his hands, sobbing in a way that nearly broke me down to see.
vi: I heavily guided Arthur down to the living room, and as soon as we reached the armchair, he collapsed into it, covering his face with his hands and sobbing uncontrollably. Watching him shake with heart-wrenching sobs, I couldn't help but feel deeply moved.
tr: I grabbed Arthur by the arm and took him to the living room, where he sat down and, upon seeing it, almost broke my heart as he covered his face with his hands, sobbing uncontrollably.
es: I took Arthur by the arm and led him to the living room, where he sat down and covered his face with his hands, sobbing like a child.

en: I went back to the room, and found Van Helsing looking at poor Lucy, and his face was sterner than ever. Some change had come over her body. Death had given back part of her beauty, for her brow and cheeks had recovered some of their flowing lines; even the lips had lost their deadly pallor. It was as if the blood, no longer needed for the working of the heart, had gone to make the harshness of death as little rude as might be.
vi: However, I still had to go meet Van Helsing. He was standing motionless, staring at the unfortunate girl, his face more sorrowful than ever. Yes, looking at Lucy, I felt as if death had cruelly returned her original beauty: her forehead, and even her cheeks, were now free of wrinkles, and even her lips had lost the pale color of a corpse. It seemed that when her heart stopped beating, the blood in her body had gathered to tint her lips a rosy hue, removing the dreadful pallor of a corpse.
tr: I returned to the room; I found Van Helsing looking at poor Lucy, the Professor's face was more stern than ever. There had been some changes in Lucy's body. Death had given back some of her beauty, as her forehead and cheeks had regained some of their flowing lines; even her lips had lost their deathly pallor. It was as if the blood, no longer needed to keep her heart working, had gone there to make the cruelty of death as little harsh as possible.
es: I returned to the room and found Van Helsing looking at poor Lucy, and his face was more serious than ever. Her body had changed somewhat. Death had returned some of her beauty to her, as her eyebrows and cheeks had regained some of their soft lines; even her lips had lost their mortal pallor. It was as if the blood, no longer necessary for the functioning of the heart, had wanted to mitigate as much as possible the rigidity and desolation of death.

en: “We thought her dying whilst she slept,
vi: "So when the girl was sleeping, we thought she was dead; and now, when she is dead, we think she is sleeping."
tr: We thought he was dying while sleeping,
es: "We think he was dying while he was sleeping, and sleeping when he died.""

en: And sleeping when she died.”
vi: I thought to myself, feeling a deep, bitter sorrow.
tr: And when he dies, he sleeps. 33
es: "We think he was dying while he was sleeping, and sleeping when he died.""

en: I stood beside Van Helsing, and said:—
vi: I approached Van Helsing and whispered softly as if afraid of waking the little girl:
tr: I stood next to Van Helsing and said, "Ah, poor girl, finally at peace."
es: I stood next to Van Helsing, and I said to him:

en: “Ah, well, poor girl, there is peace for her at last. It is the end!”
vi: — Finally, the little girl found peace! All her suffering has come to an end.
tr: I stood next to Van Helsing and said, "Ah, poor girl, finally at peace." "The end has come!"
es: –Ah! Poor girl! At last, there is peace for her. It is the end!

en: He turned to me, and said with grave solemnity:—
vi: — Oh God, no? -
tr: He turned to me and replied with grave seriousness, "No; alas, it is not so.
es: He turned to me and said with grave solemnity:

en: “Not so; alas! not so. It is only the beginning!”
vi: He turned to me and whispered. - Oh God, it's not like that! Those pains have only just begun.
tr: He turned to me and replied with grave seriousness, "No; alas, it is not so. This is only the beginning!"
es: –None of that. Oh, none of that. It's just the beginning!

en: When I asked him what he meant, he only shook his head and answered:—
vi: I asked the professor what he said, I didn't understand; he shook his head and replied:
tr: When I asked what he meant, he just shook his head and said:
es: When I asked him what he meant, he shook his head and replied:

en: “We can do nothing as yet. Wait and see.”
vi: — It's still too early to act now. Let's just wait and see what happens!
tr: “We can't do anything for now. Wait and see.”
es: –We can't do anything for her yet. Wait. You'll see…

en: CHAPTER XIII
vi: CHAPTER 13
tr: Thirteen
es: XIII.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY—continued.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD (continued)

en: THE funeral was arranged for the next succeeding day, so that Lucy and her mother might be buried together. I attended to all the ghastly formalities, and the urbane undertaker proved that his staff were afflicted—or blessed—with something of his own obsequious suavity. Even the woman who performed the last offices for the dead remarked to me, in a confidential, brother-professional way, when she had come out from the death-chamber:—
vi: We decided to hold a funeral for both Lucy and her mother in two days. I was busy handling all the paperwork. The funeral home staff seemed very obedient to their boss, even the talkative old lady who specialized in washing the deceased was very enthusiastic about the funeral. When she stepped out of Lucy's room, she even confided in me with a very professional tone:
tr: The funeral was arranged for the day after tomorrow so that Lucy and her mother could be buried together. I dealt with all the horrible official paperwork, and the polite funeral director proved that his entire staff was either cursed or blessed with his own excessive courtesy. Even the woman who performed the final duties for the dead said to me in a secret and friendly professionalism as she left the mortuary:
es: The funeral was arranged for the following day, so that Lucy and her mother could be buried together. I took care of all the unpleasant formalities, and the courteous funeral director proved to me that his employees were affected, or blessed, by some of his own gratuitous gentleness.
