Even the woman who performed the last rites for the dead commented to me, in a confidential manner, as if between colleagues, when she had left the death chamber:

en: “She makes a very beautiful corpse, sir. It’s quite a privilege to attend on her. It’s not too much to say that she will do credit to our establishment!”
vi: — You see, the girl died very beautifully, taking care of her at this moment is indeed a priority for us. It wouldn't be an exaggeration to say that she will bring honor to our company!
tr: “It has become a very beautiful corpse, sir. It is a great privilege to take care of it. It would not be an exaggeration to say that it will elevate our institution!”
es: –Sir, the young lady is a magnificent corpse. It is truly a privilege to attend to her. I do not exaggerate when I say that attending to such clients accredits our establishment!

en: I noticed that Van Helsing never kept far away. This was possible from the disordered state of things in the household. There were no relatives at hand; and as Arthur had to be back the next day to attend at his father’s funeral, we were unable to notify any one who should have been bidden. Under the circumstances, Van Helsing and I took it upon ourselves to examine papers, etc. He insisted upon looking over Lucy’s papers himself. I asked him why, for I feared that he, being a foreigner, might not be quite aware of English legal requirements, and so might in ignorance make some unnecessary trouble. He answered me:—
vi: During the entire time I was busy with work, Van Helsing did not step outside the door. None of us knew the relatives of the deceased. Moreover, tomorrow Arthur has to go home to arrange the funeral for his unfortunate father, so Van Helsing and I have to take care of all the funeral arrangements and review all the documents in the house. The professor is particularly interested in Lucy's documents. I don't understand why he is doing this, because as a foreigner, he probably doesn't fully understand the details of British Royal law, and his unfamiliarity might even cause us difficulties with the local authorities. — You forgot that -
tr: I noticed that Van Helsing never left the place. The disorder of the household made this possible. There were no relatives nearby; since Arthur had to return the next day to attend his father's funeral, we couldn't manage to inform anyone who needed to be called. Under these circumstances, Van Helsing and I took it upon ourselves to examine the documents and handle similar tasks. Van Helsing insisted on examining Lucy's documents himself. As a foreigner, I asked why, fearing that he might not be well-versed in English legal requirements and might inadvertently create some unnecessary problems. He replied: "I know; I know.
es: –I noticed that van Helsing never strayed far. This was possible due to the disordered state of the house. There were no relatives at hand, and since Arthur had to be back the next day to attend his father's funeral, we were unable to notify anyone who might have taken charge of the affairs. Under these circumstances, van Helsing and I began the examination of the papers, etc. My mentor insisted on personally taking charge of Lucy's papers. I asked him why, as I feared that he, being a foreigner, might not be aware of the English legal requirements, and could thus, out of ignorance, cause some unnecessary complications. He answered me:

en: “I know; I know. You forget that I am a lawyer as well as a doctor. But this is not altogether for the law. You knew that, when you avoided the coroner. I have more than him to avoid. There may be papers more—such as this.”
vi: He responded to my doubt - I am as good a doctor of law as I am a medical doctor. A few days ago, you were absolutely right when you said we need to avoid unnecessary troublesome investigations! Furthermore, the issue does not stop at the law but extends to other aspects as well. Who knows, we might even find documents, such as...
tr: He replied: "I know; I know. You forget that I am a lawyer as well as a doctor. But this is not just for the law. You knew this when you avoided the medical examiner. I have more things to avoid than that. There might be other documents - like this one."
es: –I know; I know. You forget that I am also a lawyer, besides being a doctor. But this is not for the law anyway. You clearly foresaw that when you avoided the coroner. I have to avoid others besides him. There may be other papers…

en: As he spoke he took from his pocket-book the memorandum which had been in Lucy’s breast, and which she had torn in her sleep.
vi: As he spoke, he pulled out a few sheets of paper from his notebook that Lucy always kept with her, the very sheets she had torn to pieces in her deep sleep.
tr: As he spoke, he took out the paper found on Lucy's chest, which she had torn in her sleep, from his pocket notebook.
es: While speaking, he took from his pocket notebook the memo that had been on Lucy's chest, and which she had torn while sleeping.

en: “When you find anything of the solicitor who is for the late Mrs. Westenra, seal all her papers, and write him to-night. For me, I watch here in the room and in Miss Lucy’s old room all night, and I myself search for what may be. It is not well that her very thoughts go into the hands of strangers.”
vi: — If you find Mrs. Westenra's notary, fill out everything and send him all the related documents. As for me, I will spend the night here or in Lucy's old room. I intend to look into a few more issues.
tr: "When you find something about who the legal advisor working for the late Ms. Westenra is, seal all her documents and write him a letter tonight. As for me, I will keep watch in this room and Miss Lucy's room all night and see what I can find. It's not good for all her thoughts to fall into the hands of strangers."
es: –When you discover something from the lawyer of the late Mrs. Westenra, seal all her papers and write to him tonight. As for me, I will keep watch here in the room and in the old room of Miss Lucy all night, and I will search for whatever it may be myself. It is not good for her most intimate thoughts to fall into the hands of strangers.

en: I went on with my part of the work, and in another half hour had found the name and address of Mrs. Westenra’s solicitor and had written to him. All the poor lady’s papers were in order; explicit directions regarding the place of burial were given. I had hardly sealed the letter, when, to my surprise, Van Helsing walked into the room, saying:—
vi: So, once again, I had to hurriedly run off to complete the task assigned by the professor. Half an hour later, I finally found the identity and address of the Westenra family's notary. All the documents of the poor woman had been fully prepared, especially her wishes regarding the organization of her funeral ceremony, which had been meticulously detailed. As I was arranging the documents, Professor Van Helsing entered the room. His question surprised me:
tr: I continued to deal with the part of the work that fell to me, and after another half hour, I found the name and address of Ms. Westenra's legal advisor and wrote to him. All the documents of the poor lady were organized; clear and precise instructions regarding the place of burial were given. I had just sealed the letter when Van Helsing surprised me by entering the room and said:
es: I dedicated myself to my part of the work, and within half an hour I had found the name and address of Mrs. Westenra's lawyer, and I had written to him. All the papers of the poor lady were in order; they contained explicit instructions regarding the burial place. I had not finished sealing the letter when, to my surprise, Van Helsing entered the room, saying:

en: “Can I help you, friend John? I am free, and if I may, my service is to you.”
vi: — Can I help you, my friend John? I don't know what else to do. If there's anything, just let me know and I'll lend a hand.
tr: "Can I help you, my friend John? I have no work and if you allow me, I am at your service."
es: –Can I help you, friend John? I am free, and if you allow me, I will collaborate with you.

en: “Have you got what you looked for?” I asked, to which he replied:—
vi: — But professor, have you found anything new yet?
tr: "Did you find what you were looking for?" he asked, and then responded:
es: "Did you find what you were looking for?" I asked him, to which he replied:

en: “I did not look for any specific thing. I only hoped to find, and find I have, all that there was—only some letters and a few memoranda, and a diary new begun. But I have them here, and we shall for the present say nothing of them. I shall see that poor lad to-morrow evening, and, with his sanction, I shall use some.”
vi: — Couldn't find anything important. I hoped to discover something new, but in the end, it was just a few letters and a diary entry. I've got them all here, but for now, let's leave them as they are. Tomorrow evening, I'll meet that poor fellow and if permitted, we'll use those documents.
tr: “I wasn't looking for anything specific. I was merely hoping to find what was there - and I did; just a few letters and some notepaper and a newly started diary. But they are here and for now, we shouldn't say anything about them. Tomorrow I will see the poor young man and with his approval, I will use some of these.”
es: –I wasn't looking for anything specific. I just hoped to find, and I found some letters and a few notes, and a recently started diary. But I have them here, and for now, we won't say anything about them. I will see the poor boy tomorrow night, and, with his consent, I will use these documents.

en: When we had finished the work in hand, he said to me:—
vi: My friend John, - the Professor continued after a brief pause - perhaps now we can go to sleep.
tr: When we finished the work at hand, he continued speaking: "And now my friend John, I think we can go to bed.
es: When we finished the work we had at hand, he told me:

en: “And now, friend John, I think we may to bed. We want sleep, both you and I, and rest to recuperate. To-morrow we shall have much to do, but for the to-night there is no need of us. Alas!”
vi: My friend John, - the Professor continued after a brief pause - perhaps now we can go to sleep. You and I need to get some rest. Tomorrow will be a busy day, and for tonight, this is enough!
tr: When we finished the work at hand, he continued speaking: "And now my friend John, I think we can go to bed. Both you and I need sleep and rest to recover. We have a lot of work to do tomorrow, and we don't need this for tonight. What a pity!"
es: –And now, friend John, I think we can go to bed. We want to sleep, both you and I, and rest to recover. Tomorrow we will both have a lot to do, but for tonight there is no need for us.

en: Before turning in we went to look at poor Lucy. The undertaker had certainly done his work well, for the room was turned into a small chapelle ardente. There was a wilderness of beautiful white flowers, and death was made as little repulsive as might be. The end of the winding-sheet was laid over the face; when the Professor bent over and turned it gently back, we both started at the beauty before us, the tall wax candles showing a sufficient light to note it well. All Lucy’s loveliness had come back to her in death, and the hours that had passed, instead of leaving traces of “decay’s effacing fingers,” had but restored the beauty of life, till positively I could not believe my eyes that I was looking at a corpse.
vi: However, before going to bed, we did not forget to take a look at the room where little Lucy was resting. The room had been transformed by the funeral home staff into a small chapel filled with white wreaths. The atmosphere in the room seemed less heavy and cold. Lucy’s face was covered with a piece of white linen cloth. For some reason, Professor Van Helsing lifted that cloth. We were surprised to see the face of the deceased glowing under the flickering light of the candles. In death, Lucy suddenly returned to the pristine beauty she had before the day she fell into the mysterious illness. The hours that passed since she took her last breath seemed only to bring her back to the beauty she had when she was alive. She looked so beautiful that I couldn't help but doubt that I was standing before someone who had died.
tr: Before going to bed, we went to see poor Lucy. The undertaker had certainly done his job well, because the room had turned into a small chapelle ardente. There was a view of a meadow made up of beautiful white flowers, and death had been made as little repulsive as possible. The edge of the shroud was draped over her face; when the Professor leaned in and pulled back the cover, we both recoiled at the beauty illuminated sufficiently by the long candles and lying before us. When she died, all of Lucy's beauty had returned, and the passing hours had revived the beauty of life in such a way that I could hardly believe I was looking at a corpse, rather than leaving the destructive marks of decay.
es: Before we left, we went to see poor Lucy. The undertaker had undoubtedly done a good job, as the room had been transformed into a small chapelle ardente. There was an abundance of beautiful white flowers, and death had been made as least repulsive as possible. The end of the shroud was placed over her face; when the professor leaned over and gently pulled it back, we were both surprised by the beauty before us, with the tall wax candles providing enough light for us to notice it. All of Lucy's beauty had returned to her in death, and the hours that had passed, instead of leaving traces of the "annihilators of death," had restored the beauty of life, so much so that I could hardly believe my eyes that I was looking at a corpse.

en: The Professor looked sternly grave. He had not loved her as I had, and there was no need for tears in his eyes. He said to me: “Remain till I return,” and left the room. He came back with a handful of wild garlic from the box waiting in the hall, but which had not been opened, and placed the flowers amongst the others on and around the bed. Then he took from his neck, inside his collar, a little gold crucifix, and placed it over the mouth. He restored the sheet to its place, and we came away.
vi: The professor looks very deep in thought. He does not love the girl as I once did, and his eyes are not filled with tears like mine. — Just wait for me here, - He told me - don't leave the room, you hear? A moment later, he returned with a bunch of garlic flowers in his hand. These were the garlic flower stalks he had stored in an iron box placed in the hallway. He gently inserted each flower among the white flowers scattered throughout the room, especially around Lucy's bed. Then he lifted the small gold cross lying hidden under her collar, placed it on her lips, and gently covered her face with the cloth. We quietly stepped outside.
tr: The professor appeared with a stern seriousness. He did not love Lucy like I did, and there was no need for tears in his eyes. "Stay here until I return," he said and left the room. He took a handful of wild garlic from the unopened box waiting in the hallway and placed the flowers among the others, here and there on the bed. Then he took a small gold cross from around his neck, under his collar, and placed it in Lucy's mouth. He covered the shroud as before, and we left the room together.
es: The professor looked with grave seriousness. He had not loved her like I did, and therefore there was no need for tears in his eyes. He said to me: "Stay here until I return," and left the room. He came back with a handful of wild garlic from the box that was in the corridor but had not yet been opened, and placed the flowers among the others, on top of and around the bed. Then, he took from his neck, beneath his shirt, a small gold crucifix, and placed it over the mouth of the deceased. He returned the sheet to its place and we left the room.

en: I was undressing in my own room, when, with a premonitory tap at the door, he entered, and at once began to speak:—
vi: Back in the room, I hadn't had time to change clothes when I saw Van Helsing burst in, knocking on the door, and he told me:
tr: Just as I was changing my clothes in my room, he knocked on the door and entered, immediately starting to speak: "Tomorrow, before evening, I want you to bring me a set of autopsy scalpels.""
es: I was undressing in my own room when, with a few warning taps, he entered and immediately began to speak:

en: “To-morrow I want you to bring me, before night, a set of post-mortem knives.”
vi: — Tomorrow evening, I want you to bring me some autopsy tools.
tr: Just as I was changing my clothes in my room, he knocked on the door and entered, immediately starting to speak: "Tomorrow, before evening, I want you to bring me a set of autopsy scalpels.""
es: –Tomorrow I want you to bring me, before nightfall, a set of dissection scalpels.

en: “Must we make an autopsy?” I asked.
vi: — What? Do we have to perform an autopsy?
tr: “Is it necessary for us to perform an autopsy?” I asked.
es: –Should we perform an autopsy? – I asked him.

en: “Yes and no. I want to operate, but not as you think. Let me tell you now, but not a word to another. I want to cut off her head and take out her heart. Ah! you a surgeon, and so shocked! You, whom I have seen with no tremble of hand or heart, do operations of life and death that make the rest shudder. Oh, but I must not forget, my dear friend John, that you loved her; and I have not forgotten it, for it is I that shall operate, and you must only help. I would like to do it to-night, but for Arthur I must not; he will be free after his father’s funeral to-morrow, and he will want to see her—to see it. Then, when she is coffined ready for the next day, you and I shall come when all sleep. We shall unscrew the coffin-lid, and shall do our operation: and then replace all, so that none know, save we alone.”
vi: — Right, but not entirely so. It's true that I plan to perform surgery, but not in the way you might think. Let me explain, but you must absolutely keep it a secret, do you understand? I'm afraid we might have to decapitate her and even remove her heart. What? You're not shocked, are you, young surgeon? Haven't I seen you perform heart surgeries on patients in critical condition? Be brave, my friend John! Ah, yes! Forgive me! I shouldn't have forgotten that you love her too! So, I will perform the surgery myself, and you will only need to assist me. I planned to do it tonight, but obviously, that's not possible because Arthur is still here. Of course, tomorrow, after his father's burial, he will surely return to see his beloved once more. But once the coffin is sealed and everyone has gone to sleep, you and I will come back to open the coffin and proceed with the surgery. After that, we will restore everything as it was, as long as no one sees us.
tr: “Yes and no. I want to perform an operation, but not in the way you think. Let me explain it to you now, but not a word to anyone else. I want to cut off his head and take out his heart. Ah, you are a surgeon and you are so surprised! You, whom I have seen with my own eyes, perform life-and-death surgeries that make others' hair stand on end without your hand or heart trembling. Ah, but my dear friend John, I must not forget that you love her; but I have not forgotten, and that is why I will perform the operation and you will only assist. I want to do it tonight, but I must not for Arthur's sake; he will be free after his father's funeral tomorrow and will want to see her. Then, when she is placed in the coffin the next day, you and I will come while everyone is asleep. We will open the coffin lid and perform the operation; then, we will put everything back in place so that no one else will know.”
es: –Yes, and no. I want to operate, but not in the way you think. Let me tell you now, but not a word to anyone else. I want to cut off her head and take out her heart. Ah! You are a surgeon and you are horrified. You, whom I have seen without a tremor in your hand or heart, performing life-and-death operations that make others tremble. Oh! But I must not forget, my dear friend John, that you loved her; and I have not forgotten, for I am the one who will operate and you must not help. I would like to do it tonight, but I won't because of Arthur; he will be free after his father's funeral tomorrow and will want to see her, see that. Then, when she is already in the coffin the next day, you and I will come when everyone is asleep. We will unscrew the coffin lid and perform our operation; then we will put everything back in place, so that no one will know, except us.

en: “But why do it at all? The girl is dead. Why mutilate her poor body without need? And if there is no necessity for a post-mortem and nothing to gain by it—no good to her, to us, to science, to human knowledge—why do it? Without such it is monstrous.”
vi: — But let me ask honestly, why are we performing surgery? The poor girl is already dead, so why do we need to dissect the body without any reason? Performing surgery is pointless if it doesn't bring any practical benefit to the deceased, to us, to science, or even to human knowledge. So what problem are we solving by dissecting? Doing so is too cruel!
tr: But why are we doing all this? The girl is dead. Why should we unnecessarily cut and dissect her poor body? And if there is no need for an autopsy and nothing to gain from it - no benefit to her, to us, to science, or to human knowledge - why are we doing it? If there is no necessity, this is monstrous!”
es: –But, why should we do that? The girl is dead. Why unnecessarily mutilate her poor body? And if there is no need for an autopsy and nothing can be gained from it (it does not benefit Lucy, it does not benefit us, nor science, nor human knowledge), why should we do it? Such a thing is monstrous.

en: For answer he put his hand on my shoulder, and said, with infinite tenderness:—
vi: The professor gently patted my shoulder and replied in a voice just loud enough to be heard:
tr: In response, he placed his hand on my shoulder and said with infinite sensitivity:
es: In response, he placed his hand on my shoulder and then said, with infinite tenderness:

en: “Friend John, I pity your poor bleeding heart; and I love you the more because it does so bleed. If I could, I would take on myself the burden that you do bear. But there are things that you know not, but that you shall know, and bless me for knowing, though they are not pleasant things. John, my child, you have been my friend now many years, and yet did you ever know me to do any without good cause? I may err—I am but man; but I believe in all I do. Was it not for these causes that you send for me when the great trouble came? Yes! Were you not amazed, nay horrified, when I would not let Arthur kiss his love—though she was dying—and snatched him away by all my strength? Yes! And yet you saw how she thanked me, with her so beautiful dying eyes, her voice, too, so weak, and she kiss my rough old hand and bless me? Yes! And did you not hear me swear promise to her, that so she closed her eyes grateful? Yes!
vi: — My dear friend, I truly understand the sorrow in your heart and deeply sympathize with you. I know that doing so will only make your pain even more profound. I am also in great pain. But there are many things you don't know yet, and you will soon realize what I haven't wanted to say, even though they are all unpleasant things. John, many years have passed since you became a close friend of mine, so have you ever seen me do anything recklessly without a practical purpose? I may be mistaken, because after all, I am only human, but I always believe in what I do. Isn't that why you invited me here? Right! And wasn't it that you weren't surprised, or rather, you weren't shocked when you saw me prevent Arthur from kissing his fiancée when she was about to die and drag him away from that bed? Right! But you also saw the girl thank me with a weak voice and with her beautiful eyes that were about to close forever, while her lips kept kissing my old hand, didn't you? Right! Didn't you hear me swear to do exactly what she asked? Right!
tr: “My friend John, I pity your poor bleeding heart; I love you even more because it bleeds this way. If I could, I would take the burden you carry upon myself. But there are things you do not know and will learn, and pray for me because I know them, for they are not pleasant things at all. John, my son, you have been my friend for years and have you ever seen me act without a just cause? I may make mistakes - I am human; but I believe in everything I do. Weren't these the reasons you called me when this great trouble arose? Yes! Weren't you surprised - no, weren't you horrified when I did not allow Arthur to kiss his beloved, who was about to die, and separated them with all my strength? Yes! But still, didn't you see how she thanked me with those beautiful dying eyes, with that weak voice, and kissed my rough old hands and blessed me? Yes! And didn't you hear me promise her as she closed her eyes in gratitude? Yes!
es: –Friend John, I sympathize with your poor bleeding heart; and I love you more because it bleeds in that way. If I could, I would take the burden you carry myself. But there are things you do not know, and yet you will know, and you will bless me for knowing them, even though they are not pleasant things. John, my son, you have been my friend for many years, but did you ever know me to do anything without a good reason? I can make mistakes, I am only a man: but I believe in everything I do. Wasn't it for this that you sent for me when the great problem arose? Yes! Weren't you astonished, rather horrified, when I did not allow Arthur to kiss his beloved, even though she was dying, and I dragged him away with all my strength? Yes! However, you saw how she thanked me, with her beautiful dying eyes, her voice also so weak, and kissed my rough and old hand and blessed me. And did you not hear me make a promise to her so that she would gratefully close her eyes? Yes!

en: “Well, I have good reason now for all I want to do. You have for many years trust me; you have believe me weeks past, when there be things so strange that you might have well doubt. Believe me yet a little, friend John. If you trust me not, then I must tell what I think; and that is not perhaps well. And if I work—as work I shall, no matter trust or no trust—without my friend trust in me, I work with heavy heart and feel, oh! so lonely when I want all help and courage that may be!” He paused a moment and went on solemnly: “Friend John, there are strange and terrible days before us. Let us not be two, but one, that so we work to a good end. Will you not have faith in me?”
vi: Therefore, now I have enough legitimate reasons to do what I want. Moreover, you have shown great trust in me all these years, and you have trusted me throughout the past few weeks full of strange events. Trust me a little longer, my dear friend John. If you don't, I will have to voice all my suspicions right now, but they are all things you don't want to hear. Furthermore, if I start the work without your complete trust, please note that whether you believe it or not, I still have to verify whether I am right or wrong, and I will certainly have to proceed with a heavy heart and an unavoidable sense of loneliness. Therefore, I really need your wholehearted help and courage! He pondered for a moment and then continued: — Believe me, my friend John, the most terrible days are still ahead of us. What I hope for now is that between the two of us, no matter what, only one of us is needed to smoothly carry out what needs to be done. I quietly held his hand tightly as if to promise that I would place my complete trust in him just like the days that have passed.
tr: Eh, now, I have a justified reason for everything I want to do. For many years you trusted me; you believed in me during the past weeks when many strange things happened that could very well have made you suspicious. Believe in me a little more, my friend John. If you don't trust me, I have to tell you what I think; it most likely won't be a good thing. And if I work without my friend who trusts me - and I will work whether there is trust or not - I will work feeling very lonely, without peace of mind, and in need of all possible help and courage!” He paused for a moment and continued solemnly: “My friend John, we have strange and terrible days ahead of us. Let us be one person, not two, and work for a good end in this way. Won't you have faith in me?”
es: "Well, now I have a good reason for everything I want to do. For many years you have trusted me; in the past weeks you have believed in me, when there have been things so strange that you might well have doubted. Trust me a little longer, friend John. If you do not trust me, then I must say what I think; and that may not be right. And if I work, as I will work, it doesn't matter the trust or distrust, without my friend's trust in me, I work with a heavy heart, and I feel, oh!, that I am alone when I desire all the help and courage that can be—he paused for a moment, and continued solemnly—: Friend John, strange and terrible days lie ahead of us. Let us be not two, but one, so that we can work successfully. Will you have faith in me?"

en: I took his hand, and promised him. I held my door open as he went away, and watched him go into his room and close the door. As I stood without moving, I saw one of the maids pass silently along the passage—she had her back towards me, so did not see me—and go into the room where Lucy lay. The sight touched me. Devotion is so rare, and we are so grateful to those who show it unasked to those we love. Here was a poor girl putting aside the terrors which she naturally had of death to go watch alone by the bier of the mistress whom she loved, so that the poor clay might not be lonely till laid to eternal rest....
vi: I quietly held his hand tightly as if to promise that I would place my complete trust in him just like the days that have passed. I opened the door to see him off and stood watching until his figure completely disappeared into the room where he would sleep. Lost in thought, I suddenly jolted when I noticed a maid silently passing the landing and entering Lucy's room. The silent shadow of the servant truly moved me. She had bravely overcome all the fear and the chilling cold that a corpse could bring to the living, to take care of the coffin where her young mistress was resting, so that the poor body would not have to endure loneliness before departing to the eternal place.
tr: I held her hand and promised her. As I left the room, I kept my door open and watched her enter her own room and close the door. While standing still, I saw one of the servants quietly pass through the corridor - his back was turned to me, so he didn't see me - and enter the room where Lucy was lying. What I saw touched me. Loyalty is a very rare thing, and we are grateful to those who show it unconditionally to our loved ones. Here before us is a poor young girl who, naturally putting aside her deep fears of death, goes alone to stand by the coffin of her beloved lady so that she is not alone before her poor body is laid to eternal rest...
es: I took his hand and promised him. As he walked away, I kept my door open and watched him enter his room and close the door. While I stood motionless, I saw one of the maids pass silently along the corridor (she had her back to me, so she didn't see me) and enter the room where Lucy lay. This impressed me. Devotion is so rare, and we feel so grateful to those who show it towards our loved ones without us asking them to…! There was a poor girl overcoming the natural terrors she felt about death, to go and keep solitary watch by the coffin of the mistress she loved, so that the poor woman would not be lonely until she was laid to her eternal rest…

en: I must have slept long and soundly, for it was broad daylight when Van Helsing waked me by coming into my room. He came over to my bedside and said:—
vi: Surely, I must have slept very long and deeply, because when Van Helsing entered the room to wake me up, it was already very bright outside. The professor walked over to the bed and told me, in a dejected voice:
tr: I must have had a long and deep sleep, because when Van Helsing came to my room and woke me up, the day was already well-lit. He came to my bedside and said:
es: I must have slept long and deeply, for it was already broad daylight when Van Helsing woke me upon entering my room. He came close to my bed and said:

en: “You need not trouble about the knives; we shall not do it.”
vi: — Don't bring the surgical tools anymore. I don't want to do it anymore.
tr: “You don't need to worry about the scalpels; we won't be doing that job.”
es: –You don't need to bother with the scalpels.

en: “Why not?” I asked. For his solemnity of the night before had greatly impressed me.
vi: — What's wrong? - I was astonished by his sudden change.
tr: “Why?” I asked. Because the seriousness of the previous night had deeply affected me.
es: We won't use them. “Why not?” I asked him, for the solemnity he had shown the previous night had deeply impressed me.

en: “Because,” he said sternly, “it is too late—or too early. See!” Here he held up the little golden crucifix. “This was stolen in the night.”
vi: — Because, - as usual, his voice remained very serious after a series of incomprehensible events in recent days - because it was too late, or still too early! — Look at this? - He said while showing me a small gold cross. - Last night, someone sneaked in and stole it. — How could it be stolen?
tr: “Because,” he said harshly, “It is now too late - or too early. Look!” Right here, he lifted the small golden cross. “This was stolen last night.”
es: Because - he said, solemnly too late... or too early. Look! - he added, holding the small golden crucifix in his hand. This was stolen during the night.

en: “How, stolen,” I asked in wonder, “since you have it now?”
vi: It's still right there in your hand!
tr: “Now that you have it in your possession,” I asked curiously, “how was it stolen?”
es: –What? Stolen? – I asked him in astonishment-. If you have it now…

en: “Because I get it back from the worthless wretch who stole it, from the woman who robbed the dead and the living. Her punishment will surely come, but not through me; she knew not altogether what she did and thus unknowing, she only stole. Now we must wait.”
vi: — I reclaimed this cross from the hands of an unfortunate person, a woman who stole from both the living and the dead. Surely she will be punished, but I will not be involved in that matter. She does not know what she has done, she is merely the perpetrator of a theft. It's as simple as that!
tr: “Because I took it back from the worthless wretch who stole it, the woman who robs both the living and the dead. Her punishment will come, but it won't be from me; she has no idea what she has done and unknowingly, she only committed theft. Now we must wait.”
es: –Because I have recovered it from the useless unfortunate woman who stole it; from the woman who stole from the dead and the living. Her punishment will surely come, but not by my hand: she did not know what she was doing, and out of ignorance, she only stole. Now, we must wait.

en: He went away on the word, leaving me with a new mystery to think of, a new puzzle to grapple with.
vi: After finishing his words, he quietly walked out. So many problems! I know that trying to unravel this new mystery would be futile.
tr: As soon as he said this, he left, leaving me with a new mystery to ponder and a new puzzle to wrestle with.
es: He walked away after saying this, leaving me with a new mystery to ponder, a new puzzle to grapple with.

en: The forenoon was a dreary time, but at noon the solicitor came: Mr. Marquand, of Wholeman, Sons, Marquand & Lidderdale. He was very genial and very appreciative of what we had done, and took off our hands all cares as to details. During lunch he told us that Mrs. Westenra had for some time expected sudden death from her heart, and had put her affairs in absolute order; he informed us that, with the exception of a certain entailed property of Lucy’s father’s which now, in default of direct issue, went back to a distant branch of the family, the whole estate, real and personal, was left absolutely to Arthur Holmwood. When he had told us so much he went on:—
vi: This morning is so gloomy and dragging! However, by noon, the notary was also present: it was Marquand, a very kind-looking man from the Wholeman law office. He thanked us for everything we had done. All the final procedures and the smallest details would be completed by him according to his legal capacity. At lunchtime, he reminded us that before she died, Mrs. Westenra had intended to settle all the family's affairs. He also informed us that since she could not transfer ownership to Lucy's father and no direct descendants of the family could be found, all her wealth and property would be left to Arthur Holmwood. The official tried to explain further:
tr: The hours before noon were dreary, but at noon the legal advisor arrived: Mr. Marquand from Wholeman, Sons, Marquand & Lidderdale. He was very cheerful and appreciated what we had done, taking the task of dealing with the details off our shoulders. During lunch, he mentioned that Ms. Westenra had been expecting to die suddenly due to her heart condition for some time and had put her affairs in perfect order; he explained that all movable and immovable properties, except for an estate belonging to Lucy's father and going to a distant branch of the family since she was not a direct heir, were left to Arthur Holmwood. After telling us this, he continued his words as follows:
es: The morning passed without incident, but at noon the lawyer arrived: Mr. Marquand, from Wholeman, Sons, Marquand Lidderdale. He was very cordial and grateful for what we had done, and he took all the care regarding the details off our hands. During lunch, he told us that Mrs. Westenra had been expecting a sudden death due to her heart for some time, and had put all her affairs in absolute order; he informed us that, with the exception of certain property with a title from Lucy's father, which now, in the absence of a direct heir, would go to a distant branch of the family, the entire estate was absolutely left to Arthur Holmwood. When he had told us all that, he continued:

en: “Frankly we did our best to prevent such a testamentary disposition, and pointed out certain contingencies that might leave her daughter either penniless or not so free as she should be to act regarding a matrimonial alliance. Indeed, we pressed the matter so far that we almost came into collision, for she asked us if we were or were not prepared to carry out her wishes. Of course, we had then no alternative but to accept. We were right in principle, and ninety-nine times out of a hundred we should have proved, by the logic of events, the accuracy of our judgment. Frankly, however, I must admit that in this case any other form of disposition would have rendered impossible the carrying out of her wishes. For by her predeceasing her daughter the latter would have come into possession of the property, and, even had she only survived her mother by five minutes, her property would, in case there were no will—and a will was a practical impossibility in such a case—have been treated at her decease as under intestacy. In which case Lord Godalming, though so dear a friend, would have had no claim in the world; and the inheritors, being remote, would not be likely to abandon their just rights, for sentimental reasons regarding an entire stranger. I assure you, my dear sirs, I am rejoiced at the result, perfectly rejoiced.”
vi: — To be honest, we tried to prevent our client from including such terms in her will. We warned Mrs. Westenra that unforeseen events could leave her daughter penniless or hinder her decision-making on her wedding day. Things between us and the client got so bad that she angrily asked if we intended to respect her final wishes or not. Clearly, we had no choice but to silently accept. But in principle, we were ninety-nine percent right, because logically, we could prove the validity of our advice. However, I must admit that in this particular case, no other form of will could have fulfilled her wishes. Because logically, she would pass away before her daughter, and the daughter would inherit all the wealth and property. Yet the daughter only outlived her mother by a short time and left no will, as confirmed by the examination, so this can be considered a case of intestacy. Thus, Lord Godalming, although a very close friend and also the fiancé of the young lady, would have absolutely no claim. Perhaps the heirs, even those far away, would not yield to a stranger for sentimental reasons. They are the rightful returnees. Trust me, gentlemen, this is an argument that truly satisfies me.
tr: “Frankly, we did everything we could to avoid such an arrangement regarding the will and pointed out certain possibilities where his daughter would be left penniless or would not be very free if she acted according to a marital bond. Seriously, we went so far on the matter that we were almost about to disagree, because he asked if we were ready to fulfill his wishes. Of course, at that moment we had no choice but to accept. In principle, we were right and with the logic of events, we could prove the correctness of our thoughts ninety-nine percent. But frankly, in this case, any other attitude would make it impossible to fulfill his wishes. Because if he died before his daughter, she would be the owner of the estate, and if she lived even five minutes longer than her mother, in the absence of a will - which would be impossible in such a case - it would be considered as if no will had been left. In such a case, Lord Godalming, despite being a very good friend, would have no rights; the heirs, being distant relatives, would not renounce their rights for emotional reasons related to a complete stranger. I assure you, gentlemen, this result pleases me, pleases me greatly.”
es: –Frankly, we did everything possible to prevent such a testamentary disposition, and we pointed out certain contingencies that could leave your daughter either without a cent, or not as free as she should be to act considering a matrimonial alliance. In fact, we pressed the matter so much that we almost came to a clash, as she asked us whether we were or were not prepared to fulfill her wishes. Of course, we had no alternative but to accept. In principle, we were right, and ninety-nine times out of a hundred we could have proven, by the logic of events, the soundness of our judgment. However, frankly, I must admit that in this case any other form of disposition would have resulted in the impossibility of carrying out her wishes. For her daughter would have come into possession of the property and, even if she had only survived her mother by five minutes, her property, in the event that there was no will, and a will was practically impossible in such a case, would have been treated upon her death as ab intestato. In which case, Lord Godalming, although he was a close friend of theirs, would not have any right. And the heirs, being distant relatives, would not so easily abandon their rightful claims for sentimental reasons related to a complete stranger. I assure you, my esteemed gentlemen, that I am happy with the outcome; very happy.

en: He was a good fellow, but his rejoicing at the one little part—in which he was officially interested—of so great a tragedy, was an object-lesson in the limitations of sympathetic understanding.
vi: Marquand must have been an excellent notary, but somehow he found joy in those details - the details that his profession always required him to pay attention to when the unfortunate were facing a tragedy. This is indeed a rigid and unsympathetic example that we often encounter in some people.
tr: The legal advisor was a good person, but his rejoicing over such a small part of a great tragedy - the part he was officially concerned with - served as a lesson on the limits of empathetic understanding.
es: He was a good guy, but his happiness over that small part (in which he was officially interested) amidst such a great tragedy was an objective lesson in the limitations of commiseration.

en: He did not remain long, but said he would look in later in the day and see Lord Godalming. His coming, however, had been a certain comfort to us, since it assured us that we should not have to dread hostile criticism as to any of our acts. Arthur was expected at five o’clock, so a little before that time we visited the death-chamber. It was so in very truth, for now both mother and daughter lay in it. The undertaker, true to his craft, had made the best display he could of his goods, and there was a mortuary air about the place that lowered our spirits at once. Van Helsing ordered the former arrangement to be adhered to, explaining that, as Lord Godalming was coming very soon, it would be less harrowing to his feelings to see all that was left of his fiancée quite alone. The undertaker seemed shocked at his own stupidity and exerted himself to restore things to the condition in which we left them the night before, so that when Arthur came such shocks to his feelings as we could avoid were saved.
vi: The notary only stayed with us for a moment before leaving with a promise to return in the afternoon to meet Lord Godalming. In any case, his presence somewhat comforted us, as he gave us a sense of reassurance about what we had done since Mrs. Westenra and Miss Lucy passed away. We waited for Arthur until five in the afternoon. A little before that, we were still in the funeral home. I call it that because now both Mrs. Westenra and her daughter are resting there. The funeral home staff seemed more enthusiastic than usual today. The sorrowful atmosphere in the small room plunged us into an unbearable feeling of numbness. Van Helsing requested the funeral home staff to restore everything in the room to its previous state. He said that Lord Godalming was about to arrive, and seeing only his fiancée here would make it less painful for him. The funeral home employee pretended to be remorseful for his foolish actions and then immediately got to work as requested by the professor. When Arthur arrived, the room had been restored to its original state as we had done the night before going to bed.
tr: Adam did not stay with us long, but he said he would come to see Lord Godalming later in the day. But his arrival had certainly reassured us, as he had given us confidence that we need not fear hostile criticism for our actions. Arthur was expected to arrive at five o'clock, so shortly before that time, we visited the death chamber. Now that both mother and daughter lay there, it truly was a death chamber. The undertaker, true to his profession, had worked to display his wares in the best possible manner, and there was an air of death in the place that immediately dampened our spirits. Van Helsing ordered that the previous arrangement be adhered to, explaining that Lord Godalming would arrive very soon and that it would break his heart less to see the remains of his fiancée alone. The undertaker, astounded by his own folly, worked hard to restore everything to the way we had left it the night before, thus preventing Arthur from experiencing a shock to his emotions when he arrived.
es: He did not stay long, but said he would return later in the day and see Lord Godalming. His arrival, however, had been a certain relief for us, as it ensured that we would not have the threat of hostile criticism for any of our actions. Arthur was expected to arrive at five, so shortly before that time we visited the mortuary chamber. And so it could truly be called, for now both mother and daughter lay in it. The undertaker, true to his skill, had made the best display of his goods that he possessed, and throughout the place there was a gloomy atmosphere that immediately depressed us. Van Helsing ordered that everything be put back as it was before, explaining that, since Lord Godalming would soon arrive, it would be less heartbreaking for his feelings to see all that remained of his fiancée alone. The undertaker seemed distressed by his own stupidity and made every effort to rearrange everything just as it had been the previous night, so that when Arthur arrived, as many bad impressions as possible would be avoided.

en: Poor fellow! He looked desperately sad and broken; even his stalwart manhood seemed to have shrunk somewhat under the strain of his much-tried emotions. He had, I knew, been very genuinely and devotedly attached to his father; and to lose him, and at such a time, was a bitter blow to him. With me he was warm as ever, and to Van Helsing he was sweetly courteous; but I could not help seeing that there was some constraint with him. The Professor noticed it, too, and motioned me to bring him upstairs. I did so, and left him at the door of the room, as I felt he would like to be quite alone with her, but he took my arm and led me in, saying huskily:—
vi: Poor Arthur! In a state of utter despair from successive pains, it seemed he was no longer himself. I understand he loved his father very much. Losing his father at this moment was like a bolt from the blue. He has shown me what friendship is and to Van Helsing, he always presented himself as a polite and strong person, but it seems to me that the pain has turned him into someone almost completely losing self-control. Surely the professor felt the same as I did, as he just gestured for me to join the poor young man. I did not intend to follow the professor's suggestion because I thought that perhaps Arthur only wanted to be alone with his fiancée Lucy at this moment. But when he saw me about to step out of the door, he hurriedly grabbed my hand and pulled me in.
tr: Poor man! He looked extremely sad and dejected; even his bold masculinity seemed to have collapsed under the strain of his heavily tested emotions. I know that he was truly and selflessly devoted to his father; losing him, especially at such a time, was a very painful blow for him. When he was with me, he was as warm as ever and showed a pleasant courtesy towards Van Helsing; but I couldn't help noticing that he was holding himself back a bit. The Professor noticed this too and signaled to me to bring Lord Godalming upstairs. I did so and left him at the door of the room, feeling that he would want to be alone with Lucy; but as he grabbed my arm and pulled me inside, he said:
es: Poor man! He was desperately sad and dejected; even his steel-like manliness seemed to have diminished somewhat under the strain of his many emotions. He had been, I know, genuinely and devotedly attached to his father; and losing him, at a time like that, was a bitter blow for him. With me, he was more affectionate than ever, and he was sweetly courteous with Van Helsing; but I couldn't help but see that there was some reticence in him. The professor noticed it too and signaled to me to take him upstairs. I did it and left it at the door of the room, as I felt that he would want to be completely alone with her, but he took me by the arm and led me inside, saying dryly:

en: “You loved her too, old fellow; she told me all about it, and there was no friend had a closer place in her heart than you. I don’t know how to thank you for all you have done for her. I can’t think yet....”
vi: — You love her too, my friend. - He said chokingly. - She told me everything, among her friends, she has no one closer than you. I really don't know how to thank you for what you've done for her. Even now, I still can't...
tr: “You loved him too, my old friend; he told me everything and had no friend closer to his heart than you. I don't know how to thank you for all you did for him. I can't think yet...”
es: –You loved her too, old friend; she told me everything about it, and there was no friend who had a closer place in her heart than you. I don't know how to thank you for everything you've done for her. I still can't think...

en: Here he suddenly broke down, and threw his arms round my shoulders and laid his head on my breast, crying:—
vi: Arthur suddenly burst into tears with incessant sobs, he threw his arms around my shoulders and sobbed:
tr: Right there she lost herself and threw her arms around my shoulders, resting her head on my chest, and said while crying: "Oh, Jack!
es: And here he suddenly showed his dejection, and put his arms around my shoulders, resting his head on my chest, crying:

en: “Oh, Jack! Jack! What shall I do! The whole of life seems gone from me all at once, and there is nothing in the wide world for me to live for.”
vi: — Oh my God? Jack, Jack? What will happen to me now? Everything is lost, what is there left for me to live for?
tr: Jack! Jack! What am I going to do? It feels as if my entire life has suddenly been taken away from me and there's nothing left in this vast world worth living for."
es: –Oh, Jack! Jack! What will I do? All the life seems to have suddenly left me, and there is nothing in the wide world for which I wish to live.

en: I comforted him as well as I could. In such cases men do not need much expression. A grip of the hand, the tightening of an arm over the shoulder, a sob in unison, are expressions of sympathy dear to a man’s heart. I stood still and silent till his sobs died away, and then I said softly to him:—
vi: Even though I knew that any words at this moment would be useless, I still tried to find the right words to comfort him. One hand tightly grasping his, the other placed on the trembling shoulder of a shattered soul, a sob that couldn't be held back mingling with the mournful sobs, that was all my heart told me to do to share and soothe my grieving friend. Waiting for his sobs to gradually subside, I finally dared to gently remind him:
tr: I comforted him as much as I could. In situations like these, a person doesn't need many words. Holding a hand tightly, putting an arm around the shoulder, sobbing together are expressions of empathy that touch a man's heart. I stood still and silent until his sobs subsided, and then I slowly said:
es: I comforted him as best as I could. In such cases, men do not need much expression. A handshake, or pats on the shoulder, a sob in unison, are pleasant expressions for a man's heart. I remained still and silent until he stopped sobbing, and then I said to him softly:

en: “Come and look at her.”
vi: — Come on, let's go visit her!
tr: "Come and look at it."
es: –Come and look at it.

en: Together we moved over to the bed, and I lifted the lawn from her face. God! how beautiful she was. Every hour seemed to be enhancing her loveliness. It frightened and amazed me somewhat; and as for Arthur, he fell a-trembling, and finally was shaken with doubt as with an ague. At last, after a long pause, he said to me in a faint whisper:—
vi: We approached the bed of the deceased and gently lifted the cloth covering the face to one side. Oh Lord, how beautiful she is! It seems as though with each passing hour, she becomes more beautiful than before. This not only surprised me but also made me feel scared. As for Arthur, it seemed to me that doubt and sorrow had driven him mad, and he began to tremble violently like someone with malaria. Finally, after a moment of silence, he leaned into my ear and whispered:
tr: We moved towards the bed together and lifted the fine linen cloth from her face. My God! How beautiful she was. It seemed as if each passing hour increased her beauty. This somehow frightened and surprised me; as for Arthur, he started trembling and eventually shook with suspicion as if he had caught a fever. Finally, after a long pause, he said in a faint whisper:
es: Together we walked towards the bed, and I removed the shroud from her face. God! How beautiful she was. Every hour seemed to increase her beauty. In some way, that astonished and frightened me; and as for Arthur, he fell trembling, and finally was shaken with doubt as if it were a chill. After a long pause, he said to me, exhaling a very weak sigh:

en: “Jack, is she really dead?”
vi: — Jack, is it true that she has died?
tr: “Jack, is he really dead?”
es: –Jack, is she really dead?

en: I assured him sadly that it was so, and went on to suggest—for I felt that such a horrible doubt should not have life for a moment longer than I could help—that it often happened that after death faces became softened and even resolved into their youthful beauty; that this was especially so when death had been preceded by any acute or prolonged suffering. It seemed to quite do away with any doubt, and, after kneeling beside the couch for a while and looking at her lovingly and long, he turned aside. I told him that that must be good-bye, as the coffin had to be prepared; so he went back and took her dead hand in his and kissed it, and bent over and kissed her forehead. He came away, fondly looking back over his shoulder at her as he came.
vi: I am compelled to affirm to you the misfortune of the young girl, because I know that your feeling of doubt, no matter what, can only last for a moment. I explain so that you understand that usually, after a person dies, the features on their face will bear a gentle expression that faintly recalls their youthful appearance, and this is even more evident in those who have endured extreme prolonged suffering before death. It seems that my explanation has convinced you. After a long time kneeling by the bed, staring blankly at his fiancée, he decided to stand up and step outside. I had to tell him that it was time to say a final farewell to the young girl, as they were about to place her in the coffin. Hearing this, he sobbed, turned back, tightly grasped his beloved's small hand, placed it on his lips, and bitterly bent down to kiss her forehead. With great effort, he managed to drag his feet out of the room, but his head still turned back to look at her beloved form one last time, until her figure disappeared from sight.
tr: Regretfully, I convinced him that it was so, and continued my words by suggesting that it is a common occurrence for faces to soften and even return to their youthful beauty after death; this is especially seen in deaths that come after heavy and prolonged suffering - because I felt that I could not allow such a terrible doubt to last for more than a moment. This explanation seemed to dispel all doubts, and after kneeling beside the couch for a while and looking at Lucy lovingly for a long time, he turned his head aside. I told him to say his farewells as the coffin needed to be prepared; thus he turned back, took Lucy's hand in his, kissed it, bent down, and kissed her forehead. As he walked out of the room, he looked at her lovingly over his shoulder.
es: I assured him sadly that it was so, and then I suggested (for I felt that such a terrible doubt should not live even a moment longer than I could allow) that it often happened that after death the faces softened and even regained their youthful beauty; this was especially so when death had been preceded by any acute or prolonged suffering. It seemed that my words dispelled any doubt, and after kneeling for a while beside the bed and looking at her long and lovingly, he left. I told him that this had to be the farewell, as the coffin had to be prepared, so he returned and took her dead hand in his, kissed it, and leaned down and kissed her forehead. Then he withdrew, looking lovingly over his shoulder at her as he walked away.

en: I left him in the drawing-room, and told Van Helsing that he had said good-bye; so the latter went to the kitchen to tell the undertaker’s men to proceed with the preparations and to screw up the coffin. When he came out of the room again I told him of Arthur’s question, and he replied:—
vi: I helped him back to rest in the living room and then hurriedly went to find Van Helsing, who was instructing the funeral home staff to prepare the coffins for the unfortunate people. I recounted to the professor how Arthur had wondered about the appearance of his fiancée.
tr: I left Arthur in the living room and told Van Helsing that Lord Godalming had said his farewells; thus, the Professor went to the kitchen to tell the undertaker's men to continue the preparations and nail the coffin shut. When he came out of the room once more, I relayed Arthur's question to him and he responded:
es: I left him in the room and told van Helsing that Arthur had already said his goodbyes to his beloved; so he went to the kitchen to tell the undertaker's employees to continue the preparations and screw down the coffin. When he came out of the room again, I relayed Arthur's question to him, and he replied:

en: “I am not surprised. Just now I doubted for a moment myself!”
vi: — That doesn't surprise me at all. - He told me. - There was a time when I didn't believe my own eyes either!
tr: “I'm not surprised. A moment ago, I also had doubts for a second!”
es: –It doesn't surprise me. Just a moment ago, I was doubting the same thing!

en: We all dined together, and I could see that poor Art was trying to make the best of things. Van Helsing had been silent all dinner-time; but when we had lit our cigars he said—
vi: During dinner, I noticed that Arthur was making a great effort to hide his heart-wrenching pain. Van Helsing just sat quietly, and it wasn't until we were lighting our cigarettes that he spoke to Arthur:
tr: We all had dinner together; I could see that poor Arthur was trying his best. Van Helsing was silent throughout the meal, but when we lit our cigars, he said:
es: We all had dinner together, and I could see how poor Art tried to do his best. Van Helsing remained silent throughout the entire dinner, but when we lit our cigarettes, he said:

en: “Lord——”; but Arthur interrupted him:—
vi: — My lord...
tr: "Lord," Arthur interrupted:
es: –Lord... But Arthur interrupted him:

en: “No, no, not that, for God’s sake! not yet at any rate. Forgive me, sir: I did not mean to speak offensively; it is only because my loss is so recent.”
vi: — No, don't call me that, for God's sake! - Arthur interrupted - No matter what, don't call me that! I'm sorry, sir, I didn't mean to offend you. But please understand and believe me, my family's funeral just recently...
tr: “No, no, not like that, for God's sake! Whatever happens, not yet. Forgive me, sir: I did not mean to speak aggressively; it's just that my loss is still very fresh.”
es: –No, no, not that, for the love of God! Anyway, not yet. Forgive me, sir, I didn't mean to offend you; it's just that my loss is very recent.

en: The Professor answered very sweetly:—
vi: Van Helsing responded in a noticeably subdued tone:
tr: The professor answered very sweetly:
es: The professor responded very kindly:

en: “I only used that name because I was in doubt. I must not call you ‘Mr.,’ and I have grown to love you—yes, my dear boy, to love you—as Arthur.”
vi: — I call you that simply because I don't know how to address you properly. In fact, I don't like calling you "sir," because up until now, I have been very, very fond of you, young man.
tr: “The only reason I used that name was because I was in doubt. I shouldn't address you as 'mr' and I have started to love you as Arthur, yes my dear son, to love you.”
es: –I only used that title because I was unsure. I mustn't call you "sir" and I've grown very fond of you; yes, my dear boy, very fond; I will call you Arthur.

en: Arthur held out his hand, and took the old man’s warmly.
vi: To me, you are always Arthur. Arthur respectfully extended his hand towards the elderly doctor:
tr: Arthur reached out and sincerely shook the old man's hand.
es: Arthur extended his hand and warmly shook the old man's.

en: “Call me what you will,” he said. “I hope I may always have the title of a friend. And let me say that I am at a loss for words to thank you for your goodness to my poor dear.” He paused a moment, and went on: “I know that she understood your goodness even better than I do; and if I was rude or in any way wanting at that time you acted so—you remember”—the Professor nodded—“you must forgive me.”
vi: — Please feel free to give me any name you like, but whatever name it is, I hope you always consider me a friend. To be honest, there have been many times I wanted to express my gratitude to you but didn't know how to articulate it. You have been wholeheartedly dedicated to my loved one! - Arthur paused for a moment and then continued - I know she will understand your sentiments better than I do, if at this moment I don't know how to behave properly then... Please forgive me.
tr: “You may address me in any manner you wish,” he said. “I hope that I will always hold the title of friend. And please allow me to say that I cannot find the words to thank you for the kindness you have shown to my poor beloved.” He paused for a moment and continued: “I know that she has understood your kindness even better than I have; if I have been rude or if I have somehow been at fault while you were acting - you remember,” the Professor nodded, “you must forgive me.”
es: –Call me whatever you like -he said-. And I hope that you always hold the title of friend. And let me tell you that I cannot find the words to thank you for all your kindness towards my poor beloved -he paused and then continued-. I know that she understood your kindness even better than I did; and if I was rude or in any way bothersome when you acted strangely, do you remember? – the professor nodded -, you must forgive me.

en: He answered with a grave kindness:—
vi: Van Helsing's answer once again demonstrates his genuine empathy. — I know! -
tr: The professor replied with a dignified politeness:
es: My teacher replied with solemn kindness:

en: “I know it was hard for you to quite trust me then, for to trust such violence needs to understand; and I take it that you do not—that you cannot—trust me now, for you do not yet understand. And there may be more times when I shall want you to trust when you cannot—and may not—and must not yet understand. But the time will come when your trust shall be whole and complete in me, and when you shall understand as though the sunlight himself shone through. Then you shall bless me from first to last for your own sake, and for the sake of others and for her dear sake to whom I swore to protect.”
vi: His voice was steady and slow - It is very difficult for you to understand and completely trust me, because to trust each other, first people must understand each other. I believe that you have not, or more accurately, have not yet trusted me, because you do not understand me. However, there are still situations where I very much need your trust, but you do not understand or cannot yet understand! But as time goes by, eventually you will fully trust me, when you understand everything as clear as day. Then you will certainly wish me well for the actions I have taken for your benefit, for the benefit of others, and for the poor child whom I have sworn to protect to the utmost.
tr: “I know that trusting me is difficult for you at this time, because believing in such violence requires understanding; now I conclude that you do not trust me -cannot trust me- because you do not yet understand. And many times more, while you cannot understand -even if you want to understand- and while you should not understand, I will ask you to trust me. But there will come times when you will trust me completely, as if you understand it as clearly as daylight. Then, for your own sake, for the sake of others, and for the sweet sake of the young lady whom I have sworn to protect, you will bless me from beginning to end.”
es: –I know it was terrible for you to give me your trust back then, because to trust in such violences one needs to understand; and I suppose you don't trust me now, you can't trust, because you still don't understand. And there may be other occasions when I want you to trust when you can't, or shouldn't, and still don't come to understand. But the time will come when your trust in me will be unrestricted, and you will understand, as if the very light of the sun penetrated your mind. Then, you will bless me for your own good, for the good of others, and for the good of the one you swore to protect.

en: “And, indeed, indeed, sir,” said Arthur warmly, “I shall in all ways trust you. I know and believe you have a very noble heart, and you are Jack’s friend, and you were hers. You shall do what you like.”
vi: — Yes, of course, - Athur replied - I will completely entrust myself to you. I know you carry a chivalrous heart, and you are a friend of Jack just as you and Jack are friends of hers. You will act according to the duty you believe is yours.
tr: "Indeed, indeed, sir," said Arthur warmly, "I will trust you in every respect. I know and believe that you have a very noble heart, that you are a friend of Jack, and also a friend of Lucy. You can do whatever you want."
es: –And, in fact, sir -said Arthur warmly-, I will trust you anyway. I know and believe that you have a noble heart, and you are a friend of Jack, and you were a friend of hers. Do whatever you deem appropriate.

en: The Professor cleared his throat a couple of times, as though about to speak, and finally said:—
vi: After a moment of contemplation, Van Helsing pensively continued:
tr: The professor cleared his throat a few times as if he were about to speak and finally said:
es: The professor cleared his throat a couple of times, as if he were about to speak, and finally said:

en: “May I ask you something now?”
vi: — Can I ask you a question?
tr: “Then can I ask you something now?” “Of course.””
es: –Can I ask you something now?

en: “Certainly.”
vi: — Of course, that's fine.
tr: “Then can I ask you something now?” “Of course.””
es: –Of course.

en: “You know that Mrs. Westenra left you all her property?”
vi: — Do you know that Mrs. Westenra has left you all the assets she had?
tr: "You do know that Ms. Westenra has left all her property to you, don't you?""
es: –Do you know that Mrs. Westenra left you all her properties?

en: “No, poor dear; I never thought of it.”
vi: — No. Poor woman! No... I never thought about that.
tr: "No, poor thing; I had never thought of that.""
es: –No. Poor lady! I never thought about it.

en: “And as it is all yours, you have a right to deal with it as you will. I want you to give me permission to read all Miss Lucy’s papers and letters. Believe me, it is no idle curiosity. I have a motive of which, be sure, she would have approved. I have them all here. I took them before we knew that all was yours, so that no strange hand might touch them—no strange eye look through words into her soul. I shall keep them, if I may; even you may not see them yet, but I shall keep them safe. No word shall be lost; and in the good time I shall give them back to you. It’s a hard thing I ask, but you will do it, will you not, for Lucy’s sake?”
vi: — Now all of that property belongs to you, so you have the right to use it as you wish. I intend to ask your permission to read all of Lucy's papers and letters. Don't doubt it, it's not because I'm curious. I'm doing this for a reason that I know she would agree with. I've found the papers and letters. Currently, I'm holding all of them before returning them to you as a part of her legacy. I will read everything if you allow, and if you haven't seen these mementos yet, it would be better at this moment - I will keep them in a safe place. I assure you that I won't lose a single piece of her papers. At an appropriate time, I will return everything to you. Perhaps I'm asking for too much, but I know that out of love for Lucy, you will agree, won't you, my friend?
tr: "And since it all belongs to you, you have the right to manage it as you wish. I ask you to allow me to read all the documents and letters belonging to Miss Westenra. Believe me, this is not an unnecessary curiosity. Believe me, I have a reason that she would approve of. All the documents are here. I took them before knowing that everything belonged to you, so that no foreign hand would touch them - no foreign eye would look at the words of her soul. If you allow, let them stay with me; you don't even see them yet, but I will keep them safe. No word will be lost and I will return them to you when the time comes. It's a difficult thing to ask, but you will do it for Lucy's sake, won't you?"
es: –And since everything belongs to you, you have the right to do with it as you please. I wish for you to give me your authorization to read all the papers and letters of Miss Lucy. Believe me, it is not mere curiosity. I have a motive that, you can be sure, she would have approved. I have them all here. I took them before we knew that everything belonged to you, so that no strange hand would touch them, so that no strange eye could see through the words into her soul. I will keep them, if you allow me; not even you will be able to see them yet, but I will keep them safe. Not a word will be lost, and in due time I will return them to you. It is a hard thing I ask, but you will do it, won't you, for the love of Lucy…

en: Arthur spoke out heartily, like his old self:—
vi: Without much thought, Arthur immediately replied in a straightforward and sincere manner, just as I knew him to be:
tr: Arthur spoke warmly, as he used to:
es: Arthur spoke sincerely, as he usually did:

en: “Dr. Van Helsing, you may do what you will. I feel that in saying this I am doing what my dear one would have approved. I shall not trouble you with questions till the time comes.”
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, please do as you wish. I know that if Lucy were still here, she would testify to what I am saying. I will not ask any questions until you feel it is time to explain your actions.
tr: “Dr. Van Helsing, you can do whatever you want. By saying this, I feel that I am doing something my beloved would approve of. Until the time comes, I will not bother you with my questions.”
es: –Doctor van Helsing, you can do as you wish. I feel that by saying this I am doing what my Lucy would have approved. I will not bother you with questions until the time comes.

en: The old Professor stood up as he said solemnly:—
vi: — You are absolutely right. - The professor jumped up and spoke in a very serious tone.
tr: The elderly Professor stood up and said in a serious manner:
es: The elderly professor stood up as he solemnly said:

en: “And you are right. There will be pain for us all; but it will not be all pain, nor will this pain be the last. We and you too—you most of all, my dear boy—will have to pass through the bitter water before we reach the sweet. But we must be brave of heart and unselfish, and do our duty, and all will be well!”
vi: - We all have a lot of work to do and quite a few concerns, but it's not just the concerns; behind them, we have many other issues to understand. Dr. Seward and I, and you too, Arthur, you and no one else, the three of us will have to endure bitter moments before returning to a peaceful life. We must be brave, not thinking about ourselves but prioritizing our duties first; only then can we succeed!
tr: “And you are right. It will be painful for all of us; but it won't all be pain and this pain won't be the last pain. We and you - especially you, my dear son - will have to pass through bitter waters before reaching the sweet waters. But our hearts must be brave, we must not be selfish, and we must do our duty; everything will be alright!”
es: –And you are right. There will be much pain for all of us; but not everything will be pain, nor will this pain be the last. We and you too, you more than anyone, my dear friend, will have to pass through the bitter water before reaching the sweet. But we must be brave and selfless, and fulfill our duty; everything will turn out well.

en: I slept on a sofa in Arthur’s room that night. Van Helsing did not go to bed at all. He went to and fro, as if patrolling the house, and was never out of sight of the room where Lucy lay in her coffin, strewn with the wild garlic flowers, which sent, through the odour of lily and rose, a heavy, overpowering smell into the night.
vi: That night, I slept on the settee in Arthur's room. Van Helsing did not rest at all. He kept pacing back and forth as if patrolling the house, but never strayed far from the room where Lucy's coffin was placed. Unlike the scent of lilies or roses, the scattered garlic flowers in the room emitted a pungent odor throughout the night.
tr: That night, I slept on the couch in Arthur's room. Van Helsing never slept. He walked back and forth as if patrolling the house and never took his eyes off the room where Lucy lay in her coffin, surrounded by wild garlic flowers that sent a dominant scent through the night amidst the smells of lilies and roses.
es: I slept on a sofa in Arthur's room that night. Van Helsing did not go to bed. He walked back and forth, as if he were patrolling the house, and never strayed far from the room where Lucy lay in her coffin, sprinkled with wild garlic flowers, which emitted, through the scent of lilacs and roses, a heavy and overwhelming smell in the silence of the night.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 22 September.—In the train to Exeter. Jonathan sleeping.
vi: • September 22 I am sitting and writing on the train that is taking us to Exeter. Jonathan is fast asleep.
tr: September 22 - Exeter train. Jonathan is sleeping.
es: September 22. On the train to Exeter, Jonathan sleeps.

en: It seems only yesterday that the last entry was made, and yet how much between then, in Whitby and all the world before me, Jonathan away and no news of him; and now, married to Jonathan, Jonathan a solicitor, a partner, rich, master of his business, Mr. Hawkins dead and buried, and Jonathan with another attack that may harm him. Some day he may ask me about it. Down it all goes. I am rusty in my shorthand—see what unexpected prosperity does for us—so it may be as well to freshen it up again with an exercise anyhow....
vi: It seems to me that I only started writing these diary entries yesterday, yet so many things have happened since we were in Whitby to plan for the future, while Jonathan was wandering in a foreign land and I was always eagerly waiting for news from him. Time flies, and now I am married to Jonathan, a notary, the owner of his own law office. Mr. Hawkins has been properly buried, and Jonathan has just gone through a new illness that makes me worry about the potentially unfavorable consequences that may occur later. There may come a day when he asks me about the things that happened while he was not conscious of them. I suddenly realize that my shorthand writing skills have deteriorated, perhaps I should take the time to practice them again occasionally...
tr: So much has happened since the last time I wrote here, which feels like it was just yesterday, when I was in Whitby and the whole world was ahead of me, when Jonathan was far away and I had no news from him; now, I am married to Jonathan, Jonathan has become a legal advisor, a partner, wealthy, and the owner of his own business, Mr. Hawkins has died and been buried; Jonathan had another fit that could harm him.
