One day he might ask me something about it. I am writing everything down. My shorthand has gotten rusty - see what unexpected happiness does to us - but it would be good to revive my shorthand by practicing in one way or another...
es: It seems like it was only yesterday when I made those intimate notes, and yet, how much has transpired between them, in Whitby and all over the world before me! Jonathan was far away and I had no news of him; and now, married to Jonathan, Jonathan as a solicitor, partner in a firm, wealthy, owner of his business, Mr. Hawkins dead and buried, and Jonathan with another attack that could harm him greatly. Someday he may ask me about it. Everything is going downhill. I am rusty in my shorthand; see what unexpected prosperity does for us, so it's not bad that I refresh it again by practicing a little.

en: The service was very simple and very solemn. There were only ourselves and the servants there, one or two old friends of his from Exeter, his London agent, and a gentleman representing Sir John Paxton, the President of the Incorporated Law Society. Jonathan and I stood hand in hand, and we felt that our best and dearest friend was gone from us....
vi: The funeral was held simply but also very emotionally. There were only the two of us, a few servants, and two or three old friends from Exeter, a staff member from London, and another gentleman who introduced himself as John Paxton, the president of a general law firm. Jonathan and I held each other's hands tightly, feeling empty inside knowing for sure that our best, closest friend had gone away and would never return...
tr: The funeral ceremony was very simple and solemn. Only we, the servants, a couple of friends from Exeter, the London representative, a gentleman representing Sir John Paxton, and the President of the United Law Society were there. Jonathan and I stood hand in hand and felt that our best, closest friend had left us...
es: The service was very simple and solemn. Only we ourselves and the servants attended, one or two old friends of his from Exeter, his agent in London, and a gentleman representing Sir John Paxton, the president of the Legal Society. Jonathan and I held hands, and we felt that our best and dearest friend had left us.

en: We came back to town quietly, taking a ’bus to Hyde Park Corner. Jonathan thought it would interest me to go into the Row for a while, so we sat down; but there were very few people there, and it was sad-looking and desolate to see so many empty chairs. It made us think of the empty chair at home; so we got up and walked down Piccadilly. Jonathan was holding me by the arm, the way he used to in old days before I went to school. I felt it very improper, for you can’t go on for some years teaching etiquette and decorum to other girls without the pedantry of it biting into yourself a bit; but it was Jonathan, and he was my husband, and we didn’t know anybody who saw us—and we didn’t care if they did—so on we walked. I was looking at a very beautiful girl, in a big cart-wheel hat, sitting in a victoria outside Guiliano’s, when I felt Jonathan clutch my arm so tight that he hurt me, and he said under his breath: “My God!” I am always anxious about Jonathan, for I fear that some nervous fit may upset him again; so I turned to him quickly, and asked him what it was that disturbed him.
vi: To get back to the city, we had to take a bus and get off at the Hyde Park stop. To ease my sadness, Jonathan invited me to stroll along a small path in the park, but I couldn't walk much, so the two of us found a place to sit and rest. There were very few people in the park, and all the benches were completely empty. The melancholy scene here made me unconsciously think of the empty chair we would see again when we returned home. So we didn't sit for long, I stood up and pulled Jonathan towards Piccadilly. Jonathan linked arms with me as he used to do in the past, back when he would take me to school. To be honest, I naturally felt that his gesture at this moment made me a bit uncomfortable. But now Jonathan is my husband, and besides, we didn't know anyone among the passersby, and even if a few of them recognized us, it wouldn't matter at all. We continued to walk straight ahead... I suddenly noticed a very beautiful young girl, wearing a wide-brimmed hat, sitting in a Victoria-style carriage parked in front of Guillano's house. But Jonathan startled me by suddenly squeezing my hand so tightly it hurt. I suddenly felt worried when he leaned into my ear and said in a choked voice: "My God!" So many unlucky days had passed that I couldn't help but worry about him, because I was always afraid he would fall into a new episode that would unbalance his nervous system. I quickly turned to ask what had happened.
tr: We boarded a bus to Hyde Park Corner and quietly returned to the city. Jonathan thought it might interest me to go to Row for a while, so we sat down; but there were very few people; seeing so many empty chairs was sad and gloomy. This made us think of the empty chairs at home; so we got up and walked to Piccadilly. Jonathan was holding my arm as he used to in the old days before I went to school. I felt this was very inappropriate because you can't teach other girls manners and etiquette for years without practicing what you preach; but it was Jonathan, and he was my husband; we didn't know any of the people who saw us - we didn't care if they saw us or not - so we continued walking. Just as I was looking at a very beautiful girl with a wide-brimmed hat sitting in a car outside Giulino's place, I felt Jonathan squeeze my arm painfully; he whispered, "Oh my God!" I'm always worried about Jonathan because I'm afraid of his nervous breakdown overwhelming him again; so I quickly turned to him and asked what was bothering him.
es: We returned to the city in silence and took a bus to the corner of Hyde Park. Jonathan thought I might be interested in going to the Row for a moment, so we sat down; but there were so few people there that it was sad and desolate to see so many empty chairs. It made us think of the empty chair we had at home; so we got up and walked towards Piccadilly. Jonathan held my hand, just as he used to do before I went to school. To me, it seemed very bold, because you can't spend years teaching etiquette and decorum to girls without the pedantry of it impressing you a little. But it was Jonathan, and he was my husband, and we didn't know anyone we saw (and we didn't care if they knew us), so we kept walking in the same way. I was looking at a very beautiful girl, with a carriage wheel hat, who was sitting in a victoria outside Giuliano's, when I felt Jonathan squeeze my hand so hard that it hurt, and he said in a whisper: "My God!" I am always anxious about Jonathan, as I always fear that some nervous attack might make him ill again; so I turned to him quickly and asked what had bothered him.

en: He was very pale, and his eyes seemed bulging out as, half in terror and half in amazement, he gazed at a tall, thin man, with a beaky nose and black moustache and pointed beard, who was also observing the pretty girl. He was looking at her so hard that he did not see either of us, and so I had a good view of him. His face was not a good face; it was hard, and cruel, and sensual, and his big white teeth, that looked all the whiter because his lips were so red, were pointed like an animal’s. Jonathan kept staring at him, till I was afraid he would notice. I feared he might take it ill, he looked so fierce and nasty. I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, and he answered, evidently thinking that I knew as much about it as he did: “Do you see who it is?”
vi: For some reason, his face suddenly turned pale as if there wasn't a drop of blood left, and his eyes seemed to bulge out with bloodshot veins. It seemed like he was paying attention to a tall, skinny man with a hooked nose like a hawk's, a black mustache, and a long, sharp beard in front of him. And that man was also staring intently at the young girl. He was so engrossed in looking at the girl that he didn't notice anyone around him, allowing me to comfortably observe him. His face truly didn't convey anything good. It looked stiff, rough, and filled with lust, with the most frightening part being his large, white horse-like teeth. Between his lips, red as chili peppers,those teeth appeared as sharp as those of a wild animal. Jonathan still stared blankly at the strange man. Suddenly, I felt afraid of him, because he indeed had something very suspicious about him. When I asked why he was so dazed, Jonathan responded as if I had known everything all along:
tr: He was very pale, and I saw that his eyes were bulging out of their sockets with a mix of half-terror and half-astonishment as he looked at the long, thin, hook-nosed man with a black mustache and a pointed beard who was watching that beautiful girl. The man was looking at the young girl so intently that he didn't see either of us, so I examined him closely. His face was not a good face; it was harsh, ruthless, and sensual, and his large white teeth, which appeared even whiter because his lips were excessively red, were pointed like those of an animal. Jonathan continued to look at him until he made me afraid that the man would notice. I feared that the man would misunderstand this, he looked very ruthless and rude. I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, thinking I had as much knowledge about the matter as he did: “Do you see who he is?”
es: He was very pale, and his eyes seemed to be popping out of their sockets, while, with a mixture of terror and astonishment, he stared fixedly at a tall, thin man with an aquiline nose, black mustache, and pointed beard, who was also observing the pretty girl. He was looking at her so intently that he didn't notice our presence, and because of that, I was able to get a good look at him. His face was not a good face; it was hard and cruel, and sensual, and his large white teeth, which looked even whiter against the bright red of his lips, were sharp like an animal's. Jonathan was staring at him so fixedly that I was even afraid the individual would notice. And I feared he would take it badly, as he looked so fierce and detestable. I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed, and he replied, evidently thinking that I knew as much as he did when he answered:

en: “No, dear,” I said; “I don’t know him; who is it?” His answer seemed to shock and thrill me, for it was said as if he did not know that it was to me, Mina, to whom he was speaking:—
vi: — Do you know him? — No, how would I know! Who is it? Your answer really shocked me. Listening to your voice, I felt like you no longer knew who I was: — It's really him...
tr: "No, dear," I said, "I don't know him; who is he?" The answer surprised and frightened me because it seemed as if it was said without knowing that the person being spoken to was me, Mina:
es: –Don't you see who is there? –No, dear -I said-; I don't know him, who is he? Her response impressed me and filled me with anxiety, as she gave it as if she didn't know it was me, her Mina, she was speaking to:

en: “It is the man himself!”
vi: It's really him!
tr: "That's the man himself!""
es: –It's the man himself.

en: The poor dear was evidently terrified at something—very greatly terrified; I do believe that if he had not had me to lean on and to support him he would have sunk down. He kept staring; a man came out of the shop with a small parcel, and gave it to the lady, who then drove off. The dark man kept his eyes fixed on her, and when the carriage moved up Piccadilly he followed in the same direction, and hailed a hansom. Jonathan kept looking after him, and said, as if to himself:—
vi: Clearly, my dear husband was terrified, or more precisely, he was utterly petrified by something. I believe that if he hadn't leaned on me, he would have surely collapsed to the ground. He seemed to be hypnotized by a man who was completely unfamiliar to me. Suddenly, a man stepped out of a shop, walked towards the young girl, and handed her a package. The stranger continued to stare intently at the girl. When the car started moving in the opposite direction towards Piccadilly, he hurriedly called for a cab to chase after it. Jonathan continued to stare blankly, and after a moment, he mumbled as if speaking to himself:
tr: It was clear that my poor lover was afraid of something - extremely afraid; if I hadn't been there to support and be with her, she would have collapsed. She continued to watch the man; a man came out of the shop with a small package and handed it to the young lady who drove away in her car after receiving it. The dark man's eyes were on the girl, and as the car moved along Piccadilly, he followed in the same direction and called for a carriage. Jonathan continued to watch after him and said as if talking to himself:
es: My poor beloved was evidently terrified by something; very terrified. I truly believe that if he hadn't had me to lean on and to hold him, he would have collapsed. He stood staring in amazement; a man came out of the shop with a small package and gave it to the lady, who then resumed her walk. The mysterious man kept his eyes fixed on the beautiful lady, and when the carriage moved away down Piccadilly, he followed in the same direction and hired a cabriolet. Jonathan followed him with his gaze, and said, as if to himself:

en: “I believe it is the Count, but he has grown young. My God, if this be so! Oh, my God! my God! If I only knew! if I only knew!” He was distressing himself so much that I feared to keep his mind on the subject by asking him any questions, so I remained silent. I drew him away quietly, and he, holding my arm, came easily. We walked a little further, and then went in and sat for a while in the Green Park. It was a hot day for autumn, and there was a comfortable seat in a shady place. After a few minutes’ staring at nothing, Jonathan’s eyes closed, and he went quietly into a sleep, with his head on my shoulder. I thought it was the best thing for him, so did not disturb him. In about twenty minutes he woke up, and said to me quite cheerfully:—
vi: — That's right, I'm sure it was the old count, but he seems to look younger, doesn't he? My God! If that was him... Oh! My God, My God! If only I knew, if only... I had to restrain myself from asking any questions, because I feared that if I did otherwise, I would remind him of thoughts that would make him suffer as if being tortured. So I had to keep silent and lead him to continue walking towards a garden named Green Campus. The autumn weather today was unbearably hot, and we had to find a stone bench under a dense bush to sit and rest. Jonathan stared blankly into the distance like a lost soul, but he could only sit for a moment before leaning his head on my shoulder, his eyes tightly closed, as he drifted into a peaceful sleep. I suddenly felt happy seeing him sleep. Clearly, he was no longer tormented by his illness as before. About twenty minutes later, he woke up and spoke to me in a very cheerful voice:
tr: “I think it was the Count, but younger. My God, if it is! Oh, my God! My God! If only I knew! If only I knew!” He was tormenting himself so much that I was afraid to ask questions and occupy his mind with the subject, so I remained silent. I quietly led him away from there, he came without resistance, holding my arm. We walked a bit more and went to Green Park and sat there for a while. It was a warm day for autumn, and there was a comfortable bench in the shade. After staring into space for a few minutes, Jonathan's eyes closed and he fell asleep quietly with his head on my shoulder. I thought this was the best thing for him, so I did not disturb him. He woke up in about twenty minutes and said quite cheerfully:
es: –I think it's the count, but he has rejuvenated a lot. My God! Oh, my God! My God! If I only knew, if I only knew! I was so nervous that I feared hurting him by asking questions, so I kept silent. Very gently, I began to lead him away from the place, and he, holding onto my arm, followed me easily. We walked a bit more and then sat for a while in Green Park. It was a hot day for autumn, and there was a fairly comfortable seat in a shaded spot. After staring into space for a few minutes, Jonathan closed his eyes and quickly fell asleep, with his head resting on my shoulder. I thought it was best for him, and I didn't wake him. After about twenty minutes, he woke up and said to me quite cheerfully:

en: “Why, Mina, have I been asleep! Oh, do forgive me for being so rude. Come, and we’ll have a cup of tea somewhere.” He had evidently forgotten all about the dark stranger, as in his illness he had forgotten all that this episode had reminded him of. I don’t like this lapsing into forgetfulness; it may make or continue some injury to the brain. I must not ask him, for fear I shall do more harm than good; but I must somehow learn the facts of his journey abroad. The time is come, I fear, when I must open that parcel, and know what is written. Oh, Jonathan, you will, I know, forgive me if I do wrong, but it is for your own dear sake.
vi: — Mina! So I finally got some sleep. Oh! Sorry, my love... Come on, let's find a place to have some tea. I understand that you have completely forgotten our meeting with that strange man, and in your pathological state, you have also forgotten all the memories that meeting evoked in you. But even so, I still do not dare to ask any questions, because I am certain that doing so would only cause unforeseeable harmful consequences rather than a good result. However, no matter what, I must find out about your recent journey abroad. Perhaps it is time for me to untie the blue ribbon binding your notebook. Oh, Jonathan, please forgive me! I always understand what I am doing, I will have to read what you wrote in that notebook. If I do so, it is only because of you.
tr: “Ah! Did I fall asleep, Mina? Oh, forgive me for being so rude. Come, let's sit somewhere and have some tea.” Clearly, due to his illness, he had forgotten everything this event reminded him of, as well as everything related to the dark gentleman. I do not like this state of forgetfulness; it could damage the brain or sustain existing damage. I must not ask him, because I fear causing more harm than good; but somehow, I must learn the facts about his journey abroad. I fear the time has come to open that bundle and find out what is written inside. Ah, Jonathan, I know you will forgive me if I am making a mistake, but this is for your dear sake.
es: –But, Mina, I fell asleep! Oh, forgive me for being so inattentive! Come; we'll have a cup of tea somewhere. Evidently, he had forgotten everything related to the strange stranger, just as during his illness he had forgotten everything that this episode had reminded him of again. I don't like these attacks of amnesia; it can cause or prolong some brain ailment. But I must not ask him about it, for fear of causing him more harm than good; however, I must somehow learn the facts of his trip abroad. I fear the time has come when I must open that package and know what it contains. Oh, Jonathan, you will forgive me, I know, if I do wrong, but it is for your own sacred good!

en: Later.—A sad home-coming in every way—the house empty of the dear soul who was so good to us; Jonathan still pale and dizzy under a slight relapse of his malady; and now a telegram from Van Helsing, whoever he may be:—
vi: • A moment later A sorrowful return home not just for one reason. Indeed, so many things! Jonathan still looked as pale as a truly sick person. Moreover, there was a telegram from a certain Mr. Van Helsing waiting for us:
tr: Later on. -A sorrowful return home from every angle- the dear person who treated us so well is not at home; Jonathan, still pale and dazed due to a slight relapse of his illness; a telegram from someone named Van Helsing:
es: Later. It was a sad return home in all respects: the empty house of the dear deceased who had been so kind to us: Jonathan still pale and dazed under a slight relapse of his illness, now a telegram from Van Helsing, whoever he may be: "I regret to inform you that Mrs. Westenra died five days ago, and that Lucy died the day before yesterday.

en: “You will be grieved to hear that Mrs. Westenra died five days ago, and that Lucy died the day before yesterday. They were both buried to-day.”
vi: “I deeply regret to inform you about the sudden death of Mrs. Westenra five days ago and the death of her daughter Lucy the day before yesterday. Both have been properly buried today.”
tr: You will be sorry to learn that Ms. Westenra died five days ago and that Lucy also died the day before yesterday. Both were buried today.
es: It was a sad return home in all respects: the empty house of the dear deceased who had been so kind to us: Jonathan still pale and dazed under a slight relapse of his illness, now a telegram from Van Helsing, whoever he may be: "I regret to inform you that Mrs. Westenra died five days ago, and that Lucy died the day before yesterday. Both were buried today."

en: Oh, what a wealth of sorrow in a few words! Poor Mrs. Westenra! poor Lucy! Gone, gone, never to return to us! And poor, poor Arthur, to have lost such sweetness out of his life! God help us all to bear our troubles.
vi: Oh my God? How can just a few lines contain so much sorrow? Poor Mrs. Westenra? Poor Lucy! So they have gone, gone forever! Poor, poor Arthur, life for him now is nothing but a miserable and dull existence! May God help us overcome this pain?
tr: Ah, what great sorrow conveyed in just a few words! Poor Ms. Westenra! Poor Lucy! They have gone, never to return to us again, gone! And poor, poor Arthur, who has lost such sweetness from his life! God, help us to endure our troubles.
es: Oh, what a heap of sorrows in so few words! Poor Mrs. Westenra! Poor Lucy! They are gone; they are gone never to return to us again! And poor, poor Arthur, who has lost such sweetness from his life! God help us to bear all our sorrows.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 22 September.—It is all over. Arthur has gone back to Ring, and has taken Quincey Morris with him. What a fine fellow is Quincey! I believe in my heart of hearts that he suffered as much about Lucy’s death as any of us; but he bore himself through it like a moral Viking. If America can go on breeding men like that, she will be a power in the world indeed. Van Helsing is lying down, having a rest preparatory to his journey. He goes over to Amsterdam to-night, but says he returns to-morrow night; that he only wants to make some arrangements which can only be made personally. He is to stop with me then, if he can; he says he has work to do in London which may take him some time. Poor old fellow! I fear that the strain of the past week has broken down even his iron strength. All the time of the burial he was, I could see, putting some terrible restraint on himself. When it was all over, we were standing beside Arthur, who, poor fellow, was speaking of his part in the operation where his blood had been transfused to his Lucy’s veins; I could see Van Helsing’s face grow white and purple by turns. Arthur was saying that he felt since then as if they two had been really married and that she was his wife in the sight of God. None of us said a word of the other operations, and none of us ever shall. Arthur and Quincey went away together to the station, and Van Helsing and I came on here. The moment we were alone in the carriage he gave way to a regular fit of hysterics. He has denied to me since that it was hysterics, and insisted that it was only his sense of humour asserting itself under very terrible conditions. He laughed till he cried, and I had to draw down the blinds lest any one should see us and misjudge; and then he cried, till he laughed again; and laughed and cried together, just as a woman does. I tried to be stern with him, as one is to a woman under the circumstances; but it had no effect. Men and women are so different in manifestations of nervous strength or weakness! Then when his face grew grave and stern again I asked him why his mirth, and why at such a time. His reply was in a way characteristic of him, for it was logical and forceful and mysterious. He said:—
vi: • September 22 Everything is done. Arthur returned to Ring with Quincey Morris. Quincey is indeed a very likable young man. He was as grieved by Lucy's death as any of us, yet he knew how to maintain a calm demeanor with the courage of a Norse pirate. If America continues to produce men like him, it will soon become a world power. As for Van Helsing, he took a bit of rest before heading back home. He had to return to Amsterdam to handle some personal matters. However, he planned to go to London tomorrow evening and stay there if possible to deal with a rather time-consuming matter. To be honest, I still worry that his enduring stamina may not last as long as it used to. At the funeral, I noticed he showed some slightly unusual signs. When the work was done, we gathered around Arthur as he emotionally spoke about the blood he had given to Lucy. I saw Van Helsing's face turn from pale to crimson. Arthur said that since he gave his blood to Lucy, he felt she had truly become his wife in the eyes of God. Of course, we were not foolish enough to mention the other blood transfusions that Arthur did not know about, and we would certainly never reveal that. Arthur and Quincey led each other to the station, while Van Helsing and I returned here. We had just gotten into the carriage when the professor suddenly had a seizure, I mean his nerves were extremely agitated. But later, he firmly denied this agitation. He explained that it was merely a humorous feeling after all the terrible events that had occurred. He laughed, laughed until he cried, laughed so hard that I had to lower all the curtains around the carriage so that outsiders wouldn't see him in such an abnormal state, and then he cried, truly cried, like a child. After that, I had to witness him laugh again, laughing hysterically. Finally, he was both laughing and crying, crying bitterly like a woman, or rather like a madman. I tried my best to comfort and soothe him, even sternly told him to stay calm, but all my efforts were in vain. So I let him be mad, until he got tired of it. In similar situations, women often react differently than men. Finally, when his face returned to its usual serious and important look, I dared to ask what had made him laugh in such a sad moment. He answered quite logically, but also as incomprehensibly as he himself is. — Ah!
tr: September 22 - Everything is over. Arthur returned to the Ring and took Quincey Morris with him. Quincey is such a good man! I truly believe that he suffered as much as we did because of Lucy's death; but he behaved like a virtuous Viking during that time. If America continues to raise such men, it will indeed be a significant power in the world. Van Helsing is lying down to rest before his journey. He is going to Amsterdam tonight, but he says he will return tomorrow night, and that he only wants to make some arrangements that he needs to handle personally. Then, if he can manage, he will stay with me; he says he has some business in London that might take up some of his time. Poor old man! I fear the tension of the past week has worn down his iron strength. Throughout the entire funeral, I could see that he was holding himself terribly tight. When everything was over, we were standing next to poor Arthur, who was talking about his role in the transfusion of his own blood into Lucy's veins; I could see Van Helsing's face turning alternately white and purple. Arthur has been saying since then that he feels as if they were truly married, as if Lucy were his wife in the eyes of God. Neither of us spoke a word about the other procedures, and we never will. Arthur and Quincey went to the station together, and Van Helsing and I came here. As soon as we were alone in the carriage, Van Helsing had a hysterical fit. Since then, he has been denying that it was hysteria and says it was just his sense of humor showing itself under terrible circumstances. He laughed until he started crying, and I had to lower the blinds so no one would see us and misunderstand; then he cried until he laughed again; then he both laughed and cried at the same time like a woman. I tried to be stern with him, just as one would be with women in such a situation; but it had no effect. The ways in which women and men express their nervous strengths and weaknesses are so different! Then, when his face took on a serious and stern expression, I asked him why he had been cheerful and why he had been cheerful at such a time. His answer was unique, because it was logical, impressive, and mysterious. He said:
es: September 22. Everything has culminated. Arthur has returned to Ring and has taken Quincey Morris with him. What a magnificent fellow this Quincey is! I believe deep in my heart that he suffered as much as any of us did over Lucy's death; but he managed to overcome his grief like a stoic. If America can continue producing men like this, there is no doubt that it will become a great power in the world. Van Helsing is lying down, taking a preparatory rest for his journey. He is going to leave for Amsterdam tonight, but he says he will return tomorrow night; he just wants to make some arrangements that can only be done in person. When he returns, if he can, he will stay at my house; he says he has work to do in London that may take some time. Poor old friend! I fear that the effort of the past few weeks has broken even his iron strength. During the entire time of the funeral, I could see that he was making a terrible effort to restrain himself. When everything was over, we were standing next to Arthur, who, poor thing, was talking about his part in the operation when his blood was transferred to Lucy's veins; I could see that van Helsing's face was turning alternately white and purple. Arthur was saying that since then he felt as if the two had really been married and that she was his wife in the eyes of God. None of us said a word about the other operations, and none of us ever will. Arthur and Quincey went together to the station, and van Helsing and I came back here. The moment we were alone in the carriage, he gave free rein to a regular fit of hysteria. Since then he has refused to admit that it was hysteria, and insists that it was only his sense of humor manifesting under very terrible conditions. He laughed until he cried and I had to lower the blinds so that no one could see us and misinterpret the situation; and then he cried until he laughed again; and he laughed and cried at the same time, just like a woman does. I tried to be stern with him, in the same way one is with a woman in similar circumstances; but it had no effect. Men and women are so different in their nervous strength or weakness! Then, when his face became grave and serious again, I asked him the reason for his joy and why precisely at that moment. His reply was in some way characteristic of him, as it was logical, full of strength and mystery. He said:

en: “Ah, you don’t comprehend, friend John. Do not think that I am not sad, though I laugh. See, I have cried even when the laugh did choke me. But no more think that I am all sorry when I cry, for the laugh he come just the same. Keep it always with you that laughter who knock at your door and say, ‘May I come in?’ is not the true laughter. No! he is a king, and he come when and how he like. He ask no person; he choose no time of suitability. He say, ‘I am here.’ Behold, in example I grieve my heart out for that so sweet young girl; I give my blood for her, though I am old and worn; I give my time, my skill, my sleep; I let my other sufferers want that so she may have all. And yet I can laugh at her very grave—laugh when the clay from the spade of the sexton drop upon her coffin and say ‘Thud! thud!’ to my heart, till it send back the blood from my cheek. My heart bleed for that poor boy—that dear boy, so of the age of mine own boy had I been so blessed that he live, and with his hair and eyes the same. There, you know now why I love him so. And yet when he say things that touch my husband-heart to the quick, and make my father-heart yearn to him as to no other man—not even to you, friend John, for we are more level in experiences than father and son—yet even at such moment King Laugh he come to me and shout and bellow in my ear, ‘Here I am! here I am!’ till the blood come dance back and bring some of the sunshine that he carry with him to my cheek. Oh, friend John, it is a strange world, a sad world, a world full of miseries, and woes, and troubles; and yet when King Laugh come he make them all dance to the tune he play. Bleeding hearts, and dry bones of the churchyard, and tears that burn as they fall—all dance together to the music that he make with that smileless mouth of him. And believe me, friend John, that he is good to come, and kind. Ah, we men and women are like ropes drawn tight with strain that pull us different ways. Then tears come; and, like the rain on the ropes, they brace us up, until perhaps the strain become too great, and we break. But King Laugh he come like the sunshine, and he ease off the strain again; and we bear to go on with our labour, what it may be.”
vi: My friend John, you still don't understand me! Don't think that just because I laugh, I'm not sad. I have cried even when I was forced to laugh out loud! But don't believe that I only express sadness when I cry. Never forget the laughter that comes knocking at your door and asks: "May I come in?" That is not genuine laughter. Never! That laughter is a king, it comes to your house when it sees your house is happy in its own way! It doesn't need anyone's permission, only joy matters to it. For example, day and night I am tormented by that gentle young girl, even though I am old and tired, I still intend to donate blood to save her. I still devote my time, knowledge, and even my sleep to her. I have neglected my other patients to give everything to her. That's it! Yet in just a moment, I burst out laughing right in front of her grave, laughing continuously, making my face flush red. That's not all. My heart also tightened when I thought of that poor young man - a young man about the age of my son if I had been fortunate enough to keep him; how their eyes, noses, and hair are so similar, I don't know! Now you understand why I cherish that young man so much, don't you? Even so, when he talked to us about the marital love he never once enjoyed, he moved me and left a strange attraction in my paternal heart that I had never experienced with my students. Of course, the same goes for you, my friend John, because everything we have done and lived through together has only brought us a more equal relationship rather than a father-son bond. I repeat, even so, the King of Laughter still comes and shouts in my ear: "Here I am, I have arrived!", so loudly that I feel a surge of blood rushing through me, making my face flush red like the sun. That's it, my friend, our world is truly strange! A world of boredom, hardship, misfortune, and always full of worries. However, when the King of Laughter arrives, everyone starts dancing together in the atmosphere that he always finds satisfying! Bleeding hearts, skeletons lying in the cemetery, burning tears on cheeks, all suddenly join in dancing together to the music emanating from the mouth of the King of Laughter. Believe me, my friend, we will have to be grateful to him! Because we, men and women alike, can be compared to strings stretched at both ends, and then there are tears falling, like raindrops on each key, suddenly making us tense up until, at some point, the tension becomes truly unbearable, and we snap. Right at that boundary, the King of Laughter suddenly appears like a ray of sunshine, loosening the string, and we can continue our work regardless of our current state.
tr: ‘Ah, you don't understand, my friend John. Even if I laugh, don't think that I'm not sad. Look, I cried even while choking with laughter. Always remember that the laughter knocking on your door and asking, ‘May I come in?’ is not real laughter. No! It is a king and comes whenever and however it wants. It doesn't ask anyone, it doesn't wait for the right time. ‘I have arrived,’ it says. Look, for example, my heart bleeds for that very sweet young girl; despite being old and exhausted, I give my blood for her; I give my time, my talent, my sleep; just so she can have it all, I allow my other patients to be deprived of it. But still, I can laugh right at her grave - while the soil falls on her coffin from the sexton's shovel until the blood drains from my cheeks and it calls out to my heart, ‘Pat! Pat!’ I can laugh. My heart bleeds for that poor child - for the beloved child who would be the same age as my own son if he had lived and whose hair and eyes would be just like his. Now you know why I love her so much. But when it strikes my husbandly heart at its core and causes my fatherly heart to be more emotional than for anyone else - not even for you, my friend John, because our experiences are more equal than those of father and son - even at such times, King Laughter comes to me, dancing with blood, bringing some of the daylight he carries to my cheek, shouting in my ear, ‘Here I am! Here I am! ’Ah, my friend John, this world is a strange, sorrowful world, full of unhappiness, pain, and trouble, and when King Laughter comes, he makes everything dance to the tune they play. Bleeding hearts, dry bones in the churchyard, and tears burning as they fall - they all dance to the music made by his unsmiling mouth. And believe me, my friend John, it's a good thing he comes. Ah, we men and women are like taut strings pulling us in different directions. The last tears come; like raindrops on the strings, perhaps they strengthen us until the tension is too much and we snap. But King Laughter comes like daylight, easing the tension again, and whatever the task is, we endure to continue our work.”
es: –Ah, you do not understand, friend John. Do not think that I am not sad, even though I laugh. Look, I have cried even when laughter choked me. But do not think that I am entirely sad when I cry, for laughter would have come in the same way. Always remember that the laughter that knocks on your door and says, "may I come in?" is not true laughter. No! Laughter is a queen, and it arrives when and how it wants. It does not ask anyone; it does not choose time or appropriateness. It says: "here I am." Remember, for example, I hurt in my heart for that young sweet girl; I give my blood for her, even though I am old and worn out; I gave my time, my skill, my sleep; I let my others suffer need so that she could have everything. And yet, I can laugh at her own grave, laugh when the gravedigger's shovel earth fell on her coffin and said thud!, thud!, over my heart, until it drained the blood from my cheeks. My heart bled for that poor boy, that dear boy, so much the age my own boy would have been if he had blessedly lived, and with hair and eyes so alike. Well, now you know why I love him so much. And yet, when he says things that move my man's heart so deeply, and make my father's heart nostalgic for him like no other man, not even you, friend John, because we are more balanced in experiences than a father and a son, for even then, in those moments, the queen laughter comes to me and shouts and roars in my ear: "here I am, here I am!", until laughter comes dancing again and brings with it some of the sunshine that she brings to my cheeks. Oh, friend John, it is a strange world, a world full of miseries, and threats, and troubles, and yet, when the queen laughter comes, it makes us all dance to the tune she plays. Bleeding hearts, and dry bones in cemeteries, and tears that burn as they fall... all dance together to the same music that she plays with that laughterless mouth she possesses. And believe me, friend John, she is good to come, and kind. Ah, we men and women are like strings in the midst of different forces pulling us in different directions. Then come the tears; and like rain on the strings, they tighten us, until perhaps the tension becomes too great and we break. But the queen laughter, she comes like the sunshine, and relieves the tension again; and we can endure and continue with our work, whatever it may be.

en: I did not like to wound him by pretending not to see his idea; but, as I did not yet understand the cause of his laughter, I asked him. As he answered me his face grew stern, and he said in quite a different tone:—
vi: I did not intend to hurt the professor when I confessed to him that I did not understand anything about his philosophy. Although he had explained, I still could not determine the reason why he laughed so uproariously. I was forced to frankly admit to him about my lack of wisdom. — Oh dear! - He continued to explain. -
tr: I didn't want to hurt him by pretending not to understand his thought; but since I still didn't understand the reason for his laughter, I asked him about it. As he replied to me, his face hardened and in a rather different tone, he said:
es: I didn't want to hurt him by pretending I didn't see his idea; but, since I didn't understand the reasons for his joy anyway, I asked him. When he responded, his face became very serious, and he told me in a rather different tone:

en: “Oh, it was the grim irony of it all—this so lovely lady garlanded with flowers, that looked so fair as life, till one by one we wondered if she were truly dead; she laid in that so fine marble house in that lonely churchyard, where rest so many of her kin, laid there with the mother who loved her, and whom she loved; and that sacred bell going ‘Toll! toll! toll!’ so sad and slow; and those holy men, with the white garments of the angel, pretending to read books, and yet all the time their eyes never on the page; and all of us with the bowed head. And all for what? She is dead; so! Is it not?”
vi: It was nothing more than the most tragic irony! The gentle girl lay quietly among the pure white flowers. She was as beautiful as life itself, so beautiful that each of us had to ask ourselves if she was truly dead or not. Now the girl is peacefully resting for eternity under a stone grave in a distant cemetery, where her dearest loved ones are also at rest. Oh God! How sad and mournful that funeral bell sounded! And the solemn priests reciting prayers in their white robes. And we all bowed our heads in reverence. Why is that? Isn't she already dead?
tr: “Ah, the bitter irony among all this was - this beautiful lady, adorned with flowers, looking so lovely as if she were still alive until we each wondered if she was really dead; she lies in that beautiful marble house in the desolate churchyard, where many of her kin rest, where she lies with her mother who loved her dearly and whom she loved dearly; that sacred bell tolls 'Ding! Ding! Ding!' sadly and slowly; those holy men, pretending to read books in angelic white garments, but their eyes never go to the pages; all our heads are bowed. What is all this for? She is dead; well! Isn't she?”
es: –Oh, it was the sad irony of it all, this charming lady adorned with flowers, who looked as fresh as if she were alive, so that one by one we doubted whether she was really dead; she lying in that fine marble house in the lonely cemetery, where so many of her kind rest, lying there with her mother who loved her so much, and whom she loved in return; and that sacred bell going: dong!, dong!, dong!, so sad and slow; and those holy men, in the white robes of the angel, pretending to read books, and yet, all the time their eyes were never on a page; and all of us with our heads bowed. And all for what? She is dead; so then, is she not?

en: “Well, for the life of me, Professor,” I said, “I can’t see anything to laugh at in all that. Why, your explanation makes it a harder puzzle than before. But even if the burial service was comic, what about poor Art and his trouble? Why, his heart was simply breaking.”
vi: — But Professor, I still don't see anything funny in what you just said! In fact, I find your explanation increasingly convoluted. If there is something funny about the burial, is it possible that poor Arthur, a man falling into the depths of pain...
tr: “Eh, whatever I do, Professor,” I said, “I can't see anything to laugh about in this. Your explanation has turned it into an even more difficult riddle. Even if the funeral ceremony was ridiculous, what about poor Art and his suffering. His heart was clearly breaking.”
es: –Well, for my part, professor -I said to him-, I don't see anything in all that which is funny. The truth is that your explanation makes it even harder to understand. But even if the funeral service was comical, what about poor Art and his problems? Because I think his heart was simply breaking.

en: “Just so. Said he not that the transfusion of his blood to her veins had made her truly his bride?”
vi: — Exactly! Didn't he say that the blood he donated to Lucy made her his wife?
tr: "Absolutely so. Didn’t he say that with the transfusion of his blood into her veins, Lucy was truly his wife?"
es: –Exactly. Did he say that the transfusion of his blood into her veins had made her his true wife?

en: “Yes, and it was a sweet and comforting idea for him.”
vi: — It is true that Arthur thought so, but that is something that would comfort him.
tr: "Yes, and this was a sweet and comforting thought for him."
es: –Yes, and it was a sweet and consoling idea for him.

en: “Quite so. But there was a difficulty, friend John. If so that, then what about the others? Ho, ho! Then this so sweet maid is a polyandrist, and me, with my poor wife dead to me, but alive by Church’s law, though no wits, all gone—even I, who am faithful husband to this now-no-wife, am bigamist.”
vi: — Yes! But if that's the case, there will be trouble. Because if just giving blood makes Arthur feel that Lucy is his wife, then wouldn't that mean she is also our wife? Ha! Ha! So Lucy, sweet gentle Lucy, has many husbands. As for me, I could also say that I lost a dear wife, but the Church and heaven still have her. I have become a faithful husband to a wife who is no longer on this earth, making me a man with two wives!
tr: “No doubt. But there was a problem there, my friend John. If so, then what about the others? Ha, ha! Then this sweet young girl is polyandrous and I, with my wife who is dead to me but still alive by Church law, but without a mind, completely gone in the head – even I am bigamous with this now non-existent wife.”
es: –That's right. But there was a difficulty, my friend John. If that was the case, what about the others? Ha, ha! Well, this poor and sweet maiden is a polyandrist, and I, with my poor wife dead to me but alive to the law of the church, though without jokes, free from everything, even I, who am a faithful husband to this current non-wife, am a bigamist.

en: “I don’t see where the joke comes in there either!” I said; and I did not feel particularly pleased with him for saying such things. He laid his hand on my arm, and said:—
vi: — I still don't see anything funny! - I have to admit my confusion once again, - Because in fact, your remarks are still not interesting. He patted my shoulder and continued his explanations:
tr: “I don't see what's so funny here!” I said; I wasn't very pleased with him for saying such things. He put his hand on my arm and said:
es: –Well, I don't see what's funny here either -I said, and I didn't feel very happy with him because he was saying those things. He put his hand on my arm and said:

en: “Friend John, forgive me if I pain. I showed not my feeling to others when it would wound, but only to you, my old friend, whom I can trust. If you could have looked into my very heart then when I want to laugh; if you could have done so when the laugh arrived; if you could do so now, when King Laugh have pack up his crown, and all that is to him—for he go far, far away from me, and for a long, long time—maybe you would perhaps pity me the most of all.”
vi: — My friend John, I'm sorry if I gave you a headache. I don't have the habit of casually sharing my feelings with others, because it can easily hurt them. But with you, it's different, John. If only you could see everything happening deep in my heart when I'm laughing, or when laughter appears on my lips, if only you could see what continues to be hidden in my heart when the Lord of Laughter has taken off his crown and robe - for he will go very far, very far from me for a very, very long time - then surely among us, I would be the one you feel most sorry for. — Why is that? - I asked, feeling truly moved when I heard him say the last sentence. - In short, I still don't understand your heart.
tr: “My friend John, if I am causing pain, forgive me. While I could have hurt others, I did not show my feelings to them, but I can show them only to you, my old friend whom I trust. If you could look deep into my heart when I wanted to laugh; if you could have done this when laughter came; if you could do this now, as King Laughter is gathering his crown and everything to go far, far away from me for a very, very long time, perhaps you would pity me more than anyone else.”
es: –Friend John, forgive me if I cause pain. I did not show my feelings to others when they would have hurt, but only to you, my old friend, in whom I can trust. If you could have looked inside my own heart then, when I wanted to laugh; if you could have done so when the laughter came, if you could do so, when the queen laughter has packed her crowns, and all that is hers, for she goes far away, very far from me, and for a long time, a very long time, perhaps you might pity me more than anyone.

en: I was touched by the tenderness of his tone, and asked why.
vi: — Why?
tr: The kindness in her voice touched me deeply, and I asked why.
es: I was moved by the tenderness of her tone and asked her why.

en: “Because I know!”
vi: Because I know it is so!
tr: “Because I know!”
es: –Because I know!

en: And now we are all scattered; and for many a long day loneliness will sit over our roofs with brooding wings. Lucy lies in the tomb of her kin, a lordly death-house in a lonely churchyard, away from teeming London; where the air is fresh, and the sun rises over Hampstead Hill, and where wild flowers grow of their own accord.
vi: Now we have said our goodbyes, each of us returning to the loneliness under our own cold roofs. So Lucy now rests in the family tomb, a silent grave nestled in an ancient cemetery, where the everyday sounds of London cannot reach, the atmosphere untouched by the dust of life, only graced by the golden rays of the sun gently descending from the Hampstead hilltop and the wildflowers scattered across the lush, velvet-like green grass.
tr: And now we are all in a wretched state; for long days, loneliness will sit with its wings deep in thought above our roofs. Lucy lies in the grand house of the dead in the deserted churchyard, far from the crowded London, among the graves of her relatives; here the air is clean, the sun rises over Hampstead Hill, and wildflowers grow on their own.
es: And now we are all scattered; and for many long days, solitude will sit upon our roofs with its wings outspread. Lucy rests in her family's tomb, a stately mausoleum in a solitary cemetery, far from prolific London, where the air is fresh and the sun rises over Hampstead Hill, and where wildflowers grow according to their own accord.

en: So I can finish this diary; and God only knows if I shall ever begin another. If I do, or if I even open this again, it will be to deal with different people and different themes; for here at the end, where the romance of my life is told, ere I go back to take up the thread of my life-work, I say sadly and without hope,
vi: So I can end these diary entries now. Only God knows when I will start another self-confession. If I have another chance like this, or if I continue these diary entries, I will surely write about different people or entirely different stories.
tr: Thus, I can now finish this journal; only God knows whether I will start a new one or not. If I do start or open this one again, it will be to talk about different people and different subjects; because here, where the story of the love of my life is told, I say with sorrow and hopelessness before I return to taking control of my professional life.
es: So I can finish this diary; and only God knows if I will ever start another. If I do start one, or if I merely open this one again, it will deal with different people and different subjects; for here at the end, where the romance of my life is narrated, here I take up the thread of my daily work again, and I say it sadly and without hope.

en: “FINIS.”
vi: After recording the entire story of my unrequited love and before returning to the life of work, I let out a sorrowful sigh that contained not a hint of hope.
tr: SON
es: THE END

en: A HAMPSTEAD MYSTERY.
vi: A mystery in Hampstead
tr: THE HAMPSTEAD MYSTERY
es: A MYSTERY OF HAMPSTEAD

en: The neighbourhood of Hampstead is just at present exercised with a series of events which seem to run on lines parallel to those of what was known to the writers of headlines as “The Kensington Horror,” or “The Stabbing Woman,” or “The Woman in Black.” During the past two or three days several cases have occurred of young children straying from home or neglecting to return from their playing on the Heath. In all these cases the children were too young to give any properly intelligible account of themselves, but the consensus of their excuses is that they had been with a “bloofer lady.” It has always been late in the evening when they have been missed, and on two occasions the children have not been found until early in the following morning. It is generally supposed in the neighbourhood that, as the first child missed gave as his reason for being away that a “bloofer lady” had asked him to come for a walk, the others had picked up the phrase and used it as occasion served. This is the more natural as the favourite game of the little ones at present is luring each other away by wiles. A correspondent writes us that to see some of the tiny tots pretending to be the “bloofer lady” is supremely funny. Some of our caricaturists might, he says, take a lesson in the irony of grotesque by comparing the reality and the picture. It is only in accordance with general principles of human nature that the “bloofer lady” should be the popular rôle at these al fresco performances. Our correspondent naïvely says that even Ellen Terry could not be so winningly attractive as some of these grubby-faced little children pretend—and even imagine themselves—to be.
vi: The surrounding areas of Hampstead are experiencing many events reminiscent of the incidents we once discussed in articles titled: The Horror in Kensington, or The Stabbed Woman, or The Woman in Black. Indeed, for the past two or three days, there has been much gossip about children disappearing from home, or more precisely, not being seen returning home after playing in the fields. Granted, the children are too young to provide convincing explanations for their absences, but every time they return, they say they followed a "blood-stained woman." And every time, as soon as it gets dark, they are nowhere to be seen. Two of the missing children were only found at dawn the next day. When the first missing child returned home, they recounted that the "blood-stained woman" had lured them to go for a walk with her. Other cases also reported a similar story. We all know that children these days do not like to imitate each other, so the idea that they all lied and snuck out overnight is impossible. One of our correspondents reported that he saw some boys mimicking the mannerisms and gestures of the "blood-stained woman" in a very amusing way. If they wish, our cartoonists could learn a lot by watching these boys' imitations!
tr: The Hampstead area is currently experiencing exciting days due to a series of developments similar to the events known as the "Kensington Horror" or the "Stabbing Woman" or the "Woman in Black" in the headlines. In the last two or three days, there have been numerous incidents involving small children who have wandered away from home or gone to play on the Heath and not returned. In all these cases, the children were too young to properly express themselves, but the common point in their supposed explanations was that they were with a "beautiful" lady. They all disappeared late at night, and in two cases, the children were not found until the early hours of the next day. There was a widespread belief that the first of the missing children used the excuse that "the beautiful lady said she wanted to take a walk with him," and the others followed this example as an excuse. These days, it is very understandable since the favorite thing of the little ones is to distract each other with small games. One of the reporters writes that it is extremely funny to see the little children playing "beautiful lady." He adds that some of our cartoonists could take lessons from these children on the fine satire of the grotesque that emerges when reality is compared to representation. The fact that the "beautiful lady" is the favorite role in these alfresco games is in harmony with the general principles of human nature. Our reporter naively states that even Ellen Terry could not have the charming appeal of some of these dirty-faced little children who are acting - and even believe themselves to be - the "beautiful lady."
es: The neighborhood of Hampstead is currently being harassed by a series of events that seem to run parallel to those known by headline writers as "The Horror of Kensington," or "The Dagger Killer," or "The Woman in Black." Over the past two or three days, several cases have occurred of small children wandering away from their homes or forgetting to return from their play on the Heath. In all these cases, the children have been too young to provide an adequately intelligible explanation of what happened, but the consensus of their accounts is that they have been with the "bloofer lady." It has always been late at night when their absence has been noticed, and on two occasions the children were not found until early the next morning. In the neighborhood, it is generally assumed that, since the first lost child gave as his reason for being away that a "bloofer lady" had asked him to go with her for a walk, the others have picked up the phrase and used it on the appropriate occasion. This is all the more natural as the favorite game of the little ones is currently to lure each other through deceit. A correspondent writes to us that seeing the little ones pretending to be the "bloofer lady" is truly amusing. He says that some of our caricaturists should take a lesson in the irony of the grotesque by comparing reality and theater. It is only in accordance with the general principles of human nature that the "bloofer lady" should be the popular role in these open-air performances. Our correspondent naively says that not even Ellen Terry could be as delightfully attractive as some of these wrinkled-faced little ones pretend to be, and even imagine they are.

en: There is, however, possibly a serious side to the question, for some of the children, indeed all who have been missed at night, have been slightly torn or wounded in the throat. The wounds seem such as might be made by a rat or a small dog, and although of not much importance individually, would tend to show that whatever animal inflicts them has a system or method of its own. The police of the division have been instructed to keep a sharp look-out for straying children, especially when very young, in and around Hampstead Heath, and for any stray dog which may be about.
vi: However, the matter does not seem to be without serious issues, as two of the children, that is, the children who ran away overnight, had small bites on their necks. It appears that these were bites from a large rat or a small dog. Although nothing serious has occurred yet, the wounds all indicate one thing: whether it is a rat or a dog, the animal always bites people in the same consistent manner. The police have received orders to monitor children who often play around Hampstead Heath or in the surrounding areas, especially the younger ones, and to also watch out for any dogs that may be wandering nearby.
tr: But maybe the problem has a serious side because some of the children -actually all of those who disappeared at night- have small tears and wounds on their throats. The wounds seem to have been made by rats or small dogs, and although they are not very significant on their own, whatever animal made them shows that it has its own unique system or method. The local police were ordered to pay close attention to children wandering around Hampstead Heath and its surroundings, especially very young ones, and to any stray dogs that might be roaming the area.
es: However, there may be a serious side to the matter, as some of the children, in fact all those who have been lost during the night, have been slightly torn or injured in the throat. The wounds seem such that they could have been made by a rat or a small dog, and although individually they lack much importance, they tend to show that whatever animal causes them has its own system or method. The local police have been instructed to keep a sharp watch on stray children, especially if they are very young, in the vicinity and within Hampstead Heath, and also for any stray dog that may be around.

en: The “Bloofer Lady.”
vi: We have just received news that yet another child went missing at dusk yesterday and was only found this morning in a gorse bush on Hunter's Hill, an area of Hampstead Heath that is less frequented than other areas.
tr: "Beautiful lady"
es: The "Boastful Lady"

en: We have just received intelligence that another child, missed last night, was only discovered late in the morning under a furze bush at the Shooter’s Hill side of Hampstead Heath, which is, perhaps, less frequented than the other parts. It has the same tiny wound in the throat as has been noticed in other cases. It was terribly weak, and looked quite emaciated. It too, when partially restored, had the common story to tell of being lured away by the “bloofer lady.”
vi: We have just received news that yet another child went missing at dusk yesterday and was only found this morning in a gorse bush on Hunter's Hill, an area of Hampstead Heath that is less frequented than other areas. With a small bite mark on the neck identical to those of previous young victims, the boy was found in a weak and pale condition. After being brought home and calming down, the boy stated that he was also lured by the “blood-stained woman.”
tr: According to the news we just received, another child who went missing last night was only found the next morning around noon, at the base of a blackthorn bush on the Shooter’s Hill side, which is less frequented compared to other parts of Hamstead Heath. He also has the small wound on his neck that was noticed in the other cases. He was extremely weak and looked skin and bones. When he partially regained consciousness, he also told that common story about being lured by the “beautiful lady.”
es: We have just received news that another child lost last night could only be found late this morning under a broom shrub on the Shooter's Hill side of Hampstead Heath, which is perhaps less frequented than other parts. He had the same tiny wounds on his throat that have been noted in other cases. He was terribly weak and seemed quite exhausted. He too, when he had partially recovered, had the same story of being lured away by the "boisterous lady".

en: MINA HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF MINA HARKER

en: 23 September.—Jonathan is better after a bad night. I am so glad that he has plenty of work to do, for that keeps his mind off the terrible things; and oh, I am rejoiced that he is not now weighed down with the responsibility of his new position. I knew he would be true to himself, and now how proud I am to see my Jonathan rising to the height of his advancement and keeping pace in all ways with the duties that come upon him. He will be away all day till late, for he said he could not lunch at home. My household work is done, so I shall take his foreign journal, and lock myself up in my room and read it....
vi: • September 23 After a restless night, today, Jonathan seems to be doing better. I feel happy to see him working more, because only then will he stop overthinking. Indeed, I felt quite uplifted seeing him busy with new tasks, because I know he will prove to be worthy and capable of handling new responsibilities, no matter what they are! He was out all day and instructed not to have lunch at home. After finishing some small household chores, I nervously returned to my room to read the pages of the diary he had written during his journey to Transylvania...
tr: September 23. - We had a bad night, but Jonathan is better now. I'm glad he has a lot of work to do because it keeps his mind off the dreadful things; I'm happy that he's not overwhelmed by the responsibilities that come with his new position. I knew he would return to his old self, and now seeing my Jonathan climb to the peak of his promotion and adapt to the responsibilities on his shoulders in every way makes me so proud. He will be out all day, until late, because he said he couldn't have lunch at home. My housework is done, so I can take the journal he kept abroad and lock myself in my room to read it...
es: September 23rd. Jonathan has improved after a bad night. I am glad that he has enough work to do, as it keeps his mind away from terrible things; and, oh, I am happy that he is no longer overwhelmed by the responsibility of his new position! I knew he would be true to himself, and now I am proud to see my Jonathan rising to the heights of his advanced position and keeping pace in every way with the duties that fall upon him. He will be out of the house all day until late, as he said he would not return for lunch. I have finished my household chores, so I will take his foreign journal and lock myself in my room to read it…

en: 24 September.—I hadn’t the heart to write last night; that terrible record of Jonathan’s upset me so. Poor dear! How he must have suffered, whether it be true or only imagination. I wonder if there is any truth in it at all. Did he get his brain fever, and then write all those terrible things, or had he some cause for it all? I suppose I shall never know, for I dare not open the subject to him.... And yet that man we saw yesterday! He seemed quite certain of him.... Poor fellow! I suppose it was the funeral upset him and sent his mind back on some train of thought.... He believes it all himself. I remember how on our wedding-day he said: “Unless some solemn duty come upon me to go back to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, mad or sane.” There seems to be through it all some thread of continuity.... That fearful Count was coming to London.... If it should be, and he came to London, with his teeming millions.... There may be a solemn duty; and if it come we must not shrink from it.... I shall be prepared. I shall get my typewriter this very hour and begin transcribing. Then we shall be ready for other eyes if required. And if it be wanted; then, perhaps, if I am ready, poor Jonathan may not be upset, for I can speak for him and never let him be troubled or worried with it at all. If ever Jonathan quite gets over the nervousness he may want to tell me of it all, and I can ask him questions and find out things, and see how I may comfort him.
vi: • September 24 Last night, I couldn't write a single line because Jonathan's diary had left me stunned. Poor my husband! Whether it's true or just a figment of his imagination, he must have endured a lot of hardship. One question always haunts my mind: Is there any part of that story that is true? Did he describe those horrific things after suffering from brain fever, or is that illness the result of terrifying imaginations? I'm afraid I won't find the answer, because I might never dare to bring up that matter with him. But it seems that Jonathan recognized the man we saw yesterday...Perhaps the sudden death of his great friend Hawkins has caused him many bizarre and vague hallucinations, that's all...But it seems there is still a faint connection between the events that I can't quite grasp...That suspicious Count seems to be carrying out a scheme in London. If it's true that he has come to London with millions of pounds, then surely this city is in a dire situation that no one but us can resolve. We must not back down from this unavoidable task. So there it is! I will have to start preparing right away, I will type up my husband's diary because that way, when needed, anyone involved can read and understand the matter. I will explain the whole story myself, because I don't want anyone to disturb Jonathan.
tr: September 24. - Last night, I didn't have the heart to write; Jonathan's horrifying journal upset me so much! Poor dear! Whether what he wrote was real or entirely a figment of his imagination, who knows how much he suffered! I wonder if there is any truth in what was written. Did he first contract brain fever and then write all these horrifying things; or did he have some reasons for all of this? I suppose I will never know, as I will never dare to bring up the subject with him... And what about that man we saw yesterday! Jonathan seemed very sure about him... Poor dear! I think it was the funeral that upset him and brought his mind back to such thoughts. He believes in all of this. I remember him saying on our wedding day: "A crucial task, whether I am asleep or awake, whether I have lost my mind or am in my right mind, as long as it does not require me to return to those painful hours.” There seems to be some kind of logical connection in all of this. That terrifying Count was coming to London. “If this happens and the Count has come to London, filled with millions of people.” It could be an important task and we must not avoid it. I must be prepared. I will get my typewriter right now and start making a copy of this journal. Thus, if necessary, we will be prepared for other eyes to read it. And if the need arises; then perhaps, if I am ready, poor Jonathan will not be further shaken by these events, because I can speak on his behalf and prevent him from being distressed and worried about this. If Jonathan can overcome this anxiety, he may want to tell me all about it, and then I can ask him questions, learn something, and understand how I can comfort him.
es: September 24th. I didn't have the heart to write last night; that terrible account of Jonathan's startled me. My poor dear! How he must have suffered, whether it is true or just his imagination. I wonder if there is any truth in all of this. Did he first have brain fever and then write all those terrible things, or was there another cause for all of it? I suppose I will never know, for I do not dare to open a conversation on the subject with him... And yet, that man he saw yesterday! He seemed quite sure of him... Poor Jonathan! I suppose it was the funeral that unsettled him and sent his mind back in a chain of thoughts... He himself believes it all. I remember how on our wedding day he said: "Unless some solemn duty falls upon me to make me return to the bitter hours, asleep or awake, mad or sane." There seems to be a thread of continuity through this... That terrible count was going to come to London... If that were so and he came to London, with his prolific millions... There may be a solemn duty; and if that duty comes, we must not shrink from it... I will be prepared. I will take my typewriter right now and begin the transcription. Then we will be ready for other eyes if necessary. And if it is so desired, then perhaps, if I am ready, poor Jonathan need not be startled, for I can speak for him and never let him be bothered or worried about the matter at all. If ever Jonathan overcomes his nervousness, he may want to tell me everything, and I can ask him questions and find things out, and see how I can comfort him.

en: “Dear Madam,—
vi: Dear esteemed lady,
tr: Dear Madam,
es: "Dear Madam:"

en: “I pray you to pardon my writing, in that I am so far friend as that I sent to you sad news of Miss Lucy Westenra’s death. By the kindness of Lord Godalming, I am empowered to read her letters and papers, for I am deeply concerned about certain matters vitally important. In them I find some letters from you, which show how great friends you were and how you love her. Oh, Madam Mina, by that love, I implore you, help me. It is for others’ good that I ask—to redress great wrong, and to lift much and terrible troubles—that may be more great than you can know. May it be that I see you? You can trust me. I am friend of Dr. John Seward and of Lord Godalming (that was Arthur of Miss Lucy). I must keep it private for the present from all. I should come to Exeter to see you at once if you tell me I am privilege to come, and where and when. I implore your pardon, madam. I have read your letters to poor Lucy, and know how good you are and how your husband suffer; so I pray you, if it may be, enlighten him not, lest it may harm. Again your pardon, and forgive me.
vi: I sincerely apologize for the suddenness of sending you this letter, but in fact, I am somewhat of a friend to you, as I bear the difficult duty of informing you about the death of Miss Lucy Westenra. With the wholehearted consent of Lord Godalming, I have read all of Lucy's papers and letters, as I am very concerned about some extremely important matters related to her. Among the documents obtained, I found your letters, which reflect the noble friendship that you and she shared. My God! Mrs. Mina, in the name of that pure friendship, I beg you to help me! For the sake of everyone, I boldly ask you... to mend the pains caused by crime, to prevent the most terrible misfortunes, which even the most imaginative person could not conceive. Could you spare some precious time to meet with me? I believe you can trust me. I am a friend of Dr. John Seward and also a friend of Lord Godalming (that is, Arthur of Miss Lucy, as you know). But once again, I must apologize because I cannot yet say what I need to ask, at least not at this moment. I will come to Exeter to visit you as soon as you inform me of the most suitable date and time. I hope you will forgive my abruptness, madam! Through the letters you sent to Lucy, I understand how kind-hearted you are, and I also understand how your beloved husband is struggling with his nervous illness! If possible, I suggest you do not let him know about this matter, as I fear that what I have to say to you will negatively affect his health. Once again, I ask for your forgiveness.
tr: Forgive me for writing to you about the sad news of Miss Lucy Westenra's death. Due to the kindness of Lord Godalming, I have the authority to read the young lady's letters and documents, as I have deep concerns about some matters of vital importance. Among these papers, I found some of your letters showing how close friends you were and how much you loved her. Oh, Madam Mina, I beg you, for the sake of that love, help me. I ask this for the good of others - to correct a great mistake and to eliminate great and terrible troubles - which may be greater than you can even imagine. Is it possible for me to see you? You can trust me. I am a friend of Dr. John Seward and Lord Godalming (who was Miss Lucy's Arthur). For now, I must keep this from everyone. If you tell me when and where I should be, I will come to Exeter immediately to see you, if I may have the privilege of doing so. I have read the letters you wrote to poor Lucy, and I know the pains you and your husband have suffered; therefore, I beg you, if possible, do not inform him about this matter to avoid causing him harm. Once again, I beg your pardon, forgive me.
es: "I beg you to forgive me for writing to you, as I am such a distant friend, and for sending you the bad news of Miss Lucy Westenra's death. By the kindness of Lord Godalming, I have the power to read your letters and papers, as I am deeply interested in certain vitally important matters. In them, I find some letters from you, which show how great a friend you were to her and how much you loved her. Oh, Mrs. Mina, for that love, I implore you to help me! For the sake of others, I ask you, to avoid much harm, and to avoid many and very terrible disturbances that may be much greater than you imagine, would you grant me an interview? You can trust me. I am a friend of Dr. John Seward and Lord Godalming (that was Miss Lucy's Arthur). For the moment, I must maintain strict confidentiality. I would come to Exeter to see you immediately if you tell me that I can have the honor of seeing you, and where and how. Madam, I beg your pardon. I have read your letters to poor Lucy, and I know how good you are and how your husband suffers; therefore, I beg you, if possible, do not tell him anything, as it might cause him harm. Again, I ask your forgiveness and remain respectfully yours,
