es: –Holy God! – he shouted. What do you mean? Has there been some mistake? Have we buried her alive? He growled with such anger that not even hope could soften it.

en: “I did not say she was alive, my child; I did not think it. I go no further than to say that she might be Un-Dead.”
vi: — I am not saying that at that time, she was still alive, my friend, and I did not think so either. I am just saying that maybe she had become an immortal, that's all.
tr: "I didn't say he was alive, my child; I never thought so. I will go no further than to say he is Not Dead."
es: –I didn't say she was alive, my friend; I don't believe that. I only say that it is possible that she is a "living dead," or "undead."

en: “Un-Dead! Not alive! What do you mean? Is this all a nightmare, or what is it?”
vi: — Not dead? And then not alive anymore, is that what you mean? What do you mean by that? Could it be that I still haven't gotten through the nightmare of my life?
tr: "Not Dead? Isn't he alive? What do you mean? Is all this a nightmare, or what is this?"
es: –Alive dead! Not dead! What do you mean? Is all this a nightmare, or what?

en: “There are mysteries which men can only guess at, which age by age they may solve only in part. Believe me, we are now on the verge of one. But I have not done. May I cut off the head of dead Miss Lucy?”
vi: — In this world, there are always mysteries that human intellect can only speculate about without knowing how to explain; there are also mysteries that, with each passing century, people can only gradually clarify parts of their content. Please believe me, my friend, we are indeed facing such a mystery, and I hope we will find its key. Let me continue my work with your permission. Will you allow me to stake Lucy?
tr: “There are mysteries that people can only speculate about, and can only partially solve from age to age. Believe me, we are on the brink of such a mystery right now. But I didn't do it. Can I cut off dead Miss Lucy's head?”
es: –There are mysteries that man can only guess at, and which he partially unravels with the passage of time. Believe me: we are currently facing one of them. But I have not finished. May I cut off Miss Lucy's head from her corpse?

en: “Heavens and earth, no!” cried Arthur in a storm of passion. “Not for the wide world will I consent to any mutilation of her dead body. Dr. Van Helsing, you try me too far. What have I done to you that you should torture me so? What did that poor, sweet girl do that you should want to cast such dishonour on her grave? Are you mad to speak such things, or am I mad to listen to them? Don’t dare to think more of such a desecration; I shall not give my consent to anything you do. I have a duty to do in protecting her grave from outrage; and, by God, I shall do it!”
vi: — Oh, heavens and earth - Arthur suddenly wailed in agony, as if his anger and suffering had reached their peak - Oh, God! There's no way I'll let anyone disgrace her. Dr. Van Helsing, you've gone too far! What have I done to deserve such torment from you! What crime has Lucy committed that you bring friends to desecrate her resting place like this? Are you mad to utter such insane words, or am I mad to listen to them? From now on, don't even dream of desecrating her resting place. No way! I must protect her, and God will witness that I will do everything to fulfill my duty!
tr: “For God's sake! No!” cried Arthur in a storm of rage. “I would not accept it even if you gave me the worlds to cut and dissect her dead body. Dr. Van Helsing, you are testing my patience excessively. What have I done to you that you are torturing me like this? What did that poor, sweet girl do to you that you want to desecrate her grave in this way? Are you mad for saying such things, or am I mad for listening to them? Do not dare to think of such disrespect any longer; I will not allow you to do anything. It is my duty to protect her grave from insult, and I will do it!”
es: –By all the devils, no! – shouted Arthur, with burning passion-. For nothing in the world will I consent to mutilate her corpse. Doctor van Helsing, you are abusing my patience. What have I done to you that you wish to torture me in this way? What did that poor and sweet girl do that you wish to cause her such great dishonor in her grave? Are you mad to say such a thing, or am I the one who is insane for listening to it? Do not even allow yourself to think of such desecration again. I will not give you my consent at all. I have the duty to protect her grave from that outrage. And I promise you that I will do it!

en: Van Helsing rose up from where he had all the time been seated, and said, gravely and sternly:—
vi: Van Helsing got up from the couch, where he had been sitting all this time, and replied sternly:
tr: Van Helsing, who had been sitting all this time, stood up and said with a serious and stern expression:
es: Van Helsing stood up from the seat where he had remained sitting all that time, and said, with gravity and firmness:

en: “My Lord Godalming, I, too, have a duty to do, a duty to others, a duty to you, a duty to the dead; and, by God, I shall do it! All I ask you now is that you come with me, that you look and listen; and if when later I make the same request you do not be more eager for its fulfilment even than I am, then—then I shall do my duty, whatever it may seem to me. And then, to follow of your Lordship’s wishes I shall hold myself at your disposal to render an account to you, when and where you will.” His voice broke a little, and he went on with a voice full of pity:—
vi: — I too, Lord Godalming, have an obligation that I must fulfill, and there is no other way. It is an obligation to everyone, to you, and to the girl who has passed away. All I need from you now is to trust me, to follow me to the cemetery to witness firsthand, to see, to hear what will happen. After that, if I still make the same proposal and you find it inconvenient to respond, then I ask to... to fulfill my duty if necessary. I will explain everything to you later. His voice gradually faded, then fell silent, and then suddenly softly resounded again, but this time it seemed a bit forlorn:
tr: “Lord Godalming, I too have a duty to fulfill, a duty to others, to you, to the dead, and with God's help, I will do it! Now all I ask of you is to come with me, watch, and listen; if in the future, when I make the same request, you are not even more willing than I am to fulfill it, then I will do my duty; whatever I think it may be. And then, to safeguard the wishes of my Lord, I will be at your service, ready to account for myself whenever and wherever you desire.” His voice cracked a little, and he continued with a tone full of compassion:
es: –Lord Godalming, I too have a duty; a duty to others, a duty to you, and a duty to the deceased. And I promise you that I will fulfill it! The only thing I ask of you now is to accompany me, to observe everything attentively, and to listen; and if when I make the same request later you are not more eager than I am for it to be carried out, then… Then I will fulfill my duty, no matter what happens. Afterwards, according to your wishes, I will make myself available to you to account for my conduct, whenever and wherever you want -the master's voice softened a bit, but continued, in a tone full of compassion-:

en: “But, I beseech you, do not go forth in anger with me. In a long life of acts which were often not pleasant to do, and which sometimes did wring my heart, I have never had so heavy a task as now. Believe me that if the time comes for you to change your mind towards me, one look from you will wipe away all this so sad hour, for I would do what a man can to save you from sorrow. Just think. For why should I give myself so much of labour and so much of sorrow? I have come here from my own land to do what I can of good; at the first to please my friend John, and then to help a sweet young lady, whom, too, I came to love. For her—I am ashamed to say so much, but I say it in kindness—I gave what you gave; the blood of my veins; I gave it, I, who was not, like you, her lover, but only her physician and her friend. I gave to her my nights and days—before death, after death; and if my death can do her good even now, when she is the dead Un-Dead, she shall have it freely.” He said this with a very grave, sweet pride, and Arthur was much affected by it. He took the old man’s hand and said in a broken voice:—
vi: — But I beg you, please don't be angry with me anymore! Throughout my life, I have rarely had the chance to do pleasant things. There were even times when I had to face heart-wrenching matters that I couldn't ignore. Do you think I don't have thoughts? I am also very sad, very heartbroken! But that's life! How many people always get what they want? However, I must admit that I have never had to fulfill a duty as difficult as the one awaiting me. Believe in me, my friend, believe that if one day, everyone's feelings towards me suddenly change, and only the feelings of a friend like you remain... For me, that would be more than enough to dispel the sorrows of this sad moment, because I have done what a person can do to ease some of your heart's wounds. Just think about it! Why do I have to struggle like this! Why do I have to take on such troublesome matters? I came from the Netherlands to wholeheartedly care for a patient. At first, I came only to respond to the invitation of our friend John here. After that, I tirelessly treated a girl—who gradually inspired in me the feelings of a true friendship. I know it's not good to bring this up, but I still have to say that I also donated blood to her, just like you did with the blood from your heart. Yes, I gave the girl a part of my blood. But the only difference is that to her, you are a fiancé, while I am just a doctor and at most, a friend. I devoted many days, even many nights, to her, and I did so not only before she died, but also throughout the time she was no longer alive. If my death could somehow ease the cruel fate of the girl, who has now become immortal, I would be ready immediately. It is not difficult to recognize that Van Helsing's voice contained something truly bitter, yet it was not lacking in sympathy. I understand that Arthur was also very emotional and in a state of turmoil, because after a moment of silently listening to the professor's confession, he trembled as he stood up to shake his hand as a gesture of regret, and responded in a breathless voice: — Oh my God!
tr: “But I beg you, do not come at me in anger. In my long life, often filled with unpleasant and heart-wrenching actions, I have never had a duty as heavy as this one. Believe me, when the time comes for you to change your opinion of me, a single glance from you will erase all this sorrowful time, because I will do everything a person can to protect you from sadness. Just think about it. Why would I burden myself with such a great task and such great sorrow? I came here from my own country to do everything I can for your well-being; first to please my friend John, and then to help the sweet, young lady whom I began to love. I gave her - I am ashamed to tell you this much, but I say it delicately - what you gave her: I gave her the blood in my veins, like you, who is not her lover, but only her doctor and friend. I gave her my days and nights - before death, after death, and even now, if my death will benefit her, she will have it willingly.” He said this with a very serious, sweet pride, and Arthur was deeply moved. He held the old man's hand and said in a broken voice:
es: But I beg you not to remain angry with me. Throughout my life I have had to carry out many things that have been deeply unpleasant to me, and that have sometimes broken my heart; however, I have never had such an ungrateful task in my hands. Believe me, if there ever comes a time when you change your opinion of me, a single look from you would erase all the immense sadness of these moments, since I am going to do everything humanly possible to spare you sadness and sorrow. Just think, why would I take so much trouble and so many pains? I have come from my country to do what I believe is right; firstly, to serve my friend John, and also to help a lady whom I too came to love. For her, and I regret having to say it, even though I do it for a constructive purpose, I gave the same as you: the blood of my veins. I gave it to her, despite not being like you, the man who loved her, but her doctor and her friend. I devoted my days and nights to her… before her death and after it, and if my death can do her any good, even now, when she is a "living dead," I will gladly put it at her disposal. He said this with a very grave and firm dignity, and Arthur was very impressed by it. He took the old man's hand and said, with a choked voice:

en: “Oh, it is hard to think of it, and I cannot understand; but at least I shall go with you and wait.”
vi: Everything is so chaotic, tragic, and confusing! But alright, I will follow the professor to the cemetery. Then we will see...
tr: “Ah, it's hard to think about this and I can't understand it; but at least I will go with you and wait.”
es: –Oh! It's something hard to believe and I don't understand it. But, at the very least, I must go with you and observe the events.

en: CHAPTER XVI
vi: CHAPTER 16
es: XVI.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY—continued
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary (continued)
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD (continued)

en: IT was just a quarter before twelve o’clock when we got into the churchyard over the low wall. The night was dark with occasional gleams of moonlight between the rents of the heavy clouds that scudded across the sky. We all kept somehow close together, with Van Helsing slightly in front as he led the way. When we had come close to the tomb I looked well at Arthur, for I feared that the proximity to a place laden with so sorrowful a memory would upset him; but he bore himself well. I took it that the very mystery of the proceeding was in some way a counteractant to his grief. The Professor unlocked the door, and seeing a natural hesitation amongst us for various reasons, solved the difficulty by entering first himself. The rest of us followed, and he closed the door. He then lit a dark lantern and pointed to the coffin. Arthur stepped forward hesitatingly; Van Helsing said to me:—
vi: Near midnight, we climbed over the wall into the cemetery. The sky was pitch black, except for the rare moments when a crescent moon would unexpectedly appear, peeking out from behind the drifting giant clouds. Van Helsing led the way, and we closely followed behind. As we approached the grave, I had to keep an eye on Arthur, fearing that sad memories might overwhelm him. But fortunately, he managed to keep his composure. Perhaps the puzzling story that Van Helsing had just told somewhat distracted him from his worries. Seeing our hesitation, the professor went in first. After we all entered, he closed the door, lit a lamp, and pointed to where Lucy's coffin was placed. Arthur hesitated to go ahead, while Van Helsing engaged me in conversation.
tr: When we climbed over the low wall and entered the churchyard, it was only a quarter past twelve. Despite the moonlight occasionally shining through the cracks between the heavy clouds drifting across the night sky, it was dark. In some way, we all walked close to each other; Van Helsing was a bit ahead of us, showing us the way. As we approached the grave, I looked at Arthur carefully, because I feared that approaching a place filled with such sorrowful memories would upset him; but he was holding up well. I concluded that the mystery of the task at hand somehow prevented his grief. The professor unlocked the door and, seeing that we all had a natural hesitation for various reasons, resolved the issue by entering first himself. We others followed him and he closed the door behind us. Then he lit a dim light and pointed to the coffin. Arthur advanced hesitantly; Van Helsing said to me: "You were here with me yesterday.
es: It was a quarter to twelve at night when we entered the church cemetery, climbing over the not very high wall. The night was dark, although, at times, the moonlight filtered through the dense clouds that covered the sky. We stayed very close to each other, with Van Helsing a little ahead, showing us the way. When we got near the tomb, I looked closely at Arthur, because I feared that the proximity of a place filled with such sad memories would deeply affect him; but he managed to control himself. I thought that the very mystery surrounding all of this was mitigating his anger. The professor opened the door and, seeing that we hesitated, which was very natural, resolved the difficulty by entering first himself. We all imitated him, and the old man closed the door. Next, he lit a dim lantern and illuminated the coffin. Arthur took a step forward, not very decisively, and Van Helsing said to me:

en: “You were with me here yesterday. Was the body of Miss Lucy in that coffin?”
vi: — Yesterday, you came here with me. Lucy is no longer in the coffin, right?
tr: Arthur advanced hesitantly; Van Helsing said to me: "You were here with me yesterday. Was Miss Lucy's body in the coffin yesterday?"
es: –You were with me here yesterday. Was Miss Lucy's body in this coffin?

en: “It was.” The Professor turned to the rest saying:—
vi: — That's right! The part where he turned to tell the other two guys: — Did you hear that?
tr: “Yes.” The Professor turned to the others, saying: “You hear, and yet there is someone who still does not believe me.”
es: –That's right. The professor turned to the others, saying:

en: “You hear; and yet there is no one who does not believe with me.” He took his screwdriver and again took off the lid of the coffin. Arthur looked on, very pale but silent; when the lid was removed he stepped forward. He evidently did not know that there was a leaden coffin, or, at any rate, had not thought of it. When he saw the rent in the lead, the blood rushed to his face for an instant, but as quickly fell away again, so that he remained of a ghastly whiteness; he was still silent. Van Helsing forced back the leaden flange, and we all looked in and recoiled.
vi: Yet, there are still people who don't believe me! Van Helsing approached the coffin again, bent down to unscrew it, and lifted the wooden lid aside. Arthur stood silently, wide-eyed, his face pale. When the wooden lid was placed aside, he anxiously moved closer. Clearly, he did not know that there was a lead lining inside the coffin. Seeing the cut on the lead lining, his face suddenly flushed red, then turned pale again. Van Helsing lifted the cut piece of lead, and we stared in astonishment:
tr: “Yes.” The Professor turned to the others, saying: “You hear, and yet there is someone who still does not believe me.” Then, he took his screwdriver and lifted the lid of the coffin. Arthur watched with a very pale face but silently; when the lid was lifted, he stepped forward. It was clear that he did not know the coffin was lead, or at least he had not thought about it. When he saw the crack in the lead, blood rushed to his face for a moment, but then it withdrew just as quickly; so much so that he remained pale and white as a sheet; he was still silent. Van Helsing threw back the lead flap and we all recoiled as we looked inside the coffin.
es: –You hear it already, and besides, I don't think there's anyone who doesn't believe it. He took out the screwdriver and removed the lid from the coffin again. Arthur watched, very pale, but in silence. When the lid was removed, he took a step forward. Evidently, he did not know that there was a lead box or, in any case, did not think about it. When he saw the light reflected on the lead, the blood rushed to his face for an instant; but, with the same speed, it receded, leaving his face extremely pale. He still remained silent. Van Helsing removed the lead lid and all of us looked and stepped back.

en: The coffin was empty!
vi: The coffin was empty again!
tr: The coffin was empty!
es: The coffin was empty!

en: For several minutes no one spoke a word. The silence was broken by Quincey Morris:—
vi: We were stunned into silence, no one said a word to anyone. Finally, Quincey Morris was the first to speak:
tr: For a few minutes, no one spoke. The silence was broken by Quincey Morris:
es: For several minutes, none of us uttered a single word. The silence was broken by Quincey Morris:

en: “Professor, I answered for you. Your word is all I want. I wouldn’t ask such a thing ordinarily—I wouldn’t so dishonour you as to imply a doubt; but this is a mystery that goes beyond any honour or dishonour. Is this your doing?”
vi: — Professor, as I said, I have great faith in you. Your sincere words are enough to make me believe. Normally, I wouldn't ask you any questions, fearing you might think I still doubt you, but here we are faced with such an extraordinary mystery that I can't help but ask: Who did this, sir?
tr: "Professor, I vouched for you. The only thing I want is what you have to say; normally, I wouldn't ask for such a thing - I wouldn't cast doubt on your honor; but this is a mystery beyond all honor and dishonor. Is this your work?"
es: –Professor, I have answered for you. All I desire is your word... I would not ordinarily ask this question..., dishonoring you or implying a doubt; but this is a mystery that goes beyond honor or dishonor. Did you do this?

en: “I swear to you by all that I hold sacred that I have not removed nor touched her. What happened was this: Two nights ago my friend Seward and I came here—with good purpose, believe me. I opened that coffin, which was then sealed up, and we found it, as now, empty. We then waited, and saw something white come through the trees. The next day we came here in day-time, and she lay there. Did she not, friend John?”
vi: — Before everything that is most sacred, I swear to you all that I did not take the girl out of here and am absolutely not involved in this matter. This is what happened: the night before last, John and I came here with the best intentions, please believe me. I opened the coffin, which was still sealed with wax, and found that there was nothing in the coffin, just like now. Therefore, we decided to stand watch outside and indeed we discovered a figure dressed entirely in white flickering among the trees. Yesterday, we came back here again, but during the day, and saw that Lucy had been lying in there since who knows when. Isn't that right, John?
tr: “I swear by everything I hold sacred that I neither carried it nor touched it. This is what happened: Two nights ago, my friend Seward and I came here - with good intentions, believe me. We opened that sealed coffin and found it empty, just as it is now. Then we waited and saw something white coming through the trees. The next day, we came again during the day and there it was lying. Isn't that right, my friend John?”
es: I swear by all that I hold sacred that I have not removed her from here, and that I have not even touched her. What happened was the following: two nights ago, my friend Seward and I came here... with good intentions, believe me. I opened this coffin, which was then well sealed, and we found it as it is now, empty. Then we waited and saw a white form heading this way, among the trees. The next day we returned here, during the day, and saw that the corpse was lying there. Isn't that right, friend John?

en: “Yes.”
vi: — Yes.
tr: “Yes.”
es: –Yes.

en: “That night we were just in time. One more so small child was missing, and we find it, thank God, unharmed amongst the graves. Yesterday I came here before sundown, for at sundown the Un-Dead can move. I waited here all the night till the sun rose, but I saw nothing. It was most probable that it was because I had laid over the clamps of those doors garlic, which the Un-Dead cannot bear, and other things which they shun. Last night there was no exodus, so to-night before the sundown I took away my garlic and other things. And so it is we find this coffin empty. But bear with me. So far there is much that is strange. Wait you with me outside, unseen and unheard, and things much stranger are yet to be. So”—here he shut the dark slide of his lantern—“now to the outside.” He opened the door, and we filed out, he coming last and locking the door behind him.
vi: — The first night, we arrived just in time. Another boy had gone missing, but thank God, we found him among the graves and fortunately, he was unharmed. Yesterday, after coming here once during the day, I returned just before sunset, because during sunset, the immortals can leave their graves. I sat here waiting from then until morning, but saw nothing unusual. Simply because I had hung garlic and a crucifix, which are things that the immortals are very afraid of, on the door of the mausoleum. The other night, the immortal had left. Today as well, before sunset, I removed the garlic and crucifix from the door. That's why the coffin is empty like this. But follow me, there are even stranger things about to happen. Let's hide in a spot not far from here, and you will see whether I am telling the truth or lying. Come on, let's get out of here. He closed the lantern lid, waited for us all to leave, and then locked the door.
tr: “We arrived just in time that night. A small child had gone missing again, and thank God, we found him unharmed among the graves. Yesterday, I came here before sunset because the Undead move at sunset. I waited here all night until the sun rose, but I saw nothing. This was very reasonable because I had covered the edges of the door with garlic, which the Undead cannot stand, and other things they avoid. No one came out last night, so before sunset tonight, I removed my garlic and other things from there. And thus, we found this coffin empty. But listen to me patiently. So far, very strange things have happened. Wait with me outside, unseen and unheard, much stranger things will happen. Therefore,” -here he closed the cover of his lamp- “now outside.” He opened the door, walked behind us, closed the door behind him, and we went out in single file.
es: –That night we arrived just in time. Another little boy was missing from his home and we found him, thank God, unharmed, among the tombs. Yesterday I came here before sunset, as at sunset the "living dead" can come out. I was waiting here all night, until the sun rose again; but I saw nothing. Perhaps it is because I placed garlic in the gaps of all those doors, which the "undead" cannot stand, and other things they try to avoid. This morning I removed the garlic and the rest. And now we have found this empty coffin. But believe me: so far there are already many things that seem strange; however, stay with me outside, waiting, without making noise or letting ourselves be seen, and even stranger things will happen. Therefore -he said, turning off the faint beam of the lantern-, let's go out. He opened the door and we all hurried out; the professor was the last to leave and, once outside, he closed the door.

en: Oh! but it seemed fresh and pure in the night air after the terror of that vault. How sweet it was to see the clouds race by, and the passing gleams of the moonlight between the scudding clouds crossing and passing—like the gladness and sorrow of a man’s life; how sweet it was to breathe the fresh air, that had no taint of death and decay; how humanising to see the red lighting of the sky beyond the hill, and to hear far away the muffled roar that marks the life of a great city. Each in his own way was solemn and overcome. Arthur was silent, and was, I could see, striving to grasp the purpose and the inner meaning of the mystery. I was myself tolerably patient, and half inclined again to throw aside doubt and to accept Van Helsing’s conclusions. Quincey Morris was phlegmatic in the way of a man who accepts all things, and accepts them in the spirit of cool bravery, with hazard of all he has to stake. Not being able to smoke, he cut himself a good-sized plug of tobacco and began to chew. As to Van Helsing, he was employed in a definite way. First he took from his bag a mass of what looked like thin, wafer-like biscuit, which was carefully rolled up in a white napkin; next he took out a double-handful of some whitish stuff, like dough or putty. He crumbled the wafer up fine and worked it into the mass between his hands. This he then took, and rolling it into thin strips, began to lay them into the crevices between the door and its setting in the tomb. I was somewhat puzzled at this, and being close, asked him what it was that he was doing. Arthur and Quincey drew near also, as they too were curious. He answered:—
vi: Wow! Coming out here, I can feel the air is much cooler and more breathable than in that eerie mausoleum. It's so pleasant to be back under the indifferent clouds drifting across the night sky. I suddenly feel that the pale moonlight peeking through those strangely shaped clouds is a rare, soothing moment, cutting through the heavy worries weighing on my heart. It's also a relief to breathe the air outside, which is less tainted with the stench of decay and death. I feel somewhat reassured when I notice the first slender rays of light about to break over a distant hill and the faint sounds echoing from a large city. But even so, our faces still couldn't hide the tension as we left the mausoleum. Arthur remained silent; I guessed he was racking his brain trying to understand why such absurd things were happening. As for me, I increasingly felt convinced by the conclusions Van Helsing had drawn. Meanwhile, Quincey showed no reaction, or rather, he had the look of someone who had accepted everything others said, but with a lingering doubt in his heart. Knowing he couldn't light a cigarette, he took a piece of tobacco and chewed it. As for Van Helsing, he was still engrossed in his work. He took out something that looked like a biscuit or a thin communion wafer, carefully wrapped in a piece of white cloth, followed by two handfuls of some white powder, probably flour. He crumbled the biscuit and mixed it with the powder into a lump. Then, he rolled the dough into long, thin strands to seal the cracks in the mausoleum doors. What he was doing didn't surprise me, but I still asked him what his purpose was. Both Arthur and Quincey also curiously came closer to hear his explanation: — I did it so that the immortal could not return there.
tr: Ah! After the grave, the night air felt fresh and pure. How sweet it was to see the passing clouds and the moonlight filtering through the swiftly moving clouds - like the joys and sorrows in human life; how sweet it was to breathe the clean air untouched by death and decay; how humanizing it was to see the red glow in the sky behind the hill and to hear that muffled hum, a sign of the great city's life. Everyone was very serious in their own way and was coping with what had happened. Arthur was silent, trying to grasp the purpose and spiritual meaning of this mystery. I was quite patient and seemed half-inclined to set aside doubt and accept the conclusions Van Helsing had reached. Quincey Morris was in a calm state of someone who accepts everything and accepts everything with a cool courage, along with the things he must risk. Since he couldn't smoke, he had cut himself a large piece of chewing tobacco and was chewing it. As for Van Helsing, he was busy with a special task. First, he took out a thin, biscuit-like thing carefully wrapped in a white napkin from his bag; then he took two handfuls of a white substance that looked like dough or paste. He crumbled the biscuit finely and mixed it with the substance in his hand. Then he took this and, after rolling it into thin strips, began to place them in the gaps between the door and the door frame of the grave. I was a bit surprised by this and, being close to him, asked what he was doing. Arthur and Quincey had also come close to us because they were curious too. The professor replied:
es: Oh! How fresh and pure the night air seemed to us after those horrible moments! It was very pleasant to see the clouds moving across the sky and the moonlight filtering through the occasional gaps in the clouds... like the joy and sadness in a man's life. How pleasant it was to breathe the pure air that did not have that unpleasant smell of death and decay! How reassuring to see the reddish glow of the sky behind the hill and hear in the distance the dull noise that signifies the life of a big city! All of us, each in our own way, remained serious and full of solemnity. Arthur still kept obstinate silence and, as far as I could infer, he was striving to understand the purpose and deep meaning of the mystery. I myself felt quite calm and patient, inclined to reject my doubts and accept van Helsing's conclusions. Quincey Morris remained phlegmatic, in the manner of a man who accepts everything with a cool head, bravely exposing himself to whatever may happen. Since he couldn't smoke, he took a rather large handful of tobacco and began to chew it. As for Van Helsing, he was busy with something specific. He took from his briefcase an object that seemed to be a biscuit similar to a wafer and that was carefully wrapped in a white napkin; then, he took out a good handful of a whitish substance, like dough or paste. He broke the wafer, carefully crumbling it, and mixed it all with the dough he had in his hands. Next, he cut narrow strips of the product and set about placing them in all the cracks and openings that separated the door from the wall of the crypt. I felt somewhat confused and, since I was near him, I asked him what he was doing. Arthur and Quincey also approached, driven by curiosity. The professor replied:

en: “I am closing the tomb, so that the Un-Dead may not enter.”
vi: — Could that silly powder really have such an effect?
tr: “I am closing the grave so that the Not Dead cannot enter.”
es: –I am closing the tomb, so that the "living dead" cannot enter.

en: “And is that stuff you have put there going to do it?” asked Quincey. “Great Scott! Is this a game?”
vi: - Quincey asked, incredulously. - It feels like you are joking!
tr: “And is this thing you put here going to provide it?” asked Quincey. “Oh my God! Is this a game?”
es: –Is that substance you put there going to stop it? –That's right.

en: “It is.”
vi: — Joking?
tr: “Yes.”
es: –That's right.

en: “What is that which you are using?” This time the question was by Arthur. Van Helsing reverently lifted his hat as he answered:—
vi: — But what exactly did you use? - Arthur asked curiously.
tr: "What is it that you are using?" This time the question came from Arthur. Van Helsing answered, lifting his hat respectfully:
es: –What are you using? This time, it was Arthur who asked the question. With a certain reverence, Van Helsing lifted the brim of his hat and replied:

en: “The Host. I brought it from Amsterdam. I have an Indulgence.” It was an answer that appalled the most sceptical of us, and we felt individually that in the presence of such earnest purpose as the Professor’s, a purpose which could thus use the to him most sacred of things, it was impossible to distrust. In respectful silence we took the places assigned to us close round the tomb, but hidden from the sight of any one approaching. I pitied the others, especially Arthur. I had myself been apprenticed by my former visits to this watching horror; and yet I, who had up to an hour ago repudiated the proofs, felt my heart sink within me. Never did tombs look so ghastly white; never did cypress, or yew, or juniper so seem the embodiment of funereal gloom; never did tree or grass wave or rustle so ominously; never did bough creak so mysteriously; and never did the far-away howling of dogs send such a woeful presage through the night.
vi: — Holy wafer. I took the trouble to bring it from Amsterdam. The Pope gave it to me. Van Helsing's answer cleverly addressed our skepticism, and naturally, everyone had to feel that with such a serious intention from the professor, an intention that required him to use the most sacred object, we could no longer have any doubts. After sealing the door gaps with that sacred charm, he pointed out hiding spots around the mausoleum for each of us. The spots he chose were indeed clever. From our hiding places, we could cover a fairly wide area, but conversely, no outsider could detect us. Suddenly, I felt concerned for my two companions, especially Arthur. After all, I was more accustomed to the eerie and ghastly surroundings of the cemetery than they were, thanks to my previous visits. However, if less than an hour ago I had denied the evidence Van Helsing presented, now I felt my heart was about to leap out of my chest. I vaguely felt that the truth was increasingly becoming undeniable. Never before had I seen the graves at night appear so eerily white and ghostly. Never before had the cypress trees, yew trees, and red-berried pines seemed so mournful. Every bush and blade of grass before my eyes had never swayed in the wind with such a ghostly appearance. Everywhere I looked, I saw mystery, coldness, and desolation; even the distant howling and yelping of the house dogs made me think of some ominous sign about to descend upon this hellish place. We sat waiting in silence, a profound silence that made me feel as if I could clearly hear the lamenting cries of the spirits beneath the ground.
tr: “Communion bread. I brought it from Amsterdam. I had my sins forgiven.” This was a response that surprised even our most skeptical member, and each of us individually felt that it was impossible to display distrust in the face of such a serious purpose as the Professor's, a purpose that could use even the most sacred objects. In a respectful silence, we took our places near the grave, but in spots where we could hide from the eyes of any approaching person. I pitied the others, especially Arthur. Due to my previous visits, my inexperience in this vigil of horror had ended; but still, even I, who had rejected the evidence until an hour ago, felt my heart sinking. The graves had never seemed so terrifyingly white to me; the cypress, yew, or juniper had never appeared so much like the embodiment of funeral sorrow; the trees or grass had never rustled and swayed so ominously; a tree branch had never creaked so mysteriously, and the howling dogs in the distance had never sent such mournful signals into the night.
es: –The Host. I brought it from Amsterdam. I have authorization to use it here. It was an answer that impressed all of us, even the most skeptical, and we individually felt that in the presence of such an honorable purpose as the professor's, who used in this task what was most sacred to him, it was impossible to distrust. Amidst a respectful silence, each of us took the place that had been assigned to us, around the grave; but hidden, so that no person approaching could see us. I felt sorry for the others, especially for Arthur. I myself had become somewhat accustomed, because I had already made other visits and had been in contact with that horror; and even so, I, who had rejected the evidence about an hour ago, felt my heart pounding. The graves had never seemed so ghostly white to me; never had the cypresses, yews, or junipers seemed to be, as on that occasion, the embodiment of the spirit of funerals. Never before had the trees and the grass seemed so threatening to me. Never before had the branches creaked so mysteriously, nor had the distant barking of dogs ever sent such a horrendous omen in the middle of the darkness of the night.

en: There was a long spell of silence, a big, aching void, and then from the Professor a keen “S-s-s-s!” He pointed; and far down the avenue of yews we saw a white figure advance—a dim white figure, which held something dark at its breast. The figure stopped, and at the moment a ray of moonlight fell upon the masses of driving clouds and showed in startling prominence a dark-haired woman, dressed in the cerements of the grave. We could not see the face, for it was bent down over what we saw to be a fair-haired child. There was a pause and a sharp little cry, such as a child gives in sleep, or a dog as it lies before the fire and dreams. We were starting forward, but the Professor’s warning hand, seen by us as he stood behind a yew-tree, kept us back; and then as we looked the white figure moved forwards again. It was now near enough for us to see clearly, and the moonlight still held. My own heart grew cold as ice, and I could hear the gasp of Arthur, as we recognised the features of Lucy Westenra. Lucy Westenra, but yet how changed. The sweetness was turned to adamantine, heartless cruelty, and the purity to voluptuous wantonness. Van Helsing stepped out, and, obedient to his gesture, we all advanced too; the four of us ranged in a line before the door of the tomb. Van Helsing raised his lantern and drew the slide; by the concentrated light that fell on Lucy’s face we could see that the lips were crimson with fresh blood, and that the stream had trickled over her chin and stained the purity of her lawn death-robe.
vi: I suddenly started when I heard the soft whisper of the professor: "Shh... shh shh!" He raised his hand, pointing towards a shadowy figure, white like mist, that had suddenly appeared among the red-fruited pine trees and was moving towards us. Yes, a figure dressed in white was holding something dark against its chest. The floating figure suddenly stopped just as the moon unexpectedly appeared between two dark clouds: it was a woman draped in a shroud. We couldn't clearly see her face, as she was bowing her head over what she was holding in her arms. In the dim moonlight, we immediately recognized a blonde-haired child. We were startled when we heard a shrill cry in the moonlit night. The sound was like a child waking up startled from sleep, or a dog panicking in a dream near a fire. We were about to leap towards her, but Van Helsing, who was still hiding behind a pine tree within our sight, signaled us to stop. The white figure continued to move as the clouds covered the sliver of the moon. In a flash, she appeared right before our eyes. Under the moonlight that once again unexpectedly shone through the clouds, her face became quite clear. My heart seemed to stop, and at the same time, I heard Arthur's terrified cry: we had just recognized the familiar features of Lucy. Lucy Westenra, but how had she changed so much? The gentleness we once knew in her had given way to hardness, cruelty, and malice. The once innocent face was now deeply marked by carnal desire. Van Helsing stepped out from his hiding place, and we sprang up, the four of us standing guard at the entrance of the tomb. Van Helsing opened the lantern's lid, raising it to chest height, letting the light shine on the woman before us. My God! Her lips were wet with fresh blood, yes, blood was flowing down her chin and dripping onto her collar.
tr: There was a long silence, a great, painful void, and then a sharp "shh" sound came from the Professor. He pointed to a spot, and below, from the direction of the distant badger-tree road, we saw a white figure approaching - a barely discernible white figure holding something black on its chest. The figure stopped, and at that moment, a beam of moonlight filtered through the passing clouds; we were astonished to see a woman with dark hair, shrouded in burial clothes, revealed before our eyes. We couldn't see his face because he was bent over something we understood to be a fair-haired child. There was a pause, and then a sharp, short scream was heard, like that of a small child in sleep or a dog dreaming by the fire. We were just about to leap forward when we stopped at the warning hand of the Professor, whom we could see because he was standing behind the yew tree; then, as we watched him, the white figure began to move forward again. It was now close enough for us to see clearly, and the moonlight was still in place. My heart turned to ice, and I could hear Arthur breathing heavily, for we had recognized the figure of Lucy Westenra. What we saw was Lucy Westenra, but how she had changed. Her sweetness had turned into diamond-like hardness, heartless cruelty, and her purity into wanton lust. Van Helsing stepped forward, and following his movement, we also advanced; we lined up at the entrance of the tomb. Van Helsing raised his lamp and lifted its cover; thanks to the intense light falling on her face, we could see that Lucy's lips were crimson with fresh blood and that the blood had trickled down her chin, staining her shroud of fine linen.
es: There was a moment of profound silence: an almost painful void. Then, the professor ordered us to be quiet with a hiss. He pointed with his hand and, in the distance, among the yews, we saw a white figure approaching... A small white figure, holding something dark pressed against its chest. The figure stopped and, at that moment, a ray of moonlight filtered through the clouds, clearly showing a woman with dark hair, dressed in the waxed shroud of the grave. We couldn't see her face, as it was tilted over what we later identified as a blond-haired child. There was a pause and then a sharp cry, like that of a child in a dream or a dog lying near the fire, sleeping. We were about to rush forward, but the professor raised a hand, which we saw clearly against the yew that served as his hiding place, and we remained motionless; then, as we waited expectantly, the white figure began to move again. It was now close enough for us to see it clearly, and the moonlight still shone fully upon it. I felt my heart freeze, and I heard Arthur's exclamation and startle when we clearly recognized the features of Lucy Westenra. It was her. But, how she had changed! Her sweetness had turned into a terrible and inhuman cruelty, and her purity into a voluptuous perversity. Van Helsing left his hiding place and, following his example, we all moved forward; the four of us found ourselves lined up in front of the crypt door. Van Helsing raised the lantern and switched it on, and thanks to the faint light that fell on Lucy's face, we could see that her lips were red, full of fresh blood, and that a stream of the liquid had trickled down her chin, staining the immaculate whiteness of her shroud.

en: We shuddered with horror. I could see by the tremulous light that even Van Helsing’s iron nerve had failed. Arthur was next to me, and if I had not seized his arm and held him up, he would have fallen.
vi: Once again, we felt a chilling shiver. In the flickering lantern light, I knew even Professor Van Helsing's steely nerves were somewhat shaken. Arthur stood beside me, and if I hadn't rushed to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground.
tr: We shuddered with horror. I could see that even Van Helsing's nerves were frayed in the flickering light. Arthur was standing beside me, and if I hadn't held his arm for support, he would have fallen.
es: We shuddered, horrified, and I realized, from the convulsive trembling of the light, that even van Helsing's nerves of steel had faltered. Arthur was by my side, and if I hadn't taken him by the arm to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground.

en: When Lucy—I call the thing that was before us Lucy because it bore her shape—saw us she drew back with an angry snarl, such as a cat gives when taken unawares; then her eyes ranged over us. Lucy’s eyes in form and colour; but Lucy’s eyes unclean and full of hell-fire, instead of the pure, gentle orbs we knew. At that moment the remnant of my love passed into hate and loathing; had she then to be killed, I could have done it with savage delight. As she looked, her eyes blazed with unholy light, and the face became wreathed with a voluptuous smile. Oh, God, how it made me shudder to see it! With a careless motion, she flung to the ground, callous as a devil, the child that up to now she had clutched strenuously to her breast, growling over it as a dog growls over a bone. The child gave a sharp cry, and lay there moaning. There was a cold-bloodedness in the act which wrung a groan from Arthur; when she advanced to him with outstretched arms and a wanton smile he fell back and hid his face in his hands.
vi: Meanwhile, Lucy - I call the figure standing before me Lucy, for she bears Lucy's form - stepped back and let out an angry snarl, like a trapped rat, casting a resentful gaze from one person to another. In appearance and color, those were indeed Lucy's eyes, but the gaze was not; the innocence and gentleness in the eyes of the girl I once loved had been replaced by the lecherous and spiteful fire of hell. Whatever remnants of my love instantly transformed into a feeling of hatred and disgust. I suddenly wanted to be the one to end her sinful existence with my own hands. With the same fierce and malicious look, she let out a twisted, naive, and lewd laugh. Looking at her made me feel nauseous!... And with the action of a she-devil, she unexpectedly threw the child she had been holding all this time to the ground in front of her, letting out a growl that was both angry and regretful. She looked just like a starving dog forced to give up a juicy bone. The child let out a terrified scream and then lay still, continuously moaning. The heartlessness of her action as she threw the child to the ground made Arthur gasp in pain. After that inhumane act, she slowly advanced towards Arthur: she was still smiling that seductive, inviting smile, extending her hands forward, her eyes sparkling as she looked at her past lover. Arthur could only retreat, covering his face in fear with both hands.
tr: Lucy -I call this thing in front of us "Lucy" because it had taken her shape- retreated with an angry growl like a cat caught off guard when she saw us; then her eyes roamed over us. These were Lucy's eyes in shape and color; but instead of the pure, gentle pupils we knew, there were sinful and hellfire-filled eyes. At that moment, what remained of my love turned into hatred and disgust; if she needed to be killed then, I could have done it with ruthless pleasure. When she looked, her eyes sparkled with malevolent light and her face was crowned with a lascivious smile. Oh God! How it made my hair stand on end to see this! With a careful movement, she threw the child she had been diligently holding to her chest to the ground with a heartless motion reminiscent of a demon, and as she did so, she growled at him like a dog growling at a bone. The child let out a high-pitched scream and lay on the ground moaning. There was a cold-bloodedness in the act itself that caused Arthur to groan; when Lucy approached him with open arms and a wanton smile, Arthur retreated and hid his face behind his hands.
es: When Lucy… (I called the thing we had in front of us Lucy, because it retained her shape) saw us, she backed away with a growl of rage, like that of a cat when surprised; then, her eyes settled on us. They were Lucy's eyes in shape and color; but Lucy's eyes, perverse and full of infernal fire, not the sweet and kind eyes we had known. In those moments, what remained of my love for her turned into hatred and repugnance; if it were necessary to kill her, I would have done it at that very moment, with unimaginable delight. As she looked, her eyes shone with a demonic glow, and her face wrinkled into a voluptuous smile. Oh, my God, how I shuddered at seeing that smile! With a careless movement, like a she-devil full of wickedness, she threw the child she had been holding in her arms to the ground and remained growling over the creature, like a hungry dog beside a bone. The child screamed loudly and lay still, moaning. There was in that act such a monstrous display of cold blood that Arthur couldn't contain a cry; when the figure advanced towards him, with arms open and a smile of voluptuousness on her lips, he recoiled and hid his face in his hands.

en: She still advanced, however, and with a languorous, voluptuous grace, said:—
vi: But she still walked slowly forward, calling my friend's name as she went. Her voice sounded melodious, as if it didn't belong to this world, and her hands swayed as if caressing the void:
tr: But she was still moving forward with a seductive and sensual grace:
es: Nevertheless, the figure continued to advance, with smooth and graceful movements.

en: “Come to me, Arthur. Leave these others and come to me. My arms are hungry for you. Come, and we can rest together. Come, my husband, come!”
vi: — Come to me, Arthur. Don't follow your friends anymore, come to me. I want to hold you in my loving arms! Come here! From now on, we will rest together! Oh, come here, my husband! Come to me!
tr: "Come to me, Arthur." "Leave the others and come to me." "My arms are open to you." "Come and let us find peace together." "Come, my husband, come!""
es: –Come to me, Arthur -she said-. Leave everyone else and come to me. My arms are hungry for you. Come, and we can stay together. Come, my husband, come!

en: There was something diabolically sweet in her tones—something of the tingling of glass when struck—which rang through the brains even of us who heard the words addressed to another. As for Arthur, he seemed under a spell; moving his hands from his face, he opened wide his arms. She was leaping for them, when Van Helsing sprang forward and held between them his little golden crucifix. She recoiled from it, and, with a suddenly distorted face, full of rage, dashed past him as if to enter the tomb.
vi: The woman's gentle yet eerie voice, like the clinking sound of glass colliding, kept resonating, resonating in my head. Meanwhile, Arthur seemed to be enchanted, his hands no longer covering his face but spreading wide as if to welcome her. Seizing the moment, the lascivious woman immediately rushed into the arms of the bewitched man as if seeking a safe haven. But at that very moment, Van Helsing jumped out, blocking her path with a golden cross held out in front of her. The immortal instantly recoiled, her face twitching in a fit of frantic rage, she leaped aside and quickly ran towards the mausoleum as if to hide inside.
tr: In her voice, there was a devilish sweetness that resonated in our minds - similar to the ringing sound you hear when you strike a glass - even though we knew the words were meant for someone else. As for Arthur, he seemed to be under a spell; he removed his hands from his face and opened his arms wide. Lucy had just leapt towards him when Van Helsing sprang forward and held his small, golden cross aloft between the two of them. Lucy recoiled from the cross and suddenly, with a contorted, rage-filled face, she darted past the Professor as if she wanted to enter the grave.
es: There was something devilishly sweet in the tone of her voice... Something akin to the sound produced by glass when struck that impressed all of us present, even though the words had not been directed at us. As for Arthur, he seemed to be under the influence of a spell; he removed his hands from his face and opened his arms. Lucy rushed towards them; but Van Helsing stepped forward, positioned himself between them, and held a gold crucifix in front of him. The form recoiled from the cross and, with a face suddenly contorted with rage, passed by him, as if to enter the tomb.

en: When within a foot or two of the door, however, she stopped, as if arrested by some irresistible force. Then she turned, and her face was shown in the clear burst of moonlight and by the lamp, which had now no quiver from Van Helsing’s iron nerves. Never did I see such baffled malice on a face; and never, I trust, shall such ever be seen again by mortal eyes. The beautiful colour became livid, the eyes seemed to throw out sparks of hell-fire, the brows were wrinkled as though the folds of the flesh were the coils of Medusa’s snakes, and the lovely, blood-stained mouth grew to an open square, as in the passion masks of the Greeks and Japanese. If ever a face meant death—if looks could kill—we saw it at that moment.
vi: But when she was only one or two steps away from the mausoleum door, she suddenly halted, as if an irresistible invisible force had prevented her from moving further. Unable to do anything else, she quickly turned back to look at us, her eyes glaring fiercely under the clear moonlight and the lantern light held by the old professor. Never before had I seen such a face, both mournful and indifferent. I hope no one will ever have to witness such a face again. Her cheeks, which had been rosy just moments ago, now turned a pale gray; only her eyes remained the same, full of resentment and darkness, just like the eyes of someone who had escaped from hell. Her forehead was deeply furrowed with winding wrinkles like worms or snakes, and her mouth, with its sensuous, blood-red lips, was agape in a square shape, looking just like the masks symbolizing anger in Turkish or Japanese culture. If ever there was a face that announced a death sentence, or if there were looks capable of killing, then we had right in front of us such a face and such a look.
tr: But about half a meter from the door, he stopped as if caught by an irresistible force. Then he turned, and his face was revealed in the light of the clearly shining moon and the lamp whose light did not waver with Van Helsing's iron nerves. I had never seen such a malevolent astonishment on a face before, and I believe that such a sight will never again be seen by mortal eyes. The beautiful color of his skin came to life, his eyes seemed to spark with the fires of hell; his forehead wrinkled as if the folds of his flesh were Medusa's snakes, and his beautiful, bloody mouth opened squarely like the masks used by the Greeks and Japanese in religious plays. If it is possible for a human face to mean death -if looks could kill- we saw it at that moment.
es: When she was thirty or sixty centimeters from the door, however, she stopped, as if paralyzed by some irresistible force. Then she turned, and her face was exposed under the glow of the moon and the light of the lantern, which no longer trembled, because Van Helsing had regained control of his nerves of steel. Never before had I seen so much evil in a face; and never, I hope, will other mortal beings see it again. Her beautiful color disappeared and her face turned livid, her eyes seemed to spark with infernal fire, her forehead was wrinkled, as if her flesh were formed by the tails of Medusa's serpents, and her adorable mouth, which was then stained with blood, formed an open square, like in the theatrical masks of the Greeks and the Japanese. At that moment we saw a face that reflected death like no other before. If looks could kill!

en: And so for full half a minute, which seemed an eternity, she remained between the lifted crucifix and the sacred closing of her means of entry. Van Helsing broke the silence by asking Arthur:—
vi: In front of me, she still stood defiantly between the golden crucifix that Van Helsing was holding in his hand on one side, and the mausoleum with its doors sealed shut with holy wafers on the other. After about half a minute, the old professor suddenly broke the silence by asking Arthur:
tr: And thus, for what seemed like an eternity of a full half minute, he remained between the cross held aloft and the sacred barrier at the entrance. Van Helsing turned to Arthur and broke the silence:
es: He remained like that for half a minute, which seemed like an eternity to us, between the raised crucifix and the sacred seals that were on his front door. Van Helsing broke the silence by asking Arthur.

en: “Answer me, oh my friend! Am I to proceed in my work?”
vi: — Speak up, my friend... Answer me, should I continue with the work?
tr: "Answer me, oh my friend! Shall I continue with my work?"
es: –Answer me, my friend: do you want me to continue?

en: Arthur threw himself on his knees, and hid his face in his hands, as he answered:—
vi: Arthur fell to his knees, covering his face with his hands, and answered in a choked sob:
tr: Arthur threw himself onto his knees and responded, hiding his face in his hands:
es: Arthur dropped to his knees and covered his face with his hands, while responding:

en: “Do as you will, friend; do as you will. There can be no horror like this ever any more;” and he groaned in spirit. Quincey and I simultaneously moved towards him, and took his arms. We could hear the click of the closing lantern as Van Helsing held it down; coming close to the tomb, he began to remove from the chinks some of the sacred emblem which he had placed there. We all looked on in horrified amazement as we saw, when he stood back, the woman, with a corporeal body as real at that moment as our own, pass in through the interstice where scarce a knife-blade could have gone. We all felt a glad sense of relief when we saw the Professor calmly restoring the strings of putty to the edges of the door.
vi: — Just do as you have planned... Go ahead and do as you have planned... There will never be anything more terrible than this. His sobs had now turned into painful groans, and if Quincey and I hadn't come to support him, he might have collapsed. Van Helsing placed the lantern on the ground and walked towards the mausoleum door, for some reason he removed the layers of talismans from the door crevice. And when he stepped aside, we couldn't help but be astonished and horrified by the scene unfolding before our eyes: the woman, in flesh and blood, easily slipped through a narrow door crevice that I thought even a knife blade would have difficulty fitting through, let alone something thicker. However, we were somewhat relieved when we saw the professor calmly resealing the door crevices with the powder fragments as before.
tr: “Do what you want, my friend; do what you want. Such a horror can never be seen again!” And he groaned with all his soul. Quincey and I moved towards him at the same time and held him by the arms. We heard the sound of the lamp being extinguished in Van Helsing’s hand; approaching the tomb, he took some of the holy symbols he had previously placed there from the gaps. When the professor stepped back, we stared in horror and amazement as we saw the woman's material body, which at that moment seemed as real as ours, pass through a crack only a knife's edge could fit through. We all sighed with relief when we saw the professor calmly placing the paste on the edges of the door again.
es: –Do what you think is best, my friend. Do whatever you want. It's not possible that such a horror could exist - he moaned. Quincey and I simultaneously advanced towards him and grabbed him by the arms. We managed to hear the click produced by the lantern being turned off. Van Helsing moved even closer to the crypt and began to remove the sacred emblem he had placed in the cracks. We all watched, horrified and confused, as the professor stepped back, and the woman, with a human body as real at that moment as ours, passed through the crack where barely the blade of a knife could have passed. We all felt a huge relief when we saw the professor calmly place the mass he had removed back in its place.

en: When this was done, he lifted the child and said:
vi: The moment he ran out to pick up the child and told us:
tr: When this task was completed, the Professor lifted the child from the ground and said:
es: After doing it, he lifted the child and said:

en: “Come now, my friends; we can do no more till to-morrow. There is a funeral at noon, so here we shall all come before long after that. The friends of the dead will all be gone by two, and when the sexton lock the gate we shall remain. Then there is more to do; but not like this of to-night. As for this little one, he is not much harm, and by to-morrow night he shall be well. We shall leave him where the police will find him, as on the other night; and then to home.” Coming close to Arthur, he said:—
vi: — Perhaps we should go back. We can't do anything right now. It's almost dawn, and there's another funeral at noon; we have to wait until they're done. We will be there when the gravedigger locks the cemetery gate. There are still many things to do, but it will be completely different from what we've been worrying about. As for this boy, it doesn't seem too serious; he might recover by tomorrow night. Now, here's the plan: we'll leave the boy somewhere the police can easily find him, just like the previous victim, and then we'll go back together. Arthur, - he said, comforting him as he walked closer - I know the reality before you is horrifying, but later, when you look back, you'll understand that everything we're doing now is very necessary.
tr: “Now come, my friends; we can't do anything else until tomorrow. There is a funeral here at noon, so we will come here shortly after the ceremony. The friends of the deceased will have left by two o'clock, and when the sexton locks the door, we will stay here. Then, there will be other tasks to do; but not like tonight. As for this little one, he hasn't been harmed much and will be healed by tomorrow evening. Let's leave him here, where the police will find him, just like last night, and then let's go home.” Approaching Arthur, he said:
es: –Let's go, friends. We can't do anything else until tomorrow. There is a funeral at noon, so we will have to return here not long after that time. The friends of the deceased will all leave before two, and when the sexton closes the cemetery gate, we must stay inside. Then we will have other things to do; but it will be nothing like tonight. As for this little one, he is not badly injured, and by tomorrow night he will be perfectly fine. We must leave him where the police can find him, like the other night, and then we will return home. He moved a little closer to Arthur, and said:

en: “My friend Arthur, you have had a sore trial; but after, when you look back, you will see how it was necessary. You are now in the bitter waters, my child. By this time to-morrow you will, please God, have passed them, and have drunk of the sweet waters; so do not mourn overmuch. Till then I shall not ask you to forgive me.”
vi: Arthur, - he said, comforting him as he walked closer - I know the reality before you is horrifying, but later, when you look back, you'll understand that everything we're doing now is very necessary. The bitter moments I've just described, and the ones you're living through now, thank God, will soon pass, and you'll have the most peaceful years, even if it's not complete happiness. I won't let you struggle with your inner sorrows forever.
tr: “My friend Arthur, you have gone through a bitter trial, but later, when you look back, you will see how necessary it was. Now you are in bitter waters, my child. By this time tomorrow, with God's permission, you will have passed these trials and tasted sweet waters; so do not mourn too much. Until then, I will not ask you to forgive me.”
es: –Arthur, my friend, you have had to endure a very hard trial; but, later, when you remember it, you will understand that it was necessary. You are full of bitterness at this moment; but, tomorrow at this time, you will have already consoled yourself, and God willing, you will have had some reason for joy; therefore, do not despair too much. Until then, I will not ask you to forgive me.

en: Arthur and Quincey came home with me, and we tried to cheer each other on the way. We had left the child in safety, and were tired; so we all slept with more or less reality of sleep.
vi: I took Arthur and Quincey to my house. On the way, we did not forget to encourage and console each other! We had to leave the boy in a place where the police could easily recognize him before going home. So tired! That day, the three of us fell into a fitful sleep.
tr: Arthur and Quincey came home with me, and we tried to cheer each other up along the way. We had left the child in a safe place and were tired; therefore, we slept in a manner that was almost like real sleep.
es: Arthur and Quincey returned to my house with me, and we tried to console each other along the way. We had left the child in a safe place and we were tired. We all slept more or less deeply.

en: 29 September, night.—A little before twelve o’clock we three—Arthur, Quincey Morris, and myself—called for the Professor. It was odd to notice that by common consent we had all put on black clothes. Of course, Arthur wore black, for he was in deep mourning, but the rest of us wore it by instinct. We got to the churchyard by half-past one, and strolled about, keeping out of official observation, so that when the gravediggers had completed their task and the sexton under the belief that every one had gone, had locked the gate, we had the place all to ourselves. Van Helsing, instead of his little black bag, had with him a long leather one, something like a cricketing bag; it was manifestly of fair weight.
vi: • September 29 Around nearly two o'clock in the afternoon, we arrived at the hotel to find the professor. The strange thing was that none of us, without any prior agreement, were all dressed in black. Clearly, we were somewhat haunted by what had just happened, because Arthur was in mourning, but the rest of us were not affected at all. About an hour and a half later, we arrived at the cemetery but only dared to wander around the small secluded paths to avoid being seen before the cemetery gates were locked. Today, Van Helsing had replaced the small black bag he had carried on previous occasions with a much longer leather bag, looking just like a cricket bat case. I guessed the bag must contain a lot of things.
tr: September 29, night. - Just before midnight, the three of us - Arthur, Quincey Morris, and I - visited the Professor. It was strange to notice that we were all dressed in black unanimously. Of course, Arthur was dressed in black because he was in deep mourning; but the rest of us had dressed this way instinctively. We arrived at the churchyard at half-past one and wandered around, staying out of sight of the officials, so that when the gravediggers finished their work and the sexton, believing everyone had left, locked the door, the entire place was left to us. Instead of his small black bag, Van Helsing had a leather bag that resembled a long cricket bag; it was evidently very heavy.
es: September 29, at night. Shortly before midnight, the three of us, Arthur, Quincey Morris, and I, went to see the professor. It was strange to notice that, as if by common agreement, we had all dressed in black. Of course, Arthur was in black because he was in deep mourning; but the rest of us dressed that way by instinct. We went to the church cemetery around half past one, and entered the graveyard, staying where we could not be seen, so that when the gravediggers had finished their work, and the sexton, believing no one was left in the cemetery, closed the gate, we remained quietly inside. Van Helsing, instead of his black portfolio, carried a long leather case that seemed to contain a cricket bat; it was obvious that it was quite heavy.

en: When we were alone and had heard the last of the footsteps die out up the road, we silently, and as if by ordered intention, followed the Professor to the tomb. He unlocked the door, and we entered, closing it behind us. Then he took from his bag the lantern, which he lit, and also two wax candles, which, when lighted, he stuck, by melting their own ends, on other coffins, so that they might give light sufficient to work by. When he again lifted the lid off Lucy’s coffin we all looked—Arthur trembling like an aspen—and saw that the body lay there in all its death-beauty. But there was no love in my own heart, nothing but loathing for the foul Thing which had taken Lucy’s shape without her soul. I could see even Arthur’s face grow hard as he looked. Presently he said to Van Helsing:—
vi: Waiting for the last footsteps to leave the cemetery and being sure that we were the only ones left, we followed the professor towards the Westenra tomb, without anyone saying a word to each other. He took out the key to open the door and signaled for me to close it, as I was the last one to enter. He lit a lantern, then lit two more candles and placed them at the heads of the two coffins beside us. It seemed like this time he needed more light. As before, he lifted the lid of Lucy's coffin and set the square piece of lead aside, in our presence. Poor Arthur, he trembled like a leaf when he recognized the familiar form of the woman lying inside. Yes, that woman lying in the coffin looked fresher and more stunningly beautiful than ever. But I knew in my heart there was no room for love, only a simmering hatred, a hatred kindled by the entity bearing Lucy's familiar form but devoid of any soul. It seemed Arthur had tried to calm himself, for I saw him ask Van Helsing:
tr: After being left alone and hearing the last footsteps leaving the churchyard fade away on the road, we silently, as if commanded for this purpose, followed the Professor to the grave. He unlocked the door, and we entered, closing the door behind us. Then he took a lamp out of his bag and lit it; then he took out two candles from his bag, which he lit and melted the ends to stick them on the other coffins so they could provide enough light to work. When he lifted the lid of Lucy's coffin again, we all looked inside -Arthur was trembling like a leaf- and saw the corpse lying there with all its dead beauty. But there was no love in my heart; in my heart, there was no feeling other than disgust for that horrible Thing that took the shape of Lucy without her soul. I could even see Arthur's face hardening as he looked into the coffin. After a while, he said to Van Helsing:
es: When we found ourselves alone, after hearing the last footsteps fade away up the street, in silence and as if by common agreement, we followed the professor towards the crypt. Van Helsing opened the door and we entered, closing it behind us. Then the old man took out the lantern, lit it, and also lit two wax candles which, after letting a few drops fall, he placed on other coffins, in such a way that they spread a glow that allowed us to work. When he removed the lid from Lucy's coffin again, we all looked, Arthur trembling violently, and saw the corpse lying there, with all its posthumous beauty. But he did not feel love at all, only repugnance for the ghastly object that had taken the form of Lucy, without her soul. I saw that even Arthur's face hardened as he observed the dead body. At that moment, he asked van Helsing:

en: “Is this really Lucy’s body, or only a demon in her shape?”
vi: — Is this truly Lucy's body, or just a demon taking her form?
tr: “Is this really Lucy's body or just a demon that has taken her form?”
es: –Is it really Lucy's body, or just a demon that has taken her form?

en: “It is her body, and yet not it. But wait a while, and you all see her as she was, and is.”
vi: — That is her body and yet not her body. But just wait a moment, and you will see the truth of the matter.
tr: “It is his body, but still not him. But wait a little; you will see what he was in the past and what he is now.”
es: –It is her body, and at the same time, it is not. But, wait a little and you will see her again as she was and is.

en: She seemed like a nightmare of Lucy as she lay there; the pointed teeth, the bloodstained, voluptuous mouth—which it made one shudder to see—the whole carnal and unspiritual appearance, seeming like a devilish mockery of Lucy’s sweet purity. Van Helsing, with his usual methodicalness, began taking the various contents from his bag and placing them ready for use. First he took out a soldering iron and some plumbing solder, and then a small oil-lamp, which gave out, when lit in a corner of the tomb, gas which burned at fierce heat with a blue flame; then his operating knives, which he placed to hand; and last a round wooden stake, some two and a half or three inches thick and about three feet long. One end of it was hardened by charring in the fire, and was sharpened to a fine point. With this stake came a heavy hammer, such as in households is used in the coal-cellar for breaking the lumps. To me, a doctor’s preparations for work of any kind are stimulating and bracing, but the effect of these things on both Arthur and Quincey was to cause them a sort of consternation. They both, however, kept their courage, and remained silent and quiet.
vi: But anyway, we still felt like we were living in a "Lucy nightmare." In front of us was a woman with sharp teeth, blood-red seductive lips that alone were enough to make me shudder in fear and my body filled with carnal desire, her face exuding a savage, ghostly look, like a grotesque mockery of the gentle innocence and purity of the former Lucy. As a habit, Van Helsing began to take out the tools from his bag and lay them out. First were the items used as welding tools, then a small wooden stake about three feet long with a sharp end, and finally a hammer. For me, someone accustomed to dissection work, witnessing a doctor preparing to act was not burdensome at all, but for Arthur and Quincey, it was different; it was clear that they were very tense when they saw the tools Van Helsing brought. However, they still showed courage, remained calm, and kept silent.
tr: What we saw, lying there, was like Lucy's nightmare; sharp teeth, bloody, lustful lips - which sent shivers down one's spine - all that sexual and non-spiritual appearance that seemed like a diabolical imitation of Lucy's sweet innocence. Van Helsing, with all his usual methodicalness, began to take various things out of his bag and prepare them for use. First, a soldering iron and some solder, then a small gas lamp that burned with fierce blue flames and emitted gas when lit in a corner of the grave, then his surgical knives which he left within reach, and finally a round wooden stake about seven or eight centimeters wide and approximately ninety centimeters long. The tip of the stake had been hardened and sharpened by being roasted in the fire. Along with this stake came a heavy hammer, similar to those used in homes to break large pieces in the coal shed. To me, the Doctor's preparation for any task is enlightening and invigorating, but the effect on Arthur and Quincey was to throw them into a kind of horror. But both of them kept their courage and stood quietly.
es: The corpse looked like Lucy seen in the middle of a nightmare, with her sharp fangs and voluptuous mouth stained with blood, which made one shudder at the mere sight of her. She had a carnal and vulgar appearance, which seemed like a diabolical caricature of Lucy's sweet laziness. Van Helsing, with his accustomed methodical movements, began to take out all the objects contained in the leather case and placed them around him, prepared to be used. First, he took out a soldering iron and a bar of tin, and then, a small oil lamp that, when lit in a corner of the crypt, released a gas that burned, producing an extremely strong heat; then, his scalpels, which he placed near his hand, and after that, a round wooden stake, about six or eight centimeters in diameter and about ninety centimeters in length. One of its ends had been hardened by putting it in the fire, and the tip had been carefully sharpened. Next to the stake was a small hammer, similar to those found in coal mines, used to break pieces of mineral that were too thick.
