For me, the preparations carried out by a doctor to perform any type of work were stimulating and reassuring; but all those manipulations filled Quincey and Arthur with consternation. However, both managed to control themselves and remained motionless and silent.

en: When all was ready, Van Helsing said:—
vi: After arranging the tools, Van Helsing turned to us and said:
tr: When everything was ready, Van Helsing began to speak:
es: When everything was ready, Van Helsing said:

en: “Before we do anything, let me tell you this; it is out of the lore and experience of the ancients and of all those who have studied the powers of the Un-Dead. When they become such, there comes with the change the curse of immortality; they cannot die, but must go on age after age adding new victims and multiplying the evils of the world; for all that die from the preying of the Un-Dead becomes themselves Un-Dead, and prey on their kind. And so the circle goes on ever widening, like as the ripples from a stone thrown in the water. Friend Arthur, if you had met that kiss which you know of before poor Lucy die; or again, last night when you open your arms to her, you would in time, when you had died, have become nosferatu, as they call it in Eastern Europe, and would all time make more of those Un-Deads that so have fill us with horror. The career of this so unhappy dear lady is but just begun. Those children whose blood she suck are not as yet so much the worse; but if she live on, Un-Dead, more and more they lose their blood and by her power over them they come to her; and so she draw their blood with that so wicked mouth. But if she die in truth, then all cease; the tiny wounds of the throats disappear, and they go back to their plays unknowing ever of what has been. But of the most blessed of all, when this now Un-Dead be made to rest as true dead, then the soul of the poor lady whom we love shall again be free. Instead of working wickedness by night and growing more debased in the assimilating of it by day, she shall take her place with the other Angels. So that, my friend, it will be a blessed hand for her that shall strike the blow that sets her free. To this I am willing; but is there none amongst us who has a better right? Will it be no joy to think of hereafter in the silence of the night when sleep is not: ‘It was my hand that sent her to the stars; it was the hand of him that loved her best; the hand that of all she would herself have chosen, had it been to her to choose?’ Tell me if there be such a one amongst us?”
vi: — Before starting the work, I would like to explain to you some additional details. In fact, my knowledge is not extensive nor profound; it is derived from science and the experiences of the ancients, or from those who have diligently researched the powers of the immortal. The state of not dying is always associated with the curse of immortal destiny. These entities cannot die; fate and they always seek to create new victims, new calamities for the earth from century to century, because if anyone dies as the prey of an immortal, they will surely become another immortal. And so, the new immortal will seek new prey to spread more disasters. The circle of calamity keeps growing, growing, like the circles on the water's surface when a stone is thrown into the lake. My friend Arthur, if that day you had kissed your girlfriend for a moment before she passed away to fulfill her wish, or if last night you had let her fall into your arms, sooner or later you would have shared the same fate, specifically becoming a nosferatu as the Eastern Europeans call it. And surely, year after year, you would become the cause of new immortal entities, terrifying many people. Fortunately, the wretched life of the unwilling immortal Lucy has just begun. The kids she sucked blood from have not yet fallen into a state of despair, but if that immortal continues to "live," the kids will lose more and more blood, as they must obey the power she has cast upon them, and they will increasingly seek her out. Her filthy mouth will suck the last drops of blood from the children. On the contrary, if she truly dies, all crimes will be stopped, the minor wounds on the children's necks will disappear, and they will return to their daily games, forgetting all those dangerous adventures. But more importantly, true death will come to the immortal, and her haunted soul will be freed. Instead of committing evil deeds in the dark and enduring increasing disgrace, she will be granted a place in heaven with the angels. But it requires a hand like a blessing for her. I am very willing to do that. But isn't there anyone among us more deserving of that privilege than me? How happy it would be from now on, whenever we wake in the stillness of the night, to think: "She has gone to the stars thanks to my own hand, the hand of the one who loved her most in the world, the hand she would choose if she could still choose. " Tell me, friends, doesn't anyone want to have a dream with such words?
tr: "Before we start, let me tell you this; what we are about to do comes from the knowledge and experience of everyone who has studied the power of the ancients and the Undead. When they transform into the Undead, the curse of immortality comes with it; they cannot die, but they must live through the ages, adding new victims to their ranks and multiplying the world's evils; because those who are hunted and killed by the Undead also turn into the Undead and feed on their own kind. And thus the circle widens forever, like the ripples created by a stone thrown into water. My friend Arthur, if you had accepted that kiss from Lucy before she died or if you had kissed her when you opened your arms to her last night, you would have become, as they say in Eastern Europe, a nosferatu44 upon her death and would have continued to create those Undead that fill us with fear. The career of this very unfortunate lady has just begun. The condition of those children whose blood she has sucked is not yet very bad; but if Lucy continues to live as an Undead, the children will lose more of their blood and come to her because of the power over them; thus she sucks their blood with her very sinful mouth. But if she truly dies, then it will all end; the wounds on their throats will disappear and they will return to their games without ever knowing what happened. But best of all, this thing that is now the Undead will be put to rest as a true dead, and then the soul of that poor lady we love will be free again. Instead of doing evil at night and degrading herself further by absorbing it during the day, she will take her place beside the other angels. Therefore, my friend, the hand that delivers the blow to set her free will be a holy hand. I am willing; but is there no one among us who has more right to it? Afterwards, in the silence of the night, won't it be a joy to think, 'It was my hand that sent her to the stars, it was the hand of the one who loved her the most; if she had a choice, it would be the hand she would choose among all,'? Tell me if there is such a person among us."
es: –Before doing anything, let me explain something that comes from the wisdom and experience of the ancients and all those who have studied the powers of the "undead". When they become undead, the change implies immortality; they cannot die and must continue through the ages taking new victims and increasing all the evil in this world; since all who die from the attacks of the "undead" themselves become those horrible monsters and, in turn, attack their fellow humans. Thus, the circle widens, like the ripples caused by a stone falling into water. Friend Arthur, if you had accepted that kiss before poor Lucy died, or last night, when she opened her arms to receive you, in time, upon dying, you would become a nosferatu, as they are called in Eastern Europe, and would continue producing more and more "undead", like the one that has horrified us. The career of this unfortunate lady has just begun. Those children whose blood she sucks are not yet the worst that can happen; but if she continues living, as an "undead", they will lose more and more blood, and because of her power over them, they will come to seek her; thus, she will suck their blood with that horrendous mouth. But if it truly dies, then everything ceases; the throats' openings disappear, and the children can continue with their games, without even remembering what has been happening to them. But the best of all is that when we make this corpse that is now "undead" truly die, the soul of the poor lady whom we all love will be free again. Instead of carrying out her horrendous crimes at night and spending the days digesting her dreadful meal, she will take her place among the other angels. So, my friend, it will be a blessed hand by her that delivers the blow to free her. I feel ready to do it, but isn't there someone among us who has a greater right to do it? Wouldn't it be a joy to think, in the silence of the night, when sleep refuses to envelop him: "It was my hand that sent her to heaven; it was the hand of the one who loved her the most; the hand she would have chosen above all others, if she could have done so."? Tell me, is there someone like that among us?

en: We all looked at Arthur. He saw, too, what we all did, the infinite kindness which suggested that his should be the hand which would restore Lucy to us as a holy, and not an unholy, memory; he stepped forward and said bravely, though his hand trembled, and his face was as pale as snow:—
vi: All of us, without saying a word, turned our eyes to Arthur, and like us, he fully understood Van Helsing's chivalrous intention. I understood his feelings through his gesture of reaching out to the professor. He stepped towards the professor, his hand trembling, his face pale:
tr: We all looked at Arthur. He saw what we were doing, saw the infinite kindness suggesting that it should be his hand to bring Lucy back to us not as a sinner, but as a sacred memory; he stepped forward and, despite his hand trembling and his face being as white as snow, he bravely said: “My true friend, I thank you from the very depths of my broken heart.
es: We all looked at Arthur. He understood, just like all of us, the infinite kindness that suggested it should be his hand that would return Lucy to us as a sacred memory, no longer infernal; he took a step forward and said bravely, even though his hands were trembling and his face was as pale as if it were made of snow:

en: “My true friend, from the bottom of my broken heart I thank you. Tell me what I am to do, and I shall not falter!” Van Helsing laid a hand on his shoulder, and said:—
vi: — From the bottom of my heart, I sincerely thank you, a friend, a true friend of mine. Tell me what to do, I will calmly follow your instructions.
tr: He saw what we were doing, saw the infinite kindness suggesting that it should be his hand to bring Lucy back to us not as a sinner, but as a sacred memory; he stepped forward and, despite his hand trembling and his face being as white as snow, he bravely said: “My true friend, I thank you from the very depths of my broken heart. Tell me what I must do and I will not hesitate!” Van Helsing placed his hand on Arthur’s shoulder and said:
es: –My dear friend, I thank you from the bottom of my broken heart. Tell me what I have to do and I will not fail! Van Helsing put a hand on his shoulder and said:

en: “Brave lad! A moment’s courage, and it is done. This stake must be driven through her. It will be a fearful ordeal—be not deceived in that—but it will be only a short time, and you will then rejoice more than your pain was great; from this grim tomb you will emerge as though you tread on air. But you must not falter when once you have begun. Only think that we, your true friends, are round you, and that we pray for you all the time.”
vi: — Hooray for the young man! You just need to be brave for a moment, just a moment, that's enough! The issue is that you have to drive this small stake through the body. I repeat that this is indeed the most terrible challenge of your life, but it will be over quickly. And the joy you will receive will be much greater than the pain you have endured. In just a moment, when you leave here, you will feel like a person with wings. However, just a bit of hesitation and you won't accomplish anything. Think that we are standing here, beside you, and always praying for you in these most terrible moments.
tr: “Brave young man! A moment of courage and it will all be over. This stake needs to be driven into him. It will be a terrifying, arduous test - do not be deceived about that - but it will be short, and then you will rejoice more than the magnitude of your pain; you will walk out of this ugly grave as if you were walking on air. But once you start, you must not hesitate. Just think that we, your true friends, are around you and always praying for you.”
es: –Bravo! A moment of courage and everything will be over. You must pierce your body with this stake. It will be a terrible trial, think nothing else; but it will only last an instant, and afterwards, the joy you will feel will be much greater than the pain that action will cause you; from this sad crypt, you will emerge as if flying in the air. But you must not fail once you have started doing it. Just think that all of us, your best friends, will be around you, constantly praying for you.

en: “Go on,” said Arthur hoarsely. “Tell me what I am to do.”
vi: — Alright, what do I have to do? - Arthur replied, choking up.
tr: “Go on,” said Arthur in a hoarse voice, “tell me what I need to do.”
es: Just think that all of us, your best friends, will be around you, constantly praying for you. Take that stake in your left hand, ready to place the tip over the corpse's heart, and the hammer in your right hand.

en: “Take this stake in your left hand, ready to place the point over the heart, and the hammer in your right. Then when we begin our prayer for the dead—I shall read him, I have here the book, and the others shall follow—strike in God’s name, that so all may be well with the dead that we love and that the Un-Dead pass away.”
vi: — You hold this stake in your left hand, with the tip of the stake aimed directly at her heart, and in your right hand, hold this hammer. When I recite the prayers for the souls, I will be holding the prayer book here, and when I read, the two of you should chant along, and you must, in the name of God, drive the hammer into the stake. Only by doing so will your beloved girl find peace and the immortal being within her body be forever banished from this world!
tr: “Take this stake in your left hand, ready to place its tip over his heart, and the mallet in your right hand. Then we will begin the prayer for the dead - I will read it, the book is right here, and the others will follow me - in the name of God, drive it in so that everything concerning this beloved dead one will be well and the Un-Dead will pass away.”
es: Take that stake in your left hand, ready to place the tip over the corpse's heart, and the hammer in your right hand. Then, when we begin the prayer for the dead... I will read it. I have the book here and the others will recite with me. Then, strike in the name of God, for thus everything will go well for the soul of the one we love and the "undead" will die.

en: Arthur took the stake and the hammer, and when once his mind was set on action his hands never trembled nor even quivered. Van Helsing opened his missal and began to read, and Quincey and I followed as well as we could. Arthur placed the point over the heart, and as I looked I could see its dint in the white flesh. Then he struck with all his might.
vi: Arthur resolutely held the stake and hammer; clearly, once he decided to act, he was no longer trembling or hesitant. Van Helsing began to open the Bible and read, Quincey and I tried to chant along. Arthur precisely placed the tip of the stake on Lucy, where the heart no longer held the passionate love of a demure girl as in his memories, and with all his strength, he drove each blow, each blow decisively.
tr: Arthur took the stake and hammer, and as soon as his mind was set in motion, his hands did not tremble for a moment. Van Helsing opened the prayer book and began to read, and Quincey and I followed him as best as we could. Arthur placed the tip of the stake over the heart; when I looked, I could see the small indentation it made in the flesh. Then, he struck with all his might.
es: Arthur took the stake and the hammer, and, since his mind was occupied with something specific, his hands no longer trembled at all. Van Helsing opened his missal and began to read, and Quincey and I repeated what he said as best as we could. Arthur placed the tip of the stake over the heart of the corpse and, as I watched, I could see the depression in the white flesh. Then, he struck with all his might.

en: The Thing in the coffin writhed; and a hideous, blood-curdling screech came from the opened red lips. The body shook and quivered and twisted in wild contortions; the sharp white teeth champed together till the lips were cut, and the mouth was smeared with a crimson foam. But Arthur never faltered. He looked like a figure of Thor as his untrembling arm rose and fell, driving deeper and deeper the mercy-bearing stake, whilst the blood from the pierced heart welled and spurted up around it. His face was set, and high duty seemed to shine through it; the sight of it gave us courage so that our voices seemed to ring through the little vault.
vi: The corpse in the coffin began to shake, struggling and writhing incessantly, and from her crimson lips suddenly came a hoarse, guttural cry that made one's heart stop. Her sharp teeth bit tightly into her sensual lips until they bled. Arthur continued to drive the stake, even though for a moment he seemed to lose his courage, letting the hammer fall slack in his hand, but only for a moment. I noticed a stream of blood flowing from the wretched heart of the immortal being down below.
tr: The thing in the coffin writhed in agony; from the open, red lips came a disgusting, blood-curdling scream. Its body shook and trembled, twisting and contorting wildly; its sharp white teeth clashed together, cutting its lips until its mouth filled with red foam. But Arthur did not hesitate. As his arm rose and fell without trembling, he drove the merciful stake deeper, even as blood spurted from the shattered heart. His face was resolute, and the expression of holy duty on his face shone; this sight gave us courage, so that our voices seemed to echo in the small tomb chamber.
es: The object that was in the coffin writhed and a chilling and horrible scream came from between the slightly parted red lips. The body shook, shuddered, and writhed with wild movements; the sharp white teeth clenched until the lips parted and the mouth filled with scarlet foam. But Arthur did not hesitate for a moment. He seemed like a representation of the Scandinavian god Thor, as his firm arm rose and fell relentlessly, driving the pious stake deeper and deeper, while the blood from the shattered heart gushed out forcefully and spread around the wound. His face was contorted and hardened by what he believed to be a duty; seeing him gave us courage and our voices rang out clearly within the small crypt.

en: And then the writhing and quivering of the body became less, and the teeth seemed to champ, and the face to quiver. Finally it lay still. The terrible task was over.
vi: The corpse gradually stopped shaking violently and writhing in agony; only her face still twitched intermittently, and her teeth remained clenched on her lip. It took a while before the corpse truly became a corpse: it lay completely motionless and showed no signs of being an immortal. Thus, the terrifying task that seemed impossible was accomplished!
tr: And then, the body's writhing and trembling began to subside, and the teeth stopped chattering, the face stopped twitching. Finally, it lay still. The horrifying task was over.
es: Gradually, the trembling and also the sudden movements of the body decreased, the teeth seemed to bite, and the face trembled. Finally, the corpse remained motionless. The terrible deed was done.

en: The hammer fell from Arthur’s hand. He reeled and would have fallen had we not caught him. The great drops of sweat sprang from his forehead, and his breath came in broken gasps. It had indeed been an awful strain on him; and had he not been forced to his task by more than human considerations he could never have gone through with it. For a few minutes we were so taken up with him that we did not look towards the coffin. When we did, however, a murmur of startled surprise ran from one to the other of us. We gazed so eagerly that Arthur rose, for he had been seated on the ground, and came and looked too; and then a glad, strange light broke over his face and dispelled altogether the gloom of horror that lay upon it.
vi: Arthur dropped the hammer, staggering unsteadily, and if we hadn't rushed to support him, he would have collapsed to the ground. He was panting, sweat beading on his forehead. The effort we asked of him was clearly extraordinary; without rationality and humane consideration, he certainly couldn't have accomplished it. We were so focused on him that no one paid attention to the coffin anymore, but about ten minutes later, a strange, indescribable feeling suddenly surged within us, causing everyone to turn their eyes to that place. No one could suppress a silent cry of astonishment. Arthur slowly stood up, as we had to let him sit and rest to recover, and approached Lucy. The feeling of joy had replaced the constant fear and melancholy on his face.
tr: The hammer fell from Arthur's hand. He staggered, if I hadn't held him, he would have fallen. Large drops of sweat were bursting from his forehead, and his breath was coming in short, labored gasps. It had truly been a terrible strain for him; he would never have undertaken this task if something much more than human considerations hadn't compelled him. For a minute or two, we were all so concerned with him that we didn't even look towards the coffin. But when we did look at the coffin, a murmur of astonishment came from each of us. We were looking with such passion that Arthur, who was sitting on the ground, got up and came to look as well; then his face lit up with a strange, satisfied smile that completely dispelled the gloom of horror on his face.
es: The hammer fell from Arthur's hands. He spun on his heels, and would have fallen to the ground if we hadn't held him up. Thick drops of sweat appeared on his forehead and he was breathing with difficulty. In reality, he had been subjected to tremendous tension, and if he hadn't been compelled to do so by considerations more important than anything human, he would never have been able to successfully complete that horrible task. For a few minutes, we were so engrossed with him that we didn't look at the coffin at all. When we did, however, a murmur of astonishment escaped all our lips. We looked so strange that Arthur got up, as he had been sitting on the floor, and also approached to look; then, an expression full of joy, with a strange gleam, appeared on his face, replacing the horror that had been imprinted on his features until then.

en: There, in the coffin lay no longer the foul Thing that we had so dreaded and grown to hate that the work of her destruction was yielded as a privilege to the one best entitled to it, but Lucy as we had seen her in her life, with her face of unequalled sweetness and purity. True that there were there, as we had seen them in life, the traces of care and pain and waste; but these were all dear to us, for they marked her truth to what we knew. One and all we felt that the holy calm that lay like sunshine over the wasted face and form was only an earthly token and symbol of the calm that was to reign for ever.
vi: Lying in the coffin was no longer the terrifying immortal, causing everyone to harbor suspicion and hatred to the point that destroying her body and soul became a priority for the most deserving among us, but rather Lucy, a Lucy with the gentle, pure face we once knew when she was alive. The contemplation, the sadness, and the true pain of the everyday Lucy had now returned to that face. The feeling of affection also returned to us. We suddenly understood that from now on, that face would bring us complete tranquility, a peaceful life filled with memories of joy and sorrow. Her physical and spiritual resurrection could only be evidence, a worldly symbol of eternal slumber.
tr: Now in the coffin, it was not that repulsive Thing we so despised and left to the person most authorized to destroy it, but Lucy as we had seen her in life, with her unique sweetness and purity. It was true that there were traces of anxiety, pain, and exhaustion as we had seen in life; but all of these were precious to us because they indicated the reality of her as we had once known her. We all felt that the holy calmness extending over that ravaged face and body like daylight was the earthly sign and symbol of the eternal calm that would reign forever.
es: There, in the coffin, no longer rested the dreadful thing we had hated so much, whose destruction we considered a privilege and entrusted to the most suitable person for it, but Lucy, just as we had known her in life, with her face of unparalleled sweetness and purity. It is true that her features reflected the pain and worry that we had all seen in life; but that seemed pleasant to us, because they were truly an integral part of the real Lucy. We all felt that the calm that shone like sunlight over the face and body of the deceased was only an earthly symbol of the tranquility she would enjoy for all eternity.

en: Van Helsing came and laid his hand on Arthur’s shoulder, and said to him:—
vi: At this moment, Van Helsing finally placed his hand on Arthur's shoulder and asked him:
tr: Van Helsing came and put his hand on Arthur's shoulder and said:
es: Van Helsing approached, placed his hand on Arthur's shoulder, and said to him:

en: “And now, Arthur my friend, dear lad, am I not forgiven?”
vi: — So, my friend? Can you forgive me now?
tr: "And now Arthur, my friend, dear young man, have I not been forgiven?"
es: –And now, Arthur, my dear friend, haven't you forgiven me?

en: The reaction of the terrible strain came as he took the old man’s hand in his, and raising it to his lips, pressed it, and said:—
vi: Arthur, with tears in his eyes, tightly grasped the old professor's hand and choked out:
tr: Arthur's reaction to this terrible tension emerged when he took the old man's hand in his and brought it to his lips:
es: The reaction to the terrible tension occurred when she took the old man's hand in hers, lifted it to her lips, pressed it against them, and said:

en: “Forgiven! God bless you that you have given my dear one her soul again, and me peace.” He put his hands on the Professor’s shoulder, and laying his head on his breast, cried for a while silently, whilst we stood unmoving. When he raised his head Van Helsing said to him:—
vi: — I am the one who should thank you, Van Helsing. God will bless you. You are the one who has restored the true soul to the girl I love and brought me peace! Arthur could only say that much before he buried his head in the man's shoulder, crying and sobbing with heart-wrenching gasps. Van Helsing waited for him to lift his face before speaking:
tr: “Forgiveness! God bless you for restoring my lover's soul and bringing me peace.” He placed his hands on the Professor's shoulders and, resting his head on his chest, cried silently for a while as we stood still. When he lifted his head, Van Helsing said to him:
es: –Forgive him? May God bless him for having returned his soul to my beloved and peace to me! She placed her hands on the professor's shoulder and, resting her head on his chest, cried silently while we remained motionless. When she lifted her head again, Van Helsing said to her:

en: “And now, my child, you may kiss her. Kiss her dead lips if you will, as she would have you to, if for her to choose. For she is not a grinning devil now—not any more a foul Thing for all eternity. No longer she is the devil’s Un-Dead. She is God’s true dead, whose soul is with Him!”
vi: — My friend, now you can embrace her tightly. And if you wish, you can place upon her sweet lips a kiss that she has long awaited. Now she is no longer a ghost with a grotesque smile, and she never will be again. Lucy is no longer an immortal, an accomplice of the devil. She is now truly one of God's dead, her soul has returned to Him!
tr: “And now, my child, you may kiss him. If you wish, kiss his dead lips; if he had the choice, he would want this too. For he is no longer a grinning demon - no longer a vile Thing that would live forever. He is no longer the Undead of the devil. His soul is now a true dead one beside God!”
es: –Now, my friend, you may kiss her. Kiss her dead lips if you wish, as she would wish if she could choose. Since she is no longer a smiling devil…, a cursed object for all eternity. She is no longer the diabolical "living dead." She is a dead woman who belongs to God and her soul is with Him!.

en: Arthur bent and kissed her, and then we sent him and Quincey out of the tomb; the Professor and I sawed the top off the stake, leaving the point of it in the body. Then we cut off the head and filled the mouth with garlic. We soldered up the leaden coffin, screwed on the coffin-lid, and gathering up our belongings, came away. When the Professor locked the door he gave the key to Arthur.
vi: Arthur bent down and placed a final kiss on the beloved face of the girl. After that, I took him and Quincey out of the mausoleum, while I had to go back in with the professor to finish the last tasks: sawing off the excess wooden stake protruding from Lucy's body and filling her mouth with garlic. Finally, we sealed the inner lead lining and screwed the wooden lid back onto the coffin as it was originally. Once done, we packed up our belongings and left. After locking the mausoleum door, the professor handed the key back to Arthur.
tr: Arthur bent down and kissed Lucy, then we sent Arthur and Quincey outside the grave; the Professor and I cut the stake so that its end would remain inside the body. Then, we cut off Lucy's head and filled her mouth with garlic. We soldered the lead coffin, screwed the lid of the coffin, gathered our belongings, and left the place. When the Professor locked the door, he gave the key to Arthur.
es: Arthur leaned in and kissed her. Then, we sent Arthur and Quincey out of the crypt. The professor and I cut off the top of the stake, leaving the tip inside the body. Then, we cut off her head and filled her mouth with garlic. We carefully welded the lead box, placed the coffin lid in its place, tightened the screws, and after gathering everything that belonged to us, we left the crypt. The professor closed the door and handed the key to Arthur.

en: Outside the air was sweet, the sun shone, and the birds sang, and it seemed as if all nature were tuned to a different pitch. There was gladness and mirth and peace everywhere, for we were at rest ourselves on one account, and we were glad, though it was with a tempered joy.
vi: Outside, the sky is blue, the clouds are clear, the sunlight is abundant, and the sounds of birds chirping create a peaceful rhythm of life. It seems that nature and the scenery have taken on a gentler tone, quite different from usual. Or perhaps it is because we no longer carry the worries and sorrows that have weighed heavily on our hearts for so long.
tr: The weather outside was pleasant, the sun was shining, the birds were singing, and it was as if all of nature had transitioned to a different pitch. Everywhere there was joy, happiness, and peace, because for some reason we had all found tranquility and, albeit with a light cheerfulness, we were content.
es: Outside, the air was gentle, the sun was shining, the birds were chirping, and it seemed that all of nature had completely changed. There was joy, peace, and tranquility everywhere. We still felt like ourselves and full of joy, although it was not an intense joy, but rather something gentle and very pleasant.

en: Before we moved away Van Helsing said:—
vi: However, before parting ways with us, Van Helsing said:
tr: Before leaving, Van Helsing said: "Now, my friends, one step of our task, the saddest for us, is completed.
es: Before we started moving away from that place, Van Helsing said:

en: “Now, my friends, one step of our work is done, one the most harrowing to ourselves. But there remains a greater task: to find out the author of all this our sorrow and to stamp him out. I have clues which we can follow; but it is a long task, and a difficult, and there is danger in it, and pain. Shall you not all help me? We have learned to believe, all of us—is it not so? And since so, do we not see our duty? Yes! And do we not promise to go on to the bitter end?”
vi: — So the first part, which can also be said to be the most difficult part, of our work has been completed. But my friends, we still have another task that, in some respects, is no less important: that is to identify the culprit who caused Lucy's misfortune and to make him disappear from this world forever. To a certain extent, I have obtained a few keys to assist in this search. But please also be aware that the work will be prolonged and even very dangerous. Will you help me? But first, what I need from you now is still faith. We will get to the bottom of this matter, won't we?
tr: Before leaving, Van Helsing said: "Now, my friends, one step of our task, the saddest for us, is completed. But we have a greater task ahead: to find and crush the source of all our suffering. I have various clues we can follow; but this is a long and arduous task, filled with danger and pain. Will you all not help me? We have learned to believe, all of us - haven't we? Since this is the case, do we not see our duty? Yes! And do we not all promise to go to the end?"
es: –Now, my friends, we have already completed a stage of our work, the hardest for us. But a much more difficult task awaits us: to discover the author of all these sufferings that we have had to endure and eliminate them. I have clues that we can follow, but it is a long and difficult task, full of dangers and pain. Won't all of you help me? We have all learned to believe, haven't we? And, being so, don't we see what our duty is? Yes! Don't we promise to go to the end, no matter how bitter it may be?

en: Each in turn, we took his hand, and the promise was made. Then said the Professor as we moved off:—
vi: We each shook his hand with a promise to offer our sincerest help. As we parted, he added:
tr: We all shook hands in turn, and thus the promise was made. Then, as we were moving away, the Professor said: "Two nights from now, you will meet me, and at seven o'clock, we will have dinner with our friend John.
es: We all accepted his hand, one by one, and promised. Then, as we walked away from the cemetery, the professor said:

en: “Two nights hence you shall meet with me and dine together at seven of the clock with friend John. I shall entreat two others, two that you know not as yet; and I shall be ready to all our work show and our plans unfold. Friend John, you come with me home, for I have much to consult about, and you can help me. To-night I leave for Amsterdam, but shall return to-morrow night. And then begins our great quest. But first I shall have much to say, so that you may know what is to do and to dread. Then our promise shall be made to each other anew; for there is a terrible task before us, and once our feet are on the ploughshare we must not draw back.”
vi: — Tomorrow evening, around seven o'clock, we will go together to have dinner at our friend John's house. I would like to invite both of you, Arthur and Quincey. All the plans have been meticulously calculated by me, I will explain later. John, now come home with me first, I want to consult you on some matters. Tonight, I might have to go back to Amsterdam to handle some business, but I will try to be here by tomorrow afternoon. After that, we will start our large-scale investigation, I will thoroughly explain everything that needs to be done and what I am still suspicious about. But remember, once we start, there is no turning back.
tr: Then, as we were moving away, the Professor said: "Two nights from now, you will meet me, and at seven o'clock, we will have dinner with our friend John. I will also ask two people whom you have not yet met; I will be ready for our work and the developing plan. My friend John, you are coming home with me because there are many things I need to discuss with you, and you can help me. I am leaving for Amsterdam tonight, but I will return tomorrow evening. And then our great quest will begin. But first, I will have much to say, so you will learn what to do and what to avoid. Then the promise we made to each other will be reiterated; because we have a dreadful task ahead of us, and once we put our foot to the plow, we must not pull back."
es: –In two nights, you must meet with me to have dinner together at our friend John's house. I need to speak with two other friends, two people you do not know yet; and I must prepare to have the work program and all our plans ready. Friend John, come with me home, as I have many things to consult with you and you can help me. Tonight, I will leave for Amsterdam, but I will return tomorrow night. Then our work will truly begin. But before that, I will have many things to tell you, so you know what we have to do and what we must fear. Then, we will renew our promise to each other, as we face a terrible task, and once we set foot on this path, we will not be able to turn back.

en: CHAPTER XVII
vi: CHAPTER 17
tr: XVII
es: XVII.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY—continued
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary (continued)
tr: Dr. Seward's journal (continued)
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD (continued)

en: WHEN we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram waiting for him:—
vi: We had just arrived at the Berkeley Hotel when a servant hurriedly ran out to inform us that someone had sent a telegram to Van Helsing: "I am coming by train.
tr: When we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram waiting for him:
es: When we arrived at the Berkeley Hotel, Van Helsing found a telegram that had arrived in his absence:

en: “Am coming up by train. Jonathan at Whitby. Important news.—Mina Harker.”
vi: We had just arrived at the Berkeley Hotel when a servant hurriedly ran out to inform us that someone had sent a telegram to Van Helsing: "I am coming by train. Jonathan is in Whitby. Important news. Mina Harker."
tr: I am coming by train. Jonathan is in Whitby. Important news. Mina Harker
es: "I will arrive by train. Jonathan in Whitby. Important news. MINA HARKER."

en: The Professor was delighted. “Ah, that wonderful Madam Mina,” he said, “pearl among women! She arrive, but I cannot stay. She must go to your house, friend John. You must meet her at the station. Telegraph her en route, so that she may be prepared.”
vi: The professor exclaimed loudly, his face very cheerful: — Ah! So it turns out to be Mrs. Mina! Our ruby! But unfortunately, she arrives and I can't wait for her. Maybe you should take her to your house, John, and perhaps you have to go to the station to pick her up. I will send her a telegram to let her know.
tr: The professor was very pleased. “Ah, the wonderful Madam Mina,” he said, “A pearl among women! She is coming, but I cannot stay. She must go to your house, my friend John. You must meet her at the station. Send her a telegram on the way so she can be prepared.”
es: The professor was delighted. "Ah! That wonderful Mrs. Mina," he said. "A pearl among women!" "She is coming; but I can't stay to wait for her." "You must take her to your house, friend John." "You must go to receive her at the station." "Send her a telegram on the way so she will be prepared."

en: When the wire was despatched he had a cup of tea; over it he told me of a diary kept by Jonathan Harker when abroad, and gave me a typewritten copy of it, as also of Mrs. Harker’s diary at Whitby. “Take these,” he said, “and study them well. When I have returned you will be master of all the facts, and we can then better enter on our inquisition. Keep them safe, for there is in them much of treasure. You will need all your faith, even you who have had such an experience as that of to-day. What is here told,” he laid his hand heavily and gravely on the packet of papers as he spoke, “may be the beginning of the end to you and me and many another; or it may sound the knell of the Un-Dead who walk the earth. Read all, I pray you, with the open mind; and if you can add in any way to the story here told do so, for it is all-important. You have kept diary of all these so strange things; is it not so? Yes! Then we shall go through all these together when we meet.” He then made ready for his departure, and shortly after drove off to Liverpool Street. I took my way to Paddington, where I arrived about fifteen minutes before the train came in.
vi: After sending the telegram, he made tea while talking to me about the diary that Jonathan Harker had written during his days abroad. He gave me a copy of his diary and one written in Whitby by Mina, both of which had been very clearly typed out. — Take it and read it, read it very carefully, my friend. Make sure that by tomorrow night, when I come back, you know all the details in these two diaries. After that, we will start studying each issue. But you must keep these papers carefully, they are all treasures. I also want to remind you that from now on, you must have absolute faith, even though you have experienced things that at first seemed unbelievable and impossible to trust. For you, for me, and for many others, the story told here - he said, placing his hand on the stack of papers - could be the beginning of an end, or it could be the death knell of the immortal being preparing to destroy life on this earth. I want you not to overlook any detail, and if you can clarify something you have contemplated, please do so, because somewhere that is the most important thing we must aim for. It seems you also have a diary recording at least more than one surprising event that has happened, right? If so, in the coming days, we will together find a thread connecting the disparate events related to the overall picture of reality. The passage where he prepares to leave for Amsterdam. As for me, I had to go to Paddington to pick up Mina Harker. I arrived about fifteen minutes before the train was due to arrive. The train arrived, and passengers quickly dispersed in various directions.
tr: When the telegram was sent, Van Helsing had a cup of tea; while drinking his tea, he mentioned the journal kept by Jonathan Harker while he was abroad and gave me typed copies of both his and Ms. Harker’s journals from Whitby. “Take these,” he said, “and study them thoroughly. When I return, you will be familiar with all the facts, so we can start our investigation better. Keep them safe, because they contain things of great value. Even though you have had an experience like today, you will need all your faith. The things described here,” he placed his hand firmly and seriously on the stack of papers as he spoke, "could be the beginning of the end for you, me, and many others, or it might sound like the death knell of the Undead walking the earth. Please, read them with an open mind and if you have anything to add to what is described here, please do so because it is all important. You have kept a journal of all these strange events, haven’t you? Yes! Then, when we come together, we will go over all of this together.” Then, he prepared to leave and shortly after, went by car to Liverpool Street. As for me, I set off for Paddington, where I arrived fifteen minutes before the train came.
es: When we sent the telegram, the professor took a cup of tea; then, he talked to me about a diary of Jonathan Harker and handed me a typed copy, as well as the diary that Mina Harker wrote in Whitby. –Take them -he told me- and examine them carefully. By the time I return, you will be up to date with all the facts and we can better undertake our investigations. Take care of them, as their content is a true treasure. You will need all your faith, despite the experience you had today. What is said here -he placed his hand heavily, with gravity, on the pile of papers as he spoke-, could be the beginning of the end for you, for me, and for many others; or it could mean the end of the "living dead" that commits so many atrocities on earth. Read it all, I beg you, with attention. And if you can add anything to the story told here, do so, as in this case everything is important. You have recorded all those strange events in your diary, haven't you? Of course! Well, then, we will review everything together when I return. Next, he made all the preparations for his trip and, shortly after, headed to Liverpool Street. I made my way to Paddington, where I arrived about a quarter of an hour before the train's arrival.

en: The crowd melted away, after the bustling fashion common to arrival platforms; and I was beginning to feel uneasy, lest I might miss my guest, when a sweet-faced, dainty-looking girl stepped up to me, and, after a quick glance, said: “Dr. Seward, is it not?”
vi: While anxiously waiting, fearing that the guest might get lost, I suddenly recognized a beautiful and elegant young woman approaching me. — Excuse me, are you Dr. Seward?
tr: After the usual bustle on the arrival platform, the crowd dispersed; I was starting to get anxious that I might have missed my guest, when a cute, petite-looking girl came up to me and, after a brief look, said, "Doctor Seward, isn't it?"
es: The crowd began to thin out after the characteristic movement on the arrival platforms. I was starting to feel uneasy, fearing I wouldn't find my guest, when a young woman with a sweet face and delicate appearance approached me, and after a quick glance, she said: –You are Dr. Seward, aren't you?

en: “And you are Mrs. Harker!” I answered at once; whereupon she held out her hand.
vi: — And you are Mrs. Harker, Mina Harker? The young woman happily extended her hand to me.
tr: "And you must be Ms. Harker!" I immediately replied; with that, she extended her hand.
es: –And you must be Mrs. Harker! – I responded immediately. Then, the young woman extended her hand to me.

en: “I knew you from the description of poor dear Lucy; but——” She stopped suddenly, and a quick blush overspread her face.
vi: — I recognized you from Lucy's description... She suddenly stammered and stopped, her face turning red.
tr: “I know you from poor dear Lucy's description, but,” he suddenly stopped and his face quickly turned bright red.
es: –I knew him from the description that poor Lucy gave me; but… she suddenly fell silent and a deep blush covered her cheeks.

en: The blush that rose to my own cheeks somehow set us both at ease, for it was a tacit answer to her own. I got her luggage, which included a typewriter, and we took the Underground to Fenchurch Street, after I had sent a wire to my housekeeper to have a sitting-room and bedroom prepared at once for Mrs. Harker.
vi: I also blushed with embarrassment, but that made us feel more comfortable, as it was, after all, a tacit response to what she had just reminded us of. I carried the guest's luggage, which included a typewriter, and led her to the subway station on Fenchurch Street. Upon arrival, I telegraphed home to ask the housekeeper to prepare a private room for Harker.
tr: The blush spreading to my cheeks also relieved us both, because it had been a silent answer to his question. I took his luggage, which included a typewriter, and after sending a telegram to my butler to prepare a living room and bedroom for Ms. Harker, we went to Fenchurch Street by subway.
es: The blush that appeared on my own face reassured both of us in a way, since it was a tacit response to hers. I took her luggage, which included a typewriter, and we took the subway to Fenchurch Street, after sending a message to my housekeeper to prepare a sitting room and a bedroom for the newcomer.

en: In due time we arrived. She knew, of course, that the place was a lunatic asylum, but I could see that she was unable to repress a shudder when we entered.
vi: I returned home at the scheduled time. Harker immediately recognized that my place was a mental hospital, but that did not deter her from hesitating when stepping through the door.
tr: We arrived on time. Of course, she knew this was a mental hospital, but I could see that she couldn't help but shiver slightly when we entered.
es: We arrived soon. The young woman knew, of course, that the place was an asylum for the insane; but I saw that she could not suppress a shudder when we entered.

en: She told me that, if she might, she would come presently to my study, as she had much to say. So here I am finishing my entry in my phonograph diary whilst I await her. As yet I have not had the chance of looking at the papers which Van Helsing left with me, though they lie open before me. I must get her interested in something, so that I may have an opportunity of reading them. She does not know how precious time is, or what a task we have in hand. I must be careful not to frighten her. Here she is!
vi: As soon as she entered the house, without even having a chance to sit down, she said that if it was not inconvenient for me, she would go straight to my office, as she had many things to discuss with me. While waiting for her to arrange her luggage, I took the opportunity to record my diary on the tape recorder. To be honest, I wasn't at all enthusiastic about having to read the pile of papers that Van Helsing had just handed over, which I had left on the table. Of course, I also had to allocate some time to read through a bit so that I could have something to ask Harker. In fact, this young woman did not yet understand how precious time was for us now, nor did she know about the crucial mission awaiting us. Mina Harker's Diary
tr: He said that he wanted to come to my study room immediately if possible because he had a lot to tell. Therefore, while waiting for him now, I am finishing this entry in my phonograph journal. Despite being open in front of me, I haven't had a chance to look at the documents Van Helsing left for me until now. I must find something that will catch Ms. Harker's interest so that I can have the opportunity to read these documents. She doesn't know how valuable time is or what kind of work we have in hand. I must be careful not to scare her. Here she comes!
es: He told me that if it was possible, he would like to accompany me to my study, because he had a lot to talk to me about. Therefore, I am finishing recording the knowledge in my phonographic diary while I wait for him. Since I have not yet had the opportunity to read the papers entrusted to me by Van Helsing, although they are spread out in front of me, I will have to get the lady interested in something so that I can devote myself to reading them. She does not know how precious time is or the nature of the task we have undertaken. I must be careful not to scare her. Here she comes!

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 29 September.—After I had tidied myself, I went down to Dr. Seward’s study. At the door I paused a moment, for I thought I heard him talking with some one. As, however, he had pressed me to be quick, I knocked at the door, and on his calling out, “Come in,” I entered.
vi: • September 29 After hastily packing my belongings, I immediately went down to Seward's office. I hesitated to knock on the door, as it seemed the doctor was seeing someone inside. However, I remembered that he had told me earlier to come see him as soon as I was done, so I boldly knocked on the door.
tr: September 29 - After tidying myself up, I went down to Dr. Seward's study. I paused for a moment at the door because I thought I heard him talking to someone. But since he was urging me to be quick, I knocked on the door, and upon hearing him say "Come in," I entered the room.
es: September 29. After settling in, I went down to Dr. Seward's study. At the door, I paused for a moment because I thought I heard him talking to someone. However, since he had begged me not to waste time, I knocked on the door and entered the study once he gave me permission to do so.

en: To my intense surprise, there was no one with him. He was quite alone, and on the table opposite him was what I knew at once from the description to be a phonograph. I had never seen one, and was much interested.
vi: He responded right away: "Come in!" Strangely, he was alone in the room, but when I looked at the table, I immediately guessed that he had just spoken into a recording device that I had never seen before, only heard about from others. The device instantly captured my attention.
tr: Apparently, there was no one inside. He was all alone, and on the table in front of him was something that I understood to be a phonograph from its description. I had never seen one before, and it intrigued me greatly.
es: I was very surprised to find that there was no one with him. He was absolutely alone, and on the table in front of him was what I immediately knew, from the descriptions, to be a phonograph. I had never seen one before and it interested me a lot.

en: “I hope I did not keep you waiting,” I said; “but I stayed at the door as I heard you talking, and thought there was some one with you.”
vi: — I hope I didn't keep you waiting for long. - I said - Actually, I have been standing outside the door for a while, but I heard you talking and thought you had a guest.
tr: “I hope I haven't kept you waiting,” I said; “but when I heard you talking and thought someone was with you, I waited at the door.”
es: "I hope I haven't kept you waiting long," I said to him, "but I stopped at the door because I thought I heard you talking and assumed there was someone in your study."

en: “Oh,” he replied with a smile, “I was only entering my diary.”
vi: — Oh! I'm just keeping a diary. - He replied with a laugh.
tr: “Ah,” he replied with a laugh, “I was just jotting down something in my journal.”
es: –Oh! – he replied, with a smile-. I was just recording the latest events in my diary.

en: “Your diary?” I asked him in surprise.
vi: — Diary?
tr: “To your journal?” I asked in astonishment.
es: "Your diary?" I asked, very surprised.

en: “Yes,” he answered. “I keep it in this.” As he spoke he laid his hand on the phonograph. I felt quite excited over it, and blurted out:—
vi: — Yes, here it is, the diary is right here. — He said while placing his hand on the tape recorder. — What? - I asked in surprise -
tr: “Yes,” he replied. “I keep it here.” As he spoke, he placed his hand on the phonograph. I got very excited about this and blurted out:
es: –Yes -he replied-, I record it on this device. As he spoke, he placed his hand on the phonograph. I felt very excited and exclaimed:

en: “Why, this beats even shorthand! May I hear it say something?”
vi: If that's the case, it's even better than my shorthand trick! Can I listen to a segment?
tr: “Hey! But he can even beat this wall! Can I hear you say something?”
es: –Wow! This is even faster than shorthand! May I listen to the device for a bit?

en: “Certainly,” he replied with alacrity, and stood up to put it in train for speaking. Then he paused, and a troubled look overspread his face.
vi: — Of course! Seward enthusiastically stood up, intending to run the machine for a test, but for some reason, he stopped, looking very hesitant:
tr: “Of course,” he replied eagerly, standing up to start the machine. Then he stopped, and a troubled expression spread across his face.
es: –Naturally, he replied kindly and stood up to prepare the device so that it would speak. Then, he stopped and a confused expression appeared on his face.

en: “The fact is,” he began awkwardly, “I only keep my diary in it; and as it is entirely—almost entirely—about my cases, it may be awkward—that is, I mean——” He stopped, and I tried to help him out of his embarrassment:—
vi: — Actually... up until now, I have only... only recorded things related to my patients, all funny things... I mean, what I want to say is... The young man stammered, unable to explain his sudden change of mind. Seeing this, I had to choose my words carefully to steer the conversation to another topic to ease his discomfort.
tr: "The truth is," he began awkwardly, "I'm only recording this in my journal; and this is entirely - almost entirely - about my cases, it might be inappropriate - I mean, what I'm trying to say is" - he paused, and I tried to help him overcome his embarrassment:
es: –The thing is -he began in a strange tone that only my diary records; and it refers entirely..., almost completely..., to my cases. It would be something very unpleasant... I mean... He remained silent, and I tried to help him out of his confusion.

en: “You helped to attend dear Lucy at the end. Let me hear how she died; for all that I know of her, I shall be very grateful. She was very, very dear to me.”
vi: — You were with Lucy in her final days. - I said. - Please tell me everything related to her death, I want to know everything about her life. You know, Lucy was my best friend.
tr: “You helped take care of Lucy in her final days. Tell me how she died; I would be very grateful for everything I can learn about her. She was someone very, very important to me.”
es: –You assisted my dear Lucy in her final moments. Let me hear how she died. I will be very grateful for anything you can tell me about her. She was truly very dear to me.

en: To my surprise, he answered, with a horrorstruck look in his face:—
vi: I was very surprised when I caught a glimpse of the panic on his face.
tr: He answered me with a look of horror on his face, surprising me:
es: To my surprise, he responded with an expression of profound horror on his features:

en: “Tell you of her death? Not for the wide world!”
vi: — Tell me about her death? No matter what, I can't tell you!
tr: “Shall I tell you about your death? It won't happen in this world!”
es: –Do you want me to talk to you about your death? Not for anything in the world!

en: “Why not?” I asked, for some grave, terrible feeling was coming over me. Again he paused, and I could see that he was trying to invent an excuse. At length he stammered out:—
vi: — Why not? - I pressed, suddenly feeling a vague sense of fear in my heart. Seward did not answer immediately. I understand you are trying to find some reason. — You see, - He said after a moment of thought - it's really hard for me to find any diary entry related to Lucy in there...
tr: “Why not?” I asked, because a terrible feeling had begun to settle over me. He hesitated once more, I could see he was trying to come up with an excuse. Finally, he stammered and said:
es: –Why not? – I asked, as a terrible feeling began to take hold of me. The doctor paused again, and I could see that he was trying to come up with an excuse. Finally, he stammered: –Do you see?

en: “You see, I do not know how to pick out any particular part of the diary.” Even while he was speaking an idea dawned upon him, and he said with unconscious simplicity, in a different voice, and with the naïveté of a child: “That’s quite true, upon my honour. Honest Indian!” I could not but smile, at which he grimaced. “I gave myself away that time!” he said. “But do you know that, although I have kept the diary for months past, it never once struck me how I was going to find any particular part of it in case I wanted to look it up?” By this time my mind was made up that the diary of a doctor who attended Lucy might have something to add to the sum of our knowledge of that terrible Being, and I said boldly:—
vi: He started to speak but then stopped halfway. It seemed like a thought had just flashed through his mind, because I noticed his tone suddenly changed, sounding more sincere, even as innocent as a child's voice: — That's right! That's it! I burst out laughing at his innocence. — This time, can I be honest with you? Do you know, ever since I started keeping a diary, I have never thought about how I would retrieve a specific entry when needed. Hearing him speak evasively, I suddenly realized that the diary of a doctor who had cared for Lucy in her final days must contain some important details that I needed to supplement what I already knew. Therefore, I immediately suggested:
tr: “As you can see, I don't know how to choose a specific part of the journal.” While speaking, something suddenly occurred to him and with unconscious simplicity, in a different tone of voice and with a child's innocence, he said, “This is really very true, I swear on my honor. If I'm lying, may I be struck down!” I couldn't help but smile, and upon seeing this, he made a face. “This time I gave myself away!” he said. “But you know, even though I've been keeping a journal for months, it never occurred to me how I would find a specific part if I wanted to look back.” During this time, I had come to the conclusion that there might be something in the Doctor's journal, who had been taking care of Lucy, that could add to our knowledge about that horrifying Creature, and I bravely said:
es: I don't know how to remove all the particular details contained in the diary. While speaking, an idea occurred to him, and he said, with a simplicity full of unconsciousness, in a different tone of voice and with the candor of a child: –That is the truth, I give you my word on it. On my honor as an honest Indian! I couldn't help but smile, and the doctor made a face. –This time I have betrayed myself! – he said-. But, do you know that even though I have been keeping the diary up to date for several months now, I never worried about how I could find any particular part of it that I wanted to examine? But this time I convinced myself that the diary of the doctor who attended to Lucy would have something to add to our sum of knowledge about the terrible being, and I said plainly:

en: “Then, Dr. Seward, you had better let me copy it out for you on my typewriter.” He grew to a positively deathly pallor as he said:—
vi: — Doctor, if that's the case, may I transfer the entire contents of the diary from the machine to paper using a typewriter? Seward vehemently refused, his face suddenly turning pale:
tr: "In that case, Dr. Seward, it would be better if you allowed me to make a copy on the typewriter for you." He was absolutely pale when he replied:
es: –Then, Dr. Seward, it would be best if you let me make a copy for you on my typewriter. He turned intensely pale, as he said to me:

en: “No! no! no! For all the world, I wouldn’t let you know that terrible story!”
vi: — No! No! No! I can't do that, I can't let her know that terrible story! Thus, the story seems much more terrifying than I had imagined.
tr: "No! No! No! It can't happen in this world, I can't let you learn that horrifying story!"
es: –No! No! No! For nothing in the world will I let you know that terrible story!

en: Then it was terrible; my intuition was right! For a moment I thought, and as my eyes ranged the room, unconsciously looking for something or some opportunity to aid me, they lit on a great batch of typewriting on the table. His eyes caught the look in mine, and, without his thinking, followed their direction. As they saw the parcel he realised my meaning.
vi: My intuition completely sensed that. While deep in thought, I unconsciously glanced around the room, hoping to find some reason that could help me persuade the young doctor in one way or another, and my eyes suddenly stopped at a stack of typewritten papers on the table. Seward also followed my gaze. I had the impression that he had guessed my intention.
tr: So it was terrifying, my intuition was right! For a moment, I thought, and as my eyes wandered around the room unconsciously searching for something or an opportunity that could help me, they landed on the large stack of typed papers on the table. His eyes caught the look in mine and, without thinking, followed the direction they were pointing. When he saw the stack of papers, he understood what I meant.
es: Therefore, it was terrible. My intuition had not deceived me! For a few moments, I was thinking, and while my eyes carefully examined the room, looking for something or some opportunity that could help me, I saw a pile of typewritten papers on his desk. The doctor's eyes fixed on mine, and involuntarily, he followed the direction of my gaze. Seeing the papers, he understood what I was thinking.

en: “You do not know me,” I said. “When you have read those papers—my own diary and my husband’s also, which I have typed—you will know me better. I have not faltered in giving every thought of my own heart in this cause; but, of course, you do not know me—yet; and I must not expect you to trust me so far.”
vi: — Perhaps you haven't had the chance to know me. - I said. - I hope that when you finish reading that pile of papers, which are the diaries of mine and my husband’s that I have retyped, you will understand me better. I have never hesitated to lend those diaries of my husband and me to others, but clearly, you still don't understand me... don't understand, and of course, I don't expect you to believe in me either.
tr: "You don't know me," I said. "When you read these papers - the journal I typed and my husband's journal - you will know me better. For this purpose, I did not hesitate to share all the thoughts in my heart, but of course, you don't know me - you don't know me yet, and at this stage, I shouldn't expect you to trust me this much."
es: –You don't know me -I said-. When you have read those papers, my husband's diary and my own, which I myself typed, you will know me a little better. I have not failed to express all my thoughts and the feelings of my heart in that diary; but, naturally, you don't know me… yet; and I can't expect you to trust me to reveal something so important.

en: He is certainly a man of noble nature; poor dear Lucy was right about him. He stood up and opened a large drawer, in which were arranged in order a number of hollow cylinders of metal covered with dark wax, and said:—
vi: Lucy is right, Dr. Seward must be a really nice person. As soon as I finished speaking, he immediately stood up and pulled out several black-painted metal tubes stored in a rather large drawer. — This is exactly what you wanted. - He said, his face flushed.
tr: Definitely possessing a noble nature, poor Lucy was not mistaken about him. He stood up and opened the wide drawer filled with boxes of metal tubes covered in black wax, each with numerous holes.
es: Of course, he is a man of very noble nature; my poor Lucy was right about him. He stood up and opened a wide drawer, in which several hollow metal cylinders covered with dark wax were neatly stored, and said:

en: “You are quite right. I did not trust you because I did not know you. But I know you now; and let me say that I should have known you long ago. I know that Lucy told you of me; she told me of you too. May I make the only atonement in my power? Take the cylinders and hear them—the first half-dozen of them are personal to me, and they will not horrify you; then you will know me better. Dinner will by then be ready. In the meantime I shall read over some of these documents, and shall be better able to understand certain things.” He carried the phonograph himself up to my sitting-room and adjusted it for me. Now I shall learn something pleasant, I am sure; for it will tell me the other side of a true love episode of which I know one side already....
vi: - The reason I didn't trust you before was because I didn't know you, that's all. But now, we know each other. Actually, I've heard about you for a long time. I know that Lucy has mentioned me to you before; and she has also told me about you. Sorry! Now please take these tapes and listen. The first six tapes are all about me and of course, there's nothing in them that should concern you. You can listen to them or not, but if you do, you'll understand me better. Dinner is probably almost ready. As for me, I might have to read these documents to learn some additional details. He took the recording device to a small living room adjacent to my room and pressed play. I eagerly prepared to listen to the first diary entries that captured another aspect of the love story, which I had only vaguely known through Lucy's account.
tr: “You are absolutely right. I didn't trust you because I didn't know you. But now I know you, and let me say that I should have known you a long time ago. I know that Lucy has told you about me, and she has also told me about you. May I use the only method of compensation I have? Take these cylinders and listen - the first half dozen are personal things and won't scare you, then you will know me better. By that time, the meal will be ready. In the meantime, I will reread some of these documents and understand some things better.” He carried the phonograph to my living room with his own hands and set it up for me. Now I will learn some pleasant things, I am sure of it; because it will tell me the other side of a true love story of which I already know one side...
es: –You are right. I didn't trust you because I didn't know you. But now I know you; and let me tell you that I should have known you a long time ago. I know that Lucy spoke to you about me, just as she spoke to me about you. May I make the only adjustment I can? Take the cylinders and listen to them. The first half dozen are personal and won't horrify you; that way you can get to know me better. By the time you finish listening to them, dinner will be ready. In the meantime, I need to read part of these documents, so I will be in a better position to understand certain things. He himself brought the phonograph to my little room and set it up so that I could hear it. Now I am going to know something pleasant, I am sure of it, since he is going to show me the other side of a true love of which I only know one part...

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's diary
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 29 September.—I was so absorbed in that wonderful diary of Jonathan Harker and that other of his wife that I let the time run on without thinking. Mrs. Harker was not down when the maid came to announce dinner, so I said: “She is possibly tired; let dinner wait an hour,” and I went on with my work. I had just finished Mrs. Harker’s diary, when she came in. She looked sweetly pretty, but very sad, and her eyes were flushed with crying. This somehow moved me much. Of late I have had cause for tears, God knows! but the relief of them was denied me; and now the sight of those sweet eyes, brightened with recent tears, went straight to my heart. So I said as gently as I could:—
vi: • September 29 I was so engrossed in Jonathan and his wife's diary that I lost track of time. When the maid came in to announce that dinner was ready, I still hadn't seen Harker come down; I had to tell her that perhaps she was tired after a long journey and to let her rest, and to serve dinner in an hour. And I continued to keep my eyes glued to the lines of the diary. When I reached the last lines of Harker's diary, she walked in. She looked sad, her eyes red, not at all like the eyes I saw when I met her at the station. — I hope I didn't upset you. - I said softly.
tr: 29 September. - I was so engrossed in the dreadful journals of Jonathan Harker and his wife that I allowed time to pass without thinking. When the servant came and announced that dinner was ready, Ms. Harker had not yet come down, so I said, "She is probably tired; let dinner wait for an hour," and continued with my work. When Ms. Harker came in, I had just finished her journal. She was in a sweet beauty, but she looked sad and her eyes were red from crying. For some reason, this affected me greatly. God knows, I have had many reasons to shed tears lately! But the soothing effect of tears was denied to me, and now the sight of those sweet eyes glistening with recently shed tears touched my heart directly. Therefore, I said as gently as I could:
es: September 29. I was so absorbed in reading Jonathan Harker's diary and that of his wife that I let time pass without thinking. Mrs. Harker had not yet come down when the maid announced that dinner was served. –It's likely that she's tired. It would be better if we delayed dinner by an hour, I told her, and went back to immersing myself in my reading. I had just finished reading Mrs. Harker's diary when she entered the study. She looked very pretty and sweet, but a little sad, and her eyes were a bit swollen, an unmistakable sign that she had been crying. For some reason, that moved me deeply. A few moments earlier, I myself had felt like crying, God knows!; but the relief that tears bring had been denied to me, and then, seeing those sweet-looking eyes that had been full of tears, affected me. Therefore, I said to her with all the kindness I could muster:

en: “I greatly fear I have distressed you.”
vi: - I said softly.
tr: “I'm afraid I upset you.”
es: –I fear that my diary has distressed her.

en: “Oh, no, not distressed me,” she replied, “but I have been more touched than I can say by your grief. That is a wonderful machine, but it is cruelly true. It told me, in its very tones, the anguish of your heart. It was like a soul crying out to Almighty God. No one must hear them spoken ever again! See, I have tried to be useful. I have copied out the words on my typewriter, and none other need now hear your heart beat, as I did.”
vi: — No, no, don't say that... That record player is wonderful, but it's a bit cruel! It tells me all the sorrows you have experienced. I feel like I'm listening to a soul in pain, pleading for blessings from the Almighty God. May no one ever have to hear such sad stories again! You know, I can help you a bit, I will type out your entire story on paper. That way, from now on, no one will have to feel the throbbing beat of your heart like I do.
tr: “Oh, no! You didn't upset me,” he replied, “but rather, I was deeply moved by your pain, more than I can express. This is a perfect tool, but brutally realistic. It conveyed to me, in its own voice, the sorrow of your heart. No one should ever hear these words spoken again! Look, I tried to be helpful. I typed what was said on my typewriter, so that no one else will have to hear your heartbeat like I did,”
es: –Oh, no! I am not heartbroken -she replied-; but your laments have moved me more than I can say. It is a wonderful machine, but cruelly true. It made me listen, in the exact tone, to the anguish of your heart. It was like a soul addressing Almighty God. No one should ever write that again! I have tried to be of use to you. I have copied your words on my typewriter and no one else needs to hear the beats of your heart now, as I have.

en: “No one need ever know, shall ever know,” I said in a low voice. She laid her hand on mine and said very gravely:—
vi: — But no one will ever know my diary anymore! There will be no one, never anyone. - I softly replied. Harker placed his hand on mine and continued in a serious tone:
tr: "Those who don't need to know, won't know," I said in a hushed voice. He placed his hand on mine and said very seriously:
es: –Nobody ever needs to know, nor will they -I told him, in a very low tone. She placed her hand on mine and told me gravely:

en: “Ah, but they must!”
vi: — Yes, it must be that way!
tr: “Ah, but they must hear!”
es: –You must meet him!

en: “Must! But why?” I asked.
vi: — Yes, it must be that way! — But why? — Why?
tr: “Ah, but they must hear!” "Are they obliged to!" "But why?" I asked.
es: –They must! Why? – he asked.

en: “Because it is a part of the terrible story, a part of poor dear Lucy’s death and all that led to it; because in the struggle which we have before us to rid the earth of this terrible monster we must have all the knowledge and all the help which we can get. I think that the cylinders which you gave me contained more than you intended me to know; but I can see that there are in your record many lights to this dark mystery. You will let me help, will you not? I know all up to a certain point; and I see already, though your diary only took me to 7 September, how poor Lucy was beset, and how her terrible doom was being wrought out. Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van Helsing saw us. He is gone to Whitby to get more information, and he will be here to-morrow to help us. We need have no secrets amongst us; working together and with absolute trust, we can surely be stronger than if some of us were in the dark.” She looked at me so appealingly, and at the same time manifested such courage and resolution in her bearing, that I gave in at once to her wishes. “You shall,” I said, “do as you like in the matter. God forgive me if I do wrong! There are terrible things yet to learn of; but if you have so far travelled on the road to poor Lucy’s death, you will not be content, I know, to remain in the dark. Nay, the end—the very end—may give you a gleam of peace. Come, there is dinner. We must keep one another strong for what is before us; we have a cruel and dreadful task. When you have eaten you shall learn the rest, and I shall answer any questions you ask—if there be anything which you do not understand, though it was apparent to us who were present.”
vi: Because it is an indispensable part of the horrific story related to the death of poor Lucy and the events that occurred before that, because in the battle we are engaged in to eliminate the shadow of evil from this earth, we need as much information and detail as possible. I have a feeling that while listening to your recorded diary entries, I have noticed more than one detail that you would normally never tell me. Indeed, they have shed some light on the dark mystery that is enveloping us. You will agree to let me help you, won't you? I fully understand the beginning of the story, and although I have only listened to your diary up to the seventh of September, I can still guess the misfortunes that have clung to Lucy and the tragic end of her life. Since Professor Van Helsing's visit, there has not been a moment when we have not thought about it. My husband has gone to Whitby to gather more information, and he will return tomorrow. I think we should not have any secrets to hide from each other; cooperating and trusting each other is the optimal way to achieve success, rather than each knowing a little and then hiding a little from each other. I was a bit surprised by the courage of the young woman standing in front of me. Looking into her eyes, I understood that she was brave and very determined; her gaze made me feel truly reassured. — Now, I can only respect your goodwill, madam. - I replied. - God will forgive me if I have a mistaken view of you! Perhaps you will learn even more terrible details! I understand that because you know a lot about Lucy's condition, you cannot help but want to know more about her tragic end.
