I assure you that once you hear the whole story about her... yes, in the end, you will feel somewhat reassured. Now, perhaps we should go have dinner. We need to maintain our health. After eating, you will continue to hear the rest of the story, and I will be ready to answer any details you find unclear. You are right, for us, everything must be clear to reach a happy ending.
tr: “Because this is part of a terrible story and the death of poor dear Lucy and the events that caused it; in the battle ahead to rid the world of this dreadful monster, we must gather all the information and help we can get. In the cylinders you gave me, I believe there is more than what you want me to learn; but I can see that there is much in your records that will shed light on this dark mystery. You will let me help, won't you? I know everything up to a certain point; although your diary only takes me up to September 7th, I already understand how poor Lucy was surrounded on all sides and how her terrible inevitable end approached. Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van Helsing came to see us. Jonathan went to Whitby to get more information, and he will come here tomorrow to help us. There is no need for secrets among us; if we work together and with mutual absolute trust, we will undoubtedly be stronger than if some of us are left in the dark.” She looked at me with such pleading eyes and at the same time there was such courage and determination in her stance that I immediately agreed to her requests. “In this matter,” I said, “you will act as you wish. If I am making a mistake, may God forgive me! There are more terrible things to learn, but if you have come up to Lucy's death, I know you will not be content to be left in the dark. Moreover, the end of the matter - the very end - may bring you peace. Come, dinner is ready. We must keep each other strong for what awaits us; we have a ruthless and hair-raising task ahead. Once you have eaten, you will learn the rest and I will answer all the questions you have - even if everything is clear to those of us who were there, if there is something you do not understand.”
es: –Because it is a part of the terrible story, a part of the death of poor and dear Lucy and the causes that provoked it; because in the struggle that awaits us, to rid the earth of that terrible monster, we must acquire all the knowledge and all the help that is possible to obtain. I believe that the cylinders you entrusted to me contain more than you wanted me to know; but I have seen that in that record there are many clues for the solution of this dark mystery. Won't you let me help you? I know everything up to a certain point; and I already understand, although your diary only led me up to the seventh of September, how poor Lucy was being harassed and how her terrible fate was unfolding. Jonathan and I have been working day and night since Professor Van Helsing was with us. My husband has gone to Whitby to get more information and will arrive here tomorrow, to try to help us all. We must not have secrets among us; working together and with complete trust we can surely be more useful and effective than if any of us is kept in the dark. He looked at me so pleadingly, and at the same time showing so much courage and determination in his attitude, that I immediately gave in to his wishes. –Do whatever you think is best regarding this matter -I told him-. May God forgive me if I am doing wrong! There are still terrible things you are going to learn; but if you have already come this far concerning the death of poor Lucy, you will not be content, I know, remaining in ignorance. No, the very end might give you a bit of peace. Come, dinner is served. We must strengthen ourselves to endure what awaits us; we have a cruel and dangerous task ahead of us. When you have dined, you can learn the rest, and I will answer all the questions you wish to ask me… in case there is something you do not understand; although it was clear to all of us who were present.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 29 September.—After dinner I came with Dr. Seward to his study. He brought back the phonograph from my room, and I took my typewriter. He placed me in a comfortable chair, and arranged the phonograph so that I could touch it without getting up, and showed me how to stop it in case I should want to pause. Then he very thoughtfully took a chair, with his back to me, so that I might be as free as possible, and began to read. I put the forked metal to my ears and listened.
vi: • September 29 After finishing dinner, I followed Dr. Seward into his study. He went to the room to get the gramophone, while I carried down the typewriter. He arranged a convenient spot for me on the couch so that I could type and operate the gramophone placed beside me. Then, he showed me how to stop the machine when I wanted to take a short break to rest. Once the seating arrangement was done, I turned on the machine to continue listening to his spoken diary entries.
tr: 29 September. - After dinner, I went to the study with Dr. Seward. He brought the phonograph back from my room, and I took my typewriter. He seated me in a comfortable chair, adjusted the phonograph so I wouldn't have to stand up to touch it, and showed me how to stop it if I wanted to take a break. Then, with great thoughtfulness, he pulled a chair to sit with his back to me so I could be as free as possible, and started reading. I placed the fork-shaped metal piece in my ears and listened.
es: September 29. After dinner, I accompanied Dr. Seward to his study. He took the phonograph from my small room and I took my typewriter. He made me sit in a comfortable seat and placed the phonograph in such a way that I could operate it without needing to get up, and showed me how to stop it in case I wanted to take a break. Then, very concerned, he sat with his back to me so that I would feel more at ease, and began to read. I put the headset on my ears and listened.

en: When the terrible story of Lucy’s death, and—and all that followed, was done, I lay back in my chair powerless. Fortunately I am not of a fainting disposition. When Dr. Seward saw me he jumped up with a horrified exclamation, and hurriedly taking a case-bottle from a cupboard, gave me some brandy, which in a few minutes somewhat restored me. My brain was all in a whirl, and only that there came through all the multitude of horrors, the holy ray of light that my dear, dear Lucy was at last at peace, I do not think I could have borne it without making a scene. It is all so wild, and mysterious, and strange that if I had not known Jonathan’s experience in Transylvania I could not have believed. As it was, I didn’t know what to believe, and so got out of my difficulty by attending to something else. I took the cover off my typewriter, and said to Dr. Seward:—
vi: Hearing about Lucy's death and what happened afterward, I collapsed into the seat, my body weak as if I had no strength left. Fortunately, I am not the type of person who faints at the slightest thing! However, Dr. Seward quickly ran to get a bottle of strong liquor for me to take a few sips, and only then did I regain my composure. But that did not stop my heart from being troubled, even though I finally heard that my dear friend Lucy had gone to be with God. I almost screamed out in anger. If I hadn't known about Jonathan's adventure in Transylvania, I might not have been so fearful. In any case, I didn't know what to think anymore, and I had to find a way to hide my inner turmoil by suggesting to the doctor:
tr: When the terrible story of Lucy's death and - and everything that happened afterward came to an end, I weakly leaned back against the back of my chair. When Dr. Seward saw me, he jumped up with a cry of fear and hurriedly took a small bottle from the cabinet, giving me a bit of brandy that revived me within a few minutes. My mind was spinning, and I think I couldn't have endured it without breaking down if it weren't for the holy light that came from the thought that my dear, dear Lucy had finally found peace amid all this horror-filled story. Everything is so wild, mysterious, and strange that I couldn't have believed it if I didn't know about Jonathan's experiences in Transylvania. Even in this situation, I didn't know what to believe, and thus I dealt with something other than the difficulty I was in. I lifted the cover of my typewriter and said to Dr. Seward:
es: When I learned the terrible story of Lucy's death and everything that followed, I remained reclined in my seat, as if paralyzed, absolutely powerless. Fortunately, I am not prone to fainting. As soon as Dr. Seward saw me, he jumped to his feet with a horrified expression, hurriedly took a bottle from a cupboard, and gave me a small glass of brandy, which, in a few minutes, restored my strength. My mind was in utter chaos, and amidst all the horrors, a slight ray of light emerged knowing that my poor dear Lucy was finally at peace. If it weren't for that, I don't think I could have tolerated it without making a scene. Everything was so wild, mysterious, and strange that if I hadn't known about Jonathan's experience in Transylvania, I wouldn't have been able to believe it. In fact, I didn't know what to believe and tried to get by by occupying myself with something else. I uncovered my typewriter and said to Dr. Seward:

en: “Let me write this all out now. We must be ready for Dr. Van Helsing when he comes. I have sent a telegram to Jonathan to come on here when he arrives in London from Whitby. In this matter dates are everything, and I think that if we get all our material ready, and have every item put in chronological order, we shall have done much. You tell me that Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris are coming too. Let us be able to tell him when they come.” He accordingly set the phonograph at a slow pace, and I began to typewrite from the beginning of the seventh cylinder. I used manifold, and so took three copies of the diary, just as I had done with all the rest. It was late when I got through, but Dr. Seward went about his work of going his round of the patients; when he had finished he came back and sat near me, reading, so that I did not feel too lonely whilst I worked. How good and thoughtful he is; the world seems full of good men—even if there are monsters in it. Before I left him I remembered what Jonathan put in his diary of the Professor’s perturbation at reading something in an evening paper at the station at Exeter; so, seeing that Dr. Seward keeps his newspapers, I borrowed the files of “The Westminster Gazette” and “The Pall Mall Gazette,” and took them to my room. I remember how much “The Dailygraph” and “The Whitby Gazette,” of which I had made cuttings, helped us to understand the terrible events at Whitby when Count Dracula landed, so I shall look through the evening papers since then, and perhaps I shall get some new light. I am not sleepy, and the work will help to keep me quiet.
vi: — Let me retype everything you recorded in the phonograph. We need to be fully prepared before Dr. Van Helsing returns. I've already telegraphed Arthur, and he will come back here from Whitby immediately. In this case, dates are the most important issue. In my opinion, if we arrange the events in chronological order, everything will become much more manageable. You just mentioned that you are also waiting for Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris, so when they arrive, they should be informed of everything that has happened. Hearing me, Seward immediately turned the machine back on, but this time he set it to run slower so that I could easily type out the contents of the diary from the beginning. I made three copies so that others could read them without wasting time waiting unnecessarily. Seward had to visit some patients, but he quickly returned. He said he needed to continue reading the remaining pages of my and my wife's diary, and moreover, he wanted someone in the room working with me to avoid feeling lonely. He truly is a gallant man. This world still seems to have many such people, but it is not without its demons. Before returning to my room, I suddenly remembered the diary entry that Seward mentioned about the newspapers - the latest issues of the Westminster Gazette and Pall Mall Gazette, which Jonathan had bought for Van Helsing when he was preparing to board the train at Exeter station - so I asked to borrow them to read in my room before going to sleep. I recalled that back home, the Dailygraph and Whitby Gazette had provided us with some very useful details for further understanding the horrific events that had occurred in Whitby when Count Dracula landed there. Lying in bed, I skimmed through the newspapers, hoping to find some new rays of light in them. I don't feel sleepy, but it seems that the newspapers have somehow helped me become calmer.
tr: "With your permission, I will write all this down. We must be ready for Dr. Van Helsing when he arrives. I sent a telegram to Jonathan, telling him to come here as soon as he arrives in London from Whitby. In this matter, dates mean everything, and if we prepare all our materials and arrange all the items in chronological order, we will have done a lot of work. You said that Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris would also be coming. When they arrive, we should be in a position to explain all this to them." For this, I set the phonograph to slow speed and began typing from the beginning of the seventh cylinder. I was using carbon paper, and thus made three copies of the journal, just like all the other documents. When I finished the work, it was late, but Dr. Seward had gone to visit his patients; when he finished his work, he came back and sat close to me reading, so I wouldn't feel too lonely while working. What a good and thoughtful person he is; the world seems full of good men - despite the monsters. Before leaving his side, I remembered what Jonathan wrote in his journal about the Professor being disturbed by something he read in the evening newspaper at the Exeter station; therefore, when I saw that Dr. Seward kept his newspapers, I borrowed the files of the Westminster and Pall Mall Gazettes and took them to my room. I remembered how much the clippings I cut from the Dailygraph and Whitby Gazettes helped us understand the terrible events that occurred in Whitby when Count Dracula came ashore; so, I will look through all the evening newspapers that have been published since then, hoping to find a new clue. I am not sleepy, and working will soothe me.
es: –Let me write all this down for you. We must be prepared for when Dr. Van Helsing returns. I have sent a telegram to Jonathan to come here as soon as he arrives in London from Whitby. In this case, the dates are important, and I believe that if we prepare all the material and arrange everything in chronological order, we will have made significant progress. You have told me that Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris are also coming. That way, we can be in a position to brief him on everything as soon as he arrives. The doctor, in accordance with what was said, made the phonograph work more slowly and I began to type from the beginning of the seventh cylinder. I used carbon paper and made three copies, just as I had done with everything else. It was already late when I finished the work, but the doctor went to fulfill his duty, on his round of visits to the patients; when he finished, he returned and sat by my side, reading, so that I wouldn't feel too lonely while working. How kind and understanding he is! The world seems to be full of good men, even though there are also monsters! Before saying goodbye to him, I remembered what Jonathan had written in his diary about the professor's disturbance when he read something in an evening newspaper at the Exeter station; so, seeing that Dr. Seward kept his newspapers organized, I took with me to the room, after asking his permission, the albums of The Westminster Gazette and The Pall Mall Gazette. I remembered how much The Dailygraph and The Whitby Gazette newspapers, from which I had kept clippings, had helped us to understand the terrible events in Whitby when Count Dracula arrived. Therefore, I intend to carefully examine the evening newspapers from then on, and perhaps I can find some clue. I am not sleepy, and the work will help to calm me.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 30 September.—Mr. Harker arrived at nine o’clock. He had got his wife’s wire just before starting. He is uncommonly clever, if one can judge from his face, and full of energy. If this journal be true—and judging by one’s own wonderful experiences, it must be—he is also a man of great nerve. That going down to the vault a second time was a remarkable piece of daring. After reading his account of it I was prepared to meet a good specimen of manhood, but hardly the quiet, business-like gentleman who came here to-day.
vi: • September 30 Jonathan arrived at around nine o'clock. He received a call from his wife while preparing to return from Whitby. Meeting him, one immediately senses that he is a very intelligent and determined man. If his diary is written truthfully, then he must also be a very brave person. For it takes an extremely courageous person to dare to venture down into the crypt of that ancient castle twice. After reading those lines of his narrative, I thought I would meet a very tough person, not someone with the calm demeanor and full qualities of a businessman sitting across from me having lunch.
tr: September 30 - Mr. Harker arrived at nine o'clock. He received his wife's telegram just before setting off. If it's possible to judge by looking at his face, he is an exceptionally intelligent and energetic person. If what is written in his journal is true - and judging by my astonishing personal experiences, it must be - he is also someone with very strong nerves. Descending into the tomb chamber for the second time is a considerable act of courage. After reading what he wrote about the events, I was prepared to meet a good example of manliness, but I was not quite ready to meet the calm, businessman-like gentleman who arrived here today.
es: September 30. Mr. Harker arrived at nine o'clock sharp. He had received the telegram from his wife shortly before setting out. He has an uncommon intelligence, if one can judge that by his features, and he is full of energy. If his diary is true, and it must be, judging by the wonderful experiences we have had, he is also an energetic and brave man. His second trip to the tomb was a masterpiece of courage. After reading his report, I was prepared to meet a good specimen of the human race, but not the calm and serious gentleman who arrived here today.

en: Later.—After lunch Harker and his wife went back to their own room, and as I passed a while ago I heard the click of the typewriter. They are hard at it. Mrs. Harker says that they are knitting together in chronological order every scrap of evidence they have. Harker has got the letters between the consignee of the boxes at Whitby and the carriers in London who took charge of them. He is now reading his wife’s typescript of my diary. I wonder what they make out of it. Here it is....
vi: • A moment later After lunch, Jonathan and his wife returned to their room. As I passed by his door, I heard the clattering sound of a typewriter again. The couple truly are persistent people. They are piecing together the scattered events in chronological order as Mina suggested. Jonathan had in his hands the letters exchanged between those who received the shipments in Whitby and the Carter, Paterson & Co. company in London. He was also engrossed in reading my diary, which Mina had just finished typing. I wonder if they will find anything that helps clarify our issues? Ah! Here it is...
tr: Later. - After lunch, Harker and his wife returned to their room, and just now, as I was passing by the room, I heard the clattering of the typewriter. They are working very hard on this. Ms. Harker says they are connecting all the pieces of evidence they have in chronological order. Harker has the letters between the recipient in Whitby and the transporters in London responsible for the crates. Now he is reading my journal, which his wife has typed up. I wonder what they will make of it. Here he comes.
es: Later. After lunch, Harker and his wife returned to their rooms, and as I passed by their door a while ago, I heard the noise made by his typewriter. They work a lot. Mrs. Harker told me that they were putting all the evidence they had in chronological order. Harker had received the letters between the consignment of the boxes in Whitby and the porters who took care of them in London. Now he is reading the copy of my journal typed by his wife. I wonder what conclusions they will draw. Here it is…

en: Strange that it never struck me that the very next house might be the Count’s hiding-place! Goodness knows that we had enough clues from the conduct of the patient Renfield! The bundle of letters relating to the purchase of the house were with the typescript. Oh, if we had only had them earlier we might have saved poor Lucy! Stop; that way madness lies! Harker has gone back, and is again collating his material. He says that by dinner-time they will be able to show a whole connected narrative. He thinks that in the meantime I should see Renfield, as hitherto he has been a sort of index to the coming and going of the Count. I hardly see this yet, but when I get at the dates I suppose I shall. What a good thing that Mrs. Harker put my cylinders into type! We never could have found the dates otherwise....
vi: There is something very strange: the thought that the house with the garden adjacent to ours could be the hiding place of the old count has never crossed my mind! However, only God knows that the behavior of the patient Renfield is actually a link that helps us find the direction of the investigation. Now, we have in our hands the letters related to the purchase of the house that Jonathan brought. If we had known those facts a few days earlier, we might have saved Lucy! But anyway, what's done is done!... Jonathan is still buried in his work. At dinner, the couple summarized for us the logic of the seemingly very disparate events that had occurred. According to Jonathan, I will understand the whole issue if I keep an eye on Renfield, as he is an unconscious signal indicating the comings and goings of the old count. I have not yet visualized the possibility of this matter, but it may be possible when comparing the dates. Fortunately, Mina has transcribed my diary onto paper, otherwise we would never have paid attention to the dates that make up the chain of events!
tr: It's strange that it never occurred to me that the house next door could be the Count's hiding place! God knows, our patient Renfield's behavior had provided us with enough evidence! The stack of letters regarding the purchase of the house was typed on a typewriter. Oh, if only we had these earlier, we could have saved poor Lucy! Wait; madness lies in this direction! Harker has returned and is organizing his notes again. He says that by mealtime, they might be able to present a coherent narrative. In the meantime, he thinks I should see Renfield, who has so far served as a sort of index to the Count's comings and goings. I don't quite understand this yet, but I believe I will when I see the dates. It's so good that Ms. Harker has typed the phonograph cylinders! We would never have found the dates otherwise.
es: It's strange that it never occurred to me to think that the neighboring house could be the hiding place of the count! However, God knows that we had enough indications because of poor Renfield's behavior! The pile of letters related to the acquisition of the house was with the typed copies. If we had known earlier, we could have saved poor Lucy's life! Enough! Those thoughts lead to madness! Harker has returned to his rooms and is once again organizing the material he has. He says that by dinner time they will be able to present a narrative that has an absolute relation between all the facts. He thinks that, in the meantime, I should go see Renfield, since up to now he has been a sort of guide on the count's comings and goings. It's still difficult for me to see it; but, when I examine the dates, I suppose I will clearly see the existing relationship. How good that Mrs. Harker typed the contents of my cylinders! We would never have been able to find the dates otherwise...

en: I found Renfield sitting placidly in his room with his hands folded, smiling benignly. At the moment he seemed as sane as any one I ever saw. I sat down and talked with him on a lot of subjects, all of which he treated naturally. He then, of his own accord, spoke of going home, a subject he has never mentioned to my knowledge during his sojourn here. In fact, he spoke quite confidently of getting his discharge at once. I believe that, had I not had the chat with Harker and read the letters and the dates of his outbursts, I should have been prepared to sign for him after a brief time of observation. As it is, I am darkly suspicious. All those outbreaks were in some way linked with the proximity of the Count. What then does this absolute content mean? Can it be that his instinct is satisfied as to the vampire’s ultimate triumph? Stay; he is himself zoöphagous, and in his wild ravings outside the chapel door of the deserted house he always spoke of “master.” This all seems confirmation of our idea. However, after a while I came away; my friend is just a little too sane at present to make it safe to probe him too deep with questions. He might begin to think, and then—! So I came away. I mistrust these quiet moods of his; so I have given the attendant a hint to look closely after him, and to have a strait-waistcoat ready in case of need.
vi: When I visited Renfield, he was sitting quietly in a corner of the room. Seeing me enter, he gave a very gentle smile. At that moment, I had the feeling that he was completely sane like a normal person. I sat down and talked to him about countless things, and he responded to me just like a person with a sound mind. Then he suddenly mentioned that he wanted to go home - something he had never mentioned since he was admitted to the institution. I believe that if it weren't for the conversation with Jonathan and hadn't read the letters he had in his possession, or hadn't reviewed the dates when Renfield had his fits, I would have discharged him in the next few days. But to be honest, from a logical standpoint, I still can't understand what happened. Let's say that Renfield's fits coincided with the appearance of the count at the neighboring house, but what is his current state of mind? Could it be that "vampires" have such great power? I can't forget how Renfield ravenously chewed on both flies and live spiders, and in a fit of madness, he went to the door of the abandoned house and shouted "master". This could confirm our hypothesis. If so, I must keep him here. He seems lucid enough to answer questions that he might guess my purpose: to understand more about the count. He has never been this clear-headed!... Yes, I will keep him here. I suddenly feel suspicious when he is obedient. I must remind the warden to keep an eye on him and restrain him with a very secure straitjacket.
tr: I found Renfield in his room, sitting quietly with his hands clasped, laughing harmlessly. At that moment, he looked as sane as anyone I had ever seen. I sat down and talked with him about many subjects, all of which he approached naturally. Then he spontaneously began to talk about returning home—a topic he had never mentioned during his stay here, as far as I knew. In fact, he spoke quite confidently about being released immediately. If I had not spoken with Harker and read the letters detailing the dates of his sudden outbursts, I would have been ready to sign off after a short observation. In this situation, I am quite suspicious. All those outbursts are somehow connected to the Count's proximity to here. Then, what does this absolute calmness mean? Could it mean that his instinct is pleased with the vampire's certain victory? Wait; he is a zoophagous, and in his wild ramblings at the chapel door of the abandoned house, he always spoke of "my Master." All this seems to confirm our thoughts. Still, after a while, I left him; my friend is currently too sane for me to examine deeply with questions. He might start thinking, and then!.. Thus, I walked away from him. I do not trust his calm demeanor; therefore, I told the nurse to watch him carefully and to have a straitjacket ready if necessary.
es: I found Renfield sitting peacefully in his room and smiling like a blessed one. At that moment, he seemed as sane as any other person I know. I sat next to him and talked with him about countless topics, which he developed in an absolutely natural manner. Then, of his own accord, he spoke to me about returning to his home, a topic he had never touched upon, as far as I know, during his stay in the asylum. Indeed, he spoke to me confidently that he could be discharged immediately. I believe that if I had not spoken with Harker beforehand and read the letters and the dates of his attacks, I would have been willing to sign his release after a short period of observation. As things stand, I suspect everything. All those attacks were somehow linked to the presence of the count in the vicinity. What did that absolute satisfaction mean then? Does it mean that his instincts are satisfied because of the conviction of the vampire's final triumph? He is the same zoophagous, and in his terrible rages, outside the chapel door of the house, he always speaks of the "master". All this seems to be a confirmation of our idea. However, after a moment, I left him; my friend was at that moment too sane to seriously test him with questions. He might start to reflect and then... Therefore, I walked away from him. I distrust those moments of calm he sometimes has, and I have given the nurse the order to watch him closely and to have a straitjacket ready to use if necessary.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 29 September, in train to London.—When I received Mr. Billington’s courteous message that he would give me any information in his power I thought it best to go down to Whitby and make, on the spot, such inquiries as I wanted. It was now my object to trace that horrid cargo of the Count’s to its place in London. Later, we may be able to deal with it. Billington junior, a nice lad, met me at the station, and brought me to his father’s house, where they had decided that I must stay the night. They are hospitable, with true Yorkshire hospitality: give a guest everything, and leave him free to do as he likes. They all knew that I was busy, and that my stay was short, and Mr. Billington had ready in his office all the papers concerning the consignment of boxes. It gave me almost a turn to see again one of the letters which I had seen on the Count’s table before I knew of his diabolical plans. Everything had been carefully thought out, and done systematically and with precision. He seemed to have been prepared for every obstacle which might be placed by accident in the way of his intentions being carried out. To use an Americanism, he had “taken no chances,” and the absolute accuracy with which his instructions were fulfilled, was simply the logical result of his care. I saw the invoice, and took note of it: “Fifty cases of common earth, to be used for experimental purposes.” Also the copy of letter to Carter Paterson, and their reply; of both of these I got copies. This was all the information Mr. Billington could give me, so I went down to the port and saw the coastguards, the Customs officers and the harbour-master. They had all something to say of the strange entry of the ship, which is already taking its place in local tradition; but no one could add to the simple description “Fifty cases of common earth.” I then saw the station-master, who kindly put me in communication with the men who had actually received the boxes. Their tally was exact with the list, and they had nothing to add except that the boxes were “main and mortal heavy,” and that shifting them was dry work. One of them added that it was hard lines that there wasn’t any gentleman “such-like as yourself, squire,” to show some sort of appreciation of their efforts in a liquid form; another put in a rider that the thirst then generated was such that even the time which had elapsed had not completely allayed it. Needless to add, I took care before leaving to lift, for ever and adequately, this source of reproach.
vi: • September 29 I wrote a diary on the train to London. When Billington enthusiastically promised to provide me with all the information he had, I immediately thought I would get lucky in Whitby. In fact, now I just want to know exactly one place in London that received the count's shady shipment. Billington's son, a kind-hearted young man, waited to pick me up at the station. They arranged for me to sleep overnight at their house. There, I was warmly welcomed in the unique Yorkshire way and allowed to do whatever I wanted. Knowing that I had to handle many tasks in a very short time, Billington had prepared all the documents related to the shipment of the dubious crates for me. I suddenly shuddered when I recognized one of the letters that I had seen on the Count's desk on the day I was still unaware of his dark plans. He had thought through every situation very carefully, acting with precision and method. It seemed he had anticipated every obstacle that might arise during the execution of his scheme. To present himself in the American business style, he "did not accept any risk" regarding the shipment, and the precision he demanded in the shipping instructions was merely the result of an extremely careful calculation for a shady deal. I noticed that the special delivery invoice had the line: Fifty boxes of soil commonly used for experiments. The landlord Billington also showed me a copy of the letter sent to the Carter, Paterson & Co. company and the reply from this company. Billington gave me a copy of the two letters. Knowing that this was the only information he could provide, I went down to the port to ask some security guards, customs officers, and the port manager. All of them had something to say about the unusual docking of the mysterious ship, which had now become a local legend. However, none of them could provide even the slightest explanation about what was contained inside those wooden crates, so I had to be content with the only information recorded on the invoice: Fifty boxes of common soil. After that, I sought out the station master. Hearing my inquiry, he immediately called those who had participated in transporting those crates. But these people could only tell me what I couldn't be sure of: that there were fifty wooden crates, and they couldn't say anything more except that "those crates were terribly large and heavy," or "lifting them up would make you die of thirst." It's truly a waste of effort! • September 30
tr: 29 September, on the train to London.- When I received Mr. Billington's kind letter, in which he said he would give me all the information he could, I thought it best to go to Whitby and conduct my desired research on site. My aim now was to trace the Count's dreadful cargo to its location in London. Then, we could deal with him. His pleasant son, Billington, met me at the station and brought me to his father's house, where they had decided I should stay the night. They showed true Yorkshire hospitality: giving the guest everything and leaving him free to do as he pleased. They all knew I was busy and that my visit would be short, and Mr. Billington had prepared all the documents related to the transport of the crates in his study. Seeing one of the letters I had previously seen on the Count's desk before learning of his diabolical plans almost caused me to have a fit. Everything was done carefully, systematically, and with sensitivity. He seemed prepared for any accidental obstacle that might arise on the path to achieving his goals. In modern terms, he "left nothing to chance," and the absolute precision with which his instructions were carried out was merely the logical result of his meticulousness. I saw and noted the invoice: "Fifty crates of ordinary soil for experimental purposes." Additionally, there was a copy of a letter to Carter Paterson and their responses; I took copies of both. This was all the information Mr. Billington could give me, so I went down to the port and saw the coast guards, customs officers, and the harbor master. They all had something to say about the ship's strange arrival, which was already becoming part of local lore, but no one had anything to add to the simple description of "fifty crates filled with ordinary soil. " Then, with great courtesy, I met the station master who arranged for me to speak with the men who actually received the crates. Their cargo list was identical to mine, and they had nothing to add except that the crates were "substantial and deadly heavy," and that loading them was a tedious job. One of them added that it was a great misfortune that no one else "like me, a gentleman," had thanked them for their efforts in liquid form; another added that the thirst that arose at that time had not entirely subsided even with the passage of time. Needless to say, before leaving them, I did not neglect to forever and adequately address the source of their grievances.
es: September 29, on the train to London. When I received the kind message from Mr. Billington, in which he told me that he was willing to provide me with all the reports in his possession, I thought it appropriate to go directly to Whitby and carry out all the investigations I desired on the spot. My objective was to follow the Count's horrible cargo to his house in London. We could deal with it later. Billington's son, a very pleasant young man, went to the station to meet me and took me to his father's house, where they had decided I should spend the night. They were hospitable, with the typical Yorkshire hospitality: giving everything to the guests and leaving them entirely free to do as they wished. They knew I had a lot to do and that my stay was going to be very short, and Mr. Billington had all the documents related to the consignment of the boxes prepared in his office. I was greatly impressed when I saw one of the letters that I had seen on the count's table again, before knowing about his diabolical plans. Everything had been carefully thought out and executed systematically and with precision. He seemed to have been prepared to overcome any obstacle that might arise by accident to prevent his intentions from being carried out. He had left nothing to chance, and the absolute accuracy with which his instructions were followed was simply a logical result of his care. I saw the invoice and took note of it: "Fifty boxes of common earth, for experimental purposes." Also the copy of the letter addressed to Carter Paterson and his response; I made copies of both. That was all the information Mr. Billington could provide me, so I headed to the port to see the coast guards, the customs officers, and the port commander. All of them had something to say about the strange entry of the ship, which was already beginning to have its place in local traditions; but they could not add anything to the simple description "fifty boxes of common earth." Next, I went to see the station master, who kindly put me in touch with the men who had actually received the boxes. Their description matched the lists and they had nothing to add, except that the boxes were "extraordinarily heavy" and that their shipment had been very hard work. One of them said it was a pity that there hadn't been some gentleman present "like you, sir," to reward their efforts in some way, with a cash tip; another expressed the same, saying that the effort had made them so thirsty that they still hadn't managed to quench it completely. It is not necessary to add that, before leaving them, I made sure they would have no further complaints in this regard.

en: 30 September.—The station-master was good enough to give me a line to his old companion the station-master at King’s Cross, so that when I arrived there in the morning I was able to ask him about the arrival of the boxes. He, too, put me at once in communication with the proper officials, and I saw that their tally was correct with the original invoice. The opportunities of acquiring an abnormal thirst had been here limited; a noble use of them had, however, been made, and again I was compelled to deal with the result in an ex post facto manner.
vi: The station master wrote a few lines of a handwritten letter introducing me to a colleague of his at Kings Cross so that when I arrived in London this morning, I could immediately discuss with him what I wanted to know more about the wooden crates when they were unloaded here. For his part, he also immediately called the porters who had participated in unloading these crates for me to inquire, but these people could only say that the number of crates was fifty. However, no one mentioned any unusual hunger. But whether there was anything unusual or not, I still had to dejectedly thank these porters.
tr: September 30. - The station master was kind enough to give me a note to take to his old friend, the station master at King’s Cross, so that when I arrived there the next morning, I could ask him questions about the arrival of the crates. He immediately introduced me to the clerks who were handling the matter, and I saw that the cargo lists matched the original invoice. Here, the opportunities for extraordinary thirst were limited; but they had been taken advantage of in a more noble manner, and once again I had to deal with the result in an expostfacto manner.
es: September 30. The station master was kind enough to give me a few written lines for his colleague at King's Cross, so when I arrived there in the morning, I was able to ask him about the arrival of the boxes. He also immediately put me in touch with the appropriate employees, and I saw that their explanations matched the original invoice. The opportunities to have an abnormal thirst had been few in this last case; however, they had been generously taken advantage of, and I found myself forced to deal with the result in an ex post facto manner.

en: From thence I went on to Carter Paterson’s central office, where I met with the utmost courtesy. They looked up the transaction in their day-book and letter-book, and at once telephoned to their King’s Cross office for more details. By good fortune, the men who did the teaming were waiting for work, and the official at once sent them over, sending also by one of them the way-bill and all the papers connected with the delivery of the boxes at Carfax. Here again I found the tally agreeing exactly; the carriers’ men were able to supplement the paucity of the written words with a few details. These were, I shortly found, connected almost solely with the dusty nature of the job, and of the consequent thirst engendered in the operators. On my affording an opportunity, through the medium of the currency of the realm, of the allaying, at a later period, this beneficial evil, one of the men remarked:—
vi: From Kings Cross station, I wearily made my way to the Carter, Parterson office in Cie, where they welcomed me very courteously. After locating my transaction records, the staff called the Kings Cross branch to ask for the exact details. The truck drivers had just returned from their deliveries. As requested, they immediately provided us with a report on the shipment. One of them was given a delivery note and other documents related to the transportation of the crates to Carfax. The number of crates here matched the number listed on the invoice. Additionally, the drivers agreed to provide me with any supplementary details they knew. The relevant details, if they can be called that, I received were merely the very unpleasant inconveniences of the job - dust and parching thirst. But when I let the drivers take a break and handed them a few small bills, one driver suddenly exclaimed loudly, in a thick rural accent: — That house, sir, is nothing but dust, just dust!
tr: From there, I went to the central office of Carter Paterson, where I was received with great courtesy. They searched the daybooks and letter registers for the transaction and immediately called their King’s Cross office for more details. By chance, the men who made up the team were waiting for work at that time, and the clerk promptly sent all the documents related to the delivery of the bill of lading and the crates to Carfax with them. Here, I also saw that the cargo lists matched exactly; the men from the transport company were able to cover the inadequacy of the written words by adding a few words. Soon I realized that these were only related to the dusty nature of the work and the thirst it created in the men. Upon seizing the opportunity to remedy this useful evil at a later date with the currency of the Kingdom, one of the men said:
es: From there, I headed to the headquarters of Carter Paterson, where I was received with the utmost courtesy. They examined the transaction in their journal and correspondence files and immediately called their King's Cross office for more details. Fortunately, the men who handled the hauling were waiting for work, and the official sent them immediately, also sending with one of them the transit certificate and all the documents related to the delivery of the boxes at Carfax. Again, I found that the duplicate corresponded exactly; the carriers were able to supplement the scantiness of the documents with a few details. Soon I learned that these details were related to the dirtiness of the job and the terrible thirst it caused the workers. When given the opportunity later to quench it, one of the men remarked:

en: “That ’ere ’ouse, guv’nor, is the rummiest I ever was in. Blyme! but it ain’t been touched sence a hundred years. There was dust that thick in the place that you might have slep’ on it without ’urtin’ of yer bones; an’ the place was that neglected that yer might ’ave smelled ole Jerusalem in it. But the ole chapel—that took the cike, that did! Me and my mate, we thort we wouldn’t never git out quick enough. Lor’, I wouldn’t take less nor a quid a moment to stay there arter dark.”
vi: It’s the strangest thing I’ve ever seen in my life! I swear! It looks like no one has set foot in that house for a hundred years! The dust is inches thick! So thick... that you could lie down and sleep without worrying about a backache! The abandoned house is like ancient Jerusalem! But the creepiest part has to be the private chapel inside!... Oh my God! I’ve never seen anything like it! When we stepped outside, my friends and I felt like we had just come back from the dead! Lord! I couldn’t stay there for a second once it got dark!
tr: “That house, boss, was one of the strangest houses I had ever entered. Believe me! But it hadn't been touched for about a hundred years. It was covered with a layer of dust thick enough to sleep on without hurting your bones, and it was so neglected that you could smell the old Jerusalem. But the old chapel - it was a disaster! My partner and I thought we could never get out quickly enough. My God! I wouldn't have stayed there after dark for less than a pound.”
es: –That house, sir, is the most neglected I have seen in my entire life. Good heavens! It looks like it hasn't been touched in a century. There was such a thick layer of dust that we could have slept on the floor without hurting our backs, and it was in such disarray that it looked like the ancient temple of Jerusalem. But the old chapel… That was the last straw! My companions and I thought we would never get out of that house soon enough. Good heavens! For nothing in the world would I stay there a single moment after nightfall!

en: Having been in the house, I could well believe him; but if he knew what I know, he would, I think, have raised his terms.
vi: Of course, I believe in his words, and I am also sure that if he knew everything I knew, he would have a much more expressive tone.
tr: Since I had been in that house before, I could very well believe him, but if he knew what I knew, I think he would raise his conditions.
es: Since I had been in the house, I had no trouble believing him; but if he had known what I did, he surely would have used harsher words.

en: Of one thing I am now satisfied: that all the boxes which arrived at Whitby from Varna in the Demeter were safely deposited in the old chapel at Carfax. There should be fifty of them there, unless any have since been removed—as from Dr. Seward’s diary I fear.
vi: No matter what, I am now certain of one thing: all the crates were shipped from Varna to Whitby by the Demeter ship and then transferred to the private Carfax church. There were fifty crates in total, and after reading Dr. Seward's journal, I fear that since then, at least a few of them must have been used already.
tr: Now I am satisfied with one thing: All the crates that came from Varna to Whitby with the Demeter have safely arrived at the old chapel of Carfax. If they haven't been taken from there since then, there should be fifty of them - according to Dr. Seward's journal, I have concerns about this.
es: There is something I am satisfied with, however: that all the boxes that arrived in Whitby from Varna, on the Demeter, were deposited in the old chapel of Carfax. There should have been fifty of them, unless some had already been removed... as I feared, based on Dr. Seward's diary.

en: I shall try to see the carter who took away the boxes from Carfax when Renfield attacked them. By following up this clue we may learn a good deal.
vi: I will try to find the truck driver who once fought with Renfield while delivering goods at Carfax. Following this lead, who knows, we might find something not too bad! • See you later
tr: If they haven't been taken from there since then, there should be fifty of them - according to Dr. Seward's journal, I have concerns about this.
es: I have to try to interview the carrier who was taking the boxes from Carfax when Renfield attacked them. Following that lead, it is possible that we may come to know many important things.

en: Later.—Mina and I have worked all day, and we have put all the papers into order.
vi: Mina and I worked all day, so now all types of documents are neatly organized.
tr: Later. - Mina and I worked all day and organized all the documents.
es: Later. Mina and I have worked all day and have organized all the papers.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 30 September.—I am so glad that I hardly know how to contain myself. It is, I suppose, the reaction from the haunting fear which I have had: that this terrible affair and the reopening of his old wound might act detrimentally on Jonathan. I saw him leave for Whitby with as brave a face as I could, but I was sick with apprehension. The effort has, however, done him good. He was never so resolute, never so strong, never so full of volcanic energy, as at present. It is just as that dear, good Professor Van Helsing said: he is true grit, and he improves under strain that would kill a weaker nature. He came back full of life and hope and determination; we have got everything in order for to-night. I feel myself quite wild with excitement. I suppose one ought to pity any thing so hunted as is the Count. That is just it: this Thing is not human—not even beast. To read Dr. Seward’s account of poor Lucy’s death, and what followed, is enough to dry up the springs of pity in one’s heart.
vi: • September 30 I felt so happy that I could temporarily be content with myself. Perhaps that was a normal reaction to the extreme anxiety that constantly lingered within me: I was always afraid that when reminded of the emotional wound, Jonathan would have another breakdown. When preparing to go to Whitby, he seemed to have completely mastered himself, but that didn't stop me from worrying to death. Thank God! All his efforts and work were carried out smoothly with the enthusiastic help of the people he needed to meet. I had never seen him so healthy, determined, and resolute to see things through to the end. The kind old professor Van Helsing was right: Jonathan is indeed a very brave person, the more difficulties and obstacles he faces, the more eager he is to confront the challenges. When he returned, he seemed full of hope and showed more determination. He helped me finish organizing the documents he had just obtained in chronological order. Now, everything is well-prepared. I feel much more relieved and excited than before. To be honest, at first, I wondered whether, after all, it was necessary to pity a hunted creature like the Count. For this creature had nothing that could be called human, yet he was not like an animal either. However, whenever I remember Lucy's death and the events that followed, I get infuriated!
tr: September 30 - I am so happy that I almost don't know how to control myself. I think I am reacting this way to the fear that won't leave me: the fear that this terrible event and the reopening of the old wound could harm Jonathan. I watched his departure to Whitby with as much courage as I could muster, but I felt as if I were sick with worry. But this effort did him good. He has never been as determined, as strong, or possessed such fierce energy as he does now. Just as dear kind-hearted Professor Van Helsing said: It was a true example of courage, and he is getting better while experiencing a tension that could kill someone of weaker constitution. When he returned, he was full of life, hope, and determination; we have arranged everything for tonight. I feel like I am going mad with excitement. One must pity something that hunts like the Count. Here it is: This Thing is not human - not even an animal. Reading Dr. Seward's writings about Lucy's death and what happened afterwards is enough to dry up the source of compassion in one's heart.
es: September 30. I am so happy that it is difficult for me to contain myself. I suppose it is the natural reaction after the horrible fear I had: that this terrible matter and the reopening of his old wounds could act to Jonathan's detriment. I saw him leave for Whitby with as animated a face as possible; but I felt sick with apprehension. However, the effort had done him good. He had never been so resolute, strong, and with such volcanic energy, as now. It is exactly what the excellent Professor Van Helsing told me: he is truly resilient and improves under strains that would kill a person of a weaker nature. He has returned full of life, hope, and determination. We have arranged everything for tonight. I feel very excited. I suppose it is necessary to pity someone who is as persecuted as the Count. Only that… that thing is not human… It is not even a beast. Reading Dr. Seward's account of poor Lucy's death and everything that followed is enough to drown all feelings of compassion.

en: Later.—Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris arrived earlier than we expected. Dr. Seward was out on business, and had taken Jonathan with him, so I had to see them. It was to me a painful meeting, for it brought back all poor dear Lucy’s hopes of only a few months ago. Of course they had heard Lucy speak of me, and it seemed that Dr. Van Helsing, too, has been quite “blowing my trumpet,” as Mr. Morris expressed it. Poor fellows, neither of them is aware that I know all about the proposals they made to Lucy. They did not quite know what to say or do, as they were ignorant of the amount of my knowledge; so they had to keep on neutral subjects. However, I thought the matter over, and came to the conclusion that the best thing I could do would be to post them in affairs right up to date. I knew from Dr. Seward’s diary that they had been at Lucy’s death—her real death—and that I need not fear to betray any secret before the time. So I told them, as well as I could, that I had read all the papers and diaries, and that my husband and I, having typewritten them, had just finished putting them in order. I gave them each a copy to read in the library. When Lord Godalming got his and turned it over—it does make a pretty good pile—he said:—
vi: • A moment later Lord Godalming and Morris arrived earlier than we expected. Dr. Seward had to take Jonathan to visit some patients, so I was the one who directly received them. To be honest, I felt a bit uneasy about this, because seeing them reminded me of Lucy's hopes a few months ago! Yes, Lucy had talked to me about them many times, and I also remember that Van Helsing had once "given a speech" praising Quincey Morris. Poor fellows! They didn't understand that I knew all about each of them proposing to Lucy! It seemed they still thought I was unaware of the tragic circumstances surrounding her death, because in front of me, they only talked about the weather and other trivial matters. Therefore, I had to explain the current situation to them. Through Seward's diary, I know that they were also present at the death - I mean the true death of Lucy, so there's nothing to keep secret here. I told them that my wife and I had read all the documents in our possession and typed them all out in chronological order. And I gave each of them a copy to read in the library. Lord Godalming asked me:
tr: Later on. - Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris arrived earlier than we expected. Dr. Seward was out for work and had taken Jonathan with him, so I had to receive them. It was a painful encounter for me because it reminded me of dear poor Lucy's hopes just a few months ago. Of course, they had heard Lucy speak of me, and as Mr. Morris mentioned, Dr. Van Helsing had "praised me to the skies." The poor fellows were unaware that I knew both of them had proposed to Lucy. Since they didn't know how much I was aware of the matter, they were unsure of what to say or do; therefore, they had to continue talking about ordinary topics. Still, I thought about the matter and concluded that the best thing I could do was to inform them about what had happened so far. From Dr. Seward's journal, I knew that they were present at Lucy's death - her real death - and that I didn't need to fear revealing a secret prematurely. Thus, I told them that I had read all the documents and journals as best as I could and that my husband and I had just finished arranging all the documents after typing them up. I gave each of them a copy to read in the library. When Lord Godalming took his copy and turned it over in his hands - it formed quite a thick bundle - he said:
es: Later. Lord Godalming and Mr. Morris arrived earlier than we expected. Dr. Seward had gone out to take care of some matters and had taken Jonathan with him; therefore, I had to receive them myself. It was very unpleasant for me, as it reminded me of all the hopes of poor Lucy, just a few months ago. Naturally, they had heard Lucy talk about me and it seemed that Dr. Van Helsing had also been "promoting me," as Mr. Morris put it. Poor friends! None of them know that I am aware of all the proposals they made to Lucy. They didn't know exactly what to say or do, as they were unaware of how much I knew; therefore, they had to talk about trivialities. However, I thought deeply and concluded that the best thing I could do was to inform them of everything. I knew, from Dr. Seward's diary, that they had witnessed poor Lucy's death... the true death... and that I shouldn't be afraid of revealing a secret prematurely. Therefore, I told them in the best way possible that I had read all the documents and diaries, and that my husband and I, after typing them, had just finished putting them in order. I gave each of them a copy so they could read them in the library. When Lord Godalming received his and read it carefully (it was a considerable bundle of documents), he said:

en: “Did you write all this, Mrs. Harker?”
vi: — Mrs. Harker, are you the one who typed all these documents?
tr: "Did you write all of this, Ms. Harker?"
es: –Have you written all this, Mrs. Harker?

en: I nodded, and he went on:—
vi: Seeing me nod, he asked further:
tr: When I nodded in agreement, he continued his words:
es: I nodded, and he added:

en: “I don’t quite see the drift of it; but you people are all so good and kind, and have been working so earnestly and so energetically, that all I can do is to accept your ideas blindfold and try to help you. I have had one lesson already in accepting facts that should make a man humble to the last hour of his life. Besides, I know you loved my poor Lucy—” Here he turned away and covered his face with his hands. I could hear the tears in his voice. Mr. Morris, with instinctive delicacy, just laid a hand for a moment on his shoulder, and then walked quietly out of the room. I suppose there is something in woman’s nature that makes a man free to break down before her and express his feelings on the tender or emotional side without feeling it derogatory to his manhood; for when Lord Godalming found himself alone with me he sat down on the sofa and gave way utterly and openly. I sat down beside him and took his hand. I hope he didn’t think it forward of me, and that if he ever thinks of it afterwards he never will have such a thought. There I wrong him; I know he never will—he is too true a gentleman. I said to him, for I could see that his heart was breaking:—
vi: — I am not quite clear about the purpose of everyone's actions, but I see that you are all very kind to me and very dedicated to me. The enthusiasm of everyone from the beginning until now seems to have brought about many results. Now, all I can do is trust and reciprocate everyone's help. I acknowledge the events and know that everyone also loves Lucy very much... He suddenly bowed his head, covering his face with his hands, his voice sobbing in between the sobs. Morris placed his hand on his shoulder for a moment, as a gesture of comforting his distressed friend, then quietly stepped outside. Surely there must be something in the instinctive nature of us women that makes a man easily express his emotions and painful feelings like that without fearing to lose face. Seeing that there were only the two of us left in the room, he collapsed onto the couch and didn't bother to hide the pain in his heart. I came over and held his hand tightly. I hoped that my gesture wouldn't be seen as too intimate for another man. And if later on, when he recalls this moment, he would never think of me that way. But perhaps I was overthinking, because I knew he was a gentleman, noble, and would never think that way. — I also care deeply for Lucy, - I confided - and I understand the feelings she had for you as well as what you did for her.
tr: “I don't quite understand the purpose of this; but you are such good and refined people, and you work with such seriousness and effort that the only thing I can do is to blindly accept your thoughts and try to help you. I have already received a lesson on the truths that will ensure a person remains humble until the last moment of their life. Also, I know that you love my poor Lucy...” Here, he turned his head away and covered his face with his hands. I could hear the tears in his voice. Mr. Morris instinctively placed his hand on his shoulder for a moment and quietly left the room. I think there is something in the nature of women that makes men feel the freedom to express their feelings about their sensitive, emotional sides and cry without feeling that their masculinity is diminished, because as soon as Lord Godalming found himself alone with me, he sat on the couch and completely, openly let himself go. I sat next to him and held his hand. I hope he didn't think I overstepped, and if he ever thinks about this moment in the future, such a thought doesn't cross his mind. Here, I am being unfair to him: I know he won't - he is a true gentleman. Seeing that his heart was broken, I said to him:
es: –I do not quite understand the purpose of all this; but you are all so good and kind and have been working so energetically and honestly, that the only thing I can do is accept all your ideas blindly and try to help you. I have already received a lesson in having to accept facts that are enough to make a man feel sad until the last moments of his life. Besides, I know that you loved my poor Lucy… Upon reaching this point, he turned and covered his face with his hands. I managed to perceive the crying in the tone of his voice. Mr. Morris, with instinctive delicacy, placed a hand on his shoulder for a moment, and then slowly left the room. I suppose there is something in the nature of a woman that makes a man feel free to collapse in front of her and express his emotional or tender feelings, without believing they are humiliating to his masculinity; because when Lord Godalming found himself alone with me, he sat on the divan and gave free rein to his tears sincerely and openly. I sat down beside her and took her hand. I hope she didn't think it was presumptuous of me, and that if she thinks about it later, nothing of the sort will ever occur to her. I am belittling him a bit; I know he will never do it... He is too chivalrous for that. I understood that his heart was broken, and I told him:

en: “I loved dear Lucy, and I know what she was to you, and what you were to her. She and I were like sisters; and now she is gone, will you not let me be like a sister to you in your trouble? I know what sorrows you have had, though I cannot measure the depth of them. If sympathy and pity can help in your affliction, won’t you let me be of some little service—for Lucy’s sake?”
vi: — I also care deeply for Lucy, - I confided - and I understand the feelings she had for you as well as what you did for her. She and I always regarded each other as sisters. Now that she is no longer here, could you consider me as a sister? I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you.
tr: “I loved dear Lucy and I know what she meant to you, and what you meant to her. She and I were like siblings, and now that she is gone, won't you let me be like a sibling to you in this troubled time? Although I cannot measure its depth, I know the pains you are going through. If sympathy and compassion can help you in your sorrow, won't you let me be of some use - for Lucy's sake?”
es: –I loved Lucy and I know what she meant to you, and what you meant to her. We were like sisters, and now that she is gone, won't you allow me to be like a sister to you in your time of sorrow? I know the sadness that has overwhelmed you, although I cannot fully measure its depth. If sympathy and understanding can help you in your grief, won't you let me help you... for Lucy's sake?

en: In an instant the poor dear fellow was overwhelmed with grief. It seemed to me that all that he had of late been suffering in silence found a vent at once. He grew quite hysterical, and raising his open hands, beat his palms together in a perfect agony of grief. He stood up and then sat down again, and the tears rained down his cheeks. I felt an infinite pity for him, and opened my arms unthinkingly. With a sob he laid his head on my shoulder and cried like a wearied child, whilst he shook with emotion.
vi: I know you have just gone through two great misfortunes in life, if my sincere feelings can somewhat ease the sorrow in your heart, please allow me to help you. The poor boy suddenly burst into tears, with tears streaming down his cheeks. I felt so sorry for him but didn't know what to do! In his emotional state, he rested his head on my shoulder and sobbed like a child.
tr: For a moment, the poor man was overwhelmed with sorrow. All the silent suffering he had endured recently seemed to suddenly find an outlet, it seemed to me. He lost himself quite a bit and, raising his hands, clapped his palms together in great pain. He stood up and then sat down again, tears streaming down his cheeks like rain. I felt infinite compassion for him and, without thinking, opened my arms. Sobbing, he rested his head on my shoulder and cried like a child exhausted from being shaken by emotion.
es: In an instant, the poor man found himself overwhelmed by pain. It seemed to me that everything he had had to suffer in silence until then burst out all at once. He went beside himself and, raising his open hands, clapped his palms together, expressing the magnitude of his pain. He stood up and, a moment later, sat back down, and the tears kept streaming down his cheeks. I felt enormous pity for him, and without thinking, I opened my arms. With a sob, he rested his head on my shoulder and cried like a tired child, while trembling with emotion.

en: We women have something of the mother in us that makes us rise above smaller matters when the mother-spirit is invoked; I felt this big sorrowing man’s head resting on me, as though it were that of the baby that some day may lie on my bosom, and I stroked his hair as though he were my own child. I never thought at the time how strange it all was.
vi: Just like other women, the instinct of a mother suddenly awakened in me when I encountered someone in need of protection and comfort. I felt that the young man sobbing on my shoulder was like a little child whom I would one day hold in my arms. I stroked his hair as if it were the hair of a son.
tr: In us women, there is a maternal aspect that allows us to overcome small events that evoke the spirit of motherhood; I felt the head of this big, sorrowful man on me as if it were the head of a baby that might lie on my chest in the future, and I stroked his hair as if he were my own child. At that time, I never thought about how strange all this was.
es: We, women, have something of mothers in us that makes us rise above less important things when motherhood is invoked; I felt that man's head, gripped by pain, resting on me, as if it were the head of the baby I might one day have in my lap, and I stroked his hair, as if he were my son. At that moment, I did not think about how strange it all was.

en: After a little bit his sobs ceased, and he raised himself with an apology, though he made no disguise of his emotion. He told me that for days and nights past—weary days and sleepless nights—he had been unable to speak with any one, as a man must speak in his time of sorrow. There was no woman whose sympathy could be given to him, or with whom, owing to the terrible circumstance with which his sorrow was surrounded, he could speak freely. “I know now how I suffered,” he said, as he dried his eyes, “but I do not know even yet—and none other can ever know—how much your sweet sympathy has been to me to-day. I shall know better in time; and believe me that, though I am not ungrateful now, my gratitude will grow with my understanding. You will let me be like a brother, will you not, for all our lives—for dear Lucy’s sake?”
vi: Finally, when he had calmed down, he slowly lifted his face and confessed that all this time, he had never had the chance to confide in anyone about the weariness and despair in his heart. He no longer felt interested in socializing with other girls and moreover, he couldn't have a close conversation with any girl after the recent ironic situations. — I know how much I have to endure, - He said while wiping his tears - but what you did for me today is so profound that right now I cannot fully understand its value, and no one will ever understand it. But I can understand that one day, when I have fully grasped your actions, please believe that my gratitude towards you will be much deeper. From today onwards, in memory of Lucy, I would like to regard you as a sister. — Yes, in memory of our Lucy.
tr: Shortly after, his hiccups ceased, and without hiding his emotion, he apologized and stood up. He said that during the past days and nights - tiresome days and sleepless nights - he couldn't talk to anyone as one should when suffering. There was no woman who could give him empathy, nor was there anyone he could openly talk to because of the terrible circumstances surrounding his grief. "Now, I know how much I have suffered," he said, wiping his eyes, "but even now, I can't know what your sweet goodwill means to me today - and no one else in my place could know either. I will understand this better over time, and believe me, even though I am not being ungrateful right now, my gratitude will grow as I begin to understand the situation more. Throughout our lives, you will allow me to be your brother, won't you - for the sake of dear Lucy?"
es: After a while, his sobbing ceased and he straightened up, apologizing, though he did not try to hide his emotion. He told me that for many days and nights, days full of fatigue and sleepless nights, he had felt unable to talk to anyone, as a man should in moments of affliction like those. There was no woman whose comfort could be given to him or with whom, due to the terrible circumstances surrounding his grief, he could speak freely. –Now I know how she suffered -he said, while wiping his eyes-. But, I don't know even at this moment and no other person will ever be able to understand, how much your sweet comfort has meant to me today. With time I will understand it better, and believe me that, although I am infinitely grateful now, my gratitude will increase as my understanding does. Will you allow us to be like siblings for all our lives... for Lucy's sake?

en: “For dear Lucy’s sake,” I said as we clasped hands. “Ay, and for your own sake,” he added, “for if a man’s esteem and gratitude are ever worth the winning, you have won mine to-day. If ever the future should bring to you a time when you need a man’s help, believe me, you will not call in vain. God grant that no such time may ever come to you to break the sunshine of your life; but if it should ever come, promise me that you will let me know.” He was so earnest, and his sorrow was so fresh, that I felt it would comfort him, so I said:—
vi: - I replied and squeezed his hand. — And also because of what belongs to your humanity, - He continued - because if there is ever anyone who deserves the gratitude and respect of a man, then you are the one who has earned my complete admiration. If in the future, whenever you need the wholehearted help of a sincere friend, please think of me. God will never let you go through dark days again! But if that still happens, please let me know immediately! I can completely sense the mood and seriousness in his voice, and perhaps my promise will somewhat comfort him.
tr: “For dear Lucy's sake,” I said as we shook hands. “Agreed - and for your sake,” he added, “because if a man's respect and gratitude are things worth earning, you have earned mine today. If in the future, there are times when you need a man's help, believe me, your call will not go unanswered. May God never show you such times that would darken the daylight of your life, but if such a day comes, promise me you will let me know.” He was so sincere and his grief so fresh that I felt this would comfort him, and so I said:
es: –For the love of our Lucy -I said, as I shook his hand. –And for yourself -he added-, since if a man's esteem and gratitude have any value, you have earned them today. If ever in the future you find yourself in need of a man's help, believe me, you will not call upon me in vain. God willing, that moment when the sunlight disappears from your life will never come; but if it does, promise me you will turn to me. He was so sincere and his pain had been so deep that I understood it would be a comfort for him, and I said to him:

en: “I promise.”
vi: — Yes, I promise to do so!
tr: “I promise.”
es: –I promise you.

en: As I came along the corridor I saw Mr. Morris looking out of a window. He turned as he heard my footsteps. “How is Art?” he said. Then noticing my red eyes, he went on: “Ah, I see you have been comforting him. Poor old fellow! he needs it. No one but a woman can help a man when he is in trouble of the heart; and he had no one to comfort him.”
vi: In the hallway, Morris was standing pensively in front of the window. As soon as he heard my footsteps, he turned and asked: — How is Arthur? Seeing my eyes red, he immediately spoke up: — Ah! I knew you would find a way to comfort him. Poor guy, he really needs to be comforted! Only a woman can soothe a man's heart, and the gentle gestures of a woman can...
tr: As I was walking through the corridor, I saw Mr. Morris looking out the window. He turned when he heard my footsteps. “How is Art?” he said. Then, noticing my red eyes, he continued: “Ah, I see you were comforting him. Poor old friend! He needs it. When a man's heart is troubled, only women can help, and he had no one to comfort him.”
es: When I stepped into the hallway, I saw Mr. Morris, who was looking outside through one of the windows. He turned around when he heard the sound of my footsteps. –How is Art? – he inquired. Then, seeing my reddened eyes, he continued saying: –Ah! I see that you have been consoling him. Poor friend of mine! That is what he needs. No one but a woman can console a man when his heart is broken, and he has no one...

en: He bore his own trouble so bravely that my heart bled for him. I saw the manuscript in his hand, and I knew that when he read it he would realise how much I knew; so I said to him:—
vi: However, even Morris is not someone who can easily overcome the pain in his heart without the courage and fortitude of a resolute man. When I noticed a stack of typed papers in his hand, I suddenly understood that he had read what I had given him and knew that I was aware of everything.
tr: He carried his burden so bravely that my heart bled for him. I saw the papers in his hand and knew that when he read them, he would learn how much I knew; therefore, I said to him:
es: He buried his own pain with such fortitude that my heart bled for him. I saw that he had the manuscript in his hand and knew that as soon as he read it, he would realize how much I knew; therefore, I said to him:

en: “I wish I could comfort all who suffer from the heart. Will you let me be your friend, and will you come to me for comfort if you need it? You will know, later on, why I speak.” He saw that I was in earnest, and stooping, took my hand, and raising it to his lips, kissed it. It seemed but poor comfort to so brave and unselfish a soul, and impulsively I bent over and kissed him. The tears rose in his eyes, and there was a momentary choking in his throat; he said quite calmly:—
vi: — I really want to comfort everyone who has pain in their hearts! - I said. - Please allow me to be a friend, a friend whom you can seek out whenever you need help. Later on, you will understand why I said this to you. Morris leaned over and kissed my hand. Honestly, I still felt too small and weak to be able to help such a gallant and selfless young man!
