I didn't know how to express my deep appreciation for him. Tears filled with emotion suddenly rolled down the cheeks of the poor young man, rendering him unable to say anything further. It took a while before he calmed down and told me:
tr: “I wish I could comfort everyone who is wounded in their heart. Will you allow me to be your friend and will you come to me if you need comfort? Later, you will understand why I spoke this way.” Seeing my sincerity, he bowed, took my hand, brought it to his lips, and kissed it. For such a brave and selfless soul, this was a very small comfort, and without thinking, I bent down and kissed him. His eyes filled with tears and his throat choked for a moment, he said with great calm:
es: –I wish I could console all those who suffer deeply. Do you want to be my friend and come to me if you need comfort? Later, you will understand what I am talking about. He saw that he was saying it sincerely and, making a bow to me, he took my hand, brought it to his lips, and kissed it. It seemed to be too poor a consolation for such a brave and selfless soul. Then, impulsively, I leaned in and kissed him. His eyes filled with tears and a lump formed in his throat. Then, he said in a calm tone:

en: “Little girl, you will never regret that true-hearted kindness, so long as ever you live!” Then he went into the study to his friend.
vi: — Little girl, you will never have to regret expressing your feelings to me, never! Then he quietly returned to the room with his friend.
tr: "Little girl, you will not regret this heartfelt kindness for as long as you live!" Then, she went to her study, to her friend's side.
es: –Little one, you will never forget that sincere kindness, in all your life! Then, he headed towards the study, where his friend was.

en: “Little girl!”—the very words he had used to Lucy, and oh, but he proved himself a friend!
vi: "Little girl..." These are indeed words laden with affection that he once used to speak to Lucy, but clearly, he also deserves to be a very close friend!
tr: "Little girl!" - The same words he used for Lucy, but it proved his friendship!
es: –Little one! The same word with which he had referred to Lucy. But he proved to be a friend!.

en: CHAPTER XVIII
vi: CHAPTER 18
tr: XVIII
es: XVIII.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: 30 September.—I got home at five o’clock, and found that Godalming and Morris had not only arrived, but had already studied the transcript of the various diaries and letters which Harker and his wonderful wife had made and arranged. Harker had not yet returned from his visit to the carriers’ men, of whom Dr. Hennessey had written to me. Mrs. Harker gave us a cup of tea, and I can honestly say that, for the first time since I have lived in it, this old house seemed like home. When we had finished, Mrs. Harker said:—
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary I returned home at five in the afternoon, when Lord Godalming and Morris were already present and they were informed about the letters and the diaries that Jonathan and his admirable wife had meticulously copied. Jonathan had not yet returned; he had to visit some truck drivers that Mr. Hennessey mentioned in his letter. Mina made each of us a cup of tea; to be honest, since becoming a doctor, this was the first time I truly felt that this hospital was "my home". While sitting and drinking tea, Mina asked me:
tr: September 30. - I returned home at five o'clock and saw that not only had Godalming and Morris arrived, but they had also already examined the various journal and letter texts prepared and organized by Harker and his excellent wife. Harker had not yet returned from the transporter's men, as Dr. Hennessey had informed me by letter. Ms. Harker gave us each a cup of tea, and I can honestly say that for the first time since I started living here, this old house felt like a home. When we finished our tea, Ms. Harker said:
es: September 30. I arrived home at five and discovered that Godalming and Morris had not only arrived but had also studied the transcripts of the various diaries and letters that Harker and his wonderful wife had prepared and organized. Harker had not yet returned from his visit to the carriers, about whom Dr. Hennessey had written to me. Mrs. Harker gave us a cup of tea, and I can say with all sincerity that, for the first time since I lived there, that old house felt like a home to me. When we finished, Mrs. Harker said:

en: “Dr. Seward, may I ask a favour? I want to see your patient, Mr. Renfield. Do let me see him. What you have said of him in your diary interests me so much!” She looked so appealing and so pretty that I could not refuse her, and there was no possible reason why I should; so I took her with me. When I went into the room, I told the man that a lady would like to see him; to which he simply answered: “Why?”
vi: — Dr. Seward, may I make a request of you? I would like to meet your patient Renfield for a moment. What you mentioned about him in your diary has caught my attention. Her voice, her eyes almost pleading, made it impossible for me to refuse. Besides, I saw no reason to do so. And I agreed to take her to meet Renfield immediately afterward. Entering his room, I told him that a lady wished to visit him, and he mumbled in response: — For what purpose?
tr: "Dr. Seward, may I ask you for something? I want to see your patient, Mr. Renfield. I want to see him. The things you mentioned about him in your journal intrigued me a lot!" She looked so charming, so beautiful that I couldn't refuse her, and there was no reason to refuse, so I took her to the man. When I entered the room, I told the man that a lady wanted to see him, to which he simply replied, "Why?"
es: –Doctor Seward, may I ask you a favor? I wish to see your patient, Mr. Renfield. Let me see him. I am very interested in what you say about him in your diary. She looked so pleading and so pretty that I couldn't refuse her; consequently, I took her with me. When I entered the room, I told the man that there was a lady who would like to see him, to which he simply responded: –Why?

en: “She is going through the house, and wants to see every one in it,” I answered. “Oh, very well,” he said; “let her come in, by all means; but just wait a minute till I tidy up the place.” His method of tidying was peculiar: he simply swallowed all the flies and spiders in the boxes before I could stop him. It was quite evident that he feared, or was jealous of, some interference. When he had got through his disgusting task, he said cheerfully: “Let the lady come in,” and sat down on the edge of his bed with his head down, but with his eyelids raised so that he could see her as she entered. For a moment I thought that he might have some homicidal intent; I remembered how quiet he had been just before he attacked me in my own study, and I took care to stand where I could seize him at once if he attempted to make a spring at her. She came into the room with an easy gracefulness which would at once command the respect of any lunatic—for easiness is one of the qualities mad people most respect. She walked over to him, smiling pleasantly, and held out her hand.
vi: — She intends to visit the hospital, - I explained - and wants to interact with the inpatients to understand some issues, that's all. — That's good! Then just tell her to come in! But wait a minute, I need to tidy up a few things first. For him, cleaning up meant devouring all the flies and spiders stored in the boxes scattered around the room before anyone could stop him. Clearly, he was afraid of others finding out about those insects. After "cleaning up," he cheerfully told me: — Bring her in! Then he sat down on the edge of the bed, head bowed, but his eyes still tried to look up, waiting for the strange guest. Looking at him, I suddenly felt anxious because he could go into a deadly rage at any moment. I remember there was a time when he appeared completely docile in my office, yet just a few minutes later, he suddenly lunged at me as if he wanted to finish me off immediately. Therefore, I had to sidle up to sit next to him so that if anything happened, I could kill him before he had a chance to attack Mina. With his consent, Mina stepped in cheerfully and extended her hand towards him.
tr: “She is wandering around and wants to see everyone inside,” I replied. “Oh, very well,” she said, “of course, let her in; but wait a minute until I tidy up here.” The tidying method was unusual: Before I could stop her, she swallowed all the flies and spiders in the boxes. It was very clear that he was afraid of interference in his work or felt jealousy. When he completed his disgusting task, he cheerfully said, "Let the lady come in," and sat on the edge of his bed, raising his eyes so he could see the lady's entrance. For a moment, I thought he might have the intention to kill; I remembered how calm he was just before attacking me in my study, and I made sure to stand in a place where I could catch him if he tried to jump on Ms. Harker. Ms. Harker entered the room with a natural grace that would suddenly earn the respect of any madman. She walked towards Renfield with a pleasant smile and extended her hand.
es: –He is visiting the entire house and wants to see everyone in it -I replied. –Ah, very well! – he said-. Let her in, no matter what; but wait a minute, until I put the place in order. His method of tidying the room was very peculiar. He simply swallowed all the flies and spiders that were in the boxes before he could be stopped. It was obvious that he feared or was jealous of any interference. When he had finished his unpleasant task, he said kindly: –Let the lady in. And he sat on the edge of his bed with his head bowed down; but with his eyelids raised, so he could see the lady as soon as she entered the room. For a moment, I thought that perhaps he had homicidal intentions. I remembered how calm he had been shortly before attacking me in my own studio, and I positioned myself in such a way that I could restrain him immediately if he tried to jump on her. Mrs. Harker entered the room with a natural grace that would have immediately earned her respect from any lunatic... since poise and grace are the qualities most respected by the insane. She approached him, smiling pleasantly, and extended her hand.

en: “Good-evening, Mr. Renfield,” said she. “You see, I know you, for Dr. Seward has told me of you.” He made no immediate reply, but eyed her all over intently with a set frown on his face. This look gave way to one of wonder, which merged in doubt; then, to my intense astonishment, he said:—
vi: — Hello, Renfield. - She said. - You see, I have been informed about you, Dr. Seward has told me about you. He frowned, staring intently at the strange woman and did not bother to answer immediately. He even showed a mix of surprise and a bit of skepticism, but he also surprised me with a question I could never have anticipated:
tr: “Good evening, Mr. Renfield,” she said. “You see, I know you because Dr. Seward has told me about you.” Renfield did not respond immediately, but with a sullen expression, he examined her carefully from head to toe. This gaze turned into a curiosity mixed with suspicion; then, to my great surprise, he said:
es: –Good afternoon, Mr. Renfield -he said-. As you can see, I know you. Dr. Seward has spoken to me about you. The alienated one did not respond immediately, but examined her with a furrowed brow. His expression changed, his face reflected astonishment and then doubt; then, to my profound surprise, I heard him say:

en: “You’re not the girl the doctor wanted to marry, are you? You can’t be, you know, for she’s dead.” Mrs. Harker smiled sweetly as she replied:—
vi: — Isn't she the woman the doctor here wants to marry? No, it can't be her, because that girl is already dead. Mina smiled and replied:
tr: “You are not the young girl the Doctor wants to marry, are you? You can't be, you know, because she died.” Ms. Harker replied with a sweet smile: “Oh, no!
es: –You are not the woman the doctor wished to marry, are you? You cannot be, since she is dead. Mrs. Harker smiled sweetly as she replied:

en: “Oh no! I have a husband of my own, to whom I was married before I ever saw Dr. Seward, or he me. I am Mrs. Harker.”
vi: — No, definitely not! Because I am married, we got married before I knew Dr. Seward, and at that time he had never met me.
tr: Ms. Harker replied with a sweet smile: “Oh, no! I have my own husband whom I married before seeing Dr. Seward or he seeing me. I am Ms. Harker.”
es: –Oh, no! I already have a husband, with whom I have been married since long before I even met Dr. Seward. I am Mrs. Harker.

en: “Then what are you doing here?”
vi: — So why did you come here?
tr: “So what are you doing here then?”
es: –Then, what are you doing here?

en: “My husband and I are staying on a visit with Dr. Seward.”
vi: — My husband and I want to visit Dr. Seward's house.
tr: “My husband and I came to visit Dr. Seward.”
es: –My husband and I have come to visit Dr. Seward.

en: “Then don’t stay.”
vi: — Don't linger at his house!
tr: "Then don't stay here."
es: –Then don't stay.

en: “But why not?” I thought that this style of conversation might not be pleasant to Mrs. Harker, any more than it was to me, so I joined in:—
vi: — Why? Afraid that this kind of conversation might upset Mina, I had to choose my words carefully to steer the conversation in a different direction.
tr: “But why?” I thought that this kind of conversation might not be very pleasant for Ms. Harker, just as it wasn't for me, so I joined in:
es: –But, why not? I thought that such a style of conversation could not be more pleasant for Mrs. Harker than it was for me. Consequently, I intervened:

en: “How did you know I wanted to marry any one?” His reply was simply contemptuous, given in a pause in which he turned his eyes from Mrs. Harker to me, instantly turning them back again:—
vi: — How do you know I plan to get married? - I asked Renfield. He responded to me with a disdainful tone, his eyes shifting from Mina to me, then immediately turning away:
tr: "How did you know that I wanted to marry someone?" In the brief moment when he shifted his gaze from Ms. Harker to me and then immediately back to her, his response was very dismissive:
es: –How do you know that I wanted to get married? His response was profoundly disdainful, and he gave it during a pause in which he averted his eyes from Mrs. Harker and fixed his gaze on me, only to immediately return his focus to the lady.

en: “What an asinine question!”
vi: — What a stupid question!
tr: "What a foolish question!""
es: –What a stupid question!

en: “I don’t see that at all, Mr. Renfield,” said Mrs. Harker, at once championing me. He replied to her with as much courtesy and respect as he had shown contempt to me:—
vi: — I don't think so, Renfield! - Mina said as if to defend me. Unlike his disdainful attitude when talking to me, he was very polite and respectful when conversing with Mina:
tr: “I don't understand anything, Mr. Renfield,” said Ms. Harker, immediately defending me. He responded to her with the same degree of delicacy and respect as his disdain for me:
es: "I don't believe that at all, Mr. Renfield," Mrs. Harker said, defending me. Renfield then spoke to him with as much courtesy and respect as he had shown disdain towards me just moments before.

en: “You will, of course, understand, Mrs. Harker, that when a man is so loved and honoured as our host is, everything regarding him is of interest in our little community. Dr. Seward is loved not only by his household and his friends, but even by his patients, who, being some of them hardly in mental equilibrium, are apt to distort causes and effects. Since I myself have been an inmate of a lunatic asylum, I cannot but notice that the sophistic tendencies of some of its inmates lean towards the errors of non causa and ignoratio elenchi.” I positively opened my eyes at this new development. Here was my own pet lunatic—the most pronounced of his type that I had ever met with—talking elemental philosophy, and with the manner of a polished gentleman. I wonder if it was Mrs. Harker’s presence which had touched some chord in his memory. If this new phase was spontaneous, or in any way due to her unconscious influence, she must have some rare gift or power.
vi: — Mrs. Harker, you must understand that for a man who is esteemed and loved like the doctor here, everything related to him concerns our small community. Not only do the friends who love Dr. Seward, but even some of his patients, due to their mental imbalance, can alter the nature of cause and effect. Since being in this asylum, I cannot help but notice that the sophistry of some inmates always tends to make them commit errors of non-causality and consequence, causing them to be confused not only due to a lack of substance awareness but also about the cause itself. I stared at him in astonishment. He was the patient who concerned me the most, so I always understood that one of the things contributing to his condition was his frequent talk about philosophy. But indeed, I had never seen him speak in such a manner: he spoke as if he were a truly distinguished philosopher. Could Mina's presence have struck a chord in his memory? If the sudden awakening of these intellectual abilities was spontaneous, or at least stemmed from the unconscious influence of that young woman, then she must surely possess a natural talent or an unusual capability.
tr: “When a man is loved and honored as our host is, you will of course understand, Ms. Harker, that everything about him greatly interests our small community. Dr. Seward is loved not only by the household and friends but even by some of his patients, whose mental balance is barely maintained and who have a tendency to distort cause-and-effect relationships. Since I live in the mental hospital, I cannot help but notice the wise tendencies of some of its residents to make errors such as non causae46 and ignoratio elenchi47. I have certainly opened my eyes to this new development. Here is my pet lunatic -the most prominent example of his kind I have encountered to date- discussing fundamental philosophy and doing so with the demeanor of a polite gentleman. Was it perhaps Ms. Harker's presence that touched a point in his mind? If this new phase is occurring spontaneously or somehow due to Ms. Harker's unconscious influence, it means she has a rare talent or power.
es: –I am sure you will understand, Mrs. Harker, that when a man is as beloved and honored as our host, everything related to him becomes interesting in our small community. Dr. Seward is loved not only by his servants and friends, but also by his patients, who, since many of them have a certain mental imbalance, are in a position to distort certain causes and effects. Since I myself have been a patient in an asylum for the insane, I cannot help but notice that the mythomaniac tendencies of some of the inmates lead to errors of non causa and ignoratio elenchi. I opened my eyes wide at this completely new development. There was the worst of all my lunatics, the most steadfast in his type that I have encountered in my entire life, speaking of elementary philosophy with the manners of a refined gentleman. I wondered if it was the presence of Mrs. Harker that had struck some chord in his memory. If that new phase was spontaneous or due to the unconscious influence of the lady, the lady must possess some strange gift or power.

en: We continued to talk for some time; and, seeing that he was seemingly quite reasonable, she ventured, looking at me questioningly as she began, to lead him to his favourite topic. I was again astonished, for he addressed himself to the question with the impartiality of the completest sanity; he even took himself as an example when he mentioned certain things.
vi: We sat and chatted for a while longer. Seeing that Renfield seemed pleased with his reasoning, Mina winked at me and then asked him more about the topic he liked. Clearly, he was surprising me more and more. He spoke freely like a man with full intellectual capabilities, and moreover, he used himself as an example to prove what he wanted to demonstrate.
tr: We continued talking for a while longer, and seeing that Renfield appeared quite rational, Ms. Harker, with questioning eyes, dared to steer him towards his favorite topic. Again, I was astonished because he dedicated himself to answering the question with the impartiality of someone entirely sane, even using himself as an example when discussing certain things.
es: We continued talking for a while and, seeing that he apparently reasoned perfectly, he ventured, looking at me questioningly at first, leading him towards his favorite topic of conversation. I was astonished again to see that Renfield approached the matter with the impartiality characteristic of absolute sanity; he even used himself as an example when mentioning certain things.

en: “Why, I myself am an instance of a man who had a strange belief. Indeed, it was no wonder that my friends were alarmed, and insisted on my being put under control. I used to fancy that life was a positive and perpetual entity, and that by consuming a multitude of live things, no matter how low in the scale of creation, one might indefinitely prolong life. At times I held the belief so strongly that I actually tried to take human life. The doctor here will bear me out that on one occasion I tried to kill him for the purpose of strengthening my vital powers by the assimilation with my own body of his life through the medium of his blood—relying, of course, upon the Scriptural phrase, ‘For the blood is the life.’ Though, indeed, the vendor of a certain nostrum has vulgarised the truism to the very point of contempt. Isn’t that true, doctor?” I nodded assent, for I was so amazed that I hardly knew what to either think or say; it was hard to imagine that I had seen him eat up his spiders and flies not five minutes before. Looking at my watch, I saw that I should go to the station to meet Van Helsing, so I told Mrs. Harker that it was time to leave. She came at once, after saying pleasantly to Mr. Renfield: “Good-bye, and I hope I may see you often, under auspices pleasanter to yourself,” to which, to my astonishment, he replied:—
vi: — If you pay attention, you will see in me a very different essence. I say this without jest, it is not surprising that my relatives always show concern for me and place me under their supervision. Occasionally, I still imagine life as a practical, eternal entity, and by consuming countless living entities, even those at the bottom of the creation ladder, one can extend their life indefinitely. I have always believed in immortality, to the extent that there will come a time when I must truly prove myself to be a man. Surely, there will be a time when the doctor here will tell you that there was once a moment when I intended to kill him to rejuvenate myself, I mean to say that I would attain immortality by absorbing his very blood, because I remember a verse in the Bible: “The blood flows, that is life.” Yet the physicians have deliberately trivialized this obvious truth to the point where he deserves to be spat in the face. Am I right, doctor? I nodded slightly, feeling very astonished to be able to find a word or even a thought about what he had just explained. Could this really be a man who, just five minutes ago, had swallowed who knows how many flies and spiders!... I glanced at the clock, as it was time to go to the station to pick up Van Helsing. Seeing me mention it, Mina immediately stood up to leave with me, but before stepping out the door, she smiled and said to Renfield: — Goodbye! I hope that I will be able to visit you often on suitable occasions!
tr: “Look, personally, I am also one of those people with strange beliefs. It is not surprising that my friends are afraid and insist on having me under control. I believed that life is a positive and continuous existence and that by consuming a large number of living beings, no matter how low they are in the order of creation, a person could indefinitely extend their life. From time to time, this belief was so strong that I even attempted to take human life. The Doctor here will confirm that once, I tried to kill him to increase my vital forces by assimilating his life through his blood - Of course, based on the phrase from the Holy Bible, ‘For the life of the flesh is in the blood.’ But in reality, the person selling certain old wives' remedies vulgarizes the matter to the point of insulting reality. Isn't that right, Doctor?” I nodded because I was so surprised that I didn't know what to think or say; it was hard to believe that just five minutes ago, I had seen him eating his spiders and flies. When I looked at my watch, I saw that I needed to go to the station to meet Van Helsing, and so I told Ms. Harker that it was time to leave. Ms. Harker kindly said to Mr. Renfield, “Goodbye, I hope to see you more often under more pleasant circumstances,” and then immediately left. Mr. Renfield responded to this, surprising me:
es: –Well, I myself am an example of a man who has a strange belief. In fact, it is not strange that my friends were alarmed and insisted that I needed to be controlled. I used to think that life was a positive and perpetual entity, and that by consuming a multitude of living beings, no matter how low they are on the scale of creation, it is possible to prolong life indefinitely. Sometimes I believed in it so firmly that I tried to eat human flesh. The doctor, present here, can confirm that once I tried to kill him in order to strengthen my vital powers, by assimilating his life into my own body through his blood, based, of course, on the biblical phrase: "For the blood is the life." Although, in reality, the seller of a certain panacea has vulgarized the truism to the point of contempt. Isn't that true, doctor? I nodded absentmindedly, because I was so astonished that I didn't exactly know what to think or say; it was hard to believe that I had seen him eating his flies and spiders less than five minutes ago. I looked at my wristwatch and saw that it was already time for me to head to the station to wait for van Helsing; consequently, I told Mrs. Harker that it was time for us to leave. She accompanied me immediately, after kindly telling Mr. Renfield: –See you later. I hope to see you frequently, under somewhat more pleasant circumstances for you. To which, to my astonishment, the deranged person replied:

en: “Good-bye, my dear. I pray God I may never see your sweet face again. May He bless and keep you!”
vi: Renfield's answer once again made me ponder: — Goodbye, dear... or rather, may God ensure that I never have to see your charming face again. May He protect you and bless you!
tr: “Goodbye, my dear. I pray to God that I may never see your sweet face again. May God bless and protect you!”
es: –Goodbye, dear lady. I pray to God never to see your sweet face again. May He bless and keep you!

en: When I went to the station to meet Van Helsing I left the boys behind me. Poor Art seemed more cheerful than he has been since Lucy first took ill, and Quincey is more like his own bright self than he has been for many a long day.
vi: I went to the station alone, leaving Arthur at home with Quincey. Today, Arthur seemed happier than he had been since his Lucy passed away. Meanwhile, Quincey also became much more cheerful with the new friend Mina Harker to talk to.
tr: When I went to the station to meet Van Helsing, I left the children behind. Poor Art looks happier than he has been since Lucy first fell ill, and Quincey seems to have returned to his bright self for the first time in many long days.
es: When I headed to the station, I left the boys behind. Poor Arthur seemed more lively than ever since Lucy had fallen ill, and Quincey was much more cheerful than he had been in many days.

en: Van Helsing stepped from the carriage with the eager nimbleness of a boy. He saw me at once, and rushed up to me, saying:—
vi: As soon as the train stopped, Van Helsing quickly jumped onto the platform like a young man. Seeing me, he hurried over, shouting loudly:
tr: Van Helsing got off the carriage with the impatience and agility of a child. He immediately saw me and, walking quickly towards me, said:
es: Van Helsing descended from the carriage with the eager agility of a child. He saw me immediately and rushed to meet me, saying:

en: “Ah, friend John, how goes all? Well? So! I have been busy, for I come here to stay if need be. All affairs are settled with me, and I have much to tell. Madam Mina is with you? Yes. And her so fine husband? And Arthur and my friend Quincey, they are with you, too? Good!”
vi: — Ah! John, how are you, still well? Good! As for me, when I was in Amsterdam, I took the opportunity to take care of everything so I could stay here for a long time if necessary. I have a lot to talk to you about. Is Mina at your house? Great! And how is her dear husband doing? And Arthur and Quincey? Are they all at your house too? Wonderful!
tr: “Ah, my friend John, how is everything going? Is it good? Alright! I was busy because I came here to stay if necessary. Everything is arranged with me and I have a lot to tell. Is Madam Mina with you? Yes. And what about her very nice husband? And Arthur and my friend Quincey, they are with you too, aren't they? Great!”
es: –Hello, my friend John! How is everything? Good? Great! I've been busy, but I've come back to stay here if necessary. I've taken care of all my affairs and I have a lot to talk about. Is Mrs. Mina with you? Yes. And her nice husband too? And are Arthur and my friend Quincey also at your house? Great!

en: As I drove to the house I told him of what had passed, and of how my own diary had come to be of some use through Mrs. Harker’s suggestion; at which the Professor interrupted me:—
vi: On the way home, I took the opportunity to tell him everything that had happened since he returned to the country, including the story of how my diary suddenly became useful when Mina typed it up and organized it in chronological order.
tr: As I was driving the car home, I told him what had happened and how my journal had been useful based on Ms. Harker's suggestion; upon which the Professor interrupted me:
es: While we were driving in the car towards the house, I brought him up to date on everything that had happened and how my own diary had come to be of some use through Mrs. Harker's suggestion. Then, the professor interrupted me:

en: “Ah, that wonderful Madam Mina! She has man’s brain—a brain that a man should have were he much gifted—and a woman’s heart. The good God fashioned her for a purpose, believe me, when He made that so good combination. Friend John, up to now fortune has made that woman of help to us; after to-night she must not have to do with this so terrible affair. It is not good that she run a risk so great. We men are determined—nay, are we not pledged?—to destroy this monster; but it is no part for a woman. Even if she be not harmed, her heart may fail her in so much and so many horrors; and hereafter she may suffer—both in waking, from her nerves, and in sleep, from her dreams. And, besides, she is young woman and not so long married; there may be other things to think of some time, if not now. You tell me she has wrote all, then she must consult with us; but to-morrow she say good-bye to this work, and we go alone.” I agreed heartily with him, and then I told him what we had found in his absence: that the house which Dracula had bought was the very next one to my own. He was amazed, and a great concern seemed to come on him. “Oh that we had known it before!” he said, “for then we might have reached him in time to save poor Lucy. However, ‘the milk that is spilt cries not out afterwards,’ as you say. We shall not think of that, but go on our way to the end.” Then he fell into a silence that lasted till we entered my own gateway. Before we went to prepare for dinner he said to Mrs. Harker:—
vi: — Oh my! This Miss Harker keeps surprising me more and more every day! She truly has the mind of a man, a man with natural talent, but carries within her the gentle heart of a woman! I tell you, don't laugh, God created her: it must be for some special divine purpose. My dear friend, fortune has brought her here to help us. However, after today, we should not let her get involved in this dreadful story anymore. Otherwise, she will have to face unforeseeable dangers. We have promised each other that the destruction of that demon is our task, the task of brave men, not of a woman, right? Even if she doesn't encounter any risk, her compassionate heart shouldn't have to endure the pressures of one horror after another. In any case, we must not allow her to have nights full of nightmares in the future. Moreover, since she is still young and has just gotten married, if not now then soon, she will have many things to arrange. You just said she has typed all the documents, so she has already participated quite a lot with us. Tomorrow, you should tell her to rest! Don't let her do any more work. We will continue the work ourselves without letting her... I completely agree with the professor's opinion and inform him of what we have just discovered during his absence: the house that Count Dracula bought is the one adjacent to the grounds of my asylum. Van Helsing seemed very surprised, but could not hide his worried expression. — Oh my God! Why didn't we know sooner? - He lamented. - If we had known earlier, we could have saved Lucy! But never mind, it's all in the past now, we shouldn't dwell on it, the issue now is to try our best to reach that final goal! He suddenly fell silent and remained that way until they got home. Before going upstairs to take off his coat and prepare for dinner, he said to Mina:
tr: “Ah, the wonderful Madam Mina! She has a man's brain - a brain that, if a man is lucky, he might possess - and a woman's heart. When the kind-hearted God made such a good mixture, believe me, He created her for a specific purpose. My friend John, so far, luck has allowed that woman to help us; after tonight, she should have no further involvement with this dreadful affair. It is not good for her to take such a great risk. We men are determined to destroy this monster - moreover, we have promised, haven't we? But this is not a woman's duty. Even if she is not harmed, her heart might fail her amidst all this horror, and she might suffer afterwards - because of her nerves while awake and because of her dreams while asleep. And besides, she is a young woman and has not been married long; there might be other things to consider, if not now, then later. You told me she has written everything down, so she should exchange views with us, but tomorrow she will bid farewell to this matter, and we will continue alone.” I wholeheartedly agreed with him and then told him what we had found in his absence: the house Dracula had bought was the one right next to mine. He was very surprised by this and seemed to be filled with great doubt. “Ah, if only we had known this sooner!” he said, “Because then we could have reached poor Lucy in time to save her. But as you said, ‘There is no use crying over spilled milk.’ We should not dwell on this and must proceed on our path to the end.” Then, he fell into silence until we reached the garden gate. Before going to prepare for dinner, he said to Ms. Harker:
es: –Oh! That wonderful lady Mina! She has the brain of a man; a very well-endowed man, and the heart of a woman. God created her with some exalted purpose, believe me, when He made such a good combination. Friend John, so far good luck has made that woman of great help to us; after tonight she should have nothing to do with this terrible matter. It is not convenient for her to run such a great danger. We men, since we have committed to it, are willing to destroy that monster; but there is no place in that plan for a woman. Even if she does not suffer physical harm, her heart may fail her on many occasions, due to that multitude of horrors; and then she may suffer from insomnia because of her nerves, and when sleeping, due to nightmares. Besides, she is a young woman and has not been married for long; there may be other things to think about at other times, though not currently. You have told me that she has written everything; therefore, she will consult with us; but tomorrow she will step away from this work, and we will continue alone. I sincerely agreed with him, and then I told him everything we had discovered in his absence and that the house Drácula had acquired was next to mine. He was very surprised and seemed to fall into deep reflections. –Oh! If we had known before! – he exclaimed. We could have reached in time to save poor Lucy. However, "there's no use crying over spilled milk," as you say. We must not think about it, but continue our journey to the end. Then, he fell into a silence that lasted until we entered my house. Before going to get ready for dinner, he said to Mrs. Harker:

en: “I am told, Madam Mina, by my friend John that you and your husband have put up in exact order all things that have been, up to this moment.”
vi: — Our friend John here has told me that you and your husband have taken the trouble to type up and organize all the documents related to what we know about Count Dracula up to this point.
tr: "Madam Mina, my friend John told me that you and your husband have put everything in the correct order so far."
es: –My friend John has told me, Mrs. Mina, that your husband and you have put in order everything we have been able to obtain up to this moment.

en: “Not up to this moment, Professor,” she said impulsively, “but up to this morning.”
vi: — Not at this moment, professor, but precisely this morning.
tr: “Not what has happened so far, Professor,” he said without hesitation, “but what has happened up until this morning.”
es: –Not until this moment -she said impulsively-, but until this morning.

en: “But why not up to now? We have seen hitherto how good light all the little things have made. We have told our secrets, and yet no one who has told is the worse for it.”
vi: — So, what's the difference? In the end, it's still a bit of light illuminating the facts, even if those facts seem the least important on the surface. We've all shared everything we know with each other, haven't we?
tr: “But why not what has happened so far? So far, we have seen how all the little things shed light on events. We have revealed our secrets and no one is worse off because of it yet.”
es: –But, why not until this moment? We have seen so far the good results that small details have given. We have revealed all our secrets and, nevertheless, none of them is going to be the worst of what we still have to learn.

en: Mrs. Harker began to blush, and taking a paper from her pockets, she said:—
vi: Mina blushed and took a piece of paper out of her pocket:
tr: Ms. Harker's face began to blush and she took out a piece of paper from her pocket, saying:
es: Mrs. Harker began to blush, and taking a paper out of her pocket, said:

en: “Dr. Van Helsing, will you read this, and tell me if it must go in. It is my record of to-day. I too have seen the need of putting down at present everything, however trivial; but there is little in this except what is personal. Must it go in?” The Professor read it over gravely, and handed it back, saying:—
vi: — Professor, could you read this note and see if I should continue? This is what I recorded today. Continuing to meticulously record what happens from now on might still be useful. I don't think there's anything personal here. Should I continue? After reading the note, Van Helsing spoke while handing it back to Mina:
tr: “Dr. Van Helsing, could you read this and tell me whether it should be included in the report?” “The record I kept for today. Even if it is insignificant, I have seen the necessity of writing everything down immediately, but there is very little here apart from personal matters. Should this be included as well?” The professor read the paper seriously and said while handing it back: “If you do not wish, it may not be included, but I request that you do include it.
es: –Doctor van Helsing, do you want to read this and tell me if it is necessary to include it? It is my report for today. I have also understood the need to record everything now, no matter how trivial it may seem; but in this, there is very little that is not personal. Should we include it? The professor read the note gravely and handed it back to Mina, saying:

en: “It need not go in if you do not wish it; but I pray that it may. It can but make your husband love you the more, and all us, your friends, more honour you—as well as more esteem and love.” She took it back with another blush and a bright smile.
vi: — This won't support other documents much if you don't want it to. However, for my part, I still think it's the right thing to do. Your husband can only feel more love for you, and through your actions, he will perceive that the appreciation and friendship we, his true friends, have for you can only grow each day. Mina blushed shyly again, taking back the piece of paper from the old professor's hand with a radiant smile on her face.
tr: The professor read the paper seriously and said while handing it back: “If you do not wish, it may not be included, but I request that you do include it. It might cause your husband to love you more and all of us, your friends, to value and respect you more, besides loving you more.” Ms. Harker, blushing and with a radiant smile, took the paper back.
es: –It is not necessary for us to include it if you do not wish so; but I beg you to accept doing it. It will only make your husband love you even more and all of us, your friends, honor, esteem, and love you even more. Mrs. Harker took the piece of paper again with another blush and a wide smile.

en: And so now, up to this very hour, all the records we have are complete and in order. The Professor took away one copy to study after dinner, and before our meeting, which is fixed for nine o’clock. The rest of us have already read everything; so when we meet in the study we shall all be informed as to facts, and can arrange our plan of battle with this terrible and mysterious enemy.
vi: So up until now, all of our notes have been completed and neatly organized. Van Helsing took a copy to ponder over after dinner, as we waited for the meeting at eight o'clock. After thoroughly studying all the documents in hand, he will plan with us the course of action against that mysterious and terrifying enemy.
tr: And thus, by this hour, all the records were completed and sorted. After dinner, the professor took a copy to work on before our meeting, which we had decided to hold at nine o'clock. The rest of us had already read everything; thus, when we gathered in the study, we would be informed about the facts and could make our battle plan against this terrible and mysterious enemy.
es: And in this way, up to this very moment, all the records we have are complete and in order. The professor took a copy to examine it after dinner and before our meeting, which has been scheduled for nine o'clock in the evening. The rest of us have already read everything; thus, when we gather in the study, we will be well informed of all the facts and can prepare our battle plan against that terrible and mysterious enemy.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 30 September.—When we met in Dr. Seward’s study two hours after dinner, which had been at six o’clock, we unconsciously formed a sort of board or committee. Professor Van Helsing took the head of the table, to which Dr. Seward motioned him as he came into the room. He made me sit next to him on his right, and asked me to act as secretary; Jonathan sat next to me. Opposite us were Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris—Lord Godalming being next the Professor, and Dr. Seward in the centre. The Professor said:—
vi: • September 30 About two hours after dinner, we gathered in Dr. Seward's study. Our meeting was like that of a council or some official committee. Professor Van Helsing sat at the head of the table as the chairperson, and he asked me to sit on his right to serve as the secretary for the group. Jonathan sat next to me. Sitting opposite my husband and me were Arthur and Morris - Arthur sat next to the professor, and Dr. Seward sat next to Morris. Seeing that everyone was already seated, Professor Van Helsing began the meeting:
tr: September 30 - When we met in Dr. Seward's study two hours after the six o'clock dinner, we had unconsciously formed a sort of committee or council. When Professor Van Helsing entered the room, he took the seat at the head of the table, as indicated by Dr. Seward. He seated me to his right and asked me to take on the role of secretary; Jonathan sat next to me. Opposite us were Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris - Lord Godalming sat next to the Professor and Dr. Seward took the middle seat. The Professor said:
es: September 30. When we gathered in Dr. Seward's study, two hours after dinner, which took place at six in the evening, we unconsciously formed a sort of board or committee. Professor Van Helsing took his place at the head of the table, in the spot indicated by Dr. Seward as soon as he entered the room. He had me sit immediately to his right and asked me to act as secretary: Jonathan sat next to me, and across from us were Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris. Lord Godalming was next to the professor and Dr. Seward in the center. The professor said:

en: “I may, I suppose, take it that we are all acquainted with the facts that are in these papers.” We all expressed assent, and he went on:—
vi: — If I am not mistaken, everyone is already fully aware of all the related events recorded in the diary and personal letters, right? Waiting for us to nod in response, he continued:
tr: “I believe I can assume that we are all aware of the facts in these documents.” We all agreed to this, and he continued:
es: I think I can take it for granted that we are all aware of the facts contained in those documents. We all nodded, and the doctor continued:

en: “Then it were, I think good that I tell you something of the kind of enemy with which we have to deal. I shall then make known to you something of the history of this man, which has been ascertained for me. So we then can discuss how we shall act, and can take our measure according.
vi: — I think it is also necessary to inform you more about the enemy we are facing. Please bear with me as I explain some points about the man whom I am now completely certain about. After that, we will discuss together to find the best course of action with the most appropriate measures possible.
tr: "In that case, it would be good if I told you some things about the kind of enemy we have to deal with. Then, as far as I have researched, I will tell you the history of this man. Thus, we can discuss how we will proceed and take our precautions.
es: –So, I think it would be appropriate for me to tell you something about the type of enemy we are going to have to face. Therefore, I am going to reveal to you part of the history of that man, which I have been able to come to know. Afterwards, we can discuss our method of action, and we can agree on all the necessary arrangements together.

en: “There are such beings as vampires; some of us have evidence that they exist. Even had we not the proof of our own unhappy experience, the teachings and the records of the past give proof enough for sane peoples. I admit that at the first I was sceptic. Were it not that through long years I have train myself to keep an open mind, I could not have believe until such time as that fact thunder on my ear. ‘See! see! I prove; I prove.’ Alas! Had I known at the first what now I know—nay, had I even guess at him—one so precious life had been spared to many of us who did love her. But that is gone; and we must so work, that other poor souls perish not, whilst we can save. The nosferatu do not die like the bee when he sting once. He is only stronger; and being stronger, have yet more power to work evil. This vampire which is amongst us is of himself so strong in person as twenty men; he is of cunning more than mortal, for his cunning be the growth of ages; he have still the aids of necromancy, which is, as his etymology imply, the divination by the dead, and all the dead that he can come nigh to are for him at command; he is brute, and more than brute; he is devil in callous, and the heart of him is not; he can, within limitations, appear at will when, and where, and in any of the forms that are to him; he can, within his range, direct the elements; the storm, the fog, the thunder; he can command all the meaner things: the rat, and the owl, and the bat—the moth, and the fox, and the wolf; he can grow and become small; and he can at times vanish and come unknown. How then are we to begin our strike to destroy him? How shall we find his where; and having found it, how can we destroy? My friends, this is much; it is a terrible task that we undertake, and there may be consequence to make the brave shudder. For if we fail in this our fight he must surely win; and then where end we? Life is nothings; I heed him not. But to fail here, is not mere life or death. It is that we become as him; that we henceforward become foul things of the night like him—without heart or conscience, preying on the bodies and the souls of those we love best. To us for ever are the gates of heaven shut; for who shall open them to us again? We go on for all time abhorred by all; a blot on the face of God’s sunshine; an arrow in the side of Him who died for man. But we are face to face with duty; and in such case must we shrink? For me, I say, no; but then I am old, and life, with his sunshine, his fair places, his song of birds, his music and his love, lie far behind. You others are young. Some have seen sorrow; but there are fair days yet in store. What say you?”
vi: First, I affirm that "vampires" truly exist in this world, simply because some of us have accidentally obtained evidence! Even if we hadn't gone through the painful reality just now, the past would still provide us with enough evidence to conclude their existence. To be honest, at first, I didn't believe it either. For many years, if I hadn't forced myself to broaden my perspective on the world and life, I would never have believed in this seemingly mythical story until a thunderbolt struck my ears: "See! I will make you see! I will give you undeniable evidence!" That's it! If from the beginning, we had known everything as we do now, Lucy's precious life might not have had such a sad ending! In the end, we failed. Now, all our efforts can only be to save other souls. It should be known that this nosferatu species cannot die like bees do after injecting their venom into a person's body. On the contrary, it only gets stronger, and the stronger it gets, the more dangerous it becomes. The "vampire" we are facing has the strength of twenty men. He is more cunning than any similar entity, as his deceitful skills have been honed over centuries. He knows how to use necromancy, a magic in its original sense of summoning the spirits of the dead to predict the future, and all the dead can come to him at his command. He is extremely ruthless, and sometimes even worse than ruthlessness. He is a demon without humanity, without a heart in many lands, he can appear anywhere, in any form he desires. Even to some extent, he has the power to control the forces of nature such as summoning storms, fog, thunder, or commanding lower animals like rats, owls, bats, moths, weasels, foxes, and wolves to obey him. He can make himself larger or smaller, and in some cases, he can disappear as if he never existed. Under such conditions, how are we to find him? And once we find him, how can we permanently destroy him? It's not easy, my friends, not easy at all. It will be an extremely difficult and terrifying task, sometimes just thinking about the consequences of that task is enough to make the bravest man shudder. Why is that? Because if we plunge into the battle, he will surely win. And then what will happen? For me, losing my life is not scary at all. The problem is that our failure carries a completely different meaning from life or death: we will become heartless, unconscious beings like him, creatures of the night, and then turn the people we love most into our prey. The gates of heaven will never close for us, because who will open the gates for us? We will be scorned and cursed by people forever. That's it! The most terrible challenge is being posed. We are facing a task entrusted by God, an arrow to be driven into the immortal for humanity. The task is there, can we retreat? As for me, I do not mind anything. Anyway, I am already old, life, the radiant sunlight, houses, gardens with chirping birds, music, love, longing... all, all are receding behind. But you, you are still very young. Some of you, although you have endured many sad things, happy days will still open their arms to welcome you. What do you decide?
tr: There are beings called vampires; some of us have evidence that they truly exist. Even if we don't have proof from our own unhappy experience, the teachings and records of the past provide enough evidence for sane people. I admit that I approached this with skepticism at first. If I hadn't trained myself to be open-minded over the years, I wouldn't have believed it until the truth roared in my ear at such a time, 'Look! Look! I am proving it! I am proving it!' Alas! If I had known at the beginning what I know now - even if I had made an assumption - such a precious life would have been spared for those of us who love it. But that is in the past; we must work so that other souls we can protect do not perish. Nosferatu, like a bee, does not die because it stings once. It only grows stronger and, because it grows stronger, it has more power to do evil. This vampire among us has the strength of twenty men, is more cunning than mortals because its cunning has developed over centuries; still, with the help of necromancy and as the root of the word indicates, it means seeing the future through the dead and that the dead it can approach come under its command, it is a ruthless and more than ruthless, a heartless demon, and it has no emotion in its heart, within certain limits, it can appear at any time, in any place, and in any form it desires, within a certain distance, it can control the air: it can create storms, mist, lightning, it can command lesser creatures - rats, owls, and bats - moths, foxes, and wolves; it can grow and shrink and at times disappear and become unknown. Then, how shall we begin our struggle to destroy it? How shall we find its place and, when we find it, how can we destroy it? My friends, this is too much; the task we have undertaken may have a dreadful outcome that would make the bravest tremble. For if we fail in this struggle, surely it will have won; then what will become of us? Life is not important; I do not care about it. But failing here is not just a matter of life and death. We would become like it; henceforth, we would be among the vile creatures of the night - heartless, merciless, feeding on the bodies and souls of those we love the most... The gates of Heaven would be closed to us forever, for who would ever open them for us again? Everyone would despise us forever, a black stain in the daylight of God, an arrow in the side of Him who died for humanity. But we are faced with duty, and should we shrink from such a cause? As for me, I say no, but I am old and life with its daylight, its beautiful places, its birdsong, its music, and its love is far behind me. You others are young. Some have seen sorrow, but there are still beautiful days ahead of you. What do you say?"
es: "There are beings called vampires; all of us have proof of their existence. Even if we did not have our unfortunate experiences, the teachings and records of antiquity provide sufficient evidence for sane people. I admit that, at first, I myself was skeptical about it. If I had not prepared for many years to keep my mind clear, I would not have been able to believe it until the facts showed me it was true, with reliable and irrefutable evidence. If, alas, I had known before what I know now and even what I guess, we might have been able to save a life that was so precious to all of us who loved her. But that is beyond remedy now, and we must continue working so that other poor souls do not perish, as long as we can save them. The nosferatu does not die like bees when they have stung, leaving their stinger. He is much stronger and, because of that, has much more power to do evil. That vampire among us is as strong personally as twenty men; he has a sharper intelligence than mortals, as it has grown over time; he still has the help of necromancy, which, as its etymology implies, is divination by death, and all the dead who die because of him are at his command; he is rough and more than rough; he can, without limitations, appear and disappear at will when and where he wishes and in any of the forms that are his own; he can, within his limits, command the elements; the storm, the mist, the thunder; he can give orders to harmful animals, to rats, owls, and bats... To moths, foxes, and wolves; he can grow and shrink in size; and he can sometimes make himself invisible. So, how are we going to carry out our attack to destroy him? How can we find the place where he hides and, after finding it, destroy him? My friends, it is a great task. We are going to undertake a terrible task, and there may be enough to make the brave tremble. Because if we fail in our struggle, he will necessarily have to defeat us and, where will we end up in that case? Life is nothing; I do not give it importance. But, failing in this case does not mean only life or death. It is that we would become like him; that henceforth we would be nefarious beings of the night, like him... Beings without heart or conscience, who dedicate themselves to the plunder of the bodies and souls of those they love most. For us, the gates of heaven will remain closed forever, because, who can open them for us? We will continue to exist, despised by all, as a stain before the splendor of God; like an arrow in the side of the one who died for us. But, we are face to face with duty and, in that case, can we retreat? As for me, I say no; but I am old, and life, with its brightness, its pleasant places, the singing of birds, its music and its love, is far behind. All the others are young. Some of you have known pain, but very happy days still await you. What do you say?"

en: Whilst he was speaking, Jonathan had taken my hand. I feared, oh so much, that the appalling nature of our danger was overcoming him when I saw his hand stretch out; but it was life to me to feel its touch—so strong, so self-reliant, so resolute. A brave man’s hand can speak for itself; it does not even need a woman’s love to hear its music.
vi: From the beginning until now, Jonathan has been attentively listening. To be honest, when I saw him grasp my hand tightly, I suddenly became worried that the danger the professor was talking about would severely affect his nerves, causing him to completely lose heart. But then I felt as if I had been revived when I sensed the message through his hand, a hand that was tight, firm, and full of determination. Clearly, the hand of a brave man has its own voice, and only a woman with a burning love in her heart can perceive that voice.
tr: While the professor was speaking, Jonathan had held my hand. When I saw his hand reaching out, I was very afraid that the terrifying nature of the danger we were facing would weaken him once again, but feeling his touch meant life to me - so strong, so confident, and so determined. The hand of the brave man can speak for him, and there is no need for a woman's love to hear his music.
es: While the professor was speaking, Jonathan had taken my hand. I feared that the terrible nature of the danger was overwhelming him, when I saw that he extended his hand to me; but feeling his touch gave me life... so strong, so sure, with such resolve... The hand of a brave man can speak for itself; it doesn't even need to be a woman in love who listens to its music.

en: When the Professor had done speaking my husband looked in my eyes, and I in his; there was no need for speaking between us.
vi: The professor silently waited, Jonathan and I exchanged glances, any words between us at this moment were useless.
tr: When the professor finished his speech, my husband looked into my eyes, and I looked into his eyes; we didn't need to speak with words.
es: When the professor stopped talking, my husband looked me in the eyes and I looked at him; we didn't need to speak to understand each other.

en: “I answer for Mina and myself,” he said.
vi: — Mina and I would like to say yes. - Jonathan replied.
tr: “I take responsibility for Mina and myself,” he said.
es: –I speak for Mina and myself -he said.

en: “Count me in, Professor,” said Mr. Quincey Morris, laconically as usual.
vi: "Please trust me, Professor," Morris asserted his inner desire.
tr: “Count me in, Professor,” said Mr. Quincey Morris, as concise as ever.
es: "Count on me, professor," said Quincey Morris laconically, as usual.

en: “I am with you,” said Lord Godalming, “for Lucy’s sake, if for no other reason.”
vi: — I also wish to accompany you to the end, - Lord Godalming expressed his feelings - I want to fulfill my duty in memory of Lucy, and even if there is no other purpose, just to lend you a hand.
tr: “I am with you too,” said Lord Godalming, “if for no other reason than for Lucy’s sake.”
es: –I am with you -said Lord Godalming-, for the love of Lucy, and for no other reason.

en: Dr. Seward simply nodded. The Professor stood up and, after laying his golden crucifix on the table, held out his hand on either side. I took his right hand, and Lord Godalming his left; Jonathan held my right with his left and stretched across to Mr. Morris. So as we all took hands our solemn compact was made. I felt my heart icy cold, but it did not even occur to me to draw back. We resumed our places, and Dr. Van Helsing went on with a sort of cheerfulness which showed that the serious work had begun. It was to be taken as gravely, and in as businesslike a way, as any other transaction of life:—
vi: As for himself, Dr. Seward just nodded silently. To him, that was more than enough to convey what was burning in his heart. All of us extended our hands to clearly show our determination. Thus, our grand wish was agreed upon. To be honest, there were moments when my heart seemed to tighten, although there was never a moment when I thought I had to refuse to participate in the dangerous task ahead. After the handshakes that demonstrated our resolve, we returned to our seats. Van Helsing continued his explanations with the enthusiasm of someone who felt very comfortable inside, understanding that our most important mission had finally begun with the highest level of unity and cooperation. — Very good!
tr: Dr. Seward only nodded with his head. The professor stood up, placed his golden cross on the table, and then extended his hands to his sides. I took his right hand, Lord Godalming his left hand, Jonathan took my right hand with his left and reached out to Mr. Morris. Thus, with all of us holding hands, our sacred agreement was made. I felt my heart freeze, but the thought of retreating never crossed my mind. We returned to our former places and Dr. Van Helsing continued his words with a kind of cheerfulness that indicated serious work had begun. As with any other matter in life, the issue had to be approached with seriousness and common sense.
es: Dr. Seward merely nodded. The professor stood up and, after placing his gold crucifix on the table, extended his hands to both sides. I took his right hand and Lord Godalming his left; Jonathan took my right hand with his left and extended his right to Mr. Morris. Thus, when we all held hands, our solemn promise was made. I felt a deadly coldness in my heart, but not for a moment did I think of retracting. We returned to our respective seats and Dr. Van Helsing continued speaking, with a satisfaction that clearly showed he had begun the work in earnest. It was necessary to take it with the same gravity and seriousness as any other important matter in life.

en: “Well, you know what we have to contend against; but we, too, are not without strength. We have on our side power of combination—a power denied to the vampire kind; we have sources of science; we are free to act and think; and the hours of the day and the night are ours equally. In fact, so far as our powers extend, they are unfettered, and we are free to use them. We have self-devotion in a cause, and an end to achieve which is not a selfish one. These things are much.
vi: Now we know what we are fighting against. We are not lacking in forces. We have the advantage in numbers, because “vampires” are always solitary, while we are many. We have information from books. Moreover, we are free to act and free to think. In terms of action, we also have the advantage, as both day and night belong to us. In fact, with the advantages we have, we can act freely as we wish. We are dedicated to a single purpose, and the purpose we aim for benefits not just one person, but all of humanity. Now, let's consider the limitations of “vampires” in general and of the count in particular.
tr: “Alright, you know what we are fighting against, but we are not powerless either. We have the power of unity on our side - a power spared from the vampire kind, we have the resources of science, the freedom to act and think, and the hours of day and night are equally ours. In fact, as our powers grow, they become more unrestrained and we are free to use them. We have a dedication to a purpose and an unselfish end to achieve. These are important things.
es: –Well, you already know what we will have to face; but we are not without strength either. We have, on our side, the power to unite... A power that is denied to the vampires; we have scientific resources; we are free to act and think, and both the daytime and nighttime hours belong to us. Indeed, as our powers are extensive, they are also overwhelming, and we are free to use them. We have a true devotion to a cause and a goal to achieve that is not selfish at all. That is already a lot.

en: “Now let us see how far the general powers arrayed against us are restrict, and how the individual cannot. In fine, let us consider the limitations of the vampire in general, and of this one in particular.
vi: Now, let's consider the limitations of “vampires” in general and of the count in particular.
tr: Now, let's see how the general forces arrayed against us are limited, while the individual ones are not able to do so. In short, let's think about the limits of vampires in general and this one in particular.
es: "Now, let's see how limited the powers we are going to face are and how the individual is limited. Indeed, we are going to examine the limitations of vampires in general and of this one in particular.

en: “All we have to go upon are traditions and superstitions. These do not at the first appear much, when the matter is one of life and death—nay of more than either life or death. Yet must we be satisfied; in the first place because we have to be—no other means is at our control—and secondly, because, after all, these things—tradition and superstition—are everything. Does not the belief in vampires rest for others—though not, alas! for us—on them? A year ago which of us would have received such a possibility, in the midst of our scientific, sceptical, matter-of-fact nineteenth century? We even scouted a belief that we saw justified under our very eyes. Take it, then, that the vampire, and the belief in his limitations and his cure, rest for the moment on the same base. For, let me tell you, he is known everywhere that men have been. In old Greece, in old Rome; he flourish in Germany all over, in France, in India, even in the Chernosese; and in China, so far from us in all ways, there even is he, and the peoples fear him at this day. He have follow the wake of the berserker Icelander, the devil-begotten Hun, the Slav, the Saxon, the Magyar. So far, then, we have all we may act upon; and let me tell you that very much of the beliefs are justified by what we have seen in our own so unhappy experience. The vampire live on, and cannot die by mere passing of the time; he can flourish when that he can fatten on the blood of the living. Even more, we have seen amongst us that he can even grow younger; that his vital faculties grow strenuous, and seem as though they refresh themselves when his special pabulum is plenty. But he cannot flourish without this diet; he eat not as others. Even friend Jonathan, who lived with him for weeks, did never see him to eat, never! He throws no shadow; he make in the mirror no reflect, as again Jonathan observe. He has the strength of many of his hand—witness again Jonathan when he shut the door against the wolfs, and when he help him from the diligence too. He can transform himself to wolf, as we gather from the ship arrival in Whitby, when he tear open the dog; he can be as bat, as Madam Mina saw him on the window at Whitby, and as friend John saw him fly from this so near house, and as my friend Quincey saw him at the window of Miss Lucy. He can come in mist which he create—that noble ship’s captain proved him of this; but, from what we know, the distance he can make this mist is limited, and it can only be round himself. He come on moonlight rays as elemental dust—as again Jonathan saw those sisters in the castle of Dracula. He become so small—we ourselves saw Miss Lucy, ere she was at peace, slip through a hairbreadth space at the tomb door. He can, when once he find his way, come out from anything or into anything, no matter how close it be bound or even fused up with fire—solder you call it. He can see in the dark—no small power this, in a world which is one half shut from the light. Ah, but hear me through. He can do all these things, yet he is not free. Nay; he is even more prisoner than the slave of the galley, than the madman in his cell. He cannot go where he lists; he who is not of nature has yet to obey some of nature’s laws—why we know not. He may not enter anywhere at the first, unless there be some one of the household who bid him to come; though afterwards he can come as he please. His power ceases, as does that of all evil things, at the coming of the day. Only at certain times can he have limited freedom. If he be not at the place whither he is bound, he can only change himself at noon or at exact sunrise or sunset. These things are we told, and in this record of ours we have proof by inference. Thus, whereas he can do as he will within his limit, when he have his earth-home, his coffin-home, his hell-home, the place unhallowed, as we saw when he went to the grave of the suicide at Whitby; still at other time he can only change when the time come. It is said, too, that he can only pass running water at the slack or the flood of the tide. Then there are things which so afflict him that he has no power, as the garlic that we know of; and as for things sacred, as this symbol, my crucifix, that was amongst us even now when we resolve, to them he is nothing, but in their presence he take his place far off and silent with respect. There are others, too, which I shall tell you of, lest in our seeking we may need them. The branch of wild rose on his coffin keep him that he move not from it; a sacred bullet fired into the coffin kill him so that he be true dead; and as for the stake through him, we know already of its peace; or the cut-off head that giveth rest. We have seen it with our eyes.
vi: To do this, we need to refer to tradition and belief. But in reality, tradition and belief do not bring anything significant when it comes to life and death... or more specifically, the issues at hand are far more important than life and death. However, we need to be content with ourselves, first because we are forced to act, and second because tradition and belief do not leave anything too important. Let me ask, about a year ago, in this nineteenth century with its peak of scientific development, who among us dared to admit what we have just learned now? We once loathed a belief, only to soon witness a reality that was not at all irrational. Believe that the “vampire” - a character that makes many people believe in its existence and its powers as well as its limitations - has also provided evidence of its existence in the eyes of many outside of us. We can see this wherever there are people on this earth. “Vampires” are mentioned everywhere: ancient Greece, ancient Rome, Germany, France, India, even the Chersonese islands. In China, a country very far from us, even today many people are so terrified just by hearing about it that they quickly hide under their blankets. Its bad reputation quietly follows the footsteps of the Irish, Hungarians, Slavs, Saxons, and nomadic Magyars across all continents. So we know everything we need to know, and we have all the necessary data to take action. But I must also say that there are still many beliefs about this character that have not been verified during the time we experienced the recent misfortune. “Vampires” live without fearing that time will gradually bring them closer to death. They will continue to expand as long as they are nourished by the blood of the living. We can see them become younger, stronger, and able to revive immediately if they find their preferred source of nourishment. They must follow this lifestyle and cannot live like ordinary people. As our friend Jonathan saw, during the many weeks at Dracula's castle, did he ever see it eat a meal? Never! Another equally strange thing: it has no shadow; its form is not reflected in mirrors, as Jonathan has also seen. Moreover, it has tremendous strength, as Jonathan described in his diary when it closed the castle gate to keep the wolves out and when it helped him down from the carriage. It can transform into a wolf, as seen when a certain ship docked at Whitby or when it attacked and tore apart a house dog, or into a bat as Mina saw on the window ledge at Whitby, as John saw when it flew from the neighboring house, or as Quincey saw when it perched on Lucy's window. It can approach the brave captain sitting at the helm by creating a thick fog around itself, but we can easily determine its limited space by that very fog. “Vampires” can appear as dust particles mingling with moonlight, as in the case of the three women Jonathan saw several times in Dracula's castle. You know, it can shrink itself to fit through a hair-thin crack in the Westenra family tomb. Once it finds its way, it can enter any place and see through the darkness, which is not a power to be underestimated in a twilight world. It can do all the things I just mentioned, but that does not mean it has free choice. It is truly a prisoner of itself, a prisoner sentenced to lifelong hard labor, a madman locked in a confined room. Going to all the places it wants is impossible for it. It is not a natural living entity but one that must live according to certain specific rules of its own. Not every door is open to it. Like other evil forces, its powers cease as soon as the first rays of dawn appear. It has the right to freedom, but only at specific times. If it is not at the place it wants to be, it cannot return there before sunset. We know this from folklore and documentary books, and we can also find similar evidence from what we have gathered here. Thus, although it can often show off its power as it pleases, “vampires” cannot ignore the limitations imposed within a specific range: coffins, hell, or an unblessed grave of a suicide in the Whitby cemetery, for instance, and it can only move at very specific times, or cross the ocean during high tide. And as we know, there are certain things that can nullify its powers, like me, or a symbolic object like a golden cross: seeing this sacred object, it must retreat and find a way to escape. There are other things you should know in case of necessity, such as wild rose placed on the coffin lid to prevent it from escaping, a holy bullet shot into the coffin will kill it, I mean a true death. And when a stake is driven into its heart, just like beheading it, we will give it eternal sleep, never to wake up again. We all understand this case, right?
tr: The only thing we can rely on is traditions and superstitions. When it comes to matters of life and death - even more than life and death - these may not seem very apparent at first glance. Nevertheless, we should be glad about it, because firstly, we are compelled to - we have nothing else under our control - and secondly, because ultimately these - tradition and superstition - mean everything. For others - but not for us - isn't the belief in vampires based on these? A year ago, in the midst of the scientific, realistic nineteenth century, which of us would have accepted such a possibility? We even rejected the belief confirmed right before our eyes. Then, assume for a moment that the belief in the vampire, its boundaries, and its cure are also based on this foundation. Because, let me tell you, it is recognized wherever mankind exists. It shines in ancient Greece, ancient Rome, all of Germany, in France, India, even in the Thracian Peninsula, in China, in places far from us under any circumstances, and even today people fear it. The Icelandic wild warrior, the son of the devil Hun, the Slav, the Saxon, the Hungarian came into the world after their revival. At that time, all we could base our actions on was this, and let me tell you that many of these beliefs have been confirmed by our own very unfortunate experiences. The vampire continues to live and cannot die merely with the passage of time; by feeding on the blood of the living, he can become even healthier. Moreover, we have seen that he can even rejuvenate over time; his vital abilities become more functional and seem to renew themselves when he has plenty of his special food. But without this diet, he cannot maintain his health; he does not eat like others. Even our friend Jonathan, who stayed with him for weeks, never saw him eat, not even once! He had no shadow, and as Jonathan observed, he has no reflection in the mirror. He possesses the strength of many men - Jonathan witnessed this again when he closed the door to the wolves and helped him down from the carriage. When he tore apart the dog, as we understood from the ship docking at Whitby, he can transform into a wolf; as Madam Mina saw him at the window in Whitby, and our friend John saw him flying very close to the house, and our friend Quincey saw him at Miss Lucy's window, he can also become a bat. He can come within the mist he creates - the captain of that noble ship proved this, but as far as we know, the distance of this mist is limited and can only be around him. He comes like pure dust particles in the moonlight - just as Jonathan saw those sisters at Dracula's castle.
