He can become very small - we saw him pass through the hair-thin gap in Miss Lucy's tomb door before finding peace. Once he finds his way, no matter how tightly bound it is or even if it is melted and fused with fire - you call it soldering - he can get out of anywhere and enter anywhere. He can see in the dark - this is no small power in a world half deprived of darkness. But listen until I finish. He can do all this but is not free. No! More captive than a galley slave, more captive than a madman in his cell. He cannot go wherever he wants; though he is not of nature, he still has to obey some natural laws - why, we do not know. He cannot enter any place for the first time unless invited by one of the household, but then, he can come as he pleases. With the dawn of day, as with all evil, his power vanishes. He has limited freedom only at certain times. If he is not in the place he is bound to, he can change himself only at noon or exactly at sunrise or sunset. These are the things we have been told and what we have been able to find evidence for based on our record. Therefore, within the unblessed place, as we saw when he went to the grave of the suicide in Whitby, he can do as he pleases within its boundaries, but at other times he can only change when the time comes. It is also said that he can cross running water only when it is still or at rising tide. Then, there are things that worry him because he has no power against them; as far as we know, things like garlic, holy items, and this symbol among us when we have made a firm decision, that is, the cross, for him, these are nothing, and in their presence, he withdraws respectfully and becomes silent. There are other things I will tell you about, in case we need them in our search. A bunch of wild rose placed on his coffin will prevent him from getting out; a blessed bullet shot into the coffin will kill him and thus make him truly dead, and as for the stake that will pass through him, we already know the peace it brings, or the peace brought by the severed head. We have seen this with our own eyes.
es: "All we have as points of reference are traditions and superstitions. These foundations do not seem, at first, to be very important when life and death are at stake. We have no way to control other means, and secondly, because, after all, these things, tradition and superstitions, are something. Isn't it true that others maintain the belief in vampires, even if we do not? A year ago, who among us would have accepted such a possibility, in the midst of our nineteenth century, scientific, skeptical, and realistic? We even refused to accept a belief that seemed justified before our very eyes. Let us then accept that the vampire and the belief in its limitations and the remedy against it rest for the moment on the same basis. For let me tell you that it has been known in all places inhabited by men. In ancient Greece, in ancient Rome; it existed in Germany, in France, in India, even in the Chersonese; and in China, which is so far from us in every respect, it still exists, and people fear them even to this day. It has followed the trail of the Icelandic navigators, the accursed Huns, the Slavs, the Saxons, and the Magyars. So far, we have everything we might need to act; and let me tell you that many of the beliefs have been justified by what we have seen in our own unfortunate experience. The vampire continues to live and cannot die simply because of the passage of time; it can grow stronger when it has the opportunity to feed on the blood of living beings. Even more: we have seen among us that it can even rejuvenate; that its vital faculties become more powerful and seem to refresh when it has a sufficient supply of human blood. But it cannot thrive without that regimen; it does not eat like others. Not even our friend Jonathan, who lived with it for several weeks, ever saw it eat. It casts no shadow, nor is it reflected in mirrors, as Jonathan also observed. It has the strength of many in its hands, as Jonathan also testified, when it closed the door against the wolves and when it helped him down from the coach. It can transform into a wolf, as we know from its arrival in Whitby and from our friend John, who saw it fly out of the neighboring house, and from my friend Quincey who saw it at Miss Lucy's window. It can appear in the midst of a mist that it itself produces, as attested by the noble captain of the ship, who tested it; but, as far as we know, the distance to which it can extend that mist is limited and can only be found around it. It arrives in the moonlight rays like cosmic dust… As Jonathan again saw those sisters at Dracula's castle. It becomes so small… We ourselves saw Miss Lucy, before she regained peace, enter through a crack the size of a hair in the door of her tomb. Once it has found the way, it can exit or enter any place, no matter how hermetically sealed, or even joined by fire…, welded, we might say. It can see in the dark…, which is no small power in a world that is always half-submerged in darkness. But, listen to me well: it can do all these things, though it is not free. No, it is even more a prisoner than the slave in the galleys or the madman in his cell. It cannot go wherever it wants. Although it does not belong to nature, it must nevertheless obey some of the natural laws… We do not know why. It cannot enter any place at first, unless there is some inhabitant of the house who lets it in; although afterwards it can enter whenever and however it wants. Its powers cease, like those of all evil things, upon the arrival of day. “Only on some occasions can he enjoy a certain margin of freedom. If he is not exactly in the right place, he can only move at noon or at the precise moment of sunset or sunrise. These are things we have known, and which we have proven in our records by inference. Thus, while he can do as he pleases within his limits, when he is in the place that belongs to him, on land, in his coffin or in hell, in a profane place, as we saw when he went to the suicide’s grave in Whitby; in other places, he can only move when the opportune moment arrives. It is also said that he can only cross running waters at the ebb of the tide. Furthermore, there are things that affect him in such a way that he loses his power, like garlic, which we already know, and sacred things, like this symbol, my crucifix, which was among us even now, when we made our resolution; for him all these things are nothing; but he keeps his distance and remains silent, with respect. There are other things as well, which I will tell you about, in case we need them in our investigation. The branch of wild rose placed over his coffin prevents him from leaving it; a consecrated bullet shot into his coffin kills him, so that he is truly dead; as for driving a wooden stake through him or cutting off his head, that makes him rest forever. We have seen it with our own eyes.

en: “Thus when we find the habitation of this man-that-was, we can confine him to his coffin and destroy him, if we obey what we know. But he is clever. I have asked my friend Arminius, of Buda-Pesth University, to make his record; and, from all the means that are, he tell me of what he has been. He must, indeed, have been that Voivode Dracula who won his name against the Turk, over the great river on the very frontier of Turkey-land. If it be so, then was he no common man; for in that time, and for centuries after, he was spoken of as the cleverest and the most cunning, as well as the bravest of the sons of the ‘land beyond the forest.’ That mighty brain and that iron resolution went with him to his grave, and are even now arrayed against us. The Draculas were, says Arminius, a great and noble race, though now and again were scions who were held by their coevals to have had dealings with the Evil One. They learned his secrets in the Scholomance, amongst the mountains over Lake Hermanstadt, where the devil claims the tenth scholar as his due. In the records are such words as ‘stregoica’—witch, ‘ordog,’ and ‘pokol’—Satan and hell; and in one manuscript this very Dracula is spoken of as ‘wampyr,’ which we all understand too well. There have been from the loins of this very one great men and good women, and their graves make sacred the earth where alone this foulness can dwell. For it is not the least of its terrors that this evil thing is rooted deep in all good; in soil barren of holy memories it cannot rest.”
vi: — Thus, - Professor Van Helsing continued - for Count Dracula, when we find his dwelling, we will do everything to keep him in his lair to destroy him right there. But don't forget that he is extremely cunning and also very intelligent. I once asked my friend Arminius at the University of Budapest to provide information about Dracula's life, and he told me everything he knew about this monstrous character. It is possible that he is the infamous leader Dracula who went down in history for crossing the river to fight the Turks right at the border with Turkey. If that is indeed the case, then he is not an ordinary person, because in that century of war, and even in many centuries thereafter, people spoke a lot about him as the most talented, boldest, and bravest son of the "land beyond the forest". His extraordinary intelligence and unshakable willpower went with him to the grave, and now, he is using them against us. According to Arminius, the Dracula family belonged to a famous noble lineage, some members of which in subsequent generations had dubious relations with the devil. They began to establish schools and preach their occult magic at Scholomance, a place in the mountains by Lake Hermannstadt, where the devil trained one out of ten disciples to become like him. There are many documents that refer to this being with names like stregoica: meaning witch; ordog: Satan; pokol: hell. And one of those documents mentioned our Count Dracula as a vampir - that is, "vampire", whose characteristics are exactly what we have come to understand so well. Dracula is the seed that created numerous other notorious male and female figures who, even in their graves, always considered this earth as the only possible dwelling place for evil...
tr: Therefore, when we learn the resting place of what was once human, if we adhere to what we know, we can imprison it in its coffin and destroy it. But it is clever. I asked my friend Arminius from the University of Budapest about its past, and he used all his resources to tell me what it was like in the past. Indeed, it must be Vlad the Impaler, Dracula, who earned his name fighting against the Turks on the great river at the border of Turkish lands. If so, then he is no ordinary person, because it was said that during those times and in the following centuries, he was the smartest, most cunning person and also the bravest of the sons of the 'land beyond the forest.' This great mind and steel-like determination went to the grave with him, and even now they stand against us. According to Arminius, the Draculas were a great and noble race, believed by their contemporaries to have dealings with the devil from time to time. They learned the secrets of the Devil at Scholomance, located among the mountains over the lake in Hermannstadt, which the tenth scholar of the devil claimed as his right. The records contain words like stregoica, meaning witch, ordog and pokol, meaning Devil and Hell, and in one of these manuscripts, Dracula is referred to as a wampyr - which we all understand very well what it means. From these seeds came great men, good women, and their graves sanctify the soil where only this evil can live. Because the fact that this evil is found at the root of all goodness is not the least terrifying aspect, it cannot find peace in the soil where sacred memories do not reside."
es: "Thus, when we find the place where that man from the past resides, we can make him remain in his coffin and destroy him, if we use all our knowledge on the matter. But he is intelligent. I asked my friend Arminius, from the University of Budapest, to give me information to establish his profile and, by all means at his disposal, he communicated what he knew to me. In fact, it must be the Voivode of Dracula who earned his nobility fighting against the Turks, over the great river that lies on the very border of Turkish lands. If so, then he was not an ordinary man; because in that time and for several centuries afterward, he was spoken of as the most intelligent and wise, as well as the bravest of the sons of the "land beyond the forests." That powerful brain and that iron resolution accompanied him to the grave and now confront us. The Draculas were, according to Arminius, a great and noble family; although, from time to time, there were offspring who, according to their contemporaries, had dealings with the evil one. They learned their secrets at the Scholomance, among the mountains above Lake Hermanstadt, where the devil claimed the tenth student as his own. In the records, there are words like..., sorcerer, and... Satan and hell; and in a manuscript, this very Dracula is spoken of as a "wampyr," which we all understand perfectly. From that family emerged many great men and women, and their graves consecrated the land where only this evil being can dwell. For it is not the least of his horrors that this evil being is rooted in all good things, but that he cannot rest in soil that has holy relics."

en: Whilst they were talking Mr. Morris was looking steadily at the window, and he now got up quietly, and went out of the room. There was a little pause, and then the Professor went on:—
vi: Although I was listening attentively, I still didn't understand why Morris kept looking out the window all this time. Finally, he quietly stood up and left the room without a word of explanation. Van Helsing was silent for a moment, then continued the story:
tr: While they were talking, Mr. Morris kept looking at the window without stopping and now he quietly got up and left the room. There was a brief silence and the Professor continued his words:
es: While the teacher was speaking, Mr. Morris was staring intently at the window and, quietly standing up, left the room. There was a brief pause and the teacher continued:

en: “And now we must settle what we do. We have here much data, and we must proceed to lay out our campaign. We know from the inquiry of Jonathan that from the castle to Whitby came fifty boxes of earth, all of which were delivered at Carfax; we also know that at least some of these boxes have been removed. It seems to me, that our first step should be to ascertain whether all the rest remain in the house beyond that wall where we look to-day; or whether any more have been removed. If the latter, we must trace——”
vi: — Now let's decide what needs to be done. Based on the data I just mentioned, we need to come up with a solution for our plan. According to Jonathan's investigation, fifty crates of earth were transported from Dracula's castle to Whitby, and all were stored in the abandoned house at Carfax, but we also know that some crates were later taken away. In my opinion, perhaps first, we should determine whether there are any crates left in that house, or if they have all been taken away. In that case, we will have to find...
tr: "And now we need to decide what to do. We have a lot of data and we must proceed by planning our battle. From Jonathan's research, we know that fifty crates of soil came from the castle to Whitby and all of them were delivered to Carfax; additionally, we know that at least a few of these crates have been moved elsewhere. It seems to me that our first step should be to find out whether the remaining crates are still in the house behind the wall we looked at today or if there are other crates that have been moved. If the second possibility has occurred, then we must track them...”
es: –Now we must decide what we are going to do. We have many data at our disposal and we must make the necessary plans for our campaign. We know from the research carried out by Jonathan that fifty boxes of earth were sent from the castle to Whitby, and that all of them must have been delivered to Carfax; we also know that at least a few of those boxes have been removed. It seems to me that our first step should be to find out if the rest of those boxes still remain in the house beyond the wall we observed today, or if others have been removed. If so, we must follow them…

en: Here we were interrupted in a very startling way. Outside the house came the sound of a pistol-shot; the glass of the window was shattered with a bullet, which, ricochetting from the top of the embrasure, struck the far wall of the room. I am afraid I am at heart a coward, for I shrieked out. The men all jumped to their feet; Lord Godalming flew over to the window and threw up the sash. As he did so we heard Mr. Morris’s voice without:—
vi: While speaking, he suddenly fell silent midway, causing everyone to be surprised. We were even more astonished when we suddenly heard a loud gunshot that made everyone jump: a bullet from an unknown source shattered the window glass, ricocheted off the window frame, and embedded itself in the far wall of the room. Surely, I am a coward, because just that made me shrink in fear, scream loudly like a madwoman. The men jumped up in panic. Lord Godalming hurried to the window to look outside. We clearly heard Morris's voice:
tr: Here, our conversation was frighteningly interrupted. A gunshot came from outside the house; the window glass shattered with a bullet that ricocheted off the top of the window frame and embedded itself in the wall at the far end of the room. I guess I am actually a coward, because I screamed. All the men jumped to their feet; Lord Godalming flew to the window and quickly raised the window glass. As he did this, we heard Mr. Morris's voice from outside:
es: At that point, we were interrupted in an astonishing way. Outside the house, the sound of a gunshot rang out; the window glass was shattered by a bullet that, deflected off the edge of the frame, crashed into the opposite side of the room. I fear that I am at heart a coward, for I shuddered deeply. All the men stood up; Lord Godalming rushed to the window and opened it. As he did so, we heard Mr. Morris say:

en: “Sorry! I fear I have alarmed you. I shall come in and tell you about it.” A minute later he came in and said:—
vi: — A thousand apologies, everyone! Perhaps I have startled you all? I will tell you right away what just happened! Later, we saw Morris hurrying back.
tr: "I'm sorry! I think I scared you. Let me come in and explain what happened." A minute later, he came in and said:
es: –I'm sorry! I think I have alarmed you. I will come up and explain everything related to my act. One minute later, he entered the room and said:

en: “It was an idiotic thing of me to do, and I ask your pardon, Mrs. Harker, most sincerely; I fear I must have frightened you terribly. But the fact is that whilst the Professor was talking there came a big bat and sat on the window-sill. I have got such a horror of the damned brutes from recent events that I cannot stand them, and I went out to have a shot, as I have been doing of late of evenings, whenever I have seen one. You used to laugh at me for it then, Art.”
vi: — I am so stupid! - He said, panting - Mrs. Harker, I sincerely apologize to you! Perhaps I have frightened you too much. But the thing is this: while the professor was engrossed in conversation, a very large bat suddenly swooped in and perched on the window ledge. After so many things had happened, I suddenly felt terrified of this filthy creature, to the point that I cannot help but shoot whenever I see them. I don't know how long this feeling has been within me. You won't mock me, will you, Arthur?
tr: “It was foolish of me to do this, and I ask for your forgiveness. Ms. Harker, I sincerely apologize, I believe I frightened you terribly. But the truth is, while the Professor was speaking, a huge bat came and sat on the window sill. After the recent events, I hate these damn animals so much that I can't stand them, and in the past few days, as I have done every night when I see a bat, I went out to shoot at it. At that time, you were mocking me for this, Art.”
es: –It was foolish of me, and I sincerely apologize, Mrs. Harker. I believe I must have frightened you quite a bit. But the fact is that while the professor was talking, a large bat landed on the window ledge. I have such a great horror of those dreadful creatures since the recent events that I can't stand them, and I went out to shoot it, as I have been doing every night whenever I see one. You used to laugh at me for it, Art.

en: “Did you hit it?” asked Dr. Van Helsing.
vi: — Did you hit the target? - Van Helsing asked.
tr: "Did you shoot it?" asked Dr. Van Helsing.
es: –Did it hurt him? – asked Dr. van Helsing.

en: “I don’t know; I fancy not, for it flew away into the wood.” Without saying any more he took his seat, and the Professor began to resume his statement:—
vi: — I'm afraid not, as it continues to fly towards the forest. Morris returned to his seat and said nothing more. Professor Van Helsing continued with what he was about to say:
tr: "I don't know, I think not, because it flew towards the forest." Without saying anything else, he sat down, and the Professor began to continue his explanations:
es: –I don't know, but I think not, since it flew away towards the forest. Without adding more, he returned to his seat, and the professor resumed his statements:

en: “We must trace each of these boxes; and when we are ready, we must either capture or kill this monster in his lair; or we must, so to speak, sterilise the earth, so that no more he can seek safety in it. Thus in the end we may find him in his form of man between the hours of noon and sunset, and so engage with him when he is at his most weak.
vi: — We will have to search each crate one by one, and when we determine where they are being sent, we will either seize them, or we will kill Dracula in one of his lairs. It could also be like this: we will neutralize the effect of the soil contained in the wooden crates, so he will no longer have a safe hiding place. We will confront him while he is still in human form from noon until sunset, meaning we will fight him when he is at his weakest...
tr: “We must track each of these crates and, when we are ready, either capture or kill this monster in its own lair; or, so to speak, cleanse the soil of germs so that it can never again seek safety in the earth. Thus, in the end, we can find it in human form between noon and sunset and fight it when it is at its weakest.
es: –We must find each and every one of those boxes, and when we are ready, we must capture or eliminate that monster or, so to speak, we must sterilize that land, so that it can no longer seek refuge there. Thus, at last, we will be able to find it in its human form, between noon and sunset, and attack it when it is at its weakest.

en: “And now for you, Madam Mina, this night is the end until all be well. You are too precious to us to have such risk. When we part to-night, you no more must question. We shall tell you all in good time. We are men and are able to bear; but you must be our star and our hope, and we shall act all the more free that you are not in the danger, such as we are.”
vi: As for you, Harker, you will not need to worry about anything from now until everything is over. To us, you are very precious, so you cannot expose yourself to the countless dangers that lie ahead. Tonight, you do not need to ask us any more questions. We promise to tell you everything at an appropriate time. We men can endure the harshest trials, but you, our lucky star and hope, must always be kept safe from all dangers.
tr: And now, Madam Mina, as for you, tonight will be your last until everything is resolved. You are too valuable to us to be put in such danger. When we part tonight, you must ask no more questions. We will tell you everything in due time. We are men and can endure; but you must be our star, our hope, and we will move more freely when you are not in danger like us.”
es: "Now, as for you, Mrs. Mina, tonight is the end, until everything goes well. You are too precious to us to take such risks. When we part tonight, you must no longer ask us questions. We will explain everything to you in due time. We are men, and we are in a position to endure it, but you must be our star and hope, and we will act with greater freedom if you are not in danger, like us."

en: All the men, even Jonathan, seemed relieved; but it did not seem to me good that they should brave danger and, perhaps, lessen their safety—strength being the best safety—through care of me; but their minds were made up, and, though it was a bitter pill for me to swallow, I could say nothing, save to accept their chivalrous care of me.
vi: So, everyone, including Jonathan, breathed a sigh of relief as if they had just shed a concern that no one had been comfortable enough to voice. However, I did not want them to exclude me from this adventure, because I thought that if we had more people, even just one more person like me, we would be stronger than without me. But in the face of their determination, I could only silently accept being left out as a guarantee of my own safety.
tr: All the men, even Jonathan, seemed relieved, but the thought of them challenging danger and perhaps reducing their safety because of me—because strength is the greatest security—did not sit well with me. However, they had made their decision, and although it was a bitter pill for me to swallow, I could say nothing other than to accept their heroic protection.
es: All the men, including Jonathan, seemed to feel relieved, but it didn't seem right to me that they had to face danger and perhaps reduce their safety, being strength the best security... just because they had to take care of me; but they were determined, and although it was a hard pill for me to swallow, I couldn't say anything. I limited myself to accepting that quixotic care of my person.

en: Mr. Morris resumed the discussion:—
vi: Having been silent until now, Morris suddenly spoke up to join the conversation:
tr: Mr. Morris returned to the discussion:
es: Mr. Morris summarized the discussion:

en: “As there is no time to lose, I vote we have a look at his house right now. Time is everything with him; and swift action on our part may save another victim.”
vi: — Perhaps we don't have much time left, I suggest we should look into what happened in the abandoned house. Once we talk about that blood-sucking demon, every minute that passes is very precious to us: acting quickly and promptly, who knows, we might prevent him from causing harm to a new victim.
tr: “Since there is no time to lose, I suggest we look at his house right now. Time is everything for him, and moving quickly might save a new victim.”
es: –Since there is no time to lose, I propose we take a look at that house right now. Time is important, and quick action on our part could save another victim.

en: I own that my heart began to fail me when the time for action came so close, but I did not say anything, for I had a greater fear that if I appeared as a drag or a hindrance to their work, they might even leave me out of their counsels altogether. They have now gone off to Carfax, with means to get into the house.
vi: To be honest, I felt completely drained when I realized that the men were about to get to work immediately, but I wasn't foolish enough to voice my fears, because if I did, I would hinder their determination and from then on, they would never let me participate in any discussions again. Now, they have gone to the abandoned Carfax house with everything they might need to break in.
tr: I confess that my heart started to fail me as the time for action drew so near, but I said nothing because I feared that if I appeared as a hindrance or obstacle to their work, they might exclude me from all their discussions. Now, they have gone to Carfax with the intention of entering the house.
es: I felt my heart failing me when I saw that the moment to take action was approaching, but I said nothing because I was afraid that if I seemed to be a hindrance or a burden to their work, they might even exclude me from their counsel. Now they have gone to Carfax, which means they are going to enter the house.

en: Manlike, they had told me to go to bed and sleep; as if a woman can sleep when those she loves are in danger! I shall lie down and pretend to sleep, lest Jonathan have added anxiety about me when he returns.
vi: Men are truly different! They told me to go to sleep immediately and not to think about anything at all. They act as if a woman can just fall asleep when the people she loves are facing danger! Alright, I will go lie down and pretend to sleep so that when he returns, Jonathan won't have anything to worry about or be concerned with regarding me.
tr: In a manly manner, they told me to lie down and sleep; as if a woman whose loved ones are in danger could sleep! When Jonathan returns, I will lie down and pretend to be asleep so that he doesn't add new worries about me to his concerns.
es: In a very manly manner, I have been told to lie down and sleep, as if a woman could sleep when the people she loves are in danger. I have to lie down and pretend to sleep, so that Jonathan doesn't feel more anxiety about me when he returns.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 1 October, 4 a. m.—Just as we were about to leave the house, an urgent message was brought to me from Renfield to know if I would see him at once, as he had something of the utmost importance to say to me. I told the messenger to say that I would attend to his wishes in the morning; I was busy just at the moment. The attendant added:—
vi: • October 1, 4 AM As soon as we poked our heads out the door, we ran into the warden coming towards us. He asked—again about Renfield—if I could go see him right now because he said he had something very important to tell me. I replied that I was very busy tonight and would meet him early tomorrow. — But this time he seems more impatient than ever, sir. -
tr: October 1, 4 AM. - Just as I was about to leave the house, I received an urgent message from Renfield asking if I could see him as soon as possible because he had something extremely important to tell me. I told the messenger to inform him that I would attend to his request in the morning and that I was currently busy. The nurse added:
es: October 1st, at four in the morning. At the moment we were about to leave the house, I received a message from Renfield, begging me to see him immediately, as he had something of the utmost importance to communicate to me. I told the messenger to inform him that I would fulfill his wishes in the morning; that I was busy at the moment. The nurse added:

en: “He seems very importunate, sir. I have never seen him so eager. I don’t know but what, if you don’t see him soon, he will have one of his violent fits.” I knew the man would not have said this without some cause, so I said: “All right; I’ll go now”; and I asked the others to wait a few minutes for me, as I had to go and see my “patient.”
vi: The warden pleaded. - Although I really wish it weren't so, I still have the feeling that if you don't go see him immediately, he's going to have the most violent outburst we've ever seen. Believing him, I told my friends to wait a few minutes while I went to meet him.
tr: “He seems very insistent, sir. I have never seen him so impatient before. I don't know, but if you don't see him soon, he might have one of his severe fits.” I knew the man wouldn't say this without a reason, so I said, “Alright, I'll go now,” and asked the others to wait for me for a few minutes as I needed to go see my “patient.”
es: –You seem very uneasy, sir. I've never seen you so anxious. I think that if you don't go to see him soon, he might have one of his violent outbursts. I knew that the nurse wouldn't tell me that without having a justified cause for it, and therefore, I said to him: –Very well, I will go see him right now. And I asked the others to wait for me a few minutes, since I had to go visit my "patient".

en: “Take me with you, friend John,” said the Professor. “His case in your diary interest me much, and it had bearing, too, now and again on our case. I should much like to see him, and especial when his mind is disturbed.”
vi: — I want to go with you, John. - Van Helsing said. - Your diary shows me that this patient is quite interesting, sometimes he is also related to our case. I really want to visit this guy when he is about to have an episode.
tr: "Take me with you, my friend John," said the Professor. "The case in your diary caught my interest and it has occasionally been related to our case as well. I would very much like to see him, especially when he is mentally unstable."
es: –Take me with you, friend John -said the professor-. Your case, which is in your diary, interests me a lot and has also occasionally been related to our case. I would very much like to see it, especially when your mind is in a bad state.

en: “May I come also?” asked Lord Godalming.
vi: — May I come along? - Lord Godalming asked.
tr: "Can I come too?" asked Lord Godalming.
es: –May I accompany you as well? – asked Lord Godalming.

en: “Me too?” said Quincey Morris. “May I come?” said Harker. I nodded, and we all went down the passage together.
vi: — What about me? - It's Quincey Morris's turn. — Me too? - Finally, it was Jonathan Harker. I nodded and said that everyone could go together.
tr: “What about me?” said Quincey Morris. I nodded and we all went down the corridor together.
es: –Me too? – inquired Mr. Morris. Can I join you? –Can I go with you? – Harker wanted to know. I nodded, and we all moved forward together down the hallway.

en: We found him in a state of considerable excitement, but far more rational in his speech and manner than I had ever seen him. There was an unusual understanding of himself, which was unlike anything I had ever met with in a lunatic; and he took it for granted that his reasons would prevail with others entirely sane. We all four went into the room, but none of the others at first said anything. His request was that I would at once release him from the asylum and send him home. This he backed up with arguments regarding his complete recovery, and adduced his own existing sanity. “I appeal to your friends,” he said, “they will, perhaps, not mind sitting in judgment on my case. By the way, you have not introduced me.” I was so much astonished, that the oddness of introducing a madman in an asylum did not strike me at the moment; and, besides, there was a certain dignity in the man’s manner, so much of the habit of equality, that I at once made the introduction: “Lord Godalming; Professor Van Helsing; Mr. Quincey Morris, of Texas; Mr. Renfield.” He shook hands with each of them, saying in turn:—
vi: Indeed, Renfield was very agitated, but I had never seen him so clear-headed and calm in his manner of speaking to me. This time, I had the opportunity to witness another manifestation in his case, one that I had never encountered in any other patient before. He believed that the reasons he presented could not be opposed by us. What made him urgently want to see me was to ask for permission to be discharged and go home. He claimed that he was now completely recovered and no longer had the slightest mental disorder. "I will talk to your friends," he said, "who knows, they might have a good assessment of my current state. By the way, you haven't introduced me to them yet...” I was so stunned that I forgot that introducing others to an inmate in my asylum was not a very usual thing to do, but honestly, at this moment, Renfield had something about him that deserved to be treated with the social courtesies of everyday life. So I had no hesitation in introducing those present to each other: "Mr. Renfield... Lord Godalming, Professor Van Helsing, Mr. Quincey Morris from Texas, USA, Mr. Jonathan Harker." He shook hands and talked with each person.
tr: We found him in great excitement, but his speech and demeanor were more rational than I had ever seen before. He had an extraordinary insight unlike anything I had encountered in a mentally ill person before, and he seemed confident that he could outthink others who were entirely sane. The four of us entered the room at once, but at first, the others said nothing. What he wanted from me was to discharge him from the mental hospital immediately and send him home. He supported this with arguments that he was completely cured and presented his current sanity as evidence. “I appeal to your friends,” he said; “perhaps they will not hesitate to judge my case. In the meantime, you have not introduced us.” I was so surprised that the oddity of introducing an inmate of a mental hospital did not occur to me at that moment; moreover, there was a kind of dignity in the man's manner, as if he were equal to the others, and so I immediately performed the introductions: “Lord Godalming; Professor Van Helsing; Mr. Quincey Morris from Texas; Mr. Renfield.” He shook hands with each and said: “Lord Godalming, I had the honor of testifying for your father in Windham, and I am saddened to understand from your holding the title that he is no longer alive.
es: We found him in a state of considerable excitement, but much more reasonable in his way of speaking and his manners than I had ever seen him before. He had an unusual understanding of himself, which went beyond anything I had encountered so far in lunatics, and he took it for granted that his reasoning would prevail with other sane people. The five of us entered the room, but, at first, none of the others said anything. His request was to be let out of the asylum immediately and to be sent home. He supported his plea with arguments related to his complete recovery, and cited his own sanity at that moment as an example. –I make an appeal to your friends -he said-. It is possible that they would not mind sitting down to examine my case. By the way, you have not introduced me to them. I was so astonished that the act of introducing other people to a madman confined in an asylum did not seem strange to me at that moment. Moreover, there was a certain dignity in the man's manners, which revealed such a habit of considering himself as an equal, that I made the introductions immediately. –Lord Godalming, Professor Van Helsing, Mr. Quincey Morris from Texas, Mr. Jonathan Harker, and Mr. Renfield. He shook hands with all of them, saying as he did so:

en: “Lord Godalming, I had the honour of seconding your father at the Windham; I grieve to know, by your holding the title, that he is no more. He was a man loved and honoured by all who knew him; and in his youth was, I have heard, the inventor of a burnt rum punch, much patronised on Derby night. Mr. Morris, you should be proud of your great state. Its reception into the Union was a precedent which may have far-reaching effects hereafter, when the Pole and the Tropics may hold alliance to the Stars and Stripes. The power of Treaty may yet prove a vast engine of enlargement, when the Monroe doctrine takes its true place as a political fable. What shall any man say of his pleasure at meeting Van Helsing? Sir, I make no apology for dropping all forms of conventional prefix. When an individual has revolutionised therapeutics by his discovery of the continuous evolution of brain-matter, conventional forms are unfitting, since they would seem to limit him to one of a class. You, gentlemen, who by nationality, by heredity, or by the possession of natural gifts, are fitted to hold your respective places in the moving world, I take to witness that I am as sane as at least the majority of men who are in full possession of their liberties. And I am sure that you, Dr. Seward, humanitarian and medico-jurist as well as scientist, will deem it a moral duty to deal with me as one to be considered as under exceptional circumstances.” He made this last appeal with a courtly air of conviction which was not without its own charm.
vi: — Lord Godalming, in Windham, I had the honor of assisting your father, and I am deeply sorry that he is no longer with us, now you bear his title. He was always respected and loved by everyone who knew him. I heard that in his youth, he invented a type of punch that was very popular among connoisseurs in Derby. Mr. Morris, you have many reasons to be proud of your great state. The annexation of Texas into the Union set a precedent, resulting in significant outcomes, as other states also wish to join under the Star-Spangled Banner. One can easily recognize the strength of the Union Treaty when the Monroe Doctrine gains a real foothold as a political agreement. How can I express my honor in meeting Professor Van Helsing? It is truly remiss of me not to have inquired about you with the usual courtesies. When someone revolutionizes diagnostic methods through discoveries about the continuous development of the human brain, all ordinary forms of politeness are altered, for if such courtesies were applied to oneself, it might seem as though one wishes to diminish the positions of others. All of you here, either by nationality, inheritance, or by nature's own favor, hold a place in our wildly spinning world. Let me give an example: I am as physically and mentally sound as the vast majority of those who are entirely free out there. Dr. Seward, I absolutely believe that as a very kind scholar, who has studied law as well as practiced medicine, you will understand that thoroughly re-examining my case is a moral duty of yours. Speaking the last sentences, he tried to put on an act, showing himself to be very confident and no less polite towards me.
tr: He shook hands with each and said: “Lord Godalming, I had the honor of testifying for your father in Windham, and I am saddened to understand from your holding the title that he is no longer alive. He was a man loved and respected by all who knew him, and as I have heard, he was the creator of the much sought-after burnt rum punch on Derby night in his youth. Mr. Morris, you must be proud of your great state. The admission of your state to the union will serve as a significant example when the Polar and Tropical Regions are also bound to the United States Flag. When the Monroe Doctrine takes its rightful place among political truths, the Treaty will prove to be a very broad instrument of growth. What can one say about the happiness of meeting Van Helsing? Sir, I do not apologize for not using traditional prefixes. When an individual revolutionizes the science of treatment by discovering the constant evolution of the brain, traditional forms become inappropriate, as they seem to limit that person to being a member of a certain class. I want to testify that I am at least as sane as the majority of those who, like you gentlemen, are fully entitled to the freedoms of holding respectable positions in a dynamic world due to your nationality, hereditary traits, or natural talents. And I am sure that, besides being a scientist, you, Dr. Seward, who is also a humane person and a forensic expert, will consider it a moral duty to treat me as someone under special circumstances. He fulfilled his last request with a subtle air of faith that was not devoid of his unique charm.
es: –Lord Godalming, I had the honor of serving under your father in the Windham; I am sorry to know, by the fact that you hold the title, that he is no longer with us. He was a man loved and respected by all who knew him, and I have heard it said that in his youth he was the inventor of the rum punch that is so appreciated on Derby night. “Mr. Morris, you must be proud of your great state. Your reception into the Union can be a far-reaching event that may have repercussions in the future, when the Poles and the Tropics can form an alliance with the Stars and Stripes. The power of the Treaty may still become an engine of expansion, when the Monroe Doctrine takes its rightful place as a political fable. What can any man say about the pleasure he feels upon meeting van Helsing? Sir, I do not apologize for abandoning all forms of traditional prejudice. When an individual has revolutionized therapeutics by his discovery of the continuous evolution of cerebral matter, traditional forms are not appropriate, as they would give the impression of limiting him to a specific class. To you, gentlemen, who by nationality, heritage, or natural gifts, are destined to occupy your respective places in the moving world, I take you as witnesses that I am as sane as, at least, the majority of men who are in full possession of their freedom. And I am sure that you, Dr. Seward, humanist and forensic physician, as well as scientist, will consider it a moral duty to treat me as someone who must be considered under exceptional circumstances.” He made this final plea with an air of conviction that did not lack its own charm.

en: I think we were all staggered. For my own part, I was under the conviction, despite my knowledge of the man’s character and history, that his reason had been restored; and I felt under a strong impulse to tell him that I was satisfied as to his sanity, and would see about the necessary formalities for his release in the morning. I thought it better to wait, however, before making so grave a statement, for of old I knew the sudden changes to which this particular patient was liable. So I contented myself with making a general statement that he appeared to be improving very rapidly; that I would have a longer chat with him in the morning, and would then see what I could do in the direction of meeting his wishes. This did not at all satisfy him, for he said quickly:—
vi: I think that even though my friends have never had a chance to interact with Renfield like I have, they are also very surprised. As for myself, despite knowing about the stages of his illness, I still believe that he is clearly trying to justify his intentions. Honestly, I just want to tell him that his condition has indeed made good progress and I will complete all the procedures so that he can be discharged tomorrow morning. But recalling his sudden and erratic changes, I want to do the opposite, I want to advise him to think carefully before making such an important decision. Therefore, I have to tell him that his condition is improving day by day, and I will talk to him more tomorrow morning, after which I will make a specific decision regarding his request. He seemed dissatisfied with my answer, as I saw him retort immediately:
tr: I think we were all taken aback. For my part, despite my knowledge of the man's personality and history, I was of the opinion that he had come to his senses and felt a strong urge to say that I was convinced he was in his right mind and that I would handle the necessary discharge procedures in the morning. But I thought it would be better to wait before making such a serious statement, because from the past, I knew the sudden changes this patient was prone to. Therefore, I contented myself with making a general statement that he was making rapid progress and said that I would have a longer conversation with him in the morning and then see what I could do to fulfill his wishes. This did not satisfy him at all, because he immediately said:
es: I think we were all astonished. For my part, I was convinced, despite knowing the man's character and history, that he had regained his sanity, and I felt compelled to tell him that I was satisfied regarding his sanity and that I would do everything necessary to release him from the asylum the next day. However, I thought it preferable to wait before making such a serious statement, since I had long been aware of the sudden changes that this particular patient experienced. Thus, I contented myself with making a statement to the effect that he seemed to be healing very quickly; that I would have a long conversation with him in the morning, and that I would then decide what could be done to satisfy his wishes. That did not satisfy him at all, as he hastened to say:

en: “But I fear, Dr. Seward, that you hardly apprehend my wish. I desire to go at once—here—now—this very hour—this very moment, if I may. Time presses, and in our implied agreement with the old scytheman it is of the essence of the contract. I am sure it is only necessary to put before so admirable a practitioner as Dr. Seward so simple, yet so momentous a wish, to ensure its fulfilment.” He looked at me keenly, and seeing the negative in my face, turned to the others, and scrutinised them closely. Not meeting any sufficient response, he went on:—
vi: — But doctor, I'm afraid you still don't understand me. What I want is to go home immediately, right now... right this moment, as I'm speaking, if possible. Time is very urgent, and time is the most crucial factor in our implicit agreement with Death. I think it would be best if you go ahead and do what you just mentioned. He stared at me intently as if waiting, seeing that I showed no sign of agreement, he turned to plead with someone else. Not receiving any answer, even just a nod, he pressed on:
tr: “But I am afraid, Dr. Seward, that you did not understand my wish very well. I wish to leave as soon as possible - right now - at this very moment, if possible. Time is running out, and this is the essence of the contract in our implicit agreement with the old reaper. I am sure that presenting such a simple, yet at the same time so important, wish to a good doctor like Dr. Seward ensures that it will be fulfilled.” He looked at me sternly, and upon seeing the negative expression on my face, he turned to the others and examined them carefully. Not finding a sufficient response, he continued:
es: –But, I fear, Dr. Seward, that you have not understood what my desire is. I wish to leave now… Immediately…, at this very moment…, without waiting another minute, if possible. Time is pressing, and in our implicit agreement with the old Scythian, that is the essence of the contract. I am sure that it is enough to communicate to such an admirable doctor as Dr. Seward a desire so simple yet so impulsive, to ensure that it is fulfilled. He looked at me intelligently and, seeing the refusal on my face, turned to the others and examined them closely. Not finding a sufficiently favorable reaction, he continued saying:

en: “Is it possible that I have erred in my supposition?”
vi: — Could I have been mistaken with my assumptions?
tr: “Is it possible that I was wrong in my assumption?”
es: –Is it possible that I was mistaken in my assumption?

en: “You have,” I said frankly, but at the same time, as I felt, brutally. There was a considerable pause, and then he said slowly:—
vi: — That's right, you were wrong, and very wrong at that. - I replied bluntly. He remained silent for a long time, then leisurely continued:
tr: “Yes,” I said plainly, but at the same time, I felt like a savage. There was a considerable silence, and then he slowly said:
es: –That's right, I told him frankly, but at the same time, as I immediately realized, with brutality. There was a rather long pause, and then he said slowly:

en: “Then I suppose I must only shift my ground of request. Let me ask for this concession—boon, privilege, what you will. I am content to implore in such a case, not on personal grounds, but for the sake of others. I am not at liberty to give you the whole of my reasons; but you may, I assure you, take it from me that they are good ones, sound and unselfish, and spring from the highest sense of duty. Could you look, sir, into my heart, you would approve to the full the sentiments which animate me. Nay, more, you would count me amongst the best and truest of your friends.” Again he looked at us all keenly. I had a growing conviction that this sudden change of his entire intellectual method was but yet another form or phase of his madness, and so determined to let him go on a little longer, knowing from experience that he would, like all lunatics, give himself away in the end. Van Helsing was gazing at him with a look of utmost intensity, his bushy eyebrows almost meeting with the fixed concentration of his look. He said to Renfield in a tone which did not surprise me at the time, but only when I thought of it afterwards—for it was as of one addressing an equal:—
vi: — If that's the case, then perhaps I must make another request of you. This time, I would like to ask everyone to make a concession for me, to grant me a favor or a priority, as you would put it. This time, I beg you not for my own personal motives, but for the happiness of others. I don't have much time to explain to you all the reasons that compel me to implore you, but please believe that they are valid, undeniable reasons, and completely devoid of any personal gain. I am inspired by the noble meaning of the duty that I feel I must fulfill. Doctor, if you could read the thoughts from the bottom of my heart, you would surely fully support the sentiments driving me. And you might even consider me one of your closest and most loyal friends. Finishing his words, he once again cast a scrutinizing glance at all of us. At this moment, I began to suspect that his sudden change in behavior was merely another form, or more precisely, another phase of his madness. And I told myself that I needed to wait and see what would happen, because with the many years of experience I had accumulated with madmen, I understood that his illness was about to relapse. I didn't understand what Van Helsing was thinking, because from earlier until now he had been frowning while observing him from head to toe. Suddenly, he asked him in a tone that, at first, I found unremarkable, but later, upon reflection, I sensed something peculiar. Clearly, he was regarding him as a completely sane person rather than a mental patient:
tr: “Then I must only change the basis of my request. Let me ask you for this privilege -kindness, favor, whatever you call it. In such a case, I am willing to plead not for personal reasons, but for the good of others. I am not free to present all my reasons to you, but I assure you, you can believe that they are good, rational, and selfless reasons, and that they stem from the highest sense of duty. If you could look into my heart, sir, you would approve of all the feelings that drive me. Moreover, you would count me among your best and truest friends.” He looked at us again with piercing eyes. I had begun to believe that this sudden change in his entire mental approach was another form or phase of his madness; therefore, from past experiences, knowing that like all madmen he would eventually reveal himself, I decided to let him continue speaking a little longer. Van Helsing was looking at him with great attention; his brush-like eyebrows almost merging with the intensity of his gaze. In a tone that did not surprise me at the time, but later did when I thought about it -because it was as if he was addressing an equal- he said to Renfield:
es: –Then, I suppose I will have to change only the way I have formulated my request. Let me beg you for that concession..., gift, privilege, whatever you want to call it. In such a case, I am happy to implore, not for personal reasons, but for the love of others. I am not at liberty to provide you with all my reasons, but you can, I assure you, take my word that they are good, sound, and unselfish, and that they stem from a high sense of duty. If you could look into my heart, sir, you would wholeheartedly approve of the feelings that motivate me. Furthermore, you would count me among your best and most sincere friends. He looked at us anxiously again. I was increasingly convinced that his sudden change in intellectual method was merely another form or phase of his madness and, therefore, I decided to let him talk a little more, knowing from experience that, in the end, like all lunatics, he would reveal himself. Van Helsing was observing him with a look of extraordinary intensity, his bushy eyebrows almost touching each other due to the fixed concentration of his gaze. He spoke to Renfield in a tone that did not surprise me at the moment, but did when I thought about it later... since it was that of someone addressing an equal:

en: “Can you not tell frankly your real reason for wishing to be free to-night? I will undertake that if you will satisfy even me—a stranger, without prejudice, and with the habit of keeping an open mind—Dr. Seward will give you, at his own risk and on his own responsibility, the privilege you seek.” He shook his head sadly, and with a look of poignant regret on his face. The Professor went on:—
vi: — Can you not explain to us why you want to leave here tonight? I am sure that you are not hiding anything from me. I say that I, a foreigner who always tries to understand everything and has no prejudice against you: then surely Dr. Seward will be responsible for letting you out of the hospital. He shook his head sadly. Seeing his expression, I knew he was regretting something. The professor, not showing any concern for his despondency, continued speaking:
tr: “Won't you honestly tell me the real reason you want to be free tonight? If you can satisfy even me -a stranger with a habit of being unbiased and open-minded- I promise that Dr. Seward will take the risk and responsibility upon himself and grant you the privilege you seek.” Renfield shook his head sorrowfully with a sad expression on his face. The professor continued his words:
es: –Can you not frankly tell us what your reasons are for wanting to leave the asylum tonight? I am sure that if you wish to satisfy even me, who am an unprejudiced foreigner and accustomed to accepting all kinds of ideas, Dr. Seward will grant you, under his responsibility, the privilege you desire. Renfield shook his head sadly and with an expression of immense feeling. The professor continued saying:

en: “Come, sir, bethink yourself. You claim the privilege of reason in the highest degree, since you seek to impress us with your complete reasonableness. You do this, whose sanity we have reason to doubt, since you are not yet released from medical treatment for this very defect. If you will not help us in our effort to choose the wisest course, how can we perform the duty which you yourself put upon us? Be wise, and help us; and if we can we shall aid you to achieve your wish.” He still shook his head as he said:—
vi: — So, my friend? Just think it over carefully. You say that you have recovered, you want to prove to us that your mind has returned to normal, but we still have doubts because you haven't done anything to prove it. If you don't help us in this test, how can Dr. Seward agree with you? Once again, I advise you to think very carefully, help us, trust me, my friend, I truly wish for you to be free! — Doctor Van Helsing, - He shook his head and replied - I can't say anything.
tr: "Come on, sir, think of yourself. Since you are trying to impress us with your entirely rational attitude, you are claiming the privilege of being the most rational. By doing this, you are the one we have reason to doubt your sanity because you have not yet emerged from the medical treatment process for this defect. If you do not help us in our effort to choose the wisest path, how can we fulfill the task you have assigned to us? Be smart and help us; we, in turn, will help you achieve your wish if we can." But Renfield shook his head again and said:
es: –Come on, my good sir, think it over carefully. You claim to enjoy the privilege of reason in its highest degree, since you try to impress us with your capacity for reasoning. You are doing something whose sanity we have the right to doubt, because you have not yet been discharged from medical treatment due to a mental defect precisely. If you do not help us choose the most reasonable option, how do you expect us to carry out the duties you yourself have assigned to us? It would be convenient for you to help us, and if we can, we will help you so that your wishes are fulfilled. Renfield shook his head again and said:

en: “Dr. Van Helsing, I have nothing to say. Your argument is complete, and if I were free to speak I should not hesitate a moment; but I am not my own master in the matter. I can only ask you to trust me. If I am refused, the responsibility does not rest with me.” I thought it was now time to end the scene, which was becoming too comically grave, so I went towards the door, simply saying:—
vi: — Doctor Van Helsing, - He shook his head and replied - I can't say anything. Your argument is indeed irrefutable, if it were just for me, I certainly wouldn't hesitate to tell you, but because I am not the only one involved in this matter. I can only ask you to trust me. If you don't let me leave here, then please inform Doctor Seward that I will not take any responsibility for what might happen. Seeing that it was time to end the pointless conversation, I stepped outside the door and called back:
tr: "Dr. Van Helsing, I have nothing to say. Your argument is complete, and if I had the freedom to speak, I wouldn't hesitate for a moment, but in this matter, I am not my own master. All I can do is ask you to trust me. If I am refused, the responsibility is not mine." I thought it was time to end this scene, which was becoming absurdly serious; so as I walked towards the door, I said:
es: –Doctor van Helsing, I have nothing to say. Your argument is complete, and if I had the freedom to speak, I would not hesitate for a single moment to do so, but it is not for me to decide in this matter. The only thing I can do is ask you to trust me. If you deny me that trust, the responsibility will not be mine. I thought it was time to put an end to that scene, which was becoming too comically serious. Consequently, I headed towards the door, while saying:

en: “Come, my friends, we have work to do. Good-night.”
vi: — Come on, everyone, let's get to work. Goodbye, Renfield!
tr: “Come, my friends, we have work to do. Good night.”
es: –Let's go, my friends. We have many things to do. Good night!

en: As, however, I got near the door, a new change came over the patient. He moved towards me so quickly that for the moment I feared that he was about to make another homicidal attack. My fears, however, were groundless, for he held up his two hands imploringly, and made his petition in a moving manner. As he saw that the very excess of his emotion was militating against him, by restoring us more to our old relations, he became still more demonstrative. I glanced at Van Helsing, and saw my conviction reflected in his eyes; so I became a little more fixed in my manner, if not more stern, and motioned to him that his efforts were unavailing. I had previously seen something of the same constantly growing excitement in him when he had to make some request of which at the time he had thought much, such, for instance, as when he wanted a cat; and I was prepared to see the collapse into the same sullen acquiescence on this occasion. My expectation was not realised, for, when he found that his appeal would not be successful, he got into quite a frantic condition. He threw himself on his knees, and held up his hands, wringing them in plaintive supplication, and poured forth a torrent of entreaty, with the tears rolling down his cheeks, and his whole face and form expressive of the deepest emotion:—
vi: However, just as I was about to open the door, the patient's demeanor suddenly changed. He rushed towards me, causing me to cry out in alarm, thinking he intended to kill me again. But I was mistaken; he merely extended both hands, urgently repeating his request to me. Although it seemed he understood that such pleading was a bit excessive, he became increasingly desperate and earnest. Yet, I still firmly refused his request, pushing him back and telling him not to waste his time. This wasn't the first time I had seen him humble himself to the utmost when he wanted to immediately obtain a favor he deemed crucial, such as the day he begged me to bring him a cat. Just like that day, I thought he would eventually accept my refusal, despite his seemingly indifferent attitude. But this time, he did not. Seeing that his requests to me were in vain, he began to go mad. He knelt down on the ground, raised his hands before me, and bowed repeatedly, hoping to appeal to my compassion. Tears streaming down his face, his expression utterly miserable, he continued his lengthy speech to me.
tr: But as I approached the door, there was a new change in the patient. He came at me with such speed that I feared, at that moment, he would attempt murder again. But my fears were unfounded, because he extended both hands in supplication and demonstrated his plea through action. When he saw that the intensity of his emotions, by rekindling our past relations, was working against him, he became even more emotional. I looked at Van Helsing and saw my view reflected in his eyes; therefore, in my demeanor, I became a bit more resolute, if not more stubborn, and indicated that his efforts were in vain. I had previously seen the same, ever-growing excitement when he was about to make a request he had long pondered, as when he wanted a cat; this time, I was ready to see the same gloomy acceptance. My expectation did not come true, because when he realized his plea would not succeed, he went mad. He threw himself on his knees, raised his hands in a tearful plea, tears streaming down his cheeks, and his entire face and body expressing his deepest emotions, he poured out a torrent of supplication:
es: However, when I approached the door, a new change occurred in the patient. He came towards me so quickly that, for a moment, I feared he was about to carry out another homicidal attack. However, my fears were unfounded, as he extended both hands in a pleading manner and made his request in an emotional tone. Seeing that the very excess of his emotion worked against him, making us revert to our old ideas, he became even more demonstrative. I looked at Van Helsing and saw my conviction reflected in his eyes; consequently, I became even more convinced of the correctness of my attitude and made a gesture that clearly meant his efforts were in vain. I had previously seen part of the same emotion that was constantly growing when he directed some request at me that, at those moments, meant a lot to him, such as, for example, when he wanted a cat; and I expected to witness the collapse into the same sullen acquiescence on this occasion. What I expected did not happen, since, when he realized that his plea was in vain, he became quite frantic. He dropped to his knees and raised his hands together, remaining in that posture, in painful supplication, and repeated his plea insistently, while tears rolled down his cheeks, and both his face and body expressed intense emotion.

en: “Let me entreat you, Dr. Seward, oh, let me implore you, to let me out of this house at once. Send me away how you will and where you will; send keepers with me with whips and chains; let them take me in a strait-waistcoat, manacled and leg-ironed, even to a gaol; but let me go out of this. You don’t know what you do by keeping me here. I am speaking from the depths of my heart—of my very soul. You don’t know whom you wrong, or how; and I may not tell. Woe is me! I may not tell. By all you hold sacred—by all you hold dear—by your love that is lost—by your hope that lives—for the sake of the Almighty, take me out of this and save my soul from guilt! Can’t you hear me, man? Can’t you understand? Will you never learn? Don’t you know that I am sane and earnest now; that I am no lunatic in a mad fit, but a sane man fighting for his soul? Oh, hear me! hear me! Let me go! let me go! let me go!”
vi: — Please, Dr. Seward, I beg you! Allow me to leave this house right now! I don't care about the manner of the send-off! You can have guards with whips and chains follow me; they can put me in a straitjacket, handcuff me, shackle my feet, collar my neck... But for the love of God, let me out of here! If you force me to stay in this asylum, you will be deliberately ignoring a cruelty, and for what reason? Please believe that my words come from the depths of my heart! Have mercy on this wretched soul! For everything that is sacred and dear to you in this world, for the love you have lost, for the hope that still lingers in your heart, and for the Almighty God, let me out of here and save my sinful soul! Are you listening to me, Doctor? Do you understand what I'm saying? Can you not see my physical and mental recovery? Do you think I'm not speaking seriously? I am not a madman in a fit of insanity, but a rational person; who will save my soul? Let me go! Let me go!
tr: “I beg you, Dr. Seward, to get me out of here as soon as possible, I implore you. Send me away however and wherever you can; send me with guards armed with whips and chains; put me in a straitjacket, handcuff me, even shackle me in a prison, but let me get out of here. You don't know what you're doing by keeping me here. I am speaking from the depths of my heart -from the very depths of my soul. You don't know whom or how you are harming, and I cannot explain it to you. Alas, what a pity! I cannot explain. In the name of everything you hold sacred -in the name of everything you love- in the name of the love you have lost -in the name of the hope that still lives- for the love of God, get me out of here and save my soul from guilt! Can't you hear me, man? Don't you understand? Will you never learn? Don't you understand that I am now sane and sincere, that I am no longer a madman having a fit of insanity, that I am a sane man fighting for his soul? Oh, listen to me! Listen to me! Let me go! Let me go! Let me go!”
es: –Allow me to beg you, Dr. Seward; let me implore you to let me leave this house immediately. Command me as you wish and wherever you wish; send guards with me, with whips and chains; let them take me in a straitjacket, handcuffed and with my legs shackled, even to jail, but let me leave here. You do not know what you are doing by keeping me here. I am speaking to you from the bottom of my heart... with all my soul. You do not know whom you are harming, nor how, and I cannot tell you. Woe is me! I cannot say it. For all that is sacred to you, for all that is dear to you; for your lost love, for your hope that she lives, for the love of the Almighty, take me out of here and prevent my soul from feeling guilty. Do you not hear me, doctor? Do you not understand that I am sane, and that I am telling you the truth now, that I am not a lunatic in a moment of madness, but a sane man fighting for the salvation of his soul? Oh, listen to me! Let me leave here! Let me! Let me!

en: I thought that the longer this went on the wilder he would get, and so would bring on a fit; so I took him by the hand and raised him up.
vi: I think that the longer this scene drags on, the more likely he is to become agitated, and if so, he might actually go crazy.
tr: As this situation dragged on, I thought he would become even more savage and thus cause a fit, so I took his hand and helped him up.
es: I thought that the longer it all lasted, the angrier he would become and that, thus, he would have another fit of madness. Therefore, I took him by the hand and made him get up.

en: “Come,” I said sternly, “no more of this; we have had quite enough already. Get to your bed and try to behave more discreetly.”
vi: — Come on, stop it! - I said seriously. - That's enough! Go lie down on the bed to calm yourself down?
tr: "Come," I said sternly, "this is enough, we've listened enough now. Go to your bed and try to behave more sensibly."
es: –Let's go, I told him firmly. Do not continue that scene; we have witnessed it enough already. Go to your bed and try to behave more discreetly!

en: He suddenly stopped and looked at me intently for several moments. Then, without a word, he rose and moving over, sat down on the side of the bed. The collapse had come, as on former occasion, just as I had expected.
vi: He helplessly stared at me. Then, without a word, he sullenly stood up and went to sit on the bed. Waiting for my friends to go out first, I stood and looked at him once more before leaving.
tr: Suddenly, he fell silent and looked at me attentively for a few seconds. Then, without saying a word, he stood up and walked over to sit on the edge of the bed. Just as I expected, he collapsed as he had in previous instances.
es: Suddenly, he fell silent and stared at me intently for a moment. Then, without uttering a single word, he turned and sat on the edge of the bed. The collapse had occurred, as on previous occasions, just as I had expected.

en: When I was leaving the room, last of our party, he said to me in a quiet, well-bred voice:—
vi: Before he was out of sight, I heard him say something after me, his voice very calm and no less polite:
tr: Ben, as he left the room from the very back of our group, said in a quiet and noble voice:
es: When I was about to leave the room, the last of the group, he said to me in a calm and well-controlled voice:

en: “You will, I trust, Dr. Seward, do me the justice to bear in mind, later on, that I did what I could to convince you to-night.”
vi: — Dr. Seward, I hope you will never forget that tonight I did everything I could to persuade you!
tr: "I hope, Dr. Seward, that later on, you will show the fairness to remember that I did my best to convince you tonight.""
es: I hope, Dr. Seward, considering what may happen later, that I have done everything possible to convince you tonight.

en: CHAPTER XIX
vi: CHAPTER 19
tr: Nineteen
es: XIX.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: 1 October, 5 a. m.—I went with the party to the search with an easy mind, for I think I never saw Mina so absolutely strong and well. I am so glad that she consented to hold back and let us men do the work. Somehow, it was a dread to me that she was in this fearful business at all; but now that her work is done, and that it is due to her energy and brains and foresight that the whole story is put together in such a way that every point tells, she may well feel that her part is finished, and that she can henceforth leave the rest to us. We were, I think, all a little upset by the scene with Mr. Renfield. When we came away from his room we were silent till we got back to the study. Then Mr. Morris said to Dr. Seward:—
vi: • October 1, 5 AM I, along with everyone else, went to Carfax House in a very relaxed state of mind, as I had never seen Mina so healthy and confident. If she were to directly participate in our work, she would likely find it hard to avoid nightmares, but fortunately, she now agrees to let us act on our own, so I am somewhat relieved. Moreover, I hope she is thinking that she has already done what needed to be done: all the smallest details have been gathered, and if they are useful to us, isn't it thanks to her effort and intelligence? I believe that all of us were haunted after visiting Renfield. From the moment we left his room, none of us spoke a word to each other. It was only when we returned to Seward's office that I heard Morris speak:
tr: October 1st, 5 AM. - I joined the search with the group with peace of mind, because I think I have never seen Mina so strong and well before. I am very pleased that she agreed to stay behind and let us men do the work. For some reason, it was horrifying for me to have her involved in this dreadful task, but now that her duty is over and thanks to her energy, intellect, and foresight, the whole story has been brought together in a way that every point is explained, she can understand that her role is over and she can now leave the remaining work to us. I think we were all shaken up because of the scene we experienced with Mr. Renfield. When we left his room, we didn't speak until we returned to the study. Then Mr. Morris said to Dr. Seward: “Tell me Jack, if that man wasn't bluffing, he is almost the sanest madman I've ever seen until today.
es: October 1st, at five in the morning. I left with the group to carry out the investigation with a calm mind, because I believe I had never seen Mina so firm and so well. I am very glad that she agreed to step aside and let us men take charge of the work. In a way, it was like a nightmare for me that she was involved in such a terrible matter, but now that her work is done and it is due to her energy and intelligence, as well as her foresight, that the whole story has been gathered, in such a way that every detail has meaning, she can rightfully feel that she has already done her part and that, from now on, she can let us take care of the rest. I think we were all a bit upset by the scene that had taken place with Mr. Renfield. When we left his room, we all kept silent until we returned to the study. Once there, Mr. Morris said, addressing Dr. Seward:

en: “Say, Jack, if that man wasn’t attempting a bluff, he is about the sanest lunatic I ever saw. I’m not sure, but I believe that he had some serious purpose, and if he had, it was pretty rough on him not to get a chance.” Lord Godalming and I were silent, but Dr. Van Helsing added:—
vi: — John, if Renfield isn't a fraud, then he is the most rational madman I have ever seen! I don't dare to make hasty judgments, but it seems like he is seriously contemplating something, so you should keep an eye on him! I and Lord Godalming did not notice anything remarkable, but Dr. Van Helsing was different; he said:
tr: Then Mr. Morris said to Dr. Seward: “Tell me Jack, if that man wasn't bluffing, he is almost the sanest madman I've ever seen until today. I'm not sure, but I believe he had a serious purpose, and if so, it must have been very hard for him not to get a chance.” Lord Godalming and I remained silent, but Dr. Van Helsing added:
es: –Tell me, Jack, if that man wasn't acting out a scene to deceive us, I think he's the sanest lunatic I've ever met. I'm not sure, but I think he had some serious purpose, and in that case, it's very cruel that he wasn't given a single chance. Lord Godalming and I remained silent, but Dr. Van Helsing added:

en: “Friend John, you know more of lunatics than I do, and I’m glad of it, for I fear that if it had been to me to decide I would before that last hysterical outburst have given him free. But we live and learn, and in our present task we must take no chance, as my friend Quincey would say. All is best as they are.” Dr. Seward seemed to answer them both in a dreamy kind of way:—
vi: — My friend John, I am truly delighted to see that you understand the stages of mental illness in patients better than I do, because if it were up to me to make the decision, I might have released Renfield right before he became so agitated. But up until now, the more we understand what concerns us, as our friend Quincey has said, we cannot afford to act recklessly when the task we are undertaking is extremely dangerous. Everything is unfolding in the sequence it is meant to. It seems that Dr. Seward intended to answer both people at the same time:
tr: “My friend John, you know more lunatics than I do and for that I am glad, but I fear, if it had been up to me, I would have released him before that final outburst where he lost control.
