But we live and learn, and in our current task, as our friend Quincey would say, we must not leave anything to chance. As it stands, everything is fine.” Dr. Seward seemed distracted as he responded to both of them:
es: –Friend John, you know more lunatics than I do, and I'm glad about it, because I fear that if it were up to me to decide, I would have set him free before that attack of neurosis occurred. But we live and learn, and at the present moment, we must not take unnecessary risks, as my friend Quincey would say. Everyone is better off as they are. Dr. Seward seemed to respond to both of them in a concerned manner:

en: “I don’t know but that I agree with you. If that man had been an ordinary lunatic I would have taken my chance of trusting him; but he seems so mixed up with the Count in an indexy kind of way that I am afraid of doing anything wrong by helping his fads. I can’t forget how he prayed with almost equal fervour for a cat, and then tried to tear my throat out with his teeth. Besides, he called the Count ‘lord and master,’ and he may want to get out to help him in some diabolical way. That horrid thing has the wolves and the rats and his own kind to help him, so I suppose he isn’t above trying to use a respectable lunatic. He certainly did seem earnest, though. I only hope we have done what is best. These things, in conjunction with the wild work we have in hand, help to unnerve a man.” The Professor stepped over, and laying his hand on his shoulder, said in his grave, kindly way:—
vi: — That's exactly right. If he were like many other patients, I wouldn't hesitate to show him that I trust him very much. But in this case, his behavior seems to depend a lot on the movements of the old count. If I let him go without paying attention to his erratic temperament, I would be making an unforgivable mistake. Once, standing in front of me, he kept babbling, calling the old count “My Lord” and “His Master.” I suspect he might be preparing to help Dracula carry out some demonic mission, this demon who can command wolves and filthy rats, not to mention other entities just like him: so how could he not think of making a madman obey him? Yes, it seems that Renfield was speaking very seriously, I realized that even though I also know very well about his illness. I hope we are doing the right thing. But this is happening just as we are conducting our mournful searches, so I fear it will dampen everyone's spirits. The professor smiled, walked over, patted Seward on the shoulder, and reassured him:
tr: “I won't be able to do anything except say that I agree with you. If that man had been an ordinary lunatic, I would have taken the risk of trusting him, but he seems so involved in the Count's affairs - through some kind of espionage - that I fear I might be doing wrong by aiding his madness. I cannot forget how he begged with almost the same fervor to get a cat and then tried to tear my throat with his teeth. Moreover, he refers to the Count as 'My Lord' and 'Master' and might want to get out of here to help him in some diabolical way. That dreadful thing has wolves, rats, and his own kind to help him, so I don't think he would hesitate to use a respectable lunatic. Still, it is true that he seems sincere. I only hope we are doing the right thing. These things, along with the wild task at hand, are enough to unnerve a person.” The Professor walked towards him and, placing his hand on his shoulder, said seriously and kindly:
es: The only thing I know is that I agree with you. If that man had been an ordinary lunatic, I would have risked trusting him, but he seems to be so strangely connected to the count that I am afraid of doing something improper by satisfying his desires. I cannot forget how he almost begged with the same fervor because he wanted a cat, and how afterwards he tried to tear my throat with his teeth. Moreover, he called the count "lord and master" and it is possible that he wishes to go out to help him in some diabolical plan. That horrible thing has wolves, rats, and its kind to help it, so I suppose it is capable of using a poor lunatic. However, it is true that he seemed sincere. It is only unfortunate that we have done the best we could in this case. Those things, along with the hard work that awaits us, are enough to affect a man's nerves. The professor stepped forward and, placing a hand on his shoulder, said to him with the usual gravity and kindness:

en: “Friend John, have no fear. We are trying to do our duty in a very sad and terrible case; we can only do as we deem best. What else have we to hope for, except the pity of the good God?” Lord Godalming had slipped away for a few minutes, but now he returned. He held up a little silver whistle, as he remarked:—
vi: — My dear friend, don't worry at all! Indeed, we are striving to undertake a truly dreadful mission, and we can only act with the reason we find most correct, but we should also hope for the mercy of God! I don't understand what Lord Godalming went outside to do a few minutes ago; I only saw that when he returned, he was juggling a silver whistle in his hand. — Maybe that house will be teeming with rats. - He held the whistle in front of us and explained.
tr: “My friend John, do not be afraid. We are trying to do our duty in a very sad and terrible case, we can only do what we think is best. What else can we hope for but the mercy of Almighty God?” Lord Godalming had left us for a few minutes in silence and had now returned. Showing a small, silver whistle, he said:
es: –Don't worry, friend John. We are trying to fulfill our duty in an extremely sad and terrible case; we can only do what seems best to us. What else can we hope for, except the mercy of the Almighty? Lord Godalming had stepped out for a few minutes, but he returned immediately. He raised a small silver whistle, while observing:

en: “That old place may be full of rats, and if so, I’ve got an antidote on call.” Having passed the wall, we took our way to the house, taking care to keep in the shadows of the trees on the lawn when the moonlight shone out. When we got to the porch the Professor opened his bag and took out a lot of things, which he laid on the step, sorting them into four little groups, evidently one for each. Then he spoke:—
vi: - I have this to drive those filthy creatures away. We quietly walked towards the abandoned house, hiding under the tree canopies to avoid the risk of being exposed by the moonlight that could suddenly break through the clouds at any moment. In front of the house, Van Helsing opened his bag and took out dozens of small items, placing them on the doorstep in four small piles, clearly indicating that each pile would be distributed to each of us. — Friends, -
tr: “The old house might be full of mice, if so, I have a ready-made remedy.” We headed towards the house, passing through the wall, taking care to stay in the shadows of the trees on the lawn as the moonlight shone. When we reached the terrace, the Professor opened his bag and took out a lot of things; he placed them on the stairs and divided them into four groups, clearly one for each of us. Then he started to speak:
es: –It is possible that the old house is full of rats, and in that case, we have an antidote at hand. After climbing over the wall, we headed towards the house, being careful to stay within the shadows of the trees cast on the lawn as the moon rose. When we reached the porch, the professor opened his briefcase and took out a bunch of objects, which he placed on one of the steps, arranging them into four groups, evidently one for each of us. Then he said:

en: “My friends, we are going into a terrible danger, and we need arms of many kinds. Our enemy is not merely spiritual. Remember that he has the strength of twenty men, and that, though our necks or our windpipes are of the common kind—and therefore breakable or crushable—his are not amenable to mere strength. A stronger man, or a body of men more strong in all than him, can at certain times hold him; but they cannot hurt him as we can be hurt by him. We must, therefore, guard ourselves from his touch. Keep this near your heart”—as he spoke he lifted a little silver crucifix and held it out to me, I being nearest to him—“put these flowers round your neck”—here he handed to me a wreath of withered garlic blossoms—“for other enemies more mundane, this revolver and this knife; and for aid in all, these so small electric lamps, which you can fasten to your breast; and for all, and above all at the last, this, which we must not desecrate needless.” This was a portion of Sacred Wafer, which he put in an envelope and handed to me. Each of the others was similarly equipped. “Now,” he said, “friend John, where are the skeleton keys? If so that we can open the door, we need not break house by the window, as before at Miss Lucy’s.”
vi: He explained - we are facing an extremely dangerous challenge, therefore, we need all kinds of weapons. The threat from the enemy is not just the ability to command spirits. Remember that he alone is more than enough to fight against twenty people combined. With his immense power, it would be difficult for us to even injure him, let alone... Moreover, if injured, he would go mad and make our situation a thousand times worse. Therefore, it's better to be a bit cautious. Wear this on your chest - he handed me a small cross, as I was the one standing closest to him - and this garland too - he handed me a garland of dried garlic to wear around my neck. - Take this handgun and knife as well, we still don't know if there are any other enemies. Each person take a lamp and put it in your jacket, and remember this: none of us are allowed to wander around the house, understood? He took a piece of holy bread, put it into a small paper bag, and handed it to me. The others also received the same "weapon" as I did: — By the way, John, where are the keychains? - The professor asked Dr. Seward. — If we can open the main door, we won't have to climb through the window like thieves. We did the same thing at Lucy's house the other day.
tr: “My friends, we are venturing into a terrible danger and we need every kind of weapon. Our enemy is not just spiritual. He possesses the strength of twenty men, and while our necks and windpipes are ordinary - and therefore breakable and crushable - his are not affected by mere physical strength. A man stronger than him or a group of men collectively stronger than him can sometimes hold him, but they cannot hurt him as he can hurt us. Therefore, we must protect ourselves from his touch. Keep this close to your heart,” - as he said this, he took out a small silver cross and handed it to me since I was the closest - “Wear these flowers around your neck,” - Here he gave me a garland made of withered garlic flowers - “for more ordinary enemies, this gun and this knife, and to help with everything, these small electric lamps you can attach to your chest, and finally, most importantly, this weapon that we must not disrespect unnecessarily.” This was a piece of consecrated bread that he placed in an envelope and handed to me. The others were equipped in the same manner. “Now,” he said, “my friend John, where are the lock picks? So, we don’t need to enter the house through the window as we did before with Miss Lucy’s; we can open the door.”
es: –My friends, we are going to take a tremendous risk, and we must arm ourselves in various ways. Our enemy is not only a spiritual one. Remember that he has the strength of twenty men and that, although our necks or our respiratory systems are of the common type, meaning they can be broken or crushed, his cannot be overcome simply by force. A stronger man, or a group of men who, together, are stronger than he is, can sometimes restrain him, but they cannot hurt him, as we can be hurt by him. Therefore, we must be careful that he does not touch us. Keep this close to your hearts. As he spoke, he lifted a small silver crucifix and handed it to me, as I was the one closest to him. –Put these flowers around your neck. When saying that, he handed me a necklace made of garlic heads. –For other more earthly enemies, this revolver and this dagger, and to help everyone, these small electric lanterns, which you can attach to your chest, and above all and beyond all, finally, this, which we must not use unless necessary. It was a piece of the Sacred Host, which he put in an envelope and handed to me. All the others were provided for in a similar manner. –Now -he said-, my friend John, where are the master keys? If we manage to open the door, we won't need to enter the house through the window, as we did before at Miss Lucy's.

en: Dr. Seward tried one or two skeleton keys, his mechanical dexterity as a surgeon standing him in good stead. Presently he got one to suit; after a little play back and forward the bolt yielded, and, with a rusty clang, shot back. We pressed on the door, the rusty hinges creaked, and it slowly opened. It was startlingly like the image conveyed to me in Dr. Seward’s diary of the opening of Miss Westenra’s tomb; I fancy that the same idea seemed to strike the others, for with one accord they shrank back. The Professor was the first to move forward, and stepped into the open door.
vi: After fumbling for a while, Seward finally chose a hook that fit the house's lock. For him, that was enough to unlock the door. The heavy door creaked loudly as it was pushed open. The sound immediately reminded me of the image of Dr. Seward and the others entering the Westenra family tomb, as he had recounted in his diary. It seemed that the others were having similar thoughts, as they all suddenly stood still at the same time. Professor Van Helsing was the one who decided to step in first.
tr: Dr. Seward tried a couple of lockpicks; his mechanical dexterity as a surgeon came in handy. After a while, he found one that worked, and after a bit of back-and-forth pushing, the lock tongue yielded and turned with a rusty clank. We pushed the door, the rusty hinges creaked, and the door slowly opened. In an eerie manner, it resembled the way Dr. Seward described the opening of Miss Westenra's tomb in his journal; I think the same thought occurred to the others because, as if in agreement, they stepped back. The first to advance was the Professor, and he stepped inside through the door.
es: Dr. Seward tried a couple of master keys, with the manual dexterity of a surgeon, which gave him great advantages in performing that task. Finally, he found one that fit and, after several advances and retreats, the latch gave way and, with a creak, it withdrew. We pushed the door; the rusty hinges creaked and it opened. It was something astonishingly similar to the image I had formed of the opening of Miss Westenra's tomb, just as I had read in Dr. Seward's diary; I believe the same idea occurred to everyone else, as they all stepped back as if by common agreement. The professor was the first to advance and head towards the open door.

en: “In manus tuas, Domine!” he said, crossing himself as he passed over the threshold. We closed the door behind us, lest when we should have lit our lamps we should possibly attract attention from the road. The Professor carefully tried the lock, lest we might not be able to open it from within should we be in a hurry making our exit. Then we all lit our lamps and proceeded on our search.
vi: — In manus tuas, Domine! - He mumbled something as he stepped over the threshold. We carefully closed the door. At this moment, each person was only paying attention to the light shining from their own hand. The professor carefully checked the door latch in case we needed to make an emergency retreat. The investigation of the abandoned house began.
tr: “Into your hands, Lord!” I said, crossing myself as I stepped over the threshold. We closed the door behind us, fearing that lighting our lamps might attract the attention of passersby. The professor carefully tested the door, concerned that in our haste to leave, we might not be able to open it from the inside. Then we all lit our lamps and began our investigation.
es: "Into your hands, Lord!" he said, crossing himself, as he crossed the threshold of the door. We closed the door behind us to prevent the glow from attracting anyone who might see it from the street when we turned on the lamps. The professor carefully pressed the latch, in case we were not in a position to open it quickly if we had to leave the house in a hurry. Then, we all lit our lamps and began our investigation.

en: The light from the tiny lamps fell in all sorts of odd forms, as the rays crossed each other, or the opacity of our bodies threw great shadows. I could not for my life get away from the feeling that there was some one else amongst us. I suppose it was the recollection, so powerfully brought home to me by the grim surroundings, of that terrible experience in Transylvania. I think the feeling was common to us all, for I noticed that the others kept looking over their shoulders at every sound and every new shadow, just as I felt myself doing.
vi: In the sickly yellow beam from the small flashlight, I saw that every object here took on a bizarre shape. Moreover, the light from one person's flashlight occasionally flashed across another, making our own shadows become very frightening. I couldn't shake the feeling that we weren't the only ones present in this dark house. Perhaps the terrifying memories of Transylvania had suddenly returned to me in the cold, dark night here. However, I believe that it wasn't just me; all my friends shared the same sense of apprehension, because every time we heard a small noise or suddenly noticed a shadow cast long on the wall, everyone would startle and turn to look.
tr: The lights of the small lamps were transforming into strange shapes as the beams intersected with each other or as our bodies cast large shadows due to their opacity. Despite my efforts, I couldn't shake the feeling that there was someone else among us. I think this was because the terrifying environment we were in strongly reminded me of that horrific experience in Transylvania. I believe this feeling was true for all of us, because I noticed that, just like me, the others kept looking over their shoulders at every sound and every new shadow.
es: The light from the tiny lamps fell on all sorts of strange shapes, when the rays crossed each other or our opaque bodies cast enormous shadows. The feeling that there was someone else among us did not leave me. I suppose it was the memory, so powerfully suggested by the eerie atmosphere, of the dreadful experience I had in Transylvania. I believe we all had the same feeling, as I noticed that the others kept looking over their shoulders whenever there was a slight noise or a new shadow was cast, just as I did.

en: The whole place was thick with dust. The floor was seemingly inches deep, except where there were recent footsteps, in which on holding down my lamp I could see marks of hobnails where the dust was cracked. The walls were fluffy and heavy with dust, and in the corners were masses of spider’s webs, whereon the dust had gathered till they looked like old tattered rags as the weight had torn them partly down. On a table in the hall was a great bunch of keys, with a time-yellowed label on each. They had been used several times, for on the table were several similar rents in the blanket of dust, similar to that exposed when the Professor lifted them. He turned to me and said:—
vi: In the house, everywhere is full of dust. I have the feeling that on the floor, except for the places with fresh footprints, the dust is thick enough to reach a finger joint. The walls are the same, dust clings in patches like a layer of filthy fur; in the corners, dust forms patches on the cobwebs hanging suspended, making me think that above my head are pieces of torn burlap. On a table in the hallway, there is a large bunch of keys, each with a plastic tag indicating the room number, yellowed by time. It seems that these keys have been used quite a few times, as I see small streaks on the dusty surface of the table, very similar to the grooves left when the professor just lifted the bunch of keys. The professor held the bunch of keys and turned to me, saying:
tr: The entire place was covered with a thick layer of dust. The floor seemed to be a few centimeters deep, except for the places where there were fresh footprints, where I could see blunt nail marks among the solidified piles of dust when I held my lamp downwards. The walls were covered and swollen with dust, and in the corners, there were clusters of cobwebs so dusty that they looked like old, worn-out carpets partially torn by the weight of the dust. On the table in the hallway, there was a large bunch of keys, each with a yellowed tag over time. They had been used many times, as there were numerous disturbances in the dust cover on the table similar to those that appeared when the Professor lifted them. The Professor turned to me and said:
es: The whole place was covered by a thick layer of dust. On the floor, that layer was several centimeters deep, except in the places where recent footprints could be seen, in which, lowering the lamp, I could see marks of tacks. The walls were moldy and covered with dust, and in the corners, there were thick cobwebs, upon which dust had accumulated, so much so that they hung like torn rags in the places where they had broken due to the weight they had to bear. On a table in the hall, there was a large bunch of keys, each of which had a yellowish tag due to the action of time. They had been used several times, as there were several marks in the dust similar to the one left when the professor lifted the keys. Van Helsing turned to me and said:

en: “You know this place, Jonathan. You have copied maps of it, and you know it at least more than we do. Which is the way to the chapel?” I had an idea of its direction, though on my former visit I had not been able to get admission to it; so I led the way, and after a few wrong turnings found myself opposite a low, arched oaken door, ribbed with iron bands. “This is the spot,” said the Professor as he turned his lamp on a small map of the house, copied from the file of my original correspondence regarding the purchase. With a little trouble we found the key on the bunch and opened the door. We were prepared for some unpleasantness, for as we were opening the door a faint, malodorous air seemed to exhale through the gaps, but none of us ever expected such an odour as we encountered. None of the others had met the Count at all at close quarters, and when I had seen him he was either in the fasting stage of his existence in his rooms or, when he was gloated with fresh blood, in a ruined building open to the air; but here the place was small and close, and the long disuse had made the air stagnant and foul. There was an earthy smell, as of some dry miasma, which came through the fouler air. But as to the odour itself, how shall I describe it? It was not alone that it was composed of all the ills of mortality and with the pungent, acrid smell of blood, but it seemed as though corruption had become itself corrupt. Faugh! it sickens me to think of it. Every breath exhaled by that monster seemed to have clung to the place and intensified its loathsomeness.
vi: — Jonathan, you are the one who knows this house better than anyone else. You have the blueprints of the house, or at least copies of them, and you have surely spent a lot of time studying them. So, do you still remember where the altar of this house is located? Of course, I know very well where the church is located, even though on my first visit to this house, I didn't have the chance to go inside. I led everyone through a few winding corridors, arriving at an oak door with an arch above it. — This is it! - The professor said as he shone the light to inspect the copy of the map that I had used when purchasing the house. He had to try a bunch of keys before he found one that fit the lock. We were waiting for something very unpleasant to happen. Indeed, as soon as the door was slightly ajar, a strong stench immediately wafted out, making us instantly imagine the disgusting air we would have to breathe when stepping inside. Except for me, no one in the group has seen the old count yet. As for myself, when I saw him, he was either lurking somewhere in his dusty rooms or fully engorged with blood in an almost outdoor dilapidated house. But the place where we are standing now is completely cramped and sealed off, with a stifling atmosphere that seems to have been there for ages. I could smell the earth, and increasingly felt a pervasive stench filling the air. I really don't know how to describe the true nature of that foul odor. Not only were all the evils that cause death in the world gathered there, but it seemed as if decay itself was transforming to create this hell. Just thinking about it is enough to make me sick! Every breath of the devil seemed to be attached to each stone of the four walls of the shrine!
tr: “You know this place, Jonathan. You had copied the plan of this place and you have more information than at least we do. Which way leads to the chapel?” Although I couldn't enter during my previous visit, I had an idea about the direction of the chapel; therefore, I acted as a guide and after a few wrong turns, I found myself in front of a low, arched, oak door with iron embossing. “Here it is,” said the Professor, turning his lamp to the small plan I had copied from the file containing my letters about purchasing the house. We found the key in the bunch without much trouble and opened the door. We were prepared for some unpleasant situations, because as the door opened, it seemed as if a slight, foul smell was coming from the gap, but none of us expected to encounter such a smell when we faced it. None of the others had encountered the Count this closely, and I had seen him either in his room during his hunger phase or in an open, ruined building in the pleasure of fresh blood, but here the room was small and airless, and its long disuse had made the air foul and malodorous. From the even worse smelling air came a dry, germy, earthy smell. But as for the smell itself, how can I describe it? It not only consisted of every kind of ailment of mortality and the sharp, acrid smell of blood, but also, as if decay itself had decayed. Ah! Thinking about it makes me sick. It was as if every breath the monster took had clung to the place and intensified its repulsiveness.
es: –You know this place, Jonathan. You have copied plans of it, and you know it at least better than all of us. Which way is it to the chapel? I had an idea of where it was located, although during my last visit I had not managed to enter it; therefore, I guided them and, after a few wrong turns, I found myself in front of a low door, which formed an arch of oak wood, crossed by iron bars. –This is the place -said the professor, while he let the small light of his lamp rest on a map of the house, copied from my files on the correspondence regarding the acquisition of the house. With some difficulty, we found the corresponding key in the bunch and opened the door. We were prepared for something unpleasant, as while opening the door, a faint and foul-smelling air seemed to emanate from the cracks, but none of us expected to encounter a smell like the one that reached us. None of the others had found the count in their vicinity, and when I had seen him, he was either in his rapid existence in the rooms or, when he was full of fresh blood, in a ruined building, open to the sky, where fresh air could penetrate; but here, the place was small and enclosed, and the long time it had remained undiscovered made the air stagnant and smell rotten. There was a smell of earth, like that of some dry miasma, that stood out from the stale air. But, as for the smell itself, how could one describe it? It wasn't just that it was composed of all the evils of mortality and the acrid, penetrating smell of blood, but it gave the impression that corruption itself had rotted. Oh! I feel sick just remembering it. Every time that monster had breathed, its breath seemed to have stagnated in that place, intensifying its repugnance.

en: Under ordinary circumstances such a stench would have brought our enterprise to an end; but this was no ordinary case, and the high and terrible purpose in which we were involved gave us a strength which rose above merely physical considerations. After the involuntary shrinking consequent on the first nauseous whiff, we one and all set about our work as though that loathsome place were a garden of roses.
vi: Perhaps in other situations, just thinking like that would have made us give up already. But before us was an important and significant goal, to the extent that we had to overcome the most disgusting obstacles. After standing still and reflexively jumping back, we suddenly remembered our task and had to view this place as a rose garden.
tr: Under ordinary circumstances, such a foul smell would have ended our endeavor, but this was no ordinary case, and the sacred, dreadful purpose we were involved in gave us a power that overcame mere physical factors. After the involuntary first breath that made us nauseous, we all set to work as if that disgusting place were a rose garden.
es: Under ordinary circumstances, such a smell would have put an end to our endeavor, but this was no ordinary case, and the lofty and terrible task we were engaged in gave us strength that overcame physical considerations. After the first involuntary shudder, a direct consequence of the initial gust of nauseating air, we all set to work as if that repugnant place were a true garden of roses.

en: We made an accurate examination of the place, the Professor saying as we began:—
vi: — First of all, - the Professor said - we need to see how many wooden crates are left.
tr: We carefully examined the place; as we began the examination, the Professor said:
es: We carefully examined the place, and the professor said, as he began:

en: “The first thing is to see how many of the boxes are left; we must then examine every hole and corner and cranny and see if we cannot get some clue as to what has become of the rest.” A glance was sufficient to show how many remained, for the great earth chests were bulky, and there was no mistaking them.
vi: We must check every corner, nook, and cranny, and any trace that might help us discover something! We had no trouble counting the wooden crates, as they were actually all quite large wooden boxes. There could be no mistake!
tr: “The first task is to see how many crates are left; the next task is to examine every hole, corner, and nook to see if we can find any clues about what happened to the other crates.” A single glance was enough to see how many were left because the large earthen crates were very big, and it was impossible to be mistaken about this.
es: –First of all, we need to see how many boxes are left; next, we should examine all the corners, holes, and crevices to see if we can find any indication of what happened to the others. A glance was enough to check how many were left, as the large boxes of earth were very bulky, and it was not possible to make a mistake about them.

en: There were only twenty-nine left out of the fifty! Once I got a fright, for, seeing Lord Godalming suddenly turn and look out of the vaulted door into the dark passage beyond, I looked too, and for an instant my heart stood still. Somewhere, looking out from the shadow, I seemed to see the high lights of the Count’s evil face, the ridge of the nose, the red eyes, the red lips, the awful pallor. It was only for a moment, for, as Lord Godalming said, “I thought I saw a face, but it was only the shadows,” and resumed his inquiry, I turned my lamp in the direction, and stepped into the passage. There was no sign of any one; and as there were no corners, no doors, no aperture of any kind, but only the solid walls of the passage, there could be no hiding-place even for him. I took it that fear had helped imagination, and said nothing.
vi: The total number according to the documents was fifty crates, but here there were only twenty-nine! While counting, I was startled and frightened when Lord Godalming suddenly turned to check the slightly ajar door leading to a dark hallway. My heart felt like it was going to jump out of my chest. I had the feeling that the Count's piercing eyes were looking through the seemingly tangible darkness, and I imagined beneath those eyes was a hooked nose, red plump lips standing out on an always pale face... About a minute later, Lord Godalming returned, muttering: "I thought it was some damned person, but it turned out to be just some silly shadows." I carefully shone the light towards the door and into the hallway, but clearly, there was no one there. There were no corners, no hidden doors, nor any crevices, just walls thickly covered in dust. I had to check to make sure there was no place inside where someone could hide - not even him. Fear had turned me into a victim of my own imagination. However, who would be foolish enough to mention this?
tr: Only twenty-nine of the coffins were there. At one point, I was startled because Lord Godalming suddenly turned and looked into the dark corridor extending beyond the arched doorway; I looked too, and for a moment, my heart stopped. Somewhere, when I focused on the shadow, it seemed to me that I saw the prominent features of the Count's demonic face, the protrusion of his nose, his red eyes, his red lips, his terrifying pallor. This lasted only a moment because Lord Godalming said, "I thought I saw a face, but it was only a shadow," and when he returned to his examination, I turned my lamp in that direction and entered the corridor. There was no sign of anyone; there couldn't have been a place for anyone to hide because there were no corners, doors, or gaps, only the solid walls of the corridor. I concluded that fear had aided my imagination and said nothing.
es: Only twenty-nine remained, out of fifty! At one point, I got quite a scare, as seeing Lord Godalming suddenly turn and look through the entrance door towards the dark passageway beyond, I also looked and, for an instant, it seemed to me that I saw the most notable features of the Count's evil face: the pointed nose, the reddish eyes, the red lips, and the terrible pallor. That happened only for the space of a second, as Lord Godalming summarized: –I thought I had seen a face, but it was just the shadows. And he went back to dedicating himself to his research. I turned my lamp in that direction and headed towards the passageway. There were no signs of anyone's presence, and since there were no doors, no corners, no openings of any kind, only the solid walls of the passageway, there could be no hiding place, not even for him. I supposed that fear had fueled the imagination, and I said nothing.

en: A few minutes later I saw Morris step suddenly back from a corner, which he was examining. We all followed his movements with our eyes, for undoubtedly some nervousness was growing on us, and we saw a whole mass of phosphorescence, which twinkled like stars. We all instinctively drew back. The whole place was becoming alive with rats.
vi: A few minutes later, while glancing around to check a corner of the church, Morris suddenly jumped back in panic. We were startled and all eyes turned towards him. Cold sweat ran down my body as I caught a glimpse of flickering lights, like phosphorescent glows, darting past in front of me. We instinctively stepped back. In the blink of an eye, countless rats were scurrying chaotically in the abandoned church.
tr: A few minutes later, I saw Morris suddenly pull back from a corner he was examining. We all watched his movements with our eyes, because undoubtedly a kind of unease was descending upon all of us, and we saw a pile of phosphorescence shining like a star. Instinctively, we all pulled back. The entire place was coming alive with rats.
es: A few minutes later, I saw Morris suddenly back away from the corner he was examining. All of us followed his movements with our eyes, because, undoubtedly, a certain nervousness was taking hold of us, and we saw a phosphorescent mass flickering like stars. Instinctively, we all backed away. The whole place was becoming populated with rats.

en: For a moment or two we stood appalled, all save Lord Godalming, who was seemingly prepared for such an emergency. Rushing over to the great iron-bound oaken door, which Dr. Seward had described from the outside, and which I had seen myself, he turned the key in the lock, drew the huge bolts, and swung the door open. Then, taking his little silver whistle from his pocket, he blew a low, shrill call. It was answered from behind Dr. Seward’s house by the yelping of dogs, and after about a minute three terriers came dashing round the corner of the house. Unconsciously we had all moved towards the door, and as we moved I noticed that the dust had been much disturbed: the boxes which had been taken out had been brought this way. But even in the minute that had elapsed the number of the rats had vastly increased. They seemed to swarm over the place all at once, till the lamplight, shining on their moving dark bodies and glittering, baleful eyes, made the place look like a bank of earth set with fireflies. The dogs dashed on, but at the threshold suddenly stopped and snarled, and then, simultaneously lifting their noses, began to howl in most lugubrious fashion. The rats were multiplying in thousands, and we moved out.
vi: The scene before us truly terrified us. Only Lord Godalming remained calm as if he had anticipated the event. He quickly rushed to the oak door, unlatched it, flung it open, and blew a single note on a silver whistle. Hearing the whistle's wheezing sound like a sick cat, the dogs behind the asylum barked loudly, filling the area with noise. About a minute later, three hunting dogs immediately ran around the corner of the abandoned house. We instinctively stepped back. As we backed near the door, I noticed that the dust here had also been trampled by many footprints: surely the missing wooden crates had been moved through this way. But that was also when another swarm of rats suddenly rushed in to join the previous group, creating a chaotic and horrifying scene before our eyes. They swarmed all over the church with their chilling squeaks, each one with eyes glowing like fireflies on the ground. The aggressive dogs tried to leap in, but for some reason, as soon as they reached the threshold, they all suddenly halted, growling and howling like wolves. The swarm of rats, easily numbering in the thousands, continued their frenzied rampage inside the church. We frantically leaped out the door.
tr: For a moment, all of us were struck with horror, except for Lord Godalming, who seemed prepared for such an emergency. Dr. Seward ran to the iron-embossed oak door he had described and I had seen from the outside, turned the key in the lock, pulled the large bolt, and opened the door. Then, he took a small silver whistle from his pocket and blew a low, sharp note. This sound was answered by barking dogs from behind Dr. Seward's house, and within a minute, three terriers came running around the corner of the house. Unconsciously, we all walked towards the door, and as we moved, I noticed that the dust was greatly disturbed: the boxes that had been taken out were carried through this way. But in that one minute, the number of rats had greatly increased. The light of the lamp shining on their dark bodies and bright, sinister eyes made the place look like a mound of earth adorned with fireflies as they swarmed there quickly. The dogs ran quickly, but suddenly stopped at the threshold of the door, growled, and then simultaneously lifted their noses and began to bark sharply. The number of rats was increasing by the thousands, and we went outside.
es: For a moment we remained motionless, astonished, all except Lord Godalming who, apparently, was prepared for a similar contingency. Rushing towards the heavy oak door with iron bands, which Dr. Seward had described from the outside and which I had seen myself, he turned the key in the lock, removed the enormous bolts, and flung the door open. Then, taking a silver whistle from his pocket, he blew it slowly and sharply. From behind Dr. Seward's house, the barking of several dogs responded, and a minute later, three terriers came running around one of the corners of the house. Unconsciously, we had all turned towards the door and, in doing so, saw that a lot of dust had been stirred up; the boxes that had been taken out had been taken out through there. But even in the single minute that had passed, the number of rats had increased greatly. They seemed to appear in the room all at once, to the point that the light from the lamps, reflecting off their dark, moving bodies and shining on their malevolent eyes, made the whole room seem filled with fireflies. The dogs appeared quickly, but at the threshold of the door, they suddenly stopped and sniffed; then, simultaneously, they raised their heads and began to howl in an extremely mournful manner. The rats were multiplying by the thousands, and we left the room.

en: Lord Godalming lifted one of the dogs, and carrying him in, placed him on the floor. The instant his feet touched the ground he seemed to recover his courage, and rushed at his natural enemies. They fled before him so fast that before he had shaken the life out of a score, the other dogs, who had by now been lifted in the same manner, had but small prey ere the whole mass had vanished.
vi: Lord Godalming grabbed a dog and threw it into the church. As soon as its feet touched the ground, the hunting dog immediately regained its inherent courage and began mercilessly slaughtering its arch-enemies. In the blink of an eye, it had killed more than twenty rats, but in that same amount of time, the rats had scattered, fleeing so quickly that they left no chance for the two other dogs that had just entered the church. The sudden disappearance of the rats made us feel as if the devil had just retreated.
tr: Lord Godalming picked up one of the dogs and carried it inside, laying it down on the ground. As soon as the dog's feet touched the ground, it seemed to regain its former courage and leapt at its natural enemies. The rats fled so quickly from the dogs that the first dog to enter took the lives of twenty, and when the other dogs were brought in the same way, there was only a small group of rats left to hunt.
es: Lord Godalming lifted one of the dogs and, carrying it inside the room, gently placed it on the floor. The very moment its paws touched the ground, it seemed to regain its courage and rushed at its natural enemies. The rats fled before him with such speed that before he had finished with a considerable number, the other dogs, which had been transported to the center of the room in the same way, had few prey to catch, since the entire mass of rats had vanished.

en: With their going it seemed as if some evil presence had departed, for the dogs frisked about and barked merrily as they made sudden darts at their prostrate foes, and turned them over and over and tossed them in the air with vicious shakes. We all seemed to find our spirits rise. Whether it was the purifying of the deadly atmosphere by the opening of the chapel door, or the relief which we experienced by finding ourselves in the open I know not; but most certainly the shadow of dread seemed to slip from us like a robe, and the occasion of our coming lost something of its grim significance, though we did not slacken a whit in our resolution. We closed the outer door and barred and locked it, and bringing the dogs with us, began our search of the house. We found nothing throughout except dust in extraordinary proportions, and all untouched save for my own footsteps when I had made my first visit. Never once did the dogs exhibit any symptom of uneasiness, and even when we returned to the chapel they frisked about as though they had been rabbit-hunting in a summer wood.
vi: The dogs were still bustling around the house, tails wagging as if they were very pleased with their recent victory. They seemed to take great pleasure in looking at the corpses of the unlucky rats on the floor. We felt as if we had just been infused with courage. It was unclear whether it was due to the appearance of the hunting dogs, the release of the stifling atmosphere in the room when the church doors were flung open, or the sigh of relief we felt when we realized we were no longer trapped, but in any case, the heavy threat weighing on us was somewhat lifted, much like shedding a filthy, uncomfortable garment. With the rats gone, we locked the church doors again, bolted them, chained them, and began to search the entire house. There was nothing special except for the dust, which covered all the remaining rooms thickly, and notably, there were no human footprints except for those I had left during my previous visit to handle the brokerage procedures. The dogs showed no particular signs, even when we returned to the church. They just ran around as if they were hunting hares on a beautiful day.
tr: With their departure, it seemed as if the evil presence had also left, for the dogs wagged their tails and barked joyfully as they made sudden attacks on their weakened enemies, flipping them over and shaking them violently before tossing them into the air. It seemed as if all our spirits had lifted. I don't know if it was the opening of the chapel door that cleared the deadly air or the relief of finding ourselves in the open, but the shadow of great fear had certainly flowed away from us like a veil, and although our resolve had not diminished in the slightest, the dreadful significance of our reason for coming here had somewhat lessened. We closed, bolted, and locked the outer door, and began to search the house with the dogs by our side. We found nothing except an extraordinary amount of dust, and nothing had been disturbed except my own footprints from my first visit. The dogs did not show a single sign of unease, and even when we returned to the chapel, they wagged their tails as if they were hunting rabbits in the forest during the summer.
es: With its disappearance, it seemed that something diabolical had ceased to be present, since the dogs began to frolic and bark joyfully, while they rushed upon their prostrate enemies, shook them, and sent them into the air with fierce jerks. All of us felt emboldened. Whether it was due to the purification of the atmosphere of death, because we had opened the chapel door, or the relief we felt upon finding ourselves at the opening, I do not know; but the fact is that the shadow of fear seemed to abandon us, as if it were a shroud, and the occasion of our visit to the house lost part of its grim significance, although we did not lose our resolve at all. We closed the outer door, barred it, and slid the bolts; then, taking the dogs with us, we began to search the house. We found nothing but large amounts of dust, and everything seemed to have been untouched, except for the trace of my footsteps from my first visit. The dogs showed no signs of uneasiness at any time, and even when we returned to the chapel, they continued to frolic, as if they were hunting rabbits in the forest on a summer night.

en: The morning was quickening in the east when we emerged from the front. Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key of the hall-door from the bunch, and locked the door in orthodox fashion, putting the key into his pocket when he had done.
vi: When we went out the gate of the house, it was also when a new day was about to begin. Van Helsing carefully locked the door and put the key in his pocket. I do not know when he removed this key from the key ring in the house. — Good! - He said. -
tr: When we stepped out the door, the day was coming to life from the east. Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key to the hall door from the bunch, and after properly locking the door and finishing his task, he put the key in his pocket.
es: The glow of dawn was breaking from the east when we went out through the main door. Dr. Van Helsing had taken the key to the front door from the bunch, carefully closed it, put the key in his pocket, and turned to us.

en: “So far,” he said, “our night has been eminently successful. No harm has come to us such as I feared might be and yet we have ascertained how many boxes are missing. More than all do I rejoice that this, our first—and perhaps our most difficult and dangerous—step has been accomplished without the bringing thereinto our most sweet Madam Mina or troubling her waking or sleeping thoughts with sights and sounds and smells of horror which she might never forget. One lesson, too, we have learned, if it be allowable to argue a particulari: that the brute beasts which are to the Count’s command are yet themselves not amenable to his spiritual power; for look, these rats that would come to his call, just as from his castle top he summon the wolves to your going and to that poor mother’s cry, though they come to him, they run pell-mell from the so little dogs of my friend Arthur. We have other matters before us, other dangers, other fears; and that monster—he has not used his power over the brute world for the only or the last time to-night. So be it that he has gone elsewhere. Good! It has given us opportunity to cry ‘check’ in some ways in this chess game, which we play for the stake of human souls. And now let us go home. The dawn is close at hand, and we have reason to be content with our first night’s work. It may be ordained that we have many nights and days to follow, if full of peril; but we must go on, and from no danger shall we shrink.”
vi: So our investigation tonight went smoothly! We now know how many wooden crates were transported. Moreover, we didn't have to face any danger as I had feared. But what makes me happiest is that we completed the first step of our work without Mina's involvement, so she won't be haunted by nightmares from the church earlier. Furthermore, this investigation also revealed something quite interesting to us, if not a definite conclusion about a completely different matter: the disgusting creatures under the Count's command do not always obey his pure psychic power. Just look at the rats, and you'll see they appear in droves at his command, just like when he summoned the wolves when you wanted to leave Dracula's castle, Jonathan, but then they immediately disappeared when they saw those little dogs! Indeed, we are only beginning to face a challenge. This is not the only time or the last time this demon will command the animal world with his power. He only temporarily disappeared before giving us a chance to cheer that "he has failed!" The game will be long. Now, let's go home. It's almost dawn. So today, we can be satisfied with our first night's work.
tr: “So far,” he said, “our night has been extremely successful. None of us have been harmed as I feared, and yet we have determined how many crates are missing. What pleases me even more is that our first - and perhaps most difficult and dangerous - step has been accomplished without disturbing our sweet Madam Mina with the terrifying sounds and smells that she would never forget, whether awake or asleep, before bringing her here. We have learned another lesson, if we can discuss it in particular: That is, these wild animals under the Count's command do not yet possess his spiritual power, because look, just like the wolves that appeared upon your departure from the castle or the ones that came out upon the poor mother's scream, these rats that came at his call, even if they came by his command, fled hastily from our friend Arthur's tiny dogs. There are other matters, other dangers, other fears ahead of us, and that monster - he did not use his power over animals for the first or last time tonight. Well, let him have gone somewhere else. Good! This situation has given us the opportunity to shout 'Check!' in this chess game we are playing for the human soul in some way. Let's go home now. Dawn is approaching, and we have reason to be pleased with our work on the first night. If it is full of dangers, we may have many more nights and days to follow, but we must continue and fear no danger.”
es: –So far -he said-, the night has truly been a success for us. We have not received any harm, as we might have feared, and moreover, we have been able to ascertain how many boxes are missing. Above all, I am very glad that this first step we have taken, perhaps the most difficult and dangerous of all, we have been able to carry out without our sweet lady Mina accompanying us, and without the need to disturb her thoughts, all the more so since she would be awake and asleep thinking of visions, noises, and smells that she could never forget. Likewise, we have learned a lesson, if we can say it particularly: that the beasts that are at the count's orders are not, however, docile to the count's spirit, since those rats would come at his call, just as he called the wolves from the tower of his castle, to come out to meet him and that poor mother. Although the rats came, they fled a moment later in disorder, at the presence of our friend Arthur's little dogs. We have other matters, other dangers, and other fears ahead of us; and that monster has not used his powers over the animal world for the last or only time tonight. Whether he has gone somewhere else... Well! He has given us the opportunity to give "check" in this chess game we are playing in the name of the good of human souls. Now, let's go back home. Dawn is already near, and we have reasons to feel pleased with the work of our first night. It is possible that we still have many days and nights full of dangers ahead, but we must move forward, without retreating from any risk.

en: The house was silent when we got back, save for some poor creature who was screaming away in one of the distant wards, and a low, moaning sound from Renfield’s room. The poor wretch was doubtless torturing himself, after the manner of the insane, with needless thoughts of pain.
vi: When I returned, I didn't see anything unusual in the asylum still immersed in Dr. Seward's sleep, except for the wailing of some unfortunate person in a room at the end of the hallway, or the groans from Renfield's room. His mind must be in great torment, as this is often seen in those with mental disorders.
tr: When we returned, the house was silent except for a wretched creature screaming in one of the distant wards and a low, moaning sound coming from Renfield's room. The poor man was undoubtedly torturing himself with unnecessary thoughts that would cause pain, in a manner consistent with the behavior of the insane.
es: The house was engulfed in a profound silence when we arrived, except for the screams of some poor creature that was in one of the farthest wings and a low, plaintive sound coming from Renfield's room. Undoubtedly, the poor man was torturing himself, in the manner of madmen, with unnecessarily painful thoughts.

en: I came tiptoe into our own room, and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to put my ear down to hear it. She looks paler than usual. I hope the meeting to-night has not upset her. I am truly thankful that she is to be left out of our future work, and even of our deliberations. It is too great a strain for a woman to bear. I did not think so at first, but I know better now. Therefore I am glad that it is settled. There may be things which would frighten her to hear; and yet to conceal them from her might be worse than to tell her if once she suspected that there was any concealment. Henceforth our work is to be a sealed book to her, till at least such time as we can tell her that all is finished, and the earth free from a monster of the nether world. I daresay it will be difficult to begin to keep silence after such confidence as ours; but I must be resolute, and to-morrow I shall keep dark over to-night’s doings, and shall refuse to speak of anything that has happened. I rest on the sofa, so as not to disturb her.
vi: I tiptoed back to the room. Mina was still deep in sleep, her breathing so slow and light that I had to lean in close to hear it. Only at this moment did I suddenly notice that she looked paler than usual. I hope yesterday's meeting didn't make her worry too much! Thankfully, she no longer participates in our investigations, searches, or decisions. She might get scared if she heard us discussing certain things. However, who knows if our keeping things from her might cause her even more distress if, at some point, she starts to suspect that we want her to stay silent about one thing or another. It is possible that in the near future, we will strive to ensure that you have absolutely no doubts about our decisions and work - at least until we can inform you that the bloodthirsty demon has been permanently eradicated from this earth. For me, keeping silent is not an easy task, especially when the two of us have the habit of sharing everything with each other. But I have decided, when she wakes up, I will definitely not tell her anything about what happened during the night. If she insists on asking, I will just mumble to brush it off. The sky was about to fully brighten, I tiptoed to lie down on the couch to avoid disturbing her sleep.
tr: When I tiptoed into our room, Mina was asleep; she was breathing so softly that I had to lean in to hear it. She looks paler than usual. I hope tonight's meeting hasn't upset her. I'm grateful that she is kept out of our future work and even our own discussions. This is too much tension for a woman to bear. I didn't think so at first, but now I understand better. Therefore, I am glad that it was decided this way. There might be things she would be afraid to hear; yet, if she suspects there is a secret, hiding it from her could be worse than telling it. From now on, our duty, at the very least, should be to remain a sealed book to her until the time comes when we can tell her that everything is over and the world is rid of a monster from hell. I think it will be hard to start keeping silent after the trust between us, but I will act decisively and tomorrow, I will not reveal any secrets about what happened tonight and will refuse to talk about it. I'm sleeping on the couch so as not to disturb her.
es: I entered my room on tiptoe and found Mina asleep, breathing so softly that I had to strain my ears to catch the sound. She seemed paler than usual. I hoped that the meeting that night had not impressed her too much. I feel truly grateful that she remains out of our future work and even our deliberations. It is too great a strain for a woman to bear. I did not think so at first, but now I know much better what to expect. Therefore, I am glad that this has been resolved. There may be things that would frighten her if she heard them; however, hiding them from her would be worse than revealing them, if she comes to suspect that there is something we are not telling her. From this moment on, we must be like closed books to her, at least until we can announce that everything is over and that the land has been freed from that monster of the darkness. I suppose it will be difficult to keep silent, due to the trust that reigns between us, but I must continue in my resolution and completely silence everything related to our actions during that night, refusing to speak of what has happened. I lay down on the divan, so as not to disturb her.

en: 1 October, later.—I suppose it was natural that we should have all overslept ourselves, for the day was a busy one, and the night had no rest at all. Even Mina must have felt its exhaustion, for though I slept till the sun was high, I was awake before her, and had to call two or three times before she awoke. Indeed, she was so sound asleep that for a few seconds she did not recognize me, but looked at me with a sort of blank terror, as one looks who has been waked out of a bad dream. She complained a little of being tired, and I let her rest till later in the day. We now know of twenty-one boxes having been removed, and if it be that several were taken in any of these removals we may be able to trace them all. Such will, of course, immensely simplify our labour, and the sooner the matter is attended to the better. I shall look up Thomas Snelling to-day.
vi: • October 1, a little later It's probably not unusual that we slept straight through until noon, because the whole day and night before, we hadn't had a moment to rest. Mina must have been very tired too, because I - the first one to wake up - had to shake her two or three times before she finally woke up. She slept so deeply that she didn't immediately realize there was someone in front of her. She looked at me bewildered and frightened, as if she had just gone through a terrible nightmare. Seeing her complain of fatigue, I told her to stay in bed for a few more minutes before getting up... Now, we know that twenty-one wooden crates have disappeared from the abandoned house. Therefore, I have to investigate where those missing crates have been taken. Today, I will go to Thomas Snelling's house.
tr: October 1, later. - I suppose it is natural for all of us to have slept more than usual, because the day had been intense and we had not rested at all during the night. Even Mina must have felt her exhaustion, for although I slept until the sun was up, I had risen before her and had to call her two or three times before she woke up. Indeed, she slept so deeply that for a few seconds she did not recognize me and looked at me with a kind of empty terror, as someone awakened from a bad dream might do. She complained of feeling a bit tired, and I allowed her to rest until later in the day. We now know that twenty-one crates have been moved, and if most of them were transported together in these operations, we can trace them. Such a situation, of course, will make our task easier, and the sooner the matter is resolved, the better. Today I will visit Thomas Snelling.
es: October 1st, later. I suppose it is natural that we all slept until a late hour, as the day was filled with hard work and the night was heavy and sleepless. Even Mina must have felt the exhaustion, since, although I slept until the sun was very high, I woke up before her. In fact, she was so deeply asleep that for a few seconds she didn't even recognize me and looked at me with deep terror, as if she had been awakened in the middle of a terrible nightmare. She complained a bit about being tired and I let her rest until a later hour in the day. We now knew that twenty-one boxes had been removed, and in the event that several were taken at once, it was possible that we could find them. Of course, this would considerably simplify our work and the sooner we resolved this matter, the better it would be. I had to go see Thomas Snelling.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 1 October.—It was towards noon when I was awakened by the Professor walking into my room. He was more jolly and cheerful than usual, and it is quite evident that last night’s work has helped to take some of the brooding weight off his mind. After going over the adventure of the night he suddenly said:—
vi: • October 1 I woke up when it was almost noon. Van Helsing had been in my room for some time, but I didn't know when he arrived. He looked visibly cheerful, which was a rare sight for him. Perhaps what we had just discovered had put his mind at ease. He began the conversation by briefly recounting last night's investigation, then moved on to discuss the matter of patient Renfield:
tr: October 1st. - When the Professor entered my room and woke me up, it was almost noon. He looked happier and more cheerful than usual, and it was clear that last night's work had lifted some of the burden of dark thoughts from his mind. After going over the night's adventure, he suddenly said:
es: October 1st. It was almost noon when I was awakened by the professor, who entered my room. He was more cheerful and kind than usual, and it was evident that the work from the previous night had helped to lighten some of the weight on his mind. After talking about the adventure from the previous night, he suddenly said:

en: “Your patient interests me much. May it be that with you I visit him this morning? Or if that you are too occupy, I can go alone if it may be. It is a new experience to me to find a lunatic who talk philosophy, and reason so sound.” I had some work to do which pressed, so I told him that if he would go alone I would be glad, as then I should not have to keep him waiting; so I called an attendant and gave him the necessary instructions. Before the Professor left the room I cautioned him against getting any false impression from my patient. “But,” he answered, “I want him to talk of himself and of his delusion as to consuming live things. He said to Madam Mina, as I see in your diary of yesterday, that he had once had such a belief. Why do you smile, friend John?”
vi: — Your patient's hand caught my attention. Can I see him again today? If you're busy, you can just let me visit him alone. I find his case quite interesting. It's fascinating how a madman can speak so accurately about logic and philosophy! Indeed, I am very busy today, so I had to ask you to go to Renfield's room alone because I didn't want you to waste time waiting. I called a warden and gave him some necessary instructions, and asked him to lead you there. But before you left the room, I still reminded you to be cautious. — I was just going to talk about him - He replied - and the passion that drove him to swallow insects alive. Yesterday, I read your diary and found out that he had spoken to Mina. But what are you laughing at, John?
tr: “Your patient interests me a lot. Can I come with you to visit him this morning? Or if you are very busy, I can go alone if possible. Finding a mental patient who talks philosophy and reasons so healthily is a new experience for me.” I had some tasks to attend to, so I told him I would be pleased if he went alone, so I wouldn't have to keep him waiting later; I called a nurse and gave the necessary instructions. Before the professor left the room, I warned him not to get any wrong impressions from my patient. “But,” he said, “I want to hear him talk about himself and his madness about eating live things. From yesterday's part of the journal, I understand that he once told Madam Mina about such a belief. Why are you laughing, my friend Jonathan?”
es: –Your patient interests me a lot. Is it possible for me to visit him with you this morning? Or, in case you are very busy, I can go see him alone, if you permit me. It is a new experience for me to find a lunatic who talks about philosophy and discourses so sensibly. I had some urgent work to do and I told him that I would like him to go alone, so that I wouldn't be forced to make him wait. Therefore, I called one of the assistants and gave him the necessary instructions. Before my teacher left the room, I advised him not to get a false impression about my patient. "I wish you would tell me about yourself and your disappointment regarding your consumption of live animals." "You told Mrs. Mina, as I saw in her diary yesterday, that you once held those beliefs." "Why are you smiling, my friend John?"

en: “Excuse me,” I said, “but the answer is here.” I laid my hand on the type-written matter. “When our sane and learned lunatic made that very statement of how he used to consume life, his mouth was actually nauseous with the flies and spiders which he had eaten just before Mrs. Harker entered the room.” Van Helsing smiled in turn. “Good!” he said. “Your memory is true, friend John. I should have remembered. And yet it is this very obliquity of thought and memory which makes mental disease such a fascinating study. Perhaps I may gain more knowledge out of the folly of this madman than I shall from the teaching of the most wise. Who knows?” I went on with my work, and before long was through that in hand. It seemed that the time had been very short indeed, but there was Van Helsing back in the study. “Do I interrupt?” he asked politely as he stood at the door.
vi: — I'm sorry, but the answer to your question lies here - I said, placing my hand on the stack of typed papers - When our rational and educated mad patient discussed the habit of eating living creatures with me, indeed his mouth was still smeared with spider legs and fly legs that he had just eaten right before Mrs. Harker entered the room. Van Helsing chuckled. — You have an excellent memory, my friend! I should have remembered this detail myself. However, it is precisely such flaws in thinking and memory that draw people to study mental patients. Who knows, by understanding the madness through Renfield's strange behavior, I might learn more about human wisdom! Who can say? Speaking of which, I have to go to the office to start work. Time flies so fast; before I knew it, the professor had already returned. — Am I bothering you?
tr: "Excuse me," I said, "but the answer is here. "I placed my hand on the typewritten draft. " Our sane and educated madman, while explaining how he once had a habit of eating life, had the repulsiveness of the flies and spiders he ate just before Ms. Harker entered the room lingering in his mouth."Van Helsing smiled at me. "Good!" he said. " Your memory does not deceive you, my friend John. I should have remembered that. But still, what makes the study of mental illness such a fascinating field is the way thought and memory can go astray like this. Perhaps I can gain more knowledge from this man's madness than from the teachings of the wisest person. Who knows? "I continued my work and finished what I had in hand shortly thereafter. Indeed, it seemed like a very short time, but Van Helsing had already returned to the study room. "Am I disturbing you?" he asked politely, standing at the door.
es: –Excuse me -I said-, but the answer is right here. I placed my hand on the typewritten pages. –When our sane and intelligent lunatic made that statement, his mouth was still full of the flies and spiders he had just eaten, a moment before Mrs. Harker entered his room. –Well! – he said. Your memory is good. I should have remembered it. And yet, that very deviation of thought and memory is what makes the study of mental illnesses so fascinating. It is possible that I may gain more knowledge from the madness of that poor lunatic than I could from the wisest of men. Who knows? I continued my work and, before much time had passed, I had finished the most urgent tasks. It seemed that not much time had really passed, but van Helsing had already returned to the study. –Am I interrupting? – he asked politely, remaining at the doorway.

en: “Not at all,” I answered. “Come in. My work is finished, and I am free. I can go with you now, if you like.
vi: — Am I bothering you? — No, please go ahead! - I replied. - I have just finished some tasks, now I can take you if you still want.
tr: “Absolutely not,” I replied. “Come in. I'm done with my work and now I'm free. If you want, I can come with you now.”
es: –Not at all -I replied-. Come in. I've finished my work and I'm free. I can accompany you, if you wish.

en: “It is needless; I have seen him!”
vi: — No need to go! I have already met him!
tr: "No need; I saw him!""
es: –It's useless. I just saw it!

en: “Well?”
vi: — Really?
tr: “So, what do you think?”
es: –And?

en: “I fear that he does not appraise me at much. Our interview was short. When I entered his room he was sitting on a stool in the centre, with his elbows on his knees, and his face was the picture of sullen discontent. I spoke to him as cheerfully as I could, and with such a measure of respect as I could assume. He made no reply whatever. “Don’t you know me?” I asked. His answer was not reassuring: “I know you well enough; you are the old fool Van Helsing. I wish you would take yourself and your idiotic brain theories somewhere else. Damn all thick-headed Dutchmen!” Not a word more would he say, but sat in his implacable sullenness as indifferent to me as though I had not been in the room at all. Thus departed for this time my chance of much learning from this so clever lunatic; so I shall go, if I may, and cheer myself with a few happy words with that sweet soul Madam Mina. Friend John, it does rejoice me unspeakable that she is no more to be pained, no more to be worried with our terrible things. Though we shall much miss her help, it is better so.”
vi: — I'm just afraid he thinks nothing of me. The conversation was really brief. When I entered, he was squatting on a stool placed in the middle of the room, his hands supporting his chin, his face stubborn and unpleasant. I tried to talk to him with a cheerful attitude and great respect, but he still didn't bother to reply. “Don't you know me?” I asked. His response was clearly inappropriate: “Of course! It's that silly old Van Helsing, who else. I want you to find somewhere else to play. Go study your stupid brain! Damn you, you stupid Dutchman!” I couldn't say anything more, and he kept his stubborn, scowling face, completely forgetting my presence. So the chance to learn something more from this intelligent patient was gone. To comfort myself, perhaps I should go talk to the gentle Mina. John, how can I describe to you the joy I feel when we manage to shield her from the hardships and dangers that lie ahead? Granted, she can still help us with some things, but we must also act rightly.
tr: “I'm afraid he doesn't like me very much. Our meeting was brief. When I entered his room, he was sitting on a stool in the middle of the room, with his elbows resting on his knees and a sullen expression of discontent on his face. I spoke to him as cheerfully and respectfully as I could. He didn't respond at all, 'I know you well enough, you are the old fool Van Helsing.' I wish you would take yourself and your foolish brain theories somewhere else. Damn all thick-headed Dutchmen!' He didn't say another word, but with his endless sulkiness, he sat there indifferently as if I wasn't even in the room. Thus, this time, my chance to learn much from such a clever lunatic slipped away; therefore, if possible, I will speak a few happy words with that sweet Madam Mina to lift my spirits. My friend John, it makes me indescribably happy that she is no longer being tormented or worried by our dreadful affairs. Though we will miss her help greatly, it's for the best.”
es: –I'm afraid he doesn't appreciate me much. Our interview was short. When I entered his room, he was sitting in a chair in the center, with his elbows resting on his knees and a sullen, grumpy expression on his face. I spoke to him with all the kindness possible, and with all the respect I could muster. He did not respond with a single word. "-Don't you recognize me? – I inquired. "His response was not very reassuring." "-I know you perfectly well. You are the old fool van Helsing. I wish you would take your stupid psychological theories somewhere else. Damn all the stupid Dutch people! "He did not utter another word and remained seated, wrapped in his discontent and ill-humor, exactly as if I had not been in the room at all; such was his indifference. Thus, I have lost the opportunity to learn something from that intelligent lunatic; consequently, I must leave to try to console myself by exchanging a few pleasant words with the sweet Mrs. Mina. Friend John, I am infinitely glad that she no longer has to suffer, nor worry about our terrible affairs. Although we will miss her help, it is better this way."

en: “I agree with you with all my heart,” I answered earnestly, for I did not want him to weaken in this matter. “Mrs. Harker is better out of it. Things are quite bad enough for us, all men of the world, and who have been in many tight places in our time; but it is no place for a woman, and if she had remained in touch with the affair, it would in time infallibly have wrecked her.”
vi: — I completely agree with you. It is best not to let Mina worry any further. The situation is very dangerous for us now, men who have experienced many difficult times in the struggle for survival in life. If she continues to join us, this young woman will surely wither away.
tr: “I agree with you wholeheartedly,” I replied sincerely, because I did not want him to soften on this matter. “It is better for Ms. Harker to stay out of this issue. Things are bad enough for us, who have seen and experienced a lot and have been in very difficult places in our time, but this is no place for a woman and if she had anything to do with this, it would undoubtedly destroy her over time.”
es: –I absolutely agree with you, I told him sincerely, since I did not want his decision on the matter to weaken. Mrs. Harker is better off staying out of all this. The situation is already quite bad for us men, who have sometimes found ourselves in unpleasant places, but it is not a suitable place for a woman, and if she had continued with this matter, it is very possible that she would have ended up being torn apart.

en: So Van Helsing has gone to confer with Mrs. Harker and Harker; Quincey and Art are all out following up the clues as to the earth-boxes. I shall finish my round of work and we shall meet to-night.
vi: So Van Helsing decided to visit and talk with the Harkers. At this time, Quincey and Arthur were continuing to search for the boxes of earth, or at least trace their whereabouts. Tonight, we will have another meeting together.
tr: Thus, Van Helsing went to meet with Ms. Harker and Mr. Harker; Quincey and Art are doing their best to track down the soil boxes. I will finish my work and meet with them tonight.
es: Thus, Van Helsing went to talk with Mr. and Mrs. Harker. Quincey and Art have gone out to discover everything possible regarding the disappearance of the boxes. I have to conclude my round of work, and we will meet tonight.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 1 October.—It is strange to me to be kept in the dark as I am to-day; after Jonathan’s full confidence for so many years, to see him manifestly avoid certain matters, and those the most vital of all. This morning I slept late after the fatigues of yesterday, and though Jonathan was late too, he was the earlier. He spoke to me before he went out, never more sweetly or tenderly, but he never mentioned a word of what had happened in the visit to the Count’s house. And yet he must have known how terribly anxious I was. Poor dear fellow! I suppose it must have distressed him even more than it did me. They all agreed that it was best that I should not be drawn further into this awful work, and I acquiesced. But to think that he keeps anything from me! And now I am crying like a silly fool, when I know it comes from my husband’s great love and from the good, good wishes of those other strong men.
vi: • October 1 I feel very upset being left out like today. For so many years, Jonathan has always shown great trust in me, but today, I had to meet him without knowing anything about their conversation. This morning, I woke up very late because I was extremely tired all day yesterday. Jonathan also woke up not long before noon, but he was still the first to wake up!
