Before leaving, he spoke to me in a gentler and more affectionate tone than ever, but he didn't mention a single word about the investigation of the old count's house last night. However, he surely understands that I am very worried about this matter. Poor him! Keeping silent will only make him more troubled because of me. They all unanimously decided to leave me out, and I can only accept it. But just thinking about my husband harboring many secrets from me makes me feel upset! Yet, I burst into tears like a child when I think that it's because of his love for me that he has to keep silent. And the rest of them too, they are gallant and kind friends who only want to ensure my health and safety!
tr: October 1st. - It feels strange to me not to be informed as I was today; after Jonathan's endless trust over the years, to avoid certain topics and the most crucial ones so openly! After yesterday's exhaustion, I slept in late this morning, and although Jonathan got up late as well, he was up earlier than me. Before leaving, he spoke to me in a sweeter and softer manner than ever before, but did not say a single word about what happened during the visit to the Count's house. But still, he must have known how worried I was. Poor dear man! I think this situation must have upset him even more than it upset me. They all decided together that I should not be drawn further into this dreadful matter, and I did not oppose it. But to think that he is hiding something from me! And now, even though I know it stems from my husband's great love and the good, good intentions of those other strong men, I am crying like a fool...
es: October 1st. I find it strange to remain in the dark, like today; after Jonathan's total trust for so many years, it is unpleasant to see him openly avoid certain topics of conversation: the most vital topics of all. This morning I slept until a late hour, due to the fatigue of yesterday, and although Jonathan also slept late, he woke up before me. He spoke to me before leaving, and never before had he done so with greater sweetness or tenderness, but he did not mention a single word about what had happened during his visit to the count's house. However, he must know the terrible anxiety I felt. Poor Jonathan! I suppose that must have distressed him even more than it did me. Everyone agreed that I should not continue with that horrible matter, and I agreed. But, it is very unpleasant for me to think that he is hiding something from me! And now I am crying like an idiot, when, in reality, I know that all of this is a product of my husband's great love and the goodwill of all those strong men.

en: That has done me good. Well, some day Jonathan will tell me all; and lest it should ever be that he should think for a moment that I kept anything from him, I still keep my journal as usual. Then if he has feared of my trust I shall show it to him, with every thought of my heart put down for his dear eyes to read. I feel strangely sad and low-spirited to-day. I suppose it is the reaction from the terrible excitement.
vi: However, the hot tears rolling down my cheeks made me feel a bit relieved. I told myself that one day Jonathan would tell me everything. For now, I will continue to write my diary as usual. If he ever doubts my faith, I will let him know my feelings and thoughts through these diary entries. Just thinking about it, but today I still feel sad and weary. Perhaps this is also the consequence of my excessive emotions.
tr: This did me good. One day Jonathan will tell me everything, and so that he doesn't think I'm hiding anything from him for even a moment, as always, I'm keeping my journal. Then, if he doubts my trust, I will show him every thought that comes from my heart written down, so that his dear eyes can read them. Today, I feel strangely sad and listless. It must be a reaction to that horrific excitement.
es: That has done me good. Well, someday Jonathan will tell me everything, and to avoid him thinking that I am also hiding something from him, I continue writing my diary, as usual. Thus, if he has doubted my trust, I must show it to him, including all the thoughts and feelings of my heart, so that he can read them clearly. Today I feel strangely sad and moody. I suppose it is the reaction due to the tremendous emotion.

en: Last night I went to bed when the men had gone, simply because they told me to. I didn’t feel sleepy, and I did feel full of devouring anxiety. I kept thinking over everything that has been ever since Jonathan came to see me in London, and it all seems like a horrible tragedy, with fate pressing on relentlessly to some destined end. Everything that one does seems, no matter how right it may be, to bring on the very thing which is most to be deplored. If I hadn’t gone to Whitby, perhaps poor dear Lucy would be with us now. She hadn’t taken to visiting the churchyard till I came, and if she hadn’t come there in the day-time with me she wouldn’t have walked there in her sleep; and if she hadn’t gone there at night and asleep, that monster couldn’t have destroyed her as he did. Oh, why did I ever go to Whitby? There now, crying again! I wonder what has come over me to-day. I must hide it from Jonathan, for if he knew that I had been crying twice in one morning—I, who never cried on my own account, and whom he has never caused to shed a tear—the dear fellow would fret his heart out. I shall put a bold face on, and if I do feel weepy, he shall never see it. I suppose it is one of the lessons that we poor women have to learn....
vi: Last night, I went to bed right after Jonathan and his friends left the house, simply because they advised me to do so. I wasn't sleepy, just terribly worried. I suddenly thought about what had happened since the day Jonathan first visited me in London, everything seemed like a horrible play where the fates were cruelly moving towards their inevitable end. It seemed that any action we took, no matter how well-intentioned, resulted in terrible outcomes. If I hadn't gone to Whitby, Lucy might not have died. Before I arrived, she never went to the cemetery, did she? If she hadn't walked there with me, she wouldn't have sleepwalked there, and thus wouldn't have been harmed by that monster. Oh my God! Why on earth did I decide to go to Whitby? Yes... and so I cried again. I wondered what was wrong with me today. Jonathan surely doesn't know that I - who have never cried out of self-pity, and have never shed a tear in front of my husband - have cried twice today. If he realized this, he would certainly be extremely confused. Because normally, if I was upset about something, I would never show it on my face.
tr: Last night, when the men left, I went to bed just because they told me to do so. I wasn't sleepy and I felt a consuming anxiety. Since the day Jonathan came to London to see me, I kept reviewing everything that happened, and everything seems like a horrifying tragedy, as if fate is relentlessly pushing towards a predetermined end. Everything done, no matter how right, seems to cause the very thing we find the worst. If I hadn't gone to Whitby, perhaps dear poor Lucy could be here with us today. If she hadn't gone to visit the churchyard until I came, and if she hadn't gone there with me during the day, she wouldn't have walked there in her sleep, and if she hadn't gone there in her sleep at night, that monster couldn't have destroyed her like this. Oh, why did I go to Whitby? Here I am, crying again! I don't know what happened to me today. I must hide this from Jonathan, because if he learns that I cried twice this morning - I, who never cry on my own and Jonathan has never caused me to shed a single tear - the poor man would be devastated with worry. I must put on a brave face, and if I feel like crying, he must never know. I think this is one of the lessons we poor women must learn...
es: Last night I went to bed when the men left, simply because they told me to go to bed. I wasn't sleepy, and I felt an enormous anxiety. I was thinking about everything that had happened since Jonathan came to see me in London, and it all seemed like a horrible tragedy, as if fate were driving everything towards a sinister end. Everything we do, no matter how good our intentions, seems to lead to something that must be deeply deplored. If I had not gone to Whitby, it is possible that poor, dear Lucy would still be with us now. It had not occurred to her to visit the churchyard until the moment of my arrival, and if she had not gone there during the day, she would not have returned sleepwalking during the night, and the monster would not have destroyed her as it did. Oh! Why did I go to Whitby? Crying again! I don't know what's happening to me today. I must hide it from Jonathan, because if he knows that I have cried twice already this morning, I who never cry and have never had to shed a single tear for him, the poor man will be discouraged and worried. I must put on a serene face, and if I feel like crying, he must not know. I suppose it is one of the lessons that we poor women have to learn…

en: I can’t quite remember how I fell asleep last night. I remember hearing the sudden barking of the dogs and a lot of queer sounds, like praying on a very tumultuous scale, from Mr. Renfield’s room, which is somewhere under this. And then there was silence over everything, silence so profound that it startled me, and I got up and looked out of the window. All was dark and silent, the black shadows thrown by the moonlight seeming full of a silent mystery of their own. Not a thing seemed to be stirring, but all to be grim and fixed as death or fate; so that a thin streak of white mist, that crept with almost imperceptible slowness across the grass towards the house, seemed to have a sentience and a vitality of its own. I think that the digression of my thoughts must have done me good, for when I got back to bed I found a lethargy creeping over me. I lay a while, but could not quite sleep, so I got out and looked out of the window again. The mist was spreading, and was now close up to the house, so that I could see it lying thick against the wall, as though it were stealing up to the windows. The poor man was more loud than ever, and though I could not distinguish a word he said, I could in some way recognise in his tones some passionate entreaty on his part. Then there was the sound of a struggle, and I knew that the attendants were dealing with him. I was so frightened that I crept into bed, and pulled the clothes over my head, putting my fingers in my ears. I was not then a bit sleepy, at least so I thought; but I must have fallen asleep, for, except dreams, I do not remember anything until the morning, when Jonathan woke me. I think that it took me an effort and a little time to realise where I was, and that it was Jonathan who was bending over me. My dream was very peculiar, and was almost typical of the way that waking thoughts become merged in, or continued in, dreams.
vi: Yesterday, I don't know when I fell asleep. I only remember suddenly hearing the loud barking of the house dogs and numerous strange murmurs coming from the room of the patient Renfield, which is the room directly below mine. Then there was a deep silence that made me feel anxious. A vague feeling of discomfort made me get up and look out the window. The silence and darkness, occasionally punctuated by a bit of faint moonlight, made the late night even more mysterious. There was nothing moving out there, everything was enveloped in a mournful and still atmosphere like in a dead world, except for a pale mist drifting very slowly, so slowly that I could barely perceive its movement across the grass towards its house; it seemed that only this mist was the embodiment of life at that moment. The mist lingered in my mind, making me feel more at ease, for when I returned to bed, I felt myself starting to drift off as if I were falling asleep. However, I still couldn't sleep; the mist was still floating in my thoughts, making me get up and look out the window once more. By now, the mist had spread out and was hovering close to the house: I could see the dense mist clinging to the walls as if trying to climb through the windows. At that moment, Renfield suddenly screamed like a mad dog; I couldn't understand what he was saying, but it was so pitiful. Then I suddenly had the feeling that I heard someone fighting, perhaps the warden had entered the room and was being fiercely resisted by him, leading to a struggle. Frightened, I went back to bed, pulled the blanket over my head, and tightly covered my ears. At this point, I no longer felt sleepy. But eventually, I gradually fell asleep, for after a dream, I couldn't remember what had happened until noon today, when Jonathan woke me up. It took me a moment to gather my thoughts and realize where I was and who was standing in front of me. In my deep sleep, I had a really bizarre dream, which showed how much I had been thinking and worrying. Indeed, I had just gone through a deep, exhausting sleep!
tr: I can't remember how I fell asleep last night. I remember suddenly hearing dogs barking and a lot of strange noises coming from Mr. Renfield's room somewhere below this room, as if someone was praying very loudly. And then, silence fell over everything, a silence so deep that it frightened me, and I got up to look out the window. Everything was dark and quiet, and the dark shadows cast by the moonlight seemed filled with their own mystery. Not a single thing was moving, everything seemed as terrible and still as death or fate; so much so that the thin line of white mist that seemed to be crawling towards the house across the grass at an almost imperceptible speed seemed to have a consciousness and life of its own. I think it did me good to get away from the subject because when I returned to bed, a heaviness had settled over me. I lay down for a while, but I couldn't sleep much, so I got up again and looked out the window. The mist was spreading and had now come very close to the house, so much so that I could see it clinging to the wall in a thick layer as if it were secretly reaching for the windows. The poor man was making more noise than ever, and although I couldn't distinguish a single word he was saying, I could detect a peculiar passionate plea in his voice. Then, the sound of a struggle came; I knew the nurses were attending to him. I was so scared that I crawled into bed and covered my head with the blankets, plugging my ears with my fingers. At that moment, I wasn't sleepy at all, or at least I thought so; but I must have fallen asleep because I don't remember anything until Jonathan woke me up in the morning, except for the dreams I had. I think it took me some effort and time to understand where I was and to realize that it was Jonathan leaning over me. My dream was quite unusual and was almost an example of thoughts conceived while awake blending into or continuing in the dream.
es: I can't stop remembering how I fell asleep. I remember hearing the sudden barking of the dogs and a clamor of strange sounds, like prayers in a tumultuous range, coming from Mr. Renfield's room, which is somewhere below mine. Then, silence reigned again, so deep that it startled me, and I got up to look out the window. Everything was dark and silent. The dark shadows cast by the moonlight seemed to be filled with a mystery of their own. Nothing seemed to move, but everything appeared gloomy and eerie, so that a slight wisp of white fog, advancing with a slowness that made its movement almost imperceptible, towards the house, over the lawn, seemed to have a life of its own. I believe that these thoughts, by making me forget the previous ones, did me good, since when I went back to bed I felt a lethargy that gently enveloped me. I remained in bed for a while, but I couldn't fall asleep, so I got up again and looked out the window. The fog was spreading and was already very close to the house, so much so that I saw it cling heavily to the walls, as if it were climbing towards the windows. The poor man was speaking more forcefully than ever and, although I couldn't quite make out his words, I understood that it was a passionate plea on his part. Then, I heard the sound of a struggle and realized that the nurses were taking care of him. I felt so scared that I covered my head with the sheets, plugging my ears with my fingers. I wasn't sleepy at all or, at least, so I thought, but I must have fallen asleep, since, except for the dreams, I don't remember anything else until morning came, when Jonathan woke me up. I think it took me some effort and time to remember where I was and that it was Jonathan who was leaning over me. My dream was very peculiar, and it was something typical, in the way that upon waking, thoughts intermingle with dreams.

en: I thought that I was asleep, and waiting for Jonathan to come back. I was very anxious about him, and I was powerless to act; my feet, and my hands, and my brain were weighted, so that nothing could proceed at the usual pace. And so I slept uneasily and thought. Then it began to dawn upon me that the air was heavy, and dank, and cold. I put back the clothes from my face, and found, to my surprise, that all was dim around. The gaslight which I had left lit for Jonathan, but turned down, came only like a tiny red spark through the fog, which had evidently grown thicker and poured into the room. Then it occurred to me that I had shut the window before I had come to bed. I would have got out to make certain on the point, but some leaden lethargy seemed to chain my limbs and even my will. I lay still and endured; that was all. I closed my eyes, but could still see through my eyelids. (It is wonderful what tricks our dreams play us, and how conveniently we can imagine.) The mist grew thicker and thicker and I could see now how it came in, for I could see it like smoke—or with the white energy of boiling water—pouring in, not through the window, but through the joinings of the door. It got thicker and thicker, till it seemed as if it became concentrated into a sort of pillar of cloud in the room, through the top of which I could see the light of the gas shining like a red eye. Things began to whirl through my brain just as the cloudy column was now whirling in the room, and through it all came the scriptural words “a pillar of cloud by day and of fire by night.” Was it indeed some such spiritual guidance that was coming to me in my sleep? But the pillar was composed of both the day and the night-guiding, for the fire was in the red eye, which at the thought got a new fascination for me; till, as I looked, the fire divided, and seemed to shine on me through the fog like two red eyes, such as Lucy told me of in her momentary mental wandering when, on the cliff, the dying sunlight struck the windows of St. Mary’s Church. Suddenly the horror burst upon me that it was thus that Jonathan had seen those awful women growing into reality through the whirling mist in the moonlight, and in my dream I must have fainted, for all became black darkness. The last conscious effort which imagination made was to show me a livid white face bending over me out of the mist. I must be careful of such dreams, for they would unseat one’s reason if there were too much of them. I would get Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward to prescribe something for me which would make me sleep, only that I fear to alarm them. Such a dream at the present time would become woven into their fears for me. To-night I shall strive hard to sleep naturally. If I do not, I shall to-morrow night get them to give me a dose of chloral; that cannot hurt me for once, and it will give me a good night’s sleep. Last night tired me more than if I had not slept at all.
vi: ... I fell into a deep sleep, dreaming that I was waiting for Jonathan to return. I was terribly worried about him, but I couldn't move to get up and follow my own will: my limbs, and even my head, suddenly felt numb under a very heavy weight pressing down on me. In the dream, I felt very uncomfortable and couldn't control my thoughts. At that moment, I had the sensation that the air around me had a heavy, damp, and chilling smell. I threw off the blanket and was astonished to find the room engulfed in darkness. The lamp I had dimmed while waiting for Jonathan was now just a small, reddish dot, emitting a light barely enough to see through an increasingly thick fog in the room. Even though I clearly remembered closing the window before going to sleep, I still wanted to check it again, but my limbs felt as if they were made of wood, unable to move. What could I do now? I had closed my eyes, but it seemed as though I could still see through my eyelids (dreams often have such peculiarities). The fog kept getting thicker, and now I realized how that eerie mist had entered the room: it didn't come through the window like smoke or steam, but through the gaps in the door. A moment later, the fog gradually transformed into a column of cloud - yes, if I could call it that - rising high to the ceiling, and at the top of the cloud, there seemed to be the light of a small, blood-red eye. Everything suddenly went topsy-turvy in my head. The denser the column of cloud became in the room, the more clearly I could read the words "Pillar of cloud by day, pillar of fire by night" through the fog, as written in the Bible. Could this be a warning I received in my sleep? The pillar of cloud was formed by two elements, day and night, because there was a fiery light in the red eye. The more I thought about it, the more I felt captivated by that image. A moment later, the red dot of fire suddenly split into two, like two eyes. That image reminded me of Lucy's words about the rays of the setting sun shining through the stained glass windows of St. Mary's Church when she and I sat on the cliff at Whitby. I was also shocked to recall Jonathan's experience of witnessing three monstrous creatures suddenly turning into dust under the moonlight and gradually transforming into three lascivious women. After that, I sank into a dark, murky sleep. In a final effort of imagination, I saw a pale face emerge from the mist and lean down close to me. Perhaps I should be wary of such dreams, because if they recur frequently, my mind will surely be seriously affected. I intend to ask Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward why I am sleeping so heavily, but I am just afraid they will worry unnecessarily. If I tell them about my dream, they will surely be even more worried about me. Tonight, I will try to sleep as comfortably as possible. If I still can't sleep, maybe tomorrow night I will ask them for a sedative pill. I think using it just once won't do any harm, and I will have a really peaceful night. A dream like the one I just had can only make me tired if I continue to suffer from insomnia.
tr: I thought I was asleep and waiting for Jonathan to arrive. I was very worried about him and had no strength to move; my feet, hands, and mind were heavy, so nothing could progress at its usual pace. Because of this, I slept a troubled sleep and thought. Then, it occurred to me that the air was heavy, humid, and cold. I covered my face with the blankets again and, in astonishment, saw that my surroundings were dim. The gas lamp I had left on for Jonathan but then dimmed, clearly appeared like a tiny red dot in the thickening mist seeping into the room. Then, I remembered that I had closed the window before getting into bed. Actually, I would have gotten up to be sure, but a kind of leaden weight seemed to chain my arms, legs, and even my will. I lay still and endured it; that was all; I closed my eyes but could still see through my eyelids. (How marvelous are the tricks our dreams play on us and our ability to imagine accordingly.) As the mist thickened more and more, I could now see how it was entering because it was seeping in not from the window but from the joints of the door, like smoke - or the white steam of boiling water. It continued to thicken until it seemed to form a column of cloud in the room, at the top of which I could see the gas lamp glowing like a red eye. The things in my head were swirling around just like the cloudy column in the room; among this, the phrase "Pillar of cloud by day, pillar of fire by night" from the Holy Bible came to mind. Was it really a kind of spiritual guide coming to me in my sleep? But this column was composed of both the guidance of night and day, because the fire, which gained a new allure for me upon reflection, was in the red eye; until, as I watched, the fire split and shone through the mist above me, just like the two red eyes Lucy mentioned during her momentary mental lapse when the setting sun's light hit the windows of Saint Mary Church on the slope. Suddenly, I was terrified, remembering that Jonathan had seen those dreadful women transform from mist into reality in the moonlight. The last conscious effort of my imagination was a very angry white face emerging from the mist and leaning over me. I must be careful of such dreams, for if they become numerous, they can take one's mind. If I weren't afraid of worrying them, I would ask Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward to prescribe me a sleeping aid. Such a dream right now would be woven into the fears they have for me. Tonight, I will try to sleep naturally. If I can't sleep, I will have them give me a dose of chloral tomorrow night; using it once won't harm me, and it will give me a good night's sleep. Last night tired me so much that I wouldn't be this exhausted even if I hadn't slept at all.
es: I thought I was asleep, waiting for Jonathan to return. I felt very anxious about him and couldn't do anything; my legs, arms, and body felt weighed down, so much so that I couldn't move as usual. Thus, I slept very restlessly and kept dreaming strange things. Then, I began to feel that the air was heavy, humid, and cold. I removed the sheets from my face and, to my great surprise, saw that everything was dark. The little gas lamp I had left on for Jonathan, though very dim, seemed like a tiny red spark through the mist, which had evidently grown denser and entered the room. Then, I remembered that I had closed the window before going to bed. I wanted to get up to make sure of it, but a leaden lethargy seemed to hold my limbs and my will. I remained motionless; that was all. I closed my eyes, but I could still see clearly through my eyelids (it's wonderful to see what tricks dreams have, and how logically our imagination sometimes works). The mist grew thicker and I could already see how it entered the room, as I saw it as if it were smoke... or like the white vapor of boiling water... entering, not through the window, but from under the door. It kept getting thicker until it seemed to concentrate into a column of vapor over which I could see the little light of the gas lamp shining like a reddish eye. Ideas crowded into my brain as the column of vapor began to dance in the room, and among all my thoughts came the phrases from the scriptures: "A column of vapor by night and of fire by day. " Was it some spiritual guide coming to me through the dream? But the column was composed of both the day guide and the night guide, for the fire was in the red eye which, thinking about it, fascinated me in a way, for as I watched it, the fire seemed to split and I saw it as if it were two red eyes, through the mist, just as Lucy had told me she had seen them in her mental wanderings, on the cliff, when the setting sun reflected in the windows of St. Mary's Church. Suddenly, I remembered in horror that this was how Jonathan had seen those horrible women of the mist materialize, spinning under the moonlight, and in my dream I must have fainted, for I found myself in the deepest darkness. The last conscious effort my imagination made was to make me see a livid face leaning over me, emerging from the mist. I must be careful with those dreams, as they can make a person's reason waver if they occur too frequently. I'm going to see Dr. Van Helsing or Dr. Seward to prescribe me something that will make me sleep deeply; the only bad thing is that I fear alarming them. A similar dream would mix at this moment with her fears for me. Tonight I must strive to sleep naturally. If I don't succeed, I must ensure that I get a dose of chloral for tomorrow night; that won't harm me for once and a good night's sleep will do me well. Today I woke up more fatigued than if I hadn't slept at all.

en: 2 October 10 p. m.—Last night I slept, but did not dream. I must have slept soundly, for I was not waked by Jonathan coming to bed; but the sleep has not refreshed me, for to-day I feel terribly weak and spiritless. I spent all yesterday trying to read, or lying down dozing. In the afternoon Mr. Renfield asked if he might see me. Poor man, he was very gentle, and when I came away he kissed my hand and bade God bless me. Some way it affected me much; I am crying when I think of him. This is a new weakness, of which I must be careful. Jonathan would be miserable if he knew I had been crying. He and the others were out till dinner-time, and they all came in tired. I did what I could to brighten them up, and I suppose that the effort did me good, for I forgot how tired I was. After dinner they sent me to bed, and all went off to smoke together, as they said, but I knew that they wanted to tell each other of what had occurred to each during the day; I could see from Jonathan’s manner that he had something important to communicate. I was not so sleepy as I should have been; so before they went I asked Dr. Seward to give me a little opiate of some kind, as I had not slept well the night before. He very kindly made me up a sleeping draught, which he gave to me, telling me that it would do me no harm, as it was very mild.... I have taken it, and am waiting for sleep, which still keeps aloof. I hope I have not done wrong, for as sleep begins to flirt with me, a new fear comes: that I may have been foolish in thus depriving myself of the power of waking. I might want it. Here comes sleep. Good-night.
vi: • October 2, 10 PM Last night, I slept very deeply and did not have any dreams. However, the deep sleep still did not refresh me, and today I still feel quite tired and exhausted. All day yesterday, I tried to read but couldn't because of drowsiness. In the afternoon, Renfield asked to see me. The poor man was very kind when talking to me, and even when saying goodbye, he kissed my hand and prayed for God's blessing upon me. Suddenly, I felt such pity for him that I almost cried. Once again, I told myself to hide this weakness, because if Jonathan knew I cried, he would be immensely sad. Jonathan and his friends only returned close to dinner time with very tired faces. I did everything I could to help them feel less tired, and considered it a comfort that helped me gradually forget my own fatigue. After dinner, they advised me to go to bed and rest, while they would go outside to smoke and relax, but I knew well that they wanted to go out and inform each other about the work each had done during the day. Looking at Jonathan, I guessed that he had just discovered something very important. Lying in bed, I felt that I couldn't sleep, so I asked Dr. Seward for a mild sedative. I explained to him that I hadn't slept well the previous night. He gave me a pill that he said was very mild and had no side effects...I took it and lay down waiting for sleep. Not long after, I felt as if I was about to fall asleep...But that was also when I was gripped by a fear: was I sure I hadn't made a mistake in taking that pill? Perhaps it would be better if I stayed awake all night! But it was too late...I was sinking into an unavoidable sleep...Goodbye!
tr: 2 October, 10 PM. - I slept last night, but I didn't dream. I must have slept deeply; I didn't wake up when Jonathan came to bed; but the sleep didn't refresh me, because today I feel terribly weak and unwell. Yesterday, I spent the whole day either trying to read or lying down and dozing. In the afternoon, Mr. Renfield asked if he could see me. The poor man was very kind and kissed my hand, wishing God's protection upon me as he left. This affected me greatly in some way; whenever I think of him, I cry. This is a new weakness I need to be careful about. If Jonathan knew I was crying, he would be devastated. He and the others were out until dinner and they all returned tired. I did my best to cheer them up and I think this effort did me good, because I forgot how tired I was. After dinner, they sent me to bed and said they were all going out to smoke together, but I knew they wanted to tell each other what had happened to them during the day; from Jonathan's demeanor, I could see he had something important he wanted to share. I wasn't as sleepy as I should have been; therefore, before they left, I asked Dr. Seward to give me some kind of sleeping medicine because I hadn't slept well the previous night. He kindly prepared a sleeping draught for me, assuring me it was very mild and wouldn't harm me... I took the medicine and am still waiting for the distant sleep to come. I hope I haven't made a mistake because when sleep starts to court me, a new fear arises: I hope I haven't been foolish by depriving myself of the power to wake up. I might want to wake up. Here comes sleep. Good night.
es: October 2nd, at ten o'clock at night. Last night I slept, but I did not dream. I must have slept deeply, since I did not wake up when Jonathan went to bed, but the sleep did not do me as much good as I would have wished, since today I have felt weak and discouraged. I spent all of yesterday trying to sleep or lying down, dozing. In the afternoon, Mr. Renfield asked if he could see me. Poor man! He was very kind, and as he left, he kissed my hand and prayed to God to bless me. In a way, that affected me a lot, and tears come to my eyes when I think of him. This is a new weakness that I have to worry about and take care of. Jonathan would be very sad if he knew that I had been crying. He and the others were out until dinner time, and they returned very tired. I did my best to cheer them up, and I think the effort did me good, since I forgot how tired I was myself. After dinner, they sent me to bed and all went out to smoke together, as they said, but I knew perfectly well that what they wanted was to tell each other what had happened to each of them during the day; I understood from Jonathan's attitude that he had something very important to communicate to them. I wasn't as sleepy as I should have been; therefore, before they left, I asked Dr. Seward to give me some kind of sleeping pill, as I hadn't slept well the night before. With great skill, he prepared a sedative drug for me and gave it to me, telling me that it wouldn't cause any harm, as it was very mild... I have taken it and am waiting for sleep to overcome me, which still seems somewhat distant. I hope I haven't done anything wrong, as when sleep begins to take hold of me, a new fear assails me; it is possible that I have made a mistake by depriving myself of the power to wake up. It is possible that I might need it. I am already sleepy. Good night!

en: CHAPTER XX
vi: CHAPTER 20
tr: XX
es: XX.– FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: XX.– FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: 1 October, evening.—I found Thomas Snelling in his house at Bethnal Green, but unhappily he was not in a condition to remember anything. The very prospect of beer which my expected coming had opened to him had proved too much, and he had begun too early on his expected debauch. I learned, however, from his wife, who seemed a decent, poor soul, that he was only the assistant to Smollet, who of the two mates was the responsible person. So off I drove to Walworth, and found Mr. Joseph Smollet at home and in his shirtsleeves, taking a late tea out of a saucer. He is a decent, intelligent fellow, distinctly a good, reliable type of workman, and with a headpiece of his own. He remembered all about the incident of the boxes, and from a wonderful dog’s-eared notebook, which he produced from some mysterious receptacle about the seat of his trousers, and which had hieroglyphical entries in thick, half-obliterated pencil, he gave me the destinations of the boxes. There were, he said, six in the cartload which he took from Carfax and left at 197, Chicksand Street, Mile End New Town, and another six which he deposited at Jamaica Lane, Bermondsey. If then the Count meant to scatter these ghastly refuges of his over London, these places were chosen as the first of delivery, so that later he might distribute more fully. The systematic manner in which this was done made me think that he could not mean to confine himself to two sides of London. He was now fixed on the far east of the northern shore, on the east of the southern shore, and on the south. The north and west were surely never meant to be left out of his diabolical scheme—let alone the City itself and the very heart of fashionable London in the south-west and west. I went back to Smollet, and asked him if he could tell us if any other boxes had been taken from Carfax.
vi: • October 1, evening I met Thomas Snelling at home, but unfortunately, he is a very forgetful person. Even though I had informed him in advance, he still went out to drink beer until he was completely drunk, not caring whether I would come or not. But in return, he had a very kind wife. After hearing my explanation, she advised me to go to Joseph Smollet's house to inquire. So I had to head up to Walworth Street again. I arrived when Smollet was sitting and having tea. He was a good-natured and intelligent worker, trustworthy enough for others to confide in about personal matters. He remembered very clearly the brawl that occurred when he came to pick up the goods at Carfax. After checking a tiny, frayed notebook, he immediately told me the address where the boxes of soil were received. He had transported a total of six boxes from Carfax to 179 Chicksand Street in Mile End New Town, and another six boxes to Jamaica Lane in Bermondsey. So if the plan was to distribute a few dirty boxes of soil in each location in London as a hideout, then Chicksand Street and Jamaica Lane were the first transit points that the Count used to later disperse them to other places. From this, it can be inferred that he was not just looking for a hideout in two areas of London. Therefore, I had to continue asking Smollet about the boxes of soil that had been transported away from Carfax.
tr: October 1, evening. I found Thomas Snelling at his home in Benthal Green, but unfortunately, he was in no condition to remember anything. Knowing that I would go there and give him beer money had tempted him, and he had gotten drunk early. However, from his wife, who seemed to be an honest, poor woman, I learned that the man carried the boxes together and that the authoritative Smollet was merely his assistant. Therefore, I went by carriage to Walworth and found Mr. Joseph Smollet at home, with his jacket off, drinking tea from a saucer. An honest and intelligent man, evidently a good and reliable worker, with a mind of his own. He remembered the entire incident regarding the boxes and gave the destinations of the boxes from a perfect notebook with curled corners, which he took out from a mysterious pocket at the back of his trousers, containing thick, semi-faded hieroglyph-like notes written with a pencil. He said there were six boxes he picked up from Carfax and loaded into the carriage, which he left at 197 Chicksand Street, Mile End New Town, and another six boxes he left at Jamaica Road, Bermondsey. If the Count intends to distribute these hideous refuges all over London, these places were chosen as the first delivery points, so that he could complete the distribution in more detail later. This systematic approach in the execution of this task made me think that he did not intend to limit himself to the two sides of London. Now he had settled at the eastern end of the north shore and the eastern end of the south shore and to the south. The north and west were never meant to be excluded from his diabolical plan - especially not the very center of the city and the favored parts of London, the southwest, and the southern hub. I started talking to Smollet again and asked him if he could tell me whether there were any other boxes taken from Carfax.
es: October 1st, at night. I found Thomas Snelling at his house in Bethnal Green; but, unfortunately, he was not in a condition to remember anything. The very lure of the beer that my anticipated visit had opened before him proved too strong, and he began to drink too soon, before my arrival. However, I learned from his wife, a decent and timid person, that he was only Smollet’s assistant, who was the responsible one of the two. So I headed towards Walworth and found Mr. Joseph Smollet at his house, in his shirtsleeves, having a late cup of tea, which he was lifting from a saucer. He is an honest and intelligent man, a trustworthy worker with an intelligence and personality of his own. He remembered everything about the incident with the boxes, and, pulling from a mysterious place at the back of his trousers a notebook with dog-eared pages covered in hieroglyphics drawn with a thick-tipped pencil and very heavy writing, he informed me of the destination of the boxes. There were six he had taken from Carfax and deposited at number one hundred and ninety-seven Chicksand Street, in Mile End New Town, and another six he had deposited in Jamaica Lane, Bermondsey. In the event that the Count wished to distribute his ghostly refuges throughout London, those places would have been chosen as starting points, so that he could then completely distribute the boxes. The systematic way in which all that was being carried out made me think that this could not mean that the monster wished to confine itself to two places in London. It was already situated in the eastern part of the north bank, to the east of the south coast, and to the south of the city. It was certain that it did not intend to leave out of its diabolical plans the north and the west... not to mention the City itself, and the very heart of elegant London, to the southwest and the west. I went back to see Smollet and asked him if he could tell us if any other box had been taken from Carfax.

en: He replied:—
vi: — Yes, sir, - He replied - you have been quite generous to me (since I slipped him half a gold coin) so I will tell you everything I know!
tr: He answered like this:
es: Then he replied:

en: “Well, guv’nor, you’ve treated me wery ’an’some”—I had given him half a sovereign—“an’ I’ll tell yer all I know. I heard a man by the name of Bloxam say four nights ago in the ’Are an’ ’Ounds, in Pincher’s Alley, as ’ow he an’ his mate ’ad ’ad a rare dusty job in a old ’ouse at Purfect. There ain’t a-many such jobs as this ’ere, an’ I’m thinkin’ that maybe Sam Bloxam could tell ye summut.” I asked if he could tell me where to find him. I told him that if he could get me the address it would be worth another half-sovereign to him. So he gulped down the rest of his tea and stood up, saying that he was going to begin the search then and there. At the door he stopped, and said:—
vi: — Yes, sir, - He replied - you have been quite generous to me (since I slipped him half a gold coin) so I will tell you everything I know! Four days ago, while drinking at the Hare and Hounds pub in the Pincher valley, I heard a guy named Bloxam say that he and another driver had entered an old house in Purfleet to work and ended up swallowing kilos of dust! You see, this kind of dirty work doesn't happen every day. I think Sam Bloxam might also be able to provide you with some information about what you want to know! — If Smollet tells me the address of the guy named Sam Bloxam, - as I promised him - I will give him the remaining half of the gold coin. Hearing my promise, he quickly drank the remaining tea in the cup and stood up, declaring that he would go everywhere to find that driver. Seeing me to the door, he told me:
tr: "Well boss, you treated me very well," -I had given him half a gold coin- "and I will tell you everything I know. I heard a man named Bloxam telling his friend at the Hare and Hounds Tavern in Pincher’s Alley about four nights ago that he did a very dusty job at the old house in Purfleet. There aren't many such jobs around here, and I think maybe Sam Bloxam can tell you something." I asked him where I could find this man. I told him that if he could find the address for me, it would be worth another half gold coin. So, he finished the rest of his tea in one gulp and stood up, saying he would start investigating right away. He stopped at the door and said:
es: "Well, sir, you have treated me very well," he had given him half a sovereign, "and I am going to tell you everything I know." "I heard a man named Bloxam saying four nights ago at the 'Are and Ounds' in Pincer's Alley that he and his partner had a dirty and strange job in an old house in Purfleet." "Jobs of that kind are not frequent here, and I think Sam Bloxam might be able to tell you more about it." I asked him if it was possible for him to tell me where I could find him. I told him that if he could get me the address, I would be very happy to give him another half-sovereign. So he took the rest of his tea in one gulp and stood up, saying he was going to start his inquiries. He stopped at the door and said:

en: “Look ’ere, guv’nor, there ain’t no sense in me a-keepin’ you ’ere. I may find Sam soon, or I mayn’t; but anyhow he ain’t like to be in a way to tell ye much to-night. Sam is a rare one when he starts on the booze. If you can give me a envelope with a stamp on it, and put yer address on it, I’ll find out where Sam is to be found and post it ye to-night. But ye’d better be up arter ’im soon in the mornin’, or maybe ye won’t ketch ’im; for Sam gets off main early, never mind the booze the night afore.”
vi: — You see, I have no reason to keep you here. I can find this Sam guy right away, but maybe not. In any case, it won't be possible tonight. It's really hard to get anything out of this guy once he's had his fill of alcohol. If you leave me a stamped envelope with your address on it, I'll let you know as soon as I find out where he is. For now, I can only tell you this: it's best to meet him early in the morning, otherwise it will be quite difficult, because he usually wakes up very early and only comes home at midnight, completely drunk.
tr: “Listen, boss, there's no point in keeping you here. I might find Sam soon or I might not, but in any case, he won't be able to tell you much tonight. When Sam starts drinking, he becomes quite a rare character. If you can give me an envelope with a stamp and your address on it, I can find out where Sam might be tonight and mail it to you. But you'd better start looking for him early in the morning or you might not catch him, because Sam gets up early no matter how much he drank the night before.”
es: –Listen, sir, it doesn't make sense for you to wait here. It's possible that you'll find Sam soon, or maybe you won't, but either way, I don't think he'll be in a condition to tell you much tonight. Sam is a strange guy when he gets upset. If you can give me an envelope with a postage stamp and your address, I'll see where I can find Sam and send you the information by mail tonight. But you'll need to go see him very early in the morning if you want to find him, since Sam gets up early, no matter how long the previous night's party lasted.

en: This was all practical, so one of the children went off with a penny to buy an envelope and a sheet of paper, and to keep the change. When she came back, I addressed the envelope and stamped it, and when Smollet had again faithfully promised to post the address when found, I took my way to home. We’re on the track anyhow. I am tired to-night, and want sleep. Mina is fast asleep, and looks a little too pale; her eyes look as though she had been crying. Poor dear, I’ve no doubt it frets her to be kept in the dark, and it may make her doubly anxious about me and the others. But it is best as it is. It is better to be disappointed and worried in such a way now than to have her nerve broken. The doctors were quite right to insist on her being kept out of this dreadful business. I must be firm, for on me this particular burden of silence must rest. I shall not ever enter on the subject with her under any circumstances. Indeed, it may not be a hard task, after all, for she herself has become reticent on the subject, and has not spoken of the Count or his doings ever since we told her of our decision.
vi: Listening to this guy talk, it seemed to make sense, so I asked his daughter to quickly run and buy an envelope and a stamp for me. In just a moment, the girl returned with what I needed in her hands. I carefully wrote the address, affixed the stamp, and handed the envelope to the kind homeowner. Before leaving, I repeatedly reminded him that as soon as there was any news, he had to inform me immediately. So finally, the mystery is beginning to be unraveled! Gradually, step by step, one step at a time. Tonight, I suddenly feel so tired, just wanting to go to sleep immediately. Mina is deeply asleep, she looks even paler than the day before, and her eyes are swollen as if she had just cried. Poor girl, ever since we stopped informing her about our plans and intentions, she seems even more worried and restless than before. However, we were right to make such a decision! It's better for her to be disappointed and anxious for a few days than to experience extreme tension when participating in our work. The two doctors were really right when they advised me to keep her out of this dangerous game. The important thing for me right now is to keep everything secret, no matter the reason, I must not let anything slip out. I fully understand the burden of silence that is placed on my shoulders. But after all, I don't believe it's something terribly difficult to do, because at this moment, it seems Mina herself doesn't want to mention our work anymore. Indeed, since we decided to let her rest, I haven't seen her mention or hint at anything about Dracula and his schemes anymore.
tr: This was very convenient; thus, one of the children went to get an envelope and a sheet of paper with a penny and kept the change for themselves. When the girl came back, I wrote the address on the envelope and stuck the stamp, and after Smollet once again promised to mail it when he found the address, I headed home. One way or another, we are on the trail. I am tired tonight and want to sleep. Mina is in a deep sleep and looks a bit too pale; her eyes look as if she has been crying. Poor darling, I have no doubt that the thought of secrets being kept from her worries her; this might cause her to worry twice as much for me and the others. But this is for the best. Experiencing disappointment and worry in this way is better than having her nerves shattered. I must be resolute as I carry this special burden of silence on my shoulders. Under no circumstances should I discuss this matter with her. To be honest, this might not be a difficult task, as she has been reticent about this matter for a while and has not spoken about the Count or his actions since we explained our decision to her.
es: That turned out to be practical, so one of the children went out with a penny to buy an envelope and a sheet of paper, and I gave him the change. When he returned, I addressed the envelope and put the stamp on it, and when Smollet promised me again that he would send me the address by mail as soon as he discovered it, I headed home. Anyway, we are on the trail. Tonight I feel tired and wish to sleep. Mina is deeply asleep and looks too pale; her eyes give the impression that she has been crying. Poor woman, I am sure it is very hard for her to remain in ignorance and that it may make her feel doubly anxious for me and for everyone else. But it is better this way. It is better to feel disappointed and anxious than to have shattered nerves. The doctors were right to insist that she should stay out of this whole terrible matter. I must remain firm, since the burden of silence must weigh mainly on me. I cannot even mention the subject to her, under any circumstances. In fact, I don't think it will be a difficult and hard task after all, since she herself has become reticent on that subject and has not spoken of the count or his actions since we informed her of our decision.

en: 2 October, evening.—A long and trying and exciting day. By the first post I got my directed envelope with a dirty scrap of paper enclosed, on which was written with a carpenter’s pencil in a sprawling hand:—
vi: • October 2 A day of exhaustion, stress that seemed never-ending. This morning, I received a letter addressed in my own handwriting. Inside the envelope was just a sloppily torn piece of paper with a scrawled address in pencil, the letters as big as hen's eggs:
tr: 2 October, evening. - A long, challenging, and exciting day. With the first mail, an envelope arrived with a dirty piece of paper stuffed inside, previously addressed; on the paper, written with a carpenter's pencil and in large handwriting, it said:
es: October 2nd, at night. It was a long, exciting day, and one that proved to be a real test. In the first mail, I received the letter intended for me, which contained a dirty sheet of paper, on which had been written with a carpenter's pencil and a very heavy hand: "Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters Cort, Bartel Street, Walworth.

en: “Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters Cort, Bartel Street, Walworth. Arsk for the depite.”
vi: Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters, Court, Bartel Street, Walworth. Ask the director.
tr: Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, Poters Square, Bartel Street, No: 4 Walworth. Ask for the assistant.
es: In the first mail, I received the letter intended for me, which contained a dirty sheet of paper, on which had been written with a carpenter's pencil and a very heavy hand: "Sam Bloxam, Korkrans, 4, Poters Cort, Bartel Street, Walworth. Ask for the bailiff."

en: I got the letter in bed, and rose without waking Mina. She looked heavy and sleepy and pale, and far from well. I determined not to wake her, but that, when I should return from this new search, I would arrange for her going back to Exeter. I think she would be happier in our own home, with her daily tasks to interest her, than in being here amongst us and in ignorance. I only saw Dr. Seward for a moment, and told him where I was off to, promising to come back and tell the rest so soon as I should have found out anything. I drove to Walworth and found, with some difficulty, Potter’s Court. Mr. Smollet’s spelling misled me, as I asked for Poter’s Court instead of Potter’s Court. However, when I had found the court, I had no difficulty in discovering Corcoran’s lodging-house. When I asked the man who came to the door for the “depite,” he shook his head, and said: “I dunno ’im. There ain’t no such a person ’ere; I never ’eard of ’im in all my bloomin’ days. Don’t believe there ain’t nobody of that kind livin’ ere or anywheres.” I took out Smollet’s letter, and as I read it it seemed to me that the lesson of the spelling of the name of the court might guide me. “What are you?” I asked.
vi: After reading the letter while still lying in bed, I quietly got up so as not to wake Mina. In her sleep, she looked even paler and more exhausted than when she was awake. Waking her now would be wrong, but another thought came to mind: after today's investigation, I will try to persuade her to return to Exeter. I think at home, even if she has to be busy with household chores, she would feel happier than being here with us without the right to know what is happening. Before leaving the house, I only met Dr. Seward and informed him where I was going today, what I was doing, and when finished, I would try to return as early as possible to report the results to the whole group. When I arrived in Walworth, I suddenly became confused about finding the Potter Court. Smollet's sloppy and misspelled writing made me search for the wrong address all over the place. However, once I found the Potter Court, I just had to go straight to the Corcoran house. The homeowner informed me that yesterday, Bloxam came here, got drunk, and slept over, but at five o'clock this morning, he went straight to his workplace in Polar. Corcoran couldn't remember the exact location of the storage warehouse I wanted to ask about to find Bloxam; he only vaguely recalled that it was a "new and modernly built house." This was the only information I could get before heading to Polar. It wasn't until almost noon that I found the house I was looking for, thanks to the directions from a worker resting in a café; it was a "vast new warehouse." I casually asked the gatekeeper and a foreman.
tr: I had received the letter while I was in bed and got up without waking Mina. She was like in a daze, sleepy and pale, and she didn't look well at all. I had decided not to wake her, but when I return from this new investigation, I will make arrangements for her return to Exeter. I think she will be happier in her own home, engaged with her own daily affairs, unaware of everything happening here between us. I only saw Dr. Seward for a moment and told him where I was going, promising to come back and tell the others as soon as I found something. I went to Walworth by car and, with some difficulty, found Poters Square. Mr. Smollet's poor handwriting had misled me because I had asked for Poter's Square instead of Potter's Square. But once I found the square, I had no trouble discovering the Corcoran Boarding House. When I asked the man who came to the door for the "assistant," he shook his head and said, "I don't know. There's no such person here; I haven't heard of anyone like that in my damn life. I don't think there's such a person here or anywhere else." I took out Smollet's letter, and the spelling lesson I received regarding the name of the square seemed like it might guide me. "What's your duty?" I asked.
es: I received the letter in bed and got up, without waking Mina. She was pale and seemed to be sleeping heavily and deeply. I thought not to wake her, but as soon as I returned from that investigation, I would make the necessary arrangements for her to return to Exeter. I believe she will be happier in our own home, engaging in her daily tasks, than being here, among us, in ignorance of everything that is happening. I only saw Dr. Seward for a moment and told him where I was going, promising to return to explain everything else as soon as I could discover something. I headed to Walworth and found Potter's Court with some difficulty. Mr. Smollet's spelling misled me, as I first asked for Poter's Court instead of Potter's Court. However, when I found the address, I had no difficulty finding the Corcoran boarding house. When I asked the man who came to the door about the "bailiff," he shook his head and said: –I don't know him. There is no such person here; I have never heard of him in my entire life. I don't think there is anyone like that living here or nearby. I took out Smollet's letter and upon reading it, it seemed to me that the lesson on spelling with which the address was written might help me. –Who are you? – I asked him.

en: “I’m the depity,” he answered. I saw at once that I was on the right track; phonetic spelling had again misled me. A half-crown tip put the deputy’s knowledge at my disposal, and I learned that Mr. Bloxam, who had slept off the remains of his beer on the previous night at Corcoran’s, had left for his work at Poplar at five o’clock that morning. He could not tell me where the place of work was situated, but he had a vague idea that it was some kind of a “new-fangled ware’us”; and with this slender clue I had to start for Poplar. It was twelve o’clock before I got any satisfactory hint of such a building, and this I got at a coffee-shop, where some workmen were having their dinner. One of these suggested that there was being erected at Cross Angel Street a new “cold storage” building; and as this suited the condition of a “new-fangled ware’us,” I at once drove to it. An interview with a surly gatekeeper and a surlier foreman, both of whom were appeased with the coin of the realm, put me on the track of Bloxam; he was sent for on my suggesting that I was willing to pay his day’s wages to his foreman for the privilege of asking him a few questions on a private matter. He was a smart enough fellow, though rough of speech and bearing. When I had promised to pay for his information and given him an earnest, he told me that he had made two journeys between Carfax and a house in Piccadilly, and had taken from this house to the latter nine great boxes—“main heavy ones”—with a horse and cart hired by him for this purpose. I asked him if he could tell me the number of the house in Piccadilly, to which he replied:—
vi: They were indeed very difficult and rude people. However, when I slipped each of them a coin, their attitudes changed immediately. And when I promised to pay the foreman a day's wage if he allowed me to meet Bloxam to ask him a few personal questions, he sent someone to fetch Bloxam right away. Bloxam was a rough and straightforward young man. I proactively promised to pay him for all the information he provided. Just waiting for that, he immediately told me that on the route from Carfax to a house in Piccadilly, he had to make two trips to transport all nine brand-new crates - all large and very heavy - using a rented horse-drawn carriage. But when asked about the house number in Piccadilly, he couldn't answer.
tr: “I am an assistant,” he said. I immediately realized I was on the right track; the way Smollet had written it had misled me once again. A half-crown tip made the assistant share what he knew, and I learned that Mr. Bloxam, who was recovering from the beers he drank the night he spent in Corcoran, had left for his job in Poplar at five o'clock this morning. He couldn't tell me where that place or job was, but he had a vague idea that it was one of those "newfangled warehouses," and with this weak clue, I had to set off for Poplar. It was twelve o'clock by the time I found a satisfactory indication of such a building, and I found it in a restaurant where some workers were having their lunch. One of these men suggested that a new "cold storage warehouse" was being built on Cross Angel Street; and since this fit the description of a "newfangled warehouse," I immediately went there by carriage. A tense conversation with a grim-faced guard and an even grimmer-faced foreman, whose cooperation I secured by offering to pay his daily wage, led me to Bloxam; the man was summoned after I indicated I was willing to pay the foreman to allow me to ask a few personal questions. Despite his rough speech and demeanor, he was a fairly intelligent man. When I told him I would pay for the information and gave him an advance, he said he had made two trips between a house in Carfax and one in Piccadilly, transporting nine large crates - "really heavy things" - from the first house to the second with a horse and cart he had hired for this purpose. When I asked him to tell me the number of the house in Piccadilly, he responded:
es: –I am the sheriff -he replied. I immediately understood that I was on safe ground. The spelling with which the letter was written deceived me again. A half-crown tip made the constable's knowledge available to me, and I learned that Mr. Bloxam had slept at the Corcaran house to dispel the fumes of the beer he had drunk the night before, but had gone to his work in Poplar at five in the morning. He could not tell me the exact place where he worked, but he had a vague idea that it was some new warehouse, and with that extremely slight clue, I set off for Poplar. It was already twelve before I managed to get directions to a similar building, and it was in a café where I got the information. There were several women eating in the lounge. One of them told me that they were constructing a new "refrigerated warehouse" building on Cross Angel Street, and since it matched the constable's description, I headed there immediately. An interview with a rather surly guard and an even more ill-tempered foreman, whose mood I improved slightly with the help of some coins, put me on Bloxam's trail; they sent for him when I suggested that I was willing to pay the foreman his full day's wages for the privilege of asking him a few questions about a private matter. He was a fairly intelligent fellow, though somewhat rough in manner and speech. When I promised to pay him for his reports and gave him an advance, he told me that he had made two trips between Carfax and a house in Piccadilly and that he had taken nine large boxes, "very heavy," from the first address to the last with a cart and horse he had rented for the job. I asked him if he could tell me the number of the house in Piccadilly, to which he replied:

en: “Well, guv’nor, I forgits the number, but it was only a few doors from a big white church or somethink of the kind, not long built. It was a dusty old ’ouse, too, though nothin’ to the dustiness of the ’ouse we tooked the bloomin’ boxes from.”
vi: — It's really frustrating, boss, I don't understand why I completely forgot the house number, but I can tell you that the house I have to deliver the crates to is only two or three houses away from a whitewashed church, or something that looks like a church. It's a shabby house full of dust, but in fact, the dust here is nothing compared to the house I have to go to pick up the goods.
tr: “Well, boss, I forget the numbers, but it was only a few buildings past a big white church or something like that. It was also an old, dusty house, though not as dusty as the damn house where we picked up the crates.”
es: –Well, sir, I have forgotten the number, but it was a few doors away from a large white church, or something similar, that was built not long ago. It was an old, dusty house, though not as dusty as the house from which I took the boxes.

en: “How did you get into the houses if they were both empty?”
vi: — So how did you get into these two houses if there was no one living there?
tr: “If both were vacant at the time, how did you get into the houses?”
es: –How did you manage to get in, if both houses were unoccupied?

en: “There was the old party what engaged me a-waitin’ in the ’ouse at Purfleet. He ’elped me to lift the boxes and put them in the dray. Curse me, but he was the strongest chap I ever struck, an’ him a old feller, with a white moustache, one that thin you would think he couldn’t throw a shadder.”
vi: — The old shopkeeper waited for me in the house at Purneet and helped me load the crates onto the vehicle. Oh, my goodness! How is he so strong? I must say he is the strongest person I have ever met in my life, even though his beard was as white as snow, and he was so thin and frail that one might think he couldn't even push over a shadow! I suddenly felt a shiver.
tr: “There was an old man waiting for me at the house in Purfleet. He helped me lift the crates and load them into the car. By God, even though he was a thin old man with a white mustache, he was the strongest man I've ever met.”
es: –The old man who hired me was waiting for me at the house in Purfleet. He helped me lift the boxes and place them on the cart. He insulted me, but he was the strongest guy I've ever seen. He was an old man, with white mustaches so fine that they were almost unnoticeable.

en: How this phrase thrilled through me!
vi: — Yes!
tr: How these words frightened me.
es: That phrase made me jump!

en: “Why, ’e took up ’is end o’ the boxes like they was pounds of tea, and me a-puffin’ an’ a-blowin’ afore I could up-end mine anyhow—an’ I’m no chicken, neither.”
vi: The old man lifted the wooden crates as if they were just packets of tea, while I had to pant like a pig and strain with all my might just to lift one end. And I am not some old geezer!
tr: “The man lifted one end of the chests as if he were carrying tea, but I had already started huffing and puffing before I could lift the end I was holding - and I'm no weakling either.”
es: –He took one end of the box as if it were a tea set, while I took the other, sweating and panting like a bear. It took me a great effort to lift my part, but I managed it and… I'm not a weakling either.

en: “How did you get into the house in Piccadilly?” I asked.
vi: — So how did you get into the house on Piccadilly? - I asked.
tr: “How did you get into the house on Piccadilly?” I asked.
es: –How did you manage to get into the house on Piccadilly?

en: “He was there too. He must ’a’ started off and got there afore me, for when I rung of the bell he kem an’ opened the door ’isself an’ ’elped me to carry the boxes into the ’all.”
vi: — When I arrived, he was already there. He must have driven very fast on the road to get there before me, because when I rang the bell, he was the one who opened the door and he was also the one who helped me carry the boxes into the hallway.
tr: “The same man was there too. He must have set out before me and arrived there, because when I rang the bell, he came and opened the door and helped me carry the crates into the hall.”
es: –He was waiting for me there as well. He must have left immediately and arrived there before me, because when I knocked on the door, he himself came out to open it and helped me unload the boxes in the vestibule.

en: “The whole nine?” I asked.
vi: — Are there nine crates in total? — Nine barrels.
tr: “All nine of them?” I asked.
es: – Nine o'clock? – I asked him.

en: “Yus; there was five in the first load an’ four in the second. It was main dry work, an’ I don’t so well remember ’ow I got ’ome.” I interrupted him:—
vi: The first trip was one barrel; the next trip was four barrels. It was truly a laborious task! And I don't understand why the work made me so thirsty! At that time, I kept wondering how I managed to crawl back home.
tr: “Yes; there were five in the first load, and four in the second load. It was quite a thirst-inducing job, and I don't really remember how I got home.” I interrupted:
es: –Yes; I took five on the first trip and four on the second. It was very hard work, and I don't quite remember how I got back home. I interrupted him:

en: “Were the boxes left in the hall?”
vi: — Have you brought the wooden crates into the hallway?
tr: “Were the boxes left in the hallway?”
es: –Did the boxes stay in the lobby?

en: “Yus; it was a big ’all, an’ there was nothin’ else in it.” I made one more attempt to further matters:—
vi: — Yes. It was an empty hallway, without any furniture.
tr: "Yes; it was a large hold and there was nothing but crates." I made another attempt to gain more information:
es: –Yes; it was a very spacious room, and there was nothing else in it. I made another attempt to learn more about it.

en: “You didn’t have any key?”
vi: — You don't have a key either?
tr: "Didn't you have the key?""
es: –Didn't he give you any key?

en: “Never used no key nor nothink. The old gent, he opened the door ’isself an’ shut it again when I druv off. I don’t remember the last time—but that was the beer.”
vi: — No keys! Nothing at all. The old man himself was the one who opened the door and then locked it when I left. To be honest, this is the latest time I can't remember everything because of the beer...
tr: “I never used a key or anything like that. The old man opened the door and he closed it as he drove away. I don't remember the last trip - because of the beer.”
es: –I didn't need any key. The old man opened the door for me and closed it again when I left. I don't remember anything from the second time, but that's because of the beer.

en: “And you can’t remember the number of the house?”
vi: — So you really don't remember the house number??
tr: “And you can't remember the house number, can you?”
es: –And you don't remember the house number?

en: “No, sir. But ye needn’t have no difficulty about that. It’s a ’igh ’un with a stone front with a bow on it, an’ ’igh steps up to the door. I know them steps, ’avin’ ’ad to carry the boxes up with three loafers what come round to earn a copper. The old gent give them shillin’s, an’ they seein’ they got so much, they wanted more; but ’e took one of them by the shoulder and was like to throw ’im down the steps, till the lot of them went away cussin’.” I thought that with this description I could find the house, so, having paid my friend for his information, I started off for Piccadilly. I had gained a new painful experience; the Count could, it was evident, handle the earth-boxes himself. If so, time was precious; for, now that he had achieved a certain amount of distribution, he could, by choosing his own time, complete the task unobserved. At Piccadilly Circus I discharged my cab, and walked westward; beyond the Junior Constitutional I came across the house described, and was satisfied that this was the next of the lairs arranged by Dracula. The house looked as though it had been long untenanted. The windows were encrusted with dust, and the shutters were up. All the framework was black with time, and from the iron the paint had mostly scaled away. It was evident that up to lately there had been a large notice-board in front of the balcony; it had, however, been roughly torn away, the uprights which had supported it still remaining. Behind the rails of the balcony I saw there were some loose boards, whose raw edges looked white. I would have given a good deal to have been able to see the notice-board intact, as it would, perhaps, have given some clue to the ownership of the house. I remembered my experience of the investigation and purchase of Carfax, and I could not but feel that if I could find the former owner there might be some means discovered of gaining access to the house.
vi: — No, sir, but it should be easy to find! The house is tall, with a stone facade, low windows, and steps outside. I remember these steps because I had to carry the boxes up with three country lads who offered to help me in hopes of earning a few coins. The old man gave them a few shillings. Seeing an opportunity, they tried to ask for more, but the old man wouldn't have it. They were almost kicked down the stairs by the old man if they hadn't run away in time, cursing as they went. Thinking like that was enough to find the house, so I paid Bloxam and made my way to Piccadilly. What I had just learned left me bewildered: the count could lift the wooden crates filled with earth by himself! Every minute passing now was very precious to me. Because it was very likely that he had already scattered the crates, one in each place, at the time he had chosen beforehand so that no one would notice. Upon reaching Piccadilly Circus, I got off the carriage and headed straight towards the west of the neighborhood. Just past the Juvenile Court, I immediately recognized the house I was looking for. I had no doubt that it was one of Count Dracula's lairs in England. The house seemed to have been abandoned for a very long time. The arched windows were all open, but every window was covered in a layer of dust. The dust of time had turned the wooden panels black and the iron decorations into objects that looked like they were made of earth. Looking at the balcony wall, I guessed there must have been a sign with the address and house name that had just been torn off, as the traces were still very fresh. I would have more information if that sign were still intact: it would tell me the name of the house's owner. I still remember how I gathered information to secure the brokerage contract for the Carfax house for Dracula before, and now I also believe that if I knew the previous owner of the house, I would be able to get inside.
tr: “No, sir. But you won't have any trouble finding it. It's a tall building with an arched entrance and high steps leading to the door. I know those steps because I carried crates up them with three idlers who came to earn a few pence. The old man gave them each a shilling, and when they saw how much they got, they wanted more; but the man grabbed one of them by the shoulder and almost threw him down the stairs until they cursed and ran away.” I thought I could find the house with this description, so I paid my friend for the information and set off for Piccadilly. I had learned a new, painful fact: Apparently, the Count could carry the earth boxes by himself. If so, time was very precious, because now that he had ensured a certain number of distributions, he could complete the task unnoticed by choosing his own timing. I got out of the cab at Piccadilly Circus and walked west; behind the Junior Constitutional, I came across the described house and was convinced that this was the next refuge arranged by Dracula. The house looked like it hadn't been lived in for a long time. The windows were covered in dust, and the shutters were open. All the frames had darkened over time, and most of the paint on the iron had peeled off. It was clear that there had been a large signboard in front of the balcony until recently, but it had been roughly removed, with the posts that held it still standing there. Behind the balcony railings, I saw some loose boards with unpolished white edges. I would have given a lot to see the signboard in its entirety, as it would probably have given some clues about the owner of the house. I recalled my experiences with the investigation and sale of Carfax and couldn't help but think that if I could find the previous owner, there might be a way to enter the house.
es: –No, sir. But you will have no difficulty finding it. It is a tall building, with a stone facade and a coat of arms, and quite high stairs that lead up to the entrance door. I remember those stairs because I had to climb them with the boxes, along with three boys who came over to earn a few pennies. The old man gave them shillings and, seeing that he had given them a lot, they wanted even more, but the old man grabbed one of them by the shoulder and almost threw him down the stairs; then, they all left, insulting him. I thought that with those reports I would have no trouble finding the house, so after paying my informant, I headed towards Piccadilly. I had acquired a new and painful experience. The count could apparently handle the boxes alone. If so, time was precious, since having carried out certain distributions, he could carry out the rest of his work, choosing the opportune time for it, going completely unnoticed. At Piccadilly Circus I got off and walked west; after passing the Junior Constitutional, I arrived at the house that had been described to me and was satisfied with the idea that this was the next refuge Dracula had chosen. The house seemed to have been unoccupied for a long time. The windows were full of dust and the shutters were raised. The entire structure was blackened by time, and the paint had disappeared from the metal parts. It was evident that there had been an advertisement on the upper balcony for some time, which had been abruptly removed, so that the vertical supports still remained. Behind the balcony railing, I saw several loose boards protruding, whose edges appeared white. I would have given much to see the advertisement intact, as it might have given me some indication as to the identity of its owner.
