I remembered my experience investigating and purchasing the Carfax house and couldn't help but think that if I could find the former owner, I might discover some means of entering the house.

en: There was at present nothing to be learned from the Piccadilly side, and nothing could be done; so I went round to the back to see if anything could be gathered from this quarter. The mews were active, the Piccadilly houses being mostly in occupation. I asked one or two of the grooms and helpers whom I saw around if they could tell me anything about the empty house. One of them said that he heard it had lately been taken, but he couldn’t say from whom. He told me, however, that up to very lately there had been a notice-board of “For Sale” up, and that perhaps Mitchell, Sons, & Candy, the house agents, could tell me something, as he thought he remembered seeing the name of that firm on the board. I did not wish to seem too eager, or to let my informant know or guess too much, so, thanking him in the usual manner, I strolled away. It was now growing dusk, and the autumn night was closing in, so I did not lose any time. Having learned the address of Mitchell, Sons, & Candy from a directory at the Berkeley, I was soon at their office in Sackville Street.
vi: So there's no reason to stay here any longer, what more can I know and do now? But I still made a round around the house, because who knows, I might find something interesting! The stables on the other side of the house were indeed bustling. I met a horse caretaker and asked him about the house. The information I received was that the house had been bought, but he didn't know who bought it. He also mentioned that about two or three days ago, there was a for-sale sign on the balcony, and if I asked the Mitchell, Sons & Candy agency, I might get the necessary information, as he clearly remembered reading the name of this real estate agency on the sign. Not wanting to attract attention, I had to thank the kind old man and leave without daring to ask more questions. It was getting dark, so I couldn't afford to waste time. Moreover, it's not like I didn't know the address of Mitchell, Sons & Candy; it's a brokerage with an office on Sackville Street. I needed to go there right away.
tr: At the moment, there was nothing more to learn or do on the Piccadilly side; therefore, I wandered to the back of the house to see if anything could be obtained from this area. Since most of the houses on Piccadilly were occupied, the stables were busy. I asked a couple of grooms and servants I saw if they could tell me anything about the empty house. One of them said he had heard that the house had been purchased recently, but he couldn't say from whom. But until recently, there had been a signboard saying "For Sale," and he suggested that the real estate agents Mitchell, Sons & Candy might be able to tell me something, as he thought he remembered seeing their name on the board. Not wanting to appear too eager or have my source guess too much, I thanked him in my usual manner and left. It was now beginning to get dark, and the autumn evening was setting in, so I wasted no time. Shortly after learning the address of Mitchell, Sons & Candy from an address book in Berkeley, I reached their offices on Sackville Street.
es: For the moment, there was nothing to discover on the Piccadilly side and nothing could be done, so I headed to the back to see if anything could be seen from that side. The stables were full of activity, as most of the houses were occupied. I asked a couple of servants and stable hands, whom I could find, if they could tell me anything about the unoccupied house. One of them told me he had heard that someone had bought it recently, but he did not know who the new owner was. One of them, however, told me that until very recently there had been a sign that said "for sale" and that it was possible that Mitchell, Sons Candy, the moving agents, could provide more details, as he believed he remembered that this was the name on the sign for all inquiries. I did not want to seem too eager to my informant, nor let him guess too much, so after giving him my most sincere thanks, I walked away. It was getting dark and the autumn night was setting in, so I did not want to waste time. After finding the address of Mitchell, Sons Candy in a Berkeley telephone directory, I headed immediately to their offices, which were located on Sackville Street.

en: The gentleman who saw me was particularly suave in manner, but uncommunicative in equal proportion. Having once told me that the Piccadilly house—which throughout our interview he called a “mansion”—was sold, he considered my business as concluded. When I asked who had purchased it, he opened his eyes a thought wider, and paused a few seconds before replying:—
vi: Receiving me was a polite but very taciturn employee. He only informed me that the house in Piccadilly had been sold and said nothing more. When I asked who had bought the house, he stared at me in surprise and then repeated in a gruff voice:
tr: The gentleman who welcomed me was particularly polite, but equally tight-lipped. When he told me that the Piccadilly house - during our conversation he referred to this building as the "mansion" - had been sold, he thought our business was concluded. When I asked him who had bought it, he widened his eyes and paused for a few seconds before answering: "The house has been sold, sir."
es: The gentleman who received me had particularly gentle manners, but he was not very communicative. After telling me that the house in Piccadilly, which he referred to as a "mansion" during our conversation, had been sold, he considered that my interest should end there. When I asked him who had bought it, he opened his eyes too wide and remained silent for a moment before responding:

en: “It is sold, sir.”
vi: — It has been sold, sir.
tr: When I asked him who had bought it, he widened his eyes and paused for a few seconds before answering: "The house has been sold, sir."
es: –It's sold, sir.

en: “Pardon me,” I said, with equal politeness, “but I have a special reason for wishing to know who purchased it.”
vi: — Excuse me, - I tried to remain polite - I would like to ask who that house was sold to, as I have some personal matters, which is why I am asking, please trust me.
tr: “Excuse me,” I said with the same politeness, “but I have a special reason for wanting to know who bought it.”
es: –Excuse me -I said, with the same courtesy-, but I have special reasons to wish to know who acquired that building.

en: Again he paused longer, and raised his eyebrows still more. “It is sold, sir,” was again his laconic reply.
vi: He glared at me even more. — I told you, the house has already been bought by someone, sir.
tr: He paused a little longer and raised his eyebrows even higher. His short and concise response was again, “The house is sold, sir.”
es: He paused again for quite a while and raised his eyebrows even higher. –It is sold, sir -he said again, laconically.

en: “Surely,” I said, “you do not mind letting me know so much.”
vi: — Of course, but can you give me some details about this transaction?
tr: “Of course,” I said, “you wouldn't mind letting me know this much.”
es: –I suppose you wouldn't mind giving me that information -I insisted.

en: “But I do mind,” he answered. “The affairs of their clients are absolutely safe in the hands of Mitchell, Sons, & Candy.” This was manifestly a prig of the first water, and there was no use arguing with him. I thought I had best meet him on his own ground, so I said:—
vi: — No, no, that's not possible, sir. With Mitchell, Sons & Candy, all client relationships must be kept absolutely confidential, please understand.
tr: "But I see an objection," he replied. "The affairs of our clients are in absolute safety in the hands of Mitchell, Sons & Candy." This was clearly first-degree formalism, and there was no point in arguing with him. I thought it would be best to speak to him by following his method, so I said:
es: –But, of course I care! – he replied-. The affairs of our clients are absolutely confidential in the hands of Mitchell, Sons Candy. It was clear that he was a pedant of the worst kind and that it wasn't worth arguing with him. I thought it would be better to confront him on his own ground and said to him:

en: “Your clients, sir, are happy in having so resolute a guardian of their confidence. I am myself a professional man.” Here I handed him my card. “In this instance I am not prompted by curiosity; I act on the part of Lord Godalming, who wishes to know something of the property which was, he understood, lately for sale.” These words put a different complexion on affairs. He said:—
vi: — Your company's clients must have been fortunate to find entrepreneurs worthy of their trust. To be honest, I am also in the same profession (I showed him my business card) and I did not come here out of curiosity, you can trust me on that. I came because of Lord Godalming's request. He asked me to gather some information about the owner, who recently tried to sell this house to him. My words immediately changed the attitude of this mechanical employee. — Is that really so?
tr: “Your clients should be happy to have a protector who guards their secrets with such determination. I am also a professional.” Here, I handed him my card. “In this case, I am not seeking information out of curiosity; I am acting on behalf of Lord Godalming, who wishes to obtain information regarding a property he understood to be for sale until recently.” These words brought a completely different color to the matters. He responded as follows:
es: –Your clients, sir, are lucky to have such a resolute guardian of their confidences. I myself am a professional -saying this, I handed him my card-. In this case, I am not interested in this matter out of curiosity: I am acting on behalf of Lord Godalming, who wishes to know something about the property that he believed, until recently, was for sale. Those words made things take on a different hue.

en: “I would like to oblige you if I could, Mr. Harker, and especially would I like to oblige his lordship. We once carried out a small matter of renting some chambers for him when he was the Honourable Arthur Holmwood. If you will let me have his lordship’s address I will consult the House on the subject, and will, in any case, communicate with his lordship by to-night’s post. It will be a pleasure if we can so far deviate from our rules as to give the required information to his lordship.”
vi: In the past, he once asked us to find a single house for him to rent when he was still the esteemed Arthur Holmwood. If you leave me the address of Lord Godalming, I will speak to my director on your behalf. After that, I will try to send a letter to the lord tonight. Surely there would be no breach of principle in providing your lord with some trivial information.
tr: “If there is anything I can do, I would like to assist you and especially Lordship, Mr. Harker. When he was the Honorable Arthur Holmwood, we once handled a small matter of renting some rooms for him. If you allow me to have Lordship's address, I will consult the Company on this matter and contact Lordship by tonight's post in any case. If we can deviate from our rules regarding the information Lordship desires, it would be our pleasure.”
es: "I would like to give you those reports if I had them, Mr. Harker, and especially I would like to serve your client." "On one occasion we carried out some transactions for him regarding the rental of some rooms when he was the Honorable Arthur Holmwood." "If you can give me his lordship's address, I would be very pleased to consult the house about the subject and, in any case, I would communicate with his lordship by tonight's mail." "It will be a pleasure to provide those reports to his lordship, if we can deviate from the rules of conduct of this house in this case."

en: I wanted to secure a friend, and not to make an enemy, so I thanked him, gave the address at Dr. Seward’s and came away. It was now dark, and I was tired and hungry. I got a cup of tea at the Aërated Bread Company and came down to Purfleet by the next train.
vi: I could only thank the staff member and leave him Dr. Seward's address before saying goodbye. Outside, it was already dark. Feeling both tired and hungry, I had a quick cup of sweet tea before boarding the train back to Purneets.
tr: I thanked him because I wanted to make a friend, not an enemy, and gave Dr. Seward's address before leaving. It was already dark, and I was tired and hungry. I had a cup of tea at the Aerated Bread Company and took the next train to Purfleet.
es: I wanted to make a friend, not an enemy, so I thanked him, gave him the address of Dr. Seward's house, and left. It was already night and I felt tired and hungry. I had a cup of tea at the Aerated Bread Company and returned to Purfleet by train.

en: I found all the others at home. Mina was looking tired and pale, but she made a gallant effort to be bright and cheerful, it wrung my heart to think that I had had to keep anything from her and so caused her inquietude. Thank God, this will be the last night of her looking on at our conferences, and feeling the sting of our not showing our confidence. It took all my courage to hold to the wise resolution of keeping her out of our grim task. She seems somehow more reconciled; or else the very subject seems to have become repugnant to her, for when any accidental allusion is made she actually shudders. I am glad we made our resolution in time, as with such a feeling as this, our growing knowledge would be torture to her.
vi: When I got home, I saw everyone sitting in the living room. Mina still looked pale and even seemed more tired than in the morning, although she tried to appear cheerful with everyone. I felt a sharp pain in my heart thinking about how I had to grit my teeth and hide so many things from her, which only made her worry even more. Thank God! This would be the last night she would sit with us, feeling like no one trusted her anymore. As for myself, I had to make a great effort to come to a fair and reasonable decision regarding her. Mina seemed to completely accept my advice. Or is it that our adventure is now truly frightening her? Fortunately, we made a timely decision; otherwise, our new discoveries would be nothing short of torture for her, day and night.
tr: When I returned, I found everyone at home. Mina looked tired and pale, but she was making a brave effort to appear lively and cheerful; the thought that I had to hide something from her and thus caused her unease wrenched my heart. Thank God, this will be the last night she will have to witness our meetings and feel the pain of our lack of trust in her. I had mustered all my courage to maintain our wise decision to keep her out of our relentless task. Somehow, she now seems more at peace or perhaps the subject itself has become repulsive to her, because whenever it is accidentally mentioned, she genuinely shudders. I am glad we made our decision in time because the increasing knowledge coupled with such a feeling would have been torture for her.
es: I found all the others in the house. Mina looked pale and tired, but she made a valiant effort to appear kind and cheerful: it hurt me to think that I had to hide something from her and that it had thus worried her. Thank God, it would be the last night she would have to be nearby without attending our meetings, believing in some way that she was not worthy of our trust. I needed all my courage to keep her truly away from everything related to our horrible work. She seems to be somewhat more accustomed to the idea, or the subject has become repugnant to her, since every time there is an accidental allusion to that topic, she truly shudders. I'm glad we made our decision in time, because with such feelings, our ever-growing knowledge would be a true torture for her.

en: I could not tell the others of the day’s discovery till we were alone; so after dinner—followed by a little music to save appearances even amongst ourselves—I took Mina to her room and left her to go to bed. The dear girl was more affectionate with me than ever, and clung to me as though she would detain me; but there was much to be talked of and I came away. Thank God, the ceasing of telling things has made no difference between us.
vi: We had to wait until the men could sit separately before I could report to the group about what I had just investigated today. Therefore, after dinner - and after relaxing with some music for a while - I went upstairs with Mina. I had never seen Mina so affectionate with me; she wrapped her arms tightly around me as if not wanting to let me go downstairs again. But I had many things to recount to the friends waiting below, so I had to go back down and leave my dear young wife alone. May God bless us! Although there are times we must remain silent about certain matters, the love between us will never change.
tr: I couldn't tell the others what I had learned that day until I was alone, so after dinner - and after dinner, we listened to some music among ourselves to keep up appearances - I took Mina to her room and left her there to sleep. Dear girl was more affectionate towards me than ever and hugged me tightly as if she wanted to keep me there, but there was much to talk about and I left. Thank God, stopping the recounting of events didn't change anything between us.
es: I couldn't talk to the others about the discoveries I had made during the day until we were alone. So, after dinner, and a small musical interlude that served to keep up appearances, even for ourselves, I led Mina to her room and let her go to bed. My adorable wife was more affectionate with me than ever and hugged me as if she wanted to hold on to me, but there was much to talk about and I had to leave her alone. Thank God, not telling each other everything hadn't changed things between us.

en: When I came down again I found the others all gathered round the fire in the study. In the train I had written my diary so far, and simply read it off to them as the best means of letting them get abreast of my own information; when I had finished Van Helsing said:—
vi: When I went downstairs, Dr. Seward and his friends were sitting around the fire in the room. I read to them the diary entry that I had just managed to write while still on the train. After listening to me, Van Helsing immediately remarked:
tr: When I went back downstairs, I found the others gathered around the fire in the study. On the train, I had written in my journal about the events up to that point, and I simply read it aloud as the best way to share the information I had gathered with them; when I finished, Van Helsing said:
es: When I went down again, I found everyone sitting around the fire in the study. On the train, I had written in my diary everything related to my discoveries of the day, and I limited myself to reading to them what I had written, as the best possible way for them to learn about the reports I had obtained. When I finished, Van Helsing said:

en: “This has been a great day’s work, friend Jonathan. Doubtless we are on the track of the missing boxes. If we find them all in that house, then our work is near the end. But if there be some missing, we must search until we find them. Then shall we make our final coup, and hunt the wretch to his real death.” We all sat silent awhile and all at once Mr. Morris spoke:—
vi: — A very important discovery, my friend Jonathan! There is no doubt anymore, we are about to find those wooden crates. If they are all hidden in the house in Piccadilly, then our work is almost done. But if any crate is missing, we will still have to struggle because of that crate! If we have all the necessary information, we only need to deliver a decisive blow to send that demon back to its true death. We were lost in thought until Morris suddenly spoke up:
tr: “It has been a terrific day, my friend John. Undoubtedly, we are on the trail of the lost chests. If we find all of them in that house, then it means our work is about to end. But if there are any missing chests, we must continue searching until we find them. Then, we will deliver our final blow and hunt down this scoundrel to his true death. For a while, we all sat in silence; suddenly, Mr. Morris spoke:
es: –You have had a magnificent day of work, friend Jonathan. Undoubtedly, we are on the trail of the missing boxes. If we find all of them in that house, then our work is nearing its end. But, if any of them are still missing, we will have to search for it until we find it. Then we will deliver the final blow and make the monster truly die. We all remained seated in silence and, suddenly, Mr. Morris said:

en: “Say! how are we going to get into that house?”
vi: — How do you think we should enter that house? — It's just like the abandoned house over there!
tr: “Tell me! How are we going to get into that house?””
es: –Say! How are we going to be able to enter that house?

en: “We got into the other,” answered Lord Godalming quickly.
vi: - Lord Godalming replied immediately. — Have you made yourself clear yet?
tr: "We entered the other one, didn't we," replied Lord Godalming quickly.
es: –The same way we did it in the other one -said Lord Godalming quickly.

en: “But, Art, this is different. We broke house at Carfax, but we had night and a walled park to protect us. It will be a mighty different thing to commit burglary in Piccadilly, either by day or night. I confess I don’t see how we are going to get in unless that agency duck can find us a key of some sort; perhaps we shall know when you get his letter in the morning.” Lord Godalming’s brows contracted, and he stood up and walked about the room. By-and-by he stopped and said, turning from one to another of us:—
vi: It's not as easy as that! To get into Carfax, we could use a hook to unlock the door. Moreover, we have the cover of night and a lush garden surrounded by walls to protect us. But with the house in Piccadilly, it's a completely different story, whether it's day or night. To be honest, I still don't understand how we are supposed to get in there without someone lending us the key. Perhaps tomorrow morning, when you receive the letter from that employee, we should consider this matter. Lord Godalming stood up and paced around the room, his face furrowed with thought. Then he stopped and looked at each of us in turn:
tr: “But Art, this is different. We forced our way into Carfax, but we had our greenery surrounded by night and walls protecting us. Entering the house in Piccadilly, whether by night or day, will be a very different thing, almost like committing a burglary. I must admit, I don’t understand how we’ll get in if that worthless realtor can’t find us a key, but perhaps we’ll learn when we receive his letter in the morning.” Lord Godalming frowned and began pacing the room. Soon he stopped and, turning to each of us in turn, said:
es: –But, Art, we broke into Carfax; but it was night and we had the park that hid us from prying eyes. It would be very different to commit that crime in Piccadilly, both at night and during the day. I confess that I don't see how we are going to be able to get in, unless that pedantic real estate agent gets us a key. Lord Godalming frowned, stood up, and paced around the room. Suddenly, he stopped and said, turning to us and looking at us one by one:

en: “Quincey’s head is level. This burglary business is getting serious; we got off once all right; but we have now a rare job on hand—unless we can find the Count’s key basket.”
vi: — Quincey has a point. Doing this is no different from stealing. We got away with it once, but this time it’s truly a difficult task... unless somehow, we get the count's key.
tr: "Quincey is very sensible. This matter of breaking into the house like a thief has started to get serious; we got away with it once, but now we have a rare task at hand - if we can't find the Count's key basket."
es: –Quincey is right. This matter of breaking and entering is getting very serious; it went very well for us once, but the job we have now is very different... unless we find the count's keychain.

en: As nothing could well be done before morning, and as it would be at least advisable to wait till Lord Godalming should hear from Mitchell’s, we decided not to take any active step before breakfast time. For a good while we sat and smoked, discussing the matter in its various lights and bearings; I took the opportunity of bringing this diary right up to the moment. I am very sleepy and shall go to bed....
vi: So we couldn't make any decision until Lord Godalming received the letter from Mitchell's company tomorrow morning. I could only take advantage of the time to jot down a few lines about the events of the day in my diary, then quietly go to sleep, feeling utterly exhausted.
tr: Since nothing could be done until morning and it would be reasonable to wait until Lord Godalming hears from the Mitchells, we decided not to take any action before breakfast. We sat for a long time, smoking and discussing the matter from various angles; I also took the opportunity to bring my journal up to date. I am very sleepy, I will go to bed.
es: Since we couldn't do anything before morning and since it was advisable for Lord Godalming to wait until receiving communication from Mitchell's, we decided not to take any steps until breakfast time. For quite a while, we remained seated, smoking, discussing all facets of the matter from different angles; I took the opportunity to complete this journal and update it to this very moment. I am very sleepy and must go to bed...

en: Just a line. Mina sleeps soundly and her breathing is regular. Her forehead is puckered up into little wrinkles, as though she thinks even in her sleep. She is still too pale, but does not look so haggard as she did this morning. To-morrow will, I hope, mend all this; she will be herself at home in Exeter. Oh, but I am sleepy!
vi: However, there are still a few lines I cannot help but write down. Mina is sleeping very soundly with steady breaths. I suddenly feel a deep sorrow when I notice the wrinkles on her graceful forehead. It seems that even in her sleep, worries and troubles do not leave her alone. Tomorrow, I hope everything will return to normal when she can come back to our home in Exeter. Oh! Why am I so sleepy!
tr: One more line. Mina is sleeping soundly and her breathing is regular. There are small wrinkles on her forehead as if she is lost in thought even in her sleep. Her color is still very pale, but she doesn't look as exhausted as she did this morning. I hope tomorrow will set everything right; she will recover at home in Exeter. Oh, but I am very sleepy!
es: Just one more line. Mina sleeps deeply and her breathing is regular. Her forehead is furrowed with small wrinkles, as if she were thinking even in her sleep. She is still very pale, but not as gaunt as this morning. Tomorrow I hope we can put an end to all this; she will go to our house in Exeter. Oh! How sleepy I am!

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 1 October.—I am puzzled afresh about Renfield. His moods change so rapidly that I find it difficult to keep touch of them, and as they always mean something more than his own well-being, they form a more than interesting study. This morning, when I went to see him after his repulse of Van Helsing, his manner was that of a man commanding destiny. He was, in fact, commanding destiny—subjectively. He did not really care for any of the things of mere earth; he was in the clouds and looked down on all the weaknesses and wants of us poor mortals. I thought I would improve the occasion and learn something, so I asked him:—
vi: • October 1 Once again, I cannot help but talk about the case of patient Renfield. First, his temperament suddenly changed just when I managed to grasp the reason why he behaved one way at one moment and another way at another moment. On the other hand, when his mood changes are not solely dependent on his inner comfort, studying the irregularities in his behavior seems to bring me considerable professional benefit. This morning, when I went to see him after he had an unpleasant conversation with Van Helsing, his behavior was exactly that of a person who is completely in control of his destiny according to his subjective inclination. Indeed, he did not bother with worldly matters at all. He was living on cloud nine, and from that lofty place, he looked down on us with disdain. I thought of asking him in the hope of understanding something more:
tr: October 1st. - Renfield surprised me once again. His mood changes so quickly that I find it difficult to keep up, and each time they signify more than just his own well-being, making them a subject of study that is more than merely interesting. This morning, after he turned Van Helsing away, when I went to see him, his demeanor was like that of a man who commands fate. In fact, he was commanding fate - subjectively. He was not interested in anything related to mere health; he was pensive and scornful of the needs of us poor mortals with our weaknesses. I thought I might learn something by seizing the opportunity, and so I asked him:
es: October 1st. I am absolutely astonished by Renfield. His mood swings are so sudden that I have difficulty recording and adapting to them, and since they always have a meaning that goes beyond his own well-being, they form a more than interesting study. This morning, when I went to see him, after he had rejected van Helsing, his manners were those of a man who was directing destiny. Indeed, he was giving orders to destiny, subjectively. He was not concerned at all with any earthly matters; he was in the clouds and looked from his watchtower at all the weaknesses and desires of us poor mortals. I decided to take advantage of the occasion and learn something, so I asked him:

en: “What about the flies these times?” He smiled on me in quite a superior sort of way—such a smile as would have become the face of Malvolio—as he answered me:—
vi: — So, what do you think about the flies today? He sneered at me with a condescending look:
tr: "What's the news about the flies these days?" He smiled in a condescending manner as he answered me - a smile that could belong to Malvolio.
es: –What can you tell me about the flies lately? He smiled at me with a very superior air..., with a smile that could have appeared on Malvolio's face, before responding to me:

en: “The fly, my dear sir, has one striking feature; its wings are typical of the aërial powers of the psychic faculties. The ancients did well when they typified the soul as a butterfly!”
vi: — Flies, huh? You want to talk about flies, right? Let me tell you that this species always has a truly impressive characteristic; their delicate wings ideally represent the spatial strength of spiritual disciplines. Our ancestors were very wise to depict the soul in the form of a butterfly!
tr: "Dear sir, the fly has one striking feature: its wings possess the qualities of spiritual abilities related to air. Ancient civilizations were right in designating the butterfly as a symbol of the soul."
es: –The fly, my dear sir, has a surprising characteristic: its wings are typical of the airy nature of psychic faculties. The ancients were right when they represented the soul in the form of a butterfly!

en: I thought I would push his analogy to its utmost logically, so I said quickly:—
vi: I really wanted him to continue his line of reasoning in a way that was logical to his thinking, so I didn't hesitate to respond:
tr: Since I wanted to push the logic of his analogy to its limits, I quickly said:
es: I thought I had exhausted his analogy, and I quickly said:

en: “Oh, it is a soul you are after now, is it?” His madness foiled his reason, and a puzzled look spread over his face as, shaking his head with a decision which I had but seldom seen in him, he said:—
vi: — Oh! So is that the soul you are looking for? He didn't know how to reason anymore, but he still shook his head vigorously and firmly replied:
tr: “Ah, so now you're after the soul, are you?” His madness was obstructing his reason, and with a determination I rarely saw in him, he shook his head from side to side as a look of astonishment spread across his face; he said:
es: –Oh! Are you looking for a soul now? His madness enveloped reason, and an expression of astonishment spread across his face as, shaking his head with an energy I had never seen before, he said:

en: “Oh, no, oh no! I want no souls. Life is all I want.” Here he brightened up; “I am pretty indifferent about it at present. Life is all right; I have all I want. You must get a new patient, doctor, if you wish to study zoöphagy!”
vi: — No, no, it's not like that! The issue is not the soul! I just want life and that's all! Moreover, I find life to be very fair to me. Life for me at this moment is perfect, I have everything I want. Doctor, if you want to delve deeper into mental illness, perhaps you should find yourself another patient!
tr: “Ah, no! Ah, no! I don't want a soul. The only thing I want is life.” He came to life here: “Right now, I am quite indifferent to it. Life is not bad; I have everything I want. If you wish to study Zoophagous, you must find a new patient, Doctor!”
es: –Oh, no, no! I don't want souls. All I want is life -his face lit up at that moment-. I feel a great indifference about that nowadays. Life is very well: I have all that I need. You have to find yourself another patient, doctor, if you wish to study zoophagy.

en: This puzzled me a little, so I drew him on:—
vi: — So you have arranged your life, you have reached the level of a saint, haven't you?
tr: This surprised me a bit, so I pressed on:
es: That remark surprised me a little, so I said to him:

en: “Then you command life; you are a god, I suppose?” He smiled with an ineffably benign superiority.
vi: — So you have arranged your life, you have reached the level of a saint, haven't you? He smirked again with a condescending attitude, but this time it seemed less overbearing.
tr: “So then, you rule over life; you are God then, I suppose, is that right?” He smiled with a greatness of indescribable kindness.
es: –So, you direct life; you must be a god, isn't that right? He smiled with a kind of benign and ineffable superiority.

en: “Oh no! Far be it from me to arrogate to myself the attributes of the Deity. I am not even concerned in His especially spiritual doings. If I may state my intellectual position I am, so far as concerns things purely terrestrial, somewhat in the position which Enoch occupied spiritually!” This was a poser to me. I could not at the moment recall Enoch’s appositeness; so I had to ask a simple question, though I felt that by so doing I was lowering myself in the eyes of the lunatic:—
vi: — Oh, no! I think it will be a long time before I have the attributes of God. In fact, I have nothing to do with His words or teachings. If I had to define my intellectual state compared to worldly matters, it would have to be on par with the rank of Enoch. The words he said to me were really vague; in fact, I couldn't remember what position his character named Enoch held.
tr: “Ah, no! Adopting the attributes of the gods is far from me. I am not even interested in His especially spiritual works. If I may be permitted to state my intellectual position, to some extent I am in the position of Enoch, who was entirely worldly but spiritually captured!” This was a difficult situation for me. At that moment, I could not recall the significance of Enoch; therefore, knowing that by doing so I was belittling myself in the eyes of a madman, I had to ask him an easy question:
es: –Oh, no! It is in no way within my calculations to arrogate to myself the attributes of divinity. I am not even particularly interested in its spiritual acts. If it is possible for me to establish my intellectual position, I would say that, regarding purely earthly matters, I am somewhat in the position that Enoch occupied spiritually! That represented a difficult problem for me; I couldn't remember at that moment what Enoch's position had been. Therefore, I had to ask him a simple question, although I understood that by doing so, I was lowering myself in the eyes of the lunatic...

en: “And why with Enoch?”
vi: — On par with Enoch? Why so?
tr: “So why Hanok?”
es: –And why do you compare yourself to Enoch?

en: “Because he walked with God.” I could not see the analogy, but did not like to admit it; so I harked back to what he had denied:—
vi: — Because he is compared to God. Even though I couldn't understand any connection in what he was saying, I still didn't intend to voice my doubts. I wanted him to return to what he was saying at the beginning.
tr: “Because he was walking with God.” I couldn't see the similarity, but I didn't want to accept it; so I returned to what he had previously rejected:
es: –Because he walked with God. I didn't understand the analogy, but I didn't like to admit it, so I returned to the topic I had already denied:

en: “So you don’t care about life and you don’t want souls. Why not?” I put my question quickly and somewhat sternly, on purpose to disconcert him. The effort succeeded; for an instant he unconsciously relapsed into his old servile manner, bent low before me, and actually fawned upon me as he replied:—
vi: — So you don't care about the soul, and this life only moves you a little. Can you say why? I asked harshly just to make him embarrassed, to see how he would respond. Perhaps I succeeded, because after a moment of futile thinking, he truly humbled himself exactly like his usual mediocre manner.
tr: “So you’re not interested in life and you don’t want any soul. Why?” I quickly and somewhat harshly asked my question to disturb his peace. My effort was successful; for a moment, that unproud demeanor unconsciously returned, he bowed before me and, in fact, while answering, he fawned over me: “I don’t want any soul, really, really!
es: –So you are not concerned about life and do not want souls, why? I asked him the question quickly and quite dryly, in order to see if it was possible to unsettle him. The effort paid off and for a moment he calmed down and returned to his old servile manners, he bowed to me and flattered me servilely, while responding:

en: “I don’t want any souls, indeed, indeed! I don’t. I couldn’t use them if I had them; they would be no manner of use to me. I couldn’t eat them or——” He suddenly stopped and the old cunning look spread over his face, like a wind-sweep on the surface of the water. “And doctor, as to life, what is it after all? When you’ve got all you require, and you know that you will never want, that is all. I have friends—good friends—like you, Dr. Seward”; this was said with a leer of inexpressible cunning. “I know that I shall never lack the means of life!”
vi: — Of course not, I don't need to worry about the soul, simply because I don't like it, and that's completely the truth. I only do what I can; the soul is of no use to me. I can't eat the soul, nor can I... He suddenly fell silent midway, his face briefly revealing a cunning expression like a breeze rippling the surface of a lake. — And what about life? Ultimately, what is it really, doctor? Once you have enjoyed what you want and never feel lacking, may I ask if you see any need to wait for anything else? Doctor, I also have good friends like you, and I know I will never lack what I need to have a place in this life.
tr: My effort was successful; for a moment, that unproud demeanor unconsciously returned, he bowed before me and, in fact, while answering, he fawned over me: “I don’t want any soul, really, really! I don’t want it. If I had them, I couldn’t use them; I can’t use them in any way. I can’t eat them or...” Suddenly he fell silent and the old cunning expression settled on his face like the wind flowing over the surface of the water. “And Doctor, when it comes to life, what is life after all? When you have everything you need and you know you’ll never feel the lack of anything again, that means everything. With friends like you -good friends- Dr. Seward,” -these words were spoken with an indescribably cunning look- “I know I will never be deprived of the riches of life.”
es: –I don't want souls. It's true! It's true! I don't want them. They would be useless to me if I had them; I would have no way to use them. I couldn't eat them or... He suddenly fell silent, and the old expression of cunning spread over his face again, like when a strong wind ripples the surface of the waters. –Listen, doctor, regarding life, what is it after all? When you have obtained everything necessary and know that you will never desire anything else, that is all. I have friends, good friends, like you, Dr. Seward -he said this with an expression of indescribable cunning-. I know that I will never lack the means to live!

en: I think that through the cloudiness of his insanity he saw some antagonism in me, for he at once fell back on the last refuge of such as he—a dogged silence. After a short time I saw that for the present it was useless to speak to him. He was sulky, and so I came away.
vi: I think that although his mind was wandering aimlessly, he still understood that I did not appreciate his theories at all, because after those seemingly sincere explanations, he suddenly fell silent. Knowing that continuing the conversation wouldn't solve anything, I left him alone in the room and went home. But after a short while, someone came to my room and told me that Renfield was very eager to see me once more.
tr: In the incomprehensibility of his madness, I think he saw a kind of hostility in me, because he immediately retreated to his last refuge - stubborn silence. Soon after, I realized that for now, there would be no benefit in talking to him. He had sulked, and so, I left.
es: I believe that amidst the mists of his madness, he saw in me a certain antagonism, since, finally, he retreated to the shelter of his kind..., to the deepest and most stubborn silence. After a short time, I realized that for the moment it was useless to try to talk to him. He was sulking. So I left him alone and went away.

en: Later in the day he sent for me. Ordinarily I would not have come without special reason, but just at present I am so interested in him that I would gladly make an effort. Besides, I am glad to have anything to help to pass the time. Harker is out, following up clues; and so are Lord Godalming and Quincey. Van Helsing sits in my study poring over the record prepared by the Harkers; he seems to think that by accurate knowledge of all details he will light upon some clue. He does not wish to be disturbed in the work, without cause. I would have taken him with me to see the patient, only I thought that after his last repulse he might not care to go again. There was also another reason: Renfield might not speak so freely before a third person as when he and I were alone.
vi: But after a short while, someone came to my room and told me that Renfield was very eager to see me once more. Normally, I only visit him when there is a specific reason, but this time, I suddenly found him so interesting that I couldn't refuse his request. Moreover, if I refused him at this moment, I wouldn't know what else to do. Jonathan had to continue his new investigation, Lord Godalming and Quincey were not at home either. Meanwhile, Van Helsing was engrossed in reviewing the documents that the Harkers had prepared in my study. He didn't want anyone to disturb him unless there was a legitimate reason. In fact, I really wanted him to accompany me to Renfield's room, but thinking about the recent conversation between the two of them, I decided against it. Moreover, I feared that Renfield wouldn't speak openly if a third person appeared.
tr: He summoned me later in the day. Generally, I wouldn't come without a special reason, but right now it interests me so much that I would gladly make the effort. Also, I am glad to have something to help me pass the time. Harker is outside, following the clues, as are Lord Godalming and Quincey. Van Helsing is in my study, examining the record prepared by the Harkers; he seems to think he might find a clue with accurate information on all the details. He does not want to be disturbed without reason while working. I could have asked him to come with me to see the patient, but I thought he might not be interested in going again after his last refusal. There was another reason: Renfield might not speak as freely in the presence of a third person as he does when it's just the two of us.
es: Later, in the course of the day, he sent for me. Ordinarily, I would not have gone to visit him without special reasons, but at this moment I am so interested in him that I am happy to make that small effort. Besides, I was glad to have something to help me pass the time. Harker is out, following leads; and so are Quincey and Lord Godalming. Van Helsing is in my study, carefully examining the records prepared by the Harkers; he seems to believe that through an exact knowledge of all the details, it is possible he may find some important clue. He does not wish to be disturbed while he works, unless for some special reason. I could have made him accompany me to see the patient, but I thought that after being rejected as he had been, he would no longer like to go see him. Besides, there was another reason: Renfield would not speak as freely in front of a third person as he would when he and I are alone.

en: I found him sitting out in the middle of the floor on his stool, a pose which is generally indicative of some mental energy on his part. When I came in, he said at once, as though the question had been waiting on his lips:—
vi: As usual, just seeing him squatting on the stool placed in the middle of the room, I immediately knew his mind was "thinking". As soon as he saw me peeking in, he immediately turned and asked, as if the question had been on the tip of his tongue all along:
tr: I found him sitting on his stool in the middle of the room, usually an indication of a kind of mental activity peculiar to him. When I entered, he immediately said as if the question had been waiting on the tip of his lips:
es: I found him sitting in the chair, in the center of his room, in a posture that generally indicates a certain mental energy on his part. When I entered, he immediately said, as if the question had been burning his lips:

en: “What about souls?” It was evident then that my surmise had been correct. Unconscious cerebration was doing its work, even with the lunatic. I determined to have the matter out. “What about them yourself?” I asked. He did not reply for a moment but looked all round him, and up and down, as though he expected to find some inspiration for an answer.
vi: — What do you think about the soul? I was not mistaken: in psychiatric patients, just like in normal people, the mind occasionally still works in an unconscious state. But I have to check and see. — What about you, how do you perceive it? - I asked back. He sat still without answering, his eyes shifting from the ceiling to the four walls around him as if he were seeking some object to inspire his response.
tr: “What happened to the spirits?” It was clear that my guess was correct. Unconscious thinking was performing its duty even in a mentally ill person. “You tell me, what happened to the spirits?” I asked. For a moment, he didn't answer, but he looked to his right, left, down, and up as if he were waiting for inspiration to respond.
es: –What do you tell me about the souls? It was evident that my postponement had been correct. Unconscious thoughts carried out their work, even in the case of lunatics. I decided to put an end to that matter. –What do you say about them yourself? – I inquired. Renfield did not respond for the moment and looked around, up and down, as if he were expecting to get some inspiration to answer.

en: “I don’t want any souls!” he said in a feeble, apologetic way. The matter seemed preying on his mind, and so I determined to use it—to “be cruel only to be kind.” So I said:—
vi: — I don't want a soul at all! - He answered in a mumble as if avoiding the truth. I have a feeling that there is indeed a specific thought in his mind, and therefore, I decided to "push" for that truth.
tr: “I don't want a soul!” he said in a feeble, apologetic manner. The matter seemed to be gnawing at his mind, and for this reason, I decided to use it - to “be cruel to be kind.” So I said:
es: –I don't want souls! – he said in a weak tone, almost as an excuse. The matter seemed to occupy his mind, and I decided to take advantage of it... to be "cruel only to be kind." So I told him:

en: “You like life, and you want life?”
vi: — You still love life very much and really want to live, don't you?
tr: “Do you love life and want to live?”
es: –Do you like life, do you want life?

en: “Oh yes! but that is all right; you needn’t worry about that!”
vi: — Oh! Yes, yes! Life is what we all want!
tr: “Ah, yes! But there's no problem with that; you don't need to worry about it.”
es: –Oh, yes! But, that's already fine. You don't need to worry about that!

en: “But,” I asked, “how are we to get the life without getting the soul also?” This seemed to puzzle him, so I followed it up:—
vi: — But how can one have a life without denying the existence of that soul? Seeing him appear confused by this difficult question, I continued to press:
tr: “But,” I asked, “how will we take life without taking the soul as well?” This seemed to confuse him, so I didn't let it go:
es: –But I asked, how are we going to obtain life without obtaining the soul at the same time? That seemed to surprise him, so I elaborated on the idea:

en: “A nice time you’ll have some time when you’re flying out there, with the souls of thousands of flies and spiders and birds and cats buzzing and twittering and miauing all round you. You’ve got their lives, you know, and you must put up with their souls!” Something seemed to affect his imagination, for he put his fingers to his ears and shut his eyes, screwing them up tightly just as a small boy does when his face is being soaped. There was something pathetic in it that touched me; it also gave me a lesson, for it seemed that before me was a child—only a child, though the features were worn, and the stubble on the jaws was white. It was evident that he was undergoing some process of mental disturbance, and, knowing how his past moods had interpreted things seemingly foreign to himself, I thought I would enter into his mind as well as I could and go with him. The first step was to restore confidence, so I asked him, speaking pretty loud so that he would hear me through his closed ears:—
vi: — I really want you to have peaceful moments when you fly away from here with the souls of thousands of flies, spiders, birds, and cats, along with the chirping, buzzing, and meowing sounds all around! You have taken the lives of those creatures, so you should also accept a bit of their souls! It seems that I have struck his imagination, for I saw him suddenly cover his ears, his eyes tightly shut like a child getting soap in their face. I felt an indescribable emotion, as if before me was a child, despite the face bearing the marks of an old man. In his mind, he must be going through another turmoil. Knowing well his reasoning and behavior from previous arguments, I thought I must be extremely cautious in understanding the intentions forming in his mind. First, I had to make him believe. I asked him, trying to speak as loudly as possible so he could hear clearly, for he was still covering his ears:
tr: “One day, you will have a good time flying there with the souls of thousands of flies and spiders and birds and cats buzzing, chirping, and meowing around you. You possess their lives, you know, and you must also endure their souls!” Something seemed to have affected his imagination, for he brought his fingers to his ears and shut his eyes tightly, like a little boy whose face was being soaped. There was something pitiful in this that touched me; it also taught me a lesson; for he seemed to be a child before me - though his features were worn and his beard was white, he appeared to be just a child. It was clear that he was going through some kind of mental disorder, and knowing how he interpreted things that seemed foreign to him in his past states of mind, I thought of getting into his mind and progressing with him as much as I could. The first step was to regain his trust, so I asked quite loudly, so that he could hear me despite his blocked ears:
es: –You will have a very amusing time when you leave here, with the souls of all the flies, spiders, birds, and cats buzzing, writhing, and meowing around you. You have taken their lives and must know what to do with their souls. Something seemed to affect his imagination, as he covered his ears with his fingers and closed his eyes, squeezing them tightly, like a child does when their face is being washed with soap. There was something pathetic about him that moved me; likewise, I received a lesson, as it seemed to me that there was a child in front of me... only a child, although his facial features reflected fatigue and the beard appearing on his cheeks was white. It was evident that he was suffering some kind of mental disturbance, and knowing how his previous moods seemed to have interpreted things that were apparently strange to him, I thought it appropriate to delve into his thoughts as much as possible, to accompany him. The first step was to regain his trust, so I asked him, speaking very loudly, so he could hear me despite having his ears covered:

en: “Would you like some sugar to get your flies round again?” He seemed to wake up all at once, and shook his head. With a laugh he replied:—
vi: — Do you want to get some honey to attract flies? He nodded, smiling as he answered, seemingly understanding the issue immediately:
tr: "Do you want some sugar to have flies around you again?" He seemed to have woken up immediately and shook his head from side to side. He replied with a laugh:
es: –Do you want some sugar to attract your flies again? He seemed to wake up suddenly and moved his head. With a laugh, he said:

en: “Not much! flies are poor things, after all!” After a pause he added, “But I don’t want their souls buzzing round me, all the same.”
vi: — Oh! As you know, after all, flies are just poor little creatures... - He suddenly fell silent and then continued - But anyway, I don't want their souls buzzing around me all day.
tr: "I don't really want to!" "After all, flies are poor creatures!" After pausing for a bit, he added. "However, I don't want their souls buzzing around me."
es: –No! Flies are of little importance, after all! – He paused slightly and added –: But, anyway, I don't want their souls buzzing in my ears.

en: “Or spiders?” I went on.
vi: — What about the spiders?
tr: “Or spiders,” I continued.
es: –Or the spiders? – I continued saying.

en: “Blow spiders! What’s the use of spiders? There isn’t anything in them to eat or”—he stopped suddenly, as though reminded of a forbidden topic.
vi: — What about the spiders? — I don't think much of spiders either! What use are they? There's nothing in the body of a spider that can be eaten or.... He suddenly fell silent as if he had just remembered something that couldn't be spoken.
tr: “Flying spiders? What good are spiders anyway? They can't be eaten or...” He suddenly stopped as if reminded of a forbidden topic.
es: –I don't want spiders! What are spiders good for? They have nothing to eat or… -he suddenly fell silent, as if he remembered some forbidden topic.

en: “So, so!” I thought to myself, “this is the second time he has suddenly stopped at the word ‘drink’; what does it mean?” Renfield seemed himself aware of having made a lapse, for he hurried on, as though to distract my attention from it:—
vi: “Good, good!” - I thought to myself. - “This is the second time he has gone silent when about to say the word drink. Why is that?” He must have realized the mistake in his half-finished sentence, so he turned to another topic as if trying to change the subject:
tr: "So that's how it is!" I thought to myself, "This is the second stance on the word 'drink' all of a sudden; what does this mean?" Renfield seemed to be aware of his mistake, because he hurriedly continued his words as if he wanted to divert my attention from it:
es: "Well, well!" I said to myself. "This is the second time he suddenly stops at the word, what does this mean?" Renfield realized that he had made a mistake, as he hurried to continue, as if to distract my attention and prevent me from noticing it.

en: “I don’t take any stock at all in such matters. ‘Rats and mice and such small deer,’ as Shakespeare has it, ‘chicken-feed of the larder’ they might be called. I’m past all that sort of nonsense. You might as well ask a man to eat molecules with a pair of chop-sticks, as to try to interest me about the lesser carnivora, when I know of what is before me.”
vi: — I don't care at all about things like shrews, mice, and all those tiny creatures that serve as food for chickens, if we speak like Shakespeare! I think we should end the discussion about these stupid animals! Making me care about these lowly creatures is like asking a European to use Chinese chopsticks to pick up tiny pieces of food! I always understand what awaits me?
tr: “I don't bother with such things. As Shakespeare said, 'Mice and rats and little deer'; they could also be called 'chicken feed in the barn'. All this nonsense is beyond me now. When you know what's in front of you, you can ask a man to eat molecules with sticks until he tries to interest you in lower carnivores.”
es: –I have absolutely no interest in those animals. "Rats, mice, and other such animals," as Shakespeare says. It can be said that they are of no importance. I have already surpassed all that nonsense. It would be the same as asking a man to eat molecules with chopsticks, to try to interest me in carnivores, when I know what awaits me.

en: “I see,” I said. “You want big things that you can make your teeth meet in? How would you like to breakfast on elephant?”
vi: — I know! What you want are those animals that you can bite into with your teeth. Do you need someone to bring you an elephant for breakfast?
tr: “I understand,” I said. “You want big things to sink your teeth into, right? How about having an elephant for breakfast?”
es: –I understand now -I said-. You want large animals in which you can sink your teeth, isn't that right? How would an elephant for your breakfast sound?

en: “What ridiculous nonsense you are talking!” He was getting too wide awake, so I thought I would press him hard. “I wonder,” I said reflectively, “what an elephant’s soul is like!”
vi: — Crazy! You talk like a madman! — Renfield, I was wondering what kind of soul an elephant might have? - I said, with a very pensive expression.
tr: “How ridiculous you are!” He was becoming more alert, so I thought I could push him further. Reflecting him, I said, “The soul of an elephant, I wonder what it's like!”
es: –You are saying absolutely ridiculous nonsense! He was waking up a lot, so I set out to delve a little deeper into the matter. –I wonder -I said thoughtfully- what an elephant's soul is like.

en: The effect I desired was obtained, for he at once fell from his high-horse and became a child again.
vi: I achieved the desired effect on my patient's demeanor, as immediately afterward, he lost his haughty attitude and instead behaved like a child:
tr: The effect I desired had occurred, because he immediately calmed down and became childlike again.
es: I achieved the effect I desired, as he came down from the heights and turned back into a child.

en: “I don’t want an elephant’s soul, or any soul at all!” he said. For a few moments he sat despondently. Suddenly he jumped to his feet, with his eyes blazing and all the signs of intense cerebral excitement. “To hell with you and your souls!” he shouted. “Why do you plague me about souls? Haven’t I got enough to worry, and pain, and distract me already, without thinking of souls!” He looked so hostile that I thought he was in for another homicidal fit, so I blew my whistle. The instant, however, that I did so he became calm, and said apologetically:—
vi: — I don't care about the soul of the elephant, nor do I need any soul at all. Then he sat there motionless like a statue and didn't say another word. After a while, he suddenly stood up, forcefully kicked the stool aside, his eyes glaring wildly as if he had just thought of something. — Damn you and your spirits! - He snapped. - Why do you keep bothering me with such wicked spirits? It's not just the spirits; there are so many other things in this life that make me so stressed and dizzy that I feel like I'm going insane, do you understand? His sudden fit of rage startled me, as I feared I was about to receive a severe beating from him. Therefore, I had to immediately pull out the whistle from my pocket and blow it loudly to call the supervisors. He immediately softened his tone and apologized to me:
tr: “I don't want the soul of an elephant; I don't want any soul!” he said. He sat in despair for a few seconds. Suddenly, his eyes lit up and he jumped to his feet with a sign of intense mental excitement. “To hell with you and your souls!” he shouted. “Stop nagging me with souls. Don't I already have enough worries, enough to cause me pain and confusion, other than thinking about souls!” He looked so aggressive that I thought he was having another murderous fit, so I blew my whistle. But, as soon as I did that, he calmed down and apologized, saying:
es: –I don't want the soul of an elephant, nor any soul at all! – he said. For a few moments, he remained seated, as if dejected. Suddenly, he stood up, with his eyes shining and all the signs of great cerebral excitement. –Go to hell with your souls! – he shouted. Why do you bother me with your souls? Do you think I don't already have enough to worry about, suffer from, and distract myself with, without thinking about souls? He had such a hostile look that I thought he was about to carry out another homicidal attack, so I blew my whistle. However, the moment I did, he calmed down and said, in an apologetic tone:

en: “Forgive me, Doctor; I forgot myself. You do not need any help. I am so worried in my mind that I am apt to be irritable. If you only knew the problem I have to face, and that I am working out, you would pity, and tolerate, and pardon me. Pray do not put me in a strait-waistcoat. I want to think and I cannot think freely when my body is confined. I am sure you will understand!” He had evidently self-control; so when the attendants came I told them not to mind, and they withdrew. Renfield watched them go; when the door was closed he said, with considerable dignity and sweetness:—
vi: — Sorry, doctor, I forgot. You don't need to call anyone at all. There are too many concerns that make me lose my temper irrationally. If you understood the problem I need to solve, you surely wouldn't blame me. Please don't make me wear the straitjacket again! I need to think, and I can't think when my body is restrained like a prisoner. I hope you understand and sympathize! Of course, he had completely mastered himself when he spoke to me in a gentle voice. When the wardens rushed over, I told them they could withdraw. Renfield stood still, watching them leave. After the door had closed behind them, he told me, his voice still gentle but somewhat more serious:
tr: “Forgive me, Doctor; I lost myself. You don't need any help. I am so anxious that I have a tendency to get angry quickly. If you knew the problem I have to face and try to solve, you would pity me, understand me, and forgive me. I beg you, don't put me in a straitjacket. I want to think, and I can't think clearly when my body is restrained. I'm sure you will understand!” Clearly, he could control himself; therefore, when the nurses arrived, I told them not to mind and they withdrew. Renfield watched them leave; when the door closed, he said with great dignity and sweetness:
es: –Forgive me, doctor; I lost control. You do not need any kind of help. I am so worried that I get irritated easily. If you knew the problem I have to face and find a solution for, you would pity me, tolerate me, and excuse me. I beg you not to put me in a straitjacket. I wish to reflect and I cannot do so when my body is tied up. I am sure you will understand! It was evident that he had self-control, so when the attendants arrived, I told them they could leave. Renfield watched them as they walked away; when they closed the door, he said, with considerable dignity and gentleness:

en: “Dr. Seward, you have been very considerate towards me. Believe me that I am very, very grateful to you!” I thought it well to leave him in this mood, and so I came away. There is certainly something to ponder over in this man’s state. Several points seem to make what the American interviewer calls “a story,” if one could only get them in proper order. Here they are:—
vi: — Dr. Seward, you have indeed been very dedicated to me these past few days, and I truly appreciate your noble heart. I just nodded and left, leaving him with the thought that he couldn't get out of his head. His case truly deserves my utmost attention for thorough examination and monitoring. Now, I can draw out some points that I had not noticed about him for a long time:
tr: "Dr. Seward, you have been very understanding towards me. Believe me, I am very, very grateful to you!" I thought it was good to leave him in this state of mind and thus left the room. Undoubtedly, there was something in this man's condition that needed to be pondered over. If one could sequence it correctly, there seemed to be many points that would form what American reporters call a "story," here they are:
es: –Doctor Seward, you have been very considerate with me. Believe me, I am very grateful to you! I thought it would be convenient to leave at that moment, so I left. There is certainly something to think about regarding that man's condition. Several points seem to form what American journalists call "a story"; it is only necessary to put them in order. Let's try it.

en: Will not mention “drinking.”
vi: He had never mentioned the word "drink".
tr: He is not talking about "drinking."
es: He does not wish to mention the word "drink".

en: Fears the thought of being burdened with the “soul” of anything.
vi: He feared the thought of being disturbed by the "soul" of any creature.
tr: He is afraid of bearing the burden of the "soul" of anything.
es: He fears feeling burdened with the "soul" of something.

en: Has no dread of wanting “life” in the future.
vi: He is not afraid of lacking what he needs "to live".
tr: He has no reservations about a lack of "life" in the future.
es: He is not afraid to think about "life" in the future.

en: Despises the meaner forms of life altogether, though he dreads being haunted by their souls.
vi: He despises all forms of lower life, that is "small animals", although he suspects he is haunted by their spirits.
tr: Despite being afraid of pursuing their souls, they completely disdain lower forms of life.
es: He despises all lower forms of life, although he fears being tormented by their souls.

en: Logically all these things point one way! he has assurance of some kind that he will acquire some higher life. He dreads the consequence—the burden of a soul. Then it is a human life he looks to!
vi: Logically speaking, all of this indicates that he has a very strong belief in a higher form of life. But he is very afraid of bearing a spiritual burden! That is his view of life!
tr: Logically, all of this points to one thing! In some way, he has the assurance of a higher life. He is afraid of the outcome - the burden of the soul. Then, what he relies on is human life!
es: Logically, all those points indicate something! He has the certainty, in a way, that he will come to acquire a certain form of superior life. He fears the consequence... the burden of a soul. Therefore, it is a human life that he is seeking!

en: And the assurance—?
vi: But what about his faith? Where did that faith come from?...
tr: But what about assurance?
es: As for the certainty...?

en: Merciful God! the Count has been to him, and there is some new scheme of terror afoot!
vi: Lord, save us from suffering and distress! It was Count Dracula who came to him and planted the seed of delusional faith in his mind. Is there any more horror awaiting us?
tr: Forgiving God! The Count has gone to him, and a new cabinet of horrors is being turned!
es: Good God! The count has been with him and some other tremendous horror is being prepared!

en: Later.—I went after my round to Van Helsing and told him my suspicion. He grew very grave; and, after thinking the matter over for a while asked me to take him to Renfield. I did so. As we came to the door we heard the lunatic within singing gaily, as he used to do in the time which now seems so long ago. When we entered we saw with amazement that he had spread out his sugar as of old; the flies, lethargic with the autumn, were beginning to buzz into the room. We tried to make him talk of the subject of our previous conversation, but he would not attend. He went on with his singing, just as though we had not been present. He had got a scrap of paper and was folding it into a note-book. We had to come away as ignorant as we went in.
vi: • A moment later I told Van Helsing about my suspicions regarding Renfield. It seemed that my story made him think a lot. After listening to me for a while, he suggested that I take him to meet Renfield. As we approached his room, we were slightly surprised to hear singing, a very cheerful voice. Entering the room, we were even more surprised to see sugar granules scattered all over the window sill. Flies, which are not plentiful in the autumn, began to swarm into the room. We intended to steer him back to the conversation I had just had with him, but it was futile; he kept singing as if we weren't even there. He was folding a piece of paper and then tucking it into his notebook. We had no choice but to quietly leave as we had just arrived.
tr: Later. - After completing my rounds, I went to Van Helsing and told him my suspicion. He became very serious and, after thinking about the matter for a while, asked me to take him to Renfield. I did so. When we reached the door, we heard the madman singing cheerfully, as he used to do in times that now seemed long past. When we entered, we saw in astonishment that he was scattering his sugar as before; the flies, sluggish with autumn, had started buzzing around the room. We tried to get him to talk about the subject of our previous conversation, but he wouldn't engage with us. He continued singing as if we weren't there. He had found a piece of paper and was folding it to make a notebook. We left as ignorant as we had entered.
es: Later. I went to see Van Helsing after finishing my rounds and told him my suspicions. He became very serious and, after reflecting on it for a moment, asked me to take him to see Renfield. So I did. When we arrived at the door of the madman's room, we heard him singing inside with great joy, as he used to do in a time that seemed to be far behind. Upon entering, we saw that he had spread out the sugar, as he used to do before, and that the flies, immersed in the lethargy of autumn, were already beginning to buzz in the room. We tried to make him talk about the subject of our previous conversation, but he refused to pay us any attention. He continued singing, as if we were not there with him at all. He had obtained a piece of paper and was folding it inside a notebook. We had to leave, without having learned anything new.

en: His is a curious case indeed; we must watch him to-night.
vi: Tonight, I have to watch to see if he plans to do anything suspicious.
tr: Indeed, it was an unprecedented case; we must keep him under observation tonight.
es: It is really a curious case. We will have to watch it tonight.

en: Letter, Mitchell, Sons and Candy to Lord Godalming.
vi: Letter from Mitchell, Sons & Candy to Lord Godalming
tr: Mitchell, Sons & Candy Letter to Lord Godalming
es: Letter from Mitchell, Sons Candy to Lord Godalming

en: “1 October.
vi: "October 1st"
tr: October 1
es: October 1

en: “My Lord,
vi: Dear Lord,
tr: My lord,
es: "Your Honor:"

en: “We are at all times only too happy to meet your wishes. We beg, with regard to the desire of your Lordship, expressed by Mr. Harker on your behalf, to supply the following information concerning the sale and purchase of No. 347, Piccadilly. The original vendors are the executors of the late Mr. Archibald Winter-Suffield. The purchaser is a foreign nobleman, Count de Ville, who effected the purchase himself paying the purchase money in notes ‘over the counter,’ if your Lordship will pardon us using so vulgar an expression. Beyond this we know nothing whatever of him.
vi: We are truly honored to have the opportunity to serve you again and to be permitted to provide you - at the request of Mr. Jonathan Harker - with information regarding the purchase of the hotel at 347 Piccadilly. According to the wishes of the executors of the will of Archibald Winter Suffield, this property has been sold to Count Ville, a foreigner who directly conducted the transaction and paid for the house. Beyond this, we do not have any additional details about this foreigner.
tr: We always take great pleasure in fulfilling your wishes. Based on the desires expressed on your behalf by Mr. Harker, I am pleased to provide the following information regarding the purchase and sale of 347 Piccadilly. The initial sellers are the trustees of the late Mr. Archibald Winter-Suffield. The buyer, who carried out the purchase himself and, if your Lordship would pardon me for using such a crude term, paid the sale price in cash "over the counter," is a foreign nobleman named Count de Ville. Beyond this, we have no information about him.
es: "We are always very willing to satisfy your desires. We are in a position, with respect to Your Lordship's wishes, expressed by Mr. Harker on your behalf, to provide the required information about number three hundred and forty-seven Piccadilly. The original sellers are the heirs of the late Mr. Archibald Winter Suffield. The buyer is a foreign nobleman, Count de Ville, who personally made the purchase, paying the stipulated price in cash, if Your Lordship excuses the use of such an exceedingly vulgar expression. Apart from this, we know absolutely nothing more about the mentioned count.

en: “We are, my Lord,
vi: Beyond this, we do not have any additional details about this foreigner.
tr: You are the respectful servants of our Lord
es: "We are, sir, the most humble servants of Your Lordship,

en: “Your Lordship’s humble servants,
vi: Hope to have the opportunity to serve you again.
tr: You are the respectful servants of our Lord
es: "We are, sir, the most humble servants of Your Lordship,

en: “Mitchell, Sons & Candy.”
vi: Mitchell, Sons & Candy
tr: MITCHELL, SONS & CANDY
es: "MITCHEL, SONS CANDY "

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 2 October.—I placed a man in the corridor last night, and told him to make an accurate note of any sound he might hear from Renfield’s room, and gave him instructions that if there should be anything strange he was to call me. After dinner, when we had all gathered round the fire in the study—Mrs. Harker having gone to bed—we discussed the attempts and discoveries of the day. Harker was the only one who had any result, and we are in great hopes that his clue may be an important one.
vi: • October 2 Last night, I ordered a guard to stand in the hallway outside Renfield's room to monitor him: he was not allowed to leave his position for even a minute, and if he noticed anything unusual, he had to report it to me immediately. After dinner, we gathered around the fire in my room to smoke (of course, Mina had already gone to bed to rest). Everyone was lost in their own thoughts. Indeed, only Jonathan enabled our work to succeed, and we all acknowledged his crucial role.
tr: October 2. - Last night, I stationed a man in the corridor and instructed him to meticulously note every sound coming from Renfield’s room and to call me if anything unusual occurred. After dinner, when we all gathered around the fire in the study -after Ms. Harker had gone to bed- we discussed the day’s endeavors and findings. Harker was the only one who had made any progress, and we have high hopes that the clue he found might be significant.
es: October 2nd. I placed a man in the hallway during the last night to provide an exact report of all the noises he might hear in Renfield's room, giving him instructions to call me immediately if anything unusual occurred. After dinner, when we were all gathered around the fire in the study, and after Mrs. Harker had retired to her rooms, we discussed the attempts and discoveries we had made during that day. Harker was the only one of us who had obtained results, and we have great hopes that the clues he has found may be of great importance.

en: Before going to bed I went round to the patient’s room and looked in through the observation trap. He was sleeping soundly, and his heart rose and fell with regular respiration.
vi: Before going on break, I went back to the night supervisor to see if there were any issues. When I reached Renfield's room, I looked at him through the glass door: he was sleeping soundly with steady breaths.
tr: Before going to bed, I went to the patient's room and looked through the peephole. He was sleeping soundly, and his chest was rising and falling with his regular breathing.
es: Before going to bed, I took a walk through the patients' rooms and looked through the peephole in the door. Renfield was sleeping deeply, and his chest rose and fell regularly.

en: This morning the man on duty reported to me that a little after midnight he was restless and kept saying his prayers somewhat loudly. I asked him if that was all; he replied that it was all he heard. There was something about his manner so suspicious that I asked him point blank if he had been asleep. He denied sleep, but admitted to having “dozed” for a while. It is too bad that men cannot be trusted unless they are watched.
vi: But this morning, the warden came to report to me that shortly after midnight, Renfield suddenly woke up and kept screaming and babbling prayers. When I asked if there was anything else, the warden replied that was all. I became suspicious: perhaps he had fallen asleep. When I mentioned this, he vehemently denied that he had fallen asleep, claiming he had only "dozed off for a moment." Today, Jonathan continues his journey with the hope of finding the traces he discovered yesterday, while Lord Godalming and Quincey go to buy horses.
tr: This morning, the attendant told me that he felt uneasy shortly after midnight and recited his prayers a bit louder. I asked him if that was all; he replied saying that was all he heard. There was something so suspicious in his manner that I directly asked him if he had slept. He denied sleeping, but admitted to having "dozed off" for a while.
