It's very unfortunate that people cannot be trusted unless they are being watched.
es: This morning, the man who remained on duty informed me that after midnight he was restless and reciting his prayers in a somewhat loud voice. I asked him if that was all, and he replied that that was all he had heard. There was something in his manner that seemed so suspicious that I frankly asked him if he had fallen asleep. He denied it but admitted to having dozed off for a while. It is unfortunate that one cannot trust men unless they are being watched.

en: To-day Harker is out following up his clue, and Art and Quincey are looking after horses. Godalming thinks that it will be well to have horses always in readiness, for when we get the information which we seek there will be no time to lose. We must sterilise all the imported earth between sunrise and sunset; we shall thus catch the Count at his weakest, and without a refuge to fly to. Van Helsing is off to the British Museum looking up some authorities on ancient medicine. The old physicians took account of things which their followers do not accept, and the Professor is searching for witch and demon cures which may be useful to us later.
vi: Today, Jonathan continues his journey with the hope of finding the traces he discovered yesterday, while Lord Godalming and Quincey go to buy horses. The Lord believes that at this moment, any information we are waiting for cannot be wasted due to our delay. From sunrise to sunset, we must find a way to neutralize the soil contained in the wooden crates; only then can we face the Count when he is almost powerless and without a hiding place. As for Van Helsing, he has gone to the British Museum to research ancient medical books. Ancient physicians often had concepts that we no longer accept today.
tr: Today, Harker is out following the lead, and Art and Quincey are looking after the horses. Godalming thinks it would be good to have horses always ready because once we obtain the information we are looking for, we will have no time to lose. We must purify all the soil brought from outside between sunrise and sunset; thus, we will catch the Count at his weakest, without a refuge to escape to quickly. Van Helsing went to the British Museum to find someone who is an expert in ancient remedies. Ancient physicians would consider things that physicians of the subsequent generations did not accept, and the Professor is looking for witch and demon treatment methods that might be useful to us later.
es: Today, Harker has gone out to follow his trail and Art and Quincey have gone to get horses. Godalming thinks it would be convenient to always have the horses ready, as when we get the reports we are looking for, there may be no time to lose. We must sterilize all the imported soil between sunrise and sunset. That way we can take the count at his weakest point, and without a place where he can take refuge. Van Helsing has gone to the British Museum looking for certain authorities on ancient medicine. The ancient doctors took certain things into account that their followers did not accept and the professor is looking for cures against demons and spells, which may be useful to us later.

en: I sometimes think we must be all mad and that we shall wake to sanity in strait-waistcoats.
vi: The professor wants to find remedies against magic and evil that he believes will be useful to us later.
tr: From time to time, I think that we all need to be crazy and that we will realize our sanity within straitjackets.
es: Sometimes I think that we must all be completely crazy and that we will regain our sanity by seeing ourselves locked in straitjackets.

en: Later.—We have met again. We seem at last to be on the track, and our work of to-morrow may be the beginning of the end. I wonder if Renfield’s quiet has anything to do with this. His moods have so followed the doings of the Count, that the coming destruction of the monster may be carried to him in some subtle way. If we could only get some hint as to what passed in his mind, between the time of my argument with him to-day and his resumption of fly-catching, it might afford us a valuable clue. He is now seemingly quiet for a spell.... Is he?—— That wild yell seemed to come from his room....
vi: • After a while We sat down for another meeting. If the traces of the old count are clearly discovered, then perhaps tomorrow will mark the beginning of the end of this terrible story. I wonder if Renfield's current calmness has anything to do with the present situation. If only we knew what was going through his mind from the time I talked to him until he started catching flies, things would have been easier to judge... The warden suddenly rushed in to inform me that Renfield was in trouble; it seemed he had just had an accident.
tr: Later on. - We have come together again. At least, it seems like we are on the trail, and tomorrow's work could be the beginning of the end. I wonder if Renfield's calmness has anything to do with this. His moods matched the Count's actions so well that he might somehow be aware of the monster's impending destruction. If we could get an idea of what went through his mind in the time between our discussion today and his resumption of catching flies, it might have given us a valuable clue. Now he seems to be calm as if under a spell... Is that so? - That wild scream seems to be coming from his room...
es: Later. We have gathered again. It seems that we are finally on the right track and that tomorrow's work may very well be the beginning of the end. I wonder if Renfield's calmness has anything to do with it. His mood swings have been so closely aligned with the count's movements that the imminent destruction of the monster may have been revealed to him in some subtle way. If we could have some idea of what is going on in his mind, especially between the moment I was talking to him and the moment he returned to his fly-catching, I could consider it a valuable clue. Apparently, he was going to be calm for a while... Could it be true...? That horrible scream seems to come from his room...

en: The attendant came bursting into my room and told me that Renfield had somehow met with some accident. He had heard him yell; and when he went to him found him lying on his face on the floor, all covered with blood. I must go at once....
vi: The warden suddenly rushed in to inform me that Renfield was in trouble; it seemed he had just had an accident. Hearing his pitiful cries, the warden hurried in and saw him lying sprawled on the floor, face down, covered in blood. I immediately rushed to his room...
tr: The nurse burst into my room and said that Renfield had had some sort of accident. He had heard his screams, and when he went to him, he was lying face down on the floor, and there was blood everywhere. I must go immediately...
es: The attendant rushed into my room and told me that somehow, Renfield had had an accident. He had heard his scream and when he went to his room, he found him collapsed on the floor, face down and all covered in blood. I must go see him immediately...

en: CHAPTER XXI
vi: CHAPTER 21
tr: XXI
es: XXI.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DR. SEWARD

en: 3 October.—Let me put down with exactness all that happened, as well as I can remember it, since last I made an entry. Not a detail that I can recall must be forgotten; in all calmness I must proceed.
vi: • October 3 I would like to recount exactly everything that has happened - as much as I can remember - since this diary was temporarily closed. I will try not to omit any detail that still lingers in my memory.
tr: October 3. - Let me record everything that has happened since my last entry here, as completely as I can remember. Not a single detail that I can recall should be forgotten; I must begin with all my composure.
es: October 3rd. Let me express exactly everything that happened, just as I remember it since the last time I wrote in the diary. I must do it calmly, as I must not overlook a single detail that I remember.

en: When I came to Renfield’s room I found him lying on the floor on his left side in a glittering pool of blood. When I went to move him, it became at once apparent that he had received some terrible injuries; there seemed none of that unity of purpose between the parts of the body which marks even lethargic sanity. As the face was exposed I could see that it was horribly bruised, as though it had been beaten against the floor—indeed it was from the face wounds that the pool of blood originated. The attendant who was kneeling beside the body said to me as we turned him over:—
vi: When I arrived at Renfield's room, he was still lying sprawled in a pool of blood on the floor, his body slightly tilted to the left. As I bent down to lift him up, I realized that he was severely injured, especially on his face: his face was the source of the blood pooling on the floor, it seemed as though he had been repeatedly slammed face-first into the ground. Bending down with me to turn him over, the warden stammered:
tr: When I came to Renfield's room, I found him lying on the floor in a pool of blood shining on his left side. When I went to move him, the fact that he had sustained horrific injuries immediately became apparent; there was nothing among the limbs of the body that indicated any unity of purpose, even if sluggishly. When his face came into view, I saw that it was horrifically battered as if it had been smashed against the ground - indeed, the pool of blood on the floor was coming from the wounds on his face. The nurse, who was kneeling beside the body, said as he turned Renfield over: "I think his back is broken, sir.
es: When I arrived at Renfield's room, I found him lying on his side on the floor, in the middle of a pool of blood. When I set about moving him, I realized that he had received several terrible wounds; there did not seem to be that unity of purpose among the parts of the body, which seem to mark even lethargic sanity. Upon observing his face, I could see that it was horribly bruised, as if it had been smashed against the floor... in fact, it was from the wounds on his face that the pool of blood had emerged. The assistant who was kneeling beside the body said to me, as we turned the body over:

en: “I think, sir, his back is broken. See, both his right arm and leg and the whole side of his face are paralysed.” How such a thing could have happened puzzled the attendant beyond measure. He seemed quite bewildered, and his brows were gathered in as he said:—
vi: — He must have broken his spine. Look at him, his right hand, right leg, and the entire side of his face are all paralyzed. I don't understand how he had such a serious accident. This is the question that made the proctor extremely surprised and embarrassed. — I don't understand why at all. - He frowned and admitted.
tr: The nurse, who was kneeling beside the body, said as he turned Renfield over: "I think his back is broken, sir. Look, his right arm and leg, and that entire side of his face are paralyzed!" Such a thing had greatly surprised the nurse. He seemed bewildered and his brows were furrowed as he continued speaking:
es: –I believe, sir, that his back is broken. Look, both his arm and his right leg, as well as the right side of his face, are paralyzed. The assistant was absolutely stunned, as he couldn't explain how something like that could have happened. He seemed absolutely bewildered and his eyebrows were very furrowed when he said:

en: “I can’t understand the two things. He could mark his face like that by beating his own head on the floor. I saw a young woman do it once at the Eversfield Asylum before anyone could lay hands on her. And I suppose he might have broke his neck by falling out of bed, if he got in an awkward kink. But for the life of me I can’t imagine how the two things occurred. If his back was broke, he couldn’t beat his head; and if his face was like that before the fall out of bed, there would be marks of it.” I said to him:—
vi: - Of course, he was injured because his face was repeatedly slammed into the floor. In the past, when I worked at Eversfield Hospital, I once saw a woman in a similar condition before someone managed to intervene in time. If his neck was broken, one could say he fell because he missed a step getting out of bed, but in this case, he was injured in the face and had a broken spine, it's really hard to understand... If his back was broken like this, how could he have slammed his face into the ground, and if he was already badly injured in the face before falling off the bed, there should be bloodstains on the bedding, right?
tr: “There are two things I can’t understand. He could have injured his face like this by hitting his head on the ground. Once, at Eversfield Asylum, I saw a young woman do this before anyone could even touch her. And he might have broken his back if his body was twisted in a strange way while falling out of bed. But I swear, I can’t imagine how both happened at the same time. If his back was broken, he couldn’t have hit his head, and if his face was like this before he fell out of bed, there would be marks of it.”
es: –I cannot understand either of the two things. One can mark their face like this, by hitting their head against the floor. On one occasion I saw a young woman who did this at the Eversfield Asylum, before anyone could stop her. And I suppose she could have broken her back by falling from the bed, if she did so in a bad position. But I assure you that it is impossible for me to imagine how both things could have happened at the same time. If her back was broken, she couldn't have hit her head, and if her face was already like that before falling from the bed, then there would be a trace of blood. Then, I said to him:

en: “Go to Dr. Van Helsing, and ask him to kindly come here at once. I want him without an instant’s delay.” The man ran off, and within a few minutes the Professor, in his dressing gown and slippers, appeared. When he saw Renfield on the ground, he looked keenly at him a moment, and then turned to me. I think he recognised my thought in my eyes, for he said very quietly, manifestly for the ears of the attendant:—
vi: — Run and get Dr. Van Helsing here immediately - I ordered - I need him here right now? The warden hurriedly ran to call, and a few minutes later he was seen rushing back with Van Helsing. Seeing Renfield lying on the ground, the professor observed in astonishment and then turned to tell me:
tr: I said: “Go to Dr. Van Helsing and kindly ask him to come here immediately. I want him without a moment’s delay.” The man ran out and within a few minutes, the Professor appeared in his dressing gown and slippers. When he saw Renfield on the floor, he looked at him sharply for a moment and then turned to me. I think he saw what I was thinking in my eyes, because he said quietly, clearly addressing the nurse’s ears: “Ah, a sad accident!
es: –Go find Dr. Van Helsing and beg him to be so kind as to come here as soon as possible. I want to see him immediately. The man ran away and a few minutes later the professor appeared, in pajamas and wearing his slippers. When he saw Renfield on the ground, he looked at him sharply and turned towards me. I think he recognized what I was thinking, as if it were clearly reflected in my eyes, since he said calmly, manifestly for the assistant to hear:

en: “Ah, a sad accident! He will need very careful watching, and much attention. I shall stay with you myself; but I shall first dress myself. If you will remain I shall in a few minutes join you.”
vi: — A truly unfortunate accident! We need to monitor him continuously, don't leave him alone anymore. Perhaps I will stay with him. But now I need to go home and change clothes first, who would wear pajamas like this. If you are still here, we will meet again in a few minutes.
tr: I think he saw what I was thinking in my eyes, because he said quietly, clearly addressing the nurse’s ears: “Ah, a sad accident! He needs to be kept under great supervision and taken care of very well. I will stay with you, but first I need to get dressed. If you wait, I will join you in a few minutes.”
es: –What a sad accident! He will need very attentive supervision and a lot of care. I am going to stay with you; but first, I am going to get dressed. If you want to stay here, I will join you in a few moments.

en: The patient was now breathing stertorously and it was easy to see that he had suffered some terrible injury. Van Helsing returned with extraordinary celerity, bearing with him a surgical case. He had evidently been thinking and had his mind made up; for, almost before he looked at the patient, he whispered to me:—
vi: Renfield suddenly let out a roar, clearly experiencing the most excruciating pain of his life. A few minutes later, Van Helsing returned with a surgical kit in hand. While heading back to the changing room, he had already devised a solution for my patient. Before examining him, he whispered in my ear:
tr: The patient was now breathing with a wheeze, and it was easy to see that he was suffering terribly from his injuries. Van Helsing returned with his surgical bag at an extraordinary speed. It was clear that he had thought and made a decision, because almost before looking at the patient, he whispered to me:
es: The patient was now breathing stertorously, and it was easy to understand that he had suffered some terrible injury. Van Helsing returned with extraordinary speed, bringing with him a case of surgical instruments. It was evident that he had been thinking and had made up his mind, since, even before taking a look at the patient, he whispered to me:

en: “Send the attendant away. We must be alone with him when he becomes conscious, after the operation.” So I said:—
vi: — Tell that supervisor to go outside. After the surgery, Renfield will regain consciousness, and I want only us to be here with him then. — Thank you, Simmons, - I said to the warden - we have done everything we could.
tr: "Send the nurse away from here." "We need to be alone with him when he wakes up after the surgery." Therefore, I said:
es: –Send the assistant out. We need to be alone with him for when he recovers from the operation. Therefore, I said:

en: “I think that will do now, Simmons. We have done all that we can at present. You had better go your round, and Dr. Van Helsing will operate. Let me know instantly if there be anything unusual anywhere.”
vi: — Thank you, Simmons, - I said to the warden - we have done everything we could. Now, we need to wait and see. Doctor Van Helsing needs to operate on him. Go visit the other patients. If anything unusual happens, come back and inform me immediately.
tr: “I think that's enough for now, Simmons. We've done everything we can for the moment. You'd better return to your rounds, Dr. Van Helsing will perform the surgery. If anything unusual happens anywhere, let me know immediately.”
es: I think that's all, Simmons. We've already done everything we could do. You'd better go take care of your rounds; Dr. Van Helsing is going to operate on the patient. If there's anything strange anywhere, let me know immediately.

en: The man withdrew, and we went into a strict examination of the patient. The wounds of the face was superficial; the real injury was a depressed fracture of the skull, extending right up through the motor area. The Professor thought a moment and said:—
vi: We waited for him to leave before we began to thoroughly examine the patient again. His face was only injured on the outside. The more serious issue was a rather long fracture in the skull. Van Helsing pondered for a moment and then told me:
tr: The man stepped aside and we carefully began to examine the patient. The wounds on his face were superficial; the main injury was a fracture extending directly to the motor area of the skull. The professor thought for a moment and said:
es: The man withdrew, and we carefully examined the patient. The wounds on his face were superficial; the real injury was a skull fracture that extended over the motor region. The professor reflected for a moment and said:

en: “We must reduce the pressure and get back to normal conditions, as far as can be; the rapidity of the suffusion shows the terrible nature of his injury. The whole motor area seems affected. The suffusion of the brain will increase quickly, so we must trephine at once or it may be too late.” As he was speaking there was a soft tapping at the door. I went over and opened it and found in the corridor without, Arthur and Quincey in pajamas and slippers: the former spoke:—
vi: — First of all, we must lower the arterial blood pressure to normal levels if possible, his pulse is terrifyingly fast, his skull is definitely injured, we need to perform a trephination to drain the hematoma immediately, otherwise it will be too late. He hadn't finished speaking when suddenly there was a knock at the door outside. I hurried out to see who it was, and it turned out to be Arthur and Quincey, both still in their pajamas.
tr: “We must reduce the pressure and return to normal conditions as much as possible; the speed of the burn shows the terrible nature of the wound. The entire motor region seems to be affected. The bleeding in the brain will increase rapidly, so we must drill the skull immediately or it might be too late.” As he was speaking, there was a slow knock on the door. I went and opened it, finding Arthur and Quincey in their pajamas and slippers in the hallway outside. Arthur spoke:
es: –We must reduce the pressure and return to normal conditions as much as possible; the rapidity of the suffusion shows the terrible nature of the damage. The entire motor region seems to be affected. The suffusion of the brain will increase rapidly, we must perform trepanation immediately if we do not want it to be too late. While he was speaking, there were some soft taps on the door; I went to it, opened it, and found Quincey and Arthur standing in the hallway, in pajamas and slippers; the latter spoke:

en: “I heard your man call up Dr. Van Helsing and tell him of an accident. So I woke Quincey or rather called for him as he was not asleep. Things are moving too quickly and too strangely for sound sleep for any of us these times. I’ve been thinking that to-morrow night will not see things as they have been. We’ll have to look back—and forward a little more than we have done. May we come in?” I nodded, and held the door open till they had entered; then I closed it again. When Quincey saw the attitude and state of the patient, and noted the horrible pool on the floor, he said softly:—
vi: — I heard the invigilator calling Dr. Van Helsing and talking about the accident. - Godalming explained to me. - That's why I called Quincey to come here. The events that happened in succession were so confusing that the two of us couldn't sleep. To be honest, lying with my hand on my forehead, I suddenly suspected that tomorrow, the direction of everything around us might change. We have to reassess what has been left behind, and even look a bit further at what we have achieved so far. — Can we come in? I opened the door, invited them in, and then closed the door tightly again. Seeing Renfield lying in a pool of blood, Quincey asked, his face turning pale:
tr: “I heard that your man called Dr. Van Helsing and told him about an accident. Therefore, I woke Quincey up, or rather, I called him since he hadn't slept yet. Events are progressing too quickly and too strangely to allow any of us to sleep soundly at such times. I think everything will be different from before tomorrow night. We will need to look at the past - and the future - more than we have so far. Can we come in?” I nodded my head "yes" and kept the door open until they entered; then I closed it again. When Quincey saw the patient's position and condition and the horrifying pool on the floor, he softly said:
es: –I heard his assistant calling Dr. Van Helsing and talking about an accident. Consequently, I woke Quincey or, rather, I called him, since he was already awake. Things are happening too quickly and in too strange a manner for us to sleep deeply these days. I've been thinking that tomorrow night we won't see things as they have happened. We will have to look back and forward a bit more than we have been doing. Can we come in? I nodded, and held the door open until they were inside; then, I closed it again. When Quincey saw the patient's condition and attitude and noticed the horrible pool of blood on the floor, he said softly:

en: “My God! what has happened to him? Poor, poor devil!” I told him briefly, and added that we expected he would recover consciousness after the operation—for a short time, at all events. He went at once and sat down on the edge of the bed, with Godalming beside him; we all watched in patience.
vi: — Oh Lord, what has happened to this poor fellow? I briefly summarized the events that had occurred and also expressed my hope to Van Helsing: Renfield would regain consciousness, even if only for a moment, after the surgery. Hearing me speak, Quincey quietly sat down on the edge of the bed, and Arthur came to stand beside him. All of us attentively watched Renfield.
tr: “My God! What happened to him?” “Poor, poor devil!” I briefly explained to him what had happened and added that we were waiting for him to regain consciousness after the surgery - at least for a short while. He immediately went and sat by the bedside, with Godalming next to him; we all watched patiently.
es: –Good heavens! What has happened to him? Poor devil! I explained it to him briefly and added that we hoped he would regain consciousness after the operation… at least for a short time. He immediately went to sit at the edge of the bed, with Godalming by his side, and we all waited patiently.

en: “We shall wait,” said Van Helsing, “just long enough to fix the best spot for trephining, so that we may most quickly and perfectly remove the blood clot; for it is evident that the hæmorrhage is increasing.”
vi: — We need to wait a moment, - Van Helsing told us - I have to check exactly where to make the incision to remove the blood clot. Clearly, the patient's hemorrhaging is becoming more severe by the moment.
tr: “For the incision procedure,” said Van Helsing, “we will wait until we determine the most suitable point; thus, we will be able to remove the blood clot from there in the fastest and most accurate way because it is clear that the bleeding has increased.”
es: –We must wait -said Van Helsing- to determine the best possible site to perform the trepanation, so we can remove the blood clot as quickly and efficiently as possible, since it is evident that the hemorrhage is increasing.

en: The minutes during which we waited passed with fearful slowness. I had a horrible sinking in my heart, and from Van Helsing’s face I gathered that he felt some fear or apprehension as to what was to come. I dreaded the words that Renfield might speak. I was positively afraid to think; but the conviction of what was coming was on me, as I have read of men who have heard the death-watch. The poor man’s breathing came in uncertain gasps. Each instant he seemed as though he would open his eyes and speak; but then would follow a prolonged stertorous breath, and he would relapse into a more fixed insensibility. Inured as I was to sick beds and death, this suspense grew, and grew upon me. I could almost hear the beating of my own heart; and the blood surging through my temples sounded like blows from a hammer. The silence finally became agonising. I looked at my companions, one after another, and saw from their flushed faces and damp brows that they were enduring equal torture. There was a nervous suspense over us all, as though overhead some dread bell would peal out powerfully when we should least expect it.
vi: Each minute passed by slowly and terrifyingly. We all fixed our eyes on Dr. Van Helsing, everything now depended on his diagnosis. As for myself, to be honest, I didn't believe Renfield could tell us anything. I didn't even dare to think about it. The breathing of the unfortunate man was becoming more and more interrupted, although there were moments when he gave me the impression he was about to open his eyes to say a few words. His groans also became more labored, he was sinking into a complete coma. I felt I could no longer bear the overwhelming emotions surging within me because of him. Looking at the beads of sweat on my friends' foreheads, I understood that they were sharing the same feeling as I was.
tr: The minutes we waited passed with a dreadful slowness. There was a terrible sinking feeling in my heart, and from Van Helsing's face, I concluded that he too felt fear or anxiety about what was to come. I was afraid of the words Renfield might say. I was definitely afraid to think, but from what I had read about those who sense the death throes, I had an idea of what was going to happen. The poor man's breath was barely perceptible. She seemed as if she could open her eyes and speak at any moment, but then this was followed by long, rattling breaths, and then she would lapse into an even more stagnant stupor. Despite being accustomed to sickbeds and death, this doubt grew and grew within me. I could almost hear my own heartbeat, and the sound of blood rushing to my temples felt like hammer blows. The silence eventually turned into torture. I looked at my friends one by one and realized from their flushed faces and wet foreheads that they were enduring the same torture. Over all of us, there was a disturbing doubt, as if a terrible bell would ring above our heads at the most unexpected moment.
es: The minutes during which we were waiting passed with dreadful slowness. I had a terrible thought, and from van Helsing's expression, I understood that he felt a certain fear or apprehension about what was going to happen. I feared the words that Renfield was going to utter. I truly feared thinking, but I was aware of what was happening, since I had heard of men who had heard the death clock. The poor man's breathing became labored and irregular. It seemed at every moment that he was going to open his eyes and speak, but then, there would be a prolonged and stertorous breath, and he would calm down, becoming even more insensible. Although I was accustomed to the beds of the sick and the dead, that expectation became increasingly intolerable for me. I could almost clearly hear the beats of my own heart, and the blood flowing in my temples resounded as if they were hammer blows. Finally, the silence became unbearable. I looked at my companions and saw in their flushed faces and the way they furrowed their brows that they were enduring the same torture as I was. A nervous suspense floated over all of us, as if a powerful bell were about to ring over our heads when we least expected it.

en: At last there came a time when it was evident that the patient was sinking fast; he might die at any moment. I looked up at the Professor and caught his eyes fixed on mine. His face was sternly set as he spoke:—
vi: It is clear that death could come to Renfield at any moment. I turned back and looked straight into the old professor's eyes for a long time. — Don't waste another minute! - He said.
tr: The moment finally came that indicated the patient's rapid decline; he could die at any moment. I looked at the professor and saw that his eyes were fixed on mine. His face was stern as he spoke:
es: Finally, there came a moment when it was evident that the patient was weakening rapidly; he could die at any moment. I looked at the professor and saw that his eyes were fixed on me. His face was firm when he spoke:

en: “There is no time to lose. His words may be worth many lives; I have been thinking so, as I stood here. It may be there is a soul at stake! We shall operate just above the ear.”
vi: - What he can reveal to us might save many lives. It might even open a path to redemption for his soul. We will remove the blood clot just above his ear.
tr: “There is no time to lose. His words could touch many lives; I was thinking about this while standing here. A soul might be in danger! We will operate just above the ear.”
es: –There is no time to lose. Your words can help save many lives; I have been thinking about it while we were waiting. It is possible that there is a soul in great danger! We must operate immediately above the ear.

en: Without another word he made the operation. For a few moments the breathing continued to be stertorous. Then there came a breath so prolonged that it seemed as though it would tear open his chest. Suddenly his eyes opened, and became fixed in a wild, helpless stare. This was continued for a few moments; then it softened into a glad surprise, and from the lips came a sigh of relief. He moved convulsively, and as he did so, said:—
vi: The section where he immediately began his surgical work. The patient occasionally let out painful roars, then suddenly screamed a heart-wrenching cry. Right after that painful cry, he opened his eyes wide in bewilderment, his face showing both surprise and joy; I could even hear his sigh of relief clearly. He spoke while smiling, the corners of his mouth twitching:
tr: Without saying another word, he performed the surgery. For a few minutes, his breathing continued to be wheezy. Then the patient took such a deep breath that it seemed as if he was going to swallow his chest. Suddenly, his eyes opened and fixed with a wild, desperate look. This lasted for a few minutes; then his gaze softened into a satisfied smile, and a sigh of relief escaped his lips. He was moving restlessly and while doing so, he said:
es: Without adding another word, the operation began. For a few more minutes, the breathing continued to be stertorous. Then, he inhaled the air so deeply that it seemed his chest would tear apart. Suddenly, he opened his eyes, and they remained fixed, with a wild and helpless look. He stayed like that for a few moments, and then his gaze softened, showing a joyful surprise. A sigh of relief escaped his lips. He moved convulsively, and as he did, he said:

en: “I’ll be quiet, Doctor. Tell them to take off the strait-waistcoat. I have had a terrible dream, and it has left me so weak that I cannot move. What’s wrong with my face? it feels all swollen, and it smarts dreadfully.” He tried to turn his head; but even with the effort his eyes seemed to grow glassy again so I gently put it back. Then Van Helsing said in a quiet grave tone:—
vi: — I will be normal again, doctor. Please ask them to help me take off this straitjacket. I just went through a terrible dream, it left me exhausted and unable to move. How is my face? It feels like it's burning. He tried to turn his head to one side but couldn't; perhaps he had truly felt his own helplessness, as the eyes that had just lit up with joy were now turning vacant like those of a dead man. Van Helsing observed and slowly told him:
tr: “I will be quiet, Doctor. Tell them to take off the straitjacket. I had a terrible dream and it weakened me so much that I can't move. What happened to my face? I feel very swollen and it hurts a lot.” He tried to turn his head; but even attempting this made his eyes glaze over again, so I gently put him back in his original position. Then, Van Helsing said in a low, dignified tone:
es: –I will be calm, doctor. Tell them to take off the straitjacket. I had a terrible dream and I am so weak that I can't even move. What is happening to my face? I feel it all swollen and it hurts horribly. He tried to turn his head, but, due to the effort, his eyes seemed to become glassy again, and gently, I made him desist from his endeavor. Then, Van Helsing said in a grave and calm tone:

en: “Tell us your dream, Mr. Renfield.” As he heard the voice his face brightened, through its mutilation, and he said:—
vi: — Renfield, please tell us about your delusion. Recognizing the professor's voice, his face lit up despite the wounds still oozing blood.
tr: “Tell us about your dream, Mr. Renfield.” When he heard the voice, despite his infirmity, the patient's face lit up and he said:
es: –Tell us about your dream, Mr. Renfield. When she heard the professor's voice, her face lit up, despite her bruises, and she said:

en: “That is Dr. Van Helsing. How good it is of you to be here. Give me some water, my lips are dry; and I shall try to tell you. I dreamed”—he stopped and seemed fainting, I called quietly to Quincey—“The brandy—it is in my study—quick!” He flew and returned with a glass, the decanter of brandy and a carafe of water. We moistened the parched lips, and the patient quickly revived. It seemed, however, that his poor injured brain had been working in the interval, for, when he was quite conscious, he looked at me piercingly with an agonised confusion which I shall never forget, and said:—
vi: — So it is Dr. Van Helsing! You are very kind to still remember me! Please give me a sip of water, my throat is burning dry here. Then I will tell you all... I had a dream... He suddenly fell silent as if he was about to faint once more. — Hurry up, - I told Quincey - go get me a bottle of strong liquor! It's in my room! Morris returned almost immediately, holding a glass, a small bottle of liquor, and a jug of water. With just a sip, Renfield regained consciousness, his eyes reflecting an endless sorrow that I could never forget for the rest of my life.
tr: “This is Dr. Van Helsing. How good it is that you are here. Give me some water, my lips are dry; I will try to tell you. In my dream...” He paused and seemed to faint, I quietly called to Quincey: “Brandy, in my study, quick!” He flew out and returned with a glass, a bottle of brandy, and a bottle of water. We moistened his parched lips and the patient quickly revived. But the poor, wounded brain seemed to have continued working intermittently, because when he came to quite a bit, he looked at me with piercing eyes filled with a pain I will never forget and continued:
es: –You are Dr. Van Helsing. I am very glad that you are here! Give me a sip of water; my lips are dry. Then I will tell you everything. I have dreamed. He paused, and seemed to fade away. I quietly called Quincey. –The brandy! It's in my study... hurry up! He left quickly and returned with a glass, a bottle of brandy, and a jug of water. We moistened the injured man's bruised lips, and he quickly regained consciousness. However, it seemed that his poor injured brain had been working in the meantime, because when he fully regained consciousness, he looked at me fixedly, with a terrible expression of bewilderment that I will never forget, and said to me:

en: “I must not deceive myself; it was no dream, but all a grim reality.” Then his eyes roved round the room; as they caught sight of the two figures sitting patiently on the edge of the bed he went on:—
vi: — Surely I am not deceived by hallucinations, clearly this is not a dream, this is a terrifying reality! - He stared blankly around the room and stopped at the two people sitting on the bed. -
tr: “I must not deceive myself; it was not a dream, it was all a terrible reality.” Then, his eyes wandered around the room; seeing the two people patiently sitting by the edge of the bed, he continued his words:
es: –I must not deceive myself; it was not a dream, but a terrible reality. His eyes scanned the room, and when he saw the two figures patiently sitting at the edge of the bed, he continued saying:

en: “If I were not sure already, I would know from them.” For an instant his eyes closed—not with pain or sleep but voluntarily, as though he were bringing all his faculties to bear; when he opened them he said, hurriedly, and with more energy than he had yet displayed:—
vi: If I still have doubts, their presence will help me confirm that I am living in reality. He closed his eyes for a moment, not because of pain or fatigue, but because he wanted to focus his attention. When he opened his eyes, he hurriedly dove into the story with a determination greater than I had ever seen in him:
tr: "If I hadn't already been sure, I would have understood from them." For a moment, his eyes closed—not from pain or sleep, but as if he was gathering all his faculties to endure; when he opened his eyes, he said with urgency and an energy he had never shown before:
es: –If I weren't already sure of it, I would know it from them. He closed his eyes for a moment..., not because of pain or sleep, but voluntarily, as if he were gathering all his strength; when he opened them again, he said hurriedly and with more energy than he had shown until then:

en: “Quick, Doctor, quick. I am dying! I feel that I have but a few minutes; and then I must go back to death—or worse! Wet my lips with brandy again. I have something that I must say before I die; or before my poor crushed brain dies anyhow. Thank you! It was that night after you left me, when I implored you to let me go away. I couldn’t speak then, for I felt my tongue was tied; but I was as sane then, except in that way, as I am now. I was in an agony of despair for a long time after you left me; it seemed hours. Then there came a sudden peace to me. My brain seemed to become cool again, and I realised where I was. I heard the dogs bark behind our house, but not where He was!” As he spoke, Van Helsing’s eyes never blinked, but his hand came out and met mine and gripped it hard. He did not, however, betray himself; he nodded slightly and said: “Go on,” in a low voice. Renfield proceeded:—
vi: — Hurry up, doctor! Hurry up! I'm about to die. I feel like I only have a few minutes left to live! Then I will find death, or something much worse than that! Let me have another sip of wine. I have a few things I want to say to you before I die, or before my mind is completely paralyzed. Thank you... It happened the night I asked you to go home but you didn't agree and left, leaving me alone in the room. At that time, I really wanted to tell the truth, but the pressure didn't allow me to do so, even though I was completely sober, as sober as I am now. That day, after you left, suddenly I felt myself sinking into an unbearable, endless despair for many hours. Then, somehow, calmness returned to me, my spirit regained balance, and I became aware of where I was again. Suddenly, I heard fierce barking from the dogs behind the hospital, right near where the old man was standing!... From earlier until now, Van Helsing has been intently watching Renfield speak and avoiding gestures that might distract his mind. Occasionally, he would grasp my hand tightly. — Please, go on! - He gently said to the patient.
tr: “Quick, Doctor, quick. I'm dying! I feel I have only a few minutes left, and then I will go to death—or something worse! Wet my lips with brandy again. There is something I must say before I die, or before my poor crushed brain dies. Thank you! It happened the night I begged you to let me go, after you left my side. I couldn't speak then, because my tongue felt tied; but I was as sane then as I am now. After you left, I suffered the agony of despair for a long time; it felt like hours had passed. Then, suddenly, a calmness came over me. My mind seemed to regain its composure, and I realized where I was. I heard the dogs barking from the back of our house, but I didn't know where He was!” As Renfield spoke, Van Helsing's eyes never blinked, but his hand reached out, met mine, and gripped it firmly. But he didn't give himself away; he nodded slightly and said in a low voice, "Go on." Renfield continued:
es: –Quick, doctor, quick! I'm dying! I feel like I only have a few minutes left and then I will fall dead or something worse. Moisten my lips with brandy again. I have to tell you something before I die, or before my shattered brain dies. Thank you! It happened that night, after you left here, when I begged you to let me out of the asylum. I couldn't speak, as I felt my tongue was tied; but I was as sane then, except for the fact that I couldn't speak, as I am now. I was desperate for a long time after you left my room; several hours must have passed. Then, I felt a sudden peace. My brain seemed to start working coldly again and I understood where I was. I heard the dogs barking behind the house, but, not where he was! While the patient was speaking, Van Helsing watched him without blinking, but he reached out, took my hand, and squeezed it tightly. However, he did not betray himself; he nodded slightly and said in a very low voice: –Continue. Renfield continued saying:

en: “He came up to the window in the mist, as I had seen him often before; but he was solid then—not a ghost, and his eyes were fierce like a man’s when angry. He was laughing with his red mouth; the sharp white teeth glinted in the moonlight when he turned to look back over the belt of trees, to where the dogs were barking. I wouldn’t ask him to come in at first, though I knew he wanted to—just as he had wanted all along. Then he began promising me things—not in words but by doing them.” He was interrupted by a word from the Professor:—
vi: — And right after that, I saw the old man suddenly appear outside my window, surrounded by a layer of mist as I had often seen him before, but this time he didn't look like a ghost at all; instead, his eyes were glaring like those of someone in a fit of rage. He bared his teeth in a grin on his bright red lips, and when he turned to look at the bushes where the dogs were barking loudly, I saw his sharp, white teeth glint under the moonlight. At first, I didn't intend to invite him into the room, even though that was something he always wanted from me. But then, he began to make promises to me, and they weren't just empty promises; there were also immediate actions. — How did the old man promise? -
tr: "As I had often seen him before, he came to the window in the mist, but this time, he was solid - not a ghost, and his eyes were fiery like those of an angry man. He was laughing with his red mouth; when he turned to look over the trees to where the dogs were barking, his sharp white teeth gleamed in the moonlight. Although I knew that this was what he wanted - as he had always wanted - I did not immediately invite him in. Then he began to make promises to me again - not with words but by doing them.” He was interrupted by a word from the Professor:
es: –He came up to the window in the midst of the fog, as I had seen him before, often; but then he was something solid, not a ghost, and his eyes were fierce, like those of an enraged man. His red mouth was laughing and his white, sharp teeth shone under the moonlight, as he looked towards the trees, where the dogs were barking. I didn't ask him to come in at first, although I knew he wanted to... as he had always wanted to. Then, he began to promise me things... not with words but by truly making them happen. He was interrupted by a word from the professor.

en: “How?”
vi: The professor pressed.
tr: "How?"
es: –How?

en: “By making them happen; just as he used to send in the flies when the sun was shining. Great big fat ones with steel and sapphire on their wings; and big moths, in the night, with skull and cross-bones on their backs.” Van Helsing nodded to him as he whispered to me unconsciously:—
vi: — What he promised was carried out immediately, for example, when the sun was shining, he drove a swarm of flies into my room. All of them were large flies with shimmering green wings. In the evening, he sent me moths with skull-shaped heads and striped patterns on their backs. Van Helsing nodded to encourage him to continue speaking, but he mumbled a nonsensical sentence in a state of near unconsciousness:
tr: "By making them happen; just like sending flies inside while the sun is shining. Big fat flies with wings of steel and sapphire, and at night, big moths with skull and crossbones patterns on their backs." While Van Helsing nodded at him, he unconsciously said to me:
es: –Making things happen; just as he used to send me flies when the sun was shining. Big, fat flies, with steel and sapphires on their wings; and huge moths, at night, with skulls and crossed bones. Van Helsing nodded towards the ear, at the same time whispering to me, unconsciously:

en: “The Acherontia Aitetropos of the Sphinges—what you call the ‘Death’s-head Moth’?” The patient went on without stopping.
vi: — Acherontia Aitetropos of the Sphinxes... But he also snapped back to reality immediately:
tr: “Acherontia atropos - the thing you call the ‘death's-head hawkmoth’!” The patient continued to speak incessantly:
es: –The Acherontia Atropos of the Sphingidae, what you call the "death's-head hawkmoth", isn't that right? The patient continued talking, without making any pause:

en: “Then he began to whisper: ‘Rats, rats, rats! Hundreds, thousands, millions of them, and every one a life; and dogs to eat them, and cats too. All lives! all red blood, with years of life in it; and not merely buzzing flies!’ I laughed at him, for I wanted to see what he could do. Then the dogs howled, away beyond the dark trees in His house. He beckoned me to the window. I got up and looked out, and He raised his hands, and seemed to call out without using any words. A dark mass spread over the grass, coming on like the shape of a flame of fire; and then He moved the mist to the right and left, and I could see that there were thousands of rats with their eyes blazing red—like His, only smaller. He held up his hand, and they all stopped; and I thought he seemed to be saying: ‘All these lives will I give you, ay, and many more and greater, through countless ages, if you will fall down and worship me!’ And then a red cloud, like the colour of blood, seemed to close over my eyes; and before I knew what I was doing, I found myself opening the sash and saying to Him: ‘Come in, Lord and Master!’ The rats were all gone, but He slid into the room through the sash, though it was only open an inch wide—just as the Moon herself has often come in through the tiniest crack and has stood before me in all her size and splendour.”
vi: — The old man began to mumble: "Where are the rats, where are the rats, where are the rats! Hundreds, thousands, millions of them, so many lives." Where are the packs of dogs, the packs of cats, come and devour these vile creatures alive! All must bleed, the more blood that flows, the more years of life, no longer just flies, you know?" I laughed heartily, for I wanted to know what abilities the old man had. Just then, there was a loud barking of dogs down there, behind the bushes near the old man's house. The old man signaled for me to approach the window. I got up and moved towards him. He raised his hands to the sky as if to summon something without uttering a word. And then a dark shadow, from who knows where, suddenly descended on the lawn and rushed towards us with many red spots that looked like a cluster of fireworks. The old man pushed the enveloping mist aside. Soon after, I saw thousands of rats with fiery red eyes like the old man's, only smaller. Once again, the old man spread his arms wide: everything suddenly stopped. I had the feeling he was telling me: "All these lives and many more, I offer to you, and more importantly, they will belong to you from century to century if you kneel before me and worship me!" And then a blood-red cloud immediately appeared before my eyes, before I could even realize what I needed to do. I opened the window and called to him: "Come in, my Lord, my master!" The rats disappeared, and the old man slipped through the window, even though it was only slightly ajar. I felt he slipped in like a slender moonbeam through a narrow crack to appear before me with full authority.
tr: “Then he began to whisper: ‘Rats, rats, rats! Hundreds, thousands, millions of them; and all of them a life; and dogs will eat them; and cats too. All life! All of them, red blood hiding years of life inside, and not just buzzing flies!’ I laughed at him because I wanted to see what he could do. Then, from beyond the dark trees of His house, dogs barked. He called me to the window with a nod. I stood up and looked outside, and He raised his hands and seemed to call without speaking. Over the grass, a dark mass spread like the flame of a fire; then He moved the mist to the right and left, and I could see thousands of rats with red eyes glowing red like His, but smaller than His. He raised his hand and they all stopped; it seemed as if He was saying: ‘If you kneel before me and worship me, I will give you all these lives, yes, more and more, for countless centuries!’ And then, a cloud as red as blood closed over me; before I knew what I was doing, I found myself opening the window and saying to Him, ‘Come in, my Lord and Master!’ All the rats were gone, but He glided in even though the window was only open a few centimeters - just like how the moon had previously entered through a tiny crack and stood before me in all its size and splendor.”
es: –Then he began to whisper: "Rats, rats, rats! Hundreds, thousands, millions of them and each one of them is a life; and dogs to eat them and also cats. All are life! All have red blood with many years of life in them; not just buzzing flies!" I laughed at him because I wanted to see what he could do. Then, the dogs howled, in the distance, beyond the dark trees, in his house. He made me come closer to the window. I stood up, looked outside, and he raised his arms and seemed to be calling someone, without uttering a single word. A dark mass spread over the grass and advanced like flames in a fire. It parted the fog to the right and left, and I could see that there were thousands and thousands of rats, with red eyes like his, only smaller. He kept his hand raised, and all the rats stopped; and I thought he seemed to be saying to me: "I will give you all those lives and many more and more important ones, through endless times, if you agree to bow down and worship me!" And then, a reddish cloud, the color of blood, seemed to place itself before my eyes and, before I knew what I was doing, I was opening the small window of that window and saying to him: "Enter, Master and Lord!" All the rats were gone, but he entered the room through the window, even though it was only slightly open a few centimeters..., like the moon has appeared many times through a small crack and presented itself before me in all its size and splendor.

en: His voice was weaker, so I moistened his lips with the brandy again, and he continued; but it seemed as though his memory had gone on working in the interval for his story was further advanced. I was about to call him back to the point, but Van Helsing whispered to me: “Let him go on. Do not interrupt him; he cannot go back, and maybe could not proceed at all if once he lost the thread of his thought.” He proceeded:—
vi: Renfield's voice suddenly weakened noticeably, so I let him sip a bit more strong liquor, and he continued his nightmarish tale. However, his memory began to falter, and the events in his recollection risked not being pieced together coherently. I intended to prompt him to recall the part he had just mentioned, but Van Helsing stopped me and whispered in my ear: — Let him tell it. Don't interrupt his train of thought. Reminding him now is impossible; he won't be able to add anything more once his train of thought is completely broken. — I sat waiting for him all day, hoping he would send me something.
tr: The voice weakened, so I moistened his lips with brandy again, he continued his words, but his mind seemed to have kept working throughout this period, because his story had progressed. I was about to direct him back to our topic when Van Helsing whispered to me: "Let him continue telling. Do not interrupt him; he cannot go back in his story and if he loses his train of thought once, he may never progress again." Renfield continued his words:
es: His voice grew weaker, so I moistened his lips with the brandy again and he continued speaking, but it seemed as if his memory had continued working in the interval, since his story had already advanced quite a bit when he resumed speaking. I was about to make him return to the point where he had left off when Van Helsing whispered to me: –Let him continue. Do not interrupt him; he cannot go back, and he might not be able to continue at all once he loses the thread of his thoughts. Renfield added:

en: “All day I waited to hear from him, but he did not send me anything, not even a blow-fly, and when the moon got up I was pretty angry with him. When he slid in through the window, though it was shut, and did not even knock, I got mad with him. He sneered at me, and his white face looked out of the mist with his red eyes gleaming, and he went on as though he owned the whole place, and I was no one. He didn’t even smell the same as he went by me. I couldn’t hold him. I thought that, somehow, Mrs. Harker had come into the room.”
vi: But no, nothing at all... not even a fly. When the moonlight appeared, I started to get insanely angry at him. When I saw him slithering into the room through the still-closed window, I truly lost my temper. Seeing me go mad, he laughed gleefully, his eyes shining like fire through a shroud of mist. He acted as if my room was his own house, and I didn't exist at all. As he passed by me, his whole body emitted a very unusual smell. I couldn't hold onto him. I think that at that moment, Mrs. Harker had already returned to her room.
tr: “I waited for news from him all day, but he didn't send me anything, not even a fly, and by the time the moon rose, I was quite angry with him. Despite being closed, when he slipped inside through the window without even tapping on the glass, I went mad with rage. He mocked me, and his red eyes and white face looked out from within the mist, and he continued this attitude as if he owned the entire place and I was a nobody. Even his scent wasn't the same when he passed by me. I couldn't hold him. Somehow, I thought Ms. Harker had entered the room.”
es: –I waited all day to hear from him, but he didn't send me anything; not even a fly, and when the moon came out, I was very angry with him. When he came in through the window, even though it was closed, without even bothering to knock, I became very furious. He mocked me and his white face emerged from the mist, while his reddish eyes shone, and he walked around the room as if it all belonged to him and as if I didn't exist. He didn't even have the same smell when he passed by me. I couldn't stop him. I think that, somehow, Mrs. Harker had entered the room.

en: The two men sitting on the bed stood up and came over, standing behind him so that he could not see them, but where they could hear better. They were both silent, but the Professor started and quivered; his face, however, grew grimmer and sterner still. Renfield went on without noticing:—
vi: Arthur and Quincey anxiously stood up, stealthily stepping behind Renfield without letting him see. At this moment, despite being very worried and anxious, Van Helsing still had to remain silent and patiently wait for him to continue.
tr: The two men sitting on the bed stood up and approached, positioning themselves behind Renfield so he couldn't see them, but they were in a place where they could hear better. Both were silent, but the Professor shuddered and trembled, his face growing increasingly stern. Renfield, without noticing this, continued his words: "When Ms. Harker came to see me today, she was different; she was like tea after the teapot has been watered down."
es: The two men who were sitting by the bed stood up and approached, staying behind the injured man, in such a way that he could not see them, but where they could hear better what he was saying. The two were silent, but the professor was startled and shuddered; however, his face took on a firmer and graver expression. Renfield continued on, unaware of anything:

en: “When Mrs. Harker came in to see me this afternoon she wasn’t the same; it was like tea after the teapot had been watered.” Here we all moved, but no one said a word; he went on:—
vi: — When she came to see me in the afternoon, Mrs. Harker was no longer herself. I only suspected her presence when she began to speak.
tr: Renfield, without noticing this, continued his words: "When Ms. Harker came to see me today, she was different; she was like tea after the teapot has been watered down." We all stirred at this, but said nothing; Renfield continued his speech:
es: –When Mrs. Harker came to see me that afternoon, she was not the same; she was like tea after water has been added to the teapot. At that moment, all of us moved, but none of us uttered a word; Renfield continued:

en: “I didn’t know that she was here till she spoke; and she didn’t look the same. I don’t care for the pale people; I like them with lots of blood in them, and hers had all seemed to have run out. I didn’t think of it at the time; but when she went away I began to think, and it made me mad to know that He had been taking the life out of her.” I could feel that the rest quivered, as I did, but we remained otherwise still. “So when He came to-night I was ready for Him. I saw the mist stealing in, and I grabbed it tight. I had heard that madmen have unnatural strength; and as I knew I was a madman—at times anyhow—I resolved to use my power. Ay, and He felt it too, for He had to come out of the mist to struggle with me. I held tight; and I thought I was going to win, for I didn’t mean Him to take any more of her life, till I saw His eyes. They burned into me, and my strength became like water. He slipped through it, and when I tried to cling to Him, He raised me up and flung me down. There was a red cloud before me, and a noise like thunder, and the mist seemed to steal away under the door.” His voice was becoming fainter and his breath more stertorous. Van Helsing stood up instinctively.
vi: No, she was no longer herself. I no longer felt attracted to people with pale, wan complexions; I only liked those with rosy skin, and she seemed to have no blood left in her body. That didn't strike me immediately when she walked in, but when she left, I began to suspect that she had been drained of life by the old man, and I went mad again. Tonight, I also waited for him to come! Indeed, the layer of mist approached my room and crept inside. I was mentally prepared to grab that ghostly mist! It seems that mad people often have some kind of supernatural strength, and knowing that I am also a madman, at least sometimes, I decided to use that strength. It seemed that he sensed my thoughts, for he stepped out of the mist to fight me. Simply put, I didn't want him to continue attacking a woman, that's all. I stood firm, even feeling at times that I could handle him well, but when I accidentally met his gaze, my body went limp. It seemed that his wild eyes burned something within me, and my strength gradually faded away, like a weak stream of water. Just waiting for that, he suddenly grabbed me and flung me to the ground, even though I tried to hold onto him once more. Another cloud surged before my eyes with rumbling sounds like thunder. The mist coiled up, and in a flash, it disappeared under the door. His voice grew weaker with each passing moment, and his breathing became more labored. — Now, we know the most basic but also the most terrifying thing... - Van Helsing exclaimed.
tr: “I didn't realize he was here until he started talking, he didn't look the same as before. I don't care about pale people, I like them when they have a lot of blood, and it seemed like all his blood was drained. I didn't think about it at the time, but after he left, I started to think, and knowing that He was taking ms Harker's life drove me crazy.” I could feel that the others were trembling like me, but we still remained silent. “That's why I was ready for Him when He came tonight. I saw the mist slipping in and grabbed it tightly. I've heard that madmen have supernatural strength, and knowing that I am mad - at least, from time to time - I decided to use my strength. Yes, and He felt it too, because He had to emerge from the mist to fight me. I held Him tightly and thought I would win; because I wouldn't let Him take ms Harker's life any longer; until I saw His eyes. His eyes burned inside me and my strength melted away like water. He escaped from my grip and when I tried to cling to Him, He lifted me up and threw me to the ground. There was a red cloud and a sound like thunder in front of me, and the mist seemed to be escaping under the door.” His voice was getting weaker and his breath more wheezing. Van Helsing instinctively stood up.
es: –I didn't know she was here until she spoke to me, and she didn't seem the same. I'm not interested in pale people; I like them when they have a lot of blood, and it seemed like she had lost it all. I didn't think about it at the moment, but when she left here, I started to reflect on it and became enormously furious upon realizing that he was stealing her life. I noticed that everyone present shuddered, just like I did; but, apart from that, we all remained motionless. –So, when he came tonight, I was waiting for him. I saw the fog seeping through the window and grabbed him forcefully. I've heard it said that madmen have supernatural strength, and knowing that I was mad, at least sometimes, I resolved to use my power. He felt it too, as he had to step out of the fog to fight me. I held him tightly and thought I was going to defeat him, because I didn't want him to continue stealing her life away. Then I saw his eyes. His gaze pierced through me, and my strength abandoned me. He broke free, and when I tried to grab him again, he lifted me into the air and let me fall. There was a red cloud in front of me and I heard a noise like thunder. The mist seemed to escape under the door. Her voice was growing weaker and her breathing more labored. Van Helsing instinctively stood up.

en: “We know the worst now,” he said. “He is here, and we know his purpose. It may not be too late. Let us be armed—the same as we were the other night, but lose no time; there is not an instant to spare.” There was no need to put our fear, nay our conviction, into words—we shared them in common. We all hurried and took from our rooms the same things that we had when we entered the Count’s house. The Professor had his ready, and as we met in the corridor he pointed to them significantly as he said:—
vi: - So he is here, not far away, and we also know who he is looking for. Perhaps it is not too late yet. Let's find weapons, just like the other night, but quickly, don't delay even a minute longer! There is no need to find words to describe our shock and fear at this moment. We ran frantically back to our room, looking for the items that had been used the day we entered the old count's house. The professor already had everything in hand, and when he reached the hallway, he showed us a handful and said:
tr: “Now we know the worst,” he said. “He is here, and we know his purpose. It may not be too late yet. Let's arm ourselves - just like we did last night, but let's not waste any time; we don't have a single second to spare.” We didn't need to put our fear and, moreover, our faith into words - we all shared these feelings. We hurried out and took the things we had with us when we entered the Count's house from our rooms. The professor was ready with his materials, and when we met in the corridor, he pointed to them with importance and said:
es: –Now we know the worst -he said-. It is here, and we know its purposes. It may not be too late. We have to arm ourselves, just like the other night; but let's not waste time. There isn't a moment to lose. There was no need to express our fears or our conviction in words…, since they were common to all of us. We hurried to take in our rooms the same things we had when we entered the count's house. The professor had his things ready, and when we gathered in the hallway, he pointed to them significantly and said:

en: “They never leave me; and they shall not till this unhappy business is over. Be wise also, my friends. It is no common enemy that we deal with. Alas! alas! that that dear Madam Mina should suffer!” He stopped; his voice was breaking, and I do not know if rage or terror predominated in my own heart.
vi: — I always carry these things with me; they will be my inseparable belongings as long as our mission is not yet accomplished. All of you too, be cautious in everything you do! Because the Count is not an ordinary person, please remember that. Oh Lord! Oh Lord! Who could have expected Mina to suffer such misfortune? His voice choked with emotion and then fell silent. As for me, I could no longer move swiftly, unsure whether it was anger or fear that had gripped my feet.
tr: “These will never leave my side, and they will not leave until this cursed task is finished. Be reasonable, my friends. What we are dealing with is not an ordinary enemy. Alas! How unfortunate that dear Madam Mina has to suffer!” He paused; his voice was cracking; I do not know whether anger or fear dominates my own heart.
es: –I never leave them, and I must not do so, until this unfortunate matter is concluded. Be prudent as well, my friends. We are not facing a common enemy. Our dear lady Mina must suffer! Alas! What a pity!

en: Outside the Harkers’ door we paused. Art and Quincey held back, and the latter said:—
vi: Upon reaching the door of the Harker couple's room, we suddenly all stopped. — Should we wake him up? - Quincey asked.
tr: We stood outside the Harkers' room. Art and Quincey stepped back, and Quincey spoke:
es: Outside the Harkers' door, we paused. Art and Quincey stayed back, and the latter asked:

en: “Should we disturb her?”
vi: — Yes, we need to wake him up, - Van Helsing replied - and if the door remains locked, we will have to break it down and enter.
tr: "Should we disturb him?"
es: –Should we bother her?

en: “We must,” said Van Helsing grimly. “If the door be locked, I shall break it in.”
vi: — Yes, we need to wake him up, - Van Helsing replied - and if the door remains locked, we will have to break it down and enter.
tr: "We must do this," said Van Helsing sternly. "If the door is locked, I will force my way in."
es: –It is necessary -said Van Helsing sadly-. If the door is locked, we will force it open to enter.

en: “May it not frighten her terribly? It is unusual to break into a lady’s room!”
vi: — But doing so will scare them to death! Who would ever enter a woman's room like that?
tr: “Doesn't this horrify her? Forcing one's way into a lady's room is quite unusual!”
es: –Won't we frighten her terribly? It's not natural to break into a lady's room!

en: Van Helsing said solemnly, “You are always right; but this is life and death. All chambers are alike to the doctor; and even were they not they are all as one to me to-night. Friend John, when I turn the handle, if the door does not open, do you put your shoulder down and shove; and you too, my friends. Now!”
vi: - Quincey said, in a very serious tone. — Normally, you are right, but the issue now is a matter of life and death. A doctor can enter any room at any time and in any manner he wishes, and if that is not usually acceptable, tonight it must be acceptable for me. My friend John, I will turn the door handle, and if the door still won't open, you must push your shoulder against it strongly! The same goes for both of you. Now, shall we begin?
tr: Van Helsing said solemnly: “You are always right, but this is a matter of life and death. For the doctor, all rooms are the same, and even if they weren't, tonight they are all the same for me. My friend John, when I turn the doorknob, if the door doesn't open, will you put your shoulder to it and push; and you too, my friends. Now!”
es: Van Helsing said solemnly: –You are absolutely right, but this is a matter of life and death. All rooms are the same to a doctor, and even if they weren't, tonight they are all as one. Friend John, when you turn the knob, if the door doesn't open, would you please put your shoulder into it and force it open? And you too, my friends? Now!

en: He turned the handle as he spoke, but the door did not yield. We threw ourselves against it; with a crash it burst open, and we almost fell headlong into the room. The Professor did actually fall, and I saw across him as he gathered himself up from hands and knees. What I saw appalled me. I felt my hair rise like bristles on the back of my neck, and my heart seemed to stand still.
vi: He turned the door handle forcefully, but the door didn't budge at all. Our whole group together pushed hard with our shoulders, causing the door to burst open with a bang, and Van Helsing lost his balance and fell, making us stagger and almost fall as well. While the professor had not yet managed to stand up, I suddenly felt weak all over, my hair standing on end like a porcupine's quills because of the horrifying scene in the room.
tr: While talking, he turned the door handle, but the door did not yield. We threw ourselves at it; it suddenly opened with a crack, and we almost tumbled into the room head over heels. The professor actually fell, and as he was gathering himself on his hands and knees, I saw the scene before him. What I saw horrified me. I felt the hairs on the back of my neck stand up, and my heart almost stopped.
es: He turned the doorknob as he spoke, but the door did not open. We all threw ourselves against it and, with a sharp noise, it swung wide open. We fell into the room and were about to lose our balance. Indeed, the professor fell flat on his face, and I could see over him as he got up on his hands and knees. What I saw left me stunned. I felt the hair on the back of my neck stand up like bristles; my heart seemed to stop.

en: The moonlight was so bright that through the thick yellow blind the room was light enough to see. On the bed beside the window lay Jonathan Harker, his face flushed and breathing heavily as though in a stupor. Kneeling on the near edge of the bed facing outwards was the white-clad figure of his wife. By her side stood a tall, thin man, clad in black. His face was turned from us, but the instant we saw we all recognised the Count—in every way, even to the scar on his forehead. With his left hand he held both Mrs. Harker’s hands, keeping them away with her arms at full tension; his right hand gripped her by the back of the neck, forcing her face down on his bosom. Her white nightdress was smeared with blood, and a thin stream trickled down the man’s bare breast which was shown by his torn-open dress. The attitude of the two had a terrible resemblance to a child forcing a kitten’s nose into a saucer of milk to compel it to drink. As we burst into the room, the Count turned his face, and the hellish look that I had heard described seemed to leap into it. His eyes flamed red with devilish passion; the great nostrils of the white aquiline nose opened wide and quivered at the edge; and the white sharp teeth, behind the full lips of the blood-dripping mouth, champed together like those of a wild beast. With a wrench, which threw his victim back upon the bed as though hurled from a height, he turned and sprang at us. But by this time the Professor had gained his feet, and was holding towards him the envelope which contained the Sacred Wafer. The Count suddenly stopped, just as poor Lucy had done outside the tomb, and cowered back. Further and further back he cowered, as we, lifting our crucifixes, advanced. The moonlight suddenly failed, as a great black cloud sailed across the sky; and when the gaslight sprang up under Quincey’s match, we saw nothing but a faint vapour. This, as we looked, trailed under the door, which with the recoil from its bursting open, had swung back to its old position. Van Helsing, Art, and I moved forward to Mrs. Harker, who by this time had drawn her breath and with it had given a scream so wild, so ear-piercing, so despairing that it seems to me now that it will ring in my ears till my dying day. For a few seconds she lay in her helpless attitude and disarray. Her face was ghastly, with a pallor which was accentuated by the blood which smeared her lips and cheeks and chin; from her throat trickled a thin stream of blood; her eyes were mad with terror. Then she put before her face her poor crushed hands, which bore on their whiteness the red mark of the Count’s terrible grip, and from behind them came a low desolate wail which made the terrible scream seem only the quick expression of an endless grief. Van Helsing stepped forward and drew the coverlet gently over her body, whilst Art, after looking at her face for an instant despairingly, ran out of the room. Van Helsing whispered to me:—
vi: The bright moonlight cast a golden glow on everything outside, even though it was blocked by the orange curtain hanging on the window, it was still bright enough to illuminate the room. We could clearly see everything happening inside. John Harker was lying there, on the bed near the window, but his face was as red as a gấc fruit, his breathing heavy in a state of unconsciousness. Kneeling on another bed, at the edge of the bed near us, was the figure of a woman dressed in white, and standing right next to her was a tall, thin man dressed in black. Although they were not facing each other, we immediately recognized him as the old count. His left hand was gripping the woman's outstretched arms tightly, while his right hand grabbed her neck roughly. Seeing us burst in, he turned around abruptly: before us was a pale face full of demonic features, exactly as Jonathan had described in his diary. Yes, I recognized in that face two eyes blazing with anger, a hooked nose like a hawk's beak breathing heavily, and two sharp, white fangs behind bright red lips. In a fit of rage, he pushed the woman down onto the bed and lunged at us. But Van Helsing managed to raise the holy wafer in front of him, forcing him to stand still and retreat, just like with Lucy outside the tomb the other night. The more we advanced, the more he retreated and shrank. Outside, a huge black cloud suddenly drifted across the moon, plunging the scene into darkness. When Quincey managed to turn on the light, all that was before our eyes was a thin mist slipping through the crack in the door. Van Helsing, Arthur, and I rushed to Mina's bedside. Her desperate scream echoed endlessly in my mind, making me feel that I would never be able to forget it for the rest of my life. She collapsed like a withered leaf, her face pale and twitching continuously, revealing sheer terror, while her eyes were vacant and lifeless like those of a mad person, and a small stream of blood was still trickling from her neck. Recognizing us, she covered her face as if to hide her shame and heartbreak. I understood that her scream was merely a temporary outburst of an emotion of boundless pain and despair. Quincey stood dazed, looking at Mina, then quietly went outside without understanding why, while Van Helsing gently pulled the blanket over her and whispered in my ear:
tr: The moonlight was so bright that even through the thick yellow curtain, the room was illuminated enough to see the surroundings. Jonathan Harker was lying on the bed next to the window; his face was flushed, and he was breathing heavily as if he had fainted. On the side of the bed facing us was his wife, with her face turned outward, her face as white as chalk. Beside her stood a tall, thin man dressed in black.
