His face was not turned towards us, but as soon as we saw him, we all recognized the Count - in every aspect, down to the scar on his forehead. With his left hand, he had grasped both of Mrs. Harker's hands, holding them away from her body; with his right hand, he had seized Mrs. Harker by the nape of her neck, pressing her face against his chest. Mrs. Harker's white nightgown was stained with blood, and a thin strip of blood was flowing from the man's bare chest, visible through his torn-open clothing. Their posture was eerily reminiscent of a child plunging a kitten's nose into a bowl to make it drink milk. As soon as we burst into the room, the Count turned his face, and that previously described demonic look seemed to appear on his face. His eyes were glowing red with a demonic passion; the wide nostrils of his white, arched nose were flaring and trembling; the white sharp teeth behind his blood-dripping mouth's full lips clashed together like those of a wild animal. He flung his victim onto the bed with a violent jerk as if he had been thrown from a height, then turned and leaped at us. But during this time, the Professor had stood up and was holding the envelope containing the blessed bread towards him. The Count, just like Lucy had done outside her tomb, suddenly stopped and recoiled in fear. As we raised our crosses and advanced, he retreated further and further. A large, black cloud drifted across the sky, causing the moonlight to suddenly vanish, and when the gas lamp was lit by Quincey's match, we could see nothing but a faint wisp of smoke. It seemed to be slipping under the door, which had quickly opened and then returned to its original state. Van Helsing, Art, and I moved towards Mrs. Harker. By that moment, she had taken a deep breath and screamed with it. It was such a wild, ear-piercing, and despair-filled scream that I think it will continue to ring in my ears until the day I die. For a few seconds, she lay there helpless and disheveled. Her face was as pale as death, highlighted by the blood smeared on her lips, cheeks, and chin; a thin line of blood was flowing from her throat. Her eyes were wild with fear. Then, she brought her poor, clenched hands, which bore the red marks of the Count's terrible grip on their whiteness, to her face, and from behind her hands came a low, mournful moan that expressed that horrifying scream as a brief outburst of endless pain. Van Helsing stepped forward and gently covered her body with the bedspread, while Art, after looking at Mrs. Harker's face in despair for a moment, ran out of the room. Van Helsing whispered to me:
es: The moonlight was so strong that, through the thick yellowish curtains, the room could be seen clearly. On the bed, next to the window, lay Jonathan Harker, with a flushed face and breathing heavily, as if in a stupor. Kneeling on the nearest edge of the bed that faced outside, the white figure of his wife could be distinguished. Beside her was a tall, thin man, dressed in black. His face was turned to the other side, but as soon as we saw him, we all recognized the count..., with all the details, including the scar on his forehead. With his left hand, he held Mrs. Harker's two hands, pulling them along with her arms; his right hand grasped the back of her neck, forcing her to tilt her head towards his chest. Her white nightgown was stained with blood, and a slight trickle of the same precious liquid ran down the man's bare chest, which appeared through a tear in his clothes. The posture of the two had a terrible resemblance to a child forcing a kitten to dip its nose into a saucer of milk, to make it drink. When we rushed into the room, the count turned his head, and on his face appeared the infernal expression I had heard described so many times. His eyes shone, reddish, with a demonic passion; the large windows of his white, aquiline nose were distended and trembled slightly; and his sharp, white teeth, behind the thick lips of his blood-sucking mouth, were clenched, like those of a wild animal. Turning abruptly, so that his victim fell onto the bed as if she had a weight, he lunged at us. But by then, the professor had already stood up and was holding out the envelope that contained the Sacred Host towards him. The count stopped suddenly, just as poor Lucy had done outside her tomb, and retreated. He retreated as we, with crucifixes held high, advanced towards him. The moonlight suddenly disappeared when a large black cloud moved across the sky, and when Quincey lit the gas lamp with a match, we saw nothing but a slight vapor that disappeared under the door, which, with the natural recoil after being abruptly opened, was back in its original position. Van Helsing, Art, and I hurried towards Mrs. Harker, who by then had caught her breath and let out a scream so sharp, so piercing, and so full of despair that it seemed to me I would be able to hear it until the last moments of my own life. For a few seconds, she remained in her posture full of helplessness and despair. Her face was ghostly, with a pallor that was accentuated by the blood that stained her lips, her cheeks, and her chin; a thin stream of blood flowed from her neck; her eyes were wide with terror. Then, she covered her face with her poor injured hands, which bore the red mark of the terrible pressure exerted by the count on them, and from behind her hands came a moan of desolation that made the terrible scream of a few moments earlier seem only the expression of endless pain. Van Helsing stepped forward and gently covered the lady's body with the sheets, while Art, looking at her pale face for a moment, with despair reflected in his countenance, left the room. Van Helsing whispered to me:

en: “Jonathan is in a stupor such as we know the Vampire can produce. We can do nothing with poor Madam Mina for a few moments till she recovers herself; I must wake him!” He dipped the end of a towel in cold water and with it began to flick him on the face, his wife all the while holding her face between her hands and sobbing in a way that was heart-breaking to hear. I raised the blind, and looked out of the window. There was much moonshine; and as I looked I could see Quincey Morris run across the lawn and hide himself in the shadow of a great yew-tree. It puzzled me to think why he was doing this; but at the instant I heard Harker’s quick exclamation as he woke to partial consciousness, and turned to the bed. On his face, as there might well be, was a look of wild amazement. He seemed dazed for a few seconds, and then full consciousness seemed to burst upon him all at once, and he started up. His wife was aroused by the quick movement, and turned to him with her arms stretched out, as though to embrace him; instantly, however, she drew them in again, and putting her elbows together, held her hands before her face, and shuddered till the bed beneath her shook.
vi: — According to my experience, Jonathan is also falling into a state of extreme terror that only “vampires” can create. We cannot do anything for this poor woman until she regains consciousness, but as for Jonathan, we must wake him up. The professor dipped a cloth into cold water and gently patted Jonathan's cheeks, while Mina continued to sob incessantly with her face in her hands. I pulled the curtain and looked out the window. The cloud drifted away, and the bright moonlight returned. I suddenly noticed Quincey walking and then running across the lawn in the garden, disappearing under a cluster of pine trees. What could be happening? I really don't understand. At the same time, Jonathan's half-awake, half-asleep cry startled me and made me turn back. I could read the surprise on his bewildered face. It took him at least a minute to return to reality before sitting up. Perhaps his sudden cry and jerky movements woke Mina up. She quickly turned towards him, her arms outstretched as if to embrace her beloved husband, but then she hastily pulled them back to cover her face, her whole body trembling violently.
tr: “Jonathan is in a fainting spell that we know could be caused by the Vampire. For a few minutes, we can't do anything for poor Madam Mina until he comes to; I must wake Jonathan!” He dipped the edge of a towel in water and began to gently pat his face with it; meanwhile, his wife was holding her face in her hands and sobbing heart-wrenchingly. I lifted the curtain and looked out the window. The moonlight was very bright, and as I looked out, I could see Quincey Morris running to the other end of the lawn and hiding behind a large yew tree. I was puzzled as to why he did this; but I heard the sound Harker made as he partially came to and returned to the bed. There was an expression of tremendous bewilderment on his face. He seemed dazed for a few minutes and then suddenly sprang up as if he had fully regained his senses. His wife was excited by his sudden movement and turned to him with her arms outstretched as if to embrace him, but instantly drew her arms back and brought her hands to her face, sobbing until the bed began to shake.
es: –Jonathan is a victim of a stupor as we know only the vampire can cause. We cannot do anything for poor Mrs. Mina for a few moments, until she recovers. I must wake her husband! He dipped the corner of a towel in cold water and began to rub Jonathan's face. Meanwhile, his wife covered her pale face with both hands and sobbed in such a way that it was heartbreaking to hear her. I lifted the curtains and looked out the window, and at that moment I saw Quincey Morris running across the lawn and hiding behind a yew tree. I couldn't imagine what he was doing there; but, at that moment, I heard Harker's quick exclamation as he partially regained consciousness and turned towards the bed. On his face, as was very natural, there was an expression of total astonishment. He seemed dazed for a few moments and then it seemed that full consciousness returned to him, and he began to sit up. His wife sat up due to the sudden movement and turned towards him, with her arms extended as if to embrace him; however, she immediately drew them back, brought her elbows together, and covered her face again, trembling so violently that the bed shook under her body.

en: “In God’s name what does this mean?” Harker cried out. “Dr. Seward, Dr. Van Helsing, what is it? What has happened? What is wrong? Mina, dear, what is it? What does that blood mean? My God, my God! has it come to this!” and, raising himself to his knees, he beat his hands wildly together. “Good God help us! help her! oh, help her!” With a quick movement he jumped from bed, and began to pull on his clothes,—all the man in him awake at the need for instant exertion. “What has happened? Tell me all about it!” he cried without pausing. “Dr. Van Helsing, you love Mina, I know. Oh, do something to save her. It cannot have gone too far yet. Guard her while I look for him!” His wife, through her terror and horror and distress, saw some sure danger to him: instantly forgetting her own grief, she seized hold of him and cried out:—
vi: — Oh my God! - Jonathan knelt down on the bed and lamented. - What is happening? Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, what is happening? What has happened? Mina, what is wrong with you? Why is your body covered in blood? Oh Lord! Oh God! Please help us, please help her! Then he leaped onto the floor as if ready to take action in response to the urgent demands of the situation. — What has happened here? Tell me! - He asked insistently, as if he couldn't believe the truth, his face still showing signs of shock. - Dear Dr. Van Helsing, I know you have devoted your noble friendship to Mina. Please save her! You can do it, it's not too late yet, right doctor? Please take care of her, so I can chase after him! Although her mind was still in turmoil, Mina somewhat understood the imminent danger approaching her. Forgetting all the bitter suffering, she tightly grasped his hand and pulled him back:
tr: “For God's sake, what does all this mean?” cried Harker, “Dr. Seward, Dr. Van Helsing, what is happening? What is the problem? Mina, my dear, what happened? What does this blood mean? My God! My God! Did this also happen?” And he knelt down and clapped his hands together wildly. “Almighty God, help us! Help Mina! Oh, help Mina!” With a swift movement, he jumped out of bed and began to dress, - all his manhood awakened for a moment of effort. “What happened? Tell me everything!” He was shouting without stopping. “Dr. Van Helsing, you love Mina, I know. Oh, do something to save her. It cannot have gone too far yet. While I search for him, you keep an eye on Mina!” Amid all his fear, horror, and sorrow, his wife saw the danger he would face; she immediately forgot her own pain, grabbed Jonathan, and cried out:
es: –In the name of heaven! What does this mean? – exclaimed Harker-. Doctor Seward, Doctor Van Helsing, what does this mean? What has happened? Mina, dear, what is happening? What does that blood mean? My God, my God! He has been here! – and getting up, he knelt and clasped his hands-. My God, help us! Help her! Oh, my God, help her! With a quick movement, he jumped out of bed and began to get dressed. All his manly resolve awoke suddenly, feeling the need to spring into action immediately. –What has happened? Explain everything to me! – he said, without pausing at all-. Doctor van Helsing, I know you love Mina. Do something to save her! It can't be too late. Take care of her, while I go to find him! – his wife, in the midst of her terror, horror, and despair, saw some certain danger for him, because, immediately, forgetting her own pain, she clung to him and screamed:

en: “No! no! Jonathan, you must not leave me. I have suffered enough to-night, God knows, without the dread of his harming you. You must stay with me. Stay with these friends who will watch over you!” Her expression became frantic as she spoke; and, he yielding to her, she pulled him down sitting on the bed side, and clung to him fiercely.
vi: — Don't go, Jonathan! Don't go anywhere, my dear! God already knows my situation tonight! If you go, you'll only become prey for him, and how could I bear being without you at this moment. Don't leave me and go. Stay here with me and your friends! The more she spoke, the more emotional she became. Her choked words made it impossible for Jonathan to leave. She pulled him to sit down on the bed and hugged him tightly.
tr: “No! No! Jonathan, you must not leave me. God knows, tonight, apart from the fear of harming you, I have suffered enough pain. You must stay with me. You must stay with your friends who will protect and watch over you!” As she spoke, she looked as if she had gone mad, and when Jonathan gave in to her, she pulled him to the bed, sat him down, and hugged him tightly.
es: –No, no! Jonathan! You must not leave me alone! I have already suffered enough tonight, God knows well, without fearing that he might harm you. You have to stay with me! Stay with our friends, who will take care of you! His expression became frantic as he spoke; and, while he leaned towards her, Mina made him sit on the edge of the bed, holding onto him with all her strength.

en: Van Helsing and I tried to calm them both. The Professor held up his little golden crucifix, and said with wonderful calmness:—
vi: Van Helsing and I had to try to find words to comfort the unfortunate couple. The professor held out the golden cross in front of them to soothe them:
tr: Van Helsing and I tried to calm them both down. The professor showed his small golden cross and said with perfect composure:
es: Van Helsing and I tried to calm them both. The professor held his gold crucifix in his hand and said with wonderful calmness:

en: “Do not fear, my dear. We are here; and whilst this is close to you no foul thing can approach. You are safe for to-night; and we must be calm and take counsel together.” She shuddered and was silent, holding down her head on her husband’s breast. When she raised it, his white night-robe was stained with blood where her lips had touched, and where the thin open wound in her neck had sent forth drops. The instant she saw it she drew back, with a low wail, and whispered, amidst choking sobs:—
vi: — Don't be afraid of anything, my friends, we are here, as long as the cross is with you, you will not be unfortunate. Tonight, you are protected. Don't worry too much, we need to stay calm to think about what needs to be done. Mina rested her head on her beloved husband's lap and did not complain any further, but her body trembled as if with fever. When she stood up, I suddenly noticed the piece of Jonathan's shirt on his chest stained with blood from her lips and other blood stains running down from her neck. As if realizing she had just been a victim of the Count, she startled and stepped back with a choking sob:
tr: “Don't be afraid, dear. We are here and no harm can come to you while we are near. You are safe for tonight, stay calm and we should discuss this matter together.” Ms. Harker, resting her head on her husband's chest, trembled and remained silent. When she lifted her head, the places on her husband's white nightshirt where her lips had touched and the open wound on his neck were stained with blood. Upon seeing this, she recoiled with a feeble moan and whispered amidst the sobs that choked her:
es: –Do not worry, dear lady. We are here with you, and as long as this crucifix is by your side, no monster like those can come near you. You are safe tonight, and we must calm down and console each other. Mrs. Harker shuddered and fell silent, keeping her head resting on her husband's chest. When she raised her face, her husband's white shirt was stained with blood where her lips had touched and where the small open wound on her neck had let out a few drops. As soon as Mrs. Harker saw him, she recoiled with a low moan and a whisper, amidst tremendous sobs:

en: “Unclean, unclean! I must touch him or kiss him no more. Oh, that it should be that it is I who am now his worst enemy, and whom he may have most cause to fear.” To this he spoke out resolutely:—
vi: — Filthy, I have become a filthy person!... So I will never be able to embrace and kiss him again! Oh my God! Now I have become the most despicable enemy of him and everyone, I am the most contemptible person! — Don't say that, Mina!
tr: “Sinner! Sinner! I must not touch her again, I must not kiss her again. How terrible it is that I am her worst enemy and the one she should fear the most!” In response, Jonathan resolutely said:
es: –Dirty, dirty! I must not touch or kiss him again. Oh! It is possible that I am now his worst enemy and that it is me whom he should fear the most. Upon hearing that, Jonathan spoke with resolve.

en: “Nonsense, Mina. It is a shame to me to hear such a word. I would not hear it of you; and I shall not hear it from you. May God judge me by my deserts, and punish me with more bitter suffering than even this hour, if by any act or will of mine anything ever come between us!” He put out his arms and folded her to his breast; and for a while she lay there sobbing. He looked at us over her bowed head, with eyes that blinked damply above his quivering nostrils; his mouth was set as steel. After a while her sobs became less frequent and more faint, and then he said to me, speaking with a studied calmness which I felt tried his nervous power to the utmost:—
vi: — Don't say that, Mina! - Jonathan comforted in a determined voice - Why are you saying that? I won't allow you to say such things for any reason. No matter what kind of suffering I have to endure, there's no way I would abandon you. He hugged his petite wife tightly and held her close. She bit her lip, trying to stifle the sobs that seemed never-ending. Finally, when the sobs of the gentle wife had subsided, Jonathan tried to calmly ask me again, although his voice could not hide the tension:
tr: “This is nonsense, Mina. How shameful it is for you to say such a thing. I would not have expected to hear such a thing from you, and I don't want to hear it again. May God judge me as I deserve, and if anything comes between us through any action or desire of mine, may He punish me with a greater penalty than I now endure!” He extended his arms and drew his wife to his chest; for a while, Ms. Harker sobbed there. Over his wife's bowed head, he looked at us with wet eyes above his trembling nostrils; his mouth was as hard as steel. After a while, Ms. Harker's sobs became less frequent and weaker; then, Jonathan, with a forced calmness that I felt strained his nerves to the utmost, said to me:
es: –Nothing of the sort, Mina! I am ashamed to hear those words; I don't want you to say anything like that about yourself, nor do I want you to even think such a thing. May God judge me harshly and punish me with suffering even greater than that of these moments, if by any act or word of mine there is a separation between us! He extended his arms and drew her to his chest. For a few moments, his wife remained embraced by him, sobbing. Jonathan looked at us over his wife's bowed head, with bright eyes that blinked incessantly, while the windows of his nose trembled convulsively and his mouth took on the hardness of steel. After a few moments, Mrs. Harker's sobs became less frequent and softer, and then Jonathan said to me, speaking with a studied calm that must have been putting his nerves to a severe test:

en: “And now, Dr. Seward, tell me all about it. Too well I know the broad fact; tell me all that has been.” I told him exactly what had happened, and he listened with seeming impassiveness; but his nostrils twitched and his eyes blazed as I told how the ruthless hands of the Count had held his wife in that terrible and horrid position, with her mouth to the open wound in his breast. It interested me, even at that moment, to see, that, whilst the face of white set passion worked convulsively over the bowed head, the hands tenderly and lovingly stroked the ruffled hair. Just as I had finished, Quincey and Godalming knocked at the door. They entered in obedience to our summons. Van Helsing looked at me questioningly. I understood him to mean if we were to take advantage of their coming to divert if possible the thoughts of the unhappy husband and wife from each other and from themselves; so on nodding acquiescence to him he asked them what they had seen or done. To which Lord Godalming answered:—
vi: — Dr. Seward, please tell me what happened. I only see that she seems too... Even though I didn't want to, I still tried to recount all the details of what had happened. He listened to me in silence, his eyes blazing with anger and a desire for revenge against that bastard. Despite that, he did not forget to caress the disheveled hair of his young wife. As I had just finished the story, Quincey and Lord Godalming knocked on the door and walked in. Van Helsing gave me a look as if to remind me to take advantage of their reappearance to divert the conversation, so that the unfortunate young couple would no longer be too preoccupied with each other. I nodded slightly in agreement for him to talk to the two friends who had just returned.
tr: “Yes, now Dr. Seward, tell me everything.” “I know the general outlines very well; tell me everything that has happened.” I told him exactly what had happened, and he listened to me with apparent indifference, but as I described how the Count's ruthless hands held his wife in that horrible and terrifying position - her mouth over the open wound on the Count's chest - his nostrils twitched and his eyes blazed. Even then, while passion was evident on the white face above the bowed head, I was struck by the sight of his hands gently and tenderly stroking her disheveled hair. I had just finished speaking when Quincey and Godalming knocked on the door. Upon our invitation, they entered the room. Van Helsing looked at me with questioning eyes. I understood that he wanted to ask if we could use Quincey and Godalming's arrival to divert the attention of this unhappy couple from each other and themselves, if such a thing were possible; thus, upon my nod of agreement, Van Helsing asked them what they had seen and done. Lord Godalming responded to this:
es: –And now, Dr. Seward, tell me everything that happened. I already know all too well what occurred, but please recount all the details. I explained to him exactly what had happened and he listened to me with forced impassibility, but his nostrils trembled and his eyes shone when I explained how the count's hands held his wife in that terrible and horrendous position, with his mouth pressed against the open wound on her throat. It interested me, even at that moment, to see that, although the face white with passion was convulsively contorted over Mrs. Harker's bowed head, the hands gently and lovingly caressed his wife's curly hair. When I finished speaking, Quincey and Godalming knocked on the door. They entered after we gave them permission to do so. Van Helsing looked at me questioningly. I understood that he wanted to indicate to me that it might be convenient to take advantage of the arrival of our two friends to distract the attention of the troubled spouses, so that they would not focus on each other for the moment; thus, when I gave him a nod of agreement, the professor asked the newcomers what they had seen or done. Lord Godalming responded:

en: “I could not see him anywhere in the passage, or in any of our rooms. I looked in the study but, though he had been there, he had gone. He had, however——” He stopped suddenly, looking at the poor drooping figure on the bed. Van Helsing said gravely:—
vi: — I ran outside to see where Dracula disappeared to, but I searched along the corridor and groped around in all the rooms and still couldn't find any trace of him. - Lord Godalming replied - I even went into Dr. Seward's office, but he had already... Arthur suddenly fell silent when he saw Mina lying on the bed. — You were about to say something, weren't you, Arthur? - Van Helsing pressed.
tr: “I didn't see him anywhere in the corridor or in any of our rooms. I looked in the study, but although he had been there, he had left. But...” He suddenly fell silent, looking at the exhausted person in the bed. Van Helsing said seriously:
es: –I didn't find him in the hallway or in any of our rooms. I looked in the study; but, even if he had been there, he was already gone. However… He remained silent for a moment, looking at the poor figure lying on the bed. Van Helsing said to him gravely:

en: “Go on, friend Arthur. We want here no more concealments. Our hope now is in knowing all. Tell freely!” So Art went on:—
vi: - Go on, Arthur. I hope what you're about to say will be our way out. Speak, my friend! — He must have entered the study, - Arthur continued - because inside, everything was thrown around, messy like a pile of trash.
tr: “Go on, my friend Arthur. We don't want any more secrets here. Our hope now is to know everything. Speak freely!” Thus, Art continued his words:
es: –Continue, friend Arthur. We must not hide anything else. Our hope now rests on knowing everything. Speak freely! Therefore, Art continued:

en: “He had been there, and though it could only have been for a few seconds, he made rare hay of the place. All the manuscript had been burned, and the blue flames were flickering amongst the white ashes; the cylinders of your phonograph too were thrown on the fire, and the wax had helped the flames.” Here I interrupted. “Thank God there is the other copy in the safe!” His face lit for a moment, but fell again as he went on: “I ran downstairs then, but could see no sign of him. I looked into Renfield’s room; but there was no trace there except——!” Again he paused. “Go on,” said Harker hoarsely; so he bowed his head and moistening his lips with his tongue, added: “except that the poor fellow is dead.” Mrs. Harker raised her head, looking from one to the other of us she said solemnly:—
vi: Books and papers were all burned to ashes. When we rushed in, the fire was still burning. The tape reels of Dr. Seward's diary were also thrown into the fire. I startled and interrupted him: — But I still have another copy stored in that chest, don't I? Arthur sighed in relief and smiled at me, but then immediately fell silent. — I ran down the stairs, but didn't see... I rushed over to Renfield's room, but there was nothing, if not... — So what? Go on! - Jonathan urged impatiently. — If it weren't for the fact that this patient had died.
tr: “Although he had been there and stayed for only a few seconds, he had turned the room upside down. All the writings were burned, blue flames flickered among the white ashes; the phonograph's cylinders were also thrown into the fire, and the wax had helped the flames.” I interrupted him here. “Thank God, there is another copy in the safe!” His face brightened for a moment, but then fell again as he continued: “Then, I ran down the stairs but I couldn't see any trace of him. I looked into Renfield's room, but there was no trace there either!..” He fell silent again. “Go on,” said Harker in a hoarse voice; thus, Art bowed his head and, licking his lips, added: “But the poor man was dead.” Ms. Harker raised her head and looked at each of us in turn, saying solemnly:
es: –He had been there and, although he could only stay for a few seconds, he put the entire study in disarray. All the manuscripts have been burned and the blue flames were still licking the white ashes -he paused-. Thank God the other copy is in the safe! His face lit up for a moment, but then he grew sad again as he added: –I then ran downstairs, but I found no sign of him. I looked in Renfield's room, but... there was no trace of him, except... -he fell silent again. –Continue -Harker said, with a hoarse voice. Lord Godalming nodded, licked his lips, and continued: –Except that the poor guy is dead. Mrs. Harker raised her head, looked at each of us one by one, and said solemnly:

en: “God’s will be done!” I could not but feel that Art was keeping back something; but, as I took it that it was with a purpose, I said nothing. Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked:—
vi: Arthur lowered his voice and swallowed, trying to finish his sentence. As for myself, I couldn't shake the thought that Lord Godalming was hiding something from us, but because of the dire situation Jonathan and his wife were in, I didn't dare ask him, not even a single question. Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked:
tr: “God's will be done!” I couldn't help but feel that Arthur was hiding something, but I didn't say anything because I understood there was a reason for it. Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked:
es: –Let God's will be done! I couldn't stop thinking that Art was hiding something from us, but since I assumed he was doing it for a specific purpose, I didn't say anything. Van Helsing turned to Morris and asked him:

en: “And you, friend Quincey, have you any to tell?”
vi: — And what about you, do you have any stories to tell us, Morris?
tr: “Well, my friend Quincey, do you have anything to tell?”
es: –And you, friend Quincey, don't you have anything to tell us?

en: “A little,” he answered. “It may be much eventually, but at present I can’t say. I thought it well to know if possible where the Count would go when he left the house. I did not see him; but I saw a bat rise from Renfield’s window, and flap westward. I expected to see him in some shape go back to Carfax; but he evidently sought some other lair. He will not be back to-night; for the sky is reddening in the east, and the dawn is close. We must work to-morrow!”
vi: — There's not much. Maybe I'll be more specific later... it could be... In my opinion, before leaving here, we need to know where the old count has gone. We really don't know where he's hiding. I only saw a bat flying east from Renfield's window. I watched to see how it transformed when it reached the Carfax house, but it clearly flew off in another direction. So tonight he won't be back, as it's almost dawn. And tomorrow we cannot afford not to act.
tr: “A little,” he replied. “In the end, it could be a lot, but for now, I can't say. If such a thing is possible, I thought it would be good to know where the Count went after leaving the house. I didn't see him, but I saw a bat flying west from Renfield's room. I was expecting to see him return to Carfax in some way, but clearly, he was looking for another refuge. He won't come back tonight, because the sky is reddening in the east and dawn is near. We must work tomorrow!”
es: –A little -said Morris-. It might be something important, but, for the moment, I can't be sure. I thought it would be convenient to know where the count was going when he left the house. I didn't see him, but I noticed a bat flying up from Renfield's window and heading west. I expected to see him return to Carfax in one of his forms, but evidently, he went to some other refuge. He won't return tonight, as the sky is beginning to redden in the east and dawn is approaching. We must work tomorrow!

en: He said the latter words through his shut teeth. For a space of perhaps a couple of minutes there was silence, and I could fancy that I could hear the sound of our hearts beating; then Van Helsing said, placing his hand very tenderly on Mrs. Harker’s head:—
vi: Morris spoke through gritted teeth. His words left us speechless for a few moments. The silence made me feel as though I could hear the heartbeat of each person in the room. Van Helsing turned to comfort Mina and asked her:
tr: He spoke his final words through his clenched teeth. There was a silence that lasted perhaps one or two minutes, and I thought I could hear our heartbeats; then Van Helsing, gently placing his hand on Ms. Harker's head, said:
es: He pronounced the last words through clenched teeth. For about two minutes, silence reigned, and I imagined that we could hear the sound produced by the beating of our hearts. Then, Van Helsing, gently placing his hand on Mrs. Harker's head, said:

en: “And now, Madam Mina—poor, dear, dear Madam Mina—tell us exactly what happened. God knows that I do not want that you be pained; but it is need that we know all. For now more than ever has all work to be done quick and sharp, and in deadly earnest. The day is close to us that must end all, if it may be so; and now is the chance that we may live and learn.”
vi: — Mina, now can you tell us what happened? The Lord wants you to share this pain with us, but it is essential now that we know every detail related to you just now. More than ever, we need to act very quickly. We can reach the goal, but the opportunity will come faster if we know more about the situation to achieve the final victory.
tr: “And now Madam Mina -poor, dear, dear Madam Mina- tell us exactly what happened. God knows I don't want you to suffer, but it is necessary for us to know everything. Because now, we must conduct our work faster and more perfectly than ever before, and this is no joke. If it can be, the day that will end everything is approaching, and we now have the chance to live and learn.”
es: –Now, dear Mrs. Harker, tell us exactly what has happened. God knows I do not want to cause you any pain, but we must know everything, as now, more than ever, we have to carry out all the work with speed and efficiency and with deadly urgency. The day is approaching when everything must be finished, if possible, and if we have the chance to live and learn.

en: The poor, dear lady shivered, and I could see the tension of her nerves as she clasped her husband closer to her and bent her head lower and lower still on his breast. Then she raised her head proudly, and held out one hand to Van Helsing who took it in his, and, after stooping and kissing it reverently, held it fast. The other hand was locked in that of her husband, who held his other arm thrown round her protectingly. After a pause in which she was evidently ordering her thoughts, she began:—
vi: Mina shuddered and leaned into her poor husband; I understood very well her tense state of mind at that moment. But then she also raised her face and tightly squeezed Jonathan's hand, looking very determined in response to the old professor's encouragement. — I took the sedative pill that the doctor gave me, but no matter how long I waited, it had no effect.
tr: The poor, dear lady trembled and as she pulled her husband closer and buried her head deeper into his chest, I could see how her nerves were strained. Then she lifted her head proudly and extended one hand to Van Helsing; Van Helsing took this hand between his own, bowed respectfully and kissed it, then quickly squeezed it. Her other hand was clasped with the hand of her husband, who was protecting her with his other arm wrapped around her body. After a pause, during which she seemed to gather her thoughts, she began to speak:
es: The poor lady shuddered violently, and I could notice the tension in her nerves as she clung to her husband more tightly, causing her head to lower even further onto his chest. Then, she raised her head proudly and extended a hand which Van Helsing took, and, bowing, he kissed it respectfully and held it between his own hands. Mrs. Harker's other hand was held by one of her husband's, who, with his other arm, encircled her waist protectively. After a pause during which she was obviously organizing her thoughts, she began:

en: “I took the sleeping draught which you had so kindly given me, but for a long time it did not act. I seemed to become more wakeful, and myriads of horrible fancies began to crowd in upon my mind—all of them connected with death, and vampires; with blood, and pain, and trouble.” Her husband involuntarily groaned as she turned to him and said lovingly: “Do not fret, dear. You must be brave and strong, and help me through the horrible task. If you only knew what an effort it is to me to tell of this fearful thing at all, you would understand how much I need your help. Well, I saw I must try to help the medicine to its work with my will, if it was to do me any good, so I resolutely set myself to sleep. Sure enough sleep must soon have come to me, for I remember no more. Jonathan coming in had not waked me, for he lay by my side when next I remember. There was in the room the same thin white mist that I had before noticed. But I forget now if you know of this; you will find it in my diary which I shall show you later. I felt the same vague terror which had come to me before and the same sense of some presence. I turned to wake Jonathan, but found that he slept so soundly that it seemed as if it was he who had taken the sleeping draught, and not I. I tried, but I could not wake him. This caused me a great fear, and I looked around terrified. Then indeed, my heart sank within me: beside the bed, as if he had stepped out of the mist—or rather as if the mist had turned into his figure, for it had entirely disappeared—stood a tall, thin man, all in black. I knew him at once from the description of the others. The waxen face; the high aquiline nose, on which the light fell in a thin white line; the parted red lips, with the sharp white teeth showing between; and the red eyes that I had seemed to see in the sunset on the windows of St. Mary’s Church at Whitby. I knew, too, the red scar on his forehead where Jonathan had struck him. For an instant my heart stood still, and I would have screamed out, only that I was paralysed. In the pause he spoke in a sort of keen, cutting whisper, pointing as he spoke to Jonathan:—
vi: On the contrary, the more time passed, the harder it was for me to sleep. My mind started to become chaotic and confused, filled with countless terrifying thoughts, and all those bizarre thoughts led me to envision death at the hands of the "vampire," with blood, pain, and bitter sorrow. Jonathan was shocked to hear his wife recount her feelings of sorrow and humiliation; clearly, he was also very tense, but she turned to gently comfort him: — Don't think too much, my love. You have to be brave and strong so that you can help me get through this difficulty. If you understand that I had to try very hard to tell the terrible story tonight, then you will see how much I need your help and everyone's help.- Saying this, she turned to look at us.- Yes, I said I wanted to sleep, and I did everything I could to sleep. Surely at first, sleep must have come to me quickly, because I don't remember anything else. I don't even know when Jonathan came back. I just suddenly woke up and realized he was lying asleep a moment later. And the white mist once again drifted into the room...Forgot, I don't understand if everyone knows what I'm about to say...When you read what I just wrote, surely everyone will know about that white mist. Indeed, I had a premonition of the presence of a stranger in the room, and a vague feeling of fear began to surge within me. I turned to wake Jonathan but couldn't. He slept so soundly that I felt like he was the one who took the sleeping pills, not me. I felt my legs go weak as I stealthily glanced around the room, wondering what was happening. I was terrified when I suddenly realized that right next to my bed, there seemed to be a man's shadow, tall but thin, just stepping out of the mist, or rather, the mist suddenly dissipated, revealing a figure dressed entirely in black. According to the description I had read in Jonathan's diary, I immediately recognized it as Dracula. I intended to scream but couldn't, the fear had paralyzed my entire body. He pointed at Jonathan and ordered me in a whispering, ghostly voice: "Shut up!
tr: "I took the sleeping pill you gave me with great delicacy, but it didn't take effect for a long time. It was as if my sleep had become even more alert, and my mind began to fill with countless horrific thoughts - all related to death, vampires, blood, pain, and distress." Her husband groaned involuntarily and turned to her lovingly, saying: "My concerns, my dear. You must be brave and strong and help me in this dreadful task. If you knew how much effort it took for me to recount this terrifying event, you would understand how much I need your help. Well, if it would be of any benefit to me, I realized that I needed to help the medicine work with my own will, and so, I resolutely went to sleep. I must have fallen asleep shortly after, because I don't remember the rest. Jonathan's arrival did not wake me, because in the next moment, Jonathan was lying beside me. There was a thin, white mist in the room, which I had noticed before. But now I forgot whether you knew this; you will find it in my journal, which I will show you later. I once again felt the same inexplicable fear and the same sense of someone's presence that I had felt before. I turned in bed to wake Jonathan, but I saw that he was sleeping quite deeply, as if he had taken the sleeping pill instead of me. I tried to wake him but could not succeed. This frightened me greatly, and I looked around in terror. Then my heart truly leaped into my mouth: Beside the bed, as if emerging from the mist - or rather, as if the mist had turned into a person, because the mist had completely disappeared - stood a tall, thin man dressed entirely in black. I recognized him from the descriptions of others. A face as white as a candle; a face where the light fell as a thin white line, an arched nose; lips parted to reveal sharp white teeth; the red eyes I seemed to have seen in the window at sunset in St. Mary's Church in Whitby. I also knew the scar on his forehead that Jonathan had left when he struck him. For a moment, my heart stopped, I would have screamed but I was paralyzed. He spoke in a sharp and harsh whisper, pointing to Jonathan:
es: –I took the drug that you so kindly gave me, but for quite some time it had no effect. I seemed to be more and more awake, and countless phantoms began to fill my imagination... All of them related to death and vampires, to blood, pain, and despair -her husband involuntarily grunted, while she turned to Jonathan and lovingly said-: Don't get upset, darling. You must be brave and strong to help me through this terrible ordeal. If you knew what a great effort it takes for me to simply talk about this horrible matter, you would understand how much I need your help. Well, I realized that I had to try to help the medicine take effect through my own willpower if I wanted it to be of any use to me. Therefore, resolutely, I tried to sleep. I'm sure I must have fallen asleep immediately, as I don't remember anything else. Jonathan, upon entering, did not wake me, as my next memory is that he was beside me. There was the same light mist in the room that I had seen before. But I don't remember if you are aware of it; you will find everything about it in my diary, which I will show you later. The same vague terror as before seized me, and I had the same feeling that there was someone in the room. I turned to wake Jonathan, but found that he was sleeping so deeply that it seemed it was he, not I, who had taken the drug. I tried as hard as I could, but I couldn't get him to wake up. That made me very scared and I looked around, terrified. Then, my heart skipped a beat: beside the bed, as if he had emerged from the mist or rather, as if the mist had transformed into him, since it had completely disappeared, there was a tall and thin man, dressed in black. I recognized him immediately from the description given to me by the others. By his wax-like white face; the long, aquiline nose, over which the light formed a thin white line; the slightly parted lips, between which appeared sharp, white teeth and the red eyes that I seemed to have seen at sunset in St. Mary's Church, in Whitby. I also knew the red scar he had on his forehead, where Jonathan had struck him. For a moment, my heart stopped and I wanted to scream, but I was paralyzed. Meanwhile, the monster spoke, with a dry and sharp whisper, pointing at Jonathan with his finger:

en: “‘Silence! If you make a sound I shall take him and dash his brains out before your very eyes.’ I was appalled and was too bewildered to do or say anything. With a mocking smile, he placed one hand upon my shoulder and, holding me tight, bared my throat with the other, saying as he did so, ‘First, a little refreshment to reward my exertions. You may as well be quiet; it is not the first time, or the second, that your veins have appeased my thirst!’ I was bewildered, and, strangely enough, I did not want to hinder him. I suppose it is a part of the horrible curse that such is, when his touch is on his victim. And oh, my God, my God, pity me! He placed his reeking lips upon my throat!” Her husband groaned again. She clasped his hand harder, and looked at him pityingly, as if he were the injured one, and went on:—
vi: Otherwise, he will pay for it! I will crush him right before your eyes!” Honestly, I didn't have the strength to argue back or make even the smallest movement. He sneered contemptuously, then placed one hand on my shoulder, the other grabbed the nape of my neck and pulled my head to his chest. “Now all my efforts have been duly rewarded! - He growled.- Now, be quiet! This is not the first time, nor the second time, that the blood within you has quenched my thirst!” I was terrified, but strangely, I didn't feel the urge to resist his craving. I believe that is the result of one of the most dreadful curses weighing on his victims. Oh! Lord, have mercy on me! Then his filthy lips pressed against my neck. Jonathan gritted his teeth as if trying to suppress the pain inside, his body trembling with anger. Mina didn't know what else to do but to hold his hand tightly to share the feelings with her husband.
tr: “‘Be quiet! If you make a sound, I'll take it and blow your brains out right in front of your eyes.’ I was terrified, too stunned to do or say anything. With a mocking smile, he placed one hand on my shoulder and, holding me tightly, exposed my neck with his other hand; while doing so, he said: ‘First, a light drink as a reward for my efforts. You better be quiet; this isn't the first or second time your veins have quenched my thirst!’ I was bewildered, and strangely enough, I didn't want to stop him. I think this is part of the terrible curse that emerges when he touches his victim. And oh, my God! My God! Have mercy on me! He pressed his foul-smelling lips against my throat!” Her husband groaned again. Ms. Harker held his hand tighter and looked at him with pity as if she were the one injured, and continued her words:
es: "-Silence! If you utter a single sound, I will catch him and crush his head." "I was terrified and too stunned to be able to do or say anything. With a mocking smile, he put a hand on my shoulder and, holding me firmly, bared my throat with the other, saying at the same time: "-First, a small refreshment, as payment for my efforts. It would be best if you remain still; it is neither the first nor the second time that your veins have quenched my thirst. "I was bewildered and, strange as it may seem, I did not wish to disturb him. I suppose it is part of his terrible power when he is preying on one of his victims. And, oh my God, oh my God, have mercy on me! He pressed his disgusting lips to my throat!

en: “I felt my strength fading away, and I was in a half swoon. How long this horrible thing lasted I know not; but it seemed that a long time must have passed before he took his foul, awful, sneering mouth away. I saw it drip with the fresh blood!” The remembrance seemed for a while to overpower her, and she drooped and would have sunk down but for her husband’s sustaining arm. With a great effort she recovered herself and went on:—
vi: — The strength within me gradually depleted, I felt as if I was about to faint. I didn't know how long I had to endure that, only that the feeling persisted until he moved his filthy, blood-stained mouth away from my neck. If Jonathan hadn't been by her side, she might have collapsed onto the bed, unable to bear the humiliation of recalling that disgusting image. But immediately after that, she tried to calm down and continued her story:
tr: “I felt my strength slowly draining away, I was half-unconscious. I don't know how long this horrifying thing lasted, but it felt like a long time before he withdrew his foul-smelling, terrible, and mocking lips. I saw fresh blood dripping from his lips!” For a while, it seemed that what she remembered affected her deeply, and she lost her strength, and if it weren't for her husband's arm holding her, she would have fallen and fainted. With great effort, she pulled herself together and continued to speak:
es: "I felt my strength leaving me and I was half-fainting. I don't know how long that terrible scene lasted, but it seemed to me that a good while passed before he withdrew his disgusting, foul-smelling, and dirty mouth. I saw that it was full of fresh blood!" The memory seemed to be more than she could bear, and she would have collapsed if not for her husband's arm supporting her. With great effort, she composed herself and continued speaking:

en: “Then he spoke to me mockingly, ‘And so you, like the others, would play your brains against mine. You would help these men to hunt me and frustrate me in my designs! You know now, and they know in part already, and will know in full before long, what it is to cross my path. They should have kept their energies for use closer to home. Whilst they played wits against me—against me who commanded nations, and intrigued for them, and fought for them, hundreds of years before they were born—I was countermining them. And you, their best beloved one, are now to me, flesh of my flesh; blood of my blood; kin of my kin; my bountiful wine-press for a while; and shall be later on my companion and my helper. You shall be avenged in turn; for not one of them but shall minister to your needs. But as yet you are to be punished for what you have done. You have aided in thwarting me; now you shall come to my call. When my brain says “Come!” to you, you shall cross land or sea to do my bidding; and to that end this!’ With that he pulled open his shirt, and with his long sharp nails opened a vein in his breast. When the blood began to spurt out, he took my hands in one of his, holding them tight, and with the other seized my neck and pressed my mouth to the wound, so that I must either suffocate or swallow some of the—— Oh my God! my God! what have I done? What have I done to deserve such a fate, I who have tried to walk in meekness and righteousness all my days. God pity me! Look down on a poor soul in worse than mortal peril; and in mercy pity those to whom she is dear!” Then she began to rub her lips as though to cleanse them from pollution.
vi: — Then he smirked, looking very contemptuous: "So you too, you also contributed to ruining my plan, you are an accomplice of those men trying to oppose me! But now, and soon enough, both you and they will understand the consequences of liking to obstruct others. They should have used their feeble strength for smaller, more trivial matters. I have crushed the plans of countless people over the centuries, and it will be the same for these ones. As for you, a very dear and precious ally of theirs, you now belong to me, you will be my flesh and blood, satisfying all my desires, and forevermore, you will be my companion and do-gooder! You will have time to rectify your mistakes, for those men cannot refuse you anything you demand of them. But now, you must be punished first for the crime of being an accomplice. You colluded with them to harm me. That's it! From now on, you will have to respond to my call. Whenever in thought, I call you: 'Come here,' you will immediately have to cross forests, mountains, and seas to meet me...” Outside, a new day begins again.
tr: “Then he spoke mockingly: ‘So, you too, like the others, are trying to outwit me. You are helping these men in hunting me down and hindering my goals! Now you know what it means to stand in my way - they know it partially and soon they will learn it completely. They should have saved their strength to use near their homes. While they play mind games with me - me, who has commanded nations, schemed for nations, and fought for nations for hundreds of years before they were even born - I am defeating them. And you, their favorite, are now flesh of my flesh, blood of my blood, my kin, for a while you are my generous wine press and in the future, you will be my friend, my helper. In return, your revenge will be taken, because not one of them will be able to meet their needs. But still, you will be punished for what you have done. You helped to hinder me; now you must come at my call. Whenever my mind says to you “Come,” you will cross lands or seas to fulfill my command; that is enough!’ Saying this, he opened his shirt and with his long sharp nails, he cut a vein in his chest. When the blood started to gush out, he held my hands tightly with one hand and with the other, he grabbed my neck and pressed my mouth to the wound so that I would either suffocate or drink his blood... Oh, my God! My God! What have I done? I, who have tried to act with humility and honesty all my life, what have I done to deserve such a fate? God, have mercy on me! Look upon this poor servant who has fallen into a fate worse than mortal danger; have mercy on those who love him!” Then, as if wanting to cleanse himself from filth, he began to rub his lips.
es: –Then, he spoke to me mockingly: "So, you, like the others, wanted to pit your intelligence against mine! You wanted to help those men annihilate me and thwart my plans! Now you know, and they all know in part and will fully know before long, what it means to cross my path. They should have saved their energies to use them closer to their homes. While they were making plans to confront me… Me, who has directed nations, intrigued for them, and fought for them, hundreds of years before they were born, I was sabotaging them. And you, the beloved of all of them, are now mine; you are flesh of my flesh, blood of my blood, kin of my kin; my wine press for a certain time; and later, you will be my companion and helper. You will be avenged in turn, for none of them will be able to meet your needs. But now I must punish you for what you have done by allying with the others to fight me. From now on, you will come at my call. When my mind commands, thinking of you, you will cross lands and seas if necessary to come to my side and do my will, and to ensure it, look at what I do!" Then, he opened his shirt, and with his long and sharp nails, he opened a vein in his chest. When the blood began to flow, he took my hands in one of his, squeezed them firmly, and with his free hand, grabbed me by the neck and forced my mouth against his wound, so that I either choked or was forced to swallow… Oh, my God! My God! What have I done? What have I done to deserve such a fate, I, who have tried to stay on the straight path all the days of my life? Have mercy on me, my God! Look down upon my poor soul that is subject to a danger more than mortal! Have compassion on me! Then, he began to rub his lips, as if to avoid contamination.

en: As she was telling her terrible story, the eastern sky began to quicken, and everything became more and more clear. Harker was still and quiet; but over his face, as the awful narrative went on, came a grey look which deepened and deepened in the morning light, till when the first red streak of the coming dawn shot up, the flesh stood darkly out against the whitening hair.
vi: Jonathan remained silent, listening to the sorrowful and humiliating story of his gentle wife, his face darkened with beads of sweat. I was startled when I noticed the strands of gray hair sticking to his forehead.
tr: As Ms. Harker recounted this dreadful story, the sky in the east began to brighten, and everything became clearer. Harker was calm and silent, but as this horrific narrative continued, a gloomy expression, deepening in the morning light, settled on her face. So much so that, as the first red streaks of the coming dawn quickly rose, her flesh stood out with its dark tone against the whitening hair in front of it.
es: While narrating his terrible story, the sky to the east began to brighten, and all the details of the room started to appear more clearly. Harker remained motionless and silent, but on his face, as the terrible tale progressed, a grayish expression appeared that deepened as the daylight became clearer; when the reddish glow of dawn intensified, his skin stood out, very dark, against his hair, which was turning white.

en: We have arranged that one of us is to stay within call of the unhappy pair till we can meet together and arrange about taking action.
vi: All day today, our group had to take turns keeping an eye on the unfortunate couple, in case something bad happened so we could respond.
tr: We decided to stay within a distance where the unhappy couple could call out until one of us organized and took action.
es: We have made arrangements for one of us to always be attentive to the call of the unhappy couple, until we can all gather and prepare everything necessary to take action.

en: Of this I am sure: the sun rises to-day on no more miserable house in all the great round of its daily course.
vi: Indeed, today, I can only be sure of one thing: the radiant sunlight is not enough to illuminate our house filled with sorrow. We will sit down together again in a meeting with the hope of quickly finding the most reliable course of action.
tr: I am certain of this: The Sun, in its great daily journey, will not rise over a house more unhappy than this.
es: I am sure that the sun will not rise today over any house more steeped in sadness than this one.

en: CHAPTER XXII
vi: CHAPTER 22
tr: XXII
es: XXII.–

en: JONATHAN HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF JONATHAN HARKER

en: 3 October.—As I must do something or go mad, I write this diary. It is now six o’clock, and we are to meet in the study in half an hour and take something to eat; for Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward are agreed that if we do not eat we cannot work our best. Our best will be, God knows, required to-day. I must keep writing at every chance, for I dare not stop to think. All, big and little, must go down; perhaps at the end the little things may teach us most. The teaching, big or little, could not have landed Mina or me anywhere worse than we are to-day. However, we must trust and hope. Poor Mina told me just now, with the tears running down her dear cheeks, that it is in trouble and trial that our faith is tested—that we must keep on trusting; and that God will aid us up to the end. The end! oh my God! what end?... To work! To work!
vi: • October 3 I feel like if I don't do something, I'll go crazy, so I have to write in my diary again. It is now half past six, in half an hour, we will have breakfast together in Dr. Seward's room. He and Van Helsing told me that no matter what, I must try to eat a little to have the strength to continue working. Today, who knows, there might be something that requires us to put in a lot more effort. I grabbed a pen and wrote a few lines here because if I stop, I'm afraid I'll start thinking all sorts of things. Indeed, everything we know so far hasn't been used for anything yet. But anyway, Mina and I still have to trust and hope for a good outcome in the end. My wife just confided that it is in such difficult times that we prove our loyalty to each other, so don't let ourselves be defeated by the circumstances, God will surely protect us to the end. To the end! Oh! God! To the end of what?...
tr: October 3. - I am writing this journal because I will go mad if I don't do something. It's six o'clock, in half an hour we will gather in the study and have something to eat; Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward agree that we cannot work at our best if we do not eat. God knows, we need to do our best work today. I must keep writing at every opportunity, because I dare not stop thinking. Everything, big or small, must be put into writing; perhaps in the end, it will be the small things that teach us the most. No lesson, big or small, could put Mina or me in a worse situation than we are in today. Still, we must have faith and hope. Just a moment ago, poor Mina, with tears streaming down her beautiful cheeks, said that our faith is tested by troubles and hardships, that we must continue to be faithful, and that God will help us to the end. The end! Oh, God! The end of what?.. Work! Work!
es: October 3rd. I have to do something, if I don't want to go crazy; that's why I am writing in this diary. It is now six in the morning, and we have to meet in the study in half an hour to eat something, since Dr. Seward and Professor Van Helsing agree that if we don't eat anything, we won't be in a condition to do our best work. God knows that today we will need to give our best. I have to keep writing, no matter what, as I cannot stop to think. Everything, the small details as well as the big ones, must be recorded; perhaps the insignificant details will be the ones that help us the most later on. The teachings, good or bad, could not have harmed Mina and me more than what we are suffering today. However, we must have hope and trust. Poor Mina just told me a moment ago, with tears running down her beloved cheeks, that it is in adversity and misfortune that we must show our faith... That we must continue to have trust, and that God will help us to the end. The end! Oh, my God! What end. ..? To work! To work!

en: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward had come back from seeing poor Renfield, we went gravely into what was to be done. First, Dr. Seward told us that when he and Dr. Van Helsing had gone down to the room below they had found Renfield lying on the floor, all in a heap. His face was all bruised and crushed in, and the bones of the neck were broken.
vi: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from Renfield's room, we sat down again to discuss what needed to be done. First, Seward recounted to us the story of the patient: when they reached his room, he and Van Helsing found him lying on the floor, his face covered in wounds, and his spine shattered.
tr: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from their visit to poor Renfield, we set to work on the task that needed to be done with seriousness. First, Dr. Seward recounted that when he and Dr. Van Helsing went to the room downstairs, they found Renfield collapsed on the floor. His face was bruised and battered, and his neck bones were broken.
es: When Dr. Van Helsing and Dr. Seward returned from their visit to poor Renfield, we gravely discussed what needed to be done. First, Dr. Seward told us that when he and Dr. Van Helsing had descended to the room on the lower floor, they had found Renfield lying on the ground. His face was all bruised and crushed, and the bones of his nose were broken.

en: Dr. Seward asked the attendant who was on duty in the passage if he had heard anything. He said that he had been sitting down—he confessed to half dozing—when he heard loud voices in the room, and then Renfield had called out loudly several times, “God! God! God!” after that there was a sound of falling, and when he entered the room he found him lying on the floor, face down, just as the doctors had seen him. Van Helsing asked if he had heard “voices” or “a voice,” and he said he could not say; that at first it had seemed to him as if there were two, but as there was no one in the room it could have been only one. He could swear to it, if required, that the word “God” was spoken by the patient. Dr. Seward said to us, when we were alone, that he did not wish to go into the matter; the question of an inquest had to be considered, and it would never do to put forward the truth, as no one would believe it. As it was, he thought that on the attendant’s evidence he could give a certificate of death by misadventure in falling from bed. In case the coroner should demand it, there would be a formal inquest, necessarily to the same result.
vi: In fact, Dr. Seward had previously instructed a hospital attendant to watch over and stand guard in the hallway outside his room. The attendant had not fulfilled his duty, as he admitted that during his watch, he had dozed off. It was during this dozing off that he was startled by Renfield's frantic cries from the room: “Oh God! Oh God!... Oh God!...” Following that was a heavy thud on the floor. When he rushed in, he saw Renfield lying sprawled on the ground, exactly as Seward had witnessed. Van Helsing asked the attendant if there had been the voice of one person or many, but he could not answer. At first, he felt that the room could not have contained only Renfield, but when he rushed in immediately after hearing the thud, he saw no one else. And he swore that only Renfield had cried out “Oh God!” Dr. Seward told us that he didn't want to push the matter too far, as the authorities would surely conduct an investigation, and any further inquiry on our part would be of no use in revealing the truth, because no one would believe the truth we presented. He said it would be best to have the warden issue a death certificate for Renfield, concluding that he had an accident after falling headfirst from his bed. If an investigation were conducted, the authorities would only be able to reach such a conclusion anyway. But then, what will we have to do? The time for decision has come.
tr: Dr. Seward had asked the nurse on duty in the corridor if he had heard anything. He said that he was sitting when loud noises came from the room, and immediately afterward, Renfield loudly shouted, "My God! My God! My God!" repeatedly - he also admitted to being half-asleep. After that, there was a sound of something falling, and when he entered the room, he found Renfield lying face down on the floor, as the doctors had seen. Van Helsing asked if he heard "a sound" or "sounds," and the nurse said he couldn't tell; at first, it seemed like there were two people, but since there was no one else in the room, it must have been just one person. He could swear, if necessary, that the words "My God!" were spoken by the patient. Dr. Seward, when we were alone, said he didn't want to delve into the matter, that the issue needed to be evaluated, and that the truth would never come out because no one would believe it. In this case, based on the nurse's testimony, he said he could issue a death certificate stating that the death was due to a fall from the bed. If the coroner requested, an official investigation would be conducted and would reach the same conclusion.
es: Dr. Seward asked the assistant who was on duty in the hallway if he had heard anything. The assistant told him that he had been sitting and was half-asleep when he heard loud voices in the patient's room and Renfield shouting loudly several times: "God! God! God!" After that, he heard the noise of a fall, and when he entered the room, he found him lying on the floor, face down, just as the doctor had seen him. Van Helsing asked him if he had heard "voices" or "a single voice" and the assistant said he was not sure; at first, it seemed to him that there were two, but since there was only one person in the room, it had to be just one. He could swear, if necessary, that the word uttered by the patient had been "God!". Dr. Seward told us, when we were alone, that he did not wish to go into details about this matter; it was necessary to consider the possibility of an inquest, and it would not contribute anything to proving the truth, since no one would be able to believe it. Under such circumstances, he thought that, based on the assistant's statements, he could issue a death certificate for an accident, due to a fall from his bed. If the coroner required it, there would be an inquest that would lead to exactly the same result.

en: When the question began to be discussed as to what should be our next step, the very first thing we decided was that Mina should be in full confidence; that nothing of any sort—no matter how painful—should be kept from her. She herself agreed as to its wisdom, and it was pitiful to see her so brave and yet so sorrowful, and in such a depth of despair. “There must be no concealment,” she said, “Alas! we have had too much already. And besides there is nothing in all the world that can give me more pain than I have already endured—than I suffer now! Whatever may happen, it must be of new hope or of new courage to me!” Van Helsing was looking at her fixedly as she spoke, and said, suddenly but quietly:—
vi: All the men among us agreed on one decision: if we cannot return to Exeter, Mina will once again directly join our group, and she will be informed of all our actions. Thus, she will have the opportunity to share in the joy, sorrow, and anxiety with us during each discussion, and it will also be an occasion for her to demonstrate her courage. — Please, everyone, don't hide anything from me anymore, can you? I have had to remain silent and ignorant about many things already. Moreover, from what I have just learned, please don't think that I cannot endure anything more beyond the misfortunes I have experienced so far! On the contrary, I have a legitimate reason to hope and to demonstrate my courage in the face of anything else that might happen! Van Helsing had been attentively observing her for a while now, as if he had noticed something unusual about her, because he suddenly asked her:
tr: When the question of what our next step would be began to be discussed, the first decision we made was to tell Mina everything, no matter how painful it might be, and to hide nothing from her. She herself agreed that this was wise; it was heartbreaking to see her so brave, yet at the same time so sad and in deep despair. "There should be no more secrets from now on," she said, "Unfortunately, we have had many secrets up until now. And besides, there is nothing in the world that could cause me more pain than what I have endured so far - and what I am enduring now! No matter what, it should give me new hope or new courage!" As she spoke, Van Helsing, who had been staring at Mina, suddenly said quietly:
es: When we began to discuss what our next step should be, the first thing we decided was that Mina should be fully trusted and kept informed of everything; that nothing, absolutely nothing, no matter how horrible or painful it might be, should be hidden from her. She herself agreed on the advisability of such a measure, and it was truly a pity to see her so brave and, at the same time, so full of pain and despair. –You must not hide anything from me -he said-. Unfortunately, too many things have already been hidden from me. Besides, there is nothing in the world that can cause me greater pain than what I have had to endure… that I am still suffering! Whatever happens, it will mean comfort and a renewal of my hopes for me! Van Helsing was staring at her intently while he spoke, and said suddenly, though gently:

en: “But dear Madam Mina, are you not afraid; not for yourself, but for others from yourself, after what has happened?” Her face grew set in its lines, but her eyes shone with the devotion of a martyr as she answered:—
vi: — But Mina, don't you feel scared after what just happened? It's not fear for yourself, I mean fear for the people around you! Her face suddenly hardened, and her eyes sparkled, reflecting the acceptance of sacrifice of a martyr. She replied:
tr: “But dear Madam Mina, are you not afraid; if not for yourself, then for those close to you after all that has happened?” The lines on Mina's face hardened, but as she responded, her eyes sparkled with the self-sacrifice of someone who sacrifices themselves:
es: –But, dear Mrs. Mina, aren't you afraid, if not for yourself, at least for others, after what has happened? Mina's face hardened, but her eyes shone with the same devotion as a martyr's when she replied:

en: “Ah no! for my mind is made up!”
vi: — No! No! Because I have already decided. — Decision? -
tr: “Ah, no! Because I have made my decision!”
es: –No! My mind has already gotten used to the idea!

en: “To what?” he asked gently, whilst we were all very still; for each in our own way we had a sort of vague idea of what she meant. Her answer came with direct simplicity, as though she were simply stating a fact:—
vi: The professor asked, wide-eyed. We silently looked at each other, as almost everyone could guess what she wanted to say. She answered nonchalantly as if it were the most natural thing in the world: — That's right!
tr: "Why?" asked Van Helsing politely; we were all very quiet at that moment because we all had a vague idea of what Mina meant. The answer came with a clarity as if stating a fact.
es: –To what idea? – asked the professor softly, while we all remained motionless, as each of us, in our own way, had a slight idea of what he wanted to say. His response was given with complete simplicity, as if he were merely stating a certain fact:

en: “Because if I find in myself—and I shall watch keenly for it—a sign of harm to any that I love, I shall die!”
vi: If I ever find that I no longer want the person I love, I will die!
tr: "Because if I find any indication that I could harm someone I love - and I will be observing carefully for this - I will die!"
es: –Because if I find in myself (and I will watch myself very carefully) any sign that I might be the cause of harm to someone I love, I must die!

en: “You would not kill yourself?” he asked, hoarsely.
vi: — "You don't mean you're going to commit suicide, do you?" the professor asked in surprise, his voice hoarse. — Of course...
tr: Van Helsing asked in a hoarse voice, "You are not going to kill yourself, are you?"
es: –Will you kill yourself? – asked Van Helsing, with a hoarse voice.

en: “I would; if there were no friend who loved me, who would save me such a pain, and so desperate an effort!” She looked at him meaningly as she spoke. He was sitting down; but now he rose and came close to her and put his hand on her head as he said solemnly:
vi: Unless I have a true friend who really wants to share with me the effort to complete such a terrible task! She glanced at the professor with a subtle look in her eyes. Hearing her speak, he slowly stood up, gently brushed her disheveled hair, and solemnly said:
tr: "I will kill; if I have no friend to save me from such pain and such a hopeless effort!" While speaking, he looked meaningfully at Van Helsing. The professor was sitting, but now he stood up and approached Mina, putting his hand to his head and said seriously:
es: –I will do it, if there is no friend who wishes to save me, sparing me that pain and that desperate effort. Mina looked at the professor gravely as she spoke. Van Helsing was seated, but suddenly stood up, approached her, and, gently placing his hand on her head, solemnly declared:

en: “My child, there is such an one if it were for your good. For myself I could hold it in my account with God to find such an euthanasia for you, even at this moment if it were best. Nay, were it safe! But my child——” For a moment he seemed choked, and a great sob rose in his throat; he gulped it down and went on:—
vi: — Mina, you have a friend here. He will act if you fall into danger. God will bear witness to this, I will never back down from danger for my friends, if necessary, I can act right now. But, madam... Emotions surged in his heart, causing him to choke up and unable to finish his sentence. It was only after a while, when he had calmed down, that he could continue speaking:
tr: “My child, if it is for your own good, such a person will be. For my part, if this is the best, even now, I would take the responsibility before God to prepare such a euthanasia for you. No, if it will be safe! But my child...” For a moment, she felt like she was choking and a great sob rose from her throat, she continued her words by swallowing:
es: –My friend, there is someone who would be willing to do it if it were for your own good. Since I myself would be willing to answer for such an act before God, if euthanasia for you, even at this very moment, were the best, if it were necessary. But, dear lady… For a moment, he seemed to be a victim of an emotional shock, and a huge sob was stifled in his throat; he swallowed hard and continued:

en: “There are here some who would stand between you and death. You must not die. You must not die by any hand; but least of all by your own. Until the other, who has fouled your sweet life, is true dead you must not die; for if he is still with the quick Un-Dead, your death would make you even as he is. No, you must live! You must struggle and strive to live, though death would seem a boon unspeakable. You must fight Death himself, though he come to you in pain or in joy; by the day, or the night; in safety or in peril! On your living soul I charge you that you do not die—nay, nor think of death—till this great evil be past.” The poor dear grew white as death, and shock and shivered, as I have seen a quicksand shake and shiver at the incoming of the tide. We were all silent; we could do nothing. At length she grew more calm and turning to him said, sweetly, but oh! so sorrowfully, as she held out her hand:—
vi: — There is someone who has stood between you and death. You should not die like this. No hand can push you towards death, except your own hand.
