Until the day the one who tainted your life truly dies, you will not be able to die! As long as there is an immortal being alive to commit crimes like him, your death will make you become like him. You must live! You must fight, fight for life, even when you think that death would be a good thing to do. You must fight against death itself, whether it comes to you in times of sorrow or joy, day or night, peace or danger! To liberate your soul, I suggest you do not die... or never think of death, until that demon is destroyed! Mina's whole body was trembling violently as if she had a fever, her face pale like a real corpse. We remained silent, as no one knew what to say at that moment. It was only after a while, when she had calmed down, that she looked up and spoke to the professor in a sad voice:
tr: “There are some who will stand between you and death here. You must not die by anyone's hand; especially not by your own. You must not die until that other, who has wronged your sweet life, tastes true death, for if he is still among the living Undead, your death will make you more like him. No, you must live! Even if death seems like an unspeakable blessing, you must fight and strive to live. Whether it comes to you with pain or joy, by day or by night, in safety or in danger, you must fight against Death itself! Until this great evil is buried in the past, I charge your living soul with this duty; you must not die - moreover, you must not even think of death.” My poor darling turned as white as a corpse, trembling and shaking as I have seen in the marshes with the rising tides. At last, she calmed a little and turned to Van Helsing, extending her hand to him sweetly but with great sorrow, and said:
es: –There are several people here who would stand between you and death. You must not die in any way, and even less so by your own hand. As long as the other, who has poisoned the sweetness of your life, has not died, you must not die either; because if he still exists among the living dead, your death would turn you into exactly the same as he is. No! You must live! You must fight and strive to live, as death would be an unspeakable horror. You must fight against death, whether it comes to you in the midst of sadness or joy; by day or by night; safe or in danger. For the salvation of your soul, I beg you not to die and not even to think of death, as long as that monster has not ceased to exist! My poor and beloved wife turned pale as a corpse and shuddered violently, just as I had seen the quicksand shudder when someone fell into it. We all remained silent; there was nothing we could do. Finally, Mina calmed down a bit, turned to the professor, and said sweetly, though with infinite sadness, while Dr. Van Helsing took her hand:

en: “I promise you, my dear friend, that if God will let me live, I shall strive to do so; till, if it may be in His good time, this horror may have passed away from me.” She was so good and brave that we all felt that our hearts were strengthened to work and endure for her, and we began to discuss what we were to do. I told her that she was to have all the papers in the safe, and all the papers or diaries and phonographs we might hereafter use; and was to keep the record as she had done before. She was pleased with the prospect of anything to do—if “pleased” could be used in connection with so grim an interest.
vi: — I promise you, our dear friend, that if God wants me to live, I will try my best until those terrible things come to an end. Mina's courage and determination were like a breath of fresh air that gave us strength and bravery in the uneven battle against the cruel enemy awaiting us ahead. Yes, her heart made us accept the inevitable hardships to save her life. I promise you that we will hand over to you all the documents stored in the chest as well as any papers, diaries, or tapes that we think will be necessary in the near future. During the time of organizing the documents, you should continue to keep your diary. The prospect of being busy with work seemed to make you feel more comfortable.
tr: “I promise you, dear friend, if God allows me to live, I will strive for this; until the time comes when this horror leaves me.” He was so good and so kind-hearted that we all felt our hearts strengthened to work and endure for him, and we began to discuss what we should do. I told him to take all the documents in the safe, all the papers, diaries, and the phonograph that we might use later, and to keep records again as he used to. The possibility of doing something pleased him - if “pleasure” could be used for such a relentless pursuit.
es: –I promise you, my friend, that if God allows me to continue living, I will strive to do so, until, if it is His will, this horror has ended for me. In the face of such a good and courageous attitude, we all felt our hearts strengthen, preparing us to work and endure everything for her. And we began to deliberate on what we should do. I told Mina that she had to store all the documents in the safe and all the papers, journals, or phonograph cylinders that we might use later, and that she should take charge of keeping everything in order, as she had done before. I saw that she liked the prospect of having something to do... if the verb "like" can be used in relation to such a horrendous matter.

en: As usual Van Helsing had thought ahead of everyone else, and was prepared with an exact ordering of our work.
vi: As usual, Van Helsing began pacing in front of us and reflecting on the entire situation from the beginning until now, after which he would tell us exactly what we needed to do.
tr: As usual, Van Helsing had thought ahead of everyone and had prepared the exact order of our tasks.
es: As usual, Van Helsing had gotten ahead of us all and was prepared with an exact plan for our work.

en: “It is perhaps well,” he said, “that at our meeting after our visit to Carfax we decided not to do anything with the earth-boxes that lay there. Had we done so, the Count must have guessed our purpose, and would doubtless have taken measures in advance to frustrate such an effort with regard to the others; but now he does not know our intentions. Nay, more, in all probability, he does not know that such a power exists to us as can sterilise his lairs, so that he cannot use them as of old. We are now so much further advanced in our knowledge as to their disposition that, when we have examined the house in Piccadilly, we may track the very last of them. To-day, then, is ours; and in it rests our hope. The sun that rose on our sorrow this morning guards us in its course. Until it sets to-night, that monster must retain whatever form he now has. He is confined within the limitations of his earthly envelope. He cannot melt into thin air nor disappear through cracks or chinks or crannies. If he go through a doorway, he must open the door like a mortal. And so we have this day to hunt out all his lairs and sterilise them. So we shall, if we have not yet catch him and destroy him, drive him to bay in some place where the catching and the destroying shall be, in time, sure.” Here I started up for I could not contain myself at the thought that the minutes and seconds so preciously laden with Mina’s life and happiness were flying from us, since whilst we talked action was impossible. But Van Helsing held up his hand warningly. “Nay, friend Jonathan,” he said, “in this, the quickest way home is the longest way, so your proverb say. We shall all act and act with desperate quick, when the time has come. But think, in all probable the key of the situation is in that house in Piccadilly. The Count may have many houses which he has bought. Of them he will have deeds of purchase, keys and other things. He will have paper that he write on; he will have his book of cheques. There are many belongings that he must have somewhere; why not in this place so central, so quiet, where he come and go by the front or the back at all hour, when in the very vast of the traffic there is none to notice. We shall go there and search that house; and when we learn what it holds, then we do what our friend Arthur call, in his phrases of hunt ‘stop the earths’ and so we run down our old fox—so? is it not?”
vi: — After entering the abandoned Carfax house, - he began to get to the point - I think we were right not to rush to touch the crates of earth in there. Otherwise, the Count would easily guess our intentions and would certainly find a way to prevent us from finding the remaining crates. Until now, he has no suspicion about our purpose, he doesn't even know that we have the ability to neutralize all his crates of earth, leaving him without a single safe haven. Now we have enough information so that after breaking into the house in Piccadilly, we will also easily find the remaining wooden crates. Thus, today will be very important for us, perhaps this will be the day that decides our final victory. The rising sun will illuminate our misfortune and will protect us until the last rays of the day fade away! Indeed, until then, that demon will not be able to change shape. He will only be able to hide within the layers of earth for shelter, he cannot blend into the air or squeeze through narrow gaps. If he wants to pass through a door, he will have to open it like any other person. Therefore, we will have an entire day to find and destroy his lairs. Tonight, even if we haven't caught him to destroy him, we must drive him into a place where he cannot escape from us anymore. Hearing this, I could no longer remain silent: the thought that we were wasting every precious minute and second to reclaim joy and life for Mina was unbearable to me. — When we talk, it is also the time we do not act! As if understanding my impatience, Van Helsing waved his hand dismissively: — Wait a moment, just a little longer, my dear friend Jonathan! - He said. - For something this important, we should not rush if we want to achieve ultimate victory. When the time is right to act, we will act! Think about it, considering all possibilities, the house in Piccadilly is likely the place that will help us clarify many issues. Dracula may have bought many houses. If so, he must have many house purchase receipts, checkbooks, and keys for each house he bought... All of those things must be kept somewhere. Why not in the quiet house in the middle of London, where he can come and go through the main gate or the side door at any convenient hour without being noticed? We will have to explore the Piccadilly house, and once we discover what is stored inside, we can completely hunt the old fox down to its den. What do you all think?
tr: “Maybe,” he said, “it was good that we decided not to do anything about the soil boxes standing there during the meeting we held after our visit to Carfax. If we had done something, the Count would have guessed our purpose and undoubtedly taken precautions in advance to thwart our efforts regarding the other boxes, but now he does not know our purpose. No, moreover, he does not know that we have the power to purify his refuges, so he cannot use them as he used to. What we know about the locations of the boxes has increased so much that when we examine the house in Piccadilly, we can even trace the last boxes. So, today belongs to us, and our hope lies in today. The sun rising over our sorrow will protect us during its course. Until the sun sets tonight, that monster must maintain its current form. It is confined within the boundaries of its earthly outer shell. It cannot dissolve into the air, pass through cracks or crevices, and disappear. If it is to pass through the door, it must open the door like any mortal. And for this reason, we have today to search all its refuges and purify them. If we have not yet caught and destroyed it, we will undoubtedly catch and destroy it somewhere in time.” Here, I jumped to my feet because I could not control myself when I thought of these very precious minutes and seconds filled with Mina's life and happiness slipping away while we talked about possible actions. But Van Helsing raised his hand to warn me. “No, my friend Jonathan,” he said, “In this matter, as your proverb says, the fastest way home is the longest way. When the time comes, we will all take action and act very quickly. But think, the key to the situation is most likely in the house in Piccadilly. The Count may have bought many houses. He has purchase documents, keys, and other things related to them. There will be papers he will write on; there will be a checkbook. He has many items he needs to keep somewhere; why shouldn't these be in such a central, such a quiet place where he can enter through the front or back door at any moment, even at the busiest time of traffic, without anyone noticing! We will go there, search that house, and when we find out what is inside, as Arthur's hunting saying goes, we will ‘block the den’ and weaken our old fox - right?” “Then let's start immediately,” I shouted, “we are wasting precious, precious time!”
es: –It is perhaps very convenient that when we visited Carfax we decided not to touch the boxes of earth that were there -he said-. If we had done so, the count could have guessed our intentions and, without a doubt, would have taken the pertinent measures in advance to thwart a similar effort regarding the other boxes, but now, he does not know our intentions. Moreover, in all likelihood, he does not know that we have the power to sterilize his refuges, so that he cannot use them again. We have advanced so much in our knowledge about the arrangement of those boxes that when we have visited the house in Piccadilly, we will be able to trace the last of the boxes. Therefore, today is ours, and in it rest our hopes. The sun that rises over us, amidst our sorrow, guides us in its course. Until the sun sets tonight, the monster must retain the form it now has. He is confined within the limitations of his earthly shell. He cannot turn into air, nor disappear through holes, openings, cracks, or crevices. To pass through a door, he has to open it, like all mortals. Therefore, we must find all his refuges today, to sterilize them. Then, if we have not yet caught and destroyed him, we will have to trap him in some place where his capture and annihilation will be certain, at the appropriate time. At that moment I stood up, because it was impossible for me to contain myself thinking that the seconds and minutes that were charged with the precious life of my beloved Mina and her happiness were passing, since while we were talking, it was impossible for us to take any action. But Van Helsing raised a hand, restraining me. –No, friend Jonathan -he told me-. In this case, the quickest way to get home is the longest, as you say. We will all have to act with desperate speed when the time comes to do so. But I believe that the key to this whole matter is, in all probability, in his house in Piccadilly. The count must have acquired several houses, and we must have the purchase receipts, the keys, and various other things for all of them. He will have paper to write on and his checkbook. There are many things he must have somewhere and, why not in that central, quiet place, where he can enter or leave, from the front or the back, at any time, in such a way that in the midst of the intense traffic, no one even notices him? We must go there and search that house and, when we know what it contains, we will do what our friend Arthur would say, referring to the hunt: "close the grounds," to chase our old fox. Does that sound good to you?

en: “Then let us come at once,” I cried, “we are wasting the precious, precious time!” The Professor did not move, but simply said:—
vi: — Then let's go right away! - I urged. - Don't waste any more time hesitating!
tr: “Then let's start immediately,” I shouted, “we are wasting precious, precious time!” The Professor did not move and only said:
es: –"Then, let's go immediately!" – I shouted-. "We are losing precious time!" The professor did not move, but simply said:

en: “And how are we to get into that house in Piccadilly?”
vi: — But how can we get into that Piccadilly house?
tr: “So, how are we going to get into the house on Piccadilly?”
es: –And how are we going to be able to enter that house on Piccadilly?

en: “Any way!” I cried. “We shall break in if need be.”
vi: - Van Helsing gently asked me. — It doesn't matter anyway! - I replied impatiently. - If necessary, just use force to get in, what's the problem!
tr: “Whatever it takes!” I shouted. “If necessary, we will force our way in.”
es: –In any case! – I exclaimed-. By breaking in, if necessary.

en: “And your police; where will they be, and what will they say?”
vi: — What about the police? Is it possible that there are no police in that neighborhood? And if there are, would they all stay silent?
tr: “So, what about your police officers; where will they be and what will they say?”
es: –And your police, where will they be and what will they say?

en: I was staggered; but I knew that if he wished to delay he had a good reason for it. So I said, as quietly as I could:—
vi: Clearly, he spoke quite reasonably, if he did not want us to set off immediately. However, I still tried to appear calm as I responded: — You always worry too much, maybe there aren't any police... Can you stop thinking about such nonsense?
tr: I was disappointed, but I knew that if he wanted to postpone it, he had a good reason for it. Therefore, I said as quietly as I could:
es: I was desperate, but I knew that if I waited, I had a good reason to do so. Consequently, I said, with all the calm I could muster:

en: “Don’t wait more than need be; you know, I am sure, what torture I am in.”
vi: I'm really suffering! — My friend, I really understand your feelings!
tr: “Don't wait longer than necessary; I'm sure you know what kind of torture I'm going through.”
es: –Do not wait longer than strictly necessary. I am sure you are perfectly aware of the torture I am being subjected to. –You can be sure of that, my friend!

en: “Ah, my child, that I do; and indeed there is no wish of me to add to your anguish. But just think, what can we do, until all the world be at movement. Then will come our time. I have thought and thought, and it seems to me that the simplest way is the best of all. Now we wish to get into the house, but we have no key; is it not so?” I nodded.
vi: And I don't want to make things harder for you. But just think about it: what can we do when the streets are full of curious eyes? Granted, it's time for us to act, but I've thought about it a lot, trust me, my friend, the simplest way is always the best way. We want to get into that house without having any keys! That's also a problem, isn't it? I nodded in response. — That's it.
tr: “Ah, my child, I know; truly, I have no desire to increase your pain. But think about what we can do until the whole world takes action. That's when our turn will come. I have thought it over and I am convinced that the easiest way is the best. Now, we want to enter the house, but we don't have the key, do we?” I nodded in agreement.
es: And believe me, I have no desire to add even more suffering to what you are already enduring. But we have to think before we act, until the moment when everyone is in motion. Then the right moment will come to take action. I have thought a lot, and it seems to me that the simplest way is the best of all. We want to enter the house, but we don't have a key. Isn't that so? I nodded.

en: “Now suppose that you were, in truth, the owner of that house, and could not still get in; and think there was to you no conscience of the housebreaker, what would you do?”
vi: Now, let's assume you are the owner of the house, but you don't have the key for some reason, what would you do?
tr: “Now, imagine that you actually own that house and you can't get inside, and imagine that you also don't have the consciousness of a thief, what would you do?”
es: –Suppose now that you were really the owner of the house, that you had lost the key and that you had no criminal intent, since you would be within your rights… What would you do?

en: “I should get a respectable locksmith, and set him to work to pick the lock for me.”
vi: — I will call a decent locksmith and tell him to open it with a hook.
tr: “I would find a reputable locksmith and have them pick the lock for me.”
es: –I would look for a respectable locksmith and put him to work to grant me entry.

en: “And your police, they would interfere, would they not?”
vi: — So the police won't come to intervene?
tr: “Well, what about your police officers, would they get involved or not?”
es: –But the police would intervene, wouldn't they?

en: “Oh, no! not if they knew the man was properly employed.”
vi: — No, if they realize that the locksmith did it at the homeowner's request. — So, - He said, looking straight into my eyes - the only thing that can be doubted is whether the person entering the house is truly the real owner or not.
tr: “Ah, no! If they knew the man was assigned according to the rules, they wouldn't interfere.”
es: –No! I wouldn't intervene, knowing that the locksmith was working for the owner of the house.

en: “Then,” he looked at me as keenly as he spoke, “all that is in doubt is the conscience of the employer, and the belief of your policemen as to whether or no that employer has a good conscience or a bad one. Your police must indeed be zealous men and clever—oh, so clever!—in reading the heart, that they trouble themselves in such matter. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London, or of any city in the world; and if you do it as such things are rightly done, and at the time such things are rightly done, no one will interfere. I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London, and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house, some burglar came and broke window at back and got in. Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through the door, before the very eyes of the police. Then he have an auction in that house, and advertise it, and put up big notice; and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them. Then he go to a builder, and he sell him that house, making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time. And your police and other authority help him all they can. And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been. This was all done en règle; and in our work we shall be en règle too. We shall not go so early that the policemen who have then little to think of, shall deem it strange; but we shall go after ten o’clock, when there are many about, and such things would be done were we indeed owners of the house.”
vi: Additionally, the success of the operation also depends on the gullibility of the local police officers. But my dear friend Jonathan, sometimes you can still use a hook to unlock hundreds of houses in London or anywhere else in the world without any trouble, as long as you create the right circumstances and do it at the right time. I can tell everyone a story that I once read. The story goes like this: There was a gentleman who owned a beautiful mansion in London. That summer, due to having to go to Switzerland for quite a long time, about five to seven months, he carelessly locked the house before leaving and didn't ask anyone to look after it. As a result, shortly after he left, a thief broke the glass of a window facing the garden and broke in. Once inside, he opened all the windows at the front of the house and boldly walked out the front door right in front of the police. After that, he openly advertised the sale of all the furniture in the house with a huge advertisement board posted on the wall outside the gate. He hired an auction representative to sell all the belongings of the gentleman who was in Switzerland. Then, he even sold the house itself to a building contractor because he found the ownership papers stored in the house. The contractor discussed with him to demolish the house on a specific day to build a new building. The police and city authorities thought he was the real owner of the mansion, so they facilitated this construction contract handover. Unfortunately for the real owner of the house, when he returned from Switzerland, all he saw was a giant hole in place of his familiar house. But what could be done, everything happened legally, following the city's buying and building regulations. Perhaps our work should also follow similar principles. We shouldn't arrive at Piccadilly too early to avoid the scrutiny of the police; only then will they not accidentally notice that our presence is unusual. At the earliest, we should only start from ten o'clock onwards, because by then, passersby will think we are the real owners of the house.
tr: "Then," he said, looking at me with sharp eyes while speaking, "the only uncertain thing is the employer's conscience and your police officers' belief regarding whether that employer has a clean conscience or not. Your police officers, given that they trouble themselves with such a matter, must be willing and smart - oh, how smart - in reading the human heart. No, no, my friend Jonathan, even if you unlock a hundred empty houses in your London or any other city in the world and do the job as it should be done, no one will interfere with your work. I had read the story of a gentleman who had a very nice house in your London and went to Switzerland for a few months in the summer, closing up his house, only for a thief to break in through the back window. Then, the thief went and opened the shutters in the front and entered and exited through the door right in front of the police. After that, he held an auction in the house, announced it, placed a big advertisement, and on the day it came, sold everything the other man owned through a major auctioneer. Then he went to a contractor and sold the house to him, agreeing to demolish it and clear it all away within a certain period. And your police and other authorities provided him with all the help they could. And when that homeowner returned from his Swiss vacation, he found nothing but a big empty space where his house used to be. All of this was done en règle, and we will act en règle while doing our job. We won't go so early that the police, who don't have much to think about at those hours, will find the situation strange; we'll go after ten, at a time when there will be many people around and such things would be done by the real owners of the house."
es: –Then -he looked at me intently, while continuing -, all that will be in doubt is the conscience and opinion of the police as to whether it is the owner who called the locksmith and the opinion of the police as to whether the craftsman is working in accordance with the laws or not. Your police must be composed of careful and intelligent men, extraordinarily intelligent to read the human heart, if they are to be sure of what they should do. No, no, my friend Jonathan, you can go and open the locks of a hundred empty houses in your London or any city in the world, and if you do it in such a way that it seems correct, no one will intervene at all. I have read something about a gentleman who had a beautiful house in London and when he went to spend the summer months in Switzerland, leaving his house closed, a criminal broke one of the back windows and entered. Then he went to the front, opened the windows, raised the shutters, and walked out the front door, right in front of the police. Next, he held a public auction in the house, advertised it in all the newspapers, and when the appointed day came, he sold all the possessions of the gentleman who was away. Then, he went to see a builder and sold him the house, establishing the agreement that it should be demolished and all the debris removed before a certain date. Both the police and the rest of the English authorities helped him as much as they could. When the real owner returned from Switzerland, he found only an empty lot where his house had been. That crime was carried out in régle, and our work must also be carried out in régle. We must not go so early that the police suspect our actions; on the contrary, we must go after ten in the morning, when there are many officers around us, and we will behave as if we were really the owners of the house.

en: I could not but see how right he was and the terrible despair of Mina’s face became relaxed a thought; there was hope in such good counsel. Van Helsing went on:—
vi: I noticed Mina's face seemed to brighten up, as it was clear that Van Helsing made a lot of sense.
tr: I could do nothing but see how right he was, and the terrible despair on Mina's face eased; in such a good view, there was hope. Van Helsing continued his words:
es: I couldn't help but understand that he was absolutely right, and even the terrible despair reflected on Mina's face softened a bit, due to the hopes that could be harbored in such a good advisor. Van Helsing continued:

en: “When once within that house we may find more clues; at any rate some of us can remain there whilst the rest find the other places where there be more earth-boxes—at Bermondsey and Mile End.”
vi: Not only her, but all of us also acknowledged and hoped in his wise explanation. — Once we are inside the house, - he continued to analyze - we might easily find more traces. In any case, we should leave one or two people there, and the rest must immediately go to Bermondsey and Mile End to find the missing wooden crates. — If so, I can be useful to everyone.
tr: “Once we get into the house, we might find more clues; while some of us stay there, others will find the other places where more earth boxes might be - the places in Bermondsey and Mile End.””
es: –Once inside the house, we can find more clues and, in any case, one of us can stay there while the others go to visit the other places where the other boxes of earth are located... in Bermondsey and in Mile End.

en: Lord Godalming stood up. “I can be of some use here,” he said. “I shall wire to my people to have horses and carriages where they will be most convenient.”
vi: - Lord Godalming enthusiastically stood up and said. - I will send a telegram to have some carriages prepared for everyone.
tr: Lord Godalming stood up. "I can be useful here," he said. "I will send a telegram to my men to have the horses and carriages ready at the nearest locations.""
es: Lord Godalming stood up. –I can be of some use to you in this case -he said-. I can get in touch with my people to obtain horses and carts as soon as necessary.

en: “Look here, old fellow,” said Morris, “it is a capital idea to have all ready in case we want to go horsebacking; but don’t you think that one of your snappy carriages with its heraldic adornments in a byway of Walworth or Mile End would attract too much attention for our purposes? It seems to me that we ought to take cabs when we go south or east; and even leave them somewhere near the neighbourhood we are going to.”
vi: — An impeccable idea! - Quincey exclaimed - But aren't you worried that such cumbersome travel through the roads of Walworth or Mile End might attract public attention? I think we should hail a cab along the way, as it would be more convenient to get on and off at any time and place.
tr: “Look here, old friend,” said Morris, “even though we decided to go on horseback, it's important to keep everything ready, but don't you think that one of their fancy carriages adorned with the family crest being seen on one of the side roads of Walworth or Mile End would be too conspicuous for our purposes? It seems to me that we should take hired carriages when heading south or east and even leave them near the neighborhood we're going to.”
es: –Listen, my friend -Morris intervened-, it's a good idea to have everything ready in case we need to retreat hastily on horseback, but don't you think that any of your vehicles, with their heraldic decorations, would attract too much attention for our purposes on any side road in Walworth or Mile End? It seems to me that it would be better to take rental cars when we go south or west; and even leave them somewhere near the point we are heading to.

en: “Friend Quincey is right!” said the Professor. “His head is what you call in plane with the horizon. It is a difficult thing that we go to do, and we do not want no peoples to watch us if so it may.”
vi: — This fellow Quincey is quite clever! - Van Helsing joked. - Indeed, in our dangerous line of work, the less attention we attract, the better.
tr: "My friend Quincey is right!" said the Professor. "As you say, head at horizon level. The task we are about to undertake is difficult, and if possible, we do not want people watching us."
es: –Our friend Quincey is right! – said the professor -. His head is, as they say, level with the horizon. We are about to undertake delicate work, and it is not convenient for people to observe us, if it can be avoided.

en: Mina took a growing interest in everything and I was rejoiced to see that the exigency of affairs was helping her to forget for a time the terrible experience of the night. She was very, very pale—almost ghastly, and so thin that her lips were drawn away, showing her teeth in somewhat of prominence. I did not mention this last, lest it should give her needless pain; but it made my blood run cold in my veins to think of what had occurred with poor Lucy when the Count had sucked her blood. As yet there was no sign of the teeth growing sharper; but the time as yet was short, and there was time for fear.
vi: It seems that Mina is becoming increasingly excited, and I am also very happy to realize that she has temporarily forgotten her terrible night. However, she still looks very pale and gaunt, and her lips are so dry that they reveal both rows of her teeth. Although I didn't say it out loud, to be honest, I got chills down my spine when I associated Mina with Lucy after the times she was drained of blood by Dracula, except that I haven't noticed Mina's teeth being sharper than usual. But regardless of what is said, since I witnessed the horrifying scene last night, only a few hours have passed, and who knows if the worst for her and us might not happen similarly to Lucy's case...
tr: I was glad to see that Mina's interest in the events was increasing and that the rapid progression of the events was helping her forget the terrible experience she had at night for a while. She was very, very pale - almost like a corpse, and she was so thin that her lips had drawn back slightly, making her teeth look a bit protruding. I did not mention this last part to avoid causing her unnecessary pain, but thinking about what happened to poor Lucy when the Count sucked her blood was chilling my blood. So far, there was no indication that her teeth were starting to sharpen, but it had been a short time and we still had time to be afraid.
es: Mina was becoming increasingly interested in all the details, and I was glad that the demands of these matters were helping her forget the terrible experience she had had that night. She was extremely pale... almost spectral and so thin that her lips were drawn back, making her teeth stand out in a certain way. I didn't mention anything, to avoid causing her deep pain, but I felt my blood freeze in my veins at the thought of what had happened to poor Lucy when the Count had sucked the blood from her veins. There were still no signs that her teeth were beginning to sharpen, but not much time had passed yet and there was reason to fear.

en: When we came to the discussion of the sequence of our efforts and of the disposition of our forces, there were new sources of doubt. It was finally agreed that before starting for Piccadilly we should destroy the Count’s lair close at hand. In case he should find it out too soon, we should thus be still ahead of him in our work of destruction; and his presence in his purely material shape, and at his weakest, might give us some new clue.
vi: But regardless of what is said, since I witnessed the horrifying scene last night, only a few hours have passed, and who knows if the worst for her and us might not happen similarly to Lucy's case... Before arriving at Piccadilly, we decided that we must destroy Dracula's nearest hideout. Because even if he discovered us immediately, we would still have the advantage to continue our work. His manifestation as a normal person for many hours under the sunlight prevented him from using his magic on us, which might bring us new signs.
tr: When it came to discussing the order of our tasks and the distribution of our forces, new reasons for doubt emerged. In the end, we decided that we needed to destroy the Count's nearby refuge before setting out for Piccadilly. If he understands this too early, we will still be ahead of him in our task of destruction, and his existence, in its purely material form and weakest state, may offer us some new clues.
es: When we arrived at the discussion about the sequence of our efforts and the arrangement of our forces, new doubts arose. Finally, we agreed that before going to Piccadilly, we had to destroy the refuge that the count had nearby. In the event that he realized too soon what we were doing, we should already be ahead in our work of destruction, and his presence, in his natural form and at the moment of greatest weakness, could still provide us with more useful indications.

en: As to the disposal of forces, it was suggested by the Professor that, after our visit to Carfax, we should all enter the house in Piccadilly; that the two doctors and I should remain there, whilst Lord Godalming and Quincey found the lairs at Walworth and Mile End and destroyed them. It was possible, if not likely, the Professor urged, that the Count might appear in Piccadilly during the day, and that if so we might be able to cope with him then and there. At any rate, we might be able to follow him in force. To this plan I strenuously objected, and so far as my going was concerned, for I said that I intended to stay and protect Mina, I thought that my mind was made up on the subject; but Mina would not listen to my objection. She said that there might be some law matter in which I could be useful; that amongst the Count’s papers might be some clue which I could understand out of my experience in Transylvania; and that, as it was, all the strength we could muster was required to cope with the Count’s extraordinary power. I had to give in, for Mina’s resolution was fixed; she said that it was the last hope for her that we should all work together. “As for me,” she said, “I have no fear. Things have been as bad as they can be; and whatever may happen must have in it some element of hope or comfort. Go, my husband! God can, if He wishes it, guard me as well alone as with any one present.” So I started up crying out: “Then in God’s name let us come at once, for we are losing time. The Count may come to Piccadilly earlier than we think.”
vi: Van Helsing wants that after the action at Carfax is done, our entire group will go straight to Piccadilly. The two doctors among us will stay there, while Quincey and Lord Godalming will head to Walworth and Mile End to destroy Dracula's remaining hideouts. Van Helsing believes that there is a possibility that during the day, he might be at Piccadilly, and if that is the case, we will catch him. But no matter what, we must join forces to pursue him relentlessly. As for me, I do not entirely agree with his plan: I want to stay home to care for and protect Mina, but Mina is adamant about not listening. She says that the group might very well need me to resolve legal matters. She argues that among the Count's documents, there will surely be things that only I—who am familiar with Dracula—can understand, and in any case, to confront his extraordinary strength, we need as many people as possible. Her reasoning seems logical, so I cannot be stubborn. — Only if everyone goes together will I have something to hope for. - She told me. - As for myself, I have nothing to fear. The most horrifying thing is over, and all that can come to me now is a bit of hope and comfort. You must go with everyone, my love! If God is merciful, then even if I am left alone, He will protect me as safely as everyone is protecting me now! — Then in the name of God, - I said - let us set off immediately! The old count might arrive in Piccadilly sooner than we think!
tr: As for the arrangement of forces, the Professor suggested that after our visit to Carfax, we should enter the house in Piccadilly; while Lord Godalming and Quincey found and destroyed the refuges in Walworth and Mile End, the two doctors and I should stay in Piccadilly. Although not very convincing, the Professor insisted that there was a possibility that the Count might be in Piccadilly during the day, and if so, we could deal with him right there. In any case, we could track him with all our might. Since my departure was also in question, I opposed this plan with all my strength, saying, "Because I intend to stay here and protect Mina." I thought I was determined on this matter, but Mina did not listen to my objection. She said that there might be a legal situation where I could be useful, that due to my experiences in Transylvania, there might be a clue among the Count's documents that only I could understand, and in that case, we needed all the strength we could gather to deal with the Count's extraordinary power. Since Mina's decision was final, I had to give in; she said that working together was her last hope. "As for me," she said, "I am not afraid of anything. Everything is already as bad as it can be, and there must be an element of hope or consolation in everything that could happen. Go, my dear husband! God, if He wills, can protect me when I am alone just as He can when someone is with me." So I jumped up, shouting, "Then for God's sake, let's leave immediately because we are wasting time. The Count might arrive in Piccadilly earlier than we thought."
es: Regarding the disposition of our forces, the professor suggested that, after our visit to Carfax, we should all enter the house in Piccadilly; that the two doctors and I should remain there, while Quincey and Lord Godalming went to find and destroy the refuges in Walworth and Mile End. It was possible, though not probable, that the Count would appear in Piccadilly during the day and, in that case, we would be in a position to finish him off right there. In any case, we would be in a position to follow him together. I objected to this plan, regarding my movements, since I intended to stay and take care of Mina; I thought I was firmly decided on this; but she would not even listen to that objection. She said that it was possible that some legal matter might arise in which I could be useful; that among the Count's papers there might be some clue that I could interpret due to my stay in Transylvania and that, in any case, we should employ all the forces at our disposal to confront the tremendous power of the monster. I had to give in, as Mina had made up her mind about it; she said that her last hope was that we could all work together. –As for me -he said-, I am not afraid. Things have already been so extremely bad that they cannot get worse, and whatever happens must contain some element of hope or consolation. Go, my husband! God, if He wills it, can help and defend me just as well if I am alone as if I am accompanied by all of you. Therefore, I began to shout again: –Then, in the name of heaven, let's go immediately! We are wasting time! The count may reach Piccadilly sooner than we think.

en: “Not so!” said Van Helsing, holding up his hand.
vi: — No, no! - Van Helsing waved his hand as if to calm my impatience.
tr: "No, it's not like that!" said Van Helsing, raising his hand.
es: –Absolutely not! – said van Helsing, raising a hand.

en: “But why?” I asked.
vi: — How did you know?
tr: “But why?” I asked.
es: “Why not?” I inquired.

en: “Do you forget,” he said, with actually a smile, “that last night he banqueted heavily, and will sleep late?”
vi: — Did you forget that last night he had a hearty feast and would wake up very late this morning? - The professor said with a sly smile.
tr: “Last night,” he said with a genuine smile, “did you forget that you had a heavy feast and would sleep until late hours?”
es: "Do you forget that last night there was a great banquet and that, consequently, he will sleep until a very late hour?" he said with a smile.

en: Did I forget! shall I ever—can I ever! Can any of us ever forget that terrible scene! Mina struggled hard to keep her brave countenance; but the pain overmastered her and she put her hands before her face, and shuddered whilst she moaned. Van Helsing had not intended to recall her frightful experience. He had simply lost sight of her and her part in the affair in his intellectual effort. When it struck him what he said, he was horrified at his thoughtlessness and tried to comfort her. “Oh, Madam Mina,” he said, “dear, dear Madam Mina, alas! that I of all who so reverence you should have said anything so forgetful. These stupid old lips of mine and this stupid old head do not deserve so; but you will forget it, will you not?” He bent low beside her as he spoke; she took his hand, and looking at him through her tears, said hoarsely:—
vi: Forget! Me, forget? Could I ever forget? Is it possible that any of us could forget something so horrifying? Mina tried to remain calm, but it seemed as though the pain in her heart had just been awakened; her restraint truly had its limits, as I saw her cover her face and sob, her whole body trembling violently from head to toe. Van Helsing's inadvertent joke was clearly a stab into her wound. At this moment, he was startled by his thoughtless words. — Oh! Mina, I'm sorry! - He rushed to the girl to comfort her - I didn't mean to hurt you. Actually, I'm in a lot of pain too! But you will forget that nightmare, won't you? — No, I will not forget, - She sobbed in response to the old professor - on the contrary, I need to remember, and the beautiful memories of you will never fade in the hearts of my husband and me.
tr: Forget? Never! How could I ever forget - will I ever be able to forget? Can any of us ever forget that horrifying scene? Mina was making a great effort to maintain her brave appearance, but the pain overcame her, she brought her hands to her face and trembled while moaning. Van Helsing did not want to remind her of the terrible experience she had gone through. However, in his mental struggle, he had completely forgotten Mina and her role in this incident. When he realized what he had said, he was horrified by his thoughtlessness and tried to comfort Mina. "Oh, Madam Mina!" he said, "Dear, dear Madam Mina, it is such a pity that someone like me, who holds you in such high regard, would say something so thoughtless! These foolish old lips and this foolish old head of mine do not deserve it, but you will forget this, won't you? " As he said this, he leaned in close to Mina; Mina, looking at him through her tears, took his hand and said in a choked voice:
es: I did not forget it! Will I ever forget it... will I be able to forget it? Will any of us ever be able to forget that terrible scene? Mina made a powerful effort not to lose control, but the pain overcame her and she covered her face with both hands, trembling and moaning. Van Helsing had not intended to recall that terrible experience. He had simply forgotten about it and the part he had played, due to his mental effort. When he realized what he had just said, he was horrified by his lack of tact and tried to console my wife. –Oh, Mrs. Mina! – he said. You don't know how sorry I am that I, who respect you so much, could have said something so unpleasant! My stupid old lips and my useless head do not deserve your forgiveness; but you will forget it, won't you? The professor leaned deeply beside her as he spoke. Mina took his hand and, looking at him through a veil of tears, said to him in a hoarse voice:

en: “No, I shall not forget, for it is well that I remember; and with it I have so much in memory of you that is sweet, that I take it all together. Now, you must all be going soon. Breakfast is ready, and we must all eat that we may be strong.”
vi: — No, I will not forget, - She sobbed in response to the old professor - on the contrary, I need to remember, and the beautiful memories of you will never fade in the hearts of my husband and me. Now, perhaps everyone is about to leave. Breakfast has been prepared, let's go down together, everyone needs to have strength now.
tr: “No, I will not forget because it is good for me to remember; however, I have so many sweet memories of you all that I keep them all together. Now, soon you all have to go. Breakfast is ready and it is essential for all of us to eat so that we can be strong.”
es: –No, I must not forget it, since it is only right that I remember; besides, amidst all of it, there are many things about you that are very sweet, I must remember everything. Now, all of you must leave soon. Breakfast is ready and we all need to eat something to stay strong.

en: Breakfast was a strange meal to us all. We tried to be cheerful and encourage each other, and Mina was the brightest and most cheerful of us. When it was over, Van Helsing stood up and said:—
vi: This morning's breakfast was quite unusual for us. We all wanted to encourage each other to cheer up a bit, even Mina tried to appear really cheerful. Finally, Van Helsing stood up and made an announcement.
tr: Breakfast was a strange meal for all of us. We tried to be cheerful and encourage each other, and Mina was the liveliest and most cheerful among us. Van Helsing stood up and said:
es: Breakfast was a strange meal for all of us. We tried to appear cheerful and encourage each other, and Mina was the most cheerful and courageous of all. When we finished, Van Helsing stood up and said:

en: “Now, my dear friends, we go forth to our terrible enterprise. Are we all armed, as we were on that night when first we visited our enemy’s lair; armed against ghostly as well as carnal attack?” We all assured him. “Then it is well. Now, Madam Mina, you are in any case quite safe here until the sunset; and before then we shall return—if—— We shall return! But before we go let me see you armed against personal attack. I have myself, since you came down, prepared your chamber by the placing of things of which we know, so that He may not enter. Now let me guard yourself. On your forehead I touch this piece of Sacred Wafer in the name of the Father, the Son, and——”
vi: — Dear all, the decisive moment is approaching! Have you prepared enough weapons like last time? I would like to remind you that these are the talismans against both physical and mental attacks, do you understand what I mean? We nodded in response. — Very great! Mina, no matter what, you don't have to worry about dealing with any danger until sunset. From now until then, we will return. If... Yes, we will return! No matter what, you don't have to worry too much, even if the enemy wants to come and harm you again, you have nothing to fear. When you came down from your room, I had already placed some necessary items there - which you surely know about - to prevent him from entering. And now, I will place a piece of the holy bread on your forehead, in the name of the Father, the Son, and...
tr: “Now, my dear friends, we set out on our dreadful enterprise. Are we all armed as we were on that first night when we visited our enemy's lair; armed against both spiritual and bodily attack?” We all assured him on this point. “Good then. Now, Madam Mina, you are quite safe here in any case until sunrise, and by then we shall have returned - if we return! But before we go, let me see you are armed against personal attack. Since your descent, I have prepared your room by placing the things we know so that He may not enter. Let me take precautions for you as well. In the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit, this blessed bread upon your forehead...”
es: –Now, my friends, let us set out to undertake our terrible task. Are we all armed, as we were the day we first went together to visit the Carfax refuge, armed against both spiritual and physical attacks? We all nodded. –Very well. Now, Mrs. Mina, you are completely safe here until sunset and I will return before that time... yes... We will all return! But, before we leave, I want you to be armed against personal attacks. I myself, while you were away, have prepared your room, placing things that we know prevent the monster from entering. Now, let me protect you personally. On your forehead, I place this fragment of the Sacred Host, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the...

en: There was a fearful scream which almost froze our hearts to hear. As he had placed the Wafer on Mina’s forehead, it had seared it—had burned into the flesh as though it had been a piece of white-hot metal. My poor darling’s brain had told her the significance of the fact as quickly as her nerves received the pain of it; and the two so overwhelmed her that her overwrought nature had its voice in that dreadful scream. But the words to her thought came quickly; the echo of the scream had not ceased to ring on the air when there came the reaction, and she sank on her knees on the floor in an agony of abasement. Pulling her beautiful hair over her face, as the leper of old his mantle, she wailed out:—
vi: All of us suddenly exclaimed in astonishment. The piece of holy bread suddenly burned a spot on Mina's forehead like a piece of metal heated to a bright white. The poor girl immediately understood what that phenomenon meant. Her cry expressed not only physical pain but also an overwhelming sense of disappointment welling up inside her. That mournful cry will echo in our minds forever. She collapsed with an indescribable look of agony and despair on her face:
tr: Mina let out a terrifying scream that almost froze our hearts. As soon as the Professor touched the blessed bread to Mina's forehead, it seemed to sear and burn her flesh as if it were a piece of red-hot metal. The brain of my poor beloved grasped the significance of this truth as quickly as her nerves conveyed the pain, and these two things affected her so much that her distressed nature found voice in that horrifying scream. But words quickly came to her; when the reaction came, the echo of the scream was still ringing in the air, and she fell to her knees with the pain of her wounded pride. Like lepers used to hide themselves with their coverings, she pulled her beautiful hair over her face and cried out bitterly:
es: A scream of terror occurred that almost froze the blood in our veins. When the professor placed the Host on Mina's forehead, it had pierced her... it had burned my wife's forehead, as if it were red-hot metal. My poor Mina immediately understood the meaning of that act, at the same time that her nervous system received the physical pain, and the two feelings overwhelmed her so much that they were expressed in that terrible scream. But the words that accompanied her thought came quickly. The echo of her scream had not yet completely ceased when the reaction occurred, and she collapsed to her knees on the ground, humbling herself. She threw her beautiful hair over her face, as if to cover the wound, and exclaimed:

en: “Unclean! Unclean! Even the Almighty shuns my polluted flesh! I must bear this mark of shame upon my forehead until the Judgment Day.” They all paused. I had thrown myself beside her in an agony of helpless grief, and putting my arms around held her tight. For a few minutes our sorrowful hearts beat together, whilst the friends around us turned away their eyes that ran tears silently. Then Van Helsing turned and said gravely; so gravely that I could not help feeling that he was in some way inspired, and was stating things outside himself:—
vi: — Oh, the shame! I am a disgrace! So, God has punished me! From now until I die, I will have to bear this stain on my forehead forever! Everyone stood stunned, watching her. I rushed over in shock to hold my poor young wife tightly, filled with fear and overwhelming disappointment. Despair left the two of us clinging to each other, not knowing what else to do. Understanding the heartbreak of my wife and me, our friends could only turn away and cry silently. Finally, as if to prove himself truly a father figure and the emotional support of the group, Van Helsing calmly approached us to comfort Mina, his voice as soft as a breath:
tr: “Sinner! Sinner! Even the Almighty God keeps away from my filthy skin!” “I must bear this stain of shame on my forehead until the Day of Judgment.” Everyone fell silent. With the pain of a desperate sorrow, I threw myself beside him and wrapped my arms around him tightly. While our friends around us turned their tear-filled eyes away in silence, our hearts beat together in pain for a few minutes. Then Van Helsing turned and began to speak seriously; he was so serious that I couldn't help but feel he was inspired and speaking things beyond himself:
es: –Dirty! Dirty! Even the Almighty punishes my corrupted flesh! I will have to bear this mark of shame on my forehead until Judgment Day! Everyone fell silent. I myself had thrown myself beside her, in the midst of true agony, feeling powerless, and, surrounding her with my arms, I held her tightly embraced to me. For a few minutes, our anguished hearts beat in unison, while the friends who were near us turned their tear-filled eyes away. Then, van Helsing turned and said gravely, in such a serious tone that I couldn't help but think he was being inspired in some way, and was declaring something that did not come from himself:

en: “It may be that you may have to bear that mark till God himself see fit, as He most surely shall, on the Judgment Day, to redress all wrongs of the earth and of His children that He has placed thereon. And oh, Madam Mina, my dear, my dear, may we who love you be there to see, when that red scar, the sign of God’s knowledge of what has been, shall pass away, and leave your forehead as pure as the heart we know. For so surely as we live, that scar shall pass away when God sees right to lift the burden that is hard upon us. Till then we bear our Cross, as His Son did in obedience to His Will. It may be that we are chosen instruments of His good pleasure, and that we ascend to His bidding as that other through stripes and shame; through tears and blood; through doubts and fears, and all that makes the difference between God and man.”
vi: — Mina, the mark imprinted on your forehead signifies that the Lord has understood your pains. Perhaps you will have to bear that mark until the Lord deems it time to absolve all His devout followers on this earth on the Day of Final Judgment. Madam, on that day, we will surely be present to witness the stain on your forehead disappear, restoring the purity that has always resided in your heart! Surely it will be erased when the Lord, in His mercy, lifts the burden that weighs upon us. From now until then, we should always carry the cross with us, just as the Son of God bore it according to the will of the Lord... All hardships will eventually pass...
tr: “Without a doubt, God will repair all the mistakes made by the world and the children He placed there on Judgment Day, so it is possible that you may have to bear this stain until the time He deems appropriate. And oh, Madam Mina, dear, dear, we who love you hope to be there to see that the red scar, which is a sign that God knows what has happened, has passed and left your forehead as clean as the heart we know. Because we know as well as our own lives that when God finds it right to lift the great burden from us, that scar will also pass. Until then, we will carry our Cross just as His Son obeyed His will. Perhaps we are the instruments chosen for His sweet joy, and just as the other rose with blows and shame, with tears and blood, with doubts and fears, and with everything that separates man from God, we too will rise by His command.”
es: –It is possible that you may have to bear that mark until God Himself wills it or for you to see it during the Final Judgment, when He rectifies all the wrongs of the earth and of His children whom He has placed upon it. And my dear Mrs. Mina, I wish that all of us who love you could be present when that reddish scar disappears, leaving your forehead as clean and pure as the heart that we all know! For I am as sure as I am alive that this scar will vanish as soon as God decides that the burden that overwhelms us should be lifted. Until then, we will bear our cross as His Son did, obeying His will. It is possible that we are chosen instruments of His good will and that we obey His command amidst stigmas and shames; amidst tears and blood; amidst doubts and fears, and through all that makes God and men different.

en: There was hope in his words, and comfort; and they made for resignation. Mina and I both felt so, and simultaneously we each took one of the old man’s hands and bent over and kissed it. Then without a word we all knelt down together, and, all holding hands, swore to be true to each other. We men pledged ourselves to raise the veil of sorrow from the head of her whom, each in his own way, we loved; and we prayed for help and guidance in the terrible task which lay before us.
vi: The sincere encouragement from the professor helped us understand that we need to endure when we must endure, and it seemed that behind that endurance, there was still a little something for us to hope for. Mina and I both felt it, we were truly moved, each of us bowed down, took one of his hands, and placed a kiss on it as a gesture of gratitude towards the heart of an old father. And before the sacred Lord, our whole group, without anyone telling anyone, knelt down together and swore to live and die together, united in strength and spirit, praying together for the Lord to help us overcome the calamity to complete our mission.
tr: There was hope and solace in his words, and it led to resignation. Mina and I felt this way, and at the same time, we both held one of the old man's hands, leaned over, and kissed it. Then, without saying a word, we all knelt together, holding hands, and vowed to remain faithful to each other. We men swore to lift the veil of sorrow covering the face of Mina, whom we all loved in our own way, and prayed to God to help and guide us in the dreadful task ahead.
es: There was hope in his words and also comfort. Moreover, they invited us to resign ourselves. Mina and I understood it that way and, simultaneously, each of us took one of the old man's hands and kissed it humbly. Then, without uttering a single word, we all knelt together and, holding hands, swore to be sincere with one another and asked for help and guidance in the terrible task that awaited us. All the men strove to lift from Mina the veil of deep sadness that enveloped her, because we all, each in our own way, loved her.

en: It was then time to start. So I said farewell to Mina, a parting which neither of us shall forget to our dying day; and we set out.
vi: It's time for us to go. I turned to say goodbye to my dear beloved wife.
tr: Then, the time came to get to work. Therefore, I bid farewell to Mina; it was a departure we would not forget until the day of our death, and we set off.
es: It was time to leave. So, I bid farewell to Mina in such a way that neither of us will be able to forget it until the day we die, and we left.

en: To one thing I have made up my mind: if we find out that Mina must be a vampire in the end, then she shall not go into that unknown and terrible land alone. I suppose it is thus that in old times one vampire meant many; just as their hideous bodies could only rest in sacred earth, so the holiest love was the recruiting sergeant for their ghastly ranks.
vi: Surely, this will be a momentous occasion that we will never forget for the rest of our lives!
tr: I was determined about one thing: If we were to find out that Mina had to become a vampire in the end, she would not go to that unknown and terrifying place alone. I think this is why, in the past, a single vampire meant many vampires; just as their disgusting bodies could only rest on consecrated ground, the most sacred love also recruits soldiers into their vile ranks.
es: There was something I was already prepared for: if we finally discovered that Mina had become a vampire, then she should not go alone to that terrible and unknown land. I suppose that was how, in ancient times, a vampire turned into many; only because their horrible bodies had to rest in holy ground, likewise the most sacred love was the best sergeant for recruiting their spectral army.

en: We entered Carfax without trouble and found all things the same as on the first occasion. It was hard to believe that amongst so prosaic surroundings of neglect and dust and decay there was any ground for such fear as already we knew. Had not our minds been made up, and had there not been terrible memories to spur us on, we could hardly have proceeded with our task. We found no papers, or any sign of use in the house; and in the old chapel the great boxes looked just as we had seen them last. Dr. Van Helsing said to us solemnly as we stood before them:—
vi: We did not encounter any obstacles when entering the Carfax house. Everything in the house remained the same as the last time. There was no paperwork or anything that could indicate someone had entered. Likewise, in the church, there was no sign that the wooden crates had been moved, even by an inch. — My friends, - Van Helsing told us - here, we have our first task to complete.
tr: We entered Carfax without any trouble and found everything in its place on the first try. In such an ordinary environment of neglect, dust, and decay, it was hard to believe that such a familiar horror could have a foothold. If we were not determined and if it were not for the terrifying memories that spurred us on, we might have struggled to make progress in our task. We found no documents or any indication of the house's use, and the boxes in the old chapel stood as they did the last time we saw them. As we stood in front of the boxes, Dr. Van Helsing said solemnly:
es: We entered Carfax without difficulty and found everything exactly the same as the first time we were in the mansion. It was hard to believe that amidst that prosaic atmosphere of neglect, dust, and decay, there could be a basis for a horror like the one we already knew. If our minds were not already prepared and if we were not spurred by terrible memories, I don't think we could have carried out our task. We found no papers or any signs of use in the house, and in the old chapel, the large boxes seemed to be exactly the same as we had seen them the last time. Dr. Van Helsing told us solemnly, as we stood before them:

en: “And now, my friends, we have a duty here to do. We must sterilise this earth, so sacred of holy memories, that he has brought from a far distant land for such fell use. He has chosen this earth because it has been holy. Thus we defeat him with his own weapon, for we make it more holy still. It was sanctified to such use of man, now we sanctify it to God.” As he spoke he took from his bag a screwdriver and a wrench, and very soon the top of one of the cases was thrown open. The earth smelled musty and close; but we did not somehow seem to mind, for our attention was concentrated on the Professor. Taking from his box a piece of the Sacred Wafer he laid it reverently on the earth, and then shutting down the lid began to screw it home, we aiding him as he worked.
vi: We will have to neutralize the soil contained in the wooden boxes. This is the soil that has been sanctified by devout memories and was transported here by the demon Dracula as a place of refuge. The reason he chose this soil is because it has been sanctified. Whether he fails or not partly depends on the effectiveness of these boxes of soil. Now, we will return this soil to God! He took a screwdriver and a universal key out of his bag to open the soil crates. A lid of a crate was pried open. The soil in the crate immediately emitted a musty, pungent odor that assaulted our noses. However, what caught our attention the most was what the professor was doing: he gently placed a piece of sacramental bread on the soil in the crate and closed the lid again with our help.
tr: “And now, my friends, we have a duty here. We must cleanse this soil, which he brought from afar for such a dreadful purpose, of its sacred memories. He chose this soil because it is blessed. Thus, we will defeat him with his own weapon, for we will make this soil even more sacred. It was blessed for man to use in this way, now we are blessing it for God.” As he spoke, he took a screwdriver and a wrench out of his bag, and shortly after, the lid of one of the chests was opened. The soil smelled musty; but somehow we didn't seem to mind, because all our attention was on the Professor. He took a piece of blessed bread from its box and respectfully placed it on the soil, then began to screw the lid back on; as he worked, we were helping him.
es: –Now, my friends, we have a duty to fulfill here. We must sterilize this land, so full of sacred relics, which have been brought from distant lands to be used. He has chosen this land because it has been blessed. Therefore, we are going to defeat him with his own weapons, sanctifying it even more. It was sanctified for the use of man, and now we are going to sanctify it for God. While he was speaking, he took a screwdriver and a key out of his pocket, and very soon, the lid of one of the boxes was lifted. The soil had an unpleasant smell, due to the time it had been enclosed, but that did not seem to matter to any of us, as all our attention was focused on the professor. Taking a piece of the Sacred Host out of his pocket, he placed it reverently on the soil and then, putting the lid back in its place, began to screw it back on. We help him with his work.

en: One by one we treated in the same way each of the great boxes, and left them as we had found them to all appearance; but in each was a portion of the Host.
vi: We also did the same with all the other boxes in the church and carefully screwed them back as they were originally to avoid drawing any attention. The work went smoothly.
tr: We performed the same operation on each of the large chests one by one and left them, from the outside, as we found them; but inside each of them was a piece of blessed bread.
es: One after another, we did the same with all the large boxes and, apparently, left them exactly as we had found them, but inside each one of them was a piece of Host.

en: When we closed the door behind us, the Professor said solemnly:—
vi: As he locked the door to leave, Van Helsing exclaimed:
tr: When we closed the door behind us, the Professor said solemnly:
es: When we closed the door behind us, the professor said solemnly:

en: “So much is already done. If it may be that with all the others we can be so successful, then the sunset of this evening may shine on Madam Mina’s forehead all white as ivory and with no stain!”
vi: — So that's one thing done! For the other barrels, if we succeed in the same way, then this afternoon, before going to sleep, the sun might cast its last rays on Mina's noble and pure forehead!
tr: "We have done this much already. If we can be as successful with the others, tonight's sunset may shine on Madam Mina's forehead as white and spotless as ivory!"
es: –This work is finished. It is possible that we will achieve the same success in other places, and thus, perhaps by the time the sun sets today, Mrs. Mina's forehead will be white as ivory and without the stigma.

en: As we passed across the lawn on our way to the station to catch our train we could see the front of the asylum. I looked eagerly, and in the window of my own room saw Mina. I waved my hand to her, and nodded to tell that our work there was successfully accomplished. She nodded in reply to show that she understood. The last I saw, she was waving her hand in farewell. It was with a heavy heart that we sought the station and just caught the train, which was steaming in as we reached the platform.
vi: When going down a small path on the way to the station to catch the train and continue our work, we passed by the mental hospital. I instinctively looked up at my room's window and caught Mina's gaze. I happily waved to signal to her that the work we had just done in our Carfax house had been smoothly completed. She also waved back and bid us farewell until my figure gradually disappeared behind a clump of trees at the end of a path. We eagerly headed to the station as the train was preparing to depart.
tr: As we crossed the grassy area on the way to the station to catch our train, we could see the front facade of the mental hospital. I eagerly looked in that direction and saw Mina at the window of my room. I waved to her and nodded to indicate that our task there had been successfully completed. She also nodded in response to show that she understood. The last I saw of her, she was waving goodbye. We barely reached the station and only just caught the train as it was hissing steam on the platform.
es: As we walked over the grass, on our way to the station to catch the train, we saw the facade of the asylum. I looked anxiously, and in the window of our room, I saw Mina. I waved at her and gave her a nod to let her know that our work there had been satisfactorily completed. She made a gesture in response to indicate that she had understood. The last thing I saw of her was that she was waving at me. We searched for the station with hearts full of sadness and hurriedly boarded the train, as by the time we arrived, it was already by the station platform, preparing to set off again.

en: I have written this in the train.
vi: I can only write these lines while sitting on the train.
tr: I wrote this on the train.
es: I have written all this on the train.

en: Piccadilly, 12:30 o’clock.—Just before we reached Fenchurch Street Lord Godalming said to me:—
vi: • Piccadilly, twelve thirty in the afternoon We were approaching Fenchurch Street when Lord Godalming turned to me and said:
tr: Piccadilly, 12:30. - As we were about to reach Fenchurch Street, Lord Godalming said to me:
es: Piccadilly, twelve thirty sharp. Shortly before we arrived at Fenchurch Street, Lord Godalming said to me:

en: “Quincey and I will find a locksmith. You had better not come with us in case there should be any difficulty; for under the circumstances it wouldn’t seem so bad for us to break into an empty house. But you are a solicitor and the Incorporated Law Society might tell you that you should have known better.” I demurred as to my not sharing any danger even of odium, but he went on: “Besides, it will attract less attention if there are not too many of us. My title will make it all right with the locksmith, and with any policeman that may come along. You had better go with Jack and the Professor and stay in the Green Park, somewhere in sight of the house; and when you see the door opened and the smith has gone away, do you all come across. We shall be on the lookout for you, and shall let you in.”
vi: — Quincey and I will go find a locksmith. It's best if the rest of you don't come along. I think we need to be prepared for any unexpected difficulties. I mean situations where we might reluctantly have to break in. As a notary, it's probably better if you don't get involved! I was about to argue back, but he brushed it off: — Moreover, the fewer people there are, the less attention we will draw. My name can instill trust in the locksmith, and his reputable name will also instill trust in the police, if he... You go with John and the professor to wait for us at Green Park, across from the house. Remember to choose a spot where you can see the house. When the door opens and the locksmith leaves, the three of you will enter the house to meet us. We will wait and call all three of you in together.
tr: “Quincey and I will find a locksmith. It would be better if you didn't come with us in case there's any trouble, because under these circumstances, it wouldn't look too bad for us to break into an empty house. But you are a lawyer, and the United Law Society might tell you that you shouldn't do this.” Since I hadn't yet shared any risk of reproach, I objected, but he continued: “Besides, if we are not too many, we will attract less attention. My title will help us deal with the locksmith and any police that might come. The best thing for you is to go with Jack and the Professor, stay somewhere in Green Park where you can see the house, and when you see the door open and the locksmith leave, come together. We will keep watch for you and let you in.”
es: –Quincey and I are going to find a locksmith. It would be better if you didn't come with us, in case any difficulty arises, since, under the current circumstances, it wouldn't be too bad for us to break into an unoccupied house. But you are a lawyer, and the Incorporated Law Society might tell you that you should have known better. I protested, because I did not wish to stop sharing any danger with them, but he continued saying: –Besides, we will attract much less attention if there are not too many of us. My title will help me a lot in hiring the locksmith and dealing with any police that might be in the vicinity. It would be better if you go with Jack and the professor and stay in Green Park, somewhere you can see the house, and when you see that the door has been opened and the locksmith has left, come over. We will be waiting for you and will open the door as soon as you arrive.

en: “The advice is good!” said Van Helsing, so we said no more. Godalming and Morris hurried off in a cab, we following in another. At the corner of Arlington Street our contingent got out and strolled into the Green Park. My heart beat as I saw the house on which so much of our hope was centred, looming up grim and silent in its deserted condition amongst its more lively and spruce-looking neighbours. We sat down on a bench within good view, and began to smoke cigars so as to attract as little attention as possible. The minutes seemed to pass with leaden feet as we waited for the coming of the others.
vi: — Sounds good! - Van Helsing praised. And we temporarily separated after a stretch of road, Godalming and Morris jumped on a horse-drawn carriage, while the three of us called another carriage. At the corner of Arlington Street, the three of us got out of the car and strolled into Green Park. I felt my heart pounding as if it were about to leap out of my chest when I caught a glimpse of the house in which we had placed so much hope for our success. It was a house lying quietly among other houses bustling with the sounds of life. We chose a bench from which we could observe the house and quietly lit cigars, waiting for the arrival of two friends and a locksmith. Each minute that passed felt like a century to us at that moment.
tr: “This is a good suggestion,” said Van Helsing, and thus we didn't say anything further. Godalming and Morris hurriedly drove off in a rented carriage, and we followed them in another one.
