At the corner of Arlington Street, our group got out of the carriage and started wandering around Green Park. As soon as I saw the house, upon which our great hopes were concentrated, standing ugly and silent among its neighbors that looked more lively and orderly in comparison, my heart began to pound. We sat on a bench with a good view of the house and started smoking cigars to attract as little attention as possible. While waiting for the others to arrive, the minutes seemed to pass as heavy as lead.
es: –The advice is good! – said Van Helsing. Therefore, we did not discuss the matter any further. Godalming and Morris went ahead in a hired carriage, and the rest of us followed in another. At the corner of Arlington Street, our group got out of the vehicle and we entered Green Park. My heart pounded when I saw the house where our hopes were centered, standing out, sinister and silent, in a state of abandonment, among the more cheerful and lively buildings of the neighborhood. We sat on a bench, in view of the house, and began to smoke some cigars, in order to attract as little attention as possible. The minutes felt eternal as we waited for the others to arrive.

en: At length we saw a four-wheeler drive up. Out of it, in leisurely fashion, got Lord Godalming and Morris; and down from the box descended a thick-set working man with his rush-woven basket of tools. Morris paid the cabman, who touched his hat and drove away. Together the two ascended the steps, and Lord Godalming pointed out what he wanted done. The workman took off his coat leisurely and hung it on one of the spikes of the rail, saying something to a policeman who just then sauntered along. The policeman nodded acquiescence, and the man kneeling down placed his bag beside him. After searching through it, he took out a selection of tools which he produced to lay beside him in orderly fashion. Then he stood up, looked into the keyhole, blew into it, and turning to his employers, made some remark. Lord Godalming smiled, and the man lifted a good-sized bunch of keys; selecting one of them, he began to probe the lock, as if feeling his way with it. After fumbling about for a bit he tried a second, and then a third. All at once the door opened under a slight push from him, and he and the two others entered the hall. We sat still; my own cigar burnt furiously, but Van Helsing’s went cold altogether. We waited patiently as we saw the workman come out and bring in his bag. Then he held the door partly open, steadying it with his knees, whilst he fitted a key to the lock. This he finally handed to Lord Godalming, who took out his purse and gave him something. The man touched his hat, took his bag, put on his coat and departed; not a soul took the slightest notice of the whole transaction.
vi: Finally, we noticed a horse-drawn carriage stopping in front of the house. Lord Godalming gracefully alighted along with Morris, followed by a locksmith carrying a toolbox. They slowly walked towards the steps. At the door, Godalming pointed to the lock that needed to be opened. The locksmith took off his outer coat, draped it over the railing, and turned to explain something to a policeman passing by on the street. The policeman nodded, said a few words, and then left, leaving the locksmith to start his work. He bent down, blew into the keyhole, and tried a large bunch of keys, finally finding one that fit after several attempts. Somehow, with just a slight nudge, the door swung open. The three of them immediately stepped into a hallway. We sat still, waiting. I kept puffing on my cigarette, while the cigar on Van Helsing's lips had gone out at some point. Nothing is more nerve-wracking than waiting. Finally, the locksmith swaggered out with his toolbox. He propped the door ajar with his knee, inserted a key, and handed it to Lord Godalming. After receiving his payment, he bowed to the "homeowner" and walked away. Clearly, no one had paid any attention to what had just happened in front of the house.
tr: Finally, we saw a four-wheeler arriving. Lord Godalming and Morris slowly got out of the carriage; a stout worker with a cross-woven tool basket in his hand got down from beside the coachman. Morris paid the coachman, who touched his hat and drove away. The two of them climbed the stairs together, and Lord Godalming showed what needed to be done. The worker slowly took off his jacket and, saying something to a passing policeman, hung it on one of the sharp points of the railings. The policeman nodded approvingly, and the man, kneeling on the ground, placed his bag beside him. After searching inside for a while, he took out some tools and arranged them neatly beside him. Then, he stood up, looked through the keyhole, blew into it, and turned to his employers to say something. Lord Godalming smiled, and the man took a large bunch of keys in his hand, selected one, and began to test the lock as if trying to feel his way with it. After trying and failing for a while by feel, he tried a second one, then a third. Suddenly, the door opened with a slight push, and he and the locksmith entered the hall. We waited without moving; my cigar was burning brightly, but Van Helsing's had completely gone out. We waited patiently when we saw the worker go out and bring his bag inside. Then he kept the door ajar and steadied it with his knee while placing the key in the lock. Finally, he handed this key to Lord Godalming, who took out his wallet and gave him something. The man touched his hat, took his bag, put on his coat, and left; not a single person saw this entire process.
es: Finally, we saw a four-wheeled car stopping nearby. From it, lord Godalming and Morris calmly disembarked, and from the driver's seat descended a stout man dressed in work clothes, carrying a box with the necessary tools for his task. Morris paid the coachman, who touched the brim of his cap and left. They ascended the steps together, and lord Godalming told the worker exactly what he wanted him to do. The worker took off his jacket, placed it calmly over the porch railing, and said something to a police officer who happened to be passing by at that precise moment. The police officer nodded, and the man knelt down, placing the toolbox beside him. After searching through his work tools, he took out several tools which he placed in order beside him. Then, he stood up, looked through the keyhole, blew, and, turning to our friends, made some remarks to them. Lord Godalming smiled, and the man raised a bunch of keys; he chose one of them, inserted it into the lock, and began to try it, as if blindly finding his way. After some time, he tried a second and a third key. Suddenly, as the employee pushed the door a little, both he and our two friends entered the vestibule. We remained motionless, while my cigar burned furiously and van Helsing's, on the contrary, went out. We waited patiently until we saw the locksmith come out with his toolbox. Then, he kept the door ajar, holding it with his knees, while he fitted a key to the lock. Finally, he handed the key to Lord Godalming, who took out his wallet and gave him something. The man touched the brim of his hat, gathered his tools, put his jacket back on, and left. Nobody observed the development of that maneuver.

en: When the man had fairly gone, we three crossed the street and knocked at the door. It was immediately opened by Quincey Morris, beside whom stood Lord Godalming lighting a cigar.
vi: When the locksmith disappeared from sight, we eagerly left the park, crossed the street, and arrived at the house to knock on the door. Quincey Morris immediately opened the door, with Godalming standing next to him smoking.
tr: When Adam had gone quite a distance, the three of us crossed the street and knocked on the door. The door was immediately opened by Quincey Morris, behind whom stood Lord Godalming lighting his cigar.
es: When the man was completely out of sight, the three of us crossed the street and knocked on the door. It was immediately opened by Quincey Morris, next to whom stood Lord Godalming, lighting a cigar.

en: “The place smells so vilely,” said the latter as we came in. It did indeed smell vilely—like the old chapel at Carfax—and with our previous experience it was plain to us that the Count had been using the place pretty freely. We moved to explore the house, all keeping together in case of attack; for we knew we had a strong and wily enemy to deal with, and as yet we did not know whether the Count might not be in the house. In the dining-room, which lay at the back of the hall, we found eight boxes of earth. Eight boxes only out of the nine, which we sought! Our work was not over, and would never be until we should have found the missing box. First we opened the shutters of the window which looked out across a narrow stone-flagged yard at the blank face of a stable, pointed to look like the front of a miniature house. There were no windows in it, so we were not afraid of being over-looked. We did not lose any time in examining the chests. With the tools which we had brought with us we opened them, one by one, and treated them as we had treated those others in the old chapel. It was evident to us that the Count was not at present in the house, and we proceeded to search for any of his effects.
vi: — This house is disgusting! - The Lord told us as the whole group went further inside. Indeed, the air in the house was filled with a smell exactly like the one we had first experienced in the Carfax house. There was no doubt about it, we were venturing into one of the count's hideouts. We checked each room one by one and carefully stayed close to each other, as the count could very well be hiding somewhere in the house. In the dining room at the end of the hallway, we found a total of eight wooden crates, while we had hoped to find nine! We slightly opened the small windows looking out onto a narrow stone-paved courtyard, separating the room we were in from a row of outbuildings—perhaps the stables—with no windows at all, so there was no fear of being seen. With that, we quickly took out the tools we had brought and opened each crate one by one, placing a piece of holy bread inside, just as we had done in the Carfax house. Having finished with the eight wooden crates, we continued our search.
tr: As we entered, "This place smells disgusting," said Lord Godalming. Indeed, it smelled disgusting -like the old chapel at Carfax- and based on our past experience, we clearly understood that the Count had been using this place freely. We set out to explore the house; we moved together in case of an attack, because we knew we had a strong and cunning enemy to deal with, and we did not yet know if the Count was at home. In the dining room at the back of the hall, we found eight boxes of earth. Only eight of the nine boxes we were looking for! Our work was not finished, and it would never be until we found that missing box. First, we opened the shutters of a window overlooking a narrow courtyard with stone paving, on the empty side of a barn painted to look like the front of a small house. There were no windows in the barn, so we had no fear of being watched. We did not waste time examining the boxes. With the tools we had brought, we opened them one by one and did to them what we had done to the boxes in the old chapel. At that moment, it was clear that the Count was not at home, and we began to search for his personal belongings.
es: –This place has an extremely unpleasant smell -commented the latter, when we entered. Indeed, the atmosphere was very unpleasant and foul-smelling, like the old chapel of Carfax, and, with our previous experience, we had no difficulty in understanding that the count had been using that place with complete freedom. Next, we set about exploring the house, and we all stayed together, anticipating some attack, as we knew we were facing a strong, cruel, and ruthless enemy and still did not know whether the count was in the house or not. In the dining room, which was located behind the vestibule, we found eight boxes of earth. Eight out of the nine we were looking for! Our work was not yet finished and would not be until we found the missing box. First, we opened the shutters that faced a courtyard enclosed by stone walls, at the back of which there were whitewashed stables that looked like a small house. There were no windows, so we were not afraid of being seen. We did not waste time examining the drawers. With the tools we had brought with us, we opened the boxes, one by one, and did exactly the same as we had done with those in the old chapel. It was evident that the count was not in the house at that moment, and we searched the entire building, looking for any of his belongings.

en: After a cursory glance at the rest of the rooms, from basement to attic, we came to the conclusion that the dining-room contained any effects which might belong to the Count; and so we proceeded to minutely examine them. They lay in a sort of orderly disorder on the great dining-room table. There were title deeds of the Piccadilly house in a great bundle; deeds of the purchase of the houses at Mile End and Bermondsey; note-paper, envelopes, and pens and ink. All were covered up in thin wrapping paper to keep them from the dust. There were also a clothes brush, a brush and comb, and a jug and basin—the latter containing dirty water which was reddened as if with blood. Last of all was a little heap of keys of all sorts and sizes, probably those belonging to the other houses. When we had examined this last find, Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris taking accurate notes of the various addresses of the houses in the East and the South, took with them the keys in a great bunch, and set out to destroy the boxes in these places. The rest of us are, with what patience we can, waiting their return—or the coming of the Count.
vi: After carefully inspecting every nook and cranny, we came to the conclusion that everything related to Dracula in this house was located in the dining room. Seemingly not satisfied, we told each other to meticulously check every item in the room again. Everything was thrown haphazardly on a very large dining table. There were many types of documents: deeds for the Piccadilly house, as well as the remaining houses in Mile End and Bermondsey, then writing paper, envelopes, ink bottles, and quill pens. A dust-covered piece of wrapping paper, a clothes brush, a hair comb, a jar, and a porcelain basin filled with dirty water that was red like blood. Finally, there were keys of all kinds and sizes, which I guessed were the keys to the other houses. Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris carefully noted down the exact addresses of the houses in Mile End and Bermondsey and took all the keys, putting them in their pockets to prepare to set off and continue destroying the remaining boxes of earth. Now, we will wait either for their return or for the appearance of the Count.
tr: After quickly glancing through all the rooms from the basement to the attic, we concluded that everything that might belong to the Count was found in the dining room, and thus we began to carefully examine them. The items were arranged in a neat disorder on the large dining table. The deeds to the house in Piccadilly were in a large bundle, along with the purchase documents for the houses in Mile End and Bermondsey, letter papers, envelopes, pens, and ink. All of them were covered with a thin wrapping paper to protect them from dust. Additionally, there was a clothes brush, a brush and comb, a jug, and a bowl - the latter containing dirty water that appeared red, as if stained with blood. Finally, there was a bundle of keys of various types and sizes, likely belonging to the other houses. After examining this last finding, Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris, who were taking notes on the various addresses of the houses in the east and south, took a large bunch of keys and set out to destroy the boxes in those places. The rest of us are waiting as patiently as we can for their return - or for the Count's arrival.
es: After quickly examining all the rooms, from the ground floor to the attic, we concluded that all the count's belongings must be in the dining room and, consequently, we proceeded to examine everything with extreme care. They were all in a kind of orderly disorder in the center of the large dining table. There were property titles for the house in Piccadilly in a small pile; bills for the purchase of the houses in Mile End and Bermondsey; writing paper, envelopes, pens, and ink. Everything was wrapped in fine paper to protect it from dust. There was also a clothes brush, a brush and a comb, and a washbasin... The latter contained dirty water, reddened, as if it had blood in it. Last of all was a keyring with keys of all sizes and shapes, probably those belonging to the other houses. When we examined that last discovery, Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris took notes on the addresses of the houses to the east and south, took the keys with them, and set off to destroy the boxes in those places. The rest of us are, with all the patience possible, waiting for their return..., or the arrival of the count.

en: CHAPTER XXIII
vi: CHAPTER 23
tr: XXIII
es: XXIII.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: 3 October.—The time seemed terribly long whilst we were waiting for the coming of Godalming and Quincey Morris. The Professor tried to keep our minds active by using them all the time. I could see his beneficent purpose, by the side glances which he threw from time to time at Harker. The poor fellow is overwhelmed in a misery that is appalling to see. Last night he was a frank, happy-looking man, with strong, youthful face, full of energy, and with dark brown hair. To-day he is a drawn, haggard old man, whose white hair matches well with the hollow burning eyes and grief-written lines of his face. His energy is still intact; in fact, he is like a living flame. This may yet be his salvation, for, if all go well, it will tide him over the despairing period; he will then, in a kind of way, wake again to the realities of life. Poor fellow, I thought my own trouble was bad enough, but his——! The Professor knows this well enough, and is doing his best to keep his mind active. What he has been saying was, under the circumstances, of absorbing interest. So well as I can remember, here it is:—
vi: • October 3 Time seemed to stretch endlessly as we waited for Godalming and Quincey Morris to return. Van Helsing tried every way to boost our spirits. I could sense his good intentions, as he occasionally glanced at Harker. How miserable he looked at that moment. Just recently, he was so lively, quick, cheerful, and full of vitality, yet now he looked like a decrepit old man, with hair almost half gray, eyes sunken deep in worry and sorrow. However, I believe that within him still lies a great deal of strength that will flare up whenever life's realities demand it. Poor fellow! How can we console him now? Professor Van Helsing also understood his state of mind very well, so he did everything he could to help him temporarily forget the constant worry in his heart. What he said to him seemed to be for the highest benefit of all of us. — I have studied it a hundred times since I got the document about the demon.
tr: October 3. - Time seemed to pass terribly slowly while waiting for the arrival of Godalming and Quincey Morris. The Professor tried to keep our minds constantly engaged to keep them active. From his occasional sideways glance at Harker, I could see his good intentions. The poor man was crushed under a pain that was terrible to witness. Last night, he was a man with a strong, young face, full of energy and with dark brown hair, looking sincere and happy. Today, however, he is a weary, grim-faced man with white hair, sunken, burning eyes, and deep lines of pain etched into his face. His energy is still intact; in fact, he is like a living flame. This might still be his salvation, because if everything goes well, it will help him in this desperate situation; then, somehow, he will awaken again to the realities of life. Poor man, I thought my own troubles were bad enough, but his! The Professor knows this very well and is doing his best to keep Harker's mind occupied. The things he was saying were interesting under these circumstances. As far as I can remember, it went like this:
es: October 3rd. The time seemed extremely long to us as we waited for Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris. The professor tried to keep us distracted, using our minds without rest. I perfectly understood the beneficial objective he was pursuing with this, from the glances he occasionally cast at Harker. The poor man is overwhelmed by a sorrow that causes pain. Last night he was a frank man, with a cheerful appearance, a young and strong face, full of energy and with dark brown hair. Today, he looks like a withered and gaunt old man, whose white hair fits well with his bright eyes deeply sunken in their sockets and his facial features marked by pain. His energy remains intact, in fact, it is like a living flame. That may still be his salvation, because if all goes well, it will help him overcome the period of despair; then, in a way, he will reawaken to the realities of life. Poor guy! I thought my own despair and problems were severe enough; but this...! The professor understands it perfectly and is doing everything he can to keep him active. What he was saying was, under the circumstances, of extraordinary interest. These were more or less his words:

en: “I have studied, over and over again since they came into my hands, all the papers relating to this monster; and the more I have studied, the greater seems the necessity to utterly stamp him out. All through there are signs of his advance; not only of his power, but of his knowledge of it. As I learned from the researches of my friend Arminus of Buda-Pesth, he was in life a most wonderful man. Soldier, statesman, and alchemist—which latter was the highest development of the science-knowledge of his time. He had a mighty brain, a learning beyond compare, and a heart that knew no fear and no remorse. He dared even to attend the Scholomance, and there was no branch of knowledge of his time that he did not essay. Well, in him the brain powers survived the physical death; though it would seem that memory was not all complete. In some faculties of mind he has been, and is, only a child; but he is growing, and some things that were childish at the first are now of man’s stature. He is experimenting, and doing it well; and if it had not been that we have crossed his path he would be yet—he may be yet if we fail—the father or furtherer of a new order of beings, whose road must lead through Death, not Life.”
vi: The more I study, the more I feel the need to destroy it by any means necessary. Everywhere I look, I see evidence of its growth; it grows not only in power but also in its own understanding of its power. According to what I have learned from my friend Arminius in Budapest, when it was alive, it was a man, a warrior, a general, and an extraordinary alchemist. Alchemy at that time was always a high-level expression of science. It must have been a person of extraordinary intelligence, unparalleled culture, and a heart of stone that knew neither fear nor remorse. In its being, the strength of its intellect remained intact even after its physical body perished, although its memory was not complete. To be precise, its mind was only comparable to that of a child. Yet it kept developing, some of its attributes suddenly matured from nothing and became perfected. It successfully experienced this through its own sinful life. If not stopped, it would surely become the progenitor or guide for a race of beings that only know existence steeped in death, unable to understand the true meaning of life.
tr: “Since the day they came into my hands, I have repeatedly examined all the documents related to this monster, and the more I worked on them, the greater the necessity of its complete destruction seemed. In all of them, there are indicators of how it progressed; not only of its power but also of its knowledge of that power. From the research of my friend Arminius in Budapest, I learned that he was a perfect man while alive. A soldier, statesman, and alchemist - the latter being the greatest advancement in the science of his time. He had a great mind, an education incomparable to anyone else, and a heart that knew neither fear nor remorse. He even dared to enter Scholomance and there was no branch of knowledge he did not engage in during his lifetime. Well, his mental powers survived physical death; although, his memory seemed incomplete. In some aspects of the mind, he was like a child, and still is, but he is growing now, and some traits that were initially childish have now become fitting for a man. He is conducting experiments and doing it well, and if we had not stood in his way, he could have been the father or supporter of a new species whose path lies through Death, not Life - if we fail, he still might be.”
es: –I have been studying, systematically and repeatedly, ever since they came into my hands, all the documents related to that monster, and the more I have examined them, the greater seems the need to erase him from the face of the earth. In all the papers, there are signs of his progress; not only of his power but also of his awareness of it. As I learned from the investigations of my friend Arminius of Budapest, he was, in life, an extraordinary man. A soldier, statesman, and alchemist... whose knowledge was among the most advanced of his time. He possessed a powerful mind, incomparable knowledge, and a heart that knew neither fear nor remorse. He even allowed himself to attend the Scholomance, and there was no branch of knowledge of his time that he had not tried. Well, in him, the mental powers survived physical death, although it seems that memory is not absolutely complete. Regarding some mental faculties, he has been and is like a child, but he is growing, and certain things that were childish at first are now of manly stature. He is experimenting and doing very well, and if it weren't for us crossing his path, he could still be, or will be if we fail, the father or the continuer of beings of a new order, whose paths lead through death, not life.

en: Harker groaned and said, “And this is all arrayed against my darling! But how is he experimenting? The knowledge may help us to defeat him!”
vi: Hearing that, Harker groaned and said: — And then, who knows how many forces will be mobilized to oppose my young wife! But what are those experiences like? We must understand the old man to defeat him.
tr: Harker groaned and said: “And all this is plotted against my beloved! But how is he conducting experiments? This knowledge could help us defeat him!”
es: Harker grunted, and said: –And all of that is directed against my beloved wife! But, how is he experimenting? The knowledge of that can help us destroy him!

en: “He has all along, since his coming, been trying his power, slowly but surely; that big child-brain of his is working. Well for us, it is, as yet, a child-brain; for had he dared, at the first, to attempt certain things he would long ago have been beyond our power. However, he means to succeed, and a man who has centuries before him can afford to wait and to go slow. Festina lente may well be his motto.”
vi: — Since arriving in England, he has never stopped testing his powers in a slow but steady manner; his intelligence, boundless strength, and complete mental focus are always used to their fullest extent. Fortunately, he is still in a childlike phase, because if he had recklessly attacked every target from the moment he departed from Dracula's castle, he would have been out of our reach long ago. However, he is determined to succeed, and someone who has left behind centuries like him can always wait and gradually move forward without any need to rush. Gradual progress, quick but not hasty, is always a principle in his mind. — I am still very vague about what you just said.
tr: "From the beginning, since his arrival, he has been slowly but surely testing his own strength; that great, childlike mind is at work. This is good for us because it is still a childlike mind; because if he had dared to attempt certain things at the very start, he would have surpassed our strength long ago. Nevertheless, he aims for success and a man with centuries ahead of him can afford to wait and progress slowly. His principle might be festina lente64.
es: –Since his arrival, he has been tirelessly practicing his powers, slowly and surely; his great childish brain is working, because if he had been able to practice certain things from the beginning, they would have been within his powers a long time ago. However, he wishes to succeed, and a man who has several centuries of existence ahead of him can afford to wait and act slowly. Festina lente could very well be his motto.

en: “I fail to understand,” said Harker wearily. “Oh, do be more plain to me! Perhaps grief and trouble are dulling my brain.”
vi: - Harker grumbled. - Please explain it more clearly. My mind is too sluggish.
tr: “I don't understand,” said Harker wearily. “Oh, please speak more plainly with me! Perhaps sorrow and troubles are dulling my mind.”
es: –I don't understand it -said Harker wearily-. Be more explicit, please. It is possible that suffering and worries are clouding my understanding.

en: The Professor laid his hand tenderly on his shoulder as he spoke:—
vi: Van Helsing smiled, gently patting the young man's shoulder:
tr: The professor gently placed his hand on Harker's shoulder as he spoke: "Ah, my child, I will speak plainly.
es: The professor put a hand on his shoulder and said to him:

en: “Ah, my child, I will be plain. Do you not see how, of late, this monster has been creeping into knowledge experimentally. How he has been making use of the zoöphagous patient to effect his entry into friend John’s home; for your Vampire, though in all afterwards he can come when and how he will, must at the first make entry only when asked thereto by an inmate. But these are not his most important experiments. Do we not see how at the first all these so great boxes were moved by others. He knew not then but that must be so. But all the time that so great child-brain of his was growing, and he began to consider whether he might not himself move the box. So he began to help; and then, when he found that this be all-right, he try to move them all alone. And so he progress, and he scatter these graves of him; and none but he know where they are hidden. He may have intend to bury them deep in the ground. So that he only use them in the night, or at such time as he can change his form, they do him equal well; and none may know these are his hiding-place! But, my child, do not despair; this knowledge come to him just too late! Already all of his lairs but one be sterilise as for him; and before the sunset this shall be so. Then he have no place where he can move and hide. I delayed this morning that so we might be sure. Is there not more at stake for us than for him? Then why we not be even more careful than him? By my clock it is one hour and already, if all be well, friend Arthur and Quincey are on their way to us. To-day is our day, and we must go sure, if slow, and lose no chance. See! there are five of us when those absent ones return.”
vi: — Alright, I'll be more explicit for you to understand, my friend! Have you noticed that over time, that demon has been increasingly enhancing its knowledge through practical experiences? You probably still remember that it used the name of the patient Renfield to infiltrate your friend John's asylum, because if a "vampire" wants to enter a stranger's house for the first time at any time, it can only be guided by an acquaintance. But that's not the most important thing. We know that initially, those heavy wooden crates were carried by others - not by it. It didn't realize that it could do much more than that. However, the utmost intelligence of a child gradually developed within it, to the point where it had to ask itself if it could lift the crates. It started by helping others lift the crates, and when it realized it was too easy a task, it tried to carry them alone. It succeeded and is now plotting to spread the crates around as hiding places, only it knows where they are hidden. It might plan to bury them deep underground. In the evening, or when it can change its form, these graves are very suitable for it to hide in, and no one can detect its movements. But don't be disheartened, my friend! Even if that knowledge is applied now, it's already too late. All the crates, except for one that we haven't found, have been rendered useless. I hope that before the sun sets, the last crate will meet the same fate. It wasn't until this morning that I had such confidence. But right now, the outcome is still uncertain. According to my watch, it's now one o'clock; if everything goes smoothly, our friends Arthur and Quincey should be on their way back. We must proceed ahead, perhaps slowly, but surely, and above all, not miss any opportunity. Just think about it! When those friends return, we will be five in total!
tr: The professor gently placed his hand on Harker's shoulder as he spoke: "Ah, my child, I will speak plainly. Don't you see how this monster has recently been infiltrating knowledge in an experimental manner? How he used the zoophagous patient to enter our friend John's house; because your Vampire, although he could enter whenever and however he wanted later, could only enter initially when invited by someone from inside. But these are not the most important experiments. Don't we see how these large boxes were initially carried by others? At that time, he didn't know it had to be that way. But that great, childlike mind of his kept evolving, and then he thought about whether he could carry the box himself. So, he started helping the carriers, and then, seeing there was nothing to it, he tried to carry them alone. And thus he made progress and distributed his graves; now no one but him knows where they are hidden. He might have intended to bury them deep. Thus, he would only use them at night or when he could change form, both of which would suit his purpose, and no one would know these were his hiding places! But my child, do not despair; this knowledge came to him far too late! We have already purified all but one of his sanctuaries, and this will be dealt with before sunset. Then, he will have no place to move and hide. I did not allow us to act hastily this morning so that we could be sure. Don't we have much more at stake compared to him? Then why shouldn't we act more cautiously than him? According to my watch, it is one o'clock, and if all is well, our friends Arthur and Quincey have already set out towards us. Today is our day, and we must proceed with sure steps, even if slowly, and not miss any opportunity. Look! When those who are not with us now return, we will be five."
es: –Very well, my friend, I will be more explicit. Don't you see how, lately, that monster has acquired knowledge experimentally? He has been using the zoophagous patient to gain entry into friend John's house. The vampire, although he can enter as many times as he wishes afterward, can only enter a building initially if one of the inhabitants invites him in. But those are not his most important experiments. Didn't we see that at first all those heavy boxes of earth were moved by others? I didn't know what to make of it then, but afterward, everything changed. During all this time, his infantile brain has been developing, and he began to think about whether he could move the boxes himself. Consequently, later, when he discovered that it wasn't difficult for him to do so, he tried to move them alone, without anyone's help. Thus, he progressed and managed to distribute his tombs in such a way that only he now knows where they are located. It is possible that he thought of burying the boxes deeply in the ground so that he only uses them at night or at times when he can change form; it is equally convenient for him, and no one can know where his hiding places are! But do not despair, my friends, he acquired that knowledge too late! All the hiding places, except one, must have already been sterilized, and before sunset, they all will be. Then, he will have no place left to hide. I delayed this morning to be sure of it. Aren't we risking something much more precious than he is? Then, why aren't we more careful than he is? From my watch, I see that it is already one o'clock, and if all goes well, our friends Arthur and Quincey should already be on their way to join us. Today is our day, and we must proceed with confidence, albeit slowly, taking advantage of every opportunity that presents itself. Look! We will be five when our two absent friends return.

en: Whilst he was speaking we were startled by a knock at the hall door, the double postman’s knock of the telegraph boy. We all moved out to the hall with one impulse, and Van Helsing, holding up his hand to us to keep silence, stepped to the door and opened it. The boy handed in a despatch. The Professor closed the door again, and, after looking at the direction, opened it and read aloud.
vi: Van Helsing had not finished speaking when a sudden, rough knock on the door startled everyone. We anxiously stepped out into the hallway. The professor signaled for everyone to remain silent and went to open the door by himself. It turned out to be a postal worker! He handed the professor a telegram. After glancing at the address on the telegram, the professor quickly slammed the door shut as soon as the postal worker left.
tr: While he was speaking, we were startled by the knocking on the hall door, the double knock of the telegraph boy. With a single impulse, we all went out into the hall, and Van Helsing, raising his hand to signal us to be silent, went to the door and opened it. The boy handed over the delivery. The professor closed the door again, and after looking at the address, he opened the telegram and read it aloud:
es: While we were talking, we were very surprised to hear a call at the main door of the mansion: the double call of the telegraph message delivery person. We all went out into the lobby at the same time, and Van Helsing, raising his hand towards us to keep silent, walked towards the door and opened it. A young man handed him a telegram. The professor closed the door again and, after examining the address, opened it and read aloud: "Beware of D.

en: “Look out for D. He has just now, 12:45, come from Carfax hurriedly and hastened towards the South. He seems to be going the round and may want to see you: Mina.”
vi: As he approached us, he opened the telegram and read aloud: "Beware of D. At 12:45, he hurriedly left Carfax and quickly disappeared to the south. He might be looking for you. Mina."
tr: Pay attention to D. Now, 12:45, he came hurriedly from Carfax and went quickly south. He seems to be turning back and may want to see you: Mina.
es: The professor closed the door again and, after examining the address, opened it and read aloud: "Beware of D. He has just hurriedly left Carfax at this moment, at twelve forty-five, and has headed quickly towards the south. It seems he is making a round and may want to see you. Mina."

en: There was a pause, broken by Jonathan Harker’s voice:—
vi: Jonathan Harker exclaimed, his voice tense:
tr: There was a silence broken by Jonathan Harker's voice: "Thank God, we will meet soon!"
es: A pause occurred, which was broken by the voice of Jonathan Harker.

en: “Now, God be thanked, we shall soon meet!” Van Helsing turned to him quickly and said:—
vi: — Thank God, we are about to meet face to face! Van Helsing turned to encourage my friend:
tr: There was a silence broken by Jonathan Harker's voice: "Thank God, we will meet soon!" Van Helsing quickly turned to him and said:
es: –Now, thank God, we will soon meet! Van Helsing quickly turned to him and said:

en: “God will act in His own way and time. Do not fear, and do not rejoice as yet; for what we wish for at the moment may be our undoings.”
vi: — The Lord will act according to His way and timing. We need to be courageous, but we shouldn't rejoice too soon, because what we desire now might lead us to those very losses.
tr: “God will act in His own way and in His own time. For now, do not fear and do not rejoice because what we desire at this moment could be our ruin.”
es: –God will act in His own way and at the time He deems appropriate. Do not fear nor rejoice yet, for what we desire at this moment may signify our destruction.

en: “I care for nothing now,” he answered hotly, “except to wipe out this brute from the face of creation. I would sell my soul to do it!”
vi: — Now nothing is important to me anymore - Harker coldly replied - except for getting rid of that vile demon from this world. Would I sell my soul for it?
tr: Jonathan replied excitedly, "I don't care about anything right now." "The only thing I care about is erasing this monster from the universe. I'd sell my soul to do it!"
es: –Now I am not worried about anything -he said warmly-, except erasing that beast from the face of the earth. I would be capable of selling my soul to achieve it!

en: “Oh, hush, hush, my child!” said Van Helsing. “God does not purchase souls in this wise; and the Devil, though he may purchase, does not keep faith. But God is merciful and just, and knows your pain and your devotion to that dear Madam Mina. Think you, how her pain would be doubled, did she but hear your wild words. Do not fear any of us, we are all devoted to this cause, and to-day shall see the end. The time is coming for action; to-day this Vampire is limit to the powers of man, and till sunset he may not change. It will take him time to arrive here—see, it is twenty minutes past one—and there are yet some times before he can hither come, be he never so quick. What we must hope for is that my Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive first.”
vi: — Oh! Shh, shh, my friend. - Van Helsing said. - God does not buy those souls, and the devils are not faithful customers. God is always compassionate and just, He knows your suffering and the love you have for Mina. As for her, she would be in much more pain if she heard the reckless words you just said. Do not fear anything, we are all united in our duty and nothing can shake that. The time to act has come. During the day, “vampires” are as ordinary as regular humans, they can only transform after the sun has set. They need time to get here. Look, it is only one twenty now, time will continue to pass before they reveal themselves to us - even if they move faster than ever. Hopefully, our two friends will arrive before them.
tr: “Ah, hush, hush, my child!” said Van Helsing. “God does not buy souls in this way, and even if the devil does, he does not keep his word. But God is forgiving and just; He knows your pain and your devotion to dear Madam Mina. Think of how much more it will hurt her to hear these rebellious words. Do not fear any of us; we have all dedicated ourselves to this cause and will see it through to the end today. The time for action is coming; today this Vampire is limited by human power and will not be able to change until sunset. It will take time for him to arrive here - look, it is twenty past one - and there is still time before he can get here, he will never be that quick. We must hope that Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive first.”
es: –"Don't say that, my friend!" – said Van Helsing. "God in His wisdom does not buy souls, and the devil, although he can buy them, does not keep his word. But God is merciful and just, and He knows your pain and your devotion to the wonderful lady Mina, your wife. Let none of us be afraid; we are all dedicated to this cause, and today will see its happy conclusion. The time has come to take action; today, that vampire is limited by human powers and, until sunset, he cannot change. It will take some time for him to arrive… It is one twenty…, and it will be a while before he gets here. What we must hope for now is that Lord Arthur and Quincey arrive before he does."

en: About half an hour after we had received Mrs. Harker’s telegram, there came a quiet, resolute knock at the hall door. It was just an ordinary knock, such as is given hourly by thousands of gentlemen, but it made the Professor’s heart and mine beat loudly. We looked at each other, and together moved out into the hall; we each held ready to use our various armaments—the spiritual in the left hand, the mortal in the right. Van Helsing pulled back the latch, and, holding the door half open, stood back, having both hands ready for action. The gladness of our hearts must have shown upon our faces when on the step, close to the door, we saw Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris. They came quickly in and closed the door behind them, the former saying, as they moved along the hall:—
vi: About half an hour after receiving Mina's call, we were startled once again when we heard the light but determined knocks on the door. We nervously stepped into the hallway, weapons in hand, and the professor gently pulled the latch and stepped back with me, ready to defend. Our joy surged to the highest level when we recognized the familiar faces of Lord Godalming and Quincey at the threshold. They quickly stepped in and slammed the door shut.
tr: About half an hour after receiving Ms. Harker’s telegram, the hall door was knocked on quietly but firmly. It was the kind of ordinary knock that thousands of gentlemen make constantly, but it caused the Professor and me to feel our hearts beating loudly. We looked at each other and went out into the hall together; both of us ready to use our various weapons - the spiritual ones in the left hand, the deadly ones in the right hand. Van Helsing drew the bolt and opened the door halfway, stepping back with both hands ready for action. When we saw Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris on the threshold, close to the door, the joy in our hearts must have shown on our faces. They quickly came inside and closed the door behind them; as they moved through the hall, Lord Godalming began to speak:
es: Approximately half an hour after we received Mrs. Harker's telegram, we heard a loud and resolute knock on the front door, similar to the one hundreds of gentlemen would give on any door. We looked at each other and headed towards the hall; we were all prepared to use all the weapons at our disposal... the spiritual ones in the left hand and the material ones in the right. Van Helsing removed the latch and, keeping the door ajar, took a step back, with both hands ready for action. The joy in our hearts must have been clearly reflected on our faces when we saw Lord Godalming and Quincey Morris near the door. They entered quickly, and closed the door behind them, and the last of them said, as we all advanced through the hall:

en: “It is all right. We found both places; six boxes in each and we destroyed them all!”
vi: — Everything is fine. - Godalming said on the way into the hallway. - We found two hiding places scattered with six boxes of earth, all of which no longer exist.
tr: "Everything is fine. We found both places; each had six chests and we destroyed them all!"
es: –Everything is settled. We have found both houses. There were six boxes in each of them, and we have destroyed them all!

en: “Destroyed?” asked the Professor.
vi: — Why not? - Van Helsing asked in surprise.
tr: "Did you get rid of it?" asked the Professor.
es: "Have they destroyed them?" inquired the professor.

en: “For him!” We were silent for a minute, and then Quincey said:—
vi: — Was I speaking to the old count? This is the first time Quincey has spoken up:
tr: "From his perspective!" We remained silent for a minute, and then Quincey said:
es: –For him! We remained silent for a few moments and then Quincey said:

en: “There’s nothing to do but to wait here. If, however, he doesn’t turn up by five o’clock, we must start off; for it won’t do to leave Mrs. Harker alone after sunset.”
vi: — There's nothing left to do but sit and wait here. But if we wait until five o'clock and he still hasn't arrived, we might have to go back. We can't leave Mina at home alone after sunset. — He must be about to show up soon.
tr: “There is nothing to do here but wait. If he doesn't come back by five o'clock, we will need to set off; because it wouldn't be right to leave Ms. Harker alone after sunset.”
es: –We have no choice but to wait here. However, if he does not arrive before five in the afternoon, we will have to leave, since we cannot leave Mrs. Harker alone after sunset.

en: “He will be here before long now,” said Van Helsing, who had been consulting his pocket-book. “Nota bene, in Madam’s telegram he went south from Carfax, that means he went to cross the river, and he could only do so at slack of tide, which should be something before one o’clock. That he went south has a meaning for us. He is as yet only suspicious; and he went from Carfax first to the place where he would suspect interference least. You must have been at Bermondsey only a short time before him. That he is not here already shows that he went to Mile End next. This took him some time; for he would then have to be carried over the river in some way. Believe me, my friends, we shall not have long to wait now. We should have ready some plan of attack, so that we may throw away no chance. Hush, there is no time now. Have all your arms! Be ready!” He held up a warning hand as he spoke, for we all could hear a key softly inserted in the lock of the hall door.
vi: - Van Helsing said while looking at his watch. - According to the telegram Mina just sent, he left Carfax heading south, which means he has crossed the river, that is, a little before one o'clock. If he is heading south, we can conclude that he still suspects our interference and from Carfax, he will first go straight to the place he suspects. You must have arrived in Bermondsey shortly before him. Since he hasn't shown up here yet, it proves that he then went around to Mile End. That detour cost him quite a bit of time, as he needed to find a way to cross the river. So we won't have to wait much longer. We should probably prepare our attack plan now, let's not waste any more time. Shh! He's here! Grab your weapons! Indeed, we heard the sound of the lock turning outside the main door.
tr: “He will be here soon,” said Van Helsing, who was looking at his pocket notebook at the time. “Nota bene, Madam’s telegram says he went south of Carfax, which means he will cross the river and can only do so when the tide is low, which should be before one o’clock. His going south has significance for us. He is still only suspicious and went first to the place where he would encounter the least obstacles from Carfax. You must have been in Bermondsey just a little before him. The fact that he hasn’t come here yet indicates that he then went to Mile End. This must have taken some of his time, because after that, he must have been transported by some means on the river. Believe me, my friends, we won’t have to wait much longer from now on. We need to have an attack plan ready so that we don’t miss any opportunity. Shh! We have no more time. Get all your weapons! Be ready!” As he spoke, he gestured with his hand because we could all hear a key being slowly inserted into the lock of the hall door.
es: –He won't take long to get here now -said Van Helsing, who had been consulting his little notebook-. Nota bene. In Mrs. Harker's telegram, it said that he had left Carfax heading south, which means he had to cross the river and could only do so at low tide, that is, shortly before one o'clock. The fact that he headed south has some significance for us. He still only suspects, and he went from Carfax to the place where he least suspects he might encounter any obstacle. You must have been in Bermondsey very shortly before him. The fact that he hasn't arrived here yet shows that he went to Mile End first. That will take some time, since he will have to cross the river again somehow. Believe me, my friends, we won't have to wait much longer now. We need to have some plan of attack ready, so we don't miss any opportunity. We don't have time anymore. Everyone, have your weapons ready! Stay alert! He raised a hand, as a warning, while he spoke, since we could all clearly hear a key being gently inserted into the lock.

en: I could not but admire, even at such a moment, the way in which a dominant spirit asserted itself. In all our hunting parties and adventures in different parts of the world, Quincey Morris had always been the one to arrange the plan of action, and Arthur and I had been accustomed to obey him implicitly. Now, the old habit seemed to be renewed instinctively. With a swift glance around the room, he at once laid out our plan of attack, and, without speaking a word, with a gesture, placed us each in position. Van Helsing, Harker, and I were just behind the door, so that when it was opened the Professor could guard it whilst we two stepped between the incomer and the door. Godalming behind and Quincey in front stood just out of sight ready to move in front of the window. We waited in a suspense that made the seconds pass with nightmare slowness. The slow, careful steps came along the hall; the Count was evidently prepared for some surprise—at least he feared it.
vi: Although it was a tense moment, I still secretly admired Quincey's calm bravery. In all our adventures, he was always the one to organize the action plans, and Arthur and I always followed his arrangements to the letter. Now, as well, we immediately reverted to that daily habit. After scanning the room, he pointed to where each person in the group should stand. Van Helsing, Harker, and I stood right behind the door so that as soon as it opened, we could immediately block the intruder's retreat. Arthur and Quincey hid in a spot, ready to jump in front of the window. We anxiously, tensely waited as each nightmarish second passed. Slow, cautious footsteps began to echo quite clearly in the hallway outside. It was clear that the Count was expecting an attack, or at least he was afraid of one.
tr: Even in such a moment, I couldn’t help but admire the way the dominant spirit manifested itself. In all our hunting parties and adventures around the world, Quincey Morris has always been the one to draft the plan of action, and Arthur and I had become entirely accustomed to following him. Now that old habit seemed to have instinctively revived. After quickly scanning the room, Quincey organized our attack plan and, without saying a word, positioned each of us with hand signals. Van Helsing, Harker, and I moved right behind the door so that when it opened, the Professor wouldn’t miss it and the two of us could stand between the door and the person entering. Godalming stood at the back and Quincey at the front, ready to act without being seen in front of the window. We waited in a suspenseful doubt as the seconds passed like a nightmare. Slow and careful footsteps came in the hall; undoubtedly, the Count was ready for a surprise - at least he feared one.
es: I could not help but admire, even at that moment, the way a dominant spirit asserts itself. In all our hunting trips and adventures of various kinds, in different parts of the world, Quincey Morris had always been the one to arrange the plans of action and Arthur and I had gotten used to obeying him implicitly. Now, the old habit seemed to instinctively renew itself. With a quick glance around the room, he immediately established our plan of action and, without uttering a single word, with a gesture, placed us all in our respective positions. Van Helsing, Harker, and I were positioned immediately behind the door, in such a way that, as soon as it opened, the professor could guard it, while Harker and I would place ourselves between the newcomer and the door. Godalming behind and Quincey in front, were ready to head to the windows, hidden for the moment where they could not be seen. We waited with such impatience that the seconds passed with a slowness of a true nightmare. The slow and cautious steps crossed the hall... The count was evidently prepared for a surprise or, at least, feared one.

en: Suddenly with a single bound he leaped into the room, winning a way past us before any of us could raise a hand to stay him. There was something so panther-like in the movement—something so unhuman, that it seemed to sober us all from the shock of his coming. The first to act was Harker, who, with a quick movement, threw himself before the door leading into the room in the front of the house. As the Count saw us, a horrible sort of snarl passed over his face, showing the eye-teeth long and pointed; but the evil smile as quickly passed into a cold stare of lion-like disdain. His expression again changed as, with a single impulse, we all advanced upon him. It was a pity that we had not some better organised plan of attack, for even at the moment I wondered what we were to do. I did not myself know whether our lethal weapons would avail us anything. Harker evidently meant to try the matter, for he had ready his great Kukri knife and made a fierce and sudden cut at him. The blow was a powerful one; only the diabolical quickness of the Count’s leap back saved him. A second less and the trenchant blade had shorne through his heart. As it was, the point just cut the cloth of his coat, making a wide gap whence a bundle of bank-notes and a stream of gold fell out. The expression of the Count’s face was so hellish, that for a moment I feared for Harker, though I saw him throw the terrible knife aloft again for another stroke. Instinctively I moved forward with a protective impulse, holding the Crucifix and Wafer in my left hand. I felt a mighty power fly along my arm; and it was without surprise that I saw the monster cower back before a similar movement made spontaneously by each one of us. It would be impossible to describe the expression of hate and baffled malignity—of anger and hellish rage—which came over the Count’s face. His waxen hue became greenish-yellow by the contrast of his burning eyes, and the red scar on the forehead showed on the pallid skin like a palpitating wound. The next instant, with a sinuous dive he swept under Harker’s arm, ere his blow could fall, and, grasping a handful of the money from the floor, dashed across the room, threw himself at the window. Amid the crash and glitter of the falling glass, he tumbled into the flagged area below. Through the sound of the shivering glass I could hear the “ting” of the gold, as some of the sovereigns fell on the flagging.
vi: Suddenly, he burst into the room, catching us off guard. His leap had a certain grace and an inhuman quality that left us stunned. The first to act was none other than Harker. He leapt like lightning to block a doorway leading to the front room. Seeing us, he tilted his head back and laughed contemptuously, baring his sharp, jagged fangs, but he immediately fell silent, his terrifying laugh replaced by a malicious and sinister glare. His malevolence became more apparent as we slowly approached him. To be honest, at that moment, I no longer knew what to do. I didn't know if the weapons we carried would have any effect on him. Clearly, Harker intended to find out, as he angrily thrust a knife straight at him. The count could only escape thanks to a lightning-fast, demonic leap backward. Instead of piercing his chest, the knife's tip merely tore through his coat, spilling a stack of banknotes and a pile of gold coins. The old man let out an angry, furious roar, which made me worry for Harker, even though I saw him raise a long, sharp knife, ready for a new attack. Instinctively, holding the cross and a piece of holy bread in my left hand, I quickly stepped forward to protect my brave companion. I felt my arm being guided by an invisible force, and it did not surprise me to see the demon stagger backward within our encirclement. The hatred and ferocity, anger and madness on the demonic face of the count were indescribable. His face gradually changed from purple-red to pale, in stark contrast to his fiery eyes filled with hatred. In an instant, he ducked under Harker's arm like a cat before he could deliver another powerful blow. He bent low, quickly grabbed a handful of gold coins, and then hurled himself through the window, shattering the shutters into countless glittering pieces. Amidst the sound of breaking glass was the clattering of gold coins rolling on the ground.
tr: Suddenly, with a single leap, he burst into the room; before any of us could raise a hand to stop him, he passed among us. There was something panther-like in his movement -something very inhuman that seemed to rouse us from the shock of his arrival. The first to act was Harker, who, with a swift motion, flung himself in front of the door leading to the front of the house. When the Count saw us, a terrible expression appeared on his face, showing his long and sharp canine teeth, but the demonic grin quickly gave way to a lion-like pride. When we all advanced on him with a single impulse, his facial expression changed again. It was a pity that we had not made a more organized plan of attack, for even at that moment, I was wondering what we would do. Personally, I did not know whether our deadly weapons would be of any help. Harker, clearly wanting to test this, prepared the large kukri and delivered a ruthless and unexpected blow to the Count with it. It was a powerful strike; however, the demonic speed of the Count's backward leap had protected him. If he had been a second late, the sharp blade would have cut through his heart. As it was, the kukri only cut through the fabric of his coat, and from the wide gash, a bundle of paper money and plenty of gold spilled out. The Count's expression was so diabolical that, even though I saw the terrible kukri being raised for another blow, I feared for Harker, and instinctively, with a protective impulse, I leaped forward with the cross and blessed bread in my left hand. I felt a great power flow from my arm to my hand, and it did not surprise me at all to see the Count recoil in fear as we all made similar spontaneous movements. It is impossible for me to describe the expression of hatred and thwarted malice -the rage and demonic fury- on the Count's face. His pale face turned a greenish-yellow, contrasting with his blazing eyes, and the red scar on his forehead seemed to pulse like a heartbeat on his pallid skin. The next moment, with a serpentine dive, he slipped under Harker's arm before the blow could land, grabbed a bundle of money from the floor, and darted to the other side of the room, throwing himself out the window. Amid the crash and sparkle of the falling glass, he fell to the stone-paved area below. Amid the crash of the glass, I could hear the clinking of some of the gold coins as they hit the stone ground.
es: Suddenly, with a huge leap, he entered the room, passing between us before any of us could even raise a hand to try to stop him. There was something so feline in the movement, something so inhuman, that it seemed to wake us all from the shock his arrival had caused. The first to take action was Harker, who, with a quick movement, positioned himself in front of the door leading to the front room of the house. When the count saw us, a kind of sinister mocking gesture appeared on his face, revealing his long and pointed fangs; but his malignant smile quickly vanished, replaced by a cold expression of deep disdain. His expression changed again when, all together, we advanced towards him. It was a pity that we hadn't had time to prepare some good attack plan, as at that very moment I wondered what we were going to do. I was not at all convinced that our lethal weapons would protect us. Evidently, Harker was willing to try, as he prepared his large kukri knife and delivered a terrible slash at the count. The blow was powerful; only the count's diabolical speed of movement allowed him to escape unharmed. One more second and the sharp blade would have pierced his heart. In reality, the tip only cut through the fabric of his jacket, creating a huge hole from which a bunch of banknotes and a stream of gold coins spilled out. The expression on the count's face was so infernal that for a moment I feared for Harker, even though he was already prepared to deliver another slash. Instinctively, I stepped forward with a protective impulse, holding the crucifix and the Sacred Host in my left hand. I felt a great power coursing through my arm and was not surprised to see the monster retreating at the similar movement made by each and every one of my friends. It would be impossible to describe the expression of hatred and terrible malignancy, of infernal rage and fury, that appeared on the count's face. His waxy skin turned yellowish-green, contrasting with his red, burning eyes, and the red scar on his forehead stood out sharply, like an open, throbbing wound. An instant later, with a sinuous movement, he slipped under Harker's armed arm before he could deliver his blow, grabbed a handful of the money on the floor, crossed the room, and hurled himself at one of the windows. Amid the tinkling of broken glass, he fell into the courtyard below the window. Amid the noise of the shattered glass, I managed to hear the sound of several sovereigns hitting the ground, on the asphalt.

en: We ran over and saw him spring unhurt from the ground. He, rushing up the steps, crossed the flagged yard, and pushed open the stable door. There he turned and spoke to us:—
vi: Looking out the window, I saw him calmly stand up as if nothing had happened. He ran across the yard, kicked open the door leading to the stables, then turned back with a sneer: — Do you think it's easy to mess with me?
tr: We ran to the window and saw him spring up from the ground unscathed. Running, he crossed the stone-paved square, climbed the steps, and opened the stable door. There he turned and called out to us:
es: We rushed to the window and saw him get up from the ground unscathed. He ascended the steps at full speed, crossed the courtyard, and opened the door to the stables. Once there, he turned and spoke to us:

en: “You think to baffle me, you—with your pale faces all in a row, like sheep in a butcher’s. You shall be sorry yet, each one of you! You think you have left me without a place to rest; but I have more. My revenge is just begun! I spread it over centuries, and time is on my side. Your girls that you all love are mine already; and through them you and others shall yet be mine—my creatures, to do my bidding and to be my jackals when I want to feed. Bah!” With a contemptuous sneer, he passed quickly through the door, and we heard the rusty bolt creak as he fastened it behind him. A door beyond opened and shut. The first of us to speak was the Professor, as, realising the difficulty of following him through the stable, we moved toward the hall.
vi: Look at you all, faces pale, bodies trembling like sheep in a slaughterhouse—how can you accomplish anything like that! Soon enough, you'll all regret it! Don't think I have nowhere to hide; I'm still here. My revenge has only just begun. This endeavor will accompany me through many centuries, and time is my ally. The women you love already belong to me, and through them, you and many others will also belong to me. They are all creations meant to carry out my commands, to serve me whenever I thirst for blood. That's how it is! The old man threw his head back and laughed triumphantly and disdainfully, then slammed the door shut. We clearly heard the sound of him sliding the bolt behind the door. After that, there was the sound of the door opening and closing once more. We understand that chasing him into the stable at this moment is very difficult. So, we have failed! The first person to speak was Van Helsing, he said as we hurriedly turned into the hallway:
tr: “You think you can stop me, you - with your pale faces lined up like sheep for the slaughter. But in the end, you will regret it, each one of you! You think you have deprived me of places where I can rest and relax; but there are others. My revenge is just beginning! I have spread it over centuries, and time is working in my favor. Your beloved girls are already mine, and through them, you and others will also be mine - my creatures to do my bidding and my jackals when I need to feed. Bah!” With a contemptuous laugh, he quickly passed through the door, and we heard the rusty bolt creak as he locked it behind him. A door opened and closed further ahead. Realizing the difficulty of following him into the stable, the Professor was the first to speak as we moved towards the hall.
es: –You think you can confuse me... with your pale faces, like sheep at the slaughterhouse. Now you're all going to feel it! You think you've left me without a place to rest, but I have others. My revenge begins now! I have walked the earth for centuries and time is on my side. The women you all love are already mine, and through them, you and many others will belong to me as well... You will be my creatures, to do as I command and to be my jackals when I wish to feed. Bah! With a laugh full of contempt, he quickly passed through the door and we heard the rusty bolt being drawn when he closed the door behind him. A door, further away, opened and closed again. The first of us who spoke was the professor, when, realizing how difficult it would be to chase him through the stables, we headed towards the hall.

en: “We have learnt something—much! Notwithstanding his brave words, he fears us; he fear time, he fear want! For if not, why he hurry so? His very tone betray him, or my ears deceive. Why take that money? You follow quick. You are hunters of wild beast, and understand it so. For me, I make sure that nothing here may be of use to him, if so that he return.” As he spoke he put the money remaining into his pocket; took the title-deeds in the bundle as Harker had left them, and swept the remaining things into the open fireplace, where he set fire to them with a match.
vi: — We have understood something, even a lot more than that. Even though he raised his voice to threaten us, it is clear that he is still afraid of us. If not, why would he run away? If I didn't mishear, his voice betrayed his true self. Why did he have to pick up those banknotes? Quickly chase after him! I believe there is nothing here that can help him anymore, even if he comes back. As he spoke, he picked up the remaining banknote and stuffed it into his pocket, then gathered the soil documents and other papers that Harker had thrown on the floor and tossed them into the stove before lighting a match.
tr: “We learned something - actually, a lot! Despite his brave words, he is afraid of us; he fears time, he fears deprivation! If that were not the case, why would he be in such a hurry? His tone of voice gives him away, or my ears are deceiving me. Why would he take that money? You go after him quickly. You are wild animal hunters, and think of him as such. As for me, I will ensure that nothing here will be of use to him if he happens to return.” While speaking, he put the remaining money in his pocket, took the deeds in the bundle as Harker had left them, and swept the rest towards the fireplace, setting them all on fire with a match.
es: –We have learned something… A lot! Despite his boasting, he fears us; he fears time and he fears needs. If it weren't so, why would he be in such a hurry? The very tone of his words betrayed him, or my ears deceived me. Why did he take that money? They will understand me quickly! You are hunters of a wild beast and you understand. In my opinion, we need to make sure he can't use anything here, if he returns. As he spoke, he put the rest of the money into his pocket; he took the property titles from the little pile where Harker had left them and threw the rest into the fireplace, setting it on fire with a match.

en: Godalming and Morris had rushed out into the yard, and Harker had lowered himself from the window to follow the Count. He had, however, bolted the stable door; and by the time they had forced it open there was no sign of him. Van Helsing and I tried to make inquiry at the back of the house; but the mews was deserted and no one had seen him depart.
vi: Godalming and Morris rushed into the yard, while Harker jumped through the window hoping to catch up with the Count. Indeed, he had bolted the door leading to the stables. When they broke down the door, they couldn't see any trace of him. Van Helsing and I circled around the back of the house to search, but all the stables were empty. No one saw the Count.
tr: Godalming and Morris ran out into the courtyard, Harker had climbed out of the window to follow the Count. But the Count had bolted the stable door, and when they forced it open, there was no trace of him. Van Helsing and I tried to search the back of the house, but the narrow streets were empty and no one had seen the Count leave.
es: Godalming and Morris had gone out to the courtyard, and Harker had climbed out the window to follow the count. However, Dracula had securely locked the stable door, and by the time they managed to open it, there was no trace of the vampire. Van Helsing and I tried to investigate a bit at the back of the house, but the stables were deserted and no one had seen him leave.

en: It was now late in the afternoon, and sunset was not far off. We had to recognise that our game was up; with heavy hearts we agreed with the Professor when he said:—
vi: The afternoon passed quickly, giving way to the fading twilight. We understood that we had lost, with a heavy disappointment weighing on our hearts.
tr: It was almost evening and there was not much time left until sunset. We had to accept that our plan had fallen through, with sorrowful hearts, we agreed with the Professor's words: "Come, let us return to Madam Mina - poor, poor, dear Madam Mina.
es: The afternoon was already quite advanced and there wasn't much time left until sunset. We had to acknowledge that the work was finished and, with sadness, we agreed with the professor when he said:

en: “Let us go back to Madam Mina—poor, poor dear Madam Mina. All we can do just now is done; and we can there, at least, protect her. But we need not despair. There is but one more earth-box, and we must try to find it; when that is done all may yet be well.” I could see that he spoke as bravely as he could to comfort Harker. The poor fellow was quite broken down; now and again he gave a low groan which he could not suppress—he was thinking of his wife.
vi: — Perhaps we should go back to Mina. - The professor told us. - There's nothing more we can do here. Anyway, we need to return soon to put her at ease.
tr: We had to accept that our plan had fallen through, with sorrowful hearts, we agreed with the Professor's words: "Come, let us return to Madam Mina - poor, poor, dear Madam Mina. For now, everything that could be done has been done, and there, at least we can protect her. But we must not fall into despair. There is only one more box of earth left, and we must try to find it; once that is done, everything will be alright." I could see that he was speaking as bravely as he could to reassure Harker. Poor man, he was quite broken; from time to time, a slight groan escaped his lips that he couldn't suppress - he was thinking of his wife.
es: –Let's return to Mrs. Mina… To poor Mrs. Harker. We have done everything we could for the moment and, at least, we will be able to protect her. But we must not despair. The vampire has only one box of earth left and we will try to find it; when we succeed, everything will be fine. I understood that he was speaking as bravely as he could to console Harker. The poor man was completely dejected and, from time to time, groaned, unable to help it... He was thinking about his wife.

en: With sad hearts we came back to my house, where we found Mrs. Harker waiting us, with an appearance of cheerfulness which did honour to her bravery and unselfishness. When she saw our faces, her own became as pale as death: for a second or two her eyes were closed as if she were in secret prayer; and then she said cheerfully:—
vi: Anyway, we need to return soon to put her at ease.
tr: We returned to my home, where we saw Ms. Harker waiting for us with a cheerful appearance that honored her courage and generosity with sorrowful hearts. When she saw our faces, her own face turned deathly pale; for a second or two, her eyes closed as if she were secretly praying, and then she spoke with joy:
es: Full of sadness, we returned to my house, where we found Mrs. Harker waiting for us, with a cheerful appearance that honored her courage and spirit of cooperation. When she saw our faces, her own became as pale as a corpse's: for one or two seconds, she remained with her eyes closed, as if praying in secret and then said kindly:

en: “I can never thank you all enough. Oh, my poor darling!” As she spoke, she took her husband’s grey head in her hands and kissed it—“Lay your poor head here and rest it. All will yet be well, dear! God will protect us if He so will it in His good intent.” The poor fellow groaned. There was no place for words in his sublime misery.
vi: But remember, don't discourage her! We only have to find one more wooden crate. If we succeed, everything can still be salvaged. I understand you are trying to comfort Harker, as he looks more disappointed now than ever before. Occasionally, he groans, perhaps thinking about his unfortunate wife. We returned home in a gloomy mood.
tr: “No matter how much I thank you, it won't be enough. Ah, my poor darling!” While speaking, she took her husband's graying head in her hands and kissed it - “Rest your poor head here and relax. Everything will be alright, my love! If we wish for it with good intentions, God will protect us.” The poor man only groaned. There was no room for words in the great pain he was enduring.
es: –I will never be able to thank you enough for what you have done. Oh, my poor husband! – while she spoke, she took her husband's grayish head in her hands and kissed it-. Rest your poor head here and relax. Everything will be fine now, dear! God will protect us, if He so wishes. The poor man grunted. There was no room for words amidst his sublime sadness.

en: We had a sort of perfunctory supper together, and I think it cheered us all up somewhat. It was, perhaps, the mere animal heat of food to hungry people—for none of us had eaten anything since breakfast—or the sense of companionship may have helped us; but anyhow we were all less miserable, and saw the morrow as not altogether without hope. True to our promise, we told Mrs. Harker everything which had passed; and although she grew snowy white at times when danger had seemed to threaten her husband, and red at others when his devotion to her was manifested, she listened bravely and with calmness. When we came to the part where Harker had rushed at the Count so recklessly, she clung to her husband’s arm, and held it tight as though her clinging could protect him from any harm that might come.
