She said nothing, however, till the narration was all done, and matters had been brought right up to the present time. Then without letting go her husband’s hand she stood up amongst us and spoke. Oh, that I could give any idea of the scene; of that sweet, sweet, good, good woman in all the radiant beauty of her youth and animation, with the red scar on her forehead, of which she was conscious, and which we saw with grinding of our teeth—remembering whence and how it came; her loving kindness against our grim hate; her tender faith against all our fears and doubting; and we, knowing that so far as symbols went, she with all her goodness and purity and faith, was outcast from God.
vi: We returned home in a gloomy mood. Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: We all had a haphazard meal together, and I think it somehow cheered us all up. Perhaps what helped us was the animal warmth of the meal in the eyes of hungry people—since none of us had eaten anything since breakfast—or the feeling of camaraderie; somehow, we were no longer as miserable as before and did not see tomorrow as hopeless. Staying true to our word, we told Ms. Mina everything that had happened, and although she paled even more at times when the danger seemed to threaten her husband and blushed at other moments when her husband's devotion to her was mentioned, she listened bravely and calmly. When we got to the part where Harker unhesitatingly attacked the Count, she clung to her husband's arm and held on tightly as if her grip could protect him from any danger that might come. But she did not say anything until the entire account was finished and the events were brought up to the present moment. Then, without letting go of her husband's hand, she stood up among us and spoke. Oh, how I wish I could convey the scene; that sweet, sweet, good, good woman standing in the radiant beauty of her youth and vitality, with the red scar on her forehead that she was aware of and that we—remembering where and how it came from—looked at with gritted teeth; her loving gentleness in the face of our relentless hatred; her compassionate faith despite all our fears and doubts; from what we could tell from the signs, all her goodness, purity, and faith were not wanted by God.
es: We dined together without appetite, and I believe that gave us all a certain encouragement. It was perhaps the simple animal warmth that food provides to hungry people, since none of us had eaten anything since breakfast time, or it is likely that feeling the camaraderie that reigned among us consoled us a bit, but, be that as it may, the fact is that we felt less sad afterward and were able to think about the future with some hope. Keeping our promise, we recounted to Mrs. Harker everything that had happened, and although she turned intensely pale at times, when her husband was in danger, and blushed at other times, when the devotion he felt for her was evident, she listened to the entire story bravely and remained calm. When we reached the moment when Harker had lunged at the count with such determination, she grasped her husband's arm tightly and remained that way, as if by holding his arm she could protect him from any danger he might have faced. However, she said nothing until the narration was finished and when she was fully aware of everything that had happened up to that precise moment, then, without letting go of her husband's hand, she stood up and spoke to us. I have no words to convey the scene. That extraordinary woman, sweet and good, with all the radiant beauty of her youth and her animation, with the reddish scar on her forehead, of which she was conscious and which we saw while clenching our teeth… remembering where, when, and how everything had happened; her adorable kindness rising against our sinister hatred; her tender faith against all our fears and doubts. And we knew that, as far as the symbols went, with all her goodness, purity, and faith, she was separated from God.

en: “Jonathan,” she said, and the word sounded like music on her lips it was so full of love and tenderness, “Jonathan dear, and you all my true, true friends, I want you to bear something in mind through all this dreadful time. I know that you must fight—that you must destroy even as you destroyed the false Lucy so that the true Lucy might live hereafter; but it is not a work of hate. That poor soul who has wrought all this misery is the saddest case of all. Just think what will be his joy when he, too, is destroyed in his worser part that his better part may have spiritual immortality. You must be pitiful to him, too, though it may not hold your hands from his destruction.”
vi: Mina was overjoyed to see us again, as if she had forgotten herself.
tr: “Jonathan,” she said, and the word rang on her lips like music; it was so full of love and tenderness! “Jonathan my dear, and all of you my true, true friends, I want you to keep one thing in mind throughout all this terrible time. I know you have to fight - just as you destroyed the false Lucy so that the real Lucy could live forever, you must destroy this too, but this is not a task of hatred. The poor man who caused all this is the saddest case of all. Think how he will rejoice when the bad side is destroyed so that the good side can attain spiritual immortality. Even if this does not stop you from destroying him, approach him with pity.”
es: –Jonathan -he said, and the word seemed to be music, because of the great love and tenderness he put into it-, my dear Jonathan and all of you, my wonderful friends, I want you to keep something in mind during all this terrible time. I know you have to fight..., that you must even destroy, as you destroyed the false Lucy, so that the true one could live afterwards; but it is not a work of hatred. That poor soul who has caused us so much harm is the saddest case of all. Imagine what his joy will be when he too is destroyed in his worst part, so that the best part can enjoy spiritual immortality. You must also have pity on him, even though that pity should not prevent your hands from carrying out his destruction.

en: As she spoke I could see her husband’s face darken and draw together, as though the passion in him were shrivelling his being to its core. Instinctively the clasp on his wife’s hand grew closer, till his knuckles looked white. She did not flinch from the pain which I knew she must have suffered, but looked at him with eyes that were more appealing than ever. As she stopped speaking he leaped to his feet, almost tearing his hand from hers as he spoke:—
vi: But when she saw the dejected faces of the men, her face suddenly turned pale. She closed her eyes as if silently praying for the best.
tr: While she was speaking, I could see her husband's face darken and his expression contort as if his passion had been drawn deep within him. Instinctively, he continued to squeeze his wife's hand until his knuckles turned white. His wife did not shy away from the pain, which I was sure she felt, but looked at him with eyes more alluring than ever. When his wife finished speaking, Harker stood up, almost tearing his hand away from hers, and said:
es: While she was speaking, I could see that her husband's face darkened and grew tense, as if the passion consuming him was destroying his entire being. Instinctively, his wife squeezed his hand even tighter, until her knuckles turned white. She didn't even blink from the pain that, I'm sure, she must have been suffering, but looked at him with more pleading eyes than ever. When she stopped speaking, her husband stood up abruptly, almost tearing his hand from hers, and said:

en: “May God give him into my hand just for long enough to destroy that earthly life of him which we are aiming at. If beyond it I could send his soul for ever and ever to burning hell I would do it!”
vi: She closed her eyes as if silently praying for the best. — You know that nothing I do can ever repay you?
tr: “I hope God leaves him in my hands long enough to destroy his earthly life as we intend. If beyond that, I could send his soul to Hell, burning in flames forever, I would do that too!”
es: –May God put him in my hands long enough to destroy his earthly life, which is what we are trying to do! If in addition to that I can send his soul to the burning hell for all eternity, I will gladly do it!

en: “Oh, hush! oh, hush! in the name of the good God. Don’t say such things, Jonathan, my husband; or you will crush me with fear and horror. Just think, my dear—I have been thinking all this long, long day of it—that ... perhaps ... some day ... I, too, may need such pity; and that some other like you—and with equal cause for anger—may deny it to me! Oh, my husband! my husband, indeed I would have spared you such a thought had there been another way; but I pray that God may not have treasured your wild words, except as the heart-broken wail of a very loving and sorely stricken man. Oh, God, let these poor white hairs go in evidence of what he has suffered, who all his life has done no wrong, and on whom so many sorrows have come.”
vi: Oh, my dear! - She said as she kissed her husband's forehead and his tousled hair. - Don't worry about anything anymore, let your mind be at ease for a moment. Everything will be alright, my love! God will protect us! Occasionally, I see Harker groaning, looking very aggrieved. Disappointment leaves him at a loss for words to express his feelings.
tr: “Ah, Jesus! Ah, Jesus! For God's sake. Don't say such things, Jonathan, my dear husband; or you will tear me apart with fear and horror. My love, maybe I too... one day... might need such pity -I have been thinking about this all day long- think about it; and think that someone else like you -someone with a reason for anger equal to yours- might deprive me of it! Oh, my dear husband! My dear husband, if there were another way, I would save you from such a thought, but I pray to God that he does not give too much value to your wild words and sees them as the broken-hearted cry of a man who loves deeply and suffers greatly. Oh, my God, see these white hairs as proof of the sufferings of this man who has done no evil throughout his life and has faced many sorrows.”
es: –Oh, enough, enough! In the name of God, do not say such things!, Jonathan, my husband, or you will make me collapse, a victim of fear and horror. Just think, dear...; I have been thinking about it all this long day..., that maybe... someday... I too might need that mercy, and that someone like you, with the same reasons to hate me, might deny it to me. Oh, my husband! My dear Jonathan! I would have wanted to spare you that thought if there had been another way, but I beg God not to take your words into account and to consider them as the lament of a man who loves and has a broken heart. Oh, my God! Let his poor white hairs be a testament to all he has suffered, he who in his whole life has harmed no one, and upon whom so many sorrows have accumulated!

en: We men were all in tears now. There was no resisting them, and we wept openly. She wept, too, to see that her sweeter counsels had prevailed. Her husband flung himself on his knees beside her, and putting his arms round her, hid his face in the folds of her dress. Van Helsing beckoned to us and we stole out of the room, leaving the two loving hearts alone with their God.
vi: As usual, we took a short rest before sitting down to a soup prepared by the servants. Dinner helped us feel more alert, as we had only had a little to eat since breakfast. Keeping our promise, we recounted the entire story to Mina.
tr: All of us men were now in tears. There was no point in resisting them, and we openly cried. Seeing that her sweet thoughts were effective, Ms. Harker also cried. Her husband threw himself on his knees beside her and, wrapping his arms around his wife, buried his face in the folds of her dress. Van Helsing signaled to us, and we left the room, leaving the two loving hearts alone with their God.
es: All the men present already had our eyes filled with tears. We couldn't resist, and we cried openly. She also cried upon seeing that her sweet advice had prevailed. Her husband knelt by her side and, wrapping her in his arms, hid his face in the folds of her dress. Van Helsing made a sign to us, and we all left the room, leaving those two loving hearts alone with their God.

en: Before they retired the Professor fixed up the room against any coming of the Vampire, and assured Mrs. Harker that she might rest in peace. She tried to school herself to the belief, and, manifestly for her husband’s sake, tried to seem content. It was a brave struggle; and was, I think and believe, not without its reward. Van Helsing had placed at hand a bell which either of them was to sound in case of any emergency. When they had retired, Quincey, Godalming, and I arranged that we should sit up, dividing the night between us, and watch over the safety of the poor stricken lady. The first watch falls to Quincey, so the rest of us shall be off to bed as soon as we can. Godalming has already turned in, for his is the second watch. Now that my work is done I, too, shall go to bed.
vi: Keeping our promise, we recounted the entire story to Mina. Clearly, she was just as disappointed as we were, as she occasionally turned pale while listening to us. I had told the whole story, and the only thing I could do now was go to sleep.
tr: Before they went to bed, the Professor prepared their rooms against the possibility of the Vampire entering and assured Ms. Harker that she could sleep peacefully. She tried to accustom herself to this belief and clearly tried to appear pleased for her husband's sake. This was a brave struggle; I think and believe that it was not without its reward. Van Helsing had placed a bell within reach that either of them could ring in case of any emergency. When they retired to bed, Quincey, Godalming, and I decided to divide the night among ourselves, staying awake and keeping an eye on the poor distressed lady. The first watch falls to Quincey, so the rest of us should go to bed as early as possible. Godalming has already gone to bed since the second watch is his. Now that my work is done, I can go to bed as well.
es: Before they retired to their rooms, the professor prepared the room to protect it from any vampire incursions, and assured Mrs. Harker that she could rest in peace. She tried to convince herself of this and, to calm her husband, pretended to be content. It was a valiant struggle and I want to believe it was not without reward. Van Helsing had placed a bell near them that any of them should ring in case any eventuality occurred. When they retired, Quincey, Godalming, and I agreed that we should stay awake, dividing the night among the three of us, to watch over the poor lady and ensure her safety. The first watch fell to Quincey, so the rest of us should go to bed as soon as possible. Godalming has already gone to bed, as he has the second watch. Now that I have finished my work, I too must go to bed.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 3-4 October, close to midnight.—I thought yesterday would never end. There was over me a yearning for sleep, in some sort of blind belief that to wake would be to find things changed, and that any change must now be for the better. Before we parted, we discussed what our next step was to be, but we could arrive at no result. All we knew was that one earth-box remained, and that the Count alone knew where it was. If he chooses to lie hidden, he may baffle us for years; and in the meantime!—the thought is too horrible, I dare not think of it even now. This I know: that if ever there was a woman who was all perfection, that one is my poor wronged darling. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet pity of last night, a pity that made my own hate of the monster seem despicable. Surely God will not permit the world to be the poorer by the loss of such a creature. This is hope to me. We are all drifting reefwards now, and faith is our only anchor. Thank God! Mina is sleeping, and sleeping without dreams. I fear what her dreams might be like, with such terrible memories to ground them in. She has not been so calm, within my seeing, since the sunset. Then, for a while, there came over her face a repose which was like spring after the blasts of March. I thought at the time that it was the softness of the red sunset on her face, but somehow now I think it has a deeper meaning. I am not sleepy myself, though I am weary—weary to death. However, I must try to sleep; for there is to-morrow to think of, and there is no rest for me until....
vi: • October 3 - 4, after midnight It seemed like yesterday would never end. There was something urging me to fall asleep, a vague belief telling me that when I woke up, I would witness a change and from now on, everything would change favorably for us. Before wishing each other good night, we had a discussion about the next step but did not come to any conclusion. All we knew was: there was still a wooden crate where the old count could hide, and only he knew where it was hidden. If he chose to remain in hiding, he would force us to fail for many years, but what we needed right now... The prospect before us was truly terrifying, making me afraid to make any guesses. I am not sure about one thing, that is if there ever was a perfect woman, but with a tragic fate, it would be my beloved wife. The more I thought, the more I loved her to the point of heartache and the more I hated that demon a thousand times over. Surely God would not let this world be impoverished by the loss of a creation like her. So within me surged a hope of certain victory. Now we are lost and have only one anchor left, which is faith. Thank God, Mina slept without any troubling dreams. I am very afraid of what might be in her dreams stemming from her terrifying memories. Since dusk until now, I have not seen her show any signs of pain or distress. In a moment, I recognized the peace on her face, like the spring weather after the sudden rains of March... I did not feel sleepy, even though I felt utterly exhausted. However, I forced myself to sleep, needing to think about tomorrow. I will not be at ease until...
tr: 3-4 October, near midnight. - I thought yesterday would never end. I fell asleep with a blind belief that everything would be different when I woke up and that any change would now be for the better. Before parting, we discussed what our next step would be, but we couldn't reach a conclusion. All we knew was that there was one more of the earth boxes and only the Count knew where it was. If he chose to hide, he could keep us at bay for years, and in the meantime... The thought is so terrifying that I dare not even think of it now. This I know: If there is a perfectly virtuous woman, it is my poor, wronged beloved. Because of the sweet pity I felt last night—a pity so profound that it made even my hatred for the monster seem base—I love her a thousand times more. God will surely not allow the world to become more wretched by losing such a creature. This is my hope. Now we are all caught in the current, heading towards the shallow rocks, and faith is our only assurance. Thank God! Mina is sleeping and not dreaming. I fear what her dreams might be like, based on such terrible memories. From what I can see, she hasn't been very calm since sunset. Then, for a while, a peace settled on her face, like the calm that follows the sudden winds of March. At the time, I thought it was the softness of the red sunset falling on her face, but now I think it has a deeper meaning somehow. Despite being very exhausted—dead tired—I am not sleepy. But I must try to sleep because there is a tomorrow I need to think about, and there is no peace for me until then...
es: October 3-4, near midnight. I thought yesterday would never end. I had the desire to fall asleep, hoping that upon waking I would discover that things had changed and that all changes would henceforth be for the better. Before we parted ways, we discussed what our next step should be, but we couldn't reach any conclusion. The only thing we knew was that there was still one box of earth left and that only the count knew where it was. If he wishes to remain hidden, he can confuse us for years on end and, in the meantime, the thought is too horrible; I cannot allow myself to think about it at this moment. What I do know is that if there has ever been an absolutely perfect woman, it is my beloved and wounded wife. I love her a thousand times more for her sweet compassion last night; a compassion that made even the hatred I have for the monster seem despicable. I am sure that God will not allow the world to be impoverished by the loss of such a creature. That is a hope for me. We are all heading towards the rocks, and hope is the only anchor I have left. Thank God, Mina is asleep and not having nightmares. I dread to think what her nightmares could be, with such terrible memories that could provoke them. She hasn't been this calm, as far as I could see, since sunset. Then, for a moment, a calm spread over her face, like spring after the storms of March. I thought at that moment that it must be the reflection of the sunset on her face, but, in some way, I now know that it was something much deeper. I am not sleepy myself, although I am tired... Terribly tired. However, I must try to fall asleep, as I have to think about tomorrow, and that there will be no rest for me until...

en: Later.—I must have fallen asleep, for I was awaked by Mina, who was sitting up in bed, with a startled look on her face. I could see easily, for we did not leave the room in darkness; she had placed a warning hand over my mouth, and now she whispered in my ear:—
vi: • A moment later I must have fallen asleep, for I was just awakened when Mina startled awake in a panic. I easily noticed a faint light in the room. She covered my mouth with her hand and whispered into my ear:
tr: Later. - I must have fallen asleep, because Mina, who was sitting in the middle of the bed with a surprised expression on her face, woke me up. I could easily see this because I hadn't left the room dark; she put her hand to my mouth as if to warn me and whispered in my ear: "Shhh!
es: Later. I must have fallen asleep, as I was awakened by Mina, who was sitting on the bed with an expression full of astonishment on her face. I could see clearly, because we had not left the room in darkness; Mina had placed her hand over my mouth and whispered in my ear:

en: “Hush! there is someone in the corridor!” I got up softly, and crossing the room, gently opened the door.
vi: — Do you hear anything? It seems like there's someone in the hallway? I sat up, tiptoed across the room, and gently opened the door to peek outside.
tr: There's someone in the corridor!" I got up slowly and, crossing the room lengthwise, gently opened the door.
es: –Shh! There's someone in the hallway! I cautiously got up and, crossing the room, opened the door without making a sound.

en: Just outside, stretched on a mattress, lay Mr. Morris, wide awake. He raised a warning hand for silence as he whispered to me:—
vi: Morris was still lying awake on a mattress. Seeing me, he gestured for silence:
tr: Just outside, lying on a mattress awake, Mr. Morris was lying. While speaking in a whisper, he raised his hand for me to be quiet:
es: Crossed at the threshold, lying on a mattress, was Mr. Morris, completely awake. He raised a hand to impose silence on me, and whispered:

en: “Hush! go back to bed; it is all right. One of us will be here all night. We don’t mean to take any chances!”
vi: — Shh! Go back to sleep. Everything will be fine. We have to take turns staying awake to watch over you, because no one wants any more accidents to happen.
tr: "Shh! Go back to your bed; everything is fine. One of us will stay here all night. We have no intention of leaving anything to chance!"
es: –Silence! Go back to bed; nothing is happening. One of us will stay here all night. We don't want to take any risks!

en: His look and gesture forbade discussion, so I came back and told Mina. She sighed and positively a shadow of a smile stole over her poor, pale face as she put her arms round me and said softly:—
vi: His gestures and gaze forced me to remain silent, and I could only turn around and whisper his words to Mina. She sighed in relief, wrapped her arms tightly around me, and said affectionately:
tr: His gaze and hand gesture left no room for argument, so I returned and told Mina what had happened. Mina sighed, and as she wrapped her arms around me, a shadow of a smile spread across her poor, pale face, and she said:
es: His expression and gesture prevented any discussion, so I lay back down and told Mina what was happening. She sighed and the shadow of a smile appeared on her pale face, as she wrapped her arms around me and said softly:

en: “Oh, thank God for good brave men!” With a sigh she sank back again to sleep. I write this now as I am not sleepy, though I must try again.
vi: — Thank God for the kindness and courage of our friends! She sighed in relief and continued to bury her head in a peaceful sleep. I took the opportunity to write a few more lines, because who knows, I might quickly fall asleep like her.
tr: “Ah, thank God for my good, brave men!” He sighed and lay down to sleep again. Although I should try to sleep again, I am writing these now because I am not sleepy.
es: –Oh, I give thanks to God for all the good men! He sighed and lay back down on his back, trying to fall asleep again. I am writing this now because I am not sleepy, although I will also try to fall asleep.

en: 4 October, morning.—Once again during the night I was wakened by Mina. This time we had all had a good sleep, for the grey of the coming dawn was making the windows into sharp oblongs, and the gas flame was like a speck rather than a disc of light. She said to me hurriedly:—
vi: • October 4, morning Mina woke me up again in the middle of the night. But in the end, we had a really full sleep, because when I woke up, I saw the dawn light outlining faint lines through the gaps in the wooden window frames, and the gas lamp was just a small, weak dot. As soon as she opened her eyes, Mina told me:
tr: 4 October, morning. - I was woken up by Mina once again during the night. This time we all had a good sleep, because the approaching dawn's grayness was turning the windows into sharp rectangles, and the flame of the gas lamp resembled a speck more than a circle of light. She hurriedly said to me: "Go, call the Professor.
es: October 4th, in the morning. Mina woke me up again during the night. This time, we had both slept well, as the dawn light was already faintly illuminating the windows, and the gas lamp was more like a point than a disc of light. "Go find the professor," he told me hastily.

en: “Go, call the Professor. I want to see him at once.”
vi: — Go find the professor! I want to meet him right now.
tr: She hurriedly said to me: "Go, call the Professor. I want to see him immediately."
es: "Go find the professor," he told me hastily. "I want to see him immediately."

en: “Why?” I asked.
vi: — But for what purpose?
tr: “Why?” I asked.
es: –Why? – I asked him.

en: “I have an idea. I suppose it must have come in the night, and matured without my knowing it. He must hypnotise me before the dawn, and then I shall be able to speak. Go quick, dearest; the time is getting close.” I went to the door. Dr. Seward was resting on the mattress, and, seeing me, he sprang to his feet.
vi: — I have an idea. An idea that randomly came up in the night and matured even before I woke up. I want to be hypnotized before a new day truly begins, only then can I speak it out. Hurry up, time is running out. I rushed out of the room. The first person I met was Dr. Seward. As soon as he saw me, he immediately jumped towards me, his voice full of panic:
tr: "I have an idea. It must have come to me at night and matured without me realizing it. You must hypnotize me before dawn, then I can speak. Go quickly, my love; time is running out." I went to the door. Dr. Seward was resting on the mattress and jumped up when he saw me.
es: –I have an idea. I suppose it must have come to me during the night, and it has matured without me realizing it. You must hypnotize me before dawn, and then I will be able to speak. Hurry, dear; there isn't much time left. I went to the door and saw Dr. Seward lying on the mattress, and when he saw me, he jumped to his feet.

en: “Is anything wrong?” he asked, in alarm.
vi: — What's going on! Another bad thing...?
tr: “Is there a problem?” he asked fearfully.
es: –Is something wrong? – he asked me, alarmed.

en: “No,” I replied; “but Mina wants to see Dr. Van Helsing at once.”
vi: — No, but Mina wants to see Dr. Van Helsing right now. — Let me call him for you.
tr: “No,” I replied; “but Mina wants to see Dr. Van Helsing immediately.”
es: –No -I replied-, but Mina wishes to see Dr. Van Helsing immediately.

en: “I will go,” he said, and hurried into the Professor’s room.
vi: Before finishing the sentence, he was already seen running quickly to the professor's office.
tr: “I will go,” he said and ran to the Professor's room.
es: Two or three minutes later, Van Helsing was in the room, in his nightclothes, and Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming were at the door, with Dr. Seward, asking questions.

en: In two or three minutes later Van Helsing was in the room in his dressing-gown, and Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming were with Dr. Seward at the door asking questions. When the Professor saw Mina smile—a positive smile ousted the anxiety of his face; he rubbed his hands as he said:—
vi: About two or three minutes later, Van Helsing appeared in my room in his nightclothes. Morris and Lord Godalming also just ran to the door to ask Dr. Seward what was happening. — Mina, you look so different!
tr: Within two or three minutes, Van Helsing was in the room with his dressing gown on; Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming were standing at the door with Dr. Seward, asking questions. When the Professor saw Mina smiling - a happy smile that wiped the worry off the Professor's face - the Professor rubbed his hands together and said:
es: Two or three minutes later, Van Helsing was in the room, in his nightclothes, and Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming were at the door, with Dr. Seward, asking questions. When the professor saw Mina, a smile, a genuine smile, caused the anxiety to leave his face; he rubbed his hands, and said:

en: “Oh, my dear Madam Mina, this is indeed a change. See! friend Jonathan, we have got our dear Madam Mina, as of old, back to us to-day!” Then turning to her, he said, cheerfully: “And what am I do for you? For at this hour you do not want me for nothings.”
vi: Look at that, my friend Jonathan, today we get to see a completely different Mina, just like the Mina from the old days! After a few friendly greetings, as if to ease the tension he had just sensed, he gently asked my wife: — What can I do to help you? Why do you want to meet me at this hour?
tr: “Ah, dear Madam Mina, this is truly a great change. Look, my friend Jonathan! Our old dear Madam Mina has returned to us today as she used to be!” Then, turning to Mina, he spoke cheerfully: “Well, what can I do for you? Because you wouldn't have called me at this hour for something trivial.”
es: –My dear Mrs. Mina! What a change! Look! Friend Jonathan, we have recovered our dear Mrs. Mina again, as before! – then, he turned to her and said kindly-: And what can I do for you? I suppose you haven't called me at this hour for nothing.

en: “I want you to hypnotise me!” she said. “Do it before the dawn, for I feel that then I can speak, and speak freely. Be quick, for the time is short!” Without a word he motioned her to sit up in bed.
vi: — I intend to ask you to hypnotize me. - Mina explained. - Please do it before the sun rises, because I feel that now is the moment when I can speak and speak very comfortably. Please hurry! We have very little time left. Van Helsing did not say another word but gestured for Mina to sit on the bed.
tr: "I want you to hypnotize me!" she said. "Do it before dawn because that's when I feel I can talk, talk freely. Be quick because time is short!" The Professor, without saying anything, gestured for Mina to sit on the bed.
es: –I want you to hypnotize me! – said Mina -. Do it before dawn, as I believe that then I will be able to speak freely. Hurry; we don't have much time left! Without saying a word, the professor indicated for him to take a seat on the bed.

en: Looking fixedly at her, he commenced to make passes in front of her, from over the top of her head downward, with each hand in turn. Mina gazed at him fixedly for a few minutes, during which my own heart beat like a trip hammer, for I felt that some crisis was at hand. Gradually her eyes closed, and she sat, stock still; only by the gentle heaving of her bosom could one know that she was alive. The Professor made a few more passes and then stopped, and I could see that his forehead was covered with great beads of perspiration. Mina opened her eyes; but she did not seem the same woman. There was a far-away look in her eyes, and her voice had a sad dreaminess which was new to me. Raising his hand to impose silence, the Professor motioned to me to bring the others in. They came on tip-toe, closing the door behind them, and stood at the foot of the bed, looking on. Mina appeared not to see them. The stillness was broken by Van Helsing’s voice speaking in a low level tone which would not break the current of her thoughts:—
vi: He looked straight into her eyes and began to hypnotize her with continuous hand movements up and down. Mina stared intently into his eyes for a few minutes... My heart was pounding as if sensing an impending decisive moment. She remained motionless, her eyes gradually closing, with only the rise and fall of her chest with each steady breath indicating that she was alive. The professor continued to wave his hands a few more times before stopping, his forehead drenched in sweat. Mina suddenly opened her eyes, but she truly looked like a completely different woman. Her voice sounded so sad, vague, and distant - something I had never seen in her before - and her eyes seemed to be gazing into some void. The professor raised his finger to his lips, signaling me to keep silent, and told the two people standing outside the door to step into the room. They tiptoed closer to Mina's bed after gently closing the door. It seemed as though she did not recognize them. Van Helsing broke the silence with a gentle and steady voice so as not to disrupt her train of thought.
tr: Fixing her eyes on him, she began to move both her hands from the top of her head down in front of Mina's face, one after the other. Mina stared at the Professor for a minute or two; during this time, my heart was pounding like a hammer because I felt a crisis was approaching. Gradually, Mina's eyes closed and she sat completely still; it was only from the slight rise and fall of her chest that one could tell she was alive. The Professor made a few more passes and then stopped; I could see that his forehead was covered with large beads of sweat. Mina opened her eyes, but she did not look like the same woman. There was a distant look in her eyes and a sad, sleepy tone in her voice that was new to me. With a gesture asking for silence, the Professor raised his hand and signaled me to bring the others inside. They entered on tiptoe, closing the door behind them, and stood at the foot of the bed, watching. Mina seemed not to have seen them. The silence was broken by Van Helsing speaking in a low tone so as not to disrupt Mina's train of thought:
es: He stared at her intently and began making magnetic passes in front of her, from the top of my wife's head, downwards, with both hands, repeating the movements several times. Mina stared at him intently for a few minutes, during which my heart beat like a hammer, because I felt that some crisis was about to occur soon. Gradually, her eyes began to close and she remained seated, absolutely motionless. Only by the rise and fall of her chest, in rhythm with her breathing, could it be seen that she was alive. The professor made a few more passes and stopped; then I saw that his forehead was covered with thick drops of sweat. Mina opened her eyes, but she did not seem to be the same woman. There was an expression of emptiness in her eyes, as if her gaze was lost in the distance, and her voice had an infinite sadness that was new to me. Raising his hand to impose silence, the professor gestured for me to let the others in. They all entered on tiptoe, closing the door behind them and remained standing near the bed, watching attentively. Mina did not seem to see them. The silence was interrupted by Professor Van Helsing, speaking in a very low tone of voice, so as not to interrupt the course of my wife's thoughts:

en: “Where are you?” The answer came in a neutral way:—
vi: — Where are you? She answered in an indistinct voice:
tr: “Where are you?” The answer came naturally: “I don't know.
es: –Where are you located? The response was given in an absolutely inflectionless tone:

en: “I do not know. Sleep has no place it can call its own.” For several minutes there was silence. Mina sat rigid, and the Professor stood staring at her fixedly; the rest of us hardly dared to breathe. The room was growing lighter; without taking his eyes from Mina’s face, Dr. Van Helsing motioned me to pull up the blind. I did so, and the day seemed just upon us. A red streak shot up, and a rosy light seemed to diffuse itself through the room. On the instant the Professor spoke again:—
vi: — I don't know. Sleep has no place to be named. The atmosphere of silence lasted for a few minutes. Mina remained still like a statue. The professor stood up and looked intently into her eyes, while the others seemed to be holding their breath. A new day was about to begin. Without taking his eyes off Mina, Van Helsing gestured for me to pull up the window curtains. A pale pink light flooded into the room. He continued:
tr: The answer came naturally: “I don't know. Sleep has no place of its own.” There was a few minutes of silence. Mina stood perfectly still and upright, and the Professor stood with his eyes fixed on her; the rest of us barely dared to breathe. The room was gradually getting brighter; Dr. Van Helsing, without taking his eyes off Mina's face, signaled me to lift the curtain. I did so, and the day appeared right above us. The red horizon was rising rapidly, and a pink light spread through the room. At that moment, the Professor spoke again: “Where are you now?”
es: –I don't know. The dream has no place that can be considered real. For several minutes, silence reigned. Mina continued to sit rigidly, and the professor stared at her intently; the rest of us barely dared to breathe. The room was becoming clearer and clearer. Without taking his eyes off Mina's face, the professor gestured for me to draw the curtains, and the day seemed to envelop us all. A reddish streak appeared, and a pink light spread throughout the room. At that moment, the professor spoke again:

en: “Where are you now?” The answer came dreamily, but with intention; it were as though she were interpreting something. I have heard her use the same tone when reading her shorthand notes.
vi: — Where are you now? Mina answered slowly as if she were deep in thought, seemingly trying to decipher something.
tr: At that moment, the Professor spoke again: “Where are you now?” The answer came as if in a dream but consciously; it was as if something was being interpreted. I had heard the same tone of voice when reading notes written in shorthand.
es: –Where are you now? The response was somnambulant, but with intention; it was as if she were interpreting something. I have heard her use the same tone of voice when reading her shorthand notes.

en: “I do not know. It is all strange to me!”
vi: — I don't know. Everything is very strange to me right now!
tr: “I don't know. They are all strangers to me!”
es: –I don't know. It's an absolutely unknown place to me!

en: “What do you see?”
vi: — What did you see?
tr: “What do you see?”
es: –What do you see?

en: “I can see nothing; it is all dark.”
vi: — Can't see anything, everything is pitch dark. — So, did you hear anything?
tr: "I can't see anything; everywhere is dark."
es: –I can't see anything; it's all dark.

en: “What do you hear?” I could detect the strain in the Professor’s patient voice.
vi: Through Van Helsing's patient tone, I guessed he was very tense.
tr: "What do you hear?" I could detect the tension in the Professor's patient voice.
es: –What do you hear? I noticed the tension in the patient voice of the professor.

en: “The lapping of water. It is gurgling by, and little waves leap. I can hear them on the outside.”
vi: — The splashing sound, of water... very close by... and the small undulating waves... I hear those sounds outside...
tr: “The splashing of the water. The water is roaring and small waves are splashing. I can hear their sounds from outside.”
es: –The sound of water. The sound of the surf and small waves crashing can be heard. I can hear them outside.

en: “Then you are on a ship?” We all looked at each other, trying to glean something each from the other. We were afraid to think. The answer came quick:—
vi: — So, you are on a ship? We exchanged glances, hoping to catch a glimpse of each other's thoughts, everyone afraid to think about the situation beforehand. Mina responded very quickly:
tr: "So you are on the ship, right?" We all looked at each other, trying to understand something. We were afraid to think. The answer came quickly:
es: –So, are you on a boat? We all looked at each other, trying to understand something. We were afraid to think. The answer came quickly:

en: “Oh, yes!”
vi: — Exactly!
tr: “Ah, yes!”
es: –Oh, yes!

en: “What else do you hear?”
vi: — Did you hear anything else?
tr: “What else do you hear?”
es: –What else do you hear?

en: “The sound of men stamping overhead as they run about. There is the creaking of a chain, and the loud tinkle as the check of the capstan falls into the rachet.”
vi: — The sound of hurried footsteps above my head. There was the clanking of chains and the resonant clicking of the winch axle.
tr: “The footsteps of the men running above. The creak of a chain and the loud clatter as the windlass chain unwinds.”
es: –Noise of footsteps of men running from one side to the other. I also hear the noise of a chain and a great clatter, when the control of the winch falls into the ratchet.

en: “What are you doing?”
vi: — So, what are you doing?
tr: "What are you doing?"
es: –What are you doing?

en: “I am still—oh, so still. It is like death!” The voice faded away into a deep breath as of one sleeping, and the open eyes closed again.
vi: — I am at peace... Oh! Very peaceful! Peaceful like a corpse. She suddenly fell silent, let out a long sigh, and closed her eyes tightly.
tr: "I am not moving - oh, I am not moving at all. I am like a dead person!" His voice faded, turning into the deep breath of someone sleeping, and his open eyes closed again.
es: –I am motionless; absolutely motionless. It's something like death! The voice faded, turning into a deep sigh, like someone who is asleep, and their eyes closed again.

en: By this time the sun had risen, and we were all in the full light of day. Dr. Van Helsing placed his hands on Mina’s shoulders, and laid her head down softly on her pillow. She lay like a sleeping child for a few moments, and then, with a long sigh, awoke and stared in wonder to see us all around her. “Have I been talking in my sleep?” was all she said. She seemed, however, to know the situation without telling, though she was eager to know what she had told. The Professor repeated the conversation, and she said:—
vi: At this moment, the sun had risen, and a new day began. Dr. Van Helsing placed his hand on Mina's shoulder and gently laid her down on the pillow. She lay still for a long time like a sleeping child, and after letting out a long sigh, she suddenly sat up and looked at the people around her, appearing very surprised. But she only asked one question: — Have I told everyone about my dream yet? However, it seemed she understood our silence, even though she was very eager to know what she had just said. The professor recounted the story to Mina, causing her to exclaim:
tr: Meanwhile, the sun had risen, and we were all in the light of day. Dr. Van Helsing placed his hands on Mina's shoulders and gently laid her head on the pillow. For a few seconds, she lay there sleeping like a child, and then, with a long sigh, she woke up and looked at us standing around her with curious eyes. The only thing she said was, "Did I talk in my sleep?" But she seemed to know the situation without us explaining; however, she was eager to know what she had said. The professor repeated the conversation that had taken place, and Mina said:
es: But this time the sun had already risen and we all found ourselves in broad daylight. Dr. Van Helsing placed his hands on Mina's shoulders and made her head rest gently on the pillows. She remained for a few moments like a sleeping child and then, with a long sigh, woke up and was very surprised to see us all gathered around her. –Did I talk in my sleep? – was all he said. However, she seemed to understand the situation without speaking, as she was anxious to know what had been said. The professor repeated the conversation to her, and Mina said to him:

en: “Then there is not a moment to lose: it may not be yet too late!” Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming started for the door but the Professor’s calm voice called them back:—
vi: — Then don't waste another moment! It might not be too late yet! Quincey Morris and the lord rushed to the door, but Van Helsing calmly called them back:
tr: "Then there is not a single second to lose; it might not be too late yet!" Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming moved towards the door, but the Professor's calm voice called them back:
es: –Then, there is no time to lose. It is possible that it is not too late yet! Mr. Morris and Lord Godalming headed towards the door, but the professor's calm voice called them back and made them retrace their steps:

en: “Stay, my friends. That ship, wherever it was, was weighing anchor whilst she spoke. There are many ships weighing anchor at the moment in your so great Port of London. Which of them is it that you seek? God be thanked that we have once again a clue, though whither it may lead us we know not. We have been blind somewhat; blind after the manner of men, since when we can look back we see what we might have seen looking forward if we had been able to see what we might have seen! Alas, but that sentence is a puddle; is it not? We can know now what was in the Count’s mind, when he seize that money, though Jonathan’s so fierce knife put him in the danger that even he dread. He meant escape. Hear me, ESCAPE! He saw that with but one earth-box left, and a pack of men following like dogs after a fox, this London was no place for him. He have take his last earth-box on board a ship, and he leave the land. He think to escape, but no! we follow him. Tally Ho! as friend Arthur would say when he put on his red frock! Our old fox is wily; oh! so wily, and we must follow with wile. I, too, am wily and I think his mind in a little while. In meantime we may rest and in peace, for there are waters between us which he do not want to pass, and which he could not if he would—unless the ship were to touch the land, and then only at full or slack tide. See, and the sun is just rose, and all day to sunset is to us. Let us take bath, and dress, and have breakfast which we all need, and which we can eat comfortably since he be not in the same land with us.” Mina looked at him appealingly as she asked:—
vi: — Wait a minute, everyone! That ship, even if it exists, has already set sail. Indeed, at this moment, there are ships setting sail from the port of London. But do you know which ship to look for? Thank God we have this information, even though we don't know where the ship is headed. Sometimes we are blind, as blind as mere mortals. Now we understand why the count was so determined to gather those banknotes even when Jonathan threatened him with a knife. He wants to flee, flee from England! He has only one crate containing filthy earth that can protect him, with many people hunting him like hounds chasing a fox. He has thrown that remaining crate of earth onto the ship and abandoned this country. He intends to escape us, but no, we will pursue him! He is truly cunning, and it is because of this cunning that we must track his footsteps. So am I, I am no less cunning, I understand his thoughts very well. In the meantime, we can rest comfortably without worry, for the sea has separated us from him. Come on! The sun is up, the whole day, until dusk, is ours. Take a bath, rest, and then have a little breakfast to feel better, for the count is no longer on the same ground as us. Mina looked at the professor with a pleading gaze:
tr: “Wait, my friends. Wherever that ship is, it was setting sail while Madam Mina was speaking. There are many ships currently setting sail in your Great London Port. Which one are you looking for? Thank God, even though we don't know where it will take us, we have another clue once again. We were partly blind; blind because of people's attitudes, because if it was possible for us to have seen what we might have seen, when we look back, we see what we can see when we look forward. Alas! But this sentence turned out like mud; didn't it? Despite Jonathan's furious knife scaring him, we now know what went through the Count's mind as he grabbed that money. He is thinking of escaping. Listen to me, ESCAPING! With only one remaining soil box and a pack of men chasing him like dogs chasing a fox, he realized that this London is not a place for him. He loaded his last soil box onto a ship and left the country. He thinks of escaping, but no! We are going after him. As our friend Arthur would say when he puts on his red coat, Tally Ho! Our fox is cunning, ah! So cunning that we must also pursue him cunningly. I am also cunning, and I will think with his mind for a while. During this time, we can rest and be at peace because there are waters between us that he does not want to cross and cannot cross even if he wanted to - of course, unless the ship runs aground and this can only happen at full or slack tide. Look, the sun has just risen, and we have the whole day until sunset. Let's bathe, dress, and have the breakfast we need and can comfortably eat because it is not on the same soil as us.” Mina looked at him with touching eyes as she asked him a question:
es: –Stay, my friends. That ship, wherever it may be, was weighing anchor while the lady was speaking. There are many ships weighing anchor at this moment, in the great port of London. Which one are we looking for? Thank God we have clues again, even if we don't know where they will lead us. We have been somewhat blind, in a very human way, since looking back, we see what we could have seen by looking forward, if we had been able to see what was possible to see! Wow! That sentence is a puzzle, isn't it? We can now understand what the count was thinking when he collected the money, when the knife wielded in anger by Jonathan put him in a danger he still fears. He wanted to flee. Listen to me: FLEE! He realized that with only one box of earth at his disposal and a group of men chasing him like dogs after a fox, London was not a very healthy place for him. Onward!, as our friend Arthur would say, putting on his red coat for the hunt. Our old fox is cunning, very cunning, and we must hunt him with wit. I am also cunning and I will think about him shortly. Meanwhile, let us rest in peace, since there are waters between us that he does not like to cross and could not do so even if he wanted to... Unless the ship docked and, in that case, he could only do so during high tide or low tide. Furthermore, the sun has risen and the whole day belongs to us, until sunset. Let's bathe and get dressed. Then, we will have breakfast, as we all really need it. Furthermore, we will be able to eat in peace, since the monster is not on the same land as us. Mina looked at him pleadingly, while asking:

en: “But why need we seek him further, when he is gone away from us?” He took her hand and patted it as he replied:—
vi: — But why are we not chasing him anymore? Is it because he has left us far behind? The professor held her hand as if to comfort her:
tr: "But if it has moved away from us, why do we need to keep searching for it?" The professor held his hand and gently tapped while answering his question:
es: –But why do you need to keep looking for him, if he has distanced himself from us? The professor took her hand and patted it while responding:

en: “Ask me nothings as yet. When we have breakfast, then I answer all questions.” He would say no more, and we separated to dress.
vi: — Don't ask anymore, dear Mina. After lunch, I will answer all your questions. He didn't say anything more.
tr: “Don't ask me any questions for now. I will answer all the questions when we have breakfast.” He didn't say anything else and we left to get dressed.
es: –Don't ask me anything about it for the moment. After breakfast, I will answer your questions. He refused to say anything more, and we all parted ways to get dressed.

en: After breakfast Mina repeated her question. He looked at her gravely for a minute and then said sorrowfully:—
vi: We each went back to our rooms to prepare for breakfast. After lunch, Mina repeated her question. Van Helsing looked at her intently for a moment before answering, his voice tinged with sadness:
tr: After breakfast, Mina repeated her question. The professor looked at her seriously for a moment and then said sadly:
es: After breakfast, Mina repeated her question. The professor looked at her gravely for a minute, and then responded in a very sad tone:

en: “Because my dear, dear Madam Mina, now more than ever must we find him even if we have to follow him to the jaws of Hell!” She grew paler as she asked faintly:—
vi: — Mina, more than ever, now is the time we must find him at all costs, even if this search leads us to hell. Mina asked insistently, her face turning pale:
tr: "Because, dear, dear Madam Mina, now, even if we have to follow him to the very mouth of hell, we must find him!" As she softly asked her question, Mina's face grew even paler:
es: –Because, my dear Mrs. Mina, now more than ever we must find him, even if we have to follow him to the very depths of hell! Mina became paler as she asked:

en: “Why?”
vi: — Why?
tr: “Why?”
es: –Why?

en: “Because,” he answered solemnly, “he can live for centuries, and you are but mortal woman. Time is now to be dreaded—since once he put that mark upon your throat.”
vi: — Because he can live for centuries, while sooner or later we are just corpses. Time is our enemy - ever since the old count placed this mark on your neck.
tr: “Because,” replied the Professor seriously, “he can live for centuries, but you are a mortal woman. We must now fear time - after he left that mark on your neck.”
es: –Because -responded van Helsing solemnly- he can live for several centuries, and you are merely a mortal woman. We must now fear time…, since it has already left that mark on your throat.

en: I was just in time to catch her as she fell forward in a faint.
vi: Van Helsing managed to reach out just in time to catch her before she collapsed, unconscious.
tr: I arrived just in time to catch Mina as she fainted and collapsed to the ground.
es: I barely had time to catch her in my arms when she fell forward, fainting.

en: CHAPTER XXIV
vi: CHAPTER 24
tr: XXIV
es: XXIV.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S PHONOGRAPH DIARY, SPOKEN BY VAN HELSING
vi: Van Helsing's message to Jonathan Harker (recorded via Dr. Seward's phonograph)
tr: Dr. Seward's phonograph diary, speaking Van Helsing
es: FROM THE PHONOGRAPHIC DIARY OF THE DOCTOR SEWARD, NARRATED BY VAN HELSING

en: THIS to Jonathan Harker.
vi: Van Helsing's message to Jonathan Harker (recorded via Dr. Seward's phonograph)
tr: This record is for Jonathan Harker.
es: This is for Jonathan Harker.

en: You are to stay with your dear Madam Mina. We shall go to make our search—if I can call it so, for it is not search but knowing, and we seek confirmation only. But do you stay and take care of her to-day. This is your best and most holiest office. This day nothing can find him here. Let me tell you that so you will know what we four know already, for I have tell them. He, our enemy, have gone away; he have gone back to his Castle in Transylvania. I know it so well, as if a great hand of fire wrote it on the wall. He have prepare for this in some way, and that last earth-box was ready to ship somewheres. For this he took the money; for this he hurry at the last, lest we catch him before the sun go down. It was his last hope, save that he might hide in the tomb that he think poor Miss Lucy, being as he thought like him, keep open to him. But there was not of time. When that fail he make straight for his last resource—his last earth-work I might say did I wish double entente. He is clever, oh, so clever! he know that his game here was finish; and so he decide he go back home. He find ship going by the route he came, and he go in it. We go off now to find what ship, and whither bound; when we have discover that, we come back and tell you all. Then we will comfort you and poor dear Madam Mina with new hope. For it will be hope when you think it over: that all is not lost. This very creature that we pursue, he take hundreds of years to get so far as London; and yet in one day, when we know of the disposal of him we drive him out. He is finite, though he is powerful to do much harm and suffers not as we do. But we are strong, each in our purpose; and we are all more strong together. Take heart afresh, dear husband of Madam Mina. This battle is but begun, and in the end we shall win—so sure as that God sits on high to watch over His children. Therefore be of much comfort till we return.
vi: "You should stay with your Mina. We will continue the investigation, if it can be called that, because we all know: we simply want a definite confirmation of the count's current status. Today, you don't need to do anything. That is the most worthwhile task for you at this moment. Today we didn't find him here, but I think it's necessary to tell you everything the four of us know. Dracula has gone, he is returning to his castle in Transylvania. He has had time to prepare everything, and the remaining box of earth is ready to be loaded onto a ship somewhere. Previously, he grabbed some money and ran because he was afraid we would catch up with him before sunset. That was his last hope, unless he had the chance to hide in Lucy's tomb, which he thought was still open. But he didn't have time. After being defeated, he planned to go straight back to his final lair. He is indeed clever! He understood the game was over here and he had no choice but to return to the place he had left. He knew he had to find a ship to escape. Now, we also have to find his ship. As soon as we complete the task, we will return to comfort you and your wife with new hope. It's not all over yet, Jonathan. The monster we are hunting took hundreds of years to reach London, yet in just one day we have driven him away. He has failed, although he is still strong enough to cause more harm. But we are not weak or cowardly. We are all determined to fight against his schemes, and our unity will give us a significant advantage over him. Be brave, dear friends! The battle has just begun, and victory will be ours. God above is always watching over each step of His children. Be patient and wait for our return.
tr: Dear Madam, you will stay by Mina's side. We are going to conduct our research - if I can call it research, because it is not research but a state of knowing, and we are only in pursuit of proof. But stay here today and take care of Madam Mina. This is your best and most sacred duty. Nothing can keep the Count here today. Allow me to tell you the things that the other four have already learned because I told them. Our enemy has gone far away; he has returned to his Castle in Transylvania. I know this as well as if it were written on the wall in fire. He prepared for this in some way, and the last soil box is waiting somewhere ready to be loaded onto a ship. He took the money for this; he hurried the last time for this so that we would not catch him before sunset. This was his only hope, apart from being able to hide in the grave of poor Miss Lucy, which he always thought would be open for him. But there was no time. When this failed, he resorted to his last chance - that is, to the last soil house, which I hope was a double entendre. So clever, ah! So clever! He knew his game here was over, and so he decided to return home. He will find a ship going in the direction he came from and board it. Now we are going to find that ship and its route; once we learn this, we will come back and tell you everything. Then we will relieve you and poor dear Madam Mina. Because this will give hope when you think everything is over: Not everything is lost. It took hundreds of years for this creature we are pursuing to come to London, and yet in one day, when we learn where he has settled, we are driving him out of here. Despite being strong enough to cause much harm and not suffering like us, his power is limited. But each of us is strong within our purpose, and together we become even stronger. Keep your heart at ease, dear husband of Madam Mina. The war has now begun, and in the end, we will definitely win - as certain as God sitting high above watching his children. So, be very at ease until we return.
es: You must stay with your dear Mrs. Mina. We must go to take care of our investigation... if I can call it that, since it is not an investigation, but something we already know, and we are only seeking confirmation. But you stay and take care of her today. That is the best and most sacred thing for all of us. In any case, the monster will not be able to appear today. Let me bring you up to date on what the four of us already know, because I have communicated it to the others. The monster, our enemy, has left; he has returned to his castle in Transylvania. I know this as surely as if a gigantic hand of fire had written it on the wall. In a way, he had prepared for it, and his last box of earth was ready to be shipped. That's why he took the money and hurried so much; to avoid being caught by us before sunset. It was his only hope, unless he could hide in the grave of poor Lucy, whom he thought was like him and therefore open to him. But he didn't have time. When that failed him, he went straight to his last resort... to his last earthly work, I might say, if I desired a double entendre. He is intelligent; very intelligent. He realized he had lost the game here, and decided to return home. He found a ship that followed the route he desired, and left on it. Now we are going to try to discover which ship that was and, without wasting time, as soon as we know, we will return to inform you. Then we will console you and also poor Mrs. Mina, with new hopes. Since it is possible to keep hope, thinking that not all is lost. That same creature we are chasing took several hundred years to reach London and yet, in a single day, as soon as we learned of his doings, we made him flee from here. He has limitations, for he has the power to do much harm, though he cannot endure it as we can. But we are strong, each in our own way; and we are even stronger when we are all together. Cheer up, dear husband of our Mrs. Mina. This battle has only just begun and, in the end, we will win... I am as sure of it as I am that God is watching over His children from above. Therefore, stay encouraged and comfort your wife until our return.

en: Van Helsing.
vi: "Van Helsing"
tr: VAN HELSING
es: VAN HELSING

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 4 October.—When I read to Mina, Van Helsing’s message in the phonograph, the poor girl brightened up considerably. Already the certainty that the Count is out of the country has given her comfort; and comfort is strength to her. For my own part, now that his horrible danger is not face to face with us, it seems almost impossible to believe in it. Even my own terrible experiences in Castle Dracula seem like a long-forgotten dream. Here in the crisp autumn air in the bright sunlight——
vi: • October 4 When Mina heard the messages recorded by Dr. Seward on the phonograph, she seemed much more at ease. Indeed, there is nothing more joyful than knowing the Count has left her country, and this very joy helped her recover. As for me, since the danger has passed, I feel as if I have regained the faith that I thought had long faded in my heart. Even the real experiences at Dracula's castle now seem like nothing more than past dreams. Here, amidst the golden autumn sunlight...
tr: October 4. - When I read Van Helsing's phonograph message to Mina, the poor girl became quite animated. She was relieved to know for certain that the Count was out of the country, and this relief gave her strength. As for me, now that I am no longer facing the terrible danger, it almost seems impossible to believe in its existence. Even my own horrific experiences at Castle Dracula feel like a long-forgotten dream. In the cool autumn air, under the bright daylight...
es: October 4th. When I read Mina the message that van Helsing left me on the phonograph, my poor wife cheered up considerably. The certainty that the count had left the country already provided her with comfort, and comfort is strength for her. As for me, now that this terrible danger is no longer face to face with us, it is almost impossible for me to believe in it. Even my own terrible experiences in Dracula's castle seem like a nightmare that happened a long time ago and is almost completely forgotten, here, in the midst of the fresh autumn air and under the bright sunlight…

en: Alas! how can I disbelieve! In the midst of my thought my eye fell on the red scar on my poor darling’s white forehead. Whilst that lasts, there can be no disbelief. And afterwards the very memory of it will keep faith crystal clear. Mina and I fear to be idle, so we have been over all the diaries again and again. Somehow, although the reality seems greater each time, the pain and the fear seem less. There is something of a guiding purpose manifest throughout, which is comforting. Mina says that perhaps we are the instruments of ultimate good. It may be! I shall try to think as she does. We have never spoken to each other yet of the future. It is better to wait till we see the Professor and the others after their investigations.
vi: Oh dear! How could I have doubted? While lost in thought, my eyes suddenly and unintentionally stopped on the red holy wafer mark on the noble forehead of my beloved wife. It is an undeniable truth. The memory of that mark reminds us that we were not dreaming. I fear that today's idleness will cause both Mina and me to constantly think about all of our diary entries. However, as the memory of that terrible reality increases, it seems that the pain and fear within us gradually diminish, because we know the constant threat is no longer near. The thread running through the diary entries gradually appears in our thoughts as a silent comfort. Mina even joked that she would use those diary entries as material for a novel. Clearly, that thought has visibly cheered her up. I also tried to think like her to forget the wandering thoughts in my head. So far, we have never talked about the future together. But it is best to wait until Van Helsing and the others return before making any plans.
tr: Alas! How could I not believe! In the midst of this thought, my eyes caught the red scar on my poor lover's pale forehead. As long as that scar remains there, disbelief is out of the question. And later, his memory will remain clear as well. Mina and I are both afraid of idleness, so we went through all the journals repeatedly. Somehow, each time the realities seem greater, but the pain and fear feel less. There has been a fundamental purpose that has been clear from the beginning, and this is comforting. Mina says that perhaps we could be instruments of great good. It could be! I will try to think like her. We have never talked about the future with each other. It will be better to wait until after the Professor and the others have completed their research.
es: However, alas, how am I going to be able to forget it? Amid the fogs of my imagination, my thoughts linger on the red scar that my beloved and troubled wife has on her white forehead. As long as that scar remains on her forehead, it is impossible to stop believing. Mina and I fear remaining inactive, so we have gone back to reviewing all the journals several times. In a way, although reality seems to be increasingly overwhelming, the pain and fear seem to have diminished. In all of this, a guiding intention is manifested, in a way, which is almost comforting. Mina says that perhaps we are instruments of a good ending. It could be! I must try to think like her. We still haven't talked about the future yet. It will be better to wait to see the professor and everyone else after their research.

en: The day is running by more quickly than I ever thought a day could run for me again. It is now three o’clock.
vi: But it is best to wait until Van Helsing and the others return before making any plans.
tr: The day is passing by faster than I ever thought a day could pass. It's three o'clock.
es: The day has passed much more quickly than I would have believed it could ever pass for me again. It is already three in the afternoon.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 5 October, 5 p. m.—Our meeting for report. Present: Professor Van Helsing, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, Mr. Quincey Morris, Jonathan Harker, Mina Harker.
vi: • October 5, 5 PM Recount our conversation. Those present: Professor Van Helsing, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, Quincey Morris, Jonathan Harker, and me, Mina Harker.
tr: October 5, 5 PM. - Minutes of our meeting. Attendees: Professor Van Helsing, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, Mr. Quincey Morris, Jonathan Harker, Mina Harker.
es: October 5, at five in the afternoon. Meeting to hear reports. Present: Professor van Helsing, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, Mr. Quincey Morris, Jonathan Harker, and Mina Harker.

en: Dr. Van Helsing described what steps were taken during the day to discover on what boat and whither bound Count Dracula made his escape:—
vi: Van Helsing recounted how he and his friends discovered Dracula's ship and found its location:
tr: Dr. Van Helsing explained the steps taken during the day to find out which ship Count Dracula boarded for his escape and what his destination was:
es: Dr. Van Helsing described the steps they had taken during the day to discover on which ship and in which direction Count Dracula had fled.

en: “As I knew that he wanted to get back to Transylvania, I felt sure that he must go by the Danube mouth; or by somewhere in the Black Sea, since by that way he come. It was a dreary blank that was before us. Omne ignotum pro magnifico; and so with heavy hearts we start to find what ships leave for the Black Sea last night. He was in sailing ship, since Madam Mina tell of sails being set. These not so important as to go in your list of the shipping in the Times, and so we go, by suggestion of Lord Godalming, to your Lloyd’s, where are note of all ships that sail, however so small. There we find that only one Black-Sea-bound ship go out with the tide. She is the Czarina Catherine, and she sail from Doolittle’s Wharf for Varna, and thence on to other parts and up the Danube. ‘Soh!’ said I, ‘this is the ship whereon is the Count.’ So off we go to Doolittle’s Wharf, and there we find a man in an office of wood so small that the man look bigger than the office. From him we inquire of the goings of the Czarina Catherine. He swear much, and he red face and loud of voice, but he good fellow all the same; and when Quincey give him something from his pocket which crackle as he roll it up, and put it in a so small bag which he have hid deep in his clothing, he still better fellow and humble servant to us. He come with us, and ask many men who are rough and hot; these be better fellows too when they have been no more thirsty. They say much of blood and bloom, and of others which I comprehend not, though I guess what they mean; but nevertheless they tell us all things which we want to know.
vi: When I knew he intended to return to Transylvania, I was certain he would follow the route of the Danube estuary or some port on the Black Sea, because when he came to England, he had also taken that route. Omne ignotum pro magnifico. What is unknown is vast. We searched for ships heading to the Black Sea the night before with heavy hearts. According to Mina's description during hypnosis, it was a sailing ship, and such ships are not significant enough to be listed in the departure schedules of the Times. Lord Godalming advised us to go to the Hoyd dock to identify departing ships, including the smaller ones. Upon arrival, we learned that there was only one ship heading to the Black Sea at high tide, the Tsarine Catherine, anchored at Doolittle dock, bound for Varna and other ports upstream of the Danube. "Here it is," I thought to myself, "this is the ship with the Count." So we had to make our way to Doolittle dock, where we met a man sitting in a small, shabby hut. We asked for information about the voyages of the Tsarine Catherine. He was a man with a face as red as a fighting cock, a voice that thundered like a storm, and he was always cursing. But anyway, he was quite kind. Quincey pulled out some gold coins and slipped them into the cloth bag hidden behind the man's coat. Just waiting for that, the man immediately became a reasonable person and very attentive to us. He led the whole group to meet the rough and hot-tempered sailors, but these strong men quickly became gentle after we offered them refreshments. They talked a lot about thunder and hell and many other things I didn't understand. However, they also told us everything we wanted to know.
tr: "Since I knew that he wanted to return to Transylvania, I was sure that he had to go from somewhere in the Black Sea, because he came from the mouth of the Danube or that route." "In front of us, there was a void that led to despair." "Omne ignotum pro magnifico69 and thus, we began to find the ships that set sail for the Black Sea last night with great difficulty." "Madam Mina mentioned that the sails were set, so he was on a sailing ship." "Since these were not important enough to be included in your list in The Times, upon Lord Godalming's suggestion, we went to Lloyd's office, where the records of all ships, no matter how small, were kept." "There, we learned that there was only one ship that set sail with the tide and headed for the Black Sea." "Its name was Czarina Catherine; it had set sail from Doolittle's Wharf towards Varna and from there it would make stops at other places and go up the Danube." "Aha!" I said, "This is the ship the Count is on." "Therefore, we went to Doolittle's Wharf and there, we found a man sitting in a small wooden office; the office was so small that the man seemed bigger than the office." "We asked him about what was happening on the Czarina Catherine." "He swore a lot, red-faced and loud, but still a good man; when Quincey gave him something that rustled as he took it out of his pocket and put it into a very small bag he took from the depths of his clothing, he became an even better friend and respectful servant to us." "He came with us and asked a lot of rough and angry men; they also became better men when their thirst was quenched." "They spoke a lot about blood, curses, and other things that I could guess the meaning of but did not fully understand; still, they told us everything we wanted to know."
es: –We knew he wanted to return to Transylvania. I was sure he would go up the mouth of the Danube; or by some route of the Black Sea, since he came following that route. We had a very difficult task ahead of us. Omne ignotum pro magnifico; thus, with a great weight in our hearts, we began to search for the ships that left last night for the Black Sea. He was on a sailing ship, since Mrs. Mina told us about the sails in her vision. Those ships are not important enough to be listed in the Times and, therefore, we went, accepting a suggestion from Lord Godalming, to Lloyd's, where all ships that set sail are recorded, no matter how small they are. There we discovered that only one ship bound for the Black Sea had left taking advantage of the tides. It is the Czarina Catherine and it goes from Doolittle Wharf bound for Varna, to other ports and, then, will go up the Danube River. "Then," I said, "that is the ship on which the count sails." Consequently, we went to Doolittle's Wharf and found a man in an office so tiny that the man seemed larger than it. We asked him everything related to the whereabouts of the Czarina Catherine. He cursed a lot, his face turned red, and his voice was very gruff; but he wasn't a bad guy, anyway, and when Quincey took something out of his pocket and handed it to him, producing a rustle when the man took it and put it in a small wallet he carried deep within his clothes, he became an even better guy, and our humble servant. He accompanied us and asked questions to several sweaty and rough men; they also turned out to be better guys when their thirst was quenched. They talked a lot about blood and other things I didn't understand, although I guessed what they meant. However, they communicated everything we wanted to know.

en: “They make known to us among them, how last afternoon at about five o’clock comes a man so hurry. A tall man, thin and pale, with high nose and teeth so white, and eyes that seem to be burning. That he be all in black, except that he have a hat of straw which suit not him or the time. That he scatter his money in making quick inquiry as to what ship sails for the Black Sea and for where. Some took him to the office and then to the ship, where he will not go aboard but halt at shore end of gang-plank, and ask that the captain come to him. The captain come, when told that he will be pay well; and though he swear much at the first he agree to term. Then the thin man go and some one tell him where horse and cart can be hired. He go there and soon he come again, himself driving cart on which a great box; this he himself lift down, though it take several to put it on truck for the ship. He give much talk to captain as to how and where his box is to be place; but the captain like it not and swear at him in many tongues, and tell him that if he like he can come and see where it shall be. But he say ‘no’; that he come not yet, for that he have much to do.
