vi: — But darling, it was you who wanted it this way, and not for your own sake. Go ask Dr. Van Helsing if what I'm saying makes sense. If he doesn't agree, then you can do as you wish, I will accept it. Moreover, if you agree, I will release you from your promise shortly. — Then I promise!
tr: “But my love,” he said with a spiritual intensity that made his eyes shine like the North Star, “I am the one who wants this and I do not want it for myself. If I am wrong, you can ask Dr. Van Helsing; if he does not agree with you, you can do as you wish. Moreover, if you accept this, you will be forgiven for your word in the future.”
es: –But, dear -she said with such spiritual intensity that her eyes shone as if they were two polar stars-, it is I who desires it, and not for myself. You can ask Dr. Van Helsing if I am not right; if he does not agree, you can do what you think best. Moreover, if everyone agrees, you will be absolved of your promise.

en: “I promise!” I said, and for a moment she looked supremely happy; though to me all happiness for her was denied by the red scar on her forehead. She said:—
vi: I said, making her face light up, even though I knew she would never have complete happiness as long as that cruel mark remained on her forehead. She said immediately:
tr: “I promise!” I said, and for a moment he looked incredibly happy; yet in my opinion, all his happiness was hindered by the red scar on his forehead. He spoke thus:
es: –I promise you! – I told him; for a moment, he seemed to feel extraordinarily happy, although in my opinion, all happiness was denied to him because of the scar he had on his forehead.

en: “Promise me that you will not tell me anything of the plans formed for the campaign against the Count. Not by word, or inference, or implication; not at any time whilst this remains to me!” and she solemnly pointed to the scar. I saw that she was in earnest, and said solemnly:—
vi: — Promise that you will not reveal any plans against the old count to me, not even a word, a hint, or a metaphor. Do not mention anything as long as this scar remains on my forehead. She pointed to the mark of the holy wafer on her forehead, her expression very serious. I suddenly understood the gravity of her words and repeated, my voice equally serious:
tr: “Promise me that you will not tell me anything about the plans for the war against Kont.” “Not a word, not an inference, not even a hint; as long as this is on me, never!” And as he said this, he seriously pointed to the scar on his forehead. I saw that he was sincere and I said seriously:
es: –Promise me that you won't tell me anything about the plans they make for their campaign against the count -he said to me-. Neither by word, nor by means of inferences or implications, as long as I keep this. And he solemnly pointed to the scar on his forehead. I saw that he was serious and I also said solemnly:

en: “I promise!” and as I said it I felt that from that instant a door had been shut between us.
vi: — I promise you that! But upon saying this, I suddenly felt as if a door had slammed shut between my spouse and me.
tr: "I promise!" And the moment I said it, I felt as if a door had closed between us.
es: –I promise you! And as soon as I uttered those words, I realized that a door had just closed between us.

en: Later, midnight.—Mina has been bright and cheerful all the evening. So much so that all the rest seemed to take courage, as if infected somewhat with her gaiety; as a result even I myself felt as if the pall of gloom which weighs us down were somewhat lifted. We all retired early. Mina is now sleeping like a little child; it is a wonderful thing that her faculty of sleep remains to her in the midst of her terrible trouble. Thank God for it, for then at least she can forget her care. Perhaps her example may affect me as her gaiety did to-night. I shall try it. Oh! for a dreamless sleep.
vi: • Midnight, the same day In the afternoon, Mina's cheerful and lively demeanor seemed to have made our entire group more courageous. Even I felt that the terrible burden that had been weighing on us for so long was lightening. We parted ways very early to return to our rooms to rest. At this moment, Mina is sleeping soundly like a child. Is it any wonder that she knows how to use sleep to somewhat forget the troubles in her heart? Her example this afternoon will surely help me a lot. Wishing you a peaceful night!
tr: Later, at midnight. - Mina was lively and cheerful all evening. So much so that, as if her cheerfulness was contagious, the rest of the team seemed to take courage from it; as a result, even I felt as if the blanket of gloom that had settled over us had somehow lifted. We all retired to our beds early. Mina is now sleeping like a child; it is a wonderful thing that her ability to sleep is not disrupted amidst her terrible distress. Thank God for that, because then at least she can forget her sorrow. Maybe just as her cheerfulness affected me tonight, this situation can also be an example. I will try this. Ah! A dreamless sleep!
es: Later, at midnight. Mina has been cheerful and lively all afternoon. So much so that everyone else seemed to cheer up in turn, as if they were infected by her joy; as a result, I also felt as if the tremendous weight that burdens us all had lightened a bit. We all retired early to our rooms. Mina is now sleeping like a baby; it's wonderful that she still has the ability to sleep, amidst her terrible problem. I thank God for that, as, in this way, at least she can forget her pain. It is possible that her example will affect me, as her joy did this afternoon. I will try. May it be a dream without nightmares!

en: 6 October, morning.—Another surprise. Mina woke me early, about the same time as yesterday, and asked me to bring Dr. Van Helsing. I thought that it was another occasion for hypnotism, and without question went for the Professor. He had evidently expected some such call, for I found him dressed in his room. His door was ajar, so that he could hear the opening of the door of our room. He came at once; as he passed into the room, he asked Mina if the others might come, too.
vi: • October 5, morning Another surprise. Mina woke me up very early and told me to go call Dr. Van Helsing. I thought she wanted to be hypnotized again, so I didn't ask any questions and ran straight to the professor's room. Clearly, he was preparing for a visit, as I saw him dressed very neatly. His door was not closed, so I thought he might have heard my door open. When I told him, he came right away. As he entered, he asked Mina if he could call the rest of our friends to join us.
tr: October 6, morning. - A new surprise. Mina woke me up early, at roughly the same time as yesterday, and asked me to bring Dr. Van Helsing. I thought it was time for another hypnosis session and went to the Professor without asking any questions. Clearly, he was expecting such a call, because I found him in his room, already dressed. His door was ajar, so he could hear our room's door opening. He came immediately; as he entered the room, he asked Mina if the others could come as well.
es: October 6th, in the morning. Another surprise. Mina woke me up early, almost at the same time as the previous day, and asked me to take her to Dr. Van Helsing. I thought it was another occasion for hypnotism and, without hesitation, I went to find the professor. Evidently, he had been expecting such a call, as I found him in his room fully dressed. He had the door ajar, as if to hear the noise made by the door of our room opening. He accompanied me immediately; upon entering the room, he asked Mina if she wanted the others to be present as well.

en: “No,” she said quite simply, “it will not be necessary. You can tell them just as well. I must go with you on your journey.”
vi: — No, - She replied briefly - it's not necessary. You can tell them later. I must accompany you on your journey.
tr: "No," Mina said briefly, "that won't be necessary. You can tell them if you want. I need to be with you on your journey."
es: –No -he said with complete simplicity-; it won't be necessary. You can tell him later. I wish to go with you on your journey.

en: Dr. Van Helsing was as startled as I was. After a moment’s pause he asked:—
vi: Like me, the professor startled and asked again after a moment of silence:
tr: Dr. Van Helsing was as surprised as I was. After a moment's hesitation, he asked:
es: Dr. Van Helsing was as astonished as I was. After a moment of silence, he asked:

en: “But why?”
vi: — But for what reason?
tr: “But why?”
es: –But, why?

en: “You must take me with you. I am safer with you, and you shall be safer, too.”
vi: — You must let me come along. I will be safer when I am with you, and him too.
tr: "You must take me with you. I am safer with you, and you will be safer too."
es: –You must take me with you. I am safer with you, and you will also be safer with me.

en: “But why, dear Madam Mina? You know that your safety is our solemnest duty. We go into danger, to which you are, or may be, more liable than any of us from—from circumstances—things that have been.” He paused, embarrassed.
vi: — But why, Mina? Taking care of and ensuring your safety, as you know, has always been our foremost duty. We are facing a danger in which you are the most vulnerable, after all the situations and events that have transpired... He suddenly fell silent, looking very embarrassed.
tr: “But why, dear Madam Mina? You know that your safety is our most serious duty. We are going into such a danger that, due to the circumstances, you are or may be more exposed to danger than any of us.” He fell silent, ashamed.
es: –But why, dear Mrs. Mina? You know that your safety is our first and most important duty. We are approaching a danger to which you are or may be more exposed than any of us, due to the circumstances and events that have occurred. He paused, feeling confused.

en: As she replied, she raised her finger and pointed to her forehead:—
vi: She answered, pointing to her forehead:
tr: While responding, Mina raised her finger and pointed to her forehead:
es: When replying, Mina raised a hand and pointed to her forehead.

en: “I know. That is why I must go. I can tell you now, whilst the sun is coming up; I may not be able again. I know that when the Count wills me I must go. I know that if he tells me to come in secret, I must come by wile; by any device to hoodwink—even Jonathan.” God saw the look that she turned on me as she spoke, and if there be indeed a Recording Angel that look is noted to her everlasting honour. I could only clasp her hand. I could not speak; my emotion was too great for even the relief of tears. She went on:—
vi: — I know. And it is precisely because of this that I must go. I can tell you when the sun has just risen. Later, I won't be able to say anything anymore. I know that when the old count demands, I must obey. I also know that if he orders me to leave secretly, I will come to him with cunning and deceit, enough to create a change, even with Jonathan. She turned to look at me, her eyes filled with deep sadness. I could only hold tightly the small hand of my beloved wife, unable to say anything. She continued, her eyes brimming with tears:
tr: “I know. That is why I must go. I can tell you now, while the sun is rising; I may not be able to tell you again. I know that when the Count calls me, I must go. If he wants me to come secretly, I know I must go by deceit; I can even deceive Jonathan in this matter.” The look he gave me while speaking was seen by God, and if there truly is a Recording Angel, that look has been recorded for the honor of living forever. I could only hold his hand. I could not speak; my emotions were too intense to be relieved by tears. He continued his words:
es: –I already know. That is why I must go. I can tell you now, when the sun is about to rise; it is possible that I won't be able to do so later. I know that when the count wants me by his side, I will have to go. I know that if he tells me to go in secret, I will have to be cunning and no obstacle will stop me… Not even Jonathan. God saw the look she gave me as she spoke, and if one of the recording angels was present, that look must have been noted for her eternal honor. The only thing I could do was take her hand, unable to speak; my emotion was too great to find solace in tears. She continued speaking:

en: “You men are brave and strong. You are strong in your numbers, for you can defy that which would break down the human endurance of one who had to guard alone. Besides, I may be of service, since you can hypnotise me and so learn that which even I myself do not know.” Dr. Van Helsing said very gravely:—
vi: — You men are always brave and strong. You become even stronger when united, as you can challenge what threatens to crush the life of humanity. Moreover, I can also be useful to you, because when hypnotized, you can read from me things that even I do not know. Van Helsing responded emotionally, his voice becoming serious:
tr: "You men are brave and strong. You are strong in numbers; because you can stand against someone who could break the human endurance of someone who has to protect themselves. Also, I might be useful, as you can hypnotize me and thus learn things that even I don't know about myself." Dr. Van Helsing said with great seriousness: "Madam Mina, as always, you are very wise.
es: –You men are brave and strong. You are strong when united, as you can face together what would shatter the human tolerance of someone who had to endure it alone. Moreover, I can be useful to you, as you can hypnotize me and make me tell you things that even I do not know. The professor paused before responding.

en: “Madam Mina, you are, as always, most wise. You shall with us come; and together we shall do that which we go forth to achieve.” When he had spoken, Mina’s long spell of silence made me look at her. She had fallen back on her pillow asleep; she did not even wake when I had pulled up the blind and let in the sunlight which flooded the room. Van Helsing motioned to me to come with him quietly. We went to his room, and within a minute Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris were with us also. He told them what Mina had said, and went on:—
vi: — Mrs. Mina, you are always a devout person. Yes, we will invite you to join us, and together we will contribute our efforts to complete our difficult mission. Mina didn't say anything more but sank deep into her thoughts in front of me. She sat still for a while and then slowly leaned back to continue her sound sleep. Even when I drew the curtains high, letting the sunlight flood the small room, she still couldn't wake up. Van Helsing waved his hand, signaling me to quietly go to his room. A few minutes later, both Lord Godalming, Morris, and Dr. Seward arrived. He recounted to them what Mina had just said and continued:
tr: Dr. Van Helsing said with great seriousness: "Madam Mina, as always, you are very wise. You will come with us and we will do together what we set out to accomplish." When the professor said these things Mina's long silence made me look at her. She had fallen asleep and slumped onto her pillow; even when I opened the curtain to let the daylight flood into the room, she did not wake up. Van Helsing silently gestured for me to follow him. We went to his room, and within a minute, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris joined us. The professor told them what Mina had said and continued his words:
es: –Mrs. Mina, you are, as always, very wise. You must accompany us, and together we will do whatever needs to be done. The long silence that Mina kept made me look at her. She had fallen on her back on the pillows, asleep; she didn't even wake up when I raised the blinds of the window and let the sunlight fully illuminate the room. Van Helsing signaled me to follow him in silence. We went to his room and, after a minute, Lord Godalming, Dr. Seward, and Mr. Morris were also by our side. He explained to them what Mina had told him and continued speaking:

en: “In the morning we shall leave for Varna. We have now to deal with a new factor: Madam Mina. Oh, but her soul is true. It is to her an agony to tell us so much as she has done; but it is most right, and we are warned in time. There must be no chance lost, and in Varna we must be ready to act the instant when that ship arrives.”
vi: — They will go to Varna today. Mina makes a lot of sense, so we have been timely warned. We must not miss any opportunity, and upon reaching Varna, everyone must be ready to act the moment the ship docks.
tr: “We will set out for Varna in the morning. We now have another matter to deal with: Madam Mina. Ah, but her soul is honest. It is painful for her to tell us these things; but we were warned very accurately and timely. No chance should be lost, and we must be ready to act as soon as that ship arrives in Varna.”
es: –In the morning, we must leave for Varna. We must now consider a new factor: Mrs. Mina. But her soul is pure. It is a true agony for her to tell us what she has told us, but it is very accurate, and thus we will be warned in time. We must not miss any opportunity, and in Varna, we must be ready to act the moment that ship arrives.

en: “What shall we do exactly?” asked Mr. Morris laconically. The Professor paused before replying:—
vi: — So what exactly do we have to do? - Morris asked briefly. After a moment of thought, the professor replied:
tr: "What exactly are we going to do?" Mr. Morris asked succinctly. The professor paused before responding:
es: – What exactly should we do? – asked Mr. Morris, with his usual laconic manner. The professor paused before responding.

en: “We shall at the first board that ship; then, when we have identified the box, we shall place a branch of the wild rose on it. This we shall fasten, for when it is there none can emerge; so at least says the superstition. And to superstition must we trust at the first; it was man’s faith in the early, and it have its root in faith still. Then, when we get the opportunity that we seek, when none are near to see, we shall open the box, and—and all will be well.”
vi: — First of all, we need to board the ship. Then, right after identifying the location of the wooden chest, we must place a wild rose branch on it to prevent him from escaping. At least, that's what I know from the belief system. First of all, we need to believe in superstitions, as it is the foundation to bring us the initial confidence in this situation. After that, if we observe that no one is lurking around, we seize the opportunity to pry open the chest and... everything will go smoothly.
tr: “First, we will board the ship; then, when we locate the chest, we will place a bunch of wild roses on it. We will tie this bunch because as long as it is there, no one can get out of the chest; at least, that's what superstitions say. And first, we must trust in superstitions; in the past, this was people's belief and the root of this belief still remains. Then, when we seize the opportunity we are looking for, when there is no one nearby to see, we will open the chest and - and everything will be alright.”
es: –First, we must take that ship; then, when we have identified the box, we must place a wild rose branch on it. We must secure it, because when the branch is on the box, no one can leave it. At least that's what the superstition says. And superstition must be trusted in principle; it was the faith of man in antiquity, and it still has its roots in faith. Then, when we have the opportunity we are looking for… When there is no one around to see us, we will open the box and..., and everything will be over.

en: “I shall not wait for any opportunity,” said Morris. “When I see the box I shall open it and destroy the monster, though there were a thousand men looking on, and if I am to be wiped out for it the next moment!” I grasped his hand instinctively and found it as firm as a piece of steel. I think he understood my look; I hope he did.
vi: — As for me, I don't need to wait for any opportunity. - Morris spoke up. - As soon as I see the coffin, I'll pry the lid open and give the demon a blow to the head to finish it quickly. Let the people watch whatever they want, we'll deal with everything later! I was moved as I tightly held the hand of the American man, his hand now as hard as steel. I hoped he would understand all the emotions in my eyes. — Hooray for the young man!
tr: “I will not wait for an opportunity,” said Morris. “Even if there are a thousand men watching me and they are about to kill me at that moment, I will open the chest when I see it and destroy the monster!” Instinctively, I grabbed his hand and realized it was as hard as steel. I think he understood my look; I hope so.
es: –I don't intend to wait for any opportunity to present itself -said Morris-. As soon as I see the box, I will open it and destroy the monster, even if a thousand men are watching me, and even if they lynch me a moment later. I grabbed his hand instinctively and discovered that it was as firm as a piece of steel. I think he understood my look; I hope he did.

en: “Good boy,” said Dr. Van Helsing. “Brave boy. Quincey is all man. God bless him for it. My child, believe me none of us shall lag behind or pause from any fear. I do but say what we may do—what we must do. But, indeed, indeed we cannot say what we shall do. There are so many things which may happen, and their ways and their ends are so various that until the moment we may not say. We shall all be armed, in all ways; and when the time for the end has come, our effort shall not be lack. Now let us to-day put all our affairs in order. Let all things which touch on others dear to us, and who on us depend, be complete; for none of us can tell what, or when, or how, the end may be. As for me, my own affairs are regulate; and as I have nothing else to do, I shall go make arrangements for the travel. I shall have all tickets and so forth for our journey.”
vi: - Van Helsing exclaimed. - Hooray for the young man! Quincey is truly a one hundred percent man. May God bless you! But young man, please believe me, none of us are trained for this job, and there isn't much time left for us to be afraid. I'm just roughly saying what we can and must do, that's all. In reality, how do we know what we must do? There could be many things happening that we cannot foresee. There will be sudden twists, unforeseen outcomes. We can't predict anything, young man. However, we should equip ourselves fully, and when the decisive moment comes, all our efforts will be most effective. Now, let's prepare thoroughly. Let's arrange everything we find most necessary, because no one can predict what outcome will happen to us, when, and in what manner. As for myself, I am ready and have nothing left to do but organize the trip. I will get the tickets and everything needed for this expedition.
tr: “Good boy,” said Van Helsing. “Brave boy. Quincey, a true man, God bless him for that. My child, believe me, none of us will stand back or hesitate out of fear. I am saying what we can do - what we must do. But truly, truly, we cannot predict what we will do. So many things can happen and their ways and ends are so different that we cannot say anything until the moment comes. We will all arm ourselves in every way and when the time comes for the end, our effort will not be lacking. Now, let us put all our affairs in order today. Let everything that touches our loved ones and those who depend on us be completed, because none of us can say what, when, or how the end will be. I have arranged my personal affairs and since I have no other tasks to do, I will go and make the travel arrangements. I will get the things needed for our journey, like tickets and such.”
es: –Magnificent! – said Professor Van Helsing. Magnificent! Our friend Quincey is a true man! God bless him for it! My friend, none of us will be left behind or stopped by any fear. I am only saying what we can do... What we must do. But in reality, none of us can say what we will do. There are many things that can happen, and their methods and ends are so diverse that, until the precise moment arrives, we cannot say. In any case, we must be armed, and when the final moment comes, our effort must not be in vain. Now, let us dedicate today to putting all our things in order. Let us prepare all the things related to other people who are dear to us or who depend on us, since none of us can say what, when, or how the end may be. As for me, all my affairs are in order and, as I have nothing else to do, I am going to prepare certain things and make certain arrangements for the journey. I am going to get all our tickets, etcetera.

en: There was nothing further to be said, and we parted. I shall now settle up all my affairs of earth, and be ready for whatever may come....
vi: There was nothing left to discuss, so we immediately got to work on the preparations. I will arrange everything related to my land and property, and be ready to face whatever may come.
tr: There was nothing else to say, and so we parted ways. Now I will put all my worldly affairs in order and prepare for whatever is to come...
es: There was nothing more to talk about, and we parted ways. Now I must put all my affairs on earth in order and be prepared for anything that might happen...

en: Later.—It is all done; my will is made, and all complete. Mina if she survive is my sole heir. If it should not be so, then the others who have been so good to us shall have remainder.
vi: • A moment later I have finished writing the will and prepared everything else. If Mina comes along, she will be my sole heir. If there were someone else, we would have been too happy.
tr: Later on. - Everything is complete; my will has been prepared and everything is finalized. If she survives, Mina is my sole heir. If she does not survive, the others who have treated us well will receive the remainder.
es: Later. Everything is already arranged. I have made my will and everything is complete. Mina, if she survives, is my sole heir. If not, then our friends, who have been so good to us, will be my heirs.

en: It is now drawing towards the sunset; Mina’s uneasiness calls my attention to it. I am sure that there is something on her mind which the time of exact sunset will reveal. These occasions are becoming harrowing times for us all, for each sunrise and sunset opens up some new danger—some new pain, which, however, may in God’s will be means to a good end. I write all these things in the diary since my darling must not hear them now; but if it may be that she can see them again, they shall be ready.
vi: The sunset gradually. Mina's gesture caught my attention. I am certain that right at the moment the sun sets, something ominous happens in her mind. Such moments are always a challenge for us, because each time the sun rises or sets, it opens up a new danger, a new endurance for the whole group. I write these lines in my diary, for at this moment, my dear wife can no longer comprehend anything. If later on, she can regain clarity like a normal person, then everything will be in the diary.
tr: Sunset is now approaching; Mina's restlessness catches my attention. I have no doubt that there is something on her mind that will emerge precisely at sunset. Times like these are always painful moments for all of us, because every sunrise and sunset brings a new danger - even if it is for a good outcome by God's will, it brings new pain. I am writing these in the journal because my beloved should not hear them now; but if she can see them again, they will be ready.
es: The moment of sunset is approaching; Mina's unease makes me realize this. I am sure there is something in her mind that awakens at the moment of sunset. Those moments are becoming very unpleasant for all of us, as each time the sun sets or rises, it represents the possibility of a new danger... of some new pain that, however, may be a means of the Lord for a good end. I write all these things in my diary because my beloved wife should not know about them for now, but if it is possible for her to read them later, she will be prepared to do so.

en: She is calling to me.
vi: I suddenly started when I heard her call.
tr: Mina is calling me.
es: He/She is calling me right now.

en: CHAPTER XXV
vi: CHAPTER 25
tr: XXV
es: XXV.– FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: XXV.– FROM THE DIARY OF DOCTOR SEWARD

en: 11 October, Evening.—Jonathan Harker has asked me to note this, as he says he is hardly equal to the task, and he wants an exact record kept.
vi: • October 11, evening Jonathan Harker suggested that I record the events that followed. He told me that it was not enough for him alone to keep a diary, and he wanted everything to be reflected as accurately as possible.
tr: October 11, evening. - Jonathan Harker asked me to write these down because, according to him, he was not quite adequate for this task and he wants the events to be recorded accurately.
es: October 11, at night. Jonathan Harker has asked me to take note of all this, as he says he is not in a condition to handle this task, and he wishes for us to keep an accurate record of events.

en: I think that none of us were surprised when we were asked to see Mrs. Harker a little before the time of sunset. We have of late come to understand that sunrise and sunset are to her times of peculiar freedom; when her old self can be manifest without any controlling force subduing or restraining her, or inciting her to action. This mood or condition begins some half hour or more before actual sunrise or sunset, and lasts till either the sun is high, or whilst the clouds are still aglow with the rays streaming above the horizon. At first there is a sort of negative condition, as if some tie were loosened, and then the absolute freedom quickly follows; when, however, the freedom ceases the change-back or relapse comes quickly, preceded only by a spell of warning silence.
vi: I think none of us were surprised when we were invited to Mina's side just before dusk. We had just learned that sunrise or sunset for her were moments of a strange liberation phenomenon, meaning her true self would manifest with some invisible dominant force either preventing her from acting, or conversely, compelling her to act. This state appears about half an hour before sunrise or sunset and lasts until the sun is high or clouds come to obscure the last rays lingering on the horizon. It is the beginning of a negative effect, like a knot being untied, very quickly followed by a state of absolute freedom. When that freedom is interrupted, the state will repeat very quickly with a brief forewarning phenomenon of her silence.
tr: I suppose none of us were surprised when we were asked to see Ms. Harker shortly before sunset. Recently, we had begun to understand that sunrise and sunset were her privileged hours of freedom; these were the times when her old self could emerge without any controlling force pressing, restraining, or provoking her to act. This mood or state begins about half an hour or a little more before the exact moment of sunrise or sunset, or it lasts until the sun has fully risen or until the minutes when the clouds are still painted red by the sun's rays hovering above the horizon. At first, a kind of restlessness appears as if a bond has been loosened, and this is quickly followed by absolute freedom; but when the freedom starts to fade, a rapid return or deterioration occurs swiftly after only a brief silence that serves as a warning.
es: I believe none of us were surprised when we were asked to go see Mrs. Harker, shortly before sunset. We had all long since come to understand that the moments of sunrise and sunset were times when she enjoyed greater freedom; when her former personality could manifest without any external force subjugating, limiting, or inciting her to action. This condition or mood always begins about half an hour before sunset and sunrise, and lasts until the sun is high, or until the clouds, with the sun hidden, still shine from the rays of light that spring from the horizon. At first, it is a kind of negative condition, as if some grip were broken, and then absolute freedom quickly presents itself; however, when the freedom ceases, the regression happens very quickly, preceded only by a period of silence, which serves as a warning.

en: To-night, when we met, she was somewhat constrained, and bore all the signs of an internal struggle. I put it down myself to her making a violent effort at the earliest instant she could do so. A very few minutes, however, gave her complete control of herself; then, motioning her husband to sit beside her on the sofa where she was half reclining, she made the rest of us bring chairs up close. Taking her husband’s hand in hers began:—
vi: This afternoon, as we sat together, she seemed somewhat reluctant with clear signs of an internal struggle. I believe the cause of the tension was the tremendous effort required of her right from the moment she regained her freedom. However, just a few minutes were enough for her to completely regain control of herself. She pointed, signaling Jonathan to sit next to her on the couch where she was half-sitting, half-lying, and then asked everyone to move their chairs closer. She tightly held Harker's hand and said:
tr: This evening, when we came together, she was a bit troubled and bore all the signs of an internal struggle. I concluded that she had exerted a more strenuous effort than she had in the earliest stages to be able to do this. But within just a few minutes, she managed to completely control herself; then, she indicated for her husband to come and sit beside her on the couch where she was leaning back slightly, and for the rest of us to pull our chairs closer. Taking her husband's hand in hers, she began to speak:
es: Tonight, when we gathered, she seemed to be holding back and showed all the signs of an internal struggle. However, I saw that she made a violent effort as soon as she could. However, a few minutes gave her complete control of herself; then, signaling her husband to sit next to her on the divan where she was half-reclined, she made all of us draw our chairs closer. Then, taking one of her husband's hands between hers, she began to say:

en: “We are all here together in freedom, for perhaps the last time! I know, dear; I know that you will always be with me to the end.” This was to her husband whose hand had, as we could see, tightened upon hers. “In the morning we go out upon our task, and God alone knows what may be in store for any of us. You are going to be so good to me as to take me with you. I know that all that brave earnest men can do for a poor weak woman, whose soul perhaps is lost—no, no, not yet, but is at any rate at stake—you will do. But you must remember that I am not as you are. There is a poison in my blood, in my soul, which may destroy me; which must destroy me, unless some relief comes to us. Oh, my friends, you know as well as I do, that my soul is at stake; and though I know there is one way out for me, you must not and I must not take it!” She looked appealingly to us all in turn, beginning and ending with her husband.
vi: — This might be the last time we gather freely together. My love, I know you will always be with me until the end. Looking at the small hands tightly holding her poor husband's hand, we knew she was very emotional. — Tomorrow, - She continued - we will set out on our mission, and only heaven knows what kind of end that mission will have in store for us. Everyone is so kind to allow me to join. I know that all the brave things a man can do for an unfortunate woman who has lost her soul to the devil,... no, not quite like that, but almost, you will do. But please remember that I am not like everyone else. My soul, the blood flowing in me, have all been tainted. I might die because of that, at least in the case that you no longer need me. Just like me, you surely understand that my soul is teetering on the edge of an abyss. I know, now there is indeed a wide road open before me, but it is not your road... She looked at all of us in turn, the first and the last person being Jonathan, her eyes seeming to question each one of us.
tr: “Perhaps for the last time, we are all sitting here freely! I know, my love; I know you will be by my side until the end.” These words were to her husband, who was holding her hand tightly as far as we could see. “We start work in the morning, and only God knows what awaits us. By taking me with you, you will treat me very well. I know you will do everything you can for a poor, weak woman - no, no, no, not yet, but still in danger - that all these brave, willing men can do. But you must not forget that I am not like you. There is a poison in my blood, in my soul that can destroy me; if we cannot find the cure, it must be destroyed. Oh, my friends! You know as well as I do that my soul is in danger, and even though I know there is only one salvation for me, you and I must not choose that path!” She looked at each of us one by one, starting and ending with her husband, in a way that moved us all.
es: –We are all together here, freely, perhaps for the last time! I know, dear; I know that you will always be with me, until the end -she said this addressing her husband, whose hand, as we could see, she had tightly held-. Tomorrow we are going to leave, to carry out our task, and only God can know what awaits each one of us. You are being very kind to me by agreeing to take me. I know what all of you, sincere and good men, can do for a poor and weak woman, whose soul is perhaps lost… No, no, no! Not yet! But it is something that may happen sooner or later. And I know you will do it. And you must remember that I am not like you. There is a poison in my blood and in my soul, that can destroy me; that must destroy me, unless we obtain some relief. My friends, you know as well as I do that my soul is at stake, and even though I know there is a way I can get out of this situation, neither you nor I should accept it. She looked at us pleadingly, one by one, starting and ending with her husband.

en: “What is that way?” asked Van Helsing in a hoarse voice. “What is that way, which we must not—may not—take?”
vi: — Which road? - Van Helsing asked impatiently, his voice hoarse. — Immediate death by one's own hand or the hand of another, before dying by the hand of the evil one.
tr: “What is that path?” asked Van Helsing in a hoarse voice. “The path we must not - cannot - choose, what is it?”
es: –What is that way? – inquired van Helsing, with a hoarse voice. What is that solution that we must not and cannot accept?

en: “That I may die now, either by my own hand or that of another, before the greater evil is entirely wrought. I know, and you know, that were I once dead you could and would set free my immortal spirit, even as you did my poor Lucy’s. Were death, or the fear of death, the only thing that stood in the way I would not shrink to die here, now, amidst the friends who love me. But death is not all. I cannot believe that to die in such a case, when there is hope before us and a bitter task to be done, is God’s will. Therefore, I, on my part, give up here the certainty of eternal rest, and go out into the dark where may be the blackest things that the world or the nether world holds!” We were all silent, for we knew instinctively that this was only a prelude. The faces of the others were set and Harker’s grew ashen grey; perhaps he guessed better than any of us what was coming. She continued:—
vi: — Immediate death by one's own hand or the hand of another, before dying by the hand of the evil one. I know, and so do you, that if I die, you can and would very much want to free my immortal soul, just as you did for poor Lucy the other day. If the only concern was death itself or the fear of death, I would not hesitate before death, among those who always consider me their closest friend. But death is not everything. I do not believe that my death at this moment aligns with the will of God, while you still have an important mission to complete. But I am still moving towards this darkness, the darkness that I believe can dispel the dark things in this world and on this earth. We sat in silence, listening, because everyone understood that this was just the prelude to unpleasant things. Everyone's face was pale, serious, and tense, while Jonathan's complexion was ashen like the color of dust. Perhaps he would understand what would happen next better than we did. Mina continued:
tr: “Before a greater evil fully takes shape, I would rather die right now by my own hand or another's. You and I both know that once I am dead, you can, and will, free my immortal soul just as you did for my poor Lucy. If the only obstacle in my path were death or the fear of death, I would not hesitate to die here among friends who love me. But it is not all limited to death. I cannot believe that in a situation where we have hope and work to do ahead of us, dying would be God's will. Therefore, for my part, I am foregoing the undeniable reality of eternal peace here and stepping into the darkness where things that could never exist in this world or in Hell reside!” We all remained silent, instinctively knowing that this was only the introduction to her speech. The others' faces had turned stone-like, and Harker's complexion was ashen; perhaps he anticipated what was to come better than any of us. Ms. Harker continued her speech:
es: –Let me die right now, whether by my own hand or by the hand of one of you, before the evil is consummated. Both you and I know that once dead, you could release my spirit and you would do so, as you did in the case of poor dear Lucy. If it were death or the fear of death the only obstacle in our way, I would have no objection to dying here, right now, among friends who love me. But death is not everything. I do not believe it is God's will for me to die in this case, when there is still hope and a difficult task awaits us all. Therefore, for my part, I reject at this moment what could be eternal rest and step outside, into the darkness, where the worst things that the world or the beyond hold may be found. We all remained silent, as we instinctively understood that it was merely a prelude. The faces of everyone else were serious, and Harker's had turned as pale as a corpse's; perhaps he guessed, better than any of us, what was to follow. Mrs. Harker continued:

en: “This is what I can give into the hotch-pot.” I could not but note the quaint legal phrase which she used in such a place, and with all seriousness. “What will each of you give? Your lives I know,” she went on quickly, “that is easy for brave men. Your lives are God’s, and you can give them back to Him; but what will you give to me?” She looked again questioningly, but this time avoided her husband’s face. Quincey seemed to understand; he nodded, and her face lit up. “Then I shall tell you plainly what I want, for there must be no doubtful matter in this connection between us now. You must promise me, one and all—even you, my beloved husband—that, should the time come, you will kill me.”
vi: — That is precisely my contribution to this cruel life. Each of you will be able to contribute something. It is also your own life, I know. It is indeed not a difficult task for brave men. Your lives are given to you by God, so you can return them to Him in the most deserving way. But what will you give me? I still recognized her questioning look, but this time that look was directed only at Jonathan. It seemed that Quincey understood the unfortunate girl's intention, as I saw him nodding sympathetically. His gesture made Mina's face brighten up. She said: — Yes! I will say what I want to everyone. Friends, each of you must promise me that if the time comes, you must end my life to help me, including you, my dear husband.
tr: “This is the contribution I can make to the inheritance sharing.” I couldn't help but notice her use of this interesting legal term with all seriousness in such a place. “So, what will you give? Yes, I know your lives,” she said and quickly continued, “this is an easy thing for brave men. Your lives belong to God, and you can give them back to Him; but what will you give me?” She looked again with questioning eyes, but this time avoided her husband's face. Quincey seemed to understand; he nodded, and Ms. Harker's face lit up with joy. “Then, let me briefly tell you what I want, because there should be no doubtful matter in this bond between us anymore. Each of you -even you, my dear husband- must promise to kill me when the time comes.”
es: –That is my contribution -I couldn't help but notice the use of those words in such circumstances and spoken with such seriousness-. What will each of your contributions be? Life, I know -he continued quickly-; that is easy for brave men. Your lives belong to God and you can return to Him what is His, but what are you going to give me? She looked at us inquisitively again, but this time she avoided resting her gaze on her husband's face. Quincey seemed to understand, nodded, and Mrs. Harker's face lit up. –Then, I must clearly tell you what I desire, since there should be no doubts about this among all of us. You must promise me, all together and one by one, including you, my beloved husband, that if it becomes necessary, you will kill me.

en: “What is that time?” The voice was Quincey’s, but it was low and strained.
vi: — When? - Quincey asked, his voice trembling.
tr: "What is it then?" The voice belonged to Quincey, but it was a weak and tense voice.
es: "When will that be?" – the voice was Quincey's, but it was low and full of tension.

en: “When you shall be convinced that I am so changed that it is better that I die than I may live. When I am thus dead in the flesh, then you will, without a moment’s delay, drive a stake through me and cut off my head; or do whatever else may be wanting to give me rest!”
vi: — At the hour when everyone sees the change in me and death becomes necessary for my life. When my body truly departs, everyone should not hesitate to drive a stake through my heart, or do something necessary like that, so that I may reach eternal death like any other ordinary person!
tr: “When you believe that I have changed so much that it would be better for me to die than to live. Thus, when I die physically, without losing a moment, you will drive a stake through my body and cut off my head, or do whatever else needs to be done to put me at peace!”
es: –When you are convinced that I have changed so much that it is better for me to die than to continue living. Then, when my flesh is dead, without a moment's delay, you will pierce me with a stake, cut off my head, or do anything that can make me rest in peace.

en: Quincey was the first to rise after the pause. He knelt down before her and taking her hand in his said solemnly:—
vi: The room seemed like it would remain silent forever if Quincey hadn't been the first to stand up. He knelt down and took the small hands of the unfortunate woman, his face solemn:
tr: The first person to stand up after the silence was Quincey. He knelt before Ms. Harker and, holding her hand, began to speak solemnly:
es: Quincey was the first to get up after the pause. He knelt before her and, taking her hand, said solemnly:

en: “I’m only a rough fellow, who hasn’t, perhaps, lived as a man should to win such a distinction, but I swear to you by all that I hold sacred and dear that, should the time ever come, I shall not flinch from the duty that you have set us. And I promise you, too, that I shall make all certain, for if I am only doubtful I shall take it that the time has come!”
vi: — I am just a rough person, perhaps I do not live up to your esteem, but I can promise you with honor that when the time comes, I will not hesitate to do what you are expecting.
tr: “I may be a crude man who has not lived in a way to deserve such a privilege, but I swear upon everything I hold sacred and love that when the time comes, I will not shy away from the duty you have given us. Furthermore, I promise that if I have doubts about the right time, I will strive until I am certain!”
es: –I am an ordinary guy who, perhaps, has not lived as a man should to deserve such a distinction; but I swear to you, by all that is sacred and dear to me, that if that moment ever comes, I will not hesitate nor try to evade the duty you have imposed on us. And I also promise you that I will make sure, because if I have doubts, I will consider that the moment has arrived!

en: “My true friend!” was all she could say amid her fast-falling tears, as, bending over, she kissed his hand.
vi: — Truly a real friend of mine! - Mina said through streaming tears and bent down to kiss her friend's hand.
tr: "My true friend!" This was all Ms. Harker could say through the tears streaming from her eyes, as she bent down and kissed Quincey's hand.
es: –My dear friend! – was all he could say in the midst of the tears that quickly ran down his cheeks, before leaning down and kissing Morris's hand.

en: “I swear the same, my dear Madam Mina!” said Van Helsing.
vi: — I assure you, Mina? - It was Van Helsing's turn to speak. — Me too!
tr: “I swear the same, dear Madam Mina!” said Van Helsing.
es: –I swear the same to you, Mrs. Mina! – said van Helsing.

en: “And I!” said Lord Godalming, each of them in turn kneeling to her to take the oath. I followed, myself. Then her husband turned to her wan-eyed and with a greenish pallor which subdued the snowy whiteness of his hair, and asked:—
vi: - said Lord Godalming emotionally. - I also kneel and promise to you. The last person was Jonathan. He turned to look at his beloved wife, his eyes vacant, his pale face appearing even more wan under his graying hair:
tr: "And me too!" said Lord Godalming; each one of them took turns kneeling in front of Ms. Harker and swore an oath. I followed after them. Then her husband turned to her and, with a face as pale as death, softened by his snow-white hair, asked:
es: –And I! – said Lord Godalming, both kneeling, in turn, before her to make their promise. I followed them myself. Then, her husband turned to her, with a discomposed face and a greenish pallor that blended with the whiteness of his hair, and asked:

en: “And must I, too, make such a promise, oh, my wife?”
vi: — And you, do you have to promise like that, my love? — You must do the same, Jonathan.
tr: “Should I also take such an oath, oh my dear wife?”
es: –Should I make that promise to you as well, my wife?

en: “You too, my dearest,” she said, with infinite yearning of pity in her voice and eyes. “You must not shrink. You are nearest and dearest and all the world to me; our souls are knit into one, for all life and all time. Think, dear, that there have been times when brave men have killed their wives and their womenkind, to keep them from falling into the hands of the enemy. Their hands did not falter any the more because those that they loved implored them to slay them. It is men’s duty towards those whom they love, in such times of sore trial! And oh, my dear, if it is to be that I must meet death at any hand, let it be at the hand of him that loves me best. Dr. Van Helsing, I have not forgotten your mercy in poor Lucy’s case to him who loved”—she stopped with a flying blush, and changed her phrase—“to him who had best right to give her peace. If that time shall come again, I look to you to make it a happy memory of my husband’s life that it was his loving hand which set me free from the awful thrall upon me.”
vi: - She said, her eyes and voice filled with love - You must not falter. You are the closest and dearest to me, you are my whole world. Our souls have intertwined in this life to become immortal. Think about it, my love, there have been times when brave men have killed their wives and women in their families to save them from the hands of the enemy. The hands of those brave men did not tremble, because the ones they loved demanded them to do so. It is the duty of men towards their loved ones in the face of brutal war. So, my love, if I must die by someone's hand, it should be by the hand of the one I love the most. Dr. Van Helsing, surely you have not forgotten the tragic moments of Lucy, have you? You witnessed a true feeling for the one she loved - she suddenly blushed, stammered, and corrected herself -... for the one who deserved to be entrusted with helping her find peace. If such a moment comes to me, please encourage my husband to let me rest eternally by his hand. I want his loving hand to help me remove the terrible burden I am carrying.
tr: “You too, my love,” he said, with a voice and eyes filled with an infinite desire for compassion. “You should not hesitate about this. You are the closest to me, the most valuable person for me, and you are worth more than the world to me; our souls are intertwined both throughout our entire lives and forever. Think, my love, there were times when brave men killed their wives and all the women in their lineage to prevent them from falling into the hands of the enemy. Their hands did not tremble because their loved ones were begging them to kill them. In times of painful trials, it is the duty of men towards their loved ones! Oh my love, if I must die by someone's hand, let it be by the hand of the one who loves me the most. Dr. Van Helsing, in the case of poor Lucy, it was the one who loved her the most,” -here he paused, blushing, and continued by correcting his words- “the one who most deserved the peace of mind for showing mercy. If such a time comes again, I trust you to turn this situation in my husband's life into a happy memory that it was his own hand that saved me from the terrible slavery I was under.”
es: –You too, my love -she replied, with infinite pity reflected in her eyes and voice-. You must not hesitate. You are the closest and dearest in the world to me; our souls are fused into one for all life and all time. Think, dear, that there have been times when valiant men have killed their wives and daughters to prevent them from falling into the hands of their enemies. Their hands did not tremble at all, because those they loved asked them to end their lives. It is the duty of men for those they love, in such times of harsh trials! And, my love, if someone's hand must give me death, let it be the hand of the one who loves me most. Doctor Van Helsing, I have not forgotten the grace you showed to the person you loved most, in the case of poor Lucy - she paused, blushing slightly, and changed her phrase -, to the one who had the most right to give her peace. If a similar occasion arises again, I count on you to establish that memory in my husband's life, that it be his loving hand that frees me from this terrible curse that weighs upon me.

en: “Again I swear!” came the Professor’s resonant voice. Mrs. Harker smiled, positively smiled, as with a sigh of relief she leaned back and said:—
vi: — Once again, I promise you! - Van Helsing said, his voice dropping significantly. Mina smiled, yes, a genuine smile, and leaned back with a sigh of relief before continuing:
tr: "I promise once again!" echoed the Professor's ringing voice. Ms. Harker, with a sigh of relief, leaned back and smiled happily as she said:
es: –I swear it again! – said the professor, with a resonant voice. Mrs. Harker smiled, truly smiled, as she leaned back with a genuine sigh and said:

en: “And now one word of warning, a warning which you must never forget: this time, if it ever come, may come quickly and unexpectedly, and in such case you must lose no time in using your opportunity. At such a time I myself might be—nay! if the time ever comes, shall be—leagued with your enemy against you.”
vi: — And now, I would like to remind everyone of something that you must be vigilant about, never forget: that moment, if it happens, could come very quickly and unexpectedly. In this case, you should never waste time waiting for any other suitable opportunity. Because at that time, I might... Yes, if that moment occurs, I must join the enemy to fight against you.
tr: “And now a warning; a warning you must never forget: If it comes, this time can come quickly and unexpectedly, and in such a situation, you must not waste any time in seizing the opportunity that comes your way. At such a time, I might unite with your enemy against you - No! If such a time comes, I will unite with him against you.”
es: –Now, I want to give you a warning; a warning that you can never forget: this time, if it appears, it may do so quickly and unexpectedly, and in that case, you must not waste time taking advantage of that opportunity. At that moment, I might be myself... better said, if that moment comes, I will be... Allied with our enemy, against you.

en: “One more request;” she became very solemn as she said this, “it is not vital and necessary like the other, but I want you to do one thing for me, if you will.” We all acquiesced, but no one spoke; there was no need to speak:—
vi: I beg you one more thing, - She said sternly - a plea less vital and less urgent, but a favor I ask of everyone if possible. None of us said a word, because it was not necessary to do so now.
tr: "I have one more request," he said very seriously, "It's not as vital and necessary as the other one, but if you wish, I would like you to do one more thing for me." We all agreed, but no one spoke; there was no need to talk:
es: "One more request -he became very solemn as he said it-. It is not as vital or necessary as the other request, but I wish for you to do something for me, if you so desire." We all nodded, but no one said anything; there was no need to speak.

en: “I want you to read the Burial Service.” She was interrupted by a deep groan from her husband; taking his hand in hers, she held it over her heart, and continued: “You must read it over me some day. Whatever may be the issue of all this fearful state of things, it will be a sweet thought to all or some of us. You, my dearest, will I hope read it, for then it will be in your voice in my memory for ever—come what may!”
vi: — I ask everyone to pray for my soul right now. Jonathan suddenly hiccuped, causing his wife to be interrupted. She took his hand, placed it on her lap, and continued: — There will come a day when you have to recite a prayer for my soul. No matter how this adventure ends, it is just a matter of faith. My dear husband, I hope it will be you who recites the prayer for my soul, that your beloved voice will be etched deeply in my eternal memory, no matter what kind of eternity it may be.
tr: "I want you to read the prayer that was read at the funeral." Her words were interrupted by her husband's deep sigh; she took her husband's hand in hers, brought it to her heart, and continued: "You will read it to me one day. No matter how this horrifying situation ends, this prayer will be a sweet thought for all of us - or some of us. I hope you read it, my love, because no matter what, it will forever be etched in my memory with your voice."
es: –I want you all to read the Office of the Dead. A strong groan from her husband interrupted her; she took his hand in hers, brought it to her heart, and continued: –Someday you will have to read it about me, whatever the end of this terrible state of affairs may be. It will be a sweet thought for all or for some of us. You, my love, I hope you will be the one to read it, because that way it will be your voice that is remembered forever, no matter what happens.

en: “But oh, my dear one,” he pleaded, “death is afar off from you.”
vi: — But my dear, - Jonathan exclaimed - death is still far away from you.
tr: "But ah, my love," her husband pleaded, "death is far away from you."
es: –Should I read that, my dear?

en: “Nay,” she said, holding up a warning hand. “I am deeper in death at this moment than if the weight of an earthly grave lay heavy upon me!”
vi: — No! Now, I am just waiting to be laid out and buried at any moment.
tr: “No!” said Ms. Harker, raising her hand in warning. “Right now, I feel even more engulfed by death than if I were under the weight of a grave filled with earth!”
es: – asked Jonathan. –That will console me, my husband!

en: “Oh, my wife, must I read it?” he said, before he began.
vi: — Oh, my little wife, do I really have to read it?
tr: "Ah! My dear wife! Do I have to read it?" said Harker before starting.
es: – was all she said.

en: “It would comfort me, my husband!” was all she said; and he began to read when she had got the book ready.
vi: — Yes, that will give you more strength, my love. Jonathan trembled as he looked at his wife holding out the Bible in front of him.
tr: The only words Ms. Harker said were, "This will comfort me, my dear husband!" and when she brought the book, Harker began to read.
es: And Jonathan began to read, after preparing the book.

en: “How can I—how could any one—tell of that strange scene, its solemnity, its gloom, its sadness, its horror; and, withal, its sweetness. Even a sceptic, who can see nothing but a travesty of bitter truth in anything holy or emotional, would have been melted to the heart had he seen that little group of loving and devoted friends kneeling round that stricken and sorrowing lady; or heard the tender passion of her husband’s voice, as in tones so broken with emotion that often he had to pause, he read the simple and beautiful service from the Burial of the Dead. I—I cannot go on—words—and—v-voice—f-fail m-me!”
vi: How can I... in a state of confusion, melancholy, fear, and pain, how can I describe this bitter, ironic life scene? My heart feels shattered seeing my friends kneeling beside the unfortunate girl, and a husband struggling to read simple prayers with a broken, fragmented voice amidst sobs. I cannot... each word, each letter cannot penetrate my mind.
tr: How can I or anyone else describe this strange scene, its seriousness, its distress, its sorrow, its horror, and yet its sweetness! Even a skeptic who sees nothing but the ridicule of the bitter truth in anything sacred or emotional would be moved by witnessing the small group of dear, loyal friends gathered around that suffering and sorrowful lady, or by hearing the simple yet beautiful prayer read during the burial, with a voice cracking from the intensity of emotion that often required pauses. "I-I can't go on - the words - and the v-voice - are f-failing me!"
es: How am I going to be able, how could anyone, to describe that strange scene, its solemnity, its gloominess, its sadness, its horror and, yet, also its sweetness? Even a skeptic, who could only see a farce of the bitter truth in anything sacred or emotional, would have been deeply impressed to see that small group of devoted and loving friends, kneeling around that sad and unfortunate lady; or to feel the tender passion in the voice of her husband, whose tone was so emotional that he frequently had to pause, reading the simple and beautiful Office of the Dead. No... I cannot continue, the words and the voice... fail me.

en: She was right in her instinct. Strange as it all was, bizarre as it may hereafter seem even to us who felt its potent influence at the time, it comforted us much; and the silence, which showed Mrs. Harker’s coming relapse from her freedom of soul, did not seem so full of despair to any of us as we had dreaded.
vi: The instinct of a human being had urged him to follow his wife's wishes. If his actions were unbelievable, then we would surely be the first ones to be surprised. But it seemed that the emotional scene before us had helped us regain our strength and determination. Mina's sudden silence indicated that her soul was once again being coerced...
tr: Ms. Harker was right in her instinct. Despite all of this being strange, and even though it would later seem awkward to us who felt its powerful effect at that moment, this prayer had greatly comforted us, and even the silence that marked the end of Ms. Harker's freedom did not seem as filled with despair as we had feared.
es: Her instinct did not deceive her. As strange as it seemed and was, and above all, as it may seem to us even now, we who could feel its powerful influence at that moment, it consoled us greatly; and the silence that preceded Mrs. Harker's loss of spiritual freedom did not seem as full of despair as we had all feared.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 15 October, Varna.—We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, got to Paris the same night, and took the places secured for us in the Orient Express. We travelled night and day, arriving here at about five o’clock. Lord Godalming went to the Consulate to see if any telegram had arrived for him, whilst the rest of us came on to this hotel—“the Odessus.” The journey may have had incidents; I was, however, too eager to get on, to care for them. Until the Czarina Catherine comes into port there will be no interest for me in anything in the wide world. Thank God! Mina is well, and looks to be getting stronger; her colour is coming back. She sleeps a great deal; throughout the journey she slept nearly all the time. Before sunrise and sunset, however, she is very wakeful and alert; and it has become a habit for Van Helsing to hypnotise her at such times. At first, some effort was needed, and he had to make many passes; but now, she seems to yield at once, as if by habit, and scarcely any action is needed. He seems to have power at these particular moments to simply will, and her thoughts obey him. He always asks her what she can see and hear. She answers to the first:—
vi: • Varna, October 15 We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, arrived in Paris the same day, and boarded the Orient Express to continue our journey. The train traveled day and night, bringing us here at around five o'clock. As soon as we got off the station, Lord Godalming hurried to the Consulate to check if there were any telegrams for us, while the rest of us headed to the Odessus Hotel to book rooms. The trip had a few hiccups, but because I was so anxious, I didn't have the heart to pay attention to trivial matters. From now until the Tsarine Catherine docks, nothing in this vast world will catch my attention. Thank God, Mina is still safe and seems to be getting healthier, her face a bit rosier. She sleeps a lot, sleeping through most of the journey. In contrast, just before dawn or dusk, she becomes wide awake and seems much more lively. Those are the times when Professor Van Helsing can perform hypnosis. At first, he encountered some difficulties, having to wave his hands many times, but now, it seems Mina complies immediately. At such times, it seems as though some power imposes itself on her, and his guiding thoughts compel her to follow. He asks her in various ways about what she can see and hear. And this time, she answered:
tr: October 15. Varna. - We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th, arrived in Paris the same night, and took the places reserved for us on the Orient Express. We traveled all night and the next day, arriving here around five o'clock. When Lord Godalming went to the consulate to see if any telegrams had arrived for him, the rest of us came to this hotel - the Odessus. Although some incidents occurred during our journey, I was too eager to continue to pay them any mind. Until the Czarina Catherine docks, there will be nothing in the whole world that interests me. Thank God! Mina seems well and appears to be gaining strength; her color is returning. She sleeps a lot; she slept almost continuously throughout the journey. But she is extremely alert and vigilant just before sunrise and sunset, and at such times, it has become Van Helsing's habit to hypnotize her. Initially, it required some effort and the Professor had to move a lot, but now Mina seems to surrender immediately as if it has become a habit, and almost no movement is needed. At such moments, the Professor seems to have power over her will, and Mina's thoughts obey his words. He always asks her what she can see and hear. Mina's first response is as follows:
es: October 15th, in Varna. We left Charing Cross in the morning of the twelfth, arrived in Paris that same night, and took the seats we had reserved on the Orient Express. We traveled day and night and arrived here at approximately five o'clock. Lord Godalming went to the consulate to see if any telegrams had arrived for him, while the rest of us came to this hotel... "the Odessus". The journey could have been enjoyable; however, I was too anxious to care about it. Until the moment when the Czarina Catherine arrives at the port, there will be nothing in the whole world that interests me at all. Thank God! Mina is well and seems to be regaining her strength; she is getting her color back again. She sleeps a lot. During the day, she sleeps almost all the time. However, before sunrise and sunset, she is very awake and alert, and it has become a habit for Van Helsing to hypnotize her at those times. At first, it required some effort and he needed to make many passes, but now, she seems to respond immediately, as if by habit, and hardly any action is needed. The professor seems to have power at those particular moments; he only needs to will it, and my wife's thoughts obey him. He always asks her what she can see and hear. To the first question, Mina responds:

en: “Nothing; all is dark.” And to the second:—
vi: — I can't see anything. Everything is pitch dark. Then:
tr: “Nothing; everywhere is dark.” And for the Second, it says:
es: –Nothing; everything is dark. And on the second:

en: “I can hear the waves lapping against the ship, and the water rushing by. Canvas and cordage strain and masts and yards creak. The wind is high—I can hear it in the shrouds, and the bow throws back the foam.” It is evident that the Czarina Catherine is still at sea, hastening on her way to Varna. Lord Godalming has just returned. He had four telegrams, one each day since we started, and all to the same effect: that the Czarina Catherine had not been reported to Lloyd’s from anywhere. He had arranged before leaving London that his agent should send him every day a telegram saying if the ship had been reported. He was to have a message even if she were not reported, so that he might be sure that there was a watch being kept at the other end of the wire.
vi: — I heard the sound of waves lapping against the side of the boat and then dissipating. I saw them pulling ropes, the sails, the masts creaking, and even the mast base. The wind was blowing very strongly, I could hear the sound of the ropes cutting through the wind and the bow of the ship slicing through the waves. It is clear that the ship Tsarine Catherine is still adrift at sea and heading towards Varna. Lord Godalming returned to us quite quickly, holding four telegrams that had been sent over several consecutive days since we set out. The telegrams only provided us with the same information. The Hoyd Company informed us of a few points that the Tsarine Catherine passed through. Before leaving London, the lord had prepared money and documents for a trustee so that he could send daily telegrams informing us of the places the ship had signaled to the mainland.
tr: "I can hear the sounds of waves hitting the hull of the ship and the sound of rapidly flowing waters. The sails and ropes are tightening, and the yards and other masts are creaking. The wind is strong - I can tell this from the sound of the sailcloth and the foam splashing from the bow of the ship." Clearly, the Czarina Catherine is still at sea and speeding towards Varna. Lord Godalming has just arrived. Four telegrams have arrived, one sent each day since we set out, and all concerning the same matter: the Czarina Catherine has not been recorded in Lloyd's registers from anywhere. Before leaving London, Lord Godalming had arranged for the agency to send him a telegram every day, informing him whether the ship had been registered or not. Even if it wasn't recorded, he would get the news, thus he could be sure that someone was keeping watch on the other end of the wire.
es: I hear the waves crashing against the sides of the ship and the characteristic sound of the water. The sails and ropes are taut, and the masts and planks creak. The wind is strong... I hear it above the deck, and the foam raised by the stern falls over the bridge. It is evident that the Czarina Catherine is still at sea, hurrying to cover the distance that separates it from Varna. Lord Godalming has just returned. He has four telegrams, one for each of the past four days, all with the same purpose: to ensure that the Czarina Catherine had not been reported to Lloyd's from anywhere. He had made arrangements for the agent to send him a daily telegram, indicating whether the ship had been reported. He had to receive a message each day, even if there was no news of the ship, so that he could be sure that they were truly keeping watch on the other side of the telegraph line.

en: We had dinner and went to bed early. To-morrow we are to see the Vice-Consul, and to arrange, if we can, about getting on board the ship as soon as she arrives. Van Helsing says that our chance will be to get on the boat between sunrise and sunset. The Count, even if he takes the form of a bat, cannot cross the running water of his own volition, and so cannot leave the ship. As he dare not change to man’s form without suspicion—which he evidently wishes to avoid—he must remain in the box. If, then, we can come on board after sunrise, he is at our mercy; for we can open the box and make sure of him, as we did of poor Lucy, before he wakes. What mercy he shall get from us will not count for much. We think that we shall not have much trouble with officials or the seamen. Thank God! this is the country where bribery can do anything, and we are well supplied with money. We have only to make sure that the ship cannot come into port between sunset and sunrise without our being warned, and we shall be safe. Judge Moneybag will settle this case, I think!
vi: We had dinner and went to bed very early. Tomorrow, we have to meet the vice consul and then prepare some necessary tasks to be ready to act as soon as the ship docks. Our opportunity, as Van Helsing put it, will only be possible during the time between sunrise and sunset. Even if he takes the form of a bat, the count cannot traverse a long distance over the turbulent sea using his powers. Thus, he cannot leave the ship. If he wants to hide in human form without arousing suspicion - something he always wants to avoid - he must stay still in the wooden box. In short, we can board the ship after sunrise, and he will be within our reach, as we can open the box and take action, just like we did with Lucy, before he has a chance to wake up. Our pity for him is clearly not an obstacle. Thank God, corruption is rampant everywhere in this land, and we are not short of money. We just need to ensure that the ship docks between sunrise and sunset, and have prior notice. May God arrange everything satisfactorily!
tr: We had our dinner and went to bed early. Tomorrow we will see the consular assistant and, if we can manage, make arrangements to board the ship as soon as we arrive at the port. Van Helsing says that boarding the ship between sunrise and sunset will be an opportunity for us. Even if he takes the form of a bat, the Count cannot cross running water of his own will and thus cannot leave the ship. And, to avoid suspicion - clearly something he wants to avoid - he will not dare to take human form and will have to remain in the box. In this case, if we can board the ship after sunrise, he will be entirely at our mercy; because we can open the box and secure the situation before he wakes up, just as we did with poor Lucy. The mercy he will receive from us will not mean much. We do not anticipate any trouble with the authorities or the sailors. Thank God, this is a country where bribery can open any door, and we have plenty of money! We just need to make sure that the ship does not enter the port between sunset and sunrise without us being informed, so we can secure our plan. I think Judge Moneybag will handle this case!
es: We had dinner and went to bed early. Tomorrow we will go to see the vice-consul, to reach an agreement, if possible, in order to board the ship as soon as it arrives at the dock. Van Helsing says our best chance is to reach the ship between dawn and sunset. The count, even if he takes the form of a bat, cannot cross the water by his own will and, therefore, cannot leave the ship. Since he cannot take human form without arousing suspicion, which must not align well with his desires, he will remain locked in the box. If we can then board after sunrise, he will be completely at our mercy, as we can open the box and secure him, as we did with poor Lucy, before he wakes up. The pity that may arise in some or all of us should not be taken into account. We do not believe we will have many difficulties with public officials or sailors. Thank God! This is a country where bribery is possible and all of us have plenty of money. We just need to ensure that the ship cannot enter the port between sunset and dawn without us being warned, and thus, we will be safe. Judge Moneybag will resolve this case, I believe.

en: 16 October.—Mina’s report still the same: lapping waves and rushing water, darkness and favouring winds. We are evidently in good time, and when we hear of the Czarina Catherine we shall be ready. As she must pass the Dardanelles we are sure to have some report.
vi: • October 16 Mina still picked up similar signals during hypnosis: the sound of water lapping against the ship's hull, the bow cutting through the waves, the dark sky... News about Tsarina Catherine still comes to us regularly.
tr: October 16. - The news from Mina is still the same: Waves crashing against the ship, the sound of water, darkness, and protective winds. It is clear that we have arrived in time; we will be ready when we hear from the Czarina Catherine. Since it has to pass through the Dardanelles, we will undoubtedly receive news.
es: October 16. Mina's report remains the same: the crashing of waves and sounds of water, darkness, and favorable winds. Evidently, we are on time, and by the time the Czarina Catherine arrives, we will be prepared. As it must pass through the Dardanelles Strait, we are sure to receive some report then.

vi: • October 17
tr: Since it has to pass through the Dardanelles, we will undoubtedly receive news.
es: October 17th.

en: 17 October.—Everything is pretty well fixed now, I think, to welcome the Count on his return from his tour. Godalming told the shippers that he fancied that the box sent aboard might contain something stolen from a friend of his, and got a half consent that he might open it at his own risk. The owner gave him a paper telling the Captain to give him every facility in doing whatever he chose on board the ship, and also a similar authorisation to his agent at Varna. We have seen the agent, who was much impressed with Godalming’s kindly manner to him, and we are all satisfied that whatever he can do to aid our wishes will be done. We have already arranged what to do in case we get the box open. If the Count is there, Van Helsing and Seward will cut off his head at once and drive a stake through his heart.
