Morris and Godalming and I shall prevent interference, even if we have to use the arms which we shall have ready. The Professor says that if we can so treat the Count’s body, it will soon after fall into dust. In such case there would be no evidence against us, in case any suspicion of murder were aroused. But even if it were not, we should stand or fall by our act, and perhaps some day this very script may be evidence to come between some of us and a rope. For myself, I should take the chance only too thankfully if it were to come. We mean to leave no stone unturned to carry out our intent. We have arranged with certain officials that the instant the Czarina Catherine is seen, we are to be informed by a special messenger.
vi: I think everything has been carefully prepared to welcome Count Dracula's return. The plan has been set: we will tell the sailors on the ship that the wooden box contains items stolen by a thief from a friend of ours, and Godalming will be responsible for obtaining permission to open the box for inspection. From London, the ship's owner gave him a handwritten letter addressed to the captain, requesting that he facilitate the full execution of his duties. The ship's owner also granted similar authority to an employee in Varna. We met this employee, and thanks to Godalming's noble demeanor, we easily persuaded him to assist us to the best of his ability. We also agreed on the measures to prepare for opening the box. If the Count is inside, Van Helsing and Seward will immediately behead him and drive a sharp stake through his heart. Quincey Morris, Godalming, and I will stand by to provide support and use any necessary weapons. The professor assured us that if we do this, the Count's entire body will instantly turn to dust. In that case, no one would have evidence to accuse us of murder. Even if the outcome does not go as planned, we are willing to face all consequences, and perhaps one day, this book will exonerate us from the gallows. As for myself, I still feel honored to take action if given the opportunity. We decided to stir heaven and earth to achieve success by any means necessary. Anyway, everything has been securely arranged, and now we just await a special message as soon as the ship Tsarine Catherine comes into our sight.
tr: October 17. - I think everything is now nicely arranged to welcome the Count after his trip. Godalming told the transporters that he believed the crate sent abroad contained goods stolen from his friend, and he almost got approval on the condition that he takes responsibility. The owner of the ship gave him a letter addressed to the Captain, instructing that every convenience be provided to Godalming when he boards the ship; he also gave a similar directive to his representative in Varna. We saw the representative, who was quite impressed by the courtesy shown by Godalming, and we were convinced that everything possible would be done to assist our requests. We have already decided what to do if we find the lid of the crate open. If the Count is there, Van Helsing and Dr. Seward will immediately cut off his head and drive a stake through his heart. Morris, Godalming, and I will prevent any interference with this process, even if we have to use the weapons we have ready with us. The Professor says that if we do these things to the Count's body, he will instantly turn to dust. In such a case, if there is any suspicion of murder, there will be no evidence against us. But even if he does not turn to dust, we will either stand by our actions or collapse, and perhaps one day these journals might serve as evidence to clear some of us. Speaking for myself; if this opportunity arises, I will gratefully seize it. We are determined to try every possible way to achieve our goal. We have arranged with some officials to be notified by a special messenger as soon as the Czarina Catherine appears.
es: Everything is already arranged, I believe, to receive the count upon his return from his trip. Godalming told the dockworkers that he believed the box probably contained something that had been stolen from a friend of his and obtained consent to open it, under his own responsibility. The shipowner gave him a paper indicating to the captain to give him all the facilities to do whatever he wanted on board the ship, and, likewise, a similar authorization intended for his agent in Varna. We have visited the agent, who was very impressed by Lord Godalming's manners towards him, and we are sure that he will do everything he can to satisfy our wishes. We have already resolved what we should do in the event that we receive the box opened. If the count is inside, Van Helsing and Dr. Seward must immediately cut off his head and pierce his heart with a stake. Morris, Lord Godalming, and I must avoid any intrusions, even if it means using weapons, which we will have ready. The professor says that if we can treat the Count's body in this way, it will turn to dust immediately. In that case, there will be no evidence against us, in the event that there are suspicions of murder. But, even if it does not happen that way, we must face the consequences of our act, whether good or bad, and it is possible that someday in the future, these writings may serve to stand between some of us and the gallows. As for me, I will take the risk feeling very grateful, if necessary. We do not intend to leave anything to chance in carrying out our plan. We have made arrangements with several officials to be informed by a special messenger as soon as the Czarina Catherine is sighted.

en: 24 October.—A whole week of waiting. Daily telegrams to Godalming, but only the same story: “Not yet reported.” Mina’s morning and evening hypnotic answer is unvaried: lapping waves, rushing water, and creaking masts.
vi: • October 24 A week of waiting has passed. The daily telegrams sent to Godalming always repeated one sentence: "Still no new information." Mina's response during each hypnosis session also remained unchanged: "The sound of waves crashing, the wind howling, the mast creaking..."
tr: October 24. - We waited the whole week. Every day a telegram comes to Godalming, but it's always the same story: "Not yet recorded." Mina's responses during the morning and evening hypnotisms haven't changed:
es: October 24. We have been waiting for a whole week. Lord Godalming receives his telegrams daily, but they always say the same thing: "Not yet reported." Mina's response in the mornings and evenings, always in a hypnotic trance, has not changed: the clash of waves, sounds of water, and creaking of masts.

en: Telegram, October 24th.
vi: Telegram from Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, kindly forwarded by H. B. M. Vice Consul at Varna

en: “Czarina Catherine reported this morning from Dardanelles.”

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 25 October.—How I miss my phonograph! To write diary with a pen is irksome to me; but Van Helsing says I must. We were all wild with excitement yesterday when Godalming got his telegram from Lloyd’s. I know now what men feel in battle when the call to action is heard. Mrs. Harker, alone of our party, did not show any signs of emotion. After all, it is not strange that she did not; for we took special care not to let her know anything about it, and we all tried not to show any excitement when we were in her presence. In old days she would, I am sure, have noticed, no matter how we might have tried to conceal it; but in this way she is greatly changed during the past three weeks. The lethargy grows upon her, and though she seems strong and well, and is getting back some of her colour, Van Helsing and I are not satisfied. We talk of her often; we have not, however, said a word to the others. It would break poor Harker’s heart—certainly his nerve—if he knew that we had even a suspicion on the subject. Van Helsing examines, he tells me, her teeth very carefully, whilst she is in the hypnotic condition, for he says that so long as they do not begin to sharpen there is no active danger of a change in her. If this change should come, it would be necessary to take steps!... We both know what those steps would have to be, though we do not mention our thoughts to each other. We should neither of us shrink from the task—awful though it be to contemplate. “Euthanasia” is an excellent and a comforting word! I am grateful to whoever invented it.
vi: • October 24 I deeply regret not bringing the phonograph. There is truly nothing that makes me feel more miserable than having to write a diary with a pen, but Van Helsing insists that it must be written. This morning, we thought we might go mad when Lord Godalming received a telegram from Hoyd. Now I understand the kind of emotions warriors must endure when waiting for the signal to attack. Among us, only Mina shows no sign of anything, because we still try not to let her know anything and try not to let her notice everyone's impatience. In the past, I was sure she would have noticed the expressions on each person's face, but since three weeks ago, everything has changed. Many times she looks dazed like a lost soul, and although she seems healthier, Van Helsing and I are still not satisfied. We often talk about her but do not tell others, for fear that it might reach Jonathan and cause him more distress. During hypnosis, Van Helsing carefully examined her two sets of teeth and said that they haven't grown any longer, which means that currently there is no change indicating an imminent danger looming over us. If we notice any signs of instability, we must take preventive measures immediately. We understand what those measures are, even though no one speaks out their thoughts. No one among us will cowardly retreat from the task, even if it is the most terrifying one. “Peaceful death” is a wonderful phrase that gives us strength!
tr: October 25. - How I miss my phonograph! Keeping a journal with a pen is very frustrating for me; but Van Helsing says I must do it. Yesterday, when a telegram came from Lloyd to Lord Godalming, we all went wild with excitement. I now understand how men feel when they learn it is time to take action in wars. Only Ms. Harker among us showed no sign of emotion. After all, it is not strange that she did not react; because we have been particularly careful to keep her uninformed about the situation and tried not to show any signs of excitement when around her. In the old days, I am sure she would have noticed no matter how much we tried to hide it, but in this regard, she has changed significantly in the past three weeks. The state of lethargy is increasing, and despite her appearing strong and healthy, and her color returning somewhat, Van Helsing and I are not pleased with her condition. We often talk about her, but we have not said a word to the others about it. Poor Harker would be hurt if he heard we had doubts about this - and undoubtedly his nerves would be shattered. Van Helsing says he carefully observes Ms. Harker's teeth while she is hypnotized, because according to him, as long as they do not sharpen over time, there is no danger of transformation. If this transformation occurs, some steps will need to be taken! Although we do not share our thoughts with each other, we both know what these steps are, and neither of us should avoid this duty - though it is terrible to think about, it is so. “Euthanasia” is a perfect and comforting word! I owe thanks to whoever coined this term.
es: October 25. How I miss my phonograph! Writing a diary with a pen is exasperating for me. But Van Helsing says I must do it. We were all very nervous yesterday when Godalming received his telegram from Lloyd's. Now I completely understand what men feel in battles when they are ordered into action. The only one in our group who showed no sign of emotion was Mrs. Harker. After all, it is not surprising that she did not get emotional, as we took special care not to let her know anything about it and all tried not to appear disturbed in her presence. In the past, I am sure she would have noticed immediately, no matter how much we tried to hide it from her, but, in reality, she has changed a lot over the last three weeks. The lethargy is becoming more pronounced in her and she is regaining some of her color. Van Helsing and I are not satisfied. We talk about her frequently; however, we have not said a word to the others. It would break poor Harker's heart, or at least his nervous system, if he knew that we had even the slightest suspicions about it. Van Helsing tells me that he examines her teeth very carefully while she is in a hypnotic trance, as he assures that as long as they do not begin to sharpen, there is no active danger of a change in her. If that change occurs... it will happen in several stages...! We both know what these stages will necessarily be, although we do not confide our thoughts to each other. None of us must shrink from the task... no matter how tremendous it may seem to us. "Euthanasia" is an excellent and consoling word! I am grateful to whoever invented it.

en: It is only about 24 hours’ sail from the Dardanelles to here, at the rate the Czarina Catherine has come from London. She should therefore arrive some time in the morning; but as she cannot possibly get in before then, we are all about to retire early. We shall get up at one o’clock, so as to be ready.
vi: From the Dardanelles to here takes about twenty-four hours if you count the wind direction from London. Therefore, the Tsarine Catherine will only appear tomorrow morning. Knowing that the ship cannot arrive any earlier, we decided to go to bed early and wake up at one o'clock to prepare.
tr: According to the speed of Czarina Catherine coming from London, it will take approximately 24 hours for her to arrive here from the Dardanelles. Therefore, she should arrive here in the morning, but since she cannot dock at the port before then, we will all go to bed early. We will wake up at one o'clock to prepare.
es: There are only about twenty-four hours of sailing from the Dardanelles to this place, at the speed that the Czarina Catherine has been traveling from London. Therefore, it should arrive during the morning, but since it is not possible for it to arrive before noon, we all prepare to retire to our rooms early. We must get up at one o'clock to be prepared.

en: 25 October, Noon.—No news yet of the ship’s arrival. Mrs. Harker’s hypnotic report this morning was the same as usual, so it is possible that we may get news at any moment. We men are all in a fever of excitement, except Harker, who is calm; his hands are cold as ice, and an hour ago I found him whetting the edge of the great Ghoorka knife which he now always carries with him. It will be a bad lookout for the Count if the edge of that “Kukri” ever touches his throat, driven by that stern, ice-cold hand!
vi: October 25, noon There is still no new information about the ship's whereabouts. The information conveyed by Mina during her trance was no different, to the point that we could immediately understand the meaning in each of her words. We were all feverish with anticipation, except for Jonathan who remained calm as if nothing had happened. His hands were as cold as ice, he quietly went outside and diligently sharpened the sharp Kukri knife, after which he never let it out of his sight. It was indeed a dire prospect for the old count: that knife's blade would pierce straight into his neck with a swift and cold-blooded hand.
tr: October 25, noon. - No news regarding the ship's arrival. Ms. Harker's hypnotic report this morning was as usual, so we can receive news at any moment. All of us are excited except for the cool-headed Harker; Harker's hands are ice-cold and I saw her an hour ago, sharpening the large kukri she now constantly carries with her. Having the edge of the kukri pressed against his throat by a ruthless, ice-cold hand will be a nasty surprise for the Count.
es: October 25, at noon. We still haven't received any news of the ship's arrival. Mrs. Harker's hypnotic report this morning was the same as always; therefore, it is possible that we will receive news about it at any moment. All the men are feverish with excitement, except Harker, who is calm; his hands are as cold as ice and, an hour ago, I found him moistening the edge of the large Gurkha knife he always carries with him now. It will be a bad moment for the count if the edge of that "kukri" touches his throat, wielded by such cold and steady hands!

en: Van Helsing and I were a little alarmed about Mrs. Harker to-day. About noon she got into a sort of lethargy which we did not like; although we kept silence to the others, we were neither of us happy about it. She had been restless all the morning, so that we were at first glad to know that she was sleeping. When, however, her husband mentioned casually that she was sleeping so soundly that he could not wake her, we went to her room to see for ourselves. She was breathing naturally and looked so well and peaceful that we agreed that the sleep was better for her than anything else. Poor girl, she has so much to forget that it is no wonder that sleep, if it brings oblivion to her, does her good.
vi: Today, both Van Helsing and I are worried about Mina. Near noon, she suddenly fell into a deep sleep. We felt sad but didn't say anything to the rest of our friends. In the morning, she was constantly busy with various unnamed tasks, sometimes even acting excessively. We were genuinely relieved when we saw her go back to her room to rest. However, when Jonathan informed us that she was sleeping so soundly that no amount of calling could wake her, we had to immediately check on her to see what was happening. She was still breathing naturally and seemingly steadily, so gently that we all thought that for her at this moment, nothing could be better than a deep sleep. Poor girl, will a long sleep help her forget everything? There is nothing surprising if the sleep is natural and suitable for her at this time.
tr: Today, Van Helsing and I are a bit worried about Ms. Harker. Around noon, she fell into a state of sleep that we did not like at all; although we told the others, neither of us liked this situation. She was very restless all morning, so we were initially pleased when we learned she was asleep. But when her husband casually mentioned that she was sleeping very deeply and that he couldn't wake her up, we went to her room to see for ourselves. She was breathing normally and looked so well and peaceful that we agreed sleep was more beneficial for her than anything else. Poor girl, she has so much to forget that if it makes her indifferent, it is not surprising that sleep is good for her.
es: Van Helsing and I are somewhat alarmed today regarding Mrs. Harker. Near midday, she fell into a kind of lethargy that we do not like at all, although we kept it a secret and did not tell the others, we do not feel happy about it at all. She was restless all morning, so at first, we were glad to know that she had fallen asleep. However, when her husband mentioned that she was so deeply asleep that he had not been able to wake her, we went to her room to see for ourselves. She was breathing naturally and looked so pleasant and full of peace that we agreed that sleep was better for her than anything else. Poor woman! She has so many things to forget that it is not surprising that sleep, if it allows her to forget, does her a lot of good.

en: Later.—Our opinion was justified, for when after a refreshing sleep of some hours she woke up, she seemed brighter and better than she had been for days. At sunset she made the usual hypnotic report. Wherever he may be in the Black Sea, the Count is hurrying to his destination. To his doom, I trust!
vi: • A moment later Our feeling was completely accurate, because when Mina woke up after many hours of deep sleep, she was energetic and even healthier than she had been in days. At sunset, in a hypnotized state, she informed us that on the Black Sea, Count Dracula's ship was speeding towards its destination. Speeding towards the place of his judgment, yes, I know!
tr: Later on. - It turned out that we were right in our thinking, because when he woke up from a few hours of refreshing sleep, he looked more lively and better than he had in recent days. At sunset, he presented his usual hypnotic report. Wherever he was in the Black Sea, the Count was rapidly progressing towards his destination. I hope towards his own demise!
es: Later. Our opinion was justified, since, after a good sleep of several hours, he woke up; he seemed brighter and better than he had been for several days. At sunset, he gave the same report as usual. Wherever he may be, in the Black Sea, the count is hastening to reach his destination. I trust it will be to his destruction!

en: 26 October.—Another day and no tidings of the Czarina Catherine. She ought to be here by now. That she is still journeying somewhere is apparent, for Mrs. Harker’s hypnotic report at sunrise was still the same. It is possible that the vessel may be lying by, at times, for fog; some of the steamers which came in last evening reported patches of fog both to north and south of the port. We must continue our watching, as the ship may now be signalled any moment.
vi: • October 26 It's strange that yet another day has passed without any news about Tsarine Catherine. By now, it should have returned. Surely, it must still be adrift somewhere, as during the dawn séance, Mina reiterated what she had said in previous days. Perhaps the ship is temporarily halted due to fog. The sailors on the steamships that just docked reported that yesterday at sea, both to the north and the south, there was a lot of fog. So, we have no choice but to continue waiting and watching, as the ship could appear at any moment.
tr: October 26. - Another day has passed and there is still no news from the Czarina Catherine. It should have arrived by now. It is definitely still somewhere on the way because Ms. Harker's morning hypnotic report was still the same. Perhaps it has stopped from time to time due to the fog; some of the steamships that arrived last night reported that there was fog in places both north and south of the port. We must maintain our watch, for the ship's signal may come at any moment.
es: October 26. Another day has passed, and there are no signs of the Czarina Catherine. It should have arrived by now. It is evident that it is still sailing somewhere, as Mrs. Harker's hypnotic report before sunrise was exactly the same. It is possible that the ship sometimes remains stationary due to the fog; several steamers that arrived last night reported encountering fog banks both to the north and south of the port. We must continue our watch, as the ship may be signaled to us at any moment now.

en: 27 October, Noon.—Most strange; no news yet of the ship we wait for. Mrs. Harker reported last night and this morning as usual: “lapping waves and rushing water,” though she added that “the waves were very faint.” The telegrams from London have been the same: “no further report.” Van Helsing is terribly anxious, and told me just now that he fears the Count is escaping us. He added significantly:—
vi: • October 27, noon Strange! There is still no new information about the ship. Yesterday afternoon and this morning, Mina continued to say the usual things: "The waves slap against the side of the ship, the ship cuts through the water," and then: "the waves are very weak." Van Helsing seemed terribly worried, he said he thought the Count had slipped out of our grasp and emphasized:
tr: October 27, noon. - Very strange! There is still no news from the ship we are expecting. Ms. Harker reported ordinary things last night and this morning: Despite adding that "The waves are barely noticeable," she still mentioned, "The sound of waves hitting the ship and water." The telegrams from London were the same: "No new records." Van Helsing is terribly uneasy and just now told me that he fears the Count has escaped from us. And he added importantly:
es: October 27, at noon. It is very strange that we have not yet received news of the ship we are expecting. Mrs. Harker gave her report last night and this morning as usual: "Crashes of waves and sounds of water," although she added that "the waves were very gentle." The telegrams from London had been exactly the same as always: "No further reports." Van Helsing is terribly anxious and told me a few moments ago that he fears the count is fleeing from us. He added significantly:

en: “I did not like that lethargy of Madam Mina’s. Souls and memories can do strange things during trance.” I was about to ask him more, but Harker just then came in, and he held up a warning hand. We must try to-night at sunset to make her speak more fully when in her hypnotic state.
vi: — I don't like Mina's way of falling into a deep sleep. Her spirit and memory might cause some issues while being hypnotized. I was about to ask a few more questions when he waved his hand repeatedly to signal silence, because Jonathan had just appeared. This evening, we will try to extract more information from her during hypnosis. Telegram from Rufus Smith, Lloyd’s, London, to Lord Godalming, kindly forwarded by H. B. M's Vice Consul at Varna
tr: “I did not like Madam Mina’s sleep condition. When in a trance state, spirits and memories can do strange things.” I was about to ask her more when Harker entered and the Professor signaled me to be silent. This evening at sunset, while Ms. Harker is hypnotized, we will try to make her talk more.
es: –I don't like that lethargy of Mrs. Mina. Souls and memories can do very strange things during trances. I was about to ask him something more about it, but Harker entered at that moment and the professor raised a hand to warn me of it. We must try this afternoon, at sunset, to make her talk a bit more when she is in her hypnotic state.

en: 28 October.—Telegram. Rufus Smith, London, to Lord Godalming, care H. B. M. Vice Consul, Varna.
vi: October 28 The Tsarine Catherine ship signaled at the port entrance of Galatz at one o'clock today.
tr: October 28 - At Lloyd's London office From Rufus Smith, Her Majesty Varna Through the Deputy Consul Telegram to Lord Godalming
es: October 28. Telegram. Rufus Smith, London, to Lord Godalming, under the responsibility of the Honorable English Vice-Consul in Varna

en: “Czarina Catherine reported entering Galatz at one o’clock to-day.”
vi: The Tsarine Catherine ship signaled at the port entrance of Galatz at one o'clock today.
tr: It was recorded today at one o'clock that Czarina Catherine entered Galaţi.
es: "They report that Czarina Catherine entered Galatz today at one o'clock sharp."

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 28 October.—When the telegram came announcing the arrival in Galatz I do not think it was such a shock to any of us as might have been expected. True, we did not know whence, or how, or when, the bolt would come; but I think we all expected that something strange would happen. The delay of arrival at Varna made us individually satisfied that things would not be just as we had expected; we only waited to learn where the change would occur. None the less, however, was it a surprise. I suppose that nature works on such a hopeful basis that we believe against ourselves that things will be as they ought to be, not as we should know that they will be. Transcendentalism is a beacon to the angels, even if it be a will-o’-the-wisp to man. It was an odd experience and we all took it differently. Van Helsing raised his hand over his head for a moment, as though in remonstrance with the Almighty; but he said not a word, and in a few seconds stood up with his face sternly set. Lord Godalming grew very pale, and sat breathing heavily. I was myself half stunned and looked in wonder at one after another. Quincey Morris tightened his belt with that quick movement which I knew so well; in our old wandering days it meant “action.” Mrs. Harker grew ghastly white, so that the scar on her forehead seemed to burn, but she folded her hands meekly and looked up in prayer. Harker smiled—actually smiled—the dark, bitter smile of one who is without hope; but at the same time his action belied his words, for his hands instinctively sought the hilt of the great Kukri knife and rested there. “When does the next train start for Galatz?” said Van Helsing to us generally.
vi: • October 28 When we received the telegram informing us that the ship was in Galatz, we were less shocked and more suspicious. We did not understand where and when this sudden change began to occur. We were waiting for some kind of surprise to happen. The ship's late delay forced us to believe that everything was happening differently from what we had planned. We could only tell ourselves that the ship might have changed its course. In reality, everything happened exactly as it should have, not as we had guessed it would. The sudden change caused each of us to react in our own way. Van Helsing raised his hands to the sky as if to explain something but couldn't say a word, after a moment he lowered his hands, his face still very calm. Lord Godalming sat down on the ground, his face pale, his breath broken. I was stunned, looking from one person to another. Quincey Morris jerked his belt tight; in this foreign land, I understood his action to mean: "we need to take action!" Meanwhile, Mina's face was as pale as a corpse, the scar on her forehead suddenly seemed to redden, and she clasped her hands as if praying. Jonathan laughed out loud, yes, a bitter, sarcastic laugh, tears streaming down as if he had lost all hope, but his hand still groped for the Kukri knife and gripped its handle with the mindset of someone harboring unresolved resentment. — What time does the next train to Galatz leave, I wonder? - Van Helsing asked aloud.
tr: October 28. - When we received the telegram announcing that the ship had arrived in Galaţi, I don't think it was as big a shock as it could have been for any of us. Okay, we didn't know where, how, or when it would come, but I think we were all expecting something strange to happen. The delay in arriving at Varna convinced us one by one that events would not unfold as we had expected; we only waited to learn where this change would occur. But still, it was a surprise. I think nature works on such a hopeful basis that, even against ourselves, we believe that everything will happen not as we know it will, but as it should. Though misleading for metaphysical people, it is a guide for angels. It was a strange experience, and we all perceived it differently. Van Helsing raised his hands above his head for a moment as if lamenting to God, but said not a word and stood up with a stern expression on his face within a few seconds. Lord Godalming's face turned pale, and he sat down, breathing heavily. I was half-dazed and looked at each person's face in curiosity. Quincey Morris tightened his belt with that quick motion I knew so well; in our old traveling days, this meant "action." Ms. Harker's face turned as white as a sheet, so much so that the scar on her forehead seemed to burn, but she meekly clasped her hands and looked upwards as if in prayer. Harker laughed - he really laughed - the dark, bitter laugh of a hopeless man; but at the same time, his actions contradicted his words because his hands instinctively searched for the hilt of the large kukri and grasped it. Van Helsing asked aloud, "When does the next train to Galaţi depart?"
es: October 28. When the telegram announcing the ship's arrival in Galatz came, I don't think it shocked any of us as much as one might have expected under the circumstances. It's true that none of us knew where, how, or when the difficulty would arise, but I believe we all expected something strange to happen. The day it was supposed to arrive in Varna, we all individually convinced ourselves that things were not going to happen as we had imagined; we were just waiting to know where the change would occur. Nevertheless, it was still a surprise. I suppose that nature works on such hopeful bases that we believe, against our better judgment, that things have to be as they should be, not as we should know they will be. Transcendentalism is a guide for angels, but a will-o'-the-wisp for men. Van Helsing raised his hand over his head for a moment, as if arguing with the Almighty, but he didn't say a word and, after a few seconds, he stood up with a hard expression on his face. Lord Godalming turned very pale and sat down, breathing heavily. I myself was absolutely stunned and looked at the others in astonishment. Quincey Morris tightened his belt with a quick movement that I knew very well: in our adventurous times, it meant "action." Mrs. Harker turned intensely pale, so much so that the scar on her forehead seemed to be burning, but she clasped her hands piously and looked up, praying. Harker smiled, with the dark and bitter smile of someone who has lost all hope, but at the same time, his action belied that impression, as his hands instinctively went to the handle of his large kukri knife and remained resting on it. –When does the next train to Galatz leave? – van Helsing asked us, addressing everyone in general.

en: “At 6:30 to-morrow morning!” We all started, for the answer came from Mrs. Harker.
vi: — 6:30 AM tomorrow. We were startled, because the person who answered was Mina.
tr: “Tomorrow morning at 6. 30!” We all stared in astonishment, because the response had come from Ms. Harker.
es: –Tomorrow morning, at half past six! – we all started, because the answer had been given by Mrs. Harker.

en: “How on earth do you know?” said Art.
vi: — My God, how did you know? - Arthur asked.
tr: "How do you know?" asked Art.
es: –How is it possible that you know that? – said Art.

en: “You forget—or perhaps you do not know, though Jonathan does and so does Dr. Van Helsing—that I am the train fiend. At home in Exeter I always used to make up the time-tables, so as to be helpful to my husband. I found it so useful sometimes, that I always make a study of the time-tables now. I knew that if anything were to take us to Castle Dracula we should go by Galatz, or at any rate through Bucharest, so I learned the times very carefully. Unhappily there are not many to learn, as the only train to-morrow leaves as I say.”
vi: — Perhaps you have forgotten, or maybe you don't know that I always have a fondness for traveling by train. When I was at home, I mean in Exeter, I had the habit of checking train schedules to help Jonathan with his work. It happened so often that I still haven't gotten rid of that habit now. Moreover, I also understand that if we are forced to go to Dracula's castle, we have to pass through Galatz or at least through Bucharest, which is why I have been paying close attention to the train schedules. But there's nothing to worry about, because tomorrow there is only one train departing at the time I just mentioned.
tr: “You forget -or perhaps you are unaware, though Jonathan and Dr. Van Helsing know- that I am an expert on trains. When I was at home in Exeter, I would always write down the train schedules to help my husband. I found this so useful at times that I now constantly study train schedules. If there was anything that would take us to Castle Dracula, I knew we had to go through Galaţi or somehow pass through Bucharest; thus, I learned the train times carefully. Unfortunately, there isn't much to learn, because the only train tomorrow leaves at the time I mentioned.”
es: –You forget..., or perhaps you don't know, although my husband and Dr. Van Helsing know very well, that I am a train enthusiast. At home, in Exeter, I always used to adjust the timetables to be helpful to my husband. I knew that if something forced us to head towards Dracula's castle, we would have to go through Galatz or, at the very least, through Bucharest; therefore, I learned the schedules carefully. Unfortunately, there weren't many schedules to learn, as the only train leaves tomorrow at the time I told you.

en: “Wonderful woman!” murmured the Professor.
vi: — She surprises us again! - Van Helsing whispered.
tr: “The perfect woman!” whispered the Professor.
es: –Wonderful woman! – said the professor.

en: “Can’t we get a special?” asked Lord Godalming. Van Helsing shook his head: “I fear not. This land is very different from yours or mine; even if we did have a special, it would probably not arrive as soon as our regular train. Moreover, we have something to prepare. We must think. Now let us organize. You, friend Arthur, go to the train and get the tickets and arrange that all be ready for us to go in the morning. Do you, friend Jonathan, go to the agent of the ship and get from him letters to the agent in Galatz, with authority to make search the ship just as it was here. Morris Quincey, you see the Vice-Consul, and get his aid with his fellow in Galatz and all he can do to make our way smooth, so that no times be lost when over the Danube. John will stay with Madam Mina and me, and we shall consult. For so if time be long you may be delayed; and it will not matter when the sun set, since I am here with Madam to make report.”
vi: — So, can't we hire a private train? - Lord Godalming asked. Van Helsing shook his head and replied: — I'm afraid not. This country is not like England, nor is it like my country. And even if there were such a trip, we certainly couldn't get there before the regular train. Not to mention, we still have quite a lot to prepare. We need to take our time to think and arrange everything properly before we go. Arthur, my friend, perhaps you should go to the station, buy tickets, and arrange everything so that we can depart tomorrow morning. Jonathan, you need to go to the shipping agent to tell them to send a letter to the company's staff in Galatz, stating the reason to inspect the wooden box just as we planned in Varna. Quincey Morris, you should meet the Vice Consul and ask him to request a colleague in Galatz to scout ahead for us, so that when we reach the Danube we don't waste any more time. And John, you stay with Mina and me, we will consider everything. With me looking after Mina, there's nothing to worry about as evening falls.
tr: “Can’t we hire a special train?” asked Lord Godalming. Van Helsing shook his head. “I’m afraid not. This country is quite different from yours or mine; even if we had a special train, it wouldn’t arrive as quickly as a scheduled one. Besides, there is something we need to prepare for. We must think. Now, let’s organize what needs to be done. You, my friend Arthur, go to the train and get the tickets, ensuring everything is ready for us to depart in the morning. You, my friend Jonathan, go to the ship’s agent here and get the letters from him that will allow us to search the ship in Galaţi, just as we did here. Morris Quincey, you see the consular assistant and get any help he can provide from his colleague in Galaţi to smooth our way, so we don’t lose time while on the Danube. John, you will stay with Madam Mina and me, and we will exchange views; if your task takes too long, you might be late; it won’t be a problem at sunset because I am here for Madam’s report.”
es: "Can't we get a special one?" asked Lord Godalming. Van Helsing shook his head. –I'm afraid not. This country is very different from yours or mine; even if we managed to get a special train, we wouldn't arrive before the regular train. Besides, we have something to prepare. We must reflect. We have to organize ourselves. You, friend Arthur, go to the station, purchase the tickets, and make all the necessary arrangements so that we can set off tomorrow. You, friend Jonathan, go see the shipping agent to get orders for the agent in Galatz, so that we can inspect the ship just as we did here. Quincey Morris, see the vice-consul and obtain his help to get in touch with his colleague in Galatz and do everything possible to smooth our way, so that we don't have to waste time when we are on the Danube. John should stay with Mrs. Mina and me, and we will talk. Thus, if time passes and you are delayed, it won't matter if sunset comes, since I will be here with Mrs. Mina, so she can give us her report.

en: “And I,” said Mrs. Harker brightly, and more like her old self than she had been for many a long day, “shall try to be of use in all ways, and shall think and write for you as I used to do. Something is shifting from me in some strange way, and I feel freer than I have been of late!” The three younger men looked happier at the moment as they seemed to realise the significance of her words; but Van Helsing and I, turning to each other, met each a grave and troubled glance. We said nothing at the time, however.
vi: — As for me, - She said cheerfully, her voice brimming with joy just like her old self - I will try to help everyone in every way I can, I will think and write as I used to. There is a very strange change happening within me, I no longer feel compelled as I have for so long. The faces of the three young men suddenly lit up when they understood the meaning of Mina's words. But Van Helsing and I did not. The two of us exchanged looks full of emotion. However, at this moment, we couldn't discuss anything.
tr: “Me too,” said Ms. Harker with a radiant expression reminiscent of her old days, “I will try to help you in every way and, as I used to, I will think and put things down on paper for you. Strangely, something is changing in me; I feel freer than I have been lately!” The three young men, who seemed to understand the significance of Ms. Harker's words, looked happier than before; but Van Helsing and I turned to each other with serious and troubled expressions. But we said nothing at that time.
es: –And I -said Mrs. Harker vividly, with an expression more similar to the old one from her happy days than we had seen in many days-, I am going to try to be useful to you in every possible way and I must think and write for you, as I did before. Something is changing in me in a very strange way, and I feel freer than I have been in recent times! The three youngest seemed to feel happier the moment they thought they understood the meaning of his words, but Van Helsing and I looked at each other with seriousness and great concern. However, we said nothing at that moment.

en: When the three men had gone out to their tasks Van Helsing asked Mrs. Harker to look up the copy of the diaries and find him the part of Harker’s journal at the Castle. She went away to get it; when the door was shut upon her he said to me:—
vi: When the three men had gone their separate ways to carry out their tasks, Van Helsing suggested that Mina check the entire set of journal copies and get him the pages that described Jonathan's time in exile at Dracula's castle. The young woman greeted us and then went to work immediately. After she was out of sight, Van Helsing said to me:
tr: When the three men went outside due to their assigned duties, Dr. Van Helsing asked Ms. Harker to look at the copies of the journals and to find the section in Harker's journal where he described his days at the castle. Ms. Harker went out to find it; when the door closed behind her, the Professor said to me:
es: When the three men left to take care of the tasks that had been entrusted to them, Van Helsing asked Mrs. Harker to fetch the copies of the journals and bring him the part of Harker's journal related to the castle. The lady went to get what the professor had asked for. As soon as the door closed behind her, he said to me:

en: “We mean the same! speak out!”
vi: — You have the same thoughts as I do. Then say it!
tr: “We are both thinking the same thing! Say it!”
es: –We think the same! Speak!

en: “There is some change. It is a hope that makes me sick, for it may deceive us.”
vi: — There is something unusual happening, an expectation that makes me somewhat uneasy, because it might lead me to incorrect reasoning.
tr: "There is a change. This glimmer of hope is getting on my nerves, because it might be deceiving us."
es: –There has been a change. It is a hope that makes me sick, because we might suffer a disappointment.

en: “Quite so. Do you know why I asked her to get the manuscript?”
vi: — That's right. So, do you know why I told her to go find the pile of diary copies?
tr: “No doubt! Do you know why I asked him to bring that text?”
es: –Exactly. Do you know why I asked her to go get the manuscript for me?

en: “No!” said I, “unless it was to get an opportunity of seeing me alone.”
vi: — No, unless you told her to leave so you could have a chance to talk to me alone.
tr: "No!" I said, "Unless it is to get an opportunity to meet with me alone."
es: –No! – I told him –, unless it was to have a chance to talk to me alone.

en: “You are in part right, friend John, but only in part. I want to tell you something. And oh, my friend, I am taking a great—a terrible—risk; but I believe it is right. In the moment when Madam Mina said those words that arrest both our understanding, an inspiration came to me. In the trance of three days ago the Count sent her his spirit to read her mind; or more like he took her to see him in his earth-box in the ship with water rushing, just as it go free at rise and set of sun. He learn then that we are here; for she have more to tell in her open life with eyes to see and ears to hear than he, shut, as he is, in his coffin-box. Now he make his most effort to escape us. At present he want her not.
vi: — That might be so, but only partially. I have something to tell you. John, it seems that I have realized a truly serious and terrifying danger. When Mina said those words, for some reason, a strange suggestion popped into my mind. Three days ago, while I was hypnotized, the Count entered her soul to read her thoughts, or more precisely, he summoned her soul to meet him in the wooden box on the ship Tsarine Catherine, at the time he was freed by dawn or dusk. Now he knows we are here. Because clearly she, who has the freedom to move around and see and hear things, always knows more than someone confined in a cramped box of earth like him. He is trying every way to escape our pursuit. He doesn't need her immediately because he believes that sooner or later she will come to him at his call.
tr: “You are partly right, my friend John, but only partly. I want to tell you something. And oh, my friend, I am taking a great -terrible- risk. A thought occurred to me when Madam Mina said those words that caught both of our attention. Three days ago, while in a trance, the Count sent his spirit to read her mind, or rather, because he can move freely at sunrise and sunset, he took her along to see him in the earth box on the ship, accompanied by the flow of the waters. He learned that we are here, because Madam Mina, with her seeing eyes and hearing ears, has much more to tell in her free life compared to the Count, who is confined in his coffin-like box. Now, he will make his greatest effort to escape from us. At this moment, he does not want Madam Mina.
es: –You are partly right, my friend, but only partly. I want to tell you something and, truly, my friend John, I am taking a terrible risk, but I think it is fair. At the moment when Mrs. Mina said those words that surprised us both so much. I had an inspiration. During the trance three days ago, the count sent his spirit to read her mind; or it is more likely that he took her to see him in his box of earth on the ship, in the middle of the sea; that is why she was freed shortly before sunrise and sunset. Thus, he knew we were here, since she had more to say in her life outdoors, with eyes to see and ears to hear, than he, locked as he is, in his coffin. So now he must be making a supreme effort to flee from us. He does not need her currently.

en: “He is sure with his so great knowledge that she will come at his call; but he cut her off—take her, as he can do, out of his own power, that so she come not to him. Ah! there I have hope that our man-brains that have been of man so long and that have not lost the grace of God, will come higher than his child-brain that lie in his tomb for centuries, that grow not yet to our stature, and that do only work selfish and therefore small. Here comes Madam Mina; not a word to her of her trance! She know it not; and it would overwhelm her and make despair just when we want all her hope, all her courage; when most we want all her great brain which is trained like man’s brain, but is of sweet woman and have a special power which the Count give her, and which he may not take away altogether—though he think not so. Hush! let me speak, and you shall learn. Oh, John, my friend, we are in awful straits. I fear, as I never feared before. We can only trust the good God. Silence! here she comes!”
vi: He cut off contact with her, withdrew his power over her so that temporarily she is no longer under his possession. That, yes, that explains why I hope the mind long belonging to humanity of our men is far superior to the childish mind of him, someone who for centuries has only known to hide in tombs and is incapable of reaching our level now, someone who is limited by selfish and petty desires. Mina is here. Don't mention anything related to her trance state! We need her to be hopeful, courageous, with a mind that can match that of a man, but still bearing the attributes of a gentle and talented woman, and with a strength that the Count has imparted to her but cannot immediately reclaim, even if he imagines he has done so. Shh? Just stay silent and listen to me, then you will understand. John, we are indeed hitting a dead end as dark as pitch! I am more scared than I have ever been. We can only trust in God. Don't say anything more, she's coming.
tr: With his vast knowledge, he knows that Madam Mina will come when he calls, but he has cut off his connection with her so that she does not go to him - he has distanced her from his influence. Ah! I have hope that our human mind, which has not been deprived of God's grace and has belonged to humans for a long time, will surpass the child's mind that has been lying in the grave for centuries, has not reached the dimensions of ours, and has remained small because it has worked selfishly. Here comes Madam Mina; not a word about her trance! She does not know about it; learning this at a moment when we need all her hope and courage could upset and drive her to despair; at a moment when we most need her great mind, which has been trained like a man's but belongs to a sweet woman, and which, despite not thinking of doing such a thing, could fully reclaim the special power the Count gave her. Shh! Let me speak, and you will learn. Ah, my friend John! We are in terrible trouble. I am more afraid than I have ever been before. We can only trust in the Almighty God. Be silent! Here she comes!”
es: "He is sure, with the great knowledge he has, that she will come to his call, but he removed his power over her, as he can do, so that she does not go to meet him. Ah! Now I have hope that our human brains, which have been human for so long and have not lost the grace of God, will go further than his childish brain that remained in his tomb for several centuries, that has not yet reached our stature and that only does selfish and, consequently, mediocre work. Here comes Mrs. Mina. Do not say a single word to her about her trance! She does not know, and it would be as much as overwhelming and despairing her just when we want all her hope, all her courage; when we must use the brain she has and that has been trained like a man's, but is that of a sweet woman and has received the power given to her by the count and that he cannot completely withdraw..., although he does not think so. Oh, John, my friend, we are among terrible reefs! I have a greater fear than ever before. We can only trust in God. Silence! Here she comes!"

en: I thought that the Professor was going to break down and have hysterics, just as he had when Lucy died, but with a great effort he controlled himself and was at perfect nervous poise when Mrs. Harker tripped into the room, bright and happy-looking and, in the doing of work, seemingly forgetful of her misery. As she came in, she handed a number of sheets of typewriting to Van Helsing. He looked over them gravely, his face brightening up as he read. Then holding the pages between his finger and thumb he said:—
vi: I thought Van Helsing was about to collapse from nervous tension like the time he witnessed Lucy's death, but he still tried very hard to show that he was truly capable and completely in control of himself when Mina cheerfully walked in. The busy work that the professor had just assigned seemed to have made her forget the misfortune in her heart. She immediately handed a stack of papers to Van Helsing. The old professor carefully reviewed each sheet one by one, his face lighting up with the neatly typed letters. Then he pinched the stack of papers between his index finger and thumb:
tr: I thought the Professor would lose himself or have a hysterical fit just like when Lucy died, but he held himself together with great effort and completely controlled his nerves when Ms. Harker entered the room with a lively and happy expression, looking as if she had forgotten her sadness because she was busy working. As Ms. Harker entered, she handed some typed papers to Van Helsing. Van Helsing looked at the papers with a serious expression, and as he read what was written, his face lit up. Then, holding the pages between his thumb and other fingers, he began to speak: “A lesson is coming for you, my friend John, who has experienced so much so far - and for you too, dear Madam Mina, who are very young:
es: I thought the professor was going to have a nervous breakdown and collapse, like when Lucy died, but with great effort he controlled himself and did not seem nervous at all when Mrs. Harker made her entrance into the room, lively and with a happy expression, and, being occupied with something, apparently forgotten about her tragedy. Upon entering, she handed van Helsing a bundle of typewritten papers. The professor leafed through them gravely, and his face began to light up as he read. Then, holding the pages between his index finger and thumb, he said:

en: “Friend John, to you with so much of experience already—and you, too, dear Madam Mina, that are young—here is a lesson: do not fear ever to think. A half-thought has been buzzing often in my brain, but I fear to let him loose his wings. Here now, with more knowledge, I go back to where that half-thought come from and I find that he be no half-thought at all; that be a whole thought, though so young that he is not yet strong to use his little wings. Nay, like the “Ugly Duck” of my friend Hans Andersen, he be no duck-thought at all, but a big swan-thought that sail nobly on big wings, when the time come for him to try them. See I read here what Jonathan have written:—
vi: — John, you have a lot of experience, and so do you, Mina. I would like to present a lesson for all of us: never be afraid of thinking too much. Occasionally, a half-formed thought flutters in my mind like a winged creature, but in the past, I was very afraid of letting it break its wings. Now, with more experience, I know I have to trace back to the starting point of every half-formed thought, and I discover that it is something entirely different, a real thought, even though it is too nascent to have small wings. Yes, it is like the ugly duckling of my friend Hans Andersen, but it is not a complete thought-duck, but a thought-swan that glides gracefully on the lake's surface with its large wings when given the chance to try. I will read to you a passage written by Jonathan: "... to what belongs to the descendants of the old man who later, once again, forced the armies to cross the river to invade Turkey?
tr: Never be afraid to think. A vague thought was buzzing around in my mind, but I was afraid to let it fully take flight. Now, with more information in hand, I return to where that vague thought originated and see that it is not actually a vague thought; despite being very young and not yet strong enough to use its tiny wings, I see that it is a complete thought. Moreover, it is not a duck thought like my friend Hans Andersen’s ‘The Ugly Duckling,’ but a great swan thought that soars nobly on its large wings when the time comes to test them. Look, here I am reading what Jonathan wrote:
es: –Friend John, for you, who already have some experience..., and also for you who are young, Mrs. Mina, here is a good lesson: never be afraid to think. A half-formed thought has frequently been fluttering in my imagination, but I fear letting it lose its wings... Now, with more knowledge, I return to the place where that embryonic thought originated and discover that it is not embryonic at all, but a complete thought; although still so young that it cannot yet use its tiny wings well. No; like the "Ugly Duckling" of my friend Hans Andersen, it was not a duck thought at all, but a swan thought, large, that flies with very powerful wings, when the time comes for it to try them out. Look, I read here what Jonathan wrote:

en: “That other of his race who, in a later age, again and again, brought his forces over The Great River into Turkey Land; who, when he was beaten back, came again, and again, and again, though he had to come alone from the bloody field where his troops were being slaughtered, since he knew that he alone could ultimately triumph.”
vi: The truce-breaker continued to attack repeatedly and left behind a battlefield with bodies lying everywhere, because he knew that in the end, only he would be victorious?"
tr: ‘Another member of his race, in the following centuries, repeatedly brought his forces across the great river into Turkish lands; when repelled, knowing that only he could achieve absolute victory, he emerged again, again, and again, despite being the sole survivor from the blood-soaked battlefield where his troops were massacred.’
es: –"That other one of his race who, in a later era, repeatedly made his troops cross The Great River and penetrate Turkish territory; who, when he was repelled, returned again and again, even when he had to return alone from the bloodied battlefield where his troops were being torn apart, because he knew that he alone could triumph…"

en: “What does this tell us? Not much? no! The Count’s child-thought see nothing; therefore he speak so free. Your man-thought see nothing; my man-thought see nothing, till just now. No! But there comes another word from some one who speak without thought because she, too, know not what it mean—what it might mean. Just as there are elements which rest, yet when in nature’s course they move on their way and they touch—then pouf! and there comes a flash of light, heaven wide, that blind and kill and destroy some; but that show up all earth below for leagues and leagues. Is it not so? Well, I shall explain. To begin, have you ever study the philosophy of crime? ‘Yes’ and ‘No.’ You, John, yes; for it is a study of insanity. You, no, Madam Mina; for crime touch you not—not but once. Still, your mind works true, and argues not a particulari ad universale. There is this peculiarity in criminals. It is so constant, in all countries and at all times, that even police, who know not much from philosophy, come to know it empirically, that it is. That is to be empiric. The criminal always work at one crime—that is the true criminal who seems predestinate to crime, and who will of none other. This criminal has not full man-brain. He is clever and cunning and resourceful; but he be not of man-stature as to brain. He be of child-brain in much. Now this criminal of ours is predestinate to crime also; he, too, have child-brain, and it is of the child to do what he have done. The little bird, the little fish, the little animal learn not by principle, but empirically; and when he learn to do, then there is to him the ground to start from to do more. ‘Dos pou sto,’ said Archimedes. ‘Give me a fulcrum, and I shall move the world!’ To do once, is the fulcrum whereby child-brain become man-brain; and until he have the purpose to do more, he continue to do the same again every time, just as he have done before! Oh, my dear, I see that your eyes are opened, and that to you the lightning flash show all the leagues,” for Mrs. Harker began to clap her hands and her eyes sparkled. He went on:—
vi: What do we learn from this? Is there nothing important? No! The childish mind of the old count does not understand anything significant, which is why he speaks so recklessly. No! But this is another answer from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what it means or what it could mean. Yes, let me explain. But have you studied the philosophy of crime? Yes and no. My friend John, yes, because this subject is an indispensable part of studying mental illness. As for Mina, no, because crime has nothing to do with her, except once. But her mind always follows a straight path and has its own way of reasoning about the world. In humans, criminals have a stable characteristic, everywhere and at all times, so much so that even police officers who do not know much about philosophy can affirm it based on experience. Criminals often pursue a single crime, at least for those who do not plan their crimes in advance and do not pursue anything else. The criminal does not have a fully adult mind. He is alert, cunning, and full of strength. But when it comes to the mind, his development is not yet complete. In many respects, he is still in a developmental stage of a child. In other words, our criminal commits crimes due to predestination, his mind is still naive because what he does is just child's play. Young birds, fry, and small animals are not raised according to principles, but only based on experience. And what they learn will propel them to continue doing what they have done in a rut. Archimedes once said: give me a fulcrum, and I will lift the earth. The first attempt is the fulcrum by which a child's brain develops into an adult, and when it tries again, it starts to do what it has done before. Dear Mina, I see your eyes are wide open and the sunlight is illuminating the entire realm for you? Indeed, Mina was waving her hands frantically, her eyes sparkling brightly. Van Helsing continued:
tr: What does this tell us? Not much, right? No! The Count’s childish mind understands nothing; that’s why he speaks so freely. Your adult mind understands nothing; my adult mind also understood nothing, until this very moment. No! A word came from someone who speaks without thinking because they do not know what their words mean - or could mean. Just like the elements in nature that progress in their paths and when they touch each other -Poof!- they cover the entire sky, blinding some, killing and destroying others, and revealing the depths of the earth with a sudden flash of light. Isn't that so? Anyway, let me explain. To start with, have you ever studied the philosophy of crime? ‘Yes!’; ‘No!’ You, John, yes; because this is a field of study within the subject of madness. You, no, Madam Mina; because crime has never approached you - except once. Still, your mind works correctly and does not argue particulari ad universale. Criminals have such a characteristic. This holds true in all countries and at all times so much so that even a policeman who does not understand much philosophy knows this experimentally. To know experimentally means this. A criminal works for only one crime - that is, the real criminal who seems to have crime in their destiny and does not think of other crimes. The criminal does not have a fully adult mind. They are intelligent, cunning, and alert; but when it comes to the mind, they are not on par with an adult man. In many ways, they are close to a child’s mind. Now, our criminal also has crime in their destiny; they also have a child’s mind and do things that only a child would do. A small bird, a small fish, a small animal learns not by principles but by experiments; once they learn to do something, they have the foundation to start doing more. ‘Dos pou sto,’ said Archimedes. ‘Give me a place to stand, and I will move the world!’ Once they do something, it is the foundation that will turn a child’s mind into an adult mind; until they aim to do more, they continue to do the same thing each time, just as they did before! Oh, dear, I see that your eyes have opened and the flashing light shows distances far away,” because Ms. Harker had started clapping her hands and her eyes were shining brightly. The professor continued his speech:
es: "What does this suggest to us? Not much? No! The childish thought of the count hides nothing, that's why he spoke so freely. His human thoughts saw nothing, nor did my human thought, until now. No! But another word comes from a person who speaks without thinking, because she also does not know what it means... what it could mean. It is like the elements at rest that, nevertheless, in their natural course, follow their path, touch each other... and, poof!, a flash of light is produced that covers the entire sky, that blinds, kills, and destroys something or someone, but that illuminates the earth below, kilometers and more kilometers around. Isn't that so? Well, I better explain myself. To begin with, have you ever studied the philosophy of crime? "Yes" and "no". You, friend John, yes, since you are a student of madness. You, Mrs. Mina, no; because crime does not touch you... except once. However, your mind really works and does not argue from the particular to the universal. "In criminals, there exists that peculiarity. It is so constant in all countries and times, that even the police, who do not know much about philosophy, come to know it empirically, that it exists. The criminal always works on a crime... that is the true criminal, who seems to be predestined for that crime and who does not wish to commit any other. That criminal does not have a complete human brain. He is intelligent, skillful, and full of resources, but he does not have an adult brain. At most, he has a child's brain. Now, this criminal we are dealing with is also predestined for crime; he, too, has a child's brain and it is childish to do what he has done. Little birds, small fish, little animals, do not learn by principle but empirically, and when they learn how to do something, that knowledge serves as a basis to do something else, starting from it. Dos pousto, said Archimedes, give me a point of support and I will move the world! Doing something once is the point of support from which the child's brain develops into a man's brain, and as long as it does not have the desire to do more, it will continue doing the same thing repeatedly, exactly as it has done before! Oh, my dear lady, I see that your eyes are opening and that for you, the lightning's light illuminates the whole terrain." Mrs. Harker began to clasp her hands and her eyes sparkled. The professor continued saying:

en: “Now you shall speak. Tell us two dry men of science what you see with those so bright eyes.” He took her hand and held it whilst she spoke. His finger and thumb closed on her pulse, as I thought instinctively and unconsciously, as she spoke:—
vi: — Now, please speak, tell us what you see in those sparkling eyes. He gently placed his thumb and index finger on the girl's wrist to check her pulse, a gesture that seemed unconscious and instinctive for a physician.
tr: “Now you will speak. Tell us two dry scientists what you saw with those sparkling eyes.” He took Ms. Harker's hand in his and held it as she spoke. While Ms. Harker was speaking, he was feeling her pulse with his thumb and forefinger - which I think he did instinctively and unconsciously.
es: –Now you must speak. Tell us, two men thirsty for knowledge, what you see with those bright eyes. He took her hand and held it between his own while he spoke. His index finger and thumb rested on her pulse, I thought instinctively and unconsciously, as she spoke:

en: “The Count is a criminal and of criminal type. Nordau and Lombroso would so classify him, and quâ criminal he is of imperfectly formed mind. Thus, in a difficulty he has to seek resource in habit. His past is a clue, and the one page of it that we know—and that from his own lips—tells that once before, when in what Mr. Morris would call a ‘tight place,’ he went back to his own country from the land he had tried to invade, and thence, without losing purpose, prepared himself for a new effort. He came again better equipped for his work; and won. So he came to London to invade a new land. He was beaten, and when all hope of success was lost, and his existence in danger, he fled back over the sea to his home; just as formerly he had fled back over the Danube from Turkey Land.”
vi: — The old count is a typical criminal - She began to speak - Nordau and Lombroso's theories classify him as such, and due to his crimes, his mind has never fully developed. Therefore, when faced with difficulties, he will seek to solve the problem in a habitual way. The origin of his only way of behaving belongs to his own past. The only page we know - and also as he himself has said - about him is that in an unfortunate time, he returned to his homeland after an attempt to invade another land. At home, he did not give up his goal and always harbored the intention of preparing to attack the foreign land once again. Indeed, he invaded again, better equipped, and achieved victory. Similarly, he came to London to conquer a new land. He won, but when all hope suddenly vanished, and his presence was placed in a dangerous situation, he immediately sought a way to the sea to return home, just as he had once done when crossing the Danube to invade Turkey.
tr: Ms. Harker said: “The Count is a criminal and from the criminal class. Nordau and Lombroso would classify him this way, and as a criminal, he has a defective mind. Therefore, when faced with difficulty, he seeks solutions in habits. The past offers clues, and a page we know about his past - and from his own mouth - tells us that once, as Mr. Morris put it, when he was 'pressed,' he returned to his homeland from the lands he tried to seize, and thus, without wasting time, he prepared for a new effort. He came back better equipped for his work and succeeded. He came to London to conquer a new country. He was defeated, and when all hopes of success were lost and his existence was endangered, he crossed the seas and returned to his homeland; just as he had previously crossed the Danube River and returned from Turkish lands.”
es: –The count is a criminal and of the criminal type. Nordau and Lombroso would classify him as such and, as a criminal, he has an imperfectly formed brain. Thus, when he finds himself in difficulties, he must take refuge in habits. His past is an indication, and the only page of it that we know, from his own lips, tells us that on one occasion, before, when he found himself in what Mr. Morris would call "a difficult situation," he returned to his own country from the land he had gone to invade and, then, without losing sight of his goals, he prepared for a new effort. He came back again, better equipped to carry out that work, and he succeeded. Thus, he went to London, to invade a new land. He was defeated, and when he lost all hope of triumph and saw that his existence was in danger, he returned by sea to his home; just as before he had fled over the Danube, coming from Turkish lands.

en: “Good, good! oh, you so clever lady!” said Van Helsing, enthusiastically, as he stooped and kissed her hand. A moment later he said to me, as calmly as though we had been having a sick-room consultation:—
vi: — Excellent, excellent, truly unexpected. Mina, you are incredibly intelligent. - Van Helsing exclaimed in admiration and bent down to kiss her hand. Then the professor fell silent as if examining a patient. After a moment of silence, he turned to me and said:
tr: “Beautiful, beautiful! Ah, you clever lady!” said Van Helsing enthusiastically, bending down to kiss Ms. Harker's hand. A second later, as if we were having a consultation in a patient's room, he calmly said to me:
es: –Magnificent! Magnificent! You are an extraordinarily intelligent woman! – said Van Helsing enthusiastically, as he bowed and kissed her hand. A moment later, he said to me with the same calmness as if we had been conducting a medical examination:

en: “Seventy-two only; and in all this excitement. I have hope.” Turning to her again, he said with keen expectation:—
vi: — Seventy-two beats, no more, and it seems very excited! I am very hopeful. Then he turned back and urged Mina, looking impatient:
tr: “The pulse is only seventy-two; even amidst all this excitement. I am hopeful.” Turning again to Ms. Harker, he spoke with great anticipation:
es: –Only seventy-two and with all this excitement. I have hopes -he turned to her again and said, with great expectation-: Continue.

en: “But go on. Go on! there is more to tell if you will. Be not afraid; John and I know. I do in any case, and shall tell you if you are right. Speak, without fear!”
vi: — Mina, continue, continue. You can speak freely if you want. There's nothing to be afraid of.
tr: “But go on. Go on! If you wish, there are more things you can tell. Don't be afraid, John and I know. I know in any case, and if you are right, I will tell you this. Speak without fear!”
es: Continue! You can tell us more if you wish; John and I know it. At least, I know it, and I will tell you if you are right or not. Speak without fear!

en: “I will try to; but you will forgive me if I seem egotistical.”
vi: — I will try, but please don't mind if I only talk about myself.
tr: “I will try to do this; but if I seem selfish, forgive me.”
es: –I will try; but I hope you will excuse me if I seem selfish to you.

en: “Nay! fear not, you must be egotist, for it is of you that we think.”
vi: — No, don't worry about anything. You should talk about yourself, because you are the one we are thinking about.
tr: “No! Don't be afraid, you must be selfish, because we are thinking of you.”
es: –No! Do not fear. You must be selfish, since it is you we are thinking of.

en: “Then, as he is criminal he is selfish; and as his intellect is small and his action is based on selfishness, he confines himself to one purpose. That purpose is remorseless. As he fled back over the Danube, leaving his forces to be cut to pieces, so now he is intent on being safe, careless of all. So his own selfishness frees my soul somewhat from the terrible power which he acquired over me on that dreadful night. I felt it! Oh, I felt it! Thank God, for His great mercy! My soul is freer than it has been since that awful hour; and all that haunts me is a fear lest in some trance or dream he may have used my knowledge for his ends.” The Professor stood up:—
vi: — Here’s the thing, from the perspective of a criminal, he is indeed a very selfish person. When intelligence is limited and actions are solely based on selfishness, he temporarily settled for a single goal and showed no remorse. Even when he crossed the Danube again to attack Turkey once more, causing countless of his soldiers to die on the battlefield, up until his recent defeat, he only thought about how to escape and did not consider anything else. It is precisely this selfishness that has somewhat freed my soul from the terrible power he cast upon me that night. Thank God, at this moment, my soul is indeed freer. There is only one worry that haunts me: I wonder if, while hiding and seeking refuge, he tried to extract information from me while I was hypnotized? — Yes, he did. - Van Helsing replied. -
tr: “Then, because he is guilty, he is selfish; because his mind is small and his actions are based on selfishness, he limits himself to a single purpose. This purpose is ruthless. Just as he abandoned his warrior forces to defeat and fled across the Danube, he is determined to be safe without paying attention to anything. Therefore, his own selfishness frees me from the power he gained over me on that dreadful night. I felt it, oh! I felt it. Thank God for His mercy! Since that dreadful hour, my soul has never been so free; the only thing that haunts me is the fear that he will use my knowledge for his own purposes while I am in a trance or dreaming.” The professor stood up:
es: –Then, since he is a criminal, he is selfish; and since his intellect is small and his actions are based on selfishness, he is limited to one end. That purpose lacks remorse. Just as he crossed the Danube, letting his troops be destroyed, so now he thinks of saving himself, without caring about anything else. Thus, his own selfishness frees my soul, to some extent, from the terrible power he acquired over me that dreadful night. I am sorry! Oh, I am sorry! Thank God for His enormous mercy! My soul is freer than it has ever been since that terrible hour, and the only thing I fear is that in some of my trances or dreams, I may have used my knowledge for his purposes. The professor stood up and said:

en: “He has so used your mind; and by it he has left us here in Varna, whilst the ship that carried him rushed through enveloping fog up to Galatz, where, doubtless, he had made preparation for escaping from us. But his child-mind only saw so far; and it may be that, as ever is in God’s Providence, the very thing that the evil-doer most reckoned on for his selfish good, turns out to be his chiefest harm. The hunter is taken in his own snare, as the great Psalmist says. For now that he think he is free from every trace of us all, and that he has escaped us with so many hours to him, then his selfish child-brain will whisper him to sleep. He think, too, that as he cut himself off from knowing your mind, there can be no knowledge of him to you; there is where he fail! That terrible baptism of blood which he give you makes you free to go to him in spirit, as you have as yet done in your times of freedom, when the sun rise and set. At such times you go by my volition and not by his; and this power to good of you and others, as you have won from your suffering at his hands. This is now all the more precious that he know it not, and to guard himself have even cut himself off from his knowledge of our where. We, however, are not selfish, and we believe that God is with us through all this blackness, and these many dark hours. We shall follow him; and we shall not flinch; even if we peril ourselves that we become like him. Friend John, this has been a great hour; and it have done much to advance us on our way. You must be scribe and write him all down, so that when the others return from their work you can give it to them; then they shall know as we do.”
vi: That is why he abandoned us here, in this land of Varna, while the ship - shrouded in the fog he created - takes him to Galatz. Surely, when he gets there, he will have prepared everything to escape our pursuit. But his childish mind does not go beyond that. He could not foresee that what he considered an absolute advantage would become his greatest misfortune. And as the great Psalmist said, the hunter may have already set the snare. Indeed, at this moment, he thinks he has escaped our grasp and is hours ahead of us. His childish mind tells him that he can rest.
