Moreover, he believes that by severing the spiritual connection between him and her, she knows nothing about him. Thus, he has made another mistake. He has infused his cursed blood into her, binding her, though she can move freely, to always think of him as she did at sunrise and sunset. But fortunately, at such times, she follows my guidance and not his. This gift becomes even more precious as he is unaware of it and mistakenly believes he has severed the connection through us via her. On the contrary, we are not selfish and we believe that God will guide everyone through this dark moment. We will hunt down the demon, even at the risk of becoming like him. My friend John, this is a momentous, extremely important time for us. Do the work of a clerk and record everything that has just happened, so that when our friends return, you can easily recount to them what we have learned.
tr: “He used your mind in this way and by that means, while the ship carrying him was undoubtedly making preparations to escape us, swiftly heading towards Galaţi through the surrounding mist, he left us here in Varna. But a child's mind can only see so far ahead; by the providence of God, it is likely that the thing the wrongdoer relies on most for his own good will turn out to be the very thing that causes him the greatest harm. As the Prophet David has decreed, the hunter falls into his own trap. For now, thinking he has completely lost all trace and is hours ahead of us, his selfish child’s mind will whisper to him to sleep. He also thinks that because he has stopped reading your mind, you will not be able to gain any information about him; this is where he is mistaken! The terrible blood baptism he subjected you to allows you to go to him spiritually, just as you did freely at sunrise and sunset when you were free. At such times, you go not by his will, but by mine; you have gained this power, which is for your and others' benefit, through suffering at his hands. Now, it is more valuable than anything that he does not know this and disconnects the link in order to protect himself, so that he will not know where we are. But we are not entirely selfish and believe that God is with us in all this darkness and dark hours. Even if we risk becoming like him, we will follow him; we will not retreat. My friend John, this was a very important hour; it caused much to propel us on our way. You must take on the duty of scribe and write it all down; then, they will know these things as we do.”
es: –He has used his mind; that is why he left us here in Varna, while the ship that carried him quickly advanced, shrouded in fog, towards Galatz, where, without a doubt, he had prepared everything to flee from us. But his childish mind did not go further, and it is possible that, as always happens according to Divine Providence, what the criminal believed was good for his selfish well-being turns out to be the greatest harm he receives. The hunter is caught in his own trap, as the great psalmist says. Since now he believes he is free from us and has left no trace and has managed to flee from us, having so many hours of advantage to do so, his childish brain will make him sleep. He also believes that by ceasing to know your mind, you cannot have any knowledge of him; that is his mistake! That terrible baptism of blood that he inflicted on you makes you free to go to him in spirit, as you have always been able to do until now, in your moments of freedom, when the sun rises or sets. In those moments, you go by my will, not by his. And that power, for the good of both you and so many others, you have acquired through your sufferings at his hands. That is all the more precious to us, as he himself has no knowledge of it, and to protect himself, he avoids being able to have knowledge of our doings. However, we are not selfish, and we believe that God is with us during all this darkness and all these terrible hours. We must follow him, and we will not fail; even if we put ourselves in danger of becoming like him. Friend John, this has been a magnificent hour; and we have gained much ground in our case. You must become a scribe and put everything in writing, so that when the others arrive, they can read it and know what we know.

en: And so I have written it whilst we wait their return, and Mrs. Harker has written with her typewriter all since she brought the MS. to us.
vi: While waiting for some friends to return, I am writing these lines to recount the events that have occurred since Mina took her husband's diary and gave it to Van Helsing. Afterward, I will ask her to type it up again.
tr: And so, while waiting for their return, I wrote this, and since Ms. Harker brought us her typewriter, she typed it up.
es: Therefore, I have written all this while we await the return of our friends, and Mrs. Harker has typed it all up with her machine, ever since she brought us the manuscripts.

en: CHAPTER XXVI
vi: CHAPTER 26
tr: XXVI
es: XXVI.–

en: DR. SEWARD’S DIARY
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: FROM THE JOURNAL OF DR. SEWARD

en: 29 October.—This is written in the train from Varna to Galatz. Last night we all assembled a little before the time of sunset. Each of us had done his work as well as he could; so far as thought, and endeavour, and opportunity go, we are prepared for the whole of our journey, and for our work when we get to Galatz. When the usual time came round Mrs. Harker prepared herself for her hypnotic effort; and after a longer and more serious effort on the part of Van Helsing than has been usually necessary, she sank into the trance. Usually she speaks on a hint; but this time the Professor had to ask her questions, and to ask them pretty resolutely, before we could learn anything; at last her answer came:—
vi: • October 29 I am writing these lines on the train from Varna to Galatz. Yesterday afternoon, just before sunset, we gathered together once again. Everyone had completed their tasks in the best possible way. Reflection, boldness, and timing will help us prepare well for a long journey, even to Dracula's castle. As usual, Mina continued to prepare for a new hypnosis session. Van Helsing took quite a bit of time to put her into a trance state. Generally, she starts speaking from the first signs of the trance, but the professor had to ask quite a lot and very precisely before understanding the issue. Finally, Mina answered something like this:
tr: October 29. - This was written on the train from Varna to Galaţi. Last evening, we all gathered a little before sunset. Each of us had performed our respective duties as well as we could; as long as there was thought, effort, and opportunity, we were ready for the entirety of our journey and the tasks we would undertake when we reached Galaţi. At the usual time, Ms. Harker prepared for her hypnotic effort; after Van Helsing's unusually long and more intense effort, she fell into a trance. Ms. Harker usually speaks in a suggestive manner, but this time the Professor had to ask her questions and direct them with great determination before learning anything; finally, the answer came: “I can’t see anything; we are stationary; there are no waves hitting the ship, only a gentle swirl of calm water hitting the ropes lightly.
es: October 29. I am writing this on the train, from Varna to Galatz. Yesterday evening, we all gathered shortly before sunset. Each of us had done our work as well as we could; in terms of thought, dedication, and opportunity, we are prepared for our entire journey and for our work when we arrive in Galatz. When the usual time came, Mrs. Harker prepared for her hypnotic effort, and after a more prolonged and serious effort from Van Helsing than was usually necessary, the lady entered a trance. Ordinarily, the lady spoke with just a hint, but this time, the professor had to ask her questions and ask them very firmly before we could learn anything; finally, her response came:

en: “I can see nothing; we are still; there are no waves lapping, but only a steady swirl of water softly running against the hawser. I can hear men’s voices calling, near and far, and the roll and creak of oars in the rowlocks. A gun is fired somewhere; the echo of it seems far away. There is tramping of feet overhead, and ropes and chains are dragged along. What is this? There is a gleam of light; I can feel the air blowing upon me.”
vi: — I can't distinguish anything at all. We are standing still in one place. It's not the sound of waves crashing, but a continuous whirlpool gently swirling around the rope. I hear the calls of the men, sometimes near, sometimes far, then the creaking of the oars. Somewhere, a sound of an explosion echoes from very far away. The sound of footsteps echoes above my head, along with the sound of ropes and chains being pulled. What is that? There is a streak of light.
tr: Ms. Harker usually speaks in a suggestive manner, but this time the Professor had to ask her questions and direct them with great determination before learning anything; finally, the answer came: “I can’t see anything; we are stationary; there are no waves hitting the ship, only a gentle swirl of calm water hitting the ropes lightly. I can hear men calling out nearby and far away, and the creaking of oars in the rowlocks. A gun was fired somewhere; its echo seems distant. There are footsteps above and ropes and chains being dragged. What is this? Light is coming; I can feel the air blowing over me.”
es: –I can't see anything; we are motionless; there are no waves, only a gentle sound of water running against the mooring line. I hear men's voices shouting, near and far, and the sound of oars in their placements. Someone fires a pistol somewhere; the echo of the shot seems very distant. I hear the noise of footsteps above and they place chains and ropes nearby. What is this? There is a ray of light; I feel the air hitting me directly.

en: Here she stopped. She had risen, as if impulsively, from where she lay on the sofa, and raised both her hands, palms upwards, as if lifting a weight. Van Helsing and I looked at each other with understanding. Quincey raised his eyebrows slightly and looked at her intently, whilst Harker’s hand instinctively closed round the hilt of his Kukri. There was a long pause. We all knew that the time when she could speak was passing; but we felt that it was useless to say anything. Suddenly she sat up, and, as she opened her eyes, said sweetly:—
vi: I feel a breeze just passed by. She said nothing more, but suddenly sat up from the couch as if she had been pushed unexpectedly, with both hands raised, palms facing up as if she were holding something very heavy. Van Helsing and I exchanged glances, for we understood what was happening. Quincey frowned in observation, while Jonathan Harker, instinctively, reached for his Kukri knife. Everyone remained silent for a long time. We all knew that saying anything now would be useless. Mina suddenly stood up, her eyes wide open, and softly asked:
tr: He stopped here. As if without thinking, he got up from where he was lying on the couch and raised both his hands in the air as if lifting weights, with his palms facing upward. Van Helsing and I looked at each other with understanding. As Harker's hand instinctively went to the hilt of his knife, Quincey slightly raised his eyebrows and looked attentively at Ms. Harker. There was a long silence. We all knew that the time when Ms. Harker could speak was passing; but we felt that saying something would be of no use. Ms. Harker suddenly sat up and gently said as she opened her eyes:
es: Here she stopped. She had impulsively risen from where she had been lying, on the divan, and raised both hands, palms up, as if she were bearing a great weight. Van Helsing and I looked at each other, fully understanding. Quincey raised his eyebrows slightly and stared at her, while Harker instinctively closed his hand over the hilt of his kukri. There was a prolonged pause. We all knew that the moment when she could speak was passing, but we thought it was useless to say anything. Suddenly, she sat up and, as she opened her eyes, said softly:

en: “Would none of you like a cup of tea? You must all be so tired!” We could only make her happy, and so acquiesced. She bustled off to get tea; when she had gone Van Helsing said:—
vi: — Does anyone want to have a cup of tea? Everyone must be very tired! We could only nod. After she went into the inner room to get tea and came back out, Van Helsing finally spoke:
tr: "Wouldn't you like a cup of tea? You all must be very tired!" We accepted her offer solely out of the desire to please her. She hurriedly left the room to bring tea; as she exited the room, Van Helsing began to speak:
es: –Would any of you like a cup of tea? You all must be very tired. We wished to please her and, consequently, we nodded. She left the room to fetch the tea. When we were alone, Van Helsing said:

en: “You see, my friends. He is close to land: he has left his earth-chest. But he has yet to get on shore. In the night he may lie hidden somewhere; but if he be not carried on shore, or if the ship do not touch it, he cannot achieve the land. In such case he can, if it be in the night, change his form and can jump or fly on shore, as he did at Whitby. But if the day come before he get on shore, then, unless he be carried he cannot escape. And if he be carried, then the customs men may discover what the box contain. Thus, in fine, if he escape not on shore to-night, or before dawn, there will be the whole day lost to him. We may then arrive in time; for if he escape not at night we shall come on him in daytime, boxed up and at our mercy; for he dare not be his true self, awake and visible, lest he be discovered.”
vi: — Friends, surely everyone understands by now. He is near a coast and has emerged from his box of earth. He needs to get ashore. In the evening, he can hide anywhere. But if he is not brought ashore or if the ship cannot dock, he will not be able to get ashore in the usual way. In such circumstances, when night falls, he can change form to jump or fly ashore as he did in Whitby in the guise of a dog. But if the sun rises before the ship docks, he can only remain in his wooden box. If he stays in there, he will surely be discovered by customs. In short, if he does not manage to get ashore tonight, specifically before dawn, he will lose an entire day and thus, we can arrive in time. Because if he cannot escape at night, we will meet him during the day, when he is still trapped in the box and his fate depends on us. He will not dare to reveal himself in his true form for fear of being discovered.
tr: “You see, my friends. The Count is near the shore: He has left his earth chest. But he still needs to come ashore. He can hide somewhere at night; but if he is not carried ashore or if the ship does not touch the shore, he cannot manage to reach land. If this happens at night, he can change form as he did in Whitby and leap or fly to land. But if it becomes daylight before he reaches the shore, then he cannot escape unless someone carries him. And if he is carried, then the customs officers might discover what is inside the chest. So, in short, if he does not escape to the shore tonight or before dawn, he will lose the entire day. Then, we can reach him in time, because if he does not escape at night, we can find him during the day, trapped in his chest, at our mercy, as he will not dare to be in his own form, awake and visible, to avoid being discovered.”
es: –Do you see, my friends? He is near the land: he has come out of his box of earth. But he still has to reach the shore. During the night he may remain hidden somewhere, but if he is not taken to the shore or if the ship does not dock next to it, he cannot reach the land. In that case, if it is night, he can change form and jump or fly to the land, as he did in Whitby. But if day comes before he is on the shore, then, unless he is taken to land, he cannot disembark. And if he is unloaded, then the customs officers may discover what the box contains. Thus, in summary, if he does not escape to land tonight or before sunrise, he will lose the entire day. Then, we will be able to arrive in time, since if he does not escape during the night, we will reach him during the day and find him inside the box and at our mercy, since he cannot be his own self, awake and visible, for fear of being discovered.

en: There was no more to be said, so we waited in patience until the dawn; at which time we might learn more from Mrs. Harker.
vi: There was nothing more to say. We anxiously awaited dawn, when Mina Harker could tell us some additional details.
tr: There was nothing else to say, so we patiently waited for dawn; when that time came, we could learn something from Ms. Harker.
es: There was nothing more to say, so we waited patiently for dawn to arrive, as at that time we could learn something more through Mrs. Harker.

en: Early this morning we listened, with breathless anxiety, for her response in her trance. The hypnotic stage was even longer in coming than before; and when it came the time remaining until full sunrise was so short that we began to despair. Van Helsing seemed to throw his whole soul into the effort; at last, in obedience to his will she made reply:—
vi: At the break of day, in a state of restless anxiety, we gathered again to hear her speak as Van Helsing hypnotized her. This time, the professor had a hard time putting her into a trance. Finally, Mina had to comply with his instructions:
tr: This morning, early, we listened breathlessly to Ms. Harker's responses in her trance state. The arrival of her hypnotic state took even longer than before, and by the time this phase came, so little time was left until the sun fully rose that we began to lose hope. Van Helsing seemed to have dedicated his entire soul to this effort; finally, Ms. Harker, complying with the Professor's will, responded:
es: This early morning, we listened, holding our breath, to the answers she might give us during her trance. The hypnotic stage took even longer to arrive than the previous time, and when it did, the time remaining until sunrise was so short that we began to despair. Van Helsing seemed to put his entire soul into the effort; finally, obeying the professor's will, Mrs. Harker said:

en: “All is dark. I hear lapping water, level with me, and some creaking as of wood on wood.” She paused, and the red sun shot up. We must wait till to-night.
vi: — Everything is pitch dark. I hear the sound of waves crashing and then the clattering of wood against wood. She didn't say anything more, and moreover, the sun had just appeared, shining brightly. We'll have to wait until the afternoon then.
tr: "Everywhere is dark. I hear the sound of waves at the same level as me and a creaking noise as if wood is rubbing against wood." He paused and suddenly a red sun appeared. We must wait until tonight.
es: –Everything is dark. I hear the water at the same level as me, and certain scrapes, like wood on wood. He paused and the reddish sun made its appearance. We will have to wait until tonight.

en: And so it is that we are travelling towards Galatz in an agony of expectation. We are due to arrive between two and three in the morning; but already, at Bucharest, we are three hours late, so we cannot possibly get in till well after sun-up. Thus we shall have two more hypnotic messages from Mrs. Harker; either or both may possibly throw more light on what is happening.
vi: We arrived in Galatz in such a state of anxiety and impatience. We were supposed to get there around two or three in the morning. But from Bucharest, we departed three hours late, so we would certainly arrive after sunrise. One of Mina's two hypnotic messages, or both, might shed some light on the events that are unfolding.
tr: And so we travel towards Galaţi with the pain of anticipation. We need to arrive between two and three in the morning, but we are still three hours delayed in Bucharest, so it is unlikely we will arrive before sunrise. Thus, we will receive two more hypnotic messages from Ms. Harker; one or both of these might shed some light on what is happening.
es: Therefore, we are traveling towards Galatz very excited and full of anticipation. We should arrive between two and three in the morning, but in Bucharest we are already three hours late, so it is impossible for us to arrive before the sun is already very high in the sky. Thus, we will still have two more hypnotic messages from Mrs. Harker! Either of them or both may shed more light on what is happening.

en: Later.—Sunset has come and gone. Fortunately it came at a time when there was no distraction; for had it occurred whilst we were at a station, we might not have secured the necessary calm and isolation. Mrs. Harker yielded to the hypnotic influence even less readily than this morning. I am in fear that her power of reading the Count’s sensations may die away, just when we want it most. It seems to me that her imagination is beginning to work. Whilst she has been in the trance hitherto she has confined herself to the simplest of facts. If this goes on it may ultimately mislead us. If I thought that the Count’s power over her would die away equally with her power of knowledge it would be a happy thought; but I am afraid that it may not be so. When she did speak, her words were enigmatical:—
vi: • A moment later Another sunset, fortunately occurring at a time when we were not disturbed by anything. If the sunset had coincided with the train stopping at a station, we certainly wouldn't have had the peace to hypnotize Mina: this time it was much harder for her to enter a trance compared to the last time. I fear the ability to decode the Count's sensations within her will vanish just when we need it the most. So far, her abilities have been limited to the simplest matters, and if this continues, she might lead us to a mistake. If I think the power the Count imposed on her is diminishing in tandem with her ability to see through issues, then I have no reason not to be happy. But honestly, I still doubt the situation she is experiencing. In the end, she only decoded it this simply: — Something just disappeared.
tr: Later. - Sunset came and went. Fortunately, it came when there was nothing distracting because if it had happened while we were at the station, we might not have been able to provide the necessary silence and isolation. Ms. Harker was even less willing to succumb to the hypnotic effect than she was this morning. I fear that at the very time we need her the most, the Count's power to read her senses is gradually diminishing. It seems as if Ms. Harker's imagination is starting to work. Until now, she has kept herself limited to the simplest facts during her trance. If this continues, there is a possibility that she might eventually mislead us. If I thought that the Count's power over Ms. Harker would decrease to the same extent as Ms. Harker's power to gather information, it would be a comforting thought, but I fear this will not be the case. When Ms. Harker spoke, her words were like riddles:
es: Later. The sun has already set. Fortunately, its setting occurred at a time when there was no distraction, because if it had taken place during our stay at a station, we would not have had enough calm and isolation. Mrs. Harker responded to the hypnotic influence even more slowly than this morning. I fear that her power to read the Count's sensations is fading, and at the moment when we need it the most. It seems to me that her imagination is beginning to work. While she has been in a trance until now, she has always limited herself to simple facts. If this continues, it is possible that it may lead us astray. If I thought that the Count's power over her would disappear at the same time as her power to know him, I would feel happy, but I fear that won't happen. When she spoke, her words were enigmatic:

en: “Something is going out; I can feel it pass me like a cold wind. I can hear, far off, confused sounds—as of men talking in strange tongues, fierce-falling water, and the howling of wolves.” She stopped and a shudder ran through her, increasing in intensity for a few seconds, till, at the end, she shook as though in a palsy. She said no more, even in answer to the Professor’s imperative questioning. When she woke from the trance, she was cold, and exhausted, and languid; but her mind was all alert. She could not remember anything, but asked what she had said; when she was told, she pondered over it deeply for a long time and in silence.
vi: I felt a cold breeze pass by. There were faint sounds coming from afar, it seemed like some people were speaking a foreign language, there was also the sound of a very strong current and the mournful howling of wolves. She suddenly stopped, shivered for a moment, and then her whole body began to shake violently as if having a seizure. She did not answer Van Helsing's questions. When she regained consciousness, she looked exhausted, drained, her body cold as ice, but fortunately, she still had control over herself. She said she didn't remember anything and wanted to know what she had just discovered. When she understood the issue, she sat silently and thought for a long time.
tr: “Something is coming out; I can feel it passing over me like a cold wind. I hear mixed sounds from afar; men speaking in strange languages, water pouring harshly, and wolves howling.” He stopped and shivered; the intensity of his trembling increased for a few seconds until he shook as if having a seizure. He didn't say anything else; he didn't even respond to the Professor's authoritative questions. When he woke up from the trance, he was cold, tired, and weak but his mind was clear. He remembered nothing and asked what he had said; when it was recounted to him, he pondered over it in silence for a long time.
es: –Something is coming out; I feel it passing by me like a cold wind. I can hear, in the distance, confused sounds… Like men speaking in unknown tongues; water falling forcefully and wolves howling. She paused, and a shiver ran through her, increasing in intensity for a few seconds until, finally, she was trembling as if in a fit. She said nothing more; not even in response to the professor's imperious questioning. When she came out of the trance, she was cold, exhausted, and languid, but her mind was wide awake. She couldn't remember anything; she asked what she had said and pondered it for a long time, in silence.

en: 30 October, 7 a. m.—We are near Galatz now, and I may not have time to write later. Sunrise this morning was anxiously looked for by us all. Knowing of the increasing difficulty of procuring the hypnotic trance, Van Helsing began his passes earlier than usual. They produced no effect, however, until the regular time, when she yielded with a still greater difficulty, only a minute before the sun rose. The Professor lost no time in his questioning; her answer came with equal quickness:—
vi: • October 30, 7 AM We are approaching Galatz, and soon, I may not have time to write anymore. All of us are awake, waiting for dawn. Knowing that it is becoming increasingly difficult to hypnotize Mina, Van Helsing began his hand movements earlier than usual. Only about a minute before sunrise did Mina finally enter a trance. Not wasting any time on trivial matters, the professor immediately proceeded to the most essential questions. She also answered very quickly:
tr: October 30, 7 AM. - We are now approaching Galaţi, and I may not have time to write later. This morning's sunrise was eagerly awaited by all of us. Knowing that it was becoming increasingly difficult to put Ms. Harker into a hypnotic trance, Van Helsing had started his attempts earlier than usual. But Ms. Harker did not succumb until just a minute before the usual time, which is just before sunrise, and even then with greater difficulty, rendering the Professor's attempts ineffective until then. The Professor wasted no time in asking questions; Ms. Harker's response came with equal swiftness:
es: October 30, at seven in the morning. We are near Galatz already and it is possible that I won't have time to write later. We are all anxiously awaiting the sunrise this morning. Knowing the increasing difficulty of inducing the hypnotic trance, Van Helsing began his passes earlier than ever. However, they produced no effect until the regular time, when she responded with increasing difficulty, just a minute before sunrise. The professor wasted no time in questioning her. Her response was given with the same quickness:

en: “All is dark. I hear water swirling by, level with my ears, and the creaking of wood on wood. Cattle low far off. There is another sound, a queer one like——” She stopped and grew white, and whiter still.
vi: — It's all pitch dark. I hear the sound of swirling water at ear level, the clattering of wood against wood. Lower down is the sound of animals crying from afar. And another sound, strange... I must say... She suddenly fell silent, her face growing increasingly pale. — What else, what other sound?
tr: “Everywhere is dark. I hear the sound of water at the same level as my ears and the creaking of wood rubbing against each other. In the distance, the bellowing of cattle. There is another sound, a strange sound; as if...” He stopped and his face turned completely white.
es: –Everything is dark. I feel the water passing close to my ears, at the same level, and the scraping of wood against wood. I hear cattle in the distance. There is another sound, a very strange one, like... She fell silent and turned pale, intensely pale.

en: “Go on; go on! Speak, I command you!” said Van Helsing in an agonised voice. At the same time there was despair in his eyes, for the risen sun was reddening even Mrs. Harker’s pale face. She opened her eyes, and we all started as she said, sweetly and seemingly with the utmost unconcern:—
vi: Continue, I order you to continue! - Van Helsing urged, his voice sounding truly earnest and imploring, his face showing clear signs of disappointment, as outside the sun had risen brightly, casting a red glow on Mina's pale complexion. She opened her eyes wide, trembling slightly as she spoke to us, her face unable to hide her worry:
tr: “Go on; go on! Speak, I command you!” said Van Helsing in a voice filled with suffering. At the same time, there was despair in his eyes, because the rising sun was painting even Ms. Harker's pale face red. Ms. Harker opened her eyes, and when she began to speak sweetly and with all her interest, we all shuddered:
es: –Continue, continue! I order you! Speak! – said van Helsing, in a firm tone. At the same time, desperation appeared in his eyes, because the sun, upon rising, was reddening even the pale face of Mrs. Harker. She opened her eyes and we all started when she said sweetly and, apparently, with the utmost lack of interest:

en: “Oh, Professor, why ask me to do what you know I can’t? I don’t remember anything.” Then, seeing the look of amazement on our faces, she said, turning from one to the other with a troubled look:—
vi: — Professor, why do you ask me things that you know very well I cannot answer? I don't remember anything! She turned to look at our still clearly bewildered faces and continued:
tr: “Ah, Professor, why do you ask me to do things you know I can't do? I don't remember anything.” Then, seeing the astonishment on our faces, he looked at each of us with a troubled expression and said:
es: –Oh, professor! Why do you ask me to do what you know I can't? I don't remember anything! – then, seeing the expression of astonishment in our eyes, she said, turning from one to another with a confused look-:

en: “What have I said? What have I done? I know nothing, only that I was lying here, half asleep, and heard you say ‘go on! speak, I command you!’ It seemed so funny to hear you order me about, as if I were a bad child!”
vi: — What have I already said? What have I already done? I don't know anything anymore, except that I am lying here half-awake, half-asleep, and I hear someone saying: "What else? Keep talking, I order you to keep talking!" Everyone talks as if they think I'm a guilty child!
tr: "What did I say? What did I do? Here, lying half-asleep, and you saying, 'Continue! Speak, I command you!' I know nothing else? It's very strange to hear you giving me orders as if I were a bad child!"
es: What did I say to you? What have I done? I don't know anything; only that I was lying here, half asleep, when I heard you say: "Continue! Continue! I order you! Speak!" It seemed very funny to hear you giving me orders, as if I were a naughty child!

en: “Oh, Madam Mina,” he said, sadly, “it is proof, if proof be needed, of how I love and honour you, when a word for your good, spoken more earnest than ever, can seem so strange because it is to order her whom I am proud to obey!”
vi: — But Mina, - the Professor replied, with a sad tone - that is precisely a proof, if I may say so, of the friendship I have for you. In fact, I have never spoken more seriously, in a very difficult situation, I hope you won't mind.
tr: "Ah, Madam Mina," said Van Helsing with sorrow, "if proof is needed for this, it is the proof of how much I love you and how much I respect you. A word spoken with such sincerity for your well-being may seem very strange, because it means giving orders to someone to whom I bow with pride!""
es: –Oh, Mrs. Mina! – said Van Helsing sadly-. That is proof, if needed, of how much I love and honor you, since a word for your sake, spoken with greater sincerity than ever, may seem strange because it is directed to the one whom I am proud to obey!

en: The whistles are sounding; we are nearing Galatz. We are on fire with anxiety and eagerness.
vi: A sudden whistle blared mournfully. So we have arrived at Galatz. We were on pins and needles with worry and impatience.
tr: Whistles are blowing; we are approaching Galaţi. We are burning with anxiety and curiosity.
es: Whistles are heard; we are approaching Galatz. We are filled with anxiety.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 30 October.—Mr. Morris took me to the hotel where our rooms had been ordered by telegraph, he being the one who could best be spared, since he does not speak any foreign language. The forces were distributed much as they had been at Varna, except that Lord Godalming went to the Vice-Consul, as his rank might serve as an immediate guarantee of some sort to the official, we being in extreme hurry. Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agent to learn particulars of the arrival of the Czarina Catherine.
vi: • October 30 Quincey Morris led me to a hotel that he had booked in advance by telegram. This is a very pleasant hotel, at least because here people do not speak any foreign languages. Just like in Varna, Lord Godalming had to meet the Vice Consul to receive the safety guarantees provided for us, even in the most urgent situations. Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agency to see if there was any news about the ship Tsarine Catherine.
tr: October 30. - Since he didn't know any foreign languages and had no other duties, Mr. Morris took me to the hotel where our rooms were reserved by telegraph. The forces were dispersed as they were in Varna; however, since we were in a great hurry, Lord Godalming went to the vice-consul, thinking his social status might provide some form of official assistance. Jonathan and the two doctors went to the shipping agency to learn the details of the Czarina Catherine's arrival.
es: October 30. Mr. Morris led me to the hotel where rooms had been reserved for us by telegraph, since he did not speak any foreign language and, therefore, was the least useful. The forces were distributed largely as they had been in Varna, except that Lord Godalming went to see the vice-consul, since his title could serve as an immediate guarantee in some way, before the official, because we were in extraordinary haste. Jonathan and the two doctors went to see the shipping agent to learn all the details about the arrival of the Czarina Catherine.

en: Later.—Lord Godalming has returned. The Consul is away, and the Vice-Consul sick; so the routine work has been attended to by a clerk. He was very obliging, and offered to do anything in his power.
vi: • A moment later Lord Godalming has just returned. The Consul General is away, while the Deputy is ill. However, everything was resolved quickly thanks to an authorized staff member who was very pleasant and dedicated to their duties.
tr: Later. - Lord Godalming returned. The consul was out and his assistant was sick; therefore, an officer was handling the routine matters. The man was very kind and said he would do everything within his power.
es: Later. Lord Godalming has returned. The consul is out and the vice-consul is sick; so the routine work is being handled by a secretary. He was very kind and offered to do everything in his power.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Journal
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 30 October.—At nine o’clock Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I called on Messrs. Mackenzie & Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of Hapgood. They had received a wire from London, in answer to Lord Godalming’s telegraphed request, asking us to show them any civility in their power. They were more than kind and courteous, and took us at once on board the Czarina Catherine, which lay at anchor out in the river harbour. There we saw the Captain, Donelson by name, who told us of his voyage. He said that in all his life he had never had so favourable a run.
vi: • October 30 It was 9 o'clock in the morning. Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I went to Mackenzie's house in Steinkoff, the agent of the Hapgood maritime company in London. Mentioning Lord Godalming, they immediately informed us that they had received his request for assistance and promptly led us to the Tsarine Catherine ship, which was anchored at a river port. We met the captain named Donelson, who recounted the entire journey of the ship to us. He said that in his entire life, he had never encountered such a horrific and bizarre voyage.
tr: October 30. - At nine o'clock, Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I paid a short visit to Mackenzie & Stenkoff, the agent of the London firm Hapgood. In response to Lord Godalming's telegraphed request, they had received a telegram from London asking them to show us every possible courtesy. They were more than courteous and respectful, and immediately took us to the Czarina Catherine, anchored at the river port. The captain, named Donelson, told us about his voyage. He said he had never progressed on his route under such favorable conditions in his entire life.
es: October 30. At nine o'clock, Dr. Van Helsing, Dr. Seward, and I visited Mr. Mackenzie and Mr. Steinkoff, the agents of the London firm of Hapgood. They had received a telegram from London in response to Lord Godalming's telegraphic request, asking them to show us every possible courtesy and to assist us as much as they could. They were more than kind and courteous, and immediately took us aboard the Czarina Catherine, which was anchored outside, at the mouth of the river. There we met the captain, named Donelson, who told us about his voyage. He said that in all his life he had never had such a favorable wind. –Wow! – he said.

en: “Man!” he said, “but it made us afeard, for we expeckit that we should have to pay for it wi’ some rare piece o’ ill luck, so as to keep up the average. It’s no canny to run frae London to the Black Sea wi’ a wind ahint ye, as though the Deil himself were blawin’ on yer sail for his ain purpose. An’ a’ the time we could no speer a thing. Gin we were nigh a ship, or a port, or a headland, a fog fell on us and travelled wi’ us, till when after it had lifted and we looked out, the deil a thing could we see. We ran by Gibraltar wi’oot bein’ able to signal; an’ till we came to the Dardanelles and had to wait to get our permit to pass, we never were within hail o’ aught. At first I inclined to slack off sail and beat about till the fog was lifted; but whiles, I thocht that if the Deil was minded to get us into the Black Sea quick, he was like to do it whether we would or no. If we had a quick voyage it would be no to our miscredit wi’ the owners, or no hurt to our traffic; an’ the Old Mon who had served his ain purpose wad be decently grateful to us for no hinderin’ him.” This mixture of simplicity and cunning, of superstition and commercial reasoning, aroused Van Helsing, who said:—
vi: — The trip terrified us because we thought we would have to pay the price for our efforts to steer the ship back on its correct course. Drifting in the Black Sea is no joke. It seemed as if some demon had blown the wind to direct the sails and take the ship where it wanted. There was no way to know what was real and what was not. Every time we tried to approach another ship, or a port, or a headland, a thick fog would suddenly descend from nowhere and follow the ship along its journey, which was truly terrifying. Only when we neared this region did that bizarre hellish scene finally let us go. We passed Gibraltar without being able to signal the mainland. Then, when we reached the Dardanelles, we were supposed to dock to present our papers before continuing, but the ship kept moving forward without any authority questioning us. At first, I intended to reduce the air pressure and let the ship sail against the wind until the fog completely cleared, but then I gave up, thinking that if the demon had decided the ship must go full speed into the Black Sea, it would do so regardless of our wishes. And the demon must have been satisfied without being annoyed by our resistance. The mixed temperament of honesty, humor, but also a certain cunning and superstitious nature typical of a merchant in the captain seemed to further intrigue Van Helsing. He said:
tr: “Wow!” he said with an accented voice, “but it scared us, because we thought we would have to pay for it with a rare misfortune to even the situation. From London to the Black Sea, it is not natural at all to have the wind at your back as if the devil himself is blowing into your sails for his own purposes. And at that time, we couldn't see anything. When we approached a ship or a port or a cape, fog descended upon us and traveled with us; but after the fog lifted and we looked around, we could see some damn things. We passed Gibraltar without being able to send a signal; until we came to the Dardanelles and had to wait for our passage permit, we didn't see anyone close enough to hail. At first, I was inclined to slacken the sails until the fog lifted; but then I thought if the devil is determined to get us to the Black Sea quickly, he will do it whether we want it or not. If he makes a fast journey, it won't cause any trouble between us and the owners of this ship, our traffic won't be disrupted; and the Old Man, who serves his main purpose because we didn't hinder his work, would be grateful enough to us.” This simplicity, a mixture of superstitious cunning and commercial logic, spurred Van Helsing into action, and he said: "My friend, that Devil is smarter than some think, and when he meets his match, he knows it!"
es: But we were fearful, because we were afraid that we would have to pay with some accident or something similar for the extraordinary luck that favored us throughout the entire journey. It is not common to sail from London to the Black Sea with a tailwind that seemed like the devil himself was blowing on the sails for his own purposes. At the same time, we couldn't see anything. As soon as we approached a ship or land, a fog descended upon us, covered us, and traveled with us, until when it lifted, we looked around and couldn't see anything. We passed through Gibraltar without being able to signal our passage, and we couldn't communicate until we were in the Dardanelles, waiting for the corresponding permission. At first, I felt inclined to lower the sails and wait for the fog to lift, but, in the meantime, I thought that if the devil was interested in getting us quickly to the Black Sea, he would probably do so, whether we stopped or not. If we made a quick journey, it wouldn't discredit us with the shipowners and wouldn't harm our traffic, and the devil, having achieved his goals, would be grateful for not having put obstacles in his way. This mixture of simplicity and cunning, of superstition and commercial reasoning, excited van Helsing, who said:

en: “Mine friend, that Devil is more clever than he is thought by some; and he know when he meet his match!” The skipper was not displeased with the compliment, and went on:—
vi: — My friend, sometimes demons are even bolder than what some people think of them, and they are fully aware of who they are facing. The professor's suggestive joke did not excite the captain.
tr: This simplicity, a mixture of superstitious cunning and commercial logic, spurred Van Helsing into action, and he said: "My friend, that Devil is smarter than some think, and when he meets his match, he knows it!" The Captain, not at all pleased with this compliment, continued his speech:
es: –My friend, that devil is much smarter than many think and knows when he meets his match! The captain did not appear displeased by the compliment, and continued speaking:

en: “When we got past the Bosphorus the men began to grumble; some o’ them, the Roumanians, came and asked me to heave overboard a big box which had been put on board by a queer lookin’ old man just before we had started frae London. I had seen them speer at the fellow, and put out their twa fingers when they saw him, to guard against the evil eye. Man! but the supersteetion of foreigners is pairfectly rideeculous! I sent them aboot their business pretty quick; but as just after a fog closed in on us I felt a wee bit as they did anent something, though I wouldn’t say it was agin the big box. Well, on we went, and as the fog didn’t let up for five days I joost let the wind carry us; for if the Deil wanted to get somewheres—well, he would fetch it up a’reet. An’ if he didn’t, well, we’d keep a sharp lookout anyhow. Sure eneuch, we had a fair way and deep water all the time; and two days ago, when the mornin’ sun came through the fog, we found ourselves just in the river opposite Galatz. The Roumanians were wild, and wanted me right or wrong to take out the box and fling it in the river. I had to argy wi’ them aboot it wi’ a handspike; an’ when the last o’ them rose off the deck wi’ his head in his hand, I had convinced them that, evil eye or no evil eye, the property and the trust of my owners were better in my hands than in the river Danube. They had, mind ye, taken the box on the deck ready to fling in, and as it was marked Galatz via Varna, I thocht I’d let it lie till we discharged in the port an’ get rid o’t althegither. We didn’t do much clearin’ that day, an’ had to remain the nicht at anchor; but in the mornin’, braw an’ airly, an hour before sun-up, a man came aboard wi’ an order, written to him from England, to receive a box marked for one Count Dracula. Sure eneuch the matter was one ready to his hand. He had his papers a’ reet, an’ glad I was to be rid o’ the dam’ thing, for I was beginnin’ masel’ to feel uneasy at it. If the Deil did have any luggage aboord the ship, I’m thinkin’ it was nane ither than that same!”
vi: — After leaving the Bosphorus, - the captain continued - the passengers began to grumble. Some Romanians came to me and demanded that we throw overboard a rather large wooden chest sent by a strange old man since we left London. At that time, I saw them glance at the old man and quickly raise two fingers as if to ward off something very unlucky when they saw him approaching. Indeed, the beliefs of foreigners can sometimes be quite strange! I had to shoo them away several times. But right after that, a fog suddenly descended upon the ship from who knows where, making me wonder if those Romanians were right, even though I saw no reason to be prejudiced against that wooden chest. Regardless, we continued our journey. The fog enveloped the ship for five days straight. I left the navigation to the winds, because if the devil wanted the ship to reach a certain place, we had no choice but to let it be, we couldn't do otherwise anyway! Then the ship kept moving forward, very safely and without any collisions at all. The day before yesterday, when the sun rose and pierced through the detestable fog, I suddenly realized the ship had reached a river, opposite Galatz. The Romanians once again went mad, demanding to immediately throw the wooden chest into the river. I had to talk to them with sticks, and when the last one jumped off the deck holding his head, I persuaded them that no matter how unlucky it was, I still placed the passengers' property and trust above all. It should be noted that before that, these Romanian fellows had already dragged that damned chest onto the deck to prepare to throw it into the water. I intended to throw it overboard when we unloaded at the port. But in the morning, about an hour before sunrise, a man suddenly appeared and climbed aboard with an authorization letter from England to receive a chest addressed to Count Dracula. All his papers were in order, so there was no reason not to hand him the chest, moreover, I was beginning to feel uneasy about that cursed thing. If the devil sent luggage onto my ship, it must be that wooden chest and nothing else!
tr: "When we crossed the Bosphorus in Istanbul, the men started grumbling; some of them, Romanians, came to me and asked me to throw a large crate that a strange-looking old man had loaded onto the ship just before we set off from London into the sea. I had seen them glaring at the man and raising two fingers to ward off the evil eye when they saw him. Wow! But the superstitions of foreigners are complete nonsense! I quickly sent them back to their duties; but immediately after, when the fog descended upon us, although I couldn't say for sure it was related to the crate, I felt they were up to something. Anyway, we continued our journey and when the fog didn't lift for five days, I let the wind take us, because if the Devil wanted to go somewhere - well, he would get his job done somehow. And if he didn't, we would be on the lookout. Indeed, we made good progress and always sailed in deep waters; two days ago, when the daytime sun broke through the fog, we found ourselves in the river opposite Galaţi. The Romanians went crazy, asking me to take the crate out and throw it into the river, whether it was right or wrong. I had to argue with them with a lever in my hand, and when the last of them got up from the ground holding his head, I convinced them that it was better for the shipowners' goods and consignments to be in my hands rather than in the Danube River, whether there was an evil eye or not. They had brought the crate onto the deck to throw it into the river, and since it was labeled 'Via Varna to Galaţi,' I thought of letting it stay on the deck until we unloaded the goods at the port and got rid of the crate entirely. We didn't clear customs that day and had to stay anchored overnight; but early in the morning, an hour before sunrise, a man came with instructions written from England, stating that he was to take a crate for someone named Count Dracula. Everything was in the man's hands. His documents were in order, and since I was getting uneasy about the matter, I was glad to be rid of the damn thing. If there was the Devil's baggage on the ship, I thought it must be this crate!"
es: –When we crossed the Bosphorus, the men began to grumble; some of them, the Romanians, came to see me and asked me to throw overboard a large box that had been loaded by a sinister-looking old man, shortly before we left London. I had seen them spying on that fellow and raising their two index fingers when they saw him, to ward off the evil eye. Well! The superstitions of these foreigners are absolutely ridiculous! I quickly sent them to mind their own business, but as the fog closed in on us again shortly after, I somewhat felt that they might have a bit of a point, though I couldn't be sure it was about the large box again. Well, we continued sailing and, although the fog didn't leave us for five days, I let the wind guide us, since if the devil wanted to go somewhere... Well, I wouldn't stop him. And if he didn't guide us, well, we would take a look anyway. In any case, we had deep waters and a good voyage all the time, and two days ago, when the morning sun broke through the fog, we discovered that we were on the river, right in front of Galatz. The Romanians were furious and wanted, with or without my consent, to throw the large box overboard, into the river. I had to argue a bit with them, with a bar in hand, and when the last of them left the bridge with his head in his hands, I had managed to convince them that, evil eye or not, my employers' property was much better off on my ship than at the bottom of the Danube. They had brought the box up to the deck, ready to throw it into the water, and since it was marked Galatz via Varna, I thought it best to leave it there until we unloaded it at the port and got rid of it anyway. We didn't do much work that day, but in the morning, an hour before sunrise, a man came on board with an order written in English and sent from London, to receive a box marked for a certain Count Dracula. Naturally, everything was prepared for her to take it away. The paperwork was in order, and I was glad to get rid of that damned box, as I myself was starting to feel uneasy because of it. If the devil had any luggage on board, I was convinced it could only be that box.

en: “What was the name of the man who took it?” asked Dr. Van Helsing with restrained eagerness.
vi: — What is the name of the person coming to pick up the goods? - Van Helsing asked impatiently.
tr: Van Helsing asked, barely containing his impatience, "What was the name of the man who took the chest?"
es: –What was the name of the man who took that box? – asked Dr. Van Helsing, controlling his anxiety.

en: “I’ll be tellin’ ye quick!” he answered, and, stepping down to his cabin, produced a receipt signed “Immanuel Hildesheim.” Burgen-strasse 16 was the address. We found out that this was all the Captain knew; so with thanks we came away.
vi: — I will tell you right away... The captain stepped down to the cabin to get a receipt signed by Emmanue! Hildesheim, number 16, Burgenstrasse. Knowing that we couldn't get any more information from the captain, we thanked him and continued on our way.
tr: “I will tell you quickly!” replied the captain, and he went down to his cabin and brought back a receipt signed by “Immanuel Heildesheim.” The address was Burgenstraße, number 16. We understood that this was all the captain knew; thus, we thanked him and left.
es: –I'm going to tell him right away! – he replied and, going down to his cabin, showed us a receipt signed by "Immanuel Hildesheim". The address was Burgenstrasse 16. We discovered that this was all the captain knew, so we thanked him and left.

en: We found Hildesheim in his office, a Hebrew of rather the Adelphi Theatre type, with a nose like a sheep, and a fez. His arguments were pointed with specie—we doing the punctuation—and with a little bargaining he told us what he knew. This turned out to be simple but important. He had received a letter from Mr. de Ville of London, telling him to receive, if possible before sunrise so as to avoid customs, a box which would arrive at Galatz in the Czarina Catherine. This he was to give in charge to a certain Petrof Skinsky, who dealt with the Slovaks who traded down the river to the port. He had been paid for his work by an English bank note, which had been duly cashed for gold at the Danube International Bank. When Skinsky had come to him, he had taken him to the ship and handed over the box, so as to save porterage. That was all he knew.
vi: We met Hildesheim in his office. He was a Jew with a face as red as a fighting cock. Without any difficulty regarding our request, he immediately recounted everything he knew. He said he had received a letter sent from London by Sir De Vilie, in which he was asked to receive - if possible before sunrise to avoid the scrutiny of customs - a wooden crate sent by the ship Tsarine Catherine to the port of Galatz; after that, he was to hand the crate over to a certain Petrof Skinsky. This was a person associated with the Slovakians who specialized in river trading. He was paid with a British banknote and had it converted to gold by the Danube International Bank. He took Skinsky to the ship and delivered the goods there to avoid paying delivery fees. That was all, he couldn't say anything more.
tr: We found Hildesheim in his office, with his nose resembling a sheep's and his fez making him look more like the Jewish characters at the Adelphi Theatre. His objections were silenced with money - we interrupted him - and with a bit of bargaining, he told us everything he knew. What he told us turned out to be simple but important. He had received a letter from Mr. de Ville of London, instructing him to collect a crate arriving with the Czarina Catherine in Galaţi, if possible before sunrise, to avoid customs officers. He was told to deliver it to someone named Petrov Skinski, who worked with Slovaks transporting goods from the river to the port. He was paid for his task with British money, properly converted into gold at the Danube International Bank. When Skinski came to him, he took him to the ship and handed over the crate to save on transportation costs. That was all he knew.
es: We found Hildesheim in his offices; he was a Hebrew of the Adelphi Theatre type, with a ram-like nose and a fez. His arguments were marked by money, we made the offer and after some haggling, he ended up telling us everything he knew. That turned out to be simple, but very important. He had received a letter from Mr. de Ville, from London, telling him to receive, if possible before dawn, to avoid customs, a box that would arrive in Galatz on the Czarina Catherine. He was to deliver the said box to a certain Petrof Skinsky, who traded with the Slovaks who trade downstream, to the port. He had received payment for his work in the form of an English banknote, which had been conveniently exchanged for gold at the International Bank of the Danube. When Skinsky presented himself to him, he had delivered the box to him, after taking him to the ship, to avoid the costs of unloading and transport. That was all he knew.

en: We then sought for Skinsky, but were unable to find him. One of his neighbours, who did not seem to bear him any affection, said that he had gone away two days before, no one knew whither. This was corroborated by his landlord, who had received by messenger the key of the house together with the rent due, in English money. This had been between ten and eleven o’clock last night. We were at a standstill again.
vi: So we had no choice but to look for someone named Skinsky, but in the end, we couldn't find him. A neighbor of his said that he had left the day before yesterday, but didn't know where he went. The landlord also told us that he had asked a postman to return the room key and the rent to him. This happened between ten and twelve o'clock last night. So we are hitting a dead end.
tr: Then we called Skinski, but we couldn't manage to find him. A neighbor, who didn't seem to feel much affection towards him, said he left two days ago and no one knows where he is. This statement was confirmed by the landlord, who received the house key and the due rent in British currency from an intermediary. This happened between ten and eleven last night. Once again, our progress was hindered.
es: Then, we looked for Skinsky, but we couldn't find him. One of his neighbors, who did not seem to hold him in high regard, said that he had left two days ago and that no one knew where. This was corroborated by his landlord, who had received the house key through a special messenger, along with the rent he owed, in English money. This had happened between ten and eleven o'clock the previous night. We were once again at a dead end.

en: Whilst we were talking one came running and breathlessly gasped out that the body of Skinsky had been found inside the wall of the churchyard of St. Peter, and that the throat had been torn open as if by some wild animal. Those we had been speaking with ran off to see the horror, the women crying out “This is the work of a Slovak!” We hurried away lest we should have been in some way drawn into the affair, and so detained.
vi: We were talking with the innkeeper when suddenly a man burst in, breathless and frantic, shouting that they had just found Skinsky's body in the Saint Pierre cemetery, with his neck torn open by the fang marks of some wild beast. Everyone who was talking to us immediately jumped up and rushed out to see the horrifying scene they had just heard about, while some women shouted after them: "It was a Slovak who did it!" We suddenly felt weak with fear, worried that we might get involved in the incident and ruin all our plans.
tr: While we were talking, someone came running and out of breath, and said that Skinski's body had been found in the garden of St. Peter's Church, with his throat torn apart as if by a wild animal. The people we were talking to ran to see the horror, and the women were shouting, "This is the work of the Slovaks!" We quickly moved away so as not to get involved in the incident, and thus our work was hindered.
es: While we were talking, a man came running up and, almost out of breath, said that they had found Skinsky's body inside the San Pedro cemetery and that his throat was torn apart, as if he had been killed by some wild animal. The men and women we had been talking to ran out to see it, while the women screamed: –That's the work of a Slovak! We hurriedly moved away from there, so as not to get involved in the matter and be questioned.

en: As we came home we could arrive at no definite conclusion. We were all convinced that the box was on its way, by water, to somewhere; but where that might be we would have to discover. With heavy hearts we came home to the hotel to Mina.
vi: Returning to the hotel, we couldn't come up with a precise conclusion. Everyone could only think that perhaps the chest continued to be transported by water, but to where? This was a difficult question that we had to answer. We met Mina again in a state of heavy anxiety.
tr: When we arrived, we couldn't come to a definite conclusion. We were all convinced that the chest was being transported somewhere by sea, but we would have to find out where it was going. Reluctantly, we returned to the hotel to be with Mina.
es: When we arrived at the house, we couldn't come to any definite solution. We were convinced that the box was being carried by the water to some place, but we would have to find out where. With great sadness, we returned to the hotel to meet with Mina.

en: When we met together, the first thing was to consult as to taking Mina again into our confidence. Things are getting desperate, and it is at least a chance, though a hazardous one. As a preliminary step, I was released from my promise to her.
vi: During our meeting, we raised the issue of hypnotizing her once more. This might be our last chance. So precarious!
tr: The first thing we did when we came together was to exchange views on whether to confide our secrets to Mina again. Things are getting more serious, and although this might be dangerous, it could at least be a chance. As a start, I was exempted from the promise I made to her.
es: When we all gathered, the first thing we discussed was whether we should once again place our trust in Mina, revealing all the secrets of our meetings to her. The situation is quite critical, and that is at least an opportunity, albeit a somewhat risky one. As a preliminary step, I was released from the promise I had made to her.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the journal of Mina Harker

en: 30 October, evening.—They were so tired and worn out and dispirited that there was nothing to be done till they had some rest; so I asked them all to lie down for half an hour whilst I should enter everything up to the moment. I feel so grateful to the man who invented the “Traveller’s” typewriter, and to Mr. Morris for getting this one for me. I should have felt quite astray doing the work if I had to write with a pen....
vi: • October 30, in the afternoon They look so tired and discouraged! At this rate, no one will be able to do anything without taking a little rest. Therefore, I had to urge them to lie down for about half an hour, during which time I will record everything that has happened so far. I am truly grateful to whoever invented the portable typewriter and to Quincey Morris, who took the trouble to bring it here for me! Surely, I would lose my train of thought if I had to keep sharpening my pen on the paper...
tr: October 30, evening. - They were so tired, exhausted, and unenthusiastic that there was nothing to be done until they rested a bit; so I asked them to lie down for half an hour while I wrote down what had happened so far. I owe such gratitude to the man who invented the "Journey" typewriter and to Mr. Morris who brought it to me! If I had to write with a pen, I would make mistakes while doing the work...
es: October 30, at night. They were all so tired, discouraged, and sad that it was impossible to do anything without them resting first; therefore, I asked everyone to lie down for half an hour while I wrote everything down, updating the diaries to the current moment. I feel very grateful to the inventor of the portable typewriter and to Mr. Morris, who got this one for me. The work would have been a bit tedious if I had had to write everything with a pen...

en: It is all done; poor dear, dear Jonathan, what he must have suffered, what must he be suffering now. He lies on the sofa hardly seeming to breathe, and his whole body appears in collapse. His brows are knit; his face is drawn with pain. Poor fellow, maybe he is thinking, and I can see his face all wrinkled up with the concentration of his thoughts. Oh! if I could only help at all.... I shall do what I can.
vi: It's all over. Jonathan was lying sprawled on the couch, his entire body limp and motionless like a paralyzed person, his face wrinkled with boredom. He must be thinking very hard. I wish I could help him! I will try to do what I can.
tr: Everything is completed; poor dear, dear Jonathan, who knows what he has endured, who knows what he is enduring. He is lying on the couch, looking as if he is having difficulty breathing, and his entire body appears collapsed. His eyebrows are furrowed; his face is strained with pain. Poor man, perhaps he is thinking; I can see that his face is completely wrinkled with the intensity of his thoughts. Oh! I wish I could help him.... I will do everything I can...
es: Everything is done; poor and dear Jonathan, how much he has suffered and how much he must still be suffering! He is lying on the divan and it is barely noticeable that he is breathing; his entire body seems to be a victim of a collapse. He has a furrowed brow and his face clearly reflects his suffering. Poor man, perhaps he is thinking and I can see his wrinkled face, due to his reflections. If only I could be of some use to them…! I will do everything possible.

en: I have asked Dr. Van Helsing, and he has got me all the papers that I have not yet seen.... Whilst they are resting, I shall go over all carefully, and perhaps I may arrive at some conclusion. I shall try to follow the Professor’s example, and think without prejudice on the facts before me....
vi: At my suggestion, Dr. Van Helsing handed over to me all the records that I had not yet seen. While he is on vacation, I plan to thoroughly read through everything and, if possible, draw some conclusions. I strive to follow the professor's example and think objectively about the events laid out before me.
tr: I asked Dr. Van Helsing and he brought me all the documents I hadn't seen yet... While they rest, I will carefully go over all of them; maybe I can reach a conclusion. I will take an example from the professor and think without prejudice about the facts in front of me...
es: I have asked Dr. Van Helsing, and he has given me all the papers that I have not seen yet... While they rest, I will carefully examine all the documents, and it is possible that I may come to some conclusion. I must try to follow the professor's example and think without prejudice about the facts that are before me...

en: I do believe that under God’s providence I have made a discovery. I shall get the maps and look over them....
vi: I believe I will make a real discovery after carefully considering and observing the local maps.
tr: I believe I have discovered something with God's permission. I will take and examine the maps...
es: I believe that, thanks to Divine Providence, I have made a discovery. I need to get a map to verify it...

en: I am more than ever sure that I am right. My new conclusion is ready, so I shall get our party together and read it. They can judge it; it is well to be accurate, and every minute is precious.
vi: Yes, I increasingly feel that I am not mistaken. I will gather my friends and tell them my thoughts. They will judge my solution. Everything must be precise. Every minute that passes is very precious.
tr: I am more certain than ever that I am right. The new conclusion I have reached is ready, so I will gather our group and read it. They can make a judgment; it is important not to make a mistake, every minute is valuable.
es: I am more certain than ever that I am right. My new conclusion is ready, so I need to gather all our friends to read it to them. They will be able to judge it. It is good to be precise, and every minute counts.

en: Mina Harker’s Memorandum.
vi: Summary of the review in Mina Harker's journal
tr: Mina Harker's notes (Recorded in her journal.)
es: Memorandum from Mina Harker (Included in her diary)

en: (Entered in her Journal.)
vi: Summary of the review in Mina Harker's journal
tr: Mina Harker's notes (Recorded in her journal.)
es: Memorandum from Mina Harker (Included in her diary)

en: Ground of inquiry.—Count Dracula’s problem is to get back to his own place.
vi: Starting point of the investigation. Issue: Count Dracula is on his way home.
tr: Research foundation. - Count Dracula's problem is returning to his place.
es: Survey base. The problem of Count Dracula is to return to his home.

en: (a) He must be brought back by some one. This is evident; for had he power to move himself as he wished he could go either as man, or wolf, or bat, or in some other way. He evidently fears discovery or interference, in the state of helplessness in which he must be—confined as he is between dawn and sunset in his wooden box.
vi: Surely someone must have brought him back. That is obvious, because if he had the power to move at will, he would have done so in the true guise of a human, a wolf, a bat, or any other form. Clearly, he is feeling suspicious that he might be exposed or troubled in his currently vulnerable state, confined in a box of earth during sunrise and sunset.
tr: (a) Must be taken back by someone. This is obvious; because if a person could act as they wished, they could transform into a wolf, bat, or another form and leave. Clearly, in the desperation I am sure he is in -trapped in a wooden box between dawn and sunset- he fears being discovered or having his work interfered with.
es: a) He must be taken there by someone. This is evident, since if he had the power to move as he wished, he would do so in the form of a man, a wolf, a bat, or any other animal. Evidently, he fears being discovered or hindered, in the state of helplessness in which he must find himself..., confined as he is, between dawn and sunset, in his wooden box.

en: (b) How is he to be taken?—Here a process of exclusions may help us. By road, by rail, by water?
vi: How could he be transported? Let's use the following process of elimination: 1. By road.
tr: (b) How will it be transported? - Here, the elimination method might be useful for us. By road, by rail, or by waterway?
es: b) How can it be transported? In this case, the process of reasoning by elimination can be useful to us. By train, by road, by water? 1. By road.

en: 1. By Road.—There are endless difficulties, especially in leaving the city.
vi: This will cause countless difficulties for him, especially when leaving the cities.
tr: 1. By road. - There are endless difficulties that can be encountered, especially when leaving a city.
es: There are too many difficulties, especially when leaving the city.

en: (x) There are people; and people are curious, and investigate. A hint, a surmise, a doubt as to what might be in the box, would destroy him.
vi: a) Encountering many people. The public will be curious and try to pry. A sign, a suspicion about what is hidden in the chest, and then he would be done for.
tr: (x) There are people; people are curious and they ask questions. A hint, guess, or doubt about what might be in the chest will ruin it.
es: x) There are people; people are curious and investigate. An idea, a doubt, or a supposition about what is in the box can mean its destruction.

en: (y) There are, or there may be, customs and octroi officers to pass.
vi: b) May or will certainly encounter customs or tax officials.
tr: (y) There are or may be customs officers or tax officials to pass through.
es: y) There are, or there may be, customs or checkpoints that one must pass through.

en: (z) His pursuers might follow. This is his highest fear; and in order to prevent his being betrayed he has repelled, so far as he can, even his victim—me!
vi: c) The pursuers chasing him could track his trail. That was his greatest fear, and it was precisely to avoid being exposed that he tried every possible way to run as far as he could, even from his victim - which was me!
tr: (z) Those who chase him can follow. This is his greatest fear; to avoid being caught, he even repelled his victim - that is, me - as much as he could!
es: z) His pursuers can follow him. That is his greatest fear, and in order not to be betrayed, he has repelled, as far as he can, even his victim... Me!

en: 2. By Rail.—There is no one in charge of the box. It would have to take its chance of being delayed; and delay would be fatal, with enemies on the track. True, he might escape at night; but what would he be, if left in a strange place with no refuge that he could fly to? This is not what he intends; and he does not mean to risk it.
vi: 2. By railway. If using this type of transportation, there would be no one to look after the wooden chest, which always has the risk of being delayed, and such a delay would be a fatal opportunity for the enemy to track him down. Of course, he could escape in the dark of night, but what would happen if he were thrown into an unfamiliar place with no suitable hiding spots? That was not his intention, nor was it a risk he could accept to take.
tr: 2. By railroad. - There will be no one responsible for the chest. He will have to risk the possibility of delay, and with enemies on his trail, a delay would be fatal. Sure, he could escape at night, but what if he ends up in a foreign place without a refuge to run to? This is not what he intends, and he does not want to jeopardize his goal.
es: 2. By train. There is no one to take care of the cash register. He would have to risk being delayed, and a delay would be fatal for him, since his enemies are pursuing him. It's true that he could flee at night, but what would become of him if he found himself in a strange place, unable to go to any refuge? That's not what he wants, and he is not willing to risk that.

en: 3. By Water.—Here is the safest way, in one respect, but with most danger in another. On the water he is powerless except at night; even then he can only summon fog and storm and snow and his wolves. But were he wrecked, the living water would engulf him, helpless; and he would indeed be lost. He could have the vessel drive to land; but if it were unfriendly land, wherein he was not free to move, his position would still be desperate.
vi: 3. By waterway. On one hand, it is the most reliable means, but on the other hand, it is also the most dangerous. On the water, he has no power, except during the night. At the same time, he can only command his fog, storms, ice, and pack of wolves. And if the ship sinks, he will be submerged by the sea god without being able to do anything, thus adding another possibility of failure.
tr: 3. By water. - Indeed, in one sense the safest, but in another sense the most dangerous route. While in the water, powerless except at night; even then, it can only summon mist, storm, snow, and its wolves. But if there is a shipwreck, the living water leaves it helpless and swallows it, and it truly disappears. It can bring the vessel to shore, but if it is in enemy territory without freedom of movement, its situation remains hopeless.
es: 3. By water. This is the safest way in a certain sense, but the one that holds the greatest danger in other aspects. On the water, he lacks power, except at night; even then, he can only summon fog, storm, snow, and his wolves. But in case of an accident, the living waters would engulf him and he would be truly lost. He could make his boat reach the shore, but if he found himself in enemy lands, where he would not be free to move, his situation would still be desperate.

en: We know from the record that he was on the water; so what we have to do is to ascertain what water.
vi: If he is on a ship, then of course we must determine which waters the ship is drifting in.
tr: From the records, we know that it is on the water; therefore, what we need to do is determine which water it is.
es: We know from what has happened so far that it was in the water; therefore, we still need to find out in which waters.

en: The first thing is to realise exactly what he has done as yet; we may, then, get a light on what his later task is to be.
vi: The first goal of ours is to accurately determine what he has done so far, which will show us what needs to be done next.
tr: First of all, we need to fully understand what you have done so far; then, we can find some insight into what your next step should be.
es: The first thing is to understand what has been done so far; then we will have an idea about what their task should be.

en: Firstly.—We must differentiate between what he did in London as part of his general plan of action, when he was pressed for moments and had to arrange as best he could.
vi: The first goal of ours is to accurately determine what he has done so far, which will show us what needs to be done next. First of all, we will consider his actions in London as part of his entire plan, while he must be in a hurry every minute and wants to escape immediately.
tr: First of all, we need to fully understand what you have done so far; then, we can find some insight into what your next step should be. First of all, during a period when he had to manage his time and do his best under tight constraints, we must recognize what he did in London as part of the overall movement plan.
