es: First of all. We must differentiate between what he did in London, as part of his general plan, when he was sometimes in a hurry and had to manage as best as he could.

en: Secondly we must see, as well as we can surmise it from the facts we know of, what he has done here.
vi: Then, we will try to infer what he did there with the events that we already know.
tr: Secondly, we need to understand what he is doing here, as much as we can infer from the facts we know.
es: Secondly, we must do our best to judge by the facts we know, what has been done here.

en: As to the first, he evidently intended to arrive at Galatz, and sent invoice to Varna to deceive us lest we should ascertain his means of exit from England; his immediate and sole purpose then was to escape. The proof of this, is the letter of instructions sent to Immanuel Hildesheim to clear and take away the box before sunrise. There is also the instruction to Petrof Skinsky. These we must only guess at; but there must have been some letter or message, since Skinsky came to Hildesheim.
vi: To begin with, it is obvious that he intended to go to Galatz. For us, the order concerning Varna was derailed if we understood that he had left England and we had to strive to determine his actual destination. His sole immediate purpose was to find a way to escape our pursuit: The main evidence is the instructions recorded in the letter to Emmanuel Hildesheim, to receive and unload the box before sunrise, as well as the instructions for Petrof Skinsky. At this point, we could only make guesses. There must surely be a letter or some form of communication, as he personally went to find Hildesheim.
tr: Regarding the first one, it is clear that he aimed to reach Galaţi and sent an invoice to Varna to deceive us so that we wouldn't learn the real reason for his departure from England; at that time, his sole purpose was to escape. The proof of this is the instruction letter sent to Immanuel Hildesheim, telling him to receive the crate before sunrise. There are also instructions given to Petrov Skinski. Here, we can only speculate; but since Skinski arrived at Hildesheim, there must have been a letter or a message.
es: Regarding the first point, he evidently planned to reach Galatz, and sent the box to Varna to deceive us, in case we discovered his means of fleeing England; thus, his immediate and sole purpose was to escape. To prove all this, we have the letter of instructions sent to Immanuel Hildesheim, stating that he should collect the box and disembark it before sunrise. Likewise, the instructions to Petrof Skinsky. In this case, we can only guess, but there must have been some letter or message, since Skinsky went to see Hildesheim.

en: That, so far, his plans were successful we know. The Czarina Catherine made a phenomenally quick journey—so much so that Captain Donelson’s suspicions were aroused; but his superstition united with his canniness played the Count’s game for him, and he ran with his favouring wind through fogs and all till he brought up blindfold at Galatz. That the Count’s arrangements were well made, has been proved. Hildesheim cleared the box, took it off, and gave it to Skinsky. Skinsky took it—and here we lose the trail. We only know that the box is somewhere on the water, moving along. The customs and the octroi, if there be any, have been avoided.
vi: According to what we know, up to this point, all of his plans have been completed. The ship Tsarine Catherine had such a terrifyingly fast journey that Captain Donelson became suspicious. How could the ship sail smoothly to Galatz through the eerie fog without encountering any trouble or collision? All of the count's preparations were effective. Hildesheim arrived to receive the wooden crate and handed it over to Skinsky. In turn, Skinsky also managed the crate - but that's as far as we know before losing track. Surely, those carrying the crate tried to avoid any encounters with customs or tax officials along the way.
tr: We know that their plans so far have been successful. Czarina Catherine made an astonishingly fast journey - so much so that it aroused Captain Donelson's suspicion; but his superstition, combined with his shrewdness, played into the Count's hands on his behalf, and he sped rapidly through the mists with a protective wind until he reached Galaţi blindly. It has been proven that the Count's arrangements were well made. Hildesheim took the chest and delivered it to Skinski. Skinski took it - and we lost track of it there. All we know is that the chest is moving somewhere over the water. Customs and tax officers, if there were any, must have been avoided.
es: Thus, so far, we know that their plans have been successful. The Czarina Catherine made an extraordinarily fast trip... To such an extent that Captain Donelson's suspicions were aroused, but his superstition, combined with his inertia, served the count, and he sailed with favorable wind through the fog and everything else, arriving blindly at Galatz. It has been proven that the count's arrangements have been well made. Hildesheim received the box, took it off the ship, and handed it over to Skinsky. He took it... and this is where the trail is lost. We only know that the box is somewhere, on the water, moving. The customs and excise office, if it exists, have been avoided.

en: Now we come to what the Count must have done after his arrival—on land, at Galatz.
vi: Now we must ponder what the old count did after arriving in Galatz.
tr: Now, we come to what the Count might have done after disembarking in Galaţi.
es: Now we come to what the count must have done after his arrival on land, in Galatz.

en: The box was given to Skinsky before sunrise. At sunrise the Count could appear in his own form. Here, we ask why Skinsky was chosen at all to aid in the work? In my husband’s diary, Skinsky is mentioned as dealing with the Slovaks who trade down the river to the port; and the man’s remark, that the murder was the work of a Slovak, showed the general feeling against his class. The Count wanted isolation.
vi: The wooden box was handed over to Skinsky before dawn. At sunrise, the old count could appear in his true form. We need to understand why Skinsky was chosen as an accomplice. According to my husband's diary, Skinsky has connections with the Slovaki people who are trading upstream at the port. And the rumored murderer is said to be a Slovaki; this notable detail indicates that people often think of these individuals. Did the old count intend to divert everyone's attention?
tr: The chest was delivered to Skinski before sunrise. At sunrise, the Count could appear in his own form. Here, we must ask why Skinski was chosen to assist in these matters. In my husband's journal, Skinski is mentioned as someone who goes down the river to the port and does business with the Slovaks; a man's comment there that the murder was the work of the Slovaks shows his general feelings towards this class. The Count wanted to be alone.
es: The box was delivered to Skinsky before sunrise. At sunrise, the count could appear in his true form. Here we ask: why was Skinsky chosen to carry out this task? In my husband's diary, the said Skinsky is indicated as an individual who trafficked with the Slovaks who traded by the river, up to the port; and the cry of the women, that the crime had been committed by Slovaks, showed the general sentiment against those of his kind. The count desired isolation.

en: My surmise is, this: that in London the Count decided to get back to his castle by water, as the most safe and secret way. He was brought from the castle by Szgany, and probably they delivered their cargo to Slovaks who took the boxes to Varna, for there they were shipped for London. Thus the Count had knowledge of the persons who could arrange this service. When the box was on land, before sunrise or after sunset, he came out from his box, met Skinsky and instructed him what to do as to arranging the carriage of the box up some river. When this was done, and he knew that all was in train, he blotted out his traces, as he thought, by murdering his agent.
vi: That is my conjecture. From London, the old count decided to return to Dracula's castle by sea, the surest and most secretive route. Previously, the Gypsies had taken him and might have had the Slovakians transport the boxes of earth to Varna, then continue by ship to London. Thus, the old count knew exactly who was capable of organizing this service for him. Now, when the coffin is brought to the surface, he will emerge before sunrise or after sunset and then instruct Skinsky to continue transporting the coffin by river. He certainly killed this man to cover his tracks and erase any evidence of his presence.
tr: My guess is this: The Count decided to return to his castle via the most reliable and secret route, the waterway, while he was in London. He had been removed from the castle by the Gypsies, and most likely they had handed over their cargo, the crates, to the Slovaks who took them to Varna; from Varna, they were loaded onto a ship to be taken to London. Thus, the Count had gathered information about the people who could arrange this service. While the crate was on land, either before sunrise or after sunset, he met with Skinski and instructed him to arrange for the crate to be transported along the river. When these tasks were completed and he realized everything was progressing smoothly, he thought he had covered his tracks by killing his intermediary.
es: I suppose that, in London, the count decided to return to his castle by water, since this was the safest and most secret way. He was taken from the castle by the gypsies, and they probably handed over their cargo to Slovaks, who took it to Varna, where it was shipped to London. Thus, the count knew the people who could perform this service. When the box was on land, before sunrise or after sunset, he came out of his box, met with Skinsky, and gave him instructions on what he had to do regarding finding someone who could transport the box by river. When Skinsky did so, and the count knew that everything was in order, he set about erasing the tracks by killing his agent.

en: I have examined the map and find that the river most suitable for the Slovaks to have ascended is either the Pruth or the Sereth. I read in the typescript that in my trance I heard cows low and water swirling level with my ears and the creaking of wood. The Count in his box, then, was on a river in an open boat—propelled probably either by oars or poles, for the banks are near and it is working against stream. There would be no such sound if floating down stream.
vi: Reviewing the map, I realized that the nearest river convenient for the Slovakians to travel upstream could only be the Pruth River or the Sereth River. I saw that Van Helsing's notes mentioned the sounds of water swirling at ear level, the clattering of wood that I sensed while being hypnotized. Thus, it is possible that the Count is still lying in the coffin, but placed in the hold of an open boat and moved by oars or poles. Of course, the boat might not necessarily be on the Pruth or Sereth River, but we can determine this.
tr: I examined the map and saw that the most suitable river for the Slovaks to exit was either the Prut or the Seret. In the typed texts, I read that when I entered a trance, I heard distant cow sounds, water sounds at ear level, and the creaking of wood. So, the Count was on an open boat on the river - most likely being propelled by oars or poles because the two banks of the river are close and the boat is moving against the current. If he were letting himself drift with the current, such sounds wouldn't be heard.
es: I have examined the maps and discovered that the most suitable river for the Slovaks to have ascended is the Pruth or the Sereth. I have read in the manuscript that in my moments of trance I heard cows in the distance and the sound of water at the level of my ears, as well as the sound of wood rubbing against wood. So, that means that the count, in his box, traveled on the river, in an open boat... probably propelled by means of oars or floats, since the banks are close and it sails against the current. Those noises would not occur if it were moving with the current.

en: Of course it may not be either the Sereth or the Pruth, but we may possibly investigate further. Now of these two, the Pruth is the more easily navigated, but the Sereth is, at Fundu, joined by the Bistritza which runs up round the Borgo Pass. The loop it makes is manifestly as close to Dracula’s castle as can be got by water.
vi: Of course, the boat might not necessarily be on the Pruth or Sereth River, but we can determine this. Among these two small rivers, navigating the Pruth River seems much easier, but the Sereth River, at the Fundu section, receives the Bistriza River, which is a small river flowing around the Borgo Pass. The bend at the foot of the pass is the point most accessible to Dracula's castle if traveling by water.
tr: Of course, it may not be the Seret and the Prut, but we can certainly do more research. Now, of the two, the journey on the Prut is easier, but the Seret is located in Fundu and joins the Bistriţa, which runs along the Borgo Pass. The point where the river bends is the closest place to reach Dracula's castle by water.
es: Naturally, it must be either the Sereth or the Pruth; but, at this point, we can investigate further. The Pruth is the easiest for navigation, but the Sereth, in Fundu, receives the Bistritza, which runs around the Borgo Pass. The curve it describes is manifestly as close to Dracula's castle as one can get by water.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal—continued.
vi: • Mina Harker's Diary (continued)
tr: Mina Harker's diary (continued)
es: From the Diary of Mina Harke (continued)

en: When I had done reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and kissed me. The others kept shaking me by both hands, and Dr. Van Helsing said:—
vi: After I finished reading, Jonathan rushed to hug me tightly. The other friends also grasped my hands firmly, looking very enthusiastic. As for Dr. Van Helsing, he exclaimed:
tr: When I finished reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and kissed me. The others shook my hand with both of theirs and Dr. Van Helsing said:
es: When I finished reading, Jonathan took me in his arms and hugged me; the others took me by both hands, shook me, and Dr. Van Helsing said:

en: “Our dear Madam Mina is once more our teacher. Her eyes have been where we were blinded. Now we are on the track once again, and this time we may succeed. Our enemy is at his most helpless; and if we can come on him by day, on the water, our task will be over. He has a start, but he is powerless to hasten, as he may not leave his box lest those who carry him may suspect; for them to suspect would be to prompt them to throw him in the stream where he perish. This he knows, and will not. Now men, to our Council of War; for, here and now, we must plan what each and all shall do.”
vi: — Once again, Mina proves herself worthy of being the guide of our group. She is truly perceptive, while we are just blind men. We have found the trail again, and if we encounter the enemy in broad daylight, on the water, our mission will be considered accomplished. Indeed, he is ahead of us, but he cannot move quickly; how could he dare to leave that coffin? The people escorting the box will surely become suspicious, and at the first sign of anything unusual, they would be ready to throw that cursed thing into the river. He understands this well and certainly wouldn't dare to do anything foolish. Now, we need to confer a bit because we must discuss the tasks each of us needs to undertake. — I will go look for a boat and the accompanying accessories.
tr: “Dear Madam Mina has once again become our teacher. Where we were blind, her eyes saw. Now we are once again on the trail, and this time we may succeed. Our enemy is at his weakest, and if we can find him in the water during the day, our task will be over. He started a step ahead, but because he cannot leave his box without arousing suspicion from those carrying him, he is too weak to hasten; to arouse suspicion in his men would mean provoking them to cast him into the stream where he would be lost forever. He knows this and will not do so. Now, gentlemen, let us convene our war council, for we must plan what each of us is to do.”
es: –Our dear lady Mina is, once again, our teacher. Her eyes have settled where we had seen nothing. Now, we are back on track and, this time, we can triumph. Our enemy is at his weakest point and, if we can reach him during the day, over the water, our task will be concluded. He has some advantage, but he cannot hurry, as he cannot leave his box in order not to arouse suspicion among those who transport him; if they suspected anything, their first reaction would be to immediately throw him overboard, and he would perish in the water. Naturally, he knows that and cannot expose himself. Now, friends, let us hold our war council, since it is necessary that we plan right here, at this very moment, what each of us must do.

en: “I shall get a steam launch and follow him,” said Lord Godalming.
vi: - Lord Godalming said.
tr: “I will find a steamship and follow him,” said Lord Godalming.
es: –I will get a steam launch to follow him -said Lord Godalming.

en: “And I, horses to follow on the bank lest by chance he land,” said Mr. Morris.
vi: — As for me, I will look to buy a horse to chase him along the riverbank if his boat comes ashore. - Quincey Morris declared.
tr: "And I will find horses to follow along the riverbank, in case by some chance he might have come ashore," said Mr. Morris.
es: –And I have horses to pursue him by land, in case he disembarks by chance -said Morris.

en: “Good!” said the Professor, “both good. But neither must go alone. There must be force to overcome force if need be; the Slovak is strong and rough, and he carries rude arms.” All the men smiled, for amongst them they carried a small arsenal. Said Mr. Morris:—
vi: — Good. - The professor continued. - Both of you have valid points, but you shouldn't go alone. You need to have strength if you encounter strength. The Slovakians are very strong and aggressive, and they are often fully armed. Everyone burst out laughing, as each person was ready to carry a small box of bullets. — I have brought along a few guns. - Morris said. -
tr: “Beautiful!” said the Professor, “Both are beautiful. But neither of you should go alone. If strength is needed, there must be strength to overcome it; Slovaks are strong and tough and carry tough weapons.” All the men laughed, because they were carrying a small arsenal with them. Mr. Morris took the floor:
es: –Good! – said the professor-. Both of you are right, but neither should go alone. We must have the strength to overcome other forces, if necessary; the Slovaks are strong and tough, and they are well-armed. All the men smiled, as they carried a small arsenal on them. –I have brought several Winchesters -said Mr. Morris-.

en: “I have brought some Winchesters; they are pretty handy in a crowd, and there may be wolves. The Count, if you remember, took some other precautions; he made some requisitions on others that Mrs. Harker could not quite hear or understand. We must be ready at all points.” Dr. Seward said:—
vi: They are very handy weapons to fend off attacks from crowds, not excluding packs of wolves. Everyone should remember that the count always has precautionary measures. He has tricks that Mrs. Harker here cannot fully hear or understand. We must be vigilant against any unforeseen events that may occur. — I think I can go with Quincey. - Dr. Seward interjected.
tr: “I brought a few Winchesters; they are quite useful in a crowd, and there might be wolves around. If you recall, the Count had taken some other precautions; he had made some requests that Ms. Harker could not hear or understand well. We must be prepared in every way.” Dr. Seward said:
es: They can be used very well in the middle of a crowd and, besides, there are wolves. The Count, if you remember, took other precautions; he gave certain instructions that Mrs. Harker could neither hear nor understand. We must be prepared for anything. –I think it would be best if I go with Quincey -said Dr. Seward-.

en: “I think I had better go with Quincey. We have been accustomed to hunt together, and we two, well armed, will be a match for whatever may come along. You must not be alone, Art. It may be necessary to fight the Slovaks, and a chance thrust—for I don’t suppose these fellows carry guns—would undo all our plans. There must be no chances, this time; we shall not rest until the Count’s head and body have been separated, and we are sure that he cannot re-incarnate.” He looked at Jonathan as he spoke, and Jonathan looked at me. I could see that the poor dear was torn about in his mind. Of course he wanted to be with me; but then the boat service would, most likely, be the one which would destroy the ... the ... the ... Vampire. (Why did I hesitate to write the word?) He was silent awhile, and during his silence Dr. Van Helsing spoke:—
vi: - You too, Arthur, you shouldn't go alone like that. You might have to confront the Slovakians, and just one mistake could ruin all our plans. This time, don't let any mistakes happen. Of course, we will only stop when the Count is beheaded and we ensure that he cannot reincarnate. He spoke while looking at Jonathan, whereas Jonathan looked at me as if pondering something. I understood that he was deeply troubled inside. Of course, he always wanted to be by my side, but only those on the boat had the chance to destroy the "vampire" (Why do I always hesitate when mentioning this word?). He stood silently without saying a word. Van Helsing had to speak up to break the silence:
tr: "I think it would be best if I go with Quincey. We are used to hunting together and, well-armed, the two of us can handle anything that may arise. You shouldn't go alone either, Art. We might have to fight the Slovaks, and a random attack—because I don't think these men carry weapons—could ruin all our plans. This time we must not leave anything to chance; we will not stop until the Count's head is separated from his body and we are sure he will not rise again." He looked at Jonathan as he spoke, and Jonathan looked at me. I could see the poor thing was torn. Of course, he wanted to stay by my side, but then, that boat trip would most likely be the thing that destroys the vam... vam... vampire. (Why am I hesitant to write that word?) He remained silent for a while, and during his silence, Dr. Van Helsing spoke:
es: –I think it would be best if I go with Quincey -said Dr. Seward-. We are used to hunting together, and both of us, well-armed, can be formidable foes for anyone who stands in our way. You shouldn't go alone either, Art. It might be necessary to fight against the Slovaks, and a stroke of luck, since I don't think they carry firearms, could ruin all our plans. We mustn't take risks this time; we won't rest until the count's head and body have been separated and we are sure that he won't be able to reincarnate. He looked at Jonathan while he spoke, and my husband looked at me. I understood that the poor man was desperate. Naturally, he wanted to be with me; but, in any case, the group that would leave in the boat would be the one most likely to destroy the..., the... vampire (why do I hesitate to write the word?). He remained silent for a moment and Dr. Van Helsing intervened, saying:

en: “Friend Jonathan, this is to you for twice reasons. First, because you are young and brave and can fight, and all energies may be needed at the last; and again that it is your right to destroy him—that—which has wrought such woe to you and yours. Be not afraid for Madam Mina; she will be my care, if I may. I am old. My legs are not so quick to run as once; and I am not used to ride so long or to pursue as need be, or to fight with lethal weapons. But I can be of other service; I can fight in other way. And I can die, if need be, as well as younger men. Now let me say that what I would is this: while you, my Lord Godalming and friend Jonathan go in your so swift little steamboat up the river, and whilst John and Quincey guard the bank where perchance he might be landed, I will take Madam Mina right into the heart of the enemy’s country. Whilst the old fox is tied in his box, floating on the running stream whence he cannot escape to land—where he dares not raise the lid of his coffin-box lest his Slovak carriers should in fear leave him to perish—we shall go in the track where Jonathan went,—from Bistritz over the Borgo, and find our way to the Castle of Dracula. Here, Madam Mina’s hypnotic power will surely help, and we shall find our way—all dark and unknown otherwise—after the first sunrise when we are near that fateful place. There is much to be done, and other places to be made sanctify, so that that nest of vipers be obliterated.” Here Jonathan interrupted him hotly:—
vi: — Dear friend Jonathan, there are two reasons why you must listen to us. First, you are young and no less brave, and you have the ability to fight, while the strength of all of us must be focused on the final battle. Moreover, you are the one who deserves to directly destroy what has caused you and your loved ones so much suffering. As for Mina at this time, you don't need to worry at all, I will take care of her to the best of my ability. After all, I am old, my legs are no longer as agile as before, I am not used to long horseback rides, nor am I good at wielding weapons. But if necessary, I can die like a true young man. How can I tell you what I am wishing for now! Here’s the plan, you will go upstream by boat with Lord Godalming, while John and Quincey will follow along the shore to guard against the possibility of the Tsarine Catherine docking unexpectedly. Meanwhile, I will lead Mina to the enemy's lair. While the old fox is still lying in the coffin on the ship heading upstream and cannot climb onto the land, or does not dare to open the lid for fear of the Slovaki throwing it into the water in panic - we will follow the path that Jonathan once took, from Bistritz to Borgo, and find our way to Dracula's castle. Mina's ability to enter a trance will certainly help us find our way in a strange land - right after the first sunrise on the necessary journey. There is still so much to do before the snake's den is eradicated. Jonathan eagerly interrupted:
tr: “My friend Jonathan, this task is yours for two reasons. First, because you are young, courageous, and capable of fighting, and for this last reason, all your strength may be needed, and it is your right to destroy this person who has caused such suffering to you and your loved ones. Do not worry about Madam Mina; if I can, she will be under my protection. I am old. My legs can no longer run as fast as they used to, and I am not accustomed to long rides, chases, or fighting with deadly weapons as required. But I can serve in other ways; I can fight in other ways. And if necessary, I can die like men younger than myself. Now, with your permission, let me tell you what I will do: Lord Godalming and my friend Jonathan, while you advance on the river with your fast, small steamship, and John and Quincey guard the riverbank where the Count might have found an opportunity, I will take Madam Mina to the very heart of our enemy's country. While the old fox progresses over the water, unable to escape ashore - the Slovak carriers, out of fear, do not dare to lift the lid of his coffin and leave him to decay - we will follow Jonathan's tracks, go from Bistriţa to Borgo, and from there find the way to Dracula's Castle. Here, Madam Mina's hypnotic power will certainly be of help, and following the first sunrise near that hateful place, with the help of her hypnotic power, we will find the otherwise completely dark and foreign path to us. There is much work to be done to destroy the nests of vipers, and other places to be sanctified.” Here Jonathan interrupted excitedly:
es: –Friend Jonathan, that is your responsibility for two reasons: firstly, because you are young, brave, and can fight. All forces may be necessary at the final moment; moreover, you have the right to destroy him, since he has caused so much suffering to you and yours. Do not worry about Mrs. Mina; I will take care of her, if I can. I am old and my legs no longer allow me to run as before; besides, I am not accustomed to riding such a long distance to chase the count, as may be necessary, nor to fighting with deadly weapons. And I can die, if necessary, as well as younger men. Let me tell you what I desire: while you, Lord Godalming, and our friend Jonathan, advance so quickly in your beautiful steam launch, and while John and Quincey guard the shore, where Dracula may have disembarked by chance, I will take Mrs. Mina directly to the enemy's territory. While the old fox is locked in his box, floating in the middle of the river current, where he cannot escape to land, and where he cannot afford to lift the cover of his box, because those transporting him would throw him into the water and let him perish in it, we must follow the trail taken by Jonathan. From Bistritz, over the Borgo, and we must find the way to Count Dracula's castle. There, Mrs. Mina's hypnotic power can surely help us, and we will set out on the path, which is dark and unknown, after the first dawn immediately following our arrival in the vicinity of that grim place. There is much to do, and other places to sanctify, so that this nest of vipers is destroyed. At that moment, Jonathan interrupted him, saying passionately:

en: “Do you mean to say, Professor Van Helsing, that you would bring Mina, in her sad case and tainted as she is with that devil’s illness, right into the jaws of his death-trap? Not for the world! Not for Heaven or Hell!” He became almost speechless for a minute, and then went on:—
vi: — What, Dr. Van Helsing? Are you planning to take my Mina to the lair of death in such a despondent state? That cannot be, it would be of no benefit at all!... He was silent for a moment before continuing:
tr: “So, Professor Van Helsing, are you saying that you will take Mina, in her distressing condition and tainted by the devil's affliction, right into the heart of the Count's death trap? Not in this world! For the love of Heaven and Hell, no!” He was almost speechless for a while and then continued:
es: "Do you mean to say, professor, that you are going to lead Mina, in her sad state and stigmatized as she is with that diabolical disease, to the wolf's den so that she falls into a deadly trap?" "By no means!" "Not for anything in the world!" For a minute, he lost his voice and then continued:

en: “Do you know what the place is? Have you seen that awful den of hellish infamy—with the very moonlight alive with grisly shapes, and every speck of dust that whirls in the wind a devouring monster in embryo? Have you felt the Vampire’s lips upon your throat?” Here he turned to me, and as his eyes lit on my forehead he threw up his arms with a cry: “Oh, my God, what have we done to have this terror upon us!” and he sank down on the sofa in a collapse of misery. The Professor’s voice, as he spoke in clear, sweet tones, which seemed to vibrate in the air, calmed us all:—
vi: — Do you know what kind of place that is? Have you ever seen such a terrifying hell? A place where even the moonlight takes on grotesque shapes? Where every speck of dust whirls madly in the wind, always potentially manifesting into female demons? Have you ever felt the filthy lips of a "vampire" sink into your neck? Then he turned and stared intently at my forehead, raising both hands and exclaiming to the heavens: — Oh my God! What did we ever do to anyone to deserve this? Unable to bear the rising tide of disappointment in his heart, he let himself fall heavily onto the couch. But as always, the warm, gentle, and confident voice of the old professor somewhat alleviated the bitterness in his heart and ours.
tr: “Do you know what kind of place that is? Have you seen that dreadful hole filled with diabolical abominations - do you know that even the moonlight itself, with its terrifying shapes, and every dust particle flying in the wind are the embryos of a devouring monster? Have you felt the Vampire's lips on your throat?” Here he turned to me, and with his eyes fixed on my forehead, he raised his arms into the air and cried out: “Oh, God! What have we done to deserve this horror!” and collapsed onto the couch in agony. The Professor's voice, which seemed to vibrate in the air with clear, sweet tones, calmed us all as he spoke:
es: –Do you know what that place is like? Have you seen that terrible den of infernal infamies... where the very light of the moon is alive and takes on all kinds of forms, and where every particle of dust is an embryo of a monster? Have you felt the lips of the vampire on your neck? He turned towards me, fixed his eyes on my forehead, and raised his arms, shouting: –My God! What have we done for you to send this horror upon us? – and he collapsed onto the divan, feeling shattered. The professor's voice, with its sweet and clear tone, which seemed to vibrate in the air, calmed us all.

en: “Oh, my friend, it is because I would save Madam Mina from that awful place that I would go. God forbid that I should take her into that place. There is work—wild work—to be done there, that her eyes may not see. We men here, all save Jonathan, have seen with their own eyes what is to be done before that place can be purify. Remember that we are in terrible straits. If the Count escape us this time—and he is strong and subtle and cunning—he may choose to sleep him for a century, and then in time our dear one”—he took my hand—“would come to him to keep him company, and would be as those others that you, Jonathan, saw. You have told us of their gloating lips; you heard their ribald laugh as they clutched the moving bag that the Count threw to them. You shudder; and well may it be. Forgive me that I make you so much pain, but it is necessary. My friend, is it not a dire need for the which I am giving, possibly my life? If it were that any one went into that place to stay, it is I who would have to go to keep them company.”
vi: — But my friend, if I wish to venture into the lion's den, it is merely to save our dear Mina. All of us men recognize what needs to be done before that dreadful place is eradicated. Remember that we are being pushed to the brink. If we let him slip through our fingers this time, the Count, a clever, immensely powerful, and extremely cunning individual, might decide to lie low for hundreds of years. And there will come a time when this poor girl here - he said, taking my hand - will become a fiend like the women you saw in Dracula's castle, Jonathan. Doesn't that sound terrifying to you? I understand that! Sorry to upset you again, but what I am saying is necessary, my friend. Do you think we should let such a harsh reality occur? However, if that harsh reality does occur, I am ready to give my life to prevent it. If someone has to go and then remain in Dracula's hell, that person must be me.
tr: “Ah, my friend! Because I will protect Madam Mina from that dreadful place I am going to. God spare me from taking her to that dreadful place. There, there are things that must be done -savage things- that she cannot see. All the men here, except Jonathan, have seen with our own eyes what needs to be done to cleanse that castle. Remember, we are in a terrible predicament. If the Count escapes us this time -a strong, cunning, and sly one- he may choose to sleep for a century, and in time our dear lady,” -he held my hand- “would go to join him, and Jonathan would become like the others you have seen. You told us about their malevolent lips; you heard their mocking laughter as they grabbed the moving sack the Count threw to them. You are trembling; let it be. Forgive me for causing you such pain, but it is necessary. My friend, if this thing for which I would give my life is not an urgent need, what is? If someone goes to stay there, I must go with them to accompany them.”
es: –My friend, it is because I want to save Mrs. Mina from that horror that I want to take her there. God forbid that I bring her into that place. There is certain work; a terrible work that must be done there, and her eyes must not see it. All the men present, except Jonathan, have seen what we will have to do before that place is purified. Remember that we are in the midst of a terrible danger. If the count escapes us this time, and we must consider that he is strong, intelligent, and skillful, he may wish to sleep for a century, and in due time, our dear lady - he took my hand - will go to his side to accompany him, and she will be like the others you saw, Jonathan. You have described to us everything about their gluttonous lips and horrible laughs when they took the moving sack that the count had thrown to them. You shudder, but it is something that can happen. Forgive me for causing you so much pain, but it is necessary. My friend, is this not an undertaking in which I will probably have to lose my life? In the event that any of us must go to that place to stay, it will have to be me, to keep them company.

en: “Do as you will,” said Jonathan, with a sob that shook him all over, “we are in the hands of God!”
vi: — Then do as you please. - Jonathan said, choking back sobs. - We are all in the arms of God!
tr: “Do whatever you want,” said Jonathan, with a sob that shook his entire body. “We are in God's hands!”
es: "Do as you please," said Jonathan, with a sob that made his whole body tremble. We are in the hands of God!

en: Later.—Oh, it did me good to see the way that these brave men worked. How can women help loving men when they are so earnest, and so true, and so brave! And, too, it made me think of the wonderful power of money! What can it not do when it is properly applied; and what might it do when basely used. I felt so thankful that Lord Godalming is rich, and that both he and Mr. Morris, who also has plenty of money, are willing to spend it so freely. For if they did not, our little expedition could not start, either so promptly or so well equipped, as it will within another hour. It is not three hours since it was arranged what part each of us was to do; and now Lord Godalming and Jonathan have a lovely steam launch, with steam up ready to start at a moment’s notice. Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris have half a dozen good horses, well appointed. We have all the maps and appliances of various kinds that can be had. Professor Van Helsing and I are to leave by the 11:40 train to-night for Veresti, where we are to get a carriage to drive to the Borgo Pass. We are bringing a good deal of ready money, as we are to buy a carriage and horses. We shall drive ourselves, for we have no one whom we can trust in the matter. The Professor knows something of a great many languages, so we shall get on all right. We have all got arms, even for me a large-bore revolver; Jonathan would not be happy unless I was armed like the rest. Alas! I cannot carry one arm that the rest do; the scar on my forehead forbids that. Dear Dr. Van Helsing comforts me by telling me that I am fully armed as there may be wolves; the weather is getting colder every hour, and there are snow-flurries which come and go as warnings.
vi: • A moment later Indeed, I was greatly comforted to work with such brave men as my husband's friends! A gentle woman cannot help but admire such serious, honest, and courageous men! But to be honest, I also secretly appreciate their financial capabilities. Without money, what could we possibly accomplish at this moment? I am very grateful for the wealth of Lord Godalming and also that of Mr. Quincey Morris. If they were poor, we could not have set out here, and so quickly at that. Each of our tasks was well arranged, and everyone tried to complete all their duties. In just three hours, Lord Godalming and Jonathan had a lovely steam launch ready to depart at the first signal. Dr. Seward and Morris managed to buy half a dozen thoroughbred horses, already saddled. We also purchased all necessary maps and equipment. At 11:40 PM tonight, I will go with Dr. Van Helsing to Veresti, where we can buy a carriage to reach the Borgo Pass. Of course, we must carry a lot of cash to buy the carriage and some horses. We have to manage on our own, as we know no one else trustworthy enough to help with the purchases. The professor is fluent in many languages, so there is no need to worry about this matter. We are all armed. Even I have a large revolver. Jonathan is only calm when he sees that I am armed like the others. Dr. Van Helsing said the gun could help me if I encounter wolves. The weather is getting colder with snowstorms swirling around as if to challenge us.
tr: Later on. - Ah, it did me good to see how these brave men work. When men are so sincere, so honest, and so brave, how can women help but love them! And this made me think of the perfect power of money. What can't it do when used correctly! And what can it do when used cowardly! I am grateful that Lord Godalming is rich, and that both he and Mr. Morris, who also has plenty of money, are ready to spend their money so freely. Because if they weren't, our little expedition could neither start so quickly nor be so well-equipped as it will be in an hour. It hasn't even been three hours since we organized the tasks each of us has to do, and now Lord Godalming and Jonathan have a nice steam launch ready to go at any moment. Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris have half a dozen well-equipped fine horses. We have taken all the maps and every kind of equipment we could find. Professor Van Helsing and I will go to Veresti tonight on the 11:40 train, where we will arrange for a carriage to take us to the Borgo Pass. We have plenty of cash with us as we will buy a carriage and horses. We will drive the carriage ourselves, as there is no one we can trust with this task. The professor knows many languages, so we will not have any problems. We are all armed, and even I have been given a large-caliber pistol; Jonathan would not be happy if I were not armed like the others. Alas! I cannot carry one of the weapons the others have; the scar on my forehead does not allow it. Dear Dr. Van Helsing reassures me by saying that I am fully armed because there might be wolves; with each passing hour, the weather gets colder, and there are flurries of snow coming and going as if to warn us.
es: Later. It did me a lot of good to see the way those brave men work. How is it possible that women do not love men who are so sincere, frank, and brave? Likewise, I thought about the extraordinary power of money. What can't it do when applied correctly? What can't it achieve when used in a low manner? I am very happy that Lord Godalming is so rich and that both he and Mr. Morris, who also has a lot of money, are willing to spend it so liberally. Because, if it were not so, our expedition would not have been able to set off, neither so quickly nor with such good equipment, as it will do within another hour. Not even three hours have passed since it was decided what role each of us would play, and now, Lord Godalming and Jonathan have a beautiful steam launch, and are ready to depart at any moment. Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris have half a dozen excellent horses, all prepared. We possess all the maps and enlargements of all kinds that it is possible to obtain. Professor Van Helsing and I must leave tonight, at eleven forty, by train, bound for Veresti, where we will get a carriage to take us to the Borgo Pass. We carry a good amount of money with us, as we will have to buy the carriage and the horses. We must drive it ourselves, as there is no one we can trust in this case. The professor knows many languages, so we will be able to get by without too much difficulty. We all have weapons, and they even got me a long-barreled revolver; Jonathan did not feel at ease unless I was armed like the rest of them. But I cannot carry a weapon that the others carry; the stigma on my forehead forbids it. Dear Dr. Van Helsing comforts me, telling me that I am well-armed, as it is possible we may encounter wolves. The weather is getting colder with each passing hour, and there are snowflakes floating in the air, like bad omens.

en: Later.—It took all my courage to say good-bye to my darling. We may never meet again. Courage, Mina! the Professor is looking at you keenly; his look is a warning. There must be no tears now—unless it may be that God will let them fall in gladness.
vi: • A moment later I had to be extremely brave to say farewell to my beloved husband. We might not have the chance to meet again. Mina, be brave! The old professor is looking at me as if to remind me not to be soft-hearted at this moment. Do not shed tears if it is not yet the time to cry for joy and happiness.
tr: Later. - I had to muster all my courage to say goodbye to my lover. We may never see each other again. Courage, Mina! You must not shed tears now - unless God allows them to be shed in happiness.
es: Later. I gathered the courage to say goodbye to my dear husband. It is possible that we may never see each other again. Courage, Mina! The professor is staring at you intently, and that look is a warning. You must not shed tears now… unless God allows them to be of joy.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: October 30. Night.—I am writing this in the light from the furnace door of the steam launch: Lord Godalming is firing up. He is an experienced hand at the work, as he has had for years a launch of his own on the Thames, and another on the Norfolk Broads. Regarding our plans, we finally decided that Mina’s guess was correct, and that if any waterway was chosen for the Count’s escape back to his Castle, the Sereth and then the Bistritza at its junction, would be the one. We took it, that somewhere about the 47th degree, north latitude, would be the place chosen for the crossing the country between the river and the Carpathians. We have no fear in running at good speed up the river at night; there is plenty of water, and the banks are wide enough apart to make steaming, even in the dark, easy enough. Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while, as it is enough for the present for one to be on watch. But I cannot sleep—how can I with the terrible danger hanging over my darling, and her going out into that awful place.... My only comfort is that we are in the hands of God. Only for that faith it would be easier to die than to live, and so be quit of all the trouble. Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward were off on their long ride before we started; they are to keep up the right bank, far enough off to get on higher lands where they can see a good stretch of river and avoid the following of its curves. They have, for the first stages, two men to ride and lead their spare horses—four in all, so as not to excite curiosity. When they dismiss the men, which shall be shortly, they shall themselves look after the horses. It may be necessary for us to join forces; if so they can mount our whole party. One of the saddles has a movable horn, and can be easily adapted for Mina, if required.
vi: • October 30 I am writing these lines under the light streaming through the boiler room door on the boat, while Lord Godalming takes on the responsibility of operating the boiler, as he is quite experienced after many years with his small boat on the Thames and on the lakes in Norfolk. After studying various maps, we decided to follow Mina's hypothesis: if there is a waterway that takes Dracula back to his castle, it can only be the Sereth River, then from the confluence continue along the Bistritza River. We consider the ideal place to cross the land, between the river and the Carpathian range, to be at 47 degrees north latitude. Our boat can speed at full throttle without any worries: the river's water is deep everywhere and the distance between the banks is always wide enough for us to glide comfortably on the water, even at night. Lord Godalming advised me to take a nap, saying that at this moment, one person is enough to manage everything. But how could I sleep when my mind is always heavy with fear about a vague danger looming over my wife on her way to that dreadful place? My only solace is to remind myself that our friends are in the protective arms of God. Without this belief, the simplest way for me to escape all the bitterness would be to seek death. Morris and Dr. Seward set off on horseback ahead of us because the route they have to take is very long and not without hardships. They followed the Sereth River upstream to maintain a certain view of the river and to avoid the rough, winding roads. Two riders with spare horses accompanied them in the initial stages to avoid drawing attention. These two riders will soon return, and then my two friends will have to manage everything on their own. There may come a time when we will have to meet them to continue the rest of the journey on horseback together.
tr: October 30, evening. - I am writing these lines by the light coming from the furnace door of the steamship; Lord Godalming is tending the fire. He is experienced in this matter, having had one boat on the Thames and another on the Norfolk Broads for many years. As for our plans, we have finally decided that Mina's predictions are correct and that if the Count has chosen any waterway for his escape to his castle, it would be the Seret and then immediately the Bistriţa beside it. We thought the crossing of the lands between the river and the Carpathian Mountains would be somewhere near the 47th parallel. We are not afraid of crossing the river swiftly at night; there is plenty of water making it easy enough to proceed with the steamship even in the dark, and the shores are far enough apart. Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while, as one person keeping watch is sufficient for now. But I cannot sleep - how can I sleep while my beloved is in that dreadful danger and heading to that terrible place... My only solace is that we are in God's hands. With this belief alone, dying and thus escaping all troubles would be easier than living. Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward had set out on their long journey on horseback before we departed; they will advance until they reach the lands high enough on the right bank of the river to see it and avoid its bends. In the initial stages, they have two men to ride and manage the spare horses - they are four in total to avoid arousing curiosity. After sending the men away - which will happen shortly - they will take care of the horses themselves. The grip of one of the saddles is movable and can be easily adjusted for Mina if necessary.
es: October 30, at night. I am writing this by the light given off by the boiler of the steam launch; Lord Godalming is acting as stoker. He has experience in the work, as he had his own boat on the Thames and another on the Norfolk Broads for many years. Regarding our plans, we have finally decided that Mina's assumptions were relevant and that if the Count had chosen a waterway to return to his castle, it must necessarily be the Sereth and Bistritza rivers. We assumed that somewhere near the forty-seventh degree of north latitude would be the chosen place to cross the country between the river and the Carpathians. We were not afraid to move at a good speed on the river, in the middle of the night; the water is deep and the banks are far enough apart from us so that we can navigate calmly and without difficulties, even in the dark. Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while; that it is enough for the moment that one of us stays on guard. But I cannot sleep… How could I, with the terrible danger hanging over my dear wife and thinking that she is heading towards that accursed place…? My only consolation is that we are in God's hands. The bad thing is that, with that faith, it would be easier to die than to continue living, to put an end to all these worries once and for all. Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward set out to make their enormous journey on horseback before we set off; they must stay on the riverbank, at a considerable distance, on the highlands, so that they can see a good stretch of the river without needing to follow its meanders. For the first stages, they have two men with them, to lead their spare horses… Four in total, in order not to arouse curiosity. When they dismiss the men, which will happen quite soon, they will have to take care of the horses themselves. It is possible that we will need to join forces, and in that case, we can all ride the horses… One of the saddles has a movable pommel, which can be adapted for Mina, if necessary.

en: It is a wild adventure we are on. Here, as we are rushing along through the darkness, with the cold from the river seeming to rise up and strike us; with all the mysterious voices of the night around us, it all comes home. We seem to be drifting into unknown places and unknown ways; into a whole world of dark and dreadful things. Godalming is shutting the furnace door....
vi: Our journey was truly an adventurous and perilous trip! We quietly traveled through the night, under the increasingly bone-chilling cold, amidst countless sorrowful sounds along the riverbanks, on unfamiliar roads full of dangers, with uncertainties looming overhead, towards a world of hell with countless horrors awaiting each person. Lord Godalming had just closed the boiler door...
tr: We embarked on a wild adventure. Here, as we hurriedly move through the darkness, we grasp the situation with the cold that seems to rise from the river and hit us, and the mysterious sounds of the night surrounding us. It feels as if we are being dragged towards unknown places and unknown paths, into a vast world filled with dark and terrifying things. Godalming is closing the stove door...
es: We have embarked on a terrible adventure. Here, as we move forward in the midst of darkness, feeling the coldness of the river that seems to rise to strike us, surrounded by all the mysterious voices of the night, we see everything clearly. We seem to be heading towards unknown places, by unknown routes, and entering a new world of dark and terrible objects. Godalming is closing the boiler door…

en: 31 October.—Still hurrying along. The day has come, and Godalming is sleeping. I am on watch. The morning is bitterly cold; the furnace heat is grateful, though we have heavy fur coats. As yet we have passed only a few open boats, but none of them had on board any box or package of anything like the size of the one we seek. The men were scared every time we turned our electric lamp on them, and fell on their knees and prayed.
vi: • October 31 Still on the pursuit journey. A new day is coming. Lord Godalming just woke up after a good night's sleep. The morning weather is very cold. We passed several cargo barges but did not see any carrying a wooden coffin like we were looking for. Our flashlight beams scared the sailors, they dropped to their knees on the deck, praying and bowing repeatedly.
tr: October 31. - We are still progressing rapidly. Dawn has broken and Lord Godalming is sleeping. I am on watch. In the morning, there is a bitter cold; despite our heavy fur coats, the fire in the stove feels good. So far, only a few open boats have passed, but none had anything resembling the crate or package we are looking for on their decks. The men, each time we shone the electric sailor's lantern on them, got scared and fell to their knees, praying.
es: October 31. We continue advancing at good speed. The day has arrived and Godalming is sleeping. I am on guard. The morning is very cold and the warmth from the boiler is very pleasant, despite us wearing thick fur jackets. So far, we have only passed a few open boats, but none of them had any kind of equipment box on board, approximately the size we are looking for. The men always got scared whenever we turned our electric lamp towards them, they knelt and prayed.

en: 1 November, evening.—No news all day; we have found nothing of the kind we seek. We have now passed into the Bistritza; and if we are wrong in our surmise our chance is gone. We have over-hauled every boat, big and little. Early this morning, one crew took us for a Government boat, and treated us accordingly. We saw in this a way of smoothing matters, so at Fundu, where the Bistritza runs into the Sereth, we got a Roumanian flag which we now fly conspicuously. With every boat which we have over-hauled since then this trick has succeeded; we have had every deference shown to us, and not once any objection to whatever we chose to ask or do. Some of the Slovaks tell us that a big boat passed them, going at more than usual speed as she had a double crew on board. This was before they came to Fundu, so they could not tell us whether the boat turned into the Bistritza or continued on up the Sereth. At Fundu we could not hear of any such boat, so she must have passed there in the night. I am feeling very sleepy; the cold is perhaps beginning to tell upon me, and nature must have rest some time. Godalming insists that he shall keep the first watch. God bless him for all his goodness to poor dear Mina and me.
vi: • November 1, afternoon Today, there is nothing new. We haven't found what we were looking for, despite keeping an eye on all the large and small boats we encountered on the river. Now we are in Bistritza. If the hypothesis our group proposed is wrong, then we have lost all our chances. This morning, we were warmly welcomed by the sailors on a government ship and managed to obtain a Romanian flag to put on our boat. The flag facilitated our approach and inquiries with the boats traveling on the river without any obstacles. Some Slovakians informed us about a large ship, with several sailors who looked like ghosts on the deck, passing them at an unusually high speed. They saw this ship near the Fundu junction, where the Bistritza river flows into the Sereth river, so they didn't know which way it intended to turn. We arrived at Fundu but didn't learn anything new, likely because the ship crossed the river during the night. My eyes are heavy with sleep, perhaps the biting cold has stimulated an instinct that is growing stronger within me. Godalming insisted on taking the first watch. God will bless him, a friend who is wholeheartedly dedicated to my wife and me.
tr: November 1, evening. - No news all day; we found nothing of the sort we were looking for. We have now moved on to Bistriţa, and if we are wrong in our guess, it means we have lost our chance. We checked all the boats, big and small. Early this morning, one of the crew mistook us for a government boat and acted accordingly. We saw something in this that would make things easier; thus, we obtained a Romanian flag now conspicuously waving at Fundu, where the Bistriţa merges with the Seret. Since then, this trick has worked on all the boats we have inspected; we are shown every respect and not once have we been opposed in what we ask or want to do. Some of the Slovaks said that a large boat, which was going faster than usual due to double crew on deck, passed by them. This was before they reached Fundu, so they couldn't tell if the boat returned to Bistriţa or proceeded up along the Seret. We heard nothing about such a boat at Fundu; it must have passed there during the night. I am very sleepy; perhaps the cold is starting to affect me badly, and even nature needs to rest at times. Godalming insists on taking the first watch. Thank God for the kindness Godalming has shown to poor Mina and me.
es: November 1st, at night. We haven't had any news all day nor have we found anything of the type we're looking for. We have already passed Bistritza, and if we are wrong in our assumptions, we will have missed the opportunity. We have observed all the boats, large and small. This morning, early, the crew of one of them thought we were a government vessel, and treated us very well. We saw in this, in a way, an improvement in our situation; thus, in Fundu, where the Bistritza converges into the Sereth. We obtained a Romanian flag which we now carry on the bow. This trick has been successful with all the boats we have encountered since; everyone has shown us great deference and no one has objected to anything we wanted to inspect or ask about. In Fundu we did not get any news about any similar boat, so it must have passed through there at night. I feel very sleepy; the cold is perhaps affecting me, and nature needs to rest from time to time. Godalming insists that he will take the first watch. God bless him for all his kindness to Mina and me.

en: 2 November, morning.—It is broad daylight. That good fellow would not wake me. He says it would have been a sin to, for I slept peacefully and was forgetting my trouble. It seems brutally selfish to me to have slept so long, and let him watch all night; but he was quite right. I am a new man this morning; and, as I sit here and watch him sleeping, I can do all that is necessary both as to minding the engine, steering, and keeping watch. I can feel that my strength and energy are coming back to me. I wonder where Mina is now, and Van Helsing. They should have got to Veresti about noon on Wednesday. It would take them some time to get the carriage and horses; so if they had started and travelled hard, they would be about now at the Borgo Pass. God guide and help them! I am afraid to think what may happen. If we could only go faster! but we cannot; the engines are throbbing and doing their utmost. I wonder how Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris are getting on. There seem to be endless streams running down the mountains into this river, but as none of them are very large—at present, at all events, though they are terrible doubtless in winter and when the snow melts—the horsemen may not have met much obstruction. I hope that before we get to Strasba we may see them; for if by that time we have not overtaken the Count, it may be necessary to take counsel together what to do next.
vi: • November 2, morning The sun was already high, but my friend still didn't want to wake me up. He said that doing so would be wrong, as a peaceful sleep would temporarily make me forget the worries in my heart. I felt a bit selfish for having slept so long. But anyway, Godalming was right because clearly this morning I felt like a completely different person, fully capable of controlling the boat and observing everything happening around. It seemed I had regained my strength and determination. I wonder where Mina and Dr. Van Helsing are now. Surely they must have reached Varesti by Wednesday noon as planned. They would need some time to buy a carriage and a few horses. If everything went smoothly, they should definitely be at Borgo Pass by now. May God protect them! I shivered at the thought of what might happen to them. I wish we could go faster. But the boat's engines were already running at maximum speed. How can we catch up with Dr. Seward and Morris?... There were many small streams flowing down from the cliffs into the river we were traveling on, but they wouldn't pose any significant obstacles to the riders—at least not today, when there was no snow. I hope to meet them again before reaching Strasba. Because if we haven't found the Count by then, we will need to meet to reconsider the situation.
tr: 2 November, morning. - The weather has brightened up completely. The kind-hearted man did not wake me up. He says it would be a sin to wake me up because I slept so peacefully and forgot my troubles. It feels very selfish to sleep so much and let him keep watch all night, but he was quite right about it. This morning, I have become a brand new man; sitting here watching Godalming sleep, I can do everything related to looking at the engine, steering, and keeping watch. I can feel my strength and vigor returning. I wonder where Mina and Van Helsing are now. They must have arrived in Veresti by noon on Wednesday. It will take them some time to find a carriage and horses; so, if they have set off and traveled quickly, they are at Borgo Pass by now. May God guide and help them! I am afraid to think of what might happen to them. I wish we could go faster! But we cannot; the engines are working hard and doing their best. I wonder how Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris are progressing. There are countless streams flowing from the mountains into this river, but none of them are very wide - although they are undoubtedly terrifying in winter and when the snow melts, for now, they are in this state - so the riders must not have encountered too many obstacles. I hope we can see them before reaching Strasba, because if we haven't caught the Count by then, we may need to come together and discuss what to do next.
es: November 2, in the morning. The day is very clear. My good friend did not want to wake me up. He said he would have considered it a sin, as I was sleeping peacefully and, for the moment, forgetting my sorrows. It seemed somewhat inconsiderate to have slept so long and left him watching over me all night, but he was right. I am a new man this morning and, while I sit watching him sleep, I can take care of the engine, the helm, and the watch. I feel my strength and energy returning to me. I wonder where Mina and Van Helsing are now. They should have arrived in Veresti around noon on Wednesday. They would need some time to get the carriage and horses, so if they had set off quickly, they would already be near the Borgo Pass. May God help and protect them! I fear to think of what might happen. If only we could move faster! But it is not possible. The engines are working at full capacity, and it is not possible to ask more of them. I also wonder how Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward are doing. There seem to be endless torrents coming down from the mountains to the river, but since none of them are too wide... at least at this moment, although they are undoubtedly terrible in winter and when the snow melts, the riders will not find great difficulties in crossing them. I hope to see them before reaching Strasba, because if we have not caught the count by then, it may be necessary for us to meet to decide what to do next.

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the journal of Dr. Seward

en: 2 November.—Three days on the road. No news, and no time to write it if there had been, for every moment is precious. We have had only the rest needful for the horses; but we are both bearing it wonderfully. Those adventurous days of ours are turning up useful. We must push on; we shall never feel happy till we get the launch in sight again.
vi: • November 2 Three days of continuous travel on the road, without any news, and even if there was, I wouldn't have found the time to record it, because every minute is precious to us at this moment. We only dared to stop when we had to let the horses rest for a moment; otherwise, we had enough strength to keep going. Our past wanderings turned out to be incredibly useful; without that experience, could we have been as persistent as we are now? We could only be happy when we reunited with the boat carrying Lord Godalming and our friend Jonathan.
tr: November 2. - Three days on the road. No news; even if there were news, there is no time to write it down as every moment is precious. We only took breaks necessary for the horses; but we both are enduring this very well. It turns out that our adventure-filled days have been beneficial. We must speed up; we will never be happy again until we see the steamship once more.
es: November 2nd. We have been galloping for three days. There is nothing new and, in any case, I wouldn't have had time to write anything, even if there had been something. We only take the necessary breaks for the horses, but we are both enduring it very well. The days when we had so many adventures are proving to be very useful. We must keep going; we will never feel content until we see the boat again.

en: 3 November.—We heard at Fundu that the launch had gone up the Bistritza. I wish it wasn’t so cold. There are signs of snow coming; and if it falls heavy it will stop us. In such case we must get a sledge and go on, Russian fashion.
vi: • November 3 At Fundu, someone told us that the boat had entered the Bistritza River. Let's hope they don't freeze to death from the cold! It seems like it is about to snow. If the snow falls heavily, we will be significantly hindered. In that case, we will have to buy a sled to travel like the Russians do.
tr: November 3. - In Fundu, we learned that the boat was going up the Bistriţa. I wish the weather wasn't so cold. There are signs that snow is coming, and if there is heavy snowfall, it will stop us. In such a case, we would need to get a sled and continue like the Russians.
es: November 3rd. In Fundu, we learned that the boat had gone by the Bistritza. I wished it wasn't so cold. There were signs that it would snow, and if the snow fell heavily, it would stop us. In that case, we will have to get a sled to continue, Russian style.

en: 4 November.—To-day we heard of the launch having been detained by an accident when trying to force a way up the rapids. The Slovak boats get up all right, by aid of a rope and steering with knowledge. Some went up only a few hours before. Godalming is an amateur fitter himself, and evidently it was he who put the launch in trim again. Finally, they got up the rapids all right, with local help, and are off on the chase afresh. I fear that the boat is not any better for the accident; the peasantry tell us that after she got upon smooth water again, she kept stopping every now and again so long as she was in sight. We must push on harder than ever; our help may be wanted soon.
vi: • November 4 Today, after inquiring, we learned that the boat had been damaged and deformed due to the effort of crossing rapids and waterfalls. The boats of the Slovak people easily overcame these obstacles thanks to the assistance of a tow rope and the unparalleled rowing skills of each person on the boat. Fortunately, Godalming is an amateur mechanic, so he was able to restore his boat to its original condition. Finally, he and Jonathan managed to cross the rapids and continue their journey with the help of the locals. I think the accident must have caused significant damage to the boat, as some farmers told us that after being repaired, it had stopped quite a few times within their sight. So we had to move very quickly. Our help was very necessary before things became too late.
tr: November 4. - Today, we heard that the boat was delayed by an accident while trying to pass a spot where the current sped up. Slovak boats can navigate against the current without issues with the help of ropes and those who know how to use the rudder. Some of them set off just a few hours ago. Godalming himself is an amateur plumber and apparently, he was the one who fixed the boat. Eventually, with local help, they passed the fast current without issues and returned to tracking. I'm afraid the boat is not in very good condition due to the accident; the villagers said it stopped occasionally while it remained in sight when it re-entered calm waters. We must go faster than ever; our help may be needed soon.
es: November 4th. Today we learned that the boat was stopped by an accident while trying to ascend the rapids. The Slovak boats ascend well, with the help of a rope and proper steering. Some of them ascended just a few hours earlier. Godalming was an amateur adjuster and, evidently, it was he who got the boat running again. Finally, they managed to cross the rapids with the help of the locals and have just set off, rested. I fear the boat did not improve much from the accident; the villagers informed us that after it returned to calm waters, it continued to stop from time to time while it remained in sight. We must advance with more vigor than ever; it is possible they will soon need our help.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 31 October.—Arrived at Veresti at noon. The Professor tells me that this morning at dawn he could hardly hypnotise me at all, and that all I could say was: “dark and quiet.” He is off now buying a carriage and horses. He says that he will later on try to buy additional horses, so that we may be able to change them on the way. We have something more than 70 miles before us. The country is lovely, and most interesting; if only we were under different conditions, how delightful it would be to see it all. If Jonathan and I were driving through it alone what a pleasure it would be. To stop and see people, and learn something of their life, and to fill our minds and memories with all the colour and picturesqueness of the whole wild, beautiful country and the quaint people! But, alas!—
vi: We arrived in Veresti at noon. The professor told me that at dawn today, he had a hard time hypnotizing me, and even then, I couldn't say anything else: "Pitch dark, quiet". He went to buy a carriage and a few horses for reinforcement - if possible - to alternate pulling on the road. The road we traveled was endlessly long. This land is truly beautiful and full of interesting things. If only we were traveling under this sky in different circumstances, how wonderful it would be! If only Jonathan and I could walk together on this road, how romantic it would be! Oh, those unfamiliar people, those magical and wild sceneries!... • A moment later
tr: October 31. - We arrived in Veresti at noon. The Professor said that he had great difficulty hypnotizing me at dawn this morning and that all I could say was, "dark and silent." Now he is outside to get a carriage and horses. He says he will also try to get spare horses so that we can change them on the road later. We have more than a hundred kilometers ahead of us. The region is very beautiful and very interesting; how delightful it would have been to see all this if we had come under different circumstances. What a great pleasure it would have been if Jonathan and I were passing through here alone. Stopping to see the people, learning something about their lives, filling our minds and memories with all the colors and impressiveness of these wild, beautiful lands and interesting people! But alas!
es: October 31. We arrived in Veresti in the afternoon. The professor tells me that this morning, at dawn, he could barely hypnotize me, and all I could say was: "dark and quiet". He is now out, buying a carriage and horses; he says that later he will try to buy more horses, so that we can change them along the way. We still have one hundred and ten kilometers to go. The landscape is beautiful and very interesting; if we were in different circumstances, how delightful it would be to contemplate all this! If Jonathan and I were traveling alone through these lands, what a pleasure it would be! We could stop, see the people, learn something about them, and fill our minds with all the picturesque and colorful aspects of the wild and beautiful countryside and the unique people. But, alas…!

en: Later.—Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He has got the carriage and horses; we are to have some dinner, and to start in an hour. The landlady is putting us up a huge basket of provisions; it seems enough for a company of soldiers. The Professor encourages her, and whispers to me that it may be a week before we can get any good food again. He has been shopping too, and has sent home such a wonderful lot of fur coats and wraps, and all sorts of warm things. There will not be any chance of our being cold.
vi: Dr. Van Helsing returned with a carriage and a few horses. Additionally, he bought a lot of woolen blankets and a few fur coats to prepare for the bone-chilling cold. We had to eat well and then depart in an hour. But the innkeeper brought out a basket of mixed food like what is usually given to soldiers. The professor had to whisper in my ear that in a week, we might not find any other pleasant food, so we had to make an effort to eat. In a little while, we will be on our way.
tr: Later. - Dr. Van Helsing returned. He got the carriage and horses; we will have dinner and set off within an hour. Our hostess prepared a huge basket full of provisions for us; it looks like enough to feed an army. The professor supports the woman and whispers to me that we might not find food for maybe a week. He also went shopping and sent home a lot of excellent coats and blankets and all kinds of materials to keep warm. There will be no chance of us getting cold.
es: Later. Dr. Van Helsing has returned. He got the carriage and the horses; we are going to have dinner, and we will set off within an hour. The landlady is preparing a huge basket of provisions for us; it seems to be enough for an entire company of soldiers. The professor encourages her and whispers to me that it might be a week before we can get more food. He has also been shopping, and has sent a wonderful set of coats and furs and all kinds of warm clothing to his house. We will have no danger of feeling cold.

vi: In a little while, we will be on our way.
tr: We will be setting off soon.
es: Soon we will set out.

en: We shall soon be off. I am afraid to think what may happen to us. We are truly in the hands of God. He alone knows what may be, and I pray Him, with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, that He will watch over my beloved husband; that whatever may happen, Jonathan may know that I loved him and honoured him more than I can say, and that my latest and truest thought will be always for him.
vi: In a little while, we will be on our way. My body suddenly trembled when I thought of what awaits us along the journey. But honestly, I still believe in God's protection. Only He knows what will happen, but no matter what, I pray that my beloved husband will return safely. I wish Jonathan could understand the sincere feelings I have always had for him from the bottom of my heart!
tr: We will be setting off soon. We are truly in God's hands. Only He knows what might happen; with all the strength of my sad and humble spirit, I pray that He watches over my dear husband and ensures that, no matter what, Jonathan knows that I love and respect him far more than I can say, and that my last and truest thought will always be of him.
es: Soon we will set out. I dread to think of what may happen to us; truly, we are in God's hands; only He knows what may happen and I pray to Him, with all the strength of my sad and humble soul, to take care of my beloved husband; that, whatever happens, Jonathan may know that I love him and that I have honored him more than I can express, and that my last and most sincere affectionate thought will always be for him.

en: CHAPTER XXVII
vi: CHAPTER 27
tr: XXVII
es: XXVII.–

en: MINA HARKER’S JOURNAL
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's journal
es: MINA HARKER'S DIARY

en: 1 November.—All day long we have travelled, and at a good speed. The horses seem to know that they are being kindly treated, for they go willingly their full stage at best speed. We have now had so many changes and find the same thing so constantly that we are encouraged to think that the journey will be an easy one.
