Dr. Van Helsing is laconic; he tells the farmers that he is hurrying to Bistritz, and pays them well to make the exchange of horses. We get hot soup, or coffee, or tea; and off we go. It is a lovely country; full of beauties of all imaginable kinds, and the people are brave, and strong, and simple, and seem full of nice qualities. They are very, very superstitious. In the first house where we stopped, when the woman who served us saw the scar on my forehead, she crossed herself and put out two fingers towards me, to keep off the evil eye. I believe they went to the trouble of putting an extra amount of garlic into our food; and I can’t abide garlic. Ever since then I have taken care not to take off my hat or veil, and so have escaped their suspicions. We are travelling fast, and as we have no driver with us to carry tales, we go ahead of scandal; but I daresay that fear of the evil eye will follow hard behind us all the way. The Professor seems tireless; all day he would not take any rest, though he made me sleep for a long spell. At sunset time he hypnotised me, and he says that I answered as usual “darkness, lapping water and creaking wood”; so our enemy is still on the river. I am afraid to think of Jonathan, but somehow I have now no fear for him, or for myself. I write this whilst we wait in a farmhouse for the horses to be got ready. Dr. Van Helsing is sleeping. Poor dear, he looks very tired and old and grey, but his mouth is set as firmly as a conqueror’s; even in his sleep he is instinct with resolution. When we have well started I must make him rest whilst I drive. I shall tell him that we have days before us, and we must not break down when most of all his strength will be needed.... All is ready; we are off shortly.
vi: • November 1 We galloped tirelessly all day long. The horses seemed to understand the kind treatment from their owners and did not let us down. They were frequently changed, and each one showed obedience to their owners, making us feel encouraged and supported. Along the way, Van Helsing seemed very reserved; he only told the locals that we were in a hurry to get to Bistritza and paid them generously to change horses for us. We only stopped briefly to quench our thirst or grab a quick bite before continuing on our journey. This land is truly wonderful, with breathtaking scenery as far as the eye can see. The people here are also admirable: they are brave, strong, simple, and equally enthusiastic towards guests. But they are also very, very superstitious. At the first house we stopped at, the landlady made the sign of the cross and held up two fingers towards me as if to ward off bad luck upon seeing the mark on my forehead. I think she even intentionally put garlic in my food for the same reason, but I can't stand the smell of garlic! Therefore, I thought to myself that I must learn from this experience for the future, not to remove my hat or veil to avoid being discriminated against. We still sped forward quickly. The professor seemed to know no fatigue; he said he didn't need to rest all day, and I could just take a long nap in the car. At sunset, he hypnotized me again to gather information. I answered as usual: "Pitch dark, the sound of water waves, the creaking of the wooden floor." So, our enemy was still underwater. Thinking about Jonathan suddenly made me shiver, even though at this moment I had no doubts about the harmful things to him and myself. I wrote these lines while waiting for people to prepare horses and carriages at a farm. Finally, Dr. Van Helsing had to lie down for a bit; he looked much older and seemed exhausted. When we continue on our way, I will persuade him to let me hold the reins, while he rests to regain his strength. I said we had more than a day's journey ahead, so he couldn't be exhausted at the moment when strength was most needed. Everything is ready again. We continue our journey.
tr: November 1st. - We were on the road all day and made good progress. The horses seem to know they are being treated kindly, as they run at their best speed of their own accord. We have changed so many horses so far and have seen the same thing consistently that we dare to think the journey will be easy. Dr. Van Helsing speaks briefly and to the point; he tells the farmers that he is in a hurry to get to Bistriţa and pays them well to change the horses. We drink soup, coffee, or tea and immediately set off again. It is a very beautiful country; filled with all imaginable beauties, and the people seem brave, strong, simple, and pleasant. They are very, very superstitious. At the first house we stopped at, the woman who served us crossed herself when she saw the scar on my forehead and extended two fingers towards me to ward off the evil eye. I think they have taken the trouble to put extra garlic in our food, and I cannot stand garlic. Since then, I have been careful not to take off my hat or veil, thus avoiding their suspicions. We are traveling fast, and since we do not have a driver who carries gossip with him, we are ahead of the gossip; but I can say that the fear of the evil eye follows us all along the way. The professor seems tireless; despite forcing me to sleep for long periods, he has not rested at all throughout the day. At sunset, he hypnotized me, and as usual, he says I responded, "Darkness, rushing water, and creaking wood." I am afraid to think of Jonathan, but somehow I am no longer afraid for him or myself. I am writing these lines while we wait for the horses to be prepared at a farmhouse. Dr. Van Helsing is sleeping. Poor thing, he looks very tired, old, and troubled, but his mouth is set as firmly as that of a conqueror; even in his sleep, he is full of determination. When we set off, I must ensure he rests while I drive the carriage. I will tell him that there are still days ahead of us and that he must not be exhausted when his full strength is needed. Everything is ready, we are setting off shortly.
es: November 1st. We have traveled all day at a good speed. The horses seem to know that we are treating them kindly, as they show a willingness to move at the best pace. We have had some changes and found the same thing so consistently that we feel encouraged to think the journey will be easy. Dr. Van Helsing is laconic; he tells the farmers that he is in a hurry to get to Bistritz and pays them well for changing horses. They give us hot soup, coffee, or tea, and we leave immediately. It is a charming landscape, full of beauties of all imaginable kinds, and the people are brave, strong, and simple; they seem to have many beautiful qualities. They are very, very superstitious. At the first house we stopped at, when the woman who served us saw the scar on my forehead, she crossed herself and held two fingers in front of me to ward off the evil eye. I think they even went to the trouble of putting an extra amount of garlic in our food, and I can't stand it. Since then, I have been careful not to remove my veil, and in this way, I have managed to escape their suspicions. We are traveling at great speed, and since we have no coachman who can gossip, we continue on our way without any scandal; but I dare say that the fear of the evil eye will follow us constantly everywhere. The professor seems tireless; he did not want to rest all day, even though he made me sleep for a while. At dusk, he hypnotized me, and he says I answered as always: "Darkness, sound of water, and rustling of wood." So our enemy continues on the river. I am afraid to think about Jonathan, but somehow I no longer feel fear for him or for myself. I write this while we wait at a farm for the horses to be prepared. Dr. Van Helsing is sleeping. Poor man! He seems very tired and has aged and turned gray. But his mouth has the firmness of a conqueror. Even in dreams, he has the instinct of resolution. When we have set off, I must make him rest while I drive the carriage myself; I will tell him that we still have several days ahead, and that he must not weaken when all his strength is needed... Everything is ready. We will leave shortly.

en: 2 November, morning.—I was successful, and we took turns driving all night; now the day is on us, bright though cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air—I say heaviness for want of a better word; I mean that it oppresses us both. It is very cold, and only our warm furs keep us comfortable. At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me; he says I answered “darkness, creaking wood and roaring water,” so the river is changing as they ascend. I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of danger—more than need be; but we are in God’s hands.
vi: • November 2, morning I succeeded in persuading him: we took turns holding the reins throughout the night. A new day had begun, it was bright but cold. The weather was strangely oppressive, I say oppressive because I couldn't find a more accurate word, as both of us felt an indescribable suffocation. It must be said that it was very cold; without the fur coats, I don't know how we would have managed. At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me once again. According to him, I responded: "Pitch dark, the sound of waves roaring, the creaking of wooden planks." So the river is undergoing some transformation as the wooden coffin is being carried upstream. I hope my husband will not be in danger. But anyway, we are still under God's protective embrace.
tr: 2 November, morning. - I made it and we drove the car in turns all night; morning came, the weather is bright but cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air - I call it heaviness because I can't find a better word; what I mean is, the air is bothering both of us. It's very cold and only our warm furs are keeping us comfortable. At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me; he said I responded with “Darkness, creaking wood, and roaring water,” so it means there are changes in the river as they move upstream. I hope, my dear, that you do not face any danger -more than necessary- but we are in God's hands.
es: November 2nd, in the morning. I was successful and we took turns driving throughout the night; now it is already daytime and the weather is clear despite being cold. There is a strange heaviness in the air...; I say heaviness because I can't find a better word; I mean it oppresses us both. It is very cold and only our warm skins allow us to feel comfortable. At dawn, Van Helsing hypnotized me, he says I answered: "Darkness, the rubbing of wood, and roaring water," so the river is changing as they ascend. My great desire is that my beloved is not in any danger; no more than necessary, but we are in God's hands.

en: 2 November, night.—All day long driving. The country gets wilder as we go, and the great spurs of the Carpathians, which at Veresti seemed so far from us and so low on the horizon, now seem to gather round us and tower in front. We both seem in good spirits; I think we make an effort each to cheer the other; in the doing so we cheer ourselves. Dr. Van Helsing says that by morning we shall reach the Borgo Pass. The houses are very few here now, and the Professor says that the last horse we got will have to go on with us, as we may not be able to change. He got two in addition to the two we changed, so that now we have a rude four-in-hand. The dear horses are patient and good, and they give us no trouble. We are not worried with other travellers, and so even I can drive. We shall get to the Pass in daylight; we do not want to arrive before. So we take it easy, and have each a long rest in turn. Oh, what will to-morrow bring to us? We go to seek the place where my poor darling suffered so much. God grant that we may be guided aright, and that He will deign to watch over my husband and those dear to us both, and who are in such deadly peril. As for me, I am not worthy in His sight. Alas! I am unclean to His eyes, and shall be until He may deign to let me stand forth in His sight as one of those who have not incurred His wrath.
vi: • November 2, afternoon Continuously walking on the road, not even thinking about taking a break. The landscape spread out before us, the peaks of the Carpathians in Veresti suddenly loomed around us and seemed to block the path we had to take. We tried to encourage each other and also to encourage ourselves, not to fall into a state of pessimism. Professor Van Helsing told us we would reach the Borgo Pass at sunrise. This area doesn't have many replacement horses, so he planned to keep the newly bought ones to go all the way. We had two spare horses, and they were all thoroughbreds with enough patience to travel long distances. Nothing went wrong with us on the way, so much so that I could easily hold the reins and control the team of horses. We will reach the Borgo Pass early tomorrow morning, and then we can rest a bit. What will happen to us tomorrow? The eerie castle where my beloved husband endured so many horrors is approaching. May God guide us in the right direction? May God watch over my husband and all the friends I love, who are facing a looming danger? As for me, it doesn't matter if He doesn't protect me. Oh Lord! I am a filthy being in Your eyes and will remain filthy until You allow me to stand before
tr: 2 November, night. - We drove all day. As we progressed, the region became wilder, and the great peaks of the Carpathian Mountains, which seemed very far from us and very low on the horizon in Veresti, now appear to be coming together and rising before us. We both seem to be in good spirits; I think we are both trying to cheer each other up, and in doing so, we are cheering ourselves up. Dr. Van Helsing says we will reach the Borgo Pass by morning. There are very few houses here now, and the Professor says that the last horses we took will have to stay with us because we might not have the opportunity to change them. In addition to the two horses we changed, we have two more, so we have roughly four horses. Dear horses are patient and good-natured, they do not cause us any trouble. The other travelers do not worry us, and thus even I can drive the carriage. We will reach the Pass in daylight; we do not want to arrive earlier. So we are taking it slow and both of us are taking long rests in turns. Oh, I wonder what tomorrow will bring us? We will search for the place where my poor beloved suffered greatly. God, help us to be rightly guided, and may my husband and our loved ones, who are in mortal danger, be watched over by God. As for me, I am not worthy in His eyes. Ah! I am a sinner in His eyes, and I will remain so until He allows me to stand before Him as one who has not aroused His wrath.
es: November 2, at night. We have been traveling all day. The countryside becomes wilder as we advance, and the great elevations of the Carpathians, which in Veresti seemed so distant and low on the horizon, now appear to surround us and rise before us. We both seem to be in good spirits; I think we strive to cheer each other up and thus find comfort. Dr. Van Helsing says that in the morning we will reach the Borgo Pass. The houses are now very scarce, and the professor says that the last horse we obtained will have to continue with us, as it is very likely that we will not be able to change it again. We have two, in addition to the other two we exchanged, so now we have a good team. The horses are patient and good and do not cause us any problems. We do not worry about other travelers, so even I can drive. We will reach the pass by day; we do not want to arrive earlier, so we go calmly and both take a long rest, taking turns. What will tomorrow bring us? We are heading to the place where my poor husband suffered so much. May God allow us to reach there safely and may He deign to take care of my husband and those dear to us, who are in such mortal danger. As for me, I am not worthy of Him. Alas! I am not clean in His eyes, and so I will remain until He deigns to allow me to be in His presence, like one of those who have not provoked His wrath!

en: Memorandum by Abraham Van Helsing.
vi: You like my honest friends. Abraham Van Helsing's Notes
tr: Abraham Van Helsing's notes
es: Memorandum of Abraham van Helsing

en: 4 November.—This to my old and true friend John Seward, M.D., of Purfleet, London, in case I may not see him. It may explain. It is morning, and I write by a fire which all the night I have kept alive—Madam Mina aiding me. It is cold, cold; so cold that the grey heavy sky is full of snow, which when it falls will settle for all winter as the ground is hardening to receive it. It seems to have affected Madam Mina; she has been so heavy of head all day that she was not like herself. She sleeps, and sleeps, and sleeps! She who is usual so alert, have done literally nothing all the day; she even have lost her appetite. She make no entry into her little diary, she who write so faithful at every pause. Something whisper to me that all is not well. However, to-night she is more vif. Her long sleep all day have refresh and restore her, for now she is all sweet and bright as ever. At sunset I try to hypnotise her, but alas! with no effect; the power has grown less and less with each day, and to-night it fail me altogether. Well, God’s will be done—whatever it may be, and whithersoever it may lead!
vi: • November 4 I write these lines of advice for my faithful friend John Seward, a doctor in the Purfleet area of London, in case I may never see him again. The day has dawned, and I write by the flickering firelight throughout the night thanks to Mina's hand. It is cold, very cold, so cold that the sky turns gray with the first snowflakes of winter. When they fall, these snowflakes will reign over the Borgo Pass throughout the bleak winter season. Mina also seems numb from the cold. The frost has turned her into a completely different person. She sleeps, sleeps, and sleeps. Normally she is so active, yet she did nothing at all yesterday. Even eating does not appeal to her. And she hasn't touched the small notebook she always carries with her to jot down notes whenever she rests along the way. I feel something unusual constantly ringing in my ears. However, yesterday afternoon, she somewhat regained her usual agility. The long sleep during the day seemed to have relieved her fatigue and made her cheerful and pleasant as always. As dusk fell at the foot of the pass, I intended to hypnotize her to see if there was anything new, but my goodness, I tried and tried with no result. My ability is diminishing day by day, and this evening, I have completely failed. Now I would like to continue recounting the subsequent events.
tr: November 4th. - This, in case I cannot see him, to my old and true friend, Doctor John Seward of Purfleet, London. This may explain everything. Morning has come, and I am writing by the fire I kept alive all night with the help of Madam Mina. The weather is cold, cold; so cold that the heavy, gray sky is filled with snow that will spend the entire winter on the ground because the earth has hardened to meet it. The weather seems to have affected Madam Mina; all day her mind appeared so heavy that she seemed not herself. Sleeping, sleeping, and sleeping! Normally very brisk, Madam Mina did literally nothing all day; she even lost her appetite. Madam Mina, who usually writes with great dedication at every break, did not record anything in her little journal. Something whispers to me that not everything is alright. But tonight she is more lively. Her long sleep has revived and refreshed her, for she is now as sweet and radiant as ever. At sunset, I try to hypnotize her, but alas! It doesn’t work; the power has diminished more and more each day, and today it failed me completely. Well, God’s will be done - whatever it is and wherever it leads us!
es: November 4th. This is for my old and sincere friend, Doctor John Seward, of Purefleet, London, in case I cannot see him again. It may clarify. It is morning, and I write by the fire that has kept us alive throughout the night. Mrs. Mina has helped me. It's cold; very cold. So much so that the gray and heavy sky is full of snow which, when it falls, will remain throughout the winter, as the ground is hardening to receive it. It seems to have affected Mrs. Mina. Her head has been so heavy all day that she doesn't seem to be the same. She sleeps, sleeps, and keeps on sleeping! She, who is always so lively, has done almost absolutely nothing all day; she has even lost her appetite. She didn't make any entries in her journal, she who had so faithfully written at each of our stops. Something tells me that not everything is going well. However, tonight she is more lively. Her long sleep during the day has refreshed and restored her, and now she is as sweet and awake as ever. I tried to hypnotize her at dawn, but without any positive result. The power has been continuously diminishing, day by day, and tonight it failed me completely. Well, let God's will be done…! Whatever it may be and wherever it may lead us!

en: Now to the historical, for as Madam Mina write not in her stenography, I must, in my cumbrous old fashion, that so each day of us may not go unrecorded.
vi: Mina no longer uses shorthand to write her diary, so I have to write it for her, even though I'm not very skilled at it, to ensure that the passing days do not fade into oblivion.
tr: Now, let's come to the historical records, because since Madam Mina does not write in shorthand, I must write using my old cumbersome method, so that not a single day passes without being recorded.
es: Now, let's move on to the historical; since Mrs. Mina didn't write in her journal, I must, in my laborious old language, do it, so that no day we spent goes unrecorded.

en: We got to the Borgo Pass just after sunrise yesterday morning. When I saw the signs of the dawn I got ready for the hypnotism. We stopped our carriage, and got down so that there might be no disturbance. I made a couch with furs, and Madam Mina, lying down, yield herself as usual, but more slow and more short time than ever, to the hypnotic sleep. As before, came the answer: “darkness and the swirling of water.” Then she woke, bright and radiant and we go on our way and soon reach the Pass. At this time and place, she become all on fire with zeal; some new guiding power be in her manifested, for she point to a road and say:—
vi: We arrived at Borgo Pass at dawn yesterday. As soon as I saw the first light of dawn, I immediately stopped the car and told Mina to prepare for hypnosis. I made a temporary bed out of fur coats: Mina would lie on it to enter a trance, but indeed this time it was very difficult for me as well. The answer was still the same: "Pitch dark, swirling water." As soon as she said this, she woke up, her face looking visibly happier and more radiant. We continued on our way and soon crossed the pass. Her enthusiasm had turned her into a very eager person. Clearly, a new strength was guiding her, as I saw her suddenly point towards the road ahead and say:
tr: Yesterday morning, just after sunrise, we arrived at the Borgo Pass. When I saw the signs of dawn, I prepared for hypnosis. We stopped our carriage and got out so we wouldn't be disturbed. I made a bed from furs, and Madam Mina, as usual but slower and for a shorter duration than before, surrendered herself to hypnotic sleep. The response was the same as before: "Darkness and violently flowing waters." Then she woke up lively and cheerful, and we continued on our way, soon reaching the Pass. Right there and then, Madam Mina was seized by a fervent enthusiasm; surely a new guiding force was manifesting itself because she pointed to one of the roads and spoke:
es: We arrived at the Borgo Pass a little before dawn, yesterday morning; when I observed the signs heralding the dawn, I prepared to hypnotize her. We stopped the carriage and got out, so that nothing would disturb us. I made a sort of couch with furs, and Mrs. Mina, after lying down, submitted to the hypnosis, as always, but more slowly and briefly than ever. As before, her response was: "Darkness and troubled waters." Then she awoke, lively and radiant, and we continued our journey, to soon reach the Pass. At this hour and place, she was filled with a new enthusiasm; a new guiding power manifested in her, as she pointed out a path and said:

en: “This is the way.”
vi: — That's the right path.
tr: "From here!"”
es: –This is the way.

en: “How know you it?” I ask.
vi: — How do you know? — It's only natural.
tr: "How do you know?" I asked.
es: –How do you know? – I inquired.

en: “Of course I know it,” she answer, and with a pause, add: “Have not my Jonathan travelled it and wrote of his travel?”
vi: She was silent for a moment, then continued: — Hasn't my brother Jonathan gone over there already? Didn't he write that in his diary?
tr: “Of course I know,” he replied and after pausing for a moment, added: “Didn’t my Jonathan travel and document his journey?”
es: –Of course I know -she replied, and after a pause she added-: Didn't my Jonathan travel because of him and write everything about his journey?

en: At first I think somewhat strange, but soon I see that there be only one such by-road. It is used but little, and very different from the coach road from the Bukovina to Bistritz, which is more wide and hard, and more of use.
vi: At first, I found it strange, but then I quickly regained my composure because, in reality, there was only one interprovincial road like this here. It seemed like this was a road with very few passersby, quite different from the road from Bukovina to Bistritza, which was wider, gravel-paved, and always bustling with people.
tr: At first, it struck me as a bit odd, but soon I thought that there could be only this one side road. It is used very little; it is very different from the wider, harder, and more practical Bukovina-Bistriţa road.
es: At first, I thought it was something strange, but soon I saw that there could only be such a path. It is very little used, and extremely different from the main road that leads from Bucovina to Bistritz, which is wider, harder, and more frequently used.

en: So we came down this road; when we meet other ways—not always were we sure that they were roads at all, for they be neglect and light snow have fallen—the horses know and they only. I give rein to them, and they go on so patient. By-and-by we find all the things which Jonathan have note in that wonderful diary of him. Then we go on for long, long hours and hours. At the first, I tell Madam Mina to sleep; she try, and she succeed. She sleep all the time; till at the last, I feel myself to suspicious grow, and attempt to wake her. But she sleep on, and I may not wake her though I try. I do not wish to try too hard lest I harm her; for I know that she have suffer much, and sleep at times be all-in-all to her. I think I drowse myself, for all of sudden I feel guilt, as though I have done something; I find myself bolt up, with the reins in my hand, and the good horses go along jog, jog, just as ever. I look down and find Madam Mina still sleep. It is now not far off sunset time, and over the snow the light of the sun flow in big yellow flood, so that we throw great long shadow on where the mountain rise so steep. For we are going up, and up; and all is oh! so wild and rocky, as though it were the end of the world.
vi: We followed the road Mina had just pointed out. When we encountered other paths, we suddenly became doubtful. Are these really the right roads? I wasn't sure, because they were all rugged and somewhat scattered with fallen snow. Our horses had stepped in and were the only ones diligently moving along the road. I loosened the reins and let them trot. We gradually recognized everything Jonathan had described in his admirable journal. The horses continued to rhythmically clop their hooves on the seemingly endless paths. At first, I had to make Mina lie down to sleep. She tried and eventually fell into a deep sleep. She slept continuously, so soundly that I became alarmed and had to wake her up. But she still slept as if nothing had happened. I didn't dare to wake her abruptly because I knew she had endured too much, and after all, a good sleep would surely make her feel better. Suddenly, I felt like I was at fault with her. Therefore, I quietly returned to my seat, holding the reins and urging the horses to go faster. Mina was still asleep. The twilight gradually descended, casting a golden hue like chicken fat on the snowflakes and our long, lanky shadows on the steep mountain slopes. Our car climbed higher and higher, amidst a desolate, remote, rugged landscape, as if we were reaching the end of the world!
tr: Thus, we embarked on this path; when other paths appeared before us - we were not always sure they were paths because they were neglected and lightly covered with snow - the horses knew where to go, in fact, only they knew. I left the reins to them, and they proceeded with great patience. Soon, we found everything Jonathan had noted in his astonishing journal. Then we progressed for long, long, long hours. At first, I told Madam Mina to sleep; she tried and succeeded. She kept sleeping until I became suspicious and tried to wake her. But she continued to sleep, and despite my efforts, I couldn't wake her. I didn't want to push too hard to avoid hurting her because I knew she was suffering greatly and that sleep was everything to her at times. I think I must have fallen asleep too, because suddenly I felt guilty as if I had done something wrong; I found myself sitting upright with the reins in my hands, and the good-natured horses were trotting along slowly as usual. I looked down and saw that Madam Mina was still asleep. There wasn't much time left until sunset, and the sunlight was streaming over the snow like a great yellow flood, casting huge, long shadows where the mountain rose steeply. Because we kept going up, up without stopping, and everything was so wild and rocky as if we had reached the end of the world!
es: So we took that path. We found other paths (we were not always sure they were real paths, as they were neglected and covered with a light layer of snow). The horses knew, and only they did. I left the reins loose, and the animals continued patiently. One after another, we found all the things that Jonathan noted in the wonderful diary he wrote. Then, we continued for long and extended hours. At first, I told Mrs. Mina to sleep; she tried and managed to do so. She slept the whole time until, finally, I felt my suspicions growing and tried to wake her, but she kept sleeping and I couldn't wake her despite my attempts. I didn't want to do it too forcefully for fear of harming her, as I know she has suffered a lot and that sleep, at times, can be very beneficial for her. I think I dozed off, because suddenly, I felt guilty, as if I had done something wrong. I found myself upright, with the reins in hand and the beautiful horses trotting as usual. I looked down and saw that Mrs. Mina was still asleep. It's not long until sunset and, over the snow, the sunlight glistens like a huge yellow stream, so that we cast a long shadow where the mountain rises vertically. We are climbing and climbing continuously and everything is, oh, very rugged and rocky. As if it were the end of the world.

en: Then I arouse Madam Mina. This time she wake with not much trouble, and then I try to put her to hypnotic sleep. But she sleep not, being as though I were not. Still I try and try, till all at once I find her and myself in dark; so I look round, and find that the sun have gone down. Madam Mina laugh, and I turn and look at her. She is now quite awake, and look so well as I never saw her since that night at Carfax when we first enter the Count’s house. I am amaze, and not at ease then; but she is so bright and tender and thoughtful for me that I forget all fear. I light a fire, for we have brought supply of wood with us, and she prepare food while I undo the horses and set them, tethered in shelter, to feed. Then when I return to the fire she have my supper ready. I go to help her; but she smile, and tell me that she have eat already—that she was so hungry that she would not wait. I like it not, and I have grave doubts; but I fear to affright her, and so I am silent of it. She help me and I eat alone; and then we wrap in fur and lie beside the fire, and I tell her to sleep while I watch. But presently I forget all of watching; and when I sudden remember that I watch, I find her lying quiet, but awake, and looking at me with so bright eyes. Once, twice more the same occur, and I get much sleep till before morning. When I wake I try to hypnotise her; but alas! though she shut her eyes obedient, she may not sleep. The sun rise up, and up, and up; and then sleep come to her too late, but so heavy that she will not wake. I have to lift her up, and place her sleeping in the carriage when I have harnessed the horses and made all ready. Madam still sleep, and she look in her sleep more healthy and more redder than before. And I like it not. And I am afraid, afraid, afraid!—I am afraid of all things—even to think but I must go on my way. The stake we play for is life and death, or more than these, and we must not flinch.
vi: That was also the moment when I woke Mina up without much difficulty, but the only thing was that I could no longer easily hypnotize her. Not only did she not go into a trance, but she also acted as if I didn't exist in this world. I kept trying and trying, and eventually, both she and I sank into darkness. I suddenly realized that the sun had sunk behind the mountain ranges. Mina suddenly burst out laughing, making me turn to look at her. She was still completely awake. I was surprised, feeling that something was not right. I stood up, took the reserved firewood from the cart, and found a spot to light a fire. She prepared dinner while I untied the horses to feed them. When I returned to the fire, the meal was already prepared. I intended to serve Mina, but she smiled and said that she had already eaten because she was too hungry to wait for me. I felt unhappy, suspecting that she was lying but said nothing for fear of upsetting her. I sat and ate alone to get it over with, then went back to the cart to get a fur coat, put it on, and sat by the fire. I told Mina to sleep first, so I could stay awake and watch over everything. But in reality, I had been awake for a long time, and when I suddenly remembered this, I quickly turned to look at her: she was lying in the fur coat I had just brought, her eyes still wide open, staring at me. How sparkling those eyes were! I just sat there and only dozed off for a moment when the sky began to lighten. I intended to turn and hypnotize her once more, but wait! It seemed she was still awake. The sun rose high, and only then did she fall asleep. Even though it was too late, she still slept deeply and heavily to the point that I had no way to wake her up. In the end, I had to carry her and place her in the cart after harnessing the horses. Mina was still asleep. She looked much more rosy. That phenomenon did not signal anything good to me. I was scared, scared, and scared. I was afraid of everything, even my own thoughts. But no matter what, I still had to see it through to the end. The game was a gamble between life and death, or perhaps even more than that. We could no longer turn back.
tr: Then I wake Madam Mina. This time she wakes up without much trouble, and then I try to put her into a hypnotic sleep. It's as if she's not trying to sleep. Still, I keep trying, trying; until suddenly I find both of us in the dark; so I look around and see that the sun has set. Madam Mina laughs; I turn and look at her. She is now quite awake and looks better than I have seen her since the night we first entered the Count's house in Carfax. I am surprised and feel uneasy at that moment; but she is so lively, so gentle and thoughtful towards me that I forget all fears. Since we brought wood with us, I make a fire; she prepares food while I untie, rest, secure, and feed the horses. Then, when I return to the fire, my meal is ready. I go to help her; but she laughs and says she has already eaten - she was so hungry that she couldn't wait. I don't like this, I have great doubts, but I am afraid of alarming her and so I say nothing. She helps me, and I eat my meal alone; then we wrap ourselves in furs and lie down by the fire, and I tell her to sleep while I keep watch. But I immediately forget that I am keeping watch, and when I suddenly remember, I find Madam Mina lying quietly but awake, looking at me with shining eyes. The same thing happened a couple more times, and I got quite a bit of sleep until morning. When I woke up, I tried to hypnotize her, but alas! Even though she obediently closed her eyes, she couldn't sleep. The sun rose higher and higher, her sleep came very late, but it was such a heavy sleep that she wouldn't wake up. When I had harnessed the horses and prepared everything, I had to lift her and place her in the carriage. Madam is still sleeping, sleeping, and in her sleep, she looks healthier and redder than before. And I don't like this. And I am afraid, afraid, afraid! (I am afraid of everything.) I am even afraid to think, but I must continue on my way. This task we have undertaken is a matter of life and death, even more, and we must not retreat.
es: Then, I woke up Mrs. Mina. This time she woke up without much difficulty and, then, I tried to make her sleep hypnotically, but I couldn't; it was as if I wasn't there. However, I keep trying repeatedly, until suddenly, we find ourselves in the dark, so I look around and discover that the sun has gone. Mrs. Mina laughs and I turn towards her. Now she is wide awake and looks as good as I have ever seen her since that night in Carfax, when we first entered the Count's house. I feel astonished and uneasy, but she is so lively, tender, and solicitous with me, that I forget all fear. I light a fire, as we brought a supply of wood with us, and she prepares food while I untie the horses and settle them in the shade to feed them. Then, when I returned to the campfire, she had my dinner ready. I went to help her, but she smiled at me and said she had already eaten, that she was so hungry she couldn't wait. I didn't like that, and I have terrible doubts, but I fear scaring her and don't mention anything about it. Mrs. Mina helped me, I ate, and then, we wrapped ourselves in the furs and lay down beside the fire. I told her to sleep and that I would keep watch, but suddenly I forget to keep watch and, when I suddenly remember that I must do so, I find her lying still; but awake, looking at me with very bright eyes. This happened once or twice and I was able to sleep until morning. When I woke up, I tried to hypnotize her, but, although she obediently closed her eyes, she couldn't fall asleep. The sun rose higher and higher and, then, sleep came to her, too late; it was so strong, that she did not wake up. I had to lift her and place her, asleep, in the carriage, once I had harnessed the horses and prepared everything. The lady continues to sleep, and her face looks healthier and rosier than before, and I don't like that. I'm scared, very scared! I am afraid of all things. Even of thinking; but I must continue my path. What we are risking is something of life or death, or even more than that, and we must not hesitate for a moment.

en: 5 November, morning.—Let me be accurate in everything, for though you and I have seen some strange things together, you may at the first think that I, Van Helsing, am mad—that the many horrors and the so long strain on nerves has at the last turn my brain.
vi: • November 5 Perhaps I must recount every detail exactly! Because although both you and I have witnessed many strange things firsthand, you can still deduce from my thoughts that countless terrifying events and prolonged nervous tension have all ended due to the madness in my mind.
tr: November 5, morning. - Let me write everything down completely, because even though you and I have seen some strange things together, you might think at first that I - Van Helsing - have gone mad, that after so much horror and tension in the nerves, my mind has become clouded.
es: November 5, in the morning. Allow me to be precise in everything, since, although you and I have seen strange things together, you may begin to think that I, Van Helsing, am crazy; that the many horrors and the prolonged tensions on my nervous system have finally managed to derange my brain.

en: All yesterday we travel, ever getting closer to the mountains, and moving into a more and more wild and desert land. There are great, frowning precipices and much falling water, and Nature seem to have held sometime her carnival. Madam Mina still sleep and sleep; and though I did have hunger and appeased it, I could not waken her—even for food. I began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was upon her, tainted as she is with that Vampire baptism. “Well,” said I to myself, “if it be that she sleep all the day, it shall also be that I do not sleep at night.” As we travel on the rough road, for a road of an ancient and imperfect kind there was, I held down my head and slept. Again I waked with a sense of guilt and of time passed, and found Madam Mina still sleeping, and the sun low down. But all was indeed changed; the frowning mountains seemed further away, and we were near the top of a steep-rising hill, on summit of which was such a castle as Jonathan tell of in his diary. At once I exulted and feared; for now, for good or ill, the end was near.
vi: We still trudged on throughout the entire winter day and were approaching the mountain peaks that blocked a land which became increasingly desolate and savage in the eyes of the traveler. I cannot recount the countless silent caves and deep crevices interspersed with roaring waterfalls, as if nature occasionally played a masquerade before its own Lent. Mina remained deeply asleep. Feeling a gnawing hunger, I had to sit and eat alone because I couldn't wake her up to share the meal. I suddenly became worried. "If she keeps sleeping all day - I thought to myself - then perhaps I'll have to sleep all night." We were traveling on a rough road, crudely made in the old style. Despite my best efforts, I still nodded off. When I awoke with a guilty feeling, Mina was still asleep. The sun had already shifted to the afternoon. But everything had changed. The suspicious mountain peaks seemed farther away, and we were near a steep hill, upon which stood an ancient, solitary castle, resembling the one Jonathan described in his diary. Joy and worry almost intertwined within me at the same time, because now, whether good or bad, the end was near.
tr: Yesterday, we were on the road all day and we are getting closer and closer to the mountains, advancing towards wilder and more desolate lands. There are alarming steep cliffs with waterfalls, and it seems as if Nature occasionally holds a carnival here. Madam Mina is still sleeping, sleeping; despite getting hungry and feeding myself, I couldn't wake her up - not even for food. Since she is tainted by the vampire's baptism, I began to fear that the deadly enchantment of this place might take hold of her. "Well!" I said to myself, "If she is going to sleep all day, then I will not sleep all night." As we progressed on the rugged road - because the road was very old and broken - I bowed my head and slept. I woke up again with a feeling of guilt and a sense that a lot of time had passed; I saw that Madam Mina was still sleeping and the sun had considerably lowered. But actually, everything had changed; the angry mountains seemed farther away, and we were in the high regions of a steep hill with a castle on its summit similar to the one described in Jonathan's journal. At the same time, I was both happy and scared; because now, for better or worse, the end was near.
es: We traveled all day yesterday, getting closer and closer to the mountains and traversing increasingly rugged and deserted terrain. There are gigantic and threatening cliffs, many waterfalls, and nature seems to have once held its carnival here. Mrs. Mina continues to sleep constantly, and although I felt hungry and satisfied it, I could not wake her, not even to eat. I began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was taking hold of her, as she is stained with that baptism of the vampire's blood. –Well -I said to myself-, if he sleeps all day, it is also certain that I will not sleep during the night. While we were traveling along the rough road, since it was an old and deteriorated road, I fell asleep. I woke up again with a feeling of guilt and the passage of time, and discovered that Mrs. Mina was still asleep and that the sun was very low, but indeed, everything had changed. The threatening mountains seemed farther away and we were near the top of a very steep hill, and at its summit was the castle, just as Jonathan indicated in his diary. Immediately I felt uneasy and fearful, because now, for better or worse, the end was near.

en: I woke Madam Mina, and again tried to hypnotise her; but alas! unavailing till too late. Then, ere the great dark came upon us—for even after down-sun the heavens reflected the gone sun on the snow, and all was for a time in a great twilight—I took out the horses and fed them in what shelter I could. Then I make a fire; and near it I make Madam Mina, now awake and more charming than ever, sit comfortable amid her rugs. I got ready food: but she would not eat, simply saying that she had not hunger. I did not press her, knowing her unavailingness. But I myself eat, for I must needs now be strong for all. Then, with the fear on me of what might be, I drew a ring so big for her comfort, round where Madam Mina sat; and over the ring I passed some of the wafer, and I broke it fine so that all was well guarded. She sat still all the time—so still as one dead; and she grew whiter and ever whiter till the snow was not more pale; and no word she said. But when I drew near, she clung to me, and I could know that the poor soul shook her from head to feet with a tremor that was pain to feel. I said to her presently, when she had grown more quiet:—
vi: I called Mina to wake her up to try hypnotizing her once more, but it was still a failure. Darkness began to fall, covering all the desolate paths, I unhitched the horses and led them to a sheltered spot to feed them, and lit a fire so Mina could warm herself in the fur cloak. She looked as lively as a bird and more radiant and beautiful than ever. I fumbled around preparing dinner, but she refused to eat with the simple reason that she didn't feel hungry. I didn't insist because I knew it would be useless. As for me, I had to eat, because I needed the strength to prepare for any dangerous challenges. To guard against any unforeseen events, I sat up and drew a circle with Mina at its center, then I crushed the holy wafers into fine powder and sprinkled it evenly around the circle to ensure every part was well protected. During that time, Mina sat silently like a corpse, her complexion gradually turning a pale, ghostly white like the snow at night. But when I approached her, she suddenly clung tightly to me. I felt her body trembling violently. Finally, waiting until she returned to normal, I dared to ask:
tr: I woke Madam Mina and tried to hypnotize her again, but alas! I couldn't succeed until it was too late. Then, before the great darkness fell upon us - because even after sunset, the sky continued to reflect the setting sun on the snow, and everywhere was enveloped in a great twilight for a while - I untied the horses and fed them in a shelter I could find. Then I lit a fire, and made Madam Mina, who was now awake and looking more attractive than ever, sit comfortably among her blankets. I prepared the meal, but she didn't eat, merely saying she wasn't hungry. Knowing it would be of no use, I didn't force her. But I ate, because now I must be strong for everyone. Then, fearing what might happen, I drew a wide circle around the place where Madam Mina was sitting for her comfort; I sprinkled some blessed bread over the circle and crumbled it well so that everywhere would be well protected. Madam Mina sat all this time - motionless like the dead; her color turned white, white until she looked paler than the snow, and not a single word came out of her mouth. But when I approached her, she clung to me, and I knew the poor thing was trembling from head to toe with great, painful terror. When she became even quieter, I immediately said:
es: I woke Mrs. Mina and tried to hypnotize her again, but to no avail. Then, deep darkness descended upon us, because even after sunset, the skies reflected the hidden sun over the snow and everything was plunged, for some time, into a gigantic twilight. I unhitched the horses and fed them at the inn I managed to find. Then, I lit a fire and, near it, I made Mrs. Mina, who was now more awake and charming than ever, sit comfortably among her furs. I prepared dinner, but she did not want to eat. She simply said she was not hungry. I did not press her, knowing she did not wish to, but I had dinner, because I needed to stay strong for everyone. Then, still gripped by fear of what might happen, I drew a large circle around Mrs. Mina and placed part of the sacred Host on it, finely crumbling it, so that everything would be protected. She remained sitting quietly the whole time; as calm as if she were dead, and she began to grow paler and paler, until she was almost the same color as the snow; she did not utter a word, but when I approached her, she clung to me, and I noticed that the poor thing was trembling from head to toe, with a shiver that was painful to see. Then, when she calmed down a bit, I said to her:

en: “Will you not come over to the fire?” for I wished to make a test of what she could. She rose obedient, but when she have made a step she stopped, and stood as one stricken.
vi: — Don't you want to move a little closer to the fire? Actually, I intended to see if you could do it. She obediently stood up, but after taking just one step, she suddenly halted as if her feet were chained.
tr: “Aren't you going to come near the fire?” Because I wanted to see what he could do. He stood up obediently, but when he took a step, he stopped and remained as if struck.
es: –Don't you want to come closer to the fire? He wanted to do a test to see if it was possible for him to do it. She stood up obediently, but as soon as she took a step, she stopped and remained motionless, as if petrified.

en: “Why not go on?” I asked. She shook her head, and, coming back, sat down in her place. Then, looking at me with open eyes, as of one waked from sleep, she said simply:—
vi: — Why don't you keep walking? - I pressed. She shook her head and went back to sit in the exact spot she had been sitting, her eyes wide open looking at me just like the eyes of someone who has been abruptly woken from a deep sleep.
tr: “Why don't you continue?” I asked. He shook his head from side to side and quietly returned to his seat. Then, like someone who had just woken up, he opened his eyes and looked at me, saying:
es: –Why don't you continue? – I asked him. She shook her head and, stepping back, sat down in her place again. Then, looking at me with wide-open eyes, like those of a person who has just woken up from a dream, he said to me simply:

en: “I cannot!” and remained silent. I rejoiced, for I knew that what she could not, none of those that we dreaded could. Though there might be danger to her body, yet her soul was safe!
vi: — I can't! - She replied curtly and then fell silent. But I felt happy, because I understood her impossibility, whatever I doubted was no longer its true nature. But the sudden, prolonged neighing of the horses made me think otherwise.
tr: “I can't!” And he fell silent. I was relieved because I knew the things he couldn't do, and he couldn't do the things we were afraid he would. Even if his body was in danger, his soul was still safe!
es: –I can't! – and he fell silent. I was glad knowing that if she couldn't pass, none of the vampires, whom we feared, could do it either. Although there might be dangers to her body, at least her soul was safe!

en: Presently the horses began to scream, and tore at their tethers till I came to them and quieted them. When they did feel my hands on them, they whinnied low as in joy, and licked at my hands and were quiet for a time. Many times through the night did I come to them, till it arrive to the cold hour when all nature is at lowest; and every time my coming was with quiet of them. In the cold hour the fire began to die, and I was about stepping forth to replenish it, for now the snow came in flying sweeps and with it a chill mist. Even in the dark there was a light of some kind, as there ever is over snow; and it seemed as though the snow-flurries and the wreaths of mist took shape as of women with trailing garments. All was in dead, grim silence only that the horses whinnied and cowered, as if in terror of the worst. I began to fear—horrible fears; but then came to me the sense of safety in that ring wherein I stood. I began, too, to think that my imaginings were of the night, and the gloom, and the unrest that I have gone through, and all the terrible anxiety. It was as though my memories of all Jonathan’s horrid experience were befooling me; for the snow flakes and the mist began to wheel and circle round, till I could get as though a shadowy glimpse of those women that would have kissed him. And then the horses cowered lower and lower, and moaned in terror as men do in pain. Even the madness of fright was not to them, so that they could break away. I feared for my dear Madam Mina when these weird figures drew near and circled round. I looked at her, but she sat calm, and smiled at me; when I would have stepped to the fire to replenish it, she caught me and held me back, and whispered, like a voice that one hears in a dream, so low it was:—
vi: I jumped before I could think to approach and soothe them. Feeling someone approaching, they immediately licked my hand gently but did not forget to let out another series of neighs before falling silent again. But only for a moment, then they started neighing incessantly once more. I had to soothe them many times during the night, before that cold moment when the heartbeat of the earth and sky fell to its weakest point. At that coldest moment, the fire began to die down, forcing me to stoke it once more, as the snow started to fall heavily amidst the freezing fog. Even though it was dark, I could still faintly see my surroundings. But the snowstorm and fog seemed to be forming the shapes of women, faintly visible in their flowing white dresses sweeping the ground. Everything exuded an aura of death, sorrow, and an eerie silence. The horses let out long, mournful neighs as if anticipating the worst to come. I shivered with a vague sense of fear until I suddenly remembered the safety circle I had just drawn. I began to think that all the apparitions were due to the darkness, my own cowardice, and my lingering fatigue. Could it be that the memories of all the terrible things Jonathan had experienced had turned me into a madman? Yes, the swirling, chaotic snow and fog made me realize the shadows of those women in white, flickering and hovering as if about to pounce on me. The horses huddled together and occasionally let out faint whimpers of fear, much like human gestures. I suddenly felt worried for Mina, as the strange faces began to flicker closer to us, but she still sat calmly and smiled at me as if nothing was happening. When I stood up to stoke the fire again, she suddenly pulled me back:
tr: At that moment, the horses began to neigh and tug at their reins; until I went to them and calmed them down. When they felt my hands on them, they whinnied softly as if they were happy, licked my hands, and stood still for a while. Throughout the night, until that cold hour when all of nature slowed down, I went to them many times, and each time my presence calmed them. At that cold hour, the fire began to die, and I was about to step out of the circle to revive it; because the snow was sweeping everything with an icy mist. Even in the darkness, there was light on the snow; it was as if the snowstorm and mist rings were turning into women wearing dresses with fluttering skirts. Everything was in deathly silence; only the horses were whimpering and cowering as if fearing the worst. I began to be afraid - terrifying fears; but then I felt the safety within the circle I stood in. I started to think that the night, the gloom, the unease I felt, and all those dreadful anxieties were causing me to dream. It was as if my memories of Jonathan's terrible experience were deceiving me, because the snowflakes and mist began to form circles, until the shadowy figures of those women who might have kissed Jonathan appeared. And then the horses cowered even more in fear, whimpering with terror like people in agony. They were not even in a state to escape from there in the madness of fear. When these strange shapes came closer and began to circle around, I feared for dear Madam Mina. I looked at her, but she was sitting calmly and smiling at me; I was about to take a step to stoke the fire when she caught me and pulled me back, whispering softly like one hears in dreams:
es: At that moment, the horses began to get restless and pull at their reins, until I approached them and calmed them down. When they felt my hands on them, they neighed softly, as if in joy, rubbed their muzzles against my hands, and remained calm for a moment. Many times, throughout the night, I got up and approached them until the cold moment came when all of nature is at its lowest point of vitality, and, every time, my presence calmed them. As the coldest hour approached, the fire began to die out, and I got up to add more wood, because the snow was falling more heavily, and with it, a light and very cold mist was approaching. Even in the darkness, there is a certain kind of glow, as always happens over the snow, and it seemed that the snowflakes and the wisps of mist took the form of women, dressed in clothes that trailed on the ground. Everything seemed dead, and a deep silence reigned, interrupted only by the agitation of the horses, who seemed to fear the worst would happen. I began to feel a tremendous fear, but then a feeling of security came over me, due to the circle within which I found myself. I also began to think that it was all due to my imagination in the middle of the night, because of the glow, the restlessness, the fatigue, and the terrible anxiety. It was as if my memories of Jonathan's terrible experiences were deceiving me, because the snowflakes and the mist began to swirl around me until I could make out a blurry image of those women who had kissed him. Then, the horses crouched down more and more and lamented in terror, as men do in the midst of pain. Even the madness of fear was denied to them, so that they could move away. I felt fear for my dear lady Mina, when those strange figures approached and surrounded me. I looked at her, but she remained seated calmly, smiling at me; when I approached the fire to add more wood, she took one of my hands and held me back; then, she whispered, in a voice one hears in dreams, extremely low:

en: “No! No! Do not go without. Here you are safe!” I turned to her, and looking in her eyes, said:—
vi: — Don't, don't, don't step out of the circle. You can only be safe if you stay in here! - She said, her voice sounding weak and vague as if echoing from a distant realm. I turned back and looked straight into her eyes:
tr: “No! No! Don't go out! You are safe here!” I turned to him and said, looking into his eyes:
es: –No! No! Don't go out. You're safe here! I turned towards her and said, looking into her eyes:

en: “But you? It is for you that I fear!” whereat she laughed—a laugh, low and unreal, and said:—
vi: — And you? You are the one who scares me! Hearing that, she burst into laughter, a gentle smile but as surreal as her voice.
tr: "Well, what about you? I'm afraid for you!" When he heard this, he laughed, it was a low and surreal laugh, and he said:
es: –But, what about you? It is for you that I fear! Upon hearing that, he burst out laughing... with a hoarse, unreal laugh, and said:

en: “Fear for me! Why fear for me? None safer in all the world from them than I am,” and as I wondered at the meaning of her words, a puff of wind made the flame leap up, and I see the red scar on her forehead. Then, alas! I knew. Did I not, I would soon have learned, for the wheeling figures of mist and snow came closer, but keeping ever without the Holy circle. Then they began to materialise till—if God have not take away my reason, for I saw it through my eyes—there were before me in actual flesh the same three women that Jonathan saw in the room, when they would have kissed his throat. I knew the swaying round forms, the bright hard eyes, the white teeth, the ruddy colour, the voluptuous lips. They smiled ever at poor dear Madam Mina; and as their laugh came through the silence of the night, they twined their arms and pointed to her, and said in those so sweet tingling tones that Jonathan said were of the intolerable sweetness of the water-glasses:—
vi: — Afraid because of me? Why? No one in this world can protect those being hunted more safely than I can, sir. I was about to ask what she meant when a sudden strong gust of wind blew, rekindling the nearly extinguished flame. It was only at this moment that I noticed the fresh red scar on her forehead. Oh my God! It was now clear to me. I suddenly understood everything, as the swirling faces of the snowstorm approached very close but seemed to halt before my Sacred Circle. Then they took shape right before my eyes, unless God had taken my sanity - in flesh and blood; they were the three women that Jonathan had encountered in the castle when they approached to caress and kiss his neck that day. I recognized the round, alluring bodies, the wickedly flirtatious eyes, the white teeth and the rosy, plump skin, then the bright red lips full of lustful desire. They giggled foolishly at Mina, their laughter piercing the silence of the dark night. They clung tightly to each other, pointing directly at her and speaking a long string of words, their voices clear and gentle like crystal, just as Jonathan had described in his diary.
tr: “Are you afraid for me? Why are you afraid for me? There is no one in the whole world who is safer than I am against them.” While I was wondering about the meaning of his words, a sudden gust of wind flared the fire and I saw the red scar on his forehead. That was when, ah! I understood! If I hadn’t understood then, I would soon learn, because the shapes of swirling mist and snow approached but always kept away from the sacred circle. Then they began to materialize, until -if God hasn’t taken my mind- I saw with my own eyes the same three women Jonathan had seen in the room, trying to kiss his throat, standing before me in flesh and blood. I recognized their swaying round forms, their gleaming hard eyes, their white teeth, their red cheeks, and their lustful lips. They laughed at poor dear Madam Mina, and as their laughter pierced the silence of the night, they entwined their arms and pointed at her, speaking in those sweet ringing voices that Jonathan compared to the unbearable sweetness of clinking water glasses:
es: –Do you fear for me? Why do you fear for me? No one in the whole world is better protected against them than I am. And while I wondered about the meaning of his words, a gust of wind made the flame rise, and I saw the red scar on his forehead. Then I understood. And if I hadn't understood then, I would have soon, thanks to the figures of mist and snow that swirled and approached, but kept away from the sacred circle. Then, they began to materialize, until, if God hadn't taken my sanity, because I saw it with my own eyes, the same three women that Jonathan saw in the room, when they kissed his throat, were before me, in flesh and blood. I knew the spinning images, the bright and hard eyes, the white teeth, the rosy color, and the voluptuous lips. They continuously smiled at poor Mrs. Mina, and as their laughter echoed in the silence of the night, they waved their arms and pointed at her, speaking with the resonant and sweet voices that Jonathan had said were unbearably sweet, like crystalline.

en: “Come, sister. Come to us. Come! Come!” In fear I turned to my poor Madam Mina, and my heart with gladness leapt like flame; for oh! the terror in her sweet eyes, the repulsion, the horror, told a story to my heart that was all of hope. God be thanked she was not, yet, of them. I seized some of the firewood which was by me, and holding out some of the Wafer, advanced on them towards the fire. They drew back before me, and laughed their low horrid laugh. I fed the fire, and feared them not; for I knew that we were safe within our protections. They could not approach, me, whilst so armed, nor Madam Mina whilst she remained within the ring, which she could not leave no more than they could enter. The horses had ceased to moan, and lay still on the ground; the snow fell on them softly, and they grew whiter. I knew that there was for the poor beasts no more of terror.
vi: — Come here with us, little brother, come here, come here! I turned back to look at Mina, feeling weak, but inside I felt as if I was seeing a glimmer of hope. Because her fearful and disgusted eyes, and her terror, told me that I could still be full of hope. Simply put, she had not yet become an accomplice of those women. I grabbed some firewood near me and held out a holy wafer, then slowly approached them. They immediately backed away, but did not forget to let out those chilling, shrill laughs. I continued to build the fire, no longer afraid, because I understood that we would be unharmed as long as we stayed within our invisible fortress. And with a weapon like the one I had, those women could not come near me or Mina. Moreover, as long as she remained within the Sacred Circle, she could not step out, just as they could not step in. The horses stopped neighing and stomping wildly; they lay down on the ground, letting the falling snow cover them, making them look like small snow-covered hills. I understood that they were no longer afraid of those ghostly figures.
tr: "Come, my brother. Come to us. Come! Come!" I turned to my dear Madam Mina in fear, and my heart leapt as if it had burst into flames of joy; for oh! The fear, disgust, and horror in her sweet eyes told a story to my heart filled entirely with hope. Thank God she had not yet become one of them. I took a few of the logs beside me and, extending some of the blessed bread forward, I advanced towards them from across the fire. They retreated before me and laughed with their low, terrifying laughter. I fed the fire and was not afraid of them, for I knew we were safe among our precautions. As long as I was armed in this way, they could not approach me or Madam Mina, who was within the circle they could not enter or leave. The horses stopped groaning and lay still on the ground; snow was gently falling on them, and the horses turned completely white. I knew there was nothing more for the poor animals to fear.
es: –Come, sister! Come with us! Come! Come! – they said to her. Filled with fear, I turned to my poor lady Mina and my heart rose like a flame, full of joy, because, oh!, the terror reflected in her sweet eyes and the repulsion and horror made my heart understand that there was still hope, thanks be to God that she was not yet one of them! I grabbed one of the logs from the campfire, which was near me, and, holding part of the Host, I advanced towards them. They moved away from me and laughed out loud, in a hoarse and horrible manner. I fed the fire and was not afraid of them, because I knew we were safe within our protective circle. They could not approach me, as long as I was armed in that way, nor could they approach lady Mina, as long as she remained within the circle, which she could not leave, and into which the others could not enter. The horses had stopped moaning and lay motionless on the ground. The snow fell gently on them, until they turned white. I knew that, for the poor animals, there was no greater terror.

en: And so we remained till the red of the dawn to fall through the snow-gloom. I was desolate and afraid, and full of woe and terror; but when that beautiful sun began to climb the horizon life was to me again. At the first coming of the dawn the horrid figures melted in the whirling mist and snow; the wreaths of transparent gloom moved away towards the castle, and were lost.
vi: We just sat still in one place until we noticed the bright pink halos of the sun piercing through the melancholy color of the white snow. All last night, I lived in a state of heavy worry, sorrow, and fear. But life truly returned to me when the sun's rays burst forth on the horizon. As soon as the sun rose, the lurking spirits immediately vanished with the swirling snowstorms and fog. The flickering, translucent shadows gradually drifted towards the old castle and disappeared within it.
tr: We stayed like that until the redness of dawn began to fall upon the gloom of the snow. I was in a state of misery and fear, filled with sorrow and dread, but once that beautiful sun began to climb the horizon again, a surge of life energy filled me. With the first arrival of dawn, those dreadful shapes melted away into the swirling mist and snow; crowns of transparent gloom advanced towards the castle and disappeared from sight.
es: We remained like that until the red color of dawn began to appear amidst the somber snow. I felt desolate and fearful, full of forebodings and terrors, but when the beautiful sun began to rise over the horizon, life returned to me. As the dawn appeared, the horrible figures melted away amidst the swirling mist and snow; the layers of transparent fog drifted towards the castle and vanished.

en: Instinctively, with the dawn coming, I turned to Madam Mina, intending to hypnotise her; but she lay in a deep and sudden sleep, from which I could not wake her. I tried to hypnotise through her sleep, but she made no response, none at all; and the day broke. I fear yet to stir. I have made my fire and have seen the horses, they are all dead. To-day I have much to do here, and I keep waiting till the sun is up high; for there may be places where I must go, where that sunlight, though snow and mist obscure it, will be to me a safety.
vi: Like an instinct, I turned to look at Mina, intending to tell her to prepare for another hypnosis attempt. But she had fallen into a deep sleep without me noticing. Knowing that I couldn't wake her up, I tried to risk hypnotizing her even while she was asleep. But she didn't respond to any questions. I quietly went to prepare the carriage to continue our journey, but my God, the sight before me made my legs go weak: our horses had frozen to death at some point. I understood that a new day would bring me many hardships. I would wait until the sun was high in the sky, because only then, even if it snowed or was foggy, I would feel secure going to the places I needed to reach.
tr: With the breaking of dawn, I instinctively turned to Madam Mina to hypnotize her, but she had fallen into a deep and sudden sleep, and I couldn't wake her. I tried to hypnotize her in her sleep, but she didn't respond at all, and morning came. I am still afraid to move. I lit my fire and saw the horses; they were all dead. I have a lot of work to do here today, and I am waiting until the sun rises fully, because although the snow and mist obscure it, I may need to go to some places where daylight will be my assurance.
es: Instinctively, at the arrival of dawn, I turned towards Mrs. Mina to try to hypnotize her, but I saw that she had suddenly and deeply fallen asleep, and I could not wake her. I tried to hypnotize her while she slept, but she gave me no response at all, and the sun rose. I am still afraid to move. I have made a fire and gone to check on the horses. They are all dead. I have much to do here today and I will wait until the sun is very high, because there may be places I need to go where that sun, though dimmed by snow and mist, will be a safety for me.

en: I will strengthen me with breakfast, and then I will to my terrible work. Madam Mina still sleeps; and, God be thanked! she is calm in her sleep....
vi: Lunch would give me the strength before tackling a difficult challenge. Mina was still in a peaceful sleep. May God bless her.
tr: I will gather my strength with breakfast and then set to my dreadful task. Madam Mina is still sleeping, and thank God she is calm in her sleep.
es: I am going to strengthen myself with breakfast, and afterwards, I am going to take care of my terrible work. Mrs. Mina is still sleeping and, thank God, she is peaceful in her slumber.

en: Jonathan Harker’s Journal.
vi: Jonathan Harker's Diary
tr: Jonathan Harker's journal
es: From the journal of Jonathan Harker

en: 4 November, evening.—The accident to the launch has been a terrible thing for us. Only for it we should have overtaken the boat long ago; and by now my dear Mina would have been free. I fear to think of her, off on the wolds near that horrid place. We have got horses, and we follow on the track. I note this whilst Godalming is getting ready. We have our arms. The Szgany must look out if they mean fight. Oh, if only Morris and Seward were with us. We must only hope! If I write no more Good-bye, Mina! God bless and keep you.
vi: • November 4, evening The accident on the river was indeed a terrible surprise for us. If not for that, we could have caught up with the ship long ago, and by then, Mina would surely have been freed. I can only dare to think that she is crossing the patches of forest growing along that dreadful place. We have found horses and are on the trail of the devil's tracks. I take advantage of this moment to write these lines while Godalming is busily preparing. We are carrying weapons. If they want to mess with us, the gypsies better watch out. Oh, how wonderful it would be if Morris and Seward were here with us? But in any case, we must remain hopeful. And if I have no other chance to write, then Mina, I bid you farewell forever! May God bless and protect you!
tr: 4 November, evening. - The accident that happened to the steamship was very bad for all of us. If it hadn't happened, we would have caught the other ship much earlier and by now dear Mina would have been free. I am afraid to think that she is in the steppes near that dreadful place. We have horses and we are on the trail. I am writing these lines while Godalming is preparing. We have weapons. If the Gypsies intend to fight, they need to be very careful. Oh! I wish Morris and Seward were with us. All we can do is hope! If I cannot write any more, farewell, Mina! God bless and protect you!
es: November 4th, at night. The boat accident had been terrible for us. If it weren't for that, we would have caught the boat a long time ago, and by now, my dear Mina would already be free. I dread thinking of her, far from the world, in that horrible place. We have obtained horses, and we continue on the path. I write this while Godalming prepares. We have our weapons ready and the gypsies will have to be careful if they wish to fight. If only Morris and Seward were with us! We can only wait! If I do not write again, goodbye, Mina! May God bless you and keep you!

en: Dr. Seward’s Diary.
vi: Dr. Seward's Diary
tr: Dr. Seward's journal
es: From the diary of Dr. Seward

en: 5 November.—With the dawn we saw the body of Szgany before us dashing away from the river with their leiter-wagon. They surrounded it in a cluster, and hurried along as though beset. The snow is falling lightly and there is a strange excitement in the air. It may be our own feelings, but the depression is strange. Far off I hear the howling of wolves; the snow brings them down from the mountains, and there are dangers to all of us, and from all sides. The horses are nearly ready, and we are soon off. We ride to death of some one. God alone knows who, or where, or what, or when, or how it may be....
vi: • November 5 The dawn light helped us recognize the Gypsies hastily moving away from the river with a cart. Snow fell lightly, and the air suddenly had an oddly exhilarating effect. It might just be a subjective feeling, but our discouragement seemed to stem from something unusual. I could clearly hear the long, mournful howls of wolves echoing from a distant place, the falling snow driving them down the mountain to threaten us from all sides. The horses were ready to join us on a treacherous journey. And at the end of that journey, some of us might have to stay behind forever. Only God knows who that person will be, where, when, and how...
tr: November 5th. - At dawn, we saw the Gypsy caravan speeding away from the river in a car. They were surrounding the car and moving swiftly. It was lightly snowing, and there was a strange excitement in the air. This could be our own excited feelings, but the anxiety is peculiar. I hear the wolves howling in the distance; the snow carries these sounds down from the mountains, and there is danger for all of us from every direction. The horses are almost ready, and we will set off very soon. We are heading towards someone's death. Only God knows who, where, when, or how someone will die...
es: November 5. At dawn, we see the tribe of gypsies ahead of us, moving away from the river in their wagons. They gather around them and move hastily, as if they were being harassed. The snow is falling slowly and there is a huge tension in the atmosphere. It may be just our feelings, but the impression is strange. In the distance, I hear the howling of the wolves; the snow brings them down from the mountains and the danger for everyone is great and comes from all sides. The horses are almost ready, and we set off immediately. We are heading towards someone's death. Only God knows whose or where, or what or when or how it may happen…

en: Dr. Van Helsing’s Memorandum.
vi: Van Helsing's Notes
tr: Dr. Van Helsing's notes
es: Memorandum, by Dr. van Helsing

en: 5 November, afternoon.—I am at least sane. Thank God for that mercy at all events, though the proving it has been dreadful. When I left Madam Mina sleeping within the Holy circle, I took my way to the castle. The blacksmith hammer which I took in the carriage from Veresti was useful; though the doors were all open I broke them off the rusty hinges, lest some ill-intent or ill-chance should close them, so that being entered I might not get out. Jonathan’s bitter experience served me here. By memory of his diary I found my way to the old chapel, for I knew that here my work lay. The air was oppressive; it seemed as if there was some sulphurous fume, which at times made me dizzy. Either there was a roaring in my ears or I heard afar off the howl of wolves. Then I bethought me of my dear Madam Mina, and I was in terrible plight. The dilemma had me between his horns.
vi: • November 5, afternoon At least I am still intact and must thank God, even though the reality unfolding before my eyes is truly terrifying. To let Mina sleep peacefully within the Sacred Circle, I cautiously made my way towards the castle. When I arrived in Veresti, I bought a blacksmith's hammer and threw it into the car.
