I have just set foot in the castle. All doors are open, but I must carefully lift each one off its rusted hinges for fear that some mishap or plot might suddenly slam them shut, blocking my way out. I learned that through the harsh reality of Jonathan. His bitter diary pages helped me find the path leading to the old church, where I know my mission awaits. The suffocating air made me dizzy, as if I had just entered a cloud of sulfur smoke. I'm not sure if my ears are ringing or if the howling of the wolves is echoing from a distant place? I suddenly felt a pang of fear when I thought of Mina: I am caught in a dilemma.
tr: November 5, late afternoon. - At least my sanity is intact. Though proving it was horrifying, I still thank God for His mercy. I left Madam Mina sleeping within the holy circle and set off towards the castle. The blacksmith's hammer I took from the carriage in Veresti came in handy; despite all the doors being open, I broke them off their rusty hinges so that no ill will or bad luck could close them and trap me inside. Here, Jonathan's painful experience helped me. Remembering his journal, I found the way to the old chapel, for I knew where my task lay. The air was very oppressive; from time to time, it seemed to emit a sulfurous gas that made my head spin. Either there was a ringing in my ears, or I was hearing the howling of wolves from afar. Then I reminded myself of dear Madam Mina and felt very distressed. This dilemma pressed upon me.
es: November 5, in the afternoon. At least, I am sane. Thank God for His mercy amidst so many events, even though they have been a terrible trial. When I left Mrs. Mina asleep inside the sacred circle, I headed towards the castle. The blacksmith's hammer that I had carried in the carriage from Veresti has been useful; although the doors were open, I removed them from their rusty hinges to prevent any malicious attempt or bad luck from closing them in such a way that once inside I could not get out again. The bitter experiences of Jonathan serve me well. Remembering his diary, I find the way to the old chapel, as I know that it is there where I will have to work. The atmosphere was stifling; it seemed that there was some sulfurous acid in it that, at times, made me a bit dizzy. Either I heard a roar, or the howls of the wolves reached me distorted. Then, I remembered my dear lady Mina and found myself in the midst of a terrible dilemma.

en: Her, I had not dare to take into this place, but left safe from the Vampire in that Holy circle; and yet even there would be the wolf! I resolve me that my work lay here, and that as to the wolves we must submit, if it were God’s will. At any rate it was only death and freedom beyond. So did I choose for her. Had it but been for myself the choice had been easy, the maw of the wolf were better to rest in than the grave of the Vampire! So I make my choice to go on with my work.
vi: I didn't dare bring her here because I thought the Sacred Circle would protect her from falling into the clutches of the "vampire". But what about the wolves? I am determined that my duty is to be here, in this dark castle; as for the wolves, we will endure them if it is God's will! Either way, it comes down to choosing between death and freedom, and I am the one making that choice for my young friend. As for myself, I find it not difficult at all: the lair of the "vampire" is worse to me than the jaws of the wolves. Therefore, I continue my work.
tr: I dared not bring her here, but I left her safe from the Vampire within the holy circle; yet even there, there could be wolves! I decided that my task was here and if it was God's will, we must surrender to the wolves. Beyond this, there was death and salvation. Thus, I made the choice on her behalf. If it were for myself, the choice would be easy; better to lie in the belly of the wolf than in the Vampire's grave! Thus, I decided to continue with my task.
es: I have not allowed myself to bring her to this horrendous place, but I have left her safe from the vampires in the sacred circle; however, there were wolves that put her in danger! I resolved that I had to do the main work in the castle, and that regarding the wolves we should submit to the will of God. Anyway, that would only mean death and freedom. So I decided for her. If the choice had been for me, it would not have been difficult to decide; it was a thousand times better to be in the midst of a pack of wolves than in the vampire's tomb! Therefore, I decided to continue my work.

en: I knew that there were at least three graves to find—graves that are inhabit; so I search, and search, and I find one of them. She lay in her Vampire sleep, so full of life and voluptuous beauty that I shudder as though I have come to do murder. Ah, I doubt not that in old time, when such things were, many a man who set forth to do such a task as mine, found at the last his heart fail him, and then his nerve. So he delay, and delay, and delay, till the mere beauty and the fascination of the wanton Un-Dead have hypnotise him; and he remain on and on, till sunset come, and the Vampire sleep be over. Then the beautiful eyes of the fair woman open and look love, and the voluptuous mouth present to a kiss—and man is weak. And there remain one more victim in the Vampire fold; one more to swell the grim and grisly ranks of the Un-Dead!...
vi: I know I need to discover at least three graves - three graves with people lying in them. Therefore, the first task is to search, search, until I find a woman lying sprawled in the sleep of a "vampire," her body full of vitality and exuding a sensual beauty that makes me shudder as if I am about to commit a crime. That's it! I am sure that if someone were in my situation, they would feel a stirring in their heart and lose all the rationality of a man. He would hesitate, hesitate, hesitate until the enchanting beauty of that woman drains his soul; then he would become dazed, dazed, dazed until the sun goes to sleep and the ghost awakens. The young beautiful woman would open her eyes full of yearning for love, her luscious red lips would place a passionate kiss somewhere on his body, and the man within him would gradually disappear. Thus, another victim becomes an accomplice of the devil, another one in the terrifying dark army of the immortals!...
tr: I knew there were at least three graves to be found, used graves; so, I searched, searched, and found one. The vampire was in its sleep; it had such a beauty so full of life and bodily desire that I shuddered as if I had come to commit murder. Ah! In the old days, when such things happened, I have no doubt that many men who set out to fulfill a duty like mine eventually realized that their hearts and then their nerves failed them halfway. Thus, they would keep postponing their duty until the frivolous Undead hypnotized them, and they would wait, wait there until sunset and the Vampire’s sleep ended. Then, the beautiful eyes of that charming woman would open, look lovingly, and offer her lustful lips for a kiss; the man would be powerless. Thus, another victim would join the vampire horde; the merciless and terrifying ranks of the Undead would increase by one more.
es: I knew there were at least three graves to find, which were inhabited. So I searched tirelessly, and I found one of them. She was lying in her vampire sleep, so full of life and voluptuous beauty that I shuddered, as if I were about to commit a crime. I do not doubt that, in ancient times, many men who were about to undertake a task like mine had their hearts and nerves fail them. Consequently, it was delayed until the very beauty of the undead woman hypnotized him; and he stayed there until sunset came and the vampire's sleep ceased. Then, the beautiful eyes of the vampire woman opened and looked at him full of love, and the voluptuous lips parted to kiss... Man is weak. Thus, there was one more victim in the vampire's lair; one more that swelled the terrible ranks of the undead...!

en: There is some fascination, surely, when I am moved by the mere presence of such an one, even lying as she lay in a tomb fretted with age and heavy with the dust of centuries, though there be that horrid odour such as the lairs of the Count have had. Yes, I was moved—I, Van Helsing, with all my purpose and with my motive for hate—I was moved to a yearning for delay which seemed to paralyse my faculties and to clog my very soul. It may have been that the need of natural sleep, and the strange oppression of the air were beginning to overcome me. Certain it was that I was lapsing into sleep, the open-eyed sleep of one who yields to a sweet fascination, when there came through the snow-stilled air a long, low wail, so full of woe and pity that it woke me like the sound of a clarion. For it was the voice of my dear Madam Mina that I heard.
vi: Yes, I was mesmerized by the women lying in a tomb stained by the dust of time over many centuries, despite the foul odor emanating from everywhere in the count's lair. Yes, I, Van Helsing, was excited, even though I had decided to act with the hatred rising in my heart and was obsessed with a desire to prolong my actions, rendering all my combat abilities completely paralyzed. I fell into a drowsy sleep, enchanted by the mesmerizing allure of the woman, but then I was startled awake by a mournful wail in the still air, like a funeral dirge. That cry was Mina's.
tr: There is undoubtedly an enchantment; even while lying in a grave decayed over time and heavy with the dust of centuries, accompanied by that dreadful smell similar to the one in the Count’s secret lair, I am affected by the presence of such a being. Yes, I was affected -I, Van Helsing, despite my entire purpose and reason for hatred- I was affected by a desire to delay that paralyzed my faculties and hindered my soul. My need for natural sleep and the strange pressure in the air might be taking hold of me. Undoubtedly, I was falling into sleep -the open-eyed sleep of someone who desires sweet enchantment- when a long, low moan full of great sorrow and pain, cutting through the air silenced by the snow, woke me like a trumpet sound. For this was the voice of my dear Madam Mina that I heard.
es: Of course, there is a certain fascination, for I am moved by the mere presence of such a beautiful woman, even when she is lying in a tomb dilapidated by the years and filled with the dust of several centuries, though there was that horrible smell that floated in the count's lair. Yes; I felt disturbed... I, Van Helsing, despite my purposes and my motives of hatred..., felt the need for a delay that seemed to paralyze my faculties and grip my very soul. It was possible that the need for natural sleep and the strange oppression of the air were overwhelming me. I was sure that I was being dominated by sleep; the sleep with open eyes of a person who surrenders to a sweet fascination, when through the silent, snow-filled air came a very prolonged moan, so full of sorrow and regret, that it woke me as if it had been a trumpet, for it was the voice of Mrs. Mina that I was hearing.

en: Then I braced myself again to my horrid task, and found by wrenching away tomb-tops one other of the sisters, the other dark one. I dared not pause to look on her as I had on her sister, lest once more I should begin to be enthrall; but I go on searching until, presently, I find in a high great tomb as if made to one much beloved that other fair sister which, like Jonathan I had seen to gather herself out of the atoms of the mist. She was so fair to look on, so radiantly beautiful, so exquisitely voluptuous, that the very instinct of man in me, which calls some of my sex to love and to protect one of hers, made my head whirl with new emotion. But God be thanked, that soul-wail of my dear Madam Mina had not died out of my ears; and, before the spell could be wrought further upon me, I had nerved myself to my wild work. By this time I had searched all the tombs in the chapel, so far as I could tell; and as there had been only three of these Un-Dead phantoms around us in the night, I took it that there were no more of active Un-Dead existent. There was one great tomb more lordly than all the rest; huge it was, and nobly proportioned. On it was but one word
vi: I steeled myself to complete my first search mission. While moving some stones aside, I discovered a second woman, also with dark hair like the first one. I did not dare to hesitate and gaze, fearing the same disheartening feeling of hesitation as before. The search continued until I found, under a large, tall tomb seemingly reserved for someone dearly beloved by the count - the blonde woman whom I, after Jonathan, had once seen in the mist. She looked beautiful, alluring, and seductive to the point that the deep instincts of a man stirred within me a desire to protect someone of the opposite sex and an indescribable emotion. But thank God, Mina's cry of pain still echoed in my ears, and before being completely bewitched by the woman's beauty, I managed to regain my senses to carry out my dreadful task. I felt as if I had searched all the tombs in the ancient church and there might not be any more such places. But no, there was still one more tomb, larger, more majestic, and seemingly more noble than the ones I had encountered before, engraved with a single name: DRACULA.
tr: Then, I gathered strength for my dreadful task and, by forcibly lifting the tomb lids, I found another of the sisters, the other brunette. So that I would not begin to be enchanted once more, I did not dare to stop to look at her as I had done with the other sister, but continued my search until I found her in a large, high tomb that seemed made for that dear blonde sister who materialized from the atoms of the mist as Jonathan had seen. She had such a pure appearance, such dazzling beauty, such graceful sensuality that the masculine instinct within me, which calls my kind to love and protect one of her kind, caused my head to spin with a new feeling. But thank God, the cry of my dear Madam Mina's soul had not yet faded from my ears, and before the spell could further take hold of me, I gathered my courage for my savage duty. By this time, I had searched all the tombs I could find in the chapel; since there were only two Undead specters around us at night, I concluded that there were no other active Undead at the moment. There was a single tomb more magnificent than all the other tombs; it was giant and had noble proportions. On it was inscribed a single word:
es: Then, I dedicated myself to my horrible task and discovered, by lifting the slabs of the graves, another of the sisters, the other brunette. I did not stop to look at her, as I had done with her sister, for fear of being fascinated again; I continued searching until, suddenly, I discovered in a large tomb that must have been built for a very beloved woman, the other sister, the one whom, like my friend Jonathan, I had seen materialize from the mist. She was so pleasant to behold, of such radiant beauty and so exquisitely voluptuous, that the very instinct of man in me, which demanded part of my sex to love and protect one of them, made my head spin with a new emotion. But, thank God, that prolonged lament of my dear lady Mina had not yet ceased in my ears and, before the spell could affect me again, I had already decided to carry out my terrible work. I had searched all the tombs in the chapel, I believe, and since there had only been near us, during the night, three of those ghosts of the undead, I assumed there were no more active undead than them. There was a great tomb, more majestic than all the others, enormous and of noble proportions. On it was written a single word: DRACULA

en: DRACULA.
vi: But no, there was still one more tomb, larger, more majestic, and seemingly more noble than the ones I had encountered before, engraved with a single name: DRACULA.
tr: DRACULA
es: On it was written a single word: DRACULA

en: This then was the Un-Dead home of the King-Vampire, to whom so many more were due. Its emptiness spoke eloquent to make certain what I knew. Before I began to restore these women to their dead selves through my awful work, I laid in Dracula’s tomb some of the Wafer, and so banished him from it, Un-Dead, for ever.
vi: That is precisely the last place where the "Vampire King" hides his immortality. The emptiness inside the tomb proves what I already knew. Before starting the task of returning those women to their former selves, I carefully placed pieces of holy bread inside Dracula's tomb to permanently banish him from this safe haven.
tr: So, this was the "Undead Lair of the Vampire King," to which many things were connected. The empty grave meaningfully told me that something I already knew was true. Through my dreadful task, before sending these women to their own deaths, I placed some blessed bread in Dracula's grave, thus banishing him from that grave forever while he was in his Undead state.
es: Thus, that was the tomb of the Vampire King, to whom so many others owed their existence. The fact that it was empty was eloquent enough to confirm what I already knew. Before beginning to restore those women to their true dead state through my horrible work, I left a part of the sacred host in Dracula's tomb, thereby prohibiting his entry and ensuring he would remain eternally as the undead.

en: Then began my terrible task, and I dreaded it. Had it been but one, it had been easy, comparative. But three! To begin twice more after I had been through a deed of horror; for if it was terrible with the sweet Miss Lucy, what would it not be with these strange ones who had survived through centuries, and who had been strengthened by the passing of the years; who would, if they could, have fought for their foul lives....
vi: I had to begin such a dreadful task before retreating. If there were only one corpse to deal with, it wouldn't be too difficult. But there are three corpses! This means I will have to repeat the process two more times! For me, if the execution was terrifying when standing before Lucy, how much more horrifying will it be to stand before three strangers who have lived for centuries, growing ever more powerful with the passage of time, thus protecting their absurd existence.
tr: Then, my dreadful task began, I was afraid of this. If there had been only one, it would have been relatively easy. But three! To start twice more after committing a horrifying act; if it was dreadful with sweet Miss Lucy, who knows how it would be with these strangers who have survived for centuries and grown stronger over the years, who would fight for their vile lives if they could...
es: Then my terrible task began, and I was horrified by it. If it had only been one, it wouldn't be relatively difficult. But, there were three! I had to start over twice after reaching the height of horror. Since if it was terrible with sweet Lucy, how could it not be with those strangers, who had survived for several centuries and had been strengthened by the passage of years? If they could, would they fight for their horrendous lives…?

en: Oh, my friend John, but it was butcher work; had I not been nerved by thoughts of other dead, and of the living over whom hung such a pall of fear, I could not have gone on. I tremble and tremble even yet, though till all was over, God be thanked, my nerve did stand. Had I not seen the repose in the first place, and the gladness that stole over it just ere the final dissolution came, as realisation that the soul had been won, I could not have gone further with my butchery. I could not have endured the horrid screeching as the stake drove home; the plunging of writhing form, and lips of bloody foam. I should have fled in terror and left my work undone. But it is over! And the poor souls, I can pity them now and weep, as I think of them placid each in her full sleep of death for a short moment ere fading. For, friend John, hardly had my knife severed the head of each, before the whole body began to melt away and crumble in to its native dust, as though the death that should have come centuries agone had at last assert himself and say at once and loud “I am here!”
vi: — So there you have it, my friend John! Is that the work of a butcher? If it weren't for the resolute thought of a true death, and a life placed in such a terrible vice, I might never have dared to go all the way. I am still trembling, but until the entire job is finished, may God help me return to myself! I returned to the first woman and suddenly had the feeling of witnessing a fleeting satisfaction on her face just before she was freed, as if to acknowledge that her soul had been completely conquered: without such a feeling, I certainly wouldn't dare to do the work of a butcher. I couldn't bear the hair-raising sound of driving the stake into the girl's body. I was so terrified that I abandoned the job. But in the end, everything was finished! Now I can mourn for those wretched souls, those who could rest peacefully in the contentment of a true death, even if that moment of peace only briefly passed before my eyes before turning to dust and returning to the past, as if the deaths that had been restrained for centuries finally asserted their rightful claim and proclaimed: "Here I am."
tr: Ah, my friend John! This is butchery! If I hadn't gathered my courage by thinking of other dead and those living with such a shroud of fear over them, I wouldn't have been able to continue my work. Even after it all ended, I keep trembling, thank God my nerves endured it. If I hadn't seen the peace indicating the soul was reclaimed, the satisfaction spreading across the face before the final dissolution, I couldn't have continued my butchery. I couldn't bear that horrifying scream heard as the stake was driven in, the lunges of the writhing form, and the blood-filled frothy lips. I would flee in terror and leave my work unfinished. But it's all over! And thinking that in that brief moment before their annihilation, each of them appeared docile in their true death sleep, I can pity them and shed tears for them. Because, my friend John, it was as if the death that should have come centuries ago finally appeared and suddenly declared loudly, "I am He!" before each of their heads was freshly severed, and their entire body crumbled and merged back into the soil from which it came.
es: Oh, friend John, it was a butcher's job! If the thought of other dead and the living upon whom a similar mistake weighed had not given me courage, I would not have been able to do it. I still tremble, even though the work has long been finished. Thank God, my nerves did not betray me. If I had not seen the peace first and the joy that spread over the face of the corpse a moment before the dissolution began, as a demonstration that a soul had been freed, I would not have been able to conclude my butchery. I would not have been able to endure the terrible noise of the stake penetrating, the lips covered with bloody foam, nor the writhing of the body. I should have left my work unfinished, fleeing from there in terror, but, it is now concluded! And as for the poor souls, I can now feel pity for them and shed tears, since I saw the peace that spread over their faces before disappearing. Since, friend John, I had barely cut off their heads with my knife when the bodies began to disintegrate into natural dust, as if the death that should have occurred several centuries before had finally firmly established itself, proclaiming: "Here I am!"

en: Before I left the castle I so fixed its entrances that never more can the Count enter there Un-Dead.
vi: Before leaving the castle, I must ensure that all the passages are blocked so that the old count can never enter and become immortal again.
tr: Before leaving the castle, I arranged the entrances so that the Count could never enter there again as the Undead.
es: Before leaving the castle, I closed the doors in such a way that the count could never enter again as an undead.

en: When I stepped into the circle where Madam Mina slept, she woke from her sleep, and, seeing, me, cried out in pain that I had endured too much.
vi: A moment after I returned to the Sacred Circle, where Mina was deep in sleep, she suddenly woke up and looked at me.
tr: As soon as I stepped into the circle where Madam Mina was sleeping, she woke up from her sleep and let out such a scream of pain upon seeing me that it was hard to bear.
es: When I entered the sacred circle, inside which Mrs. Mina was sleeping, she woke up and, upon seeing me, told me tearfully that I had already endured too much.

en: “Come!” she said, “come away from this awful place! Let us go to meet my husband who is, I know, coming towards us.” She was looking thin and pale and weak; but her eyes were pure and glowed with fervour. I was glad to see her paleness and her illness, for my mind was full of the fresh horror of that ruddy vampire sleep.
vi: — Come here, - She told me, her voice so painful that I couldn't help but feel moved - we will leave this dreadful place together. We need to go meet my husband. I know he is heading towards us. She looked emaciated, her skin was pale, and she appeared haggard, with only her eyes remaining clear and sparkling. I felt happy when I noticed her paleness and sorrow, because not long ago, I was haunted by the terrifying thought of the "vampire" sleep within her.
tr: “Come!” she said, “come, let's get away from this dreadful place! Let's go meet my husband, whom I know is coming towards us.” She looked weak, pale, and frail, but her eyes were pure and shone with enthusiasm. I was glad to see her paleness and illness, because my mind was filled with fresh fears about the rosy-cheeked vampire's sleep.
es: –Let's go! – he said-. Let's get away from this horrible place! We are going to meet my husband, who is already on his way to us; I know it. He had a fragile, pale, and weak appearance, but his eyes were pure and shone with fervor. I was glad to see his paleness and sickly appearance, as my mind was still filled with the horror produced by seeing that dream of the vampire women.

en: And so with trust and hope, and yet full of fear, we go eastward to meet our friends—and him—whom Madam Mina tell me that she know are coming to meet us.
vi: So, in a state filled with faith and hope, but also not lacking in anxiety, we went together towards the east to find our friends and him, the one who, as Mina had affirmed, would come to meet us.
tr: And so, with trust and hope, but still filled with fear, we advanced eastward to meet our friends - and him; because Madam Mina says she knows they are coming to meet us.
es: Thus, with confidence and hope and, nevertheless, full of fear, we head east to meet our friends and him, since Mrs. Mina says she knows they are coming to meet us.

en: Mina Harker’s Journal.
vi: Mina Harker's Diary
tr: Mina Harker's diary
es: From the diary of Mina Harker

en: 6 November.—It was late in the afternoon when the Professor and I took our way towards the east whence I knew Jonathan was coming. We did not go fast, though the way was steeply downhill, for we had to take heavy rugs and wraps with us; we dared not face the possibility of being left without warmth in the cold and the snow. We had to take some of our provisions, too, for we were in a perfect desolation, and, so far as we could see through the snowfall, there was not even the sign of habitation. When we had gone about a mile, I was tired with the heavy walking and sat down to rest. Then we looked back and saw where the clear line of Dracula’s castle cut the sky; for we were so deep under the hill whereon it was set that the angle of perspective of the Carpathian mountains was far below it. We saw it in all its grandeur, perched a thousand feet on the summit of a sheer precipice, and with seemingly a great gap between it and the steep of the adjacent mountain on any side. There was something wild and uncanny about the place. We could hear the distant howling of wolves. They were far off, but the sound, even though coming muffled through the deadening snowfall, was full of terror. I knew from the way Dr. Van Helsing was searching about that he was trying to seek some strategic point, where we would be less exposed in case of attack. The rough roadway still led downwards; we could trace it through the drifted snow.
vi: • November 6 The evening gradually faded as Van Helsing and I walked eastward, where I knew Jonathan was heading towards us. We couldn't walk fast, even though we were going downhill, because we had to carry rather bulky fur coats to guard against the cold and snow in case we had to rest along the way. We also had to carry some of the reserve supplies. Indeed, we were in a state of isolation and, as far as our strength could penetrate the snow curtain, we would likely struggle to find a shelter. Not even a mile in, I was forced to sit down on the ground to rest because my legs were utterly exhausted. Behind us, Dracula's castle was etching stark white lines against the horizon. We had descended a long way, yet the hill bearing the castle still loomed, almost entirely obscuring the desolate, cold Carpathian range. Only at this point did we notice again the mournful howls of the wolves echoing from afar. They were still very far away, but those savage howls, though somewhat muffled by the falling snow, still echoed as if to threaten the lone travelers on the long road. Watching Professor Van Helsing as he walked and glanced around, I understood he was trying to find some shelter that could help us be less exposed to an attack. We could still make out the rugged road stretching out of sight, even though snow had already fallen heavily below.
tr: November 6. - It was almost evening when the Professor and I started heading east, knowing that Jonathan had arrived. Despite the steep downhill slope of the road, we weren't going fast because we had to take heavy blankets and shawls with us; we couldn't dare face the possibility of not having something to keep us warm in the cold and snow. We also had to take some of our supplies with us, because we were in a completely desolate place and, as far as we could see through the falling snow, there was no sign of any settlement in sight. After advancing about two kilometers, I got tired from the heavy walk and sat down to rest. Then we looked back and saw the place where the distinct outlines of Dracula's castle cut the sky, because we were so far down the hill it stood on that the perspective of the Carpathian Mountains was well below the castle. We saw it in all its glory, perched atop a three-hundred-meter-deep precipice; it seemed as if there was a great void between it and the summit of any adjacent mountain. There was something wild and sinister about this place. We could hear the howling of wolves in the distance. They were very far away, but even muffled by the deafening snow, their voices were filled with terror. I knew from Dr. Van Helsing's exploration of the surroundings that he was trying to find a strategic point where we would be less exposed in case of an attack. The rough road still stretched downward; we could trace it partly from the accumulated snow.
es: November 6. It was already quite late in the afternoon when the professor and I set off towards the east, where I knew Jonathan was approaching from. We did not advance quickly, due to the steep terrain and the heavy furs and coats we had to carry with us, as we did not want to risk being without warm clothing in the midst of the cold and snow. Moreover, we had to bring some of our provisions, as we were in an utterly desolate area and, as far as our eyes could see over the snow, there was no inhabited place in sight. After we had covered approximately a kilometer and a half, I felt tired from the heavy walk and sat down for a moment to rest. Then, we looked back and saw the place where Dracula's proud castle stood out against the sky, as we were in such a low place compared to the hill on which it stood, that the Carpathians were far behind it. We saw it in all its grandeur, almost hanging over a huge precipice, and it seemed that there was a great separation between the summit and the other mountains that surrounded it on all sides. We could hear the distant howl of the wolves. They were very far away, but the sound, although muffled by the snow, was horrifying. I understood from the way Professor Van Helsing was looking around us that he was searching for a strategic point where we would be less exposed in case of an attack. The main road continued downward and we could see it despite the snow that covered it.

en: In a little while the Professor signalled to me, so I got up and joined him. He had found a wonderful spot, a sort of natural hollow in a rock, with an entrance like a doorway between two boulders. He took me by the hand and drew me in: “See!” he said, “here you will be in shelter; and if the wolves do come I can meet them one by one.” He brought in our furs, and made a snug nest for me, and got out some provisions and forced them upon me. But I could not eat; to even try to do so was repulsive to me, and, much as I would have liked to please him, I could not bring myself to the attempt. He looked very sad, but did not reproach me. Taking his field-glasses from the case, he stood on the top of the rock, and began to search the horizon. Suddenly he called out:—
vi: After a while, the professor signaled for me to stand up and walk over to him. He had just found a rather ideal spot, a cave with an entrance resembling a vestibule situated between the two ends of the cave. He reached out and pulled me in. — Try to look, maybe you will be safe here. - He said. - If the wolves come, I can take them down one by one for you to see. Then he turned around, took some fur coats, and made a fairly neat bed for me, just enough for me to lie down, and forced me to eat some compressed rations. But I couldn't eat. I really didn't care about anything other than sitting and breathing for a while to catch my breath, even though I really wanted to please him. He seemed sad but didn't have the heart to blame me with a single word. I saw him quietly step out onto a rock, take out his binoculars, and look towards the horizon. Suddenly, he shouted out to me:
tr: Soon after, the Professor signaled to me, and I stood up and went to him. He had found a perfect spot, a kind of natural hollow with an entrance like a door between two large rocks. He took my hand and led me inside: "Look!" he said, "You will be safe here, and if the wolves come, I can face them one by one." He carried our furs inside, prepared a secure nest for me, and tried to force me to eat some provisions. But I couldn't eat; even attempting it was repulsive to me, and although I wanted to please him, I couldn't bring myself to try. He looked very sad, but he did not scold me. He took his binoculars out of the bag, stood on top of the rock, and began to look at the horizon. Suddenly, he shouted:
es: After a moment, the professor signaled to me and, standing up, I walked towards him. He had found a magnificent spot; a sort of natural hollow in a rock, with an entrance resembling a door, between two boulders. He took me by the hand and led me inside. –Look! – he said to me-. Here you will be safe, and if the wolves come near, you can deal with them one by one. He brought all our furs inside and prepared a comfortable bed for me; then, he took out some provisions and forced me to consume them. But I couldn't eat, and even trying to do so was repulsive to me; although I would have liked very much to please him, I couldn't do it. He seemed very saddened. However, he did not reproach me. He took his glasses out of their case and remained at the highest part of the rock, carefully examining the horizon. Suddenly, he shouted:

en: “Look! Madam Mina, look! look!” I sprang up and stood beside him on the rock; he handed me his glasses and pointed. The snow was now falling more heavily, and swirled about fiercely, for a high wind was beginning to blow. However, there were times when there were pauses between the snow flurries and I could see a long way round. From the height where we were it was possible to see a great distance; and far off, beyond the white waste of snow, I could see the river lying like a black ribbon in kinks and curls as it wound its way. Straight in front of us and not far off—in fact, so near that I wondered we had not noticed before—came a group of mounted men hurrying along. In the midst of them was a cart, a long leiter-wagon which swept from side to side, like a dog’s tail wagging, with each stern inequality of the road. Outlined against the snow as they were, I could see from the men’s clothes that they were peasants or gypsies of some kind.
vi: — Look, Mrs. Mina? Come here and see this? I stood up abruptly, hurriedly walked closer to him, and took the binoculars he had just handed over. Snowflakes began to fall thickly and swirl chaotically due to the gusts of cold wind blowing in. However, occasionally the gales would stop blowing, giving me a fairly clear view. From the rock ledge where I was standing, I saw the horizon wide open before my eyes. I could make out in the distance, beyond the thick snowy plain, a river winding like a soft ribbon. Not far ahead of us - in fact, so close that we were surprised we hadn't noticed sooner - was a group of people riding horses uphill. Among the group was a long wagon, occasionally lurching forward like a dog being prodded each time it strayed off the path. This group stood out clearly against the white snow, so much so that I immediately recognized them as farmers, or Bohemians, thanks to the style of clothing they wore.
tr: "Look! Madam Mina! Look! Look!" I jumped up from my place and stood beside him on the rock; he handed me his binoculars and pointed. The snow was now falling even more heavily, and the fierce snowflakes were swirling as if caught in a vortex, because a strong wind had started to blow. But there were occasional gaps in the heavy snowfall, and I could see a long distance. From our height, it was possible to see a great range; in the distance, beyond the empty snowy fields, I could see the river winding like a black ribbon. Right in front of us and not very far away - in fact, so close that I wondered why we hadn't noticed them before - a group of horsemen was advancing rapidly. In the middle of them was a carriage, a long wagon that swayed from side to side with every bump in the road, like a dog's wagging tail. Since they stood out clearly against the snow, I could tell from the men's clothing that they were either peasants or Gypsies.
es: –Look, Mrs. Mina! Look! Look! I jumped to my feet and climbed onto the rock, stopping beside him; he handed me the binoculars and pointed with his finger. The snow was falling more heavily and swirling around us furiously, as a strong wind had picked up. However, there were times when the blizzard would calm down a bit, and I could see a vast expanse of land. From the height where we were, it was possible to see a great distance, and in the distance, beyond the white layer of snow, the river winding like a black ribbon, right in front of us and not very far away... in fact, so close that I was surprised we hadn't seen them before, a group of men on horseback was advancing as quickly as they could. In the middle of them, they were carrying a cart, a long vehicle that swayed from side to side like a dog's tail when it passed over some uneven ground. In contrast with the snow, as they appeared, I understood from their clothes that they must be peasants or guanos.

en: On the cart was a great square chest. My heart leaped as I saw it, for I felt that the end was coming. The evening was now drawing close, and well I knew that at sunset the Thing, which was till then imprisoned there, would take new freedom and could in any of many forms elude all pursuit. In fear I turned to the Professor; to my consternation, however, he was not there. An instant later, I saw him below me. Round the rock he had drawn a circle, such as we had found shelter in last night. When he had completed it he stood beside me again, saying:—
vi: On the vehicle, there was a large rectangular coffin. My heart felt like it was about to leap out of my chest, as the scene before me made me think of the ending of a ghost story that was closely tied to my own life. In no time, another day would pass, and I fully understood that right after sunset, the thing lying in that coffin would be free to move around in some suitable guise to evade all pursuits. Fearful inside, I turned to look at the professor, but I didn't know where he had disappeared to, which scared me out of my wits. A moment later, I saw him return at my feet, scattering pieces of holy bread in a protective circle around the rock, similar to the circle that had protected us the night before. After finishing the work, he climbed up to sit near me and said:
tr: There was a large square chest in the car. My heart skipped a beat when I saw it, because I felt that the end had come. Evening was falling, and by that time, that Thing which had been imprisoned here would regain its freedom and escape all pursuits. I turned to the Professor in fear; I was very surprised not to see the Professor there. A second later, I saw him down below. He drew a circle around the rock, similar to the one we had taken refuge in last night. When he completed the drawing, he came back to me and said:
es: On the cart, there was a large square box, and I felt my heart begin to beat strongly because I sensed that the end was near. The night was already approaching, and I knew perfectly well that, at sunset, the thing that was locked in that box could come out and, taking one of the forms that were in its power, evade the pursuit. Terrified, I turned to the professor and saw, dismayed, that he was no longer by my side. A moment later, I saw him below me. Around the rock, he had drawn a circle, similar to the one that had served the previous night to protect us. When he finished, he stood by my side again, saying:

en: “At least you shall be safe here from him!” He took the glasses from me, and at the next lull of the snow swept the whole space below us. “See,” he said, “they come quickly; they are flogging the horses, and galloping as hard as they can.” He paused and went on in a hollow voice:—
vi: — At least here, she isn't afraid of him. He picked up the binoculars again and looked towards the horizon in front of him: — Look at that, they're in such a hurry, they're urging the horses to run at full speed. He remained silent for a moment, then continued in a contemplative tone:
tr: "At least here you will be safe from him!” He took the binoculars from me and, once the snow had stopped again, he scanned the area beneath us thoroughly. "Look,” he said, "they are coming fast; they are whipping their horses and galloping as fast as they can.” He paused and continued speaking in a muffled voice:
es: –At least you will be safe from him here! He took the glasses from my hands, and in the next moment of calm, he scanned the entire terrain that stretched out at our feet with his gaze. –Look -he said-: they are approaching quickly, spurring the horses and advancing as fast as the road allows -he paused and, a moment later, continued, with a hollow voice-:

en: “They are racing for the sunset. We may be too late. God’s will be done!” Down came another blinding rush of driving snow, and the whole landscape was blotted out. It soon passed, however, and once more his glasses were fixed on the plain. Then came a sudden cry:—
vi: — They are racing against the sun... Perhaps we have arrived too late! May God's will come true? Another violent storm suddenly swept in, erasing everything, but this event lasted only for a very short time. When the sky calmed down again, the binoculars in the professor's hands were pointed down at the plain. He suddenly exclaimed:
tr: "They are running for the sunset." "We might be too late." "God’s will shall be done!” A blinding snowstorm came from below again and the entire landscape disappeared under the snow. But the storm passed quickly and once again the Professor's binoculars were fixed on the opening ahead of us. That's when the Professor suddenly shouted:
es: They are hurrying because the sun is about to set. It is possible that we may arrive too late. May the Lord's will be done! The snow fell heavily once again, and the entire landscape disappeared. However, it soon calmed down, and once more, the professor scrutinized the plain with the help of his glasses. Then, he suddenly shouted:

en: “Look! Look! Look! See, two horsemen follow fast, coming up from the south. It must be Quincey and John. Take the glass. Look before the snow blots it all out!” I took it and looked. The two men might be Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris. I knew at all events that neither of them was Jonathan. At the same time I knew that Jonathan was not far off; looking around I saw on the north side of the coming party two other men, riding at break-neck speed. One of them I knew was Jonathan, and the other I took, of course, to be Lord Godalming. They, too, were pursuing the party with the cart. When I told the Professor he shouted in glee like a schoolboy, and, after looking intently till a snow fall made sight impossible, he laid his Winchester rifle ready for use against the boulder at the opening of our shelter. “They are all converging,” he said. “When the time comes we shall have gypsies on all sides.” I got out my revolver ready to hand, for whilst we were speaking the howling of wolves came louder and closer. When the snow storm abated a moment we looked again. It was strange to see the snow falling in such heavy flakes close to us, and beyond, the sun shining more and more brightly as it sank down towards the far mountain tops. Sweeping the glass all around us I could see here and there dots moving singly and in twos and threes and larger numbers—the wolves were gathering for their prey.
vi: — Look! Look down there! There are two horsemen rushing from the south. It must be Quincey and John. Take the binoculars and look, quickly, or the storm will rise again. I held the binoculars. Indeed, those two men must be Dr. Seward and Mr. Quincey Morris. I believe so, as neither of them bore the familiar appearance of Jonathan. But I also knew Jonathan was not far from us. I noticed that a little to the north of where the two riders were, there were two other men also hastily spurring their horses to a gallop. I immediately recognized Jonathan, and of course, the other was Lord Godalming. They were also chasing after the carriage and the escorting party. Hearing my account, Van Helsing cheerfully shouted "hooray" like a schoolboy, and after carefully observing ahead until a snowstorm obscured his view, he held the Winchester rifle ready for battle. — They are all converging towards the same point. - He said. - The time will come when we surround those Bohemians. I also groped for the gun, because while we were talking, the howling of the wolves had become closer and much more terrifying. Another moment of calm wind helped us see more clearly. Before our eyes was a magical and mysterious scene, with heavy snowflakes falling very close to us while the sun was casting its last rays of the day and gradually setting behind the distant mountain peaks. Holding the binoculars and scanning back and forth towards the horizon, I noticed here and there groups of two or three black dots, or more, moving on the white snow carpet: those were the hungry wolves rushing to compete for the unfamiliar prey.
tr: "Look! Look! Look! Look, two horsemen are rapidly coming from the south. It must be Quincey and John. Take the binoculars. Look before the snow hides everything!” I took the binoculars and looked. The two men coming could be Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris. In any case, I knew that neither of them was Jonathan. At the same time, I knew Jonathan wasn't far away; when I looked around, I saw two other men coming at lightning speed to the north of the approaching group. I knew one of them was Jonathan and concluded that the other was, of course, Lord Godalming. They were also chasing the group with the carriage. When I told this to the Professor, he shouted with joy like a schoolboy and, after watching carefully until the snow reduced visibility to zero, he propped his Winchester rifle against the rock at the entrance of our shelter and got it ready. “They are getting closer to each other,” he said. “When the time comes, we will see Gypsies everywhere.” I took my pistol in hand to use, because as we talked, the howling of the wolves grew stronger and closer. When the snowstorm subsided for a moment, we looked again. It was strange to see the snow falling around us in such large flakes and the sun shining even brighter as it set over the peaks of the distant mountains. When I scanned the surroundings with the binoculars, I saw dots moving here and there, in pairs, in threes, and in large groups - the wolves were gathering for their prey.
es: –Look! Look! Look! See: two riders are following them quickly, coming from the south. They must be Quincey and John. Take the binoculars. Look before the snow prevents us from seeing again! I took the glasses and looked. The two men could be Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward. In any case, I was sure that neither of them was Jonathan. At the same time, I knew that Jonathan was not far away; looking around me, I saw to the north of the group that two other men were approaching, galloping at full speed on their mounts. I realized that one of them was Jonathan and, of course, I assumed that the other must be Lord Godalming. They were also chasing the cart group. When I told the professor, he jumped for joy like a schoolboy and, after looking intently until another snowstorm made all vision impossible, he prepared his Winchester, placing it on one of the rocks, ready to shoot. –They are all converging -he said-. When the time comes, we will have gypsies everywhere. I drew my revolver and kept it ready to fire, as, while we were talking, the howling of the wolves sounded much closer. When the snowstorm calmed down a bit, we looked again. It was strange to see the snow falling so heavily in the place where we were, and a little further on, to see the sun shining, with increasing intensity, approaching ever closer to the line of mountains. Looking around us, I could see spots moving over the snow, alone, in pairs or trios, and in large numbers... The wolves were gathering to attack their prey.

en: Every instant seemed an age whilst we waited. The wind came now in fierce bursts, and the snow was driven with fury as it swept upon us in circling eddies. At times we could not see an arm’s length before us; but at others, as the hollow-sounding wind swept by us, it seemed to clear the air-space around us so that we could see afar off. We had of late been so accustomed to watch for sunrise and sunset, that we knew with fair accuracy when it would be; and we knew that before long the sun would set. It was hard to believe that by our watches it was less than an hour that we waited in that rocky shelter before the various bodies began to converge close upon us. The wind came now with fiercer and more bitter sweeps, and more steadily from the north. It seemingly had driven the snow clouds from us, for, with only occasional bursts, the snow fell. We could distinguish clearly the individuals of each party, the pursued and the pursuers. Strangely enough those pursued did not seem to realise, or at least to care, that they were pursued; they seemed, however, to hasten with redoubled speed as the sun dropped lower and lower on the mountain tops.
vi: Each minute of waiting for us felt like a century. The cold wind howled, blowing into fierce, raging gusts, angrily driving the snowflakes into a flurry and piling them into successive crescent-shaped ice ridges. Occasionally, we couldn't even recognize our own outstretched arms; but whenever the wind calmed, we had the chance to gaze far into the distance. For a long time, we had developed the habit of attentively observing the moments of sunrise and sunset. And this time was no different, the sun would disappear behind the mountain range in just a moment. Without a clock, we couldn't believe we had been waiting for the other three groups for nearly an hour. The north wind continued to blow more fiercely and intensely. But it seemed that after the short gusts, the snow stopped falling, and if it did, it was blown far away from us. Now, we could clearly identify each member of every group, the hunters and the hunted. It seems that the Bohemian group did not realize someone was urgently following them, or at least they did not care about it. However, they still hurried forward as the sun was gradually sinking behind the mountains.
tr: Every second we waited felt like a year. The wind was increasing in intensity, and the snowflakes swirling around us, creating small vortices, were being driven with great fury. At times, we couldn't even see the tip of our noses, but at other times, as the wind passed by with its echoing sound, it seemed to clear the airspace around us so we could see into the distance. We had become so accustomed to waiting for sunrise and sunset lately that we could predict exactly when it would happen, and we knew that the sun would set very soon. It was hard to believe that our watches showed we had been waiting in that rocky shelter for less than half an hour until the newcomers began to approach us closely. The wind was now blowing more violently and harshly, mostly coming from the north. Apparently, the wind had driven the snow clouds away from us, because now there were only occasional bursts of snow. We could easily distinguish the members of both groups, those being chased and those doing the chasing. The strange thing was that the ones being chased seemed unaware of their pursuers or at least didn't care, but as the sun descended over the mountain peaks, they seemed to double their speed.
es: Each passing moment felt like an eternity as we waited. The wind suddenly grew stronger, and the snow fell furiously, swirling around us without rest. Sometimes we couldn't see even as far as our outstretched arms; but at other times, the air cleared, and our gaze encompassed the entire landscape. In recent times, we had become so accustomed to waiting for the sunrise and sunset that we knew exactly when it would happen. It wasn't long until dusk. It was hard to believe that, according to our watches, we had been on that rock for less than an hour, waiting, while the three groups of riders converged on us. The wind kept getting stronger and blew more steadily from the north. It seemed that the snow-laden clouds had moved away from us, as it had stopped, except for occasional flakes. It was quite strange that the pursued did not realize they were being pursued, or that they did not care at all. However, they seemed to hurry more and more as the sun descended over the mountain peaks.

en: Closer and closer they drew. The Professor and I crouched down behind our rock, and held our weapons ready; I could see that he was determined that they should not pass. One and all were quite unaware of our presence.
vi: As the group approached, Professor Van Helsing and I retreated to hide behind a rock, weapons ready in hand. Clearly, he did not want to let them pass by unnoticed. It seemed that none of them suspected our presence.
tr: They were getting closer and closer. The Professor and I crouched behind our rock and took our weapons in hand; I could see that the Professor was determined not to let them pass through here. They were all unaware of our presence.
es: They were getting closer… The professor and I crouched behind a rock and kept our weapons ready to fire. I realized that he was firmly determined not to let them pass. None of them had noticed our presence.

en: All at once two voices shouted out to: “Halt!” One was my Jonathan’s, raised in a high key of passion; the other Mr. Morris’ strong resolute tone of quiet command. The gypsies may not have known the language, but there was no mistaking the tone, in whatever tongue the words were spoken. Instinctively they reined in, and at the instant Lord Godalming and Jonathan dashed up at one side and Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris on the other. The leader of the gypsies, a splendid-looking fellow who sat his horse like a centaur, waved them back, and in a fierce voice gave to his companions some word to proceed. They lashed the horses which sprang forward; but the four men raised their Winchester rifles, and in an unmistakable way commanded them to stop. At the same moment Dr. Van Helsing and I rose behind the rock and pointed our weapons at them. Seeing that they were surrounded the men tightened their reins and drew up. The leader turned to them and gave a word at which every man of the gypsy party drew what weapon he carried, knife or pistol, and held himself in readiness to attack. Issue was joined in an instant.
vi: Suddenly, two voices shouted together: "Stop!" I recognized Jonathan's voice, hoarse from an indescribable emotion. The other voice, more resolute and calm, belonged to Quincey Morris. Although they did not understand what the two were saying, the Bohemian crowd could not mistake the emotions contained in their voices, even if it was in a foreign language. They instinctively reined in their horses. At that moment, Lord Godalming and Jonathan rode up close on one side, while Dr. Seward and Morris flanked the other side. The leader of the gypsy group, a stunningly handsome young man riding a centaur-like horse, glared and signaled my friends to retreat, angrily ordering his followers to move forward. They pulled the reins, urging their horses to lunge forward. The four men immediately placed their hands on their gun triggers - an action that could not be misinterpreted - ordering the gypsies to stop. At the same time, Van Helsing and I stepped out from behind the rock, weapons in hand. Seeing themselves surrounded, the group of Gypsies pulled the reins to stop their horses. The leader said something I didn't understand, I only knew that the followers simultaneously grabbed their weapons, which were all knives and pistols, to prepare for battle. It seemed like the outcome would be decided within a few minutes.
tr: At the same time, two voices shouted, "Stop!" One of the voices was Jonathan's, high-pitched with anger; the other was Mr. Morris's, strong, determined, and calm in command. The Gypsies might not have known the language, but it was impossible to misunderstand the tone, no matter what language the words were spoken in; instinctively, they pulled the reins, and at that moment, Lord Godalming and Jonathan attacked from one side, while Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris attacked from the other. The chief, a magnificent-looking man sitting on his horse like a Centaur, signaled them to go with his hand and angrily commanded his companions to advance. They whipped their horses, and the horses surged forward; but the four men raised their Winchester rifles and unmistakably ordered them to stop. At the same time, Dr. Van Helsing and I stood up from behind the rock and aimed our weapons at the Gypsies. Seeing they were surrounded, they pulled the reins and stopped. Their leader turned to them and said something, upon which each of the Gypsies drew their weapon - knife or pistol - and stood ready to attack. An argument ensued instantly.
es: Suddenly, two voices shouted loudly: –Stop! One of them was that of my Jonathan, which rose in a tone of passion; the other was the resolute and commanding voice of Mr. Morris. It was possible that the gypsies did not understand the language, but the tone in which that word was spoken left no room for doubt, regardless of the language in which it was said. Instinctively, they pulled on the reins and, suddenly, Lord Godalming and Jonathan rushed to one side while Mr. Morris and Dr. Seward went to the other. The leader of the gypsies, an impressive-looking man who rode a horse like a centaur, gestured to them, ordering them to retreat and, with an angry voice, commanded his companions to take action. They spurred their horses forward, but the four riders raised their Winchester rifles and, in an unequivocal manner, ordered them to stop. At that very moment, Dr. Van Helsing and I stood up behind the rocks and aimed our weapons at the gypsies. Seeing that they were surrounded, the men pulled on the reins and stopped. The leader turned to them, gave an order, and upon hearing it, all the gypsies reached for the weapons they had, knives or pistols, and prepared to attack. The result was not long in coming.

en: The leader, with a quick movement of his rein, threw his horse out in front, and pointing first to the sun—now close down on the hill tops—and then to the castle, said something which I did not understand. For answer, all four men of our party threw themselves from their horses and dashed towards the cart. I should have felt terrible fear at seeing Jonathan in such danger, but that the ardour of battle must have been upon me as well as the rest of them; I felt no fear, but only a wild, surging desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our parties, the leader of the gypsies gave a command; his men instantly formed round the cart in a sort of undisciplined endeavour, each one shouldering and pushing the other in his eagerness to carry out the order.
vi: The leader pulled the reins, urging his horse to break away from the group and move to the front, pointing towards the sun that was setting very close to the mountain peaks and the castle, then said something. In response, each member of our group of four allies immediately dismounted and rushed towards the carriage. Seeing Jonathan rush into the danger zone should have made me tremble with fear, but the thrill of the battle made me and my friends forget everything. I did not show any fear, but only had a wild desire to fight. At our unexpected action, the leader shouted out orders once more. The Bohemian crowd immediately gathered around the carriage, forming a chaotic circle.
tr: The leader of the community spurred his horse forward with a swift movement of the reins and, pointing first to the sun, which was now approaching the hills, and then to the castle, uttered some words I did not understand. In response, four men from our team dismounted from their horses and quickly ran towards the carriage. When I saw Jonathan putting himself in such danger, I should have been horrified, but the fire of battle must have affected me like the others; I felt no fear, only a wild and great desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our team, the chieftain gave an order; his men instantly formed an undisciplined circle around the carriage, each one pushing and shoving the other to carry out the command.
es: The leader, with a quick movement of his reins, launched his horse forward, heading first towards the sun, which was already very close to the mountain peaks, and then towards the castle, saying something I could not understand. In response, the four men in our group dismounted from their horses and quickly rushed towards the carriage. I should have felt terribly terrified to see Jonathan in such great danger, but the fervor of the battle had taken hold of me, just like everyone else; I was not afraid, but had a wild and pressing desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our friends, the leader of the gypsies gave an order and his men instantly formed around the carriage, in a somewhat disorganized formation, pushing and hindering each other in their eagerness to execute the order quickly.

en: In the midst of this I could see that Jonathan on one side of the ring of men, and Quincey on the other, were forcing a way to the cart; it was evident that they were bent on finishing their task before the sun should set. Nothing seemed to stop or even to hinder them. Neither the levelled weapons nor the flashing knives of the gypsies in front, nor the howling of the wolves behind, appeared to even attract their attention. Jonathan’s impetuosity, and the manifest singleness of his purpose, seemed to overawe those in front of him; instinctively they cowered, aside and let him pass. In an instant he had jumped upon the cart, and, with a strength which seemed incredible, raised the great box, and flung it over the wheel to the ground. In the meantime, Mr. Morris had had to use force to pass through his side of the ring of Szgany. All the time I had been breathlessly watching Jonathan I had, with the tail of my eye, seen him pressing desperately forward, and had seen the knives of the gypsies flash as he won a way through them, and they cut at him. He had parried with his great bowie knife, and at first I thought that he too had come through in safety; but as he sprang beside Jonathan, who had by now jumped from the cart, I could see that with his left hand he was clutching at his side, and that the blood was spurting through his fingers. He did not delay notwithstanding this, for as Jonathan, with desperate energy, attacked one end of the chest, attempting to prize off the lid with his great Kukri knife, he attacked the other frantically with his bowie. Under the efforts of both men the lid began to yield; the nails drew with a quick screeching sound, and the top of the box was thrown back.
vi: In that chaos, I saw Jonathan on one side and Quincey Morris on the other, both desperately rushing to make their way to the vehicle. They needed to reach the vehicle to complete their mission before sunset. It seemed nothing could stop the two of them at this moment. The clashing of swords and the flashing of blades, along with the savage howls of the approaching wolves, seemed to not concern them. Jonathan's unyielding bravery and determination clearly demoralized those blocking his path, causing them to start moving aside, leaving an open way for him. Just a split second was enough for him to leap onto the vehicle and throw the coffin to the ground with all his strength and fury. At the same time, Morris also bravely made his way through. In my interrupted breaths, I watched Jonathan, but Morris's desperate scream startled me: the flashing blades of the Gypsies continuously swung around him and his short sword like a flying steel net. At first, I thought there would be no problem, but when he rushed towards Jonathan - who had just jumped down from the vehicle - I suddenly realized his left hand was clutching his side, futilely trying to cover a stream of blood seeping through his fingers. Despite this, with the strength of a man in despair, he still threw himself into prying open one side of the wooden coffin lid with his knife, simultaneously with Jonathan on the other side. The efforts of the two men forced the coffin lid to gradually give way, the nails creaking as they were pulled out, and finally, the wooden lid was forcefully thrown to the ground.
tr: In the midst of all this, I could see Jonathan on one side of the circle of men and Quincey on the other, trying to clear a path to the carriage; it was clear they were determined to finish their work before sunset. Nothing could stop or even hinder them. Neither the guns and gleaming knives aimed by the Gypsies in front, nor the howling of the wolves behind seemed to catch their attention. Jonathan's boldness and evident determination seemed to have frightened and subdued those in front of him. In an instant, he jumped onto the carriage and, with what seemed like extraordinary strength, lifted the large chest and hurled it to the ground over the wheel. Meanwhile, Mr. Morris had to use force to get through the Gypsy circle on his side. During the time I watched Jonathan breathlessly, I saw out of the corner of my eye that Mr. Morris, in desperation, lunged forward and made a path through them, the Gypsies' knives flashing and stabbing him. He fended off the attacks with his large hunting knife, and at first, I thought he had safely overcome it, but then I saw him leap to Jonathan's side, who had jumped down from the carriage, clutching his side tightly with his left hand and blood gushing between his fingers. Still, he did not stop, for as Jonathan, in desperation, used the large kukri to pry open the lid from one end of the chest, Mr. Morris, in a frenzy, attacked the other end with his hunting knife. With the efforts of both men, the lid began to give way; the nails were pulled out with a sharp, scream-like creak, and the lid of the chest was thrown back.
es: In the midst of them, I managed to see Jonathan making his way towards the cart from one side, while Mr. Morris did so from the other. It was evident that they were in a hurry to carry out their task before the sun set. Nothing seemed able to stop them or block their way: neither the weapons aimed at them, nor the knives of the gypsies standing in front of them, nor even the howls of the wolves behind them seemed to attract their attention. Jonathan's impetuosity and the apparent firmness of his intentions seemed to overwhelm the men in front of him, as they instinctively stepped back and let him pass. A moment later, he climbed onto the cart and, with an incredible strength, lifted the box and threw it to the ground, onto the wheels. Meanwhile, Mr. Morris had to use force to break through the circle of gypsies. All the while I had been anxiously watching Jonathan, I saw out of the corner of my eye Quincey advancing, desperately fighting among the gypsies' knives that gleamed in the sun and pierced his flesh. He had defended himself with his dagger and, finally, I thought he had managed to pass without being wounded, but when he leapt to Jonathan's side, who had already gotten down from the cart, I could see that he was holding his side with his left hand and blood was oozing between his fingers. However, he did not let this discourage him, as Jonathan, with a desperate energy, was attacking the wood of the box with his large kukri knife to remove the lid, and Quincey frantically attacked the other side with his dagger. Under the effort of the two men, the lid began to give way and the nails came out with a dry screech. Finally, the lid of the box fell to one side.

en: By this time the gypsies, seeing themselves covered by the Winchesters, and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, had given in and made no resistance. The sun was almost down on the mountain tops, and the shadows of the whole group fell long upon the snow. I saw the Count lying within the box upon the earth, some of which the rude falling from the cart had scattered over him. He was deathly pale, just like a waxen image, and the red eyes glared with the horrible vindictive look which I knew too well.
vi: Seeing the gun barrels pointing directly at them, entrusting their lives to Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, the Bohemian group all hesitated, none of them daring to resist. The sun began to set, giving way to the darkness that gradually enveloped the snow-covered world. I witnessed with my own eyes the old count lying stretched out on the filthy soil inside the fateful wooden coffin, beneath the wood shavings that had peeled off when the coffin was thrown from the carriage to the ground. He looked as pale as a leaf, more accurately like a wax figure. His eyes were wide open, clearly showing a terrifying hatred.
tr: At this moment, seeing that they were surrounded by Winchesters and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, the Gypsies gave up and ceased to resist. The sun had almost descended from the mountain peaks, and the long shadows of the entire group were cast upon the snow. I saw the Count lying on the soil that had spilled partially over him due to the hard fall from the cart. He was pale as death, resembling a mummy, and his red eyes shone with that terrible vengeful look I knew so well.
es: By then, the gypsies, seeing themselves covered by the Winchesters and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, had yielded and no longer offered any resistance. The sun was almost hidden among the mountain peaks, and the shadows of the entire group were cast upon the ground. I saw the Count lying in the box, on the ground, part of which had been spilled over him due to the violence with which the box had fallen from the cart. He was deeply pale, like a wax figure, and his red eyes shone with the vengeful and horrible look that I knew so well.

en: As I looked, the eyes saw the sinking sun, and the look of hate in them turned to triumph.
vi: The moment I saw him was also the moment his eyes gleamed with triumph as he caught a glimpse of the late sunset.
tr: While looking at her, those eyes saw the setting sun and the expression of hatred turned into triumph.
es: While I was watching him, his eyes saw the sun sinking on the horizon and his expression of hatred turned into one of triumph.

en: But, on the instant, came the sweep and flash of Jonathan’s great knife. I shrieked as I saw it shear through the throat; whilst at the same moment Mr. Morris’s bowie knife plunged into the heart.
vi: But at that very moment, Jonathan's blade had already swung up like a flashing lightning bolt. I gasped in shock as I realized that the slash had just severed his long neck. At the same time, Quincey Morris's short sword managed to stab right into the heart of the wretched old man.
tr: But at that moment came the speed and brightness of Jonathan's large knife. I screamed when I saw the knife cut the throat; at the same time, Mr. Morris's hunting knife also plunged into the heart.
es: But, at that precise moment, Jonathan's terrible knife sliced through the air. I screamed as I saw it cut the vampire's throat, while Mr. Morris's dagger plunged into its heart.

en: It was like a miracle; but before our very eyes, and almost in the drawing of a breath, the whole body crumbled into dust and passed from our sight.
vi: Like a miraculous scene, yes, right before our eyes, just as everyone had barely managed to let out a sigh of relief, the entire body of the old count suddenly turned into layers of mist and dissipated very quickly.
tr: Everything that happened was like a miracle, but right before our eyes and in almost a single breath, the entire body turned to dust and disappeared from sight.
es: It was like a miracle, but right before our very eyes and almost in the blink of an eye, the entire body turned to dust and disappeared.

en: I shall be glad as long as I live that even in that moment of final dissolution, there was in the face a look of peace, such as I never could have imagined might have rested there.
vi: Within me began to surge an indescribable joy at that miraculous moment, or rather a sense of unprecedented peace and serenity gradually spread across my entire face.
tr: Even in that final moment of death, I will be grateful for as long as I live that there was an expression of peace on that face that I could never have imagined.
es: I will rejoice throughout my entire life that, a moment before the dissolution of the body, a peace spread over the vampire's face that I never would have expected could be expressed.

en: The Castle of Dracula now stood out against the red sky, and every stone of its broken battlements was articulated against the light of the setting sun.
vi: At this moment, Dracula's castle stood towering against the deep red backdrop of the sunset horizon.
tr: Dracula's Castle now stood facing the red sky, and each stone of its broken battlements was emerging one by one in the light of the setting sun.
es: Dracula's castle stood out at that moment against the reddish sky, and each of the rocks of its various buildings was outlined against the light of the setting sun.

en: The gypsies, taking us as in some way the cause of the extraordinary disappearance of the dead man, turned, without a word, and rode away as if for their lives. Those who were unmounted jumped upon the leiter-wagon and shouted to the horsemen not to desert them. The wolves, which had withdrawn to a safe distance, followed in their wake, leaving us alone.
vi: Witnessing firsthand that we were the cause leading to a strange end for the one lying in the coffin, the Bohemian group immediately pulled the reins and turned their horses back, none of them saying a word to each other, as if their entire lives depended on that corpse. Those who couldn't jump onto their horses quickly leaped onto the wagon and called out to those galloping ahead not to leave them behind. The pack of wolves also quietly retreated along the old path, leaving us alone in a strangely silent world.
tr: In some way, the Gypsies, who saw us as the reason for the extraordinary disappearance of the dead man, turned their backs without a word and moved away as if they wanted to save their lives. Those without horses jumped onto the horse-drawn carriage and shouted at the riders not to leave them behind. The wolves, which had pulled back to a safe distance, left us alone and followed them.
es: The gypsies, considering us responsible for the disappearance of the corpse, turned their horses around and sped away, as if fearing for their lives. Those who were on foot jumped onto the cart and shouted to the riders not to abandon them. The wolves, who kept a respectable distance, followed them and left us alone.

en: Mr. Morris, who had sunk to the ground, leaned on his elbow, holding his hand pressed to his side; the blood still gushed through his fingers. I flew to him, for the Holy circle did not now keep me back; so did the two doctors. Jonathan knelt behind him and the wounded man laid back his head on his shoulder. With a sigh he took, with a feeble effort, my hand in that of his own which was unstained. He must have seen the anguish of my heart in my face, for he smiled at me and said:—
vi: Quincey Morris collapsed, his elbows on the ground, his hand still clutching the bleeding wound. I ran over in shock, as the Sacred Circle could no longer hold me back. The two doctors also rushed to his side. Jonathan knelt down and hurriedly supported his friend. The young man groped to grasp my hand with his weak breath. My face must have shown extreme anxiety because I saw him smile and say to me:
tr: Mr. Morris, who had collapsed to the ground, was leaning on his elbow, holding the hand pressed against his side; blood was still gushing from between his fingers. I ran to his side, for the sacred circle no longer held me back; both doctors also ran to Mr. Morris. Jonathan knelt beside him, and the wounded man rested his head on Jonathan's shoulder. With a sigh and a feeble effort, he took my hand in his unbloodied one. He must have seen the pain in my heart on my face, for he was looking at me and smiling as he spoke:
es: Mr. Morris, who had collapsed to the ground with his hand pressed against his side, saw the blood flowing between his fingers. I ran towards him, as the sacred circle no longer blocked my way; the two doctors did the same. Jonathan knelt beside him, and the wounded man rested his head on Jonathan's shoulder. With a sigh, he took one of my hands, the one not stained with blood. He must have seen the anguish in my heart reflected on my face, as he smiled at me and said:

en: “I am only too happy to have been of any service! Oh, God!” he cried suddenly, struggling up to a sitting posture and pointing to me, “It was worth for this to die! Look! look!”
