vi: — I feel very honored to have accomplished something. Oh! My God, - He exclaimed and suddenly sat up, pointing at me - even if I have to die, I have no regrets! Look, everyone, look!
tr: “I am so happy to have been of use!” “Oh, my God!” he suddenly shouted; struggling to sit up and showing me something, “It was worth dying for this! Look! Look!”
es: –I am happy to have been useful! Oh, God! – he suddenly shouted, struggling to sit up and pointing at me-. Is it worth dying for that? Look! Look!

en: The sun was now right down upon the mountain top, and the red gleams fell upon my face, so that it was bathed in rosy light. With one impulse the men sank on their knees and a deep and earnest “Amen” broke from all as their eyes followed the pointing of his finger. The dying man spoke:—
vi: The sunset cast its final rays, making the face glow like a halo. All my friends knelt down and exclaimed "Amen" as they followed the direction of his pointing finger. He whispered:
tr: The sun had now descended to the very peak of the mountain, and its red rays were falling on my face; it was as if my face was being bathed in a pink light. As the dying man continued to speak, all the men who were following his finger with their eyes suddenly dropped to their knees, and a deep and heartfelt "Amen!" was heard from all of them.
es: The sun was already over the mountain peaks and the reddish rays fell upon my face, so that I was bathed in a rosy glow. With a single impulse, the men fell to their knees and said, "Amen," with deep emotion, as they followed with their gaze what Quincey was pointing at. The dying man spoke again:

en: “Now God be thanked that all has not been in vain! See! the snow is not more stainless than her forehead! The curse has passed away!”
vi: — God has blessed us: so it was all not in vain! Everyone, just look, even the snowflakes cannot be purer than her forehead. So the curse has been lifted.
tr: "Now, thank God that all this was not in vain!" "Look! Now, the snow is not more spotless than his forehead!" "The curse is lifted!""
es: –Thank you, my God, because all of this has not been in vain! Look! Not even the snow is cleaner than his forehead! The curse has ended!

en: And, to our bitter grief, with a smile and in silence, he died, a gallant gentleman.
vi: He departed amidst our boundless love and immense pain: on his lips, a gallant young man, a quiet smile remained forever imprinted.
tr: And leaving us in great pain, smiling and in silence, the brave gentleman died.
es: And, amidst our profound sorrow, with a smile and in silence, an extraordinary gentleman passed away.

en: NOTE
vi: CONCLUSION Jonathan Hacker's Notes
tr: Not
es: NOTE

en: Seven years ago we all went through the flames; and the happiness of some of us since then is, we think, well worth the pain we endured. It is an added joy to Mina and to me that our boy’s birthday is the same day as that on which Quincey Morris died. His mother holds, I know, the secret belief that some of our brave friend’s spirit has passed into him. His bundle of names links all our little band of men together; but we call him Quincey.
vi: So, it has been seven years since the day we escaped those nightmares. We are the ones who enjoy happiness at the cost of the pains in our own lives. The fact that our son was born on the anniversary of Quincey Morris's death brought even more joy to Mina and me. I know, you have kept in your heart a secret belief that some aspect of your heroic friend has been instilled in our child. We gave the boy the names of all the members of our group of friends, but Quincey is still the name we use the most.
tr: Seven years ago, we all went through fire, and since then, some of us believe that the happiness we have now is worth the pain we endured. The fact that our son's birthday is on the same day Quincey Morris died gives Mina and me extra joy. I know that his mother has a secret belief that a part of our brave friend's spirit has passed into him. The bundle of names he carries ties our small community together, but we call him Quincey.
es: Seven years ago, all of us went through the flames; and for the happiness that some of us have enjoyed since then, I believe it was well worth the suffering. For Mina and me, it is an additional joy that our son's birthday is on the same day that Quincey Morris died. His mother secretly believes, though I know it, that part of the spirit of our dear friend has passed into the child. His set of names links those of our entire group of men, but we call him Quincey.

en: In the summer of this year we made a journey to Transylvania, and went over the old ground which was, and is, to us so full of vivid and terrible memories. It was almost impossible to believe that the things which we had seen with our own eyes and heard with our own ears were living truths. Every trace of all that had been was blotted out. The castle stood as before, reared high above a waste of desolation.
vi: Last summer, on the way back to visit Transylvania, we returned to the land filled with terrible memories that are indelible in everyone's mind. We couldn't believe the things we saw and heard were still so vivid, even though all traces had been erased. All that remained was the majestic, silent, solitary castle standing alone on a windswept hill.
tr: This summer, we took a journey to Transylvania and went to that old place which holds -and still holds- very vivid and terrifying memories for all of us. It was almost impossible to believe that the things we saw with our own eyes and heard with our own ears were vivid realities. The traces of everything that happened had been erased. The castle was standing as before, rising over the desolation.
es: During the summer of this year, we took a trip to Transylvania, traversing the terrain that for us was and is so full of terrible memories. We found it almost impossible to believe that the things we had seen with our own eyes and heard with our ears could have existed. Every trace of that has completely disappeared. The castle remains as before, rising before a landscape full of desolation.

en: When we got home we were talking of the old time—which we could all look back on without despair, for Godalming and Seward are both happily married. I took the papers from the safe where they had been ever since our return so long ago. We were struck with the fact, that in all the mass of material of which the record is composed, there is hardly one authentic document; nothing but a mass of typewriting, except the later note-books of Mina and Seward and myself, and Van Helsing’s memorandum. We could hardly ask any one, even did we wish to, to accept these as proofs of so wild a story. Van Helsing summed it all up as he said, with our boy on his knee:—
vi: We reminisce about the old times with a heavy heart, as Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward have both married and are living very happy lives. I reopened the papers stored in the iron chest after our first return, a long time ago. Strangely enough, among all the documents that make up the record of this story, it would be very difficult to find an authentic part: everything is just typewritten copies, except for the last diary pages of mine, Mina, Seward, and a few notes from Professor Van Helsing. That being said, how could we possibly make others acknowledge these papers as evidence of a tragic and mystical story now? Once, Van Helsing held our son in his arms and said a few very brief words:
tr: When we returned home, we began to talk about the old times, which we no longer remember with sorrow because Godalming and Seward had happy marriages. I took the documents out of the safe where they had been since we returned long ago. We were horrified by the fact that there were almost no original documents among all this pile of material where the records were arranged; apart from Mina's, Seward's, and my later journals and Van Helsing's notes, there was nothing but a heap of typewritten papers. Even if we had such a desire, we could not ask anyone to accept these documents as evidence of such a wild story. Van Helsing, with our son sitting on his knee, summarized the matter as follows:
es: When we returned home, we talked about the old times... which we could remember without feeling despair, since both Godalming and Seward are happy in their marriages. I took the papers out of the safe where they have been kept since our return, so long ago. We were surprised to see that the entire set of papers that make up the entirety of the records cannot be said to constitute an authentic document; they are merely a pile of typewritten papers, with the exception of the last notes taken by Mina, by Dr. Seward, and by myself, as well as the memorandum from Dr. Van Helsing. We cannot ask anyone, even if we wish to, to accept that pile of papers as proof of such a terrible story. Van Helsing summed it all up when he said, having our little son on his knees:

en: “We want no proofs; we ask none to believe us! This boy will some day know what a brave and gallant woman his mother is. Already he knows her sweetness and loving care; later on he will understand how some men so loved her, that they did dare much for her sake.”
vi: — Evidence? We don't need anyone to believe us. The important thing is that one day this kid will understand how brave his mother was. Now he knows she is a gentle and loving mother. Later on, he will also know that there were men who truly loved him and dared to do everything for his birth.
tr: “We don't need evidence; we don't want anyone to believe us! This child will one day know how brave and valiant his mother was. He already knows her sweetness and warm attention; later, he will understand how some men loved her and how they defied many things for her sake.”
es: –We don't need proof. We don't ask anyone to believe us! This boy will someday know how brave and extraordinary his mother is. Now, he already knows her sweetness and affection; later on, he will understand how some men loved her, who risked so much for her well-being.

en: Jonathan Harker.
vi: END
tr: JONATHAN HARKER
es: JONATHAN HARKER.

en: THE END
vi: END
